column2: WASHINGTON, March 17 -- In whatever report may be made to the people of the United Nations of the results of the visit to Washington of the British Foreign Secretary, Mr. Eden, no announcement of important agreements should be expected. That is not the purpose of the conversations.

Plans for the creation of a "power pool" in the northern Illinois-Wisconsin region as an aid to war production in that highly industrialized area have been completed and an interconnection between two of the country's big power systems will be undertaken in the immediate future, it was learned yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 18 -- American infantrymen thrust forward toward the tactically important town of El Guettar, seventy-two miles west of Gabes, and the sea today after a swift thirty-mile advance yesterday had occupied Gafsa and rewon much of the territory lost to Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel last month.

CHUNGKING, China, March 18 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have killed more than 1,100 Japanese north of the Yangtze River in Western Hupeh Province, the Chinese High Command announced tonight in a communique that also reported the annihilation of hundreds of other enemy troops in the Hupeh-Hunan border area south of the Yangtze and the recapture of four towns.

Disregarding two requests from the National War Labor Board that they discontinue a strike that started last Saturday, members of the Casket Makers Union, Local 1728, of the A.F. of L., voted almost unanimously yesterday to continue the strike and "take the consequences."

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -The Navy stated today that Army-Navy "E" awards to manufacturing plants for excellence in war production would be withheld from organizations "failing to show a good employe attendance record."

Triumphs attained yesterday in Madison Square Garden sent Andrew Jackson High of Queens and James Madison High of Brooklyn into the final round of the city P.S.A.L. championship basketball competition. They will meet on the same floor for the title on Wednesday.

" The Last Will of Dr. Mabuse," made by Fritz Lang in France before he began directing pictures in Hollywood, will have its local premiere at the World Theatre today. Described as a psychological study of the criminal mind, the picture features Jim Gerard, Thomy Bourdelle and Rudolph Klein-Rogge. The film has English titles.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Ways and Means Committee tax bill was denounced as "a monstrosity" this afternoon by Representative Martin, the House minority leader, after a conference at which the Republican members organized to support the Carlson bill, which incorporates a modified version of the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 18 -- Joe McCarthy has no illusions about the problems he faces in shaping the 1943 Yankee ball team. He may go right down to the wire without positive knowledge of what his array will be, conditions being what they are.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- More than 1,000 Upper Darby High School students "ambushed" Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today and forced her to make a speech to them before they cleared a path for her to enter the school building to address an adult war bond rally from which the youngsters were barred.
LONDON, Friday, March 19 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- Kate Smith will appear in the Warner film version of "This Is the Army," which will reach the screen as "Irving Berlin's This Is the Army." Miss Smith will sing "God Bless America," around which a specialty sequence is being built. She will arrive on April 5.

The shortage of dressed poultry here will become even more acute and the field will be left to black market operators if amended ceilings on dressed poultry, announced recently by the Office of Price Administration, go into effect tomorrow, it was asserted yesterday at a meeting of the Poultry Committee of the Marketmen's Association of the Port of New York with representatives of the Army, Navy and Coast Guard at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Captain Charlotte Day Gower, who witnessed the fall of Hong Kong and later was imprisoned in a Japanese internment camp, has been appointed director of training for the Women's Reserve of the Marine Corps, the Navy Department said today.

LONDON, March 18 -- Beating "The Greatest Show on Earth" in Madison Square Garden by two weeks, the American Red Cross staged its own circus in Rainbow Corner, Picadilly, tonight. There was no Gargantua and the hot dogs turned out to be familiar British sausages, but otherwise one could hardly tell the difference.

Reflecting the heavy tax payments for the first quarterly period, bank clearings of the leading cities of the nation in the week ended on Wednesday increased 14.1 per cent to $8,827,263,000 from $7,739,569,000 for the corresponding week of 1942, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 18 -- United States Vice President Henry A. Wallace arrived here by plane at noon today. He was greeted by President Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia, the Cabinet, the diplomatic corps and thousands of enthusiastic Costa Ricans.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 18 -- With the approval of the Chilean Government on the understanding that "teh arrangement shall not allow profits to traders, but shall benefit exclusively consumers," the British Government has commenced to operate a new plan to transport commodities from the East and other points for delivery at cost to Chile and other Latin-American countries.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., March 18 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district held about unchanged for the third consecutive week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Industrial production last week reached a new high record, mainly as a result of impressive gains in steel-mill operations and in bituminous coal production; electric power production declined slightly.

EDGEWATER, N.J., March 18 -- E.H. Grotefend, manager of the Aluminum Company of America plant here, disclosed today that 550 of the plant's 3,000 employes would be laid off because of reduced quotas of aluminum allotted to the plant by the War Production Board.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- John W. Houser, under whose direction the public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission weathered some of the most severe attacks on the public utility holding company act of 1935, has resigned, it was announced today.

LONDON, March 18 -- General Charles de Gaulle, who was named today with General Henri Honore Giraud as joint commander of the French Army of the future in an Algiers broadcast to the people of France, was still in London tonight.

Robert P. Boylan, former vice chairman of the board of the New York Stock Exchange, has withdrawn his name for consideration for the chairmanship, the nominating committee reported yesterday. Raymond Sprague also withdrew his name.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Hull, Under-Secretary Welles, Norman Davis, Myron C. Taylor, Dr. Isiah Bowman and Dr. Leo Pasvolsky on post-war problems, and with Henry J. Kaiser, Rear Admirals Emory S. Land and Howard L. Vickery and Artemus Gates; other visitors were Charles F. Palmer and Bernardo Ibanez, secretary-general of the Chilean Federation of Labor, who was accompanied by William Green and Philip Murray.
LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- Note circulation in the last week established a new record high with an increase of 1,033,000 to a total of 927,383,000, as reported by the Bank of England today.

LONDON, March 18 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force Coastal Command planes, operating from bases in Iceland, Northern Ireland and other North Atlantic islands, probably sank two enemy submarines during a recent convoy battle, the Air Ministry news service announced today.

Officials of the Hosiery Wholesalers National Association will seek an early conference with Prentiss M. Brown, administrator of the OPA, to request substantial changes in and deferment of the effective date of MPR-339 covering women's rayon hosiery, it was announced yesterday by Leo Guzik, counsel and executive secretary of the group.

Net income of the Pepsi-Cola Company in 1942 amounted to $6,274,776, or $3.30 a share, comparing with $9,363,106, or $4.93 a share in 1941, according to the annual report of Walter S. Mack Jr., president.

Roses, annuals and wild flowers were discussed yesterday at the fourth and final day of "Garden Week," held for the benefit of the Red Cross war fund drive in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in a twenty-minute talk to key members of Congress in the closely guarded rooms of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today, said it was too early, at this stage of the war, for the United Nations to plan with too much detail for the post-war period.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- To 122 officers and enlisted men of the Army Air Forces who operated planes carrying troops from England to North Africa during the invasion nights of Nov. 7 and 8 have been awarded the Air Medal.

The vast increase in the services rendered last year by the Travelers Aid Society to the hordes of war workers and military personnel crowding the city's terminals was reported yesterday at the society's thirty-fifth annual meeting at the Hotel Biltmore.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -- Government agencies and the armed forces were accused today by G.H. Shafer of St. Paul, president of the National Association of Regional Transportation Advisory Boards, of "wasting transportation'' and assuming the attitude that their actions should not be questioned.

We believe that the Senate has made a serious mistake in adopting the Bankhead-Johnson amendment to the Selective Service Act. This new proposal, which now goes to the House for its consideration, would grant blanket deferment to any and all men of draft age who are engaged "substantially full time" in farm work.
The fiftieth annual championships of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association will start this afternoon at 3 o'clock and continue through tomorrow night at the Salle Santelli.
SAN JOSE, March 18 (U.P.) -Vice President Henry A. Wallace, speaking before the Costa Rican Congress today, reaffirmed that freedom from want must be the basis for post-war reconstruction.

Reconsideration of the "bedrock" or minimum consumption requirements data of the Office of Civilian Supply as they apply to furs has been promised by Joseph L. Weiner, director of the OCS, to the National Federation of the Fur Industry, it was announced here yesterday by Avery T. Salter, executive secretary.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The War Production Board ruled today that men's and boys' lounging wear and bath robes put into process before Aug. 29 last are not subject to restrictions on manufacture of these types of garments. The concession was contained in an amendment to order L-130.

MONTREAL, March 18 -- The Montreal Canadiens fought their way into the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs tonight when they turned back the New York Rangers, 6 -- 3, in their last game of the regular season. The 2 points collected as the result of the victory lifted the Habitants into fourth place, 1 point ahead of the Chicago Black Hawks, who lost in Detroit.

Fritz Kuhn and ten other German-American Bund leaders were deprived of United States citizenship yesterday by Federal Judge John Bright. The Court decided that the bund and its predecessor organizations accepted Adolf Hitler's "leadership principle" and were thoroughly un-American.
It is heartening to read the editorial in THE TIMES today advocating amendment of the Constitution to provide for the ratification of treaties by a majority vote of both houses of the Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Of the deluge of complaints which came to this department from country dwellers in the East against the so-called "pleasure driving" ban, not one expressed the belief that actual pleasure driving should be provided for by government gasoline or rubber allotment.
MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) -- The Russian midday communique:

KAPURTHALA, Punjab States, India, March 16 (Delayed) -- In a kaleidoscopic picture of India's princely States Kapurthala deserves honorable mention. Here is a corner of French civilization brought into the heart of India.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, in Great Britain, March 18 (AP) -- "This time they were ready for us," said Lieutenant Robert I. Brown of Englewood, Calif., a pilot of the Susie Q., which led the Liberator formations in today's American raid on Vegestak.
CHUNGKING, China, March 18 (U.P.) -- A Chinese communique:

NEW ORLEANS, March 18 (AP) -- Hugh S. Nesbitt's Orange Leaves, a filly that seems to thrive on racing, made a show of six other 3-year-olds in the Guadalcanal Purse before some 3,000 fans at Fair Grounds today.

The Rev. Patrick F. O'Connor, former Roman Catholic chaplain of the New York City Fire Department, was struck last night by a taxicab in West Forty-fifth Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, and severely injured, according to a police report.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- An executive order has been requested by Harold L. Ickes, from President Roosevelt giving him, as Solid Fuels Coordinator for War, powers over coal production and distribution on a par with those he holds over petroleum by virtue of the directive granted him on that product last year.

The food situation has become so complex that the New York City Department of Markets has started a new system of checking supplies and prices of meats, poultry, dairy products, fresh fruits and vegetables, fresh and frozen fish, and several other commodities.

LONDON, March 18 -- In the stock markets here today dealings were restricted again. Gilt-edge stocks remained steady and home rails lost 1/8 to 1 point. Leading industrial shares showed little change.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- The President's fact-finding board in the dispute between the railroads and fifteen non-operating unions over a demand for a wage increase was told today that the roads would have to spend not less than $1,000,000,000 annually for many years for improvements to meet competition.

URBANA, Ill., March 18 -- A hot-air furnace which cuts fuel consumption in half and burns the cheapest grades of coal without smoke even in the hands of unskilled firemen has been developed by two University of Illinois engineers, J.R. Fellows and J.C. Miles.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 18 (AP) -- Ninety swimmers, representing 18 colleges, will participate in the eastern intercollegiate individual championships tomorrow and Saturday at the Harvard pool. Yale's 'spectacular tankmen, however, have not been entered because of travel restrictions.

News that the basic A ration for passenger-car drivers is to be cut in half on Monday undoubtedly will come as a shock to motorists in the East Coast region, where it is effective. However, the curtailment is relieved of some of its sting by the lifting of the ban on so-called "pleasure driving."

TRENTON, March 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, in a letter to Governor Edison, made public today, said the Army took full blame for the fiasco of the prearranged blackout in New Jersey on March 9 and gave assurances that the Army's failure to send out the signals for the alerts "could not have happened in the case of a real air raid."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 18 -- Swedish overseas traffic, hitherto maintained by freighters under safe conducts from all belligerents, has temporarily ceased, strangling Swedish transatlantic trade, the Stockholm syndicalist newspaper Arbetaren reported today in a dispatch from its Copenhagen correspondent, citing the newspaper Politiken.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 18 -Holding in mind that this continues to be an age wherein wonders never cease, just who do you suppose practiced first base for the Giants today? To end the suspense to this burning question, it was the manager himself.

The Midtown Business and Professional Women's Club of this city brought suit in the Supreme Court here yesterday to enjoin the New York State Federation of such clubs from withdrawing its charter after it had admitted two Negro members.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Navy communique 316:

Because of its sociological responsibilities, industry must go back to the manufacture of 1942 models in major consumer durable goods when the war ends, speakers declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the post-war planning group of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Sheraton.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- The Russians have thrown powerful units of their air force into the fighting in the northern Donets valley. Their fighters are engaging German dive-bombers, which in small groups are trying to suppress Russian artillery posts, and their Stormoviks are carrying out frequent and audacious attacks on enemy tanks.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 18 (AP) -- Reliable informants French North African leadership in Brazil said tonight that the pro-Vichy government of French Guiana had resigned and that a committee pledged to support the of General Henri Honore Giraud had taken charge.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- French Guiana's government has broken away from Admiral Georges Robert, High Commissioner at Martinique, and joined forces with General Henri Honore Giraud, the French military mission here said today.

The United States Maritime award, including the "M" pennant, the Victory Fleet flag and maritime merit badges for employes, was presented yesterday to the Socony Paint Products division of the Socony Vacuum Oil Company, at the plant at 5-22 Forty-sixth Avenue, Long Island City.

Today's events: "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:15 P.M.; Ines Gomez Carillo, piano, Town Hall, 8:30; Festival of American Music, auspices of Juilliard School of Music and the Society for the Publication of American Music, Museum of Modern Art, 8:15; Rudolf Firkusny, piano, auspices of Czechoslovak Cultural Circle of New York, Webster Branch, New York Public Library, 8:45.

The Air Warden Service has undertaken recently the tremendous task of enlisting the aid of landlords, superintendents or a designated tenant living in all dwellings containing three or more families, to become Building Defense Directors and take over the control of their houses in the event of enemy attack.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -Henry J. Kaiser, the shipbuilder, expressed a conviction today that the country's coal miners would refuse to follow John L. Lewis "very long" if he should ask them to strike for a pay increase.

A wicked corporation's swollen profits are in one respect like a useful public agency's drastic economies. The sums are much more impressive if we omit the time factor. We are all familiar with exposes of high finance in which somebody got several hundred million dollars in dividends.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Office of Price Administration issued today the following series of questions and answers on meat rationing, which starts March 29:

AT THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 18 -- United States artillery fire and a bombing attack, rocking the earth miles away, hurried the already retreating Italians and Germans on their way, and mines offered the chief obstacle as American troops hurried through Gafsa. The most elaborate preparations had been made to assure recapture of this key oasis, twice before taken by the Americans and last abandoned Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A House Military Affairs subcommittee reported favorably today the Sparkman bill to allow women physicians and surgeons in the Medical Corps of the Army and Navy. A bill introduced by Representative Celler permitting women to be commissioned directly in the Army was tabled.

LONDON, March 18 -- A strong force of American Flying Fortresses and Liberators poured explosives today on a U-boat construction center fifteen miles northwest of Bremen and destroyed or damaged many of the seventy-five to one hundred Nazi fighters that beat against them almost continuously throughout the 800-mile round trip.

The portal-to-portal proposal of the United Mine Workers was rejected by the Southern Coal Producers Association yesterday, at a closed meeting in the Hotel Commodore. This was made known by John O'Leary, vice president of the union, and was confirmed by former Senator Edward R. Burke of Nebraska, president of the Southern association, who said there had been a disagreement on this issue.

LONDON, March 18 (U.P.) -- British naval forces fought against their heaviest odds in history in holding control of the Eastern Mediterranean during the first eighteen months of war, the Admiralty revealed today in a sixty-three-page publication entitled "East of Malta and West of Suez."

For the first time since the inception of the program "America's Town Meeting of the Air," conducted last night by radio a two-way forum across the Atlantic, with a British speaker sitting in London being "heckled" by members of the forum audience sitting in the Town Hall on West Forty-third Street, New York.

Why all this pother about the Ruml plan? In making out my tax return I noticed at the upper right-hand corner of the blank the figure "1942." If that figure were "1943" I would have had to pay more. Yet I favor the Ruml plan. Why? Just my psychological reaction.

In the first wedding within the naval service in the Third Naval District, Lieutenant Philip L. McHugh (j.g.) of the Naval Reserve and Ensign Alice Martens were married shortly before 6 o'clock last night in the rectory of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church, 529 West 121st Street, by the Rev. William J. Kenealy, a chaplain in the United States Maritime Service, stationed at Huntington, L.I.

For the eighth successive session, trading in cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was uneventful, with volume small and prices continuing on an almost horizontal plane. The market closed at the day's low levels, 6 to 12 points under Wednesday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Secretary Morgenthau today called the income tax picture encouraging despite the fact that the dollar volume of March collections reported so far is behind the record of last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18--The Henry J. Kaiser Company, Inc., was accused today by the War Production Board of accepting delivery, during the last six months, of millions of dollars' worth of critical war materials for its Richmond Shipyard No. 3 to which it was not entitled under priority regulations.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -Prospects of an out-of-court settlement of the Kaiser shipyards labor dispute reappeared today with an announcement by the National Labor Relations Board that, at the request of Henry J. Kaiser, it had postponed for ten days the resumption of hearings in the case to afford the parties a further opportunity to reach an agreement.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Women bus and street-car operators will become a common sight on city streets in the United States, as they have long been in England, it was stated today at a conference on womanpower in transportation, called by the Office of Defense Transportation.

LONDON, March 18 -- A plea that the Allies should treat German prisoners of war as hostages for the safety of Jews in Warsaw came in a message from the Warsaw ghetto to the Jewish labor representative of the Polish National Council in London today.

Louis (Buff) Balner, 32-year-old ex-convict, told a jury yesterday before General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen how he shot and killed Harry Nichols, Williamsburg gambler, on the platform of the crowded BMT subway station at Essex and Delancey Streets more than nine years ago.
The Conservation Department has issued some statistics regarding the last deer season in the State, showing that one out of every thirteen hunters took a buck.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- The American Meat Institute issued this statement tonight in reply to criticism of the institute made today in Washington by A.C. Hoffman, director of the OPA Food Division:

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 18 -- Two of the slimmest, trimmest and most tanned outfielders Manager Leo Durocher has seen since his Dodgers left Havana last March checked in to the Bear Mountain Inn today.

The Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company, in its fifty-ninth annual report to stockholders issued for publication today, reveals a net income of $11,237,132 for 1942, after all charges including $7,511,000 provision for Federal and State income and excess profits taxes. The net income for the previous year, after providing $15,183,000 for similar taxes, was $14,989,178.

DETROIT, March 18 (AP) -- The champion Detroit Red Wings came from behind in the third period tonight to knock the Chicago Black Hawks out of the National Hockey League play-offs with a 6-to-5 victory. By bagging a single point Doug Bentley of Chicago equaled the all-time league individual scoring record for one season.

While three Negro youths were being held in the stabbing early yesterday of a 17-year-old youth in a Harlem "racial" fight, it was announced that 150 rookie policemen have been assigned to the Harlem area in an effort to check muggings and other vicious assaults.
Lieut. Col. Lawrence Higgins, U.S.A., and Mrs. Higgins have arrived from Washington and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (U.P.) -- Selective Service officials said tonight that draft boards were being set up in State prisons throughout the country to facilitate the induction of prisoners whose records make them acceptable to the armed forces.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in his capacity as chairman of the War Finance Committee of the New York Federal Reserve District, announced yesterday the appointment of regional chairmen to serve during the $13,000,000,000 War Loan Drive, which will begin on April 12.

LINDEN, N.J., March 18 -- Casualty lists are growing and by Spring they will be appalling, Brig. Gen. Alden H. Waitt of the Chemical Warfare Service declared here today as he warned of a period of "blood, sweat and tears" in store for the American people.

The 1942 annual report of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges of $16,854,474. This is equal, after preferred charges, to 56 cents a share on the company's outstanding common stock and compares with a net of $21,751,256, or 77 cents a common share, in 1941.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 18 (AP) -- A communique:

The problem of what to do with veteran cavalrymen in mechanized warfare seems to have been solved in the case of Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., sometimes known to his troops as "Old Blood and Guts" and sometimes as "The Green Hornet," whom General Eisenhower yesterday appointed to succeed Major Gen. Lloyd R. Fredendall in command of the front in Western Tunisia.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- A drastic program of standardization to conserve paper supplies was recommended to the War Production Board today by representatives of the commercial printing industry.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, March 19 -- Allied airmen sowed destruction over the enemy's 2,000-mile invasion front above Australia yesterday, blasting fourteen Japanese bases, shooting out of action seven planes, strafing oil barges, and setting fires visible for sixty miles, a communique said today.

The Hampton-Mitchell amendments to the Redevelopment Companies Law, now pending at Albany, raise some troubling questions. The law, as passed last year, offered two inducements for private housing enterprises: the right of eminent domain, so that areas of practicable size could be assembled; and tax exemption for a twenty-year period.

A total of $6,890,000 in war bond sales will be realized from the concert by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony, with Vladimir Horowitz as piano soloist, to be given at Carnegie Hall on April 25, according to present indications.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- President Roosevelt resumed his consideration of post-war food, relief and rehabilitation problems at a meeting with a group of officials who have been advising him on the subject in recent weeks. The group, according to the White House, will meet with the President every week, probably on Thursdays.
Lockwood J. Towne, vice president of Stone and Webster Engineering Corporation has leased an apartment in 15 Park Avenue, according to Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The formula used by OPA in determining emergency inventory adjustments of wholesalers, in cases where stocks of processed foods are not adequate to meet demands under rationing, was liberated today by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A picture of a complete breakdown of authority in industrial plants if organized labor were permitted to form foremen's unions was presented today by C.E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, in a telegram to four House committees.

One of the three local representatives in the sixth annual national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden was eliminated last night, but only after a gallant uphill battle, as Manhattan College bowed to Toledo, 54 -- 47, in the opening round.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador to Moscow, has taken another step to acquaint the Soviet Union with the scope of what the United States is doing in the war by inviting Red Army officers to view thirty-two newsreels showing Pacific battle scenes and workers turning out tanks, planes and ships.

Efrem Kurtz, conducting his second Thursday night program with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, introduced one score new to this audience and two great and strongly contrasted symphonies belonging to that era known as the "romantic," and therefore, as of course, viewed most condescendingly by the lions of the musical avant garde of today.
LONDON, March 18 (AP) -- A single fighter pilot was the sole air defense for the entire British Eastern Mediterranean Fleet for a time during the early part of the war, the Admiralty disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The importance of Anglo-American economic harmony as the key to a sound postwar society of nations was emphasized by Dr. Herbert Feis, economic adviser to the Secretary of State, in an article published in the April issue of Foreign Affairs, which appears tomorrow.

A FLYING FORTRESS BASE, Somewhere in England, March 18 (U.P.) -- A bombardier died at his post in a Flying Fortress over Germany today after crawling, mortally wounded, back to his bombsight and dropping his deadly missiles square on the target.

The stage was set yesterday for an interesting duel between St. John's Prep and St. Francis Prep for the swimming championship of the Catholic High School Athletic Association tomorrow when the final events are held in the Columbia University pool, starting at 11:30 in the morning.

BOSTON, March 18 (AP) -- Bull-like rushes which generally ended in a lusty two-fisted body barrage by Jackie Callura of Hamilton, Ont., enabled him to gain a divided fifteen-round decision over Jackie Wilson of Pittsburgh and retain the National Boxing Association's version of the featherweight title tonight before a slim crowd of 4,318 at Mechanics Building.

ALBANY, March 18 (AP) -- The Republican Party's accession to full State power was burlesqued in the Legislative Correspondents' Association's forty-third annual show tonight, the opening chorus shouting "We're In -- At Last."

A statement of "political principles," resting upon six "pillars of peace," which has been formulated by the Commission to Study the Bases of a Just and Durable Peace, instituted two years ago by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, was outlined yesterday by John Foster Dulles, chairman of the commission.

TRENTON, March 18 (AP) -- A representative of a postal employes' organization told the State Senate Judiciary Committee today he feared workers in certain industries might receive "the same harsh treatment employes in Newark were subject to" if John F. Sinnott Jr. became State Superintendent of Weights and Measures.

NEW DELHI, India, March 18 (U.P.) -- Continued Japanese pressure in Western Burma has forced the second "adjustment" of British lines there in less than a week, but a British communique said today that in Northern Burma native troops had thwarted the enemy drive to wipe out guerrilla resistance.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The House authorized the continuation of two investigations today and voted to permit the Agriculture Committee to undertake an investigation of the Farm Security Administration and its practices, which have been the subject of much Congressional discussion in the last few days.

A heavy sustained run on all kinds of hard cheese, indicating large-scale hoarding, has developed in New York, Daniel P. Woolley, Commissioner of Markets, reported yesterday, adding a warning that most domestic hard cheeses cannot be kept long without spoiling.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of a new issue of $5,000,000 of Boston, Mass., notes, dated March 22 and due on Nov. 3, 1943. They bid an 0.67 per cent basis, plus a premium of $115. The notes were reoffered on an 0.60 per cent basis and were oversubscribed quickly.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase for the week of $176,256,000 in holdings of United States Government securities.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Department store sales for the week ended March 13 were 3 per cent above the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 14 per cent in the week ended March 6 as compared with the corresponding week a year ago.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 18 -- Plans for the expansion and development of State parks in Southern New York after the war, outlined today at a meeting of the State Council of Parks, include a super-highway project to connect the New Jersey side of the George Washington Bridge with the Bear Mountain Bridge Traffic Circle.

Practical business men must make a distinction between the "grandiose" schemes for the post-war world and their actual needs in that period and should begin immediate consideration of their requirements on a "realistic and modest" basis in order to avoid the risk of being hit by the popular revulsion against such larger programs likely to arise -- when the war is ended, Wilbert Ward, vice president of the National City Bank, declared yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 18 -- Reconstruction of the French Army disbanded by Germany on Nov. 11, last, is now under consideration, according to an announcement by Fernand de Brinon, who represents the Vichy government in Paris.

ALGIERS, French North Africa, March 16 (Delayed) -- The Vichy government today "is a German government" that no longer can exist when French armies enter France, General Henri Honore Giraud declared in an interview today with this correspondent.

IF Jimmy Conzelman ever gets into the Army, it Can be absolutely guaranteed that the Chicago Cardinal football coach will not elect to join the parachute troops. He'll probably want an assignment with the sappers who burrow beneath the ground. Jimmy belongs to the old generation. He definitely is not air-minded.

Declaring that only a degrading of materials will permit the paper industry to furnish 14,500,000 tons this year, the paper committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents yesterday urged its members to change paper specifications immediately.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has made it clear that the views expressed in a leading article of The Times of London on "Security in Europe" do not represent the ideas of the British Government on the vital question of the future relations of Russia, Great Britain and the United States.

BOMBAY, March 18 -- The Pir of Pigaro, leader of the wild Hur terrorists of Sind Province, whose operations brought parachutists into action for the first time in India, was sentenced to death today for "abetting, conspiring and preparing to wage war against the King-Emperor," a dispatch from Karachi said.

Formation of a Board of Advisers to the Japanese Cabinet to help stimulate "an increase of fighting strength" has been announced by the Tokyo Radio in broadcasts that quoted Premier Hideki Tojo as warning his nation that "the war situation is becoming more serious."

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The aerial assault on Kiska, Japanese stronghold in the Aleutians, is continuing to mount in fury. Four more raids were made Tuesday; the submarine base and other installations were damaged, the camp area was set afire, and two enemy planes were shot down, a Navy communique reported today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

AN ADVANCED AMERICAN BASE IN CENTRAL TUNISIA, March 18 -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., a rip-roaring tank fighter known to his men as "Old Blood and Guts," has taken over command of American troops on this front and given the only order he knows, "Attack?"

Mrs. George F. Baker, chairman of the Manhattan Women's Special Gifts Committee, announced yesterday that her group has already raised $505,648, or more than two-thirds of its quota of $750,000, for the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City.

Appeals for "a new birth of freedom" among the nations who are now fighting for the ideal that Abraham Lincoln fought to establish were made yesterday by participants in the Town Hall Honors Day ceremony at 123 West Forty-third Street.

Record net earnings last year of $3,134,356 for the United Air Lines Transport Corporation, a rise of $598,050 over 1941, were largely the result of abnormal wartime traffic, W.A. Patterson, president, declared in the annual statement to stockholders for release today.

Members of the advisory committee of rayon and cotton fabric converers appointed last month by the OPA held an organization meeting yesterday in the Hotel McAlpin, which was also attended by Dr. Bernard F. Haley, chief of the textile section of OPA, and other staff members.

Vacating the Broadhurst on Saturday night, April 3, will be "Show Time," starring George Jessel, Jack Haley, Ella Logan and the DeMarcos, after a satisfying run of twenty-eight and a half weeks. This engagement, avers publicist Richard Maney, sets "an all time endurance record for a vaudeville show in this country."

LONDON, March 18 -- The government's proposals for eliminating the old barriers so any man with requisite ability would be eligible for Britain's foreign diplomatic or consular service was approved by the House of Commons today by a vote of 153 to 6.

The fifty-six family garden apartment building at 10 North Fulton Avenue, in Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has been sold by Ferdinand Wolf to a client of Roy Ellinghouse, broker. The same investor recently purchased through Mr. Ellingnouse a taxpayer in Tuckahoe and a store in Meriden, Conn.

The Vichy government announced last Sept. 29 that it had established a system of Vichy-appointed local councils to rule France's Western Hemisphere possessions in place of the elective general councils dissolved in October, 1940. French Guiana, Martinique and Guadeloupe were affected.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -Henry J. Kaiser said tonight that he had not been informed officially that the War Production Board had charged his Richmond shipyard with thirty-one violations of priority on war supply orders.

Parents Magazine has announced the winners of the seventeenth annual award for the outstanding books for parents published each year. Two medals are being awarded for the 1942 books, on the advice of a committee of leaders in parent education.

EDGEWATER, N.J., March 18 -- Hydrogen in a two-story storage tank at the Spencer, Kellogg Linseed Oil Company plant on River Road here exploded at 9:10 o'clock tonight. Two blasts in succession were heard for miles around, the first sending a sheet of blue flame seven stories high, the second a similar one four stories high.

LONDON, Friday, March 19 -- German infantry and tanks are counter-attacking endlessly "in an attempt to retrieve lost positions" along the Donets River below Kharkov, where the Red Army yesterday captured an important hamlet, Moscow announced early today in a communique telling also of continuing Russian successes in the sweep toward Smolensk on the central front.

That the nation's banks experienced no great money strain as a result of quarterly income tax day last Monday, due to advance planting by the monetary authorities, was evidenced yesterday in the weekly Federal Reserve System figures, covering the week ended on Wednesday.

Patrolman Harold W. Reagan was acquitted last night in Richmond County Court of a charge of first degree assault with intent to kill. The charge was a result of the shooting of Joseph Egan, 88 Walnut Street, a photo-engraver for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Office of Price Administration has issued a new regulation to prevent the diversion of seed potatoes to table uses and has also approved a further increase in seed potato ceilings, wholesale produce dealers here were notified yesterday.

The stock market drifted back yesterday into one of the few foggy sessions that it has experienced since the start of the year. Not only was interest confined to fewer issues than in more than a month, with closing prices mixed, but business was the lightest since Feb. 8.

ATLANTA, March 18 -- After sharp criticism of both the New Deal and the Georgia Power Company by opposing sides, the Senate, voting 34 to 12, accepted a House bill to tax Federal enterprises which compete with private industries. The measure had passed the House by a vote of 120 to 0, and will be voted on in a special general election in August.

LONDON, March 18 -- Sabotage is so prevalent in Czech factories, despite repressive measures, that Nazi foremen have been armed with automatic pistols, according to Dr. Jura Slavik, Czech Minister of the Interior.

William Park, president of the American Stores Company, said yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that the meat situation was "most dxastic." Supplies were increasingly hard to get, and some plants from which the company had purchased meat had gone out of existence.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, March 19 (AP) -- The noon communique: rSpiw-tot-O

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 18 -- Rutgers University will compete in twenty-three Spring sports contests, according to the schedules announced today by Director of Athletics George E. Little. In releasing the baseball, crew, lacrosse and track slates, Little pointed out that they had been arranged to eliminate unnecessary travel and featured games with near-by institutions.

A pair of fistic freaks, each the fabricator of practically unbelievable ring achievements, will meet in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. Interest in boxing being what it is, their clash is likely to attract a crowd of 18,000 fans and a gate of $75,000.

It is not by any means a retrospective show that Albert Sterner is now holding at the Kleemann Gallery, 65 East Fifty-seventh Street, until April 10. All save one of the fourteen oils were painted within the last two years. A few prints are included, all of them familiar, and a drawing or two (most of Sterner's drawings are stored in his studio in the country).

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Representative Kleberg, Democrat of Texas, part owner of King Ranch, was astonished when he opened a box today and recognized a pair of shoes which he had worn nearly six years and had given away four years ago to one of his Mexican ranch hands.

PATERSON, N.J., March 18 -- Iron mines that yielded ore from which George Washington made cannon, wagon wheel rims and huge chains to balk Britain's fleet in the Hudson River are going into production near here again, it was learned today.
I would like to take issue with some of the points raised in THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial of March 17, "French Union Now."

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Cattle and hog raisers, after concluding a hearing before executives of the Office of Price Administration, carried their fight tonight against proposed price ceilings on livestock to James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Allied High Command has decided to give the public more information on the fight against the Nazi U-boats, it was reported today, thus modifying a policy of silence that has been enforced with few exceptions since the start of the war.

TORONTO, March 18 (Canadian Press) -- S.G. Hibben of Bloomfield, N.J., said today he had told the Illuminating Engineering Society and the Electric Club of Toronto that a plane with foreign markings could approach within 200 miles of New York City without detection.

Half the lend-lease supplies forwarded for China are said to have come to rest in India. They can't all be flown "over the hump" to Chungking. They can move in quantity only after the Burma Road has not only been re-conquered but rebuilt. This probably can't be accomplished before the end of the rainy season, next Fall.

Insurance companies were urged yesterday to switch their advertising emphasis to the job of selling the insurance agent to the public by James E. Rutherford, executive vice president of the National Association of Life Underwriters, speaking at the Eastern Round Table of the Life Insurance Advertisers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Ski enthusiasts, looking forward to running mountainous trails and slopes under brilliant sunshine each Spring, find the combination of "corn" or granular snow, the result of thaw during the day and freeze at night, the outlook for this week-end.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 18 -- United States and Brazilian officials signed today at the Ministry of Finance an agreement providing an additional Export-Import Bank credit of $14,000,000 for the Rio Doce Corporation to exploit the Itabira iron mines.

Randolph Godfrey Phillips, former editor-in-chief of Columbia University's Spectator, yesterday told Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court that he would rather die than kill a man even if New York City were under attack by the enemy.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Confusion continues in the cash corn markets in the West and for a time today on the Board of Trade buyers for several large users of that grain were offering different prices for grain, each declaring that his price was the ceiling, and it took several telephone calls to Washington to clear up the situation.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (U.P.) -The War Manpower Commission today announced a reshuffle of labor market classifications, bringing the total number of critical manpower shortage areas up to 36 from 32.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Testimony strongly endorsing the Austin-Wadsworth national war service bill and urging its early enactment into law was given before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- The voluntary plan filed by the United Gas Improvement Company for partial compliance with the "death sentence" clause of the Holding Company Act and looking toward ultimate dissolution of the holding company itself was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, less than three months after it was submitted.

Coal trucks which formerly traveled empty from this city to the mines now carry sugar, potatoes and materials needed by war plants on their outbound trips, it was revealed yesterday as the Office of Defense Transportation announced relaxation of the twenty-four-hour weighing provision in the municipal solid fuel ordinance.

The five-story garden residence at 131 East Sixty-ninth Street has been sold by the estate of Hiram Burlingham through Warren Marks Associates and Albert B. Ashforth, Inc. Assessed at $31,000, the property adjoins the former residence of Douglas Gibbons which the present owner acquired several years ago through Warren Marks.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Hailing "good news from the production front," James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, reported tonight in a radio talk that 40,000,000 20-mm anti-aircraft shells or more than 1,000 for every minute of the day were loaded for the Navy during February.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 18 -- For more than a week General Douglas MacArthur's communiques have been telling of his bombers' efforts to harass the Japanese in the islands northwest of Australia. The enemy is fast strengthening his hold on the western portion of Netherland New Guinea and on all the small island groups in the Arafura Sea above Darwin, Australia.

The investigation into the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law disclosed yesterday an alleged system of kickback payments whereby an X-ray laboratory is said to have paid to employes of the State Insurance Fund $3,500 to $4,000 a month.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation announced terms today under which it will sell government wheat to converted whisky distillers for the production of industrial alcohol in the second quarter of this year.

In the face of warnings by a spokesman for retail gasoline dealers that the cut in the basic ration to one and one-half gallons a week mgiht cause a black market boom and a revolt in the industry, the Office of Price Administration here said yesterday that it believed "voluntary cooperation by motorists who want us to win the war" would keep the situation on an even keel.

The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company of Boston reports earned premiums of $74,254,670 for 1942, comparing with $55,698,946 in 1941, while losses incurred were $47,542,375, against $37,032,063, and underwriting expenses were $11,091,993, against $8,573,751. Gain from underwriting was $15,620,302, against $10,093,132.

For the first time since the prosperous Twenties, New York University's Bureau of Employment has been obliged to advertise the number and variety of jobs it can offer. On bulletin boards in all college buildings there are now brightly trimmed posters announcing openings that normally would be filled before a poster could be printed.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Detailed information on methods of simplifying and speeding traffic control systems was sent today to the Mayors of all cities of 10,000 or more population by Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Led by continued sharp advances for farm products, principally fruits and vegetables and livestock and poultry, the Bureau of Labor Statistics index of prices in primary markets again moved up by 0.3 per cent and reached a new high during the week ended March 13.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Inquiries at the State Department today failed to elicit official comment on the ordinance promulgated yesterday by General Henri Honore Giraud, Civil and Military Commander in Chief of French North Africa, which continued the denationalization of native Algerian Jews carried out by the Vichy government in 1940 and later.

A UNITED STATES ARMY BASE, Somewhere in Central England, March 17 -- The tractor backed up and clanked to a stop, then grated forward again. The blades of a disk plow bit into the clayey soil. The soldier in the driver's seat made a few more turns, then relaxed a while with the tractor motor still throbbing.

The solution of a murder at the West Sixty-first Street entrance to Central Park on Dec. 27 was announced yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan. He said that John Scheer, 17 years old, a resident of Staten Island, had confessed the crime.

OTTAWA, March 19 -- A clear statement that Canada is an autonomous member of the United Nations, just as she is an autonomous member of the British Commonwealth, and that the whole purpose of her foreign policy is to do what is likely to prove most in the common interest was made in the House of Commons this afternoon by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.

PAOSHAN, West Yunnan, China, March 12 (Delayed) -- After bailing out over Japanese-occupied territory west of the Salween River on March 6 Lieutenant Greg Carpenter of Keene, N.H., now in the Fourteenth Air Force, came bounding cheerfully into Poashan this afternoon with thirty-one Indians who had escaped from a Japanese prison camp.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The House today heard both the Ruml plan of pay-as-you-go taxation and the Ways and Means Committee's substitute labeled as bills for the rich.

MUNCIE, Ind., March 19 (AP) -- In 1886 the Ball brothers first considered moving their factory to the Middle West, where natural gas would provide cheaper fuel. Frank Ball came here and made the negotiations preliminary to moving the plant.

ALGIERS, March 19 -- General Charles de Gaulle, leader of Fighting France, expects to fly to North Africa to consult with General Henri Honore Giraud on plans for the union of his French National Committee with the latter's provisional government, according to a telegram received today from General Georges Catroux, head of General de Gaulle's mission to General Giraud.

Despite an increase to 49,169 student nurses between June 1, 1942 and June 1, 1943 over the 44,300 of the previous year, the National Nursing Council for War Service yesterday disclosed a need for 6,000 more to reach its quota of 55,000.
LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, March 20 (U.P.) -- Allied planes yesterday destroyed a Japanese submarine in the harbor of Lae, enemy stronghold on New Guinea's north coast, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- With production of naval anti-aircraft guns tremendously increased, the Navy's modern battleships are "100 times" more effective against air attack than they were before Pearl Harbor and the Japanese never could win a Bismarck Sea victory over American warships, Rear Admiral William H.P. Blandy, chief of the Naval Bureau of Ordnance, asserted today at Secretary Knox's press conference.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, told holders of gasoline A books in the East today that, except in rare cases, they would be unable to get supplemental rations unless they formed ride-sharing clubs.

Navy deprived New York University of two championships and placed the Violet in jeopardy of losing its third, the three-weapon crown, when the fiftieth annual tournament of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association started at Salle Santelli yesterday.

In order to overcome the labor shortage in food-canning centers, the National Canners Association is urging the industry to cooperate in a newspaper advertising drive to recruit workers for the 1943 season in more than 2,800 communities in and around canning centers.
LONDON, March 19 -- Two British submarines sank six supply ships, a tanker and a naval auxiliary in a recent ten-day patrol in the Mediterranean, the Admiralty announced today.

The letter of Borough President Nathan in reference to the location of the proposed aquarium in Coney Island is pertinent and in line with previous protests on the part of civic organizations such as the Municipal Art Society.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19 -- Fines totaling $16,000 were levied in Federal Court today against E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and the Atlas Powder Company of Wilmington, Del., and four executives after they changed their pleas from innocent to no defense in connection with charges of conspiring to fix prices of commercial explosives in violation of the antitrust laws.

In the press of wartime production the value of fundamental aeronautical research and study should not be neglected. It was this factor, expressed both through the leadership of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics and the foresight of the manufacturers themselves in plowing back so much of their earnings into research and development that gave us the vital technical and qualitative leadership on which the quantitative expansion of our air industry has been based.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Lieut. Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commander of the Army Air Forces, was nominated today by President Roosevelt for promotion to the four-star rank of a full general, and the Senate immediately confirmed the nomination.

Our fourth set of menus for a week follows the pattern set by their predecessors in that they (1) are built around fresh vegetables and fruits that are comparatively plentiful, (2) call for small amounts of meat and cheese, (3) stay within the points' allowance for a family of four, (4) are simple and reasonably quick to assemble.

TRENTON, March 19 -- Motor fuel tax receipts in New Jersey declined nearly 50 per cent last January contrasted with January, 1942, with the receipts for the months $1,111,081 and $2,185,381, respectively, it was reported today by the State Tax Department.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, delivered to President Roosevelt today a confidential verbal message from President Castillo of Argentina relating to the relations between this country and Argentina, the only nation in the Western Hemisphere which has not broken off diplomatic relations with the Axis powers.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, said at a press conference today that WPB was reorganizing "its whole thinking about civilian economy," and added that plans had been made to bring back into production a number of consumers' products such as refrigerators.

A lot has been said, and more written, about the work of the American Red Cross, but only one who has been confined in an Army hospital for several months, as I have, can really appreciate what it is doing. Only he can fully realize the effect the presence of its workers have upon the well-being of the bedridden service man.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., warns the Democratic party and particularly Southern Democrats in the current issue of his union's house organ, that unless they stop "crucifying" the trade union movement "they will find themselves as they did before, from March, 1921, until March, 1933, a crawling, impotent minority."

Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, opened yesterday the three-day Fiesta of the United Nations in the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, held under the auspices of the Pen and Brush Club for the benefit of the Red Cross War Fund Drive.

Southern blooms hold the center of the flower stage this week, the New York Department of Markets announced yesterday. Virginia daffodils are added to North Carolina shipments, with the latter reported on the wane. However, first shipments arriving from Portsmouth indicate that the best Virginia quality is as yet available in limited quantities only.

Sammy Angott, one-time ruler of the lightweight division, halted the longest winning streak in the history of modern boxing when he defeated Willie Pep of Hartford in the star bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, March 19 -- The official investigation into the subway shelter disaster in London on March 3 when 173 men, women and children lost their lives while seeking safety during a German air raid, was finished today after a coroner's jury heard witness after witness testify that there was a complete absence of panic.

MEXICO CITY, March 19 -- In its annual report published today, the fifth anniversary of the expropriation of the foreign oil companies, Petroleos Mexicanes paid a tribute to the cooperation the United States Government was giving to the Mexican oil industry.

Today's events: "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Dance of the Hours," from "La Gioconda," and "Pagliacci," 2, and "Carmen," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Young People's concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; Josef Hofmann, piano, Carnegie Hall, 3; Gregory Ashman, piano, and Albert Stoessel, violin, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Rudolf Serkin, piano, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; '"Aida," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Cheering tidings of greater resources of cloth for smart and warm Fall clothing were imparted here today by government representatives. Generous stocks of men's wear fabrics, becoming available as more men go out of mufti and into uniform, will be available for feminine outfits.

MONTREAL, March 19 (Canadian Press) -- Apparent total consumption of newsprint in the United States in February at 280,139 tons was 10,721 tons, or 3.7 per cent, lower than in February, 1942, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- A sweeping labor measure, to outlaw any union rule or practice which "interferes with the full utilization" of the country's manpower, was before the House Militory Committee today while Congress weighed a protest against organization of industrial foremen.

Patrolman James J. Donovan, 37 years old, was in Kings County Hospital yesterday in a critical condition, suffering from two gunshot wounds in his chest after engaging in a gun fight with two other patrolmen.

Perhaps the college athletic directors have some inside information on the shape of things to come, but to this outsider who has steadfastly maintained a strong interest in college sports for many years, their action in canceling intersectional football games for next Fall seems hasty.
MOSCOW, March 19 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique:

The Metropolitan Opera Association operates under a tax handicap which last year amounted to $145,000. It has no subsidy and no stockholders. No private person receives a cent of profit from its activities, which are purely cultural. To remedy this obviously inequitable situation Senator Coudert and Assemblyman Moffat have introduced a bill at Albany to exempt from real estate taxes that portion of the property of the Association used for musical purposes.

Ines Gomez Carrillo, talented young Argentine pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The modest, serious artist came to this country recently following her winning of the award in the National Art Commission of Buenos Aires competition, which entitled her to a year's stay in the United States.

The management of the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation sent a follow-up proxy solicitation to shareholders yesterday urging them to send in their proxies for the annual meeting to be held in Wilmington, Del., on April 1. The solicitation was in the form of a rebuttal to the recently issued statement of an opposition proxy group formed by W.H. Danforth, who holds 5 per cent of Columbia Oil's common stock.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt endorsed today the broad principles of a proposed Senate resolution pledging cooperation by the United States with other nations to maintain the future peace, but indicated that the time might not be ripe for such a declaration.
LONDON, Saturday, March 20 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt nominated Lieut. Gen. H.H. Arnold to be a full general, signed the first 1943 deficiency appropriation bill, held his press conference and met with the Cabinet; his visitors included Mrs. Demas T. Craw and son, to whom he presented the Congressional Medal of Honor awarded posthumously to Colonel Demas T. Craw, killed in Africa; David Dubinsky and Eric A. Johnston.

NEWARK, N.J., March 19 -- Warnings to comply with price regulations or face punitive action, which may include suspension of licenses to do business, have been sent by the New Jersey office of Price Administration to ninety-two food dealers in this area, Nathan L. Jacobs, chief attorney of the bureau, announced here today.

Prime Minister Winston Churchill has sent a copy of the new British Eighth Army film, "Desert Victory," to Premier Joseph Stalin, the British radio reported yesterday in a broadcast to Africa recorded by the United States Federal Communications Commission.

Gertrude Lawrence will return to the cast of "Lady in the Dark" at the Broadway Theatre this evening, it was announced yesterday by the Sam Harris office. Performances of the musical play were temporarily suspended last Tuesday when Miss Lawrence, its star, contracted a cold following a benefit appearance at Madison Square Garden on Monday evening.

In deciding that foremen are eligible to form and to become members of labor unions, the National Labor Relations Board has made a decision that ignores industrial realities. Such a decision, as C.E. Wilson, president of the General Motors Corporation, has pointed out in a telegram to four House committees, would mean "complete breakdown of authority and internal plant discipline."

New financing here this week was the smallest for such a period in a month, consisting of only two issues of municipal securities aggregating $7,000,000. It compared with flotations totaling $7,960,000 last week, $6,000,000 of which was in an industrial loan, and with tax-exempt issues amounting to $9,827,000 in this week a year ago.

" Venerable," the guide books call the Murray Hill Hotel on Park Avenue. It was built in the Eighties. So early in New York is structural old age. A landmark in affectionate memories, it has just passed to new owners who will allow it to live at least until the war is over.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The American Meat Institute made public tonight a report which it submitted to the Office of Economic Stabilization setting forth a program to meet "the acute and chaotic situation surrounding the national meat supply."

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, March 19 (U.P.) -- A shake-up in the administration of French Guiana, involving the resignation of Vichy-appointed Governor Rene Weber, followed the territory's pledge of allegiance to General Henri Honore Giraud, French North African commander, it was reported here today.

Even in ordinary times a city of strangers comes to New York every day. Among them will always be clients aplenty for the Travelers Aid Society. It has information booths for them in the railroad stations. It unites families. It sets right the bewildered. It takes care of lost children.

NEW DELHI, India, March 19 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have relaxed their pressure on British positions east of the Mayu River in Western Burma, it was announced today, but fighting has flared again on the Mayu Peninsula west of the river, where British advance forces in the Donbaik area are within twenty miles of the enemy-occupier port of Akyab.

The week-old strike of 700 coffin rankers was settled yesterday following an all-day meeting of representatives of the manufacturers and Local 1728 of the Casket Makers Union, A.F. of L., with Magistrate Edward C. Maguire, Mayor La Guardia's labor adviser, at City Hall, and it was announced that the strikers would return to work this morning.

With the American Toy Fair here closing today after a two-week run, indications were that manufacturers probably will not be able to ship more than two-thirds of the orders placed and retail shortages next Christmas are inevitable, according to estimates in trade quarters yesterday.

LONDON, March 19 (U.P.) -- Steelhelmeted Mobile Guards were reported tonight blocking all roads and mountain passes leading to Haute Savoie where French patriots, resisting forced labor conscription, ignored a "last appeal" from the Vichy government to surrender "before it is too late."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 19 -- A Russian-German separate peace is not unthinkable, declares the Nazi-owned Stockholm Dagsposten today editorially, telling its readers to look out for the month of August. This is the first time that a Berlin-owned and inspired newspaper has been permitted to discuss the subject.

A train journey these days is always an adventure. To those who traveled during the mobilization of Europe for this war, it never seemed strange to see Hungary or Rumania, Germany or France, gather up their young men and pack them into creaking coaches and box cars bound for the camps or the borders.

Tomorrow another Spring begins, but it is not the usual thoughts of Spring that come to mind. The moon will be full tomorrow night, but many young men who a year ago were driving their sweathearts to the movies or walking with them under the campus elms are in training camps, at sea, on Pacific islands, flying bombers over Europe.

One man was convicted yesterday in General Sessions of compulsory prostitution and another pleaded guilty to a similar charge after two young women had testified against him before Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Petroleum Administration for War reported today that while Atlantic seaboard petroleum stocks had dropped to a record low of 29.9 per cent of normal during the week ended March 13, "the demand for heating oils should be decreasing because of warmer weather."

Count Fleet, 2-to-1 future-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, was discharged from a railroad car yesterday at Belmont Park, and last night was munching his oats at Mrs. John D. Hertz's stable, apparently none the worse for his two and one-half day trip from Little Rock, Ark.

The air is full of post-war plans. Most of them are so elaborate as to guarantee their failure. We forget not only the wretched break-down of that League of Nations, the hope of ardent souls twenty-odd years ago, but also the various Utopias of many of the greatest minds of all time, including Plato, St. Augustine, Sir Thomas More and Francis Bacon.
Mrs. Reginald B. Rives has come to the Ritz-Carlton from Peapack, N.J.

Apropos of the data that are being released in conjunction with the forthcoming anniversary of National Wildlife Restoration Week, there comes a message from Ohio. The Buckeye State is dedicating the entire month of April to conservation, and its literature on the subject takes a sound approach in an effort to interest the general public.

For some time Ben K. Simkhovitch's "The Playboy of Newark" has been one of the mental hazards facing Broadway producers. A number of them have bought it, planning, of course, immediate production, and then after further thought and desk drumming have turned it back.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (U.P.) -- After a half hour of debate on Governor Tugwell, the House Rules Committee approved today a proposed House investigation of his administration of Puerto Rico.
CHICAGO, March 19 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the generalissimo of China, was welcomed to Chicago today at the Union Station by 2,000 cheering admirers.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 19 -- Civil service employes throughout the Reich have now been placed on a fifty-six-hour-week work schedule, it was learned today.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- The third issue of the weekly newspaper Wolna Polska, published in Moscow by what is described as the Union of Patriotic Poles, continues a fierce polemic with the Polish Government in London on the subject of partisan strategy.
CHUNGKING, China, March 19 (UP) -- A Chinese communique:

JERSEY CITY, N.J., March 19 -- Failure of the railroads to pay $25,000,000 in taxes allegedly overdue to this city was cited by Mayor Frank Hague today as the principal reason the Board of Education would be unable to appropriate an additional $900,000 for salary increases for teachers.

LONDON, March 19 -- The British Communist party renewed today its application for admittance into the Labor party. The application had previously been rejected by the Labor party's executive committee, but the question will certainly arise at the party's June conference to be settled by the rank and file, with the result of the balloting very much in doubt.

The attempted withdrawal of the Midtown Business and Professional Women's Club charter by the Business and Professional Women's Clubs of New York State, Inc., drew protests yesterday from a number of prominent men and women.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Irritation against the War Production Board's priority and other regulations is rapidly disappearing among industrialists who recognize the necessity for strict conservation of available raw materials, W. John Logan, director of the war agency's compliance division, said today. Mr.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- It was in the face of threats of a Presidential veto that the House adopted the legislation on the relationship between the price which the farmer pays for the things he buys to the price he obtains for the products he sells.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has acquired film rights to the diary of the late William E. Dodd, American Ambassador to Germany, and to "Through Embassy Eyes," written by his daughter, Martha, which will be made into one picture, according to an announcement today by William F. Goetz.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 19 -- A dripping, leaden sky made visibility low today, but Manager Mel Ott thought he detected a rift in the clouds of uncertainty hovering over the Giants' outfield prospects.

DETROIT, March 19 (AP) -- Jacob La Motta of New York gained a sixth-round knockout over Jimmy Reeves of Cleveland tonight to square accounts for two defeats sustained at the hands of Reeves in 1941. A crowd of 9,491 paid $20,702 to see the scheduled ten-rounder.

The 905,000 children in New York's secondary schools were urged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia to become members of the Junior Red Cross. "A nickel contribution will make you a member," the Mayor told a radio audience from City Hall, "and you will never get as much for a nickel if you live 250 years."

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Henry J. Kaiser, shipbuilder, asked Donald M. Nelson, WPB chairman, tonight whether his shipyards should cut down their rate of production in order to comply with WPB procedure.

Operations in the black market in watches appear to be increasing rather than otherwise, despite attempts to check sales in violation of OPA ceilings, according to trade reports here yesterday. Estimates on the volume of the black market trading were that it was "substantial," with all of it done on a cash basis at prices anywhere from 30 to 70 per cent above normal prices.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19 -- Highly favored Gene Rogers, 19-year-old Columbia freshman sensation from Bayside, L.I., captured the 220-yard free-style crown in a stirring due with Amherst's Jim Ammon tonight to furnish the individual opening-day feature of the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League invitation meet.

For the first time the Battle of the Atlantic against the German U-boat fleet appears to have become a united effort. Washington reveals a series of continuing conferences of Allied representatives, under Admiral King, to pool the resources of the United States, Great Britain and Canada into a single campaign against the submarines.

The two-family house and store at 7922 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Anna Himstedt to John H. Bahrenburg. The property is assessed at $23,500. The buyer was represented by Daniel McNamara and the seller by Herman A. Holsten. Title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 19 -- Accompanied by a long tirade against the Swiss press, "which has been deliberately misled by Anglo-Saxon propaganda," the Axis-controlled Toulouse radio in a French domestic broadcast tonight gave the first public report within France of the Haute Savoie situation, as follows:

Mayor La Guardia gave away a military secret yesterday, but no harm came of it. Addressing a group of women volunteers who had assembled in front of City Hall to receive certificates attesting to their work of at least three months in the Auxiliary Aircraft Warning Service, the Mayor mentioned the fact that it was raining and his words were broadcast by WNYC, the municipal radio station.
A High, Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

As the Federal Government continues to pile up vast food stores for the armed forces, lend-lease and other preferred groups and as spokesmen of the food industry warn that the nation is dangerously near famine, the Army Quartermaster General has notified eleven prime contractors to hold up production of Rations K and C, emergency allowances for the armed forces, as of March 31.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Because of war contracts running out, about 75 per cent of the productive capacity of the furniture industry will be available for civilian goods, labor and raw material permitting, Colonel Lawrence H. Whiting, president of the American Furniture Mart, told members of the Chicago Retail Furniture Association here today.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 19 -- While a military band played the national anthems of the United States and of Costa Rica, Vice President Henry A. Wallace laid the cornerstone of the building that will house the Inter-American Institute of Agricultural Sciences.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Motorists not eligible for more than the six gallons monthly permitted under "A" book rations will have considerable difficulty in keeping their car batteries in efficient working order, representatives of the Office of Price Administration and battery dealers said today.

The Tokyo Radio, in a broadcast reported yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission, appealed to the Japanese people for greater efforts in war production with a warning that the United States plans to "launch out in a counter-offensive against Nippon in the Pacific."

Two young Negro women were charged with disorderly conduct last night as the result of a disturbance about 10 P.M. at one of the entrances to the Independent subway station at Rockaway Avenue and Fulton Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Frank (The Enforcer) Nitti, successor to Al Capone and head of the new gang of terrorists that has invaded Chicago labor unions, shot and killed himself today a few hours after he was indicted in New York on charges of racketeering.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- National income and gross national product, the money value of the nation's total production, increased 26 and 27 per cent, respectively, in the United States in 1942, compared with 1941 to new record figures of $119,800,000,000 and $151,600,000,000, respectively, it was announced today by Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones.

LONDON, March 19 -- The war news from North Africa increased interest today in South African gold and diamond mining shares on the stock markets. Western Holdings jumped 3/4 to 25 1/4 shillings, Western Reefs gained 3/8 at 50 shillings, but profit-taking eased Blyvoor to 54 3/4 after it had touched 55 1/4 shillings.

Brewers will be forbidden to continue the use of "one trip" bottles in the domestic market under the terms of a conservation order which will be issued by the War Production Board within the next few days, it was authoritatively learned yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, March 19 (AP) -- A vigorous counter-attack covered by airplanes was launched by reinforced Japanese forces yesterday in the Hupeh area south of the Yangtze River, a Chinese High Command communique announced today.
