LONDON, March 19 -- The largest force of American planes ever sent against Germany made the deepest penetration to date into the Reich yesterday when Flying Fortresses and Liberators dropped their heaviest load of bombs, on the U-boat building center at Vegesack, near Bremen, and shot down the greatest number of enemy fighters bagged this year, United States Eighth Air Force headquarters announced today.

Ernest P. Seelman of Brooklyn, a member of the Board of Higher Education since July 19, 1934, announced yesterday that he had submitted his resignation to Mayor La Guardia, effective immediately. Mr. Seelmann's term would have expired on June 30.

The Junior Show, annual presentation of the juniors of Barnard College, was given last night by the class of '44 at the Brinckerhoff Theatre on the campus before a capacity audience of 500 persons. The show, "Faith, Hope and Hilarity," concerned triplets who sought to get a single Barnard degree for Hilarity.

LONDON, March 19 -- Foreign diplomatic quarters said today that Washington was seeking approval of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York as wartime civil administrator of occupied Italian territory in Africa.
ALBANY, March 19 (AP) -- The sap is running in New York, the country's second largest maple syrup and sugar producing State, and prospects of a good yield are bright despite an acute labor shortage.

MOSCOW, March 19 -- The Germans, continuing to challenge the growing strength of Russian resistance on the Northern Donets, severely hammered the Russian lines yesterday at points where they had been advanced slightly in Tuesday's and Wednesday's fighting in the Chuguyev region.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 19 -- Shortage of labor to peel shrimp has caused thousands of pounds of this seafood to be dumped overboard in this area, a waste which, the industry believes, could be avoided by relaxation of the Federal Child Labor Laws to permit children of 14 to 16 to do the work.

BUFFALO, March 19 (AP) -- Nine Buffalo livestock slaughtering firms, about one-third of the number in the city, have closed within recent weeks, says Louis F. Grauer, president of the Greater Buffalo Associated Meat Industry.

The decision of the Supreme Court in the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Western case is of special interest to the two dozen or more insolvent railways which have thus far been unable to agree upon a plan. The obstacle which for more than a dozen years has stood in the way of such reorganization has been failure of the different classes of securities to reach common ground.

Announcement that the House had passed unanimously a rule to bring the Pace Bill to the floor for debate ran cotton prices to increases up to 15 points in late dealings yesterday, but profit taking in the May and July positions on the New York Cotton Exchange pared the advances to final net gains of 4 to 9 points.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today a measure rescinding President Roosevelt's executive order freezing salaries at $25,000 net. A written report will be filed with the Seante probably on Monday.

The 20,000 students attending the National University of Mexico represent a vigorous medium for promoting the good neighbor policy in the Western Hemisphere and also will contribute importantly to the war program of the United Nations as soon as their country's plans for their military training can be put into effect, it was asserted yesterday by their rector, Dr. Brito Fouchet, now visiting here.

LONDON, March 19 -- Until the immense quantities of oil required for the offensive plans forecast by President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill have been supplied to the vital fronts no complacency is tolerable either on the side of economy or of supply organization, Geoffrey Lloyd, British Parliamentary Secretary for Petroleum, said today on his return from Washington.

LONDON, Saturday, March 20 -- Outnumbered Russian troops, battling countless German tank and infantry assaults, were forced back again and lost two populated places to the Nazis in bitter fighting on the southern front, Moscow announced early today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt told his press conference today that he wanted to avoid compulsory national labor service to aid the war effort as long as he possibly could because such legislation would create a lot more governmental machinery, make life more complicated and make for increased regimentation.

Grocers in the New York area, through spokesmen for their associations, gave indications yesterday that the Office of Price Administration point rationing system was having a generally adverse effect on trade.

PITTSBURGH, March 19 -- The W.J. Dillner Transfer Company has applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board in Washington for authority to set up an air hauling service to any point in the United States and Canada. The company operates a fleet of forty trucks and several service cars.

The medical director, the chief auditor and four supervisory employes of the State Insurance Fund were suspended yesterday pending investigation of charges that they got "kickbacks" from an X-ray laboratory where they sent injured workers for examination.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- William Allen White told the Executives' Club today that the small business man was gravely imperiled by totalitarian business on the one hand and the totalitarian State on the other, but that he hoped the "little guy" would have the faith to fight on and win his battle as he has in the past.

The directors of the Erie Railroad at a meeting held here yesterday approved an issue of $10,000,000 of serial collateral trust notes due in one to ten years. The company stated that it would issue a call for bids on the issue within a few days. The bidders will name the coupon rate.

This letter is to point out the great value of a certain basketball player to his team. His name is Stanley Skaug, captain of the Dartmouth squad which will participate in the coming National Collegiate Athletic Association tourney in Madison Square Garden.

Supplementing the report of almost normal Spring sports activity made by leading colleges and universities of the East, Harvard has come through with a statement revealing that the Cantabs will engage in a good deal of varsity competition through the middle of May.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Henry J. Kaiser dismissed today as "merely the latest smear attempts of jealous rivals," the technical charges of priority violations filed against him in San Francisco.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 19 (AP) -- A happy ending to the legend of Jim Thorpe, once described as the greatest athlete in the world, was the undertaking assumed today by two Oklahoma Indian legislators.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 19 -- Manager Joe McCarthy today dissipated the suspicion that he is worrying about the absence of Bill Dickey, veteran backstop and a sparkplug for his Yankees.
NEW DELHI, India, March 19 (AP) -- A United States Army Air Force Headquarters communique:

One measure of Wall Street's current activity is the fact that volume on the New York Curb Exchange from the beginning of the year to March 13 was 12,958,772 shares, only 10,000,000 shares short of the total volume for 1942.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 19 -- With the signing and imminent arrival of Reuben Frank Melton, the Gastonia (N.C.) "farmer without a farm," this camp will take on more of the attributes of a real, old-fashioned Dodger layout. Melton reached New York yesterday.
A High Command communique as broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded here by The United Press:
NEW DELHI, India March 19 (AP) -- A British communique:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 19 (AP) -- A communique:

Retail trade here turned "soft" this week, but managed to show an increase over the comparative 1942 week. Estimates indicated department store volume showed an increase of 1 to 2 per cent over a year ago. Apparel store figures also ran well below the heavy percentage increases of recent weeks, which at one time reached 81 per cent above 1942.

The British Broadcasting Company said yesterday that Axis reports of an Eighth Army offensive were unfounded, The United Press reported. London observers, how ever, believed that General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery may have begun a series of small thrusts that will pick up momentum until they reach the tempo of a full offensive.

LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- The Morocco radio reported today that General Charles Nogues, Governor of French Morocco, had sent a telegram to General Henri Honore Giraud, stressing the importance of General Giraud's statement Sunday on the future of France and the union of the French Empire in a republican France.

The United Nations have pooled merchant marine resources and now have a huge fleet of at least 30,000,000 deadweight tons devoted to the common cause, according to an independent calculation taking into account ship production and losses.

Declaring his intention to submit a balanced budget for the city for 1943-44 on April 1, although the Assembly killed the bill that would have permitted the City Council to vote on increasing the present 1 per cent sales tax, Mayor La Guardia yesterday invited "the legislators at Albany" to listen to his broadcast from City Hall tomorrow if they desired to know what he planned to do.

CLINTON, N.Y., March 19 -- For the United Nations "to yield even by way of an exception to any imperialistic tendency of one of its partners at the cost of another would lead to a new Munich," Jan Ciechanowski, Polish Ambassador to the United States, declared tonight in addressing "a model conference of United Nations" held by students of twenty-eight Eastern colleges on the Hamilton campus.

Artists are being asked by the Greater New York CDVO to contribute their services. The need of such cooperation and the specific ways in which it may be used are stressed by Ethel Katz, coordinator of art production in the public relations department.

TORONTO, March 19 (AP) -- Sir Owen Dixon, Australian Minister to the United States, said today that the war against Japan must be conducted with vigor to keep her from reaching a strength so great that her "defeat becomes a formidable task for the United Nations."
The racehorse tactics displayed by many basketball teams in Madison Square Garden this season clearly demonstrate how the game has deteriorated during the last decade.

MONTREAL, March 19 (Canadian Press) -- Mervyn (Red) Dutton, acting president of the National Hockey League, today announced Stanley Cup play-off dates, starting Sunday night with the first-place Red Wings entertaining the third-place Toronto Maple Leafs at Detroit and the second-place Bruins entertaining the fourth-place Montreal Canadiens at Boston.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- John H. Fahey, commissioner of the Federal Home Loan Bank Administration in Washington, declared today that hasty liquidation of the Home Owners Loan Corporation would "bring havoc to the country."

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The general pattern by which civilian economy in territories recaptured from Axis powers will be organized on an interim basis has been set in North Africa and will be carried into Europe and wherever else United Nations forces take over, according to government officials recently returned from the North African theatre of operations.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 166 United States Army personnel wounded in action in the Asiatic, European, North American, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

A charge that the Rapp-Coudert Committee, investigating the administration and financing of the New York City school system, ignored the recommendations of its own survey staff on the question of transferring the purchase of school supplies from the Board of Education to the city authorities was made yesterday by Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the board.

The recent statement of General Henri Honore Giraud, announcing the abrogation of all racial laws introduced by Vichy, represents a certain advance, but until the decrees abolishing these laws have been promulgated the announcement will be simply a declaration of intention, the American Jewish Congress and the World Jewish Congress have declared in a joint statement.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- March income tax collections have reached $1,835,353,710, the Treasury reported today, this total being well ahead of last year's corresponding period.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 19 -- Fifty thousand boys and girls are expected to join the New York State Farm Cadet Victory Corps of 1943 to work on vegetable, fruit and dairy farms of the State, W. Jack Weaver, supervisor of the Bureau of Agricultural Education of the State Department of Education, said this afternoon in announcing the set-up of the corps.

The need for new capital in the amount of perhaps $1,500,000,000 to finance anticipated post-war construction throughout the Bell system was forecast yesterday by officials of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, parent concern of the system.
One thousand patrolmen, plainclothes operatives and detectives, most of them armed with nightsticks, entered the campaign against muggers last night, principally in Harlem and Brooklyn.

The past few days of pleasant Springlike weather brought up the question of a little golf this year for those who have to stay at home doing their regular jobs while others fight, operate the factories and work on farms.

Eight of Al Capone's gangland successors, with a Newark labor leader, were indicted here yesterday and identified by United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa as "the boys in Chicago" who had taken over a movie union and fleeced employers and employes alike of $2,500,000.

TURRIALBA, Costa Rica, March 19 (AP) -- A complete change in living conditions of the Western Hemisphere in a single generation will be possible as a result of experiments to be carried out by the Inter-American Institute of Agricultural Sciences, Vice President Henry A. Wallace said today in inaugurating the institute here.
BOSTON, March 19 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the wool market tomorrow:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 19 -- The palm trees rustle gently in hotel lobbies and the moonbeams have a frosty gleam, but Spring training nears the end of its first week in this "Southern" resort of the Giants. Master Melvin Ott is agreeably surprised at the results to date and beginning to suspect that his diamond heroes may be more fit to answer the opening gong than either of their rivals for metropolitan esteem.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- The tragic story of how scores of women risked death on a sinking Brazilian ship in shark-infested waters of the South Atlantic rather than face capture by Axis seamen was related today by survivors of the Afonso Penna, sunk by a submarine off the east coast of Brazil on March 2.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Plans are being formulated to broadcast the address that Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, will make to the Maryland Legislature next Friday, to the approximately twenty other State Legislatures then in session, it was understood here today.

DAYTON, March 18 -- The success of Army Air Services Command experiments at Patterson Field in wartime replacement of industrial manpower with women has given rise to a broad training program and special study of the health of women in industry.

Lady Halifax, wife of the British Ambassador, was the guest of honor at formal exercises in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, marking the dedication of a room in the pediatric ward in memory of her son, Francis Hugh Peter Courtenay Wood, who was killed in action last October.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Criticism of French sailors who leave their ships, which are being repaired in United States ports, to join the de Gaulle movement was expressed by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox at his press conference today.

Sooner or later it was bound to happen. Somebody in the news the other day received a wage increase "of from" $2,000 to $2,500; the precise amounts do not matter. Note now how this fake's progress in the uglification of language operates.

LONDON, March 19 -- Planning for the post-war relief of liberated Europe has reached a stage now where members of the Inter-Allied Committee would like to know more about the United States' ability and willingness to supply the needs.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- In a forty-eight-page report covering war plants in this State in which the Congress of Industrial Organizations has labor contracts, the California C.I.O. Council criticized War Production Board policies and "rah rah" literature today, and said that nearly 85 per cent of the labor-management committees formed under the Nelson plan became "dormant" within three months.

Values of corporation shares were impaired further along an irregular route yesterday as selling in a long list of specialties and low-priced issues on the Stock Exchange overbalanced points of strength. Sales of numerous large blocks of low-priced stocks lifted the session's volume to 1,065,330 shares from 865,910 on Thursday and produced the twenty-seventh-million-share day for the year to date.

In a move to streamline procedure, eliminate "red tape," and expedite the handling of labor-management disputes, the Regional War Labor Board and the New York State Mediation Board made public yesterday a new plan of cooperation between the two agencies.

A petition to restrain the management of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company from holding the annual meeting of stockholders, scheduled for next Thursday, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by George O. Antil of Holyoke, Mass.

The Transamerica Corporation, a holding company for stocks of various financial and other concerns, announced yesterday in its annual report for 1942 a consolidated net profit of $9,161,625, including $5,511,270 proportion of net profits of subsidiaries in excess of dividends received.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- American farmers will plant about 279,000,000 acres of beans, oil seeds, corn, peanuts and other crops this year to meet war production goals, an increase of almost 10,000,000 acres, or 3.5 per cent, over the acreage planted last year.

Sooner or later it was bound to happen. Somebody in the news the other day received a wage increase "of from" $2,000 to $2,500; the precise amounts do not matter. Note now how this fake's progress in the uglification of language operates.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- President Roosevelt and James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, may make a week-end decision on the "Little Steel" formula, which has been used by the War Labor Board since last Summer as a yardstick for measuring the extent to which it would grant wage increases.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The House adopted by voice vote and sent to the Senate today the Pace bill to include the new factor of farm labor, including the farmers' families' work, figuring in the farm parity relationship, thus threatening to remove a keystone from the Administration's price stabilization policy.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (U.P.) -- The House Rules Committee, despite War Department opposition, approved today the Kilday bill to grant deferment proirities to fathers and to establish draft quotas on State-wide rather than local board bases.

" Lasse-Maja," a Swedish impor tation, will have its premiere today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The film, which has English dialogue titles, is a historical romance set in eighteenth century Sweden and stars Sture Lagervall.

Before imposing State prison sentences of two and one-half to five years each yesterday on William Walsh and Harry Waltzer, former business agents of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers' Independent Union, in the extortion of $5,000 from a publisher on threats to call out his employes on strike, Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions declared there should be a law passed that would make the acceptance of a bribe as culpable as giving it.

WHEN Singapore fell the collapse was blamed on the "Singapore Mind," or the "whisky-swilling planters," or the complacent members of the cricket club who refused to take part in the air raid precautions drill. But George Weller, Chicago Daily News correspondent, thinks that such explanations are simple-minded. A subtle writer with a great gift for evocative language, Mr. Weller tries to probe behind the surface of events in his "Singapore Is Silent."*

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The National Banking System, after a full year of operation under wartime conditions, has entered 1943 in a strong position reflecting steady progress in improving assets, in strengthening management, keeping down expenses, in conserving earnings and, where possible, increasing capital protection, according to the annual report of Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency, released today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 19 -- Raids on five stores and dwellings suspected of being headquarters for policy slip operators were conducted simultaneously late this afternoon in Westchester County by forty deputy sheriffs and policemen of local communities.
Ward Mayer, in 480 Park Ave; Mrs. Elsa Allen, Pauline Kohn, Kathleen Landy, in 321 E 54th St -- Pease Elliman, brokers.

TURRIALBA, Costa Rica, March 19 (U.P.) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace, in his address inaugurating the Inter-American Institute of Agricultural Sciences here, disclosed today that the institute already had progressed far in developing a rubber plant capable of resisting diseases that formerly had prevented the successful cultivation of rubber in Latin America.

The Pan-American Life Insurance Company had admitted assets of $48,271,131 at the close of 1942, comparing with $44,253,393 the year before, according to a statement issued yesterday. Capital and surplus were $2,685,162, against $2,400,866, and policy reserve was $41,623,172, against $38,431,028.

The recent act of cutting gasoline allowance to one and a half gallons a week for all holders of A cards and, at the same time, restoring to us the right of "pleasure driving," is remarkable for its irony as well as its lack of discrimination.

Colonel William F. Kernan, author of "Defense Will Not Win the War," has completed his new book "We Can Win This War," which will be published April 5 by Little, Brown. This is the sixth new title to be added to Little, Brown's Spring book list.

E.S. Thompson, president of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., said yesterday in his annual report to stockholders, covering 1942, that the utility industry should be entitled to "consideration and relief" from the heavy burden of taxation in view of the fact that its rates to consumers were not permitted to increase, despite the increased costs of fuel, materials, supplies and other items of doing business.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, March 20 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Mrs. Mary V. Craw of Charlottesville, Va., received from President Roosevelt today the Congressional Medal of Honor awarded posthumously to her husband, Colonel Demas T. Craw, who was killed in the North African landings when he was trying to pass through the enemy lines and locate the French commander with a view to suspending hostilities.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The new manpower committee of the National Association of Manufacturers, holding its first meeting today, was reported to have shown a general sentiment for giving the existing voluntary system of getting war workers a thorough tryout before any labor draft was invoked.

Next week's volume of new municipal financing will aggregate $6,260,836, compared with this week's revised total of $9,168,500, according to Daily Bond Buyer. Next week's financing will comprise bonds and notes of eighteen municipalities.

Suggestions for amending and improving OPA's rayon hosiery regulation MPR-339 will be submitted to Administrator Prentiss M. Brown next week by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, it was announced here yesterday.

BALTIMORE, March 20 -- With a few exceptions, butchers here are reserving the little supply of meat they get for their "regulars." There was virtually no beef and little of any other kind of fresh meat at retail this week. There were sparse offerings of lamb and pork.

Yachtsmen in fourteen classes already have applied to the Yacht Racing Association for starting times in the championship series racing to be held this Summer on Long Island Sound. The official circulars will be made up after the delegates of the various clubs meet in the New York Yacht Club on March 31 to outline the schedule.

NEW ORLEANS, March 20 (AP) -- An chances that Ben F. Whitaker's Pops Pick had of starting in the Kentucky Derby suffered a setback with the running of the Fort Livingston Handicap at the Fair Grounds today. Favorite in a field of eight 3-year-olds, the Texas-owned colt finished second to Noonday Sun, a Greentree Stable gelding that scored by a head and returned $16.80 for $2.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 20 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace, accompanied by his party of United States experts and Costa Rican officials, yesterday flew to a banana plantation on the Pacific Coast. He observed the latest methods of spraying, irrigating and cutting the fruit.

A rare piece of old blue Staffordshire ware, prized by many art collectors since early in this century, was sold at auction yesterday with other art objects in this classification at the closing session of a four-day sale in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Dr. Altmeyer's suggestion of the extension of old-age insurance to cover agricultural labor, domestic service, public employment and self-employment, made before the Child Care Conference in New York and reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 4, has much to commend it.

WOODY GUTHRIE is an American jongleur, a wandering minstrel, a guitar-busker who packs his guitar into saloons, 'burger joints, chili houses and plays for the nickels and dimes men throw into his hat.

LONDON, Sunday, March 21 -- The Red Army reported today that it was locked in fierce defensive battles in the Chuguyev area southeast of Kharkov, but on the central front had captured more towns and villages in the enveloping drive aimed at Smolensk.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (U.P.) -The War Department announced today the award of Distinguished Flying Crosses to nineteen members of the Army Air Forces for achievement in aerial flights.

The faculty of Columbia College has approved a resolution, presented at a recent meeting, declaring that "the study of the liberal arts must not be permitted to languish during the existing national emergency, but that such study must be pursued with great vigor and to as full an extent as the circumstances of war will permit."

The United Air Lines Transport Corporation may soon extend its operations from the boundary between the United States and Mexico to Mexico City and elsewhere in the neighboring republic under an option for the acquisition of a controlling interest in the Lineas Aereas Mineras of Mexico acquired a few days ago upon granting of a $250,000 loan to the Mexican airline.

Increased emphasis upon physical education to prepare young men for the rigors of modern warfare has taken place in colleges and universities throughout the country. Most of the colleges now make this training compulsory.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Warning employers that their manpower problems could not be solved by "escalating wages," Roger D. Lapham, industry member of the National War Labor Board, appealed tonight to his colleagues to stand firm against labor demands for modification of the "Little Steel" formula and greater pay increases.

Considered by some business executives to be the most important labor relations development that the war has produced, the "job relations training program" of the Training Within Industry Division of the War Manpower Commission has been completed after a year of preparation and has been introduced on a limited scale.

NEW YORKERS will be getting their first look at the last motion picture made in France before the Nazi invasion when "The Heart of a Nation" has its world premiere here next month. A dramatization of French history through three Teutonic invasions, starting with the Franco-Prussian War, the film also will be shown shortly on the once more free soil of French North Africa.

THE experts say that sweet corn is no crop for a small garden, and advise against planting it in a garden less than 50 by 50. We grant that it would be ideal to have a garden large enough to provide sweet corn for two months from succession plantings.

WHEN we win the war, our college presidents point out, we must survive not merely as a free but as a civilized people, and among the most civilizing of peacetime pursuits is the growing of flowers. Much of our garden space is converted this year to vegetables.

NOVELISTS, like movie stars, baseball players and other public figures, live and work in a fiercely competitive world. As soon as the wellsprings of their creative imagination show signs of running dry, as soon as their current work becomes inferior to their previous achievements, as soon as age, illness or any other factor, impairs the quality or reduces the quantity of their literary production, young, ambitious, talented writers are always ready to take over.

Nancy Schaefer, 15 years old, played the scherzo and the finale from Ernest Schelling's Scherzo Fantastique at the Young People's Concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. The young pianist, who played a harp solo with the Philharmonic last year at Town Hall, gave an excellent account of herself, in a clean and straightforward performance.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 20 -- The occupying authorities in Poland have begun "rearranging" the functions of the Catholic Church in the Gouvernement General, according to the Apologetische Blaetter, organ of the Swiss Roman Catholic National Union.

A shortage of experienced seamen in a number of skilled categories is increasing and is now at an acute stage where it may threaten the efficiency of war shipping operations, it was declared here yesterday by Marshall E. Dimock, director of recruitment and manning of the War Shipping Administration.

WHEN Clark Lee first began to get his Bataan stories through the censors and over the radio to American papers, soldier readers who weren't among the few who had access to the official dispatches began to see the fighting a lot more clearly.

DEBUTANTES of this season headed by Miss Jane Eyre, chairman, and Miss Dudley Kenyon, vice chairman, will act as hostesses to a large group of service men at the performance of "Harriet," with Helen Hayes in the leading role, on Thursday night at Henry Miller's Theatre for the benefit of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Office of Defense Transportation stated today that the fleet of 500 wooden petroleum tank barges, twenty-one towboats and 100 tugboats now under construction to step up the flow of oil to the East would be operated by private companies on a charter basis.

This provision in the Constitution (Article II, Section 2) has frequently risen to plague Presidents. Treaties signed after long and delicate negotiations have gone to the Senate, where they have failed to obtain the necessary two-thirds vote. This power of the Senate has been sharply illustrated after the nation's wars.

" HOW can some women waste their time putting flowers into vases, much less studying how to do it, now when there are so many important things to be done?" That question is often asked these days, and some, having asked it, have abandoned the art of arrangement for the duration.
CHUNGKING, China, March 20 -- All Japanese operations in China indicate they are not an all-out military offensive but military steps in a politico-economic war.

ST. LOUIS, March 20 -- In this second largest livestock market in the United States, an acute meat shortage has developed in the last few weeks. Meat in retail stores of the district is estimated by the St. Louis Metropolitan meat Dealers Association at 25 per cent of the seasonal normal.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The ears of those Federal officials charged with responsibility for the country's food production this year must have been rugged indeed if they withstood without damage the blasts of criticism loosed here this week by every element in the food industry from farmer to retailer.

THE planting of ornamental shrubs this year particularly may be considered a wise wartime investment. If correctly planted, the young specimens will need only a minimum of care and attention during the next year or two.

IT is correct to classify the gladioli and dahlias as Summer flowering bulbs even though, botanically, one is a tuber and the other a corm. In view of the fact that both are well known, this article will not deal with them, except to mention several outstanding new varieties recently introduced.

Topping off a hockey season filled with unexpected performances by almost every club except the Detroit Red Wings, the National Hockey League's post-season play-offs get under way tonight with the Red Wings rated as odds-on favorites to win the coveted Stanley Cup, The Associated Press reports.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 20 -- German U-boat packs sank thirty-two ships in attacks on a heavily guarded Eastbound convoy in the North Atlantic this week, a special High Command communi que, released in Berlin, said tonight.

FROM the U.S.S.R. last week came the promised series honoring "Heroes of the Great Patriotic War." On a 20-kopecs deep blue with portrait of Lieut. Talalikhin is a design picturing his Stormavik fighting plane crashing into a Nazi bomber.

LONDON, March 20 -- Despite recent flurries of optimism regarding the progress of the war at sea, sinkings by German submarines are still causing gravest concern among the Allies. Merchant tonnage is a limiting factor in every Allied scheme and many strategists feel that no full-scale offensive against the enemy can be undertaken on the Continent until the U-boats are beaten.

IS it just a fancy of mine, and a mistake, when I seem to feel the Puritan tradition is still the strongest undercurrent in American literature? Not least in that part of it that is termed outspoken, hardboiled, emancipated from the taboos of the past.

A GROUP of entertainers led by A. Shaps gave 855 conccerts in Russia in eleven and a half months to July 3 last, according to the Moscow News. Some of the dramatic actors of the company found that they could sing and others discovered they could dance.

IN wartime there is bound to be a certain amount of insanity, so that it hardly seems necessary or prudent to promote it. Nevertheless, that is what this newspaper -- although with the kindest of motives -- is doing by printing nearly every Sunday, on the page opposite this one, what it calls the Puns and Anagrams puzzle.
" Most people, unfortunately, do not think; they feel and act according to their feelings." -- Jawaharlal Nehru, "Glimpses of World History."

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Wheat and rye made a firm start and a tame finish today on the Board of Trade. There was scattered buying early as a result of the passage late yesterday of the Page bill by the House in Washington, but the upturn was short-lived, as profit-taking and a little commission-house selling developed and both grains slipped more than a cent a bushel from the top and closed near the day's bottom.

The trophy representing the three-weapon championship of the Intercollegiate Fencing Association left University Heights for Annapolis yesterday when Navy finished on top in the association's fiftieth annual tournament at Salle Santelli.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -With the war effort of the whole country as a backdrop the biennial coal wage drama is being played out scene by scene following a more or less familiar pattern.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Apportionment of representation for the various sections of the State should be, in the essence, a most important governmental action. Yet in New York, as in most States, the political effects are usually more important than the governmental ones.

CAYENNE, French Guiana, March 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- A peaceful, bloodless coup, carried out on March 16 by high colonial army officers with the backing of a population enthusiastically supporting both the anti-Axis French factions of Generals Giraud and de Gaulle brought France's largest Western Hemisphere possession to the Allied side in the war.

THE tow-plane ahead roars off, our glider wheels along the ground a few dozen feet and abruptly swoops into the air. Below us the concrete runway whizzes by, an indistinct blur of gray. To the right, level with us and a little to the rear, we see two other gliders, pulled by the same "mother" ship.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 20 -- The war in the Southwest Pacific has entered a new phase. This new phase has been developing for months and, appropriately enough, it has appeared a year after General Douglas MacArthur arrived in Australia to take command of the Allied forces in that area.
WHILE the New York City Symphony Orchestra, now only a memory, was under the musical direction of Emerson Buckley, assisted by guest conductors, it gave ninety-three concerts and broadcasts combined.

WITH "Send Your Stamps to War" as a theme, the American Stamp Dealers Association inaugurated last week a nation-wide drive to influence philatelists to donate worth-while stamps and other recognized auction pieces which will be publicly sold for the benefit of the United Service Organizations on the evening of May 19 at the Collectors Club, 22 East Thirty-fifth Street.
BOSTON, March 20 -- A desperate food shortage beset the Massachusetts housewife today and sent her home from the market with an empty basket or a depleted purse.

Jim Moore registered ten goals last night to lead the Rovers to a 15-5 triumph over Great Neck in one of two polo games played at the New York Polo Club. In the other test the Ramblers downed the home trio, 14 -- 13.
TOMORROW surely belongs to the youngsters who will find Dr. Zim's book on air navigation a starting point in their lives. And a full and exciting tomorrow it is bound to be!

THIS book, which is an outgrowth of Miss Smith's work with Robert O. Ballou on "The Bible of the World," contains selections from the sacred writings of the world's great religions. For each of the thirteen sections, which deal respectively with the American Indian.

LONDON, March 20 -- Archbishop Spellman is expected to celebrate mass at Westminster Cathedral at 9 A.M. tomorrow in memory of Cardinal Hinsley. He will also participate in a solemn pontifical Mass at the funeral service on Tuesday, when Westminster Cathedral will be crowded to its capacity of 6,000 persons.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Declaring that the Office of Price Administration "must realize that they haven't exclusive rights on all the patriotism in America," Judge Michael L. Igoe, in the Federal court today, denied a temporary injunction to the OPA against a Chicago meat wholesaler charged with violating its price ceilings.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau discussed the Treasury's $13,000,000,000 second war loan campaign today with representatives of the newspaper industry and government officials.

Despite denials by an Office of Price Administration spokesman here that there had been any layoffs of employes in the regional office or any notices of impending lay-offs "as yet," a reflection of the new economy drive in that government agency was seen in reports by several employes that they had been told they were being cut from the payroll, effective next Tuesday.

One of the most dangerous jobs in the whole war is that of the "catafighter," the pilots catapulted from a merchant ship in a convoy to knock down attacking Nazi bombers or torpedo planes. It is said that Winston Churchill gave them their nickname.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 20 -- Despite heavy rain and deep mud that hampered operations off the main roads, American troops in the Gafsa-El Guettar area of Southern Tunisia consolidated their positions today against a probable enemy counter-attack and prepared to make the most of their new lines within striking distance of the main north-and-south communications of the Axis forces.

HORSES: The famous Windsor grays, matched horses that pulled the royal coach for the coronation of George VI, faced a new career last week Stabled at Windsor Castle, they will be put to work on royal acres converted to vegetable gardening.

Two $100,000 libel actions, instituted by Douglas Douglas-Hamilton, Duke of Hamilton, against the author and publishers of "That Day Alone" were settled amicably in the United States District Court on Friday when Horace S. Manges, attorney for Pierre Van Paassen, the author, apologized publicly for his client before Judge John C. Knox and fifty spectators, including Hiram C. Todd, attorney for the Duke of Hamilton.

" To provide a method for the payment currently or individual income taxes, and for other purposes." Thus reads the introduction to the Ways and Means Committee's proposed bill which is intended to provide for withholding the income tax and for placing the taxpayer upon a current basis.

Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, called yesterday on Mayor La Guardia at City Hall, where they conferred briefly, apparently on topics closely related to Allied unity and the problems involved in preserving it after the war.

EIGHT in the morning is the high-water hour for reception of short-wave news from the world-wide scenes of combat. Then Australia on 9.54 sends a walloping signal into the east. At the other end of the dial, Paul Winterton has just finished his talk from Moscow for the evening Newsreel; and Howard Marshall, the new BBC radio voice of the First Army, is heard sending his report from the 16-megacycle Algiers outlet.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 20 -- A New York baseball writer, encountering Dick Bartell for the first time in a Detroit Tiger uniform a couple of years ago, greeted him warmly: "My old pal," he said, "I'm certainly glad to see you again, Rowdy Richard." Bartell quickly put his finger to his lips and glanced around. "Shhhhhh," he whispered, "go easy on that Rowdy Richard stuff.

Interested parties met with Mayor La Guardia at his office yesterday and approved the plan.

STUDENTS of the Gardner School -- oldest girls' school in this city, which now maintains branches at the Hotel Plaza and in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. -- are concerned with an ambitious as well as patriotic venture in their plans to present a performance of "Buddies," a play by George V. Hobart, next Saturday afternoon at the Heckscher Theatre.
In THE TIMES of March 14 R.L. Schuyler brands as "silly and mischievous" the statement by R.H. Tawney that "Either war is a crusade or it is a crime."

NEW DELHI, India, March 20 (AP) -- The British Indian Army appeared tonight to have absorbed the force of a determined Japanese counter-attack and was moving back against Donbaik, north of Akyab, in the wake of a punishing naval bombardment that had started numerous fires in the enemy jungle stronghold.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Military observers here have their eye on fog-bound, mountainous Kiska, the bleak bastion in the Rat group of the Aleutian Islands, where the entrenched Japanese have been subjected to relentless aerial poundings in recent weeks, but their opinions as to our possible intentions in that Alaskan area are divided.

MONTREAL, March 20 (Canadian Press) -- The coveted Gordon International Medal, played for annually among top-flight curlers from Canada and the United States, appeared headed back this way following first-round play today, when Dominion teams gained a 194-160 edge in sixteen games.

Two improved water repellents have been developed by du Pont chemists to protect clothes. One is to be used with dry-cleaning fluids and the other with wet washes. Both are extensively employed in caring for the clothes of the armed forces. After treatment the fabric sheds water and resists staining.

THE bush fruits fit so well into the home garden that it is somewhat surprising that they are not more generally planted. Those who have once become acquainted with the delights of eating fully ripened berries direct from the garden usually become confirmed berry growers.

SWEET cherries are among the things that make June so pleasant to those fortunate enough to have such a tree in the dooryard. This luscious fruit is esteemed for its juiciness, delicacy and richness of flavor. As for the large handsome trees with their luxuriant foliage and profusion of snow-white blossoms in early Spring, they are well worth planting if only for ornamental reasons.

Miller, 39 years old, of 16 Sherbrooke Road, Scarsdale, N.Y., an advertising executive and son of George H. Miller, president of the Musterole Company of Cleveland, slipped and plunged fifteen stories to his death early yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Of the 1,479 war-plant projects owned by the government's Defense Plant Corporation, 1,022 have gone into operation, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, said today. Eight hundred of the active 1,022 plant-construction or equipment projects were begun by DPC, a subsidiary of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation since Pearl Harbor, he added.
The Fairleigh Dickinson (N.J.) Women's Reserve Corps has been formed to give to college students an opportunity to supplement their regular curriculum with various war activities.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -The Navy gun crew aboard the Liberty ship William Moultrie shot down eight German planes, damaged twelve others, drove away a submarine and scored a direct hit on a torpedo, causing it to explode, during a recent voyage to an Allied port, the Navy reported today.

THE March Snowdrops and the returning blackbirds of Spring find Mr. and Mrs. Novice out of doors, attired in overalls, sweaters and old shoes and engaged in staking out their second Victory Garden. The Novices (Joe and Jane to their friends) are in a much better position for victory than when we saw them a year ago struggling with the first garden of their lives.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A combined January-February report on war production issued today by Donald Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, showed an 8 per cent decline in output in January as compared with December, followed by an 8 per cent increase in February as compared with January.

MANY dinner parties will precede the recital to be given by Fritz Kreisler, noted violinist, tomorrow night at Carnegie Hall to augment the Red Cross War Fund. Mr. Kreisler has donated his services for the event.

" FISH-EYE" CAMERA -- Photographs made with a "fish-eye" camera, which shows everything in a room above its level, now make it possible to solve quickly problems of illumination which would otherwise require elaborate and lengthy calculations. So Frank Benford, General Electric engineer, revealed before a joint meeting of the Rochester section of the Optical Society of America and the Western New York section of the Illuminating Engineering Society.
EVERY gardener looks forward to having his own blueberry patch; often it is the only sure way of having blueberries. For there are limits to the supply in the market and transportation is a problem.

Decisions recently made by the Combined Export Markets Committee concerning the manner in which the United States and Britain have divided up world markets for vital chemicals should be made public now by the Lend-Lease Administration, it was asserted here yesterday by chemical exporters.

THIS Spring reveals the talent and skill of American fabric makers as no other season has done in the past. The war has taken its toll of raw materials, machinery and manpower and yet there is such undeniable beauty in the products turned out by the mills that one is not aware of these handicaps.

THIS year, with millions of Victory Gardens in the making, there is bound to be a shortage of seedlings, or young plants. The farsighted gardener won't be caught without them, however, because he will start raising his own right now.
CHICAGO, March 20 -- An acute shortage of beef, "sky high" sales of groceries, a plentiful supply of butter and rising prices for fresh vegetables mark the food story here.

Members of the food industry here were advised yesterday that a cut in 1943 production of canned foods was seriously being considered by canners whose warehouses still are stocked with government purchases of the 1942 pack for the armed forces, lend-lease and other priority groups.

LONDON, March 20 -- With German military might virtually knocking on her doors at the Pyrenees and while the United States and Britain nurse her along by seeing that she gets food supplies that her supposedly protective Nazi friend cannot give her, Spain appears to be in a muddled state of mind as to what attitude she should adopt toward the Allies.

LONDON, March 20 -- Blackpool, favorite for the football league's Northern Division War Cup, was beaten by Liverpool today in the feature British soccer match before 40,000 at Liverpool. The score was 3 -- 1.

Acting for the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, Local 16, A. F. of L., Mayor La Guardia yesterday presented ambulances and surgical kits, donated by the union, to the Royal Air Force, the Soviet and Chinese armies and the American Red Cross at ceremonies in City Hall Plaza.

A wreath from President Roosevelt was laid on the grave of Grover Cleveland in Princeton last Thursday, as on former anniversaries of President Cleveland's birth. When we think of Grover Cleveland as being born in the last year of Andrew Jackson's Presidency we have the sense of dealing with a remote past.

MR. WALLACE STEGNER in your issue of Feb. 28 stirs me to unwonted protest. I have not read Mr. Saroyan's novel, "The Human Comedy," but I look forward to it with the greater interest for having read Mr. Stegner's review.

THE plot about the wife-in-name-only is a cherished standby in light romantic fiction. Ethel M. Dell has used it with titillating effect at least a dozen times, and so have countless other popular novelists up and down the scale.

Details of the two leading field trials for pointers and setters in this section have been announced. The Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club will hold its meeting April 1 to 4 on the State grounds in Clinton, N.J. This will be followed April 7 by the meeting of the English Setter Club of America over the famous course in Medford, N.J.

FEW shows of work by Augustus John have been held in this country. The most recent, perhaps, was of etchings at the gallery of the late M. A. McDonald, and a memorable event it was. Now Mrs. Ala Story director of the American British Art Center, has brought together a score of paintings and twice as many of his expert drawings, mostly from the artist's studio, with a few notable loans from American collections.

IN normal times a discussion of tomato growing would begin or close with a list of recommended varieties. In 1943, however, such a list is impractical, since many kinds of tomatoes might not be available. Instead of specific recommendations, therefore, it may be suggested that the novice gardener consult his seeds-man, the Victory Garden committee of his local OCD, or a reliable florist, for information on what varieties are available.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 -In one of his rare press conferences, Major Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commander of the Marine Corps task force in the Solomon Islands, explained here today why it had taken so long to dislodge the Japanese force from Guadalcanal.

GLADYS SWARTHOUT was taking a chance when she agreed to make an album of Musical Show Hits (Victor M-935, four 10-inch records). The uncompromising longhaired contingent might be expected to condemn her performance as undignified, while the hepcats were likely to pronounce her efforts corny.

THE local seekers after nocturnal divertissement soon will get another opportunity of viewing the tempestuous talents of Carmen Amaya and her tribe of flamenco dancers. Contracts have been signed for Miss Amaya and her troupe to return on May 1 to La Conga, where she was recently seen. The Spanish gypsy dancer is presently touring in "Priorities," the Clifford C. Fischer and Messrs. Shuberts' variety offering.

THE Loop's only television station, W9XBK, has just rounded out six months of operation under a feminine staff. With the exception of Chief Engineer Arch Brawley, the entire technical staff is composed of women.

The epic of the war in North Africa seemed near its climax last week. Allied troops were on the move. Allied planes swept the sky, hammered German bases. In the mounting roll of drumfire it seemed clear that battles were under way or impending whose significance would spread far beyond the bare Tunisian hills upon which they would be fought.

Two years ago Samuel Goldwyn sold one-half of his contract with a young actor, Dana Andrews, to Twentieth Century-Fox because he was then unable to give employment to the unknown player. Now the co-owners of Mr. Andrews are trying desperately to buy each other out. Mr. Goldwyn, who wants him for the romantic male lead in "Up in Arms," reportedly offered $150,000 to Fox for its share of the ascending star's contract.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 20 -- Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa and United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery announced today that the United States would start the immediate purchase of unshipped portions of Brazil's coffee quotas for the quota years 1941-42 and 1942-43 in compliance with the agreement made last fall between the United States and Brazil.
A 17-year-old boy was held by the Federal authorities here yesterday on a charge of impersonating a captain in the Army Air Forces.

A huge audience in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon paid, homage to a great musician and a great figure in the history of piano-playing when Josef Hofmann made his 150th appearance on the stage of that auditorium for his only recital here this season.

AS an experiment last week-end, Miss Mildred K. Marshall, executive director of information, and Mrs. Helen Williams, in charge of room registry for service men, stayed on the job at the New York City Defense Recreation Committee headquarters until 2 o'clock Sunday morning.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -The City of Flint, an American steamship which was the center of a sharp pre-war controversy in 1939 when it was seized by the Germans, has been torpedoed and sunk in the Atlantic.
CHICAGO, March 20 -- The bar quivered as 14,000 fans in the Chicago Stadium held their breath as if in fear of blowing it off.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (U.P.) -The Germans may be sending some of their submarines into waters far away from the North Atlantic in an effort to divert Allied escort strength from the vital convoy routes to Britain, Russia and North Africa.
Retail trade here last week turned "soft" in comparison with preceding weeks. Department store volume was estimated as even with to 2 per cent higher than a year ago.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 20 (AP) -- Roy Cullenbine was regarded today as a possible pretender to the Indians' first base job. Although he came to the tribe as an outfielder, Cullenbine recently has been bracketed with Catcher Otto Denning in Manager Lou Boudreau's discussions of the problem created by Les Fleming's decision to remain in war work.

CONCERNING Dr. Graf's article on Richard Strauss, the composer was no Social Democrat. He invited Vienna Socialists as long as the Socialist party there was in power -- never afterward, as the leading Viennese Socialist music critic repeatedly told me.

Three members of the All-Metropolitan basketball team will be seen in action tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, where St. John's University tackles Rice of Houston, Texas, and Fordham takes on the Hilltoppers of Western Kentucky in the sixth annual national invitation tournament.

ALTHOUGH a number of excellent lives of Lincoln for boys and girls have been published, this is a very welcome volume, for Mrs. Meadowcroft has an exceptional understanding of the tastes and interests of the middle group of boys and girls, the 10 to 14-year-olds, as her "The Gift of the River," "Benjamin Franklin," and her two stories, "By Wagon and Flatboat" and "Along the Erie Towpath," have proved.

THE Lighthouse Players, a group of blind actresses, will present three one-act plays on Wednesday and Thursday evenings at the Lighthouse Little Theatre, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street. The program will comprise "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals," by James M. Barrie; "Sunday Costs Five Pesos," by Josephine Niggli, and "The Witch," by Ferenc Molnar.

EVEN though it was deemed essential to depart this year from the custom of permitting American artists to submit their work to a jury of admission, the Corcoran Gallery of Art remains in the ring. Its eighteenth biennial of contemporary American paintings opens today in Washington and will remain current until May 2.

AN Englishman who makes an appeal to the magnanimity of the American public can only do so with a great deal of diffidence, for the American public has since the beginning of the war been inundated with such appeals, and it has responded to them with a generosity that seems inexhaustible.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 20 -- Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night stayed Mrs. Florence W. Jakob from the swift completion of her appointed rounds as Plainfield's first woman mail carrier, but the weight of the mail bag did, so she resigned today after four days on the job.

For the first time in the sixty-year history of the public-utility industry, the Federal Government alone in 1942 took a greater percentage out of the gross revenue received by the utilities than the utility worker earned as his share in producing the nation's electric light and power supply.

NEW YORK booksellers are strongly protesting the omission of books in the exemption list appended to the projected curfew law of 8 P.M. for retail stores, now before the City Council. Food, flowers, newspapers and tobacco are included but books are absent.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The role played by Edwin F. Jaeckle, chairman of the Republican party in the State, in determining the policy of the State government has become increasingly important during the current session of the Legislature.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 20 -When the late John D. Rockefeller chose a site amid the pines here to lay out his private golf course years ago, he did not dream that these grounds some day would have a far-reaching influence upon the Spring conditioning of a major-league ball club.

Fashion and current events have joined hands this Spring. New styles at Jay Thorpe stress the importance of the Four Freedoms of the Atlantic Charter and are designed as reminders of what these freedoms will eventually mean to all men and women.

IT was over two years ago when last we saw Paul Henried (then Hernried) as he wiped off the grease paint in his dressing room at the Guild Theatre. He was in high spirits and he had reason. Within a few months after his almost penniless arrival from England, Mr. Henried, by a close play between his luck and his talent, had assailed Broadway's attention in a twin thrust.

IN September, 1939, a British newspaper ran a questionnaire for its readers. They were asked what they disliked most about the war. In those days there was not much war to dislike, so the proffered list was mostly home discomforts.

CHICAGO, March 20 -- Miss Waulhillau La Hay, movie critic of The Chicago Sun, and John J. Wildberg, New York attorney and theatrical producer, will be married here early next week. The ceremony will be performed by the Rev. Harold L. Bowman in the Westminster Presbyterian Church.

The longest and largest pipe line ever laid for oil transmission is being hustled on its way from the Midwest to the eastern seaboard by approximately 750,000 pounds of dynamite. It will cross thirteen large rivers, go over mountain ranges and through valleys.

THE children have been ill; now they are getting better. Some will be restless, skipping across draughty floors without their slippers; some will be content to sort their stamps on the coverlet, some will demand undue attention -- or so it may seem to parents worn out with sleepless nights and home nursing.

SWEEPING SEASON -- In the Spring -- just about the same time that the man of the house begins a search for last season's straw hat -every woman is seized with an irresistible desire to turn her home topsy-turvy.

Hopes in retail circles that adequate steps will be taken to preserve the civilian economy rose last week in the wake of several developments. Toward the end of the week, Chairman Nelson of the WPB, in announcing that plans were under way for the resumption of production of some types of consumer goods, confirmed reports that a reorganization of the Office of Civilian Supply was imminent.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- An "alarming" increase in crime and delinquency among women and girls in 1942 and a rise of 7.2 per cent in the number of "crimes against the person" by all offenders as compared with the pre-war years 1939-41 was reported today by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

IF "beauty were their only excuse for being" we would cultivate the company of birds in the garden. But some scientists tell us that if it were not for the services of birds in destroying harmful insects, we would have no garden in spite of our powders and sprays.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- The overall food supply picture in the Philadelphia area worsened during the week with fresh meats at the lowest point in years, while black market practices were reported in almost all food supplies.

WHATEVER the origin of universally accepted symbols, they acquire their own life. Uncle Sam, as a symbol of the United States outside the United States, has special validity for Europe. The United States was a place where most Europeans had an uncle who was, it was hoped, rich, and with luck, childless.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -There is a team of six admirals and a civilian in Washington to whom the Navy owes a lot. The admirals get to sea only rarely, when they can shake loose from their desks, but even if they have more headaches and less excitement, they are doing as much to win the war as the men who command the flagships.

Conservation is the keynote of the Spring fashions. To designers the government's program has been a spur into new and fresh creative realms. From it they have drawn inspiration. They must cooperate with the government's ruling to save material and labor; yet they must uphold the standards of American design.

The Office of Defense Transportation's ban against private bus service for apartment dwellers was extended yesterday to fifteen lines that have been providing special service in Westchester, the Bronx and Queens. Twelve other lines discontinued similar service last week upon order of the regional ODT.
PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -Full control of the Phillies was turned over today to a syndicate of New York and Philadelphia business men headed by William D. Cox, New York lumber broker and sportsman.

" TO MEET MISS LONG" is also to meet Miss Joan Kahn, sister of E.J. Kahn, who wrote "The Army Life." This is her first novel -- a simple, straightforward, honest young book about a high school girl and her family.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, March 21 (AP) -- Three Japanese merchantmen have been bombed and damaged by Allied planes off New Britain and New Guinea, the Allied High Command reported today.
LONDON, Sunday, March 21 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill will broadcast today to Britain and the other United Nations at 9 P.M., London time -- 4 P.M., Eastern war time, in the United States.

NOW day by day the spinning earth inclines a little farther toward its progenitor, the sun. Now the alternate light and shadow on this little planet change proportion, and in our latitudes the light begins to win again over the dark. City workers, walking to the office, look up and see the buds of the horse chestnut swelling.

WHAT bout books in 1943? What of publishers' problems, as the war tightens all our belts? What of the problems the booksellers face? What do readers want and what have the authors to offer? In brief, what about book publishing in the months immediately ahead?

The chess players of Russia, who outnumber by far those of any other country, cannot very well be compared, as to skill, with those of the United States, because the Russians have not competed in the team tournaments of the International Chess Federation.

PLANNING a vegetable garden is the paramount suburban topic of the moment. The first question is, "How much, and of what?" It may be well at the outset to offer a word of dissuasion to the enthusiast, lest, through inexperience or forgetfulness, he should be tempted to let his zeal outrun his discretion and lay out a larger plot than he can perseveringly cultivate.

H. Morin de Linclays, general representative of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, known to thousands of Americans as the French Line, announced yesterday that he had organized an American subsidiary, French Line, Inc., with the approval of the War Shipping Administration, under Admiral Emory S. Land.
NEW DELHI, India, March 20 (AP) -- A communique:

HARTFORD, March 20 -- At an organization meeting of the new State War Council today, Governor Baldwin said that a major aim of the unit must be to provide for the recruitment of men and women for war industries in Connecticut.

THE greatest task of organization and reconstruction in history awaits the victors in the European war -when they sit down at the peace table -providing, naturally, that those victors are the United Nations. The reason that is so is relatively simple to grasp in its essentials.

Stay-at-home yachtsmen who, instead of being in Tunisia, the Southwest Pacific or elsewhere in uniform, are still able to plan some Springtime puttering about on their craft and dream of their vacation cruises of the future when gasoline rationing will be forgotten, are expressing elation over the progress of the cross-Jersey Canal.

As government agents continued their search yesterday for six of the eight racketeers and labor gangsters indicted here Friday for extorting $2,500,000 from motion-picture operators, United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa declared the government will go to trial as soon as the fugitives are apprehended.

YOU can read "You Can't Do That to Svoboda," by John Pen, as a humorous little story about a very simple man or you can read it as a satire with profoundly searching implications. Either way, it's a gem of a little tale.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 20 -- Main interest in Australia continues to be centered on the problem of getting more outside aid for the Southwest Pacific war area. The newspapers daily feature long dispatches from Washington and New York detailing activities of the Kenney-Sutherland mission and summarizing American comments on the Pacific war situation.

TOTAL war has brought the government face to face with both an industrial and an educational problem. A war of machines, radio, high explosives and airplanes must obviously be fought by men who understand the instruments of production and destruction committed to their care and use.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, March 21 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The Red Cross blood donor centers in New York and Brooklyn announced yesterday that new records had been set last week with donation of 7,408 pints. Colonel Earle Booth, director of the New York Center, and John T. Haviland, director of the Brooklyn Center, said the volume would have been even greater except for the difficulty in training new doctors and nurses and the inability of the processing plants to increase their capacity.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, March 20 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace is certain to have a most cordial reception during his current visit to the countries of Central and South America. He is highly regarded and very popular in Latin America with all classes, but particularly with the middle class and the workers, who consider him a champion of their rights and their future hopes.

OMAHA, March 20 -- If there is an impending breakdown in American agriculture the farmers of the Middle West do not themselves know it. They think that, barring some unforeseen and unpredictable catastrophe, they are going to surpass last year's record food production.

Now that the scare buying frenzy has run its course at least temporarily, retail trade has returned to its wartime normal and the wholesale markets have received something of a breathing spell, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

The old-fashioned Strawberry-shrub, or Calycanthus floridus, the favorite of bygone gardens and linen-chests, is an interesting accent for the shrubbery borders. A strong-growing hardy subject, it has rather heavy, oval and pointed dark green leaves, with a slight brownish tinge.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- To Commander Frank W. Fenno Jr., whose submarine carried a huge amount of gold, silver and securities out of the Philippines before Corregidor fell, has been awarded a Navy Gold Star in place of a second Navy Cross for sinking 31,000 tons of Japanese merchant shipping and damaging 15,000 tons more.

FROM Buenos Aires comes word that Argentina plans to release on April 1 a 5-centavos stamp to commemorate the "Primera Feria del Libro" (First Book Fair). The quantity printed will be 20,000,000 and the vignette will be allegorical in character.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -A new management-labor-agriculture advisory committee of nine members was created today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, to succeed a seventeen-member group, which recommended the change.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 20 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's 2-to-5 favorite, Mar-Kell, scored an easy victory at Oakland Park today in the $1,500 Majestic Hotel Handicap. A length back of the winner was the lone 3-year-old in the race, the Silver Star Stock Farms' Chipamink. A.C. Ernst's slow-starting Alohort was third.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 20 -- Things are looking up in the Yankee training camp.

BARBARA STANWYCK is back to rhinestones and spangles again for her latest picture, "Lady of Burlesque," which is a shined-up version of Gypsy Rose Lee's "G-String Murders." In it Miss Stanwyck threatens to revolutionize the entire undress industry with a strip tease in which she doesn't take off a thing.

MR. MORTON has made his fame and, I hope, his fortune, by a series of volumes that have won a popular public by showing to men what may be seen by keeping their eyes open. There is a charming affliction suffered by some of us that might be described as round-the-corner-itis.
WARTIME shortages in pyrethrum and rotenone are being met this year both by stretching the available supply in various ways and by using other materials as stomach poisons and contact insecticides.

The post-season week at the Metropolitan, which ended with yesterday's performances, proved such a pronounced success that in addition presentations of Wagnet's "Parsifal" on Wednesday night, April 21, and Friday afternoon, April 23, matinees will be given Saturdays, April 17 and 24, and in all likelihood an evening bill will be offered on the last-named date.

OMAHA, March 20 -- The food situation here is generally satisfactory, W.E. Kavan, secretary of the Independent Retail Grocers and Meat Dealers, said today. This is due largely to Ohama's position as a center of production and processing.

FEW careers have been so full of achievement in a chosen field of science as has that of Rear Admiral Stanford Caldwell Hooper, who retired from active duty last week after nearly forty years of service in Navy radio affairs.

ANNE GREEN speaks of that "class most purely French, artisans who, throughout the history of their country, bad preserved the characteristics of a gay, laborious and serious race." Some of the artisans' strength and gayety and persistence belong to this loving and brilliant story.

THE not inconsiderable number of New Yorkers who miss burlesque, if not as an art form in the theatre, then, at least, as a part of the Broadway scene, may be cheered to know that it survives in London.

WHEN John Lardner went out to Australia with the first American convoys the Japanese were calling their own shots and were making them unhindered. The Pacific was their pooltable and they sprawled all over it, raking its green spaces with their machine guns and cannon from all angles.

Stocks on hand in New York City department stores at the end of February showed a decrease of 11 per cent from the level of a year earlier, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. February sales for the stores here increased 20 per cent over February, 1942.

COUNTLESS gardeners who have never grown an onion or a beet are planning vegetable gardens this year. Some of them are experienced flower growers; others are novices armed with little more than determination and dreams of home-canned tomato juice and garden-fresh sweet corn.

A new citizens' committee embracing business, industrial and real estate groups was organized yesterday under the chairmanship of Walter Hoving to oppose any attempt by Mayor La Guardia to levy any new taxes whatsoever toward meeting the Mayor's estimated deficit of $32,000,000 in the new city budget.

Johnny Greco, Montreal fighter who is now a private in the Canadian Army, will have a chance to show that his upset victory over Cleo Shans two weeks ago was no fluke. The pair will meet again at Madison Square Garden over the ten-round route on Friday night.
ONE of the questions foremost in the minds of women today is: What will happen to fashion in the months to come?

SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- The shortage of meat is most critical in the larger population centers all along the West Coast. The beef shortage is most serious and there is hope that a new ruling authorizing increased slaughtering of lambs will help the situation.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Indications were given today that additional manpower and machinery may be made available for the agricultural front which urgently needs them as Secretary Wickard emphasized yesterday in reporting farmers' intentions to plant.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 20 -- In spite of anything the weather man could do about it, and he was not cooperative, to say the least, the Dodgers completed six full days of training in the West Point field house today. That's something that frequently wasn't true in other years when the club trained in the supposedly salubrious climate of Florida.

SEVERAL performances of current Broadway productions in the near future have been taken over to augment funds for carrying on the work of philanthropies and wartime enterprises. Bundles for America will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Harriet," starring Helen Hayes, on the night of April 1 at Henry Miller's Theatre.
LONDON, March 12 (Correspondence of The Associated Press) -- Golf balls are rationed and sheep graze on the fairways, but the ancient and honorable game still is a popular sport in war-time Britain.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The past week may have been tough on some 40,000,000 citizens, but it also was the most difficult week in the history of the Bureau of Internal Revenue. Although tax collecting goes on continuously, the week for filing income tax returns and making first payments is the "madhouse" period for the bureau.

OTTAWA, March 20 -- The intricate problem of the relations of the United Nations was raised indirectly in the House of Commons this week when in answer to a question regarding Canada's foreign policy Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King defined Canada's position as "a nation dealing with other nations on these international matters."

VEGETABLES from the family garden will grace most tables this year, but even with the urgent emphasis on them there is no reason why bouquets from the flower garden should be missing. The so-called cutting garden will be little missed if plant materials for garden borders are selected with care.

Two thousand persons of Polish descent from various parts of the metropolitan area attended a solemn memorial mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday in honor of Polish civilian and soldier dead of World War II.

To enliven a Spring garden of bulbs, the hardy perennial Doronicum (Leopardsbane) is a good choice, This plant is outstanding in its own right, too, for it brings to any garden a contrasting texture of both foliage and bloom in April and May.
WITH fats about to be rationed, you will be concerned with ways of stretching butter effectively and methods of salvaging and using what our thrifty grandmothers called "trimmings and drippings."

" The intense hatred of the Belgian people for the Nazis makes the great majority of them immune to Axis indoctrination," August E. de Schryver, Minister Without Portfolio, now acting as liaison between the Belgian Government-in-Exile in London and the United States, said last night, "but some small groups may have to be 're-educated.'
Mr. and Mrs. Mather K. Whitehead have come to the Ritz-Carlton from East Greenwich, R.I.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 20 (AP) -- Governor John W. Bricker said today he would recommend that the Ohio Legislature memorialize Congress for immediate action on resolutions adopted by eleven Midwestern Governors outlining steps they believed the Federal Government should take if agriculture is to meet record food production demands in 1943.

The National War Labor Board is at last coming to recognize that such phrases as "substandard" wages and "inequalities" in wages need precise limitation if they are not to become loopholes so large as to destroy any wage stabilization formula. The Board recently adopted a "short-cut method" and a series of "simple yardsticks" to speed up the handling of voluntary requests for wage and salary changes before the Regional War Labor Boards.

HERMANN SCHMIDT of Lehrberg, Germany, came here to escape Nazi oppression. He wanted to become an American citizen, but hated to wait five long years -- the residence requirement. So he joined the United States Army two months ago, took his oath of allegiance to the Constitution last week, and today his flag is the Stars and Stripes.

MR. FISHER'S tale is of man before he became man, of a group of thirteen individuals -- man-apes rather than ape-men -- and of their daily life and wanderings. The mighty Ho-wha was the head of the family and the others comprised his females with their children and several strays, male and female, who clang to group life.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Government reports that the synthetic rubber plant construction program is proceeding "better than expected" led today to proposals that the high priority ratings assigned to some of the plants be reduced to speed the construction of escort vessels, which are vitally needed by the Navy for the war against the submarines.

FOR those who like variety in the garden, some of the lesser known annuals will provide an interesting change.
