With many dozens of bright varieties easily available, there is no need to plant the same things year in and year out; and, for the inveterate plantsman, nothing is more diverting than experimenting with something a little different.

CAIRO, Ill., March 20 (AP) -- Even more than in peacetime the Cardinals' farm system is proving its value today at the champions' Spring training camp, where Manager Billy Southworth faces the problem of replacing his war losses.

HERE in New York the group known as American Abstract Artists opened last week its seventh annual, at the Riverside Museum. Forty-two artists are involved, many of whom have been firmly identified, over a long period, with the nonobjective movement.

THE most astonishing thing about the story of Rickenbacker and his seven companions, drifting for twenty-one days on three little rubber life boats in the Pacific, is that it maintains its unique character, despite all the other tales of suffering and heroism at sea in recent months.

ONE may expect twenty pounds of snap beans from a fifty-foot row, according to the New York Victory Garden Leaflet No. 1. That is quite a bit of food, enough for a good many meals for a family, since there is almost no waste in preparation.
While rationed foods in general are reported ample in a survey of food stocks in thirteen leading cities of the country, meat, vegetable and butter shortages are reported in almost every case.

Main floor and acccessory departments were busy last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

St. Francis Prep's swimming team captured only three first places, but managed to garner enough of the minor positions to retain its city C.H.S.A.A. team title in the annual championships completed yesterday in the Columbia University pool.

ON Friday nights, these several months since Georgia Gibbs began to raise her voice on behalf of the WABC-Columbia Caravan (from which she moves this week to Thursday evenings on NBC), students of the vocal arts have pricked up their ears and ransacked their memories, allowing that they were sure they had heard those mellifluous tones somewhere before.

THE new contract bridge laws, which become effective on April 1, try to temper justice with mercy. For example, a small card (ten-spot or lower), carelessly dropped on the table and exposed during the auction, was subject to penalty under the previous code.

The United States Coast Guard announced last week that a nationwide plan for enlisting civilians to guard docks, terminals and other waterfront facilities would be placed in operation as soon as the various ports could be organized. The plan was tried out in Philadelphia with success, and the port of Baltimore has been selected as the next area.

Early Spring is the ideal time to divide the later-blooming perennials, as soon as they have begun to make growth and before they have had a chance to shoot up too much. Some that have been in place for two or three years will profit by the division and be enabled to maintain quality and quantity of bloom.

LONDON, March 20 -- The 20-year-old bombardier who completed his assignment, though mortally wounded, in Thursday's Flying Fortress raid on Vegesack, Germany, was Lieutenant Jack Mathis of San Angelo, Texas, the United States Eighth Air Force revealed tonight.

MOSCOW, March 20 -- Cash prizes of more than 5,000,000 rubles were distributed today to Soviet musicians, actors, artists and writers for their achievements in 1942. A fund for such prizes was established in Premier Joseph Stalin's honor on his sixtieth birthday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 20 -- Double triumphs by Gene Rogers, Columbia freshman distance ace, and Ed Hall, Massachusetts State veteran sprint star, coupled with the splendid success achieved by a small Rutgers contingent, highlighted the annual Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League invitation meet concluded tonight in the Harvard Pool.

An initial spurt in cotton prices yesterday met hedging, New Orleans selling and local realizing, depressing the list of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange to an irregular close, 1 point higher to 5 points lower than Friday's final quotations.
The nautical pleasure rider has the laugh on his brother of the concrete highways and back-country roads, it developed yesterday.

Last year the Republic Aviation Corporation had a net profit of $1,105,061 after a reserve of $1,000,000 for possible post-war losses on inventories, a deduction for Federal income taxes of $915,000 and a provision of $3,465,000 for the excess profits tax after estimating the post-war refund at $385,000.

PLANTS, like human beings, require adequate amounts of nourishment to thrive and mature. However, there is an essential difference between the nutritional demands of the human beings and those of the plants. The food we eat has already been prepared, whether it is in the raw state or cooked.
Sammy Angott's surprising victory over previously undefeated Willie Pep on Friday night had the lightweight boxing situation all upside down yesterday.

The occupation of French North Africa by United States and British troops has been followed by a series of political complexities, of which a great deal has been heard. The prize complexity has been supplied by General Giraud in his orders concerning the Algerian Jews.

CHUNGKING, China, March 20 -- Chinese forces have recaptured Hwajung, important city in Northeastern Hunan Province occupied by the Japanese last week in their drive south of the Yangtze River, the Central News Agency reported tonight.

There has been much discussion of how to obtain for small business a larger share in the war effort. No doubt improvement in organization and program by Government agencies can extend the amount of direct contract business handled in this way. But the fact is that sandlot shops are already playing a highly important role in war production as sub-contractors.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Driving home the Treasury's main argument against the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan of income taxation, that it bestows a benefit "in inverse ratio to need," the Ways and Means Committee majority made public today its tax bill report.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 20 -- The provisional government of General Henri Honore Giraud has met and passed a major political crisis during the past week and now it faces the twin problems of (1) solving with Allied help the threatening economic crisis and (2) forming something more than a surface union with the Fighting French led by General Charles de Gaulle.

LONDON, Sunday, March 21 (AP) -- American parachute troops led all other air-borne soldiers into action in North Africa and were the first flying fighters of the Allied nations to be flown directly into battle from distant bases, the Air Ministry said today in disclosing for the first time details of the November operation.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A 1943 indemnity-payment program which will provide a market for up to 35,000 bales of surplus low-grade American cotton and at the same time promote commercial manufacture of cotton insulation materials was announced today by the Department of Agriculture.

Faced with a deadlock in wage negotiations and a threatened coal strike April 1 that might cripple war production, the soft-coal operators of the Appalachian region appealed to President Roosevelt for Federal intervention yesterday. Two telegrams were sent -- one by the Northern operators yesterday morning, and the other by the Southern group at 10:30 o'clock last night.

TIME cannot be spent this year on sulky or fussy plants, nor can the busy gardener afford to worry about what diseases his favorites have contracted and what bugs are having a feast at his expense. Then, too, both insecticides and fertilizers are much too valuable at this time to expend on flowering material alone.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- A forty-eight-hour week throughout the steel industry to replace the present one of forty hours has been recommended to the War Production Board's steel division by a steel labor advisory committee consisting of Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and six other members of the United Steel Workers of America.

LONDON -- The Greek Navy, which lost so heavily during the battle of Greece and evacuation from Crete in the Summer of 1941, is once again as strong as it was before its battered units limped into Alexandria bearing, almost two years ago, the last of the heroic defenders of Crete.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (U.P.) -- Five State Commissioners of Agriculture and two cotton farmers announced today the formation of a new farm organization, the National Farm Committee, which they frankly admit is political.

RED, white and blue morning glories smothering the chicken wire fence are among the final touches to the Victory Garden. Chicken wire and snow fencing will probably be used most widely, but any sort of enclosure, even though it be only brush, offers the chance to work in a bit of flower color without taking any planting space from the precious vegetables.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 20 -- In an interview today Homer M. Green of the Mount Joy Farm declared it "supreme effrontery" to expect farmers to redouble their efforts this year to raise additional food supplies for urban dwellers, who work but a few hours daily and only five and one-half days a week.

THIS week Frank Ross, producer of pictures starring his wife, Jean Arthur, turned down a major company offer of $250,000 for the screen rights to Lloyd C. Douglas's best seller, "The Robe." The previous week he refused another company's bid of $200,000.

Archbishop Spellman's recent visit to Rome has brought to the forefront of world interest the role which the Papacy is playing in this war. To those familiar with Vatican affairs, one thing seems to be certain. The Vatican will not depart from its official attitude of complete political neutrality nor will the Fascist government of Italy adopt anti-clerical measures that might force Pius XII to leave Rome.

BOOKS and the war. When did the war start? 1931, Japan into Manchuria? 1934, Italy into Ethiopia? 1937, Germany and Italy into Spain? March, 1939, Germany into Czechoslovakia? September, 1939, Germany into Poland? June, 1941, Germany into Russia? December, 1941, Japan into Pearl Harbor?

THE idea that roses are difficult and time consuming to grow has little basis in fact. There are few plants that give so much joy and satisfaction for the time spent on them as does the rose. This year, when efficiency is the keynote in gardening, roses more than ever have a place.
Two Negroes, one of them running from a fight in which he had drawn a 12-inch knife, the other leaving the scene of two hold-ups, were shot and killed by policemen last night in Harlem.

Some call it the vernal equinox, not content with Spring, which, rooted in the soil itself, has the strength of the reaching leaf, the opening bud. Spring, which in this land of ours means blackbirds over the lowlands and meadowlarks on the prairies and robins strutting in the sun.

In the event that the government decides rationing of tea is necessary, despite the present outlook for continued balancing of supplies with demand, the most practical method would be to ration tea separately from coffee and not on an "either or" basis, Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today in its final cotton ginning report of the 1942-43 season that ginnings of the 1942 crop totaled 12,821,414 equivalent 500-pound bales of lint cotton, exclusive of linters, compared with 10,741,589 bales ginned for the 1941 crop and 12,564,988 bales for the 1940 crop.

" LIFE is so funny," said Miss Helen Hayes the other day. "I had my Summer all planned. I was going to be a very serious farmer. Now here I am with a success on my hands. I really don't know what to do. It upsets me."

Every once in so often somebody from the Wall Street-hating hinterland appears in the public prints with a statement that the stock markets should be shut down or put under wraps because they are interfering with the main job of selling war bonds.

To aid the work of the Girls' Service League of America, Miss Cornelia Otis Skinner will present a program of monologues on the night of May 5 at the Colony Club. The benefit committee will meet next Friday afternoon at the home of the chairman, Mrs. Kelley Graham of 1021 Park Avenue, to formulate plans.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., March 20 -- Rudy Mucha, formerly of the University of Washington; Herman Schneidman, Iowa, and Paul Anderson, Purdue, have been transferred from the Great Lakes Naval Training Station to other bases for advanced training, bringing to fifteen the number of football men now on their way to fighting fronts, Navy officials said today.

Two merchant marine captains and a ship's carpenter who performed acts of merit and valor after their ships had been attacked at sea received yesterday the Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal. Captain Edward Macauley, a member of the Maritime Commission and the War Shipping Administration, presented the medals in the office of Captain Granville Conway, at the WSA's headquarters at 45 Broadway.
THE most outstanding collection of Bach publications in America, and one of the most important depots of Bachiana in the entire world, is in Berea, Ohio, a town of 7,000, twelve miles from here.

LONDON, March 20 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, who has flown safely from the United States to Italy, North Africa and Britain, was involved in a minor motor-car crash a few minutes after his arrival in London today from Algiers. He was not injured.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Croix de Guerre has been conferred on sixty United States soldiers by the general commanding the French Army Corps for outstanding acts in fighting alongside the French.

Harts Island, a branch of the New York City Penitentiary and for years a haven for aged vagrants and erstwhile narcotic addicts, has been taken over by the Navy for use as a naval prison, it was disclosed yesterday.

After extending their losses moderately, stocks closed dull and mixed yesterday aftter the dullest Saturday session in two months. The volume on the New York Stock Exchange was only 484,290 shares, against 829,830 for the week before.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 20 -Some highlights in the log of the "Goonie Bird," a Flying Fortress that winged on sixty-eight combat missions in the Southwest Pacific and was officially credited with downing nineteen Japanese planes, were released for publication today.
Siamese twin stars are theoretical probabilities, concludes Dr. Bancroft W. Sitterly of the Van Vleck Observatory at Wesleyan University after studying the problem from a new angle.

THE Mutual Music Society, Inc., 1270 Sixth Avenue, announces two contests open to American composers. One competition is a piano teacher's contest for pieces in the second, third and four grades, one of each to be selected for publication, and the other is for a sacred anthem suitable as an offertory.

Total war brings out words seldom seen in times of peace, as if every idle syllable in the book had to be drafted and made to do its bit. Scarcely had Mme. Chiang's recent "obtunded" sent thousands of her admirers to the dictionary when a distinguished newspaper went to press with "requidated" -- Admiral Standley's remarks on aid to Russia, unless "requidated," would be regarded as official.
WHEN the actual hard work of housecleaning is over, with its accompaniment of frayed nerves for every one living in the house at the time, the more congenial task of refurbishing begins.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -President Roosevelt was confined to his living quarters at the Executive Mansion today with what was described as the beginning of a head cold. He planned to remain indoors tomorrow, also, as a precautionary measure.

MEAT rationing means that you will have to add some new "stretcher" recipes to your repertory, that you will have to perfect your technique in order to make the most of little. And with much less beef and veal, pork and lamb in evidence, you will want to know a good deal more about other available sources of protein.

With the advance of medicine, the mean expectancy of life at birth has risen. In 1850 only 2.5 per cent of the population was 65 years and over; in 1930 about 5.5 per cent. If this rate is extrapolated, about 14.5 per cent of the population will be 65 and over in 1980. This means 22,000,000 persons.

To the Drama Editor: MY name may perhaps be known to you as the producer in America, with Gilbert Miller, of "Journey's End," as the co-author with Robert Nichols of "Wing's Over Europe," and as the co-founder with Miss Ellen Van Volkenburg of the Chicago Little Theatre.

ARTUR RODZINSKI has been appointed to one of the biggest and toughest jobs in the musical world -- music director and conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Even though he does not take over active leadership until next Fall, he has had occasion to discover how tough the job is.

Thus far a common ideal has held the democratic nations together. If they had a common language the amalgamation would be better than it is, because it would transcend the necessities of war. Sir Richard Gregory has considered this matter in the British Scientific weekly Nature and the British Association Committee on Post-War University has dwelt upon it.

Although the city hospitals had fewer patients to treat in 1942 than in 1941, the depletion of hospital staffs because of the demands of the armed forces far exceeded the decline in the number of cases, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Hospital Commissioner, declared yesterday in a report submitted to Mayor La Guardia.

CHICAGO, March 20 (AP) -- A coroner's jury thought it over for five minutes today and then decided that Frank (The Enforcer) Nitti committed suicide "while temporarily insane and in a despondent frame of mind."
A young friend, now going through the rigors of Army training, has sent me a letter from which I cull some excerpts that may be generally interesting. He writes:

Anthony Eden is to be congratulated on dissociating the policy of his country from the editorial in The Times of London last week which proposed an Anglo-Russian joint guardianship of the peace of Europe and advance approval by the United Nations of any frontier changes which Russia may want to make after the war is won.

CLEVELAND, March 20 -- Hundreds in this city are having meatless Sundays, thousands find difficulty in buying butter and supplies of other commodities are dwindling, but the food situation here is not critical, according to members of the Agriculture Department's Food Distributing Committee.

Many beginning gardeners wonder what "corn-salad" is and what it is used for. This lettuce-like vegetable, also known as fetticus (and listed thus in some catalogues) or lamb's lettuce is a good plant for the kitchen garden and is useful for salads, especially when used in conjunction with herbs.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that the country would not avoid "extreme inflation" unless the Administration acted firmly to resist "pressure groups" seeking higher wages and prices.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 20 -- Legislators of the State met here today in special session and began paving the way today for California to take independent action toward solving its critical agricultural labor problems without sole reliance on Federal agencies.

PUSSY WILLOWS are harbingers of Spring, not only to children but to all who note the seasons as nature specially marks them. Native from Nova Scotia to Manitoba and south to Virginia and Missouri, this bush or small tree, botanically termed Salix discolor, generally grows fifteen to twenty feet tall and is valued either as a landscape specimen or simply as a helpful adjunct to the cutting garden.

THE popularity of the soybean has been steadily creeping forward until, this season, the item is listed by almost every Victory gardener for inclusion with other plants that are high in vitamin value. Soybeans are delicious as well as nutritious and may be eaten dried or green.
PHILADELPHIA, March 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Falcons scored their third victory in the Eastern Amateur Hockey League play-offs tonight, defeating the Rovers, 5 to 3.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 20 --An Italian steamer and a small British passenger vessel neared a rendezvous in Turkish waters off the port of Mersin in South Central Turkey tonight to begin an exchange of nearly 800 Italian and German naval and civilian prisoners against an equal number of Britons.

A TELEPHONE rings in the night. Somewhere in the city an accident has occurred and ambulance drivers are needed immediately. A Red Cross Motor Corps girl, roused from sleep, pulls on her uniform and hurries out to pilot an ambulance through the dimmed-out streets or to manoeuvre an emergency canteen unit to the scene of disaster.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The situation surrounding the French possessions in the Western Hemisphere has been thrown into confusion, according to frank admissions here today, by an announcement from London of a sudden turnover of French Guiana to General Charles de Gaulle, head of the Fighting French.

ALREADY a reasonably busy gentleman as orchestra conductor for "Stage Door Canteen" on CBS and for Morton Downey's serenade to the ladies over the Blue, Raymond Paige is soon to be represented on NBC (WEAF), too.

Henry Wittenberg of the West Side Y.M.C.A. successfully defended the metropolitan senior A.A.U. 191-pound wrestling championship last night at the West Side Y. A graduate of C.C.N.Y., Wittenberg, now a member of the New York City police force, pinned Ted Lord of the New York A.C. in 8:38 of the final.
Thousands of individuals, many of them women, will file State income tax returns this year for the first time.

Purim, the Jewish festival to be observed today to mark the deliverance of the Jews of Persia by Queen Esther from the machinations of Haman, the Prime Minister, should inspire renewed confidence in the ultimate triumph of the democracies over the forces of hatred and oppression, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

TRENTON, March 20 -- The many New Jersey industrial concerns that have failed to file employe replacement schedules, listings of employes in their order of essentiality to a firm, were taken to task today by State Selective Service Director Edgar N. Bloomer.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, has just finished a week of almost incessant visits and consultations in Washington, on a mission that has for its object nothing less than paving the way and preparing the mental atmosphere for the kind of continuing common action by the great powers of the world that was sought in vain the last time Germany was beaten back to her frontiers and Europe liberated.

With the opening of metropolitan racing April 8 less than three weeks away, predictions by horsemen and officials are that New York is in for one of its biggest seasons of racing. And this despite the fact that a reduced attendance is looked for because of transportation difficulties.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -New York State and Northern New Jersey, Region II of the WPB, despite more than their share of obstacles in gearing to all-out war production, entered 1943 leading the other eleven regions in dollar volume of war contracts, with a total of $13,200,000,000 worth, according to a review of the situation in the New York area issued today by the WPB's division of information.

Simultaneously with the announcement yesterday that the investigation into irregularities and abuses in workmen's compensation insurance would be extended upState tomorrow, it was reliably learned that at least $10,000,000 in irregular siphoning of funds and "kickbacks" was expected to be uncovered before the current Moreland investigation is completed.

LONDON, March 20 -- Fighting French headquarters announced tonight that the population of French Guiana, on the northeast coast of South America, had rallied to the cause of General Charles de Gaulle and that former Governor Rene Veber, a Vichy adherent, had been obliged to leave the colony.
HOW and why Singapore fell is a heartbreaking, personal, searing story. To stand on Fort Canning and watch the city of Sinqapore crumbling under the crash of Japanese bombs was pure, naked tragedy.

Casualty lists are an inescapable part of war, but there is one casualty list to which too little attention is paid either in peace or in war. It is the toll of the lives lost in accidents in the homes, the factories, the mines, the steel plants, and on the farms of the United States.

Musical instruments are among the items most sought by prisoners of war throughout the world, according to the War Prisoners Aid of the Young Men's Christian Association which pro vides materials and guidance for recreation, education and religious worship to war captives.

THE Scottish side of the border country between England and Scotland. Our own day with its roots, realistically and romantically, in a far-back past. A house. No great, ancient castle but a lived-in, sunny, gracious old home that, when Celia Dunne, in 1905, bequeathed it to an as yet unborn Celia Dunne, had still only one bathroom.

THE Scottish side of the border country between England and Scotland. Our own day with its roots, realistically and romantically, in a far-back past. A house. No great, ancient castle but a lived-in, sunny, gracious old home that, when Celia Dunne, in 1905, bequeathed it to an as yet unborn Celia Dunne, had still only one bathroom.

CONSERVATION of beauty aids is easy and necessary these days. The manufacturers themselves have set up guide posts, for they are anxious that their products be used both intelligently and parsimoniously.

BALTIMORE, March 21 (AP) -Senator Alben W. Barkley, majority leader, sharply criticized today three groups of Americans who he said wanted to win the war but objected to Russia, England and President Roosevelt from sharing in it.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Federal intervention to compel the bituminous coal operators to extend the present Applalachian contract with the United Mine Workers beyond its expiration on April 1 and to make the new agreement retroactive to that date is expected in a few days, according to authoritative Administration sources.

Sales of the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company increased 12.9 per cent last year to the record volume of $118,968,117 from $105,405,550 for 1941, but higher operating costs and taxes reduced earnings from the previous year, according to the annual report to stockholders, to be issued today by E.H. Little, president.

New York fashion creators supply evidence of the fact that they were as vulnerable to the charms of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek as were the gentlemen of Congress. Almost concurrent with her departure from this city, a whole crop of Spring and Summer fashions have sprung up to pay homage to China and to her beauty and fascination.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- The profession of medicine was praised today for "lasting contributions to the cause of liberty" by Ralph A. Bard, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, in an address at the eighty-fifth commencement of the medical schools of Northwestern University.

A plot of 215 acres of waterfront and riparian lands at the dividing line between Jersey City and Bayonne and between the east bank of the old Morris Canal and the New York Bay has been taken over by the City of Jersey City under foreclosure of two tax liens on which $6,842,666 was due.

Love is the law of the good life, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholiic University of America, Washington, declared yesterday in the second in a series of Lenten sermons at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. His topic was "Law and Love."

ALBANY, March 21 -- Heading for adjournment of both houses of the Legislature on Friday, legislative clerks worked at a high pitch over the week-end handling a rush of last-minute legislation and amendments to legislation previously enacted. The legislators themselves got ready for the grind of actually enacting or killing legislation whose fate has already been informally determined.
Dr. John R. Huffman, New York Athletic Club star, defeated Warren Dow and Dr. Tibor Nyilas in a fence-off to capture the metropolitan foils championship at Salle Santelli yesterday.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 111.55 to 111.7. The foodstuffs index went up 0.9 per cent as a result of increases in the prices of eggs, apples, oranges and potatoes.

Darius Milhaud's Symphony received its first New York performance by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, late yesterday afternoon in Radio City. The program of the concert also contained the conuductor's own transcription of Mussorgsky's "Pictures at an Exhibition."
A German communique broadcast Sunday by Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 -- Reports from Berlin that Hungary is making overtures to the Serbs are interpreted here to mean that the Hungarians now believe in an Allied victory and are already doing the spade work for obtaining membership in a Balkan bloc of the future, the pivots of which might conceivably be Yugoslavia and Greece.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Checks for $68,087, gifts of Midwestern Chinese, were presented to Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, First Lady of China, in Chicago's Chinatown today. Representatives of the donors were among the crowds, estimated at 15,000 to 20,000, who lined the flag-festooned streets, awaiting Mme. Chiang's arrival.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 21 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler appeared in the Berlin Zeughaus on Unter den Linden today to solemnize Heroes' Memorial Day with a eulogy of Germany's soldier dead in the Second World War.

Women have become so "conservation conscious" recently that shoe repair concerns in the city that also repair, dye and clean handbags have been swamped with work. One establishment started a bag repair service last June as an experiment and found it only moderately successful.

In comparison with recent hectic weeks when scare buying dominated retail demand, the wholesale markets were relatively quiet last week, according to a summary prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident offices.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -The Securities and Exchange Commission today released its jurisdiction over fees payable to Dillon, Read Co. of New York after the investment banking firm had voluntarily reduced the fees that it was to receive for handling two bond issues totaling $31,000,000 for two subsidiaries of the United Light and Power Company.

A Negro hold-up suspect, whose brother had been shot dead by a probationary patrolman a few hours earlier, after two Harlem robberies, drew the condemnation of Magistrate Charles Solomon in Felony Court yesterday, and was held in $50,000 bail for hearing Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Everything indicates that the revenue measure containing a provision for a 20 per cent withholding levy, as projected in the Ways and Means Committee bill, will be passed by the House and probably by the Senate in pretty much its present form.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Establishment of a Combined Aluminum Committee to coordinate the activities of the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada in respect to that vital metal has been established with Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, as chairman, the Office of War Information announced today.

The crowning safety of democracy and freedom is a worshiping people, the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker, rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, declared yesterday in his sermon at the morning services.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (U.P.) --- In less than a year the Japanese have developed Rabaul on New Britain into a stronghold that bars Allied access to Japan's naval base at Truk and remains as a constant threat to Australia, according to military experts.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Ensign Cornelius Warmerdam shipped his 16-foot-2-inch vaulting pole back to Chapel Hill, N.C. today, with charges "collect," indicating that he is confident the Navy will send him out to try for that 16-foot mark.

Emile Baume, French pianist, played Debussy, Ravel and Prokofieff with an are not often heard in the performance of these composers' works, in his piano recital at Town Hall last night. The lithe, almost spineless tone Mr. Baume commands was perfect for the Debussy "Poissons d'Or" and painted a picture in sound that is likely to haunt for a long time the memories of those fortunate enough to hear it.

The Public Affairs Council of the American Labor party, through George S. Counts, its chairman, called upon the United States Senate yesterday to restore the appropriation of $1,400,000 for continuance of the work of the National Resources Planning Board.

In his farewell concert as guest conductor of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, Efrem Kurtz presented two works in what was announced as their "first perfomance by the society."
LONDON, March 21 -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York said mass today for the late Arthur Cardinal Hinsley at Westminster Cathedral, where the Roman Catholic primate will be buried Tuesday.

Snapping a string that comprised seven straight setbacks in the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States play-offs, the New York Rovers finally mangaed to gain a tie last night at Madison Square Garden. They led the Philadelphia Falcons for the greater part of the game, but the visitors managed to square the count before the end of regulation play, sending matters into overtime.
CHUNGKING; China, March 21 (U.P.) -- A communique from the headquarters of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell

CHICAGO, March 21 -- The Chicago Board of Trade, which rescinded its 95-year-old rule against women employes recently, has come to recognize the competency of the ten young women who are serving as messengers on the floor of the world's greatest grain market.
The threat of a coal strike affecting 450,000 bituminous miners in all parts of the country appeared to have receded yesterday as a consequence of imminent government intervention in the dispute.
Finnish communique as broadcast by the Lahti radio of Finland and reported by the Federal communications Commission:

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 21 -- Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel -- the Fox -- is in a hole. With the British Eighth Army and the U.S. forces that form the southern flank of the British First Amy hitting him at the same time, he must slug it out rather than rely on tricks. On his ability to do this depends the length of the Tunisian campaign.

Under General Patton's vigorous command American forces have surged back to the Tunisian gates from which Marshal Rommel drove them a month ago. Their latest advance from Gafsa has carried them through Sened Station well toward Maknassy, the limit of our former thrust at the coast.
LONDON, March, 21 (U.P.) -- The Russian midday communique as broadcast by Moscow:
Following is the text of the speech, by Prime Minister Winston Churchill broadcast over BBC as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Anne O'Hare McCormick put her finger right on the spot when she said in her column of March 15 that "the question other nations must ask is whether we (Americans) will help enforce" the provisions of the Atlantic Charter "when the war is over." Note the word "enforce."
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The OP explained today why meat, cheese and the fats and oils are lumped in rationing. It said:
LONDON, March 21 (Reuter) --New disorders have broken out in Lyon and several German officers have been killed by French patriots, the Algiers radio announced tonight.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 20 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American bomber pilots told today how their low-flying planes were brushed by flames and water spurting from a Japanese submarine, bombed and sunk last Friday night as the vessel unloaded cargo at Lae.

Reminding New Yorkers that the next blackout drill or air attack drill, to be called by the Army, will be "very severe," Mayor La Guardia yesterday reminded listeners to his radio broadcast to familiarize themselves with the warning signals.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 21 -- A group of Russian engineers is expected to arrive here this week to begin consultations with TVA engineers on hydroelectric plants, of which TVA has been authorized to design at least two for the U.S.S.R.

The interest in Hitler's speech yesterday lies chiefly in the fact that he delivered it in person. The speech was not new, but his emergence from the shadows of rumor and mystery is news. Mr. Churchill came back after a serious attack of pneumonia to speak with more rather than less of his habitual vigor.

DETROIT, March 21 -- About 250 war plant workers boarded a train here today bound for Camp Atterbury, Indiana, where they will dig their own foxholes, live for three days as members of infantry units and see at first hand how essential to the soldier are the weapons they produce in their factories.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, March 21 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, French Commander in Chief, escaped death by a few feet last week during a four-day tour of the Tunisian front, where he constantly asked where "le Boche" was.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Nine of the ten Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee declared today in a minority report that the tax bill sent to the House floor by the committee was "a reactionary and backward looking measure" which utterly repudiated the pay-as-you-earn objective of the taxpayers.
An Italian communique broadcast by Rome and recorded by The United Press:

There is nobody else quite like Argentinita. Returning to Carnegie Hall last night for her only recital this season with a number of new dances, some new dresses and two new partners, she put on a performance which was just about as engaging an entertainment as the season has produced.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt will attend Thursday evening's performance of "Counselor-at-Law" at the Royale Theatre and address the audience during the intermission on the subject of "The Theatre in War Time," it was announced yesterday by John Golden, producer of the revival starring Paul Muni.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 21 -- A fast moving American column, paced by tanks and covered by formations of Spitfires and Airacobras, hacked its way eastward toward Maknassy and the main Axis communications in Central and Southern Tunisia today after having taken Sened Station by assault just after dawn this morning.

ALGIERS, March 21 -- The abrogation of the Cremieux decree by General Henri Honore Giraud's regime, an act that disfranchised 40,000 male Jews in Algeria, was chiefly a military measure to forestall widespread discontent among the Moslems, who form roughly 80 per cent of the French North African forces, according to legal sources that helped General Giraud to draft the ordinance.
Gasoline station attendants in the city were a little busier than usual yesterday pumping gasoline into the tanks of motorists who still had No. 4 coupons, which expired at midnight.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., March 21 -- A class of twenty-two men who were graduated today from the National Farm School here were urged by speakers at this, the forty-third annual commencement, to remain in agriculture to help win the war and the peace afterward.

GROTON, Conn., March 21 -- Tomorrow's submarines will be even deadlier fighting craft than those that now are taking heavy toll on enemy shipping, Lieut. Comdr. W.A. Hardy, senior inspection officer for the Navy at the Electric Boat Company, predicted today.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 21 -Whatever posibility there may have been of seeing the Giants plagued by a serious holdout this Spring vanished today when Dick Bartell, doughty veteran, signed a 1943 contract.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 21 -- Probably little will be published in France on Prime Minister Churchill's address tonight. Consideration of post-war problems is not encouraged among the French, who are presented officially with a single alternative in the event of a German defeat -- servitude for Europe, under either the Anglo-Saxon or the Soviets.

MIAMI, Fla., March 21 (AP) -Clarence E. Gauss, United States Ambassador to China; Dr. Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador to Great Britain, and General P.H. Whang, Chinese military air attache in Washington, arrived here in a special Army plane today on their way to Washington.

Police Commissioner Valentine released yesterday the names of 163 members of his department cited for bravery and excellent police duty. Three of those honored in general orders died in the line of duty.

A strange state of affairs is perplexing those industrious females who have found their way into a man's world to help win the war. It's about their hands -- the appearance of which they still are frivolous enough to consider. The oftener these busy women suds and scrub their fingers, the dingier they seem.

LONDON, Monday, March 22 (U.P.) -- United Press Helsinki dispatches reported three major air raid alarm periods between 8 P.M. Saturday and 9 A.M. yesterday, the longest lasting nearly seven hours. Bombs fell at many places, the dispatches said, and caused many fires.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor of St. Nicholas Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, protested in his sermon yesterday morning that the present generation was a "fact-finding one that loves to gather information but does nothing with it."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 21 (U.P.) -- A communique:

When our visitor from Staten Island dropped in it was easy to see that he was bringing a message that interested him. The first guess was that he had discovered some off-shore salt water fishing grounds not under Coast Guard restriction.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 21 -Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced tonight that a leave of absence had been granted to Elton E. (Tad) Wieman, head coach of football, to permit him to accept appointment as head of the physical training section of the Army Specialized Training Division.

There seems no good reason to doubt the authenticity of the coffee recipe quoted in your editorial columns. Indeed, for some time I have wondered why none of your readers has come to the support of the Mayor in this controversy; for both he and the seventeenth-century authority are, to some extent, in agreement with the original method for preparing this delicacy; the method employed to this day in its ancient home, Arabia.
The world listened to two speeches yesterday, and took greater courage and larger hopes from both. One was by Prime Minister Churchill, the other by Adolf Hitler. The contrast was striking.

Leaden skies and a blustery breeze marred the official advent of Spring at 8:03 A.M. yesterday. March, famed for its fitful temperament, followed up a mild, balmy Saturday that drew thousands of Winter-weary New Yorkers to the outdoors, with a Sunday more akin to Winter than to Spring.
CHUNGKING, China, Marc 21 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WOODY GUTHRIE might well be an American folk hero all by his own self. A spontaneous, natural man spouting double negatives and mangling the English language beyond belief, yet giving it a heightened, emotional, breathless rhythm, he is the self-appointed minstrel of the workin' stiffs. In bars, on waterfronts, in oil towns and box cars he twangs his old guitar and

BOSTON, March 21 (AP) -- A "sudden-death" goal by Don Gallinger enabled the Bruins to open their National Hockey League play-off series against the Canadiens with a 5-to-4 victory tonight before 11,977 fans at the Boston Garden.

LONDON, Monday, March 22 -- Russia announced today the loss of Belgorod, railway city fifty miles north of Kharkov, and the German High Command said its counter-attacking southern army had reached the upper Donets River "on a broad front" and had secured its communication on a 200-mile stretch between Kharkov and Orel.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- Although parts of Eastern and Northern Kansas received some moisture last week, a large area in the Southwest still needs surface moisture, and unless this is received soon some deterioration in the outlook for the Winter wheat crop is expected. Part of this area produced large quantities of wheat in 1942.

" Apology," a play by Charles Schnee, will open tonight at the Mansfield under auspices of Lee Strasberg, Elissa Landi heads the cast, which includes Erin O'Brien-Moore, Theodore Newton, Ben Smith, Clay Clement, Thelma Schnee (the author's sister), James Todd, Merle Maddern, Peggy Allardice, Harold J. Stone, Lewis Charles and Robert Simon.

It is interesting to speculate on what the course of American history might have been if Frank Lowden instead of Warren Harding had been President of the United States. The train of political events would certainly have been different. Lowden had a much broader outlook on world affairs than the Ohio Senator.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 21 -- Five sailing dinghy races held today at the Larchmont Yacht Club resulted in one of the closest contests of the cold-weather season for point honors.

LONDON, March 21 -- H.G. Wells, whose estimate of "the shape of things to come" is always interesting and sometimes uncomfortably accurate, had a good deal to say today about newspapers and books in the post-war world.

Mayor La Guardia proposed yesterday that the Legislature empower the city to levy a substantial business tax, known as the "Brandeis plan," on retail merchants in place of the projected city sales tax increase that was defeated last week at Albany.
CHICAGO, March 20 -- The grain trade of the country is in a stage of great confusion as the result of uncertainty in regard to price ceilings on corn and prospective farm legislation.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 21 -- Despite a temperature that was 40 degrees or less, and a raw, penetrating wind that blew over the field, the Yankees today opened their second week of training with their first full-fledged drill.

The report for 1942 of the American Smelting and Refining Company, issued for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $12,252,352 after all charges and taxes, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $3.99 each on the 2,191,669 common shares outstanding.

ATLANTA, March 21 (AP) -- Between 2,500 and 3,000 residents of lowlands north of Hattiesburg, Miss., were being evacuated tonight by the Red Cross as rain-swollen rivers reached dangerous crests in several areas in the southeast.

The pamphlet report of the Western Electric Company for 1942 shows net sales of $553,282,000, an increase of 44 per cent over 1941 and a gain of 35 per cent over 1929, the previous peak year, when sales were $410,950,000.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- Owen M. Richards, manager of the American Dairy Association, said today that dairy producers, operators and retailers favor the freezing of retail butler sales as a necessary course, "although this should have been done last Fall."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 21 -- The kink in Kirby Higbe's pitching arm, which he said last night had disappeared, today seemed to have returned to plague the gentleman from South Carolina when he took his regular turn in pitching to batting practice in the West Point field house.

It was in some ways an utterly normal Spring, as viewed in March of 1943. The first publicity for the Greatest Show on Earth had come out of Winter quarters in the South. The Big League baseball teams had begun their annual warm-up, though in new quarters.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -Representative Ditter, Pennsylvania Republican, declared today that the Office of War Information "is running wild with its millions of dollars" and suggested that the agency "go out of the field of producing radio programs, movies and magazines and leave that to those who know how."

MOSCOW, March 21 -- The issue of the series of battles raging on the Donets front is still in doubt, but the indications today are that the determination with which the onslaught of German tanks, fully supported by the Air Corps, has been met has forced the enemy to change his tactics.
ALBANY, March 21 -- Governor Dewey has sponsored a bill permitting him to defer, until after the end of the current session of the Legislature, the several Cabinet appointments he has not yet made.

HYDERABAD, India, March 21 (AP) -- Sayed Sebghatullah Shad, the Pir of Pagara, who once dreamed of becoming "King of Sind," was executed Saturday after having been condemned to death by a military court. The Pir, leader of the fanatical Hurs of Sind Province, was charged with conspiring to war against the King-Emperor.

With the elimination of Creighton, the St. John's basketball team suddenly found itself the favorite in the sixth annual national invitation tournament, and tonight at Madison Square Garden the Brooklyn Redmen will attempt to live up to the nice things being said about them.

The first public action of the newly formed Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace, was taken yesterday when it sent an appeal to the United States Senate to provide for participation by the United States with the other United Nations in a system of collective security.

CHUNGKING, China, March 21 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have driven Chinese advanced forces from Hwajung in Northeastern Hunan Province and have cut the Yangtze River and Tungting Lake dikes to destroy rice paddies and cause tremendous losses to Chinese civilians, Chinese sources said tonight.

LONDON, March 21 -- According to the British Board of Trade, wholesale prices in February declined 0.1 per cent from the averages for January, food prices being slightly higher and industrial materials rather lower. The aggregate increase since the outbreak of the war is now 65 per cent, food being 77 and industrial materials 59 higher.

Court action to test the constitutionality of the new legislative reapportionment act was regarded in political circles yesterday as certain, although who will bring the action has not been determined. William J. O'Shea, counsel of the Democratic State Committee, has held that the increase in the number of Senate districts violates a provision of the State constitution and any taxpayer may bring an action.

AT A NORTH BRITISH NAVAL BASE, March 21 -- Britain's sea-roving monarch tonight completed a thorough inspection of many important units of the Home Fleet, watched an impressive demonstration of his country's naval might, and congratulated hundreds of battle-tested officers and men for their prowess.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, March 22 (AP) -- The noon communique:

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today adoption of an amendment to a rule under the investment company act regarding the valuation of portfolio securities of investment companies in special cases.

LONDON, March 21 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill surprised listeners all over the world tonight by devoting almost all of his forty-five-minute radio address to post-war problems, domestic and foreign. In the latter field he proposed a new concert of nations in Europe and Asia in which small nations in groups or confederations, rather than as separate States, would help the great powers enforce peace.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 21 -- Joe McCarthy sounds as though he has just been bitten by the Rotarian bug or else has been named as spokesman for the Asbury Park Chamber of Commerce. He seems to think that it is simply wonderful down here, despite a slight dew which practically eliminated the outdoor phase of the first week of Yankee practice.

A variety of proposals to add further restrictions to advertising of alcoholic beverages has been introduced in Congress and in State Legislatures, according to Allied Liquor Industries, Inc. In some instances these dry-sponsored proposals would amount to complete bans on all advertising of liquor.

Before placing boiled carrots on the table, chop up a few mint leaves and sprinkle them on top, and rather than serve the omelet "as is," dress it up with minced chives. "Where would I get fresh mint and chives?" you ask. Why, from your kitchen window sill!
Lieutenant Antelo Devereux, U. S. A., and Mrs. Devereux have { joined Lieutenant Devereux's mothr, 1Virs. Radcliffe Cheston of i Sandy Run, Oreland, Pa., at Hampshire House.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, March 21 (U.P.) -- The headquarters of Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of United Nations Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific, announced today the award of Oak Leaf clusters to fifteen members of the American Air Corps in lieu of second Distinguished Flying Crosses.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., March 21 -- Rogin W. Quigley, 67 years old, a retired New York City lawyer, was found unconscious in his library at 4 o'clock this morning when three men entered his home at 85 South Center Street after seeing flames in the structure.

The majority of the Ways and Means Committee, following the Treasury, has declared itself in favor of putting individual income taxes on a pay-as-you-go basis. But the committee majority, still following the Treasury, rejects the only simple, fair and practicable method of getting the taxpayers on such a basis.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- Rita Hayworth goes back on salary at Columbia tomorrow, ending her suspension of nine weeks because she refused to appear in "My Client Curley." The picture, with her role built up, will be made this Summer with Miss Hayworth and Cary Grant co-starred.

Harold S. Osborne of Montclair, vice president of the Regional Plan Association, declared yesterday that cities in New Jersey, as well as counties and the State government, so far have failed to plan adequately for post-war public works.
As if summoned by a single bugle call, New Yorkers dashed from their homes yesterday afternoon in a butter-buying stampede when word came on the radio of the midnight freezing order.

DAVID, Panama, March 21 (AP) -Vice President Henry A. Wallace, in his first speech to a Panamanian audience on his present Latin-American tour, said today that agricultural production was destined to decide the fate of liberty among peoples of the world.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) -Twenty-six of the fifty-five new Republican members of the House pledged "whole-hearted support" today to a collective security resolution introduced by four Senators. Attempts were being made to obtain a similar expression of approval from the nine freshman Senators of the same party.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- To correct an impression of the mothers of America that their sons in the armed forces were not getting enough to eat, the women's interest section of the War Department in Washington invited newspaper women to make a two-day tour of the Quartermaster Corps depot in Chicago.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., March 21 -- Second Lieutenant James M. Eagan, 21 years old, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel F. Eagan of 44 Bryn Mawr Avenue, Trenton, N.J., was killed here this morning when he parachuted from a fighter plane that had collided with another fighter plane piloted by Second Lieutenant Robert A. Farley, 21, of 251 Spring Street, Trenton.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -Without warning, the Office of Price Administration announced this afternoon a ban for a week on the sale of butter to the public.

The text of Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler's Heroes' Memorial Day address yesterday in the Berlin Army Museum as broadcast for foreign consumption by the German Trans-ocean agency and recorded here by The Associated Press follows:
I was greatly interested and somewhat amused in reading the editorial comment in the March 18 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES under the caption "Topsy-Turvy Democracy."
Five new films will reach local theatres this week. The openings follow:

The four-story American basement dwelling on a lot 16 by 100 feet at 159 East Sixty-second Street has been sold by Mrs. Frederick Cromwell through Pease Elliman, to an out-of-town buyer for occupancy. The house has twelve rooms and is assessed at $45,000.

The New York City Tunnel Authority has submitted to Governor Dewey and the State Legislature a progress report finding that the proposed Narrows Vehicular Tunnel to connect Staten Island and Brooklyn is "practicable, feasible and necessary."

WASHINGTON, March 21 -Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, had lunch with President Roosevelt today and told him about plans being made by the United States Commission for Inter-American Development for Post-War Cooperation and Trade Development by business men of this country and Latin-America.

Twenty sermons on the uniform subject of "The Nature of God" were delivered yesterday by as many pastors in their respective churches in the area west of Central Park, from Fifty-ninth Street to 110th Street and from Central Park West to Riverside Drive.

Meatless Tuesdays in New York City restaurants will be optional for a trial period of thirty days or longer after meat rationing goes into effect next Monday, Mayor La Guardia announced in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 21 (U.P.) -- Berlin was in flames for three days after the great R.A.F. raid the night of March 1 and, where circumstances permitted, many civilians cursed Adolf Hitler rather than the Allied leaders for the death and destruction in the German capital.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21 -Reports late last week that the Pace parity revision bill was going before the House of Representatives for immediate debate caused strength in cotton futures after farm legislation uncertainties earlier in the week kept trading interest in futures at low ebb.

Deploring the public statements of "certain citizens in civilian and military life" who hold that the spread of hatred is necessary to winning the war, the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America declared yesterday that the dissemination of hatred in this country and others not only would hinder the war but prevent the achievement of a "just and durable peace."

Last week's decline in stocks was at first ascribed in Wall Street to Monday's decision of the Supreme Court upholding the Interstate Commerce Commission's attitude and excluding from reorganization plans the stock of certain insolvent railways.

LONDON, March 21 -- A new high record of nearly 927,500,000 was reported last week by the Bank of England for its circulation. The week's rise of 1,033,000 was smaller than recently, but even so it was larger than in the same week of last year and disappointed those who had expected that the big drive here for savings would have brought about some reduction in the total of outstanding currency.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a comment by Matthew Woll, second vice president of the American Federation of Labor, on a recent editorial in this newspaper concerning the position taken by the A.F. of L. members (of which he is one) on the War Labor Board. Mr. Woll reads into this editorial views which we did not express in it and which we do not hold.
In the suburbs, excepting communities in Rockland County, an unusual demand for butter and other articles coming under the freezing order was reported.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, AUSTRALIA, Monday, March 22 (U.P.) -- A Consolidated Catalina flying boat crippled a large Japanese destroyer with two direct bomb hits in the Solomon Sea north of New Guinea last night and other Allied planes attacked enemy shipping from the Kei Islands to New Britain, raiding seven ships and two luggers, General Douglas MacArthur announced today.

LONDON, March 21 -- Although some revival of the stock markets here had been expected to follow the confusion of London's great savings week labeled "Wings for Victory," none occurred. The special week here was only the commencement of a national savings campaign which will be spread over the next four months and will embrace the whole country.

LONDON, Monday, March 22 (U.P.) -- Survivors reaching Britain described today a two-day running battle in the Atlantic between a large Allied convoy and what British naval men described as a "tremendous concentration of U-boats," a number of which were sunk by escorting Allied warships and Sunderland and Catalina flying boats.

W.W. Colpitts of Coverdale Colpitts, reorganization managers of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Company, announced yesterday that it is their intention to put through a reorganization without borrowing. Through the use of receiver's cash, the program of rehabilitation has been largely completed, except for extension of the Minneapolis shops, for which machines and materials cannot now be obtained, he said.

A plea for inter-racial understanding, good-will and brotherhood was voiced in a sermon yesterday by the Rev. Frederick W. Teichmann, pastor of Christ Evangelical Lutheran Church, West 153d Street, near Broadway, whose son was attacked and stabbed by hoodlums near his home on the night of March 14.

BALTIMORE, March 21 (AP) -Baltimore Transit Company employes, affiliated with the Amalgamated Association of Street, Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, A.F.L., voted unanimously tonight to go out on strike.

The Ukrainian Leontovich Chorus, under Frank H. Ilchuk, was heard yesterday afternoon in its first Town Hall recital in two years. Assisted by Maria Dmytryshyna and Mary Holod-Kowalchuk, sopranos, and with Zlatko Balakovic, violin, as guest artist, the talented group, composed of youthful amateur Ukrainian-Americans, presented an interesting Russian program devoted to folk songs, Soviet songs by Shotakovich, Dunayevski, Knipper and Fomin; excerpts from operas by Lysenko and Dzerzhinsky, and other numbers.

Enactment by Congress last month of legislation permitting but not requiring the merger or consolidation of domestic telegraph companies and operations presents certain possibilities of advantage, should a merger take place, but there are many difficulties because of the conditions imposed by the legislation, A.N. Williams, president of Western Union Telegraph Company, says in the pamphlet report for 1942.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- There was a brisk trade in cash oats and futures last week on the Board of Trade here, the cash grain selling at the highest price in fifteen years because of lack of offerings and reports that navigation on the Great Lakes would be late in opening this year, preventing the early arrival of Canadian grain at Eastern points.

Defeating the Queens team of Woodside by 6 1/2 -- 1 1/2 in the fifth and final round at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club yesterday, the Marshall players finished first in the annual interclub competition of the Metropolitan Chess League, retaining the title they have held for the past two seasons.

Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, says in the pamphlet report for 1942 that a special planning committee appointed by the company in 1941 carried on long-range planning activities last year, but only to the extent that they do not interfere with the full dischage of the company's responsibilities in the present emergency.
The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, preaching yesterday in the Riverside Church, appealed for prompt and continued help for starving children, particularly in the war areas abroad.

Quite unexpectedly the Westchester domestic help problem is being solved in part by Army wives who are taking household jobs to be near their husbands at Fort Slocum. A survey conducted recently by the United Service Organizations on the housing problem around military reservations in the New York area reveals that USO clubhouse directors are working effectively on Army wives' problems.

The New York, Brooklyn and Queens Borough Public Libraries arranged last week to have displays at 130 branches of winning essays in the Thomas Jefferson Bicentennial Essay Contest originating with schools in immediate neighborhoods.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 15 (AP) (Delayed) -- Diseased and hungry Greece is beginning to raise her emaciated hand more and more frequently against Italian and German occupation troops.

PITTSBURGH, March 21 -- Raw steel output last week reached 100 per cent of rated capacity, thereby establishing a new high on a weekly tonnage basis. There is every indication that this will be matched or exceeded this week.
DETROIT, March 21 (AP) -- The Red Wings scored three goals in the third period tonight to defeat Toronto, 4 to 2, in the opener of their best-of-seven National Hockey League play-off series.

The State of West Virginia announced yesterday it would open bids on March 30 on a new issue of $1,000,000 of road bonds. The issue will be dated April 1, 1943, and will mature serially from April 1, 1944 to 1968. Bidders are asked to name the rate of interest at not to exceed 4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -While Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, having returned from New York, continued his conversations here today during a visit to Secretary of State Cordell Hull and at a luncheon with President Roosevelt, comments by Mr. Eden, Mr. Hull and others indicated that the radio address of Prime Minister Winston Churchill yesterday was regarded as throwing further official light upon the scope and purposes of Mr. Eden's visit to this country.
The Monday German communique as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Democratic leaders began today a formal canvass of the party's House membership in a move to head off possible help to Republicans in favor of action embodying the Ruml pay-as-you-go tax plan.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The connotations of the political words "Liberal" and "Conservative" are as unprecise in Great Britain as they -- and "Democrat" and "Republican" -- are in this country, as Mr. Churchill's post-war program of social economics demonstrated when he outlined it in his Sunday radio speech.

Of the $13,000,000,000 to be raised in the nation-wide War Loan Drive beginning on April 12, $8,000,000,000 is to come from investors other than commercial banks, and of the latter amount, the New York Federal Reserve District is to raise at least $3,000,000,000, Perry E. Hall, executive manager of the New York Victory Fund Committee, announced yesterday.

SEVERAL years ago Captain Puleston of the Navy tangled in debate with historian Charles A. Beard over the foreign, as distinct from the Revolutionary and the Civil, wars of the United States. Captain Puleston said he considered the Mexican War the single moral blot on an otherwise irreproachable escutcheon. Beard, in Sardonic vein, said the Mexican War had been our only worthwhile foreign war.

Despite the heavy volume of first-quarter tax receipts still pouring into the Treasury, as fast as the checks can be put through the banks for collection, the Treasury yesterday notified commercial bank depositories in this district that it would withdraw funds on Thursday, Friday and Saturday from its war loan account.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey told a Congressional committee today that the government should "set the example" in releasing non-essential workers to the armed forces -- but that it did not do so.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Here are the texts of statements made by Roger D. Lapham, representing industry members of the War Labor Board, and Wayne Morse, public member, in explaining their votes today to sustain the "Little Steel" formula in deciding wage questions:

A system of teacher-committees to replace administrative directors in the public schools and thus utilize latent abilities in the teaching staff was recommended in a report submitted yesterday by the law committee on the Board of Education.

Louis Balner, 31-year-old ex-convict who appeared yesterday as a State witness at the first-degree murder trial of two men accused of killing Harry Nichols, Williamsburg gambler, nine years ago, declared under cross-examination that he knew who was the slayer responsible for a double murder in Queens in 1935.

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE, in England, March 22 (AP) -- The Flying Fortresses and Liberators ranged over Germany today to plaster the huge naval base at Wilhelmshaven, smacking their bomb down upon the docks in one of the heaviest and most accurate attacks of the United States Eighth Air Force.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 22 -- Jack (Tex) Kraus, the altitudinous southpaw from the Lone Star State, who pitched for Montreal last season, finished only his third day of exercising as a Dodger today, but already he has had unusual attention from Manager Leo Durocher.

John W. McKinlay, president of the National Tea Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at Chicago yesterday that there is no hope for a common dividend in the immediate future. The company has paid all arrearages on the preferred stock and placed dividends on that issue on a regular quarterly schedule, he said, pointing out that the book value of the common stock is about $15 a share.

Possibility of a breakdown in the new decentralization plan for Latin America, through the inability of the control agencies abroad to supply the specific trade data on the Import Recommendations, as required by the Board of Economic Warfare, was seen yesterday by foreign traders here.

ALBANY, March 22 -- The battle over whether New York City shall have additional taxing powers for the support of its government, and the possible shape those taxes might take, shifted to Albany tonight and will be fought to a finish tomorrow.

Two nationally heard radio programs, and four on local stations or regional networks elsewhere in the country, were announced yesterday as winners of the annual George Foster Peabody Radio Awards, administered jointly by the National Association of Broadcasters and the Henry W. Grady School of Journalism of the University of Georgia.

The Axis radios said last night that full agreement on building a "new world order based on justice and eternal world peace" and carrying forward a joint war had been reached yesterday by representatives of Japan, Germany and Italy, sitting in Tokyo under provisions of the Axis tripartite pact.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 22 -- Suffering from a recurrence of the general fatigue that affected him last year, Pope Pius XII was ordered today to remain in bed, seeing no one but his more immediate collaborators, according to an official report issued by the Vatican this afternoon.

Details of the revised nutrition program, which takes into consideration present foods shortages, were sent out yesterday by the Grocery Manufacturers of America to food companies throughout the country. Paul S. Willis, president of the association, predicted that the new plan will receive aggressive support from advertisers, pointing out that last year the official theme of the first nutrition program was incorporated in about $40,000,000 worth of advertising.

HOLLYWOOD, March 22 --Twentieth Century-Fox will make a picture with an all-woman principal cast dealing with wives of commissioned officers who follow their husbands from one Army camp to another. The proposed picture will be based on an original story, "Paris, Tenn.," by Michael Uris, who is collaborating on the screen play with Arthur Kober.

AT THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 22 -- "Well, you can go about five miles ahead without shelling," said Major Thomas F. Lancer, Military Police Chief for a United States division and formerly a member of Company L, New York State police.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 22 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors pledged itself today to give the Pelham-Port Chester Parkway right-of-way to the State for development of an arterial highway after the war. The property, acquired by the county fifteen years ago but never used, is ten miles long and has cost $8,000,000 in purchase charges and bond interest.

A petition signed by 282 scholars and scientists in the country's leading universities was submitted yesterday to President Roosevelt, calling on him to speak and act in protest against the crimes of the Nazis and their satellites against the defenseless Jewish population of the subjugated countries, particularly in Eastern Europe.

Although there are two proposals pending before the State Legislature to alter stock transfer taxes -- which place the New York Stock Exchange at a disadvantage with respect to Exchanges in other States -- there is some hope that one or the other may be enacted before adjournment in the next few days.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., March 22 (U.P.) -- The 1943 aspirations of the Braves suffered a triple setback today with the definite loss of two players, Max West and Billy Myers, and the probable retirement of another, Catcher Ernie Lombardi.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- The wheat market developed a heavy undertone today on the Board of Trade with pressure from cash interests and spreaders causing a break of more than 1 cent from the early high. There was a lack of aggressive support from mills and commission houses, but late in the session scattered buying developed on reports of dust storms in parts of Kansas, and a small rally followed.
NORFOLK, Va., March 22 (AP) -Lieut. Edward J. Gaughan has been decorated for heroism after perhaps the longest "run" on record in response to a fire alarm.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 22 -- Manager Joe McCarthy came out of the snow drifts today with the announcement that he was perfectly satisfied with his picket line, with or without Charley Keller, who, with Catcher Bill Dickey and Infielder Joe Gordon, constitutes the Yankee holdout problem.

Orders booked by the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company last year reached the record total of $241,461,632, according to the company's annual report issued yesterday. In 1941 orders amounted to $187,253,978.

It has been called to my attention that a bill (Assembly Int. 1923) abolishing the qualifications of the Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, thus permitting the appointment of a lay Commissioner, was introduced March 17. It is thought that it probably will be rushed through to the Senate for final vote next week.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "The Moon Is Down," Twentieth Century-Fox's screen version of the John Steinbeck novel and play, which will arrive at the Rivoli Theatre on Friday morning. Nunnally Johnson wrote the script and produced the film, which was directed by Irving Pichel.

Twenty-two divisions of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund's Commerce and Industry Committee have surpassed their quotas in the current campaign, it was announced last night by Eugene W. Stetson, chairman of the committee. He said that they had reported total contributions of $1,021,462 with quotas totaling $831,000.

A last-second field goal by little Hy Gotkin brought St. John's a 51-49 victory over Rice in a thrilling first-round encounter in the sixth annual national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden last night. By way of making it a banner night for the local talent, Fordham came through with a 60-58 upset triumph over Western Kentucky State in the afterpiece.

The New York department stores having successfully led the opposition to the Mayor's proposal to double the retail sales tax, the Mayor now comes back with a tax proposal which he declares, with remarkable candor, will hit the department stores particularly. What the Mayor proposes, in brief, is a spite tax.

CHUNGKING, China, March 22 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, stalled in their two-week-old drive south of the Yangtze River, again have resorted to the use of poison gas against Chinese troops, the Chinese High Command charged tonight in a communique that also reported the recapture of an important highway center in Southern Hupeh Province.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The War Department has issued a booklet, "You're Going to Employ Women," which advises employers on hiring, training and supervising them.

With the opening of the trout season in near-by counties of the State scheduled for a week from Saturday, a last-minute request is being made by sportsmen to Mayor La Guardia to permit boats for fishing on the New York water shed lakes.

BALBOA, Canal Zone, March 22 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace arrived here by plane this afternoon after having had a farewell luncheon with the President of Panama, Ricardo Adolfo de La Guardia, and Senora de La Guardia in the picturesque mountain village of Boquete, in the heart of the coffee growing country.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- At a stormy meeting of the War Labor Board today the American Federation of Labor's petition to scrap the "Little Steel" formula was rejected by a vote of eight to four, the public and industry members furnishing the majority, while the labor members dissented.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Representative Sikes, Democrat of Florida, told the House today that David Ginsburg, chief counsel for the Office of Price Administration, had prepared at government expense 500 copies of a post-card size map showing the way to his home in Washington.
MIAMI, Fla., March 22 (AP) -Colorful ceremonies attended the presentation here today of ten speedy Coast Guard anti-submarine patrol boats by the United States to Cuba.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Roosevelt is drinking milk with his breakfast instead of coffee, which he has given up except for an occasional demi-tasse after dinner.

Employers are naturally anxious to know what their duties will be under the new tax bill. The answer is simple. Suppose an employer is engaged in producing household furniture or sports shirts or newspapers.
Mrs. F. Bartholomay Jelke has arrived from Newport and is at the Savoy-Plaza.

No appreciable effect on business was reported yesterday by independent gasoline service stations in the Metropolitan area with the lifting of the ban on pleasure driving together with the slashing of the A ration.

Members of New York City's food industry were stirred yesterday by reports that Federal and municipal officials and representatives of the industry would meet privately here tomorrow to try to deal with the food crisis.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 22 (AP) -- On the night of March 20-21 troops of the Eighth Army attacked Mareth Line positions. Fierce fighting ensued. Operations are contihuing satisfactorily.
BERNE, Switzerland, March 22 -- Thousands of young Frenchmen are still being sent daily to Germany. When they resist the "white terror" operates.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Women's part in the April drive of the Treasury Department to raise $13,000,000,000 will include the selling of at least $13,400,000 in bonds to equip 2,000,000 enlisted men.
LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- The German War machine shows no sign of critical weaknesses despite the batterings of the past four months, authoritative British circles reported today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- Playing "Tail-End Charlie" was nearly the last aerial role for Second Lieutenant Norman W. Jackson of Carter, Mont.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 160 United States Army personnel killed in action, in the Alaskan, Asiatic, European, North African, Pacific, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.
