WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Since the beginning of the war, 1,626 women postmasters, fourth class, have been appointed, this representing a 25 per cent increase in the rate at which they were named in the preceding eight years, the Postoffice Department made known today.
BOSTON, March 22 -- A program of action now, entitled "What to Do Today," was made public today by the Massachusetts Committee off Post-War Readjustment.

As a newspaper man reared in the tradition of Melville E. Stone he practiced the kind of journalism that has made the American press the most independent and honorable in the world. To other work as consultant of public spirited organizations he brought the same fidelity and understanding.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 23 -- The Times of London published today the sequel to its March 10 editorial arguing that Britain and Russia must bear the brunt of responsibility for maintaining order in Europe. Perhaps it should be called an amplification. At any rate it was detailed, specific and pointed.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 22 -- Today's infantry attack from El Guettar to take the high ground to the northeast, east and southeast was a model of coordination and drive. Accurate American artillery fire silenced the enemy artillery on the hills while Italian 75-mm. artillery and 47-mm. anti-tank guns were captured in a flanking movement from both north and south and turned against the enemy.

The Packard Motor Car Company more than doubled both its sales and profits in 1942 compared with 1941, according to a preliminary report for the year made public yesterday by Alvan Macauley, chairman, and George T. Christopher, president of the company.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The population of the Continental United States rose 1.2 per cent last year to a total of 135,604,000 with a record number of births due, primarily, to business prosperity and "anticipation of conscription," according to figures made public today by the Bureau of the Census.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A glance at the lighter side of life with generals on Guadalcanal was given by the War Department in a release of correspondence from Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon's files concerning the "expenditure" of eight bullets by Major Gen. Joseph L. Collins in the extermination of one Japanese sniper.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Oklahoma Power and Water Company received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to change its existing issues of common and preferred stock, all of which are held by the Middle West Corporation, into 23,141 shares of capital stock of $100 par value.

CAMP ATTERBURY, Ind., March 22 -- C.I.O. labor leaders from Midwestern war plants plunged into the first strenuous activity today of their visit to this Army camp and tried hard to match the combat training routine of their hosts, the soldiers of the Eighty-third Division.

Mayor La Guardia's proposal to abolish the Board of Education's Bureau of Supplies and to transfer its functions to the City Purchasing Department was killed yesterday when the City Council's Committee on State Legislation voted unanimously to pigeonhole a resolution asking the Legislature to sanction the change.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Madame Chiang Kai-shek, wife of the Chinese Generalissimo, appealed to Americans tonight to cultivate "toughmindedness" in their march onward to "a just and permanent peace" and to recapture "faith in our fellow-men in the spirit of your pioneer fathers."

Based on the preliminary merchandise offerings yesterday, indications pointed to a good response to the announcement by the Allied Purchasing Corporation that it was open to buy $10,000,000 worth of goods from retailers, manufacturers and wholesalers who find themselves with surplus stocks under the inventory control order L-219, officials here reported.

Prime Minister Churchill's Sunday broadcast has provided new impetus to the fascinating occupation of planning for a better world. Such planning now claims the attention of all Governments and numerous private organizations throughout the world, and especially in this country.

LONDON, March 22 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today following yesterday's speech by Prime Minister Winston Churchill. Activity in industrials was confined mainly to radio and manufacturing issues. British celanese showed further rises.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Senate Finance Committee made public today its report on the House-approved bill increasing the national debt limit from $125,000,000,000 to $210,000,000,000 and voiding President Roosevelt's $25,000 salary "ceiling" order.

An unusual arrangement in the complicated relationship affecting Hollywood, Broadway and the Dramatists Guild now permits film companies to buy picture rights of stage productions backed by them without having to outbid rivals in the open market.

Alfredo Felix Diaz Escobar, president of the Anti-Nazi-Fascist National Committee and a member of the Mexican Chamber of Deputies, declared yesterday in an interview that the Sinarquista movement in Mexico was fascist in character and had from a million to a million and a half members.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- President Roosevelt telegraphed disputants in the bituminous coal wage conference requesting them to continue in effect the present contract beyond its expiration date of March 31 with the understanding that when an agreement is reached it will be retroactive to that date.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of war Information, denied today that there had been wholesale deferments of OWI employes as charged at hearings of a House Military Affairs sub-committee investigating deferments of Government workers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (U.P.) -- Hammering Henry Armstrong, former triple champion, defeated Al Tribuani in ten rounds tonight to continue his successful comeback campaign. The bout attracted 12,633 to Convention Hall.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Development of a steel producing center in the east-central section of New York State is held a possibility by the State Division of Commerce in its report issued today on the mineral resources of the State.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, March 22 (AP) -- To three American soldiers, including one who led a charge on a Japanese machine-gun nest armed only with a pistol, were awarded today Silver Stars for gallantry in action. The awards were made by Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, commander of United States troops in New Guinea.

The preliminary annual report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for 1942, issued yesterday, showed, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges, a consolidated net income of $4,093,931. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 96 cents a common share, and compared with a net of $4,692,858, or $1.27 a common share, in 1941.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE IN CHINA, March 22 (AP) -- Two pilots and a crew chief of transport planes received Distinguished Flying Crosses today for repeated dangerous missions in flying men and materiel to fighting front bases in Free China, and to Air Medals were bestowed on New York State men of the combat personnel of the old China Air task Force.

PITTSBURGH, March 22 -- The State Supreme Court, in what is believed here to be the first case of its kind in the legal history of the United States, upheld today a conviction of murder against a 26-year-old Allegheny County woman despite the fact that the body of her victim has never been found.

The estate left by Richard Washburn Child, author and former Ambassador to Italy, was fixed at $60,419 gross and $49,780 net in the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday. Mr. Child died intestate on Jan. 31, 1935, and valuation of the estate was delayed by a contest for the issuance of letters of administration between the widow, now Mrs. Dorothy Child Filipponi, and Mr. Child's former wife, now Mrs. Maude Parker Pavenstedt.

Forty-five million Brazilians are "just as interested as you and all our Allies" in winning a "smashing and staggering victory," necessary for security and of avoiding forever the rise of dangerous political adventurers, Oscar Correia, Consul General of Brazil, told an audience yesterday at a United Nations Day symposium in Town Hall.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, March 23 (AP) -- The Allies, infiltrating further against the Japanese in New Guinea, have completed occupation of the Mambare River area on the northeast coast, General Douglas MacArthur's command announced in its noon communique today.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Governor Dewey cut in half tonight the scheduled $5,000,000 State appropriation to set up centers for the care of children of war workers. He acted on an offer from the Federal Government to match State expenditures on a fifty-fifty basis.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, March 23 (AP) -- NORTItWESTERN SECTOR Reconnaissance activity only.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn stores showed a decrease of 3 per cent in sales last week in comparison with the same week a year ago, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported an increase of 3 per cent over 1942.

LONDON, March 20 (AP) (Delayed) -- Allied commanders were studying today the results of a recent "trial offensive" sham exercise of such genuine character that the Germans, according to their broadcasts and newspapers, thought it was the beginning of a real invasion of the Continent.

Today the writer reviews much she has said in the last three months about the scarcity of fats. It is hoped that at least some of the material will help to tide you over until next Monday, when the sale of shortenings and oils will be resumed under point rationing.

NEW DELHI, India, March 22 (AP) -- United States bombers and fighter planes, continuing their attacks against the Japanese in Northern Burma while the British are pounding them in the south, blasted enemy installations and left great fires burning at Mogaung, a United States communique said today.

The ballot being prepared for the annual election of officers of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs will carry as the only candidate for president the name of Mrs. Kenneth S. Strayer of Tottenville, S.I. The general election, at which a successor to Mrs. Guy Percy Trulock will be named, will be held at the Hotel Astor on May 7.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Increases of $135,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $231,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $120,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $269,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $296,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

Mayor La Guardia began yesterday his annual 'budget retreat." In seclusion to consider the city's operating costs, he faced the need of making drastic economies, finding new tax sources or imposing additional burdens on real estate if the budget that he is to submit to the Board of Estimate by April 1 is to balance.

TRENTON, N.J., March 22 -- Reappointment to the State Unemployment Compensation Commission was denied by Governor Charles Edison today to Colonel Hugh A. Kelly of Jersey City. The nomination of Charles Englehard of Bernardsville as successor in the unsalaried position was sent to the Senate for confirmation.
MOSCOW, March 22 -- Today will be remembered in Moscow as the end of a Winter that, though milder than usual, placed the city's inhabitants under a severe strain.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Office of Price Administration relaxed its ban on retail sales of butter today, allowing sales where spoilage is threatened and in other cases of "undue hardship."
KEY WEST, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- Axis submarines are on the prowl again in the Caribbean.

George Chavchavadze, pianist, gave a remarkable presentation at Town Hall last night of de Falla's "El Amor Brujo" and of modern Russian pieces, at the end of a long and exacting rogram. The extraordinary work of the Spanish composer was given with vitality, vivid color and wild abandon, technical facility and ease.

While a trial date was set yesterday in Bronx County Court for a Negro charged with mugging, just eight days after his arrest, four clergymen, representing parishes in Harlem and Washington Heights, met with police officials of the two districts and reached the conclusion, based on police statistics, that "there is no crime wave in Harlem."

ANKARA, Turkey, March 21 (Delayed) (AP) -- News of forty American prisoners of war, mostly from the air forces, was gathered from some of the 787 British who were exchanged today at Mersin for 863 Italians and Germans in the biggest exchange of able-bodied prisoners during the war. All forty Americans were reported to be held at Prison Camp 21 near Rome, the best of the Italian camps.
A recommendation that the State Legislature should legalize bingo was made yesterday by County Judge Joseph M. Conroy in Long Island City, Queens.

Among the bills introduced at Albany last week, as the session was hurrying toward its close, was one eliminating the requirement that the State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene should be a qualified psychiatrist. Of necessity the Commissioner is an administrator, though the State Department of Standards and Purchases, the Department of Public Works, the State Civil Service Commission and the Budget Director take care, under the law, of many administrative problems in his department.

Lumber shortages will soon replace manpower as the limiting factor in production of furniture, F.E. Seidman of Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, serving a large group of manufacturers, predicted here yesterday. He reported that, since the government recently lowered the specifications for its own requirements, manufacturers had found it increasingly difficult to obtain the grades used for furniture.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 22 -This streamlined Spring training season being one in which any number of things can happen without a word of warning, it remained for an overnight snowfall to proide. the latest touch in the way of variety.

Slipper manufacturers may be granted some relief from the WPB's order M-217 to permit them to utilize "frozen" inventories of non-critical materials, Benjamin Seligman, counsel for the National Association of Slipper Manufacturers, declared last night at a meeting of the group held in the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, March 22 -- Purchase by the National Trust of 950 acres where stand the famous prehistoric remains of Avebury in Wiltshire was announced today. The acquisition takes in the greater part of the site regarded as one of the most important archaeological areas in Europe.

If the Nazis ever started laughing at their own shortcomings, they would become hysterical, Mayor La Guardia remarked yesterday afternoon in opening officially an exhibition of cartoons and drawings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Many air-minded women anxious for a flying job in the war effort may have to keep their wings folded unless the Civil Aeronautics Administration obtains from Congress the funds it seeks for women flight instructors in high schools, and unless the Army makes a right-about-face from its statement today that the CAA's War Training Service program already has a sufficient number of instructors.

LONDON, March 22 (U.P.) -- The government, invoking for the first time in the case of an aircraft company its enormous powers under the defense regulations, has taken full charge of the famous Short Brothers, Ltd., maker of four-motored Stirling bombers and Sunderland flying boats and the oldest established airplane designer and producer in Britain, it was announced today.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 23 -Red Army troops have captured more than forty inhabited places in a single day in their two-pronged drive on Smolensk, have killed 5,500 Germans in three days in a battle north of Bryansk and are holding firm along their Donets River front in the south, the Russian Monday midnight communique reported.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, received remuneration of $537,724 in 1942 as an officer and director of the company and its subsidiaries and paid off $502,001 of indebtedness to the concern, according to the proxy statement for the annual meeting to be held in Wilmington, Del., on April 13.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Reorganization of the War Production Board has been ordered by its chairman, Donald M. Nelson, through a directive signed by Mr. Nelson Friday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 22 -Tank and infantry divisions of the British Eighth Army bit into the Axis positions on the Mareth Line, already scourged and blasted by aerial assault, and American armor and infantry smashed toward Maknassy and the sea today as the second important phase of the Allied offensive in Southern Tunisia opened successfully.

MIAMI, Fla., March 22 -- Captain Joseph H. Hart of Pan American Airways set a record last week when he flew his clipper across the South Atlantic twice in twenty-four hours. Pan American officials said today it was the first time a commercial plane had made the round trip in a single day.

ALBANY, March 22 -- A charge that the Federal Government is not solving and apparently cannot solve "the complex multiplicity of problems" confronting food producers of New York State, was contained in a special report on food production, made to Governor Dewey and released by him "without comment."

THE Giant train was humming along the rails a few seasons ago, and Burgess Whitehead, the Phi Beta Kappa man, was busily engaged in a learned discussion with Hal Schumacher, another brilliant student, on a problem in ballistics. They were talking about shooting a rifle bullet in the air and wondering just where it would land if directed exactly and unerringly straight upward.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- Officers and men of the First Marine Division (reinforced), who stormed the Solomons and seized Japanese positions in August, were cited by President Roosevelt today for heroism.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Ralph Cowan, circulation manager of The Toronto Star and past president of the International Association of Circulation Managers, warned American publishers today not to live in a "fool's paradise" becuse a cut in newsprint had been postponed.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -Judge Paul Leahy in Federal District Court in Wilmington has granted a stay of action requested by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the suit brought by Illinois Iowa Power Company to recover alleged damages from North American Light and Power Company, it was disclosed today.

Former President Herbert Hoover and former Ambassador Hugh Gibson declared in a joint statement yesterday that Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in his Sunday radio address, made "an effective declaration of the primary regional responsibilities of Europe and other areas." The statement, issued from the Waldorf Towers, follows:

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A 50 per cent increase in the amount of English combed cotton yarn which may be used for reinforcement purposes by manufacturers of women's rayon hosiery was announced today by the WPB.

MOSCOW, March 22 (AP) -- The newspaper Pravda, official organ of the Communist party, asserted today that Japanese newspapers had falsely represented four Soviet sailors as saying that their ship, the Kola, had been sunk by an American submarine in the East China Sea and said the vessel had been held up and searched by the Japanese two days before the sinking.

I read with amazement the statement in THE TIMES of March 17 regarding the speech of Dr. Otto Dietrich, German press chief, in which he claims that any one is wrong who "asserts that National Socialist philosophy contends that wars are unavoidable; the direct opposite is the case."

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- An attorney for the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that Junius Rawls of Nashville, Tenn., former treasurer of the board of missions of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, received a rebate from his brother, a broker, on investments made in behalf of the church.

MADISON, Wis., March 22 (AP) -- An Eastern intercollegiate title-holder and a former Pacific Coast Conference champion will be among thirty-nine boxers battling for honors in the ninth annual National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament opening for three days Thursday at the University of Wisconsin.

LONDON, March 22 -- American Flying Fortresses and Liberators threw the Allied aerial offensive over Europe into high gear again today, bombing the German naval base at Wilhelmshaven for the third time in daylight. One pilot reported the attack was more concentrated "than even at Vegesack, which was our best previous" -- a reference to the raid on U-boat yards near Bremen last Thursday.

A national conference of women at which prominent women will discuss patterns for the post-war world will be held on April 7 in The New York Times Hall. Sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the event will embrace an afternoon and an evening session devoted to the theme, "What Kind of World Do We Want?"

Violent German counter-attacks appear to be slowing down the Russian advance on Smolensk. The Russians have indeed taken Durovo, a railroad town only fifty-seven miles from the provincial capital, but they are not moving with the same speed they developed after the German collapse at Rzhev.

Hitler had to admit in his belated "Heroes' Memorial Day" speech that German civilians are "suffering the brunt of the enemy's lust for destruction." This is his way of saying that the bombardment from the air which he and Goering had reserved for other countries has been brought home to Germany.

LONDON, March 22 -- In this city, where the wine lists of many restaurants consist mainly of black lines, like those penciled through the only worth-while meat dishes on the menu within fifteen minutes of the opening of the eating places, an auction of distinguished drinkables is an event.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Senate groups moved cautiously today in preparation for grappling with post-war problems, as the lines at the Capitol appeared to be drawn more sharply between those who would have detailed, bluprinted planning for peace now and those who warn of controversy and disunity in such a course.

When Fritz Kreisler was asked to say something for the Red Cross War Fund, he replied that he could speak only through the four strings of his violin. After his own fashion he spoke eloquently at Carnegie Hall last night, and the voice -- or voices -- of his violin brought the Red Cross War Fund a sum of $10,200.

Stocks displayed a firmer tone toward the end of the session yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing irregularly higher with trading restricted to the smallest volume and breadth in more than a month. The Churchill and Hitler speeches had little effect on prices, outside of a slight firming up in the so-called war stocks on Prime Minister Churchill's forecast of a longer war.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- Consumers will probably find that when the rationing of meats, cheese, butter and other fats and oils goes into effect Monday, all these rationed foods will not be available immediately, in exchange for coupons, L.A. Baumann, chief of the dairy branch, food rationing division of the Office of Price Administration, said today.

Those who live by writing, editing and publishing newspapers and books cannot be expected to react favorably to H.G. Wells's declaration this week that the newspaper is "as dead as mutton" and the bound book likely to disappear. Mr. Wells's further prediction that we may be entering a period in which pamphlets will serve to "ventilate ideas" will help somewhat, but not much.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 23 (UP) -- The Soviet Monday midnight communique as broadcast by Moscow:

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A new bill containing a further modification of the Ruml tax plan was introduced in the House today by its chief sponsor of the pay-as-you-go method, Representative Carlson of Kansas.

Startled by Donald Nelson's reported announcement of the likelihood of a resumption of mechanical refrigerator production late last week, the industry came to the conclusion yesterday that such a step was still a long way off and, if it did develop, output would be confined to a restricted number of so-called war models from a few small plants.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Judiciary Committee of the Senate, by a tie vote of nine to nine, blocked today President Roosevelt's nomination to the Circuit Court of Appeals of James V. Allred, defeated last year in Texas as a candidate for the seat of Senator O'Daniel.

Masters of a variety of types of writing, from the detective story to biography, will describe their techniques to authors and would-be authors in an "Authors Guild Craftsman Series," to be offered at the Washington Square Writing Center of New York University Tuesday and Thursday evenings, beginning April 6, it was announced yesterday.

With substantial buying support lacking, trading in cotton futures yesterday followed the listless pattern of the last two weeks. Only a late switch of New Orleans operators to the buying side prevented the market from reacting on the general apathy of demand. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed 4 to 6 points above Saturday's final quotations.

A reception to Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway will be given tomorrow at the Waldorf-Astoria from 5 to 7 P.M. Funds will be raised for Norwegian charities through an auction of ninety-six choice seats for the opening of the motion picture "The Moon Is Down" at the Rivoli Theatre on Friday.
CHUNGKING, China, March 22 (U.P.) -- UItUKIG, Ukina, Marel 22 (U.).4. oommuniqM:

The seventy-sixth annual exhibition of the American Water Color Society opens with a private view at 8:30 tonight and to the public tomorrow, in the galleries of the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue. It is a large show, containing 361 examples in the specified medium, some of the painters being represented more than once.

Benjamin Franklin, apostle of thrift, never tired of reminding that "time is money." To buyers of war savings bonds, time is indeed money. The sooner a war bond is acquired, the sooner it starts on its ten-year run to maturity. To delay now is to postpone the day of reward.

Despite the intervention of President Roosevelt, the coal wage deadlock remained unresolved yesterday as the United Mine Workers and bituminous operators of the Appalachian region continued to jockey for position on the question of continuing negotiations beyond March 31, expiration date of the current contract, so as to avoid a stoppage of the mines if no new agreement is reached.

The sudden death of Hans von Moltke, the recently appointed German Ambassador to Madrid, cuts off the task at which for some weeks he had been trying his hand: to entangle the Franco regime in a conflict with the British and Americans.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 24 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Tuesday midnight communique as broadcast by Moscow:

It was announced at District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office yesterday that the New York County grand jury had refused last Monday to vote an indictment on the charge by the police that Rudolph Muhsam had "kept a room for gambling" at the Cavendish Club, 14 East Sixty-second Street, where he is the bookkeeper, in permitting its members to play bridge for stakes.

LONDON, March 23 -- Cheers greeted Prime Minister Churchill today when he entered the House of Commons during question time. While the lobbies buzzed with talk about his Sunday night broadcast urging a four-year plan for post-war Britain under a coalition government, there were only indirect references to it from the floor.

Discussions are under way between Republican and Democratic leaders on a bipartisan judiciary ticket for this Fall's elections, it was learned yesterday. As yet the negotiations have not progressed to the stage where either side has made any definite commitments.
Several leases of space on Fifth Avenue to clothing firms and rentals of stores in the midtown district were reported yesterday.

Somehow the average human being abhors letter writing. Particularly in my mind is the letter writing to our boys in the services. A few days ago the thought occurred to me that the most interested person in the world today is the boy at the front and letters from home mean everything to him.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Definite steps soon will be taken by the hotel industry of the United States to obtain consideration from Washington authorities for supplies, equipment repairs and a more favorable treatment of personnel under the manpower and selective service divisions.
WASHINGTON, March 23 --- The Senate is pressing a demand for priorities on scarce materials to remodel one of its restaurants where Senators now eat under "unsanitary and primitive" conditions.
WASHINGTON, March 23 --- The House debated today a bill to close the gaps in anti-saboteur laws and set the death penalty for aiding the enemy, but postponed action until tomorrow.
LONDON, March 23 -- Improvement in the stock markets was well maintained today.

By the full of the Spring moon yesterday just after midnight, William Collins, 45 years old, a brawny longshoreman, moved toward his home at 64 East Broadway, near The Bowery. He had a good part of his $67 in wages still in his pocket, and in his heart good will toward all men.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 23 -- A major expansion of the New Zealand Air Force and the appointment of R.V. Goddard, acting air vice marshal, as air chief of staff, were revealed by Prime Minister Peter Fraser today.

Products perfected by the petroleum industry under the stress of war will mean cheaper, quicker and smoother driving for the American motorist in the post-war era and longer life for engine parts, George H. Freyermuth, engineer of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, declared yesterday at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Appropriations by Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York totaling $1,501,872 -- which came within $1,000 of the income from all sources -- were listed in an annual report made public yesterday by Rev. James J. Lynch, the organization's financial director, in connection with the 1943 drive for funds now in progress.

There is cause for satisfaction in the progress report of the New York City Tunnel Authority. It finds that the proposed vehicular tunnel at the Narrows to connect Brooklyn with Staten Island is "practical, feasible and necessary." as a post-war undertaking. This project has been under consideration for a long time.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 23 -- Survivors of the sinking of a United States merchantman somewhere in the Atlantic, who landed at a Dutch Caribbean port, related how a sudden "lucky shot" had destroyed their vessel, after which they spent eleven days aboard an escort vessel chasing submarines.

Sergeant Howard Walker of Portland, Conn., and the Army Aviation Ground Force, walked into the Stage Door Canteen on Forty-fourth Street last night and was hailed as the millionth visitor to the service man's funspot since it was opened, March 2, 1942.

Two hours before sunrise yesterday New York City underwent a test air raid alert that awakened about half the slumbering population and left the others blissfully unaware, tumbled 76,708 sleepy air raid wardens into the streets and set off a false alarm in Weehawken, N. J., across the Hudson River.

The twelve-story business building at 840 Broadway, southeast corner of Thirteenth Street, has been sold by Marvin S. Winter, Inc., of which Benjamin Winter is president, to a woman investor represented by Morris Holman, lawyer.
BAYONNE, N.J., March 23 -- A strike of thirty truck drivers of the refinery here of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company, called yesterday, continued today.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- An extensive summary of Prime Minister Churchill's Sunday broadcast was published prominently today in the Moscow press. His warning to Britain not to let planning for peace divert the nation's energy from the task of defeating the enemy and his underlining of the principle that international planning after Reichsfuehrer Hitler's fall must be the joint task of Britain, the United States and Russia was appreciated here.

Products developed by the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company are being used effectively against the enemy in every battle area, and the company's technical and research departments have been working on many entirely new problems submitted by the Army, Navy and aircraft manufacturers, John D. Biggers, president, said yesterday in his report for 1942.

First Lieutenant Norman Segal of 195 Bennett Avenue in Washington Heights has received five decorations for valor as navigator of American Flying Fortresses over enemy territory in Europe and in North Africa, it was disclosed yesterday.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., March 23 -- Bill Dickey came into the fold today as cold weather again drove the Yankees indoors for another session of restricted training.

LONDON, March 23 -- Speaking from a wheelchair in the House of Commons, Lady Apsley, Conservative member for Bristol Central, made her maiden speech today in a debate on pensions for the war wounded and crippled. Herself an invalid for life as the result of a hunting accident, Lady Apsley spoke in support of an appeal for higher pensions made by Sir Ian Fraser, chairman of St. Dunstan's organization for the blind.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,013 as against 1,158 in the preceding week and 953 in the like period of 1942, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 417, which compared with 418 last Tuesday.

The basketball tournament games that are making fans slightly dizzy this week will continue unabated tonight, when N.Y.U. meets Georgetown and De Paul faces Dartmouth in Madison Square Garden. These will be Eastern semi-final contests in the National Collegiate A.A. tournament and the first of them, De Paul vs. Dartmouth, will begin at 8:15 P.M.

TRENTON, March 23 -- The New Jersey Senate adopted today a resolution, in which the Assembly will be asked to concur, calling upon Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum as head of the Eastern Defense Command and Leonard Dreyfuss, State Director of Civilian Defense, to end the present confusion over air raid warning signals.

Pleasant news comes from Washington. Mr. Roosevelt has given up coffee and taken to milk. It was doubtless to set an example of saving that he recommended and tried for a little while that distant imitation of coffee produced by reassembling and repeating its own grounds.

The food shortage in this city is unnecessarily stringent, members of the New York City League of Women Voters contended yesterday. Miss Anna Lord Strauss, president of the league, disclosed that it was urging formation of a central civic committee to investigate the problem and make remedial suggestions to city, State and Federal officials.

The Municipal Art Society presented yesterday to Station WNYC a citation of merit for outstanding cultural service to the City of New York. This was the first such award made by the society, an independent organization founded fifty-one years ago to further the city's cultural interests.

The demand for books of all kinds in England has jumped "more than 150 per cent" since the beginning of the war, according to Curtice Hitchcock, president of Reynal Hitchcock, who recently returned from England after a survey of the book situation there.

To increase available cash with which to enter a major subscription for new government bonds in the War Loan drive that will start on April 12 New York City will sell $10,660,000 of its 3 per cent serial assessment bonds, now held in various sinking funds of the city. This announcement was made yesterday by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick.

While buying for Fall is getting off to an early start in the wholesale apparel markets here, much of the advance business is being taken subject to mill confirmation on piece goods orders of manufacturers, according to comment here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Types of canned goods subject to rationing were extended today by Secretary Wickard to include caviar, all other fish roe and all fruits and vegetables now on the list, whether or not they are packed in containers "sterilized by the use of heat."

Holders of A gasoline ration books in the Eastern States, whose allowance has been halved for the next four months to approximately 1.37 gallons weekly find themselves less fortunate than their Canadian neighbors in the same non-essential classification.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- B.G. De Silva announced this afternoon that Paramount would make a picture titled "The Hitler Gang," showing the rise and fall of the Nazi regime. Principal parts will be chosen as to acting and resemblance to Nazi leaders, irrespective of the box-office name value of the players.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 23 (U.P.) -- In a tiny jungle camp, far from other military installations, three American officers and eight enlisted men flirt with death daily so that their comrades may live, it was learned today.

A reporter for this newspaper encountered a major of American Military Police at a crossroads in Tunisia. The major gave him information as to how much farther he could go without being shelled and then asked: "Why not give the M.P.'s a break?" Inquiry showed that the M.P.'s are not the legendary ogres of the first World War.
Mrs. William Wickham Hoffman and Miss Anne Hoffman have gone to the Homestead, Hot Springs, V.
New sculpture by Maria and recent paintings by Piet Mondrian make up the current exhibition at the Valentine Gallery, 55 East Fifty-seventh Street, scheduled to continue until April 10.

PANAMA, March 23 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace spoke of the vision of Simon Bolivar and translated President Roosevelt's four freedoms into Spanish in a brief address today in the ancient hall here in which the first Pan-American conference was held more than a century ago.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Roosevelt informed a press conference today he would check up on reports from Chungking that Japan again had used poison gas in battling the Chinese. He said he had not heard about these reports.
Interesting editorial report by The Miami Herald of March 18:

A little more than twenty-three years ago -- on Jan. 16, 1920, to be precise -a small but vociferous group in this country paraded through the streets and shouted from the rooftops in celebration of a victory.
MOSCOW, March 23 (AP) -- The midday communique:

Mention of a threat to kidnap Joe Louis just before he became the world's heavyweight champion marked the testimony yesterday of Louis Balner, ex-convict, in the General Sessions first-degree murder trial of two other men in Balner's admitting slaying of Harry Nichols, Williamsburg gambling "overlord."

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 23 -- American forces entered the vital pass beyond Maknassy tonight, endangering Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's rear communications. The Americans, with little opposition, and that from the fleeing Italians, have reached a point from which Marshal Rommel apparently thought that the mud and their recent drubbing at Kasserine Pass would withhold them.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- A Congressional committee heard today a report from its counsel that privately owned merchant vessels, chartered to the British Ministry of War Transport in 1941 to carry war supplies to the Red Sea, realized sufficient profit from a single trip to pay off, many times over, the total book value of the vessel.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Sharp argument developed today at a hearing of the Securities and Exchange Commission after counsel for the SEC declared that an exhibit showed that a securities house realized a profit of $8,345 on a single day's transaction in $25,000 of securities in February, 1940.

Extending the late advance of the previous day, stocks moved forward yesterday from fractions to more than a point, but profit-taking in the late dealings reduced gains at the close. The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange increased, with sales aggregating 1,191,700 shares; the twenty-ninth time this year that sales have crossed the million-share mark.

A suite for string orchestra by Scarlatti-Burns and Paul Creston's symphony, Op. 20, had first performances on Manhattan Isle by the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. After the symphony, which had a handsome reception, the composer bowed from the stage.

Mathias F. Correa, United States attorney, said yesterday that his office would continue to prosecute Selective Service delinquents with the aim of bringing about their induction into the Army. He called his policy sound and fair.

Consolidated net income of the International Business Machines Corporation and United States and Canadian subsidiaries for 1942 was $8,679,755, equal to $8.77 each on 990,116 shares of stock, compared with $9,844,633, or $10.44 each on 943,028 shares, earned in 1941, the concern reported yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Wednesday, March 24 -- Early returns from the Danish Parliamentary elections, held yesterday, indicate a record poll by 90 to 95 per cent of the registered voters. In 1939 only 78 per cent voted.
The meat shortage in New York City has become so acute that private hospitals are now forced to forage for supplies in Connecticut.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 23 (AP) -- Forty-eight-year-old Bobby Cruickshank of Richmond, Va., a veteran of World War I, led the field at the end of the first round in the forty-first annual North and South open golf championship today with a card of 36, 35-71, one under par. Bobby is a grandfather.

A hero of the United States Merchant Marine who survived five torpedoings only to lose his life in a sixth, was honored yesterday by the posthumous award of the bronze medal of the Liverpool Shipwreck and Humane Society.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The government is ready for a rush by housewives to get home-canning equipment.
WILMINGTON, Del., March 23 (AP) -- The Bellanca Aircraft Corporation got a new set of officers tonight the second set to be elected by directors in eight days.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 23 -- Warning that Bermuda should proceed carefully in placing the facilities of Darrell's Island airport at any one company's disposal was sounded in the Assembly today by the Speaker, J. Reginald Conyers.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Completing its plans for limiting attendance at the Kentucky Derby on May 1 to residents of Louisville, the Office of Defense Transportation announced today that the railroads, the Churchill Downs race track and the bus companies were cooperating with ODT efforts.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The President saw Don Bodolfo Michels, Chilean Ambassador; Eduardo Cruz-Coke, member of the Chilean Senate, and General Oscar Escubero, Commander in Chief of the Chilean Army; Colonel Arthur Evans, M.P.; Major J.G. Lockhart, and Trygvre Lie, Norwegian Foreign Minister, and held a press conference.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- With the Independence, first of her class, believed to be ready for action, Navy designers are awaiting with interest reports on the results of one of the most ingenious experiments of the Bureau of Ships, the rapid conversion of partly built light cruisers into small aircraft carriers.
LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Roosevelt held one of his shortest press conferences of record today.

ELMER RIPLEY played his last game of professional basketball in 1930, which is almost in the believe-it-or-not category, because he participated in his first one in 1908. By any method of reckoning twenty-two years is a pretty long stretch in a sport which places such unyielding demands on youth, speed and endurance. But Rip did it and looks none the worse for it today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- (AP) -- The Office of War Information has announced the establishment of rules under which books may be distributed to "officially identified" prisoners of war and civilian internees in enemy-occupied countries.

DETROIT, Wednesday, March 24 (AP) -- Jack McLean's goal at 10:18 of the fourth overtime period gave the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-to-2 victory early this morning over the Detroit Red Wings in their National Hockey League play-off game. The series now stands at one triumph each.

MOSCOW, March 23 -- Today's Russian reports indicated that Field Marshal General Fritz Erich von Mannstein's forces were being held at all points on the Donets River line, where the heaviest pressure now seems to be exerted in the Belgorod region above Kharkov.

In celebration of its seventy-fifth anniversary the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has published a 496-page book called "A Family or Thirty Million." It traces the history of the $6,000,000,000 company from its foundation on March 24, 1868, in two small rooms on the second floor of 243 Broadway to the end of 1942.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Advocates of immediate post-war planning were challenged today by Senator La Follette of Wisconsin to show how their proposal for an organization of the United Nations would be binding on any country, including the United States.

A three-pronged drive made up of a safety program, a program of health and medical supervision, and a plan for labor-management cooperation "to penalize that small group of workers who are shirking their legitimate responsibilities,'' would reduce absenteeism and add nearly 2,000,000 trained and skilled workers to the industries of the nation, Dr. J.J. Wittmer, personnel and medical director of the Consolidated Edison Company, asserted yesterday.

CHESTER, Pa., March 23 -- The blue and white "M" flag, award of merit of the United States Maritime Commission, was hoisted to a masthead at the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company as three new tankers were launched inside of sixteen minutes today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Refusing to take a "maybe" answer from John L. Lewis, the Truman committee issued a subpoena today to make sure that the United Mine Workers president appeared Friday to testify about strikes, war production, inflation and jurisdictional disputes.
CHUNGKING, China, March 23 (UP) -- A communique:
Brisk buying by the trade near the close on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday pushed the list of active futures to final net gains of 10 to 12 points and to the season's highest closing level.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 23 -- After three months of relative quiescence, anti-Semitism flared up again in Bulgaria this week with mass deportations to the Reich from Bulgaria and occupied Thrace and Macedonia.

MERSINA, Turkey, March 22 (delayed) -- The Italian authorities have established a prison camp at Chieti, 100 miles northeast of Rome, where the Axis is concentrating American fliers, tank officers and war correspondents captured in North Africa, according to British prisoners exchanged against Axis prisoners in Mersina harbor yest day.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, March 24 -- American heavy bombers made another big predawn attack yesterday on airfields around the major Japanese base at Rabaul, New Britain. The attack lasted an hour and a half and was carried out by three formations of Flying Fortresses.
One of the luxuries of pre-war America, the elegant railroad dining car, is still bravely speeding along the rails, bearing more passengers and less food.

LONDON, March 23 -- The plight of the victims of Nazi persecution in occupied Europe is one of the urgent problems Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden has discussed with Secretary of State Cordell Hull, Viscount Cranborne, the Government leader, announced in the House of Lords today after the Archbishop of Canterbury had made an eloquent plea for action now to save the Jews from extinction.

Mrs. Jennie Lenox, 53 years old, a widow, who lives at 2970 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, and is an investigator for Bellevue Hospital, refused in the Felony Court yesterday to sign a grand larceny complaint against a woman gypsy who, she had suspected in the Fifth Street station the preceding midnight, had "cheated" her out of $8,980 by sleight-of-hand tactics in virtually an empty store at 162 Avenue B.

Phil Terranova of the Bronx gained a popular verdict over Charles (Lulu) Costantino of the East Side in last night's feature eight-round bout at the Broadway Arena before a near-capacity crowd of 4,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The situation in French Guiana was believed here today to be moving toward stabilization as the result of the arrival in Cayenne of Colonel Albert Jean-Paul le Bel, representative of General Henri Honore Giraud, French civil and military commander in chief in North Africa and the declaration of Lieut. Col. van Egue, commander of the French military forces in French Guiana, for General Giraud.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, March 24 (AP) -- The Wednesday noon communique:

BOSTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins gained a 2-0 lead over the Montreal Canadiens in their National Hockey League play-off series by scoring an exciting 5-3 triumph tonight before 12,900 at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- A swing toward the Ruml and Robertson pay-as-you-go tax plans and away from the incentive-tax scheme of the Ways and Means Committee majority appeared to be developing in the House today as members exchanged a verbal barrage to tune up for the four-day tax debate which opens Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The United States has established a West African Sea Frontier Force with a naval operating base at Casablanca, both under the command of Rear Admiral John L. Hall Jr. of Williamsburg, Va., the Navy Department disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -The government sought to bulwark its charges against George Sylvester Viereck of New York today with a new indictment designed to avoid another Supreme Court reversal such as freed the alleged pro-German propagandist three weeks ago after he had served a year in jail.

Because twenty-four electrical workers had refused to accept an agreement affecting 1,200 employees of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, operating the Hudson Tubes, the Utility Workers Organizing Committee, Local 213, CIO, has voted to call a strike on the railroad on April 5.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Dewey today cut the State appropriation for home relief another $5,200,000 to $21,000,000, the lowest on record since relief has been recognized as a State responsibility.

Security for the child based on the old idea of home and community has been destroyed forever by the war, and a new concept of security based on affirmation of the individuality of human beings must supplant it in the post-war world, Pearl S. Buck, author, declared last night.
Emanuel Winkelman, general manager of Lane Bryant, Inc., has leased a large penthouse in 40 East Sixty-sixth Street through Frederick Fox Co., completing the renting of this apartment building.

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Paramount the new attraction will be "Happy Go Lucky," a Paramount comedy with music in Technicolor. Heading the cast are Mary Martin, Dick Powell, Betty Hutton, Eddie Bracken and Rudy Vallee....
MOSCOW, March 23 -- Among more than 500 Soviet scientists and inventors who have received cash prizes for distinguished work during the last year, the following appeared in lists made public today:

The ice cream industry is now in a more critical position than is generally realized because of the increasing demands for milk solids, Dr. W.B. Silcox, Administrator of Food Distribution Order No. 8, which restricts the industry's use of milk products, declared yesterday.

The decision of the War Labor Board to stand by the "Little Steel" formula is the most encouraging sign of firmness that the Board as yet has shown. The case for refusing to break these ceilings at this time is unanswerable. As the Board has pointed out before: "It is the duty of this Board to stabilize wages on the basis of the Sept. 15, 1942, levels.

The regional priorities division of the War Production Board is now handling on the average 300 applications daily for preference ratings from industry, or three times the number developing before the regional office received power to issue ratings on requests for material costing $100 or less, it was learned here yesterday.

When the rationing of meats, fats and cheese goes into effect on Monday, it will be shrewd to reserve a few of your points for some Cheddar or Munster or one of the other hard varieties that are to be included in the program. For cheese -- one of the most concentrated foods known -- is important on two counts.

Eight major objections to the OPA's new rayon hosiery regulation MPR 339 were announced yesterday by the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute in a communication to Deputy Price Administrator Clyde Herring, who has advised the group that the regulation is to be reconsidered and that careful attention will be given to the order's effect on dry goods wholesalers.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- The Office of Price Administration received another judicial rebuke today when Judge Philip C. Sullivan in the Federal court refused to issue an injunction against C. Quinlan, Inc., wholesale meat dealers, charged with selling veal for 25 cents per hundred pounds above the OPA ceiling price.

CHUNGKING, China, March 23 (U.P.) -- Fighting in the Hupeh-Hunan border area south of the Yangtze River continues to fluctuate inconclusively the Chinese High Command reported tonight, but Chinese forces have scored successes in a diversionary offensive against the Japanese in Central Hupeh, north of the Yangtze.

Mayor La Guardia arose at 4:25 Tuesday morning and dashed to City Hall. Soon 76,708 air raid wardens, 6,453 extra policemen, a little army of extra firemen, auxiliary policemen, auxiliary firemen and others whose duties authorize and require them to be abroad when real or make-believe enemy planes come over were in the streets and at their posts.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 23 (AP) -- A communique:

There are advantages in being not only the leader of a militant organization but its only member. Such is the case of the man who called himself the founder of the Gray Shirts of America and who seems to have constituted the whole enrollment.

The Book-of-the-Month Club announces a dual selection for June -- "Combined Operations: The Official Story of the British Commandos," to be published by Macmillan, and "Winter's Tales," by Isak Dinesen, to be published by Random House.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The four Senators, whose quarterback is Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota and who are the authors of what is becoming known as the B2H2 resolution (for Ball, Burton of Ohio, Hatch of New Mexico and Hill of Alabama), are pressing their proposal so vigorously that many may not realize it is only one of several to the same general purpose.

While the battle in Russia seesaws back and forth in what Hitler himself describes as a German effort to stabilize the Eastern Front the attention of the world shifts to Africa, where the Western Allies have launched a Spring offensive on a major scale to drive the Germans and Italians into the sea, and open up the soft underbelly of the Axis for an invasion of the European continent.

Kenneth Leslie, editor of The Protestant, declared here last night that "it is our immediate duty, without any further delay, to switch this war into an anti-Fascist war, severing our ties with Finland and Spain, and opening a second front through .the west into the heart of Europe in such fashion that will establish, in living deed, a basis for understanding and confidence between Russia and the West."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 23 -- British Eighth Army infantry, after two days of furious fighting, established a bridgehead through the main Mareth Line position along the coastal road to Gabes today, according to the latest reports from the battlefield, while the main body of the Eighth Army hammered its way through the outer perimeter of the enemy's positions.

Colby M. Chester, general chairman of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City, announced yesterday a contribution of $350,000 by the George F. Baker Charity Trust of 2 Wall Street. This gift, one of the largest yet received by the fund, was $100,000 greater than that made by the trust a year ago.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 23 -- The Dixie Walker Marching and Chowder Club of Flatbush can go into training immediately, for Brooklyn's most popular Dodger will be doing his stuff at Ebbets Field again this year.

Men's wear campaigns for the Spring season will not get under way for another week or so and may be delayed if the weather does not become more favorable, retail executives indicated yesterday. The extremely late Easter this year is another factor delaying the release of newspaper campaigns on Spring clothing and furnishings.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture has announced that the Commodity Credit Corporation made 533,232 loans on 405,501,606 bushels of 1942 wheat totaling $458,262,794 through March 13.

Long Island duckling is having its day as a result of the growing poultry and meat shortage, it was disclosed yesterday by United States Department of Agriculture reports showing that receipts of Long Island dressed ducks here since Jan. 1 totaled 358,957 pounds compared with 9,129 pounds for the corresponding period last year.

Down on Lafayette Street, where for many years the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital has tended to the sick and the strays of the animal kingdom, ailing dogs and cats are getting a special kind of attention these days.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 23 -- Legislative conferees rejected tonight the "suggestion" of Governor Warren that the proposed California Farm Production Council, which would deal with the agricultural labor shortage, should not be composed exclusively of farmers, but should have as a voting member the State Director of Industrial Relations, Paul Scharrenberg.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Preliminary moves aimed at the eventual granting of relief to importers of finished goods who complain they now are caught in a serious price "squeeze" as a result of the General Maximum Price Regulation were started here today when the Office of Price Administration arranged for meetings with importers in New York two weeks hence.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -What this country needs to meet an admitted ineffective use of war manpower is not a national service compulsion law, such as is proposed in the Austin-Wadsworth bill, but "a clear mandate from Congress of authority to mobilize the industry and resources of the country for all-out war," R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., told a Senate committee today.

A General Sessions jury, after deliberating five hours, returned yesterday a not-guilty verdict in the trial of three Negro youths in the hold-up of Dr. Henry K. Cudmore, a physician, known as the "White Angel" of Harlem. Dr. Cudmore was severely beaten and robbed on the night of Jan. 4 in the tenement at 59 East 117th Street when he responded to a telephone call to attend a charity case there.

Clarence Adler and the National Orchestral Association Alumni Orchestra, Leon Barzin conducting, gave last night at Town Hall the sixth and final concert in the Mozart Concerto series that began in the Fall.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- At least $20,000,000 of residential construction, providing 3,000 new homes and 2,000 remodeled units, was authorized today by the National Housing Agency for the Chicago metropolitan area in an interim quota.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, March 23 -- Australia has acted as far as she is able to meet with her own resources the growing menace of the Japanese concentration in the network of islands to the north. This was made evident today by Prime Minister John Curtin's announcement that the Australian Ninth Division had been withdrawn from the Mediterranean theatre and brought back to Australia.

WASHINGTON, March 23 - The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing deportation to the seat of their governments-in-exile of deserting alien seamen who are nationals of Axis occupied countries.

MOSCOW, March 23 (AP) -- Fifteen thousand copies of "Why the United States Fights Against Hitlerite Germany," by Alexander A. Troyanovsky, former Soviet Ambassador to Washington, have been placed on sale in the Soviet Union, it was announced today.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 23 (AP) -- Dr. Clarence W. Spears, director of athletics and head football coach of the University of Toledo, Toledo, Ohio, has been appointed head football coach at the University of Maryland, President H.C. Byrd announced today.

Mary Graham Bonner, widely known author of children's books, was announced last night as the 1942 winner of the Constance Lindsay Skinner Award. The presentation was made at the annual dinner of the Women's National Book Association, held at the New Weston Hotel.

CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co. and subsidiaries reported today net income for 1942 of $33,946,989, equivalent to $5.87 a share on the outstanding common stock. Net income for the previous year was $36,711,504, or $6.35 a share.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Roosevelt has named Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley as his personal representative in the Near and Middle East war theatres. General Hurley may make another trip to Russia, where he has talked with Premier Stalin and visited the Stalingrad front, the President said.

By a vote of 19 to 4, the City Council yesterday officially buried Mayor La Guardia's proposal to abolish the Board of Education's Bureau of Supplies on grounds of "inefficiency and wastefulness" and to transfer its functions to the City Department of Purchase.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- America's stepped-up air offensive against the Japanese force on Kiska Island, it developed today, is designed primarily to prevent the enemy from accomplishing the almost impossible task of building an airfield on the mountainous Aleutians base.

AT THE MARETH LINE, March 22 (Delayed) -- Throughout last night engineers were at work making a causeway across Wadi Zigzau. It was a hard job, for the causeway had to be of sufficient strength to bear the weight of the best part of the British Eighth Army's armor, which is now ready to pour through into territory that the enemy held until yesterday and defended with a system of fortifications inherited from the French.

LONDON, March 23 (UP) -- Prime Minister Churchill, defending his son Randolph, in the House of Commons today, said bitterly that the younger Churchill was being attacked in the same way as were the four sons of President Roosevelt who are in the fighting services.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 23 -- Charges made by Colonel George Drew, Progressive Conservative Leader in the Ontario Legislature, and by a Washington correspondent of a New York newspaper regarding the financing of the Ship-shaw power plant of the Aluminum Company of Canada provoked this afternoon a stormy scene in the usually placid Canadian House of Commons and an explanation from C.D. Howe, Munitions Minister, which was finally applauded by a large majority of members.

Simplicity of style and beauty of pelt were artistically combined by Alfred Rainer in his showing of fur originals yesterday at luncheon in the Oval Room of the Hotel Ritz Carlton. Furs for immediate Spring wear and an advance glimpse of designs for next Fall were included.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 284 United States soldiers missing in action in the European, North African and Pacific areas and at sea in the North Atlantic.

ALBANY, March 23 -- Mayor La Guardia made his heralded trip to Albany today to get from the legislative leaders of both parties approval for additional taxing powers for New York City. He came by plane, conferred for an hour and left by train without any definite commitment; yet he seemed to have made a dent in the legislators' resolution not to give him anything at the current seasion.

It is reported from Berne, Europe's busiest rumor factory, that Mussolini and Laval are about to meet in Rome. Such a report, even if it turns out to be true this time, is of very slight importance except as it fits in with rumors that Hungary is making advances toward Serbia and that Finnish trade delegates going to Turkey have more in mind than the renewal of a commercial treaty.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Senate approved by a vote of 74 to 3 today the Finance Committee's recommendation to revoke President Roosevelt's salary limitation order, thus adding its rebuke of the President to that administered by the House on March 12. The House vote was 268 to 129.

Because of the illness of George Coulouris, the opening of "Richard III" at the Forrest has been postponed from tonight until Friday evening. Mr. Coulouris, who has the leading role and who has directed the production, was taken ill Monday evening after a dress rehearsal, according to his spokesman.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Wheat futures fluctuated in an aimless manner during the greater part of today's session on the Board of Trade. Selling by houses with Northwestern connections, presumably representing spreading with Winnipeg, held prices down for a time, but late in the day there was a good rally on buying induced by reports that the Steagall bill would be passed by the House within a day or so.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, March 22 (Delayed) (AP) -- Rear Admiral Richmond K. Turner of Carmel, Calif., 57-year-old commander of amphibious forces, today received the Distinguished Service Medal from Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., for "Distinguished service in a position of great responsibility."

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Deliberate faking of analyses of the quality and strength of an estimated 28,000 to 36,000 tons of sub-standard steel to meet the specifications of war orders at the Irvin plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Corporation was charged and admitted today before the Special Senate (Truman) Committee investigating the war program.

LAKEWOOD, N. J., March 23 -- An icy wind whistled through the murmuring pines and hemlocks today and, whether it was because the tune was a merry one or the bite of the gale had plenty of sting to it, there is no denying the Giants moved at top speed as they returned to their outdoor drilling.

LONDON, March 23 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force threw nearly 300 four-motored bombers against the battered U-boat base at St. Nazaire last night and lost only one plane, the Air Ministry reported today. Returning pilots described how large fires took hold on the docks of the Nazi-used French port.

The right of a representative of the Soviet Consul General to appear in behalf of Latvian citizens who allegedly fled into Russia after the Nazi invasion of their country, was denied yesterday by Surrogate James A. Delehanty in a proceeding involving the $3,300,000 American estate of Captain Fricis Vilnis Grauds, Latvian shipowner.

Tonight`s events: NBC Symphony Orchestra, Arturo Toscanini conducting, Carnegie HaII, 8:30 o'clock; Nelson Eddy, baritone, Town Hall, 8:30; Robert Goldsand, pianist, in Beethoven sonata series, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.

Johnny McCall, 17 years old, of 3459 Morgan Avenue, the Bronx, was quite the cut-up Monday afternoon. He climbed down into the pandas' pen in the Bronx Zoo to play with Pan-Dee, 190-pound male, and Pan-Dah, the 203-pound female. Johnny chased the pandas for a while and then the pandas chased Johnny -- right out of their pen.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The chiefs of diplomatic missions from the United States to the twenty Latin American republics were placed on the same plane today when President Roosevelt asked the Senate to promote to the rank of Ambassadors the Ministers to the five Central-American republics, the Dominican Republic and Haiti.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 23 (U.P.) -- Top-seeded Miss Pauline M. Betz of Los Angeles meets Miss Lillian Lopaus of City Island, N.Y., tomorrow in the top bracket of the semi-final round of the women's national indoor tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club's covered courts.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Governor Dewey accepted today in a one sentence letter the resignation of Dr. William J. Tiffany, Commissioner of Mental Hygiene, a Democratic holdover.
PANAMA, March 23 (AP) -- Following is the text of Vice President Henry A. Wallace's address today before the Bolivar Society:

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 23 -An Army fighter plane crashed into the Barnard Hall Science Building of Hofstra College at 5:15 o'clock this morning, bursting into flames after ripping a gaping hole in the two-story brick building and killing the pilot.

ALBANY, March 23 -- The Republican housing program won approval in the Assembly today, with the principal measure, the Hampton-Mitchell urban redevelopment bill, going to the Governor for signature. It was debated at some length.

DHOLPUR, Rajaputana, India, March 19 (Delayed) -- How deeply Mohandas K. Gandhi's latest fast has touched the heart of old India is to be seen here in Dholpur with its intensely religious paternalistic ruler.
A German High Command communique, as broadcast by the German radio and by The Associated Press:

Boatmen using Peter's Dock in Whitestone Landing have banded together in an effort to help the war effort. Starting on April 2, from the dock at the foot of 151st Street, Whitestone, open and party boats will be run up the Sound for flounders and blacks.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The question whether foremen are to be treated as employes under the National Labor Relations Act will be the subject of a public hearing, April 6, before the National Labor Relations Board.

Estimating that at least 500,000 families in the United States borrowed a minimum of $100,000,000 to pay their March income taxes, Syd J. Hughes, vice president of the Morris Plan Bank of New York, said in a statement issued yesterday that a minimum of 50, 000 families in New York City had borrowed "a conservatively estimated" $10,000,000 from banks and lending agencies to meet the first quarter tax payments.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 -- San Francisco's Chinatown, which sheltered and encouraged Dr. Sun Yat Sen some three decades ago in his efforts to rebuild a new China and has sent more than $5,000,000 since 1937 to the government of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek for the same purpose, was preparing today to give a colorful welcome to China's First Lady.

The five-story factory at 221-27 Powell Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the East Brooklyn Savings Bank to a client of Kalmon Dolgin, Inc., broker. This building is on a plot 100 by 100 feet and contains about 50,000 square feet of space.

MIAMI, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- A stanch United States freighter salvaged last April after an attack by enemy raiders met her final fate in February when an Axis submarine sent her down in the Atlantic off the west coast of Africa.

Predicting a decline of 25 per cent in production of softwoods in the northeastern States this year, and a drop of 30 to 40 per cent in hardwood output, the Northeastern Lumber Manufactures Association has called upon Congress for help following several unsuccessful attempts to obtain an upward revision of ceilings from the Office of Price Administration.

LONDON, Wednesday, March 24 -- Strong German forces that smashed against the Moscow-Bryansk trunk rail line north of Zhizdra have been beaten back in four days of violent fighting, which cost them 7,000 officers and men in killed alone, Moscow announced today.

Preliminary work in converting facilities of the Continental Can Company to war production has been largely completed and first deliveries are being made on some contracts, Carle C. Conway, chairman of the company, said yesterday at the annual meeting held at Millbrook, N.Y.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 24 (U.P.) -- Miss Pauline M. Betz of Los Angeles, top-seeded, will face Miss Katherine Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass., ranked second, tomorrow in the finals of the women's national indoor singles tennis championships at the Longwood Cricket Club's covered courts.

LONDON, March 24 -- Major Gen. Ira C. Eaker, commander of the Eighth United States Air Force, held his first formal press conference today for American and British correspondents. It was held, he said, because the experimental phase of United States operation in the air over Europe had been concluded.

LONDON, March 24 (Reuter) -The Danish general election -- the only parliamentary election held in any European country except Iceland since the war -- has yielded an overwhelming majority for the democratic ideal.

The Erie Railroad Company awarded yesterday to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., of Chicago and Otis Co. of Cleveland the issue of $10,000,000 one-to-ten-year collateral trust notes on their bid of 100.145 for a coupon rate of 3 1/8 per cent.

Resumption of active buying by the trade yesterday extended gains in the cotton futures market, raising quotations to the highest levels for the life of the six active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange. The market ended with net gains of 3 to 9 points, with the near months strongest.

NEW DELHI, India, March 24 (U.P.) -- American fliers, continuing their attacks on Japanese supply lines in Burma, have struck new blows at the Gokteik viaduct and the Myitgne bridge, both vital to enemy transportation in the occupied territory, the Tenth United States Air Force reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee agreed unanimously today to submit all pending and impending resolutions relating to post-war settlements and cooperation among the United Nations to a subcommittee of eight members, to be appointed and headed by Senator Connally, chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -Conscription of civilians for war work, as proposed by the Austin-Wadsworth bill, would be not only a negation of democracy but probably also practically unworkable, asserted Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, appearing as a witness today before the Military Affairs Committee of the Senate.
CHUNGKING, China, March 24 -- The entire Chungking daily press, except for the official Central Daily News, comments today on Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech Sunday.

PITTSBURGH, March 24 -- Officials of the United States Steel Corporation started today an investigation of personnel and conditions at the Irvin Works of the corporation, a Carnegie-Illinois Steel subsidiary, to determine the responsibility for the delivery to the government of sub-standard steel for war use.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 24 -- British and American collaboration in the air tightened yesterday as Royal Air Force bombardiers and gunners flew with American crews from a field that sent thousands of pounds of bombs against a German armored division attacking American infantry southeast of El Guettar.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 24 -- Italian-German negotiations for a "definite and satisfactory settlement'' of the Reich's outstanding clearing debt to Italy of some 7,000,000,000 lire were reliably reported tonight to have reached a deadlock in Rome.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 24 -- In the wake of more confusion than ever involved the Dodgers in the most zany moments of their colorful past, President Branch Rickey finally announced at 8:45 o'clock tonight that he had acquired Bobby Bragan, 24-year-old shortstop-catcher, from the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -The President awarded Congressional Medals to Major Kenneth D. Bailey and Major Robert E. Galer, Marine Corps. He saw Senator Green of Rhode Island, Emil Ludwig, Secretary Knox and Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, Secretary Hull, Randolph Paul, Treasury counsel, and Dr. Vannevar Bush, regent of the Smithsonian Institution.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, head of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, agreed today to reopen talks looking to an end of jurisdictional raiding.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The House accepted this afternoon the Senate's revision of its bill which, in effect, revokes President Roosevelt's order limiting salaries to $25,000 net. The report of the conferees was adopted by a vote of 297 to 46.
LONDON, Thursday, March 25 (U.P.) -- The Wednesday midnight communique as broadcast by Moscow:

Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, warned last night that "there is some danger that our country may go totalitarian" unless the free enterprise system, which has worked so well in the war, is allowed to function without governmental domination in peacetime.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Crown Prince Olav and Crown Princess Martha of Norway attended a reception given in their honor last evening by representatives of the diplomatic corps, in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria, at which 400 prominent guests attended and $5,000 was raised for the benefit of Norwegian charities.

PANAMA, March 24 -- A nineteen-gun salute, the only ceremony of departure for Vice President Henry A. Wallace, today sped him on his way to Chile for the first of his South American visits. He already has visited Costa Rica and has just completed in Panama a full three-day program.

Hundreds of American soldiers wounded over the bombing ranges of Europe and on the battlefields of North Africa are being treated at the huge new Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island, according to Colonel Ralph G. DeVoe, Army Medical Corps veteran in charge.

BERNE, March 24 -- Thirteen more death sentences have been passed on Alsatians by the section of the Reich high court sitting temporarily in Strasbourg for the purpose of eradicating "treason." Of twenty-seven persons accused, fourteen were sent to forced labor for long terms.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Restaurants will be restricted, starting Monday, to three-fourths or less of the meat they used last December, the Office of Price Administration announced tonight in the wake of its disclosure that eaters-at-home must get along on an over-all average total of no more than two pounds a week of high-grade meat, cheese and butter per person.
Finnish communique as broadcast by the German radio and recorded by The United Press:

Ohio State University yesterday entered a twelve-man team, headed by Bill Smith, freshman record-breaker from Hawaii, and Kiyoshi Nakama, also of Hawaii, in the fifty-fifth annual National A.A.U. indoor swimming championship scheduled for April 2 and 3 at the New York A.C.

DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- Ice hockey is so fast that even the players sometimes don't know what's going on, and that was the case today following the Toronto Maple Leafs' drawn-out National League play-off victory over the Red Wings that tied their series at one game each.
