A warning that the public should study values of securities before investing was issued yesterday by Fred C. Moffatt, president of the New York Curb Exchange. Earlier in the month, Mr. Moffatt recalled, Emil Schram of the New York Stock Exchange pointed out that many "raw" investors appeared to be buying stocks that had no virtue other than low prices.

LONDON, March 24 (U.P.) -- The Vichy Government charged tonight that the United Nations had started a propaganda campaign to "shatter the morale of the French people" as a forerunner to a continental invasion.

Property of the estates of Arnold Genthe and Agnes H. Forbes of this city, as well as property of Irving J. Marantz, South Norwalk, Conn., and others, was sold at auction yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc., for $10,577.
Leases in apartment buildings along the West Side from Fourteenth Street to the Dyckman section formed the bulk of renting in Manhattan yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Office of Price Administration issued today the following questions and answers on meat rationing:

LONDON, March 24 -- Baron Bruntisfield, Parliamentary Secretary to the Admiralty, assured the House of Lords today that as a result of recent conferences in Washington the organization of Atlantic convoys, together with their protection by sea and air, would be further improved and simplified.

Two guides for spending the red stamps in War Ration Book No. 2 have been prepared by this department, which has been poring over the Official Table of Consumer Point Values for Meat, Fats, Fish and Cheese. These guides were designed for a family of four, hava total of sixty-four points weekly.

ASBURY PARE, N.J., March 24 -- Joe McCarthy was like the sun here today. He was beaming, and not without reason. For the Yankees, hampered since their arrival by unfavorable weather conditions, got in their first real training workout.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 24 -- Manager Mel Ott took full advantage of the return to good weather today. There was still a bit of a snap in the air, but there was a clear sky and a bright sun and all this added up to a Giant workout that lasted another full three hours.

CHUNGKING, China, March 24 (UP) -- Colonel Robert F. Tate of the United States Army Air Force today received the Distinguished Service Medal for "exceptionally distinguished and meritorious service while in a position of great responsibilty."
The four fighting sons of Mrs. Catherine Breen came home from the wars on her fifty-sixth birthday yesterday to reunite the seagoing Breen family for the first time in three years.

A labor program to increase war production will be sought by the National Association of Manufacturers, it was announced yesterday, through a new industrial relations policy committee. This committee will hold its first meeting at a dinner at 6:30 o'clock tonight in the Biltmore Hotel.

ALBANY, March 24 -- With only two more days to go, the chances of action on New York City's tax problems at the current session of the Legislature dwindled further today, while the probability of a special session in May or June increased.

LONDON, Thursday, March 25 (AP) -- For the first time in weeks Nazi bombers raided Scotland early today after a raid yesterday on a southeastern English town where more than twelve persons were killed.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- At a press conference today Elmer Davis, the OWI chief, assailed Republican members of Congress as attacking his organization "for doing the job Congress directed it to do." He said the attacks which got publicity invariably came from members who made no attempt to learn the facts before they gave tongue.

Although the circus isn't scheduled to come to town until April, there'll be a three-ring affair today up at Stillman's Gymnasium when Henry Armstrong, one-time king in three boxing divisions, starts work for his bout with Beau Jack, one-time Augusta bootblack, in Madison Square Garden on April 2.

LONDON, Thursday, March 25 -- Red Army troops, fighting stubborn battles through long-established and strong German fortifications on the central front, captured several more inhabited points yesterday in a continuing advance on the big Nazi base of Smolensk, Moscow announced today.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Attempts of the Democrats to bring to the floor their proposal to reduce the voting age in the State from 21 to 18 were defeated in the Senate today. By a vote of 19 to 30 the Republican majority defeated a motion to discharge the proposed constitutional amendment from committee, and this is tantamount to defeat of the measure.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Describing voyages made in 1941 to carry war materials for the British to the Red Sea as "a bargain freely entered into which turned out profitably" for the shipping lines, a spokesman for six of the lines involved stated today that they had no intention of acceding voluntarily to suggestions for return of some of the profits.

A threat of a butchers' strike, in protest against "unfair" and "illegal" price-fixing on meat by the Office of Price Administration, was made last night at a meeting of 400 meat dealers called by the Retail Meat Dealers Protective Association of Greater New York in the Knights of Columbus Institute, 81 Hansen Place, Brooklyn.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 24 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin said today that Prime Minister Churchill's broadcast address last Sunday did not change the strategical problems of the Pacific, and that present Allied global strategy committed Australia to a long "holding" war against the Japanese.

An aura of pink cast its flattering glow over the new Spring collection of custom made clothes shown yesterday by Lange, Inc., during luncheon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The designer took his cue from the Ziegfeld Follies where pink in all its variations was used as a color to make lovely women appear lovelier.

With the arrest of three boys, whose ages range from 10 to 13, on charges of juvenile delinquency, the police disclosed yesterday that 11-year-old Thomas Reidy of 547 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn, had been mugged and robbed of 18 cents as he was entering the building in which he lives on Tuesday evening.

Representatives of packing houses were not certain yesterday that the meat supplies that will be available in the metropolitan district will be sufficient every week to supply each consumer with the quantity his ration points entitle him to buy.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- An American submarine surprised, torpedoed and sank a Japanese submarine in the far Pacific so quickly that the Japanese "never knew what hit them," the Navy disclosed today in telling the story of an undersea boat commanded by Lieut. Comdr. William Edward Ferrall of Pittsburgh.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, March 23 (Delayed) -- Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel is now engaged in an all-out and desperate effort to dislodge our elements from the bridgehead that they achieved on the first and second nights of the British Eighth Army's attack.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- If the Seventy-eighth Congress had not in several ways announced to the executive department that it intends to make the laws hereafter, and look to the Executive for enforcement only and not for legislation, Senator George's warning to this effect yesterday might be treated cavalierly by the administrators, as often before.

The New York Institute for the Education of the Blind at 999 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, has become Victory Garden conscious. Yesterday thirty Boy and Girl Scouts, some partly, others totally, blind, broke ground for a Victory Garden that in time will cover six acres and help supply the institute's commisary.

Sales of products and services by the United States Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries last year amounted to $1,865,951,692, or 18.7 per cent more than in the previous best year, 1941, and 38.8 per cent above World War I's peak of $1,344,600,000, according to the annual report made public yesterday by Irving S. Olds, chairman.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Work of regional consumer and distributor cooperatives will become more efficient as a result of the incorporation of the National Cooperative Finance Association, it was announced here today at the meeting of the Cooperative League.

The volume of domestic orders booked by the Otis Elevator Company in 1942 was the largest in the history of the concern, it reported yesterday. The total, $92,819,862, compared with $54,710,471 in 1941.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Giving a dinner for guests is going to be a difficult problem under meat rationing.

Tomorrow is Greek Independence Day. One hundred and twenty-two years ago Archbishop Germanos hoisted the standard of the Cross at Kalavryta. It was the signal for the Greeks that started their war of liberation from Turkish rule, imposed upon them since the fall of the Byzantine Empire in 1453.

The former residence of the late Adrian H. Larkin at 61 East Eighty-second Street has been sold by Mrs. Margaret Foster to an advertising executive who will occupy it. The house is a modern structure with a frontage of twenty feet and was bought by Mrs. Foster last December, but was never occupied by her.

LONDON, March 24 -- In the stock markets today speculative interest continued in the Kaffir mining shares but prices turned irregular on the news from Tunisia. Blyvoor, after reaching a new high mark of 57 shillings, reacted to 56 1/2.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- Diana Barrymore has been assigned to one of the two feminine leads in Universal's "Fired Wife," which will go into production April 15, with Charles Lamont directing. The film is a revamped version of "Marriage of Inconvenience," shelved in December, 1941, because of casting difficulties.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Expectations that the Steagall bill would be passed by the House of Representatives before the end of the day imparted considerable strength today to the grain markets. Wheat, oats and rye were up around 1 cent a bushel at the extreme, with short covering and commission-house buying in evidence.

The program of four city departments to salvage manpower from the ranks of the "Bowery bums" and other homeless men has already shown most encouraging results, it was reported yesterday by First Deputy Commissioner Edward E. Rhatigan of the Department of Welfare.

A man who could have poisoned Adolf Hitler's pastry has been seized here by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Besides this, the bureau has unmasked as a Japanese a "Chinese" lecturer on the "corruption" of the political set-up in China.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Establishment of "a service of supply" for civilians holding equal authority with the armed services' agencies of similar character, by setting up a civilian supply agency outside the jurisdiction of the War Production Board and answerable only to James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, was advocated today by Joseph L. Weiner, director of WPB's Office of Civilian Supply.

Plans for the double-header involving the Yankees, Giants and Dodgers at the Yankee Stadium on Wednesday, April 14, were completed yesterday at a meeting in the Municipal Building among Mayor La Guardia, Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, which will benefit, and executives of the three clubs.
The overwhelming vote of 74 to 3 in the Senate, rescinding the $25,000 salary limitation order, is an even sharper rebuke to the President's action than the vote in the House.

LONDON, March 24 -- Britain's drab wartime diet has been a boon to the national health, Sir Wilson Jameson, Chief British Medical Officer, declared today in presenting statistics that must be highly encouraging to all friends of these 40,000,000 islanders who took the worst Adolf Hitler had to offer and came up apparently stronger than ever.

LONDON, March 24 (AP) -- Sir Archibald Sinclair, Secretary of State for Air, announced today in the House of Commons that four of the five directors of the British Overseas Airways Corporation had resigned after a dispute with the Air Ministry on one point of working with the new Royal Air Force Transport Command.

LONDON, March 24 -- Archbishop Francis Spellman of New York today had luncheon with Prime Minister Winston Churchill at 10 Downing Street, visited Admiral Harold R. Stark and received John McCormack, famous singer, whom he assured that a cruet which Mr. McCormack presented to the late Cardinal Hayes fifteen years ago was still used at all pontifical masses in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Despite their individual difficulties with the OPA's price ceilings, retail liquor dealers would rather have them than no price controls at all, it was learned yesterday. Reports that the exemption of whisky, and other luxury products was being considered in official quarters has developed widespread opposition in the retail liquor trade.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24 -The Standard Gas and Electric Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a voluntary plan for recapitalization providing for a reduction of its six issues of notes and debentures and four classes of stock to one short-term loan and one class of common stock.

"I have been," writes J.B.K., "very much interested in the stories I've read and the talk I have heard of the Victory Garden campaign being run throughout the country. In these times it is a great piece of work and one well worthy of support.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Office of Price Administration made public today point values for the meats, fats, oils, canned fish and cheese under rationing which starts Monday. An average weekly ration of about two pounds of meat and half a pound of butter per head was indicated.

The report of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on Feb. 28, issued yesterday by Justin R. Whiting, president, showed a consolidated net income of $11,551,115 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges.

The movement of important canned vegetables to the markets has dropped 60 to 95 per cent under the point-rationing system, according to a report made yesterday by the American Institute of Food Distribution.

CHUNGKING, China, March 24 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have launched a four-pronged drive against Chinese troops harassing their positions in the Kingmen area of Central Hupeh Province, it was announced tonight. A determined attempt by 4,000 of the enemy to crush Chinese resistance in Anhwei Province was reported smashed with heavy losses to the invaders.

Thousands of American women who have taken war plant jobs are finding that safety engineers and not fashion experts are designing the workaday clothes of the nation's womanpower, delegates to the fourteenth annual safety convention and exposition of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania were told yesterday.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 24 -- Bobby Cruickshank retained the lead in the North and South open golf championship today when he scored a 72 for his second round and a 36-hole total of 143. This gave wee Bobby of Richmond, Va., a two-stroke lead over Joe Kirkwood of Philadelphia, whose two rounds are 72, 73 -- 145.

Four thousand stores controlled by the 1,600 members of the Federation of Kosher Butchers of Greater New York will be closed from noon tomorrow until 7 A.M. Monday, in preparation for the installation of the meat-rationing system, it was announced yesterday.

More than 90 per cent of the population of Denmark went to the polls this week and cast an overwhelming vote for democracy. The holding of free elections in a Nazi-dominated country is in itself a remarkable phenomenon, explainable only on the ground that the Germans still miscalculate the extent of their failure in Europe.

BOSTON, March 24 (U.P.) -- Wounded and thrown overboard when the transport Gregory sank, a 23-year-old Coast Guardsman punched and drowned a Japanese sailor after a terrific struggle in Guadalcanal waters, the First Naval District disclosed today.
MOSCOW, March 24 (AP) -- The midday communique:

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- After canvassing Democratic members, Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, the majority whip, predicted tonight that the House will approve a pay-as-you-go tax bill wiping out a substantial part of one year's income levies.

Yonkers, N.Y., yesterday awarded to the Bank of Westchester of Yonkers a new issue of $500,000 of certificates of indebtedness, payable Sept. 10, 1943. The price paid was an 0.50 per cent basis, plus a premium of $50.

The National War Labor Board is making a great mistake in failing to adjust the "Little Steel" formula, which permits only a 15 per cent rise in wage rates compared with Jan. 1, 1941, so as to make it conform to the present-day facts.

NEWARK, N.J., March 24 -- A Negro youth under arrest here on charges of armed robbery has confessed that he committed nine muggings in New York City, holding up his victims at the point of a knife, it was disclosed today by Detective Captain Frank O'Neil.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- President Roosevelt conferred the Congressional Medal of Honor today on two Marine Corps majors (one of whom died in defense of Henderson Field on Guadalcanal) for heroic conduct in action in the Solomon Islands area last year.

Plans to recruit between 15,000 and 25,000 youthful farm aides to help in berry patches, on dairy farms and in rural kitchens this season were revealed yesterday by a joint committee representing the Camp Fire Girls, the Girl Reserve Staff of the Young Women's Christion Association and the Girl Scouts.

JERUSALEM, March 23 -- Preliminary investigations designed to provide for Palestine a social security plan resembling in some particulars the plan proposed for Great Britain by Sir William Beveridge have been announced in Jerusalem.
A liquid diet, in the words of a certain authority on feminine refurbishment, is just as beneficial to the face as to the "figger."

Dr. Simon Flexner, who guided the growth of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research from its fledgling days into maturity as an organization of world-wide scope and importance, cast a backward glance yesterday on the eve of his eightieth birthday.

CAMP ATTERBURY, Ind., March 24 (AP) -- Many members of the recently formed Austrian battalion in training at this Army center are refugees from that country, but they are so busy with combat training routine that they have little time for reflections on the past.

With rationing scheduled to start for additional foods on Monday, experience to date has shown that it has had little effect on brand preferences, manufacturers and retailers reported yesterday. Sales of canned products have declined, of course, but the decline has been proportionate for all grades, brands and price ranges and cheaper unbranded lines, for example, have not prospered at the expense of branded lines.

Clarence Mitchell, 21-year-old Negro, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to ten to twenty years in Sing Sing for participating, on the night of Jan. 20, with another Negro, Herman Smith, 23, in the hold-up of several passengers on a Seventh Avenue subway train.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -Complaints of hosiery manufacturers and retailers regarding the price regulation on women's rayon hosiery were referred today by Prentiss M. Brown. Price Administrator, to the OPA's Industry Council for examination.

Noami Aleh Leaf made her formal debut last night at the New York Times Hall in a program of "Dances of the Bible and the Near East." Miss Leaf has appeared previously in joint recitals in the Y.M.H.A. dance theatre series and elsewhere in the environs, and her work is accordingly not unknown to dance followers even though this was her first solo program hereabouts.

ALBANY, March 24 (AP) -- New York's wartime food production problems were referred by Governor Dewey today to a new, eleven-member emergency food commission whose leader said it hoped "to foresee and meet situations as they arise."

The United Nations are "a solvent institution" in the field of war materials and can win the war, no matter how prolonged, with the raw materials on hand, William L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board, declared here yesterday at the annual meeting of the Swedish Chamber of Commerce in the United States in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Medical research was nothing to boast of in this country at the opening of the century. Aware of its deficiencies, the late Frederick T. Gates suggested to John D. Rockefeller that money could be spent on it profitably. Out of the suggestion came the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research.

Disregarding the recommendations of its Board of Superintendents and Board of Examiners, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday rejected by a 4-2 vote the nomination of Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, for the $7,500 position of adult education director.

Vice President Wallace's remark about people who might be tempted to double-cross Soviet Russia was called unfortunate because it was so untimely. But we must remember one thing about words which people call untimely.

Industrial shares led the stock markets to higher ground yesterday and, despite spottiness among the railway issues, the list on the New York Stock Exchange closed strong, with a firm undertone. Sales there were 1,161,080 shares, bringing the number of million-share days this year to thirty, against nine for all 1942.

Mrs. Vincent Sheean (Diana Forbes-Robertson) and Francis Merriam will be guests on the "Fighting Words" program next Saturday from 6:45 to 7 P.M. over WMCA. Stanley Rinehart of Farrar Rinehart will do the interviewing.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- The Revitalized Smaller War Plants Corporation was divorced almost completely from the War Production Board today and set up as a virtually autonomous agency to get war contracts into the plants of little business men.

The campaign started last November by the Federal Reserve authorities to encourage commercial banks to qualify as depositaries for government funds is beginning to bear fruit, it was revealed yesterday by figures released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 24 -- Flags, dragon kites and streamers flew in profusion today in the largest Chinese city outside the Orient, as San Francisco's Chinatown put last-minute touches on its preparations to welcome Mme. Chiang Kai-shek tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- In 1942, our first war year, Americans spent more for consumer goods and services than ever before, the Commerce Department reported today.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- While German pressure on the Donets River line appears to be slackening the heaviest fighting reported today was in the Belgorod sector, where the enemy struck northward yesterday without avail after being driven from a temporary lodgment keep a tight cheek on the impulse.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 24 (AP) -- War plane production in Germany and the countries she dominates has dropped from a peak of 3,000 a month to about 2,000 a month within the last year, an industrial engineer thoroughly familiar with Nazi war economy declared today.

A joint statement of policy by the Secretaries of War, Navy, the Treasury and the Chairman of the Maritime Commission outlining the general lines to be followed in dealing with termination of contracts during the war was urged yesterday by Eric A. Camman, partner in Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co.

LONDON, March 24 -- The political complications that arose after Prime Minister Winston Churchill's broadcast sketch of Britain's post-war foreign and domestic roles began today to smooth themselves out.

Men 38 years old or more who desire a discharge from the Army to enter essential industry may now register for employment at the office of the United States Employment Service of the War Manpower Commission nearest their camp, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the commission, announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, March 24 -- Francisco Javier Gaxiola, Minister of National Economy, conveyed today to the press an appeal of President Manuel Avila Camacho to cooperate with the government in its effort to stabilize prices and check the cost of living.

ST. LOUIS, March 24 (AP) -- Johnny Mize, the Giants' first baseman, took his examination at Jefferson Barracks today for possible induction into the armed forces, but officers at the induction center said the results of his tests would not be known before tomorrow.

Outlining an extensive program of war work, W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, disclosed yesterday in his report for 1942 that the concern and its subsidiaries set new records in the petroleum, utility and natural gas fields.

With the cooperation of her entire company, Katharine Cornell has reserved this afternoon for a special matinee of "The Three Sisters." The Red Cross will be the beneficiary, with the entire gross, it was announced, being turned over to that organization.
NEW YORK The Countess of Gainsborough and her daughter, Lady Maureen Noel, who were at Essex House for several weeks, have gone to Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- An indictment charging sixteen flour milling corporations, eleven of their executives and their national trade association with conspiring to fix prices of flour sold throughout the country was returned today by a Federal grand jury before Judge John P. Barnes. The indictment was the first such action here.

When bids for supplying 62,600,000 square yards of unbleached raincoat materials are opened April 8 by the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot, it will mark the adoption of a new program whereby the depot will supply all the necessary piece goods to raincoat contractors in the future, it was reported yesterday in the Worth Street market.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A bill directing the price control authorities not to include benefit payments or government subsidies of any kind in computing prices of farm products was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 24 -- Johnny Murphy, who certainly should know, enjoys his role of relief pitcher for the Yankees. He did not enjoy it too much last year when he had a bad season. But he believes that he has regained both his health and the hop on his fast one to such an extent that he is looking forward to the coming campaign with complete complacency.

Marking the completion of their training, twenty-nine nurse's aides received their graduate Red Cross nurses' aide caps and pins yesterday afternoon from Miss Bessie Parker, director of Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing at a ceremony held in the hospital's board room.
With 2,100 theatres throughout the country already lined up to show it, a play entitled "It's Up to You" will open here next week to teach Americans how to conserve food and fight black markets.

LONDON, March 24 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's remarks in the House of Commons today regarding the Tunisian fighting, in response to a question from the deputy Labor party leader, Arthur Greenwood:

The Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company announced yesterday the borrowing of $12,000,000 in the form of a five-year sinking fund loan from a group of banks, insurance companies and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, at an average interest rate of 4 1/4 per cent, to refund outstanding indebtedness.

It will be Georgetown against De Paul in the Eastern final of the National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship at Madison Square Garden tonight. For last night on the same court the Hoyas came through with a surprisingly easy triumph over New York University, 55 -- 36, after the Blue Demons from Chicago had conquered Dartmouth, 46 -- 35.

Disturbed by hospitals' assertions that their continued operation was jeopardized by the rationing of processed foods, the Regional Office of Price Administration here said yesterday that the present rules provided a simple method by which hospitals could get supplemental allowances.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 24 (AP) -- The Danish people, smarting under the yoke of the occupying Germans, gave a smashing demonstration for democracy as the count came in today from yesterday's parliamentary elections.

A contribution of $150,000 from the Carnegie Corporation of New York to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund was announced yesterday by Colby M. Chester, general chairman of the War Fund, which is now seeking to raise $12,920,700 in this city as part of the nation-wide campaign to raise $125,000,000 for the American Red Cross.

The threat of a strike in the Northern Appalachian region, employing 172,000 of the country's 450,000 soft coal miners, was staved off yesterday when representatives of the United Mine Workers and operators of the Northern Appalachian area signed an agreement extending their wage negotiations for one month if no accord is reached by April 1, when the current contract expires.

One might feel reassured by the item in THE TIMES this morning that four Harlem and Washington Heights clergymen, after conference with high police officials, announce that "there is no crime wave in Harlem," if it were not for their additional statement that "what has been happening is essentially a social condition."

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The tax plans which will receive most attention in the four days of debate opening in the House tomorrow are the Ways and Means Committee bill, the Carlson bill and the Forand bill. Here are features of the measures:

Stocks of the principal oil products on the East Coast declined to a new low record last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The index of the institute, covering gasoline and light and heavy fuel oils on the Atlantic Coast, at the close of last week stood at 29.2, compared with 29.9 at the end of the previous week and 58.3 on Nov. 7, when the current downward trend started.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The bill which was passed quietly by the Legislature several weeks ago to enable Mayor La Guardia to enter the armed forces without losing his post as Mayor or control over the city administration was amended in the Assembly today, but not quietly.

The forty-three-story office skyscraper at the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and Fortieth Street, known as 22 East Fortieth Street, was sold yesterday in one of the largest deals to be closed in recent months in the Grand Central district.

Total dollar volume of leading independent retail grocers throughout the State in the two-week period between the inauguration of points rationing and March 15, dropped 14.6 per cent and sales of the rationed foods declined 73 per cent, according to a survey just completed by the New York State Food Merchants Association.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 24 -- California farm organizations late today won their fight in the Legislature to keep "labor" representation off the Farm Production Council which is to tackle the State's food and farm labor shortage problems.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 24 -- Veteran infantry of the British Eighth Army rebuffed a furious Axis counter-attack today and hacked its way forward in the Mareth Line position as the heaviest fighting of the campaign flared on Tunisia's southern front from Maknassy to Mareth.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Dewey's system of "pre-veto" on legislation he opposes or does not wish to have presented to him suffered a setback today when the Senate Committee on Judiciary reported out, for probable passage tomorrow, the bill legalizing bingo games under some conditions.
"How the Women of the Americas Can Help Keep Their Countries United" is the subject for a conference of women's organizations, to be held at The New York Times Hall on Pan-American Day, April 14.

Two new films will open in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's State the attraction will be "The Powers Girl," a United Artists release featuring George Murphy, Anne Shirley, Carole Landis, Alan Mowbray and Benny Goodman and his orchestra.

ALGIERS, March 24 -- Maurice Couve de Murville has been appointed deputy for civilian affairs to General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa. He replaces General Jean-Marie-Joseph Bergeret, who resigned March 14.

The Toscanini concert given with the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis was not devoted to previously unknown compositions, nor did Mr. Toscanini depart markedly from earlier interpretations of acknowledged masterpieces on the program.
Civilian defense councils were urged yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, regional director of civilian defense, to enlist friendly aliens, whereever local regulations permit their enrollment.

HERVEY ALLEN'S "The Forest and the Fort"* is Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe" in reverse. The first panel in a series of six long novels which will be published individually and collected ultimately under the title of "The Disinherited," it is the story of a white boy who grew up among the Shawnees and later returned to civilization.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses belittled yesterday a suggestion by Walter Hoving, chairman of a committee of city sales tax opponents, that the Mayor's occupancy of Gracie Mansion be discontinued to save the municipality money.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Allied battle for Tunisia is evidently going to be "a long, tough fight which is some distance from a decision," Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, told a press conference today.

In one of the most exciting finals on record, James Madison of Brooklyn attained a 32-to-31 victory and dethroned Andrew Jackson of Queens as the city P.S.A.L. senior high school basketball champion before 8,000 enthusiasts in Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The rationing of meat, allowing 2 to 2 1/4 pounds of steak a person a week, or 3 1-5 pounds of hamburger, will supply a sufficient amount of protein for the requirements of the average adult, provided the prices are kept within the means of the average family, according to nutrition authorities questioned here yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, March 25 (AP) -- Allied aircraft hammered Japanese positions in the Mubo area of New Guinea with a deadly, aerial artillery barrage yesterday in one blow of a busy day aimed at keeping Japanese forces back on their heels throughout much of the Southwest Pacific.

Various bills in the State Legislature to lower the age limit for employment of children and to remove safeguards were scored yesterday by the New York State League of Women Voters as indicating "complete indifference" to the welfare of the children.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 24 (AP) -- The Purdue University atmosphere gives them college spirit and the Boilermaker field house makes it possible to get in excellent physical condition, so the Indians now worry only about a nettlesome first-base situation and a mild shortage of outfielders as they build up for the coming American League season.

For the second year under Axis rule, the hungry, tormented but unconquerable people of Greece observe Independence Day, the 122d anniversary of the first battle for liberation from the Ottoman Empire. Last year students were shot down in Athens for patriotic demonstrations in honor of the day.

Beverage sales in twenty-three transient hotels here jumped 40.9 per cent over last year during February and totaled $1,339,513, Harris, Kerr, Forster Co., hotel accountants, reported yesterday. The largest gains, averaging 46 per cent, were found in the Central Park area, followed by increases of 45.8 per cent in the Times Square zone and 44.8 per cent in the Pennsylvania section.

Frits Reiner will begin tonight at Carnegie Hall, two weeks as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony as the orchestra goes into its last four weeks of the season. Tonight's program consists of Brahms's Second symphony, William Schuman's "Prayer -- 1943" in its first New York performance, and the Brahms violin concerto with Joseph Szigeti as soloist.
A special High Command communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The rationing program announced today will give wholesalers "allowable" working inventories of the rationed foods amounting to better than a two-week supply of fresh and frozen meats and a large quantity of the rationed items which turn over more slowly.

MONTREAL, March 25 (AP) -- The Bruins gained their third successive National Hockey League playoff victory over the Canadiens tonight, 3 to 2. Boston won in overtime after tying the score in the final minute of the third period.

" The big four" -- the largest meat-packing concerns in the country -- came under fire last night at a meeting of 1,500 independent retail butchers, members of the Manhattan and the Bronx branches of the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers.

TRENTON, N.J., March 25 -- The operations of black market dealers in poultry have cut the volume of sales at the New Jersey cooperative farm auction markets by about 50 per cent, an official of the State Department of Agriculture said here today.

Less than twelve hours after Albert A. Smith, 39 years old, a Negro, of 109 Norfolk Street, had been arrested in the attempted rape and robbery of a white woman at West Broadway and Duane Street early yesterday morning, the grand jury indicted him and Judge John J. Freschi set his pleading for Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A new table of point values for canned goods and other processed foods, higher for some items and lower for others, will be put into effect Monday by the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull refused at his press conference today to be injected into the controversy over the status of small nations in the post-war world or to discuss inferences drawn by commentators and observers from the speech of Prime Minister Winston Churchill last Sunday.

The Rev. Michael D. Lopez, 66 years old, a secular priest who was chaplain at the Franciscan Brothers Juniorate School at Smithtown Branch, L.I., died of a heart attack in a Long Island Railroad train near Jamaica late Wednesday night.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 25 -- Bobby Cruickshank of Richmond, Va., won the forty-first annual North and South open golf championship today with a total of 292 -- exactly 21 strokes above the 271 with which Ben Hogan triumphed last year when most of the golfing great competed.

A 15,000-word forecast of the "American economic system" of the post-war period was released yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers, after two years of preparation by a committee of ninety-two leading industrialists of the nation.

The factory building at 252-2541 Java Street, Brooklyn, situated on a plot 75 by 200 feet and assessed i at $40,000, has been sold to Henry] Lange by Anthony Giambalvo, Nino Firenze, Giovanna and Genne Tascarella and Nelle Pisciolla. A purchase money mortgage for $10,000 was executed at the closing.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Four days of general debate on pay-as-you-go taxation opened in the House today with sledge-hammer blows dealt to the Carlson bill to place taxpayers on a current payment basis, this being a modified form of the Rural plan, and the Ways and Means Committee measure to induce payment of two years' taxes in one year by granting tax discounts.

Produce merchants of the Washington Street market area -- the Manhattan sector through which flows most of the fresh fruits and vegetables that metropolitan housewives serve -- have laid before the Office of Price Administration a proposal which they say will enable the government to prevent runaway prices and give them a chance to restore normal operation of the market, now disrupted by regulations that they find impossible to apply.

Protesting the rejection of Mark Start, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, for the $7,500 post of New York City adult educational director, David Dubinsky, president of the union, called upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday to order an immediate investigation of the Board of Education's' action.
MOSCOW, March 25 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 25 -- Baron George Gripenberg, Finnish envoy to the Vatican, will succeed Professor Jarl Vasastjerna as Finland's Minister to Stockholm, it was learned here today on good authority.

" Richard III," the first Shakespeare revival of the season, will have its delayed opening tonight at the Forrest under the auspices of Theatre Productions. This will be the first revival of the play since Walter Hampden appeared in it for eight performances in 1935.

From sudden death to a slight fever, it's all in the day's work. Ambulance drivers of the Red Cross Motor Corps will testify to that. By 7 P.M. yesterday at the end of a twelve-hour shift, the women on duty at Knickerbocker Hospital had chalked up nineteen trips.

WITH U.S. FORCES in Southern Tunisia, March 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- It was an artilleryman's dream -- those 300 to 400 German infantrymen approaching in a body across the plains of El Guettar toward the American-held heights. When hidden United States artillery got through with them, they were blasted and scattered with direct hits, which, observers said, left only a fraction of them alive and unwounded.

The mystery of the "pants burglar," who made a specialty of robbing grocery and shoe stores throughout the city and then forced the managers to take off their trousers to delay pursuit, appeared solved last night with the arrest of Paul Pacia, 31 years old, who has a long police record and many aliases.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- Today's news from the Russian front followed the pattern set by earlier reports. Air fighting at Leningrad, mentioned in yesterday's communique, is broadening in scale. Destruction of thirty-two enemy planes was reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Marines do not have much time these days to attend to such things as back home church dues. One of them recently received word from the senior warden of his church that he was behind in his normal contributions.

Patrick J. Curtey of Dorchester, Mass., the No. 1 service father among its 50,000 employes, was honored yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey at an informal ceremony in the company's offices, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. R.W. Gallagher, Esso president, presented him with a $100 war bond for each of his six sons in the armed services. Mr. Curley also has six nephews in the armed services.

The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, 200 West Seventy-second Street, last year spent from the hospital, witnessed the trants, according to the annual report made public yesterday. The expenditure represented an increase of $99,963 over 1941 and resulted in a deficit of $11,795.

Never losing their poise, even when they fell 8 points behind late in the opening half, Georgetown came from behind to conquer De Paul of Chicago in the Eastern final of the National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship at Madison Square Garden last night.

Those who have been worrying that the war will bring such a decline in hunting and fishing that the income from these sources might put in peril the continuance of conservation plans throughout the country may be encouraged by the figures announced yesterday by the New York State Conservation Department.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., March 25 (UP) -- Miss Pauline M. Betz of Los Angeles tonight was crowned triple champion of the women's national indoor tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club's covered courts.

BOSTON, March 25 (U.P.) -- Fifty-five of the seventy-four crew members of a medium-sized United States merchantman are dead or missing after the ship was torpedoed in the icy Atlantic late last month, the First Naval District revealed today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Responsibility for changing from non-deferrable to essential jobs is now put on the individual, according to an announcement today by Fowler Harper, deputy chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Reports have reached here from some war industry cities that war workers, who had never filed income tax returns before, have refused to file them this year. This drew from Treasury officials today a statement that it was still too early to say how many returns had been filed but that all would be obliged to comply with the law.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) --Representatives of coal operators called today for legislation to prevent the United Mine Workers of America from organizing 90,000 supervisory coal mine employes.

War changes children as it does their elders. The Children's Aid Society, which for ninety years has been ministering to the needs of youth in this city, now finds itself confronted by new problems and new demands. In order that its long usefulness may not be impaired in an anniversary year that falls in the midst of a great struggle it is appealing to the public for help in keeping up the good work.

LONDON, March 25 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill said in the House of Commons today that the United Nations had afloat substantially larger fleets than at the worst moment in the U-boat war and that the improvement was continuing.

We are "over the hump" so far as fresh vegetables are concerned, Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, director of the Consumers' Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, announced earlier this week. Supplies, she explained, would be increasing for the next few months.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 25 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of the new Fourteenth Army Air Force in China, and Brig. Gen. Clayton L. Bissell, commander of the Tenth Air Force in India and Burma, were among twenty-three brigadiers whom President Roosevelt asked the Senate today to elevate to the temporary rank of major general.

Industrial shares climbed yesterday to their best levels since October, 1941, on the New York Stock Exchange. The volume of 2,121,410 shares was the heaviest since Dec. 30, 1941, and the gain in THE NEW YORK TIMES averages was the widest of the year.

The pamphlet report for 1942 of the Shell Union Oil Corporation, released for publication today, shows a net income of $16,860,006 after all charges, taxes and provision of $4,345,486 for amortization of general revaluation of properties, equal to $1.29 each on the 13,070,625 shares of common stock outstanding.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The temporary Economy Commission, set up by the Legislature last year to recommend savings in State Government, urged in its first report today that as much care be used in spending budget appropriations as in their preparation.

LONDON, Friday, March 26 -- Japan and Russia, not at war against each other but fighting on opposite sides in the world struggle, have signed an agreement extending Japanese fishing privileges in Soviet Far Eastern waters, it was announced today.

LONDON, March 25 -- Ivan M. Maisky, Soviet Ambassador, speaking at a luncheon of the Cooperative Wholesale Society here today, got in a word for early Allied intervention in Europe, suggesting that future Anglo-Russian relations would be improved by timely and effective assistance. Mr. Maisky said:

NEWARK, N.J., March 25 -- Assemblyman Lester E. Mahr, who had been accused of violating the State Constitution by serving also as counsel to Anthony P. Miele, Superintendent of Elections and Commissioner of Registrations in Essex County, has resigned the latter position, it was disclosed here today by Mr. Miele.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Better that the war endure "a year longer" than that women be conscripted in a labor army under the proposed national war service act, Mrs. Mildred Scott Olmsted of Moylan, Pa., director of the National Committee to Oppose Conscription of Women, told the Senate Military Affairs Committee today.

Trademarks would become a liability instead of an asset if the OPA persists in its present policy of setting up "arbitrary" garment standards and thereby prevent individual producers from ascertaining what measurements are most satisfactory to customers, A.F. Allison, secretary of the International Association of Garment Manufacturers, declared yesterday.

Johnny Greco, Montreal lightweight who is a private in the Canadian Army, will be out to make it two straight over Cleo Shans of Los Angeles when the pair clash in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Edward Foss Wilson, president of Wilson Co., Inc., of Chicago, meat packers, said yesterday that the company was preparing to issue $20,000,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, due 1958. It is expected that a registration statement will be filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission early next week.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 25 (AP) -- Cadet Alexander Horner Jr. of 32 Fiftieth Street, Weehawken, N.J., was injured fatally near Baker Hill, Ala., late yesterday when his plane crashed during a routine flight, the Gunter Field public relations office said today.

The Finance Section of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City has raised $1,475,000 of its quota of $1,700,000, it was announced yesterday at a report luncheon of the section. The finance section is a subdivision of the fund's Commerce and Industry Committee, which is taking a leading part in the drive to raise $12,920,700 in this city toward the national goal of $125,000,000 for the Red Cross.

DENVER, March 25 (AP) -- Governor John C. Vivian projected a showdown in the farm labor shortage question today by ordering an immediate halt to military induction of Colorado men actually engaged in farming, stock raising and dairying.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized two railroads today to adjust their debt structures so as to extend bond maturities and reduce interest payments.

Purchases by the General Motors Corporation from thousands of subcontractors and suppliers were about $900,000,000 in 1942, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman, said in a statement issued yesterday preliminary to the coming annual report.

ALBANY, March 25 -- A move gained headway today to provide a substantial pay7 rise for about 40,000 State employes. State C.I.O. representatives, after canvassing legislative leaders, spent an hour with Governor Dewey in an effort to induce him to approve a plan for a 15 per cent increase in salaries between $1,200 and $2,100 a year and 10 per cent for those of more than $2,100.

Representatives of the frozen food industry have appealed to the Office of Price Administration in Washington for a sharp downward revision in the point values of frozen fruits and vegetables so that these commodities may move more freely in trade channels and current high inventories can be lowered, thereby to make room in warehouses for 1943 packs, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Final decision on the legalizing of bingo was put up today to Governor Dewey. The Senate, by a vote of 29 to 18, passed the Wilson bill permitting local governing bodies to authorize bingo, on petition of 5 per cent or more of the voters in the locality.

In the current discussion concerning a sales tax and various alternative suggestions to provide additional revenue and to avoid increasing the real estate tax load there has been much emphasis upon drastic economies in the city government. I agree that there are many areas where economies can be and should be effected.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Patrons of a chain "supermarket" in the Northeast section came face to face today with a long meat counter stocked in pre-Pearl Harbor style.

There is no other war relief organization more familiar to the American public than the American Red Cross. Its shipments of food and clothing to United Nations prisoners of war is a most magnificent piece of work. Since the war, numerous other relief organizations representing the United Nations have sprung up in this country, one of their activities being the shipment of packages to individual prisoners of war.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 25 -- It is not the Bears who come over the mountains here, it's the deer and the Dodgers. Neither seems to disturb the other, and if the deer prefer to pasture at night on the ball field just outside the inn, there need be no cause for concern. The Brooks are not using it very much these days anyway.

Despite the reduction of the basic gasoline ration for motorists, a critical shortage of gasoline at supplier levels has been intensified in the last two days to the extent that some retail stations faced a temporary shutdown, according to reports last night from the dealers, the petroleum industry and the office of the Petroleum Administrator for War.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, March 26 (AP) -- The noon communique:

LONDON, March 25 (U.P.) -- The Greek Government has transferred most of its operations to Cairo and is strengthening its army there in anticipation of an Allied invasion of the Balkans that Premier Emmanuel Tsouderos predicts will come this year, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -An assertion that the agreement between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations to arbitrate jurisdictional disputes was not worth the paper it was written on was made by John Green, president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., when he appeared today before the Senate Defense (Truman) Investigating Committee.

LONDON, March 25 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force Whirlwind fighter-bombers, escorted by Spitfire fighters, bombed the rail marshaling yards at Abbeville, France, today after German planes made widespread night raids against Scotland and Northern England, which cost the enemy six planes. All British planes returned.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, March 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Germans, attacking the 100-yard road across the Wadi Zigzau that was the lifeline of the British bridgehead through the Mareth Line, poured tanks and infantry into battle yesterday in such numbers that they closed this breach today after twenty-four hours of fierce fighting.

Most of the city's butcher shops were either wholly without meat or had only limited supplies yesterday. But there were a few in the midtown West Side section where a customer could gaze on huge mounds of meat of every sort, and buy whatever he wanted at reasonable prices.
AN AMERICAN AIR BASE IN INDIA, March 21 (Delayed) -- The longest runway in India has been completed by the United States Army Tenth Air Force.

LONDON, March 25 -- Greek Independence Day was marked here today, but hardly celebrated. With the situation in the home country clear only to the extent of indicating enormous suffering and deprivation, the Greeks here had little occasion to fly flags, although those who heard Oliver Lyttelton at a rally tonight were cheered up by his declaration that retribution was at hand for "the latest of the barbarians."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Senator Connally, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, appointed today a subcommittee of eight members, headed by himself, to study all pending and impending resolutions relating to cooperation with the United Nations in the prosecution of the war and the establishment of agencies to preserve post-war peace.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 434 United States Army personnel missing in action in North Africa. Next of kin of personnel on this list live in thirty-eight States, the District of Columbia and Mexico.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Army's venereal disease rate dropped almost 50 per cent in January, compared with the same month in 1942, the War Department reported today.
LONDON, March 25 -- The stock markets hero were quiet and steady today. Gilt-edge stocks were firm and the 3 1/2 per cent war loan rose to 1057/8. Home rails were steady.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 25 -- The roar of a tractor and the rattle of plows echoed across the fairways of the Wykagyl Country Club here today as a warm sun and balmy breezes brought club members into the open to prepare for the most unusual Summer in the fashionable club's forty-five-year history.

How careful one must be with the delicate tool called the English language! This column the other day said that Grover Cleveland was born "in the last year of Andrew Jackson's Presidency." The writer was thinking of the year 1837, in which Jackson's second term ended and Cleveland was born.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Senate passed today, without debate or opposition, the Ives bill designed, according to statements made in the Assembly yesterday, to clarify the measure passed earlier which would allow Mayor La Guardia to join the Army without forfeiting his office and would keep Fusion control of the city.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 25 -- An official communique issued in Rome today announced that King Victor Emmanuel of Italy had bestowed the Supreme Order of the Annunciata on Count Dino Grandi, President of the Chamber of Fasces and Corporations.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- Prices of wheat broke sharply today on the Board of Trade following a firm opening. The actual passage of the Steagall bill by the House of Representatives failed to bring in the outside and mill buying that brokers had expected, and liquidation developed later on a wide-open attack on the Bankhead-Steagall and Pace measures by Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown, which held out a threat of a Presidential veto.
ALBANY, March 25 -- The Gugino bill raising the minimum unemployment insurance benefit rate from $7 to $10 was sent to Governor Dewey today after the Senate passed it by a unanimous vote.

Magistrate Morris Rothenberg denounced yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court the arrest of thirty-five men, including war workers, for sleeping in subway trains. He called the action of the police scandalous. The men were charged with disorderly conduct and Magistrate Rothenberg declared: "It is difficult to understand how one can be guilty of the offense of disorderly conduct while asleep."
LONDON, Friday, March 26 (UP) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast by Radio Moscow:

LONDON, March 25 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler has informed King Leopold of Belgium that "war necessities" prevent Germany from halting the deportations of Belgian workers to the Reich, it was disclosed here today.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- "The President announced that he had drafted Mr. Chester C. Davis to serve as administrator," today's White House statement said.

Through the continued careful and considerate use of railroad facilities in Canada, the rationing of travel or freight movements should not be necessary and is not expected, Albert A. Gardiner, assistant general passenger traffic manager of the Canadian National Railways, said yesterday in an address at the monthly forum meeting of the New York Traffic Club.

Executives of the recording and transcription industries will hold a special meeting at 10 A.M. tomorrow to decide whether to attempt a further conference with James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, on the question of settling the recording controversy.

NEWARK, N.J., March 25 -- The credentials of seventy-six of the 2,690 tire inspectors in the Northern New Jersey district have been canceled by the Office of Price Administration because of "chiseling," and steps are being taken to weed out others, William J. Culkin, OPA district tire examiner, disclosed here today.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Chester C. Davis, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of the St. Louis district, was named Food Administrator for the country in an Executive order issued today by President Roosevelt. By the order, Mr. Davis will serve in the Department of Agriculture headed by Secretary Wickard, who has functioned as Food Administrator since Dec. 5.

Predicting that woman's influence on industry is going much further than beauty, Miss Vivien Kellems, Westport, Conn., industrialist, told 100 Republican women in Brooklyn yesterday that "it's high time that industry became humanized a bit." Miss Kellems was the principal speaker at a meeting of the Kings County Republican Women's Club in the home of Mrs. Paul Windels at 10 Pineapple Street, Brooklyn.

A piece in this newspaper yesterday reported the transformation of certain inhabitants of the Bowery, homeless, derelict, habitual misdemeanants in the Magistrates' Courts. Last November Chief Magistrate Curran, the Welfare Commissioner, the Commissioner of Correction and the chairman of the City Parole Commission agreed upon a plan that, it was hoped, would save money to the city and turn the "Bowery bums" into regular workers.

Many dinner parties were given in advance of the performance of "Harriet," with Helen Hayes in the leading role, last night at Henry Miller's Theatre for the benefit of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies. J. Frederick Talcott, chairman of the benefit committee, and Mrs. Talcott, entertained with a dinner at their home, 16 East Sixty-sixth Street, taking their guests later to the benefit.

Restoration of the Fair Employment Practice Committee to its original independent status "with sufficient funds to carry on its work effectively" was urged yesterday afternoon by the Interracial Committee of the Women's Division of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

After breaking into higher ground for the life of the six active contracts, the cotton futures market yesterday reversed its movement under pressure of profit-taking and hedge selling and closed with net losses of 10 to 14 points.
LONDON, March 25 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England reported an increase of more than 1,000,000 in note circulation, which reached an all-time high of 928,717,000.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Prices of farm products, which have advanced steadily for several months, receded by 0.9 per cent during the week ended on March 20. There were few other changes in commodity prices in primary markets.

Germany and the Nazi party have failed in their attempt to break the spirit of the Norwegian people, their government, judiciary, church and educators, Crown Prince Olav of Norway declared in a speech before nearly 900 members and guests of the Rotary Club at their weekly luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.
Mrs. Malcolm P. Aldrich of Washington, wife of Lieut. Comdr. Aldrich, U.S.N.R., has joined Mrs. Julian C. Stanley of Syosset, L.I., at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The New York Credit Men's Association has named Raymond Hough as acting executive manager and secretary to carry on the duties heretofore performed by Clarence L. Riegel, who resigned earlier this week, it was announced yesterday by Harry J. Delaney, president of the group.

" The Moon Is Down," Twentieth Century-Fox adaptation of the John Steinbeck book and play, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rivoli. Produced by Nunnally Johnson, who also wrote the script, the film was directed by Irving Pichel and features Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Dorris Bowden, William Post Jr., Henry Travers, Lee J. Cobb, Margaret Wycherly and E.J. Ballantine.

Sketches by Howard Willard, instructor in graphic arts at Cooper Union, have been drawn upon by the War Department in compiling the new guide books for American troops overseas -- the literature issued to men on their way to the battle fronts.

Captain Charles F. Kelley Jr., 22 years old, of 158-18 Thirty-second Avenue, Flushing, Queens, who received the Silver Star from Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt on Dec. 14 for gallantry under fire, was killed in action in Tunisia on March 9, according to a telegram from the War Department made public yesterday by his father.

The suits started in the New York courts in 1941 by representatives here of the Central Banks of Belgium and Poland to recover $228,294,283 and $64,050,641 in gold from the vast hoard of the Bank of France now in the vaults of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York moved a step nearer settlement yesterday with the passage of the Mitchell bill by the Assembly in Albany.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- How the great difficulties affecting food production and distribution can be overcome by setting up another sub- departmental agency with limited powers and many bosses was not explained today in the executive order that put Chester C. Davis in charge of these matters in the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A committee of the leading local officials in French Guiana has sent a cable message to General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader urging that he and General Henri Honore Giraud, civil and military commander in North Africa, agree upon a Governor for Guiana, according to information reaching General Giraud's military mission here today.

WINCENT SHEEAN, personal historian, intrepid interpreter of the crack of doom and boon companion of the world's great, is now a major in the Army Air Forces. But before his military duties put an end to his peripatetic journalism he contemplated the march of events in Austria, France, Italy, England, the Orient and this country.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Intensification of submarine warfare notably in the past fortnight when enlarged U-boat packs are believed to have been turned loose in the Atlantic, has removed for the present whatever possibility there was for reconsideration of the refusal to permit food ships to pass the blockade to relieve occupied European countries, it was indicated authoritatively here today.
Mrs. Maitland Dwight heads the committee for a two-day sale in behalf of Bundles for America to be held at the organization's Salvage Division, 22 East Seventy-ninth Street, on April 1 and 2.

WASHINGTON, March -- President Roosevelt appointed Chester C. Davis food administrator and nominated ninety-six Army officers for promotion to brigadier general or major general; his visitors included Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission chairman; Charles E. Wilson, vice chairman, of the War Production Board, and Harold Smith, budget director.

Premier Hideki Tojo painted a glowing picture of Axis unity and Allied dissension to the Japanese Parliament yesterday, during which he claimed that the Axis "is rushing forward toward the destruction of America and Britain," but cautioned that "the world war situation does not permit useless optimism."

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- Some Latin Americans feel that the United States is a greater menace to their independence than Germany can be," Dr. Dana Munro, director of the School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, told the opening session of the Conference on Inter-American Affairs here today.

No aspect of American industry has been more emphasized than its precision where precision is demanded. The "tolerances" on airplane engines and many other instruments have been whittled down to thousandths and even ten-thousandths of an inch. Similar tests for qualities desired in metals and metal alloys have been devised.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, March 26 -- Four-motored American Liberators, battering Rabaul, New Britain, in a two-hour raid with the heaviest load of 2,000-pound bombs ever dropped on that enemy stronghold, started fires and explosions in the waterfront area yesterday that threw columns of smoke and flame more than a half-mile into the air.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 24 (Delayed) -- With the armored division that fought off the Canadians, British and Americans at Dieppe, France, stopped dead outside El Guettar, east of Gafsa, by United States infantry and artillery, Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel today took tentative pokes in the Maknassy sector to the northeast.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, March 24 (delayed) -- Late last night a large part of the Eighth Army artillery concentrated its fire upon the enemy-held positions in the northern and central sectors of the Mareth Line with the view of demolishing the organized defense systems, which, although deprived of their guns by the Italian armistice commission, had been so reconditioned as to present obstacles of the first magnitude.

A warm Spring day plus the sight of a glittering circus ticket wagon being pulled around by a strapping pair of Belgian percherons yesterday drew thousands of New Yorkers to the wagon's windows to purchase almost $15,000 in War Stamps and Bonds.

Still deadlocked on President Roosevelt's proposal for continued negotiations on a retroactive basis, the joint wage conference between the Southern Coal Producers Association and the United Mine Workers at the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon took a recess until 10 o'clock this morning.
CHUNGKING, China, March 25 (U.P.) --A Chinese communique:

Stephen J. Smitney, 52 years old, who told the police he got even with the General Electric Company for refusing to promote him after he had served it for eleven years as secretary to the president by sending to prominent persons in the last four years more than 200 letters attacking Owen D. Young, was arrested yesterday.

WITH U.S. FORCES in Southern Tunisia, March 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieut. Gen George S. Patton Jr., a lifelong exponent of the thesis that military leaders must take an active part in battle action, rode through German artillery fire today to visit front-line forces east of El Guettar and compliment them officially for taking and holding the valley heights.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Warning that "if victory is to outlast the ships we are building, we must resolve to maintain in peace a first-class merchant marine and a healthy shipbuilding industry," Rear Admiral Howard LeRoy Vickery, U.S.N., vice chairman of the United States Maritime Commission and Deputy Administrator of the War Shipping Administration, asserted last night.

Fritz Reiner returned as guest conductor with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. He devoted the program principally to such unfamiliar scores as Johannes Brahms's Second symphony and the same composer's violin concerto, magnificently played by Joseph Szigeti.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Department store sales for the week ended March 20 were 2 per cent less than for the same week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 3 per cent in the week ended March 13 as compared with a year ago.

Restaurant supplies of meat will be out to 50 per cent of normal next week through the operation of the point-rationing system, spokesmen for two restaurant trade associations declared yesterday after a study of the OPA formula for determining the April meat allotments of institutional users.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- W. Lester Baker, a Washington commission agent, and his wife acknowledged before the House Naval Affairs Committee today that they had 1942 net earnings of $34,000 each in fees on government contracts.

Representative Ramspeck of Georgia, the majority whip, predicts that the actual tax bill that the House will now pass "will be written on the House floor." This is the worst possible way of passing legislation, above all tax legislation. But it has been made necessary in this case by the sheer incompetence of the majority of the Ways and Means Committee.

In an expansion move, the International Mailing Tube and Wrapper Company has leased from the Robert Realty Corporation an additional floor of 16,000 square feet in 425 Greenpoint Avenue, Brooklyn, doubling its space. Frank R. Fischer negotiated the lease.

The Office of Price Administration, and Secretary Wickard as Food Administrator, have been in recent months the objects of more adverse criticism than perhaps all other agencies of the Government combined. Their sudden order canceling all sales of butter and other fats for this week only served to increase that criticism.

PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, March 25 -- Details of an alleged pro-Nazi plot in the Brazilian Army were related today at the trial of Second Lieutenant Arthur Stillner and several soldiers, all Brazilians of German descent, and others, including ministers of the Lutheran and Evangelical Church.

In an attack on the Albany legislative leaders opposed to his sales tax program, Mayor La Guardia predicted last night that the city's budget would be "balanced," but at a much higher figure than last year. He said the new tax rate would be $2.99 on every $100 of valuation, as compared to a 1942-43 rate of $2.79.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 25 -- The Allies' aerial offensive over Western Germany and France has cut German airplane production 30 per cent and has cut steel and coal production 50 per cent, according to information received here from Germany.

For many years the cheerful, smiling face of Millicent Baum could be seen whenever the teachers gathered at meetings, conferences or luncheons. She never made a speech, but when her name was called she arose from her seat on the dais, nodded at her host of friends and colleagues, and in a few well-chosen words presented the sentiments of the Mayor.

About six high Spanish officers, including two generals, have been interned in Portugal after escaping by plane from Spain, where they were threatened with arrest when a plot against General Francisco Franco was uncovered, advices from European sources to The United Press said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Senate, faced by the specter of the coal mine and other industrial wage negotiations and with its farm group divided sharply for the first time since the drive for higher agricultural prices began, showed signs today of backing away from the Pace bill, which would require the inclusion of all increased farm-labor costs in the parity, or "fair exchange," formula.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The WPB announced today that its compliance division was formulating plans to check compliance with Controlled Materials Plan regulations. In the near future, it was said, a representative group of between 5,000 and 10,000 users of controlled materials would be checked by the division's investigators.

The eleven-story apartment house on a plot 75 by 100 feet, at 205-211 West Fifty-fourth Street, has been sold by the Union Dime Savings Bank to the Garmil Realty Corporation. A purchase money mortgage for $345,000 was executed.

HOUSTON, Texas, March 25 (AP) -- Forty farm produce dealers refused to sell their vegetables 'at the municipal market yesterday and said they would not be back until the Office of Price Administration authorized higher prices for cabbage, spinach, snap beans and carrots. Chicken dealers left the market after a similar dispute several weeks ago and have not returned.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Heavy American casualties would be part of the price paid for an Allied victory in Tunisia, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said at a press conference today.

Renegotiation of war contracts is proceeding smoothly, it was indicated yesterday by Kenneth H. Rockey, chairman of the Price Adjustment Board of the Navy Department, who said that thus far there has been only one instance where it has been necessary for the board to refer a case to the Secretary of the Navy. In this case a voluntary settlement was reached shortly afterward.
LONDON, March 25 -- Prime Minister Churchill's Sunday broadcast revived the exiled governments' efforts to arrive at preliminary understandings on the creation of federations and regional blocs.

As the aftermath of the quarterly income-tax collections, excess reserves of all member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell an even $500,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $1,630,000,000, the lowest since April 6, 1938, it was revealed in the weekly statistics released yesterday.
In New York City most homes faced a meatless week-end, but restaurants were said to have ample stocks. Police dispersed 2,000 butchers who staged an angry demonstration in Brooklyn.

Despite pessimistic forecasts, advertising volume in 1942 registered a decrease of only 5.2 per cent from the previous year, according to Dr. L.D.H. Weld, director of research, McCann-Erickson, Inc., writing in the current issue of Printers' Ink, out today.

LONDON, March 25 -- Brig. Gen. Newton Longfellow, chief of the bomber command of the Eighth United States Air Force, disclosed today that the recent United States raid on Rennes, France was considered by transportation experts as one of "the most devastating of its kind of the war," while the raid on Vegesack, Germany, March 18, crippled the German U-boat base there for a considerable time to come.

Grade-crossing accidents in this State continue to show a rising curve. In 1942 there were 510 accidents and ninety-eight deaths, compared with 358 accidents and fifty-five deaths three years ago. It is true, of course, that the exigencies of wartime demand for materials and labor have made it difficult to obtain priorities for grade- crossing elimination.

A renting office will be opened on Monday in the Equitable Life Assurance Society's Clinton Hill housing project at Clinton and Willoughby Street, in Brooklyn, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable, announced yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia took time out from his "budget retreat" last night to announce that the Park Department is prepared to assist all citizens who are planning Victory Gardens.

" An increase in bread prices is inevitable, but I do not know how soon the increase will be needed," Faris R. Russell, chairman of the Ward Baking Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday. "Higher material costs, particularly flour, and increased wages are the factors which will bring about higher bread prices.

NEW DELHI, India, March 25 (AP) -- The R.A.F. continued its warfare against the Japanese last night, a British communique said today, by sending long-range bombers against the base at Toungoo in Eastern Burma, where bombs were seen to burst on runways and in the plane dispersal areas near by.

LONDON, March 25 (U.P.) -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister for Aircraft Production, caused a sensation in the aircraft industry today by appointing his own controller for the General Aircraft Corporation "in order to safeguard production."

About 100 keepers and other attaches of the city prisons under the Department of Correction were called to a meeting behind closed doors last evening in the chapel of the new Tombs prison, at Center and White Streets, but when the meeting broke up two hours later, none of those present, including Magistrates Edgar Bromberg and Ambrose Haddock, who were known to have addressed the gathering, would comment.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 25 -- Heavy fighting raged in the three main battle areas in Southern Tunisia yesterday and early today as Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's troops battled to hold their positions in the Mareth area against Anglo-American strokes at their flank and main communications.

TORONTO, March 25 (AP) -- The Red Wings regained the lead in their National Hockey League play-off series with Toronto by beating the Maple Leafs tonight, 4 to 2. The victory gave Detroit a 2-1 edge in the best-of-seven series between the first and second-place clubs in the regular-season standing.

LONDON, Friday, March 26 -- Russian troops have overpowered another German strong point and captured additional villages in the central-front drive toward Smolensk while repulsing Axis efforts to crack their defensive line east of Kharkov in the Ukraine, Moscow announced early today.
