Chester Charles Davis was born on an Iowa farm, but soon after he was graduated from Grinnell College, in 1911, he went to South Dakota and worked as a newspaper reporter and editor in Redfield and Aberdeen. Three years later he was editor and manager of The Montana Farmer, which he directed from 1917 to 1921, when he was named State Commissioner of Agriculture and Labor for Montana.

An official of the State Insurance Fund, whose resignation under fire was announced yesterday at the inquiry into irregularities in the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law, took the stand to clear himself of perjured testimony last week and admitted he had accepted hundreds of dollars from physicians whose bills he had approved.

Sergeant Marion Hargrove, whose "See Here, Private Hargrove" became a best seller, is about to become an actor. Next Sunday at Fort Knox, Ky., he will have one of the leading roles in "The Eve of St. Mark" when the Maxwell Anderson war play is presented for the benefit of the armored force division at that camp.

Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard has suspended temporarily the milk price formula for the New York milkshed, thereby eliminating the possibility of a reduction of half a cent a quart in the retail price of milk starting April 1, and insuring New York dairy farmers of about $500,000 more for their April milk than they otherwise would have received, it was disclosed last night.
With everything in your editorial "Tuesday's Gray Dawn" I quite agree, except the implication that 4:55 A.M. would be a suitable time for additional air raid alarms and excursions.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A recommendation that the freight rate "handicap" on Southern and Western industry should be eliminated and that instead of five regional systems of rates there should be one nation-wide system, is made in a report to President Roosevelt on "Regionalized Freight Rates: Barrier to National Productiveness," by the Tennessee Valley Authority, which the President transmitted to Congress today for its information.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 25 -- The greatest Chinese colony in the New World, its population swollen by thousands of other Chinese from all over the West, welcomed Mme. Chiang Kai-shek here today with a mixture of gayety and reverence.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Congress told President Roosevelt in effect today that it would lift the national debt limit if he would forget his Executive Order for a $25,000 net salary ceiling.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday, aided by further heavy income-tax payments, exceeded the preceding week's turnover by a slight margin, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total for twenty-three cities was $8,897,704,000, compared with $8,827,263,000 the week before and with $6,755,820,000 a year ago.
Henry Strater, in 930 Fifth Ave; Mrs. Charles Dellale, duplex suite in 101 W 55th St; J. Scott Gerdner, in 436 E 73d St; Irving Bloom, in 301 E 21st St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The War Department is making an intensive survey of its own manpower problem with a view to seeing that its military and civilian personnel is used to the best advantage without needless effort, overlapping and duplication.

LIMA, Peru, March 25 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace told a press conference shortly after his arrival here tonight that Pan-Americanism, which he described as an unfinished work still subject to perfection, would provide "the vertebral column" for any new world organization based on understanding among peoples.
Henry Strater, in 930 Fifth Ave; Mrs. Charles Dellale, duplex suite in 101 W 55th St; J. Scott Gerdner, in 436 E 73d St; Irving Bloom, in 301 E 21st St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The War Department is making an intensive survey of its own manpower problem with a view to seeing that its military and civilian personnel is used to the best advantage without needless effort, overlapping and duplication.

LIMA, Peru, March 25 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace told a press conference shortly after his arrival here tonight that Pan-Americanism, which he described as an unfinished work still subject to perfection, would provide "the vertebral column" for any new world organization based on understanding among peoples.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will build a musical, in which Eleanor Powell will be star, around its recently acquired magazine story, "You Can't Fool a Marine," by Natalie Marcin. The story concerns a 4-year-old who repeatedly runs away "to join the Marines," a part that probably will be played by Jack Jenkins, the youngest Macauley in "The Human Comedy."

Dollars-and-cents prices on pork, the first meat placed under specific retail ceilings, follow in a general sort of way the ration point values placed on different parts of the pig, but there is enough variation between the two curves to require double-entry budgeting by the housekeeper who wants both money and points to go the farthest.

CHUNGKING, China, March 25 (U.P.) -- The main theatre of fighting in Central China has shifted to Central Hupeh Province, north of the Yangtze River, a Chinese communique reported tonight, while a military spokesman disclosed that the Japanese had concentrated three divisions in Western Yunnan and Northern Burma for a new offensive across the Salween River.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company announced yesterday that the overall price of its securities tendered by holders in response to the invitation of Feb. 25, last, was 59.1964. The prices at which the various securities were accepted ranged from 46 in the case of consolidated mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds of the Buffalo, Rochester Pittsburgh Railway to a high of 88 for the carrier's secured 4 per cent notes of 1944.

Now that housewives and women who formerly worked in offices are taking jobs in war plants there is no longer any such thing as the "factory type," D.I. Robinson, employment supervisor of the Sperry Gyroscope Company, said yesterday at a session devoted to discussion of women in war industries, at the fourteenth annual safety convention of the Greater New York Safety Council at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- A later communique of the Ministries of Air and Home Security:

Corporate investments, rather than tax-exempt securities, as in the preceding week, were offered here this week to investors. A total of $13,493,000 in railroad and industrial bonds was marketed, compared with $7,000,000 for two municipal issues the week before and $2,472,000 for three loans for municipalities in this week a year ago.

Richard Sprayregen, 22 years old, is now the youngest member of the New York Stock Exchange. He became a member on Wednesday, when the board of governors approved transfer to him of the seat formerly held by, the late Emil A.C. Keppler.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- War and Navy Departments announced jointly today that forty-one more industrial plants had been selected to receive the award in recognition of outstanding performance on war work.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (U.P.) -- A handbook explaining the why and wherefore of the government price control program, entitled "Battle Stations for All," is scheduled for publication Tuesday, the Office of War Information announced today.
B. Reath Riggs, newly appointed American Consul to Malmo, Sweden, accompanied by Mrs. Riggs and their children, has arrived from Georgia Farm, West Chester, Pa., and is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

As a result of the introduction of the points rationing system on canned foods, some chain and independent retail grocers have begun concentrating their replacement purchase on nationally advertised and better-known brands, it was learned yesterday.

SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA, March 26 -- Some 50 per cent of the motorized equipment of the United States forces in North Africa is now being assembled in an open-air plant, the first peripatetic factory in the world that is able on ten hours' notice to pick up its equipment and move on its own power at a rate of thirty miles daily in any direction required.

NEW DELHI, India, March 26 (AP) -- Heavy American aerial blows in two days of raiding against the Japanese in Burma were announced today in a communique of the Tenth United States Air Force, including "a highly successful operation" against a key airfield at Meiktila.

ALGIERS, Algeria, March 26 (U.P.) -- General Georges Catroux, liaison officer for the Fighting French, has arrived at Algiers to arrange for a conference between General Henri Honore Giraud and the Fighting French leader, General Charles de Gaulle, on world French unity, it was announced today.

Many retail grocers are foraging for potatoes in Nassau and Suffolk Counties as a result of supply shortages in regular wholesale markets here, according to A.F. Guckenberger, secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association.

Within the next few days each member of Congress will receive a copy of a leaflet issued yesterday by the National Women's Trade Union League, setting forth its opposition to the proposed Equal Rights Amendment, sponsored by the National Woman's party.

A survey of the retail meat markets in the city yesterday revealed that while some small shops did virtually no business others had long lines of persons waiting outside their doors throughout the day. Those shops with policemen stationed in front of their doors or meat delivery trucks drawn up to their curbs attracted customers in large numbers.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 26 -- In an order described as an innovation in the field of public utility rate regulation, the Arkansas Utilities Commission has established as its wartime policy a program of ordering annual refunds of excess earnings to customers by private utility companies.

TULSA, Okla., March 26 -- Mrs. Ella B. Howard, a gray-haired divorcee of Fort Worth, was charged with murder today in the slaying of Mrs. T. Karl Simmons, wife of a wealthy oil man and nationally known exhibitor of show horses.

TRENTON, March 26 -- Basing his action on a recent opinion by the Court of Errors and Appeals, New Jersey's highest tribunal, that Senate President George H. Stanger had no constitutional right to State remuneration as counsel to the Milk Control Director, Attorney General David T. Wilentz advised State Controller Homer C. Zink today against any payments to legislators other than their $500 yearly salaries.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- "The main source of additional labor supply is among younger women, including married women, and even mothers of young children, who have not yet taken war jobs," said J.C. Capt, Director of the Census Bureau, Commerce Department, today in disclosing facts about unemployed women as shown in the 1940 census.

Steps have been taken by the New York Stock Exchange to implement the warning of its president, Emil Schram, against stock issues which possess no virtue other than cheap price. The institution has ruled that there may be no margin buying of stocks at less than $5, or of bonds at less than 5 per cent of par.
Dr. William Parche, in 561 Madison Ave; Ebra Pulver, in 320-330 Park Ave; Ferdinand Buckens, in 116 E 53d St; Harold M. Stern, in 301 E 21st St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co. brokers.

Samuel W. Reyburn, former department store head and former chairman of the board of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation who retired recently, was the guest of honor last night at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Among the 400 persons who attended were Benjamin H. Namm, who was toastmaster, and Oswald W. Knauth, David Ovens, Joseph E. Pridday, Lew Hahn, Dr. Norris A. Briscoe and Edward N. Allen.

More than 250 doctors received a "substantial" part of $30,000 in kickbacks allegedly paid out in 1942 by Bendiner Schlesinger X-ray Laboratories, Inc., according to a statement yesterday at the inquiry into the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law before Moreland Act Commissioner William F. Bleakley at the bar association.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 26 (AP) -- Yale, clarifying its athletic program for the duration, announced today that intercollegiate competition would be restricted to football, baseball, swimming and basketball.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Roosevelt signed an Executive Order defining the duties of the new Food Administrator, Chester C. Davis, held his press conference, met with the Cabinet and proclaimed May 1 as Child Health Day; his visitors included Admiral Leahy, General Marshall and General Arnold, Rear Admiral Vickery and the Right Rev. St. George Tucker, Dr. Roswell P. Barnes and John F. Dulles.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Roosevelt signed today an executive order vesting broad powers in Chester C. Davis as Food Administrator and announced plans for providing more farm machinery, the deferment this year of about 3,000,00 agricultural workers, and, possibly, the recruiting of a "land army."

The question of shot and shell for sports gunning is still in the debating stage, with officials of WPB struggling with the question of whether the food value, the interests of conservation or the intangible called morale -- or, perhaps, all three -- offer a worth-while reason for releasing the materials to manufacture sporting ammunition and allow its sale.

TRENTON, March 26 -- Two members of the crew of a New Jersey Conservation and Development Department fire-fighting truck are known to be dead, and two others are in an Atlantic City hospital in a critical condition with first and second degree burns as the result of a forest fire raging tonight over several thousand acres in the southern part of the State.

On April 1, for the first time since 1923, a New York Stock Exchange member firm will open an office in Latin America. The firm of Richard J. Buck Co., which succeeded John Melady Co. on May 1, 1941, will establish a branch in Caracas, Venezuela.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 26 -- Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, told a joint session of the Maryland General Assembly tonight that the United States, Great Britain, Russia and China must act together in war and in peace if they were to win victory over the Axis and prevent future conflicts.

With the aim of formulating a practical plan for post-war European federation to be submitted to United Nations leaders at the peace conference, participants in the Pan-European Conference being held here at the invitation of New York University organized three commissions to treat specific topics and offered several preliminary recommendations concerning actions which should be taken now.

ALEXANDER WOOLLCOTT, who died only the other day, literally spent his last energies assembling a pocket anthology for the soldiers of the United States. It's called "As You Were,"* and it's no ordinary book. In his foreword Mr. Woollcott, who was modest as all get-out, except when he was telling of idiots, says "As You Were" is just a collection of verse and prose.

The public should be trained to distinguish "an alert" signal for an air raid without the customary preliminary signals given in recent tests, Major Glenn S. Reeves of the Army Engineer Corps declared yesterday at a conference of officials engaged in municipal signal maintenance.

SYRACUSE, March 26 (AP) -- President Roosevelt's "very best wishes" have been sent to Mrs. Elizabeth Checkosky, a widow, ten of whose children are serving their country in the armed services and on the home front.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- American shipyards are turning out "dozens" of auxiliary aircraft carriers, which present "a triple menace" to the enemy, it was revealed today at Secretary Knox's press conference by Mr. Knox and Vice Admiral Frederick J. Horne, vice chief of naval operations.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 26 (U.P.) -- Planes of the western desert air striking force are now dropping 4,000-pound block-buster bombs on Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's installations in Tunisia, it was announced tonight.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, March 27 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Federal authorities authorized the shipment of an additional 1,000,000 pounds of meat to New York City yesterday after Mayor La Guardia had certified that the shortage was so critical as to endanger public health and morale as well as war work.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 26 -- Following is the text of the speech made this evening by Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, before the joint session of the General Assembly here:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 26 -- The hammer and tongs battle of the Mareth Line upon which hinges the immediate fate of Tunisia continued without surcease all day today, with British infantrymen of the veteran Eighth Army managing to inch forward slightly into German defensive positions under a terrific curtain of aerial bombardment and artillery fire.

Although municipal bonds amounting to $16,433,474 will come up for award next week, $10,660,000 will represent the sale on Wednesday by New York City of blocks of old bonds now held in various city sinking funds. The city will sell these obligations, consisting of 3 per cent assessment bonds, to provide funds with which to subscribe to new government issues in next week's War Loan Drive.

How Quakers with their gospel of peace can help in a world at war will be discussed at the 248th annual session of the New York Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends of the Friends General Conference, which will open Wednesday at 10:30 A.M. and continue through Sunday evening in the Friends Meeting House 221 East Fifteenth Street.

In this column you will find menus for the forthcoming week, which are planned for a family of four -- a moderately active woman, a moderately active man and two children, a boy of 13 and a girl of 11. Such a household has sixty-four points to spend on meat and fats and cheese, forty-eight for processed foods.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- The organization of special youth detachments in the Yugoslav Partisan army is described by the Moscow newspaper Komsomol Pravda. It says that 20 per cent of the personnel of the detachments are girls, though in some brigades they equal the men numerically.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 26 -- More than one hundred thousand persons turned out to welcome Vice President Henry A. Wallace this afternoon, practically lining all the way from Los Cerrillos airport to his guest residence on the principal avenue of the capital.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek intimated today that in her opinion the American public did not favor waiting until Germany had been crushed before engaging in "all-out" war against Japan. She ended a press conference, however, by saying:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- Charles K. Feldman signed a deal today with Warner's under which a film "Battle Cry," will be made for that company with Howard Hawks as director and Felman asciate producer. According to the studio, twenty-two prominent players will be in the cast.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- Plans for operating 1,200 specially built sleeping cars and 400 mess cars were approved today by the Association of American Railroads. More than 100 railroad executives were in Chicago for the meeting.

Several months ago the Office of Defense Transportation passed the word around that all large business and fraternal conventions involving railroad travel be abandoned during wartime. It goes without saying that many such annual meetings could be dropped without working any great hardship for the organizations concerned.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Children's Bureau of the Labor Department is pushing plans whereby State health departments may provide maternity care for wives of enlisted service men, following the Congressional appropriation of $1,200,000 to meet the estimated need until July, Miss Katharine F. Lenroot, buerau cheif, said today.

ALBANY, March 26 -- The 166th regular session of the Legislature ended tonight as it started, with Governor Dewey, first Republican Chief Executive in twenty years, in control of legislation. Every measure which the Governor pressed was enacted and virtually all those he opposed fell by the wayside.

Withholding invasion of Europe until 1944 or 1945 invites the "grave danger of not winning the war at all," Israel Amter, New York State chairman of the Communist party, told 2,000 members of the Young Communist League last night at the opening session of that organization's fourth State convention in Central Opera House, Third Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street.
BOSTON, March 26 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

MOSCOW, March 26 -- There were indications today that on the central front sufficient Russian strength has crossed the upper Dnieper River for a determined assault on the Germans' Yartsevo line, which is based on the Vop River.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (U.P.) -- Arthur T. Edinger, the Office of Price Administration official who fixed the point values for meat rationing, likes to be known as "a former meat delivery boy from Chillicothe, Ohio."

The name of Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, came before the Board of Education on Wednesday as candidate for the $7,500 post of adult education director for the city. Mr. Starr was picked from a hundred candidates by the Board of Examiners and the Board of Superintendent.

With officials in Washington, from the President down, Mr. Anthony Eden has discussed practically every question of common concern to his country and ours -- and this covers the whole gamut of human affairs in a world not only in a state of war but in a state of extraordinary political flux.

In anticipation of a series of district leadership fights at the primary election in September, Tammany Hall, it was learned yesterday, will start a court action to determine whether these contests shall be fought out within the boundaries of the present Assembly districts or within the lines of the new Assembly districts to be drawn by the City Council under the Reapportionment Act recently passed by the Legislature.

Highlighted by a return clash between two outstanding New York City teams, St. John's and Fordham, the semi-finals of the national invitation basketball tourney will be played in Madison Square Garden tonight before a capacity crowd of more than 18,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- By a unanimous voice vote the Senate today sidetracked the Pace farm parity revision bill by sending it back to the Agricultural Committee for "further study" and hearings.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Among the names of 247 United States soldiers whom the War Department announced today had been wounded in North Africa were twelve New Jersey residents. The list, covering casualties since early November, 1942, included the following:

LONDON, March 26 (U.P.) -- The Germans, displaying increasing fears of an Allied continental invasion, have proclaimed a state of emergency in the coastal areas of the Netherlands, where they are leveling entire villages to make way for steel and concrete defenses, it was reported today.

Control of the Wickwire Spencer Steel Company passed yesterday into the hands of a group of men pledged to direct their efforts toward a sale or merger of the company on terms most beneficial to its stockholders by nearly a two-to-one vote of the shares represented in person or in proxy at the annual meeting here.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 26 -- The body of Captain Clarence A. ["Duke"] Schiller, who, with three others died in an R.A.F. Ferry Command air crash here on March 13, was buried this afternoon with full Air Force honors and with a party of pallbearers from the British Dockyard.

The Administration has so far failed to solve the problem of inflation chiefly because it has been trying to improvise measures as it goes along, dealing first with this symptom and then with that, as each makes its appearance. The problem cannot be solved in that manner.

LONDON, March 26 (U.P.) -- The Vichy radio tonight reported a general shake-up in the Vichy regime, including the resignations of five Ministers, apparently designed to give greater power to Pierre Laval, Chief of Government.

Hopes for prompt deferment by the OPA of its rayon hosiery regulation MPR 339 to June 15 at least were expressed here yesterday by Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, upon his return from Washington, where the industry's five-man committee, of which he is a member, held conferences with Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown and the OPA's industry council.

Father Bernard R. Hubbard, the glacier priest, yesterday interpreted renewal of the Russo-Japanese Kamchatka fisheries agreement as "a distressing gesture of friendship by Russia toward our enemy" that threatens American lives in Alaska and in the Aleutians.

The American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, has rejected without explanation the offer of one of the smaller record concerns to accept the union's own plan for ending the controversy over recordings, it was made known yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 26 -- The will of J.P. Morgan, bequeathing the bulk of his fortune to his two sons, Junius Spencer Morgan and Henry Sturgis Morgan, was filed for probate here this afternoon in the office of Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

Net sales of the Glenn L. Martin Company were at a new high record of $337,556,000 in 1942, more than five times the sales of $67,237,699 reported for 1941, according to a statement issued yesterday by Glenn L. Martin, president of the company.

With only five days remaining before their present contract expires on March 31, after which a strike has been threatened unless the contract is renewed or extended, the Southern Appalachian soft-coal operators and the United Mine Workers remained deadlocked yesterday in their wage negotiations at the Hotel Commodore.

CHESTER, Pa., March 26 -- The dateline "Chester" does not appear in the war communiques, but battles are won here. Each month now, the great tank depot here feeds 5,000 tanks, tank-killers and other armored vehicles of the latest and most deadly types to the fighting fronts where they are most needed, and the total is going up.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, March 27 -- Flying Fortresses in one of their greatest attacks in the Southwest Pacific blasted Wewak, Japanese New Guinea base, and also hit a 4,000-ton merchant ship, General Douglas MacArthur's command announced today.

CHUNGKING, March 26 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces in the Hupeh-Hunan border area south of the Yangtze River have recaptured Michitai, strategic center seized by the Japanese late last week in their drive southward along the Shasi-Changteh highway, a Chinese communique reported tonight.

The new books go on being kindlier and kindlier to America, but we need not fear. Discontent will always be with us, as long as the American purpose holds good. That historic purpose assumes and encourages discontent -- of the right kind.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Declaring that Samuel Okin of New York had failed to support his accusations of fraud, the Securities and Exchange Commission today denied a series of morons made by the stormy petrel of stockholders of the Electric Band and Share Company in connection with the sale by the National Power and Light Company of a gas company in Tennesse.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 26 (AP) -- Texas, co-champion of the Southwest Conference, tonight upset favored University of Washington, 59 to 55, to enter the final of the N.C.A.A. Western regional basketball play-offs.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 26 (AP) -- A communique:

A contest that will afford an opportunity for "arm chair strategists" to expound their theories in selecting the hour and date that this country will emerge victorious over Germany, was announced yesterday by William Helbein, president of the Helbros Watch Company.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 26 -- A complaint asking appointment of a receiver for the Great Lakes Transit Corporation and seeking a ruling that the company had "illegally" engaged in the egg-dehydration business has been filed in Federal Court by Ormond E. Laird, Minneapolis, a preferred stockholder.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Action has been taken by the Department of Agriculture to put into effect provisions of the law releasing an additional 100,000,000 bushels of Government-owned wheat for feed, passed by Congress last week and signed by the President yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 26 -- Joe Gordon, the rock of the Yankee infield, and Charley Keller, slugging guardian of left field have received their final offer from President Barrow. This was the ultimatum issued to the absent players today by the club executive over the telephone from New York.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Linen Supply Board of Trade of New Jersey, whose address is in Newark, and its officers, directors and member companies to cease entering into or continuing price-fixing agreements and combinations for the restraint of trade.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 26 -- Whether it was the effect of the first real Spring day, his own expert observation or a combination of both, Ted McGrew, chief scout of the Brooklyn baseball organization, today, went all out on Big Poison Waner.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Clashing repeatedly today with members of the Truman committee of the Senate investigating the war program, John L. Lewis kept the hearing in an uproar. He denounced the government's anti-inflation policy and asserted that the government had one policy for "profiteering" corporations and another for labor.

Barnard College, Columbia University, has announced publication of a pamphlet, "Great Books," compiled by Professor Helen Huss Parkhurst of the Department of Philosophy, issued with the approval of the Committee on Instruction of the faculty and printed with the aid of the Adam Leroy Jones Memorial Fund.

American Jewry must assume greater responsibility for the future status of Jews in Europe and Palestine, speakers declared last night at the opening session of the American Labor Zionist convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Anthony Eden did what he could in his speech at Annapolis yesterday to lay the ghost of a private boundary agreement between Britain and Russia. He wished, he said, "once again to make plain that we have no secret engagements with any country." This is simple language from an honorable man and should be accepted as such.

Today's events: Janet Fairbank, soprano, and Marcel Hubert, 'cello, in Victory Concert, New York Public Library, 5:30 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; College of St. Elizabeth Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; Columbia University Orchestra, McMillin Theatre, 8:30; Don Cossack Chorus and Dancers, Metropolitan Opera House, evening; "Faust," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

Max Lippe, bail bondsman, who recently finished a one-to-two-year prison term for perjury in the Amen investigation of police corruption in Brooklyn, related in General Sessions yesterday that the police of the Clinton Street station had permitted him in 1933 to visit the cell of Harry Balner, alleged slayer of Harry Nichols, Williamsburg gambling racketeer, to tell Balner "not to worry" and to give him $10.

In the only court tennis match of the season Pierre Etchebaster, the world's open champion, gave another exhibition of his unequaled skill at the expense of two opponents and for the benefit of the American Red Cross yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- While the two leading tax proposals now before the House were being torn to bits in a second day of verbal bombardment on the floor, attention turned to Democratic manoeuvres.

LOUISVILLE, March 26 -- For flying over 10,000 miles of jungle and ocean with five invalid soldiers and ministering to them on the way, Second Lieutenant Elsie S. Ott, a 29-year-old Army nurse, received today the first United States Air Medal ever awarded to a woman.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:
American dress designers have excelled even the War Production Board in the conservation of fabrics. Proof is at hand in the slim silhouettes of the Spring, 1943, clothes.

The responsiveness here to the Red Cross appeal on behalf of the armed forces was graphically pictured yesterday with the announcement that more than 375,000 subscribers to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City had been listed at headquarters toward the 2,000,000 regarded as the minimum necessary to the successful completion of the campaign.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 26 -- A strike of employes of the Ontario Western Railroad was threatened here today when workers prepared to vote on an ultimatum demanding a 10 per cent wage increase.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State new offered by dealers.
Johnny Greco made it two in a row over Cleo Shans of Los Angeles by scoring a ten-round decision over the West Coast boxer at Madison Square Garden last night.

Hotels in New York will be able to get from 65 to 70 per cent of the meat and butter they received last December, Martin Sweeney, president of the Hotel Association of New York City, said yesterday as members of the association's rationing committee discussed problems raised by curtailment of meat allowances.
The Franklin Arms Hotel, a seven-story building containing 100 rooms, at 66 Orange Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by Ira Bernknopf builder. David Jaret Company was the broker in the deal.

Two youths, 14 and 17 years, were being held yesterday in connection with the theft of a purse containing $3,000, of which $1,640 has been recovered. Arraigned in Bronx Magistrate Court, Joseph Bunsfield, 17, of 674 East 139th Street, the Bronx, was charged with criminally receiving stolen property.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (Science Service -- Submarine mishaps are sometimes converted into disasters when the vessel is stuck on the bottom so long that the imprisoned crew exhaust all the air and thus die of suffocation. To avert such unnecessary tragedies, a British inventor, Frederick J. Gray of Cheltenham, England, has devised an airtube-carrying float, on which he has just received United States patent No. 2,314,698.

Close on the heels of Spring, B. Altman Co. ushered in a new display of Summer furniture yesterday. Flower-sprayed chintzes, Gauguinesque colors and brilliantly hued cretonne-lined umbrellas lend a tropical air to its Fifth Floor Center.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 26 -- About 3,600 Britons and Americans have been rounded up in what Vichy continues to call the "free zone" of France. Women and children will remain in that zone, for the present at least. The men, whatever their age, are likely to be deported.

Furniture factories this week have received numerous urgent requests for immediate shipment of goods on order from retailers who expect to be frozen under inventory control, which starts April 1 for some of them and May 1 for others.

In his letter in THE TIMES last Saturday, Murray Jackman criticized modern-day basketball for its "racehorse tactics." He stated that speed had been added to the game at the expense of "skill and finesse" and that there are few teams left that display "high-caliber and polished passing."

Charges of payment of "excessive commissions" to members of the former controlling group in the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, which was ousted when the Federal Government took temporary control last Spring, were aired yesterday in Supreme Court at the opening of the trial before Justice J. Sidney Bernstein of a $5,000,000 suit brought by stockholders of the company and by the group that obtained control last year as a result of Federal intervention.

Price control to prevent inflation in one thing; reducing profits and causing a change in business practices is quite another and specifically forbidden by law. Yet the OPA continues to flout the law of the land and goes merrily on its way regimenting anything and everything.

Mild weather favored retail sales here this week, but volume failed to go ahead of the heavy pre-Easter trade which last year was concentrated in the closing weeks of March. Department store sales up to yesterday were estimated as even with or somewhat under the comparative week of 1942.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Prentiss M. Brown, the Price Administrator, asserted today that he wanted "the coupons to be good when meat rationing starts," and asked packers to work with the OPA in ironing out problems arising in the first few weeks after the point system is applied to meat on Monday.

Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato charged yesterday that the crime wave involving Negroes could be attributed to recent arrivals from the South and not to those who had been born and brought up in the metropolitan area.

More stock market records fell yesterday as buying flooded into the New York Stock Exchange, shoving prices to the highest levels since September, 1941, and volume to 2,142,800 shares, the best since Dec. 30, 1941. Reactions late in the day held most of the gains to fractions, but the close was firm.

LONDON, March 26 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force Whirlwind fighter-bombers raided the electrical transformer station at Saint Lo, at the base of the Cherbourg peninsula, and other targets in Normandy in daylight raids this morning, the Air Ministry announced tonight.

Chaplain Alexander Goode, reported by the War Department as missing in action in the North Atlantic, is the first casualty among Jewish chaplains in this war, it was said yesterday by Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein, executive director of the National Jewish Welfare Board's Committee on Army and Navy Religious Activities.
NEW DELHI, India, March 26 (AP) -- A United States communique:

MEXICO CITY, D.F., March 26 -- An editorial in the popular magazine Nacion asks Efrain Buenrostro, director of the government-owned oil industry, to give a "clear" picture of the industry. It says that no one may guess from the annual report published March 18 just what the condition is.

ALBANY, March 26 -- A resolution asserting the conviction of the Legislature that international peace could be maintained after the war only by an organization of nations was adopted tonight by the Assembly and later received concurrence by the Senate.

No conclusion should be drawn from the signing by Russia and Japan of a treaty regulating Japanese fishing off the coast of Siberia. It does not denote "appeasement" of Japan, and neither the Russians nor the Japanese will so construe it. It is a matter of annual routine, the regulation of the conditions on which Japan will enjoy the fishing rights in Russian waters that it has had since the Russo-Japanese War.

It has been depressing in recent weeks to read that many high schools in New York City have decided to drop football from their sports programs next Fall, primarily because a shortage of coaches has compelled such a move.

LONDON, March 26 -- Royal Air Force intruder planes, taking off from battered Malta, where for months the words "bomb Rome" have been chalked on the walls of ruined buildings, sallied boldly over the Italian capital and environs last night, and one of the pilots on his return expressed regret at not having been able to single out the "big bullfrog" -- Premier Mussolini.

Reversing an earlier decline attributed to commission-house liquidation, the cotton market turned active and strong in late dealings yesterday, with the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closing at final net gains of 12 to 17 points.

LONDON, March 26 -- Mining shares were again the feature today on the stock markets, where activity was stimulated by reports of talks in Washington on stabilization of the pound sterling and the dollar and a suggestion of a higher price for gold.

Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra and Vladimir Horowitz, pianist, have donated their services for the Easter Sunday afternoon concert to be held at Carnegie Hall under the auspices of the War Bond Concert Committee of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is chairman.

A large exhibition of work by contemporary Mexican artists opened with a preview yesterday in the Philadelphia Museum. This is work in various mediums. There are a hundred oils, fifty water-colors, about 140 prints and a group of fifty photographs.

Mrs. Rose Daniello, 30-year-old mother of two children and an inveterate pickpocket with a record dating back to 1932, of 1055 Duncan Street, the Bronx, was held yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court on two charges growing out of a pickpocket charge.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 26 -- The phone rang in the Milwaukee hotel room of Ted McGrew. Larry MacPhail was on the other end of the wire. "Stop whatever you're doing," ordered the irrepressible and impetuous redhead, "and dash down to Chattanooga. There's an outfielder I want you to see, a fellow named Nicholson."

LONDON, Saturday, March 27 -- Russian troops beating against Smolensk's distant defenses wiped out a German garrison at one strong point and captured another, while other Soviet forces held firm against Nazi counter-assaults on the Donets River front near Kharkov in the south, Moscow reported today.

What has become of that part of the French gold reserve that, in the Spring of 1940, was transported to Dakar: about 48 per cent of the total, or some one billion dollars? I am told that the hoard was scattered in 1941 among various hiding places in the back country and that investigations are being made to locate them.

In 1899 the Chicago Juvenile Court was established under a statute that introduced a new principle into American law. Henceforth, the juvenile lawbreaker was not to be regarded as a criminal but as under the protection of the State and the guardianship of the Juvenile Court.

Henri Bernstein, the French playwright, is writing his second English play. It is temporarily entitled "Unconquered Land" and deals with occupied countries in general. According to Mr. Bernstein, "the play's action might take place in Denmark, Norway or anywhere in occupied Europe."

LONDON, March 26 -- Coincidentally with General Georges Catroux's arrival in Algiers, North Africa, from Syria, General Charles de Gaulle, leader of the Fighting French, made a radio broadcast tonight expressing hope for complete unity with General Henri Honore Giraud, with whom General de Gaulle will soon confer.

Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick defended the La Guardia administration's position on the sales tax last night with the assertion that regardless of its need the city should have the power to enact the increase so that when the budget is presented to the City Council next week that body can be in the position to decide the issues without the pressure of outside influences.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

ALBANY, March 26 -- Forty-five thousand State employes will receive an emergency pay increase starting May 1, as the result of a recommendation made by Governor Dewey today and enacted into law by both houses.
CLEVELAND, March 26 -- Gregory Rice, former Notre Dame star, broke his own world indoor record tonight in the Columbian two-mile, feature event of the Knights of Columbus games at the Arena.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Two officials of the unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations appeared before the Senate Military Affairs Committee today to oppose the Austin-Wadsworth bill for compulsory civilian participation in the war effort.

One amazing fact has been ignored by Beardsley Ruml and his supporters. Only 3 per cent of taxes due was abated in the twenty-one years of income tax collection, despite depression of 1921, 1932 and 1938. The scientist begins to solve a problem by inquiring, "What are the facts?"
Investments buying of houses and loft buildings featured realty activity in Manhattan reported yesterday.

Last season Adolf Busch revived a gracious institution that had flourished under his benevolent guidance in pre-Hitler Germany. He reconstituted his group of Chamber Music Players made up of members of his family and friends, and they presented a series of notable concerts.
LONDON, Saturday, March 27 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique recorded by the Soviet monitor:

NEWARK, N.J., March 26 -- The constitutionality of the Federal Emergency Price Control Act was challenged on three points here today by counsel for a group of indicted meat wholesalers during a four-hour hearing before a Federal statutory court.

The Don Cossack Chorus, under Serge Jaroff, gave the first of a series of three concerts at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The large size and ardent enthusiasm of the audience attested to the undiminished popularity of the choral group, which had been heard in two previous sold-out concerts in Carnegie Hall during its current thirteenth season in this country.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 26 -- The burning question of who will play first was still an unsolved problem with the Giants today, but if the answer is worrying Manager Melvin Ott it can be said our young skipper is carrying his cares lightly.

An exhibition of Dutch antiques and of paintings, sculpture and prints by artists who are present or former tenants of St. Mark's Garth will open tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock with a special program in the Parish Hall of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie.

To a season thus far bereft of all Shakespeare, George Coulouris last evening brought a revival of "Richard III." It has been a decade since the story of the murderous Gloucester last was told on the Broadway stage, two decades since the magnificent voice of John Barrymore told it, so perhaps Mr. Coulouris is right in thinking the time has come again.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- Today's newspapers publish stern indictments of German brutality in Smolensk Province, the most moving of which is an account by a Russian writer who returned to Byelyi with the Red Army after an absence of twenty years.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 247 United States soldiers wounded in North Africa. These men were wounded in the period since early November, 1942, including the time of the landing operations.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 26 (AP) -- After equaling the world record twice this afternoon in qualifying preliminaries of the 50-yard freestyle, Henry Kozlowski, 19-year-old Northwestern University freshman from Chicago, clipped half a second from the mark with a time of 0:22.1 in winning the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tonight.

TORONTO, March 26 (Canadian Press) -- The Minnesota and Ontario Paper Company and subsidiary companies in the United States and Canada showed a consolidated 1942 net profit of $1,618,863 after income taxes and contingencies.
MOSCOW, March 26 (AP) -- The midday Soviet communique:

AT THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 25 (Delayed) -- The Americans and Germans withheld their armor from combat today, but opposing infantry slugged it out to the accompaniment of mortars and artillery on both the Maknassy and El Guettar sectors. Little progress was made by either side, despite bitter fighting.
LONDON, March 26 (AP) -- Lady Sarah is distantly related to Prime Minister Churchill, whose grandfather was the seventh Duke of Marlborough.
OTTAWA, March 26 (AP) -- The Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board and the United States War Production Board have made arrangements for a continued exchange of information about pulpwood supplies.

The Rev. Dr. James E. Walker, pastor emeritus of the Astoria Presbyterian Church, Astoria, Queens, has accepted a call to the pastorate of the Gilead Presbyterian Church, Carmel, N.Y. Last Tuesday his family celebrated his seventieth birthday at the Walker home, 305 West Forty-fifth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, March 26 -- "More profit for the industrialist" is the demand voiced in today's Sin Hua Jih Pao, the New China daily and organ of the Chinese Communist Party. Behind this seemingly anomalous demand is the alarming effect of inflation on production which is falling off because of hoarding, and trade in the scarcity values is a much safer way of making money.

The dairy farm situation in New York State is in desperate condition owing to lack of labor. Every kind of help is being prepared for the farmer through the efforts of the Governors, but we are unable to get trained dairymen and other livestock men.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Merchants with excess inventories of particular lines of consumers' goods will be allowed to barter them for other lines with other merchants, the War Production Board announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 26 -- In Vichy, according to all accounts, the government today underwent a change that will be announced officially tomorrow. In itself the news has not much importance beyond the fact that various nonentities replace other nonentities either as ministers or under-secretaries.

"Gyandev of India," an Indian feature film produced in Bombay, will have its premiere on Friday, April 9, at the Little Carnegie Playhouse. Enacted by a native cast, the film's story is adapted from the life of Dnyaneshwar Maharaj, a thirteenth century poet-saint of Maharashtra and stars Yashwant and Shahu Modak.

The American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday urged its members and other agencies to cooperate in the campaign of the American Newspaper Publishers Association to have space buyers state three optional dates on their insertion orders instead of one.
Here are my selections for an alltime all-star baseball team contain-, ing one player from eachof the ixteen clubs in the major leagUes.

THE single hybrid tea roses are one of the most thrifty and best-behaved groups for any garden. Though it were possible to have only one plant in a small rose bed, the writer would never be without pink Dainty Bess, probably the best known of the single hybrid teas.

THE Spring season of the Ballet Theatre gets under way at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night with two new productions, four revivals and a brace of guest stars on its roster. The first novelty will be David Lichine's version of the Offenbach "Helen of Troy," with Vera Zorina in the title role, on Saturday evening.
In THE TIMES of March 17 there appeared the headline: "President Cites Epicurus on Copha."

PAN-AMERICAN relations took a pleasant upward turn during the filming of "The Mayor's Dilemma" in Mexico City this Winter. Herbert Kline, the producer and director, had been persona grata to the Mexican authorities ever since the making of "The Forgotten Village."

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Spring training of the New York Yankees baseball team has quickened the arrival of visitors this year, many of them bent on watching the conditioning of professional athletes north of the Mason-Dixon Line.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Of 4,000 land, sea and air casualties treated in the South Pacific and Australia by the Navy, only seven died, establishing a record-breaking mortality rate of only 0.18 per cent, the Navy's Bureau of Medicine and Surgery revealed tonight.

THE first thing that strikes a casual listener from up North who does some random tuning around are the greyhound racing blurbs. They're all over the dial. In fact, the dog track commercials on the stations in and around Miami and Palm Beach do more than almost anything else to give some regional flavor to broadcasting down here.

LORNA LINDSLEY apparently never liked hanging about on the fringes of anything, even death and disaster, which is probably why she saw so much of both during the years from 1938 to 1941. Waiting in Perpignan for the commission from a Paris newspaper which would get her into Spain was something much more trying than life in bombed and beleaguered Madrid.

LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force pounded the Rhine-Ruhr city of Duisburg, Europe's largest inland port, and other targets in the industrial Ruhr Valley last night, breaking a two-weeks' weather-enforced lull in night operations of the Allied aerial offensive against Germany.

EL GUETTAR, Tunisia, March 26 (delayed) (UP) -- Fifty Yanks did not return, but the rest of Company G was back today with its harrowing tale of two days of hell in the shallow foxholes of a rocky ridge outside El Guettar.

In the face of strong intimations in Washington yesterday that Mayor La Guardia would be commissioned a brigadier general to serve as an administrator in North Africa and perhaps in Italy after an invasion, the Mayor continued to be noncommital on the subject.

THE big building boom at Twentieth Century-Fox has tapered off now that construction of exterior sets for the filming of "The Song of Bernadette" has been completed. When the hammer clanging was at its peak as many as 125 workmen were engaged in putting up twenty-six buildings spread over four acres to simulate the village of Lourdes during the period of the miracle recounted in the Franz Werfel book.

Ulysses Grant-Smith confesses in his letter published in THE TIMES of March 21 not to understand "Asiatic standards and psychology." And he says that "the East and West are at opposite ends of the ellipse as far as standards are concerned."

The article in THE TIMES of March 19, "Japanese Mine Site in Jersey Is Seized" is interesting, but in some respects misleading or inaccurate. The statement that the land adjoins the Erskine Hewitt mines and that Erskine Hewitt was surveyor general on General Washington's staff is not correct, in that Robert Erskine was surveyor general to the Continental Army and the mines were not owned by him.

NEW HOUSES FOR OLD -- Any one embarking upon the construction of anything bigger than a bird's house is likely these days to meet with serious governmental restrictions. It is no time to build a home or even add a wing. But one thing you can do -- and that is to make your old house look like new.
LONDON, March 27 (Reuter) -- Today's football results in the British Isles follow:

One point of objection the Treasury has made to the Ruml plan is that upon the death of a taxpayer one year's taxes are canceled. One possible solution appears to be the adoption of the Ruml plan as originally proposed plus the following alternatives:
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 27 -- Despite the holdout by two of the Yankees' key players, President Ed Barrow said today he expected the American League champions to win the pennant again this season.

LENTEN fetes and other divertissements arranged in the interests of the Red Cross War Fund drive will continue this week with several novel events to which members of society and artistic circles are contributing their active cooperation and support.

CAMP LEE, Va., March 27 -- Huddled over rough, unpainted tables and benches, hundreds of raw-boned, intent-looking soldiers in khaki or blue fatigue uniform have laid aside the rifle and bayonet to struggle with books and pencils. Outside the company band plays "Over There" and "From the Halls of Montezuma," but the martial strains do not interfere with the serious business of learning to read and write.

THE famous letter of Lincoln to General Hooker placing him in command of the Army of the Potomac was bought at the Colonel Kolb sale by Alfred W. Stern, a member of the Caxton Club of Chicago. The letter has since been reproduced in facsimile by the club with an explanatory text by Paul M. Angle, librarian of the Illinois State Historical Library.

WINFIELD R. SHEEHAN, bustling around town for the past few weeks like a man chock-full of plans, is, however, still non-communicative as to how his projected film on the life of Captain Eddie Rickenbacker is progressing.

Warnings were sounded in the fur industry here yesterday of a possible head-on collision between the higher ceiling placed by the government on its sealskins and the lower OPA price regulations for the trade at the auction to be held in St. Louis on Monday.

LONDON, March 27 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill has demonstrated several times that he is just about as shrewd a politician as President Roosevelt, but never has he so completely confounded his critics by an adroit manoeuvre as he did on Sunday night with his unexpected broadcast on the postwar world at home and abroad.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- The arrival of warm Spring weather during the past few days has re sulted in activity among owners and renters of Summer cottages at Buck Hill Falls, Canadensis, Cresco, Mount Pocono, Mountain-home and Skytop, Pa.

FROM his threefold misery of being, all in one, a German, a Jew and a poet, Heinrich Heine escaped into laughter. And for the hilarious fun she had with him for many a year, language rewarded Heine regally.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- An unusually clement Winter has broken down over the greater part of the Soviet Union. For a period it will sneak back at night and put a new film of ice on the surface water flowing on the still frozen rivers of Central Russia, stiffen the mud roads and discourage premature budding.

The report of the White Motor Company and its subsidiaries for last year was made public yesterday. It shows a net profit of $3,189,119 after Federal income and excess profits taxes, a provision of $2,500,000 for post-war and other contingencies, and other charges.

The mystery of what happened to the assets of the established banks in the Netherlands Indies and in Malaya just before, and after, the invasion by the Japanese is beginning to be cleared up. Representatives here of the Dutch, British and American banks involved have not been inclined to discuss the matter freely lest by so doing they give aid to the enemy.

LONDON, Sunday, March 28 -- The Red Army wiped out a German spearhead driven into its Donets River line northeast of Kharkov yesterday and on the central front captured two inhabited localities in its slow drive toward Smolensk, a Soviet communique said today.
What's golf going to do this year?

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Office of Price Administration under its chief, Prentiss M. Brown, is entering upon a new era, one in which officials frankly concede that they hope to salvage most of the public good-will they feel was lost by the agency during the months it fought inflation under the captaincy of Leon Henderson.

When women go to the movies tomorrow morning it will be for instruction, not amusement. Seventy-one neighborhood motion picture theatres throughout the city, cooperating in the Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization's Consumer Services Division educational program for meat add butter rationing, have agreed through the War Activities of the Motion Picture Industry to aid by throwing open their doors.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- A new anti-tank gun, revealed by the War Department today, makes the soldier using it the "master of any tank which may attack him," the Army's Chief of Ordnance declared tonight.

Point rationing of meat will begin throughout the nation tomorrow, but New York and large sections of the whole nation face shortages that promise to be only slowly relieved, despite action yesterday by the Office of Price Administration widely extending the "emergency" areas marked for the receipt of special supplies.
I read the statement in the New York papers how the late Frank M. Lowden missed being a President of the United States. Here are the real facts:

A tough little Naval seaman-gunner, Basil Dominick Izzi, 20 years old, will start today on a tour of eastern and mid-western shipyards and war factories to tell workers of the miracle of his survival after drifting 2,200 miles in eighty-three days on a bobbing, unprovisioned liferaft in the Atlantic.

WHEN other sources of diversion in a motion picture fail, this watcher gets a certain satisfaction out of checking over in his mind the prior films to which the one in evidence bears a measure of resemblance here or there. True, this is meager entertainment -- something like sitting there catching your thumb -- but for one who has formal obligations to see them through, it's a way of passing time.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., March 27 (AP) -- Scoring in eight of the ten events in which it was eligible to compete, Notre Dame's track team tonight rolled over weak opposition to win the university division championship in the first Purdue relays.

IT is almost unheard-of to make a vulnerable overcall in a four-card suit, especially when the hand contains a six-card suit which might safely be shown. But there is one situation in which such an overcall pays occasional dividends.

EVEN if the infallible Farmers' Almanac had not told you that Spring would arrive a week ago today, you would have known twenty-four hours later that the vernal season was technically at hand. People were handing out prizes, an old custom which, in the world of the arts, goes hand in hand with springtime, regardless of the temperature.
MOSCOW, March 27 (AP) -- The Soviet mid-day communique:

MANY people who are real gardeners at heart, cannot find the space for what they consider to be a man's size garden, even in wartime. They should remember that a small Victory Garden is better than no garden at all, and that every little bit of home cultivation helps the country.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The only issue before the House, despite the torrent of oration and abuse that flows from the current tax debate, is whether the country's income taxpayers, some 40,000,000 of them, should be assisted in paying the highest taxes on record by being put on a current payment basis.

BOSTON, March 27 -- Convinced that voluntary conservation of railroad transportation facilities must be carried much further than it has been if government-imposed embargoes and priorities are to be avoided, representatives of shippers and carriers have banded together here in an emergency committee on the problem.

ANKARA (Delayed) (AP). HOLLYWOOD doesn't know its own strength. The tremendous impression which American films make abroad is a constant source of surprise to an American accustomed to treat them purely as entertainment. In blacked-out Britain, going to the "cinema" is a favorite evening pastime, and Americans grow used to being asked how many stars they know personally.

LONDON, March 27 -- Spring, with its ageless torment, has come to Europe. But this year in the restlessness of the loveliest season there are elements of hope that the man-made torment that has gripped the Continent for nearly four years will be alleviated, at least in some degree, before Spring comes again.

THE first book is one well designed for self-study. All of the basic ideas in trigonometry are developed in very great detail (sometimes even in boring detail), no doubt, to the advantage of those who work alone. Everything which is normally contained in a course in trigonometry is here included, together with five-place tables of logarithms and of logarithms of the trigonometric functions.

TULSA, Okla., March 27 (AP) -- Before a packed courtroom, Mrs. Ella B. Howard, a 44-year-old divorcee, pleaded innocent today to a charge of murder in the hotel room slaying of Mrs. T. Karl Simmons, 55, widely known horsewoman.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 27 -- Ohio state University's great swimming team added the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship to its Western Conference crown tonight.

Many industrial companies have progressed in their post-war planning to the point where they are translating paper work into definite action, ranging from the establishment of new departments to binding arrangements with present subcontractors for first call on their post-war services, it was learned here last week.

THE eve of the Tennessee Valley Authority's tenth anniversary finds this region, from the rugged peaks of the Southern Appalachians to the Mississippi levees, deep in war. It is an amazing spectacle. For an observer who followed the course of the river, almost ten years ago, from the site of Norris Dam on the Clinch, down past Knoxville to Paducah, before TVA had done more than a little brush-cutting, it takes the breath away.

CITIZENS of Burbank, Calif., population 55,000, ordinarily a peaceful suburban adjunct of Los Angeles in the San Fernando Valley, began to acquire all sorts of lethal knowledge and military lore long before most of us learned to spot the difference between a Signal Corps lieutenant and a three-star general.

COMMITTEES representing the Child Education Foundation have taken over the performance of the new show "Oklahoma," a musical version of the Lynn Riggs folk play "Green Grow the Lilacs," for the night of April 13 at the St. James Theatre.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 27 -- Stubbornly battering forward in clouds of dust churned up by a ceaseless artillery barrage and frequent waves of aerial bombardment, General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army was again able to report satisfactory progress for the second successive day of the week-old battle for the Mareth Line.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 (AP) -- Sweeping criticism of British political and business practices and an expression of fear that American lend-lease policy might boomerang upon India were voiced today by G. L. Mehta, president of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry, in an address at the federation's national convention.

For the first three minutes of their game at Madison Square Garden last night Fordham was the complete master of St. John's. But the next thirty-seven minutes of play told an entirely different tale and the Redmen from Brooklyn romped off with a 69-43 victory to move into the final round of the sixth annual national invitation college basketball tournament.

ON the eve of meat rationing the question of the weekend was not whether the points would mean enough meat but whether there would be enough meat to meet the points. Shops were closed and many wholesalers were bare in this city, and similar breakdowns were reported from other sections.
LONDON, March 27 (Canadian Press) -- Blackpool today scored five late goals to defeat Liverpool and advance to the third round of the Northern League War Cup competition.

NOT counting Dieppe, Canada's major military operation of the war thus far may be said to be "The Army Show," an all-soldier stage entertainment that is currently rehearsing in Toronto, where, on Friday night, it will have its world premiere at the Victoria Theatre.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 27 -- One of the most important events thus far in Vice President Henry A. Wallace's visit to Chile was the luncheon given in his honor today by President Juan Antonio Rios. The luncheon was regarded as of more than ordinary significance because numerous national figures, representing various shades of political and economic belief, attended.

The British have found that ultraviolet lamps reduce absenteeism in blacked-out factories by as much as 60 per cent. American war plants are now following the example set. For Americans a "merry-go-round" has been devised which consists of a revolving platform on which ten workers ride at a time.

IT would seem hard to contrive greater contrast than that furnished by juxtaposing sculpture by Maria (wife of the Brazilian Ambassador, Carlos Martins) and paintings by Piet Mondrian. This neatly turned service you will find performed at the Valentine Gallery.

Squash racquets players of the Harvard Club scored a clean sweep yesterday over West Point in seven matches on the former's courts. The Army team was led by Colonel G. Epley, and its other competitors were cadets.

THE irrepressible George S. Kaufman, never happy if he isn't busy, must be happy these days because he is hard at work on a new musical show. This is news because only last week the master said he didn't have anything in mind and was resting.

NEW ORLEANS, March 27 -- Marriage, the 7-year-old gelding that graduated from a $1,000 plater to a giant killer among the nation's stakes horses, performed his specialty again on the getaway card at the Fair Grounds today when he won the American Handicap by a nose in new track record time.
MIAMI, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- A mid-March assault sank a medium-sized United States merchant vessel in the Caribbean Sea, a survivor reported here. Loss of the ship was announced in Washington today.

A "complete investigation" of the action of the Board of Education in rejecting Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, for the $7,500 post of the adult education director of the New York City school system was ordered yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Sidney Friefeld was a familiar figure at the New York Red Cross Blood Bank before we entered the war. He was one of cur first and most frequent blood donors. Since moving overseas with an Army medical unit he has come to know the value, first hand, of the Red Cross blood plasma program.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- The National Football League's participation in war relief during 1942 produced a purse of $680,384.07, Elmer Layden, commissioner of professional football, said today. Layden pointed to the total as the largest raised by a single athletic organization and one of the largest by any sport.

THE Dayton Triangles were leading by three points, 21 to 18, and the clock was running out fast. There were only a couple of minutes left to play when Jim Thorpe shook off his blanket, pulled on his helmet and trotted out on the gridiron. The ball snapped back from center and the Indian calmly drop-kicked a 60-yard field goal to tie the score.

COMPOST, to provide humus for the soil, will be necessary this year for the Victory Garden. Properly made compost should result -- after a period ranging from four months to a year or more, according to the kind of organic matter composted and whether or not preparations to speed up fermentation, are used -in a fine, humus-like material.

Some weeks ago I attended a meeting of the Temporary Committee on Food for Europe's Children. Herbert Hoover, Dr. Rufus M. Jones and other speakers presented a very poignant picture of the situation abroad as it affects the children of our allies. They pointed out that, contrary to popular belief, sending food abroad will not involve any drain upon the food resources of the United States, upon its shipping or upon its funds.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Burton Ingwerson, for the last eight years line coach at Northwestern and formerly head coach at Iowa, yesterday was named head coach of the Navy Pre-Flight School eleven. He succeeds Lieut. Comdr. Jimmy Crowley, who has been transferred to duty outside Continental United States.

DR. ALBEE'S grandfather was an expert in grafting fruit trees, and it was through his example that the boy who was to develop a new technique in bone surgery became inspired to rebuild men with similar methods.

The deadlock between John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers and the Southern Appalachian soft coal producers was intensified yesterday when the union refused to accept a compromise proposal that would have limited any wage increases to accord with the Stabilization Act passed by Congress last October for the control of wages and prices to avert inflation.

CLEVELAND, March 27 -- It will be at least two weeks before the colossal task of moving 95,000,000 tons of ore down the lakes gets under way, Great Lakes vessel operators predicted today after a careful study of Lake Superior ice reports.

MONTREAL, March 27 (AP) -- Paul Bibeault drew the first shutout of the National Hockey League play-off season tonight when the Canadiens blanked Boston, 4 -- 0, to keep in the running for the Stanley Cup finals. Boston is leading, 3 -- 1, in the semi-final series.
ONE big difficulty that authors in this war are up against is that of getting back to home base with notes made on the scene of action.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- A Constitutional amendment to disqualify any person from serving more than two four-year terms as President of the United States was proposed today by Representative Mason, Republican of Illinois.

Fritz Reiner conducted an all-Mozart program at last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall. Hortense Monath, pianist, was the soloist. The carefully contrived list comprised the overture to "The Magic Flute," "Eine Kleine Nachtmusik," the piano concerto in F major (K. 459) and the Symphony in E fiat major.

Retail trade was active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floors were crowded, accessory counters were very busy, while a good demand was noted for dresses, coats and suits.

The isolationist was a rare bird in the South long before the United States got into the war. Anything in the nature of a scrap is Dixie's dish, whether it is with a gun or on the athletic fields, and Johnny Reb is in all the way with his Yankee brethren up North in keeping up the fight on the home college front.

WITH UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE, in China, March 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Claire L. Chennault declared at a dinner party of officers and enlisted men celebrating his appointment to the command of the Fourteenth United States Air Force today that the new unit would play a major part in bringing the unconditional surrender of Japan.

On the spacious lawn before the Schwab mansion at Seventy-third Street and Riverside Drive 100 victory gardeners gathered at noon yesterday to witness the official opening of the CDVO's Demonstration Victory Gardens in Manhattan.

WITH the first visit of the Metropolitan Opera Company to Chicago in thirty-four years, rumors have been revived of some kind of combination of the Chicago Opera Company with the Metropolitan. Our Chicago correspondent, howover, reports a published denial of the rumors by Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan and James C. Thompson of the Chicago Opera organization.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A demand for post-war planning now as the only wise procedure in all the circumstances was made by Senator Guffey of Pennsylvania in a radio address today over the National Broadcasting System.

Hope for the establishment of a European federation as a necessary step toward a peaceful post-war world was expressed last night by speakers at the dinner of the Pan-European Conference at the Waldorf-Astoria. The conference was held on invitation of New York University.

Easing of the ban against pleasure driving should have an important bearing on the forthcoming open-air season for dog shows. It solves immediately the greatest problem confronting show committees, and while the amount of gasoline available has been reduced, fanciers are relieved of the threat that has been hanging over their heads and may now drive freely to exhibitions, with or without dogs.
WASHINGTON -- The Oriental Flowering Cherry Trees that line the capital's Tidal Basin will bloom about April 4, or at least a day or two later, and will shed their fragance for a week or ten days.

IN the exhibition of colored drawings and photographs of Shaker furnishings at the Metropolitan Museum the public may acquire a good deal of useful lore usually limited to antique collectors who specialize in this early nineteenth century craft work.

The training division of the War Shipping Administration announced yesterday that the first group of sixty student seamen selected for advanced training as merchant marine radio operators would report this morning to the former Otto H. Kahn estate near Huntington, L.I., which was taken over under lease recently for use by the United States Maritime Service.

SINGLE disks have been more limited this year than in previous seasons. The reason is twofold: the ban on the making of new records in effect since Aug. 1 and the restrictions on the use of virgin shellac imposed by the government.

Elementary as this aspect of learning might appear to be, it is one of the things least understood by many adults. In her lectures to volunteers in child care, Miss Jessie Stanton makes the point by telling how, when she was learning to swim, her instructor assured her cheerfully, "Just lie on the water.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Considerable damage was done yesterday by American heavy bombers in an attack on Japanese-held Nauru Island, west of the Gilbert group in the South Pacific, the Navy announced today. It was the first attack made on this base, 675 nautical miles northeast of Guadalcanal Island. The operation was carried out by Liberator Consolidated B-24s and hits were scored on the wharf, runway, officers' quarters and the barracks area.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Prices of hogs were nominally unchanged today at the close of a week which saw the average price rise to the highest level for a March since 1919. The 500 head on sale were not enough to test the market, and the quotable top was $15.90 a hundredweight.

Elsewhere on this page we publish a letter from the employer members of the National War Labor Board. The case that the employer members make for continuing the tripartite nature of that body is in some respects a persuasive one. But we see no reason for altering the opinion expressed in our editorial of March 22.

The population of the country rose 1.2 per cent last year to a total of 135,604,000, largely because births exceeded deaths by almost two to one. This is exactly what the statisticians expected in the light of what happened in Europe during the last war. Manifestly our growth must be attributed to prosperity and to the hasty marriages that "selectees" have contracted.

BOSTON, March 27 -- Police Commissioner Joseph F. Timilty and six of his chief subordinates in the Boston Police Department were indicted today by the Suffolk County Grand Jury on charges of conspiracy to permit the operation of gambling houses and the registration of bets.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Behind-the-scenes efforts of leaders of the Democrats in the House to find a workable compromise between the Carlson bill, which would cancel all of the 1942 tax liability to put taxpayers on a current payment basis, and the Ways and Means Committee bill, which grants no cancellation, came out into the open this afternoon.

THE average backyard gardener usually considers that his vegetable garden is a big success if he picks a succession of harvests from June until the first frost. Throughout the Winter he has been dependent on the grocery store.

IN the Winter months of this year three men have died who had the full gifts of imagination, of originality, could be amused and share their amusement, amazed and share their amazement, who were story-tellers and at the same time men of strong belief.

WASHINGTON, D.C., March 27 -- The gift of Lessing J. Rosenwald, announced on March 17, has brought to the Library of Congress, and, through it, to the American people, a magnificent collection of rare books and manuscripts, the library announced yesterday.

Mild weather favored retail trade here last week, but the stores were up against the high pre-Easter sales figures of the corresponding week last year. Department store volume was estimated as even with to somewhat under last year. Spring apparel and accessory volume continued to gain.
Royal Air Force bombers raided Berlin with a "heavy attack" last night, the Air Ministry at London announced early today.
