PORT LYAUTEY, French Morocco, March 25 (Delayed) -- On an ochre-colored mound overlooking the Atlantic and situated beside the ruined battlements of Moorish fortresses and against the background of fields and grazing donkeys, goats, sheep and shaggy cattle are two tiny graveyards punctuating America's first battle in the western sector of this global war.

BERNARD DE VOTO was born in Ogden, Utah. "It has its hideousness," he remarks in this book of that inland empire, "it has its beauty, nor are they separated in the depths of any mind that has known them." De Voto, in his adult years, reversed the direction of the pioneers and came East.

Paintings selected from Randolph-Macon Woman's College permanent collection, considered one of the finest privately owned in the State, have been assembled for public exhibition in the college art gallery. The twenty-one pictures on display were chosen from the college's seventy-five oil paintings, ten water-colors and numerous drawings, etchings and lithographs.

THE outstanding event in the life of the Broadway night prowler this week is the opening at the Hurricane on Thursday evening of Dave Wolper's new revue, "Mood Indigo," featuring Duke Ellington and his band.

Despite some of the more recent predictions that there would be an easing of civilian supplies, furniture manufacturers reported yesterday that operations were now entering a period when cuttings could be expected to average, or even fall below, 50 per cent of last year's level.

CHUNGKING, China, March 27 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces have been smashed in their attempts to regain lost positions in the Hupeh-Hunan border area south of Tchang on the Yangtze River, and large stores of enemy supplies have fallen into Chinese hands, the Chinese High Command reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (U.P.) -- The country's war manufacturers are using military heroes, prizes, banquets, posters, visiting nurses and plant policement to combat absenteeism in the munitions program, says the Office of War Information.
LAKELAND, Fla, March 27 -- Bulging prosperity has come to the Florida citrus industry, with the largest crop in the history of the industry bringing far and away the heaviest returns ever received.

A self-styled "Little Goebbels of Yorkville," formerly employed in one of the largest war plants in New Jersey, and his wife were among thirteen German and one Japanese enemy aliens arrested here during the week-end, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday.

CANOE enthusiasts are already looking up likely waters for a Spring furlough that will carry them away from busy workshops. Most canoe lanes are at some distance from New York City; near-by, the small rivers of New Jersey will be explored by an increasing number of paddlers not only because of their convenience but because of their quiet charm.

The cuts of meat with an appreciable percentage of bone are those that will be in comparatively good supply during the coming months, and hence relatively low in point value. On this page you will find descriptions of four of such cuts, with suggestions on how to prepare them. Recipes serve four to five.

MANY home gardeners miss knowing a really delicious fresh vegetable by not having an asparagus bed. One hears that it requires too much space, that it takes too long to come to bearing age and that returns are too small for the soil area devoted to it.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 27 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace told the Chilean Congress today that mankind is in full revolution to achieve freedom from poverty, to create international brotherhood and to abolish the present significance of frontiers.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 27 -- Bobo Newsom, who often in his colorful dozen seasons in the major leagues pitched even better games than he talked, has capitulated before the persuasiveness of President Branch Rickey and will report to the Dodgers' camp Tuesday morning.
Spring schedules for three Columbia varsity sports teams have been announced by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics.

The constant threat of sudden expansion in military needs for high tenacity rayon will continue to obscure the outlook for civilian users during 1943, no matter what program of simplified synthetic fabrics is ultimately adopted by the WPB's Office of Civilian Supply, it was asserted yesterday by rayon yarn producers.

Gains of 1 to 3 points were made yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange in the broadest Saturday trading in more than a year. Leaders were firm, the close was irregularly higher and the volume was 798,030 shares, third largest of the year for a two-hour session.

DURING the last decade the work of such musicians and collectors as John and Alan Lomax, Weldon Johnson, Dorothy Scarborough, Carl Sandburg, J.J. Niles and others have made us conscious of the fact that America is richly supplied with folksongs.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Food was a fighting word this week, with shortages of meat, vegetables and butter reported in most of the leading cities of the country, butchers rioting on loading platforms because the trains which pulled in to them brought no meat, and many a consumer putting mayonnaise on his bread because a week's freeze on butter had caught him with little or none in the house.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- The popular lectures on timely topics sponsored by Victory Forum of the Jewish Community Center, end here tonight with an address by Jay Allen, noted war correspondent. The only correspondent to interview General Weygand during his regime as Proconsul for the French African Empire and the only American correspondent to interview Marshal Petain in Vichy, Mr. Allen recently returned from a visit to the African battle zones.

With the exception of the Museum of Modern Act's Film Library, there appears to be far too little permanence connected with the better achievements of our film industry. The sporadically announced projects to present in book form a permanent record of cinema productions for reference purposes have apparently never achieved any appreciable success.

Ethelbert Smith said that he has been making a diligent study of the new spherical maps of the aviation age. The airplane has made obsolete the old maps of the flat world that we have always known. The new maps show the world as it really is. Ethelbert smith said he hasn't quite got used to thinking in terms of the new geography and the new air schedules, but he has caught the general idea.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 27 -- Hundreds of Brazilian aviators will be sent for training in the United States, according to plans believed already completed between American and Brazilian air authorities.

OTTAWA, March 27 -- The nature of the post-war world is under discussion every day in Canada, simultaneously with what is now only detail argument about the conduct of the war. For Canada, after three and a half years of effort, has reached what may be called her utmost possible contribution in men, munitions and food without serious disturbance of her internal economy and way of life.

NATCHEZ, Miss. -- The girls of Natchez, center of Deep South Spring pilgrimages, have put grandma's hoop skirts back on the closet shelf and, dressed in the latest cotton fashions, are dancing with real soldiers instead of make-believe warriors of the Confederacy.

Speakers at a round-table discussion of the Labor Zionist Convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania called yesterday for the formation of a World Jewish Representation to work for Jewish equality all over the world and to further plans to build Palestine into a Jewish commonwealth.

NEW WAR GAS -- The "nitrogen mustards" have appeared, a group of liquid blistering agents, Brig. Gen. Alden H. Waitt states in The Infantry Journal. Like the well-known mustard gas, they have a delayed action of several hours. If heavy concentrations are breathed, a fatal action may be delayed as much as four days.

AT THE New York Botanical Garden a three-day short course in vegetable gardening will be held this week, beginning tomorrow at 10:30 A.M. Three all-day sessions will include such practical work as planning the garden, selection of varieties, soil preparation, seed sowing, Summer care, harvesting and storing.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to dismiss the government's appeal from a decision by the Federal District Court for Delaware leaving in effect a 1932 consent decree on anti-trust charges which had been brought against the Radio Corporation of America, General Electric Company and others.

LONDON, March 27 (Netherlands News Agency) -- With a warning that "if we do not resist, we die," the population of occupied Holland has received an urgent underground call to "close ranks" for a last-ditch struggle against German labor conscription measures, it was learned tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 27 -- German operations leading up to the capture of Kharkov, which marked the first Soviet reverses after the brilliant Winter offensives, suggest both German strength and weakness to military observers here.

A SMILING, white-haired woman in a CDVO beige smock sits behind a desk labeled "Mrs. Webb" at the CDVO Information Center in Pershing Square. To look at her young face and slight figure, few would guess that she is a grandmother of eight, or that she holds a record as a blood donor.

THIS is a book by a gifted theologian for readers with theological minds. Mr. Niebuhr is a Protestant clergyman and professor of divinity who does not shrink from making an intellectual approach to the doctrines of his chosen pulpit. By the intellectual rather than the mystic approach he accepts them.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Winston Churchill's broadcast speech on post-war tasks, widely discussed this week here and abroad, was probably more severely criticized than any other he has delivered since he took command in London at one of the darkest moments of Britain's history.

THE final program of a series of Sunday afternoon entertainments and buffet suppers conducted for service men this month will be given today at the Dug Out, 235 East Fifty-second Street. Mrs. Clarence Mackay will sing as request numbers several popular songs and old favorites.

TO an out-of towner from the prairie abutting Lake Michigan the theatres of New York seem at first glance to afford an endless variety of opportunities for entertainment and self-improvement. It does not take long to find, however, that the scene is considerably less panoramic than it originally looked, that there is a certain monotony about the attractions in the New York theatre, no matter how diverse their subject-matter and moods may be.

IT was not exactly a penthouse in the Manhattan tradition, being only a two-flight walk-up over a cantina and a defunct newspaper shop. The cantina catered to lower-class cafe society, entertaining its patrons around the clock with one cracked tango record.

AMERICANS who saw Mme. Litvinoff in the years before she came to Washington as the wife of the Soviet Ambassador will not be surprised by her publication of a mystery novel, and an excellent one at that.

ADMIRERS of Thorne Smith, and they are many in number, will be delighted with the recently published "Thorne Smith Three Bagger." Its one volume includes three complete Smith novels, "Skin and Bones," "The Glorious Pool" and the famous "Topper."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 27 -- American troops launched a surprise offensive toward Fondouk in Central Tunisia today and met with initial success as the British Eighth Army, doggedly fighting its way into the Mareth Line fortifications, was reported to be "proceeding according to plan in spite of stiff resistance by the enemy."
THE Federal Communications Commission made public last week some figures on the average salaries of radio people. Here are a few of the weekly payments to network employes:

BERNE, Switzerland, March 27 -- Adolf Hitler reviewed his Honor Guard at Franz Josef Platz on Unter den Linden last Sunday noon after his Nazi Heroes' Day speech and gave Berliners their first public view of him since last November, according to advices from the German capital.

THE current jury appointed by the American Institute of Graphic Arts to decide on the "Fifty Books of the Year" was composed of three competent men of long and varied experience in fine printing: Messrs. Elmer Adler, Research Associate in the Graphic Arts at Princeton University; George Macy, director of the Limited Editions Club, and Ray Nash, at Professor of Art and Printing Adviser at Dartmouth College.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Librarians throughout the country are assuming leadership in preparing the American people for intelligent participation in planning for the post-war world and for understanding of present-day national and international problems.

IF in the making of the peace after the war there could be included some people like Kathryn Forbes's "Mama," it would be a fine thing. Mama had a deep belief in security and was happy to work and plan for it. She was kindly and generous and had an extraordinary amount of common sense.

LONDON, March 27 (U.P.) -- Swedish reports said tonight that 500 British secret service agents and a similar number of Norwegian soldiers had been dropped by parachute during the Winter on Norwegian soil, where they are hiding, awaiting orders for action.

ALBANY, March 27 -- As the last of the legislators headed home today, following last night's adjournment of the session, interest shifted back to the financial policies of the Dewey administration. The Governor is expected to discuss them, and to review as well the legislative session and the role of the State in the war, in a radio speech he has announced for Thursday evening over a Statewide network.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The War Labor Board's refusal to scrap its "Little Steel" formula has deepened the wage crisis precipitated by organized labor.

THE impulse to garden this year, chiefly for the purpose of raising food, is driving many people to seek land other than their own property. Either one's own home ground has been so well planted in the course of years that there is not room for an adequate vegetable garden, or, in this year of food by the "point" system, an extra plot seems advisable if one has a family of four or more.

Soldiers who will be stationed at City College under the Army Specialized Training Program will take courses in physics, chemistry, English, history and geography as well as engineering, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the College.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Members of the Army Air Forces from New York and New Jersey named today in the list of 579 receiving decorations included from New York:

More Orders than could be filled continued to be received in the wholesale markets, where it seemed a toss-up as to whether or not the shortage of fabrics or of labor is more acute, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- To help housewives surmount the first obstacles of the new meat, fats and cheese rationing system, the American Red Cross Nutrition Service offered today a list of one week's purchases for an average family of four.

The detailed story of how the Nazis recruit workers in the occupied countries of Europe, how the trick and exploit their victims, and how the latter resist, is told in a 10,000-word survey, "The Nazi Slave Labor Society," published by the Foreign Service Division of the Office of War Information.

Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox is expected to address the eleventh graduating class of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School next Wednesday at Riverside Church. Yesterday four members of the class of 980 received awards for excellence in their studies at a regimental review on South Field.

THE date 1837 inscribed on Costa Rica's forty-centimos blue stamp with portrait of Manuel Aguilar, illustrated in these columns on March 7, includes not to the year of his death as was erroneously reported. But to the year in which he was elected to the republic's "Jefe de Estado" (Chief of State) under a special decree by the National Assembly.

MANHATTAN CDVO's Consumer Service Division will present a wartime budget fashion show at the Biltmore tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. Ways of making most of your wardrobe through use of accessories and home touches will be shown in four parts, entitled "Wardrobe Stretchers," "Mixed Match Wardrobe," "Fabric Fashions Insured of Long Line" and "Buy Little -- Make a Lot."

SERGEANTS kneel and pray under fire and testify that "there are no atheists in foxholes." Shipwrecked sailors and aviators float for weeks without food or water, reading testaments, and later thank God openly and unashamed for superior faith which sustained them.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 27 -- Seven Hearts, stout-hearted son of Grand Slam and Lovie, won the $10,000 added Arkansas derby today for the Brown Hotel Stable with a front-running exhibition that was too much for the Calumet Farm's Ocean Wave.

Now that food is rationed, what will be the effect on the nation's health? There is no reason for alarm. We know much about the body's vitamin and mineral needs. Besides, we have the experience of Germany during the last war -- a time when not much was known about vitamins.

The cliche "he's leading a dog's life" is derogatory no longer these rationed days. Any man so described will be well-fed. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruetly to Animal declares there is plenty of food left to provide a sustaining diet for pets.
THE late Alexander Woollcott, who made his reputatation as a soldier-writer on The Stars and Stripes during the last war, fittingly devoted his last days to a book for the fighting men of today.

May I call attention to two inaccuracies in the following assertion made by Ulysses Grant-Smith in his letter treating of post-war peace conferences, published March 20 on the editorial page of THE TIMES.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Time is here for first plantings (as soon as soil is dry enough to be dug) of onion sets, asparagus and rhubarb roots, and smooth peas. . . . . Seeds of onion, radish, lettuce, beets, carrots and turnips can go in within the week if surface soil dries out enough to make a good seed bed; surface freezing or a late snow-fall will not hurt them.

EDWARD ALDEN JEWELL has recently reported the findings of a voluntary committee (composed of William Zorach sculptor; James Montgomery Flagg, painter; William Lescaze, architect; Juliana Force, museum director; Chester Dale, collector, and himself, critic) upon the question of "Should we melt down our heroes?"

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate, and all Washington with it, is watching the time-bomb that was hurled into the upper house of Congress on March 16 in the form of the Ball-Burton-Hatch-Hill resolution, calling for establishment now of a United Nations organization to combine definitely charted post-war action with the fighting of the war.
CHUNGKING, China, March 27 (U.P.) -- A communique:

The Butler Memorial Scholarship Committee of Marymount College announces the scholarship examinations which will be held at Marymout College Extension, 1027 Fifth Avenue, on Saturday afternoon, April 17.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Office of Price Administration made public tonight a revised list of point values for processed foods. It lowered the values of some items which were found to be slow sellers in the first few weeks of point rationing and increased "prices" of others which sold at a greater rate than the supply could stand.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced a plan to put the rayon hosiery regulations into effect gradually over a three-month period to allow sellers and manufacturers to adjust their operations to the requirements for marking the quality and prices on stockings.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The latest news from the Atlantic -- ominous but not at all unexpected -- is that the Nazi U-boat wolf packs are prowling the seas again in what may be the dread harbinger of an all-out Spring offensive against Allied shipping.

THE Cushion, or Azalea-Flowered Chrysanthemum, has become an indispensable addition to the garden. Since its introduction a few years ago, this variety of dwarf chrysanthemum has increased steadily in popularity until now it is more widely used than almost any other.

HERVEY ALLEN makes a success of his books not so much because of his style of writing, but out of his method, invention, characterization. In "The Forest and the Fort" he makes another novel suite as good as but quite different from that beguiling book, Anthony Adverse."

ONE of the minor miracles of our time is the vast production of whodunits. Every one seems to be writing them these days, from diplomats to strip-teasers; and, in spite of their alarming numbers, the best of them are still better entertainment than most of our current novels.

MR. CARROLL'S "Time study for Cost Control" reflects the earnestness, sustained enthusiasm and boundless energy with which the author carries on the work of his profession. He has written much in this field, and he has been ever willing to share his time with younger engineers.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- In the largest list of awards for heroism yet issued at one time, the War Department announced today 579 decorations to officers and enlisted men of the Army Air Forces "for outstanding aerial actions" in the European and North African theatres of operations.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 27 -- Ralph Ingersoll, 42-year-old editor of the New York afternoon paper, PM, whose troubles with his local draft board last June were somewhat of a cause celebre in the nation's press, has just returned to headquarters after having entered action for the first time on a Tunisian battlefield as a lieutenant in the United States Army Engineers.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Mayor La Guardia definitely appears headed for the Army, according to guarded admissions made today by Stephen T. Early, Presidential secretary.

Advance sales of tickets for "the Red Cross Show," to be staged in Madison Square Garden on April 5, a week from tomorrow, have passed the $200,000 mark in boxes alone, Judge Benjamin Shalleck, executive chairman of the show, announced yesterday.

FOLLOWING the recent meeting of the Association for Stamp Exhibitions, Inc., at the Collectors Club, planning has been begun for the International Philatelic Exhibition which the association endorsed. The show, the first since 1936, will be held, unless the war is prolonged, in New York in 1947, probably in October.

Deploring the Legislature's rejection of the recommendation of the Rapp-Coudert committee to give more power to the New York City Superintendent of Schools, Dr. George D. Strayer, director of the committee's survey staff, declared yesterday that a lobby would be set up next year to see that the measure was passed.

THE question of orchestral programs has been raised, with some attendant heat, in San Francisco. It appears that protests have been made in certain quarters as more than once they have been made by the more conservative-minded of this city, against the inclusion of too many "modern" works on the programs which Pierre Monteux has been giving this season.

Even so experienced a veteran of the fishing waters of the world as S. Kip Farrington Jr. has learned things since he began assisting in the preparation of the emergency fishing kit which is being placed in lifeboats, rafts and floats in the Navy and Coast Guard and, in a smaller edition, aboard the aircraft of Army and Navy.

Trading in cotton futures reflected yesterday the uncertainty regarding the ultimate fate of pending agricultural legislation. Activity on the New York Cotton Exchange was confined chiefly to routine trade business. Price-fixing in the near months afforded slight strength early and hedging depressed values toward the close of the short session.

FOR some time past it has seemed to this reporter that the discrepancy between the supposed effect and the actual effect of war on children must indicate something or other, if one could only define it. On the one hand, we have a torrent of speculative comment, much of it anxious; on the other, the observed behavior of the children, who seem, by and large, to be getting on all right.

Now that thousands of women are entering war industries, the eternal question, "What shall I wear?" assumes real significance. There is no agreement as to the most suitable types or as to serviceability or safety features of the garments. A job of standardizing, therefore, had to be done.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The great columned Thomas Jefferson Memorial, considered by many to be one of the national capital's most beautiful architectural achievements, will be dedicated at noon on April 13, the two hundredth anniversary of Jefferson's birth.

Two more craft are to be added to the Swedish fleet now engaged in carrying food supplies to Greece under safe conduct granted by the belligerent nations, it was announced here last week by the American-Swedish News Exchange.

SEDATE old Oxford with its accent, its dons and its gowns sometimes has its moments. Some dull mathematician like Dodgson of Christ Church elopes with an Alice through a looking-glass into Wonderland and gambols with Jabberwocky and slithy toves; or a Rhodes Scholar turns Communist.

AN AMERICAN FIGHTER STATION, in Southern Tunisia, March 24 (Delayed) -- A United States fighter group followed the British Eighth Army advance all the way from El Alamein. Now in the latest phases of the battle of Tunisia the pilots are still on the job around the Mareth Line and in the air above the Axis salient south of Gabes.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The measures taken by General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, on matters of religious discrimination were defended today by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, in a letter to Baron Edouard de Rothschild of 1,000 Park Avenue, New York, president of the Central Consistory of Jews in France and Algeria.

IN the opinion of connoisseurs of the adventure story, C.M. Sublette had only one serious failing. He never wrote half enough. Books like "The Bright Face of Danger," which was intended for older boys, come along only once in a generation or so -- and a lucky generation, at that.

SANTOS, Brazil, March 27 (AP) -- United States naval authorities authorized the disclosure today that twenty-six survivors of a United States merchantman sunk in the South Atlantic had arrived recently after forty-two days at sea.

IT is perhaps characteristic of our time that a new series of concerts beginning at the Stoll Theatre in a day or two should be described as "A Season of Music for the People." The "people" is very much in everybody's mind just now, and, no doubt, will continue to be, even though it is not always clear what some men mean when they speak of the people.

SUPERFICIALLY Ramon J. Sender's "Dark Wedding" (the original Spanish title was "The Nuptial Song of Black Trinidad") is a blood-stained story of a revolt in a Caribbean convict settlement, but more profoundly it is an allegory of ignorant men caught in a world of war.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 27 -- A series of conferences between General Henri Honore Giraud and General Charles de Gaulle's emissary here, General Georges Catroux, began today in a friendly atmosphere.

ONE of New York's most widely known companies of amateur Savoyards -- the Blue Hill Troupe -- will present four performances of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "Iolanthe" this Spring at the Heckscher Theatre as the organization's nine-teenth annual stage production for charity.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- The departure from the Securities and Exchange Commission this week of John W. Houser, director of the public utilities division, typifies the rapid turnover of key personnel in the agency that has been an important factor in connection with the long delays in most "death sentence" proceedings.

IN the nearly three years since the Germans swarmed across Norway after their treacherous attack in April, 1940, the Norwegian people have had a bitter awakening. Their military unpreparedness, in that first Spring of the war, was as nothing to their mental unpreparedness.

Asserting that property owners and realty men favored "a sound program of rent control," Cyrus Crane Willmore, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, last night called for broad changes in the present Federal regulations.

ALBANY, March 27 -- An early investigation of black markets in meat was promised today by Senator Desmond, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition. One of the last acts of the Legislature, before adjournment, was to continue the Desmond committee with broadened powers to investigate all matters affecting the State's food supplies.

SPRING is here, and it's again time to overhaul the home radio. This Spring, however, there are other than seasonal reasons why the set should have a little extra home treatment. War has wrought vast changes in radio supplies and servicing.

Holders of Southwestern Public Service Company serial notes, dated June 1, 1942, are being notified that $750,000 of the notes has been called for redemption on April 16 at a varying scale of prices, according to maturity. Payment will be made by Dillon, Read Co.

In normal times more than 50,000,000 tons of food flow through its markets every day. Last week the flow in vegetables was about as usual.

IT is unfortunately obvious that all the gayer assets to the theatre which have been set up during the last several weeks can be counted on the fingers of the one hand shading the eyes against the sudden Spring sunlight. Miss Hayes and her "Harriet" deserve a couple of credits, of course, but after that time and worry may be saved by the simple process of giving George Abbott most of the remainder.

THE distinguishing mark of Mr. Sheean's report on the recent and current stream of world history is his ability to wrap himself around the people and the events he writes about. Characters who are great, or wise, or merely bizarre move about within the bracket-like enclosure of the upright pronoun.

THE versatile Mexican floss-flower, or ageratum, is almost unsurpassed as an ever-blooming annual. It harmonizes equally well with the extremes of flower society -- from the regal rose to the more plebian marigolds and zinnias -- and is therefore invaluable as a bedder for massing or edging, for color in the rock garden, or as an accent to bouquets.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 (AP) -- Allied official quarters stressed today the strong resistance of Japanese forces on the Mayu Peninsula north of Akyab which has bogged down successive Allied attacks for more than two months.

FROM a real world haunted by dictators and sudden death, Mrs. Seeley has drawn background for a novel which advances her to the front ranks of the writers of crime fiction. IS Gandhi a saint or a charlatan, a patriot of pure ideals or a party politician? Here in India you will find him described as each in turn. Take his recent happily concluded fast. To most Hindus he was a tormented spiritual leader seeking truth, justice and "soul force"; to most Britishers he was a shrewd and dangerous politician seeking to gain his way by a particularly low form of blackmail.

CINCINNATI, March 27 (AP) -- Major Gen. Levin Campbell, Chief of Ordnance, predicted today invasion of the European continent as soon as the Allies controlled the African situation, and added that Germany would be out of the war within two years, followed soon by Japan.

SPOKANE, Wash., March 27 (AP) -- The crew of the Flying Fortress, "Jack the Ripper," who had only one fresh egg apiece during many months in England (and that was a reward for a hazardous flight into Germany) puts eating at the top of its entertainment list.

HOLLYWOOD was having a hard time making ends meet when Mack Sennett tossed a bevy of his beauties into Mother Hubbard bathing suits one day, drove them to a near-by beach and told his photographers the movies were going in for art on a major scale. It was a history-making occasion.

YOUNG women of Society under the leadership of Miss Mary Louise Strong will circulate through the audience at Town Hall late this afternoon bearing trench helmets of the first World War type, with which they will collect donations to advance the wartime projects of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, 283 Lexington Avenue.

Thomas J. Patterson, acting director of the budget for the city since the resignation four months ago of Kenneth Dayton, was sworn into the position permanently by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in a "surprise" appointment that continued the Mayor's policy of promoting career men in the city service.

ATLANTA, March 27 -- Seventy-four Waves were graduated today from the Atlanta Naval Air Station's link instrument training school. They received ratings as third-class teacher specialists at ceremonies attended by Rear Admiral George D. Murray, chief of the Air Intermediate Training Command, and Captain A.W. Radford, chief of training in the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics.

And on ships -- big, graceful vessels, and the smaller, unromantic craft -- depends in large part the outcome of this war.

THE New Opera Company is looking for a singer for the title role of a planned production of Bizet's "Carmen." The date of the presentation depends on discovering a vocalist suitable for the part. Auditions will be held during April and May, to which any young woman in the United States is eligible to try out for the role.

Fordham University will sponsor a conference on Oriental rites and liturgies next Friday and Saturday. It will open on Friday evening in Collins Auditorium on the Bronx campus and will be adjourned on Saturday morning with the concelebration of the Mass according to the Byzantine-Melkite rite at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek looked back over the centuries tonight and drew from history a lesson which she held up for the United Nations to study, lest they quarrel among themselves and sacrifice all the advantages of victory once they had won the war.

Drake is supervising the new course in seamanship which the North River Power Squadron will continue to conduct at the Downtown A.C. every Tuesday night at 7 o'clock until the Final examination on May 25. Squadronites as well as officers of the naval reserve comprise the weekly attendance.

Some of it Rickenbacker has sketched, but only briefly, probably because of his innate reticence. But in this book by Lieutenant James C. Whittaker, the whole religious significance of that episode has been set forth almost in the form of a personal confession.

Rosenblum urged in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

A TEA dance will be given at the Stork Club on April 17 under the auspices of a group of the season's debutantes. The proceeds from the event will be used for the purchase of an incubator and cribs for the obstetrical ward of the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals.

LONDON, March 28 -- Financial London turned a week ago with greatest interest to Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address that concerned it most directly. It was reassured by the fact that future States were envisaged wherein private enterprise will still play a leading part and that it will be the Administration's aims to secure sound modernized finance and a managed exchange and currency system.

Donald, chairman of the Advisory Committee on Government Questionnaires, said yesterday.

Most women wear altogether too much make-up, and what they do use is in the wrong places. Such is the reluctant decision of two sprightly young women who have spent the last few years traipsing about the United States on a sort of cosmetic survey for their beauty firm.

The present state of war shows itself in more ways than one in the Guggenheim fellowship awards, announced today. The number of fellowships is smaller than usual, since funds are being held for future grants to persons now in service. Women received eleven of the sixty-four grants, which, if not an even break, is more than they had in any of the Foundation's seventeen previous years.

PEARL HARBOR, March 27 -- Marine Major Jack R. Cram of Seattle, who won a Navy Cross for sinking a Japanese transport off Guadalcanal on Oct. 15 by using a Catalina patrol bomber as a torpedo plane when no torpedo planes were available, said here today that Guadalcanal had been built into a major air base with two bomber strips and two fighter plane strips.

PITTSBURGH, March 28 -- The steel industry last week was rushing toward new high levels of steel production, and it is believed here that March output will be the heaviest on record. Ingot production last week is estimated to have been at 100 per cent of rated capacity, unchanged from the week before.
The annual report of Central Maine Power Company for 1942 shows combined operating revenues of $16,089,934, an increase of $1,610,367 over 1941. Net income rose $241,697 to $3,436,932.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 28 -- Quality and spirit, not numbers and masses, will win the war, Dr. Walther Funk, German Minister of Economy, told leaders of national chambers of commerce today in an address on civilian labor recruitment.

After nearly fifty years of association with New York University, Dean Frank H. Sommer of the School of Law will retire Sept. 1 as Dean Emeritus, at which time Professor Arthur T. Vanderbilt, former president of the American Bar Association, will assume the deanship, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Secretary Wickard may be asked by President Roosevelt to take a commission to help coordinate the food production programs of the United States, Great Britain and Russia and to develop a production program for North Africa, it was reported tonight.

New Yorkers who intend planting Victory gardens may have their plots inspected, without charge, by a Park Department gardener, who will advise them of the suitability of the soil for the proposed crop and recommend fertilizer and type of treatment, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday.

The Washington conferences between President Roosevelt and Mr. Anthony Eden and their advisers on political and economic war and post-war problems are now approaching their end. The problems are so complicated, cut so deep, and are still so much in flux that these particular conferences could not and were not supposed to produce any startling agreements or precise blueprints for the future.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 28 -- The University of Puerto Rico at a special convocation has conferred the degree of LL.D. on Major Gen. James L. Collins, who is departing for the United States after commanding the island's military department for two years.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Establishment of an international trusteeship over the post-war industries of Germany and other Axis nations, to prevent their rearming, was proposed tonight by Dr. Alexander Loudon, the Netherlands Ambassador.

Ninety outstanding offset-printed books of 1941-42 will be on display this evening at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, before the joint dinner meeting of the Trade Book Clinic and the Textbook Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Office of Price Administration warned manufacturers of toys and games today that they may not raise their prices beyond their levels of March, 1942, by stopping customary allowances, discounts and other price differentials in effect then.

After a month's ownership, the three-story dwelling at 63 East Ninety-third Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, has been resold by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to Walter H. Mallory. John J. Blesch was the broker in the sale of the house, which is on a lot 15 by 100 feet.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will star Mickey Rooney in a Technicolor musical, "Honey Boy," to be based on the life of George (Honey Boy) Evans, the famous minstrel of the early nineteen hundreds. Slated for the second lead in this picture, to be produced by Arthur Freed, is Gene Kelly.

LONDON, March 28 -- Perhaps, as one story has it, it was because while Prime Minister Winston Churchill was ill he got to thinking about countless other invalids who would have been cheered by bunches of cut flowers from friends. Or perhaps it was for the more practical reason of combating the black market.
Shortages of manpower are responsible for shortages of goods, according to the April issue of Banking, journal of the American Bankers Association. It recommends lengthening the work week.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- New England fishermen, made stubborn by the bitter weather they meet off their rock-bound coast, are slow to change their minds.

NEW ORLEANS, March 28 -- Passage of the Steagall bill in the House prohibiting deductions of benefit payments from ceilings and optimism over prospects of a favorable vote on the Pace bill to raise parity prices to meet added labor costs accounted for enough speculative and trade buying in cotton futures last week to put the market here up a dollar a bale and even slightly more in the forward positions.

In voting to continue the Rapp-Coudert Committee for another year the Legislature provided the survey staff investigating the costs and administration of New York City's schools with further opportunity to analyze the local school situation. In its report of March 8 the Coudert Committee presented a clear pattern for future reforms.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- An Illinois Central Railroad official said today that its eleven-car Sunchaser Limited from Florida passed a yellow and a red signal before plowing into the rear of the road's Creole Limited last night, injuring seventy passengers.

The vision and dauntless pioneering spirit that have guided America since Colonial days will insure victory in this war, Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation, told 300 persons yesterday at a memorial meeting at the Explorers Club, 10 West Seventy-second Street.

ALGIERS, March 28 (U.P.) -- General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, and General Georges Catroux, Fighting French liaison officer, are discussing three possible forms of a provisional French "unity" government, it was disclosed authoritatively today.

Despite a large increase in the volume of business, the Long Island Railroad reported yesterday for 1942 a net loss of $15,047. For 1941 it had reported a net deficit of $1,290,686. Gross revenues were $34,966,725, of which passenger traffic accounted for $21,761,286 and freight for $11,613,853.

PALO ALTO, Calif., March 28 -- One-third of a group of California high schools represented at an American history teachers' conference conducted during the last two days by Stanford University include in their American history courses subject matter having no relation to history, a poll taken during the session showed.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 28 -- Considerable damage to outlying residential districts of Berlin was reported today by the correspondent at the Reich capital of the Stockholm paper Aftonbladet in a dispatch on last night's R.A.F. raid.

The American Viscose Corporation reports a net profit of $5,590, 032 for 1942 after reserving $1,156,000 in respect of the Federal excess profits tax post-war credit, equal after preferred dividends to $2.53 a share on 1,720,443 common shares, comparing with $7,993,598, or $3.92 a share, earned in 1941. Federal income and excess profits taxes, without giving effect to the credit, were $15,013,000, against $6,395,000 in 1941.

Featuring economy and conservation in clothes, the War Time Fashion Show will be presented this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock by the Consumer Service Division of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office in the Music Room of the Biltmore Hotel.

In the year 1777 an 11-year-old boy named Conrad Knight went with his father to a Revolutionary Army camp. He was tall and strong for his age, and was enlisted as a drummer boy. Surviving the war and later serving as a captain of infantry in the War of 1812, Conrad Knight married three times.

Despite a Winter which was, in many respects, the most severe of recent years in New York State, the Conservation Department made public encouraging reports today on the condition of three of the State's most important game species -- pheasants, grouse and deer.

The victory for which the United Nations are fighting has for its purpose not only the preservation, but the extension of freedom, Alben W. Barkley, majority leader of the Senate, declared last night in an address to 1,000 persons at the thirty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Order Sons of Zion, in the Hotel Astor.

Any respite from bombing which Berlin now experiences must be merely one of apprehension. Each raid grows deadlier, more destructive. The latest, delivered after a two-week interval of stormy weather, is officially pronounced the heaviest yet. Wreckage from the last visitation had not been cleared away when a fresh load of explosives, double any ever unloosed on London, spread more devastation through the city.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Navy communique 326:
LONDON, March 21 (Correspondence of The Associated Press) -- American soldiers in Great Britain want the major leagues to play a complete baseball season this year.

Service station operators in the Metropolitan area reported that the gasoline situation was "serious but not critical" over the week-end with supplies dwindling. With most of the stations closed on Sunday an accurate report could not be obtained yesterday, Sol A. Herzog, counsel for the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Association, said in sharply questioning the "coincidence in timing" of the present shortage and the recent cut in the value of A ration book gasoline coupons.

After achieving a Broadway run of almost twenty-three weeks, "The Pirate," co-starring Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, will vacate the Martin Beck on May 1, it was announced yesterday. Prior to its local debut the S.N. Behrman play, jointly sponsored by the Playwrights Company and the Theatre Guild, toured for ten weeks.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, March 29 (AP) -- Japanese bombers raided Oro Bay on the east coast of New Guinea Sunday and sank one merchant ship, the Allied Command said today.

Demand for merchandise continued strong last week, but wholesale trading was a little more orderly than it had been over the preceding month, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The report for 1942 of the Continental Oil Company, released for publication today, shows a net income of $14,924,698 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal to $3.19 each on the 4,682,563 capital common shares outstanding. For 1941, the company had reported a net income of $15,398,082, or $3.29 a share.

Nothing can help the Rovers, it seems. They played an exhibition game against the Montreal Royals at Madison Square Garden last night and had Lynn Patrick and Phil Watson of the Rangers in the line-up.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Federal Trade Commission has issued a complaint charging the Celanese Corporation of America, 180 Madison Avenue, New York, with failing to disclose adequately to the public that the yarns and fabrics it makes and sells under the name of "Celanese" are acetate rayon products and are not composed of silk or wool which they resemble in texture and appearance.
A communique, as broadcast by Rome and recorded by The United Press:
LONDON, March 28 (UP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

DETROIT, March 28 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings roared from behind in the third period tonight to defeat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4 -- 2, thus taking a 3-2 advantage in their best-of-seven National Hockey League play-off series. Modere (Mud) Bruneteau scored the winning goal.

The piano recital given by Helena Morsztyn in Town Hall attracted a large and responsive gathering. Miss Morsztyn, who was heard here previously two years ago after many years' absence from the local concert stage, is a mature artist with solid musicianship and a secure command of the mechanics of the keyboard.

The annual Isaac Mayer Wise Founder's Day Service, sponsored by the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues in cooperation with the New York City Alumni of the Hebrew Union College, was held yesterday afternoon at Central Synagogue, Fifty-fifth Street at Lexington Avenue.

Leopold Stokowski made his farewell appearance for the season late yesterday afternoon with the NBC Symphony Orchestra and received an ovation at the close from an audience that filled the Radio City studio.
MARYKNOLL, N.Y., March 28 -- Twenty young priests of the Maryknoll Missionaries left here today for posts in Latin America, marking the third group departure of missionaries here this year.

Leopold Teraspulsky, 21-year-old 'cellist of this city, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The talented youth, who received his musical education here, presented a program which had as its chief offerings the Haydn concerto, Martinu's second sonata, and the Wieniawski "Scherzo-Tarantelle," the latter in a transcription by his teacher, Diran Alexanian. Shorter pieces by Turina, Faure, Moor and Bloch completed the schedule.

Our esteemed friend and neighbor the Herald Tribune has put the journalistic world in its debt by plunging fearlessly into a discussion of why editorial writers do what they do. The genesis of this discussion was an innocent, well-intended announcement by the editor of The Christian Advocate of Chicago that he would award "an appropriate plaque" to the writer of the best editorial on the subject of Easter appearing in a daily or weekly newspaper.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 28 (U.P.) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 28 -- Each of six young American pilots operating P-38 Lightning fighters on the Tunisian front can now claim the destruction or a pair of enemy aircraft on the same day.

Bishop William T. Manning confirmed a class of nine persons yesterday morning at the Episcopal Chapel of the Comforter, 10 Horatio Street, advising them to go forward in their Christian lives with fuller faith and courage.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 111.7 to 112.2. Increased prices for farm products and foodstuffs were responsible for the 0.45 per cent increase in the all-commbdity index. The foodstuffs index advanced 1.3 per cent as a result of increased prices for eggs and potatoes.

The first city-wide report luncheon of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City will be held in the Hotel Commodore on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday by Colby M. Chester, general chairman of the fund. John P. Stevens, vice chairman, will report on receipts at that time.

There are in Washington today several army divisions of public officials whose ostensible job it is to "present the facts" to the American people. Yet when a sudden shortage of meat and other foodstuffs develops throughout the nation, the public looks in vain for a full, or even reasonably adequate, official explanation.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A reorganization of Army Air Forces headquarters, designed primarily to transform it into an over-all policy-making body and to transfer to field commanders in the supply and training spheres the responsibility for putting those policies into execution, was announced today by the War Department.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 28 -- In his first long address delivered to the people themselves, Vice President Henry A. Wallace thrilled 80,000 persons gathered in the National Stadium this afternoon when, amid silence, he asked the blessing and protection of God for the Allied leaders.

IN his final minor league game he fanned eighteen men while pitching a no-hitter for Canton against McKeesport. In his final major league game he was edged out, 1 to 0, by a strong-armed rookie, Grover Cleveland Alexander. But during the twenty-two years which separated these two feats, Denton (Cy) Young compiled a matchless record on the mound, one that the past will ever cherish and the future will never surpass.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, March 29 (UP) -- The noon communique:

INDIANAPOLIS, March 28 (AP) -- Colonel H. Weir Cook, who served in the Army Air Forces in both World Wars and was one of Indiana's leading aviation exponents in the interval between, died in the South Pacific war area Thursday from injuries suffered in a plane accident.

Even though supplies, of meat are short now, it is believed that once rationing is established stocks will be sufficient to go around. Bony, tough cuts, we are told, will be more available than solid, tender ones, and what's more, they will have A lower .point value.

Rabbi Meyer Berlin, president of the World Mizrachi Organization, spoke yesterday at the public ordination exercises of sixty-two graduates of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, at Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street. He urged the rabbis "to encourage and foster the creative genius of man for peace and goodwill."

MOSCOW, March 28 -- That the Soviet Union now has its energies devoted exclusively to waging a patriotic war for expulsion of the enemy from its lands is the gist of an article by President Mikhail Ivanovitch Kalinin in today's Izvestia and Red Star, the closing words of which are:

ATLANTA, March 28 -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker told more than 5,000 Atlantans today that time was the essence of victory and that every delay caused by absenteeism or slowdowns or strikes would prolong the war and add to deaths in battle.

LONDON, March 28 -- Britain's industrial manpower demands have created such a shortage of domestic help that it is beginning to be a serious threat to the health of those British women who, either because they have large families already or because they have just had babies, cannot carry the full load of housekeeping duties alone.

" WHAT'LL we do now, Captain?" Lieut. Comdr. John Morrill, U.S.N., is the kind of a man who can generally answer when he hears that question -- and answer in such a way that his men retain their trust and confidence in his judgment and leadership. If he couldn't, one of the most remarkable individual exploits of the war would not be the subject of a dramatic little book called "South From Corregidor."*
LONDON, March 28 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midday communique:

LARCHMONT, N.Y., March 28 -- There has been no more spirited dinghy racing since Election Day, when the present session started, than this afternoon at the Larchmont Yacht Club. With a fairly strong breeze, under which no craft turned over, much to the surprise of the onlookers, Arthur Knapp won five of six contests with the Popcorn.

The "unhappy task" of drafting married men for military service, now confronting local selective service boards, will require that "those left behind will unquestionably, be called upon to make many great sacrifices," Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service for New York City, declared yesterday.

Chocolate Easter bunnies and eggs, victims of War Production Board order M 145 of Dec. 15, 1942, will be mighty scarce this season. WPB decreed that no novelty candy, "made wholly or partially with a chocolate coating, observing any holiday, event, animal, season or person," could be manufactured after the date of the order.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 28 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek championed today the purchase of United States War Bonds by persons of Chinese origin in this country, telling them that "every war bond you buy is an aid to China."

The "metropolitan instinct," which causes the individual to dread being alone, is often the symptom of a conscience at war with itself, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America declared yesterday at a Lenten sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Girls outnumber boys more than three to two in the 493 Thomas Jefferson Bi-Centennial Essay Contest school winners certified to THE NEW YORK TIMES by their principals last week. The writing phase of the competition closed on Friday.

LONDON, March 28 -- The Italian Navy will act under German orders in the future as the result of German Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz's recent conference in Italy with Admiral Arturo Riccardi, Italian Navy Chief of Staff, reports reaching London said today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 (U.P.) -- Expressing fears that the United States might attempt a financial "squeeze" on India after the war, members of the Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry adopted a strongly worded resolution today opposing India's unrestricted adherence to the Atlantic Charter and the unlimited repayment of lend-lease aid.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 28 -- Opening a new offensive in Central Tunisia, American troops punched twenty miles yesterday through the Axis lines and captured the key position of Fondouk as General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's desert veterans made further dents in the Mareth Line and swept up hard against Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's right flank, advancing ten miles to the outskirts of El Hamma.

LONDON, March 28 -- An ambitious plan for a post-war international clearing union, designed to increase the freedom of international commerce, has been prepared by John Maynard Keynes, economist and adviser to the British Exchequer.

Advertising volume will wind up the first quarter of this year with the respectable gain over the corresponding 1942 months. The comparison, of course, is with a period in which advertisers were uncertain and in some cases had canceled campaigns.
The week's film openings, numbering only four, follow:
To have a better world "ideals must be translated into action," declared the Rev. Joseph Irvine Chapman in a sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Baptist Church, 179 New York Avenue, Brooklyn.

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 (U.P.) -- British fliers and anti-aircraft gunners yesterday destroyed twelve Japanese planes over Western Burma and the near-by Chittagong district of India, and American airmen have made a "telling" attack on enemy installations in Rangoon, it was announced today.

The danger of "ultimate moral confusion" was foreseen by the Rev. Dr. J. Harry Cotton, president of the Presbyterian Theological Seminary of Chicago, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, where the spoke as guest preacher.

ALBANY, March 28 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Mitchell bill, abolishing the State Transit Commission as of next Thursday, April 1. His action is the culmination of a long fight by Mayor La Guardia to free his administration of the mandatory expenses of the commission, a State agency, set up in 1921 to achieve transit unification and to watch over the city's activities in connection with transit.

The Women's City Club expressed "profound indignation" yesterday at remarks by Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, regarding the eligibility of Mark Starr for the post of New York City Director of Adult Education and at the board's refusal to appoint him.

Settlement of the labor-management dispute that had halted production at two plants of the Bendix Aviation Corporation in Brooklyn was announced last night by John J. Buckley, president of Local 853, United Automobile workers. The stoppage, which the union refused to call a strike, began Saturday morning.

The executive committee of the National Basketball Committee, meeting on rules changes, yesterday approved a "definite program of experimentation" for next season, including one move designed to take away an especially tall player's defense advantage under the basket, according to The Associated Press.

Soldiers are well fed, but the United Service Organizations are helpful in recreation areas and cities because the men like an opportunity to get other than regular Army food, Brig. Gen. Ralph K. Robertson, commanding general of the metropolitan military district said last night at a dinner of the Jewish Welfare Board in the Hotel Commodore.

LUCKNOW, United Provinces, India, March 24 (Delayed) -- This vast province whose eastern portion shared with Bihar the unhappy fame of providing the most violence last Summer, failed to respond outwardly in any way to Mohandas K. Gandhi's. fast.

LONDON, March 28 -- Berlin shuddered and exploded last night under the impact of the Royal Air Force's heaviest raid on the Reich capital, an attack described officially as twice as heavy as anything the Nazi air fleets ever inflicted on London. United States bombers pitched in today to keep up the revitalized pre-invasion offensive against the Continent with a heavy daylight assault on the French rail center of Rouen.
ALBANY, March 28 (AP) -- New York college enrollment has declined 12 per cent since last Fall and is continuing to drop at an accelerated pace, the Education Department reported today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 28 -- British officials and modernized Hindus are fighting shoulder to shoulder in the Indian Legislature in an effort to advance the emancipation of Hindu women another step. They are confident of winning a fight to place before the final drafting committee a measure that in effect gives to women the right to inherit property on a status almost equal to that of men.
A communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Member banks in the Second Federal District showed an average return of 4.4 per cent on their capital funds in 1942, compared with 5.5 per cent in the previous year, according to the annual compilation of operating ratios of banks in this district, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, March 28 -- Major Sidney S. (Sy) Bartlett of the United States Army Air Force, a former newspaper man and scenario writer at Hollywood, claimed today the distinction of being the first American officer actually to bomb Berlin.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 28 -- Reports reaching here today through German sources said that Georges Scapini, known as "the blind deputy," would become French Minister to Sweden. Officials commented that preliminary approval had not been sought in Stockholm, as is the diplomatic Custom.

Conferences between representatives of the Southern Coal Producers Association and of the United Mine Workers will be resumed at the Hotel Commodore this morning in one more effort to reach an accordon the extension of the current agreement, pending continuance of wage negotiations, to avert a strike in the Southern Appalachian field, employing 130,000 workers and representing 175,000,000 tons of production estimated for 1943.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, who is spending the week-end at the White House, saw the President again today and is expected to continue his conversation tomorrow with Mr. Roosevelt, Secretary of State Cordell Hull and others.

When the man in the street reads about mass spectrometers, atom-smashing, and X-rays turned on matter to reveal the arrangement of its atoms he may wonder what is the good of it all. Unlike most men of his scientific training, Sir Charles Darwin took the public into his confidence when recently he addressed the Institution of Civil Engineers in London.

Mayor La Guardia, whose commissioning as a brigadier general is regarded in informed quarters as imminent, let it be known yesterday that he intends to remain as Chief Executive of the city for at least another week.

Developments in Washington on farm price legislation induced last week a moderate amount of buying in the cotton futures market, lifting values to new high levels for the life of the six active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange. The net advances were 17 to 21 points.

LOS ANGELES, March 28 -- Sergei V. Rachmaninoff, pianist, composer and conductor, who for fifty years had been a leader in the music world on two continents, died today at his Beverly Hills home of complications resulting from pneumonia and pleurisy, which twice had caused him to cancel recitals here this month.

KEARNY, N.J., March 28 -- Two destroyer escort vessels, the first launched in the Third Naval District, went down the ways yesterday afternoon at the Port Newark yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

LONDON, March 28 -- The outstanding feature of the stock markets here last week was a decided increase in business in the speculative security groups, with textile, radio and gold shares leading the way.

There is no doubt that Lotte Goslar, who gave a recital of mimes and dances last night at THE NEW YORK TIMES Hall, is a very gifted clown, distinctive in style, outrageous looking with her false noses and eyebrows, and intuitively funny.

Net income of General Aniline Film Corporation in 1942 amounted to $3,483,466, subject to war contract renegotiations, comparing with $4,115,731 in 1941. Gross sales were $43,240,715, against $45,644,761 for 1941, according to the report on the first year's operations under United States Government supervision of the major German company taken over by the Alien Property Custodian.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- The Russian communiques describing yesterday's operations returned to a phrase long absent from war reports, saying no significant changes occurred. The front, however, is far from quiet.

IN NORTHEASTERN BRAZIL, March 27 (AP) -- Sixty-two German war prisoners are held here, healthy and quite happy. The tall, blond, blue-eyed men formed the crew of a German raider that they scuttled when intercepted between Africa and Brazil.

The older sections of New York City are scarred with widespread decay. They present the same opportunity for complete rebuilding as do the bombed areas of European cities. The devastating effects of obsolescence and population drift are among the deep-seated causes of the constantly recurring budget crises which now annually confront the city.

Although last week's war news was still confused and at times contradictory, the forward movement in both stocks and bonds was resumed. On Friday, transactions in stocks reached 2,142,880 shares, the largest day's trading since December, 1941, and THE TIMES average was the highest since September of that year, though far below the best figures of the six preceding years.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Office of Price Administration released today details of the new meats and fats rationing program as it affects "primary distributor establishments," the producing and processing plants and importers, large and small, from which will flow the great variety of rationed meats, cheeses, canned fish products, butter and other edible fats and oils.
Sixty-four fellowships, with grants of funds totaling $140,000, were announced yesterday by the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation, to assist research and creative work.

LONDON, March 28 -- A message to the New York mass meeting scheduled this week to protest against the execution of the Polish Socialist leaders, Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter, was read tonight by the Labor party leader, George Dallas, as chairman at a gathering of international Socialists commemorating victims of the Soviet.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company operated at a deficit of $81, 683 in 1942, and in the five years from 1938 to 1942, inclusive, it has operated at a loss of more than $850,000, primarily because of "two-men" operating rule of the Transport Workers Union and sharply increased taxes, John A. Ritchie, chairman, declared yesterday in his annual report to stockholders, employes and the public.

BUFFALO, March 28 (AP) -- Philip J. Clowes, associate director of the War Production Board's labor division, said today that "the job of licking absenteeism is the job of labor and management working together."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 28 -- Whenever anything becomes "confusion utterly confounded" the Dodgers are sure to be responsible. Today they played their first exhibition game against a combination Montreal Royals-Durham Bulls team, a queer combat witnessed by 2,100 frozen fans, a majority of them from Flatbush -- and nobody knows yet who won.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- There is an ample supply of surface moisture for the Winter wheat crop in virtually all sections of the main producing area except the western third of Kansas and Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle, according to trade and official returns, but more rain or snow is needed in the dry areas and unless it is received, further deterioration in the outlook is anticipated.

The American people embark upon point rationing of meats, cheese, fats and canned fish today, following assurances by Federal Government spokesmen last night that a number of independent packers have been authorized to rush supplies of beef to meat-famished areas where ration coupons otherwise would be of little value.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Wheat prices tended lower last week despite approval by the House and Senate of a bill that would prevent inclusion of benefit payments to farmers determining what constistuted parity prices. At the inside figures the market showed a decline of around 5 1/2 cents a bushel from the recent high marks, with sentiment much less bullish than had been the case recently.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 28 -- Three young students of Munich University were sentenced to death and hanged last week after the Gestapo had discovered an anti-Nazi group within the school which wrote and distributed seditious tracts among the students.

A United Lenten Preaching Program went forward yesterday in a cooperative effort on the part of pastors to reach the unchurched residents in the area from Fifty-ninth Street to 110th Street and from Central Park West to Riverside Drive.
CHUNKING, China, March 28 (UP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- In the first "surface-to-surface" action reported in the Aleutians area, a light detachment of American warships exchanged shots with a formidable Japanese force of four cruisers and four destroyers Friday and apparently drove them away, the Navy announced today.

Top honors in the sixth annual national invitation college basketball tournament, with the added incentive of a chance to meet the winner of the National Collegiate A.A. championship in the big Red Cross benefit game on Thursday night, will be at stake tonight at Madison Square Garden, where St. John's and Toledo clash in the final.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 28 -- The Yankee reconstruction program was threatened today by the war's demands.

To Several of his visitors in recent weeks President Roosevelt has recounted a story which has passed into a proverb in the Balkans. It tells of the advice given to his son by a priest of the Rumanian Orthodox Church. The boy was starting on a long journey and the old priest was warning him of the dangers that lurked along the road.

A memorial mass of requiem will be celebrated at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, at 11 A.M. Wednesday for Lieutenant (j.g.) Thomas Sergeant La Farge, commander of the Coast Guard cutter Natsek, who, with his crew of thirty, was reported missing recently by the Navy.

Arbitrary production quotas, which tend to stifle the ingenuity of manufacturers, must be rescinded if minimum civilian needs are to be met and if small dealers are not to be forced out of business by shortages, Roscoe R. Rau, vice president and executive secretary of the National Retail Furniture Association, declared in an interview here yesterday.
ALBANY, March 29 (AP) -- Issuance of war service diplomas to high school pupils who leave school early to assist in Spring planting on farms was approved today by the State Board of Regents.

Hailing the appointment of Chester C. Davis as Food Administrator and the announced policy of greatly extending draft deferment of farm workers as important moves toward an integrated food program, the Guaranty Trust Company, in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey, at the same time warns that all steps thus far taken do not appear to be sufficiently well coordinated or thoroughgoing to meet the requirements of the situation.

We have heard much talk in recent years that in America, once the land of opportunity, there is no longer room at the top for the man who begins with nothing but character. It never troubled James A. Farrell. For twenty-one years he had occupied his place at the top as president of the United States Steel Corporation, the greatest industrial unit in the world.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 29 -- For the first time since the launching of the Allied offensive to break the Axis positions in Tunisia, today's Italian communique and the military spokesman in his press conference began preparing the Italian people for the worst.

The Allied Spring offensive, begun about two weeks ago with the aim of throwing the Germans and Italians out of Africa and opening up the soft underbelly of the Axis for an invasion of the European continent, has produced its first important victory. After what Berlin describes as a "murderous" battle lasting for eight days, the veteran British Eighth Army under General Montgomery has smashed through the Mareth Line.

Allen Co. notified Automatic Products Corporation that it proposes to exercise its option to purchase 138,000 shares of Great American Industries, Inc., owned by Automatic and will pay for such shares at the agreed price before the option expires on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -The Truman War Investigating Committee reported today that it pays "both in personal satisfaction and in dollars" for war contractors to tailor their profits to a size "which can clearly be defended in the court of public opinion."

As nation-wide point rationing of meats and other foods began yesterday and the Federal Government halted Army and lend-lease buying for two weeks to replenish vanishing civilian food supplies, New York City received only 100,000 pounds of the promised 1,250,000-pound meat supply that Wilson Co., Chicago packer, is rushing here from the Midwest.

Major Gen. James A. Ulio, Adjutant General of the Army, asserted yesterday that the projected Army of 8,200,000 by the end of 1943 was the minimum force needed to achieve victory in the present war situation.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, West of Gabes, March 28 (Delayed) -- In his biggest gamble of the entire African campaign General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery has outfoxed the "Fox of the Desert" by one of the boldest and most daring manoeuvres accomplished by the British Eighth Army in its campaign to drive Field Marshal Erwin Rommel out of North Africa.

LONDON, March 29 (U.P.) -- Captain Byron W. Miller of Houston, Texas, searched his torpedoed ship from stem to stern for crew members who might still be aboard, ceremoniously hoisted the Stars and Stripes and then consented to leave the sinking vessel, the War Shipping Administration disclosed today.

The most pressing public health problem at the moment is the relocation of physicians and dentists to care for "scarcity areas" of civilian need, Professor Harvey B. Stone of the Johns Hopkins Medical School, member of the Procurement and Assignment Service supplying medical and allied personnel to the armed forces, said last night.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Byrd joint committee, which is seeking to slash governmental expenditures through reductions and eliminations of non-war New Deal agencies, was told today by John H. Fahey, commissioner of the Home Loan Bank Administration, that in the case of the Home Owners Loan Corporation the only road to savings was to continue it until 1948 or later.
A two-year search for the last of three, suspects in the fatal shooting of Frank Servicio ended early yesterday with the arrest of Frank Demaria, 24 years old.

COINCIDENCE certainly has a mighty long arm. The day after mention was made here of Jim Thorpe, this operative found himself in a gathering of football men whose opening topic of conversation, oddly enough, was the great Indian.

ALGIERS, March 29 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, conferred again today with General Georges Catroux, head of the Fighting French mission here, on plans for the reconstruction of France.
WASHINGTON March 29 -- Reorganization of the Office of Vice Chairman for Operations and Appointments was announced today by Donald. D. Davis, WPB vice chairman.

The Treasury is losing no time in drawing on its war loan deposits in commercial bank depositaries. Late yesterday afternoon such depositaries were notified that the Treasury will make withdrawals on Thursday, Friday and Saturday, equivalent, in the aggregate, to 24 per cent of such deposits in these banks as of the close of business last Saturday, less the previously announced calls, effective yesterday and today.

Mayor La Guardia entered yesterday the battle between rights and lefts in the labor movement over the execution by the Soviet Government of Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter, when it was announced that he would be a speaker at the memorial protest meeting for the two Polish labor leaders at Mecca Temple tonight.

Confident that the courts will declare the office of Mayor vacant if Mayor La Guardia accepts a commission as a brigadier general, as he is expected to do soon, Democratic leaders have begun discussion of potential candidates for an election this Fall, it was learned yesterday.
A German communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has announced that Kathryn Grayson and Van Johnson will have two of the three leading roles in "A Tale of Two Sisters," a story of the rivalry of two sisters, one a prima donna and the other a torch singer.

The 'cello is an elusive, exacting instrument for solo recital purposes. To play it well is not enough; it must be played brilliantly if it is to sustain interest over a whole evening. Stefan Auber, who appeared at the Town Hall last night, is an accomplished 'cellist, and he undoubtedly makes a happy partner in ensemble music, but his attainments are not outstanding enough for the challenge of an entire program.
President Roosevelt intervened again in the soft coal wage dispute yesterday and averted the threatened strike in the Southern area of the Appalachian region.

The ten section chairmen of the employes' gifts committee of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City have reported "splendid progress" in their task of organizing solicitation effort among the employes and executives of New York business concerns, it was announced yesterday by John H. Callen, chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Dissatisfied over "leaks" which enabled the trade and public to learn of contemplated reductions in the April point values of processed foods, the OPA will follow a much different procedure when May values are fixed, according to word here tonight.
