Having read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 26 the article of Alice Gorham suggesting that men in the Merchant Marine be given some official status in the matter of uniforms for members of this fine body of men and gold stars for the heroic mothers who have given their sons in this branch of the service, I wish to express my own views on a somewhat similar matter.

John Maynard Lord Keynes has acquired world-wide reputation as an antagonist of stability of foreign exchange rates and as a champion of currency devaluation and credit expansion. His doctrines triumphed when England went off the gold standard in 1931 and embarked upon increased protectionism, and when all other nations very soon followed the British example.

Dr. Charles Dewey Crandall, senior deputy medical superintendent at Bellevue Hospital, was ousted March 4 for refusing to accept a transfer made necessary by the war shortage of physicians, it was revealed yesterday by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals.

Even if it is too early in the season to preserve much except citrus fruits, it isn't at all premature to start thinking about a Victory garden, to plan what you will can during the Summer and how you will do it. Accordingly, this department commends to your attention a helpful handbook just issued by the American Women's Voluntary Services and entitled "Garden for Victory."

OTTAWA, March 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian National Railways System had its most profitable year's operation during 1942 and was able to turn over $25,063,268 to the government after payment of taxes and interest to the public and government, it was shown today when the annual report was tabled in the House of Commons by Transport Minister J.E. Michaud.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The War Production Board assured American housewives today that the more than 3,000,000,000 jar covers to be made available for home canning would fit almost any type of canning jar.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 29 -- The British Eighth Army under General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery has outflanked and occupied the main positions of the Mareth Line after a brilliant enveloping move across the fringe of the Sahara, it was officially announced today.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 9 per cent last week under the comparative 1942 week, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. In the preceding week the bank had reported a decline of 3 per cent.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 29 -- Delegates of labor organizations representing 300,000 workers visited Vice President Henry A. Wallace at his residence today. They explained the problems of the different groups, stressing their firm allegiance to democracy and their firm ambition to work side by side with the United States and the other Allies to defeat nazism and fascism.

The National Collegiate A.A. basketball championships will be decided tonight at Madison Square Garden, when Georgetown, Eastern survivor, and Wyoming, standardbearer of the West, meet in the final. The winner will clash with St. John's, national invitation kingpin, in a Red Cross benefit engagement Thursday night at the Garden.

NEWARK, N.J., March 29 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal Court panel by a 2 to 1 vote today dismissed proceedings brought by a group of indicted meat wholesalers attacking the constitutionality of the Federal Emergency Price Control Act of 1942.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, March 30 (U.P.) -- Allied Hudson bombers set fires visible fifteen miles in daylight in a low-level raid Monday on the Japanese-occupied town of Tual, trading center and pre-war capital of the Kei and Tenimber Islands and raided two other enemy-held towns in the Kei group.

LONDON, March 29 -- Lord Keynes's report recommending an international clearing union, with a currency of its own to be geared to gold and to be known as "Bancor," is not the only plan of that nature being prepared here. The noted economist's recommendation, soon to be published by the Exchequer as a White Paper, is to be followed by other comprehensive plans for post-war agreements on international investments and trade treaties.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 29 (AP) -- Extensive battles between Yugoslav patriots and German forces and the arrival of fresh German troops in Belgrade were reported today in well informed Balkan quarters.

MONTREAL, March 29 (Canadian Press) -- Thousands of Montrealers plodded homeward on foot tonight as the tie-up of street cars and buses that resulted from a strike of Montreal Tramways Company employes remained air-tight.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A bill to empower the government to seize and operate plants where war work is halted by labor disputes "or other cause" was revived today, the Senate Judiciary Committee voting unanimously to recommend its passage.

NEW ROCHELLE. N.Y., March 29 -- Representatives of thirteen community chest organizations in Westchester County met here tonight to discuss plans to combine the annual Fall appeal for funds of the groups with the drive of the National War Fund.
CHICAGO, March 29 -- The open hearths and blast furnaces of the Gary (Ind.) works of the Carnegie Steel Corporation for the first time in thirty-five years have admitted women.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- One hundred and fifty-seven war workers from eighteen States, ranging from Massachusetts to California, including nine women, were named by the War Production Board today as winners of national honors for suggestions that increase and improve production.

BENAIRES, India, March 26 (Delayed) -- An eloquent plea to the United States to understand and help India in her distress was made to me this morning by Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, grand old man of Hindu India, whose long career began with the formation of the Congress party in 1885.

The Army, Navy and Lend-Lease Administration agreed yesterday to cooperate with the Office of Price Administration to provide meat supplies for relieving acute shortages which may develop in any district in the first few days of coupon rationing.
The Ruml plan seems to be subject to various and widely diversified interpretations in its application to the realities of the present tax situation.

With less than a month of pre-Easter selling now remaining, indications are that the back-order and delivery situation on Spring garments will begin to show some easing this week following the extremely tight situation which has prevailed for several months, according to reports in merchandising quarters here yesterday.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 22, under an Associated Press byline, there appeared a news item entitled "Anti-Bias Plea Is Passed."

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., March 29 -- With clenched fists which she pounded on a table to give emphasis to fighting words, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek exhorted workers of America tonight to increase industrial production to end the war "at the earliest moment possible."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 29 -- Returning to the warmth of the West Point field house today after having invited chilblains and pneumonia by their battle with the temperature here yesterday, both the Dodgers and the assorted Montreal Royals and other minor leaguers went through a complete workout indoors.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, March 30 (AP) -- The noon communique:

An entire floor in the remodeled dwelling at 51 East Fifty-first Street has been leased to William N. Robson of the Columbia Broadcasting System through Warren Marks Associates, brokers. Other rentals follow:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Future fighting plans for every area of the Pacific Ocean were outlined in Washington at a series of "post-Casablanca" conferences just concluded between the Joint Chiefs of Staff and fifteen top-ranking representatives of Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, General Douglas MacArthur and Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., the War Department revealed today.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday for 1942 a consolidated net income of $30,558,547 after taxes, charges and reserves for depreciation and depletion, equal to $2.35 each on the 13,003,953 capital shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Cooperation has been promised by the Army, Navy and Lend-Lease Administration to relieve any unusually acute meat shortages which may develop during the next few days, the Office of Price Administration stated today.
PINEHURST, N.C., March 29 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta won the qualifying medal today in the forty-first annual North and South women's golf championship with a 41, 37 -- 78.
LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The sixteen-day visit to this country of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, came to a formal close tonight with a dinner given in his honor by Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

The twelfth biennial international water-color exhibition will open to the public at the Brooklyn Museum on April 9. A preview and luncheon will be held the previous afternoon. The exhibition will be installed in the entrance hall and in the adjoining special exhibition gallery and will continue through May 23.
LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The debate on the tax bill closed tonight amid denunciations that it was "class legislation," and with several of the substitutes which will be offered subjected to a crossfire of opinion.

The regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that, in addition to home owners, several other groups would be eligible for ration certificates enabling them to buy coal-burning stoves.

Theft of $90,000 worth of precious stones while they were being flown here from Burbank, Calif., for Princess Doris Farid es Sultanah, former wife of S.S. Kresge, chain store owner, was revealed yesterday.

Two City College professors of German, who together have served there a total of fifty-four years, will retire in June, after having reached the mandatory retirement age of 70. They are Professor Edwin C. Roedder, chairman of the German Department since 1929, and Assistant Professor Carl W. Kinkeldey, who has been on the faculty since 1903.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Frank Krulikowski, who won the WPB's certificate of individual merit for helping to avert a bottleneck at the Westinghouse Electric Manufacturing Company's meter division plant in Newark, is 43 years old and the father of three soldiers and father-in-law of a fourth soldier.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- The merger of two groups of brokerage houses to submit a single bid for $52,000,000 principal amount of first mortgage bonds, due 1972, of Puget Sound Power and Light Company was defended today in a hearing before a trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission as a necessary expedient.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The House of Representatives as it enters the last stages of debate on the new tax bill is hearing from the country, and the overwhelming popular message is that an equitable plan for pay-as-you-go taxation is expected of the legislators.

Mayor La Guardia's recent suggestion that consumers report to him or the Department of Markets if they feel they are being charged more than ceiling prices for foodstuffs by wholesalers or retailers has resulted in about 200 such complaints being received at his office in City Hall in the last three weeks, Market Commissioner Daniel P. Woolley said yesterday.

Peru is now prepared to supply "huge quantities" of rubber, quinine and other strategic materials and, under the terms of a pact signed recently with the United States, is selling its entire output of quinine, twenty-four tons yearly, to this country at cost, Dr. Cesar Gordillo, Director General of Public Health, of Peru, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt contended today that women throughout the country would have to do more to match the war effort of the women of Great Britain, Russia and China if they desired to speak "the same language" as the other women of the world in the peace.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- United States planes, fighting the Japanese in the Solomons, stop at nothing, even "butting down" the enemy on occasion, and one brash American pilot was "decorated" with the Rising Sun for such an exploit, Rear Admiral John S. McCain, Chief of the Navy Bureau of Aeronautics, revealed today.

General Foods Corporation has sold control of Frosted Foods, Ltd., of London, England, to Lever Bros. Unilever, Ltd., already deeply interested in the preserved foods industries, it was announced yesterday by Edwin T. Gibson, vice president of General Foods.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29 -- The proposal by Electric Bond and Share Company to spend $15,000,000 to purchase a portion of its outstanding preferred stock in the open market was supported today by four stockholders in a hearing before a trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (U.P.) -- Gardner Cowles Jr., publisher and director of the OWI's domestic division, tonight criticized American distrust of the Soviet Union and called on the United States to make an "unequivocal commitment" on post-war collaboration with Russia and other members of the United Nations.

Rationing, and especially meat rationing, may be endured more philosophically if we bear in mind certain facts about the American diet. Normally that diet -- with local exceptions caused by poverty or poverty and ignorance combined -- is the most diversified and abundant in the world.

BEYOND EL GUETTAR, Tunisia, March 29 -- American infantry, hammering ahead through fierce mortar and artillery fire, captured the German stronghold of Djebel el Mcheltat, a 1,500-foot hill, during the night after attacking it throughout yesterday.

WITH ALLIED TROOPS IN CENTRAL TUNISIA, March 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Eight American soldiers who were held prisoner by the Germans for a short time owed their release today to accurate American artillery shooting that landed a high explosive shell right on the nose of the vehicle in which they were riding with their captors.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA March 29 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 29 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Prentiss M. Brown, wife of the price administrator, who "hasn't seen any meat for a long time," hopes that meat rationing will provide more steaks, roasts and chops for every one.

Although American cotton textile output in 1942 reached an all-time high, with gains of 50 per cent or more in yardage and in fiber consumption, recent "unsettling developments" mean that even greater efforts will be required if the industry is to maintain peak production in 1913, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared yesterday in his annual report.

CHICAGO, March 29 -Chicago meat packers commended the move suspending government set-aside quotas temporarily as an action which would not only enable wholesalers and retailers to build up stocks to meet rationing requirements, but one which would have a favorable psychological effect on the public.

A tribute to the memory of Sergei Rachmaninoff was paid by Alexander Uninsky, Russian pianist, in his second recital this season at Carnegie Hall last night. Mr. Uninsky played the Chopin Funeral March immediately after the intermission as the audience that filled the auditorium that was so many times the scene of Rachmaninoff triumphs stood and then sat down without applause.

A proposal favoring two meatless days a week, but with Tuesday not being one of them, was approved by the Society of Restaurateurs at a meeting last night in the London Terrace Restaurant, 405 West Twenty-third Street, as one practical means of meeting the meat shortage.

Even the letter carrier got drawn into it. He was covering his route along Ninth Avenue yesterday when he spied a mobile unit of the American Women's Voluntary Services parked at Fortieth Street. Stepping over to the open window, he looked just as puzzled as the other men and women standing around.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- United States naval and air forces in the Aleutians were described today as on the alert against the possible return of the Japanese heavy surface force with which American warships clashed Friday west of Attu, but no further details of the battle were revealed by the Navy.
HONOLULU, March 29 -- Honolulu bade more than 2,600 Japanese-American soldiers a typical chamber of commerce aloha yesterday before probably the largest crowd in the city's history.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The National War Labor Board claimed today jurisdiction over all labor disputes, large and small, whether in war industries or not, whether they are disputes affecting intrastate commerce or interstate commerce, whether they involve strikes or threats of strikes in hotel barbershops, in laundries or cleaning and dyeing establishments or elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- President Roosevelt has filled out his corps of half a dozen White House administrative assistants by selection of Jonathan Daniels of Raleigh, N.C.

Wilson Co. of Chicago, meat packers, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the issuance and proposed public offering of $20,000,000 of 3 per cent first, mortgage bonds due 1958 by a banking group headed by Smith, Barney Co. and Glore, Forgan Co. Preliminary announcement concerning the bond issue was made last week.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The present system of apportioning physicians between the armed forces and the civilian population is "inadequate," the Office of War Information asserted today in making public the results of a survey.

Eleven straight points, after they had spent the first eight and a half minutes of the second half scoreless, broke the game wide open for the Redmen of St. John's and Joe Lapchick's team went on to overwhelm Toledo, 48 -- 27, in the final of the sixth annual national invitation college basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

The report of American Airlines, Inc., and subsidiary companies for 1942 by A.N. Kemp, president, shows a net profit of $3,016,869, excluding $834,846 from the sale of flight equipment sold at the direction of the government. The net was equal to $4.88 each on the 574,848 outstanding shares of common stock after preferred stock dividends.

Sergei Rachmaninoff was one of the towering figures of music in our time. He achieved this position entirely through his gifts as an interpreter and creator of music. He never sought to cut a figure in the world other than as a musician. He gave few interviews, issued fewer pronunciamentos and held himself aloof from the narrow disputes that trouble the world of music.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- In a pamphlet entitled "Battle Stations for All," issued today, the Office of War Information outlines a plan for three more ration books, following War Ration Book No. 2. The new books, it was stated, could be put into use without warning.

LUCKNOW, India, March 25 (Delayed) -- The story of how they learned the value of the Indian rupee was told by some American soldiers to Lady Hallett, wife of the Governor of the United Provinces, Sir Maurice Hallett, a few days ago.

LONDON, March 29 -- With rather mischievious, if unconscious, irony, London shops were just beginning to show this year's new utility fashions about the time that Hugh Dalton, president of the Board of Trade, was announcing that clothing coupons would have to last until Sept. 1 instead of Aug. 1 as originally intended.

TRENTON, N. J., March 29 -- Acting without assurance that the Republican-controlled Senate would grant confirmation and ignoring a last-minute attack by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Governor Charles Edison today nominated Dr. John W. Studebaker of Washington, the United States Commissioner of Education, to succeed Dr. Charles H. Elliott of New Brunswick as New Jersey State Commissioner of Education.

The building containing 11,000 square feet of space at 25-28 Fiftieth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has been leased by the Richmond Radiator Company, Inc., to the Quality Art Novelty Company, Inc, Lehr Benes were the brokers.
Just how informed are the informed quarters so often cited in the news? How well informed are the well-informed sources from which so much news is derived? Just how high is a highly informed person?
Lieutenant J. Gordon Douglas, U.S.A., and Mrs. Douglas of Westbury, L.I., are at Hampshire House.

If the international date line were a real instead of an imaginary line it would roughly represent our Pacific air and naval front except in the far southwest, where we have thrust a sharp wedge into New Guinea and the Solomons. Since the Battle of Midway the Japanese have never ventured to cross this line in strength.

The balance of payments between the United States and foreign countries, now largely on a government-to-government basis, no longer require cash settlements and foreign trade has ceased to be influenced by peacetime considerations, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its twenty-eighth annual report, released yesterday.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 29 -Two very swell fellows named Melvin T. Ott and Leo (Gabby) Hartnett began a great battle of wits today as Jersey City's Little Giants arrived for their first workout. Inasmuch as they had to drill at the same time as the big Giants they pretty soon were swallowed up completely, a matter which Gabby feared would happen practically from the beginning.

LONDON, March 29 (U.P.) -- Axis forces claimed to have sunk 972,600 tons of Allied shipping during the first four weeks of March, according to a Berlin broadcast heard today by Exchange Telegraph. German submarines were credited with the destruction of 790,100 tons of shipping, while the Italian navy and air force claimed 182,500 tons.

Reflecting the effects of wartime transportation restrictions, passenger traffic on railroads and ferryboats serving New York City increased about 13.5 per cent in 1942 over 1941, while the vehicular traffic on ferryboats, bridges and tunnels dropped sharply, the Transit Commission disclosed yesterday in its annual report.

MOSCOW, March 29 -- The seventy-fifth anniversary of the birth of Maxim Gorki was marked by several days of ceremonies, in which the writer's work was shown on the stage and screen, discussed at meetings and interpreted in the press throughout the Soviet Union.

The Italian-American Labor Council, an organization representing 300,000 organized workers of Italian origin, headed by Luigi Antonini, announced yesterday that Attorney General Francis J. Biddle would receive the council's newly established Four Freedoms Award.

Child-placing agencies are now faced with the problem of fewer and, in many cases, substandard foster homes with a correspondingly greater need for them by parents entering war work, Miss Dorothy Hutchinson, Assistant Professor of Social Work at Columbia University's School of Social Work, reports in a book "In Quest of Foster Parents," just published by Columbia University Press.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -Chester C. Davis, taking over the job of producing the food necessary for a United Nations victory, appointed another banker as associate food administrator today and gave orders to Department of Agriculture employes that the status quo, as far as they were concerned, was to continue for the present.

With the opening this week of the trout season in the State, anglers are looking up bus schedules and train schedules and other ways and means of reachng the streams without gasoline. There are, however, probably a good many for whom it is impossible at present to plan being out, either at the start of the season or at any certain time later.

Although the fight against venereal diseases "is going better in the present war" than in World War I it is "not going well enough," Dr. Walter Clarke, executive director of the American Social Hygiene Association, said yesterday in making public the association's annual report.

DETROIT, March 29 (AP) -- Jimmy Orlando, 28-year-old player of the Detroit Red Wings, National League Hockey team, pleaded guilty today to a charge of obtaining draft deferment by posing as an essential war worker.

Oscar Serlin will present "The Family," a play by Victor Wolfson based on the novel by Nina Fedorova, at the Windsor tonight. The premiere was first scheduled for last Tuesday. Featured in the cast of twenty-one performers are Lucile Watson, Carol Goodner, Evelyn Varden, Nicholas Conte, Elisabeth Fraser and AnoldKorff.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -Secretary Morgenthau said today that March income tax collections are running ahead of last year and that reports indicate they will exceed Treasury estimates by $250,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York, in a statement made to the Interstate Commerce Commission, inferred today that Southern States normally Democratic were threatening political reprisals if the freight rate differentials against the South were not wiped out, and called upon the I.C.C. to decide the pending rate case "on the merits and on the facts," without doing an injustice to New York.

Brooklyn soldier invoked yesterday the Soldiers and Sailors Civil Relief Act to save his family from regular visits by collectors for debts incurred before he was inducted. Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff reserved decision.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 30 -- Russian tanks and infantry shock troops, fighting their way into the main German defense system before Smolensk, have smashed a series of enemy pill boxes and captured three inhabited places, the Soviet Monday midnight communique said today.

The report for 1942 of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, released for publication today, shows that the road broke all previous records for traffic. Gross operating revenues were $181,809,761, an increase of $31,572,427 over those of 1941. Net income was $33,153,436 after charges and taxes of $49,998,351, compared with $44,939,743. Taxes in 1941 were $19,678,804.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Navy reported today eight casualties, including two dead, and six missing.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 30 -- The Royal Air Force bombed Berlin last night for the second time in three nights and also attacked targets in the Ruhr Valley, British officials announced today.

" Hitler -- Dead Or Alive," a topical melodrama, will open this morning at the Globe. Produced by Ben Judell and directed by Nick Grinde, the picture features Ward Bond, Dorothy Tree, Paul Fix, Bob Watson and Warren Hymer. . . . "Dead Men Walk" and "The Fighting Buckaroo" compose the week's new dual bill, opening today, at the New York Theatre.

Beau Jack, lightweight champion, and Henry Armstrong, former triple crown holder, went through their workouts at Stillman's Gym yesterday before a capacity crowd. The pair will meet at Madison Square Garden on Friday night in a ten-round non-title battle.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan made public yesterday his annual report, in which he revealed a sharp decrease last year in the total of crimes in New York County, fewer even than in the administration of his predecessor, Governor Dewey, but showing a marked increase in crimes of violence and sex offenses, particularly the latter.

CAIRO, March 29 (AP) -- Major Gen. Hoo Hsien-chung, whose tanks inflicted the first defeat in open battle in this war on the Japanese, at Taierhchwang in Kiangsu Province in 1937, has come to North Africa to see American tanks in action and if possible to thumb a ride on one.

LONDON, March 29 -- The appointment of an Allied high commissioner for education in Germany to cooperate with the occupying authorities in eradicating the effects of Nazi propaganda was advocated in a report published today by the joint commission of the London International Assembly and the Council for Education in World Citizenship.

Irving Premisler testified in his defense yesterday in his General Sessions trial with Harry Ehrlich on a first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Harry Nichols, Williamsburg gambling "overlord," in the Essex Street BMT subway station in September, 1933.

" Art, a Weapon for Total War" is the title of a large, rambling and extremely diverse exhibition that opened yesterday, to continue until April 16. It starts on the fifth floor of the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, rambles down to the fourth and thence to the third.

The stock market continued active and strong yesterday, advancing to new highs in the recovery movement which began early in January. Many of the largest gains on the day were in high grade preferred shares and common stocks of investment caliber.

LONDON, Tuesday, March 30 (AP) -- British bombers, which blast'ed' the Brovul House, headquarters i of the Nazi party, during the con!centrated attk on lVZunich-the night of March 9, devastated about fifty blocks of commercial buildin. gs and caused extensive damage to military establishments in the Bavarian city, the Air' inistry! announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- If neither the Ruml plan nor the "no abatement" tax bill drawn by the Ways and Means Committee musters a majority, one Democratic leader predicted today, the whole pay-as-you-go issue may be tossed back to committee, resulting in long delay on final disposition.

OTTAWA, Ont., March 29 (Canadian Press) -- The government has instructed the Canadian Wheat Board to permit the marketing of all durum wheat produced in the West in 1942, Trade Minister James MacKinnon announced today in the House of Commons.

Thirty-four survivors of a Norwegian vessel torpedoed and sunk last month in the North Atlantic barely escaped a second torpedoing within an hour, the Navy disclosed yesterday at Boston, where the seamen were landed, The United Press reported.

CHUNGKING, March 29 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces, striking behind the Japanese lines in the Hupeh-Hunan border area, have recaptured two localities south of the Yangtze and encircled others in "ferocious" attacks that inflicted severe losses on the enemy, it was announced today.

A meeting in observance of Religious Book Week will be held Thursday evening at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

LONDON, March 29 (U.P.) -- Both the Axis and the Allies have assured Spain that they will respect her neutrality, reliable diplomatic informants said today, but Spaniards were reported to be nervous still because of the presence of German troops on their frontier.
A Japanese communique, as broadcast by Tokyo and recorded by The United Press:

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Plans to get more equipment for farmers and to distribute it without running afoul of Federal anti-trust laws were discussed at the opening session here today of a two-day conference of farm equipment manufacturers and government officials.
LONDON, March 29 -- The old American military slogan, "Don't shoot until you see the whites of their eyes," has become a handicap for one section of the modern United States Army.
The time is at hand to insure an inspired determination in the American people to win the war and retain democracy in this country "by turning loose the giant of advertising."

On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures fluctuated yesterday within a 4-to-10-point range and closed unchanged to 3 points below Saturday's final quotations as business slackened on the announcement that President Roosevelt would confer soon with Food Administrator Chester C. Davis, Secretary of Agriculture Claude R. Wickard, Price Administrator Prentiss Brown and members of the Congressional farm bloc on pricing and production of food.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Large receipts of cash wheat at Northwestern and Southwestern markets that were taken by elevator concerns on a liberal scale brought in sufficient hedging pressure to give the market on the Board of Trade a heavy undertone, and closing sales were 1/4 cent a bushel lower.

DANBURY, Conn., March 29 -Mayor William J. Hannah, Democratic incumbent, was reelected today for his second term in Danbury's municipal election, defeating his Republican opponent, W. Edwin Harrison, by a majority of 619 votes.
LONDON, March 29 -- The latest news from Tunisia created a cheerful feeling in the stock markets although trading was sluggish.
LONDON, Tuesday, March 30 (UP) -- The Soviet midnight communique, as broadcast by Moscow:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 29 (U.P.) -- The Brazilian Government has decided on active military participation in the war, it was learned today, and unless unforeseen obstacles develop, a Brazilian expeditionary force will be sent abroad for active duty as soon as possible.
Eight new leases in the Empire Trust Building, 580 Fifth Avenue, were announced yesterday by Ruford D. Franklin, owner's representative.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 100 by 98.9 feet at 37-43 West Twenty-sixth Street and the five-story adjoining structure on the east known as 35 West Twenty-sixth Street have been purchased by David W. Frankel, operator, from the West Twenty-sixth Street Corporation.

LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- Headquarters of the Eighth Air Force announced today awards of decorations to 530 American airmen following a ceremony at which forty-two other members of Army Air Forces bomber crews, including Major Algene E. Key of Meridian, Miss., noted endurance and combat pilot, were formally decorated by Colonel John H. Hayden of Tampa, Fla.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Chairman Jerry Giesler of the California Racing Commission said tonight that he had advised the Bay Meadows Race Track near San Francisco to accept, tentatively, entries for racing next Thursday. Friday and Saturday, for Navy Relief.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A full-dress international conference on post-war monetary stabilization to resolve differences between British and American approaches to the problem appeared likely today after an ambitious plan for an international clearing union had been disclosed in London.
MOSCOW, March 29 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Edward R. Stettinius, lend-lease administrator, issued a statement today, as meat rationing went into effect in this country, reporting on lend-lease shipments of food in the first two months of this year.

Bennett Cerf will interview Lewis Gannett, book reviewer of The New York Herald Tribune, on the "Books Are Bullets" program over WQXR tomorrow at 5 P.M. The program is a weekly feature of the station and is sponsored by the Council on Books in Wartime.
CHUNGKING, China, March 29 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Housewives may pay their ration points in advance for home deliveries of butter and cheese, the Office of Price Administration said today. This authorization allows for early morning and late afternoon deliveries when often housekeepers are not at home to make point payments. Now, for instance, when butter is ordered on Monday to be delivered on Friday, payment can be made when ordered.

LONDON, March 29 -- A case alleging food rationing offenses against Major Gen. Sir Percy Laurie, Provost Marshal of Britain [chief of military police], occupies many columns in this evening's newspapers.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 100 by 98.9 feet at 37-43 West Twenty-sixth Street and the five-story adjoining structure on the east known as 35 West Twenty-sixth Street have been purchased by David W. Frankel, operator, from the West Twenty-sixth Street Corporation.

LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- Headquarters of the Eighth Air Force announced today awards of decorations to 530 American airmen following a ceremony at which forty-two other members of Army Air Forces bomber crews, including Major Algene E. Key of Meridian, Miss., noted endurance and combat pilot, were formally decorated by Colonel John H. Hayden of Tampa, Fla.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Chairman Jerry Giesler of the California Racing Commission said tonight that he had advised the Bay Meadows Race Track near San Francisco to accept, tentatively, entries for racing next Thursday. Friday and Saturday, for Navy Relief.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 29 -- Presenting an Army and Navy E pennant to the contractors for the United States naval air station this afternoon, Rear Admiral Jules James, commandant of the United States naval operating base, said he desired to express his gratification for the speed with which the base had been constructed and for the splendid spirit displayed.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The President saw Secretary Wickard and farm organization leaders and Governor Johnston of South Carolina and held a press conference.
Signs pointed to it and so did the painted wagon in Times Square but when the big fellow walked into the office -- that made it official.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Industrial confusion as chaotic as that which produced the fall of France was pictured today as a certainty if foremen and supervisors in war factories are permitted to form unions.

American industry should submit to the government information on its position in the post-war period, so that the government "can establish a realistic plan of its functions in post-war matters," Herman L. Hirt, assistant to the president of International General Electric Company, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Rejecting centralization of taxing power in the Federal Government as a solution to the problem of overlapping Federal, State and local taxation, the Committee on Inter-Governmental Fiscal Relations after two years of study has recommended "coordination and cooperation" to Secretary Morgenthau as the preferable approach.
Paul Windels's letter to THE TIMES presents two points: (1) A fine housing project contemplated by an insurance company; (2) to make this possible, a plea for partial tax exemption.

LONDON, March 30 -- Two powerful fleets of British and Canadian bombers set Berlin aflame last night for the second time in three nights and bombed the great Ruhr Valley coal production center of Bochum for the first time in more than two years.
The church should seek to reform systems as well as save souls, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Church, declared yesterday.

"Air Force" today starts a ninth week at the Hollywood Theatre. . . . Beginning second weeks today are "Happy Go Lucky," at the Paramount; "Hello, Frisco, Hello," at the Roxy, and "Diary of a Nazi," the Russian film at the Stanley. . . . "It Ain't Hay," today starts its fourth and final week at Loew's Criterion. . . .

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- Republic announced today that in collaboration with the Navy it will produce a picture, "The Fighting Seabees," about the Navy Construction Battalions. This will be the most ambitious program in the history of this company and will carry a budget of $1,500,000, it is stated.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has built up what it considers the most important collection of Latin-American art in the world. In an exhibition that opened with a preview yesterday, filling all of the galleries on the second floor, 224 new acquisitions in this field were placed on view for the first time here.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Reports of dry weather and dust storms in Western Kansas gave notice today to the grain trade that a considerable time must elapse before the Winter wheat crop would be safe from adverse weather conditions. This, with expectations that the President would sign the Bankhead bill, brought in sufficient scattered buying of wheat futures to give the market a firm undertone.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Inventory forms which must be filled out by all members of the shoe trade have been prepared by the Office of Price Administration and will be available starting Monday, April 5, at banks handling ration banking accounts, the OPA announced today.

Studies of post-war advertising, which will cover its relation to general distribution problems and to consumption problems, have been authorized by the executive board of the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, Inc. The committee's project calls for a series of interim reports dealing with the advertising effects of zoned distribution, victory models, labeling, price control, rationing and similar war measures.

In its annual report the Community Service Society reveals again the importance of maintaining private welfare agencies, particularly in times of war and stress. During the past year the society has helped nearly 80,000 persons, at a cost of more than $2,500,000. New problems have arisen -- family security in wartime, health problems, fatherless families, overburdened mothers, workers dislocated by war, confused young people and the need for child care.

Albert Einstein, Thomas Mann, Pearl Buck, Sigrid Undset, Maurice Maeterlinck and other Nobel Prize winners now living in the United States are in the cast of the film "The Spirit of Nobel," to be given this evening at the American Common, 40 East Fortieth Street, under the auspices of the Common Council for American Unity.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Present ceiling prices for fluid milk at wholesale and retail in the metropolitan New York area will be continued until necessary economies in distribution are effected, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

Mrs. John Hay Whitney and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson were co-hostesses at a supper last evening in the penthouse of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, on the occasion of the private preview of the exhibition of Latin-American art in the museum's collection which opens to the public today,

Close bidding featured the award yesterday by the State of West Virginia of a new issue of $1,000,000 of road bonds, due on April 1, 1944 to 1968. The award went to a syndicate headed by Graham, Parsons Co. and including Eastman, Dillon Co., Otis Co., H.M. Byllesby Co., Inc., and Fox, Ruesch Co. of Cincinnati.

LONDON, March 30 -- The stock markets here continued cheerful today on encouraging Tunisian war news, with most activity in the mines section. Kaffirs went ahead at the opening of business, but profit-taking later caused prices to decline.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Meat shortages cannot be cured by rationing and will continue to plague the country until the government summons courage to impose ceilings on livestock prices at the farm level, Wilbur LaRoe Jr., general counsel for the National Independent Meat Packers Association, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.

An equitable pricing formula on government contracts that assures the Quartermaster General a continuing and adequate supply of "battle dress" uniform fabrics, and at the same time permits cotton textile producers to pass along any subsequent cost increases over which they have no control, is expected to be worked out as the result of a meeting held here yesterday between procurement officers and leading Worth Street suppliers.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 31 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique, a broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

"Alcohol unfits men for service and destroys their availability for the war effort," Mrs. D. Leigh Colvin, State president of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, told delegates yesterday at their annual institute in the John Street Methodist Church, where they were guests of the Friendly League for Christian Service.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -Secretary Ickes announced today that Independence Hall in Philadelphia had been designated a national historic site.

With the threat of a strike upon expiration of soft coal agreements at midnight tonight removed by extensions of the contracts until May 1, negotiations for new wage agreements both in the North and South of the Appalachian area were continued yesterday under the mediation of Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service and President Roosevelt's personal representative at the parleys.

LONDON, March 30 -- Richard Austen Butler, President of the Board of Education, appealed today for help from the church in providing a philosophy for the schools that will insure a generation worthy of the British national destiny.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 30 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Commenting upon the visit to Washington of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, who departed today for Canada, President Roosevelt at his press conference this afternoon said discussions of post-war problems would continue with Russia and other members of the United Nations, and he gave an extremely optimistic picture of ...

CLEVELAND, March 30 (AP) -Cyrus S. Eaton, of the investment banking firm of Otis Co., Inc., of this city, who started the protest that upset the Erie Railroad's recent award of a $14,000,000 bond issue to Morgan Stanley Co. of New York, is to be added to the board of directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, a holder of stock in the Erie.
CHUNGKING, China, March 30 (UP) -- A communique:

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 983, which compared with 1,013 in the preceding week and 607 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals numbered 403, as against 417 last Tuesday.
NEW DELHI, India, March 30 (AP) -- A communique:

A world approach to post-war problems on a scale equivalent to that needed to wage the war successfully was envisaged yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at a luncheon of The Woman Pays Club, Inc., in the Hotel Warwick.
A communique, as broadcast by Tokyo and recorded by The United Press:
A REPORTER watched the Giants at practice and was particularly interested in the reasonable facsimiles of first basemen who appeared. When the drill was over he approached Master Melvin Ott.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 30 (U.P.) -- An Axis spy plot directed against United States war plants, American air bases in Northern Brazil and United Nations shipping was uncovered here last night with the arrest of ten Brazilian members of an espionage organization directed from Argentina.

OTTAWA, March 30 -- Warning is being given quietly today that, because of food conditions in the United States, Canada will have to shoulder an even larger share of the burden of feeding Britain and that therefore more severe rationing may be expected here.

Twenty-one bombers is a heavy price to pay for the latest raid on Berlin, the second in three days. But such a loss emphasizes the mounting scale of these attacks. There is now no doubt that they inflict tremendous and in some cases paralyzing damage on the German war machine.

STOCKHOLM, March 30 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Swedish Athletic Association today said Gunder Haegg, world record holder at distances from one mile to 5,000 meters, Arne Andersson and Hakan Lidman planned to leave for the United States early in May to compete in a series of track meets.

As an emergency measure to safeguard New York City's water supply from bombing attacks and sabotage, forty-two miles of the eighty-five-mile-long Delaware Aqueduct, the longest bombproof tunnel in the world, has been quietly placed in limited operation during recent weeks and is actually bringing water into the city from the up-State watersheds heretofore tapped by the vulnerable Croton and Catskill Aqueducts.

Governors of the New York Curb Exchange moved yesterday to forbid margin trading in stocks selling below $5 a share and in bonds selling below 5 per cent of face value. The New York Stock Exchange passed a similar rule last week.

Unwilling by a small majority to accept the Ruml-Carlson pay-as-you-earn plan, still more unwilling to accept the Ways and Means Committee's do-practically-nothing-at-all plan, the House voted to throw the committee's bill back into its lap. It was a parliamentary manoeuvre to save the committee's proposal from direct defeat.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 30 -- The gradual shift in the strategy of the Allied aerial offensive in North Africa, which has been hinted at in recent communiques emphasizing the increasing strafing and bombing of troop concentrations, was officially confirmed today.
LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, March 31 (U.P.) -- Allied heavy bombers intercepted a convoy of four enemy destroyers attempting to run supplies into New Guinea Tuesday, probably sank one with a direct hit five miles off Finschhafen, and forced the rest to flee northward under cover of clouds, it was announced today.

Reaffirming the determination of American labor and the American people to aid Soviet Russia to the utmost in the war, leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations joined last night in a memorial and indignation meeting in Mecca Temple at which they denounced the execution by the Soviet Government of Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter, Polish-Jewish labor leaders, as alleged defeatists and advocates of a separate peace with Hitler.

Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, in an unexpected interview yesterday at City Hall, announced that he was ready to accept "full responsibility" to the people of New York if Mayor La Guardia becomes a brigadier general in the Army.

Oscar Serlin's production of "The Family," which opened last evening at the Windsor, provides one of those agonizing occasions found in the theatre only when the play is just not quite good enough. On the public record, this story based on Nina Fedorova's well-known book should have everything it needs.

Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service for New York City, told 500 Brooklyn employers yesterday that "the factories, the shipyards and the commercial enterprises of the nation" would have to furnish 3,500,000 able-bodied men this year to meet the requirements of the armed forces.

'lotables 'of the stage will pay tribute to Frank Gillmore, president of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America and president emeritus of Actors Equity Association, at noon today when Mr. Gillmore's funeral will be held at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), i East Twenty-ninth Street.

LOTA, Chile, March 30 (U.P.) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace of the United States, addressing a crowd of 10,000 coal miners and other workers, a few of whom waved Communist party flags, asserted today that this will be the century of the common people when men learn to organize their own industries with their own hands.

Although they eased moderately at midday, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange closed the day yesterday strong and active, with prices at highs for the recovery movement. Volume was 1,938,040 shares, again approaching the 2,000,000-share level and barely failing to cross it.

The time for publication of quarterly condition statements by the nation's banks is at hand, although thus far the Controller of the Currency has not announced the call date for the banks. Usually the national bank call is made first, and the various States then make calls covering their respective State-chartered institutions.

We must remedy post-war ill health and disease abroad or they will find their way to our own shores, Thomas W. Lamont, chairman of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., asserted last night at the closing session of a two-day symposium on the effect of the war on the medical system, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALGIERS, March 29 (Delayed) Undoubtedly, as General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, and General Georges Catroux, head of the Fighting French mission here, continue their conferences on the North African military and political situation, the status of France's protectorate in the Sultanate of Morocco is figuring considerably.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 -Deluged with thousands of letters and telegrams from well-wishers, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek ended her local visit this evening. She is due tomorrow morning in Los Angeles, where she will stay until after her address in Hollywood Bowl Sunday afternoon.

A cost analysis of twenty-one manufacturers of Fall and Winter knit underwear shows that earnings will fall 80 per cent below the level calculated on the basis of last year's production costs at the time when OPA imposed MPR 221 upon the industry, it was announced yesterday by the Underwear Institute.

"Day Shift-Night Shift" was the name Waiter Florell gave to his showing of Spring and Summer hats yesterday during luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. Florell, one of the young creators of high-fashion millinery, is now working day shift in a factory making airplane parts and night shift dreaming up beautiful hats for his clientele.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Specifically citing the city of New York as an example of the "bad way" in which many municipalities find themselves with respect to tax resources, the Committee on Inter-Governmental Fiscal Relations urged today that States undo the fiscal "straightjackets" in which they had put the cities.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Mounting concern in Washington over the serious food situation confronting the country because of the war was reflected today in a series of official moves designed to recruit more farm laborers, especially 50,000 dairy farm workers, and to release more canned fruits and vegetables for civilian consumption.

The entire eighth floor, comprising about 50,000 square feet of space, in 345 Hudson Street has been leased by the Standard Aircraft Products, Inc., of Dayton, Ohio, manufacturers of airplane lighting equipment. This will be the Eastern plant of the company.

The Cramp Shipbuilding Company had a net profit of $693,824 in 1942, subject to war contract renegotiation, after providing $1,316,000 for Federal and State income and excess profits taxes, less an allowance of $900,000 for a post-war refund.
MOSCOW, March 30 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique:

With "Warsages," the new Easter war stamp corsages, and jeep drives and 20,000 women volunteers, the Women's Division of the New York State War Savings staff is preparing to play a substantial role in realizing the State quota of more than three billion dollars in the Second War Loan drive, which will start April 12.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 30 -- The Dodgers today entered into an obligation to the United States Treasury Department and the Kings County war Savings Staff to sell $16,000,000 in War Bonds during the "second war loan" drive, scheduled to open officially on April 12.

The reading habits of clergymen are slovenly, without plan or discipline, and "fall short of the standard one would expect of a group with such high educational background and so rich an opportunity for intellectual leadership," according to a study made by Harold Lancour, librarian of Cooper Union. Results of the survey were announced yesterday.

WALTER GRAEBNER flew to Russia last May for Time-Life-Fortune. Like his colleagues and rivals in Russia he failed to see much front-line action and did not become a personal friend of Comrade Stalin. But he did see more of Russia at war than most of them, and among the half dozen who have written books about their Russian reporting he easily wins top honors.

Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany Hall, announced yesterday the appointments of Michael J. O'Shea and James B.M. McNally as members of a special Tammany committee to make recommendations to the City Council with respect to Assembly district lines to be drawn in pursuance of reapportionment legislation enacted at the recent session of the State Legislature.

The twenty-seven Work Projects Administration day nurseries, which were to have gone out of existence with the ending of the WPA today, will be continued for thirty days with city funds and for a longer period under a proposed plan that will include State aid, Mayor La Guardia announced last night.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, March 30 -- The armies of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel have just suffered their worst defeat since the battle of El Alamein last October. In the savage seven-day battle in which the Mareth Line was smashed superior Allied air power turned the tide. Now the Allies, not the Axis, have the initiative; this time it is the Germans who are harried and driven by superior air power.

LONDON, March 30 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado plans to come to England soon in behalf of the Anglo-American Committee for a Jewish Army, it was declared here today by Joseph Leftwich, General Secretary of the British section of the committee which urges a separate fighting force made up of stateless and Palestinean Jews.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A program for legislative action to establish uniform freight rates throughout the nation was submitted to President Roosevelt today by a board created by Congress in 1940, largely as the result of protests by Southern and Southwestern States that present rate differentials discriminated against their economic development.

Taking its cue from changing wartime conditions, Saks Thirty-fourth Street opened a new shop yesterday afternoon on the fifth floor with a collection of clothes to take a busy woman through an active day. These were styled especially for women whose size is 36 or larger.

Thousands Of enthusiasts will pile into the waters of New York Saturday for the opening of the trout season, and most of them will be worried about casting, placing the fly, and choice of fly. Only the veterans, thinks John Crowe, will be aware that many have already destroyed their chances before wetting a line.

Crushing the opposition with a spectacular offensive in the final two minutes, the University of Wyoming captured the National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship by downing Georgetown before 13,206 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

New York City's worst meat shortage continued without abatement yesterday despite official efforts to ease the situation as government spokesmen disclosed that the Food Distribution Administration's new quarterly quotas for the packing industry were designed to obviate a recurrence of the near famine.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Uniform price ceilings at retail for sales of beef, lamb, mutton and veal will be announced by the Office of Price Administration on Monday. Specific dollars-and-cents maximum prices for veal at the wholesale and packer levels were given out today, effective Saturday.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 30 (AP) -- The first all-American train carrying United States war supplies to Russia has steamed into Teheran after a 650-mile journey from a Persian Gulf port, where it was landed by Americans from American ships lying at American-built docks.

If we had not been sending lend-lease food shipments abroad, almost all to Britain and Russia, during the first two months of the present year American consumers could have made the following additions, per capita, to their weekly rations: one-fourth of an ounce of butter; one-fourth of an ounce of beef; three ounces of pork, ham and bacon; three-fifths of an ounce of lamb and mutton; and one egg.

A plea for immunization of every child over 9 months old against diphtheria was made yesterday by City Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins as the seventh death from the disease in the city so far this year was reported from the Bronx. Dr. Stebbins warned that in twelve weeks of 1943 there have been as many deaths from this preventable children's malady as occurred in New York during all of 1942.

The retreat of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel and his Africa Corps before the advance of General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army is a military defeat for which history furnishes no exact parallel. From El Alamein to Gabes by the coastal road is a distance of 1,430 miles.

CHUNGKING, China, March 30 (U.P.) -- Chinese successes on three widely separated sectors of the broad front were announced tonight in a Chinese communique. For the first time in weeks there was no mention of fighting in the Hupeh-Hunan border area.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (U.P.) -- Paul V. McNutt, war manpower chief, warned tonight all draft-age men in thirty-five designated nondeferrable occupations that starting Thursday local draft boards will begin to reclassify them for induction regardless of dependency status.
The five-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 102 feet at 2028 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, was purchased by Cahn Cahn, operators, from the Shabercraus Realty Corporation.

Chosen from a field of 350 entries among camp publications of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard, both here and abroad, America's Alertmen, official newspaper of Major Gen. Sanderford Jarman's Anti-Aircraft Artillery Command, Eastern Defense Command, was cited yesterday as the best publication in the nation's armed forces.

Maximum utilization of the manpower and tools already employed in war industry was urged yesterday as a solution of the critical labor shortages by James P. Mitchell, director of the industrial personnel division of the Army Service Forces, at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Property owners and realty brokers in the city, aroused at Mayor La Guardia's "threat to increase the real estate tax rate here by as much as 20 points," will meet on Monday at 2:30 P.M. in the Hotel Commodore to map out a program of unified protest against such a plan.

MOSCOW, March 30 -- Hard fighting is continuing on the Donets front, where, according to today's reports, the Germans are persisting in their attempts to reach the river's edge at the few places now suitable for organizing crossings.

LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- The British Air Ministry declared tonight that the R.A.F. now was the "mightiest air force in the world" and indicated that new, deadly planes, which at the moment must remain secret and nameless, were being added to its strength.

Two thousand, six hundred American soldier-citizens -- who happened to be of Japanese ancestry -- paraded in Honolulu this week, led by a band and cheered by 20,000 onlookers. At the palace of the Territorial Governor, Ingram Stainback, they listened to eight speeches, including one by the Hawaiian-Chinese Secretary of State Ernest Kai.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 30 -- General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army has marched into the important Southern Tunisian port of Gabes and the oasis of El Hamma on the other side of the sixteen-mile gap through which the defeated Axis forces withdrew as Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel once more resumed his retreat northward, it was officially announced today.

LONDON, March 30 -- Albert V. Alexander, First Lord of the Admiralty, today sounded a mildly cheerful note on the shipping question when he revealed at the Guildhall that during the last eight months new Allied merchant tonnage had exceeded submarine losses by "a good deal more than" 2,000,000 tons.

Any doubt that may have existed as to the condition of Henry Armstrong's eyes were dispelled yesterday when the California boxer and Beau Jack, whom he will meet Friday night in Madison Square Garden, visited the offices of the State Athletic Commission for a physical check-up.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Army has set up nine rehabilitation centers at which, by means of a training program that combines hard work and modern psychological methods, soldiers guilty of military offenses but not deemed incorrigible are "salvaged" and restored to active duty, Major Gen. Myron C. Cramer, Judge Advocate General, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- "The magna charta of science" was the description applied today by Thurman Arnold, former Department of Justice "trust buster," to the science mobilization bill reintroduced in Congress by Senator Kilgore and others.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, promised home canners today that they could have a reasonable amount of sugar, and aides indicated that he had disapproved proposals to take canned goods ration points from home canners.

The Allied victory in Tunisia is growing by the hour. Hotly pursued by the victorious British Eighth Army, Marshal Rommel is rapidly withdrawing to the north. The British have already closed the gap at Gabes, increasing their bag of prisoners. And Prime Minister Churchill indicates that many more are still to be rounded up -mostly Italians whom Rommel left behind, as usual.

LONDON, March 30 -- Minister of Home Security Herbert L. Morrison announced today that pleasure visitors might be banned from any area in a large part of the British coast after tomorrow at any time the military authorities deemed it wise.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, March 30 -- The newspaper La Prensa published today a report that is believed to have originated in the Argentine Foreign Ministry to the effect that peace feelers were being put out by "certain (European) countries that collaborate with the Axis" and that representatives of these countries had "already established diplomatic contacts with one Allied nation."

LONDON, March 30 -- Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee told the House of Commons today that "the magnificent offer" Sir Stafford Cripps took to India last year looking toward that subcontinent's self-government was still open to acceptance.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -Widely haphazard policies reflect the puzzlement in the nation's war plants over the best method of handling a problem new to many -- the matter of maternity leave for women employes, now being absorbed into industry at an ever increasing momentum.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 30 (U.P.) -- Strong anti-German activity was reported tonight in occupied Lithuania, where it was said to be causing grave concern to Nazi authorities in view of the proximity of Russian troops to the Baltic States.

A new score by Paul Bowles, young American composer, had its first performance last night at the Museum of Modern Art in the third of a series of five serenades. The music was for a zarzuela in one act, "The Wind Remains," which the composer adapted from the work of Garcia Lorca, the Spanish poet.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Western Hemisphere cooperation in the organization and maintenance of an international army to enforce post-war agreements and prevent the outbreak of another world war was endorsed at the first anniversary meeting here today of the Inter-American Defense Board.

Ensign Leslie T. Fossell, in 455 E 57th St; Mrs. Ellery James, through J.H. Taylor Management Co, in 205 E 69th St; Jeanne Kennis, in 563 Madison Ave; Mrs. F.B. Smith, in 81 Irving Pl -- Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, brokers.

The four-family house on a plot 26.8 by 100 feet at 2044 Eightieth Street, Brooklyn, was sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Charles Trachtenberg through Slomka Bros., Inc., brokers. This property is assessed for $12,000.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -More than 300 of 814 American soldiers listed by the War Department today as missing in action in North Africa came from a single State -- Iowa.

The Soviet Tass Agency declared yesterday under a Berne [Switzerland] date line that the German High Command had informed Premier Benito Mussolini of Italy that it wanted Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel appointed immediately commander in chief of the "southern defense area" of Italy and the Mediterranean coast of France.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 30 -- The inference that Berlin's Tempelhof Airdrome may have been put out of operation by damage in the Royal Air Force raid on the Reich capital during the night was drawn here from the circumstance that Stockholm-Berlin air traffic was interrupted today in both directions.

LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- Belgian authorities in London exposed today what the British Ministry of Information described as "one of the meanest forgeries put out by the Nazis", a letter purportedly from Joseph Cardinal van Roey, Archbishop of Malines and Catholic Primate of Belgium, professing support of the Nazis.

With a note from the International Red Cross near by, saying her mother had died recently in Germany, Mrs. Anna Haecks, 35-year-old widow, was found yesterday moaning in a normally untenanted room at 337 East Fiftieth Street suffering from gas poisoning.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Action to obtain the release of Jews from German-occupied Europe and to establish sanctuaries for them in the United States, Palestine and neutral countries was urged upon the State Department at a "Voice of Washington" meeting tonight.
Mrs. David K.E. Bruce and Mrs. A. Charles Schwartz have gone to Hot Springs, Va., for a stay of several weeks.

Protests were sent to President Roosevelt yesterday by the operators of three private bus companies engaged in serving apartment houses and transporting school children in the University Heights area, Riverdale and the Bronx, who have received orders from the Office of Defense Transportation to discontinue service at midnight tonight.

Warning against indulgence in political and economic dissensions that might jeopardize the success of our war program, the National Bureau of Economic Research, in its annual report made public yesterday, said that this nation can prevent a slowing down and eventual decline of war production and an accelerated rise in wages and prices, "only by efficient management, strenuous effort, cheerful acceptance of minor privations, and sinking our personal differences in devotion to the common cause."

The government has made a humane, no less than a politically wise, move in releasing the 6,000 conscientious objectors from the exigencies of the draft and placing them in various camps. In these camps they can now be selected by the heads of State institutions to augment rapidly dwindling personnel.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Foreign traders who have urged for months that the Office of Price Administration amend its export price regulation to permit the payment of compensation for export functions performed on lend-lease sales won their point today when OPA announced that such compensation had been provided for in a revision of the export pricing schedule.

Price-fixing by the trade yesterday was the only feature in an otherwise listless cotton futures market. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts retained moderate gains throughout the session and closed 3 to 9 points above Monday's final quotations.

BOSTON, March 30 (AP) -- Rookie Ab DeMarco made the red light flash at 3:41 tonight to give the Bruins a 5-4 sudden-death decision over the Canadiens that put them into the Stanley Cup finals. A crowd of 14,394 saw the game at the Boston Garden.

A picture of conditions at Creedmoor State Hospital for the mentally ill in Queens, where lack of sanitation recently caused a widespread dysentery epidemic, where meals fed to patients and employes are frequently unfit to eat, and where inadequate staffing has impaired administration, was painted yesterday by witnesses in the State investigation of the institution.

A Europe that we do not know looks out of barred windows on a world with which it has lost touch. Watching from here the play of events developing around that closed amphitheatre, the observer sometimes wonders where the main stage is -- in the wings where the armies are battering their way in, or in the great pit where the crowds wait, pushing and straining toward the exits.

Fifteen hundred leaders of the 150,000 volunteers who are serving in the 1943 Red Cross War Fund campaign will meet today at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore for the first city-wide report on progress of the drive to raise $12,920,700 here as part of the national goal of $125,000,000 for the Red Cross.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 30 -- Vinal H. Tibbets, Superintendent of Manhasset Public Schools, has received a petition bearing the names of 189 parents and pupils of the district, urging the elimination of the "core" program that now occupies a ninety-minute period of the school day.

Under the title "The Cliche and the Classic" Professor Irwin Edman, writing in The Nation with a volume of selections called "A Treasury of the Familiar" as his text, dilates on the classic by excellence and the popular by election or right of seniority. He describes this collection as a "rich goulash of the beautiful and the banal."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 30 -- Charlie Keller's signed contract is on the way to the Yankees' office in New York and the fly-chaser is en route here. He accepted terms this morning in a talk over the telephone with President Ed Barrow and started immediately from his Frederick, Md., home for camp.

Leaders in finance and banking, including many former associates in these fields, attended a solemn mass of requiem yesterday for James A. Farrell, for many years president of the United States Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The House rejected the Ruml plan by 215 votes to 198 today, with Democratic Representatives ringing up their first major victory of the Seventy-eighth Congress, and then sidetracked all pay-as-you-go tax legislation, including proposals for a 20 per cent withholding from wages and salaries.

The college student of today has more interest in the political and military aspects of this war than the student of 1917-1918 had in World War I, according to a survey of books requested from the City College circulating library from the days of the first World War to the present, made by Thomas G. Schwartz, librarian.

To assist the Treasury in achieving its objective of selling the record total of $13,000,000,000 worth of war bonds in April, the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association has approved a plan to ask all stores throughout the United States to make each Tuesday for the duration of the drive "Bond Tuesday," it was made known here yesterday.

A rich home-made dessert every day -- an apple pie, butter cake, lemon pie -- is an impossibility under the new rationing program. At least that's the conclusion reached by this department, which has decided that if you apportion your points sensibly among meats and cheese and fats you're not going to have much shortening to use in elaborate cookery.

LONDON, March 30 -- The London Daily Mail said today that General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, had told its correspondent, G. Ward Price, that any Allied invasion of Europe must be strong enough to take a large piece of territory, not merely a bridgehead.

Leaders in finance and banking, including many former associates in these fields, attended a solemn mass of requiem yesterday for James A. Farrell, for many years president of the United States Steel Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The House rejected the Ruml plan by 215 votes to 198 today, with Democratic Representatives ringing up their first major victory of the Seventy-eighth Congress, and then sidetracked all pay-as-you-go tax legislation, including proposals for a 20 per cent withholding from wages and salaries.

The college student of today has more interest in the political and military aspects of this war than the student of 1917-1918 had in World War I, according to a survey of books requested from the City College circulating library from the days of the first World War to the present, made by Thomas G. Schwartz, librarian.

To assist the Treasury in achieving its objective of selling the record total of $13,000,000,000 worth of war bonds in April, the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association has approved a plan to ask all stores throughout the United States to make each Tuesday for the duration of the drive "Bond Tuesday," it was made known here yesterday.

At least that's the conclusion reached by this department, which has decided that if you apportion your points sensibly among meats and cheese and fats you're not going to have much shortening to use in elaborate cookery.

TORONTO, March 30 (AP) -- Adam Brown, called up from Indianapolis of the American League less than a week ago, fired a goal past Turk Broda of Toronto at 9:21 of the first overtime period tonight to put Detroit in the Stanley Cup hockey finals for the second straight year.

The executive committee of the National Association of College Basketball Coaches, in session at the Belvedere Hotel yesterday, voted to recommend the following suggestions in rule changes to the Rules Committee:

ALBANY, March 30 -- The State War Council, at a four-hour session today, allocated $1,100,000 for its activities in the fiscal year and drafted preliminary application forms for State aid in the care of children whose parents are employed in war industry.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Tunisia, March 28 (Delayed) --There were two ways to win this battle of the Mareth Line. One was a frontal attack on the artificial defenses in the narrow area near the coast; the other was an outflanking movement, sending a force around the Matmata hills or through some gap in them and attacking the enemy in the rear.

Cross-word fans are in a peculiarly favorable position with respect to the Tunisian war maps, and for that matter, the whole war in the Mediterranean area. Cross-word addicts know all about the hot dry winds that blow in that part of the world, seriously affecting the course of military operations, like the khamsin, which has been blowing dense sand clouds before it in Tunisia.
LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- Under the heading "Pistols and Trumpets at Albert Hall," The London Press enlightened its readers on the American game of basketball.
The Tuesday German communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ALGIERS, March 30 -- Indications of a definite rapprochement between the Fighting French leader, General Charles de Gaulle, and General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, received definite affirmation today from General Georges Catroux, who, as the envoy of the former and an old friend and collaborator of the latter, is skillfully laboring here to bring about a complete union of Frenchmen.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -Following is the text of a statement read by President Roosevelt at his press conference on steps being take to supply needed farm labor:

PINEHURST, N.C., March 30 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, medalist and pre-tournament favorite, defeated Miss Anne Hotchkiss of Pinehurst, 8 and 7 today in their first round match of the forty-first annual North and South women's golf championship.

The annual report of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, issued yesterday by Robert E. Gross, president, shows that last year the corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $8,163,721 after provision of $3,500,000 for post-war adjustments and contingencies and a reserve of $2,000,000 against possible obsolescence of inventories, equivalent to $7.59 a share on the common stock.

Terminating seven years of acrimonious battles, the Columbia Oil and Gasoline Corporation, a subsidiary of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, relinquished yesterday its voting and stock control over the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

Total payrolls of General Motors Corporation set a new high record of $859,314,062 in 1942, with average employment in the year at a peak of 314,144, comparing with $669,744,870 and 303,827 respectively for 1941, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation, announced yesterday.
