WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -Chairman Truman of the Senate War Investigating Committee said today he had forwarded to the Justice Department new evidence which he said indicated that knowledge of the shipment of steel plate on "faked" tests at the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's Irvin plant in Pennsylvania "extends upward into the Carnegie-Illinois organization."

Though the war has probably made inroads into its manpower, the Oratorio Society of New York continued with its tradition of recent years by presenting Bach's B minor Mass at Carnegie Hall last night. With Albert Stoessel conducting, the society gave its seventeenth complete performance of the monumental score.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Powerfully armed Army and Navy fighting planes teamed up yesterday to carry out low-level strafing attacks on two Japanese bases in the Solomons, setting fire to an enemy destroyer and five to seven seaplanes, a Navy communique announced today.

The fourteen-acre country estate, formerly owned by the estates of Charles A. and Mary L. Stone, known as "Solano" on Duck Pond Road, Matinecock, L.I., was sold to a client of J. Ralph Bloomer, broker.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Thirty-eight governments have been invited to be represented through small groups of technical experts at a United Nations conference on post-war problems of food and other essential agricultural products which will be convoked at "some suitable place" in this country on April 27.

Frank Kominsky, 13 years old, born and reared in the gashouse district, was a rich boy for a day. But today the Police Department has custody of the small fortune because Frank's conscience, his brother and parents thought it would be a good idea.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 30 -If numbers mean anything, and in these days of scarcities they certainly must count for something, neither the Giants nor their Jersey City farmhands are going to run short of pitchers.

"Oklahoma!" a musical play based on Lynn Rigg's "Green Grow the Lilacs", will open this evening at the St. James under the auspices of the Theatre Guild. The music is by Richard Rodgers and the book and lyrics are the work of Oscar Hammerstein 2d. Rouben Mamoulian directed and the dances were arranged by Agnes de Mille.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Charges that the "Big Three" copper companies -- Anaconda, Kennecott and Phelps-Dodge -- were holding back on maximum production of war-needed copper for selfish purposes were denied before a Senate Small Business subcommittee today by H.O. King, chief of the War Production Board's copper production division.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, was confirmed for a new six-year term by a 70-to-5 vote of the Senate late today after a five-hour floor fight over charges laid against his administration of the shipping program by Senator Aiken of Vermont.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 30 -- The head of the Bermuda contractors constructing the United States Army base, A.D. Saunders, declared before the Transport Commission today that motor traffic would spoil Bermuda.

The fifty-third annual exhibition of photographs by members of the Department of Photography of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences has opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, to continue through April 10.

John McKenzie, City Commissioner of the Department of Marine and Aviation, promised yesterday that the Idlewild Airport now under construction in the southern part of Queens would be able to handle the tremendously increased air traffic that is expected after the war.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 31 -- British paratroop sabotage headquarters has been established in the vast Moorland tracts of the Hardanger plateau, southeast of Bergen, according to Oslo reports from the German-operated Scandinavian Telegraph Bureau.

New York's meat shortage was eased yesterday as additional supplies, including 600,000 pounds of the emergency allotment of 1,250,000 pounds made last week, became available and household buyers manifested a disposition to use their red coupons sparingly, possibly in the hope that they would be able to buy a Sunday roast.

In a case he himself had brought to the attention of the police by a declaration that he was being blackmailed, Dr. Anthony Renda, 58 years old, of 132 East Nineteenth Street, was arrested on charges of abortion and homicide yesterday at the East Twenty-second Street police station.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICCA, March 31 (AP) -- A communique:

What should be done with soldiers in training who have committed non-criminal minor offenses such as absence without leave and insubordination? In the first World War they were kept in clink, a waste of time and money and human material. In the present war a more humane and, it is hoped, more useful method is to be followed.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek took Los Angeles by charm today. Extraordinary precautions were arranged for her safety by the city police, military and naval patrols and secret service men.

The Aluminum Company of America reported yesterday for 1942 a consolidated net income of $33,361,761 after charges, taxes and also the results of renegotiation through which $76,000,000 will be paid to the United States Government this year in four quarterly payments.
The American Designers Institute will discuss post-war applications of plastics at a dinner meeting at the Architectural League on April 6.
LONDON, March 31 -- United States Flying Fortresses today bombed the harbor and shipbuilding area of Rotterdam, third largest port on the Continent and chief port of call for German coastal convoys.

Whatever effect the petitions will have which Westchester and Putnam County sportsmen have signed requesting permission to use boats on lakes of the New York City watershed during the approaching trout season, it is not likely that any changes will take place for Saturday's opening day.

General Montgomery's dramatic victory at the Mareth Line has so centered attention on land operations in Tunisia that we are apt to overlook its effect on the Mediterranean sea-front. Yet it will have a profound effect on that front which should eventually be felt from Gibraltar to Alexandria.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The President conferred with Congressional leaders, members of the War Board of the National Platform Guild, Governor Adkins of Arkansas, Justice Roberts and Secretary Hull and met with the Pacific War Council.

AT A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE in Northeastern India, March 29 (delayed) (U.P.) -- An unarmed American training plane swept down in movie-thriller fashion this afternoon to snatch from death a stranded P-40 fighter pilot who was holding out alone against Japanese ground fire in Japanese-occupied Burma, where he had landed, lost and out of gasoline.
Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the heaviest of any month since May, 1940, while for the first quarter it was the heaviest in six years.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Several measures in line with Donald M. Nelson's recent pledge to keep the home as well as the fighting fronts supplied with essentials were taken today by the War Production Board.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The defeat of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel in time to allow an invasion of the European Continent this year was forecast today by Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information, but purely as a personal opinion.

LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- It has been illegal to give away rationed foods -- even to your mother, unless she lives with you -- ever since Britain's complex rationing scheme was introduced, but the news is just beginning to get around to some quarters.

In its first downtown purchase in recent months, the firm of Webb Knapp yesterday acquired from the Havemeyer estate three old holdings on Broadway, Fifth Avenue and Liberty Street in a cash transaction, leaving the properties free of mortgage.

Your news articles and editorials on the Ruml plan have been excellent. I sent a copy of the editorial which appeared on March 22 to Congressmen representing the State of New Jersey where I reside and vote, suggesting a copy of this should be circulated among members of the House prior to any vote being taken on the Ruml plan or the amendments thereto.

Metropolitan New York's wholesale grocers, having gone through March with an avalanche of blue ration stamps for processed foods snarling their operations, are appalled at prospects for April and thereafter with a new set of stamps -- the red ones covering meats, butter, canned fish and cheese -- added to their problem, a survey among leading concerns disclosed yesterday.

The case of a man who for ten years harbored an obsession against chain stores, because he believed that the competition of one of them had put his small store out of business, was brought to light yesterday with the arraignment of two men in Yorkville Court on malicious mischief charges.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 31 (AP) -- Persons recently in Berlin said today that German officialdom was making energetic efforts to provide new housing for residents bombed out in the mass R.A.F. raids this month.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Courses in history and English adapted to current needs, and many more scientific subjects than ordinarily put in a college program, will be included in the Naval College Training Program. Details of the cultural and technical courses for aviation, deck, supply, engineering, medical and dental officers are set forth in a special catalogue issued today.
A Fighting French North African communique, as broadcast by Brazzaville and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Capitol the newcomer will be "Slightly Dangerous," a romantic comedy starring Lana Turner and Robert Young. In supporting roles in the Metro production are Walter Brennan, Dame Mae Whitty and Eugene Pallette. . . .
The National Association of Manufacturers urged prompt passage yesterday of legislation designed to prohibit establishment of foremen's unions.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 31 (AP) -- German Catholic Bishops have spoken "loudly and emphatically against the introduction of force" to bring about marriages and immorality, especially among young women, so that more children may be produced to build the nation, the Catholic International Press Agency said today.

LONDON, Thursday, April 1 -- Red Army troops, resuming their Kuban River offensive as the swampy terrain along the stream dries, have captured a base of utmost importance to the remnants of the Axis Caucasus army holding the Novorossiisk bridgehead, the Russians announced today.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Dewey signed today three bills providing for State employes pay increases of about $6,700,000 a year.

It is certainly reassuring to see how many people are interested in the discussion of war aims and post-war problems. While it is scarcely necessary to bring further projects into a discussion that ranges already far and wide -- sometimes, perhaps, even too wide -- I should like to draw attention to two basic points in this crucial debate.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- There was fighting on a considerable scale in at least three parts of the front yesterday and repetition of the phrase "no substantial change" in the Soviet communiques clearly does not mean that the whole front has become quiescent.

The 67-year-old Prudential Insurance Company, second largest life insurance company in the world, was completely mutualized on Tuesday when the board of directors met at Newark, N.J., to order the transfer of the thirty-two remaining shares of stock to the company for cancellation.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 31 -- One of the largest crowds Melbourne has seen in many years warmly welcomed the parade through the beflagged city of the men of the Ninth Division, Australian Imperial Force, who have just returned from the Middle East.

OTTAWA, March 31 -- Endorsement of President Roosevelt's statement yesterday that the United Nations were "about 95 per cent together" on the broad principles to be followed in current and post-war planning was given here today by British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden at an hour's press conference in the Parliament Buildings.

Caught in a "squeeze" by having to pay higher prices shortly for fresh supplies of raw cotton when their current stocks of low-priced fiber become exhausted, spinners of cotton yarns used by producers of such essentials as hosiery, underwear, sweaters, rugs, etc., may request permission from the OPA to sell their output on an f.o.b. mill basis instead of the present freight-paid terms, it was reported yesterday in the Worth Street market.
In THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 30 you print an item quoting a Japanese propaganda broadcast as reported by the Office of War Information. In it the broadcaster is quoted as saying:

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Although wheat traders were disposed to act with caution today, prices on the Board of Trade advanced moderately on buying induced by reports that the government would open bids on 150,000 barrels of flour on Friday and that parity price on the grains had increased about 1 cent a bushel in the month ended on March 15.
ALLIED HEADQUATERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 1 (AP) -- The Thursday noon communique:

Retail advertising to the Easter trade will rise steadily in the next two weeks and reach its peak the third week of this month, the latest in many years, store executives said yesterday. Since volume is based on a percentage of sales, the advertising total has been running somewhat ahead of last year.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee, by a vote of 21 to 19, disapproved today spending $44,000,000 for a barge canal across Northern Florida to bring more petroleum to the Eastern Seaboard.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- With all members pledged to strict secrecy, the special Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on postwar problems began consideration today of pending resolutions calling for United Nations cooperation and joint action in maintaining the peace after the second World War.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Democratic leaders of Congress discussed the food situation with President Roosevelt today as a Senate Agriculture subcommittee heard several witnesses voice opposition to general food price increases as a means of obtaining maximum production.

Tokyo dispatches quoted by the German radio yesterday said that an unspecified number of Japanese cruisers were damaged "slightly" in last Friday's long-range battle with an American flotilla in the first surface action reported in the Aleurians area, The United Press reported.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Experts from the price and rationing staff of the Office of Price Administration have been ordered to New York to make an immediate study of the meat shortage problem there, Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, told a group of New York Representatives and meat wholesalers who called on him today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Testimony of a high petroleum administration official that fuel oil rationing in the East would be unnecessary next Winter, provided requirements remain "normal," was made public today by a House appropriations subcommittee.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., March 31 -- As part of a program to provide as much baseball entertainment as possible for service men in near-by encampments, the Giants today revealed plans to play four games before their regular exhibition schedule opens at the Polo Grounds a week from Saturday against the Red Sox.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 31 (AP) -- Superior Court Judge Edward J. Quinlan has ordered a default judgment entered against Mrs. Marjorie Gould Drexel Gundry, 27-year-old great-granddaughter of Jay Gould and the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia, defendant in a $100,000 alienation of affections suit brought by Mrs. Margaret E. Danielson, 44, of Greenwich.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 356 United States soldiers held as prisoners of war by the Japanese.
CHUNGKING, China, March 31 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Carelessness caused 93,000 Americans to lose their lives last year, 15,750 of them in accidents in the home and the others on highways, factories, ships and trains, former Governor Lewis O. Barrows of Maine declared yesterday.

LONDON, Thursday, April 1 -- Yesterday's pounding of the key convoy point of Rotterdam by American Flying Fortresses topped off the Allied aerial offensive for March, during which, observers estimated today, 15,000 tons of bombs were dropped on Nazi-occupied Europe.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Invitations to serve on the national retail food industry advisory committee of the Food Distribution Administration have been issued by the Department of Agriculture. The committee will present the points of view of the various types of food retailers, outline their distribution problems and consult with the Food Distribution Administration in formulating programs to solve these problems.
Although all donations of rationed foods must be accompanied by a transfer of stamps, the Office of Price Administration explained yesterday that charity itself has not been rationed.

A picture of sports in the blackout of an occupied country -- of the resistance of the athletes of Norway to the efforts of Nazi sports Fuehrers to exact their cooperation with the "new order," of executions, bribes and arrests, athletic Quislings and underground activity -- was unfolded yesterday by a young man who has been through it all.

The directors of the Creole Petroleum Corporation and of the Lago Petroleum Corporation have approved a plan for consolidation of their properties and operations, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by C.H. Lieb, president of both companies.
MOSCOW, March, 31 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Britain's Royal Air Force is celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary today, mostly in ways the Nazis do not like. The flying services, of course, have more than a quarter of a century behind them. Britain's was born in April, 1912, and soon turned out to be twins -- the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 31 (AP) -- The consistent play of Miss Dorothy Kirby of Atlanta, who fired a 35 -- men's par -- on the first nine, paid off in an 8-to-7 victory for her over Miss Helen Waring of Pinehurst in the second round of the forty-first annual North and South women's golf championship today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 31 (AP) -- Military missions representing the United States and Brazil have arrived at Cayenne, French Guiana, where a government appointed by General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, is administering the colony's affairs in behalf of the Allies, diplomatic sources disclosed tonight.

One hundred and twenty-five volunteers who expected to join the French North African Army under General Henri Honore Giraud held an assembly yesterday in the headquarters of the French Military Mission in the United States at 531 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, Thursday, April 1 -- Messages of congratulation on the twenty-fifth anniversary of the Royal Air Force, including one from King George, have been received by Air Minister Sir Archibald Sinclair; Air Chief Marshal Sir Charles F.A. Portal, chief of the Air Staff, and other members of the Air Council.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Democratic leaders of the House interpreted yesterday's votes defeating the Ruml pay-as-you-go tax plan and recommitting the Ways and Means Committee bill as carrying a clear implication that a majority of the House wanted some kind of pay-as-you-go.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- The United States merchant fleet is expected to exceed Great Britain's before the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Fifty-three per cent of all passenger automobiles still exceed the thirty-five-mile speed limit on rural roads, the Public Roads Administration reported today, but a year ago 91 per cent were over the limit.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 31 -- One of the world's greatest collections of original manuscripts and documents on the early history of Western America, including the personal diaries and letters of men and women who trekked across the plains in search of gold, furs, religious freedom and new land, has been given to the Yale Library.
Mayor La Guardia's message submitting the 1943-44 executive budget to the Board of Estimate, follows:

The, demand for coats at retail has continued to improve, with suits finding a diminishing call, it was reported here yesterday. Untrimmed dressy and Shetland coats, particularly, are favored. Coat deliveries continue tight. Suits, however, have yet to reach their pre-Easter peak in many cities.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, March 31 -- General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's British Eighth Army, which has now plunged through the narrowest confines of the Gabes gap, capturing Metouia and Oudref and clearing out three passages leading northward among the salt marshes, has again made contact with enemy rear guards seeking to delay the steady Allied advance behind hastily prepared and clearly flimsy new defenses, it was officially announced today.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- A hint of a revolutionary invention which would eliminate the hazards of blind flying was given by Ernest R. Breech, president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, in an address last night before the Illinois Manufacturers Association.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Peace negotiations between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations, which began six years ago, were resumed today.

ALGIERS, March 29 (Delayed) -- There is considerable cleavage among the French elements in French Morocco. Since some reputedly first-class observers have told the writer that the French population was overwhelmingly de Gaullist, while others have said that the preponderance of sentiment favored General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, it is impossible to give the true picture.

It is good to know, on the authority of Albert V. Alexander, First Lord of the British Admiralty, that during the past eight months Allied shipping gains have exceeded losses by "a good deal more than 2,000,000 tons." It is also good to know that new ways of destroying submarines are being tried.

Predicting that the most difficult problems ever faced by the nation would come after the war, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase of New York University urged yesterday at commencement exercises of the College of Medicine that the new doctors not neglect national affairs when the conflict ended.

President Roosevelt announces that he hopes and expects that talks on war and post-war problems such as he has just concluded with Mr. Anthony Eden may soon be held between the United States and Russia. This is the second publicly announced invitation he has issued to Mr. Stalin to meet him in an effort to promote unity among the United Nations and to map out a common policy for the post-war world.
Henry Miller's Theatre, 124 West Forty-third Street, will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary tonight.

OSSINING, N.Y., March 31 -- The mobile unit of the blood donor service, New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, visited Sing Sing Prison this afternoon and took 183 pints of blood from as many convict volunteers. This was a record for the unit, according to Mrs. Jay E. Mason, chairman of the blood donor service of the Westchester Red Cross, which arranged the visit.

Basketball makes its annual periodic exit from the sports parade tonight when a gala Madison Square Garden charity double-header involving four outstanding collegiate quintets will write finis to the highly successful 1942-43 campaign.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 31 (AP) -- The Fascist press and officials today stressed home defenses, especially those on Sicily, which extends from the toe of the Italian boot to within less than ninety miles of the Tunisian coast.

If Frank Kominsky, the 13-year-old boy who found $13,901.28 in a junk heap on Monday, thinks that he'll collect his findings six months from now if the real owner is not located in that time he has another guess coming.

LONDON, March 31 -- Axis occupation authorities have demanded an additional 100,000 workers of France to rush fortifications along the Mediterranean, reports from the Continent said today, and Italy announced a decree providing machinery for placing the country under martial law "instantaneously."

Dr. Joseph Nisonoff of 110 Riverside Drive and Dr. Max Weinstein, 2285 Sedgwick Avenue, the Bronx, were found guilty last night of criminal abortion in the death of Madylon McGeehan of Washington, a government clerk, who died in Prospect Hospital last November.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The first contingent of Bahaman Negroes recruited for farm work is due to land on American soil this week, it was stated today in connection with plans formulated under President Roosevelt's direction for recruitment of foreign farm workers.

For years they have been saying the Theatre Guild is dead, words that obviously will have to be eaten with breakfast this morning. Forsaking the sometimes somber tenor of her ways, the little lady of Fifty-second Street last evening danced off into new paths and brought to the St. James a truly delightful musical play called "Oklahoma!."

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards, stating that various defects had developed in the administration of the Rent Control Law "which are defeating its purposes," presented today a four-point program of suggested improvements to Price Administrator Prentiss Brown.

BERNE, Switzerland, March 31 -- At least 400 persons were killed outright and more than 2,000 seriously injured shortly after noon on Sunday when an ammunition dump in the port area of Naples blew up, flattening buildings in a wide sector, according to private information received here tonight.

PHILADELHIA, March 31 -- In a reversal of the National Labor Relations Board the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals exonerated the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Corporation today of charges of unfair labor practices and upheld a six-year-old consent election in which an independent employes union defeated the C.I.O. industrial union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.

Near the close of the first ration period for processed foods, which ended yesterday, this column made a survey of city markets -- leading chain and department stores and several independent groceries -- and questioned their managers on customer reactions.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The fight in the Office of Price Administration over the merits of grade labeling entered a new phase tonight with a demand by the agency's labor policy committee for the removal of Lou R. Maxon, Detroit advertising executive, who is serving as public relations director for the OPA.

PEORIA, Ill., March 31 (AP) -- George P. McNear, president of the Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad Company, demanded today that the Office of Defense Transportation pay various obligations of the line "without further delay." The demand was made in a telegram to Joseph B. Eastman, director of the ODT, which took over management of the 239-mile line more than a year ago in a labor dispute.

Eight thousand Girl Scouts will be added to troops throughout the country as a result of a forty-four per cent increase in leaders, according to an announcement yesterday from Girl Scouts of America national headquarters, 155 East Forty-fourth Street.

There was a strike at the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, but it was considered to be a strike against the War Labor Board or the United States Government, not against the Exchange. Fifty page boys and page girls who reported on the floor at 9:30 A.M. refused to work.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Postponement of further curtailment of supplies of newsprint to newspapers depends in large measure on the economical use of present supplies by the industry, W. G. Chandler, director of the division of printing and publishing of the War Production Board, said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 1 (AP) -- Striking at the important Madang-Wewak highway, running 200 miles along the New Guinea northeast coast, Allied planes yesterday hit a large new bridge and bombed the road at various points in blows to disrupt this strategic Japanese artery of supply.

WHEN it was announced that Darryl F. Zanuck, head of Twentieth Century-Fox Studios, had been sent by the Army to North Africa to photograph the war against the Axis in Tunisia, one's first thought was of the current gag about "Hollywood war." What would Napoleon, Schlieffen or Stonewall Jackson have had to say about such a business?

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- A 16-year-old Italian high school lad from Youngstown, Ohio, answering to the name of Tony Janiro, won the admiration of 19,733 boxing fans in the Chicago Stadium tonight by achieving his twenty-eighth consecutive triumph.
A German special communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 31 -- The important part George Stirnweiss is expected to play in Yankee doings this year was indicated today when Manager Joe McCarthy announced the line-up for the first exhibition game of the campaign on Saturday at Plainfield, N.J., against the Newark Bears.
OTTAWA, March 31 -- Meat rationing will be introduced in Canada early in May, Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley announced in the House of Commons this afternoon.

The United Nations are not the only ones with a frontier problem on their hands. Tammany Hall is now busy on a new map of Manhattan. From time immemorial, practically speaking, and up to the year 1917, Manhattan and Bronx between them had their thirty-five Assembly districts.

The major responsibility for victory at sea "remains with the United States because we have the greatest fleet," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared yesterday in an address in Riverside Church to 980 newly commissioned ensigns in the naval reserve.

Relations of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation with the Brewster Export Corporation and Miranda Brothers, Inc., were examined in detail yesterday in testimony by F. William Zelcer before Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein in the trial of the $5,000,000 action brought by minority stockholders and the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation against the Mirandas, Mr. Zelcer, Brewster Export and former officials of Brewster Aeronautical.

Wartime developments in packaging of products for the Army, Navy, lend-lease and essential civilian needs were among the selections announced yesterday by judges in the twelfth annual competition sponsored by Modern Packaging.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 31 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace told a press conference today that after the war United States investments in Latin America should be under the control of "an international board."

With the opening of the metropolitan racing season just a week away, the matter of post times still is undecided, but the likelihood is that Jamaica will start the first race at 2 P.M. There is the further prospect that each of the five racing associations may nave a different post time, which is an indication of what wrestling with train schedules is doing to the racing moguls.

While holding within a maximum range of 6 points in dull trading, cotton prices worked yesterday to the best closing levels in a week. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended with net gains of 2 to 4 points as price-fixing, mainly for rubber companies, exceeded light liquidation and hedging.

The dismissal yesterday of the last 200 women engaged in the housekeeping service of the Work Projects Administration, ended another WPA project in this city. This means, according to WPA spokesmen, that 500 families either will need additional aid from social welfare agencies or will have to be taken into city hospitals, homes and other institutions.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The State Emergency Food Commission drafted a broad attack today on State food production problems and delegated to members the direction of one phase of the program, which will reach out to every farm and dinner table in the State.
LONDON, Thursday, April 1 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Wednesday midnight communique, as broadcast by Moscow:

LONDON, March 31 -- A system of "death convoys," under which French Jews are being rounded up, herded in concentration camps and then shipped out to various points in Eastern Europe, after which they are no longer heard from, was described here today by the British section of the World Jewish Congress, which charged that the "full force" of the Nazi and anti-Jewish terror now was being concentrated in France.

Ten United States Army officers taken prisoner by Axis forces have been sent to Oflag 9 A/Z, an officers' camp in Germany, it was announced yesterday by War Prisoners Aid headquarters of the Young Men's Christian Association at 347 Madison Avenue.

LONDON, March 31 (U.P.) -- Private advices received in London said today that the German Gestapo chief, Heinrich Himmler, had ordered the extermination of the remnants of the Yugoslav Army and all its sympathizers, by poison gas if necessary, to prevent a possible Spring uprising timed with any Allied invasion of Southeastern Europe.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday in the April issue of its review of credit and business conditions that of upward of $4,500,000,000 of income taxes paid throughout the country on March 15, more than $1,200,000,000 was in tax-savings notes turned in by taxpayers in lieu of cash.

The Delaware Hudson Company yesterday reported for 1942 a consolidated net income of $6,592, 364 after charges and taxes, equal to $12.87 each on the 512,135 capital shares outstanding. For 1941 the company had reported a net income of $4,336,480, or $8.47 a share. Gross revenues were $75,681,309, against $58,543,635.

Volume dropped yesterday but prices gained on the New York Stock Exchange. After moderate declines the list closed firmer, with rails making the best gains. Turnover was the smallest of the week, 1,540,290 shares, against 1,938,040 on Tuesday.

Championship series racing dates on Long Island Sound were set yesterday at a meeting of delegates to the Yacht Racing Association at the New York Yacht Club. The Sundays and holidays were absorbed with a proverbial bang.

A pastoral letter from Archbishop Francis J. Spellman in which he declares that the word "sacrifice" has been burned into every American heart by the flames of war will be read Sunday in all the churches of the Archdiocese of New York.

A moderate improvement in stocks of the major oil products on the East Coast was made last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's index, covering gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil stocks, stood at 29.7 at the close of last week, compared with 29.2 a week earlier and 58.3 on Nov. 27, when the current downward trend started.

Richard Flannigan, in 911 Park Ave through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc; Joseph R. Vogel, in 888 Park Ave through Tishman Realty and Construction Company; Harold Jackson, in 36 Central Park South; James R. Howlett, in 1088 Park Ave; David Mendelsohn, in 177 E 77th St; John P. Rutherford, in 784 Park Ave; William Morgan Carpenter, in 35 E 84th St -- the Madison Realty Co, broker.

"We have abundant evidence of the value of the practical training that Boy Scouts receive," Dr. James E. West said yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore honoring him on his elevation to the post of Chief Scout of the Boy Scouts of America.

The cooperatives of the United States will actively push plans for participation in post-war reconstruction here and abroad, Wallace Campbell, local executive of the Cooperative League of the U.S.A., said in an interview here yesterday.

Something went seriously wrong with our democratic processes on Tuesday. It is of the first importance that we understand clearly just what it was. Under our multi-agency form of government it is often difficult to know where or how to fix responsibility when an obvious failure of this sort occurs.
LONDON, March 31 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

IT was the eve of the battle between St. John's, the National Invitation Tournament winner, and Wyoming, the National Collegiate A.A. champion, for what amounts to the unchallenged college leadership of the country. They meet at the Garden tonight in a basketball offering of superlative attractiveness with, as a crowning touch, all of the proceeds going to the Red Cross.

A special German communique made the claim yesterday that Nazi U-boats, dealing new "heavy blows to various supply lines of the enemy," had sunk seventeen heavily laden Allied merchantmen, totaling 103,500 tons, in the North and Central Atlantic and in the Mediterranean.

The love of a train conductor for a strange dirty white dog proved yesterday to be stronger than the rigors of a railroad's timetable. Train 1041 of the Long Island Railroad, which left Far Rockaway, Queens, at 10:26 A.M., arrived in Pennsylvania Station five minutes late because of Conductor J.H. Hudson's kindness to the mongrel that ambled along disdainfully ahead of the train for almost two miles between Rego Park and Woodside, Queens.
A frantic production man picked up the movie house telephone yesterday and heard the voice of a woman.

There used to be a deep crimson cordial -- distilled from ripe black currants in pre-war France. It was smooth and very sweet, and one sipped it slowly from tiny crystal glasses. If a glass were held up to the light the liquid looked clear and sparkling as a ruby.
CHICAGO, March 31 (U.P.) -- One of every 13 men reporting for induction in the armed services is rejected as mentally unfit, the American Medical Association said today.

The Affiliated Young Democrats, a New Deal organization that supported Mayor La Guardia for reelection for a third term, called yesterday upon the Mayor to resign if, as is expected, he enters the armed forces.

Directors of the Childs Company began at 3 P.M. yesterday what may be one of their final meetings to study the situation facing the company as a result of the lack of response of debenture holders to the plan of exchanging the $4,493,000 of debentures which will mature today for a new 5 per cent issue due in 1957.

ALBANY, March 31 -- The Legislature "forgot" to enact the bill allocating $35,000,000 of housing bond funds for post-war public housing in New York City, it was disclosed today. The Assembly passed the Moffat bill making the allocation after Governor Dewey had given the measure his approval, in preference to other plans, but no action was ever taken by the State Senate.

LONDON, March 31 -- Four British submarines, operating against Axis supply lines to Tunisia, have sunk six enemy ships, seriously damaged four and destroyed a number of smaller vessels, the Admiralty announced tonight.
Investments in loft buildings and apartment houses, most of which are on the West Side, were among the property sales in Manhattan reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- House opponents of the War Security Bill, designed to strengthen the Federal laws relating to espionage and sabotage, succeeded today for a second time in blocking passage.

The International Mining Corporation reported yesterday for the year ended on Dec. 31 a net loss of $44,267, against a net profit of $199,364, or 41 cents a share, in 1941. This did not include $85,001 of net profit on securities transactions, which was added to reserve for investments and advances.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A limitation order slashing by 60 per cent the amount of metal permitted in the manufacture of standard utility and industrial incandescent lighting fixtures and by 80 per cent amount allowed in residential type fixtures was issued today by the War Production Board.

CLEVELAND, March 31 (AP) -- Erich Leinsdorf of the Metropolitan Opera Company was named conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra tonight. Thomas Sidlo, president of the Musical Arts Association, sponsor of the orchestra, announced the appointment of the 32-year-old musician for a three-year period to succeed Artur Rodzinski, who becomes the director of the New York Philharmonic next season.

John Erskine is announced as the honorary chairman of the meeting to be held in McMillin Theatre, Tuesday evening, in memory of Dr. George Washington Carver, Tuskegee Institute scientist, under the auspices of the Columbia University Bookstore and the Institute of Arts and Sciences.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 31 -- Seven persons were killed tonight when a Navy plane crashed in a cornfield two and a half miles southwest of here, the State police announced.

As a tribute to the memory of Sergei Rachmaninoff the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, performed the Adagio Lamentoso from Tchaikovsky's Sixth symphony at the beginning of the concert given last night in Carnegie Hall.

Herman Bloom, manager of the Bronx Opera House at 463 East 149th Street, the Bronx, and twelve youths were indicted yesterday by the Bronx County Grand Jury on charges growing out of the rape of a 17-year-old war worker in the theatre on March 11.

CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared here tonight that "it is desirable that we do not curtail civilian production much further," but he cautioned against undue optimism because "in these uncertain times there is no telling how heavily the hand of war may yet fall upon us."

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., March 31 -- Bobby Bragan, lifted from the lowlands of Philadelphia to the heights of Brooklyn recently when he was traded to the Dodgers, thinks he has a better future in baseball as a catcher than as a shortstop.

NEW DELHI, India, March 31 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fliers intercepted twenty-two Japanese bombers and fighters attacking a British forward landing ground in Southeastern Bengal, India, and damaged thirteen, five of them severely, a British communique reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (AP) -- Aero Supply Manufacturing Company, Inc., Corry, Pa., paid Garret Corporation, its sales representative, $290,795 during the 1942 fiscal year, while Aircraft Steel and Supply Company, another sales representative, received $122,900.

As the thief who Tuesday night stole six Plymouth Rock chickens from Dr. John A. Ward, veterinarian of 1050 Forest Avenue, West New Brighton, S.I., faced the danger of slow death through poisoning, the police spread the alarm last night among natives of the island not to buy such fowl from strangers, meat shortage or no.

Harlem children who are members of the neighborhood clubs of their house district are cooperating to stage a variety show at Mecca Temple, 133 West Fifty-fifth Street, on May 7 for the benefit of the Harlem Servicemen's Center and to raise funds to buy seed, tools and fertilizer for Harlem children's Victory Gardens.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 31 -- Premier Mustafa Nahas Pasha outlined the first steps for Arab unity in the Senate tonight in reply to a question by the president of the Nationalists regarding Egypt's attitude toward the statement of Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, for the creation of an Arab federation.

WITH THE BRITISH FIRST ARMY, in the Sedjenane Sector, March 31 (AP) -- Moroccan goumiers from the hills, fighting on the seaward and right flanks of the British in this sector, advanced through bushy undergrowth today and took up positions six miles east and southeast of Sedjenane.

ALLAHABAD, United Provinces, India, March 29 (Delayed) -- This correspondent's trip through the United Provinces, which ended today after visits to Agra, Lucknow and Benares, gives full assurance of the frustration, discouragement and pessimism into which Indians, especially the nationalist Hindus, have fallen since the failure of Mohandas K. Gandhi's latest fast.

The 1942 annual report of the Ogden Corporation, released yesterday by B.H. Brewster, president, shows a net income of $552,095 after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This compares with a net of $276,978 in 1941.

TRENTON, March 31 -- With 1942 automobile registrations expiring at midnight, a rush for renewals was reported today from agencies of the State Motor Vehicle Department. Although they declined to estimate total renewals, officials said they had reason to hope that the decline in revenue from this source would not be as severe as expected earlier in the year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Columbia is expected to complete negotiations the week for the film rights to the All-Army show, "Hey, Rookie," which has been playing at the Mayan Theatre here for twenty-five weeks. The cast comprises service men stationed at Fort MacArthur.

SAN MATEO, Calif., March 31 (U.P.) -- Jerry Giesler, chairman of the California Horse Racing Board, tonight informed the California Jockey Club that Bay Meadows track had been permitted three more days of racing -- tomorrow, Friday and Saturday this week.

LONDON, March 31 -- Prime Minister Churchill, one of the most distinguished leaders of the Conservative party in this country, whose liberal views are respected even by some of his political opponents, told a gathering of college students today that "conservatism has played a significant part in the progressive history of the British nation and must exert a potent influence on the shaping of her future.''

A proposal to merge the International Mercantile Marine Company with the United States Lines Company is before the Securities and Exchange Commission awaiting action by that body before submission to the stockholders for their approval, it was learned yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- Three young hoodlums confessed today that they stole three cars, held up a priest and abducted and robbed an heiress and her two escorts, all in one exciting night.

The Chase National Bank was the successful bidder yesterday for a block of $10,660,000 New York City 3 per cent serial assessment bonds, due July 1, 1944 to 1948. The price paid was 104.5059, or a 1.41 per cent basis. There were four other bidders.

Dead since the days when the Indians sold Manhattan, barter broke into its own once again yesterday. The first formal swap shop in the city was set up in the Henry Street Settlement home planning workshop at 334 Madison Street, under the auspices of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

Mayor La Guardia submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday an executive budget of $753,071,123.40 for 1943-44, balanced by jumping the present basic tax rate of 2.79 to a new high "in the neighborhood of 2.94 or 2.95" to produce an estimated increase of $18,471,290.77 in the year from real estate taxes.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Roosevelt reported at length to the Pacific War Council at a meeting in the White House today on his recent conversations with Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, and was represented by members of the council as delighted that there had been so general an agreement in discussions of post-war problems among the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Army authorities said today that this country is still building dive bombers, but, on the other hand, has found that fighter planes, in many instances, can do quite as effective work as the specially designed diving planes.

The sixth annual report of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation and its subsidiary, issued for publication today by J. Carlton Ward Jr., president, shows consolidated sales of $47,080,224 for 1942, a gain of 240 per cent over sales of $13,802,436 in 1941, and a net income of $626,744, aganist $541,079, an increase of 16 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Moving to curb speculators, the Office of Price Administration, put ceiling prices today on all used commercial motor vehicles. These cut their current market values in some eases by more than 59 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Uniform maximum ceiling prices for pork effective tomorrow, will replace maximums based on a store's highest prices in March, 1942. Under the old system, prices varied from store to store in the same city.

Negotiations for a new agreement affecting 80,000 hard coal miners in Pennsylvania were begun yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel between representatives of the United Mine Workers and the Anthracite Joint Wage Conference, the operators' organization.

With flotations here the largest for the month since 1941 and the second largest for any month since last April, a more diversified list of new bonds was offered to investors in March. They included the first industrial offering since October, the biggest railroad financing since December, 1941, and public utility bonds for the first time this year.

The 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City had $10,654,312 in cash in hand at the close of the first month of its campaign yesterday, it was announced by John P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the war fund, at a luncheon rally at the Hotel Commodore which was the first city-wide report meeting since the drive started.

CHUNGKING, March 31 (AP) -- The Japanese have begun an offensive apparently intended to disperse Chinese troop concentrations between the Yangtze and Han Rivers, west of Hankow, which were threatening Japanese positions in that area, the Chinese High Command announced today.

Bishop William T. Manning turned the first spadeful of earth yesterday as preparations were made for one of the largest victory gardens in the city at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Twenty thousand square feet of land, including part of the century-old lawn in front of the Bishop's house to the south of the Cathedral, will be used this Spring and Summer to grow a large variety of vegetables.

LONDON, Thursday, April 1 (U.P.) -- Born of strife, nurtured in peace and matured in adversity, the Royal Air Force celebrates the twenty-fifth anniversary of its founding today with the power of its blows proclaiming that the "few" now are many.

LONDON, March 31 -- The markets were quiet today, but gilt-edge stocks improved, the war loan 3 1/2 per cents rising 1-16 to 105 15-16. Among the foreign bonds, Brazilian issues hardened. Home rails held their previous prices but foreign rails declined.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in North Africa, March 31 (U.P.) -- The Royal Air Force said today that the dive-bomber is an "obsolete weapon" and that the damage done in the African desert warfare by German Stukas was "minute compared with the losses which they suffered."

"Ziegfeld Follies," the first revue of that title since 1936, will open tonight at the Winter Garden under the auspices of the Shuberts, in association with Alfred Bloomingdale and Lou Waiters. The stars are Milton Berle, Ilona Massey and Arthur Treacher.

Without altering the fact that scrip paid to security holders by a corporation is subject to income tax, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here set aside yesterday the valuation fixed for scrip issued by the Associated Gas and Electric Company in 1936 and sent the matter back to the Tax Court for a new appraisal.

More than 400 persons prominent in the theatrical profession and organizations associated with it attended a funeral service for Frank Gillmore, president of the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, at noon yesterday in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner), 1 East Twenty-ninth Street.

More than 700 photographs which the members of the Press Photographers Association of New York, Inc., consider their best work of the year, will be placed on public exhibition tomorrow morning in the Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

The annual report of the Boston Manufacturers Mutual Insurance Group for 1942 shows insurance of $2,887,166,163 in force at the year end, a new high record and a gain of $465,060,100 for the year, while net premium deposits rose $2,412,513 to a high record of $14,659,981.
ALBANY, April 1 -- Following is the prepared text of Governor Dewey's radio address tonight on "Your State in the War":

The Greater New York Industrial Union Council, local C.I.O. group dominated by the left wing, upheld last night the action of its officers in condemning the Ehrlich-Alter protest meeting, staged last Tuesday night by A.F. of L. and C.I.O. leaders, as a "deliberate effort at disruption" by anti-Soviet groups.

Leading French exiles in this country have formed a new French Republican Committee (Comite Republicain Francais) to further the restoration of the French Re public and promote a "sincere and unequivocal return to the republican tradition," it was announced yesterday at the offices of the group, 587 Fifth Avenue.

The Department of Justice has begun an investigation of the wine industry and is seeking to ascertain whether independent bottlers in this area are unable to obtain supplies because of monopolistic activities on the part of the larger operators, it was learned yesterday.
The Staten Island excitement over stolen chickens came to a satisfactory end yesterday for all concerned except six youngsters.

PITTSBURGH, April 1 -- New world records for production by a single blast furnace and an individual blooming mill were established in March by the Aliquippa works of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, it was stated today.

ALBANY, April 1 -- In a move to speed administration of the law by eliminating red tape and delays, New York City has been given Selective Service status independent from the rest of the State, Governor Dewey's office revealed today.

The Chase National Bank consummated yesterday agreements to sell its remaining holdings of 105,000 common shares of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation to a group of investment trusts and individual investors represented by Lehman Brothers, White, Weld Co. and Glore, Forgan Co. The stock, bought for investment, was priced at about $19 a share.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 1 -- The art of putting spectacles on a chicken is one of the most intriguing phases of poultry raising, according to eighteen city farmerettes, who completed an eight-week poultry course at the State Institute of Agriculture here today.

LONDON, April 1 -- The honor of wearing the coveted Royal Air Force wings was accorded today to Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who knows how to pilot an airplane. Mr. Churchill, who holds the honorary rank of air commodore, the equivalent of brigadier general, has never hitherto been privileged to wear the flying badge when in his Royal Air Force uniform.

Wheeler Beckett, conductor of the Youth Concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, led seventy members of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in the Hunter College Auditorium in the first of a series of three educational concerts for high school students of this city.

Listed on the honor roll of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, released today by Dean John T. Madden, is the name of Leo Blond, 27-year-old fireman attached to Hook and Ladder Station 22, 766 Amsterdam Avenue.

Malaria, for which science has not yet found a sure cure, is today one of the most formidable enemies of the United States armed forces scattered over the globe, Lieut. Col. Paul F. Russell of the United States Army Medical Department told an audience at the New York Academy of Medicine last night.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Dewey today signed the Moffat bill authorizing State and local authorities to undertake a $15,000,000 program for the care of children whose parents are employed in war work.
PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- A plan outlining final steps in the dissolution of the National Power and Light Company has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, it was disclosed today.

Woody Guthrie, Oklahoma minstrel-author of "Bound for Glory," a recent Dutton publication, will be the guest author on "The Author Meets the Critics" program today over WGY, Schenectady, N.Y. Granville Hicks will be chairman of the program.

WITM U.S. FORCES AT EL GUETTAR, Tunisia, March 30 (Delayed) -- Even in the height of battle Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., Commander of United States forces on the Tunisian front, is a stickler for the rules, because he believes that the best disciplined troops are the best fighters.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- The constitutionality of Section 11 (B) (2) of the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935, which empowers the Securities and Exchange Commission to require holding companies to undergo corporate simplification, was upheld today by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation.

The Transit Commission created by the Legislature in 1921 to regulate transit lines within the city limits and to tackle the problem of transit unification, went out of existence yesterday, under the law recently signed by Governor Thomas E. Dewey.

Reductions in retail delivery mileage and substantial savings in gasoline and tires have resulted from the government campaign asking consumers to carry small packages, the Office of Defense Transportation announced yesterday.

The pamphlet report for 1942 of the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad Company, released for publication today, shows that the road last year reduced its indebtedness by $7,879,858, including about $2,500,000 used to pay a maturing bank loan.

The circus and the "Ziegfeld Follies" being two changeless traditions of the American theatre, the Messrs. Shubert and associates last evening upheld their end by bringing in the latest edition of the familiar revue. It opened at what Mr. Berle called the "Olsen and Johnson National Bank" -- which is the Winter Garden -- and it gave every indication of staying there as agreeably as the other recent "Follies" have, and other Winter Garden shows.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- Note circulation of the Bank of England established a new high record with an increase of 5,815,000 for week ended yesterday, as reported today by the bank. Outstanding notes reached 934,532,000, which is about 15,000,000 under the Treasury's authorized total of 950,000,000.

A 36-year-old house Painter, father of three children, admitted yesterday in the line-up at Police Headquarters that he fell in love with a burlesque queen and donned an Army uniform to woo her. The courtship was so successful that he finally married her.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A broad conservation program on men's, women's and children's hosiery was ordered into effect May 15, in a War Production Board Conservation Order L-274. The regulations lists specific manufacturing practices which must be followed in production of all types of hosiery to assure elimination of the poorest wearing types and, in addition, limits the colors and patterns in which hosiery may be made.

LONDON, April 1 -- Business on the stock markets here improved after a quiet opening today. Gold-winning shares were again the feature. Blyvoor jumped 4 shillings to 66 1/2 shillings, and West Wit, 5 shillings to 8 1/3. Diamond shares also improved.

The Berlin radio in a transmission intended for foreign consumption asserted last night that preparations for setting up military rule in Italy had had "a decidedly favorable echo" among all citizens and said that Italians realized that "the whole of Italy" was now a war zone.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Treasury plan for the stabilization of currency after the war is basically a grand elaboration of the pre-war tri-partite agreement scheme of employing special funds to combat currency fluctuations. Secretary Morgenthau said at a press conference today that the plan would probably not be made public. He repeatedly stressed its "tenative" nature.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday called upon the States of New York and New Jersey to take "prompt and constructive" steps to meet the "serious problems" that will confront the port at the end of the war.

Parents who have sent their boys off to war are turning to books "to find a worthy motive why those boys should run heroic risks, struggle and die," Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College, declared last night at a meeting in observance of Religious Book Week.

The Panhandle Producing and Refining Company reported yesterday for 1942 a net income of $33,678 after taxes, charges and $75,313 as costs of drilling a "dry hole" in King County, Washington. This compared with a net income of $288,583 for 1941. On Dec. 31 last, current assets were $1,261,210 and current liabilities were $466,710.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 1 (AP) -- A communique: In the southern sector our patrols pushed forward and gained contact with the enemy's prepared positions north of Oudref.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Officials of the War Manpower Commission expressed satisfaction today over first reports of compliance with the order for a 48-hour work week in thirty-two labor-short areas and, throughout the country, in lumber and nonferrous mining industries.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 1 (AP) -- Miss Dorothy Kirby and Miss Jane Crum, ranked as favorites from the start, met little trouble today in disposing of their opponents in the North and South women's golf semi-finals. They will battle tomorrow for the championship, which was won last year by Miss Louise Suggs of Lithia Springs, Ga.

When Serge Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra come to New York they bring gifts of exciting programs, spiced more often than not with new works. At Carnegie Hall last night they introduced to New York Aaron Copland's "A Lincoln Portrait," and a hasty judgment based on one hearing might hazard the guess that this is the American composer's best score.

THERE is always something intriguing about any sort of match between a pupil and a teacher, regardless of the sport. There will be a fight at the Garden tonight in which Professor Henry Armstrong, past master at the art of fisticuffing, will discover for himself how well Student Beau Jack has absorbed his instructions in the delivering of what the more learned savants call "a smack on the whiskers."
WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, in Northern Tunisia, March 31 (Delayed) -- Two British medical orderlies captured ninety-eight Italian enlisted men and a major today without firing a shot.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Efforts to arrange a "no raiding" pact between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations failed today at the second session of peace committees of the two organizations which began meeting here yesterday for the first time since Dec. 2.

Statements of the condition of banks at the end of the first quarter of the year, published today, reveal uneven trends in deposits, cash and holdings of government securities and in loans and discounts. Many banks gained ground, while others lost.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 1 -- American Field Service volunteer ambulance drivers are working night and day with the main body of the British Eighth Army in the sweep toward Tunis. The only Americans with the ground forces of the Eighth Army, they have been in action with infantry sections throughout the Mareth Line battle.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY AT GABES, March 31 (Delayed) -- Gabes is a ruined town. Most of the houses, both European and Arab, are without roofs or walls. None remained whole.

Bank clearings this week again increased sharply over a year ago, but they were slightly lower than in the two preceding weeks. The volume of twenty-three leading cities, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., for the week ended on Wednesday was $8,370,530,000, compared with $6,442,145,000 in the corresponding week of last year, with $8,897,704,000 for the week ended on March 24 and with $8,827,263,000 for the week ended on March 17 of this year.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 1 (U.P.) -The gunners and the bombardiers had choice seats for the big show over the Sardinian harbor of Cagliari yesterday.
Mayor La Guardia denied yesterday morning that he was to report to Governors Island later in the day for a physical examination, preliminary to his entry into the military service.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary today by attacking two towns in Western Germany. Startled Germans stood gaping in the streets at swift British Mosquito bombers, which dipped as low as fifty feet to plant their delayed-action explosives on industrial objectives.

CHUNGKING, China, April 1 -- The Chinese defenders of Southern Yunnan have repulsed all Japanese attempts to drive into the province and are counter-attacking the enemy on Burmese soil, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

CHICAGO, April 1 (U.P.) -- Production at the Ford Motor Company's Torrence Street plant was halted tonight when 600 employes called a meeting in the lunchroom to protest the transfer of two plant guards to the assembly line; without observance of seniority rights.

Supplies of green vegetables are increasing daily, reports the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, and prices are appreciably lower than they were last Friday. Spinach dropped an average of 3 cents during the week; kale, 4. Boston lettuce and asparagus are also cheaper.

LONDON, April 1 -- An assistant sergeant at arms caused the liveliest incident in the House of Commons today when, at the end of the committee stage of the government's catering bill, he removed the mace.

The execution in the Soviet Union of Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter, Polish Socialist leaders, arose out of a conspiracy of American citizens, organized on American soil, to overthrow the Soviet Government, Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party, charged yesterday in an address at Aperion Manor, Brooklyn.

The household of the Prentiss Browns at Washington was a typical American home last week. It was butterless. The wife of the director of OPA told the reporters that she gets no advance rationing tips. The sudden radio freeze on butter came down here as all over the country like the wolf on the fold.

Two 22-year-old "muggers" were convicted yesterday in Bronx County Court of robbery in the second degree after a short trial in which they offered no defense. The State produced four witnesses, including the complainant, who because of deafness made his answers from written questions.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 1 (AP) -- Fifteen Connecticut meat dealers were fined a total of $113,990 by Judge Carroll C. Hincks today in the Federal District Court on charges of violating APO ceiling prices in the sale of meat to Connecticut consumers.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- In an atmosphere of secrecy, a bill is being prepared for introduction in the Senate which would authorize the payment of what is viewed in some quarters as government subsidies, in the form of Treasury Department advertising, to a large part of the American press.

Net sales of the General Motors Corporation and consolidated subsidiaries amounted to $2,250,548,859 in 1942, second only to the record volume of $2,436,800,977 reported for 1941, but $1,898,195,445 of last year's sales was war materials, comparing with $406,149,273 in 1941.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 (U.P.) -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek received Hollywood's elite tonight when more than 200 guests, ranging from Sam Goldwyn to Shirley Temple, met her in relays.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Though conclusive reports from the Navy on the recent engagement between Japanese and American warships in the Aleutians still are lacking, a Navy communique revealed today that Army bombers and fighters were continuing to pound the enemy bases in that area.

The plant of Grace Episcopal Chapel, 410-14 East Fourteenth Street, between First Avenue and Avenue A, will be closed May 2 and its remaining communicant membership will merge with Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, which established the East Side parish forty-seven years ago and has maintained its work.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., April 1 -- Colonel Douglas Johnson, commanding officer of Mitchel Field, presented Distinguished Flying Crosses here today to Mrs. Nelly Lipsky of 183 Middleneck Road, Great Neck, mother of Lieutenant Clarence W. Lipsky, and Mrs. Helen M. Cook of Haverstraw, N.Y., widow of Lieutenant John J. Cook.
LONDON, Friday, April 2 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast by Radio Moscow:
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., April 1 -- Branch Rickey today assumed his favorite role -- teacher of young baseball players.

The gift most likely to make a hit with the girl in the nation's armed forces is a simple folding iron -- and not the candy, cookies, lingerie or books on which most friends, husbands and parents pin their faith.

A keen battle for the team honors between Yale and Ohio State is expected in the annual men's National A.A.U. indoor swimming championships which open a two-day stand this afternoon in the New York A.C. 75-foot pool.

The people of this country should follow the example of the British in reducing the consumption of food and drink during shortages of these commodities in wartime, Dr. Charles McDowell, a trustee of the Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, declared yesterday at the New York yearly meeting of the Religious Society of Friends.

In a letter to Prentiss M. Brown, Office of Price Administration head, made public yesterday, the National Consumer-Retailer Council, Inc., declared that it believes the informative and grade labeling of canned fruits and vegetables to be "basic to wise buying by the consumer."

WASHINGTON, April 1 (U.P.) -- An American freighter, Independence Hall, was riding out a North Atlantic Winter gale holding her place in a convoy when a mountainous wave crashed amidships and broke her in two.
A Japanese Imperial Headquarters communique broadcast by the Tokyo radio and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Retail credit collections in February showed an increase of 10.87 per cent, according to the twenty local store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage was 56.07, against 45.20 for February, 1942. The gain compared with a rise of 8.45 per cent in January and 12.31 per cent in December, 1942.

Moscow newspapers yesterday praised Allied successes in Tunisia and printed lengthy reports and analyses of the African campaign, the Russian news agency Tass said in an English-language Morse-code transmission to Europe and North America.

The manufacture of precision instruments for the Army and Navy by the Sperry Gyroscope Company was interrupted yesterday at its Brooklyn and Long Island plants through a work stoppage which, according to a spokesman for the employes, was staged "in protest against the failure of the management to negotiate a contract in good faith."

A hoof injury will keep Devil's Thumb out of the Kentucky Derby on May 1, it became known at Belmont Park yesterday, where horses continued to arrive from many points in the racing compass. The W.E. Boeing colorbearer, a multiple stakes winner at Saratoga last Summer, had been in light training at the big Nassau oval, where some considered him the most formidable of Mr. Boeing's eight derby candidates.

TRENTON, April 1 -- A combined salary increase and bonus for all State employes now receiving not more than $5,000 a year was voted by the Legislature late today after leaders of the Republican majorities in the Senate and Assembly worked out a compromise plan to bring agreement between groups supporting opposing proposals.

Industrial development in South America after the war will provide thousands of jobs for returning United States soldiers and ex-war workers, Eric Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, declared last night in an address before the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, April 1 -- The aggressive London Base Command quintet, made up of former high school and college players, captured the United States armed services basketball tournament championship tonight with a 52-43 upset victory over the Army Greys.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Department stores sales in the week ended March 27 were 3 per cent below those in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a decline of 2 per cent from the corresponding period of last year for the week ended March 20.

Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44, balanced by assuming an all-time high tax rate of at least $2.94 for each $100 of assessed valuation, was the target yesterday of vigorous criticism from real estate and business groups as well as teachers' organizations.

DETROIT, April 1 -- Detroit's rampaging Red Wings streaked through Boston for six goals, gave the Bruins a sound 6-2 thumping and climbed the first notch toward possession of the Stanley Cup and world professional hockey title in the first game of the final play-off series before 12,562 fans in Olympia Stadium tonight.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler is 81 years old today but his advanced age has not dimmed his ardor for the two great interests in his life -- Columbia University, over which he has presided for almost forty-two years, and world peace.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 1 -- Despite their defeat on the Mareth Line the Axis armies in Tunisia are still virtually intact and fighting strongly.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Roosevelt signed the supplemental Naval appropriation bill and legislation extending the time in which application may be made for relief from corporation excess profits taxes and extended the eligibility provisions for the Army Good Conduct Medal.

Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, declared in an address here yesterday that the "acid test" of our post-war willingness to maintain world peace would be whether Congress renewed the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act of 1934 when it expired in June.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 1 -- More than 1,000 Nassau County school children reached school today by means of travel to which they have not been accustomed. They walked or rode bicycles, and established bus lines such as Valley Stream, Rockville Centre, Bellmore and Oceanside school districts curtailed school bus service in compliance with an order of the State War Council designed to conserve equipment.

PAOSHAN, China, March 16 (Delayed) -- Although thirty-one Indians who escaped from a Japanese prison camp in mid-February are still waiting for transportation home, they regard everything in this pinched, ruin-cluttered town for the best in the best of all possible worlds.

Price ceilings, in many instances, had a favorable effect upon retailers' profits in 1942, according to the results of a survey of retail trends by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., which were made known here yesterday.
ALBANY, April 1 (AP) -- Restrictions governing release of high school pupils for farm work were outlined today to principals.

Trim and chic, as crisp as lettuce and as vivid as tulips, a parade of springtime cotton costumes for both daytime and evening enlivened the scene yesterday at luncheon in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel, where the newest collection of Chez Rosette was shown to an appreciative audience.

Corporations engaged in manufacturing, trade, public utility services and finance showed declines in net earnings, as groups, in 1942, compared with the previous year, while those engaged in transportation, mining, and construction showed gains, according to a tabulation of the reports of 2,560 leading concerns, in the April issue of the National City Bank's review.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Suspension in the New York City area of the "set aside" order by which slaughterers of meat are required to earmark a given percentage of their meat for the armed services and lend-lease will enable the city to replenish its meat stocks without further emergency action, officials of the Department of Agriculture said tonight.

Indications are that the reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad is moving ahead. According to information available yesterday, the committees representing the senior bondholders and the junior stockholders are in accord on a compromise plan which soon will be submitted to the United States District Court and to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

OTTAWA, April 1 -- Thunderous applause greeted Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, in the Canadian House of Commons today at a joint meeting of the members and the Senate when he declared that Germany, Italy and Japan must never again have a chance to disturb the world's peace.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Giving unstinted credit to the British for the "decisive defeat" of the Axis forces at the Mareth Line, Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, warned today, however, that, despite heavy losses, the bulk of the Axis army still was intact and "a great deal of heavy fighting," in which American divisions would participate, might be expected before the "final phase" of the Tunisian campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Reports were current tonight of an open break between old-line executives of the Office of Price Administration and representatives of the new regime of Prentiss M. Brown, following in the wake of an order issued by Mr. Brown yesterday requiring prior review by Lou R. Maxon, Mr. Brown's public relations director, of all orders, field instructions, enforcement regulations and similar material originating here.
Following British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's departure from Washington, some salient points in Anglo-American relations come up for explanation.

Some of them had their letters from the War Department in their pockets or handbags. With mixed emotions they displayed them. Relief followed the paragraph telling that a son, brother or husband, previously listed as "missing in action," was a prisoner of war.

The American Public Health Association's Committee on Administrative Practice has issued a report which deserves earnest consideration because it suggests a plan for the better distribution of medical care. As matters stand, 62 million of our continental population receive some medical attention from local governments, 16.5 million more from county or district health departments, and 12 million from municipal hospitals and health officers.

Despite a plea of diplomatic immunity from suit in the State courts, Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein ruled yesterday that he had jurisdiction in a suit by Mrs. Mary Duran-Ballen against her husband, Sixto Duran-Ballen, Consul General of Ecuador in New York.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 1 -- Princeton University offered today to help its oldest living alumnus, Dr. William H. Vail, 97 years old, who face eviction from his home in Newark, N.J.
Several loft buildings, including a large structure in the Fourth Avenue district, were reported yesterday as having changed hands.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed decrease of $31,332,000 in holdings of United States Government securities and an increase of $150,810,000 in note circulation.

The six-story, fifty-nine family apartment house at 200 East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Barta Realty Corporation to the Albemarle Housing Corporation. Dreyer Traub represented the seller and Benjamin Mintz acted for the buyer.
