Twice referred to in introductory speeches as a brigadier general "soon to be" at a ceremony which opened the new headquarters of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization yesterday, Mayor La Guardia, in a speech in which he warned of more stringent civilian restrictions to come, chose to ignore both references.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 1 -- The Eighth Army has now pushed through hastily constructed enemy rear-guard defenses beyond Oudref to a new line of prepared positions erected by Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel in the region north of Gabes, where the Desert Fox apparently is making at least a temporary stand.

A fight that seems to have caught the fancy of the boxing public to an extravagant degree will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight when Beau Jack, recognized by the New York Athletic Commission as the lightweight champion of the world, will trade punches with Henry Armstrong, former holder of the featherweight, lightweight and welterweight championships, in a ten-round clash.
Though responsibility for the tax bill fiasco must be distributed, it rests in the first instance upon the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Frank C. Walker, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today that he would like to make an agreement with the Republicans for late political conventions in 1944 and a short Presidential campaign beginning in September or October and conducted "on a very high plane."

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Railway Brotherhoods asked President Roosevelt today to use his good offices in an effort to have retail food prices reduced to the levels of Sept. 15, 1942, the date set for wage stabilization by Mr. Roosevelt's executive order which followed enactment of the anti-inflation act of Oct. 2.

Four captains, masters of United States Lines freighters, won yesterday the company's Distinguished Service Medal, in recognition of "specially meritorious service under unusual stress and hazard." The presentations were made by Basil Harris, president of the United States Lines, in his office at 1 Broadway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 1 -- Following the preview last night of "More the Merrier," in which he appears, Charles Coburn today signed a term contract with Columbia, under which his first picture will be "Without Notice." Twentieth Century-Fox announced today that Don Ameche will be starred in a film version of the Phil Stong novel "One Destiny," which is scheduled for May production.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) -- A French communique broadcast by the Algiers radio and recorded by The Associated Press today announced that French camel corps troops had occupied Kebili, a road junction near the eastern edge of the Chott Djerid and sixty-eight miles southwest of Gabes.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Army and Navy Nurse Corps and interested government agencies stand behind the new Bolton Nursing Subsidy Bill, it was learned here today, because, if enacted, it would allow the nursing profession to compete for woman power on a fairly equitable basis with the Waacs, Waves, Spars, Women Marines and industry.

With trade sources again providing the bulk of buying support, the cotton futures market yesterday continued its moderate upward movement in light dealings. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts approached the fourteen-year high levels established early last month, but the advance was frustrated by some local liquidation and hedging.

The United States Government has invited thirty-eight other Governments, representing the United Nations and eight associated nations, to send delegates to a conference to be held at the end of April to discuss post-war food problems. This meeting has more importance than immediately meets the eye.

A fourth attraction has been added to tomorrow evening's list of departures from Broadway. It is the season's only Shakespearean offering, "Richard III," which will vacate the Forrest after its eleventh performance. George Coulouris, who was instrumental in having the revival done, staged it and took the title role.

More than 200 management executives of Canada and the United States have joined the Association of Canadian Advertisers in the organization's continuing study of post-war trends, B.W. Keightley, advertising manager of Canadian Industries, Ltd., and chairman of the A.C.A. committee on post-war planning, announced yesterday as the second booklet of the committee's digest was issued.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- A "master war plan," providing that the entire war program -- manpower, procurement and production as well as military strategy and operation -- shall be cleared through the joint chiefs of staff, was proposed today by Representative Maas of Minnesota.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Donald M. Nelson, War Production Board chief, told a Senate small business subcommittee today that he favored "the fullest possible use" of small and marginal ore deposits without regard to the cost to the government in all cases where production will justify the use of the manpower and strategic materials required.
Conservation Department officials regard it as an unpredictable trout year, but it opens, nevertheless, tomorrow in this State, rain or shine.
While the lawbreaker languishes behind bars his food ration books remain in use despite an Office of Price Administration order requiring him to turn in his books to the warden.

Elmer F. Andrews, former State Industrial Commissioner, testifying yesterday at the inquiry into the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law at the Bar Association, admitted that he had made appointments after receiving recommendations from an "eminent jurist," Democratic committees and others in political positions.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Disposing of rumors that income tax collections on March 15 this year fell below expectations, Guy T. Helvering, Internal Revenue Commissioner, stated today that collections of income and excess profits taxes collected during March totaled $4,882,184,543, compared with $3,077,931,976 in March of last year.

LONDON, Friday, April 2 (AP) -- Russian troops have captured several localities in the continuing drive to wipe out the Nazi Caucasian bridgehead at Novorossiisk, reduced another stronghold on the Smolensk front and held firmly on their Donets River defense line, Moscow announced early today.

The Childs Company notified the New York Stock Exchange early yesterday that the principal of the 5 per cent fifteen-year debentures due yesterday would not be paid, but that interest accrued to April 1 on the debentures and also on the new fifteen-year debentures issued in exchange, due in 1957, would be paid.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

" AH tol' all de folks yo' was comin' to mah house and make talk about how we ought to live. Ef dey do lak yo' say dey'll benefit by it. Some say yo' know more'n God does." That was the way Negro farmers in Alabama felt about Dr. George Washington Carver, a great American scientist whose labors conferred incalculable benefits on the agricultural South. Dr. Carver was a Negro, a humble, kindly, godly man.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, said today that he would like to postpone induction of fathers as long as possible, but acknowledged that calling them was likely to begin about July 1.

LONDON, April 1 (U.P.) -- His nerves cracked from the strain of a German bombing raid, Professor Arthur Lloyd James hanged himself with a necktie and scarf from a bar in his cell at the Broadmoor Insane Asylum March 24, an inquest disclosed today, thus bringing to a close a strange wartime murder case.

A list of large contributions to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City, headed by a gift of $200,000 from the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, was announced yesterday at the fund headquarters, 130 West Forty-second Street.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Dewey, reporting to the people on the radio on his three months in office, stated tonight that the State had a cash surplus of $69,000,000 and that a start had been made on "the long job of sweeping away some of the accumulated cobwebs of the last twenty years."

The transportation facilities that are required to move one armored division to fight this modern war were graphically illustrated yesterday in an advertisement published in this newspaper by the Pennsylvania Railroad. It pointed out that seventy-five trains would be required to move 12,000 troops, including tanks, jeeps, armored cars, supply trucks, tractors, anti-aircraft guns and other items.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 1 -- Clearing skies and a sharply rising temperature enabled the Giants to stage another intracamp game today for the enjoyment of about 2,500 onlookers, most of them school children who had received a half-holiday for the occasion.

Following is the full text of the address of Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, on "Post-war Commercial Policies of the United States," delivered yesterday before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York:

Leon Eddie's, after a six-month dispute with the American Guild of Variety Artists, has agreed to raise the wages of principal and chorus performers, it was announced yesterday by Dave Fox, an official of AGVA's New York local.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of prices in primary markets rose 0.3 per cent to a new high during the week ended on March 27 as a result of a marked increase in prices for farm products.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Grain markets turned upward today with fairly general buying early on reports that pressure was being placed on the President to have him sign the Bankhead bill in order to forestall more inflationary farm legislation.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

A banking group headed by Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; Lehman Brothers and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including 137 banking firms and dealers throughout the country will offer today a new issue of $52,000,000 of bonds of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company, which operates in the State of Washington.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force fliers blasted oil installations in a damaging raid yesterday on Bhamo, Japanese supply base in Burma near Yunnan Province, China, and American airmen continued their destructive attacks on enemy objectives in Central and Northern Burma, it was announced today.

What the Mayor's budget message boils down to is that the City's revenues, on the existing tax basis, are not sufficient to meet necessary expenses. This leaves four possible courses. The City could borrow to meet the expected deficit. Mayor La Guardia properly rules this step out, since it would merely postpone and aggravate the crisis.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Roosevelt has come to the defense of David Ginsburg, former general counsel of the Office of Price Administration, who was the target of charges by House members that he had sought an Army commission after having been deferred from the draft as irreplaceable.

A review of the first year of activity of the special War Committee of the New York City bar, showing the extent to which it has provided special consultative and advisory services to government agencies, organizations and individuals was made public yesterday by Charles E. Hughes Jr., its chairman.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 (AP) -- United States Headquarter coramuniqud : Formations of B-25 Mltchells, medium bombers, of the Tenth United States Air Force, 3Jarch 30 attacked enemy railway facilities at Maymyo, Burma.

Buyers were in a mad scramble yesterday for railroad shares to the exclusion of virtually all other securities, and the strength in the carriers offset profit-taking and weakening tendencies in other sections of the stock market. Gains of fractions to more than 2 points were scored by a wide variety of rails, low-priced as well as those of the standard systems.

New York's meat supply situation appeared yesterday to have passed the crisis stage as some retailers were reported refusing cuts available to them although others were still complaining that they were unable to get enough meat. The improvement was hastened by a drastic curtailment of consumer demand that started with the operation of point rationing on Monday and has been accentuated by "point" hoarding."

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 1 -- Two of Manager Joe McCarthy's recent casualties returned to work today as the Yankees went through a two-hour drill under conditions that surpassed anything the team has encountered since pitching camp here.

MOSCOW, April 1 -- While the battle for the Donets River loops continued today, with all German attacks stonewalled by a resolute defense, the Russians' revived offensive on their southern wing in the Caucasus intensified its threat to the remaining German positions north of the swollen Kuban River.
MOSCOW, April 1 (AP) -- The midday Soviet communique:

A hit-and-run automobile accident that horrified witnesses and the police alike at 8:55 o'clock last night killed Mrs. Minerva S. Le Bland, 22 years old, of 2601 Glenwood Road, Brooklyn and fatally injured her mother, Mrs. Tillie Schwartz, 46, of the same address.

Paul Windels' letter of March 26 is significant, not so much for its stanch defense of the amendments proposed to the existing Redevelopment Companies Law, but rather for its failure to discuss the elimination of the beneficial and protective features now contained in that law.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- William M. Jeffers told a Senate subcommittee today that the processing of synthetic rubber was being perfected to a point where it would "very nearly" meet all requirements without mixture of any natural rubber.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The story of how a skilled Navy gun crew aboard a 30-year-old United States merchantman routed a Nazi submarine in a surface gun duel, enabling their Ship to escape without damage, leaving the U-boat "dead in the water" was told today by the Navy Department.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- "Slug 'em again for the good of Chem," "Pin back their ears, you Engineers," "Knock 'em dead for Old Pre-Med."

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1 -- President Juan Antonio Rios told this correspondent in an interview yesterday at the Hacienda Larosa that the visit of Vice President Henry A. Wallace to Chile had been much more than an act of courtesy and good-will.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Plans were under discussion here today for further collaboration between the Chicago Opera Company and the Metropolitan Opera Association, which ends its first Chicago season in thirty-three years at the Civic Opera House Saturday night, a season unofficially reported to have taken in more than $160,000 for fourteen performances.

Bette Davis, Ann Sheridan and Julie Bishop will appear in the starring roles in Warners' screen version of "Dark Eyes," the Elena Miramova-Eugenie Leontovich comedy which has been at the Belasco Theatre here since Jan. 14. The picture will follow "Mrs. Skeffington" on Miss Davis's schedule and will serve as Miss Bishop's first starring assignment.

At the appointed hour last night, or very nearly so, the lights at the Metropolitan Opera House dimmed, two little V's on the sides of the proscenium lit up while Fate knocked at Mr. Beethoven's door, the national anthem sounded and the gala Spring season of Russian (sic) Ballet was under way.

Yale libraries, so rich and various in treasures, are to house a new and valuable collection. William R. Coe of this city, with the aid and advice of Edward Eberstadt, another New Yorker who is a connoisseur in Western history, has assembled in the last twenty-five years a great mass of material, much of it manuscript, about the history of the West, beginning with the Spanish explorers.

Excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City rose $25,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to $100,000,000, highest since Feb. 24, but for the nation as a whole excess funds dropped $110,000,000 in the week to $1,520,000,000, lowest in five years.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Three men, one accused of being a German-born enemy agent, were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiracy to acquire and export gold in violation of the Enemy Trading Act. They were arrested March 16 by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- A split in the Democratic leadership of the House developed over pay-as-you-go taxation today when John W. McCormack, the majority leader, called on the Ways and Means Committee to report out a compromise bill to grant "partial forgiveness" of tax liability, and Chairman Robert L. Doughton flatly refused to act on tax matters until May or June.

WITH BRITISH FORCES, in Northern Tunisia, April 1 (U.P.) -- British forces on the Northern Tunisian front successfully held off German attempts to return to Sedjenane from the east along the Mateur road today.

LONDON, April l -- Baron Bruntisfield, Parliamentary Secretary to the Admiralty, speaking in the House of Lords today, detailed the estimated losses of Axis merchant shipping, either captured, sunk or damaged since the beginning of the war to the end of February, 1943.

Your editorial on population last Sunday was better than most items appearing on this subject nowadays. The sharp rise in births which we are experiencing just now has led some people to believe that the trends of recent years are being substantially reversed.

An investing client of Elisha Sniffin, broker, purchased yesterday from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company the nine-story apartment house at 13-17 West Fifty-fifth Street, on a plot 75 by 100.10 feet. The assessed valuation of the property is $410,000.

Former Municipal Court Justice Dorothy Kenyon and Miss Fannie Hurst, author, have been added to the list of speakers who are to discuss women's responsibilities and hopes for the post-war world at the national women's conference called by THE NEW YORK TIMES for Wednesday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 1 -- American Flying Fortresses in the largest number ever assembled for a single raid -- nearly a hundred -- delivered the heaviest bombing attack of the entire North African campaign on Cagliari harbor and south Sardinian airfields yesterday, it was disclosed today.

Forced into overtime by an amazing St. John's comeback in the last two minutes, the University of Wyoming team sped away in the extra five-minute session and triumphed, 52 -- 47, in the season's final basketball contest at Madison Square Garden last night before 18,316 fans.

ALBANY, April 1 -- For the convenience of income taxpayers, all offices of the Department of Taxation and inance will keep open until 6 P. M. Saturdays April 3 and April 10. The offices in Albany, New York, Brooklyn, Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Utica will have examiners on duty to assist the taxpayers, according to an announcement of President Rollin Browne of the Ta Commission.

LONDON, April 1 -- General Charles de Gaulle is expected to leave Britain for North Africa soon for his conversations with General Henri Honore Giraud looking toward the ironing out of any differences that mark the unity between the French factions combatting a common enemy, it was learned today.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it will open sealed bids on April 8 on a new issue of $2,775,000 of temporary loan notes. The issue will be dated April 23 and will be payable Oct. 22, 1943.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 2 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek emerged smiling and triumphant today from her seventh press conference since arriving in the United States and, as her countryman who introduced her remarked, "probably" her last.

The veto of the Bankhead-Steagal bill by President Roosevelt did not come as surprise to commodity traders here. This bill, which would have prevented the inclusion of benefit payments made by the government to growers in the determination of price ceilings on farm products, had passed the Senate with only two dissenting votes, and the House, by 149 to 40.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- Representative Flannagan of Virginia said in the House today that he would apologize to no one, "not even my good friend the President of the United States," for his recent attack on the draft record of David Ginsburg, resigned general counsel of the Office of Price Administration.

Paul Zeckhausen, a mild married man who never brought home a strange hair on his coat, was troubled yesterday by long, blond tresses -- lots of them. His suit was sprinkled with them early in the day, even before he finished the morning's mail at the War Production Board's regional Office in the Chanin Building, where he is executive secretary of the general salvage branch.

N. Chanin, chairman of the administrative committee of the Jewish Labor Committee, yesterday struck back at Earl Browder, Communist party secretary, who charged in an address Thursday night that the Polish Socialist leaders Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter were executed in the Soviet Union because they had acted as representatives of an "anti-Soviet conspiracy" here.

New issues of municipal bonds: aggregating $5,625,000 will come up for award next week, representing the requirements of fourteen communities throughout the country. This compares with this week's revised total of $17,233,474, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $20,342,818.

Service men's families were warned yesterday by the Army to be on the lookout for a bogus "Sergeant Gallagher" who is engaged currently in a new confidence racket. Calling on wives, sweethearts and mothers of Army men, the Second Service Command announced, the man, usually wearing a first sergeant's chevrons, has secured money supposedly to bring a relative home for "one last trip" before changing stations.

IN 1931, when Hitler was still only one of many menaces, European labor was a great force. The Social Democratic parties had 26,000,000 adherents; more than 1,300 representatives of these parties sat in the European legislatures. No government in Germany, France or England was possible without at least the tacit consent of labor.

The American Institute of Public Opinion, in cooperation with the Advertising Council, has submitted a report to the Office of War Information that highlights the need for a better understanding on the part of consumers of the nature and operations of black markets, the council announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 2 -- The British Labor party today advocated the creation after e war of an international colonial commission which would supervise the "open door" policy whereby all nations would have equal access to raw materials, markets and capital investments in any colony owned by any country in the world.

" Air Raid Wardens," a Metro comedy starring Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rialto. Directed by Edward Sedgwick, the film's supporting cast includes Edgar Kennedy, Donald Meek, Jacqueline White and Horace McNally.

The joint invitation issued by New York's seven family-welfare agencies urging draft registrants who are troubled by personal or family problems to "come in and talk things over" is another reminder that these privately supported social bodies play an essential part in the life of our community.

The twelve French sailors who were interned on Ellis Island after seeking to transfer their allegiance from General Henri Honore Giraud to the Fighting French under General Charles DeGaulle were released yesterday in bond of $500 each.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- In four indictments, the Federal grand jury today accused 218 persons all over the country of conspiracy to violate the lottery laws. J. Albert Woll, United States attorney, said that the indictments involved four Chicago companies which did an annual business of more than $2,000,000.

The regulation that only the radio shall give the all-clear signal after an air raid would be impossible on the Pacific Coast. I went through several alerts there last year, and our first indication always was that the radios went off the air, silenced by the Army Command, as incoming enemy planes would use their directional beams.

The stock market was thrown off balance yesterday when the unhealthy situation created by the flare-up in the railway shares, on Thursday, unaccompanied by corresponding confirmation of the advance by the industrials, invited profit taking.

Food dealers of New York City began slashing ration-point values of meats yesterday. In different boroughs some dealers took point readjustments into their own hands under an Office of Price Administration regulation permitting them to lower points on any foods "in imminent danger of spoilage."

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt today vetoed the Bankhead bill to exclude government benefit payments from calculation of parity prices for ceiling purposes. It would give farmers "an unwarranted bonus at the expense of the consumers," he said, and thus set off "an inflationary tornado."

The first public utility financing in 1943 lifted the total of new bond issues offered here for public subscription this week to $78,575,000 for six diversified flotations, the largest weekly figure since mid-January, and the second biggest since the end of April, 1942.

Sayed Sebghatullah Shad, the Pir of Pagara, bold and bad, robber of trains and mugger in Sind, has gone with the wind. He had been in jail since the Fall of '41. He was the head of a marauding Moslem sect or tribe called the Hurs. India, prolific in religions, has seldom had a queerer one than this, judged by the conduct of its devotees.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 2 -- It was announced in Sofia tonight that Adolf Hitler received King Boris at his field headquarters for a long conversation on Wednesday. Details of the talk are lacking, but in usually well-informed circles in the Bulgarian capital it is an open secret that the King has been called upon to make "important decisions" linking the fate of Bulgaria more closely with that of the Axis.
The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States has sold eleven houses in New Jersey through Abeles-Stevens, Inc., brokers. Six are in Newark as follows:
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Chairman Tydings of the Senate Territories Committee introduced today a bill to give independence to Puerto Rico.
TULSA, Okla., April 2 (AP) -- The State summed up its case against Mrs. Ella B. Howard today by describing her as "the rootin', tootin' shootin'" slayer of Mrs. T. Karl Simmons.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the Board, said today that at the first meeting of the Management-Labor Council problems related to increasing aircraft production were discussed.

Latin America offers today the most promising field for immediate development in the entire world, John B. Glenn, president of the Pan American Trust Company of New York, said yesterday at a meeting here of the New York Society of Security Analysts.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The War Department announced today award of the Distinguished Service Cross for heroism in North Africa to two officers and seven enlisted men and the citation in general orders of three enlisted men.

NEW DELHI, India, April 2 (U.P.) -- British fliers, in a new victory over the reinforced Japanese air force in Burma, yesterday shot down five planes when a formation of thirty bombers escorted by fighters attacking an Allied air base town in Southeastern Bengal, it was announced today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- Ann Richards, a young Australian actress, little known here, today was cast as the feminine lead in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's biggest undertaking for this year, the King Vidor production "America." Miss Richards left the Antipodes on Dec. 8, 1941, on the last passenger boat to leave for this country.

DETROIT, April 2 (AP) -- The third and fourth games of the Stanley Cup hockey series will be played Tuesday and Thursday nights in Boston, as now scheduled, President Mervyn (Red) Dutton of the National Hockey League declared tonight following a stormy meeting at which Manager Art Ross of the Boston Bruins sought to have the dates changed.

In a cash transaction Frederick Brown has acquired through the Charles F. Noyes Company seven properties in Manhattan and two in Brooklyn. The aggregate assessed valuation of the parcels involved in the deal is $274,000.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, April 2 -- The valor of a Honduran identified only as "Gamez" is the subject of an editorial under the heading "La Epoca," commenting on the recent sinking by a Nazi submarine off the coast of Yucatan of a merchantman on which Gamez served as a seaman.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 2 -- Determined to snap his Giants out of the hitting slump which seems to have been fastened on them even before a single exhibition game has been played, Manager Mel Ott sent his charges through a long and intensive batting drill today.

As a Lenten attraction the Blackfriars Guild is giving a sincere and respectful production of the late John Drinkwater's "A Man's House." This is a play telling of the effect of the crucifixion on the members of a well-to-do Jerusalem family; it was shown at Malvern almost a decade ago and since has attracted some attention from Broadway managers, though none thus far has offered it professionally.

The Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee yesterday announced Spring selections in its quarterly list of one hundred recommended books. Named as outstanding in the list of titles were "A Companion to the Summa," Vol. IV, by Father Farrell; "Medieval Europe," by Dr. Jeremiah O'Sullivan and the Rev. John F. Burns; "These Two Hands," by the Roy. E.J. Edwards and "Balcony Empire," by Reynolds and Eleanor Packard.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 2 -- The Brazilian Coordinator of Economic Mobilization, Joao Alberto Lins de Barros, confirmed yesterday that Germany was spreading agents throughout the northeastern section of the country with instructions to discourage rubber workers from going to the Amazon region.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Truman Senate defense committee condemned John L. Lewis today for "repeatedly asserting that he did not regard his promise to the President not to strike as 'necessarily binding,'" and vigorously took issue with his testimony before the committee last Friday.

The former town home of Jesse Livermore at 8 West Seventy-sixth Street, now used for small apartments, has been sold by the Guaranty Trust Company as trustee under the will of William Henry McAlister, to the Willmur Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- As an indication of the tremendous part that United States Army aircraft played in the rout of the Axis at the Mareth Line by the British Eighth Army, the War Department disclosed today that American planes, on March 30 alone, made 1,399 sorties against Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's fleeing forces.

The number of women in war work in the metropolitan region has nearly doubled within a year, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, announced at her office at 11 West Forty-second Street yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (Science Service ) -- A recently granted patent covering an improved individual package for ready-to-eat cereals which also serves as a bowl has just been disclosed. It is now being supplied to Army messes. After opening the perforated front panel of the handy package the sealed wax paper bag inside is slit open and sugar and cream poured on.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A group of railroad labor executives, appearing before the Senate's Truman war investigating committee denounced today as "false and pernicious" charges that rail workers were hampering the war effort by insistence on retention of longstanding, so-called "featherbed" regulations under which they receive pay for time when they are on duty but not actually moving freight and passengers.

Plans to introduce new laws in Connecticut and Maryland during current legislative sessions in order to effectuate uniform compliance with a recent Supreme Court decision governing assignment of accounts receivable by business debtors were made known yesterday by Theodore H. Silbert, executive secretary of the Association of Commercial Discount Companies, Inc.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 2 -- Louis Austin, president of District 11 of the United Mine Workers, alleged here tonight that a man dressed in civilian clothes who had "credentials showing he was from the United States Army Intelligence" was here Wednesday asking why Indiana union miners have not signed a temporary agreement with the operators of strip mines.

Rex Stout and Mignon G. Eberhart, authors of detective stories, will discuss jointly "The Mystery Story: How the Writer Solves It," at the opening meeting Tuesday of the Authors' Guild Craftsman Series, presented at the Washington Square Writing Center of New York University, in Room 703 of the university's main Washington Square building.
NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (AP) -- A United States Air Forces communique:

Marty Forkins, the theatrical producer who has not been represented hereabouts since his presentation of the Negro musical "Brown Buddies" in 1930, sends word from the Coast that he has acquired a new play, "Assembly Call," and will produce it on Broadway some time in September.

The important duty of assuring security on the home front was emphasized yesterday by Mgr. Robert F. Keegan, secretary for charities to Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, in his annual report made public in support of the current New York Catholic Charities appeal.

Commissioner Daniel P. Woolley of the Department of Markets declared last night on the weekly Business Forum broadcast over Station WMCA that the city is doing all in its power to stamp out black markets in food and that the public will be informed at all times of the facts in the situation.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The text of President Roosevelt's veto of the Bankhead bill today follows:
Still $2,266,388 short of the $12,920,700 goal set for the city this year, the American Red Cross War Fund announced yesterday the receipt of a $100,000 gift from John D. Rockefeller Jr.

Under-Secretary of State Welles did not overstate the case when he told the Chamber of Commerce of this State that within the next few weeks a decision must be made by Congress which "will be regarded by peoples throughout the world as an acid test of our future intentions."

MOSCOW, April 2 -- Interest today centers on the narrow tip of the Western Caucasus, where, in the Kuban delta and on terraced vine-clad slopes, Russian pressure is being exerted with increasing strength. Three more localties were reported wrested from the enemy in today's communique.

Among the twenty-nine American artists whose paintings for war bond posters are to be shown in the "Art for Bonds" exhibition sponsored by the Treasury Department at the Brooklyn Museum, are Reginald Marsh, Alexander Brook Thomas Benton, John Steuart Curry, John Atherton and Allen Saalburg.

A tribute to the work of news photographers on the war and home fronts was paid last night by Major Gen. Sanderford Jarman, commanding general of the Antiaircraft Artillery Command of the Eastern Defense Command, at the opening of the eighth annual exhibition of the Press Photographers Association of New York, Inc., at the New York Museum of Science and Industry, Rockefeller Center.

LONDON, April 2 -- Another hint on the imminence of a second front came today from Food Minister Lord Woolton, who warned that the British public might have to look forward to variations in food supplies when the next phase of extensive military operations starts, as Britain would then probably be living on her own resources.

Many of the less essential civilian rayon outlets such as men's neckwear and drapery fabrics may have to be abandoned for the duration when the Office of Civilian Supply announces its long-awaited program to conserve dwindling output of synthetic yarns, it was reported yesterday by rayon suppliers.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, modified today his order of Wednesday giving Lou R. Maxon, his deputy administrator in charge of public relations, virtual veto powers over all OPA orders, field instructions, regulations and vital policy decisions.

Today's events: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; Cornell University Chorus, Town Hall, 2:30; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; "Pique Dame," in concert form Russian Opera Company, Town Hall, 8:30; Joseph Szigeti, violin, Washington Irving High School, 8:30.

The 150th anniversary of Christ Episcopal Church, 205 West Seventy-first Street, west of Broadway, will be celebrated tomorrow. The anniversary sermon will be delivered at 11 A.M. by the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island and for many years rector of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, Manhattan.

NEWARK, N.J., April 2 -- Officials of this city and the Office of Price Administration, gathered in City Hall today to inquire into the persistence of the meat shortage, were told by the representative of a local wholesaler, with more than enough beef in storage to provide a pound of meat for every individual in Newark, that he could not afford to sell it at prevailing ceiling prices.

Only through the creation of an international structure of mutual responsibility will the world obtain a lasting post-war peace period, speakers declared yesterday at the Thirty-eighth Council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, which opened its three-day meeting in the Hotel New Yorker.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, April 4 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The Rev. Dr. Edgar Franklin Roming is receiving felicitations on his completion this week of twenty-five years as a minister of the Collegiate Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of the City of New York. Since 1931 he has been the pastor of the church at Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue, one of its eight houses of worship in Manhattan.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- An eight-car elevated train rolled through Chicago's partly completed $57,000,000 subway today, carrying 450 Federal, State and municipal leaders on the first official inspection of the new tubes, which are expected to open for revenue operation probably in about two months.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Labor Department officials intimated today that there was every reason to believe that women workers in war industry were saving their money or spending it wisely. They said that the characterization of "spendthrift" for these women was not an accurate one.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Dewey signed today a bill giving him authority to make major appointments, requiring Senate confirmation, when the Legislature is not in session. During legislative debate on the measure several Republicans stated that the bill was being passed to insure the Governor's right to displace Democratic holdovers.

A large penthouse has been leased in 383 Park Avenue by Beatrice Osorio through N.A. Berwin Co., brokers; Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, agents. Through the same brokers, Dr. Joseph W. Moore and Ensign Charles F. Craig rented apartments in 108 East Thirty-eighth Street and Thomas B.G. Henderson in 20 Park Avenue, Cruikshank Co., agents, Other rentals follow:

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The House, in its third tempestuous session in two weeks devoted to consideration of the Justice Department's War Security Bill, passed the measure with a voice vote today. It tightens existing law to provide adequate punishment , including death, for spies, saboteurs and others convicted of hostile acts against the United States.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 2 -- The Hudson County Board of Taxation announced today its 1943 schedule of property assessments for this city, showing a net decrease on all ratables of $40,733,035.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The New York region, comprising New York State and Northern New Jersey, has contributed as much to the war effort as it did to the peacetime economy of the country, according to a report by Carl H. Henrikson Jr., regional business consultant to the Commerce Department.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Charging that a "gigantic conspiracy" exists to fix transportation rates in violation of the law, Senator Shipstead of Minnesota introduced today a resolution calling for a full investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Sharp curtailment in the purchase of wool cloths by government agencies in January compared with the preceding month and an increase of about 25 per cent in the sale of men's and women's civilian fabrics during the period were disclosed yesterday in the monthly report issued by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 2 -- For the first time since training began, all the eligible Yankees were in camp today. Joe Gordon, last to report, was in uniform, leaving only the suspended Frankie Crosetti absent.
Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Brokaw have returned from Palm Beach and are at the Savoy-Plaza.

PASADENA, Calif., April 2 (U.P.) -- Sailors or airmen adrift on the ocean now can survive as long as twenty-five days on sea water purified through a simple chemical formula, according to Dr. Alex Goetz of the California Institute of Technology.
I enjoyed greatly Arthur Daley's column regarding the trials and tribulations of Dick Bartell, who has made many a dull afternoon memorable.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Roosevelt vetoed the Bankhead bill which would exclude Federal farm benefit payments in the calculation of parity prices.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Proposed pricing methods for manufacturers of Fall outerwear garments for women, girls and children will be announced publicly and discussed with apparel producers in simultaneous nationwide meetings on Monday, April 12, the OPA announced today.

CLINTON, N.J., April 2 -- Pointers gained awards today in the open junior all-age stake, second event of the annual Spring field trial meeting held by the Jockey Hollow Club on the public shooting grounds here.

International policy and international cooperation are in process of development. At this moment, when nations are struggling for survival and new ideas are in conflict with the old, they are at a painful and critical stage of that process. This is the real meaning of the troubled debate going on both within and between the states of the anti-Axis coalition.

COS COB, Conn., April 2 -- With a generous mixture of hard work and Yankee ingenuity, Harold C. Powers and his six helpers, including his wife, have won an Army-Navy "E" pennant for the small machine shop in which they serve the nation's war effort by making precision parts for aircraft.

Declaring that he would not permit "hysteria" nor any other consideration to swerve him from the orderly performance of his duty, Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, took issue with Mayor La Guardia yesterday that the Board of Education is "afraid" to retire teachers who are unfit for service.

LONDON, April 2 -- Sergeant Bronislaw Godlewski, 19-year-old Polish-American air gunner in the Royal Air Force who comes from Chicago, received today as he lay in bed in a British hospital the Polish Medial Virtuti Militari, equivalent to the American Congressional Medal of Honor or the British Victoria Cross, for valorous conduct.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Examination of the texts of the "no raiding" proposals made in the last two days by the peace committees of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations showed today the reasons for the failure to reach an agreement.

MEXICO CITY, April 2 -- In a statement published yesterday, Javier Rojo Gomez, Mayor of Mexico City and head of the Central Committee of Civil Defense, advocated stronger vigilance against Axis sympathizers.

The world's most expensive vegetables will be probably those grown in a victory garden at Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street. It is situated on the grounds of the Synod House of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where day before yesterday Bishop Manning turned the first spadeful of earth.

ALBANY, April 2 -- Governor Dewey today told a delegation of eight Saratoga Springs officials and citizens that if they could prove to him operation of the Saratoga track would not waste gasoline or rubber, he would recommend to William M. Jeffers, Federal Rubber Administrator, that racing be permitted as usual at the historic up-State track next August.

The United Gas Improvement Company, for many years the owner of a majority of the common and preferred stocks of the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company, announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement to sell its entire interest in the company to Charles U. Bay of Bridgeport, Conn.

Prices on cotton futures dipped yesterday to losses of as much as 17 points after President Roosevelt's veto of the Bankhead-Steagall bill, which would have prohibited the inclusion of benefit payments in the determination of ceilings on farm products, but moderate price-fixing by the trade in the absence of any follow-through on the selling side rallied the market to closing levels that were only 2 to 4 points below Thursday's final quotations.

The clubs which young people organize among themselves in American cities are sometimes considered a "problem," and those existing in this city's Harlem are not an exception. That the clubs can also be an opportunity is shown by the way in which the Harlem organizations, of which there are said to be about 200, are waking up to what they can do in time of war.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- The War Department today made public the names of 562 United States soldiers held as prisoners of war by the Japanese.

The blue-ribbon jury in the three-week General Sessions trial of Irving Premisler, 40 years old, and Harry Ehrlich, 42, on the first-degree murder indictment in the shooting of Harry Nichols, Williamsburg gambling "overlord," on Sept. 26, 1933, was discharged yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Seagoing battleship drydocks unlike anything that any other navy in the world has seen, will be ready in three months to go into service with the United States Fleet, Rear Admiral Ben Moreell, Navy Engineering Chief, disclosed today at Secretary Knox's press conference.

LONDON, April 2 -- The combined operations of the public relations branches of the Admiralty, War Office and Air Ministry were criticized today in a report by the Committee on National Expenditure, which found that there was no real machinery to insure that on any given day a balanced presentation of news stories from the British fighting services could be made to the world.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, proposed yesterday that the government subsidize the wage increases he is asking the hard coal industry to pay its 80,000 workers. He urged the coal operators to make the request for subsidies to the proper government agencies.

A van sent out by the Opportunity Shop, 46 West Forty-seventh Street, some time ago to collect articles donated for charity, brought back a load of assorted objects that included an antique doll's bureau.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and its four maritime unions asserted today that waste, confusion and lack of planning were holding down the efficient use of our available shipping resources "to an alarming degree" and hampering the successful prosecution of the war.

An audience which showed its pleasure and excitement at every possible opportunity attended the second concert of the now notable series projected by Adolph Busch and his selected chamber music players last night in Town Hall. The first of these concerts had presented three of the six Brandenburg concertos of J.S. Bach.

ARROWHEAD SPRINGS, Calif., April 2 (U.P.) -- Dorothy Lamour, screen actress, who is resting at this resort, announced today that she would be married to Captain William Ross Howard 3d of the Army Air Forces in about ten days.

Frank B. Warren, formerly assistant counsel of the Federal Communications Commission, was appointed yesterday general counsel of R.C.A. Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of the Radio Corporation of America. For the last year, Mr. Warren has been assistant general solicitor of the National Association of Railroad and Utility Commissioners.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 2 -- British First Army Troops in the north fought their way toward the Axis strongholds of Tunis and Bizerte today while General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's Eighth Army gathered force in the south for more smashing blows coupled with the continuing massive air assaults on Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's divisions retreating up the Tunisian east coast.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -- Senator Stewart of Tennessee assailed Governor Dewey today for a recent statement that freight rates had become the subject of "sectional political debate."

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- United States fighter planes, beating back what was believed to have been a strong attempt by the Japanese Air Force to attack the American airfield on Guadalcanal Island, shot down sixteen enemy Zeros yesterday, Solomon Islands time, the Navy reported today in a communique.

After an ownership of more than twenty-four years, the Donner Realty Company has sold the twenty-four family apartment building with four stores at 268 East 181st Street, the Bronx. The house is on a plot 100.03 by 54.04 feet.

TRENTON, April 2 (AP) -- The New Jersey Department of Health charged tonight that many large packing and distributing houses and meat markets were working a "widespread fraud" by selling adulterated hamburger, and announced that Attorney General David T. Wilentz might be asked to bring suits under the State's Pure Food and Drug Act.

Freight car loadings in the second quarter of this year are expected to be 2.5 per cent above the 8,947,071 in the similar period of last year, according to estimates compiled by the thirteen shippers' advisory boards. On this basis the freight loadings of twenty-eight principal commodities will be 9,170,439 cars.
Beau Jack won just enough of a margin in the earlier chapters to defeat Henry Armstrong in their ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The noon Soviet communique, as recorded by the Soviet radio monitor:

Igor Stravinsky and quite the most brilliant aggregation of ballerinas to be found in any single company shared the rather copious honors of last night's performance by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Hogs sold at the stockyards today for $16.10 a hundred pounds, a peak previously unequaled since October, 1920, while packers and producers, at a meeting in the Loop, strove to prevent what they called an "acutely chaotic situation surrounding the national meat supply."

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, declined today to express an opinion to the Senate Banking Committee on the Maloney bill to make the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply an independent agency, but urged that it receive "a stronger and louder voice regardless of where it is placed."

Some 15,000 eager young college and high school students filed into the classrooms of 144 schools and colleges here at 9 A.M. yesterday to take the joint qualifying examination of the Army specialized training program and the Navy college training program.

Despite objections by the Attorney General of the State and the New York County Medical Society, the appointment of a doctor as X-ray technician, handling numerous workmen's compensation cases, was approved by the State Labor Department in 1937, according to evidence yesterday before Moreland Act Commissioner William F. Bleakley.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 -- A "work pile" plan designed to take up the slack during the critical period after the war was started today by the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Milwaukee today was named winner of the 1942 Inter-Chamber Fire Waste Contest sponsored by the National Fire Waste Council of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

Four advertising agencies have been appointed to handle the advertising of the Radio Corporation of America, it was announced yesterday. Three of them will handle the various advertising activities of the RCA Victor Division, which was among the first of the producers of radio sound and electronic equipment to convert for all-out war output.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York appealed yesterday to Mayor La Guardia and the members of the Board of Estimate to fix April 14 and 15 or April 15 and 16 as the dates for the board's public hearings on the Mayor's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44.

Time was -- before 1939 -- when pilgrims from all over the world gathered in Jerusalem for an Easter dawn service that was broadcast by short wave to America and other lands. On this Easter dawn, April 25, the broadcast will be reversed.

In their strictly utilitarian days, aprons were no embellishment for a costume. Hostesses whisked them off in a jiffy when the doorbell rang. Now they emerge in a wholly new character, so chic and sartorially frivolous that one rushes to don them as the guests arrive.
LOS ANGELES, April 2 -- After thirty-four years of married life, Mrs. Viola B. Selwyn obtained an interlocutory decree of divorce today from Arch Selwyn, play producer.
It may be that by nightfall some of the one-to-three-pound trout reported to have been planted in Westchester and Putnam County waters recently will have found their way into fishermen's creels.

James Silvers, 48 years old, who gave the Delmonico Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, as his address, and swore that for years he had been "public relations officer" for racetracks across the country, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of maintaining a room for gambling in the ten-room suite at 525 Park Avenue that was raided by the police on the night of last Jan. 9.
ANTOFAGASTA, Chile, April 2 -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace has begun his tour of the nitrate fields near Antofagasta, where he arrived by plane this afternoon after flying from Santiago.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, April 3 -- General Douglas MacArthur announced today that Brig. Gen. Howard K. Ramey, commander of the Fifth Bomber Command of the Fifth United States Air Force, failed to return from a recent mission.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- War and Navy Department spokesmen declared today that the earnings of the capital's commission agents, dealing in war contract procurement, were "outrageous and scandalous," and sought power to curb the profits of those claiming influence and operating from "offices in their hats."

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Reports that the President would veto the Bankhead bill, which would prohibit benefit payments to farmers being used in computing parity prices, were in circulation today before the grain markets on the Board of Trade opened.

I always have thought that basketball coaches, with a comparatively few exceptions, know less about the game than they pretend, and the rule recommendations made by their national association on Tuesday strengthen that belief.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Colonel Robert W. Johnson, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, told a meeting of business men and government officials today that 8,000 to 10,000 small manufacturing businesses in the United States were in distress but their distress could be ended in three months if 15,000 to 20,000 buyers for government and private enterprise would suffer a change of heart.

General Henri Honore Giraud warned Chief of Government Pierre Laval of Vichy last night in a dramatic broadcast that the French Army in Africa was going to take the truth to France with its bayonets and march on until it reached the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.

LONDON, April 2 -- A moving tribute was paid today to Flying Officer Raimund Sanders Draper, American member of the Royal Air Force, who was killed recently when his disabled plane crashed after he had skillfully prevented it from ramming a school building in Hornchurch in which there were nearly 1,000 children.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

John W. McCormack, the House majority leader, has had the courage to assume that his title means something. He has called on the Ways and Means Committee immediately to report out a compromise pay-as-you-go plan. Joseph W. Martin Jr., the House minority leader, will show equal statesmanship if he immediately endorses this proposal.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, April 3 -- American heavy bombers struck at a concentration of shipping off Kavieng, New Ireland, at dusk Thursday in one of the biggest long-range air attacks carried out in the Southwest Pacific for some time, today's Allied Headquarters communique revealed.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The story of a "ghost ship," a torpedoed Dutch merchantman that would not stay dead and came back, against almost unbelievable difficulties, to fight again for the Allies was told today, by the Navy Department as "another heroic adventure of men of the sea against tremendous odds."

CHUNGKING, China, April 2 (U.P.) -- Front dispatches indicated tonight that the main fighting in Central China had shifted north of the Yangtze River, with Chinese troops striking at Japanese garrisons and communication lines over a widespread area from Central Hupeh Province to Southern Honan.

During April and May, 1942, and ever since October, 1942, I have been spending about two hours a night, five nights a week, trying to recruit men and women for air warden duty. The men were told that they must sit out a four-hour night watch at our headquarters once every twelve days.
BOSTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:
ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 2 (AP) -- Eastman Kodak Company, summarizing its hugely accelerated 1942 war production, disclosed today it is a "veritable arsenal of photography."

Here you will see menus for next week for a family of four -- a moderately active man, a moderately active woman, a boy of 13 and a girl of 11 -- that are intended to help you in feeding your household whatever its size.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Quartermaster Corps is still far short of its current requirements in cotton herringbone twills, the Army's fabric for "battle dress" uniforms, it was admitted today by Colonel Robert T. Stevens, chief of the textile and clothing branch of the procurement division of the Quartermaster General.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Nine governments, including those of Soviet Russia, the United Kingdom and China, have already accepted the invitation to the United Nations conference of technical experts on post-war food problems which will open in this country April 27, Secretary Hull said today.

Additional bank statements of condition reported yesterday as of March 31, like those issued on the previous day, showed a mixture of trends for the quarter. Some of the institutions gained deposits and increased their holdings of United States Government securities, while for others, the opposite was true.

Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, declared yesterday that he had voted against Mark Starr, education director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, who was rejected by the board for the post of school adult education director, because some of his Writings "tend to create class hatred."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 2 -- Yesterday morning, not yet twenty-four hours after an equal number of Flying Fortresses had pasted Cagliari Harbor and South Sardinia's three main air bases without losing a single plane, nearly a hundred light and medium bombers, including Bostons, Mitchells and Baltimores, covered the El Maou Airfield in the Sfax area with a dense pattern of bomb bursts.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 2 -- Rumors of bombings in France, notably in Lyon, continue to reach here. They are unconfirmable. Indeed, there is ground for doubting their accuracy in view of trustworthy information that "groups of resistance" are devoting all their energy to preparing to aid an eventual Anglo-American landing.

Immediate establishment by the United Nations of an International Education Organization, similar in its general organization and structure to the International Labor Organization, has been recommended by twenty American and European educators.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Office of Price Administration gave a warning today to butchers in several cities who have been selling meat point-free because of alleged danger of spoilage, that they would be sternly dealt with if they continued the practice.

LONDON, April 2 -- The tone of the stock markets today was cheerful on the latest news from Tunisia, but business was quiet because of week-end considerations. Giltedge stocks held yesterday's prices and home rafts hardened.

Sales of war bonds in the Second Federal Reserve District in March, by agencies other than postoffices, totaled $140,100,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with $142,000,000 in this district in February, and with $109,000,000 in March, 1942.

LONDON, Saturday, April 3 -- Germany suffered 1,193,525 casualties -- 850,000 dead and 343,525 captured -- in the great Red Army Winter offensive, which swept back the Germans to the west as much as 435 miles and freed 185,328 square miles of Soviet territory, Russia announced early today in a special communique.

KEARNY, N.J., April 2 (AP) -- The Western Electric Company announced today it was manufacturing for the Army a field cable over which seven telephone and telegraph messages could be transmitted simultaneously and secretly.

Outdoor daffodils grown in the near-by regions of Southern or "barnyard" New Jersey made their bow on flower stalls here this week, the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets announced yesterday. So far these neighboring daffodils appear in one variety only, the large-sized, orange-petaled King Alfreds.
Sports fans of the metropolitan district should consider themselves fortunate, for if any city rates the distinction of being the wartime sports capital of the nation it is New York.

In a two-to-one decision, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday upheld a ruling in which Federal Judge Murray Hulbert ordered the return of $500,000 in checks seized last Dec. 2 from an employe of the American Dealers Service, Inc.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- M.W. Clement, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, criticized labor today for asking that an additional fireman be placed on electric locomotives. He told how improvements in railroading had lightened work and increased wages, making it possible in one instance for an engineer to get four and a half days' pay for one round trip between New York and Washington.
CHUNGKING, China, April 3 (U.P.) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 2 -- Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz, it was revealed today, is in complete agreement with Secretary Frank Knox's statement that the present war is pre-eminently a naval war. The conurrence, however, appears to derive from conflicting premises.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- An Administration move to avoid a controversy over renewal of the reciprocal trade program prompted a proposal today by Senator Taft that Congress extend the authority for three years but provide that all agreements expire six months after the war ends.

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente granted judgment yesterday against the Koppers Company directing it to pay back, with interest, to the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, its affiliate, $346,358 that the court held had been received as unlawful profits from the collection of management, construction and engineering fees from the Brooklyn company.

CHICAGO, April 2 (AP) -- Prices of live hogs reached today the highest level since October, 1920, at $16.10 a hundredweight, but the gains were not maintained and some closing sales were 10 to 15 cents lower than Thursday's averages. Today's report by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt Pell gave a luncheon yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. James Lenox Banks Jr., Lady Ewart, Mrs. M. Taylor Pyne, Mrs. Jorge Andre, Mrs. C. Whitney Carpenter and Mrs. Albert Gould Jennings.

It is already apparent that flight will be immensely extended by the developments in range, speed and load which have been accelerated by the demands of war. Not only have planes and engines, landing gears and "high-lift" devices, for the utilization of small and difficult fields, been advanced; instrumentation and the development of radio aids have taken new strides to meet military demands.

One quarter of the 18-and-19-year-olds examined under selective service have been found unfit for military duty, despite the fact they are considered the healthiest group in the nation, Colonel Leonard G. Rowntree, chief of the medical division of National Selective Service, revealed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Navy communique 333:

LONDON, April 2 -- In a speech today in which he announced big increases in Britain's output of war materials, Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, said the days of desert warfare were numbered "and we must look forward to fighting in an enclosed country, a country with roads, rivers and railways."

AT AN ADVANCED UNITED STATES AIR BASE, in Southern Tunisia, April 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- Led by the glazing guns of their 28-year-old commander, Colonel William W. Momyer of Seattle, who knocked down four Stukas, a group of P-40 pilots bagged thirteen Nazi planes in fighter sweeps yesterday and today, raising their victory string to thirty-four since March 25.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 2 -- The Dodgers concluded this unique Northern training visit by scoring a sort of half-and-half triumph over Lieutenant Paul Amen's Army team, 12 -- 8, in an eight-inning game on Doubleday Field today.
The editorial "A World Language" published in THE TIMES of March 21 has been read with great appreciation by those of us concerned with definite work for the world language.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics cost-of-living index, which has been widely criticized inside as well as outside of the bureau as not accurately reflecting the pattern of individual consumption in the emergency period, is going to be corrected, it was learned today.

Talent-loaded Ohio State, headed by Bill Smith, sensational 18-year-old freshman from Hawaii, launched its expected strong bid for the national A.A.U. indoor swimming team championship last night as the annual meet opened before a capacity throng at the New York A.C. 75-foot pool.

Retail trade here was spotty this week. Rainy weather and the fact that stores were up against the high Easter sales totals of last year brought a sharp percentage drop in sales. The average decline was estimated as in excess of 10 per cent.

LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- Reuter, in a dispatch from an advanced Allied base in New Guinea, reported today that special Australian patrols on Goodenough and the Trobriand Islands had captured hundreds of Japanese survivors from smashed convoys in the Bismarck Sea.

LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- Keeping one eye on the progress of the Allied armies in Tunisia, the Germans and Italians are reported continually strengthening the coastal defenses of Europe, particularly those of the "underbelly" in Italy and Southern France, in preparation to meet invasion.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Tunisia, April 1 (Delayed) -- The whole network of roads and passes connecting the trails through the Matmata hills, almost all of which had been thoroughly mined and booby-trapped in an effort to make the mountainous bastion impervious to attack, was cleared in sixty hours by Indians, with the usual admixture of British artillery and infantry, it may now be revealed.

It was coincidence, I know, but in three recent columns concerning Bill Grieve, Joe McCarthy and Elmer Ripley the city of Wilkes-Barre was mentioned by Arthur Daley in one way or another. They were all interesting and I would like to say that his daily dissertations are pleasant breaks in reading wartime newspapers.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Demands that farming and industrial America take a vigorous hand in fashioning the post-war revival in this country and predictions both that there would and would not be economic shocks when peace came were voiced today at the Midwest post-war planning conference of the Council of State Governments.

TO those who find difficulty in deciphering dates in Roman numerals on title pages there was comfort in the drawing by Chon Day in The New Yorker two years ago. It showed a togaed personage on ice skates describing a figure VII.

The major systems will be augmented by feeder systems, using smaller and more adaptable equipment, which will bring the speed and convenience of flight to remote areas and small communities.

An editor of a German language weekly published here and his wife were among eight German enemy aliens rounded up by Federal agents in a series of spot raids in metropolitan New York over the week-end.

HOLLYWOOD. PARAMOUNT'S decision to turn the cinema searchlight on the unsavory and vicious lives of the Nazi leaders in a picture to be called "The Hitler Gang" is the result of a "rage" experienced by Production Chief B.G. De Sylva as he witnessed a private showing of the German propaganda picture, "Oom Kruger."

SOME people are born with a gift for music or painting or writing. Mother, the presiding angel of Rosemary Taylor's book, had it for keeping boarders. To her, sleeping and feeding a lot of extra people in her house in Arizona meant no trouble.

The Cornell Chorus gave a concert at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, with some of the best a cappella singing heard in the city this season. It was assisted by Thelma Emile, pianist, who played a short recital of her own as part of the general program.

A faulty final turn, enabling Harry Holiday of Michigan to shade him in a stirring finish, terminated Adolph Kiefer's amazing long chain of backstroke triumphs last night as the annual men's national A.A.U. indoor swimming championships were concluded in the New York A.C. seventy-five-foot pool.

Dr. Serge Koussevitsky, who, in a recent New York season of Boston Symphony concerts devoted his first two programs to American music, has made his last two concerts in this city of the series of 1942-43 principally of the works of native songs.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Representative Martin, Republican leader of the House, demanded tonight immediate action by the Ways and Means Committee on a pay-as-you-earn tax plan, asserting that "pride of authorship, political expediency, social experimentation and economic theory must give way to realism, necessity and speed."

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Onota Lake at Pittsfield, one of the largest lakes in the Berkshires, is to be opened for fishing this year on April 15 along with other great ponds and streams in the Bay State. This will be the first time in seven years that the start of the trout-fishing season at Onota has been set ahead from May 30.
The sophomore class of Barnard College won over the freshman class, 62 to 34, at the forty-first presentation of Greek games in the Barnard gymnasium yesterday.

A bud is a marvelous thing. There it sits on the branch, the Winter through, while the wind and the rain, the sleet and the snow, deliver their worst. It shows no more sign of life than the ice-bead which clings to its tip on a January morning. But when the earth has reached that particular point in its orbit, when the sun casts that first vernal ray, life appears.

IN last Sunday's article some stress was laid on the marked prominence of Latin-American art in the realm of exhibition activities just now. A comprehensive Mexican show opened late last month at the Philadelphia Museum. In the Brooklyn Museum watercolor biennial, due next Friday, 81 of the 219 examples, we are informed, will be by Argentinean, Brazilian, Cuban and Mexican artists.

PRIME MINISTER CHURCHILL in his address of March 21 made the first British pronouncement of world organization to preserve peace. He suggested that as a basis "one can imagine that under a world institution embodying or representing the United Nations, and some day all nations, there should come into being a Council of Europe and a Council of Asia."
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The noon Soviet communique, a$ recorded by tke Ioviet 'ado monitor:

IN the United States we have a popular picture of Churchill which, from what I see and hear over here, isn't so far off the track. It's somewhat of a chromo, over-colored and unflawed, but most Americans think of him as an honest, bulldog patriot * * * who kept the heart in his people when they were threatened with annihilation, and who is pretty much of a realist.

ABOUT four months ago my wife and I were driving down Sunset Boulevard in Hollywood accompanied by our teen-age daughters, Diana and Pamela, and by our beautiful but feeble-minded springer spaniel, Moronica.

With the sole exception of copper sulphate, no agreements have been made concerning the manner in which the United States and Great Britain will divide world markets for exports of chemicals, it was made known yesterday by the Office of War Information.

Despite the currently tight situation in critical materials, the conviction is growing in business circles that by September a surplus of major materials will have developed and the production of some civilian items can be resumed, it was reported last week.

The Jewish Consumptives Relief Society is "keeping faith with 10,000,000 Americans on the fighting front" in maintaining its tuberculosis sanatorium at Denver, Newbold Morris, president of the City Council, declared last night at the opening session of the society's five-day convention.

ABOUT six years ago an erstwhile newsreel editor and producer of industrial shorts got a bright idea. The idea occurred simultaneously with the coronation of George VI of England. Gathering all the best newsreel records of that event the producer hastily compiled a ten-minute film on 16 and 8 mm. and in no time at all any householder with a projector could witness the pomp and circumstance at his own leisure in his own home.

In your editorial "The Meat Shortage" of March 29 you raise a number of very pertinent questions. A comparison between reported supplies and the number of points available to each consumer illustrates the need for more light.
