SMITHTOWN, L.I., April 3 -- Streams and ponds of the Wyandanch Club, rendezvous of many a hardy city angler, were well populated with fly casters early today when the trout fishing season opened.
Setting: A Chicago department store during the Christmas rush.

Lessons learned diving off city piers as a boy enabled James A. Goldner, Navy torpedoman, to return from the Pacific yesterday as a hero, wearing the Silver Star Medal, presented personally by Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., and bearing the stripes of a chief petty officer.

The Motor Wheel Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended on Dec. 31, last, a net profit of $1,126,894 after Federal income and excess profits taxes of $3,452,465, and a reserve of $450,000 for contingencies to care for post-war adjustments.

THE thirteenth annual Eastman School Festival of American Music will be held April 13-17, in Rochester, N.Y. The festival will consist of five evening performances and will be under the direction of Howard Hanson. In addition to Dr. Hanson the conductors will include Dr. Paul White, Frederick Fennell, Dr. Herman Genhardt, and as guest conductor, Roy Harris.

MELBOURNE. AS a bridge between its 1942 and 1943 series of Winter orchestral concerts in six State capitals, the Australian Broadcasting Commission presented in Sydney in February and March a Beethoven Summer festival of seven concerts conducted by Bernard Heinze.

In an open letter to Representative Andrew J. May, chairman of the House Military Affairs Committee, William D. Rawlins, executive secretary of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, protested yesterday in behalf of "thousands of building owners in New York City" against any legislation looking toward the unionization of foremen, building superintendents or executives in violation of "the principle that business management should not be divided against itself."

A COUPLE of old masters whom radio in recent months has heard chiefly as guest stars on sundry programs are now on the air with shows of their own, and the ether waves are a good deal more cheerful for it. The old masters are, of course, the Messrs.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Renegotiation of all outstanding war contracts when the war ends to reduce the profit on them to an unattractive level and purchase by private operators of all except a few of the $14,000,000,000 worth of war plants and facilities financed by the government were suggested today by W.L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board, as a means of disentangling government and private industry.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The dollar value of building construction started in urban areas of the United States in February was 73 per cent less than the total for February last year and marked the twelfth consecutive month of declining valuations, Secretary Perkins said today.

THE Jewish Music Forum, A.W. Binder, chairman, will hold a round-table conference on "The Bases of Jewish Music: Historical, Anthropological and Psychological," Monday night, April 12, at 8:30, at the Y.M.H.A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
Setting: A small village in the mountains of California.
LONDON, Sunday, April 4 -- Heavy bombers of the Royal Air Force were over Germany last night, British officials reported briefly early today.
ONE of the most popular of the apocryphal yarns now making the rounds of training camps concerns the worthless rookie who was called in and put on the carpet by his company commander.

Ever since the rejuvenation of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms its officers have been toying wistfully with the idea of institutional advertising. They felt that the place of auction markets in the economy of the nation was too little understood, that demagogic over-emphasis on the faults of the past, now largely corrected, had been allowed to obscure the positive advantages of low commissions and deals in the full light of day.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., April 3 -- Professor Charles Dillon Stengel was not feeling too happy. The professor was in one of the finest and most exclusive schools in the country, Choate, but his own private enrollment of students had sloughed off dreadfully. Casey never had to worry before about having his pupils graduate on him, but so many have advanced into the services that he is beginning to see great promise in Class D ball players.

OREGON, Ill., April 3 -- Frank O. Lowden, a former Governor of Illinois, bequeathed his large plantation holdings in Arkansas to the National Farm Foundation to aid tenant farmers. His will was filed today for probate in the Ogle County court house.

PANAMA, April 3 -- The extent of Latin America's contribution to the war effort in the way of raw materials is a matter of conjecture since statistics are not available, but they supplement our domestic supply sufficiently to make us independent of other sources.
Prisoners have been used in this country for medical experiments, to the best of our knowledge, only three times in the history of modern medicine.

The United States will not play Santa Claus to the entire world after the war, former Governor Herbert Lehman, now Director of the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, declared yesterday.

Greeted by Jack Frost and a lot of deuces -- 2,222 fans defied the weather -- the Dodgers came home to Ebbets Field yesterday and engaged the Red Sox in their initial interleague exhibition. So far as the outcome was concerned, it was no struggle.

Trading in cotton futures was somewhat stymied again yesterday by the President's veto of the Bankhead-Steagall bill. Much business has been suspended while traders await knowledge of prospects in Congress for overriding the veto, and dealings yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, were only routine.

AFTER the delight of Spring flowering bulbs and early perennials has passed and before Summer annuals are at their best, there is apt to be a period of scanty bloom in the garden unless Summer flowering bulbs have been planted.

IN the decades after the Civil War a small, dark Ulysses moved through the bare towns of the Middle West. His beginnings had the mark of the folk hero. Born to slavery, he had been kidnapped with his mother and traded back to her original owner, a kindly man, for a three-hundred-dollar race horse.

ABSOLUTE statements regarding the continuing fame of artists are tempting to their admirers, but ever dangerous. Time, the great refuter, is ever ready to invalidate an overenthusiastic contentions. Yet of William Keith it may with assurance be said that he holds a place in the annals of American art which no painter has held before him, and which none is likely ever again to hold.

IN the vast swirling activity which is a part of the great battle of transportation here, the center of interest is usually focused on Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station. Yet within the city limits is another station through which more than 600 trains carrying 200,000 passengers pass daily.

A NEW opportunity for the conservation of fruits and vegetables from the home garden has been offered lately in some Eastern States by the construction of commercial locker plants with service for storing and quickly freezing products brought in by individual customers.

WITH only the thinnest of clues to go by, Miss Mildred K. Marshall, executive director of information at the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, helped a 17-year-old soldier locate his mother one day last week.
NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (AP) -- A United States Air Forces communique:

AT 3:30 P.M. today, and for an hour thereafter, there will go winging across the country -- and later, by shortwave, around the world -- the program known as the Army Hour, which has been making this trip for just a year of Sundays.

PRE-EASTER travel in 1943 is similar in pattern to that in other years, according to travel agents recently consulted. The sweep is wide, stretching from the Virginias, Carolinas and Midsouth points to Mississippi and Louisiana.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 3 -- Protests by the Catholic hierarchy of Belgium against the Nazi authorities' actions, especially in shipping Belgians to forced labor in Germany, were contained in a bitterly worded pastoral letter signed by the Archbishop of Malines and the Bishops of Liege, Ghent, Bruges, Tournai and Namur, the text of which was learned here today.

FIJI -- pronounced somewhere between the "Feejee" of the early voyagers and the "Viti" of its own inhabitants -- has not yet come into the war news. If our luck -- and our lines -- in the Pacific hold, it is now likely that those fortunate islands will avoid that uncomfortable fame.

The Student Board of Columbia College, campus governing body, has voted itself out of existence for the duration of the war, drawing up a new constitution with provisions for an Emergency Council, it was announced yesterday.

College freshmen throughout the nation reveal a striking ignorance of even the most elementary aspects of United States history, and know almost nothing about many important phases of this country's growth and development, a survey just completed by THE NEW YORK TIMES has shown.

EIGHTEEN artists of the Metropolitan Opera and other singers of repute will appear in the Grand Opera Festival to be presented by the Essex County Symphony Society, Mrs. Parker O. Griffith, president, May 4-9, at the Mosque Theatre, Newark, N.J.

Baron Edouard de Rothschild of 1000 Park Avenue, president of the Central Consistory of Jews in France and Algeria, applied the epithets "erroneous and inaccurate" yesterday to statements of an unidentified "unbiased specialist" who was quoted by Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles recently in defending General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civilian Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, against criticisms made by the Baron in connection with religious discrimination in North Africa.

CROCUSES and other Spring flowers are now greeting visitors to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The grounds are open to the public from 8 A.M. to dusk weekdays and from 10 A.M. on Sundays and holidays. On Wednesday a course of ten weekly trips for the purpose of studying ornamental shrubs will begin at 11 A.M.

LONDON, March 1. IT'S like old times down at Denham this month, with the vanguard of the Kordas -- brother Vincent, the art director -- newly arrived from Hollywood, Sir Alexander himself expected home at any moment to make "War and Peace," with all sorts of stars who seem surprised by the advice, and Anna Neagle and Herbert Wilcox at work on their eighteenth joint venture.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Preliminary steps to form a national committee of State governments to plan for post-war rehabilitation were taken today by Governors and 150 other delegates from seventeen Middle Western States at the final session of the Mid-West Conference on Postwar Planning, sponsored by the Council of State Governments.

The American Communications Association and the United States Coast Guard have started a survey of communications on American sea-going vessels to determine what facilities are needed, if any, to increase safety at sea, it was announced yesterday by Harry Morgan, vice president of the association's marine department, a union of maritime radio officers.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- William M. Jeffers, rubber director, made it plain today that while he hoped to go back to railroading about July 1, he would stick right here until he knew the rubber program was a success. He added: "I'm not going to let anybody down."

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 (U.P.) -- India-based American fliers have made new strong attacks during the past three days on Japanese positions in Central Burma, concentrating their main blows on railway junctions and communications lines south of the vital supply center of Mandalay, a communique stated.

OTTAWA, April 3 -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's speech to the Canadian Parliament here on Thursday and that of United States Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles to the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York the same day have been interpreted here as complementary.
CAMP KILMER, N.J., April 3 (AP) -- The Army took over newspaper coverage of the Giants exhibition game with Jersey City of the International League today.

AUSTIN, Texas, April 3 -- Texas schools dominated the Texas relays more than at any time in the sixteen-year history of this track and field carnival today, partly because travel restrictions kept most traditional standbys at home. Texas and Texas A. and M. took two championships each, and the only out-of-State team to edge in with a title was Oklahoma A. and M.

Mayor La Guardia praised the high caliber of the photographs presented yesterday by 150 members of the Press Photographers Association at the official opening of the annual exhibition in the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

Thomas Kennedy, secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers of America, has tendered his resignation to President Roosevelt as one of the four labor members of the National War Labor Board, it was disclosed here yesterday at the headquarters of the miners in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The simple stories of twelve French sailors who spent twenty-five days in internment on Ellis Island because they want to fight the Germans but will do so under Giraudist officers were told by the men themselves yesterday in the office of Arthur Garfield Hays, their attorney, who arranged their release in bail of $500 each.

THIS book is subtitled "The Story of Bathhouse John and Hinky Dink." HIDING with Mexican bandits from the time he was 12 years old, when his parents were killed, Lefty Allen certainly got a bad start in life. At 19 he was thrown into jail because he couldn't prove he was not an outlaw, and sentenced to ten years in the Wyoming penitentiary.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Retail pharmacists, through the National Association of Retail Druggists, today came out into the open in active support of a proposed bill which would permit retailers to pool their buying without fear of prosecution under the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

QUARRY HEIGHTS, Canal Zone, April 1 (Delayed) -- The story of the American soldier in Panama begins at the end -- the end of the tourist trail. Beyond that point, the casual visitor may not pass -- where the public road breaks suddenly and, without explanation, disappears at the very threshold of the Panama jungle -- a watchful, listening jungle, with its thousands of eyes and ears.

LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The Axis took a blustery attitude toward the increased threats of an Allied invasion of Nazi-held Europe today, claiming adequate steps had been taken to protect the continent from attack.
TULSA, Okla., April 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Ella B. Howard was freed in $10,000 bond today to await trial on a manslaughter charge in the slaying of Mrs. T. Karl Simmons, wife of a wealthy oil man.

A NEW intimate supper club, to be known as The Blue Angel, is scheduled to join the roster of New York's nocturnal oases on April 14 under the auspices of Herbert Jacoby, one-time secretary to Leon Blum and for many years a staff member of Blum's paper, Le Populaire.

The Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association at 331 East Seventieth Street, which provides more than a thousand families with recreation facilities and opportunities for healthier living, has added a new wartime schedule to its list of activities.

RETAIL trade last week continued to slacken in comparison with activity in recent weeks, but particularly so in comparison with a year ago. The latter comparison, however, is distorted inasmuch as the 1942 week saw the brisk wind-up of Easter trade.

OIL AND NORTH AFRICA -- Oil from Palestine to drive the Allied war machine in North Africa may relieve the fuel crisis on the East Coast of the United States, says Ethyl News. Allied victory in Tunisia, it is pointed out, will reopen the Mediterranean, formerly the world's second most important sea route for oil traffic, and enable the United Nations to transport petroleum in tankers from Haifa to Algiers.

Kleinhaus, manager of the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Thomas Carey, began to think seriously about using the stage to further the work of the church.

Marking the thirty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the Boys Clubs of America, Boys Club Week will be observed tomorrow to April 12 with more than a quarter of a million members demonstrating the part they are playing in the war, it was announced yesterday.

Study of Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44 indicates that almost $9,000,000 of additional savings can be achieved, Walter Hoving, chairman of the Committee to Balance the Budget Through Sensible Economies, asserted yesterday.

THE most significant short-wave development of the year is the BBC's 25 per cent increased service to Europe, effective last week. Further added transmitters will talk toward the Continent "within the next few months" and "station power will be increased," reports London.

THE tragical disappearance from our musical life of Sergei Rachmaninoff, who died last week in his seventieth year, is a most poignant loss. The sentences are short, the vocabulary simple; nevertheless, Miriam Mason has written this tale of an independent cat, who set out in search of a home to her liking and found it, in a style which has genuine charm and is touched with humor.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- When the subject of reporting the forthcoming international food meeting arose at a recent White House press conference, the President, in answer to a question, said he "hoped" no newspaper correspondents would have access to the delegates. He smiled as he said it. But subsequent developments confirmed the apprehension of many of his hearers that the President expressed himself with complete candor.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- A nightmare period of problems connected with the distribution of meats, a period during which the Office of Price Administration and the Department of Agriculture tried to combat black-market and excessive consumer buying with wordy statements filled with pious hopes, came to an end last week.

ALGIERS, April 3 -- The average American infantryman is somewhat cockily overconfident when he approaches his first battle experience, pretty damned scared when he actually gets in the thick of things and slightly bewildered for a time, then sore as hell and anxious to do something effective to an enemy who is causing him all sorts of discomforts such as having to spend a good deal of time dodging in and out of slit trenches.

Many dinner parties will precede the concert to be given by the Pro Arte Quartet tonight at Town Hall for the benefit of Belgians in Britain. Among the prospective hostesses are Mrs. Benjamin P. Watson, Mrs. W. Hamilton Russell, Mrs. Garret A. Hobart 3d, Mrs. Raymond Torfs, Mrs. Edmond Tolkowsky and Mrs. Nicholas Boruchovitz.

The National Maritime Union's upgrading and sea safety school will be opened formally tomorrow evening in the union's headquarters, 346 West Seventeenth Street, by Rear Admiral Russell R. Waesche, commandant of the Coast Guard.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 3 -- The steady pitching of Roy Talcott and John Eide provided the Princeton baseball team with a 3-2 victory over Manhattan today in the opening game of the season for both nines. Because of cold weather, the contest was limited to seven innings.

Now Mr. Royal is a vice president of the National Broadcasting Company and some of the players whom he used to judge also have moved along in radio.

With only ten business days remaining before the State income tax deadline for filing returns, the New York City office of the State Tax Department at 80 Centre Street came to life yesterday. For a year affairs at the office had been quietly routine, with a few visits from taxpayers, who normally send their installment payments after the first one directly to the department's main bureau at Albany.

PERFORMANCES of current Broadway productions during the coming week have been taken over to raise funds for wartime enterprises and philanthropies. WASHINGTON, April 3 (U.P.) -- The United States will propose at a United Nations conference establishment of an international fund from which nations with meager foreign exchange can bolster their post-war monetary stability, authoritative government sources revealed tonight.

From the south the British Eighth Army, with its deadly train of 3,000 guns, pressed closer.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The battle against inflation reached its crisis this week. It was the unanimous opinion of those conducting anti-inflation warfare that what Congress does to farm prices within the next week or ten days will be decisive.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- In the first two months this year the Class 1 railroads of the United States had an estimated net income of $125,000,000 after interest and rentals, compared with slightly less than $50,000,000 in the same period last year, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, April 4 -- Blasting at Japanese warships in a devastating, pre-dawn raid, heavy Allied bombers Saturday blew up two enemy cruisers, left a large destroyer sinking and damaged two others near Kavieng, New Ireland, the High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- The Institute of Women's Professional Relations, seeking a better place for women in the post-war economic and business world, has arranged a conference of college representatives here Friday and Saturday. BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, April 5 -- Alleging the existence of an Anglo-American plot to kidnap members of the old French republican regime and set up an exiled government "designed to trouble the French people and spread confusion in France," the German Foreign Office, in an official communique issued early this morning, announced the removal to Germany of Edouard Daladier and Leon Blum, former French Premiers, and General Maurice Gustave Garnelin, former Allied commander in chief.

DAVISVILLE, R.I., April 4 -- Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said today in an address at the dedication of Camp Endicott, construction battalions (Seabees) training center here, that "nothing can be more arrogant than to assume we are on the way to quick victory."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 4 -- In the next to last dinghy fixture of the Spring series at the Larchmont Yacht Club, Jack Sutphen, with his craft Rum Dum, today won five of eight races and moved close to Arthur Knapp and his Popcorn in the battle for leadership in the third regatta series of the cold-weather sailing season.

Brown, National OPA Administrator, as the result of appeals by the OPA Enforcement Division, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, April 4 -- Accompanied by United States Ambassador John G. Winant, British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden returned to London tonight from his visit to the United States. He conferred immediately with Prime Minister Winston Churchill, then went to the Foreign Office to study documents that had accumulated during his three weeks' absence and to prepare an early report to Parliament regarding his journey to the United States and Canada.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 5 -- Allied heavy bombers attacked the enemy-held harbor at Kavieng, New Ireland, early Sunday for the third day in a row and scored direct hits with heavy bombs on three, and possibly four, vessels, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique stated.

Pearl Harbor is sufficient proof that Japan reveals her war plans only when she strikes. So the loud propaganda accompanying Premier Tojo's visit to Japanese-occupied China and the visit of Dr. Ba Maw, the Burmese puppet, to Tokyo, all calculated to create an idyllic picture of Japan quietly consolidating her conquests and preparing only to defend them, has a hollow ring.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 4 -- A sabotage wave sweeping German-occupied Europe has now reached the Reich itself. The big railroad bridge across the River Oder at Frankfort has been blown up, according to information received here through private channels from usually reliable sources.

The House to House parish campaign of the Catholic Charities begins this week, to continue for ten days. It is the culmination of the yearly appeal of this experienced and kind ministrant to multitudes of the distressed. Its needs are swollen with war. More than 500 of the doctors in its hospitals joined the armed forces last year.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 4 -- Whatever Pacific moves may be planned, or whatever increased air assistance may be given as a result of Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney and Major Gen. Richard K. Sutherland's visit to the United States, there seems little or no prospect of a definite counter-offensive on any large scale.

NAGPUR, Central Provinces, India, March 31 (Delayed) -- The pall of pessimism that hangs over the Indian political situation deepens as one gets nearer to the hear of Congress party influence, which is at Wardha, less than fifty miles from here.

MONTREAL, April 4 (Canadian Press) -- The annual financial statement of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company issued today reported that in 1942 bonds, notes and other obligations totaling $34,447,221 were retired without refunding.
Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler made public yesterday his annual report for 1942 as director of the Division of Intercourse and Education of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., April 4 -- When first discovered, Lefty Gomez was on the mound wheeling them in to the hitters in batting practice. That seemed normal enough. Then he disappeared and was found playing squash, right-handed, of all things. When next seen, he was on the basketball court, his back to the hoop and tossing in field goals-backward.
OTTAWA, April 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's Fourth Victory Loan, in which the minimum objective is $1,100,000,000, will be offered in two maturities, Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley announced tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 4 -- The German military commentators voice the unanimous opinion that the Winter offensive on the Eastern front has come to a definite end and that the strategic advantage for the coming Spring and Summer months is now on the side of the Axis.
The bulk of realty transactions in Manhattan reported over the week-end involved sales of parcels held by savings banks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 4 -- The nineteenth biennial convention of the Catholic Daughters of America in New Jersey criticized at the closing session here today the "glamourizing" of war industry to the extent of attracting mothers with school-age children.
Your editorial "A 'New' World Currency" is excellent. You clearly show that countries, the same as individual citizens, have to have an incentive to build themselves up.

Two hundred and fifty members of the Mutuel Ticket Agents Union, Local 23293, A.F. of L., voted yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Forrest, 229 West Forty-ninth Street, that if the management of the Jamaica race track failed to acknowledge the union's request for recognition as a bargaining agent they would strike on Wednesday, the day before the track is due to open.
LONDON, April 4 (UP) -- A later joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 4 -- Declaring that college professors of American history have been vainly trying to get a hearing on the matter for years, the Rev. Joseph U. Bergkamp, Professor of American History at Providence College and chairman of its department of history, "heartily endorsed" both THE NEW YORK TIMES statement of last June and the "survey of ignorance" presented in today's TIMES.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Hugh Russell Fraser, an official of the United States Office of Education and chairman of the Committee on American History, commenting on THE NEW YORK TIMES survey of the retention of American history by college freshmen, said that "social studies extremists" were responsible for "the present appalling neglect of American history in the high schools and elementary schools of the nation."

The Associated Hospital Service of New York, in its financial statement for 1942 filed with the State Department of Insurance, showed at the year-end total assets of $10,120,944, including $8,299,091 United States bonds. Cash amounted to $1,564,011.

The Hispanos won the championship of the American Soccer League by defeating the Philadelphia Americans, 2 -- 1, at Brooklyn Oval yesterday before a crowd of 3,500. Brookhattan downed the Wanderers by 4 -- 0 in the opener of the double-header.

DETROIT, April 4 -- The Red Wings flashed back in the third period and blasted three goals past Frankie Brimsek to beat Boston, 4 -- 3, tonight and gain their second straight victory in the final series for the Stanley Cup.

The Red Cross Show at Madison Square Garden tonight, in which seventy-five stars of the stage, screen and radio and a supporting cast of 1,000 will appear, promises to be a complete sell-out and will realize $275,000 for the 1943 Red Cross War Fund, according to its co-chairmen, Robert M. Weitman and Ed Sullivan, who said yesterday that this sum would break all records for a single theatrical performance.

Criticizing as "cold and cruel" the government's present procedure of admitting refugees, Representative Emanuel Celler told 250 Jewish War Veterans yesterday at the eighth annual convention of their New York County Council, at the Hotel Astor, that America, must take a more active role in aiding the oppressed people of Europe.

Results of the nation-wide survey revealing deplorable ignorance on the part of college freshmen of basic fundamentals of United States history provoked widespread comment yesterday, not only in educational quarters but in official circles at Washington.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4 -- A mountain-to-Mohammed experiment, designed to reduce absenteeism and otherwise aid employe morale is being conducted jointly by the L. Bamberger department store here and the aeronautical division of the Otis Elevator Company by the establishment of a shopping center in the division's plant in near-by Harrison where there are 500 women employes.

Despite the prevalence of job opportunities, as the academic year draws to a close, most high-school and junior-college girls are continuing their studies with post-war rather than emergency work in mind, a survey of schools in the metropolitan area revealed yesterday.

An appeal for 550 volunteers to serve as Red Cross Gray Ladies in six city hospitals was made yesterday by Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, at the request of city officials. The Gray Ladies are the gray-uniformed volunteers of the chapter's hospital and recreation service, enrolled and trained by the Red Cross.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 4 -- An eighth-inning intracamp game that drew a crowd of about 3,000 sent the Giants off to their final week of training here today. Mel Ott's regulars wound up on the short end of the score as the Gould jayvees tripped the Rockefellers, 5 to 3.

Early ordering of Fall apparel increased last week, as buyers, fearful of serious shortages later, took all offerings for delivery when ready, despite inventory regulations, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Jewish farmers in the United States have joined with their fellow-Americans in gearing their activities to war demands, Dr. Gabriel Davidson, managing director of the Jewish Agricultural Society, declares in the annual report of the organization, just made public.

If all clothing were to be rationed the average American woman would be more sensibly and more tastefully dressed than she is now, according to Mrs. Mabel Goode Bowers, director of the clothing division of the New York University School of Education home economics department.

Charity must be given out of love, not out of obligation, and the giver must not question the worthiness of the cause to which he gives, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen of the Catholic University of America, Washington, declared yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 4 -- French Moroccan goumiers, supported by units of General Henri Honore Giraud's African Free Corps, brought to a climax their quiet offensive of the past few days in Northern Tunisia by the occupation of Cap Serrat on the Mediterranean, thirty-five miles west of Bizerte, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The United States literally doubled the tempo of its air offensive against Kiska Friday when eight raids were pressed home against the Aleutian base, twice as many as have been staged on any one day since the Japanese occupied the strategic island ten months ago.

Teachers of American history in undergraduate colleges reported in general yesterday that the results of THE TIMES'S survey of college freshmen's knowledge of their subject coincided with their experience, but were divided in their explanations of the situation. Their comments follow:

Additional bank condition statements for March 31 show a lack of uniformity in changes for the past quarter in the principal items. Holdings of government securities were higher, as a rule, but cash, deposits, loans and discounts and resources were mostly lower.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- A complaint charging Procter Gamble Company of Cincinnati with misrepresentation of Teel, its liquid dentifrice, and with disparagement of tooth pastes and powders sold by competitors has been issued, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.
LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique, as broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

At the annual convention of the Greater New York Safety Council emphasis was put on the prevention of industrial, home and traffic accidents. Good organizational progress has been made by the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, which is operating through the National Safety Council.

The Pro Arte Quartet of the University of Wisconsin, formerly of Belgium, gave a concert last night in Town Hall for the benefit of Belgians in Britain. The members of the quartet are Antonio Brosa, first violin; Laurent Halleux, second violin; Germain Prevost, viola, and George Sopkin, 'cello.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, April 4 (AP) -- Calvin Leon Graham, seaman first class, is going back to the seventh grade.

Dr. George D. Stoddard, New York State Commissioner of Education, will be the main speaker at the Thomas Jefferson bi-centennial celebration to be held at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, the evening of April 13. Dr. Stoddard will announce the final winners and present the grand prizes in the Thomas Jefferson essay contest, which THE NEW YORK TIMES has been conducting in city schools since Feb. 1.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 4 (U.P.) -- Extending their advance north of Djebel Abiod to twenty miles, French Moroccan goumiers, supported by the British First Army, broke through to the coast at Cap Serrat yesterday, it was announced, and secured the end of the Allied line thirty-five miles west of Bizerte.

Declaring that "even amid the blackness of war, the light and love of charity must shine," Archbishop Francis J. Spellman yesterday opened the 1943 Appeal of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York in a broadcast from London heard here over WEAF.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Dry surface conditions in parts of the Southwest increased last week as the result of high winds and higher temperatures. There were some reports of dust storms in South Central and Southwestern Kansas, which composes the bulk of the area in that State where moisture is needed.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, March 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- Ten months and twelve hours after setting out on a Rabaul bombing mission that ended in a crash off Japanese-held New Britain, three young American airmen were brought back to a United States base recently.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4 -- An appeal to labor and liberal forces in New Jersey to organize for the 1944 Presidential election and become the balance of political power in that State was made tonight by Dean Alfange, American Labor party candidate for Governor of New York at the last election.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, April 5 -- In his address to workers at Lom on the Danube today, the Bulgarian Minister of Public Works, Dmitri Vassileff, gave the first official inkling of his government's new attitude following the meeting Wednesday of Adolf Hitler and King Boris III.

LONDON, April 4 -- Although opportunities in London to participate in Wall Street's buoyancy are extremely limited, there is developing something more than an academic interest in the strong upward trend of the American market.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Wage Adjustment Board for the Building and Construction Industry, headed by Daniel J. Tracy, Assistant Secretary of Labor, is awarding wage increases in some cases above the 15 per cent "Little Steel" formula and the War Labor Board has been approving such increases since early this year.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Cost of Living Committee of the C.I.O. expressed today "grave concern for the future effectiveness of the OPA" and urged that final control over farm and food prices be retained by Stabilization Director James F. Byrnes.
LONDON, Monday, April 5 (UP) -- The Sunday midnight communique as broadcast by Moscow:

Reflecting the uncertainty that has been prevalent over the ultimate fate of pending agricultural legislation, the cotton futures market last week underwent comparatively minor day-to-day price changes under dull trading and ended the period unchanged to 9 points higher than the preceding week.

Despite the fact that there were only four Sundays last month as against five in March, 1942, advertising linage of eight New York newspapers registered a gain of 5.1 per cent over 1942, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures.
Negotiations for new wage agreements in the bituminous and anthracite coal fields will be resumed here this morning between the United Mine Workers and the operators.

With Harvard and Yale out of the annual competition because of curtailment of their sports activities, the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League's 1943 race will start April 16. A twenty-game schedule has been arranged for the five members which will be represented this season, namely Princeton, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth and Pennsylvania.

D.W. BROGAN is a Scottish Professor of Political Science at Cambridge University, an authority on American history, a brilliant and spectacular artist on the literary trapeze. The arcs of his epigrams, the breathless parabolas of his paradoxes and the daring flights of his wit should command admiring applause even from those who are frankly bewildered by his bravura performance.

By the Constitution each house of Congress "shall keep a journal of its proceedings." The Senate and House Journals fulfill this requirement. They include all motions, action taken, votes on roll-call or divisions, but no speeches. The Congressional Record, established in 1873, is the fourth of the series of publications that have issued the debates of Congress.

Janet Bush, mezzo-soprano from Montclair, N.J., was heard in her second recital of the season yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The first half of the carefully contrived program contained arias by Purcell and Handel; a practically unknown song by Dr. Arne, "Too Late for Redress"; four of the sacred songs from the Gellert set of Beethoven, and the Dvorak "Gypsy Songs."

LONDON, April 4 -- Plans for speedy and effective relief for Jews threatened with extinction by the Germans were submitted today at an Anglo-Jewish religious conference held in London under the auspices of the Joint Foreign Committee of the Board of Deputies of British Jews.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 4 -- With considerable ingenuity Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel has succeeded in establishing the wholesale manufacture of mines in Tunisian shops, where the defensive weapons are turned out by the thousands from materials -- mainly explosives -- shipped to North Africa from Italy.

LONDON, April 4 -- Captured by the Germans while attending Belgian refugees in May, 1940, when the Germans overran the Low Countries, Mary Booth, a colonel in the Salvation Army and granddaughter of General William Booth, its founder, returned to London last night with three other Salvation Army officers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- Sergeant Albert A. Schmid of the Marine Corps, who killed 200 Japanese soldiers on Guadalcanal Island before suffering wounds that impaired his sight, and Ruth Hartley, the girl he left behind, were married quietly in a magistrate's office on Friday, it became known today.

PORTLAND, Ore., April 4 -- Henry J. Kaiser's Oregon Shipbuilding Corporation became today the first ship fabricator in the country to receive the Maritime Commission's Golden Eagle Merit Award, emblematic of "unprecedented performance" in the shipbuilding industry.

When United Nations bombing planes go over Paris, Bremen or Berlin, civilians are killed. A Stockholm dispatch estimated 2,000 dead and 30,000 homeless in the Berlin raid of March 1. The attack on the night of March 27-28 may have been even more deadly. We can confidently say that there are some things Nazi fliers have done that ours will never do.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- President Roosevelt's veto of the Bankhead-Steagall bill last week was not a surprise to the grain trade and had relatively little effect as a price-making influence in wheat and other grains except for a brief period.

An hour and a half after Engine Company 255 had extinguished a small yet smoky rubbish blaze in the basement of an apartment house at 2610 Glenwood Road, Brooklyn, yesterday evening four of its members were rushed in ambulances to Kings County Hospital for treatment of smoke poisoning and a fifth was sent home after receiving treatment at the fire house, 1369 Rogers Avenue.

LONDON, Monday, April 5 -- American Flying Fortresses in large force pounded and blasted the Renault works at Billancourt, outside Paris, by daylight yesterday, after heavy British bombers Saturday night, renewing the large-scale assaults on Essen in the Ruhr, unloaded more than 900 tons of high explosives on and near the great Krupp plant there.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (U.P.) -- Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat of Oklahoma, said tonight in an interview that the establishment of a world bank founded on a standard international coin was inevitable after the war, but that no nation dared make positive commitments now on post-war monetary stabilization because the economic future was too uncertain.

NEW ORLEANS, April 4 -- Week-end long liquidation, mainly induced by the President's veto of the Bankhead-Steagall bill and growing doubt that the Pace parity-raising bill can come out of the Senate Agricultural Committee until the current wage controversies are out of the way, almost wiped out gains of around 50 cents a bale earlier in the week in cotton futures here.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The National War Labor Board today refused a general wage increase to 1,000 employes of the printing press manufacturing division of the R. Hoe Company, Inc., plant in New York. The board said that hourly earnings of these employes are already higher than the prevailing rate for similar work in the metropolitan area.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 5 (AP) -- In addition to the clean-up raid on the enemy ships at Eavieng, Allied bombers carried out widespread raids in the northeastern sector.

LONDON, April 4 -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain spoke out for the first time today against the Americans by name, linking them with the British as perpetrators of "unjustifiable" bombing raids on France, and asserted that he was giving France an authoritative regime that was the wisest and met the common sense of the masses.

Alicia Markova in "Giselle" is the miracle that never fails. In the Ballet Theatre's first performance this season of that foolish old masterpiece last night at the Metropolitan Opera House the story of the betrayed peasant maid who is doomed to dance as a wraith throughout eternity assumed once again the reality of romantic tragedy, unlikely though that may seem.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., April 4 (AP) -- Young Dick Wakefield lost an easy fly in the sun for a three-run homer in the fifth inning, enabling the Cubs to rally and defeat the Tigers, 7 to 5, in an exhibition game today.

The Atlantic, Gulf West Indies Steamship Lines reported yesterday for 1942 a consolidated net income of $3,630,530 after charges, taxes and provisions for contingencies of $776,000, equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $22 each on the 150,000 shares of common stock outstanding.
Fifteen thousand women are on active duty in the Women's Reserves of the Navy, Coast Guard and Marines, Third Naval District Headquarters announced yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, April 4 (U.P.) -- Military experts here said today that all Japanese attacks in the last month, especially those in the last week, had indicated Japanese attempts to forestall the use of China by American forces as a base for attacks on Japan.

Warning that discussion of the coming peace by two or three nations is not only insufficient but constitutes "a grave peril" and "the most dangerous delay in history," the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, retired bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, urged yesterday immediate action by the United States in convening United Nations' representatives now to set up the essentials of the peace.

An underwriting group headed by A.G. Becker Co., Inc., will offer today 40,000 shares of the Heyden Chemical Corporation's 4 per cent cumulative preferred stock, Series A, $100 par value, at $100 a share. Other members of the banking group are Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, Hornblower Weeks and Ladenburg, Thalmann Co.
The Sunday German communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

In a report in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the Pan-European Conference organized by Count R. Coudennove-Kalergi, one of the participants, Radu Irimescu, is described as former Rumanian Minister to the United States. This description inevitably conveys the impression that Mr. Irimescu has expressed the opinions of the Rumanian people concerning the future European organization.

ALBANY, April 4 -- The Wilson bill providing for the licensing and regulation of bingo games, passed by the Legislature and still pending before Governor Dewey, has become one of the most controversial of the remaining thirty-day bills.

Mayor La Guardia challenged critics of his executive budget for 1943-44 yesterday to examine it "line by line" and to point out to him just how its total of $753,071,123 could be reduced "without danger or injustice."

The five-story building containing five stores and twenty-four apartments at 268 East 181st Street, southwest corner of Valentine Avenue, in the Bronx, was sold by the Donner Realty Corporation to a client of M.J. Goldston. Occupying a plot 54 by 100 feet, the building was sold subject to a first mortgage of $40,750.

In last week's early markets the advance continued. On Thursday the average for stocks reached the highest level since July, 1941, and for bonds the highest since July, 1937. Then the market became irregular. It was a week of unbroken five-hour million-share days.

Arturo Toscanini returned to the podium of the NBC Symphony Orchestra late yesterday afternoon in Radio City after an absence of eight weeks. The works he presented constituted what ordinarily would be called a "popular" program. But every composition of the nine performed was transfigured by such phenomenal treatment, that despite the general lightness of the fare, the concert turned out to be one of the major events of the current musical season.

LONDON, April 4 (AP) -- The five French leaders imprisoned in Germany are among those on whom Reichsfuehrer Hitler -- through the Riom trial, administered through Vichy -- had tried to pin the blame for the outbreak of the war. The Riom trial failed in that objective.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 4 -- Four New York State boys of a group specially trained for low-level "skip-bombing" took part in a daring Mitchell attack on an Axis convoy off Northern Tunisia four days ago.

The National Association of Manufacturers, through its board of directors, voiced opposition yesterday to the drafting of labor as a solution of war industry's manpower problem and offered an alternative program designed to achieve the objective through voluntary cooperation of management, labor and government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -Paramount has opened negotiations with David O. Selznick for the loan of Joan Fontaine to play the title role in Henry Bellamann's new novel "Victoria Grandolet," to be produced by David Lewis. The company bought the story from galley proofs last week after Warners had announced its purchase as a possible starring vehicle for Ann Sheridan. Miss Fontaine is set for Paramount's "Frenchman's Creek."

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that he would appoint this week a committee to work out a plan of public health and medical insurance for persons and families of average means. It was indicated that the committee would be named on Wednesday and would consist of prominent citizens and representatives of the city, employer and employe groups and medical and health organizations.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., April 4 -- Persons in sedentary occupations and those with organic ailments were warned today not to overexert themselves in Victory gardening. Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester County medical examiner, issued the warning after a Bronx man had died of a heart attack while digging in a garden here.
Leases of several large penthouse apartments in buildings on the East Side were among the latest rentals reported over the week-end in Manhattan.

For the first time since Sept. 4, 1942, the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices declined. The drop last week from 112.2 to 111.7 was the result of declines in both the foodstuffs and the farm products indexes.
Labor is soon to have its counterpart of "This Is the Army," a full-length revue to be known as "Roll Up Your Sleeves," which will tour the war production centers of the country.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- The line established by the Red Army as the result of the Winter campaign should be considered as the starting line from which the enemy should be driven westward, said Izvestia, the government newspaper, editorially this morning.

" By Jupiter" resumes its run at the Shubert this evening, Ray Bolger having recovered from the illness which caused suspension of performances since last Tuesday. Ronald Graham who also has been ill, likewise will be back in the cast tonight.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 4 (U.P.) -- A communique:
Appended is a comment clipped from The Baltimore Sun which I believe will interest THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The missions represent the strongest link between China and the United States, Bishop James E. Walsh, superior general of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, declared yesterday at the annual communion breakfast of the Catholic Young Women's Club in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 4 (AP) -- Governor Chauncey Sparks of Alabama declared today that "absolute segregation" and "independent development" should govern the conduct of the white and Negro races in the South.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- Representative Ditter of Pennsylvania said today that the Democratic majority in the House used "straight out politics" to beat the Carlson-Ruml income-tax proposal, and that Democratic members of the Ways and Means Committee had no plan except to oppose."

Some of the opening day anglers in Putnam and Westchester Counties were almost inclined to believe that they were frost fishing, judging from the way they felt after being in the streams for a few minutes.

Canada is playing an increasingly important part in producing combat as well as training planes for the United Nations. Aviation Magazine reports that a production of 400 planes a month has been reached in the Dominion, compared with an output of forty planes in the course of a whole year before the war.

While the OPA legal division sought to stabilize the shaky point-ration front, the Treasury Department's drive against ration coupon counterfeiters resulted in its first arrest after a two-mile automobile chase through the streets of Yonkers yesterday afternoon.

Yesterday two reports appeared in rather embarrassing juxtaposition in this newspaper. One was an account of the latest of many plans for the reeducation of Germany. The other was a survey of American education in the field of United States history.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 4 -- Civilians went aloft for the first time today in one of the Army's new troop-transport gliders when a group of newspaper and radio men took off from Stout Field, headquarters of the First Troop Carrier Command.

The Union of American Hebrew Congregations ended its three-day convention yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker with the adoption of a resolution calling upon President Roosevelt and the State Department to use their influence to "correct'' the pronouncement by General Henri Honore Giraud, "which deprives the Jews of Algiers of the citizenship rights guaranteed them by the Cremieux Law of 1870."

A sparkling performance by Alfred Snyder, one-armed fencer, featured the metropolitan and non-divisional trials for the men's national individual open foils championship at the Salle Santelli yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, today expressed concern over "a notion getting about that there is no longer need for conserving rubber."

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES in Tunisia, April 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- General Saleh Oumertak, chief of the Turkish delegation touring Allied bases in the Mediterranean area, predicted today that the Allies would win the war.

Additional social and health facilities rather than increased police protection were recommended yesterday by Mrs. David M. Levy, a director of the Community Service Society, as "one basic solution to the alleged crime wave in Harlem."
Commencement exercises of the Fordham University School of Business and the Fordham Evening College were held yesterday afternoon in Collins Auditorium on the campus in the Bronx.

Christians the world over cannot help hoping for some reorganization of the world that would maintain order, administer justice among nations and foster mutual services through trade and the exchange of the more precious goods of the mind and soul, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday in a sermon in James Memorial Chapel.

The late afternoon audience at the recital by Robert Kitain, violinist, in Carnegie Hall yesterday, heard some unusually fine violin playing, and some great music. The recital opened with a first performance in this country, according to the program, of Evaristo Felice dall'Abaco's sonata Ops. 1, No. 5, arranged by Alexandroff.

At 11:30 in the morning a certain Lexington Avenue bakery becomes a beehive of activity, for it is then customers congregate, knowing rich pastries are about to emerge from the oven. A portly gentleman inquires about the dobos torte he has ordered, a middle-aged woman selects petit fours for tea, and a young mother pacifies her fretful youngster with a promise of French macaroons for supper.

Unlike the day before, the weather at Ebbets Field yesterday was bearable but the same cannot be said of he Dodgers. They had runners on the basepaths in every inning, stranded ten of them, bounced into three double plays, committed four errors and in the end submitted to a 5 -- 0 white-washing by the Red Sox.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The remarkable vagueness of American college freshmen on American history disclosed in a NEW YORK TIMES survey published this morning will probably be the subject of Senate discussion this week.

Nearly 2,000 children in Catholic institutions or boarding homes in the New York Archdiocese will be permitted to work on farms as a result of recent legislation lowering the minimum age for child labor to 14 years, it was announced yesterday by the New York Catholic Charities.

The defeat of the Ruml plan and, still more, the burying of tax reform with the recommitting of the Administration bill, emphasizes again the now obvious fact that politics has not been put aside for the duration, at least not by the New Deal.
Five new films will arrive on Broadway this week. The schedule follows:

To advance the musical education work at the Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, a concert will be given on the evening of April 13 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Sloane, 48 East Ninety-second Street. The musicale is under the auspices of the Women's Auxiliary of the settlement, represented by a special benefit committee under the chairmanship of Mrs. Albert Stoessel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -- Madame Chiang Kai-shek, given the tumultuous accolade of 30,000 persons in Hollywood Bowl today, made the last scheduled talk of her United States tour, pledging that China would do its part toward attaining the four freedoms for the world -- a world, she said, which would never forget President Roosevelt for his leadership in making America the arsenal of the democracies.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 1 (Delayed) -- What is said by its tough but soft-spoken commanding general to be the only air training center of the world's armies that is actually situated in a zone of military operations is now functioning here and graduating pilots, gunners and navigators virtually every week to front-line service.

STOCKHOLM, April 4 (AP) -- Premier Per Albin Hansson of Sweden in a speech today at Falun noted an increased "irritation" among Swedes over the German transit traffic of goods and soldiers on leave from Norway, but termed this concession to Germany "one of the burdens" his country must bear to keep out of war.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Prices of May oats on the Board of Trade and of actual grain in the cash market went last week to the highest levels since 1928 on reports that navigation of the Great Lakes might not open until late this month. This prospective delay of a large import movement of that grain, as well as of barley influenced sentiment.
Erasing a 2 -- 1 lead established by the New York Americans in the first period, the Kearny Scots won the American Soccer League fixture at Starlight Park yesterday by a score of 3 -- 2.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 4 -- The puzzling feature of the present air warfare in the Southwest Pacific is the failure of the Japanese to exploit their air strength more than they have. Recent photographic reconnaissance of the Rabaul area showed more than 250 enemy planes at the La- kunai, Vanukanau and Rapopo airdromes.

The Metropolitan Opera Association has announced that it will give six performances here and one of "Parsifal" in Philadelphia on its return from its three-week tour in Chicago, Cleveland and, for one performance, Rochester.

SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., April 4 (AP) -- A war bond advertisement caricaturing a dachshund with Hitler's face so enraged John Anson, a 6-year-old dachshund fancier, that he wrote to Secretary Morgenthau saying that "you ought to be ashamed of yourself."

NEWARK, N.J., April 4 -- It was warmer today at Ruppert Stadium and, with Joe Gordon and Charley Keller lending their moral support in the first game of the year for both, the Yankees were hotter. It was an easy matter, therefore, for the major leaguers to trounce the Newark Bears in their second Spring skirmish.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- A tight situation has developed in cash corn and with a deadlock in the futures market, all deliveries holding at the ceiling level bid, millions of bushels of grain stored in elevators cannot be sold because of the inability of warehouse men to remove hedges on the exchanges.

MANHASSET, L.I., April 4 -- Francis T. Ward of the Wall Street brokerage firm of Clark, Dodge Co. and his wife narrowly escaped injury at 1:40 o'clock this morning wehn flames, of unknown origin, swept up the staircase of their frame dwelling in the Shelter Rock Road colony, here, trapping them in their bedroom.
WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, in Tunisia, April 4 (Reuter) -- During his visit to Gabes, General Giraud made this statement:

Vice President Henry A. Wallace seems to have fallen into an error common to many who view life idealistically, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and West Twenty-ninth Street, asserted yesterday morning in his sermon on "Confidence in the Brighter Tomorrow."
LONDON April 4 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

It is the world's custom to think of college professors as mild men. But the war has upset everything. Dr. C.E. Joad, a professor at the University of London and an author and philosopher as well, has asserted in a moment of daring that monogamy is "unsatisfactory" and that because this is so Britain should alter its marriage laws to allow a man to take a number of wives.

An investor represented by Goldstein Goldstein, attorneys, purchased the four-story apartment house for sixteen families at 1319 East New York Avenue, corner of Lincoln Place, in Brooklyn. Louis W. Alpher and H.J. Sachs Co. were the brokers in the deal, in which the seller took back a purchase money mortgage for ten years at 4 1/2 per cent.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 4 (AP) -- The Athletics landed on the veteran Si Johnson for five runs in the third inning today and defeated the Phillies, 5 to 3, in the first exhibition game of the season for both teams.

LONDON, April 4 -- The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on 1927 as 100, was 114.2 on March 23. This compared with 113.5 a fortnight before, 113.4 a month before, 110.3 a year ago and 70.3 at the end of August, 1939.

LONDON, April 4 -- When Gestapo agents found the underground press of Glos Poiski [the Voice of Poland], W.K. Werner, a Czechoslovak printer, said today, the detachment flung hand grenades into windows and shot every one in near-by houses -- men, women and children -- eighty-three of them.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- Colonel Svoboda's Czechoslovak unit, which recently had its baptism of fire on the Soviet-German front, is composed of men from all parts of Czechoslovakia -- Czechs, Slovaks and sub-Carpathian Ruthenians, most of whom had escaped through the Carpathian Mountains since the Germans occupied Prague.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 5 (AP) -- The noon communique:

READING, Pa., April 4 (AP) -- Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, declared tonight there was no reason to fear Soviet Russia, asserted there was no plan to build buffer states against her, and called for post-war cooperation with the Soviets.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Black-market operations in meat have grown to such an extent that even the Army has experienced difficulty in obtaining adequate supplies, the Office of War Information said today in an analysis which indicated that such illegal trading had become far more widespread than has been reported.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the National War Fund, announced last night the names of officers and directors of this recently created organization, which will conduct coordinated campaigns for funds this year for all approved war-related appeals, except the American Red Cross.
Here is the text of the broadcast speech delivered today by Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, as reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE in England, April 4 (AP) -- American fliers viewed Paris from Flying Fortresses for the first time today and came back after bombing the Renault works to describe the scene as "beautiful" and "wonderful."
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Treasury officials tonight were completing plans for the second war loan drive, starting a week from tomorrow, in which the government will borrow at least $13,000,000,000.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Stocks of lard in cold storage here showed less than a normal seasonal increase during the past week, a gain of 1,390,000 pounds as compared with a month ago being due entirely to a gain in pork rendered fat, the supply of prime steam lard showing a small reduction.

LONDON, Monday, April 5 -- Germany, in a strong but futile bid to crack the Russian Donets River line, has lost more than 1,000 men killed, nine tanks knocked out, thirty infantry trucks destroyed and seven planes downed in a day of heavy fighting south of Izyum, Russia's midnight communique said early today.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Jewish leadership of Chicago today turned first to solemn recitation of the Kaddish, or memorial prayer, for 2,000,000 massacred Jews of Europe and then to the shaping of programs designed to save the 5,000,000 living Jews from the Nazi threat of extermination.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- To twenty-seven additional industrial plants and three construction projects has been granted the Army-Navy production award for excellence in performance of war work, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 4 (AP) -- Fewer than 100 men, working in stormy seas and menaced by explosives and falling wreckage, cleared a path into Tripoli Harbor so that it could be used by the British six days after its capture, although the Germans had sunk seven ships across the channel, authorities said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 4 -- "Mum" Sullivan broke a bottle of champagne on the bow of a destroyer today, but it was really her tears which christened the ship, named The Sullivans in honor of her five sons dead in battle.

PITTSBURGH, April 4 -- The volume of steel orders reaching the mills last week continued to show a decline over the early part of March. This situation bore no particular significance, however, since new bookings in the aggregate were still in excess of actual shipments.

Only a policy of closer cooperation of the United States and Great Britain with China and Russia will win the war and insure a proper and lasting peace, speakers declared last night at a meeting under the auspices of the Committee of Jewish Writers and Artists in Carnegie Hall.

Even more exhilarating than the effect of a saucy new bonnet -- and everyone knows what a bit of millinery can do for a woman's "morale" -- is the pleasure of putting on a new complexion. Especially if you have a dreary-looking skin that you'd like to pack away in moth balls with your Winter woolens.

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Prices of wheat held within relatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade today as traders awaited further action by Congress on the Bankhead bill, vetoed last week by the President. There was no material pressure.

The Austin-Wadsworth bill, which would give the Government power during the war to draft manpower to meet critical labor shortages, has had hard sledding since a committee of the Senate began hearings on it several weeks ago. Organized labor, both C.I.O. and A.F.L., is against it.

Warner Brothers will make a film of the play, "Pillars of Society," by Henrik Ibsen and have assigned Julius J. and Philip G. Epstein to prepare the script and produce the picture. Among other Ibsen works to reach the American screen are "Peer Gynt," which was released in 1915; and "A Doll's House," which first appeared in 1918 and later, in 1921 with Alla Nazimova.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 31, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Decreases of $697,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $248,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $280,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, $551,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and $205,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Signs appeared, today that the almost solid front in the Senate which last month passed the Bankhead bill to forbid the deduction of farmer benefits in the setting of ceiling prices on agricultural products was cracking under the impact of President Roosevelt's veto.

Frank Lambertus, 20 years old, of 31 Varick Street, Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday in Queens Court of Special Sessions to a charge of petit larceny, admitting that he stole $19 from a blind storekeeper on March 28. Lambertus was remanded to Queens City, Prison pending investigation and sentence.

Indicating the increased rate of production achieved by the Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, LeRoy R. Grumman, president, disclosed in the annual report to stockholders, released today, that more planes were delivered in the last two weeks of November, 1942, than in the entire year of 1940.
Supported only by routine price-fixing for Southern mills, the cotton futures market fluctuated narrowly yesterday and closed with net gains of 1 to 6 points over Saturday's final quotations.

The role women must take in planning the postwar world will be discussed by twelve women distinguished in as many fields who comprise the speakers' list for the national women's conference than will be held Wednesday under the sponsorship of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Barbara Custance, Canadian pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Miss Custance, a pupil of Sigismund Stojowski, played a program ranging from Bach through Chopin to Paderewski. The opening group consisted of the Bach-Siloti organ prelude in G minor, three sonatas by Scarlatti, six variations, Opus 34, and two country dances by Beethoven.

Walter Curran, 33-year-old employe of the Department of Sanitation in Staten Island, was arrested yesterday on charges of homicide and leaving the scene of an accident, after an investigation of the death in Brooklyn last Thursday of Mrs. Tillie Schwartz and her daughter, Mrs. Minerva Le Blang.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Following is the text of the statement on international stabilization of currencies which Secretary Morgenthau presented today to Senate committees:

Net earnings of Reo Motors, Inc., in 1942 amounted to $1,389,378, subject to contract renegotiation, it was announced at Lansing, Mich., yesterday by H.E. Hund, president and general manager. This was equal to $2.99 a share on 465,000 capital shares, comparing with $433,968, or 93 cents a share, in 1941.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 5 -- The heavy hand of war again reached into the ranks of the Giants today. Manager Mel Ott, whose first-string catcher, Harry Danning, is slated for military induction on the West Coast tomorrow, revealed that three more of his players had been called for preliminary examinations tomorrow.

Six matches were listed yesterday in the opening round of the squash racquets handicap tournament at the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. There were fifty-one entries in the tourney, held for the benefit of the Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Congress received from Secretary Hull today a declaration that continued authority for the Administration to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements was of paramount importance in prosecuting the war and framing the peace.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- The national Football League requested delegates to its Spring meeting to park their long faces outside the door tonight as they checked in for the three-day parley which opens tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, April 5 -- Poetry apparently succeeded where pleas failed for William Scheid, father of four children, who had been turned down by more than 200 landlords in his efforts to rent living quarters.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Max Stephan, Detroit restaurant owner sentenced to hang for treason, lost today his bid for a Supreme Court review of his conviction of shielding a German who fled from a Canadian prison camp.

All Coast Guard cutters have orders to sink submarines by ramming them, it was revealed here yesterday by Commander James A. Hirshfield of the Coast Guard cutter Campbell which, in February, battled six enemy submarines twelve hours, sinking at least one by ramming and shell fire.

The major portion of the 148,847 mechanical refrigerators released last week from the nation's stockpile of 400,000 units by a War Production Board order will not stay in the hands of either distributors or dealers very long, reports here yesterday indicated.
TRENTON, April 5 -- Angered by the Senate's failure to act on a score of nominations, Governor Charles Edison today turned to the voters for help.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 5 -- A new composing team for pictures was formed today with the signing by Columbia of Jerome Kern to write the music, and Ira Gershwin the lyrics, for the forthcoming Technicolor musical "Cover Girl." The picture is scheduled to start May 1.
You can never tell what is going to bounce into this station house, Sergeant John Collins said yesterday at the West 123d Street station.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 -- The right of the holders of common stock of a holding company undergoing dissolution to share in the distribution of assets, even if their securities have no equity, was established today by the Securities and Exchange Commission by a vote of 4 to 1.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 5 -- The Second United States Army Corps, continuing its determined offensive through the difficult terrain south and east of El Guettar to join the British Eighth Army, captured two hills overlooking the valley leading to the sea yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Deciding a question not answered in the more than 200 years of copyright legislation, the Supreme Court today held that the copyright of "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling" legally belongs to M. Witmark Sons, New York music publishers.
LONDON, April 5 -- Most of today's activities in the stock market were confined to gilt edge home railway and mining issues with gains being recorded in each section.

Today's events: Philadelphia Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 8:45 P.M.; Valentina Vishnevska, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Bach's St. Matthew Passion, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:15; Ralph Leopold, pianist, lecture recital on "Die Meistersinger", Studio 506 Steinway Building, 8:30; Frederick Jacobi, lecture recital on Stravinsky, Juilliard Graduate School, 5.
An Italian communique, as broadcast by Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

Substantial quantities of more than 130 different kinds of critical materials were rounded up in warehouses during the "treasure hunt" recently completed by the regional redistribution division of the War Production Board, and many of these materials have already been put to work in war plants where they were urgently needed, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Congress was informed politely but firmly today that the State Department's policy in North Africa was based on winning the war. Secretary Cordell Hull put it thus: "We knew that we would get into a hopeless tangle if we stopped fighting to take up politics."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The War Production Board's alcohol and solvents section today killed any hopes distillers or others may have had that a suspension of stock piling of industrial alcohol is probable. One effect of such a suspension would be to permit the production of beverage spirits by distillers.

A resolution protesting Mayor La Guardia's proposal to balance the budget by increasing the basic real estate tax rate fifteen or sixteen points was adopted unanimously yesterday at a meeting of 500 property holders at the Hotel Commodore.

The first campaign of the National War Fund, which will raise funds for all war-related causes except the American Red Cross, will be conducted from Oct. 1 to Nov. 20, it was decided yesterday at a meeting of the organization's directors in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- A Senate Small Business subcommittee recommended today that legislation be introduced at once to place all retail distribution of tires in the hands of independent dealers. "The destructive pricing policies of the major corporations destroy the independents' profit margins," said the group in a report by Senator Wherry, Republican of Nebraska.

Rackham Holt, author of "George Washington Carver: An American Biography," published last week by Doubleday, Doran, will speak this evening at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, under the sponsorship of the university's Institute of Arts and Sciences.
FORT OGLETHORPE, Ga., April 5 (AP) -- Miss Helene Rains, 21, a swimming champion since she was 12, is in a new kind of swim these days -- she's in the Army.
The German Monday communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The $13,000,000,000 Second War Loan, the greatest borrowing drive in the history of the world, will be launched formally for the entire nation by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., at a meeting at 8:30 P.M. next Monday at Carnegie Hall.

Dr. Samuel McCune Lindsay of Columbia University, chairman of the International Labor Organization Committee of the United States, cooperating with the International Labor Office of the League of Nations, yesterday announced the establishment of a committee representing management and labor in the textile industry of the United States to advise the I.L.O. in its current studies of the probable position of the textile industry in the postwar period.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A review of three test cases of laws requiring members of Jehovah's Witnesses to salute the American flag was promised by the Supreme Court today. All the situations are challenges to the constitutionality of a Mississippi law aimed at curbing disloyalty and under which representatives of the sect were prosecuted in Vickburg, Canton and Columbia, Miss.

Immediate intervention of the National War Labor Board into the soft coal wage dispute, affecting 450,000 miners, did not appear likely yesterday as negotiations were resumed between the United Mine Workers, headed by John L. Lewis, and operators of the Northern and Southern areas of the Appalachian region.

ALGIERS, April 5 -- Information has just been received here that the Mexican Government will admit all Spanish Republican refugees now interned in North African prison camps who wish to go to Mexico. Approximately 1,500 such internees will have the choice of selecting Mexico as a foster homeland.

The lack of understanding of the nature of workers' education and its relation to adult education revealed by the Board of Education's rejection of Mark Starr for the position of Director of Adult Education will, unless corrected, prevent the development of a comprehensive adult education program in New York City.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 5 (AP) -- Major Gen. Harold L. George, Chief of the Air Transport Command of the United States Air Forces, declared today that the tasks being performed by the men under him were "something no one would believe unless he'd been reading Jules Verne."

The New York Stock Exchange stole a march on Federal Reserve authorities by reporting yesterday, for the first time, detailed figures on brokers' loans. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports the brokers' loans volume weekly, but gives no breakdown of the figure.
