The Lavallee Smith Choir of the Chateauguay Regiment of Montreal, Canadian Army Reserve, with Jean Charbonneau as conductor, will appear at Town. Hall next Sunday night. It will be the choir's first New York appearance.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (AP) -- An additional twenty-five days of racing at the Bay Meadows track was granted by the California Horse Racing Board today. The new meeting will start tomorrow and continue through May 8.

NATAL, Brazil, March 12 (AP) (Delayed) -- Brig. Gen. Patrick Hurley, former Secretary of War and now a special representative of President Roosevelt, had one of the closest calls of his life this week in a plane mishap between the United States and Africa.

A wave of buying orders unequaled in fifteen months pushed prices yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange to peak levels for several years. Additions of major fractions to more than 2 points in the rail stocks and bonds were registered in the heightened activity which ran through the session and reached its greatest tempo in the final hour.

WITH THE UNITED STATES AIR FORCES IN CHINA, April 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Captain Burrall Barnum of Old Lyme, Conn., holder of the Distinguished Flying Cross for an exploit in which he took on thirty-nine Japanese planes single-handed, was killed in the April 1 air battle in which American fighters shot down five and probably destroyed two of nine planes attempting to attack an advanced airdrome.
LOS ANGELES, April 5 (AP) -- The American bluejacket is the world's finest fighting man, Lieut. Comdr. Robert Montgomery, says, because of his tenacity, courage and devotion to duty white under fire.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The British Eighth Army's success in driving Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's Africa Corps out of Egypt, across Libya and into Tunisia was due partly a "a surprise supply" of the latest type American tanks and American-built, self-propelled, high-caliber anti-tank guns, the Office of War Information reported today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 5 -- Coincident with the arrival of Vice President Henry A. Wallace in Bolivia on his good-will tour, the Council of National Defense of Bolivia announced its recommendation to President Enrique Penaranda de Castillo that he decree that a state of war exists with the Axis powers.

Charles J. Farley, 26-year-old nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, and Louis Caridad, 24, went on trial before Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein yesterday on an indictment charging them with murder in the first degree. They are accused of killing Patrolman Nicholas C. Moreno on the night of May 23, 1939, while holding up a gasoline station at 392 Leonard Street, Brooklyn.
FORT HANCOCK, N.J., April 5 -- Joe McCarthy unveiled Marius Russo and Tiny Bonham today with satisfactory results.
Mrs. Frank P. Corrigan, wife of the United States Ambassador to Venezuela, is expected to come to Essex House today from Arlington, Va.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Uniform retail price ceilings on cuts of beef, veal, lamb and mutton were announced today by the Office of Price Administration. The schedule, similar to a program already invoked for pork, established maximum prices in all stores of the same type in each of twelve zones into which the country has been divided.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- New York City lost a controversy with the Federal Government today with the Supreme Court's refusal to review a dispute involving the cost of the new postoffice in Foley Square.

LONDON, April 5 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commanding general of the United States Fifth Army in Tunisia, has paid a friendly visit to Lieut. Gen. Luis M. Orgaz Yoldi, High Commissioner for Spanish Morocco, and received the honor of a review of troops of the Spanish Legion, a United States Army communique revealed tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Reversing an earlier stand, the Senate Judiciary Committee today approved legislation requiring Senate confirmation of most Federal jobholders who receive $4,500 or more a year, including employes of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

BUFFALO, April 5 -- War industries in this region, employing about 100,000 workers, among whom are several thousand women, have organized through a committee of five representatives, the Buffalo Victory and Child Care Association, Inc.

Wearing qualities of Winter-weight underwear would be materially reduced if manufacturers of nationally advertised lines were forced to adopt the OPA's proposed minimum grade specifications, it was declared yesterday by the Underwear Institute.

Teachers of United States history and other educators continued yesterday to discuss the results of the nation-wide survey of college freshmen's knowledge of the subject, which were interpreted as disclosing a striking ignorance of this or branch of history.

A young man who took the trouble to fake the stationery and handwriting of a physician, and then misspelled the diseases he was fraudulently attributing to his "dependent" mother and sister, was one of a group rounded up on charges of draft evasion last week, according to E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The House today passed by unanimous-consent vote the Sparkman bill providing for the appointment and commissioning of women physicians and surgeons in the Medical Corps of the Army and Navy.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., April 5 -- Two vital war activities are functioning on the once quiet 400-acre estate of the late Otto Kahn, banker. In the massive chateau sixty young men pursued their intensive radio studies in their first week at the United States Maritime Service training station, which has taken over forty acres of the estate.

Two New York lawyers, a former chief of Daytona Beach, Fla., detectives, and an escaped murderer were among thirteen men indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of conspiracy and violation of the National Stolen Property Act. All the defendants except Odie V. Fluker, the convicted killer, have been apprehended by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 5 -- A condition bordering on famine now exists in the city of Tunis and the local population of Bizerte has been evacuated to suburban and resort districts, according to eye-witness reports reaching here today.
Alice -- age 13 -- said she had coffee every morning for breakfast, and why shouldn't she? Didn't her mother and father always drink it?

LONDON, April 5 -- After General Charles de Gaulle literally had packed his bags for his trip to North Africa, it was learned today, a message from General Dwight D. Eisenhower, transmitted through the British Foreign Office, asked him to delay his departure.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, April 6 (AP) -- Allied warplanes bombed a number of Japanese bases Monday, including a three and one-half hour raid on Buka, General MacArthur reported today.

LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- Before the French National Committee's announcement today, a foreign diplomatic source stated that a momentous decision affecting the entire status of General de Gaulle's part in French resistance was believed to have been reached in Washington during recent British-American conferences.

I was interested in the analysis of ministerial reading made by Mr. Lancour, librarian of Cooper Union, as reported in your columns March 31. Perhaps, as a minister, my judgment is not sufficiently objective, but I am inclined to consider unwarranted the conclusion that the absence of certain significant titles and the predominance of religious books in their general reading necessarily imply "slovenly reading habits."

The Public Service Commission, by a 3 to 2 vote, decided yesterday that the Orange Rockland Electric Company was entitled to a return of only 5 1/2 per cent on the fair value of its utility properties and ordered the concern to reduce charges to its customers in Orange and Rockland Counties about $50,000 a year.

The 1942 report of the Norfolk Western Railway, for publication today, shows, after taxes and charges, net income of $21,908,764, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $14.93 each on 1,406,483 common shares. For 1941 the company had reported a net income of $27,194,003, or $18.69 a common share.

Despite frequent suggestions that advertising be curtailed to alleviate material shortages, the United States Department of Commerce, which has been a consistent advocate of keeping brand names alive regardless of whether a product is available or not, continues to view favorably the strong trend toward maintaining wartime advertising as near as possible to peacetime levels.

LONDON, April 5 -- Thanks to the ingenuity and skill of United States Army engineers, the Flying Fortress "Werewolf" is back where she belongs -- in the skies -- carrying destruction to Germany's war plants.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 6 -- Russian forces driving against the Nazi base at Novorossiisk in the Kuban area have captured several populated places in two days of hand-to-hand fighting in the Caucasus, and in the Izyum area of the Donets Valley have turned back new enemy attempts to cross the river, Moscow announced today.

One reason why American boys in high school and freshman college year know so little about the history of their country is that America has had a Horatio Alger and an Oliver Optic, but America never developed a George Alfred Henty or an Alexandre Dumas.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Contract negotiations between the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company and the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, have broken down over the issue of a retroactive date for the new agreement, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- An appeal to the members of the Sea Food Workers Union, who went on strike this morning in Boston, to return to work pending a settlement of the dispute over the terms of their contract which expired April 1, was made by telegram today by R.H. Gabrielson, director of the Fish and Wildlife Service and Acting Coordinator of Fisheries.

The thirty-family apartment house at 1366 Lyman Place, the Bronx, was sold by Anna Rogozin to Minnie Segnes for cash above mortgages of $64,500. Abraham L. Sobil was the attorney for the seller. Matthew J. Lyons represented the buyer. S. Isaacs Co., were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Reversing itself after first sending the measure back to committee, the House passed a bill today authorizing the government to accept a permanent loan of $5,000,000 for the benefit of the National Gallery of Art.

DENVER, April 5 -- Charles E. Greene, superintendent of Denver public schools, in a statement issued here today characterized the statement of Hugh Russell Fraser, an official of the United States Office of Education and chairman of the Committee on American History, that the teaching of history was dropped in the Denver schools in 1924 as "completely erroneous."
Today is Army Day, the twenty-sixth anniversary of the entry of the United States into the first World War. But this year there will be no parade because the Army is too busy with war tasks.

VANCOUVER, Wash., April 5 -- The first aircraft carrier ever launched on the West Coast slid into the Columbia River today carrying with it the high hopes of President Roosevelt that the fleet of which it is the vanguard would play a vital part in the United Nations' prosecution of the war.

Sounds of laughter, hammering and music fill the white-lined corridors of the Red Cross building at Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island. In this Army hospital women volunteers from the New York chapter and professional Red Cross workers see that wounded men back from the front lines are once more learning how to relax and "keep busy" at occupations far different from shooting Japanese, digging foxholes and manning guns.
CHUNGKING, China, April 5 (U.P.) -- A communique:

ALBANY, April 5 -- Persons who refuse to sell alcoholic beverages to minors, apparently intoxicated persons or habitual drunkards are relieved of the threat of civil or criminal action under a bill signed today by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A list of 200 "hard goods" items and classes of items, including many articles for household use, on which production must continue in order to assure the nation of a sound civilian economy in wartime, was made public tonight by the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply.

AT A UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE in Tunisia, April 4 (Delayed) (AP) -- Striking savagely just as Stukas were unloading explosives on American positions in the El Guettar area, a single squadron of American-piloted Spitfires shot down thirteen Junkers 87s late Saturday, almost certainly destroyed several more and damaged others in spectacular dog fighting.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 5 -- The specter of Gestapo rule moved a step closer to Denmark when it was officially announced in Copenhagen today that a fresh epidemic of sabotage broke out last night in and around Hilleroed, a factory town twenty miles northwest of Copenhagen.

Four more properties in various sections of the city have been purchased by Charles F. Noyes. They include the vacant plot at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirtieth Street, which is assessed for $120,000. This parcel was bought from Frederick Brown, who acquired it last week with six other parcels in Manhattan.

AT THE NAVAL PROVING GROUND, Dahlgren, Va., April 5 -- New weapons to increase the Navy's efficiency in destroying Nazi submarines and shooting down Japanese bombers are being developed in this ordnance center amid the sharp crack of anti-aircraft batteries and the ear-pounding roar of the biggest guns in the world.

Miss Alice Key Adams, the only daughter of Newton Adams and the late Mrs. Alice Potter Adams Martin, was injured fatally early yesterday at Fifty-fifth Street and Second Avenue, a few blocks from the apartment where she lived alone at 325 East Forty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- While no confirmation was available tonight from hither the War or State Department on General de Gaulle's statement that his visit to North Africa had been postponed at General Eisenhower's request, some responsible observers thought it more likely that the British authorities had made the decision.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle said today that a Federal grand jury has indicted Otis T. Wingo Jr. of Washington on charges of willful failure to register as a foreign agent.
LONDON, April 5 -- The John Mavnard Keynes plan for stabilization of post-war currency will be submitted to the House of Commons this week in the form of a Government White Paper.

MARACAY, Venezuela, April 4 -- The Spanish Minister to Venezuela, Jose Antonio Sangroniz, who left for Spain on the Spanish ship Cabo de Homo yesterday, is reliably reported to have talked by telephone for nearly an hour with Prince Juan in Switzerland regarding a plan for the prompt restoration of the monarchy.

As the Office of Price Administration announced meat price ceilings and revamped rationing regulations to halt the cut-point war that developed here over the weekend, Mayor La Guardia and representatives of city departments, the local OPA and the Food Distribution Administration conferred yesterday at City Hall on plans to tighten enforcement of regulations to end black markets.

Tribute to the press for its cooperation in the last war was paid yesterday by Major General Dennis E. Nolan, retired, founder of The Stars and Stripes, the American soldiers newspaper of World War I, at the weekly luncheon of the Advertising Men's Post of the American Legion at the Hotel Lexington.

Three women were beaten and robbed yesterday in different parts of the city, and Magistrate Abner C. Surpless, before whom one of the suspects appeared in court, suggested action by the State Legislature to impose more severe penalties for mugging.

The Senate is expected today to reconsider the Bankhead bill. If it is a responsible body it will sustain the President's veto. The case that the President's message made against the bill was complete and unanswerable. It would burden consumers with a still further increase in food prices. It is a straight-out inflationary measure.
Everett, Mass., announced yesterday that it will be in the market tomorrow with a new issue of $300,000 of temporary loan notes. The issue will be dated April 7 and will be payable on Nov. 22, 1943.

BALTIMORE, April 5 (AP) -- The executive committee of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, which controls all minor circuits today declared George Ferrell, brother of Wes and Rick Ferrell of major league fame, the property of the Binghamton, N.Y., Eastern League Club.

Repetitions of "Swan Lake," "Aleko" and "Helen of Troy" made up last night's bill by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House. If none of these was a novelty, there were cast changes which constituted important novelties in the first two numbers, and Robert Lawrence, dance critic of The Herald Tribune, appeared as guest conductor of both works.

MIAMI, April 5 (AP) -- E.C. Burland of the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations of the State Department said on his return today from North Africa that in Tunisia the need for civilian relief would be greatest in the areas regained from Axis forces.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Major General Lewis B. Hershey, director of the Selective Service System, indicated today that men between the ages of 38 and 45 who are being released from the Army might be reinducted unless they got into essential occupations.

The history of France, of Britain, of America, even of Germany, contains many examples of the struggle for freedom of speech and of the press. In pre-Revolutionary France Voltaire boldly defended the rights of men with whom he vehemently disagreed. A German bookseller in Napoleon's time sold a book Napoleon didn't like.

Sumner Welles in his address to the Chamber of Commerce April 1 sounded a hopeful and sensible note about the future relations of American business and finance with our Latin-American neighbors. These were to be left in the hands of private enterprise. It was such a statement as one might expect from one who knows Latin America and the American tradition.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court moved today toward possible examination of the validity of the rent-control powers of the Office of Price Administration. It agreed to review an Indiana case, but postponed until after arguments a ruling on whether it has jurisdiction over the merits of the issue.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Tentative proposals for United States participation up to $5,000,000,000 in a United Nations fund for postwar stabilization of currencies on a gold foundation in the furtherance of vitalized and equalized world trade were disclosed here and in London today.

ATLANTA, April 5 -- Negro artists from many sections of the United States have examples of their work on display in the second annual art exhibition which is being held this week at Atlanta University. It will run through May 2.

BALTIMORE, April 5 -- Whirlaway, the turf's greatest money winner of all time, headed a field of thirty-two topnotchers announced today for the $20,000 Dixie Handicap on May 1, one of the high spots of Pimlico's Spring "street car meeting."

LONDON, April 5 -- A great-fleet of four-motored Royal Air Force bombers, possibly numbering 700 to 800, attacked the German naval base of Kiel last night, and today American precision bombers, prolonging one of the greatest air offensives of all time, struck German war factories at Antwerp, Belgium.

LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- Through a sixteen-page pamphlet, with a preface signed by Professor H. Stanley Jevons, British author, and T. Corder Catchpool, a prominent Quaker, a committee of seven Britons has petitioned the government and the R.A.F. to "stop bombing civilians" in Europe, it was learned today.

Madison Square Garden was packed to the rafters last night by a crowd that had paid from $2.20 to $5,000 for the privilege of witnessing an extraordinary galaxy of stage, screen and radio stars in a benefit performance for the 1943 Red Cross War Fund.

NEW DELHI, India, April 5 (U.P.) -- Four-engined Liberator bombers of the Tenth United States Air Force, in one of their most successful blows against the Japanese in Burma, blasted the great Thilawa oil refinery south of Rangoon with more than 26,000 pounds of bombs yesterday, starting fires visible fifty miles away, it was announced today.

THE National Football League opens its annual meeting in Chicago today and the moguls are faced with the important task of deciding whether they will operate this season and with whom. The circuit was half drained of manpower last year and the process has been almost completed in the interval. Some clubs will not have much left besides the franchise.

Recruits are urgently needed for the Manhattan Civilian Defense Corps, a picked body of women volunteer workers, who represent the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office at rallies, pafades, memorial services and other functions.

NEW CITY, N.Y., April 5 -- A stunned silence fell over a crowd-filled Rockland County courtroom today as former Sheriff Edward C. Dormann and two co-defendants pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy to operate a numbers racket in the county.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 5 -- Almost 100 Flying Fortresses of the Northwest African Strategic Air Force bombed Naples yesterday afternoon in the heaviest raid ever made on the port.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The National Association of Women Artists opened its fifty-first annual exhibition to the public yesterday in the galleries of the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. Oils, water-colors, prints and sculpture are shown, water-colors and work in black and white being hung in the Center Gallery; sculpture distributed. The entries this year run to 340 items.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 5 (AP) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Household items recommended for wider production included the following:
The twenty-eight family apartment house at 2271 Hudson Boulevard Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the Fidelity Union Trust Company to Salem Apartments, Inc., a New York syndicate.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the owner of voting common stock of a corporation need not pay a Federal income tax on a stock dividend based on corporate earnings paid in nonvoting common stock of the corporation.
TUCKERTON, N.J., April 5 (AP) -- A forest fire which threatened this ocean county borough of 1,500 residents was partly under control.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- War as desperate as that in which this nation now finds itself lowers the standards of living for all who are engaged in it if the conduct of war is equitable. Among the American standards which war has necessarily restricted are those of democracy. Some of its processes become a perilous luxury, and by statutory law and administrative act they are by common consent curtailed.

WARDHA, India, April 1 (Delayed) -- The saddest place in India is five miles from here in Sevagram, where Mohandas K. Gandhi's ashram, or hermitage, stands almost empty. A year ago it was like the heart of India, just as it is, in fact, her geographical center, but now almost all its important members are jailed.

Mayor La Guardia demonstrated his versatility anew yesterday morning when he appeared on a transatlantic radio quiz. Pitting his wits against a panel of experts in London, he came off none the worse in a cross-fire exchange on such topics as freedom, prohibition, the sad life of the politician and why should it be the man who proposes marriage.
LONDON, April 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

In his budget message of March 31 Mayor LaGuardia advocates a higher tax rate for New York real estate. In your editorial of April 2, reviewing the situation, you conclude that a higher tax rate, kept down by all practical economies, is inevitable. Neither of you favor using the city's borrowing credit in this emergency.

CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- The poor umpire, who works two to four hours a day seven days a week unless it rains or the teams have a day off, will be doubly on his guard against injuries or sickness in the American League this season, for there will be only ten arbiters in uniform instead of the twelve who took the field last year.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 5 -- An indictment charging a conspiracy to sell jobs at the Federal Ship Building and Dry Dock Corporation at Kearny and obtain draft deferments on false recommendations was returned today by the Hudson County Grand Jury against seven men.

Retailers are now showing sharply expanded interest in covering Fall requirements in ready-to-wear, furs and staples. Many of the buyers here yesterday who were primarily interested in obtaining Spring fill-ins were also anxious to place commitments on Fall merchandise to be shipped when ready.

American Red Cross headquarters in Brooklyn was completely taken over by the Dodgers for about an hour yesterday as the athletes spent their first off-day in three weeks donating blood. Nearly three gallons went into the Red Cross blood bank from the Dodger contingent, which included three newspaper men and a ball player's wife, Mrs. Bob Bragan.

The trial of three hotel men on charges of running their places as houses of prostitution opened yesterday with the testimony of a clerk that uniformed policemen stationed in the lobby of one of the hotels had accepted drinks, meals and cigarettes from him in return for which the policeman was expected to ignore vice conditions.

To aid the American Red Cross and the National War Fund, the United States Golf Association, in agreement with those two organizations, is recommending a unified program of tournaments to the country's 5,400 private and public courses and associations.

AT A FLYING FORTRESS BASE, in England, April 5 (U.P.) -- Flying Fortresses were dogged so closely by Nazi fighters over Antwerp today that an empty shell ejected from the 20-mm. cannon of a German plane was brought back by Staff Sergeant Don Devan of Springfield, Mass. It fell at his feet as he stood at the waist gun of his Fortress bomber.

To help mothers in war find the best possible daytime care facilities for their children, a new Manhattan office of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children was opened yesterday at 303 Ninth Avenue. In Room 303, overlooking a city playground filled with youngsters romping on swings and see-saws, a staff familiar with West Side agencies is prepared to direct mothers in vital jobs to possible havens for their children.

ALBANY, April 5 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Wicks bill exempting from the State income tax compensation for service in the armed forces of the United States. The statute applies to such pay earned last year and those affected will not be required to pay a State tax on earnings this year.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- In predicting that the meat price ceilings issued today would mean lower prices on the average, officials of the Office of Price Administration said it was believed that some current prices were illegal and the wide ceiling variation from store to store had made it impossible to police them.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Joint Congressional-Departmental Committee on Economy opened an investigation today into a maze of Federal corporations which its chairman, Senator Byrd of Virginia, described as "the fourth branch of the government."

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A table setting forth the maximum prices to be charged for each of the 102 meat cuts covered by the retail ceilings established today, effective April 15, was issued by the Office of Price Administration. The list gives cents-per-pound prices for each cut in the various classifications into which the meat is graded.

Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator and chairman of the Maritime Commission, struck back yesterday at his critics at a luncheon of the United Seamen's Service, calling them "no-doers and half-doers" and suggesting that they "knock off bellyaching."

Major changes in the executive set-up of the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company were made yesterday at a special meeting of the company's board of directors. William G. Maguire was elected to the newly created post of chairman of the board and chief executive officer, and Edward Buddrus was elected president in charge of all operations.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decrease of 10 per cent last week under the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

William Bergsma, a teaching fellow at the Eastman School of Music, Rochester, N.Y., has won the 1943 Joseph H. Bearns prize of $900, awarded annually by Columbia University for the best musical composition by an American composer between the ages of 18 and 25, it was announced yesterday.

Ducks Unlimited has asked governmental agencies to "permit only normal harvesting of surplus wildlife crops" and warns against the danger of indiscriminate shooting and unwarranted slaughter of game under the guise of increasing the wartime meat supply.

Vinton Freedley has decided to close "Dancing in the Streets" for the time being after Saturday night's performance in Boston, where it has been playing to excellent business since it first opened there on March 23.

Two Brooklyn printers charged with conspiring to counterfeit B gasoline ration coupons were held for the Federal grand jury yesterday by United States Commissioner Martin C. Epstein in Brooklyn Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A group of fifty men, representing the business, labor and agriculture committees of the National Planning Association, has submitted to President Roosevelt an eight-point memorandum of agreement declaring that "the first goal of postwar planning should be a foundation for better living through provision for enough jobs and lasting jobs."

For five months the Germans have been planting land mines along every approach to the Tunisian coast. They cannot be dug up in five hours or five days. This mechanical rear guard which Rommel left behind him has served him as well as Axis tanks and guns to delay our attacking columns.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, April 6 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres today. "The Heart of a Nation," a French production, will have its world premiere at the newly reopened Abbey Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-first Street. This will be a night opening under the joint sponsorship of the Coordinating Council of the French Relief Committee and the Fighting French Relief Committee.
CHUNGKING, China, April 6 (U.P.) -- A communique:

General Dwight D. Eisenhower's decision to have General Charles de Gaulle postpone his departure to Algeria for an indefinite period, the second decision of the kind within one month, can easily be explained on military grounds. A letter from a friend in North Africa that reached me today and a good deal of other evidence make it quite clear.

BOSTON, April 6 -- Although they have won only two games in Boston during the last six National Hockey League seasons, the Red Wings today appeared confident that they would beat the Bruins on successive nights, tomorrow and Thursday, and wind up the Stanley Cup final series with four straight victories.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- Nearly 500,000 youths in their middle teens are receiving technical training in the Soviet Union that will enable them to enter industry as qualified workers. This figure was given today by Vasily Prokofieff, assistant chairman of the government's Labor Reserve Bureau, who since the end of 1940 has been responsible for the mobilization, training and distribution of Soviet youth in industry and transport.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he agreed with the decision of Representative Doughton, North Carolina, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, to sidetrack action on "pay-as-you-go" tax legislation until the committee handled legislation to extend the reciprocal trade agreements and the Guffey coal bill.

Antony Tudor's star-crossed production of "Romeo and Juliet," which has been on the Ballet Theatre's schedule for nearly a year, has suffered another misadventure, and was not presented in its entirety at the Metropolitan Opera House last night according to plan.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 6 (U.P.) -- Italian occupation forces in France have refused to hand over American and British men in their territory for deportation to Germany and have held back, at the muzzles of machine guns, Vichy police who tried to seize them, Swiss press dispatches said today.

When the larger food chains discovered yesterday that their current prices generally were under Office of Price Administration meat ceilings and when the smaller food stores found they were generally above ceilings the latter conceded that they would be unable to compete with the chains.

A Silver Star Medal has been awarded posthumously to Dr. Jacques Conrad Saphier, a lieutenant, junior grade, in the Navy, for "conspicuous gallantry" last year in a marine action on Guadalcanal in which he was killed, a relative disclosed yesterday. The medal and citation have been received by Lieutenant Saphier's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Conrad J. Saphier of 1062 Carroll Street, Brooklyn, from Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox.

So many young men had converged yesterday on the Special Sessions trial of a trio of midtown hotel owners for operating alleged places of prostitution in their establishments that Presiding Justice Gustav W.M. Weiboldt opened the proceeding with an order to the clerk to "notify the War Manpower Commission we have considerable husky looking material here among the spectators that more fittingly should be engaged in war work."

Pending detailed study of the American plan for post-war currency stabilization, an instructive contrast must immediately present itself. The principles which Secretary Morgenthau now lays down are the exact opposite of those that the President enunciated in his famous wireless message of July 3 that torpedoed the London Economic Conference of 1933.

Extension of the mandatory forty-eight-hour week to all plants in the steel industry would increase total steel payrolls by an estimated $100,000,000 yearly, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The institute pointed out that such action would mean eight hours of work a week at time-and-a-half wage rates for an estimated 500,000 employes and, at the present base scale of wages, this would represent $2,000,000 in overtime payments a week.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (U.P.) -- Representative James W. Wadsworth of New York urged today enactment of the Austin-Wadsworth Labor Draft Bill, of which he is co-author, because, he said, "in this long, tough war the element of coercion must appear."

LONDON, Wednesday, April 7 -- A study of reconnaissance photographs taken after the R.A.F.'s heavy raid on Berlin the night of March 1 showed at least twenty-two acres of workshops in one district alone wrecked, the Air Ministry reported today.

Unsettled by growing indications reported from Washington that the farm bloc will be unable to array sufficient votes in Congress to override the Presidential veto of the Bankhead-Steagall bill, the cotton futures market yesterday weakened in late dealings under commission-house liquidation and closed with net losses of 12 to 21 points, or 60 cents to $1.05 a bale, the sharpest decline in five weeks.

While operators of the northern Appalachian region continued their conferences yesterday with representatives of the United Mine Workers in the negotiations for a new wage agreement, Edward R. Burke, president of the Southern Coal Producers Association, again called for submission of the dispute to the National War Labor Board as the only means of bringing about a settlement.

Your article concerning the results of your poll of freshmen in various colleges has caused a great deal of consternation in our minds. We were shocked at the answers which were given, and at the present moment we have many misgivings concerning the value of education in secondary schools.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- An inquiry to determine how the Federal Government can remedy the "appalling neglect of United States history in secondary schools," as disclosed Sunday by THE NEW YORK TIMES, was asked of the Senate today by Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania.
The Tuesday Italian communique, as broadcast by Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The implications of THE TIMES survey of the college freshman's knowledge of United States history are much more significant and far-reaching than your analysis demonstrates. Nor do they admit of such an easy solution as you suggest.

Social security and liberty are "incompatible concepts," James G. Mitchell, member of the American Bar Association's committee on international legal problems, declared last night in attacking the Beveridge plan in a talk before the Republican Business Women at the Republican Women's National Republican Club.

Secretary Knox's statement yesterday that shipping losses in the Atlantic have taken a turn for the worse is a badly needed reminder that our first front is not in Tunisia but on the sea that separates us from our troops. That is where the war against Hitler will be won or lost.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Chicagoans established a record in local political history by voting today to retain their Democratic Mayor, Edward J. Kelly, in office for another four years, thus extending his unbroken service as the city's chief executive to fourteen years.

The sixth annual Greater New York Fund campaign will be opened formally on behalf of 400 voluntary welfare and health agencies and hospitals on May 3, the organization announced yesterday. The goal will be roughly $5,000,000, although the exact amount has not yet been determined.

Extensive research has enabled the Loose-Wiles Biscuit Company to develop a substitute packaging material for Army rations that is lighter, cheaper and more waterproof than tin, Gene Flack, director of public and trade relations for the company, declared yesterday at the luncheon of the Sales Executive Club of New York in the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Southern New York State Fish and Game Association survey of the opening of New York's trout season substantiates other reports that some good sized fish were taken, here and there, by the hardy anglers.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 185 United States soldiers missing in action in the European, Middle East, North American, Pacific, Southwest Pacific and South Pacific areas and missing at sea in the North Atlantic.

The Produce Distributors of America, Inc., a new organization designed, its founders say, to acquaint the Office of Price Administration with the way they feel that its regulations are destroying produce distribution channels and the public with the way these controls are interfering with its food supply. launched a nation-wide campaign for membership in a market meeting yesterday morning that drew charges that it stifled discussion and democratic methods.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- In a surprise move, the Cleveland Rams dropped out of the National Football League today for the duration, but the owners of the remaining nine clubs voted to continue in the face of a terrific manpower shortage.

LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- Admiral Sir William James, Chief of Naval Information, said today that "the dice are loaded heavily" in favor of the Axis in any Allied attempt to land on the Continent of Europe, but he added that ways and means would be found "when the time comes" to attack.

Thomas E. Murray, president of the Murray Manufacturing Company, Brooklyn, received a citation yesterday from the Army Ordnance Department for distinguished service to the country in designing a mass production 81-mm. trench mortar shell and a 60-mm. mortar shell to replace models made by machining and hogging out forgings.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 6 -- In the pitch-black at 4:30 A.M. today, the British Eighth Army attacked Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's new Southern Tunisian position along Wadi el Akarit, which lies about twenty miles north of Gabes.

Your expose showing that training in the social sciences is not adequate came as no surprise to me, since I am a student. However, I don't think it was a fair representation. The blame can't be placed on the colleges or the students, since some of your questions weren't clear.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 6 -- Apparently in answer to grossly exaggerated figures published in the German press, the Italian Ministry of Food Supplies has just issued official figures outlining German aid in foodstuffs to the Italians since the war began.

While the wind howled and movie cameras ground, the Dodgers attempted a workout at Ebbets Field yesterday, but their efforts were not too successful. Here and there a few, like Arky Vaughan and Dolph Camilli, walloped several long hits, but for the most, little was accomplished.

HARDSHIP and privation, the risk of mutilation and death, are the lot of all front-line soldiers in all wars. And the human race, being brave, patient and long-suffering by instinct and inclination, endures the woes of war with rarely failing fortitude. But the endurance is strongest when based on support, understanding and sacrifice from the nation, from civilians and ranking officers.

Praising THE NEW YORK TIMES of college freshman knowledge edge of United States history as a "real service to education," prominent educators joined yesterday in urging that the subject be given greater stress both in high school and in college.

Mario Abbate, captain of the New Utrecht fencing team, led five other qualifiers into the final round of the city P.S.A.L. individual foil championship tournament on the strips of Washington Irving High School last night.
NEW DELHI, India, April 6 (AP) -- A communique:
A dozen members of the Madison Square Boys Club set out yesterday to prove rationing is no problem to a good to cook.

The Hecla Mining Company in its annual statement for 1942 reported yesterday a net profit of $1,446,693 after Federal income and excess profits taxes of $855,539 and other deductions. The profit is equivalent to $1.45 a share on 1,000,000 shares of capital stock.

NEWARK, N.J., April 6 -- The alleged existence of a black-market meat conspiracy of national scope, purportedly dominated by an erstwhile liver peddler, was disclosed here today by officials of the New Jersey Office of Price Administration in announcing that the Federal Grand Jury for the District of New Jersey had indicted seven corporations and eleven individuals on charges of having plotted to violate Office of Price Administration price quota regulations.
The German Tuesday communique, as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Major Joseph Sailer of the Marine Corps has been killed in action in the South Pacific, where in November he commanded an air squadron which was credited with sinking a battleship and destroying fourteen Japanese transports.

The weather clock seemed to have turned back yesterday and Victory gardeners all over the New York area returned gloomily to Winter quarters as the temperature fell to 23 degrees at 8:30 A.M., a record low for April 6 in the history of the local Weather Bureau.

A rise in juvenile delinquency in the first three months of this year in comparison with the corresponding periods of 1942 and 1941 is indicated in a statement issued yesterday by the Children's Division of the Domestic Relations Court, showing the numbers of allegedly delinquent children brought before the court in the three periods.

LONDON, April 6 -- Sir Ramaswami Mudaliar, Indian member of the War Cabinet, suggested today that the advice of American, Canadian and Australian experts be sought as consultants in connection with the drawing up of any constitution for India.

Because of the war the 200-inch telescope cannot be completed. Physicists who were devoting their lives to probing the secrets of the atom have abandoned their cyclotrons to improve death-dealing weapons. Mathematicians who once constructed new relativistic universes now solve problems in ballistics.

The twenty-second annual exhibition of advertising art, sponsored by the Art Directors Club and to be held in the main exhibition room of the New York Public Library, June 7 to 30, will differ radically from previous exhibits in many respects, it was announced yesterday.

Cesar Rubio of Mexico City, who until now has designed for the Mexican stage and screen, opened his new millinery salon at 30 East Fifty-fourth Street yesterday afternoon with a special press showing of new Spring and Summer hats.
ALGIERS, April 6 -- General Henri Honore Giraud is considering a visit to the United States as soon as the military campaign in Tunisia has been finished, responsible sources indicated today.

With the armed forces on worldwide battle fields, Army Day was celebrated here yesterday with attention centered on the home front, Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding the Eastern Defense Area and the First Army, predicting compulsory service soon for factory and farm workers.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 954, as against 983 in the preceding week and 662 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 420, which compared with 403 last Tuesday.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 6 -- Whenever baseball authorities are asked whether professional baseball will continue for the duration of the war, they usually say, "It's up to the public."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 6 (AP) -- A communique said today:

In an address delivered at Reading, Pa., last Sunday Assistant Secretary of State Adolf Berle scotched a lot of rumors and speculations going the rounds in regard to the official American attitude toward the Soviet Union. He flatly denied, among other things, that there was any inclination in this country, let alone a plan or "plot," to build a so-called "cordon sanitaire" against Russia or to construct buffer States designed to be hostile to Russia.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 6 -- Three volunteer crews of the Ninth United States Army Air Force Liberator bombers successfully carried out "suicide" attacks on Axis Mediterranean bases on April 2 and all returned safely.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 6 -- The Third Battalion of the Sixth Armored Infantry was cited today by General Dwight D. Eisenhower for "gallantry in action at Oran in the initial landing Nov. 8."

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- President Roosevelt said today that he had no plans to nominate Mayor La Guardia for a commission in the Army. The President's statement, made in reply to a question at his press conference, apparently ruled out reports that the Mayor would be commissioned soon as a brigadier general, since a Presidential nomination and Senate confirmation would be required for that rank.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The War Department said tonight that it had been informed that five recent Tunisian war area photographs were "misleading in their captions" and that The Associated Press had suspended the photographer responsible on the ground that he had violated its "elementals of accurate news-photo reporting."

Instead of another appeal for funds, a large group of business and social leaders who attended a luncheon meeting called yesterday by the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies at the Hotel Plaza heard an urgent recommendation to telegraph or write to the President and their Representatives in Congress asking their support for measures to free frozen French, Belgian and Dutch funds in this country to buy food for children in Nazi-occupied countries.

LONDON, April 6 -- United States Army medical authorities have drawn up detailed plans whereby Army hospitals and their staffs at strategic points in this country would give all possible help to both military and civilian casualties in event of a heavy air raid anywhere in the United Kingdom.

ANY superlative generally can find steady employment on the sports pages. Athletics generate such spontaneous enthusiasm that writers get lyrical in their praise of various performers and, from long habit, hesitate not a bit in terming the current hero the greatest of them all.

An operating group headed by Alexander Hirsch has purchased the group of three apartment buildings at 49-55, 57-63 and 65-71 Wadsworth Terrace from Bernard London. The properties are reported fully occupied, each house accommodating forty-five families.

Allied planes were active yesterday over a great stretch of territory reaching all the way from the English Channel to the Bay of Bengal. German installations in Northern France were heavily pounded by British and Canadian fighters and fighter-bombers. Americans and British teamed up to attack Japanese bases over a widespread area in Burma.

Mr. and Mrs. William Vail Martin gave a dinner last night in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Their guests included Sir George Bettesworth-Piggott and Lady Piggott, Countess de Bouteville, Herbert C. Smyth, Robert Irving Wyner and E.A.L. Bennett of London.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique, as recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

The German-controlled Paris radio said yesterday, in a broadcast recorded by The United Press in New York, that Raoul Laparra, well-known French musician and composer, was killed in the American bombing raid on the Renault Works in the Paris suburbs Sunday.

Indications are that the earnings of most companies this year will decline below those of 1942. While it is too early to make any definite forecast, it now appears that companies not engaged largely in war work wil report a much smaller volume of business this year than they reported for 1942.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, April 6 -- General Douglas MacArthur himself pinned the Silver Star for gallantry in action and the Air Medal for meritorious achievement on Captain Fred P. Dollenberg of Philadelphia today, along with the Oak Leaf cluster that signified the pilot's second award of the Distinguished Flying Cross.
OMAHA, April 6 (AP) -- Samuel E. Jacobs, one of three Omahans indicted in the Newark, N.J., meat conspiracy cases, commented today "We're as innocent as they make 'em."

Walter Nash, New Zealand Minister to the United States, has just made some important revelations regarding decisions reached at the recent Pacific War Council held in Washington. According to Mr. Nash, the strategy mapped out at that council called for a change from a mere defensive holding war in the Pacific to offensive action which will give the Japanese a "shock" when it gets going.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Secretary Morgenthau made public this afternoon complete details of the post-war currency stabilization proposals of the Treasury. He declared that machinery should be set up as soon as two-thirds of the United Nations and their associates had agreed upon procedure, and expressed confidence that, "given time," they would come to agreement.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 6 -- Patrolman Alfred Lundgren, 41 years old, of 131 Leonard Street, regarded as a model in the department, was fatally shot early this morning by Mrs. Elsie Hendrickson Farr, 35 years old, who is awaiting a divorce, according to police officials.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 6 -- All signs indicate that Bolivia will be the next South American nation to proclaim a state of war against the Axis powers.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company will continue their policy of distributing most of the system's earnings to stockholders as dividends, Charles Y. Freeman, chairman, said today. Such a policy is possible, he indicated after the company's annual meeting, because of a favorable ratio of debt to capital stock and the absence of early maturities of funded debt.

CHUNGKING, China, April 5 (U.P.) -- New Japanese drives against Chinese guerrilla resistance in Shantung and Honan Provinces have been repulsed with heavy losses to the enemy, and the invaders have been held in check on all sectors of the broad Hupeh front, a Chinese communique reported tonight.

NEW DELHI, India, April 6 (U.P.) -- American and British airmen teamed yesterday to deal destructive blows to Japanese communications over a widespread area of Burma, and Royal Air Force fliers routed a large enemy formation attempting to raid Allied bases in Southeastern Bengal, it was announced today.

MEXICO CITY, April 6 -- In a speech published today, Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla said real victory, which should give to the world the four freedoms proposed by President Roosevelt, would be achieved only through frank collaboration of all nations.

LONDON, April 6 (U.P.) -- British and Canadian fighters, fighter-bombers and bombers attacked railways, air fields and industrial targets of the Nazis in Northern France and Belgium by daylight today, carrying forward the tremendous Allied aerial offensive that has been sustained almost without a break since Friday night.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 6 -- Newspapers in Axis-occupied France devoted by order the greater part of their space today to stories of "ruthless Anglo-American bombings." Omission of any reference to the Renault plant and other factories working for the Germans has the obvious object of leading the reader to imagine only civilians and their homes were hit.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a series of transactions, including the merger of the Northern Power Company into the Superior Water, Light and Power Company. Both companies are Wisconsin subsidiaries of the American Power and Light Company of the Electric Bond and Share Company system.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The tentative proposals to stabilize post-war currencies were submitted to thirty-seven nations.

Nine prominent editors and writers from Argentina arrived in New York yesterday after an extensive five-week tour of the United States, during which they visited New Orleans, San Antonio, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago and Detroit.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today awards of the Distinguished Service Cross for heroism in North Africa to two officers and seven enlisted men of the Army of the United States and the citation of three enlisted men in general orders.
Mrs. Frederic Winthrop Allen has come to Hampshire House from Manhasset, L.I.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Bernard Gimbel of Gimbel Brothers, New York, and Fred Lazarus of the Lazarus Stores, Columbus, Ohio, headed a group of business executives who conferred here today with Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 7 -- The Russians announced today that they had driven the Germans back from a favorable position in a strong counter-attack south of Izyum on the Donets River front, and late broadcasts from Berlin acknowledged that the Nazis were on the defensive at one point in this sector.

M.J. Sullivan, president of the American Can Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting in Flemington, N.J., yesterday, that the volume of business in the first quarter of this year was below that of last year. However, he added that in the similar period last year the government's restrictive orders on metals were not fully in effect and that during those months buying was on an unusually heavy scale in anticipation of such curtailment.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 6 -- Taking everything into consideration, Joseph Vincent McCarthy is highly pleased with his 1943 Yankees after the club's three exhibition games.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 6 -- Allied planes today continued this theatre's greatest air offensive, which was launched yesterday, when they took off more than 1,000 times to smash enemy airdromes from Sicily south to Sfax in Tunisia, destroy eighteen air transports, and leave ships flaming and ground fires leaping high enough into the sky to be seen for 100 miles.

Arthur De Bebian, chairman of the advertising division of the New York War Finance Committee, who is second vice president of the Chase National Bank, announced yesterday that retail advertisers would take the leadership in using newspaper advertising space in connection with the Second War Loan Drive, which will begin on Monday.

Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes's announcement that he was momentarily at peace with every one climaxed the last Book and Author luncheon of the season, held yesterday at the Hotel Astor, under the joint sponsorship of The New York Herald Tribune and the American Book Sellers Association.

ST. LOUIS, April 6 (AP) -- A compromise plan of reorganization for the Missouri Pacific Railroad, proposed to resolve differences between bondholder and stockholder interests, was considered today without definite action at a meeting of the debtor company's board of directors.

The so-called "Arizona Plan" is being explained to us by means of an exhibition that opened privately yesterday at the Metropolitan Museum (Gallery D 6) and that, beginning today, may be attended by the public. It is to remain there through April 27.

The bill passed by Congress restoring the rank of Commodore has been sent to the President. It was desired by the Navy to give naval officers of small groups of ships the status of flag-officers. In the British Navy the rank of Commodore is given temporarily only to senior officers commanding detached squadrons.

Autographs, books and other rarities were sold for $14,571 at a two-session auction which ended yesterday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, Inc. The sale included property of John Stuart Groves, Wilmington, Del.; Charles S. Thompson, Holton, Kan.; the estate of Wadsworth R. Lewis, Ridgefield, Conn., and others.

The names of eight girls and six boys who advanced to the finals of the Thomas Jefferson Bicentennial Essay Contest in the all-city judging held in the New York Times Hall on Friday were announced yesterday. All entries had been judged anonymously. The winners were as follows:

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Peter Golas, indicted today as the mysterious kingpin of a nation-wide beef black market conspiracy, denied tonight that there was anything mysterious about his far-flung packing-house enterprises.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 125 by 100 feet at 3000 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by a client of Kahn Posner through E. Osborne Smith, Inc., brokers. This structure contains fifty-four apartments.

Trousseau finery for the wartime bride was featured yesterday by Emma Maloof, 444 Madison Avenue, during a luncheon showing in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Beautiful long breakfast coats with matching gowns, a group of dinner-at-home gowns and several dinner pajamas made up a collection of handmade garments to delight the eye.

Representatives of approximately 100 associations of service station operators on the Eastern seaboard, who fear that another 20,000 stations may be forced out of business within the next six months, are planning to demand immediate relief at a conference scheduled for next Saturday and Sunday in Philadelphia, Sol A. Herzog, counsel for the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Association, announced yesterday.

A dispatch to this newspaper from Algiers throws some light on the situation of the political internees in North Africa. The picture is more encouraging than that presented at a mass meeting Monday night in Carnegie Hall, at which two officials of the Spanish Republic, former Foreign Minister Alvarez del Vayo and former Ambassador Fernando de los Rios, were among the speakers.

Moves which are expected to startle the over-the-counter securities business were taken yesterday by J. Arthur Warner Co., one of the largest firms in that field which deal at retail with the public. Realizing that a broker-dealer firm has a fiduciary responsibility to the public, regardless of the public's general ignorance of that responsibility, Mr. Warner announced that, effective May 1, his firm will serve the public only as a broker.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 7 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Net assets of Phoenix Securities Corporation on Feb. 28 last were equivalent to $22.25 a common share, a new high against $6.22 a share a year earlier and $9.32 a share on Aug. 31, 1942, according to the semi-annual report made public yesterday.

ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Todd-Murray bill permitting, under sharply restricted conditions, more general employment of women and minors between the ages of 16 and 18 in industries linked with, but not actually, a part of the war effort.

MILWAUKEE, April 6 (AP) -- The Bucyrus-Erie Company announced today a series of revisions in executive personnel which included the election of N.R. Knox to the presidency. He succeeds W.W. Coleman, president for thirty-two years. Mr. Coleman will remain as chairman of the board of directors.

The current economic boom in Brazil is "fantastic" in its size and scope and yet the signs are unmistakable that the country is on its way to an economic stability which may tend to consolidate the present commercial gains throughout the post-war period, Daniel A. del Rio, assistant to the vice president of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- William M. Jeffers, rubber director, said today that he expected the United States to be "over the hump" in rubber by this time next year, and he expressed a belief that synthetics eventually would take care of the country's needs.
LONDON, April 6 -- It can be said with reasonable certainty that, following the recent talks in Washington, the United States and Britain are not far apart in their attitude toward Russia.
" Counterattack" will end its run at the Adelphi on Saturday evening, April 17, after having played eighty-four performances divided between the latter house and the Windsor, where it first opened.

LONDON, April 6 -- The indomitable few thousands of Fighting French troops who completed a historic trek from the Chad territory, in Central Africa, when they entered Tripoli two days after General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery's troops, have since been in the thick of the battle for Tunisia.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Disclaiming any intention to threaten the National Labor Relations Board if it changed its present policy of permitting supervisors to form unions under protection of the Wagner act, Walter Nelson, counsel for the Foremen's Association of America, said today that despite any action by the board, supervisory staffs in industrial plants would continue to form organizations for collective bargaining.

Educational reconstruction, especially in those countries now under Axis domination, will be discussed today and tomorrow at a conference at New York University sponsored by the United States Committee on Educational Reconstruction in cooperation with the Central and Eastern European Planning Board.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- Marguerite Chapman, now in the feminine lead of "Appointment in Berlin" at Columbia is to have the role opposite Charles Coburn in that studio's "Without Notice," which is slated for production April 19.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Leaders of the divided Senate farm group, put on the defensive by President Roosevelt's veto of the Bankhead bill and his placing of inflation responsibility on Congress, moved late today to have the White House message and the measure he attacked committed to the Committee on Agriculture.

Direct methods aimed at spreading war contracts among distressed small plants in the New York-New Jersey region will be inaugurated at noon today with the formal opening of an exhibit arranged jointly by Major Gen. Clifford L. Corbin, chief of the procurement service of the Army Quartermaster Corps, and Colonel Robert W. Johnson, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 6 -- A million inhabitants of Santiago were badly shaken up shortly after noon today by a strong earth tremor which aroused fear of a repetition of the disastrous quake of January, 1939, that wrecked many towns and killed tens of thousands.

NEWARK, N.J., April 6 -- The Live Poultry Mart on Vanderpool Street here, one of the chief sources of supply for the metropolitan area, was thrown into an uproar today when eighty retailers, all-members of the New Jersey Retail Live Poultry Dealers Association, staged what they called "an anti-black market" demonstration.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- With an increased number of U-boats now operating against Allied shipping and apparently employing new tactics, the Battle of the Atlantic swung in favor of the Germans last month and the submarine sinking toll was "considerably worse" than in February, Secretary of the Navy Knox declared today at his press conference.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 6 -- A number of Senators and Congressmen "will be included among members of the United States delegation to the Anglo-American refugee conference here, according to information given to the Legislative Council this morning by F. Goodwin Gosling, chairman of the committee in charge of arrangements for accommodation of the delgates.

A sound way to budget your ration of fats -- at least, it seems so to this column -- is to use approximately a half as a spread for bread and as a seasoning for vegetables to employ about a third for general cookery -- biscuits, muffins waffles -- and to expend the remainder (in the form of oil) for salad dressings.

A recital was given last night by Valentina Vishnevska, soprano, at Town Hall before an enthusiastic audience that should have been larger, for it became apparent from the beginning that here was an artist of unusual sensitivity and intelligence.

LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- A special Soviet commission investigating alleged German atrocities in Russia accused the Nazis today of committing "acts of violence, tortures and murders against peaceful citizens as well as Soviet war prisoners."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 6 -- Mrs. Eve Hegeman, who led a placid life at her home on Bear Ridge Road in Pleasantville until four months ago, and who now is one of the nation's leading fabricators of camouflage nets for the Army, today moved her mushrooming business into a larger factory of 22,000 square feet here.
NEW DELHI, India, April 6 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 6 (AP) -- General Montgomery's fighting men moved forward against the entrenched German machine-gun and infantry positions with clock-like precision after a fierce bombardment through the night by concentrated British artillery.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 6 -- Mayor Thomas D. Taggart Jr. today took the witness stand in his State Supreme Court fight to regain city control at a hearing enlivened by a fist fight of two spectators for a front row seat.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A spokesman with broad authority to champion the cause of civilian needs in wartime is destined to be set up regardless of the action which Congress may take in regard to proposed legislation to establish an independent civilian supply agency to replace the Office of Civilian Supply now in the War Production Board.

The New York Trust Company plans to increase its capital by $2,500,000 to a total of $15,000,000, it was announced yesterday by John E. Bierwirth, president, following a meeting of the board of directors Under the plan the number of shares outstanding would be increased by 100,000 to a total of 600,000.

Johnstown, Pa., awarded yesterday a new issue of $185,000 of bonds, dated April 1, 1943 and due serially from 1944 to 1953, to a syndicate comprising Hemphill, Noyes Co., and three Pittsburgh firms, Phillips, Schmertz Co. S.K. Cunningham Co. and Moore, Leonard Lynch.

LONDON, April 6 -- The stock markets here remained rather quiet today pending the government's budget statement. Although business in most sections was small, prices showed a tendency to rise where there were transactions.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 6 (U.P.) -- Football's role this year, despite a considerable lowering of the quality of the nation's teams, will be to provide entertainment for members of the armed services and insure continuation of the game itself, Paul Brown, football coach of Ohio State University, said today.

OTTAWA, April 6 (Canadian Press) -- Arrangements to insure that producers of coarse grains in Western Canada benefit from higher prices obtained for the product when it is exported to the United States were announced today in the House of Commons by Trade Minister MacKinnon.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., April 6 -- The Giants invaded the outer rim of our coastal defenses today and by a display of fortitude that perhaps surpassed the dictates of prudence they trounced the soldier nine of Fort Hancock, 23 to 0.

The Senate Judiciary Committee, reversing an earlier stand, this week approved the McKellar bill requiring Senate confirmation of some 30,000 Federal employes receiving an annual salary of $4,500 or more. By strenuous efforts Mr. McKellar succeeded in having the Tennessee Valley Authority, with which he does not always see eye to eye in the matter of jobs, included in this blanket coverage.

LONDON, April 6 (U.P.) -- Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, indicated to the House today that a full-dress debate might be held in Commons on the British and American plans for post-war current stabilization, but he refused to be drawn out on the subject for the present.

Additional quarterly statements of conditions as of March 31 were issued yesterday by several banks, including two Wall Street institutions which for several years had reported total assets of almost equal amounts. The two, the Bankers Trust Company and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, have had a nip-and-tuck, but quite unofficial, race for the rank of fourth largest bank in Wall Street.

CHALLIS, Idaho, April 6 (AP) -- Five Army fliers who balled out of a bomber a week ago are safe at an isolated mountain cabin while planes are searching the Central Idaho wilderness for four other members of the crew and one of the searching craft, which failed to return to base.

Mayor La Guardia promised last night to "break up" any black market in New York "before it can get started." On his return to La Guardia Field after a conference in Washington with Food Administrator Chester C. Davis, the Mayor said he felt satisfied that he and Mr. Davis "see eye to eye."

LONDON, April 6 (U.P.) -- Sir Kingsley Wood, Chancellor of the Exchequer, indicated to the House today that a full-dress debate might be held in Commons on the British and American plans for post-war current stabilization, but he refused to be drawn out on the subject for the present.

Additional quarterly statements of conditions as of March 31 were issued yesterday by several banks, including two Wall Street institutions which for several years had reported total assets of almost equal amounts. The two, the Bankers Trust Company and the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, have had a nip-and-tuck, but quite unofficial, race for the rank of fourth largest bank in Wall Street.

CHALLIS, Idaho, April 6 (AP) -- Five Army fliers who balled out of a bomber a week ago are safe at an isolated mountain cabin while planes are searching the Central Idaho wilderness for four other members of the crew and one of the searching craft, which failed to return to base.

Mayor La Guardia promised last night to "break up" any black market in New York "before it can get started." On his return to La Guardia Field after a conference in Washington with Food Administrator Chester C. Davis, the Mayor said he felt satisfied that he and Mr. Davis "see eye to eye."

Large space on the eighth floor of the Architects Building, 101 Park Avenue, has been leased by Anthracite Industries, Inc., a trade association of coal operators, through Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., brokers.
CAPE GIRARDEAU, Mo., April 6 -- Manager Luke Sewell of the Browns was philosophic today over the discouraging outlook for his team, once highly regarded as a pennant contender.

BETUL, Central Provinces, India, April 3 (Delayed) -- One of the problems that makes the administration of India the most complicated of any country in the world is the aboriginals, those jungle tribes that have lived here long before the Aryans came down from the North.

Contributions of $857,000 have been received by the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City within the last week, it was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the campaign. These bring the current total of the fund to $11,511, 000, or almost 89 per cent of the goal of $12,920,700 that has been set as New York City5s share of the national quota of $125,000,000.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Following is the "preliminary draft outline of proposal for a United and Associated Nations Stabilization Fund" announced by the Treasury:

The garage on a plot 113.2 by 100 feet at 642 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the S.L. Bruck Estate, Inc., to Eve Abramowitz, subject to a mortgage of $18,651. Louis J. Sieven was the broker. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

Because the French Club at New York University sent food and money to "adopted" French children as long as was possible, and because the children live in the same towns that many of the battleship Richelieu's sailors come from, more than eighty members of that vessel's crew will break a precedent Saturday evening by singing and acting at a soiree presented by the club in the School of Education auditorium, Washington Square.
LONDON, Wednesday, April 7 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Tuesday midnight communique, as broadcast by Moscow:

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- State directors of the Farm Security Administration from eleven States ranging from Maryland to Maine have reported that farmers are not worrying about prices, J.H. Wood, regional FSA director, said today. He suggested that some of the "so-called spokesmen" of the farmers in Washington and elsewhere should find out what the men on the farms really were thinking about.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, ended its New York season at Carnegie Hall last night with a splash. Assisted by four soloists, all members of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and by the ranks of the chorus of the Westminster Choir School, the orchestra made a gala closing of it by doing Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Otto S. Beyer, Director of Transport Personnel in the Office of Defense Transportation, said today that 65,187 women were employed in seventy-four types of jobs on the country's railroads in January, as against 39,590 in forty-nine jobs in September, representing an increase of almost 60 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The farm bloc strategy that produced the move in the Senate today to recommit the Bankhead bill is based generally on the lack of an over-all labor policy and labor agency in the Administration. Because of the lack other special legislative interests can never be sure when, whether and in what quantity wage concessions will be made to labor.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 7 (AP) -- Salamaua and Finschhafen in New Guinea, Cape Gloucester and Gasmata in New Britain and the islands of Aru and Tenimber have been bombed in new raids by Allied planes, the High Command announced today.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- Liquidation of grain futures induced by reports that the Senate farm bloc would not be able to pass the Bankhead-Steagall bill over President Roosevelt's veto carried prices of wheat and rye off aruond 3 cents a bushel at one time today on the Board of Trade, and oats dropped 1 3/4 cents before the selling movement ran its course.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Army has issued new regulations prohibiting any men on active duty from seeking or accepting any public office not held by them at the time they entered service.

HONOLULU, April 6 (U.P.) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the United States Pacific Fleet, sent an Army Day message to soldiers in the Pacific today in which he praised the Army's fighting spirit as "an inspiration to all hands."

TORONTO, Ont., April 6 -- Civilian ranks in Canada are being kept solidly behind their military forces without "homefront hysteria creating shortages and black market gyp prices because the Canadian Government had confidence in business men and appointed them to manage wartime prices and trade," David R. Craig, president of the American Retail Federation, told Dominion merchants here today.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The President saw a group of Congressional leaders, the Bolivian Ambassador and General David Toru and Budget Director Smith, and held a press conference.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 6 -- The Foreign Ministry announced today that Juan Antonio Rios, President of Chile, had accepted an invitation to visit Argentina on his return from his trip to the United States, where he is scheduled to go at the end of June.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The economy drive on Capitol Hill struck home today as the House Appropriations Committee recommended that Congress get along with less money during the fiscal year starting July 1 than it had for the current year.

CHICAGO, April 6 (AP) -- The Multnomah Athletic Club of Portland, Ore., was considered favorite to win the team championship of the senior women's national A.A.U. swimming and diving meet until Wave came along today.

Despite the new order restricting hard-surface floor covering manufacturers to 50 per cent of the linseed oil used in the base period, yardage output should continue at 65 to 75 per cent of the 1940-41 level, it was estimated in the trade yesterday.

One comment on THE TIMES story about college freshmen and their ignorance of American history was inevitable and proper. The director of the Philadelphia public schools thinks that the test put an old-fashioned emphasis on names and places.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Not only must the American Red Cross meet the immediate problems created by the war but it must face the staggering task of aiding in the rehabilitation of the war-torn world, Thomas W. Lamont, chairman of the Red Cross War Fund's National Advisory Committee, declared here today.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, now director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, received the gold medal of Pi Lambda Phi fraternity for humanitarian services last night at the fraternity's annual Founders Day dinner in the Hotel Biltmore.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 6 -- Following the lead of factories in England, American industry in the East is solving one phase of its labor problem by employing women on a part-time basis. At the Johnson Johnson plant here nearly 300 women, including college girls and housewives, are working from three to twenty-four hours a week to turn out surgical dressings.

In the post-Dunkerque days of June, 1940, when a German invasion of Great Britain appeared imminent, Prime Minister Winston Churchill was prepared to await the enemy's arrival in Downing Street and shoot at them until they shot him, a British officer was quoted here yesterday as saying.
