Raymond B. Fosdick, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, in a review of some of the foundation's activities during 1942 made public yesterday, announced the development of a new type of vaccine against yellow fever that makes the African continent, and other lands where this dread disease is rampant, safe for soldiers and sailors of the United States and its allies.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 7 Roane Waring, national commander of the American Legion, is at the fighting front in North Africa. His movements since the last week in February had not been announced.

LONDON, April 7 -- Aware of the unprecedented Nazi looting of occupied countries, the United Nations have agreed on a scheme to recover as much as possible, Viscount Simon, Lord Chancellor, revealed in the House of Lords today.

Having alloted himself ample time for the improvement of his musical comedy offering, "My Dear Public," Irving Caesar reported yesterday he had lined up Ethel Shutta, Susan Miller, Fred Keating, John Philliber and Rose Brown for the cast, which will star Willie Howard.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- In an appeal here tonight on behalf of the Red Cross, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt described the organization as "part of our actual fighting forces," saying that, in many cases, "what it has given has kept the spirit alive in the men at the front to go on with the fight."

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Educational authorities from a dozen States, supported by a score of spokesmen for educational and civic organizations, warned a Senate education subcommittee today that failure to pass promptly a pending measure proposing $300,000,000 a year in Federal aid to education would result in a breakdown of the country's public school system under the impact of the war program.

New England fishing guides expect to receive supplemental gasoline allowances to use in transporting anglers to some of the backwoods locations where the big trout lurk, according to the report received from the New Hampshire Fish and Game Department.

Harper Sibley, attorney and former national president of the United Service Organizations, has been elected chairman of the newly organized Church Committee on Overseas Relief and Reconstruction of the Federal Council of Churches and the Foregin Missions Conference.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -Easing its prohibition against the use of steel for non-essential purposes, the War Production Board authorized today limited manufacture of many civilian products containing the metal.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 7 -- The Giants continued their pounding of our coastal defenses today but, happily, it still was only baseball and all in fun.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A measure to clamp down on excessive profits of commission agents on government war contracts, gained unanimous endorsement from the House Naval Committee today.

LONDON, April 7 -- Commenting on a Reuter report from North Africa, which said late tonight that General Dwight D. Eisenhower had expressed surprise at the French National Committee's statement on the postponement of General de Gaulle's visit, a spokesman for the Fighting French said the National Committee was just as surprised when General Eisenhower's telegram reached here.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 7 -- At least 500 Allied planes bombed and strafed Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's rear airfields yesterday in coordination with the British Eighth Army's land blow, while others striking at Sicily and the Mediterranean narrows off Tunisia sank or damaged at least seventeen more Axis ships, of which at least seven were sunk.

YORK, Pa., April 7 -- Century Ribbon Mills, Inc., of New York proudly flew an Army-Navy "E" flag over their York plant tonight, the fifth such banner floating over this city, as 150 women employes moved happily through the roar and clatter of looms, where tape and webbing for the armed forces are woven.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The reported refusal of General Dwight D. Eisenhower to permit General Charles de Gaulle to proceed from London to North Africa at this time for a conference with General Henri Honore Giraud is not going to be upset from here, according to all indications today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (U.P.) -- Forty-five State Selective Service directors endorsed the principle of the Austin-Wadsworth labor draft bill at an extraordinary meeting today with members of the Senate and House Military Affairs Committees.

Seven New York State labor market areas in which labor shortages exist, or are expected within six months, are indicated on a pictograph map of the State issued yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 7 (AP) -communique:

"Dixie Dugan," a Twentieth Century-Fox film based on the comic strip character, will open this morning at the Palace. Lois Andrews appears in the title role, with Charles Ruggles, Charlotte Greenwood, James Ellison, Helene Reynolds and Raymond Walburn among the featured players.
Boxing will return to Madison Square Garden in a big way when the elephants, lions and clowns have cleared out after their long stay.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A fight to restore to the National Resources Planning Board the funds necessary for its continued existence and incidentally assure Congressional consideration of its recent proposals for social security and post-war economic conversation will begin before the Senate Appropriations Committee Friday morning.

Nine "iron lungs," purchased for service men and seamen with a fund raised by 8,000 employes of Schenley Distillers Corporation throughout the country, were presented yesterday to the Army, Navy and merchant marine in a ceremony in the Empire State Club at 350 Fifth Avenue.

Indications are that the retirement of railroad bonds, which assumed large proportions last year, will continue throughout this year. According to a report recently made to the Interstate Commerce Commission, thirty of the leading solvent railroad companies made last year net reductions of $296,600,000 in debt.

It is gratifying to find, packed between articles of war and post-war problems, an editorial such as "The Bud," which I read with keen delight in the April 4 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Despite its peaceful subject-matter, it is obvious that the editor is not unmindful of the present worldwide struggle.

WEST POINT, N.Y., April 7 -Army opened its intercollegiate baseball campaign today and shut out Swarthmore, 9 -- 0, on Doubleday Field. The cadets had already been out against the Dodgers and Montreal who have been training in this region, but this was their initial intercollegiate contest.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -Failing Axis air strength in Tunisia indicates that the Luftwaffe is strained to its utmost, Director Elmer Davis of the Office of War Information said today. It appears "very doubtful," in his opinion, that Germany is holding back any large reserves of planes in Europe.

Revealing that more than 1,500,000 New Yorkers already have contributed to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund here, John P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the fund, predicted yesterday that another 500,000 would join them within the next few weeks. He declared that their gifts would carry the fund over the top in its drive to raise $12,920,700.

Under the title "International Clearing Union," the British plan for post-war stabilization of world trade and currencies was released in London yesterday and also given out here by the British Treasury through the British Information Service, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

One of the things that every woman knows is the contrary quality of cosmetics. At precisely the moment when you count on them to make you look your best, everything goes completely haywire. Powder looks too dark, rouge too light and lipstick insists on smearing in a most exasperating fashion.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 8 (U.P.) -- Allied airmen attacked fifteen enemy targets, including a three-ship convoy at Kavieng, along a 1,500-mile stretch of islands and waterways above Australia yesterday, and scored near-misses beside a Japanese destroyer off Bougainville Island in the Northern Solomons, General Douglas MacArthur's communique revealed today.

American leadership in competition with other nations in international affairs, hard work and private enterprise in domestic affairs, and the strengthening of State's rights at home, were urged by Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio last night as post-war measures for maintaining world peace and national prosperity.

CHICAGO, April 7 (U.P.) -- The National Football League today moved to meet a stringent manpower problem by the reduction of its player limit and then sought to solve a transportation problem by following big-league baseball's example and voting for "at-home" training camps.

Public offering of a block of 18,750 shares of capital stock of J.P. Morgan Co., Inc., representing the entire holdings in the bank of J.P. Morgan, who died on March 13, will be made today by Morgan Stanley Co.; Smith, Barney Co., and a group of twenty-five other underwriters, including the First Boston Corporation, Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., and Kidder, Peabody Co.

Another alleged former prostitute at the Hermitage Hotel, in Seventh Avenue near Forty-second Street, was being interrogated yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Alexander-Dreiband in the Special Sessions trial of the three alleged owners of the hotel on vice charges, when one of the three jurists declared that the testimony was too objectionable.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- After two days in which no communiques were issued on aerial activity either in the North or South Pacific, the Navy announced today a resumption of attacks both against Kiska and against Japanese positions in the Central Solomons.

JERSEY CITY, April 7 -- Testimony that directors of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company received more than $1,000,000 in bonuses in the first five years of operation of the company's incentive compensation plan was given today before Vice Chancellor Charles M. Egan in Chancery Court.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 7 (AP) -Brig. Gen. Auby C. Strickland, commander of United States fighter pilots in the Western Desert, said today that "the effort put forth by American fliers in the last week is one for the books."

Though the Russians have officially ended their Winter offensive there is one front which they still keep under heavy pressure. That is the Kuban valley, where the Nazis maintain a last precarious grip on the Caucasus. There, in a narrowing circle, they cling to all that is left of Hitler's hope of seizing Russia's oil fields.
Continuing its sales of repossessed real estate in Manhattan, the Manhattan Savings Bank has disposed of four more properties.

Price-fixing by the cotton trade for Southern mills against current orders of the government for twills sustained the cotton futures market at moderate increases yesterday and won back almost all of the preceding session's losses. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts, in a small market, worked to closing gains of 11 to 15 points, the day's peak.

Selling to garner accumulated profits again yesterday stalled the forward movement in the stock market, but, as in the previous session, the forces for the advance resumed command of proceedings in the afternoon. Losses, which ran to 2 points in the railroad issues, were reduced generally to fractions at the close as some prime industrial stocks assumed the task of righting the list.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -Republican Representatives attacked in the House today the Army's restrictions on political activities of soldiers, with two of the speakers raising the question of its effect on consideration of General MacArthur for the Presidency.

There isn't much to talk about in "Something to Shout About", now at Loew's Criterion. To say that it falls into a familiar pattern would be an understatement. To say that the script and direction are as inept as we've seen in a month of musicals would be putting it mildly.

There has been a great deal of publicity in newspapers and magazines and over the radio recently about the need of day-care centers for the children of working mothers during wartime. This is not a new need in New York City but one that has been recognized as a community need for years.

The City Club of New York and the Citizens Union called upon Mayor La Guardia yesterday to resign his office if and when he enters military service. Both civic organizations coupled their suggestions of resignation with vigorous condemnation of the Ostertag law, under which the Mayor would be able to take a military leave of absence and delegate some of his powers to a deputy of his own choice.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Scattered selling of September corn which disclosed a lack of aggressive demand for a short time and brought about a break of 3/4 cent a bushel below the ceiling price, the first outright trading below the latter in some weeks, unsettled the grain markets today on the Board of Trade.

With a record field of eighteen named for the Experimental Free Handicap, victory gardens located at various places, threats of a strike vanishing into conversations, parking spaces closed and pleasant weather predicted, Jamaica is set to open the New York and Eastern racing season today.

Trade groups in the women's and children's apparel field expressed favorable reaction yesterday to amendment No. 4 to MPR No. 287 which goes into effect next Monday. This amendment provides a simplified method for manufacturers to calculate labor costs under the week-work system of production and permits estimating and averaging of such costs.

Operating for the first time under completely "surprise' conditions, the Fifth Brigade of the State Guard repelled "enemy invasions" at three places of public assembly in Brooklyn and the Bronx last night, proving that in case of an emergency the brigade would be ready for immediate action.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -Hermann Rauschning who indicted the Nazi regime in his books, "The Revolution of Nihilism" and "The Voice of Destruction," will arrive on Monday under contract to Paramount, to collaborate with Albert and Frances Hackett on the screen play for "Hitler's Gang."
NEWARK, N.J., April 7 (AP) -- The decree entered here today is the latest step in anti-trust litigation which the Justice Department started against the Standard Oil Company and subsidiaries.

LONDON, April 7 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill gave the House of Commons good news from Tunisia in an unexpected statement today, supplementing the communique from Allied headquarters with later information and details.

High real estate taxes and special imposts have been powerful factors in a general decline of retail business in New York City, Walter Hoving, chairman of the Committee to Balance the Budget Through Sensible Economies, declared yesterday in a statement issued on the eve of a public hearing before the Board of Estimate on Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44.

LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force disclosed through a commentator today that American heavy bombers in their daylight attack on March 18 at Vegesack had inflicted severe damage on seven of 15 U-boats building there.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 7 (U.P.) -- The Tribune de Lausanne, quoting a letter from German Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop to Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, Chief of State in the Vichy Government, said today that General Maxime Weygand, as general delegate for North Africa, had received special instructions from President Roosevelt to collaborate with the Allies.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Taking another step toward the day when it expects to send armies of occupation into conquered territories, the War Department has established a new Civil Affairs Division in the Office of the Chief of Staff.
Following are the chief portions of addresses made yesterday at The New York Times Hall on "What Kind of a World Do We Want?"

A further increase was made last week in oil stocks along the Atlantic Coast, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period the institute's index, covering gasoline and light and heavy fuel oils, stood at 30.5, compared with 29.7 a week earlier and 58.3 on Nov. 7, 1942, when a downward trend started.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, April 6 (Delayed; via Algiers) -- The resumption of the Eighth Army's offensive began this morning. The preparatory fire was the heaviest yet and from more guns than were ever concentrated previously in this theatre.
MOSCOW April 7 (AP) -- The noon communique:

A result of a two-weeks' survey of the reference and informational services of the New York Public Library made public yesterday by Francis R. St. John, Chief of the Circulation Department, disclosed that during a fourteen-day period in March librarians in the sixty-five branches of the library answered 137,782 questions for information and lent 339,729 books.

If there was any doubt about the ability of members of the various branches of the New York War Price and Rationing Board to answer questions on the subject of gasoline and tire rationing, it was dispelled last night at a dinner at the New York Athletic Club when more than 150 members of boards met.

New State and municipal financing in March amounted to $50,670,378, compared with $51,234,791 in the same month last year, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. For the first quarter of this year, allowing for a revised figure of $61,335,700 for February, the total of new State and municipal flotations was $173,178,719, compared with $216,269,012 in the first three months of 1942.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The President opened the Treasury's second war loan drive and saw Secretary Wickard; Chester C. Davis, Food Administrator; and farm organization leaders; Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower chairman; Postmaster General Walker and Secretary Hull.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 8 (AP) -- The noon communique:
LOS ANGELES, April 7 -- Shielded from all intrusions Mme. Chiang Kai-shek today rested comfortably in her Ambassador Hotel suite following a nervous collapse Tuesday night.
Despite reports that Mayor La Guardia is seeking a commission in the Army, he disclosed jokingly yesterday afternoon that the job he really wanted was that of college president.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 7 -President Enrique Penaranda and his Cabinet tonight promulgated a decree putting Bolivia in the war as a partner of the United Nations against the Axis -- the second South American country to take up arms -- and calling for general mobilization.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- British counter-proposals to the United States Treasury's post-war currency stabilization plan were made public here and in London today. Like the American plan, the British plan is offered on an exploratory basis without government commitment, and both aim at the similar objectives of currency stability and international trade free of restrictions.

Directors of the New York Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation have appointed officers for the new year: Fred C. Moffatt, president; David U. Page, vice president; James A. Corcoran, second vice president; William B. Steinhardt, secretary and treasurer; Austin K. Neftel, assistant treasurer, and C.E. Sheridan, assistant secretary.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 7 -- Premier Per Albin Hansson's coalition Cabinet faces a "near-crisis" as a result of dissatisfaction with its allegedly "unneutral policy, detrimental to Norwegian patriots fighting the German invaders."

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 7 -- The present stability of the war fronts in the South and Southwest Pacific is not likely to continue much longer. The ingredients for a flare-up of action have been cooking for some time on both sides, and it its reasonable to surmise that the brew will come to a boil before long.

ALBANY, April 7 -- The highest number of new stock corporations since May, 1942, were formed in March and the highest capitalization since April, 1942, was recorded, Secretary of State Curran revealed today. There were 714 corporations chartered last month, with an aggregate capitalization of $8,173,795, of which 461 elected to issue stock shares of no par value.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 7 -- Meeting the Newark Bears for the third time, the Yankees today walloped their International League farm link by 14 to 0 before a gathering of 3,584.

CALLANDER, Ont., April 7 (U.P.) -- The Dionne quintuplets today received morocco-encased invitations from United States Secretary of State Cordell Hull to visit Superior, Wis., May 9 and christen five new cargo ships for the British merchant navy. It will be the Quints' first trip to the United States.

LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- The Bishop of St. Albans asked the government in the House of Lords today whether the manufacture of contraceptives was regarded officially as work of national importance in recruiting labor and received the reply of "No, sir," from the Earl of Munster.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 7 -- The American force moving southward from El Guettar and the left wing of the British Eighth Army met on the Gafsa-Gabes road today after the Eighth Army had smashed the Germans' Wadi el Akarit position north of Gabes and taken more than 5,000 prisoners.

LONDON, April 7 -- The Labor party as well as the Labor Ministers in the government are uncommitted as to the political composition of any post-war government, Clement R. Attlee, Deputy Prime Minister and leader of the Labor party, told a private meeting of the Parliamentary Labor party today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Maritime Commission's goal of 18,000,000 tons of ships this year is threatened by manpower shortages which have become "critical," Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the commission, said today.

ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Dewey today vetoed the Brady bill which would have permitted the release of well-behaved first offenders from prison, provided they entered the armed forces or engaged in essential war work.
MOSCOW, April 7 -- For the fifth successive day the Germans attacked the Russians' Izyum bridgehead on the middle Donets yesterday without gaining any ground.

Shad are in the limelight at Fulton Fish Market, for the peak of their season is fast approaching. So declared a spokesman for the Fishery Council as he conducted the writer on a tour of that huge open-air establishment.

It is imperative that a drastic withholding tax should be put into effect without a day's unnecessary delay. Such a tax would be the Treasury's greatest single source of revenue. It is an absolutely essential measure if we hope to combat inflation. It is the only form of income tax that will siphon off excessive purchasing power from the great mass of those who have it.

The release of men's sports shoes from rationing in the Northern section of the country was held likely in the trade yesterday following reports from Washington that the Office of Price Administration planned such a move to free the frozen stocks of these numbers held by retailers and manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- World peace can come only through a global organization in which the United States must play a definite and not a passive part, even to maintenance of peace by force, Summer Welles, Under-Secretary of State, told a luncheon of the Institute of Pacific Relations today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 7 -- Bolivia's decision to recognize a state of war with the Axis powers came as a surprise to Chileans and the situation was analyzed with only lukewarm approval today by two leading papers here, the Mercurio and the Nacion.
In a recent address before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York Sumner Welles said:

Although deaths and injuries resulting from motor vehicle accidents in New York State during 1942 decreased in comparison with 1941, the percentages of decrease were considerably short of the reduction in the number of miles driven, according to the Victory edition of Motor Vehicle Safety, a pamphlet issued yesterday by the New York Bureau of Motor Vehicles.

The Brooklyn Museum's twelfth biennial water-color exhibition will open with a preview for museum members and invited guests this afternoon. The show, which will be open to the public tomorrow and will remain on view through May 23, contains 219 papers, installed both in the Special Exhibitions Gallery and in the large entrance hall.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 7 -- Sacajawea, white and liver pointer bitch, owned by Euclid Claussen of Augusta, Ga., and handled by Fred Bevan of High Point, N.C., won the open puppy stake, with twenty entries, that launched the English Setter Club of America's Spring meeting today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Release from existing price ceilings on their products was asked of the Office of Price Administration today by a group of manufacturers of carded cottons. The plea was carried directly to Prentiss M. Brown by the mill owners.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday that he had suspended from duty the previous night a sergeant and two patrolmen involved in the Houdini-like handling of cash which an elderly man, now under observation in the Bellevue psychiatric division, had reported that he had cached in his tenement home in Harlem.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, April 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -The British Eighth Army, sweeping across the flat plain before Gabes Gap under cover of a violent artillery barrage, burst into the thickets Axis defenses on Wadiel Akarit just as the sun rose over the Mediterranean today.
LONDON, April 7 -- The scope of Russian purchases of non-military supplies through the United Kingdom Commercial Corporation was disclosed today.

WENDELL L. WILLKIE'S "One World"* is the work of an engaging personality who is quite breathless with a sense of discovery. Willkie has had the opportunity, given to few men in these days of strict passport regulations, practically no commercial travel, rigid currency restrictions and ubiquitous secret police "security'' regulations, of girdling the earth in a four-engined Consolidated bomber.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Turning threatened defeat into a tactical victory, the Senate farm group saved the Bankhead bill today from death by Presidential veto by sending it to the Committee on Agriculture.

LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- The Axis' Tunisian stand is fast becoming a death-trap for Italy's already hard-hit shipping, with British submarine attacks on a light cruiser, two tankers and a supply ship raising to forty or more the number of Italian ships sunk or badly damaged in a single week of the Allied naval-aerial onslaught.
A special German communique as broadcast Wednesday by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Ensign Arthur R. Hess, Lieut. Leo F. Mahan, Lieut. Robert H. Becker, Margaret C. Sommer, Lieut. Harry H. Threlkeld, Lieut. Grinnell Jones Jr., Einar Beyer, Beatrice Mulligan, Hugh L. Mulligan, Malcolm B. Varney, Arnold P. Plues, Mrs. Julia Leon, Mrs. Elizabeth R. Betts, Angela M. Caramore, Woodrow S. Leafer, Mrs. Leonora O. Stephens, Vee Scavon, in Tudor City, through the Fred F. French Management Co.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (U.P.) -- The Justice Department announced today the filing of a supplemental judgment against Standard Oil Company (N.J.), making available to all persons at a reasonable royalty rate some of the concern's patented processes for making high octane gasoline.

Resentment appeared yesterday to be the principal reaction of the over-the-counter trade to the announcement that J. Arthur Warner Co., one of the biggest houses in the retail group, had decided to put all their dealings with the public on an agency basis, effective May 1.

The total market value of shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose $2,307,076,624 last month, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. Average price per share of all listed stocks on March 31 was $31,20, compared with $29.61 at the end of February.
NEW DELHI, India, April 7 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, April 7 (U.P.) -- Thirteen Americans of Polish extraction and one Texas-born Irishman who wanted to fight in a hurry entered an American recruiting station today and transferred from the Polish to the .American Air Force.

Recently I have talked with many who are in close association with high school students and all tell me that the girls, even those from 12 to 18, are so imbued with the spirit of service that teachers are constantly bombarded with the query, "What can we do to contribute something to the war effort?"

Burton B. Turkus, Assistant District Attorney, demanded the death penalty yesterday for Charles J. Farley, 26-year-old nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, and Louis Caridad, 24, before Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein and a blue ribbon jury.

TRENTON, April 7 -- A request for action on the twenty-one executive nominations now being held in the Senate Judiciary Committee was sent today to the eighteen Republican members of the Senate by State Republican Chairman H. Alexander Smith, who also urged the Senate to pass the Assembly's constitutional referendum bill.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 (AP) -Bayonet fighting and ju-jitsu will be all the rage as spectator sports after the war, drawing bigger crowds than professional boxing and wrestling, William J. Herrmann said today.

The use of extreme caution against the heedless circulation of unchecked and often un founded rumors was urged upon the public yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, regional director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Mail boxes at farm gates in several parts of the country have been given coats of yellow paint by neighbors recently, a disturbing consequence of the Administration's confused manpower policy. Within those gates are young men who left the farm to take jobs in war industries and returned when they heard of the drive in Congress to make a blanket deferment of agricultural workers.

Gains in the net asset value of a share in the Lehman Corporation have raised it to $34.54, topping the $33.33 originally paid in 1929, according to a report yesterday by Robert Lehman, president, on the first nine months of the investment trust's current fiscal year.

LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Edward Orlando Kellett, well known big-game hunter and Conservative member of the House of Commons from the Aston division of Birmingham, has been killed in action with the British Eighth Army in North Africa, it was announced today.

BOSTON, April 7 -- The Detroit Red Wings stand on the threshold of the hockey championship of the world. They defeated the Bruins at the Boston Garden tonight, 4 to 0, and in so doing drew within one game of snaring the Stanley Cup and the honor that goes with it.
George W. Fischer was elected yesterday an assistant trust officer of the Fifth Avenue Bank of New York.

The Office of Price Administration is now ready to start a vigorous drive to enforce retail food price ceilings with the help of the New York City Department of Markets, Walter Gellhorn, regional OPA attorney, said yesterday. The enforcement drive is being timed to start with the increasing use of "flat" ceilings in place of outdated "freeze" ceilings that have been in effect on most commodities since last Summer.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -A group of Democrats formed today in support of a drive for immediate reconsideration of pay-as-you-go income tax legislation, and Majority Leader McCormack of Massachusetts expressed hope that the House might vote again on this knotty issue before it begins an Easter recess April 17.

Argentinita and her little company of Spanish dancers stepped into the breach made by the cancellation of "Romeo and Juliet" in last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, and walked away with the honors of the evening.

LONDON, April 7 -- The women of this country won a major political victory today. Their long fought battle against sex discrimination under the war injury compensation plan came to a close when Sir Walter Womersley, Minister of Pensions, announced in the House of Commons that, beginning April 19, women would receive the same payment from the government for injuries resulting from air raids as those heretofore paid to men.

LONDON, Thursday, April 8 (U.P.) -- German tanks, shock troops and air forces, after suffering heavy losses in days of persistent attacks on the Izyum sector of the Donets River front, have given up, if only for the moment, and activity has subsided, the Soviet midnight communique announced today.

Madison Square Garden had its annual mass of confusion all day yesterday. But when night fell the booming turmoil of ringing hammers, snorting elephants, prancing horses and bodies hurtling through empty space, had given way to what resembled the 1943 version of the Ringling Brothers, Barnum and Bailey Circus.
LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

PHILADELPHIA, April 7 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today to the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation the right to reduce the stated value of its $6 preferred capital stock from $150,000,000 to $15,000,000, or from $100 a share to $10.

Mid-season pitching by Sanford Silverstein in a relief role carried New York University's baseball team to another victory over C.C. N.Y. yesterday, the Violets winning, 5 to 2, in a spirited contest played before a somewhat slender and frost-bitten crowd at Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Department of Agriculture's order under which livestock slaughterers were required to set aside certain percentages of their production for government purchase was suspended for an indefinite period today by the War Food Administration to facilitate a more even flow of meat under the rationing program.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 7 -They may have made a lot of friends, but the Dodgers did not influence a lot of people today when the Brooks dropped in for a visit at Yale. Of course, the major leaguers won, but it was hardly the anticipated rout.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A $24,551,070,000 appropriation for the Navy for the fiscal year of 1944, the largest amount ever sought for the sea-fighting forces in one year, has been requested of Congress by President Roosevelt, it was learned tonight.

A nation-wide syndicate of forty-one investment banking houses of which Smith, Barney Co. and Glore, Forgan Co. are managers will offer today a new issue of $20,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 3 per cent series due in 1958, of Wilson Co., Inc., Chicago, one of the large meat packing concerns.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Office of War Information tonight issued these questions and answers designed to clarify confusion over food rationing:

Small New York manufacturers in a variety of fields received an opportunity yesterday to bid for war orders on thirty items, when an exhibit arranged jointly by the Army Quartermaster Corps and the Smaller War Plants Corporation was opened in Room 725 at the Chanin Building.
LONDON, Thursday, April 8 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique, as broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

NEW DELHI, India, April 7 (U.P.) -- British and Indian troops have withdrawn thirteen miles from their advanced positions in Burma's Mayu Peninsula to avoid being trapped by Japanese who infiltrated behind their lines, and further withdrawals are expected, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- A decision as to whether the rent-control program of the Office of Price Administration shall continue to function along the present lines or be modified in accordance with requests of the National Association of Real Estate Boards is likely from Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, within a week to ten days.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday an amendment to the capital outlay budget for 1943, providing for expenditure of $200,000 for studies and plans for a wholesale produce market in lower Manhattan to replace Washington Market.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Club owners of the National Football League, at their annual meeting here, cut the player limit today from thirty-three to twenty-five to meet manpower difficulties, and voted to permit free substitutions of players in-and-out of games for the 1943 season against the wishes of most of the coaches.

The Government of the United States is preparing "very shortly" to add the re-education of postwar Europe to the discussions with the United Nations, which already include conferences on food, refugees and the international monetary system, it was disclosed here yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 7 (U.P.) -A special Allied communique today disclosed the long-awaited meeting of the British and American Armies. Front dispatches indicated that they might have trapped and captured numerous Axis troops below the Gafsa-Gabes road.

The United Jewish Appeal's Greater New York Campaign officially gets under way this week, Alexander E. Arnstein, general chairman announced yesterday. William L. Batt, Vice chairman of the War Production Board, is scheduled to speak at a campaign dinner Wednesday night at the Hotel Plaza.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Roosevelt sold a $25 war bond today to one of his Negro messengers and two $100 bonds to a White House girl supervisor and thus started the government's campaign to dispose of $13,000,000,000 of the securities to the people this month.

It was announced in Washington yesterday that the Declaration of Independence has been taken out of its wartime hiding place and, guarded by Marines and resting "in a heavy steel case with bullet-proof glass," may be seen by the public next week at the opening of the Jefferson Memorial.

No doubt exists that Mayor La Guardia has been, and is being, considered for some kind of war job that will take him temporarily or permanently out of City Hall. The rank, title and duties proposed for him are of secondary importance. We think that before this matter goes any further a few questions ought to be asked and answered.

To assist in the training of thousands of volunteers, an illustrated "Handbook for Nurses Aides," has been written by Katharine T. Orbison and will be published on April 25 by Devin-Adair. Miss Orbison, a graduate of Vassar and of the Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, is a member of the New York Junior League and an authorized Red Cross Nurse's Aide Instructor in Westchester County.

WITH THE SECOND UNITED STATES CORPS, in Tunisia, April 7 (Via Algiers) -- Advance elements of the American forces met the forward patrols of the British Eighth Army just south of Djebel Chemsi along the road from Gafsa Oasis to the seaport of...

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, appeared in Brooklyn Adolescent Court yesterday in connection with his investigations of anti-American and anti-Semitic activities to press charges of disorderly conduct against six Brooklyn youths accused of throwing stones through the windows of Congregation Ohab Zedek at 954 Jefferson Avenue, Brooklyn, and thereby desecrating the congregation's service flag.

The bituminous wage negotiations, affecting 450,000 miners, reached another crisis yesterday when the operators, declaring that the negotiations were hopelessly deadlocked, took steps to have the dispute taken over by the National War Labor Board in defiance of the opposition to such action by the United Mine Workers, headed by John L. Lewis.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A Russian merchant ship dodged two torpedoes from an enemy submarine in the North Atlantic early in January, the Navy reported today, and scored one and probably two direct hits on the submarine with its deck guns.

A bulletin from the battlefield in Tunisia last night announced the long-hoped-for news of a union between the British and American forces. General Montgomery and his veteran Eighth Army are driving up the coast. One week after breaking through the Mareth Line they have smashed through the enemy's new defenses at Wadi el Akarit, north of Gabes, and Marshal Rommel is once more on the run.

The Board of Visitors of Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens, set up by law to check on administration of that institution for mental diseases, relied almost entirely on reports by Dr. George W.T. Mills, the superintendent, it appeared yesterday from testimony of members of the board before Archie O. Dawson, Moreland Act Commissioner.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 7 -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Commander in Chief of Allied forces in North Africa, today expressed "surprise" at the statement issued on behalf of General Charles de Gaulle in London asserting that General Eisenhower's attitude led to the postponement of General de Gaulle's trip here.

The 3 per cent tax on transportation of property as it affects goods consigned for export is "unreasonable, uncalled for and unnecessarily burdensome," exporters asserted yesterday at the monthly round-table conference of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

If it is feasible for the nation to have compulsory service for industry, obviously women want to be in on it, Miss Charlotte Carr, assistant to the deputy chairman of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday at the Womanpower in War session of the Academy of Political Science in the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, April 7 -- News of the advances of the forces of the United Nations in Tunisia cheered the stock markets today, and prices rose in several sections. Gilt-edge stocks turned dull toward the close of trading, the War Loan 3 1/2 per cents, old Consols and local loans declining 1-16 each.

Continued praise as well as criticism was voiced yesterday for THE NEW YORK TMES American history survey that showed that college freshmen are ignorant of many basic facts in United States history. College presidents called the survey an "educational contribution" and one said that the results would not have been much better if the test had been given to the country's high school teachers, with the exception of history instructors.

MONTREAL, April 7 (AP) -- Bill Cowley, play-making center of the Bruins, was named today as winner of the Dr. David A. Hart Trophy as the most valuable player to his club in the National Hockey League in the 1942-43 season.
LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- The Berlin radio reported today that a member of the Bulgarian Cabinet had declared that Bulgaria would fight against any Allied invasion of the Balkans.

A sharp increase in the demand for business quarters in the Bronx is indicated by recent leases made through the Michael Santori organization, brokers. Firm members report that last month they obtained tenants for seven factory units totaling 69,250 square feet in the borough.

Four women essayists who unanimously demanded that the United States participate in post-war world order were winners in a competition sponsored by The Atlantic Monthly and the National Council of Women, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Harold V. Milligan, president of the council.

Price ceilings as fixed by the Office of Price Administration will drive small meat dealers out of business "for the next fifty years," it was charged last night at a meeting of about 400 meat handlers in Manhattan Center. One of the primary purposes of the meeting was to select a committee that will confer with OPA officials in Washington to see if some relief cannot be obtained.

Changes in the rules of the New York Stock Exchange for special offerings of stocks have been approved by the board of governors and are being discussed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, which must sanction them before they may take effect.
An exhibit of Homasote "precision-built homes of the future," designed for quick construction through prefabrication of parts, will be opened today on the ninth floor of the R. H. Macy Co. store.

LONDON, April 7 -- Great Britain proposed the most far-reaching world banking and currency plan for the expansion of world trade thus far advanced by any major power, with publication today of a White Paper by Lord Keynes, economist and adviser to the Exchequer.

The Independent Pneumatic Tool Company reported yesterday that net earnings for 1942 after all charges amounted to $1,611,636, equal to $4.29 a share on the common stock. In the preceding year the company had a net of $1,555,005, or $4.14 a share.

Chicago likes to hold on to its Mayors, though a cynic might prefer to put it the other way. Chicago's Mayors may like to hold on to office and know how. In any event, Mayor Edward J. Kelly has been elected for a third term of four years.

Hunter College will begin recruiting students for volunteer farm work at a mass meeting in the college auditorium today, when the college's decision to back one unit of the Columbia County project, "Farm for Freedom," will be announced.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt's "hold-the-line" order tonight against inflation was received with general approval on Capitol Hill and in official circles, but representatives of organized labor preferred in the main not to comment until they had studied the order and the message which accompanied it.

That the people of Argentina are "on the side of the Americas" in the war, although their government has not broken relations with the Axis, was the consensus of speakers yesterday at a luncheon given by the Pan American Society at the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of nine Argentine journalists.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 9 -- John Curtin, Australia's Prime Minister, said today that the first anniversary of the fall of Bataan was a sad reminder that the Pacific has become a front of lost opportunities.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 8 -- Princeton's baseball team spoiled Fordham's opening game today by defeating the Rams, 5 to 4, behind the seven-hit pitching of Roy Talcott. It was the second straight victory for the Tigers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 8 -- As Britain's First Army pushed the German columns some miles back from the vital road between Beja and Medjez-el-Bab, the shortest route to Tunis and Bizerte, the Eighth Army and Allied Air Force forced the Africa Corps fifteen miles northward toward Sfax.

Operations of Libby, McNeill Libby in its fiscal year ended on Feb. 27, 1943, resulted in the largest volume of sales since 1919 but a slightly lower profit than for the previous year, Daniel W. Creeden, president, declared yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 8 -- Continuing their heavy shelling of the last few days, the Giants defeated their Jersey City farm hands today, 11 to 7. Their bristling attack included home runs by Babe Barna and Vic Bradford and three singles by Manager Mel Ott.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- All that would be required to place the British post-war currency proposals in operation would be the agreement of the United States and Great Britain. This statement was made by Redvers Opie, counselor of the British Embassy, at a press conference held this afternoon by Sir Frederick Phillips, American representative of the British Treasury, to explain the British proposals which were made yesterday.

The manner of living when peace comes, with new materials, "born of war-quickened imaginations," being put to uses that would make "Jules Verne feel like a piker," was pictured yesterday by Carl H. Henrikson Jr., regional business consultant of the Department of Commerce, at a luncheon of the Rotary Club in the Hotel Commodore.

All monthly records for steel production in the United States were shattered in March when the industry operated at an even 100 per cent of capacity to produce a high record of 7,670,187 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, nearly 90,000 tons more than were produced in the previous best month, October, 1942, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

They met in a cloud of dust on a ridge in the desert. The vanguard of one army, marching westward, encountered the forward patrols of the other, marching eastward through an endless minefield. The meeting place was a little crossroads on a camel trail traced in a sand bowl shadowed by the black peaks of mountains.

Today the Circus Maximus opens its doors. Good luck to it, but to some of us it brings back other Springs and other shows. There are good men and true who hold that the best days of the circus were when it traveled by wagon. And the site of a true circus must be rural, a four-acre lot, or at the crossroads.
Investors and operators were active yesterday in the purchase and sale of a variety of properties in Manhattan.

WITH THE BRITISH FIRST ARMY, in Northern Tunisia, April 7 (Delayed) (Reuter) -- A British regiment captured the highest feature in the mountain range directly north of the Oued Zarga-Medjez road early this morning as the British advance continued to make satisfactory progress.
ALGIERS, April 8 -- General Eisenhower's letter to General de Gaulle, it is learned, left it to the Fighting French leader to make his own decision on whether to visit North Africa now.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- President Roosevelt established a committee today to coordinate Federal, State and local efforts to combat commercialized vice and deal with other social problems arising in overcrowded war centers.

Today, on the first anniversary of the fall of Bataan, the telephone operators at General Douglas MacArthur's Australian headquarters as supreme commander of the United Nations forces in the Southwest Pacific, will answer calls as usual: "Bataan speaking!"

Lyle Wilson, one of three hotel owners on trial on the charge of operating the Hotel Hermitage, in Seventh Avenue near Forty-second Street, for purposes of prostitution, was acquitted yesterday on this charge. But he still is a defendant, with his father-in-law, Oliver Clandorf, and the latter's son, Frank, on a similar charge relating to another of three hotels in the midtown district.

Sales and total income of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., for the fiscal year ended with February were the largest in its history, Max Weinstein, president, disclosed yesterday in the annual report to stockholders.

A modern pioneer may live off the land as his ancestors did, but what with germs and fire hazards nowadays he must keep the place clean, especially if it is within the city limits, Magistrate Henry A. Soffer ruled yesterday in Flushing Court in adjourning a case against John August, 45-year-old World War I veteran, of 152-12 148th Street, Cornell Park, Queens.

Progress in negotiations for a settlement of the $5,000,000 suit involving the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation was reported late yesterday after attorneys for both sides had been closeted in chambers all afternoon with Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein.

The New York City Housing Authority sold through competitive bidding yesterday a new issue of $2,775,000 of temporary loan notes dated April 23 and payable on Oct. 22. A syndicate comprising the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, the National City Bank, the New York Trust Company and Brown Brothers Harriman Co. obtained the award of $1,775,000 of the notes, bidding an 0.55 per cent basis, plus a premium of $31.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Owners and coaches of National Football League teams conducted their biggest college player, draft in history today, with each club emerging from the nine-hour session armed with rights to thirty collegians, but it was estimated fewer than 5 per cent of these would play pro ball before the war's end.

LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today reported an increase of 4,979,000 in note circulation to the record total of 939,511,000. It was the tenth consecutive weekly increase and about 10,000,000 under the Treasury's authorized total of 950,000,000.

Mrs. Lillian Rosenlicht, 45 years old, who, the police said, had been identified with women's gambling in the midtown district for years pleaded guilty yesterday in Special Sessions when she was about to go on trial as a common gambler for operating a poker game for women in a West Seventy-ninth Street apartment.

The unopened weekly pay envelope of a chain restaurant waitress and gifts of $25,000 and $30,000 from large corporations helped swell the total of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City yesterday, it was announced by J.P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the campaign to raise $12,920,700 in this city as part of the national goal of $125,000,000.

WITH THE BRITISH FIRST ARMY, in Northern Tunisia, April 7 (Delayed) (UP) -- British infantry, supported by the heaviest artillery concentration so far employed by the First Army, swept northward from the Beja-Medjezel-Bab road more than two miles along a twelve-mile front today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 8 -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower declared today that the Army, Navy and Air Force were in a position "to exact the full price" from the Axis forces in Tunisia.

PHILADEPHIA, April 8 -- In an unusual presentment a Federal grand jury indicted today seventeen individuals and one corporation on charges in connection with black market activities in meat and suggested that Congress and the Office of Price Administrator set ceiling prices on livestock as well as dressed meat to stamp out violations of the Emergency Price Control Law.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- OPA decided today to make sugar available to home canners again this year without ration coupon penalties after arranging for an extra 200,000 tons of sugar to be imported from Cuba.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Senator Vandenberg warned the War Department today not to try to stop any man from becoming President merely because he was serving with the military forces, while Secretary Stimson flatly denied that the department's ban on political activity was aimed at General Douglas MacArthur or any other specific person.

LONDON, April 8 -- Herbert H. Lehman, United States Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, arrived in London tonight for an indeterminate stay during which he will explore the relief needs of the areas the United Nations are determined to wrest from Axis control and to get all the information collected here on relief matters by various United Nations representatives.

The decision of the Bolivian Cabinet to declare war against the Axis is important as an act of confidence in the future of the United Nations. President Penaranda has long displayed friendship for the United States, in spite of some opposition within his own country.

Major Gen. Basilio Jose Valdes, Secretary of National Defense and Chief of Staff of the Philippine Army, arrived yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria from Washington. He is here to take part in the Treasury Department program of patriotic ceremonies this afternoon in the Sculpture Court of the Brooklyn Museum to commemorate Bataan Day.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, April 9 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Further gains in primary market prices for agricultural commodities, particularly fruits and vegetables and cattle, brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index up 0.1 per cent during the week ended April 3.
As an old believer in Latin-American rubber possibilities, it was with natural satisfaction that I read in THE TIMES the news item titled "South America Reports Big Rubber Output Rise."

The results of the survey on United States history conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES furnish a strong incentive for high schools and colleges to improve their teaching of American history, according to comments received yesterday from educators.

Specific recommendations for reducing Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44 by amounts ranging from $19,965,059 to $27,655,232 were submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday at the first of its two public hearings on the document.

An important factor in the nation's battle of production has been the quick adaptability of inexperienced American youth to war industry jobs, L. R. Grandy, assistant supervisor of engine testing at the Buick division of General Motors, reported yesterday at the opening session of the two-day national aeronautic meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers at the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 3 were 7 per cent below sales of the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a decline of 3 per cent for the week ended March 27.

The presidents of the four city colleges and the chancellor and dean of the School of Education of New York University issued a joint statement yesterday taking issue with the Board of Education for its rejection of Mark Starr for the post of adult education director.

Despite a recommendation for mercy made by the jury, Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn threatened yesterday to "give a limit sentence" to Patsy Zeuli, a bartender, unless he told probation officers the entiire truth concerning the theft of more than 11,000,000 gallons of gasoline coupons from a Long Island City, Queens, rationing board.

WASWHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Prentiss Brown, Price Administrator, aroused a storm of protest from members of the Senate Agriculture Committee today by advocating increased appropriations for incentive payments to farmers as preferable to two bills designed to increase prices.
Sixteen trained teams will start a drive for $2,200,000,000, the quota for Manhattan and the Bronx, in the second war loan campaign, which opens nationally for $8,000,000,000 next Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Although House leaders of both parties urged prompt reporting by the Ways and Means Committee of a pay-as-you-go income tax bill, Representative Doughton, chairman of the committee, saying he was still convinced that the demand for action on pay-as-you-go taxation was "mostly politics," insisted tonight he saw no reason for asking his committee to reconsider the matter.

Diminution of trade buying at midday reversed yesterday an upward movement in cotton prices which was edging the list of active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange close to the fourteen-year high levels established a month ago.

MADRID, Spain, April 8 (AP) -- The Madrid press published for the first time tonight the text of an oath which it said all newly appointed Spanish Bishops are required to take to "the chief of the Spanish State and the government established according to Spanish laws."

Artichokes have dropped an average of 5 cents each since last Friday. Supplies are plentiful, the Department of Agriculture reports, for seven cars arrived from California yesterday and eight the day before. This represents a considerable increase over last year's receipts, which were approximately four cars a day during the month of April.

James Callen, 41 years old, of 479 East Thirty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, father of two children, shot and killed himself, according to the police, early yesterday morning on the lawn of the Grace Reformed Church in Flatbush. Detectives said he had been brooding because his efforts to join the armed forces had been thwarted by physical disability.

With housecleaning and rationing confronting her simultaneously, there still is little cause for a housewife in this unprecedented Springtime to doubt her ability to freshen up her rooms successfully as of old. In spite of shortages, all essentials for sprucing up the decor are obtainable.

Low-priced shares had an easy time yesterday in pushing fractionally higher on the New York Stock Exchange, but selling in the last quarter-hour hit the prime industrials and brought an irregularly lower closing level for the market.

By the Bergen County precedent 5 per cent of American families should, theoretically though not scientifically, be able to furnish the whole manpower for an army of eight million. Three families in Bergen County, across the Hudson, have sent six sons each into the armed forces.

MITNCIE, Ind., April 8 -- Frank Frisch sent the clubhouse boy out for a hamburger. "I'm in such marvelous condition," he said, "that I've got to stock upon my vitamins before I become too thin. If I get in any better shape I'll start thinking about getting into the line-up again. That would be unfair to the Pirates, the public and Frisch."
LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique, broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet radio monitor here:

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- A simple resolution extending the Bituminous Coal Act for three or four months to prevent its lapse on April 26 because time is lacking for action on pending extension bills has been decided on by Administration leaders in the House.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 8 -- County Executive J. Russel Sprague disclosed tonight that Governor Dewey had requested that he release Colonel Edward C.O. Thomas, Nassau County director of civilian protection, so that he could be appointed State Director of Civilian Protection.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- There will be no Army commission, "at least for the present," for Mayor La Guardia, Secretary Stimson stated today in his press conference.

While condemning the clergy of the world for having failed in their vital duty of combating nazism before it had become an international horror, Dr. Carl J. Hambro, president of the Norwegian Parliament and former president of the League of Nations Assembly, declared yesterday that unless churchmen vigorously brought the principles of religion into any peace conferences they would fail in their duty again.

The Curtis Publishing Company and consolidated subsidiaries reported yesterday for 1942 a net profit of $902,470, equal to $1.32 a share for the prior preferred stock, comparing with $2,059,657, or $3.10 a share on the prior preferred stock, earned in 1941.

Many of the boys who participated in the athletic and civic programs sponsored by three leading settlement houses on the lower East Side were among eighty-three selectees who left their homes in that section yesterday for Army service at Fort Dix, N.J.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Revealing that his office is concerned over the possibility that crude-oil reserves in the mid-continent fields may decline at a rate that will present an acute problem by the end of 1944, Harold Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War, said that a plan to build a pipe-line from West Texas fields to supply refineries in the Midwest is under study.

Residence has been established in Reno by Mrs. John Jacob Astor 3d, the former Miss Ellen Tuck French, preparatory to beginning a divorce action, according to a statement made yesterday at Mr. Astor's office, 30 Rockefeller Plaza. They have been separated for several years.

LONDON, April 8 -- An assertion that may point a moral for the United States was made in the House of Lords today when Lord Portal declared flatly that salvage was the greatest factor in the economy of war materials vital to the war effort.

VASHINGTON, April 8 (U.P.) -- Rubber Director William J. Jeffers said today that his office planned to release 12,000,000 new passenger car tires this year, or 8,525,468 more than were distributed in 1942, He declared that the rubber shortage would be solved "if we don't run into any interference."

Charles J. Farley, 26-year-old nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, was positively identified yesterday as a participant in the Brooklyn gasoline hold-up that ended in the killing of Patrolman Nicholas C. Moreno. Farley is on trial with Louis Caridad, 24, before Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein on charges of first-degree murder.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, parent company of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company, told a meeting of the War Production Board's steel industry advisory committee today that those responsible for irregularities in the testing procedure on some steel plates produced by the Carnegie-Illinois Irvin plant had been dismissed.

The pamphlet report for 1942 of the Reading Company, operator of railway and mining properties, released for publication today, shows that last year the company reduced its funded debt and that of its leased or operated lines by $7,965,101, bringing total publicly held indebtedness at the year-end down to $128,223,760.

The Vaughan Williams Fantasia on the Tallis theme, with which Bruno Walter opened his program with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, is by method a set of variants for double-stringed orchestra on an Elizabethan air; actually this is a tone poem of a singularly glamorous atmosphere, due not merely to the composer's invention and technical resource but to the quality of his imagination.

Apparently Mayor La Guardia must remain a member of the great civilian army. Secretary Stimson's statement to this effect at his press conference yesterday seem conclusive. It would indeed be "very difficult to find any place" in the armed forces where the Mayor "could be as helpful as in his present job."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 8 -- A tax rate of $57.45 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation, an increase of $3.72 over last year, was announced for this city today by the Hudson County Board of Taxation.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Chester C. Davis, Food Administrator, declared today that $35,000,000,000 in surplus spending power would have to be recaptured by the government if present price and wage controls are to combat inflation efficiently.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, in Australia, Friday, April 9 (AP) -- Australian-flown Hudsons bombed and strafed nearly a score of small Japanese ships in the area between Australia and Netherland New Guinea yesterday, while to the northeast Liberator bombers attacked scattered points in New Ireland, New Britain and New Guinea, the High Command announced today.

The United States Committee on Educational Reconstruction, a body of civilian authorities whose cooperation had been invited by the State Department, forwarded a plan yesterday for the "urgent" establishment by the United Nations of an international education office.

Six employes of the Department of Sanitation were suspended by Mayor La Guardia yesterday in connection with the hit-and-run deaths of two women who were struck by an automobile last Thursday at Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. The women were thrown into the path of an Ocean Avenue trolley car that crushed them.
MOSCOW, April 8 -- The important role played in recent operations by the German Army's self-propelled artillery is the subject of an interesting article today in the army newspaper Red Star.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt strengthened the anti-inflation program today with a sweeping executive order forbidding wage increases above the level of the "Little Steel" formula and restricting future price rises to the minimum extent required by law.

The factory building at 98-100 Green Street, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Oak-Cal Realty Corporation through Corwith Brothers, broker. The sellers were Elliot H. Leward and the City Bank Farmers Trust Company. The size of the plot is 50 by 100 feet and the property is assessed at $7,500.

LONDON, April 8 -- Though most of the Americans here are aware that sooner or later they will compete in the biggest "game" of all somewhere on the other side of the English Channel, plans are going forward for a sort of United Nations Olympic games to be spread over three seasons and held in various parts of this island.

_4, funeral service for Mrs. Janet Lord Roper, for twenty-seven years house mother of the Seamen's Church Institute, was held in the institute's Chapel of Our Savior at 25 South Street yesterday afternoon, at which 500 persons, among them representatives of seamen's agencies and consular and shipping officials of the United Nations, were present.

Characterizing as "erroneous" any impression that the Army has overbought on wool textiles, Major Gen. Clifford L. Corbin, assistant quartermaster general and Chief of the Army's Supply, declared last night that Army wool requirements have leveled off for the present and it is not anticipated that there will be any material increase in requirements of wool in the near future.

Two persons are missing and four others were injured a little after 9 o'clock last night when an explosion, preceding a fire, blew out the fronts of three upper floors of the five-story brick building at 69 Beekman Street, between Gold and Cliff Streets, in the heart of the chemical district downtown.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Senate farm group, in another showing of strength today, pushed through a bill to set up a mobile and migratory land army, composed largely of imported Mexican and Bahaman workers, to relieve agricultural manpower short ages.

LONDON, Friday, April 9 (U.P.) -- The Germans, their costly and futile attacks in the Izyum sector of the Donets front broken, have shifted their offensive spearhead twenty-five miles up the river to the Balakleya sector in a new attempt to crack the Russian line, a Soviet communique reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (U.P.) -- New pressure was being brought on government agencies today to cut their use of print paper to match paper economies being practiced by newspaper, book, magazine publishers and commercial printers.

The showdown between the 53-year-old North American Company utilities system and the Securities and Exchange Commission over the constitutionality of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act drew a step closer yesterday when the holding company assailed "the destructive" provisions of the act in a brief filed with the United States Supreme Court.

To mark the third anniversary of the invasion of Norway today, the Norwegian Information Services have published a booklet, "After Three Years -- Norway." It contains statements by about sixty representative Americans praising the Norwegians for standing up to the threats of the terror of the German oppressors.

An advertising campaign which promises to be among the most vigorous in the drug field will be started May 17 in six Western States to promote Stan-B, vitamin product containing vitamin B complex with iron, it was announced yesterday by Standard Brands, Inc.

In a Springtime floral setting, the annual Gay Thirties Dinner Dance in aid of the Boys Club of New York was given last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. The event drew an attendance of several hundred persons of prominence, many of whom are actively interested in the philanthropic and educational activities of the beneficiary.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 8 (U.P.) -- More than 4,000 American and Australian soldiers have been loading and unloading ships all this week as a result of a "wildcat" strike called by Sydney dock workers twelve days ago, it was revealed today when military authorities withdrew a strict censorship.

The United States Employment Service reported last night that since Monday, when the government opened another drive to bring former seamen back to sea to alleviate a shortage in skilled maritime workers, 142 seamen have qualified for duty.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Office of Price Administration moved today to stop the growing diversion of selected seed potatoes to table use by issuing an order eliminating the premium of 75 cents a hundredweight which selected seed potatoes had previously been permitted over the table stock potato ceilings.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Roosevelt issued an Executive Order authorizing the War Labor Board to keep wage increases within the Little Steel formula and instructing the Office of Price Administration and the Food Administrator to permit no further price increases; his visitors included Senator Truman, Representative Gavagan, the polish Ambassador, Leland Olds and J.A. Krug, Richard Delano and Herbert Pell.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 8 -- A movement gradually taking on national importance under the impact of war is the movement to lower the voting age to 18.

The delightful proposal of President John L. Lewis of the United Mine Workers that the government should pay $2 a day more to all the miners suggests an easy solution of this whole problem, which I submit herewith:
ALGIERS, April 8 (AP) -- General Giraud announced tonight the reinstallation of democratic governing assembles and councils in French North Africa as they existed before the collapse of France.

BOSTON, April 8 -- Samuel J. Solomon, president of Northeast Airlines, disclosed today plans for a post-war setup wherein helicopters would be used to carry mail and passengers from town and city rooftops to major airline terminals as part of what he called "an aerial taxi service."

Harold Haugh, tenor, who had not been heard in this city for several seasons, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. His exacting and varied program included early English songs; "Ossian's Ode," by Hopkinson; Mozart's solo contata, "Die ihr des unermesslichen Weltalls Schoepfer ehrt"; arias by Bach, Rossini and Massenet; Respghi's "Ballata"; German songs by Wolf and Schubert, and a group of contemporary English lyrics.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The government continued its reciprocal trade agreements program by signing a pact with Iran today, the action coming as indications persisted that there would be a fight in Congress over renewal of the authority of the President to make such arrangements.

Waac cooks and bakers are undergoing careful training to save all usable or salable waste matter, according to an announcement yesterday by officers at the Second Waac Training Center at Daytona Beach, Fla. They report that "wasteful average Americans would do well to take some garbage detail lessons from their mess halls," since almost everything labeled garbage and trash before Pearl Harbor is salvaged and put to useful war service.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- At no time today were prices of wheat above the finish of yesterday and a bearish feeling prevailed in the trade due to more favorable crop comments from the Southwest, and later there was fairly general selling on a wide-open break in Winnipeg, where prices were off 5 1/2 cents a bushel at one time.

To strengthen the reserve position of members banks so that they may be able to enter maximum subscriptions to next week's Victory bond drive, the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System bought $629,891,000 of United States Government securities in the week ended on Wednesday.

Failure of the American Bar Association to elect to membership Assistant District Attorney Frank E. Rivers, a Negro, has resulted in the resignations of General Sessions Judge Jonah J. Goldstein and Arthur Garfield Hays, attorney, it was disclosed yesterday.
The Yankees came home last night.

Two midtown theatres will present new film attractions today. At the Strand, "Edge of Darkness," a Warner Brothers' drama starring Errol Flynn and Ann Sheridan, will have its world premiere. Directed by Lewis Milestone, the picturization of the novel by William Woods includes Walter Huston, Judith Anderson, Ruth Gordon, Helmut Dantine, Morris Carnowsky and Nancy Coleman among its featured players. . . .

The Office of Price Administration moved yesterday to penalize three dairy chains, operating a total of sixty-four stores, on charges of selling butter without collecting the required number of ration point coupons. Daniel P. Woolley, City Markets Commissioner, disclosed that checks by his department had revealed that much of the hamburger sold here during the last ten days contained an excessive amount of fat.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A year ago tomorrow General Douglas MacArthur was in Melbourne, ordered there from Bataan by his superiors. It was in Melbourne, April 9, 1942, that word came to him of the capitulation of the forces under Lieut. Gen. Wainwright from whom he had been obliged most reluctantly to part.

The National Committee on the Cause and Cure of War, formed Jan. 18, 1925, was dissolved yesterday at a meeting in the Henry Hudson Hotel and henceforth will cooperate with the Women's Action Committee for Victory and Lasting Peace, which was formed several weeks ago.
Pending before the House Judiciary Committee is the recommendation of one of its subcommittees providing for the so-called Equal Rights Amendment.

The winners of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award for this year are Dolores Daurine Miller, violin, born in Healdsberg, Calif., and pupil of Louis Persinger; Constance Keene, piano, born in Brooklyn, a pupil of Abram Chasins, and Ruth Geiger, piano, born in Vienna and pupil of Josef Lehvinne, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 8 -- Further slight gains were made by the Russians on the right bank of the Donets River in yesterday's fighting in the Izyum sector. Soviet Stormovik planes carried oue several strafing sweeps up the river, shelling and machine-gunning enemy concentrations, and the low-altitude attacks proved to be highly damaging, especially where the enemy was surprised at grips with transport problems on muddy and overburdened roads.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, east of E1 Guettar, Tunisia, April 6 (delayed) (AP) -- German night-raiding bombers, seeking to break the morale of advancing American troops, have showered them with steel darts, but the unimpressed doughboys are building roofs over their foxholes to protect them against the new "devil's needles."

LONDON, April 9 -- Emphasizing his belief that with intelligent control more effective use could be made of the inadequate motor transport available in the Middle East, Fred Winant, American chairman of the Executive Committee of the Middle East Supply Center, said today that he did not feel he should support requests for assistance from governments that had not established adequate con trol.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Axis armies which have been under the separate commands of Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel and Colonel General Dietloff von Arnim now will stand together and "presumably" make a last-ditch fight under "unified command" against Allied forces determined to destroy them completely, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson declared today.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Prentiss Brown, Price Administrator, settled a long-standing dispute today by taking all responsibility for administrative decisions in OPA out of the hands of its lawyers and placing it on the shoulders of operating officers.

ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Dewey signed today the legislative Reapportionment Bill, the first one enacted since 1917, and at the same time Attorney General Goldstein released an opinion holding that the present district lines would remain in effect, for primary election purposes, until after the regular election in 1944.

Although the country's bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday were only slightly larger than during the week before, a sharp rise at New York and the largest gains recorded so far this year by outside cities lifted the total almost 50 per cent above the volume for the corresponding week of 1942.

ALLIED FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 8 -- The American fighter pilot with the greatest number of victories in Tunisia is Major Levi R. Chase of Cortland, N.Y., who shot down his ninth and tenth enemy planes yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- United States fighter planes have scored a smashing victory over the Japanese at Guadalcanal, shooting down thirty-seven of an attacking force of ninety-eight planes, with a loss of seven American craft, the Navy announced today in a communique that told of the greatest aerial battle in the Solomons since last Winter.
