Industry must make many readjustments because of the number of women now in war jobs, Samuel G. Cooper, supervisor of personnel training of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, said yesterday when he spoke on "What Industry Asks of Women" to the New York City branch of the American Association of University Women at its clubrooms at Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 8 -- Bermuda's Governors -- one of whom only a few years ago resigned immediately after the Assembly had refused to allow him an automobile -- will in the future be permitted to have an automobile as a result of an Assembly decision today.

Men and women of the theatre will hold an exhibition of their work, including paintings and sketches, at the Hall of Art, 24 West Fortieth Street, from May 23 to June 14. The Treasury Department will cooperate. On the closing day, the entire collection will be sold at a war-bond auction to be conducted by the stars and chorus of the Ziegfeld Follies.

A huge mechanical "brain," a device that solves in minutes highly complex mathematical problems that would take expert mathematicians months and years, is now employed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on the solution of vital war problems, it was revealed yesterday in the Rockefeller Foundation's review for 1942 by Raymond B. Fosdick, president.

Many months have passed since the Office of Defense Transportation banned sightseeing buses, yet week-end visitors from out-of-town war factories, service men and just plain gawkers at the wonders of New York are still making guided tours of Chinatown, Greenwich Village and other sections that attract sightseers.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 8 -- Gasoline supplies are so low in Westchester County that services provided by vehicles of the Police, Fire, Health and Public Works Departments face possible curtailment, Mayor William Hart Hussey of Mount Vernon said this afternoon.

The Sperry Corporation last year earned $7,044,961, or $3.94 a share, after provision for taxes but before post-war reserves, according to the annual pamphlet report of Thomas A. Morgan made public yesterday. The net income for 1941 was $9,281,144, or $4.60 a share.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Navy communique 337:

LONDON, April 8 -- A new political party, hitherto ignored by the vast majority of voters, made an unexpected appearance on the British political horizon today when for the first time since its formation only eight months ago it succeeded in electing a candidate to Parliament to represent the Eddisbury, Cheshire, constituency.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that all shoe establishments, whether retailers, distributors, jobbers or manufacturers, must take inventory of shoes and ration currency which they have on hand at the close of business on April 10.

Wendell L. Willkie's "One World" has already reached the second printing stage just one day after publication, Simon Schuster announces. Seventy-five thousand copies more have been ordered, bringing the total to 145,000, Mr. Willkie will be a guest on "Information Please" Monday, at a special bond-selling program to be broadcast from Hartford, Conn.

Nine days of contract bridge play for two national championship titles will begin tonight when thirty-six invited experts open their first of five sessions for the contract bridge masters' individual championship, at the Park Central Hotel.

There is every likelihood that "The Miracle" will be revived here in the Fall before the filming of the religious pantomime by Warner Brothers, it was learned yesterday. The screen firm owns all the rights to the spectacle, which made theatrical history in 1924 when staged here by Max Reinhardt and presented by Morris Gest.
NEW DELHI, India, April 8 (AP) -- A British communique:

The Dominion of Canada, which until 1937 had neither a national airline nor an integrated civil aviation policy, intends to strive vigorously for a place in international air transportation after the war, H.J. Symington, president of Trans-Canada Air Lines, declared here yesterday.

Every available means of transportation was utilized by the throng of 26,424 racing fans that streamed into Jamaica track yesterday for the Metropolitan Jockey Club's "automobile-less" meeting opening the 1943 New York turf season.

WESTFIELD, N.J., April 8 -- The police of nine States have been requested by authorities here to search for Rollin C. Dean, director of the purchasing department of the Rockefeller Foundation, who has been missing since last Monday.
TRENTON, April 8 (AP) -- Legislation interpreted as laying the groundwork for possible liquor rationing in New Jersey was signed today by Governor Charles Edison.

Estimates made by various salesmen's associations indicated yesterday that they have reduced their traveling at least 50 per cent, and in some industries, especially representatives of heavy durable civilian goods sellers, have cut their mileage on railroads and in automobiles about 80 per cent below that of 1940.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., April 9 (U.P.) -- Fitted with a pair of giant skis, a four-engine plane of the Air Transport Command, trapped for two months in the snowbound wilds of Quebec, returned yesterday to its home base after what was described as one of the most ambitious rescue missions in Army history.

Some suggestions have been made by the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission regarding the protection of channel bass, or red drum. It is understood that other committees are at work preparing reports on other species and that the New York commissioners are soon to hold their own session.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 8 -- An indication that the German authorities are now reckoning with the possibility of an invasion of their home territory is seen in what may well be the first step toward organized partisan units within the Reich.

The opening of the Eastern racing season at Jamaica yesterday survived all obstacles, including transportation worries, labor troubles, congestion and seven losing favorites, as a surging crowd of 26,424 found its way in and out of the popular Metropolitan Jockey Club course.

TRENTON, April 8 -- The Proctor bill, providing pay increases for most of New Jersey's 15,000 employes at an estimated $4,000,000 cost, was signed today by Governor Edison, who expressed the hope that the finances of the State would remain sufficiently stable to obviate the necessity for a future reduction of the salary adjustments.
Tonight is the night for the young, the middle-aged and the old. Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus unfolds its 1943 version at Madison Square Garden.

New assets of Incorporated Investors, an open-end diversified investment company, rose more than $10,000,000 in the first quarter of 1943, according to a report yesterday by William A. Parker, president. The increase was from $34,276,205 at the end of 1942 to $44,440,454 on March 31 last and net assets for each share gained 27 per cent, or from $14.64 to $18.61.

An elastic work week and a sliding retirement age, to meet shifting economic conditions in the post-war era, were proposed last night by Mayor La Guardia. He presented the first of 212 scrolls of honor which were awarded at the Manhattan Center to union electrical' workers past the age 60 years who are foregoing $50-a-month pensions to remain on the job.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Failure of Congress twenty years ago to pass legislation for Federal aid to State educational systems has burdened the Army with men more unfit for the present type of mechanized warfare than soldiers with venereal disease, Dr. William F. Russell, dean of the Columbia University Teachers College, told a Senate education subcommittee today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, virtually charged here today that the quantity of United Nations war supplies being shipped to the Southwest Pacific was less than the amount which President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill would regard as essential even in the face of their 'beat-Hitler-first" strategy.

The bulk of Spring apartment renting activity reported by brokers yesterday was in the residential section on both sides of Central Park. Several leases were made in Park Avenue and West End Avenue. The list follows:
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's Executive Order on prices and wages:

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; "The Crucifixion of Christ" (Bach's St. Matthew Passion), Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Adolf Busch and Chamber Music Players, Town Hall, 8:30; Marcel Grandjany, harp, Juilliard School of Music, 8:15; Frances Lehnerts, mezzocontralto, free recital, Bronx House, 1637 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, 8:15.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 8 (AP) -- A communique:

BOSTON, April 8 -- The Detroit Red Wings are the new hockey champions of the world. The fast-skating, fast-checking crew managed by Jack Adams took possession of the Stanley Cup tonight by shutting out the Boston Bruins, 2 to 0, for a 4-0 sweep of the final series.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 8 (AP) -The swift Eighth Army pursuit indicated that Marshal Rommel would be unable to make another defensive stand in the Cekhira sector between the sea and the salt marsh known as Sebkret en Noual.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's Executive Order on prices and wages:

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P.M.; "The Crucifixion of Christ" (Bach's St. Matthew Passion), Metropolitan Opera House, evening; Adolf Busch and Chamber Music Players, Town Hall, 8:30; Marcel Grandjany, harp, Juilliard School of Music, 8:15; Frances Lehnerts, mezzocontralto, free recital, Bronx House, 1637 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, 8:15.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 8 (AP) -- A communique:

BOSTON, April 8 -- The Detroit Red Wings are the new hockey champions of the world. The fast-skating, fast-checking crew managed by Jack Adams took possession of the Stanley Cup tonight by shutting out the Boston Bruins, 2 to 0, for a 4-0 sweep of the final series.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 8 (AP) -The swift Eighth Army pursuit indicated that Marshal Rommel would be unable to make another defensive stand in the Cekhira sector between the sea and the salt marsh known as Sebkret en Noual.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Inquiry about what some call the mystery of the indefinitely postponed visit to North Africa by General Charles de Gaulle brought from Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson today the comment that, pending the conquest of Tunisia, the "undivided strength" of the Allies must be focused on the military crisis.

The regional War Labor Board here approved yesterday increases of $2 to $5 weekly to floor operators of the New York Stock Exchange. The rates, previously agreed upon by the Exchange and the Independent Employes Association, will add $1,779 to weekly wages and lift the wage range of 384 employes to $20 to $49 a week.

LONDON, April 8 -- The stock markets here gave no sign today of expansion on the good war news from Tunisia. Gilt-edge stocks and home rails made no noteworthy changes and dollar shares eased on profit-taking in Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Representative Colmer of Mississippi opened the debate today on the Hobbs anti-racketeering bill by declaring that if Congress was not "big enough and strong enough to meet this situation" it could not pass any bill "to which labor objects."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- Pola Negri, who arrived here eight months ago after having been retirement in France, will return to the screen in "Hi Diddle Diddle," which Andrew Stone will produce and direct for United Artists, with Martha Scott in the leading role.

ALBANY, April 8 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Feinberg bill establishing a State-wide uniform procedure for excusing essential workers and members of the armed forces from jury service without the necessity of reporting personally in court.

Returning to Washington from a five-day vacation on his North Carolina farm, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Doughton, announces that he will not object to further consideration of the tax problem at this time "if the members of the committee want to put pay-as-you-go ahead of other pressing matters."

QUITE probably there are as many ways of writing history that are right as there are of composing tribal lays. Within the last few weeks four different works of history at complete variance with each other in technical method have been offered to the reading public. On only one common ground do the four meet -- their scrupulous reliance on exact and exhaustive research.

LONDON, April 8 -- Reporting to the House of Commons today on his American visit Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, went out of his way to lay the ghost of suspicion remaining both here and in the United States that the State Department entertained special "tenderness for Vichy."

One of the major disgraces of the Nazi regime is the deliberate suppression of scholarship. If the German Government had been only half as foresighted as it was supposed to be in preparing for war it would not have exiled so many eminent scientists who were liberals or ethnically unacceptable.

Hope for an eventual solution of the "Bowery bum problem" was expressed yesterday by speakers at a conference on the rehabilitation "of unattached and homeless men in New York City," held at the Theodore Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street, under the auspices of the Welfare Council of New York City.
NEW DELHI, India, April 8 (AP) -- A United States communique:

In spite of the shortage of meat in retail stores, the total supply of meat in the country, the Institute of Applied Econometrics points out, is greater than ever before. It is on the farms, in living cattle, on the hoof. Many reasons contribute to the shortage at the stores, but a major one is the building up of herds in the country.

The House passed the Steagall Bill yesterday, and if quick action is taken by the Senate, the nation's banks will be aided greatly in their subscriptions next week to the Second War Loan Drive. The Steagall Bill suspends until six months after the war the Federal Deposit Insurance assessments on bank deposits and eliminates reserve requirements on government war loan accounts in insured banks.

LONDON, April 8 (AP) -- Eighty German planes, including many from Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's elite yellow-nosed Focke-Wulf fighter squadrons, were destroyed in running dogfights incidental to the American heavy-bomber attacks on the Renault works near Paris last Sunday and the Erla aero engine factories at Antwerp, Belgium, on Monday, an official tally showed today.

NEW DELHI, India, April 8 (U.P.) -- British and Indian troops maintained their positions yesterday in western Burma, where British guns, firing at point blank range, tore large gaps in the ranks of a Japanese infantry unit attempting to advance in the Indin area of the Mayu Peninsula and forced it to withdraw, it was announced today.
LONDON, Friday, April 9 (UP) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast by Radio Moscow:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, April 9 -- General Douglas MacArthur commemorated the anniversary of the fall of Bataan today in a statement that revealed his bitterness over successive disappointments and his unswerving hope that he may lead a conquering army back to the lost Philippines.

Four one-hundredths of 1 per cent comprise the total losses of the Air Transport Command of the United States Air Forces during February, the heaviest month to date for delivery of aircraft to the battlefronts. Behind this cold figure reported by Major Gen. Harold L. George, chief of the command, lies an almost incredible story of skill, resourcefulness and expert achievement.

Leasing of large space in Park Avenue to a joint committee of two Jewish organizations and expansion of a Seventh Avenue firm were noted in the list of commercial rentals reported yesterday. The contracts for business space were announced as follows:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 8 -- Important changes in the ranks of leading German diplomats were hinted at in reports from Berlin tonight. It is said that an announcement might be forthcoming in the next few days.

Retail sales volume of processed foods under point rationing increased 109 per cent and total grocery dollar volume advanced about 7 per cent during the last two weeks of March, compared with the initial two weeks of rationing beginning March 1, according to the results of a survey by the New York State Food Merchants Association.
NEW DEHLI, India, April 9 (AP) -- A British communique:
Current uncertainty on the wool fabric supply situation is not expected to delay early showings of Fall women's wear lines by producers next month, comment in the market here yesterday indicated.

If New Yorkers did not enjoy the fishing weather on the opening day of the season they may be interested to know what happened up-State, for the Conservation Department turned in a rather rosyhued report.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (Science Service) -- Among the 662 patents granted this week by the United States Patent Office was one covering an improvement in television scanning, patent No. 2,315,621, obtained by the well-known research physicist Dr. Herbert E. Ives of the Bell Telephone Laboratories. Dark streaks in present-day television transmission are due to the narrow, rapidly moving beam of light used to stimulate the apparatus passing over imperfections in the sensitive screen.

The production in this country of tanks for the British forces is going so well now that Michael B.U. Dewar, chairman of the tank-procurement mission sent here by the British Government, said yesterday that he believed that he could "safely go home now to look after my farming and my own industrial plants, after a good rest, which I think I deserve."

WASHINGTON, April -- Frank E. Tripp, general manager of the Gannett newspapers and chairman of the Allied Newspaper Council, announced today that newspapers would "go into battle" Monday "to help their government borrow 13,000,000,000 fighting dollars."

Changes in the meat-rationing system in the light of two weeks' experience will be mapped for recommendation to the Office of Price Administration by the New York State Food Merchants Association tomorrow.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today the Burney bill providing that the furnishing of medical treatment by an employer should not be construed as an admission of liability on his part under the Workmen's Compensation Law.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, attacked President Roosevelt's new "hold-the-line" executive order freezing wages as unfair to the coal miners yesterday, but immediately agreed to "revise" his demand for a $2-a-day increase if the operators would guarantee a six-day week all round the year and an annual wage potential according to the present scale.

LONDON, Saturday, April 10 -- Dr. Marion C. Loizeaux, the only woman surgeon with the United States Army in the European Theatre of Operations, announced today that she was preparing the groundwork for a medical service for the Waacs.

Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A.C., recent winner of the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association, captured his opening match in the handicap squash racquets tournament for the Red Cross at the Yale Club last night.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- An American in a streamlined P-40 Warhawk wrote the finish -- in blood -- to a taunting Japanese who irritated the boys up in Assam when he came over in a high-flying twin-engined reconnaissance plane.

LONDON, Saturday, April 10 -- Royal Air Force bombers returned to Germany last night to keep up a new round-the-clock blasting of the Reich, after twilight raids by swift Mosquito bombers on the Cologne area and daylight attacks on supply trains in France, British officials announced today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, April 10 (U.P.) -- Allied Flying Fortresses, Mitchell medium bombers, Beau-fighters and Lightning fighter planes teamed up for the heaviest raid of the war on Madang, Japanese base in New Guinea, 300 miles northwest of Buna, yesterday, loosing bombs and 63,000 rounds of gunfire from a low level and leaving enemy supplies blazing and six Japanese planes destroyed on the ground.

LONDON, April 9 (U.P.) -- Stockholm reports today said Italian censors had clamped down on dispatches filed by Swedish correspondents, but hints of Fascist apprehension and depression about the African setbacks managed to get through.

From oddly assorted quarters the American Red Cross War Fund was enriched yesterday by slightly more than $25,000 in lump contributions of more than $5,000 each.These came from firefighters and prizefighters, from art and a shipyard.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York has sold for cash the two-story commercial and apartment building at 616 DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, to a client of Anthony E. Maglio. The size of the plot is 23 by 75 feet and the property is assessed at $10,500. Davis Quat represented the seller.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., April 9 -- Making their fourth appearance in four days in a military camp, the Giants today finished their week's program of providing entertainment for men in service by defeating the Mitchel Field Fliers, 18 to 5.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 9 -- The growing might of the United States Navy, with emphasis on airplane carriers and destroyer escorts, was translated into stirring facts and figures by Secretary Knox tonight at an Indianapolis rally opening the second war loan ...

CHICAGO, April 9 -- The one place in the automobile picture that is not clouded by shortage of supplies or priority tangles, namely repair parts, is facing a difficult year due to an acute lack of labor, according to E.E. Peters, of the Chicago headquarters staff of the Motor and Equipment Wholesalers Association, which will open a three-day conference here Monday.

A vast audience crowded the Metropolitan Opera House last night to see and to hear a stage version of J.S. Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew," presented as a "modern form of miracle play" by Leopold Stokowski, the conductor, with the collaboration of Robert Edmond Jones, the scenic artist, and George Balanchine, the dancer, and various cohorts of musicians, dancers and "mimes" under their command.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- When Uncle Sam borrowed Mrs. Philip L. Crowlie to advise the Office of Price Administration on pricing and rationing food and clothing, he did not give her any red tape for apron strings.

Inspired by that picture in yesterday's paper of General Eisenhower and General Montgomery shaking hands in Tunisia, having come respectively from the Atlantic Ocean and from the Nile all the way across North Africa, this department's private poet turned up with three lines of verse which seem not inappropriate, from whatever source derived:

MOSCOW, April 9 -- An eloquent tribute to Czechoslovak people, to their armed forces in Russia and to their commander, Colonel Ludovic Svoboda, has just been paid by Alexander Fadayev, president of the Soviet Writers Association, in Pravda.
LONDON, Saturday, April 10 (AP) -- The regular Soviet midnight communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

Two attractions, "Dancing in the Streets" and "Harem Scarem," close their tryout tours this evening in Boston and Pittsburgh, respectively. Both are scheduled to undergo repairs before resuming their careers in six weeks or so.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Income payments to individuals in February were 29 per cent above those of the year before and 96 per cent greater than in the same month in 1939, the Department of Commerce reported today. Their total of $10,428,000,000 was below the January figure of $10,725,000,000, but the decline was less than seasonal.
BOSTON, April 9 -- Willie Pep staged a final-round rally that enabled him to beat Sal Bartolo, veteran Boston campaigner, in a briskly fought ten-round bout at the Boston Garden tonight.

The cooperation of parents and citizens in all communities is necessary to insure the protection of underprivileged children in wartime, Miss Martha F. Allen, national executive of the Campfire Girls, said yesterday before 100 delegates from Middle Atlantic councils at the annual luncheon of District 2, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The five women on the General Sessions jury that is trying Manolo Espejo, 30-year-old, undersized Filipino, for bigamy wept softly yesterday, and their seven men associates shifted in their chairs repeatedly as the second wife of the defendant, a mother, although only 14, with a childish lisp revealed her love for him and told of their happiness from their marriage in this city last August up to Espejo's arrest in December.

Wendell L. Willkie has received and would like to accept an invitation to visit Australia. Should the State Department grant him a passport, he then will have visited virtually all the principal war arenas.

Activity in the new investment market here this week was less than a third of the volume of the week before and was limited to a single issue of industrial bonds totaling $20,000,000. In the preceding week public subscription was invited for six assorted flotations amounting to $78,575,000, and in this week a year ago, five municipal loans aggregating $22,068,300 were marketed.

OTTAWA, April 9 (Canadian Press) -- C.D. Howe, Munitions and Supply Minister, said tonight that until reports giving the extent of the cut of pulpwood in Canada during the past Winter were available it was impossible to say what the newsprint situation would be.

Machines Would Aid, Settling of Thinly Inhabited Areas in U.S., Designer Claims Within ten years after the war hundreds of thousands, possibly a million, helicopters will be in the hands of American private plane owners, Igor I. Sikorsky, designer and builder of the highly successful Vought-Sikorsky rotary aircraft, told 600 automotive and aeronautical engineers last night.

The annual proxy notice of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., forwarded yesterday to stockholders, discloses that five resolutions will be submitted at the annual stockholders' meeting on May 17, all of which the management is opposing and against which it is soliciting proxy votes.

DETROIT, April 9 (AP) -- The second of two work stoppages which interrupted production of war vehicles in the Ford Motor Company's. Rouge and Highland Park plants was settled tonight and company spokesmen said that they expected production would be back at normal tomorrow.

LONDON, April 9 -- Johann Nygaardsvold, Premier of the Norwegian Government-in-exile, told his fellow-countrymen over a radio tonight that the Norwegian Army was "preparing to play an important role during the reconquest of our country."
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 9 -Following is the text of the address delivered this evening at the cruiser Vincennes war bond rally:

In your issue of March 3 you published a letter from Mrs. Margaret Chanler Aldrich concerning the education subsidized by the Boxer indemnity. As one having been on the board from its foundation, I probably am in a position to answer some of the questions raised in this letter as well as any one else.

Election of William S. Street and Luther H. Hodges as vice presidents of Marshall Field Co. was announced yesterday by Hughston M. McBain, president, following the annual meeting of directors. Mr. Street is general manager of Marshall Field's Chicago and suburban retail stores and Mr. Hodges is general manager of the company's manufacturing division, with headquarters in New York.

The annual report of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., announced yesterday, disclosed for 1942 a net profit of $3,684,158 after $5,500,000 for Canadian income and excess profits taxes, and other charges, equal to $2.22 a share on the combined Class A and Class B stocks. The net profit includes $465,000 tax provision which is refundable to the company two years after the war ends.

A couple of Dodger left-fielders disturbed the peace of mind of both Managers Leo Durocher and Joe McCarthy at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the Yanks and Dodgers tangled in the first of their three week-end clashes. But in the end it was only Lippy Leo's equanimity that was restored as the Bums eked out a 4-3 decision.

WASHINGTON, April 9-Acting under authority of an order issued Saturday by the War Production Board, the Office of Defense Transportation moved today to keep some fifty vehicles owned by the Empire Trucking Corporation in operation in the New York milkshed.

The members of the Captain Edward L. Grant Post 1225, American Legion, named in honor of the former major league third baseman who lost his life in the first World War, believe that his name should be placed in baseball's Hall of Fame at Cooperstown, N.Y.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 9 (AP) -- With no special trains or buses scheduled to run and taxicab service very much in doubt, but with the parking lots open to private cars, Narragansett Park tomorrow will open New England's second wartime racing season.

Charged with having threatened Victor Hurwitz, former assistant district attorney and now counsel for Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, A.F. of L., three elevator operators, described by their counsel as members of an anti-administration faction in the local, were paroled for hearing next Tuesday by Magistrate Raphael Koenig in Yorkville Court yesterday.

Five firemen were overcome, three of them seriously enough to require hospital treatment, in a fire in the Supreme Mattress Company store, 707 Avenue U, Brooklyn, a little before 6 o'clock last night.

OTTAWA, April 9 -- The Canadian Government has decided to establish a Consulate General in New York, Prime Minister Mackenzie King announced today in Parliament. It is expected that the new office will be opened about May 1 under the direction of Hugh D. Scully as Consul General.

LONDON, April 9 -- Activity in the stock markets here was restrained today by the approach of the government's budget, but the tone was cheerful. Gilt-edge stocks were again dull, with old Consols at 82, and local loans at 96 1/4, each 1/8 down. Home rails hardened, Great Western gaining 1/4 to 59 1/4.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Legislation to award medals of honor to war correspondents who are wounded or distinguish themselves by conspicuous service in actual combat was proposed today by Representative Dewey, Republican of Illinois.

Play for the most highly rated contract bridge title for which tournament players compete, the national masters' individual championship, began at the Park Central Hotel here last night. The field in this annual contest is limited to thirty-six entrants, invited in the order of their bridge ranking, and almost all are of "life master" or "senior master" standing in the rankings of the American Contract Bridge League.

The report of the United Corporation, Public utility holding company, for the first three months of this year, made public yesterday, shows a net income, after expenses and taxes, of $911,131. This was equal to 36 cents a share on the corporation's outstanding $3 preference stock, and compares with a net of $1,185,528, or 47 cents a preferred share, in the March quarter of 1942.

LONDON, April 9 -- Despite Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden's clear-cut statement that Britain and the United States see eye to eye on the French political sitution, there remains a carping note in the British critical weeklies suggesting that there was some underlying ulterior purpose connected with General Dwight D. Eisenhower's request that General Charles de Gaulle postpone his visit to North Africa.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, chairman of the Legislative Committee on Nutrition, said today that preliminary investigations by his committee indicated large quantities of black market meat were being sold throughout the State.

A Bible in Every Kit" is the slogan of the American Bible Society expressed in a letter to its friends and supporters issued yesterday from Bible House, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, saying the organization "needs $150,000 for this purpose."

The stock market experienced yesterday its worst shake-out since late 1941 as inflationary psychology was stifled suddenly by the Presidential order installing more rigid restrictions on wages and prices. Losses ranged from 1 to 3 points, with a few issues undermined as much as 4 points, and the list exposed at its worst level of the day at the close.

Now that public opinion has expressed approval through the medium of the Gallup Poll on the question of whether baseball and other professional sports should be continued during the war, it seems to me that proper steps should be taken to keep necessary athletes on the playing fields.

Discontinuance of the housekeeping unit in this city would appear to be a short-sighted policy and unwise economy. Operated under WPA funds since its establishment in 1934, the service has provided care for thousands of households and has supplied "mothers" to sick children or families who are hit by sudden disasters or emergencies.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Plans for the establishment of immediate price ceilings and controls on wheat, cotton, fresh fish, fresh fruits and certain other commodities were announced today as government agencies moved to give full effect to the stringent economic controls imposed by President Roosevelt's "hold-the-line" inflation order.

Sales of leading chains and mail order companies showed an increase of 3.1 per cent in March, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The gain was well under the rise of 11.2 per cent reported for February.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- A Winter wheat crop of 558,551,000 bushels was forecast today by the Department of Agriculture in a report that said over-all crop prospects declined in March as the result of unfavorable weather and delays in farm work.

CHICAGO, April 9 (AP) -- The Multnomah Club of Portland, Ore., captured the first three places in the 100-yard free-style tonight to compile 10 points for a wide lead over twelve other organizations for the team championship of the Women's National A.A.U. swimming and diving meet.

A total of 140 entries hit the trail that will lead eleven of their number to 1943 national A.A.U. wrestling championships at the West Side Y.M.C.A. last night. It was a surprisingly large entry, one of the biggest the tournament has over drawn, and indicated that of all sports wrestling has felt the effect of the war least.

Although net sales of the International Paper Company and subsidiaries, amounting to $209,400,055 in 1942, were only 2 per cent below the $214,334,236 reported for 1941, it was announced yesterday in the company's report for last year, the amount available after all charges, taxes and preferred dividend requirements was only $1,264,985, or 69 cents a share, on 1,823,855 common shares.

The possibility of standardization of the shoe industry loomed here yesterday, when it was reported that such a program was under consideration by OPA at an industry conference in Washington. It was believed in trade circles that if such action were taken models, materials and prices would be controlled from manufacture to final distribution and shoes would probably be sold under three or four price brackets.

Governor Thomas E. Dewey and the Chief Executives of two other leading Eastern States asked yesterday for a return to the States of powers granted to the Federal Government in the prosecution of the war as a prime need in postwar recovery.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- By a vote of 270 to 107 the House today adopted the Hobbs anti-labor racketeering bill after accepting from the Judiciary Committee, which reported it, an amendment designed to make it less unpalatable to organized labor.

If it were possible to be in England this April one might meet on some country lane a man on a bicycle who looked as though his name were not so much Hugh or Oliver or Reginald as Giuseppe or Salvatore or Pasquale. He might be dark-complexioned, and he might be whistling or singing an operatic strain, and he might be an Italian prisoner of war on his way to work.

LONDON, April 9 -- Axis U-boats attacking an Atlantic convoy last month sank Britain's famous Hero Class destroyer Harvester, the Admiralty disclosed today, but the loss was avenged by the Fighting French corvette Aconit, which sank two of the submarines.

The Treasury Department's national "Art for Bonds" exhibition of thirty-six original paintings by distinguished American artists, which will soon be shown throughout the nation in poster form in behalf of the second War Bond drive, was opened yesterday afternoon at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

The recent elections in Denmark, in which the Nazis received the support of only 2 per cent of the electorate, demonstrated that although Denmark could not be a military bulwark for the north, she has once more fulfilled her mission as the spiritual bulwark for humanism, for true northern culture, Henrik Kauffmann, Danish Minister to the United States, declared last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 -- How they escaped from a circle of twenty Japanese destroyers after their little PT boat had just sunk the twenty-first destroyer with three well-aimed "fish," was told here today by one of three seagoing "cowboys" back from the Solomons.

The National Association of Women Artists is presenting a series of demonstrations and talks during its fifty-first annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Gallery. As announced, the demonstrations will be given at 3 o'clock on the days listed in the following schedule:
There are several factors which must be analyzed carefully before any further consideration is given to the suggestion that the height of the basketball basket be raised to twelve feet.

The Rev. Joseph Assmuth, Professor of Zoology and Entomology at Fordham University and pioneer in the science of termite control, will mark the fiftieth anniversary of his entrance into the Jesuit order today. Because of the Lenten season, formal celebration of the event by the Jesuit community at Fordham will be postponed until May 2.

The Board of Estimate, which on Thursday listened for nearly five hours to the pleas of taxpayers for a substantial cut in Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44, spent almost six hours yesterday hearing the arguments of city employes and municipal service groups for pay rises of 15 per cent that would increase the Mayor's budget total far above its present level.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, with the nostaligc flavor of the Nineties and some modernistic flourishes, opened last night in Madison Square Garden. It was the Big Show, warm with color and taut with thrills, that brought applause and cheers from the 14,212 spectators.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Senate today under unanimous consent ordered THE NEW YORK TIMES survey revealing college freshmen's lack of knowledge of American history published as a Senate document.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Roosevelt signed the bill authorizing officers of armed services to act as notaries public during war or national emergency and the bill granting pay increases to some employes in the postal system, met with the Cabinet and held his press conference; his visitors included Representative Bulwinkle, Maury Maverick, the Belgian Ambassador and August Raymond Schryver, Representative Kleborg, Representative Slaughter and Commander Robert T. Marill with Florence Ollila and Omar Ketchum.

In an appeal yesterday for additional volunteers on the home front, Mayor La Guardia called for stricter enforcement of price ceilings, declaring that "it is not going to be easy for black markets and chiselers in New York City."
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

INDIANAPOLIS, April 9 -- For a youth of 25 Lou Boudreau is a surprisingly somber and serious young man. No gray hairs sprinkle his black locks as yet, but it is not for the lack of worry. From a carefree, happy-go-lucky ball player, Boudreau has become a solemn manager, bearing the woes of the world on his shoulders.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- A misconstruction placed by traders on President Roosevelt's order to freeze prices and wages led today to general selling of grain futures at the opening of the Board of Trade which carried wheat off around 2 1/2 cents a bushel; corn, 1 cent; oats, 1 3/8 cents, and rye, 3 cents to the lowest price of the current downturn.

NEWARK, N.J., April 9 -- New Jersey had a surprise blackout test lasting forty-three minutes tonight, the first since the abortive drill on March 9, when the Army failed to send out the alert signals.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY IN TUNISIA, April 8 (Delayed) -- Soon after American troops and contingents of the British Eighth Army had effected their junction on the Gafsa-Gabes road yesterday and continued on their separate ways, several British armored cars detached from the main body were surrounded by a superior enemy force.

LONDON, April 9 (U.P.) -- Two British liberal weeklies, in attacks on the bombing policy of the United States Army Air Forces in this theatre, intimated today that German propagandists, by giving uncontradicted reports that thousands of French and other civilians were being killed, might be successful in turning people of the occupied countries against the Allies.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 9 -- Steps to resuscitate the moribund Balkan Entente under the aegis of the Italian Foreign Office are drawing to a quasi-successful close in Bucharest, Rumania, under the guise of economic negotiations, according to reports today from both Ankara, Turkey, and Budapest, Hungary.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Persistent reports that the United States is getting a substantial share of the crude rubber now in Japanese hands as a result of Axis conquests in the Pacific were dismissed as "fantasy" today by government officials whose responsibilities include the acquisition of raw materials for the war effort.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- With organized labor deeply disturbed by what it regards as rigidity in President Roosevelt's new executive order on wages, it was announced today that the War Labor Board would ask James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, to issue clarifying directives if the board encountered difficulties or hardships in administering the order.

The cotton futures market sold off nervously at the outset yesterday on President Roosevelt's directive to halt the upward spiral of prices and wages, subsequently recovered to within 5 to 10 points of the previous closing levels and then returned to the downward trend in late dealings.

Labor and management cooperating on a voluntary basis in most sections of this State are already carrying out an effective program to end the pirating of labor, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday, in discussing President Roosevelt's latest move toward job stabilization.

William D. Frad, 63-year-old card player who lost a very happy hunting ground when the transatlantic liners stopped carrying wealthy and venturesome men to and from Europe, was convicted yesterday of failing to pay all the income tax he should have on his winnings for 1936 and 1937.

Further indication that New York has its greatest concentration of thoroughbreds was afforded yesterday when officials at Jamaica found it necessary for the first time in the history of the Paumonok Handicap, that goes back to 1906, to split today's renewal into two divisions.
LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- The midday Russian communique as recorded by the Soviet radio monitor:
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 9 (U.P.) -- Danes and Norwegians began their fourth year under Nazi rule today.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The following is the roll-call vote by which the House today passed the Hobbs Anti-Racketeering Bill:

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- By a unanimous vote and without debate the Senate adopted today the resolution of Senator Byrd of Virginia, calling upon the War Labor Board to submit by May 10 a full and detailed accounting of all industrial wage increases it has approved since it was created in January of 1942, and the effect of the rises on basic hourly rates and weekly earnings.

Anthony Eden concluded his report to the House of Commons on his trip to this country and Canada with a statement he made frequently while he was here. "I have come back, I say frankly," he declared, "with a different view of the sentiments of the United States toward both this struggle and the post-war period."

COLONEL W.F. KERNAN is a man of unexceptionable principles. Last year, in his "Defense Will Not Win the War," he made an eloquent plea for an offensive strategy. This year, in "We Can Win This War,"* he continues his argument against spreading our forces thin over all the islands of the sea. Global strategy, to him, is no strategy; it is just a way of trying to be strong everywhere, which is impossible.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 9 -- The forces of Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc's Fighting French and General Henri Honore Giraud have been cooperating for some time without regard to political considerations, it now can be revealed.

Another export market, Spain, has been lost to American producers of copper sulphate through apparent extension to that country of the British-American joint area agreement dividing up world markets for the product, it was reported here yesterday by chemical exporters.

The effect of war on menus for the high-chair trade are reflected in problems being encountered by dietitians in the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street. Vegetables, such as cabbage, turnips, parsnips and Brussels sprouts, which have been dubbed "victory" foods because they are comparatively plentiful, are no solution for the 300 small charges there.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- The absence of a United Nations policy is the one thing upon which the Axis pins its hope of driving a political wedge into the phalanx of the Allies, Count Ferdinand Czernin, chairman of the American Federation of Austrian Democrats, declared tonight at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

While we are all united in the determination to win the war, which sooner or later we will, there are still among us not a few in influential positions who are at heart opposed to America's participation and leadership in the great but onerous and perpetual task of founding and maintaining peace and order in a world now tattered and torn.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- RKO will release the film version of Lloyd C. Douglas's best-seller, "The Robe," and a minimum expenditure of $2,000,000 for its production has been guaranteed, it was announced today. Frank Ross, who bought the screen rights to the book for $100,000, while it was still unfinished, will produce the picture in Technicolor late this Summer on the RKO lot.

" Moscow Dateline: February 1941-February, 1943," is the title of the new book on Russia to be published late in May by Houghton Mifflin. Henry J. Cassidy, the author, head of The Associated Press Bureau in Moscow, recently returned to the United States after two and a half years in Russia.

Advertising linage in monthly magues for April continued to make good gains over their corresponding 1942 issues, according to compilations yesterday. April volume was about 12 per cent ahead of the like 1942 period on a linage basis and the four months gain was about 7 per cent.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 9 -- The victor today in the $1,000 free-for-all stake, feature of the English Setter Club of Americas Spring field trials, was the pointer Claussen's Ranger Doone, owned by Euclid Claussen of Augusta, Ga., and handled by Fred Bevan.

Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, who is overseas, announced yesterday the elevation of three priests, all of whom are Archdiocesan Consulters, to the rank of Prothonotary Apostolic, which raises its bearer to "the highest college of prelates in the Roman Curia" and gives him certain ceremonial privileges of a Bishop.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- To the Association of American Railroads and the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., have been presented the first Booker T. Washington awards of the National Association of Negroes in American Industry for outstanding achievements in industrial employment of Negroes.

William Fox, former motion picture producer, now serving a year and a day in the Federal penitentiary, will be paroled on May 3, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin was informed yesterday by Emil K. Ellis, his attorney here.
A few chips of wood daily are vital ingredients of the American home-front ration.

A court action to test the validity of the new legislative reapportionment law was begun yesterday in Queens Supreme Court less than twenty-four hours after Governor Thomas E. Dewey had signed the measure.

In his battle against inflation, the President, following his courageous veto of the Bankhead bill, has taken a step forward of the first importance. His new Executive Order is accompanied by the most vigorous anti-inflation statement that he has yet made. He appropriately calls his latest move a "hold the line" order:

Leaving the field clear for the Second War Loan Drive, only $1,307,207 of new municipal financing has been scheduled for award next week. This is the smallest total of any week thus far this year, according to Daily Bond Buyer. Next week's total compares with this week's revised total of $7,188,200 and with the weekly average for 1943 to date of $19,403,202.
LONDON, April 9 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:
The address of Governor Thomas E. Dewey yesterday at a regional meeting of the Council of State Governments at the Hotel Roosevelt follows:

LONDON, April 9 -- Herbert H. Lehman, United States Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, who arrived here last night to explore the postwar relief needs of European countries, called on Ambassador John G. Winant at the United States Embassy today and held preliminary conversations with American officials who have been in constant touch with the Leith-Ross committee.

The American automobile of the period immediately following the war is likely to be the 1942 model with such modifications and improvements as can be made without important engineering development or changes in tools, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of General Motors, announced yesterday in a message to the corporation's automobile dealers.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, April 10 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Josephine Tencza, 17 years old, who is accused of operating a juvenile vice ring on the lower East Side, was arraigned in General Sessions Court yesterday on an indictment charging her with abduction and impairing the morals of a minor. But at the request of Assistant District Attorney Whitman Knapp she was paroled to the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, pending an investigation whether she can be "rehabilitated."

CAIRO, Egypt, April 9 -- Marshal Rommel's shattered forces re treating toward Sfax along the coastal road were subjected to the most intense air pounding Wednesday night and from dawn to dusk yesterday. The flow of traffic moving under cover of darkness was located by Halifaxes and Wellingtons through close cooperation of naval aircraft and they heavily bombed enemy motor transport and encampments along the Mahares-Sfax road, leaving fires blazing.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 (AP) -- A communique of the United States Army Air Force:

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Bond Stores, Inc., of 261 Fifth Avenue, New York, which has manufacturing plants at Rochester, N.Y., and New Brunswick, N.J., and retail stores in various cities, has promised the Federal Trade Commission to desist from certain merchandising practices.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 9 (AP) -- A communique:

SOMEWHERE IN NORTH AFRICA, April 9 (AP) -- General Sir Harold R. L. G. Alexander, deputy commander under General Dwight D. Eisenhower in charge of all land operations, said today that the junction of American and British forces in Southern Tunisia would mean a tremendous relief to Allied shipping.

Today's events: Dorothy Eustis, piano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; William Masselos, piano, and Rashella Jelnik, soprano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Alexander Kipnis, bass, McMillin Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street, 8:30; Liederkranz Male Chorus and Orchestra, 111 East Fifty-eighth Street, 8:15; Helvetia Maennerchor, Town Hall, 8:15.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, Administrator of the War Shipping Administration, declared today that the two proposals in the over-all plan of shipping reorganization proposed by maritime unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations were "wholly unwise" and impracticable.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Representatives of more than 130 colleges and universities from all parts of the country were told today by officials of the government and leading industrialists that the present and post-war need of trained personnel, including women, was greater than ever in the nation's history.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Hobbs bill, sponsored by Representative Hobbs of Alabama, seeks to strengthen the 1934 racketeering law by defining robbery and extortion in the interference with interstate commerce.

LONDON, Saturday, April 10 (AP) -- An Algiers radio broadcast recorded last night by Reuter said General Georges Catroux, Fighting French liaison representative between General Charles de Gaulle and General Henri Honore Giraud, left Algiers yesterday for London after winding up his conferences with General Giraud.

NEW DELHI, India, April 9 (U.P.) -- American airmen yesterday struck a crippling blow against Japanese ground operations in Northwestern Burma by destroying a large supply dump accumulated by the enemy in the jungles around Shingbwiyang, the Tenth United States Air Force announced today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 9 -- Using only reserve pitchers, the Yale nine was routed, 18 -- 0, by the Braves today before 1,500 spectators. The National Leaguers made twenty hits.

JERSEY CITY, April 9 -- Cornell, New York University, Hunter and Jersey City State Teachers, as a result of tonight's competition, will enter the final portion of the fifteenth annual women's intercollegiate foil fencing championships tomorrow deadlocked for the team laurels with three successes apiece. Nine colleges are represented in the tournament on the strips of the Jersey City Teachers, defending team.

Retail trade here this week was favored both by mild weather and comparison of sales with the post-Easter period last year. Increases of 10 per cent or more for department stores here were estimated. Specialty shop gains were larger.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 9 -- Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, once financial dictator of Germany and influential factor in shaping early financial policies of the Nazi regime, has retired to Lienzi, a quiet spot in the Tyrol, according to private advices from Berlin.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Four Allied vessels, including a destroyer, the majority of which were presumed to be United States vessels, were sunk in the large-scale Japanese air attack on shipping near Guadalcanal Island three days ago, the Navy Department announced today.

E. Roland Harriman of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., was named permanent chairman yesterday of the Red Cross Greater New York Camp and Hospital Council, which will unify Red Cross units serving camps and hospitals within the area.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The text of the reply of Rear Admiral Emory S. Land, War Shipping Administrator, to proposals of the Congress of Industrial Organizations for a reorganization of American shipping operations is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted permission today to the Houston Gulf Gas Company to effect a series of transactions which would enable it to convey to the Federal Government for $2,625,000 a natural-gas transmission line in Texas for conversion into an oil pipe line.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 9 -- Marauding Allied airmen, sweeping by daylight throughout France to blast freight and passenger trains with bombs and cannon fire, are slowly but steadily paralyzing the Nazi-used railway system of the country, according to reliable information received here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 9 -- A preview of the Westchester Warfair, an exposition arranged by 2,000 defense workers to dramatize the wartime transition of life in the suburbs, was held tonight at the County Center for the heads of county, State and national defense organizations.

The Crop Reporting Board of the Department of Agriculture issued yesterday its first estimate on the indicated yield of wheat from this year's Winter crop. Although it forecast an output of only 558,551,000 bushels, a Winter wheat crop of that size would be more than enough for the nation's demand when the Spring crop and the huge carryover from previous crops are added.

Cattle were steady! and lambs steady to 10 cents higher than[ yesterday. The report of the United States] Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Navy communique 338:

The Germans boast that their line of defense for the "impregnable" Fortress of Europe is now 125 miles longer than the Great Wall of China. If this propaganda could be accepted at its face value it would betray a curiously subdued mentality in the conquerors of the Maginot Line.

From the dusty terraced plains of Honan, in the valley of the Yellow River, come new reports of starving millions of Chinese. Word of the Honan famine reached this country six months ago. It was then estimated that about 20,000,000 people were affected. That is still the high estimate.

As is its habit on Saturdays, this department presents today a set of menus designed to be used during the forthcoming week. These meals, which are patterned specifically for a family of four (a moderately active man and woman, a boy of 13 and a girl of 11), lay particular stress on fresh vegetables, supplies of which are increasing as the Spring season advances.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 9 -- Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel's forces hastened their retreat today, abandoning Mahares, fifty miles north of Gabes, and leaving nearly 12,000 troops as prisoners of the British and American forces since the Eighth Army's breakthrough at the Wadi el Akarit last Tuesday.

The stock market reacted sharply yesterday in response to the latest White House move to curb inflationary tendencies. Prices dropped 1 to 3 points, and in scattered instances as much as 4. It was the worst shakeout for the market since late 1941 and was tied in to the Washington developments, as a substantial part of the buying in recent months had been prompted by inflationary signals.

The Laurel and Hardy comedy, "Air Raid Wardens," enters a second week today at the Rialto.... Revivals of two Swedish films, "Soliga Solberg," and "Goda Vanner Och Trogna Grannar," open an engagement today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.... Revivals of "All That Money Can Buy," and the French picture, "Crime in the Maginot Line," will be shown today through Tuesday at the Park Theatre....
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- President Roosevelt signed today a bill providing for pay increases for postal employes, effective until June 30, 1945.

Young people do like music, and libraries with their wealth of material about music and musicians are logical places for young people to hear and make music. No one ever thinks of including in library appropriations money for such items as records and pianos, although books of music would be doubly influential if they were brought to life in sound.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Point values for meats under the present rationing system will be subject to considerable alteration before the month is over, Prentiss M. Brown, Administrator of the OPA, told the House Committee on Small Business today.

LONDON, Saturday, April 10 (AP) -- Russian troops, charging out of their defenses near Balakleya, thirty-five miles southeast of Kharkov, killed 1,200 Germans yesterday in hand-to-hand fighting, Moscow announced early today.

Earnings last year of the Consolidated Oil Corporation rose $2,000,000 over those of 1941, despite an increase of $4,000,000 in taxes, according to the annual report of H.F. Sinclair, president, issued yesterday.

In its first purchase of a Manhattan property in some years, the Alliance Realty Company has acquired the five-story business building at 572 Fifth Avenue on a lot 25 by 100 feet, near Forty-seventh Street. The sale of the structure by the Mutual Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, which recently negotiated the sale of 581-83 Fifth Avenue to A. Wells Peck.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee considered today the request of the National Resources Planning Board for a renewal of its appropriation (which was reduced by the Senate last year and was eliminated by the House this year) and asked for more data before deciding the issue.
Max Macon and Ed Head yesterday shut out the Yankees with only five safe blows while the Dodgers made it two straight over Joe McCarthy's champions at the Yankee Stadium. The score was 3 to 0.

KITTY BARNE has already given us two stories of wartime England which were revealing as well as amusing. Now she has spun a tale to set beside Marie McSwigan's "Snow Treasure," for like that one of young patriots' silent heroism this is a vivid story of Norway under the German heel.
Queens College walked and batted to a 10-to-7 victory over Columbia at Baker Field yesterday in the opening game of the letter's baseball season. A seven-run rally in the ninth settled the issue.

THIS enlightening description of the debacle in the West in 1940 by a French staff officer who was a participant in the tragic events fully deserves to be given a careful study by military as well as civilian readers.

MOST folks who enjoy working with plants find real satisfaction in producing a few high-quality apples, pears, peaches, plums and other fruits in their own back yards. It is not difficult to grow well-colored, high-quality fruit provided the varieties are suited to the location and provided the trees are given reasonable care.

American skiing lost one of its most promising young athletes several days ago when 17-year-old Johnny Neal of the Lake Placid Northwood School succumbed to internal injuries sustained when he overjumped the "Little Headwall" on Mount Washington.

WRITERS of historical romance are forever beset by the problem of keeping history and fiction in proper balance. History should not be allowed to overshadow the story, nor should the story distort the essential facts of history.

The only two Greek underground newspapers ever seen in the United States are part of an exhibit of Greece under the Axis that opened yesterday in City College's Lincoln Corridor. The papers were smuggled out of the country by escaping refugees and were lent to the college by the Greek Office of Information.
CHICAGO, April 10 -- When private Ludwig Fuchsel of Hoboken, N.J., entered the Chicago Service Men's Center Number 2 in the Loop at 11 A.M. today Mayor Edward J. Kelly stopped him:

The following hints are abridged from an "A B C for Child Care Aides," a little handbook of useful reminders for volunteers, issued by the Division of Child Care of the American Women's Voluntary Services of Greater New York. (Available to any one for 10 cents, from the AWVS, 11 East Fifty-eighth Street.) The director of the division, Mrs. Max J.H. Rossbach, supervised the text; Miss Peggy Frank did the drawings.

THOUGHTFULLY sized and priced for the convenience of the young, this little book makes it possible for the 8-year-old as well as his older brothers and sisters to do his share of Victory gardening this year. Simply and explicitly it describes each step in the planning and planting of a five-foot square plot, designed for easy cultivation.

A strange ninth inning that produced nine runs on three hits, one error, five bases on balls and a struck batsman ended three hours of frigid, windblown baseball between New York University and St. John's and gave the Violet victory at 15 to 14 on Ohio Field yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, April 10 (AP) -- A communique:

CORALBELLS, though none too common, are excellent for border planting or the rock garden and lend distinction wherever found. Botanically named Heuchera sanguinea and also called alumroot, they respond readily to intelligent care.

WHEN Captain Maurice Evans arrived in Hawaii early last December only 10 per cent of the tens of thousands of soldiers in this war theatre has even seen a stage show, either before or since entering the Army.

Hedge selling, attributed to the announcement that ceiling prices would be imposed on cotton, depressed the future market yesterday in brisk trading. The list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the session's lows at net losses of 3 to 15 points.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Resignations from the domestic branch of the Office of War Information reached a total of fourteen tonight, including two more division chiefs.

THE news along the bistro belt this week concerns the unveiling of a new Broadway late spot, the presentation of three Spring shows and the return of Libby Holman to the local cafe scene. The first mentioned of these events takes place Wednesday evening when Herbert Jacoby opens the doors of the Blue Angel at 152 East Fifty-fifth Street.

As Under-Secretary of State Welles says in his letter to Professor Ralph Barton Perry of Harvard, one has to know much about the North African political situation to assess accurately the United States policy, or rather the United Nations policy, in that region. The inference is clear, and probably correct, that a great many people who have been throwing brick-bats at Washington do not know sufficiently all the angles of the issues involved.

In the Summer of 1940, while the Nazis were hoping to finish off Europe during our American political preoccupation, a sensitive woman wrote a deeply felt little essay. She saw that certain nations, whatever their fanatical errors, had divined better than the democracies how to arouse and discipline extraordinary mass energies.

DARTMOUTH'S assistant librarian, who is also a poet and novelist, writes this book in defense and application of the principle that "history is of no great use to us if it does not reveal the probable relationship between cause and effect, in terms of moral conduct."

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will give a popular-priced all-Russian program on Thursday evening, April 29, at Carnegie Hall, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, to aid the Red Cross War Fund. Mishel Piastro, concert master of the orchestra, will be soloist, playing Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto in D, Opus 35.

ASK a Texan about Roy Bean and you'll probably hear a dozen stories. Anecdotes, like the one about the time "Judge" Bean, finding $40 and a revolver on a corpse, fined the corpse $40 for carrying concealed weapons.

IT took a flight lieutenant in the Royal Air Force to solve the mystery of that queer race of air-minded people, the Gremlins, who, we learn with considerable relief, at last have been won to the United Nations' banner. Their story is told by Flight Lieutenant Roald Dahl in a little book soon to be published by Random House and illustrated by Walt Disney, from which the pictures on these pages were taken.

A MILITARY and naval reception for high-ranking officers of the various branches of service will be a distinctive feature of the Red, White and Blue Dinner Dance, an annual Springtime fete in aid of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, which will take place May 7 in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

MIAMI, Fla., April 10 -- A Navy flier who fell unconscious from a crashing plane was saved yesterday when the lines of his partly opened parachute became entangled with the shrouds of a parachute with which another flier was floating to safety.

IT is quite evident that when one undertakes to pick the biggest lie told by Adolf Hitler one at once undertakes to cover a wide territory indeed. The very record of the man is marked by a series of falsifications and deceptions perhaps beyond the record of any other man who has played a role in public life.

After 2 partial premiere earlier in the week while it was still unfinished, Antony Tudor's "narrative ballet" on Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" was revealed in its entirety last night by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House.

JOHN SHIRLEY HURST has found the perfect setting for a modern love story. The growing awareness that China's destiny is linked with ours gives added significance to this story of China in those desperate days when she stood defenseless and alone against our common foe.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 10 -- Moving rapidly from one crisis to another, the political situation in Bulgaria is approaching a climax. King Boris yesterday assumed the de facto charge of foreign affairs from his erstwhile Minister, Bogdan Philoff, who has been relegated to the post of Under-Secretary, according to reports received in diplomatic quarters here tonight.

LONDON, April 10 -- General Charles de Gaulle, who was said to have been taken completely aback earlier in the week by General Dwight D. Eisenhower's request that he delay his projected visit to Algiers, has sent the Allied Commander in Chief in North Africa an enthusiastic message of encouragement over the fighting, it was revealed today.

BHOPAL, Central India, April 5 (Delayed) -- This is the second largest Moslem-ruled State in India, and it is one of the best run. Its people are better fed and clothed and generally happier than anywhere the writer has been in British India.

One reader who normally has a good opinion of this column now writes in to say, presumably more in sorrow than in anger, that we were guilty the other day of distorting facts. The thing happened in a discussion of American history and how often in the books we find fact sacrificed to dogma.

ALTHOUGH there are in Manhattan certain provincial folk who regard Brooklyn as a foreign and in hospitable country so remote as to be hardly worth thinking about, the facts are entirely contrary. To be sure, in Brooklyn the Bums are heroes and all visiting teams are vice versa, but taking the tolerant point of view this is no more than a pleasant form of chauvinism.

Thirty-seven men and women, as well as twenty-two children -- all farmers -- en route yesterday from their homes at Clarksburg, W. Va., to Stafford Springs, Conn., stopped long enough at the Pennsylvania Station to emphasize that they welcomed the opportunity "to do farm work and help the nation's war effort."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, April 11 (AP) -- A Japanese merchant ship was destroyed and another small ship set afire by Allied planes that dropped thirty tons of bombs on Wewak, New Guinea, the High Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt put a "stop" order on inflation this week. It was, as he conceded, long overdue. Only time could tell whether it would be successful in view of the inflationary pressures now in existence.

Truesdale Clarke of Rochester, N.Y., led thirty-six of the highest-ranking contract bridge players in the country at the end of three sessions of play in the national master's individual championship at the Park Central Hotel here last night.

MRS. FERGUSON complains that her weekly grocery bill averages $5 more than it did a year ago. Mrs. Slater says that her favorite storekeeper has become so rude that he fairly takes her head off if she asks him why he hasn't any cocoa.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Political analysts differ, in some cases probably according to party affiliations, as to the conclusions to be drawn from the results of last Tuesday's Mayoralty election in Chicago.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- June and Joan Fogle, the sensational swimming sisters of Indianapolis' Riviera Club, won two championships in the second round of the Women's National A.A.U. indoor meet tonight to give the Hoosier organization 21 points to 28 for the Multnomah Club of Portland, Ore., in the team competition.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 10 (AP) -- General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery gave the British Eighth Army this motto in a message released today:

In your Magazine of Sunday, March 28, there appeared an article on Gandhi by your corre spondent, Herbert L. Matthews. In it Mr. Matthews speaks of Gandhi's mixing up politics with religion -- and why shouldn't he?

TWO mid-Spring luncheon-fashion shows, each of which has elicited widespread interest, will be given this week to aid respectively a notable New York philanthropic organization and an internationally known war relief agency.

DURING World War I a wave of horticultural hysteria swept the country, forcing misguided but patriotic amateurs to sacrifice perfectly good lawns to dubious potatoes. Again we are faced with a fresh wave of precisely similar scope and quite possibly leading to even worse results, for there is as much shortage of fertilizer, seed and insecticides as of food.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- More than 300 individuals who tried to profit from black-market operations in meats have been brought to book on criminal charges since Jan. 15. The individuals in most cases permitted a greed for money to lead them into the error of confusing wartime strictness with the comparatively easy-going attitudes of peaceful years.

THERE has been a lot of writing and talk of recent years about the decline of the American theatre. And any survey of the present condition of Broadway would seem to show that much of this writing and talk is justified, Pessimism pretty general and heavy hangs over the once Great White Way, as you can read in the fast metropolitan dailies on any bright Sabbath morning.

BOSTON, April 10 (AP) -- Teddy Vogel, a 17-year-old Watertown runner who had a four-minute allowance, spurted the final 400 yards today to win the thirty-third annual Cathedral Club ten-mile road race, often used as a warm-up for the Boston A.A. marathon.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 10 -Some 18,000 racing fans, many of whom came by automobile, wagered $748,129 on a nine-race card at Narragansett Park today that opened the New England horse-racing season.

In my far-off younger days it was the custom of the youth of this country to take particular pride in its appearance. This applied to male and female alike. The lads saw to it that their shoes were shined -- we usually did the shining ourselves -- that their high, starched collars and their stiff-bosom shirts were clean and that their suits were brushed and pressed.

LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- Veiled hints of a tug-of-war between Adolf Hitler and Benito Mussolini with the Balkans as a pawn are reaching diplomatic circles in London and neutral countries, it was reported here today.

As a general rule when the American people determine upon a reform, they eventually get it. Reports indicate that over 80 per cent of all taxpayers, and a larger percentage of the smaller taxpayers than of the larger, are in favor of adopting a pay-as-you-earn tax plan.

IN his new book, entitled "One World," Wendell Willkie presents an exceedingly interesting report of his unusual trip around the world in September and October of 1942, coupled with a vigorous restatement of his view on world problems and America's relationship to them.

AN official announcement released by the postal authorities at Helsinki last December and just received in New York tells of a series of semi-postal stamps issued on Jan. 1 for the benefit of the Red Cross in Finland.

THE first half of the nineteenth century was open season for the literary-minded of England, after long or short visits to the United States, to write books of travel or appraisals, trends or politics. Frances Milton Trollope was among the first of these enterprising writers, and her "Domestic Manners of the Americans," published in 1832, was popular enough in her own country, but intensely irritating to the sensitive Americans who resented such unfair criticism.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The farm bloc in Congress, traditionally powerful and effective, has rushed headlong into its greatest and toughest fight since the advent of the New Deal. If it wins now it may lose in the end, for it has been made, along with labor, a symbol of uncontrolled inflation and its danger sign.

ONE of the least described sections of North America is that part of Mexico known as Baja California extending some eight hundred miles southward from the southern border of our own State of California.
FAMILIAR figures in the war-time scene receive advice from physicians and beauty authorities on how to keep their fingers faultlessly groomed in spite of shortages.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The report on his American visit that Anthony Eden, British Foreign Secretary, made in the House of Commons at London this week, together with the publication of the British and American currency proposals, afforded illuminating glimpses of the progress toward that Anglo-American cooperation which seems indispensable to a stable peace.
Reading your account of Mr. Morgan's will carries me back over the years. Do you remember his father's will? It was published in the morning newspapers of April 20, 1913.

IT is a curious bit of irony. When word went out that Colonel Darryl F. Zanuck, former production chief of Twentieth Century-Fox, was supervising a United States Signal Corps documentary film of November-December activity in Tunisia you naturally expected something pretty extraordinary, for Colonel Zanuck is a mighty man in Hollywood, accustomed to making miracles blossom where mere celluloid had been before.

A STRANGE assortment of people inhabited the wild farm by the Pacific in Mendocino County. There was the old man, who had been a fashionable clergyman in Maryland, ran off with the wife of one of his parishioners and living on after her death with Breck, her elder son, and Breck's wife.

The German people have been warned not to underrate the efficiency of the Allied powers' intelligence agents operating in Germany and have been told that they must continue to exercise the "greatest restraint" in their conversations because of the "serious spy danger," the Swedish newspaper Dagens Nyheter said in an article reported yesterday to the Office of War Information.

LIEUTENANT E.J. KAHN Jr. came in recently and told of writing conditions in the Army. "I typed some chapters wearing heavy gloves because the only typewriter I could borrow was on the stage of an unheated theatre in Australia.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., April 10 (AP) -- "Definite improvement" in the condition of the Negro people is expressed in the 1941-42 annual report just issued by President F.D. Patterson of Tuskegee Institute.
