ATLANTA, April 10 -- A meeting here this week, attended by more than a hundred white Southerners, many of them leaders in their fields, accepted in principle the statement of objectives issued last October by a conference of leading Southern Negroes at Durham, N.C., and moved in the direction of a better understanding and greater cooperation between the two races.

THE sight of the shimmering city of Casablanca strikes American troops with awe and almost bewildering wonderment; few of us have ever seen such a varied lot of humanity, even in the movies. All the stories remembered from childhood about shabby beggars, women carrying loads on their heads, veiled ladies dressed from head to foot in white sheets, and other things which give Africa its thoroughly Oriental atmosphere, turn out to be reality.

A YOUNG artist -- younger even than the 23-year-old Parkman as he set out upon the Oregon Trail -- adventured into the Great Sioux Reservation in Dakota Territory less than forty years later and found the westernmost bands not yet greatly changed in looks and ways.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The Mint is planning to melt down about 50,000,000 worn silver dollars and use the alloy in making new silver coins from a dime to a half dollar.

Winners of the ninth annual Baird Memorial Latin Sight-Reading contest, sponsored by the New York University chapter of Eta Sigma Phi, honorary classics fraternity, were announced yesterday by Dr. Casper J. Kraemer Jr., chairman of the classics department of the Washington Square College of Arts and Science.

JACK SKIRBALL, independent film producer and sponsor of the current Alfred Hitchcock melodrama, "Shadow of a Doubt," is enlarging his picture production program and plans to make four films during the next twelve months.
PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP) -The Athletics made it two straight over the Phillies in the city series today when they defeated their National League rivals, 5 -- 2, before a crowd of 1,600.

By its location New York City has long been the home of salt water fishing addicts, and each season during the pre-war era the number of enthusiasts appeared to be increasing. Those who lived somewhere between our oceans, from the Midwest or West, came here each year, anxious to do some salt water angling off Long Island, Staten Island or New Jersey.
The 200th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Jefferson will be celebrated in Washington next Tuesday by the dedication of the memorial to the third President.

AT the first faint smell of Spring in the air the average homeowner is off with the same intense concentration as a beagle pup working his first scent. Mr. Homeowner is getting ready to fix up the house. This year he's going to feel pretty much frustrated, because many of the things he'll need for the purpose will be in the tight clutches of Mars.

I WAS much interested in the article, "Government Support for Music," by Sir Robert Mayer, in the music pages of THE TIMES March 7, telling of the establishment and splendid work of Britain's Council for the Encouragement of Music and the Arts.

By producing in four years the machine tools necessary to the nation's war effort, the machine tool industry has virtually deprived itself of a peacetime market for at least ten years after the war, in the opinion of Alexander G. Bryant, president of the Bryant Machinery and Engineering Company.

A combination of astute detective work plus a keen knowledge of human nature on the part of a Department of Corrections officer resulted in a prisoner held on a minor charge in the Bellevue Hospital prison ward confessing voluntarily that he had escaped last year from the Brooklyn City Prison.

The Helvetia Maennerchor of New York, Swiss male chorus, Germain P. Lachat, conductor, gave its eighty-fifth annual concert last night at Town Hall. It was assisted by the Tenafly String Quartet, consisting of Gerald Reidy, first violin; Walter H. Stalder, second violin; Herbert R. Johnson, viola, and Theodore T. Mattmann, 'cello.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The vexing question whether an adequate supply of consumer goods for the civilian population of the country is being assured by the War Production Board or whether it should be handed over to a separate agency seemed to be coming to the fore this week.

The final meeting for pointers and setters competing on liberated quail in the metropolitan area is scheduled Friday, Saturday and Sunday, April 23, 24 and 25. It will be the thirty-second anniversary meeting under the auspices of the Orange County Field Trial Club and will be held over the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club in Verbank, N.Y.

A celebration to commemorate the bicentennial of Thomas Jefferson and to announce the winners in the Jefferson essay contest sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the public, parochial and private schools will be held Tuesday evening in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 10 -- This week in the African war theatre has not only seen a terrific air "blitz," but has provided a preview of things to come when United Nations forces invade the Continent.

With only four business days remaining in which to file statements on the 1942 State income tax, returns were "hardly 10 per cent" in hand yesterday, State tax officials complained. Consequently, they predicted, a highly uncomfortable "last-minute rush" will develop the first half of this week to beat the deadline Thursday midnight.

The New Leader, a Social Democratic weekly, will celebrate its twentieth anniversary today with a dinner at the Hotel Commodore. Speakers will include A.A. Berle Jr., assistant Secretary of State; William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Bertrand Russell.

PORTRAITS of distinguished personalities of the New York scene in the "Golden Nineties," as painted by eminent artists of that era, will be combined with portraiture by noted contemporary artists of leading figures of today, in a unique loan exhibition to be held from May 4-16 at the Grand Central Art Galleries branch in the Hotel Gotham, to raise funds for the American Red Cross.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- The Four Arts Club has concluded its Winter season and inaugurated one for the Summer, planned mainly around the needs of service men stationed near by. The program includes a series of weekly dances for officers, similar to those held during the Winter.
CHUNGKING, China, April 10 -- Additional evidence of the extent to which Japan feels the shortage of shipping is seen in various recent developments in territories she has occupied.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- There is one feature of the Spring line along which the Russian and German armies are at a temporary standstill that cannot have failed to engage the attention of foreign map readers. It is the fact that the establishment of Russian positions on the western banks of rivers point to future offensive operations.

MOSCOW, April 10 (Reuter) -- Hitler's soldiers have hanged a number of American-born men and women colonists on the model collective farm near Salsk in the Kuban, it was disclosed in reports reaching Moscow today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, April 11 (AP) -- The noon communique:
MEMPHIS, April 10 -- Memphis Bill Terry parked his plow against a fence post, took a long draw on his cigar and said, "There are just two jobs in all baseball that could take me away from this farm."

J.A. Beirne, acting president of the National Federation of Telephone Workers, sent yesterday a protest to President Roosevelt and other high government officials against the executive order freezing all wages and wage levels and eliminating the "chances of correcting inequalities and inequities."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 10 -- For the first time in months the Wilhelmstrasse press spokesman has again assailed Sweden, complaining of the attitude of the Swedish press, reports from Berlin today said. He inveighed at what he called "the lack of objectivity shown by Swedish newspapers in comment on the third anniversary of the German invasion of Norway."

It had been a dull day at the White House. Toward 6 o'clock Stephen Early, the President's press secretary, warned reporters in the narrow press room to stand by. There would be an important announcement. The newspaper men waited while the golden moments of Washington's traditional cocktail hour slipped awry.
LONDON, April 10 (U.P.) -- Reports from Europe said tonight that Reichsfuehrer Hitler had refused Premier Mussolini's plea for more guns and planes to defend Italy.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Hugh Russell Fraser resigned today as an information officer of the Office of Education as a result of differences in opinion over instruction in American history in high schools.

STAMPS received from Algeria show that "Republique Francaise" has been removed from reissued 30-centimes bright blue, view of Algiers; 40c olive and 50c bright red, La Pecherie Mosque, and 1.50-francs red-violet, glimpse of Oued River.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The nation's manpower problem is not one of recruitment but of more efficient use of the men and women now in war jobs, the Institute of Women's Professional Relations was told today.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 10 -- Four-hit pitching by Jeff Davis of the Navy shut oat the Princeton baseball team today, the visitors scoring a 3-to-0 victory, their third straight this season in intercollegiate competition.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (U.P.) -- An operational report released by the War Department tonight revealed that Japanese fliers as well as German have attempted to bomb American Flying Fortresses in flight.

ALBANY, April 10 -- Registration dates for the 1943 election are changed throughout the State under the Baum bill signed today by Governor Dewey. The changes were made to avoid conflict with observance of Yom Kippur, Oct. 9; Rosh Hashonah, Sept. 30 and Oct. 1, and Columbus Day, Oct. 12.

A NEW type of metropolitan antique show -- a regional one, picturesquely representative of historic Greenwich Village -- will be opened on Friday to last throughout Sunday, at Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street. It is for the benefit of the settlement's health work and also the Music Box Canteen, the Village's center for service men.

Six thousand Boy Scouts, ranging from cubs to Scouts who soon will be called to the Army, gathered yesterday afternoon at Brooklyn Borough Hall to be sworn in by the Borough President, John Cashmore, as "junior war bond commandos" of the Treasury Department in its Second War Loan drive.

AMERICAN boys and girls are taught to think for themselves, whereas German children have their thinking regulated for them. Freedom of thought has provided our American youths with the equipment to decide what to do and how to do it when a problem confronts them.

The first large-scale exhibit of the accomplishments of the armed forces in packaging and shipping thousands of items will be shown at the Wartime Packaging Conference and Exposition sponsored by the American Management Association, which opens on Tuesday at the Hotel Astor and continues through Friday.

One big inning, the second, in which five Manhattan runners crossed the plate, gave the Jaspers a 9-to-3 victory over City College in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game on the windswept Van Cortlandt Park diamond yesterday.

SOME weeks ago a Philadelphia policeman saw a small truck stopping in front of a meat store. The truck was apparently loaded with manure and old burlap bags. The policeman began to wonder why this truck should drive up to a meat store. He decided to investigate and found hidden under the manure and the burlap bags uninspected meat. The black market was being supplied. The farmer who had been driving the truck was arrested.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 10 (AP) -- The American Legion today issued its annual call for 500,000 baseball players -- not to fill depleted major league ranks but to take part in the Legion's eighteenth annual junior baseball program.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The House ordered today an investigation into whether the government contemplates curtailment of newsprint and paper, which Representative Shafer of Michigan said would enable the Congress to determine the extent to which "a conspiracy exists to destroy the freedom of the press."

The annual report of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Company and its subsidiaries, signed by Edward P. Farley, chairman of the executive committee, and released for publication yesterday, shows a net profit of $1,621,379 for the year ended Dec. 31, or $3.81 a share on 425,700 shares of common stock. In 1941 net income was $2,817,947, after a reserve of $473,562 for contingencies, or $6.49 a share on 433, 800 common shares.

A man of 38 is in the peak period of his mental powers, but his physical condition has been slowly declining from the high point reached at around 25. He may still be strong physically but his muscles have probably lost tone, his motor coordination is slower, his endocrine glands governing endurance and recuperation have undergone change.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce suggested today that "every community deeply affected by the war should start a survey in order to measure its own reconversion task," and cautioned against a too swift relaxing of controls with the advent of peace.

RADIO is a highly developed science founded on formidable symbols, terms, definitions and formulas. This, to many beginners, seems a great barrier. But scientific training ideas change, especially in wartime, as shortcuts are tried out.

YOUNG Cynthia Barstow and her fragile old grandmother lived alone in a big rambling house that had seen a couple of other wars and was now taking a look at the big new one. It was filled with guests from time to time, handsome soldiers, war workers out of the top drawer.

TWO of the world's most famous expressions of religion in music, Wagner's "Parsifal" and J.S. Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew," will be given productions in the next fortnight in New York, by the Metropolitan Opera and the Philharmonic-Symphony Society respectively, as observances of the Easter season.

That the United Nations as a group and this country in particular will have to restore starving Europe to health is now generally accepted. How far that aid must extend is evident from six papers which were presented recently at a liaison session held under the auspices of the Committee on Food Habits of the National Research Council.

The mid-Manhattan Office of Price Administration war price and rationing board headquarters, the country's largest, moved into new quarters yesterday at 1775 Broadway, the old General Motors showrooms, in order to handle 10,000 applicants a day with the least waiting.

Favored by mild weather retail trade here was active last week. Percentage comparisons were with the post-Easter period of 1942 and estimates indicated department store volume was ahead by 10 per cent or more. Larger gains were seen for apparel specialty stores.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The House broadened today its attack upon "bureaucrats" who presumed to be "self-appointed legislators," and passed the Halleck resolution to provide for an investigation of the OPA grade-labeling program.

Strong opposition to the adoption of a resolution approving, with certain reservations, President Roosevelt's new executive order on prices and wages resulted in its being referred back to the program committee at a conference yesterday of 800 delegates representing 1,300,000 Committee of Industrial Organizations trade unionists in New York State and Northern New Jersey at the Hotel Capitol.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The directors of the War Damage Corporation have decided that there will be no change in its present established premium rates, it was announced today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

A resolution urging the closest possible cooperation of government, industry, labor and agriculture to meet post-war problems was adopted yesterday as the Eastern conference of the Council of State Governments ended its two-day deliberations at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WITH THE UNITED STATES AIR FORCE IN CHINA, April 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- Japanese-occupied Fort Bayard, its airdrome, radio station and dock area and the near-by Japanese commander's headquarters in the former French-leased territory of Kwangchowwan, on the South China Coast, were heavily attacked by American P-40s today.

A new metal salvage campaign -- this time for copper, brass and bronze -- will begin on April 20 with 20,000 grocery stores and neighborhood food markets in this city as depositories, the regional War Production Board announced yesterday.

MUNCIE., Ind., April 10 (AP) -- Rookie Outfielder Dick Wakefield's triple with the bases full in the seventh inning gave the Tigers a 4-to-1 victory over the Pirates today. It was their third triumph in five exhibition games.

A WOMAN has become a member of the British Diplomatic Corps -- and that is news. Canadian-born Mary Agnes Craig McGeachy (pronounced McGaihkey, with the K almost silent) is the first of her sex to crack a once exclusively male field and she has been accepted into the most conservative (outwardly, anyway group of men in the world, the British Foreign Office. She has been made a first secretary to the Embassy in Washington.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 10 -- The hard-pressed remnants of Marshal Rommel's motor transport are being relentlessly pounded from the air by day and night.

DETROIT, April 10 -- Gradually Detroit is licking one of its toughest labor problems, and by doing so it is materially relieving its demand for war manpower and is increasing production by the elimination of a chief source of labor friction.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 -- In recognition of China's aid to the Jesuit missionary fathers, who founded the first Catholic missions in that country in the fifteenth century, Loyola University conferred an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws on Mme.

OLD BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 10 -- L.F. Bissell of Rockville, Conn., had the satisfaction of duplicating his victory of a year ago in the open all-age stake of the Southern New York Field Trial Club meeting, which opened today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 9 -- Germany's need for foreign exchange was reflected in a statement today by Dr. Friederich H. Landfried, State Secretary in the Ministry of Reich Economy, to the effect that in no case may restrictions now imposed on domestic industry be applied to the export and import trades.

"I CAN'T understand this matter of being an emigre," says one of Vera Lebedeff's characters. "To be an exile for a year or two, even five years, is conceivable. But to be a Russian emigre after spending fifteen or twenty years in America -- that's a case of arrested development."

There was a definite drop in the number of orders received in wholesale markets last week, particularly in staple lines, reflecting retail adjustments to the inventory control order and to the heavy buying done in preceding weeks, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co.

LANCASTER, Pa., April 10 -- Pete Gray lost his "good arm" when he was a boy, but the Athletics will agree that he's doing all right with the other. And they can't help wondering what he'd do with both.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 10 -- There will be no more horse racing in Paris because of the bombing of the Longchamps track last Sunday, which, the Germans said, caused thirty deaths. The announcement is made by the Minister of Agriculture, Max Bonnafous, whose department controls horse racing.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Chester C. Davis, Food Administrator, announced today an immediate advance of 5 cents a bushel in the ceiling price of feed corn, increase of the recently announced support price for live hogs from $13.25 per hundredweight to $13.75 and plans to import feed from Canada and Australia.

In view of British and American proposals now under consideration for stabilization of currencies in the post-war period, prompt clarification of immediate trade problems and commercial relations between the two governments is essential, foreign traders asserted last week.
FRED Allen contributes some disturbing news this morning. He said last week that he intended to leave the air for at least six months and that there was no certainty he would return then.

UNLESS something goes wrong in the meanwhile, the end of June should see Vincent Youmans restored to the theatre, a connection he broke some eleven years ago. Remember his songs, "Tea for Two," "Hallelujah" and "Sometimes I'm Happy," among numerous others? He has plans for at least three productions, the immediate one being a Latin-American revue which he will help write but the tunes for which will be done by some one else.

The Army and Navy training programs have been the object of severe criticism by educators who have felt that they subordinated the values of a normal college education to short-term technical and scientific training. Now that the details of the programs have been made known, much of the earlier criticism must be modified.

LONDON, April 10 -- There are guns in the parks and rusted coils of barbed wire, but there are flowers, too. Most young couples are in uniform, but the girl usually takes the boy's arm just as though she were in a gay print dress. And the moon silhouettes Westminster's famous tower with all its storied solemnity and peace, although every night is tense with the patterned vigilance of the air-raid precautions system.

LONDON, April 10 (U.P.) -- The Red Army of the Ukraine, fighting from newly won positions, today beat off fresh attacks against its Izyum-Balakleya salient jutting twenty miles westward into the German lines, a prime springboard for a Soviet offensive this Spring.

PRISONER FREED: Last week from England came word of an American Flying Fortress that made a forced landing in an English village. Somehow the pilot brought it down in a space so small it couldn't be flown out. Army engineers moved in, took out 120 feet of wall and hedgerow, moved hundreds of trees, filled and graded a 2,250-foot runway, watched the take-off and went back to their base.

PICHON, Tunisia, April 8 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American and British forces struck today with infantry, tanks and massed artillery at the German positions defending the gateway to the holy city of Kairouan.

LONDON, April 10 -- How Belgium lent Britain 3,000,000 ounces of gold in March, 1941, to help pay for vitally needed war materials was revealed tonight in a radio broadcast to the occupied homeland by Camille Gutt, Belgian Minister of Finance.

EDITH RUBEL MAPOTHER needs no introduction to lovers of music in America to whom it will be no surprise to find this first venture in a different form of artistic expression shot through and through with not a little of the magic, the intuitive comprehension and the strange, wild beauty that set music apart among the arts and distinguish its finest interpreters.

THE herb corner is becoming an increasingly popular part of the American garden, especially now when we must use all our culinary wiles to vary a wartime fare. No one can know too soon the aromatic pleasures of herbs and so this little book, which does for them what Irmegarde Eberle's "Spice on the Wind" does for spices, is welcome.

IT'S about time that the United States Army's engineers revised their motto. Almost since the Revolution when General Washington, himself an engineer, made them a separate corps, the engineers have borne on their banners -- and on their buttons, too -- the strange device "Essayons," which means, roughly, "We Will Try."
The Stars and Stripes and flags of twenty-one Latin-American Republics led a colorful parade of 2,000 persons yesterday afternoon on Central Park West in a demonstration of inter-American solidarity.

LONDON, April 10 -- A suggestion that the United Nations set up an office of education comparable to the International Labor Office and disclosure that the Rockefeller Foundation had already set aside "an important fund" for post-war use in international education cooperation were made today at a meeting of the Association of University Professors and Lecturers of Allied Countries.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 10 -- The special delegation representing the Emergency Advisory Committee for the Political Defense of the Continent that has been meeting in Montevideo has been at work in Buenos Aires for a week to ascertain whether Argentina has taken the necessary steps to carry out the recommendations of the committee majority.

When the crapshooter cries "Come seven, come eleven!" and wishes hard for the numbers, does he have any effect on the "bones"? He thinks he does, but you can't get any physicist to believe it. Dr. J.P. Rhine of Duke University has been making some tests which convince him that there may be more in this wishful thinking than the scientific world believes, and so he speaks of the "PK" or the "psychokinetic effect."

LETTUCE has been grown in gardens in all parts of the world from ancient times to the present. It is the most popular of all the salad plants which are consumed raw. Even a sandwich ordered in a restaurant is likely to have a portion of a lettuce leaf served with it as a garnish.

Fighters now engage in combat at heights of seven miles. It is cold there -- bitter cold. The planes may travel at speeds of 400 miles an hour, so that they must withstand hammer blows of air. How will they endure the blows at subzero temperature in the lower stratosphere?

A MUCH wider circle than even that of Albert Payson Terhune's friends will be glad that this book was written. It is indeed conceivable that a good many readers who did not know his name will find it worth while because it is the simple and stirring chronicle of a happily married man and woman.
MY role in radio had its counterpart in vaudeville, a sort of interlocutor, is necessary to newspaper and radio today as it was to Lew Dockstader's Minstrels.

Recognizing the untenable "ceiling position" of cotton textile mills on long-term contracts, due to uncontrollable cost factors, the Quartermaster General's office in Washington has indicated that it will accept tentative bids or "letters of intent" from mills in lieu of firm price quotations on essential war output, Worth Street suppliers declared yesterday.

Governor Dewey's signature to the legislative reapportionment bill marked only a step, but an important step, toward the first change in the boundaries of the State's Senate and Assembly districts, which three Democratic Governors -- Alfred E. Smith, Franklin D. Roosevelt and Herbert H. Lehman -- strove unsuccessfully to bring about.

Yachtsmen generally throughout the country, according to Drake H. Sparkman of the Seamanship Training Corps National Committee, are following the advice of Commodore George Roosevelt of the New York Y.C. and contributing everything possible to the war effort.
HEADLINES roar the heroism of the Army nurse as she follows the flag into jungle and desert. Here is the story of drama behind the battles, the quiet but powerful tale of the woman in blue.
THE way the lawn is watered may mean the difference between healthy, vigorous, always fresh-looking grass and grass that is shallow-rooted and apt to fare badly in hot weather.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Roosevelt remained in the Executive Mansion today and worked on the address he will make Tuesday, the bicentennial of the birth of Thomas Jefferson. The address, according to Stephen T. Early, Presidential secretary, will be "brief and Jeffersonian."

PASADENA, Calif., April 10 (AP) -- Two of the world's greatest scientists, Dr. Robert A. Millikan and Dr. Thomas Hunt Morgan, scoff at the notion that war stimulates scientific research. Both are deeply involved in work related to the war, and both look forward to peace and the unimpeded forward movement of science.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., April 10 -- Saratoga prepared today to argue for thoroughbred racing as usual at its historic track this Summer on the basis of reports from down-State Jamaica's opening on Thursday.

Apache and With Regards won the two Paumonok Handicaps at Jamaica yesterday as 29,209 persons saw the famous old race split into two divisions for the first time on an afternoon when the public pool reached $1,743,370. This closely approached the all-time high for the track of $1,822,832, which is expected to fall next Saturday when the Wood Memorial is run.

IN the sublime climax of what is incomparably the greatest of state papers, the Declaration of Independence, Jefferson caught a vision of "the road to happiness and to glory" opening up before a united people. From this exalted document Mrs. Kimball has appropriately drawn the title for a work which moves steadily forward to the great year of crisis in the life of her subject and of the nation.

MR. WHITAKER'S heart is on his sleeve in this book. He is a very good reporter, ubiquitous and quick-witted, but he is also a believer in the American creed, a bitter foe of all tyrants, and a man of sensibility.

The 1,133 bond issue issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $72,856,093,356 par value as of March 31, had a total market value of $71,575,183,604, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of Feb. 27 there were 1,133 issues, aggregating $72,961,678,106 par value which had a total market value of $71,346,452,852.

Formal Organization of the United Nations to insure future peace and extension of the reciprocal trade agreements were urged yesterday by speakers at a luncheon discussion of the Foreign Policy Association on "The Opening Salvo for the Future," at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10 -- The Yale Corporation has approved creation of a new program of instruction in agricultural sciences in the Sheffield Scientific School of the university. It is designed to train men skilled in the sciences basic to agriculture to help solve food problems during and after the war.
ONE of the most remarkable characteristics of Robert Frost as a poet has been his sureness of touch. His poems run the gamut of scope and intensity, but in quality they vary little, if at all.

FOR soldiers and for some others war is much more than a conventionalized form of killing. It arises out of the total conditions of social and economic life, is determined by what those conditions are, and produces or hastens changes in them.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand -- Japan is pushing long-prepared plans for developing cotton crops in the region of Southeast Asia which is under her control, according to information reaching here. Supplies are sought to replace the cotton which the Nipponese used to buy from India and the United States.

ABOUT this time in pre-war years the Easter cruise was promising fun and respite for weary workers, with gay-colored pamphlets slyly spreading the lure of white beaches and blue seas, palm trees and banana boats.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (U.P.) -- Harvey S. Firestone Jr., prophesied today a crime wave "of major proportions" when soldiers, schooled in use of lethal weapons and accustomed to living intimately with death, return to civilian life.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- Headquarters of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, of which Harry R. Bridges is president, said today that copies of this week's issue of the union's newspaper, The I.L. W.U. Dispatcher, attacking the War Shipping Administration for alleged inefficiency and mismanagement in Wartime shipping, had been sent to every member of Congress.

A woman 100 years old Tuesday has the answer to Nazi toughness -- be tougher, Mrs. Mathilde Wertheimer survived twenty-two months in the filth and horror that is one of the deadliest concentration camps in Europe -- Gurs in the Pyrenees.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Practically every method of publicity known to the American people has been enlisted to put over the Treasury Department's campaign to sell $13,000,000,000 of Victory Loan securities in the second war-loan drive scheduled to start on Monday and to last for three weeks, the department said today.

DETROIT, April 10 -- More than 4,000 scientists and industrialists will participate in the 105th meeting of the American Chemical Society which will open a five-day meeting here on Monday. Several hundred papers and addresses outlining progress in the nation's research laboratories and on the production front will be presented.

MEXICO CITY -- If one really wants to "get away from it all" for a little while, one can slip into Mexico and there be about as far away from the world conflict as radio, the newspaper and conscience will allow.

Hofstra College of Hempstead, L.I., spoiled Brooklyn College's baseball opening by crushing the Kingsmen under a 17-7 score yesterday on the loser's diamond. The game was called at the end of the seventh on account of the cold weather.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 10 -- The Wilhelmstrasse has this week echoed the earlier threats of Adolf Hitler, Reich Marshal Hermann Goering and Dr. Joseph Goebbels to wreak horrible vengeance on London for the Allied air raids on Germany, which for some time past have been reducing large parts of the vital Reich cities from Berlin on down to a mass of ruins and jumbled wreckage.

Since its inauguration last Summer, the job methods training program of the Training Within Industry Division of the War Manpower Commission has saved millions of dollars to the war program, drastically cut production time and increased output substantially, it was reported here last week.
THERE was a time when an opening lead from a K-x-x-x suit, against a trump contract, was considered one of the worst leads in bridge. Players much preferred to open from a Q-x-x-x suit.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The conference of representatives of the United Nations on problems of food and agriculture in the postwar world will be held at the Homestead Hotel in Hot Springs, Va., and will open on May 18, the State Department announced today.

IT may be true, as has sometimes been averred, that we are an exuberant age, but, if so, we have not formed the habit in every case of channelizing our exuberance into anything concentrated enough to be called enthusiasm.

WHEN the purchase of Thomas Jefferson's library was finally ratified by a reluctant Congress, this nation was started on a career that led to its becoming the custodian of one of the world's great repositories of books.

PLANKTON, sponges, jellyfish, starfish, the various kinds of shellfish, sea angels, devil fish and other forms of sea life are described in readable, lively fashion in this little book which will answer the questions of those boys and girls whose curiosity has already been aroused and will no doubt stimulate an initial interest in others.

A PLANTED rock wall is a charming and useful addition to the home garden. On small uneven lots where sloping ground has long been a problem, where grass will not grow or shrubs take hold, the rock or dry wall, its interstices filled with rich garden compost instead of cement, is just the answer to a trying situation.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Senator Pepper of Florida told the American Academy of Political and Social Science tonight that he would introduce Monday in the Senate a resolution calling upon President Roosevelt to inform the United Nations that the United States was "ready to enter into a solemn pact that it will within six months after the conclusion of the war in Europe become a full participating member of an acceptable form of United Nations."

A port-wide organization of harbor launch services, under the jurisdiction of Federal authorities, has been effected in recent weeks to increase efficiency in harbor shipping operations, it was disclosed yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 10 (AP) -- Four hits in the sixth inning after two were out gave the Reds a 4-to-3 victory over the Indians in their exhibition series opener today. Cincinnati grouped its blows against Ray Poat after two balks and an outfield error.

FORT DIX, N.J., April 10 -- One of the first groups "in the field" in this area, the Forty-second Headquarters Company of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps, 150 strong, has taken Fort Dix. Stationed at the reception center here, they are infiltrating offices of the warehouse, the personnel division and the testing and transport sections.

THIS is a story about ordinary nice people living in Denver, concentrating on making a living and getting married, as much as they are able to concentrate on anything. They are the kind, alarmingly popular in light fiction now, who flaunt their ignorance of anything which might smack of literary or any other artistic taste.

LONDON, Sunday, April 11 (AP) -- Russian troops mowed down 300 Germans attacking their Donets River line yesterday near Balakleya, thirty-five miles southeast of Kharkov, boosting their two-day toll of the enemy to 1,500, Moscow announced early today.

The flags of France and of the United States hung side by side last night in New York University's Washington Square auditorium while seventy-five members of the battleship Richelieu's crew presented a musical and dramatic program under the sponsorship of the university's French Club.

The fifteen leading banks in Wall Street now have 53.8 per cent of their total resources invested in United States Government securities, a high record for them, it is revealed by the quarterly condition statements issued last week. One year ago the percentage was 37.4.

BOSTON, April 10 -- It is rather hopeful for the future that both the American Treasury plan for an international fund to stabilize currency and the British plan of Lord Keynes for an international clearing union -- both brought out this past week -- have similar objectives.
The United Nations are fighting today to preserve the democratic ideals handed down by Thomas Jefferson, whose 200th birthday will be celebrated Tuesday, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Philadelphia honored one of its heroes of the war today, paying tribute to Sergeant Albert A. Schmid of the Marines, who is credited with killing 200 Japanese an Guadalcanal.

FLETCHER PRATT, expert on naval affairs, inexhaustible writer of books and magazine and newspaper articles dealing with the war, may have got the idea for his latest book while cleaning off his desk. For "The Navy Has Wings," a sketchy, disjointed book that bounces in the wake of a whole armada of books on naval aviation, is made up largely of material already used by Mr. Pratt in magazine articles.

AS the taxi drivers cavort about town they don't sigh for the good old days. They don't care if the old days never come back. They are making so much money it runs out of their ears and into savings banks. From cowboys they have become business men, and they only watch the clock to see that it doesn't stop.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 10 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Ben M. Smith, Alabama Selective Service director, asserted today that strikers in War plants would be promptly reclassified in the future for armed service drafting.

Intercollegiate athletics are still going strong at most of the schools on the Pacific Coast, but a sharp revision in football schedules is generally anticipated. The revision will not necessarily mean a heavy reduction in the number of games to be played but will serve to cut down traveling and eliminate all intersectional contests.

Three fireboats and apparatus summoned on three alarms were engaged in a two-hour fight early last night to control a stubborn, smoky fire that destroyed the upper floors of a four-story brick loft building at 636 to 644 First Avenue, between Thirty-sixth and Thirty-seventh Streets.

PUBLIC sales of some of the most notable stamp collections in America are on the auction calendar of New York and Philadelphia dealers during the coming seven weeks. The man only mildly interested in philately is apt to ask, "Is the stamp market doing well in wartime?"

CHICAGO, April 10 (AP) -- The supply of salable hogs was insufficient today to test market conditions, but all buying interests were talking of sharply lower quotations in view of news dispatches from Washington that the government was expected to announce ceilings of $14.50 a hundred pounds.
NEW ZEALAND Spinach has many qualities to recommend it for the Victory garden. It is one of the greens Uncle Sam wants planted in abundance for vitamins A and C.

"THE Aldrich Family" having begun life under another name as a play in the theatre -- in, specifically, the Biltmore Theatre and on the night of April 13, 1938 -- the radio cannot properly lay claim to an anniversary this Tuesday evening.

The United Nations are nothing if they are not a fellowship of peoples among whom there can be the frank interchange of ideas upon matters of common concern; and because it is so vitally important, at this critical epoch in the history of mankind, that we should be as sure as human fallibility permits that we are reading its lesson aright I venture to write this letter.

NOTHING in the world is more pleasant than to sit and stare out of it at a fresh blue sky. In Manhattan, however, this vernal occupation is all too likely to be thwarted by the presence of a thick film of coal dust on the glass.

LONDON, April 10 -- Britons flocked to football stadiums today to watch leading wartime teams draw one game closer to the conclusion of a long and successful season. Cup games that produced semi-finalists for Northern and Southern league cups attracted most attention.

CARROLL T. COONEY JR. wrote "A Green Field For Courage," in which a little boy and his father transform his toys into an essential world of struggle and heroism. That made a book for children which was read by many adults.

OTTAWA, April 10 -- Canadians this week have had the contradictory experience of hearing their "truly amazing war effort" praised in the British House of Commons by Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, of seeing their example of controlled but adjustable price and wage ceilings adopted by the President of the United States, and at the same time of finding their government and themselves abused in Parliament and the press.

Since we hear so much about the possibility of a token German air attack, it is worth noting that an intri cate, extensive network of volunteer workers, armed forces experts and telephone and radio connections protects the country. The number of the civilian sentinels in what is called the Aircraft Warning Service is 1,500,000. Most of the volunteers are women.

JOSEPH HONE'S life of W.B. Yeats, so long awaited, has at last appeared on the booksellers' shelves. The reviewers are evidently disappointed with it in some respects. Desmond MacCarthy, in The Sunday Times, considers it a good piece of work, but thinks its author has been hampered by being, so to speak, the official biographer of a great poet.

For women interested in working on dairy and poultry farms, the University of Connecticut at Storrs will begin another training period on April 12. Students who have completed the previous course are now working on farms, employed as full-time hands.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A "group pricing" arrangement for new designs of furniture having similar changes in the cost of production, which is expected to speed up pricing procedure and eliminate time-wasting reports, was provided today by the Office of Price Administration. It may be used as an alternative to the old unit pricing procedure.

AMONG the members of the combat team of a big bomber there is a standing joke to the effect that the bombardier is the most important man of the lot. With mock seriousness pilot, navigator or gunner will tell you that the bombardier is the "featured player" and it is just so he can lay his eggs that they go to all the trou ble and danger of flying through anti-aircraft fire and enemy fighters.
LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The "supreme danger" facing the American Negro today is that powerful reactionary forces may succeed in reversing or effectively sabotaging the present domestic and foreign policies of the Roosevelt Administration, 300 delegates attending the Eastern Seaboard conference of the National Negro Congress were told yesterday by Edward R. Strong, executive secretary.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 10 -- A tree-shaded farm in this Morris County community houses an experiment which, if carried out elsewhere in the United States on even a modest scale might serve to make this country entirely independent of Japanese silk after the war.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 10 -- Dr. Henry P. Jordan of New York University, who is lecturing at the University of Puerto Rico this semester on problems of post-war reconstruction and Latin-American economic relations, in his address this week emphasized the opportunity of the United States to use its moral power to show the way in bringing Europe in line with twentieth century world conditions.

AS a collection of Frank Luther's songs, made familiar through his record and radio repertoire, this book will have its greatest appeal. It contains music for 125 songs, with and without accompaniment, in simple adaptations and arrangements made by him since 1929; and it reveals, through its selections and comments, the average American taste.

WITH the engagement of Erich Leinsdorf as conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra the question arises of who will take over his work at the Metropolitan Opera. It is considered possible that George Szell will inherit most of the repertory of Wagner and Strauss, with possibly some of the operas going to Bruno Walter and Sir Thomas Beecham.

LONDON, April 10 -- British bombers, attacking in the industrial Ruhr Valley of Germany for the second consecutive night, hammered the inland port of Duisburg and other targets last night. Lighter Allied planes continued the day-and-night offensive by slashing at German-used rail and waterway communications from Havre to the Netherlands in daylight today.

A post-war international police force composed of units of all the United Nations that would stand to crush military aggression anywhere in the world provides the only sure solution for keeping the United States out of future wars, in the opinion of United States Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota.

KEY WEST, Fla., April 10 -- A submarine sneaked into heavily guarded coastal shipping lanes early this month to make a hit-and-run attack and sink a merchantman in waters off the eastern coast of the United States for the first loss reported there since last Summer.

Not in many years have educators, school administrators and the general public been as interested in the study of United States history as they have been during the past week. From coast to coast the importance of knowing and understanding American history has been debated in the press and in educational circles.

A 17-year-old high school student was fatally stabbed in front of his home in Harlem yesterday afternoon, after a quarrel with two men. Meanwhile, three other men were arrested on charges of attempted robbery, accused of mugging a man in 126th Street between Lenox and Seventh Avenues at 2 P.M.

AFTERNOON tea and the flu are the general subjects of this story. Surely there never was another New England town where tea and sandwiches and cake made their appearance in the homes of the well-to-do on schedule every afternoon.

A FEATURE of the current twenty-fifth anniversary season of the Cleveland Orchestra was a prize contest instituted by the Musical Arts Association and made possible by Mr. and Mrs. E.J. Kulas. A prize of $1,000 was offered for a symphonic work of approximately fifteen-minute duration.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- With the approach of mid-year the Selective Service System appears to be preparing for some drastic changes, with pressure of the armed services for a maximum of 11,000,000 men by the end of the year largely responsible.

WESTFIELD, N.J., April 10 -- Police Chief John Schreiber disclosed today that Springfield, Mass., police had informed him that Rollin C. Dean, missing Rockefeller Foundation purchasing director, had registered at a hotel there Monday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, called on law enforcement agencies today for "a counter-offensive" against increasing crime which, he said, threatens "a breakdown on our home front."

MEDFORD, N.J., April 10 -- The white-and-orange pointer Kingwood Jack, handled by his owner, H.T. Heisel of Frenchtown, N.J., won the members' shooting-dog stake sponsored by the English Setter Club of America today.

THE Soviet Art Committee's Music Department meets occasionally to hear and discuss the new works of Russian composers. Men like Gliere, Kabalevsky, Belyi and Muradeli, and musicolo gists like S. Shlifstein, D. Rabinorich, G. Polianski and E. Martinoff attend these sessions, and the discussion is frank.

The American Export Air Line plane Flying Ace landed at La Guardia Field yesterday from Britain with fourteen passengers, among them being Fran Gabrovsek, member of a committee of the Yugoslav Government in Exile, who has come here for three months of work on post-war problems.

AS was expected, retail trade showed substantial percentage gains last week, reversing the declining trend noted for the last three weeks for the country as a whole. Comparison, of course, was with the post-Easter period last year, whereas this year's holiday is still two weeks away.
Retail trade was generally good in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

THIS week Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer cameras turned on the first studio scenes for "America," the picture King Vidor says he has been planning to make for the last eighteen years. As he launched the production Mr. Vidor said that there has never been a more propitious time than now for his drama of the nation's industrial resources and the opportunities that are open to individuals under our democratic way of life.

Suspension proceedings were begun by the District Office of Price Administration yesterday against a hotel and thirteen restaurants in Manhattan, accused of violating OPA regulations. Specifically, the fourteen are charged with having failed to report complete inventories of point-rationed processed foods to their local War Price and Rationing Boards last March.
CHUNGKING, China, April 10 (UP) -- A communique:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10 -- Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, replied today to a request of Professor Ralph Barton Perry of Harvard that he state "the real attitude of the State Department" dealing concretely with criticisms that its policy was based "not on military expediency but settled reactionary sentiments."

DOVER, N.J., April 10 -- Officials of the Picatinny Arsenal announced today that more than 200 employes in the loading department of the arsenal have been discharged because of habitual absenteeism. Investigators visited this week the homes of workers who were absent without permission and found that more than half had no valid excuse.
The following account of the burial of an American naval aviator on Savo Island in the Solomons was written by Walter L. Stewart. USA:

There is no defense for willful absenteeism in our war plants. It is the next-door neighbor of sabotage and attains some of the same ends. But that not all absenteeism is willful and deliberate is once more made clear by a survey completed by the West Coast Aircraft War Production Council, of which eight large airframe manufacturers are members.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- A report of the welcome given by Frenchmen to Brig. Gen. Jacques Leclerc of the Fighting French when he entered Gabes was received today by the Fighting French delegation here.

The Nederlandsch Americaansche Stoomvart Maatschappij, known to thousands of American travelers as the Holland-America Line, quietly observed its seventieth anniversary last week in the New York headquarters and branch offices in a dozen American and Canadian cities.

A QUITE personal style prevents classification of Eugene Paul Ullman simply as a belated impressionist. In an introduction to the catalogue of Ullman's exhibition at Georgette Passedoit's Gallery, Guy Pene du Bois goes so far as to say that "few men painting today are more thoroughly versed in their craft and therefore more at ease, which is to say, charming, in expressing what they have to say."

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Senator Guy M. Gillette of Iowa, a farm bloc leader, expressed the prevailing Washington opinion of the President's newest anti-inflation order when he said it should have been issued a long time ago but was a very constructive step, anyhow. The President himself seemed to anticipate that comment and share that viewpoint in the following passage in his explanatory statement:

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- A cross-section of leading American war industries, reporting for 1941 final net profits of as much as 133 per cent of invested capital, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for use in renegotiation of war contracts that carried excessive profits.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The pay-as-you-go tax situation appeared to be headed for a showdown in the House next week, possibly on Monday, at a meeting of the Ways and Means Committee.

The Giants came home yesterday, surrounded by emptiness in the stillness of the Polo Grounds, and wound up with an overabundance of nothing. Not more than 1,000 fans turned out and it was probably just as well, because Giant followers did not enjoy what happened to their favorites when they met the Red Sox.

The department stores and other retailers of the city will open a drive tomorrow to help the Treasury Department sell $13,000,000,000 worth of war bonds and stamps. The slogan is: "Buy a bomber a day."

ELIZABETH SEIFERT must know that in this she has written her best book to date, and the long list of admirers she has rolled up since "Young Doctor Galahad" will be pleased to know it too. There is less concern here with the problems of doctors, medical, ethical and social, and more good straight story telling.

Prospects for a dividend declaration by the Long Island Railroad and a boom in property values in the vicinity of the Jamaica track brightened yesterday as 29,209 racing fans flocked there for the inaugural Saturday program of the new turf season.

THE saga of "Dark Eyes," as luck and Elena Miramova would have it, may properly be said to have begun with England's declaration of war. Now Lake Placid is far from Downing Street, but not so far as to leave unaffected an English actor who had agreed to drive two impecunious actresses to the mountains for a long week-end.

Consolidation of the activities of the Immigration and Naturalization Service in this city in a twelve- story building the government recently has acquired at 70 Columbus Avenue, between Sixty-second and Sixty-third Streets, was announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 10 (AP) -- A communique EIGHTH ARMY Our forward elements were in contact with the enemy rearguards with tanks and infantry. Our troops occupied Mahares after some enemy resistance. The advance continues. General Mannerini and the headquarters of his Saharan Group were captured April 8.

Harold V. Smith, president of the Home Insurance Company, will serve as Manhattan chairman for the sixth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund, 11 West Forty-second Street, which starts May 3, W. Randolph Burgess, general chairman, announced yesterday.

WHEN Margaret Eileen Dorney, 23, and Lois Coots, 25, leave their desks at the United States Weather Bureau in Washington, D.C., and join the homeward-bound throngs of government workers, you would never guess that these extremely pretty young women are professional meteorologists -- a field heretofore held sacred to men.

ON the Sunday evening last July before he was shot by the Nazis as a hostage in the Cherche Midi prison in Paris the Communist Deputy Gabriel Peri wrote: "I should like my friends to know that I have been faithful to my life-long ideal. I should like my fellow-countrymen to know that I am dying that France may live.

A total of $162,435 has been raised for the American Red Cross War Fund in New York City from foreign groups by the Foreign Language division, of which Mrs. Bertha Jackson is chairman, it was announced yesterday by J.P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the city-wide drive.

MIAMI, Fla., April 10 (AP) -- Three of us swam a race with death out there, and there were times when I thought we would be the losers. One of the three died after we fought our way clear of burning oil that raced behind us on the surface of the sea.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 10 -- The attack on Europe may be drawing near. In Homeric days the onslaught was heralded by invectives hurled across the battlements as hero challenged hero to combat. Today this phase is called a war of nerves or of propaganda.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass, April 10 -- In a colorful military ceremony, the first battalion of nearly 200 aviation cadets was graduated from the Navy Flight Preparatory School at Williams College today, with James Phinney Baxter 3d, President of Williams, as the principal speaker.

Police Commissioner Valentine called his commanding officers yesterday and discussed many things with them, ranging from increased protection for shopkeepers during Easter to the number of policemen who have been injured by being struck by falling tops of department automobile baggage compartments.

Dorothy Eustis gifted young pianist from Seattle, Wash., where she received her musical training, was heard in her first New York recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. Though new to the East, Miss Eustis has concertized extensively on the Pacific Coast and has appeared as soloist with Sir Thomas Beecham and Karl Krueger.

QUICK BUILDING -- Mass-production methods built the mammoth Pratt Whitney aircraft-engine plant near Kansas City. A series of mobile roof forms were jacked up into place, the reinforcing steel and mesh were fitted and the concrete was poured. When the concrete was hard the jacks were released and the forms dropped away, leaving the roof at rest on pillar supports.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- An indication of the extraordinary steps taken to safeguard the nation's treasure of historic documents, valuable paintings and other important mementos was given this week in an announcement that the Declaration of Independence would be taken from a secret place of safekeeping for display Tuesday when the Jefferson Memorial will be dedicated at the celebration of the bicentennial of Thomas Jefferson's birth.

With 1,056,510 shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday was the most active Saturday in more than a year. As investors struggled to adjust themselves to the sharp Friday dip, prices moved upward and downward and the close showed mixed changes, representing neither a continuation of nor a recovery from the sharp set-backs of the day before.

A general meeting of retailers to discuss "what retailers can do to help preserve the effectiveness of government price control" will be held under the auspices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association next Thursday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, it was made known here yesterday.

With deliveries of petroleum to the East Coast now at the highest level in more than a year, it is quite probable that the rationing authorizes in Washington soon will consider increasing the value of gasoline coupons, particularly those of the A class, which have been reduced to 1 1/2 gallons a week.

A 15-year-old schoolboy, one of the youngest of 400 entrants, was selected Friday night as the best physical specimen among youths of pre-induction age in the Madison Square Boys Club, at a final examination in the club, 301 East Twenty-ninth Street.

As the war drags on to its inevitable end and victory begins to loom in sight, discordant voices make themselves heard on both sides of the Atlantic. Those people whose thoughts and ideas are strictly circumscribed within the frontiers of the country they happen to live in are beginning to beat the alarm drums.

It is with regret that the president of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. of Baltusrol, representing 1,000 or more women golfers, directs the following letter to this department.

Yesterday German resistance in Southern Tunisia collapsed. Marshal Erwin Rommel's Afrika Korps was fleeing north over roads that once knew the tread of the soldiers of Rome and Carthage. Ancient towns, Mahares and Sfax, had been abandoned with little attempt to defend them.

In view of the clear-cut and mounting air superiority of the United Nations in the European and African theatres, and in view also of the success of the Russian Winter offensive, one certainly is entitled to ask what has become of the vaunted might of the German air arm.

Two thousand Waves and Spars, with only a month's training, went through their first regimental review for "company" yesterday with all the aplomb their civilian sisters reserve for the Easter Parade.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. April 10 -- Alden Kimball, New York coal merchant, hanged himself yesterday in the cellar of his home on Jeffreys Lane, here, it was asserted today by Chief of Police Francis Leddy. Although Chief Leddy pronounced the death a suicide, Coroner John Nugent said an inquest would be held Wednesday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 10 -- The New Jersey State Teachers team, consisting of the Misses Irene Gaczynski, Josephine Schaffert and Mildred Mackay, retained the women's intercollegiate fencing championship without the loss of a match on the home strips tonight.
THE Dazian Dynasty has passed the 100-year-mark. That for Broadway, site of so many brief flights of fancy, is something to behold with reverence.

CAPTAIN JOHN SMITH was one of the first great Englishmen to set foot in the New World; he was also one of the New World's first press agents. Edison Marshall has delved deep in the various pamphlets which the captain published on his return from Jamestown to celebrate the virtues of His Majesty's colony in Virginia -- and his own prowess as its chief settler.

IF "the answer to the manpower problem is womanpower," as has been said repeatedly of late, does it follow that the answer to the womanpower problem is conscription? The Senate Military Affairs Committee is trying to make up its mind.

Leaders of national labor organizations made strong pleas yesterday for a unitel labor front and expressed opposition to individuals and groups, who, they charged, are impeding the war program by anti-labor activities, at a meeting conducted by the Labor for Unity and Victory Committee, whose function is to organize a May Day labor rally.

THE times being what they are, one would not expect to have many more volumes so handsomely and lovingly produced as this one. In "California's Missions" Hildegarde Hawthorne gives a brief historical sketch of the founding of the early Spanish missions in California, then describes in detail, in order of their antiquity, twenty-one missions stretching in a chain along the old Camino Real.

MEXICO CITY, April 10 -- Acknowledging the recrudescence of anti-American feeling that has been developing in Mexico in the past weeks, United States Ambassador George S. Messersmith, in a speech published yesterday, scored the anonymous agents of a campaign to sow distrust between the two nations.

One hundred thousand New Yorkers, including men and women, boys and girls, temporarily win discard other interests tomorrow to become bond salesmen for Uncle Sam in launching the $13,000,000,000 Second War Loan of the Treasury.

Denouncing President Roosevelt's wage-freezing executive order as "a false and unsound way to control inflation," John L. Lewis called yesterday on all labor and farmers to support the coal miners in their demand for higher wages, and urged Congress to override the President's order with new legislation.

Bill Maxwell of Michigan State proved himself quite a boy in winning the 145-pound title as the annual national A.A.U. senior wrestling championships came to an end last night at the West Side Y.M.C.A., the organization that regained the team title.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 10 (AP) -- Rutgers University's track team ran up the largest scoring total in Scarlet track history today as it defeated Brooklyn College, 116 to 10.
A month ago the silence of Winter was thick on the evening air. The nights had the quiet of the starlight and the days still had a frosty reticence, for Spring had not yet stirred.

THE sabotage front of Europe is the biggest single war front ever constituted in the whole bloodstained history of the human race. It extends from the Arctic Sea to the Mediterranean and from the Atlantic coast of France to the Ukrainian steppes. It has 200,000,000 combatants -- the German nation versus European humanity.
CHUNGKING, April 10 -- April 7 marked the fifth anniversary of the Battle of Taierchwang, in South Shantung Province. It is right that Taierchwang should be remembered.

A plan for the utilization of classified help-wanted advertising to assist the voluntary mobilization of manpower for the war effort has been approved by Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the War Manpower Commission, according to an announcement yesterday. The plan has just been announced to the 1,700 daily newspapers in the country in bulletins issued by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the Association of Newspaper Classified Advertising Managers.
LONDON, April 10 (U.P.) -- The "Cocktail Kids" of the battle-scarred Flying Fortress Dry Martini today were proclaimed the most deadly band of Fortress gunners in the world.

THIS is the tale of the exploits of the Polish pilots who played so notable a role in the Battle of Britain. The author's praise of Polish valor is substantiated by official reports and by the endorsement of all who have seen these fliers in action.
BUFFALO, April 10 (AP) -- All employes in manufacturing departments of the Niagara Falls assembly plant of the Bell Aircraft Corporation will work nine hours a day, six days a week, beginning Monday.

PARDEE LOWE'S father was born in China, but he lived in America and his problems were those of any American father. He had to build a business, raise a family and compromise with the ideas of the new generation.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The decrees of Algiers suppressing the measures taken since the Armistice against Jews and Masons have been put into operation in French Guiana, where adherents of General Henri Honore Giraud are in control of the government, the French Military Mission here announced today.

IN the Winter of 1939-40, the period of Dennis Wheatley's new and exciting spy story, Russia was Germany's ally, France believed in her Maginot Line, England's planes were dropping leaflets instead of bombs, and there still were innocent optimists who believed in the existenee of a sufficient number of anti-Nazi Germans to make a successful revolt against Hitler possible.

HERE is a book carrying the sting of realism that is written without bitterness. The keynote of Nurse Redmond's book is service, and the spirit of service predominates over this drama of agony and destruction, blood and death.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 10 -- Wyatt W. Hale, 42, dean of Birmingham-Southern College since 1934, took his own life today with a pistol believed to have been carried in his brief case as he left his home, apparently headed for his office.

Third Naval District Headquarters, 90 Church Street, announced yesterday that three more companies in this district have won the right to display three stars on the Army-Navy E flags flying over their plants.

ST. EXUPERY'S new book is a very different one from his "Night Flight," "Wind, Sand and Stars," or "Flight to Arras." And yet it has the same fine, clear, rarefied quality of the high lonely spaces where a man's mind has the range to ponder and question and wonder about the meanings of things.

LONDON, April 10 -- The Amalgamated Engineering Union, which after a study severely criticized British war production last year as being far below what it should be, finds after another similar investigation that there is still great room for improvement, even though big advances have been made in some respects.

THE New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States will add to its many home front activities with a preview opening tomorrow of its Kitchen Cupboard, a gaily decorated shop at 746 Madison Avenue for the sale of non-rationed food delicacies and kitchen gadgets.

Dwelling "in marble halls" will be no idle dream for service women in New York when, on April 30, the new Women's Military Services Club is opened at 451 Madison Avenue, formerly the Whitelaw Reid mansion.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Escort vessels of the British and other Allied navies are being equipped with Red Cross emergency clothing kits for rescued seamen, similar to those supplied to the Navy and Coast Guard. Expansion of the service, begun in July, was requested of the Red Cross by the British Admiralty.

ST. LOUIS, April 10 (AP) -- Opening the only major league competition for the two teams this Spring, the Browns defeated the world champion Cardinals today, 3 to 2. It was the first contest of a seven-game city series.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 10 -- We have not rolled the Japanese very far up in the Pacific but we have tangled with them enough to prove that we are better man for man and better by and large machine for machine.
Problems affecting the economic, political and geographic relationships of ten Latin-American nations and the United States will be discussed tomorrow in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

BUYING day-old chicks is the easiest, simplest and most economical way to start a small poultry flock -- and raising Victory chicks is not hard work. In fact, it will be found extremely interesting work. Those little balls of down, with shoe-button eyes, weighing only two ounces each, will be matured and ready to produce deliciously fresh eggs in five to six months.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- When Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, made known recently that there was neither a present nor a prospective plan to ration railroad travel, he pointed up in effect an impression that has been growing increasingly on the American public -- namely, that in this war, contrary to the situation in the last one, the country's railroads are "delivering the goods."

Eighty prominent New York educators have sent a letter to Ellsworth B. Buck, President of the Board of Education, urging that the board reconsider its refusal to appoint Mark Starr as director of adult education, it was announced yesterday by Dr. George S. Counts, State chairman of the American Labor party.

Following a year in which many new lines were added to maintain volume, large furniture retailers, most of whom are frozen under the inventory control order, are faced with the need for trimming down or even eliminating departments in order to conserve their limited "open-to-buy" position.

GHOST towns are a phenomenon of the American scene as enduringly fascinating as gangsters or adolescents, as Cape Cod or the Civil War. There is endless drama in those skeleton clusters of homes, saloons, stores, dance halls and fancy houses, which bloomed with such vigor on the rich edges of gold strikes and withered so fast when the gold ran out.

NEW DELHI, India, April 10 (AP) -- R.A.F. bombers staged a series of raids yesterday on Japanese shipping and highway traffic among the strong enemy defenses of Southern Burma, a British communique said today.

BOSTON, April 10 -- A Suffolk County jury at 8 o'clock tonight convicted Barnett Welansky, 48 years old, owner of Cocoanut Grove, of nineteen counts of manslaughter but acquitted his brother, James, and Jacob Goldfine, wine steward of the night club where fire and panic nineteen weeks ago tonight caused the loss of 491 lives.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Opposition developed in the Senate today to the House-approved Hobbs anti-racketeering bill, but supporters of the measure insisted that they would push it to an early vote and showed confidence in the outcome.

OMAHA, April 10 -- A few weeks ago the Corn Belt lay drab and desolate, a land of half-frozen clods and a litter of trampled cornstalks. The land was at its peak of unloveliness, waiting for the miracle of a somewhat belated Spring.

THIS is the oratorio season, and Victor issues its second album of this material within two months. In March Richard Crooks was heard in excerpts from oratorios, and now Eleanor Steber, talented young soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, appears in an album of Oratorio Arias (DM-927, three twelve-inch records).

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 10 -- The British Eighth Army occupied Sfax at 8:30 A.M. today and drove on northward as American, British and French forces breached the mountains at Fondouk, only fifty-five miles from the sea at Sousse.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Reports that the Office of Price Administration was contemplating raising the ceiling prices on cash corn, which were confirmed after the market closed, combined with a runaway rye market in Winnipeg, resulted today in fairly active buying of grain futures on the Board of Trade here.

An entirely new starting and course schedule has been drawn up for the championship and special regattas to be held this Summer at the Western end of Long Island Sound. The outstanding feature of it is that instead of the fleets getting away over a long-drawn-out period, a whole regatta will be started in forty minutes.

MOSCOW, April 10 -- Details published today by the Moscow News of the rapid recovery of Soviet agriculture after the tide of the enemy's conquest was rolled back allow a moderately optimistic picture to be drawn of Soviet food prospects should natural conditions remain normal and the population prove itself capable of carrying out the government's plan.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 10 -- Major Gen. James H. Doolittle's Flying Fortresses today bombed the 10,000-ton heavy Italian cruisers Trieste and Gorizia in the Northern Sardinian naval base at La Maddalena, putting them out of action at least for the period of the North African campaign.

UNDER the joint auspices of the Pan-American Woman's Association, the National Council of Women of the United States and THE NEW YORK TIMES, women representing many facets of interest in both North and South America will participate in the Pan-American Day Conference on Wednesday in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

HELEN HULL, author of a number of thoughtful novels -- the last to be published is "A Circle in the Water" -- reports that she is alternately praised and insulted by people who are convinced that she wrote "The Sheik," which was, of course, the very profitable labor of E.M. Hull.

Because of the food shortage, New Yorkers owe it to the war program either to respond to the call for volunteers to work on State farms during the Summer or to grow Victory Gardens in all available space in the city, Newbold Morris, President of the City Council and chairman of the New York City War Council, declared yesterday.

LONDON, April 10 -- Brig. Gen. Frank Armstrong, much-decorated hero of the United States Army Air Forces in the European theatre, has distinguished himself again. This time he is credited with having saved the life of a badly wounded navigator after their Flying Fortress had been hit by a shell in the Antwerp raid last Monday.

Mr. Churchill warns against overoptimism regarding current events in Tunisia. All right, sir, it comes hard, but we will do our best. Rommel's outfit, after baffling Montgomery at the Mareth Line, is skillfully rushing north according to plan, probably for a running jump off the dock at Bizerte and an underwater swim to Sicily, thus escaping us utterly.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 10 -- By pushing forward the range of their fighter and medium bomber operations, the Allied air forces in the Southwest Pacific are driving an aerial salient into the main Japanese defense line running across New Britain and Northern New Guinea.

"IT was pioneering," Dr. Hamilton says of her early years as the only woman in America in industrial medicine, "exploration of an unknown field. No young doctor nowadays can hope for work as exciting and rewarding.

OF conspicuous interest is the large twelfth biennial exhibition of water-colors that got under way late in the week at the Brooklyn Museum -- where the "Art for Bonds" show, not available in time to make this page, concurrently beckons.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 10 -- One of the track's largest opening day crowds turned out today at Churchill Downs to see Brownell Combs's Miss Dogwood win the Phoenix Handicap, $2,500 added feature of the first day of the Keeneland Park racing program, transferred here from Lexington.

In Washington the National Gallery and the Library of Congress have joined in an exhibition to honor the bicentennial of Jefferson. They will illustrate some of the many facets of his acquirements and achievements. The gallery has sought to assemble all portraits of him made in his life, with busts and medallions, and so on, of him and the other great figures of his time.

Staten Island firemen had a busy day yesterday fighting brush fires in almost every section of the island. From 8 A.M. until after 6 P.M. the firemen responded to fifty alarms. The biggest fire started at 3 P.M. in the woods back of the old Downey shipbuilding plant at the corner of Holland Avenue and Catherine Place, Mariners Harbor, and before it was put out two small unoccupied buildings on this property were destroyed.

LONDON, Monday, April 12 (AP) -- Fierce new German attempts to crack Soviet defense lines on the western bank of the Donets River below Kharkov have been broken with "tremendous losses" to the invaders in another explosion of heavy fighting on that front, Moscow announced early today.

A drive to speed up the recovery of frozen steel stocks for use in war production will be undertaken by the Salvagers and Redistributors Association, a group just formed by dealers in the principal steel centers throughout the country, it was announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 11 -- The battle of Central Tunisia seemed to be virtually over tonight as the British Eighth Army plunged forward north of Sfax twenty-seven miles through La Hencha, on the road to Sousse.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Hugh Russell Fraser, chairman of the Committee on American History, whose resignation from the staff of the Office of Education as a result of differences of opinion with his superiors over the teaching of history in the high schools was announced yesterday, reiterated his statement today that historical instruction suffered its first mortal blow at Denver, Col., in 1924.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- To Corporal William Barnes of Philadelphia, 23-year-old Marine credited with killing twenty-six Japanese himself as gunner in charge of a mortar crew, and with his crew getting at least another 100, has been awarded the Navy Cross, the Marine Corps announced here today.
