INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 11 (U.P.)-The Reds made it two straight over Cleveland today with a 5-to-2 victory as Johnny Vander Meet held the Indians hitless for four of the seven innings he pitched and scoreless until the last of the seventh.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 11 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Closer relationship between the ten nations of Middle America and the United States will be the theme of a meeting to be held today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to signalize Pan-American Week. The meeting, which will be held in two sessions, will be sponsored jointly by the Latin-American section of the New York Board of Trade and the Middle America Information Bureau, conducted by the United Fruit Company.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Light receipts of hogs last week at leading markets and the start of rationing have thrown the provision trade into confusion. Packers, faced with the heavy losses in slaughtering operations, have refused to follow the upturn in prices of hogs, with the result that the country has withheld supplies from market and a very tight situation has developed.

Marian Anderson's recital yesterday afternoon was the first in her career to be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House. At this third local appearance of the season the contralto again attracted a capacity audience, which included a group of 150 service men who were invited to attend and occupied seats on stage.

The Ballet Theatre appears to be determined that even its revival of familiar ballets shall have the element of novelty somewhere about them. Accordingly its first presentation of Leonide Massine's "Three-Cornered Hat" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night had none other than Argentinita as the Miller's Wife.
Six midtown theatres wilt present new films this week. The schedule follows:

Mrs. Orme Campbell, national director of Bundles for America, has purchased the four-story dwelling at 223 East Sixty-second Street from the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as trustee. The property, which contains a garden and will be occupied by the new owner, is assessed at $19,500.

In a letter signed by George H. Hallett Jr., secretary, the committee on legislation of the Citizens Union has asked Governor Dewey to veto the Ehrlich bill, which would authorize municipalities to issue five-year bonds to pay for salary "bonuses" to employes.

LONDON, April 11 -- Queen Elizabeth broadcast a message of appreciation, hope and encouragement to the women of the British Empire tonight after having taken part in celebrations marking the fourth anniversary of the revival of the Wrens, the auxiliary service of the Royal Navy, which came into existence first during World War I.

LONDON, April 11 -- Benito Mussolini, whose country is now dangerously exposed to invasion by a conquering Allied Tunisian army, has just concluded a four-day conference with Adolf Hitler, Berlin announced tonight, and Axis commentators said that this "working conference -- free of red tape" was held "against a background of stern military events, especially in the Italian realm."

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Liquidation in oats was on, last week, on the Board of Trade, induced largely by the action of other grains. The Presidential directive that ceiling prices be placed on agricultural products is not expected to affect oats to any great extent, as the law prohibits the placing of a ceiling on this grain at less than parity.

LONDON, April 11 -- The Russians joined the general aerial offensive against the Axis last night with a raid on the East Prussian capital of Koenigsberg and the Royal Air Force pounded Southwestern Germany.
CHUNGKING, China, April 11 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces have begun another large-scale effort to mop up Chinese troops far behind the front, where they have harassed the enemy for more than four years.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the award of the Distinguished Service Cross for heroism in the Southwest Pacific area to Brig. Gen. Albert W. Waldron of Rockville Centre, N.Y., for extraordinary heroism in action near Buna Village, New Guinea, on Dec. 5, 1942.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- Charley Fuchs and Jack Kraus held the Athletics to three hits today as the Phillies defeated the American Leaguers, 2 -- 0, to win their first victory in the city series.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- In a move to stop the rise in the cost of eating out, Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown authorized regional OPA offices today to establish maximum prices for food and beverages served by restaurants, cafeterias, hotels and other eating and drinking places.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 11 (AP) -- The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company announced today net income of $6,373,606 for 1942, the largest since 1929. This compared with net income of $3,256,469 for 1941, an increase of $3,117,137, or almost 100 per cent.

New York City has ample facilities, and will mobilize them, to enforce price ceilings on food commodities, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday. At the same time the Mayor declared that he planned to proceed against violators under local laws on short weights and short measures.

STOCKHOLM, April 11 (AP) -- Modest Gunder Haegg is getting into condition for a trip to the United States, but he doubts that he will get a chance to match his long-distance running prowess with America's best.

Wednesday will be the fifteenth annual Spring shopping day for the benefit of the Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Arnold Constable will give a percentage of the proceeds from all sales made in its New York store that day to the scholarship fund of the Village, a home and training school for underprivileged boys.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 11 -- In the midst of westerly puffs, the Spring series of sailing-dinghy racing was concluded today at the Larchmont Yacht Club. Jack Sutphen, with his craft Rum Dum, tied for the day's points with Bill Cox, at the helm of Pat O'Gorman's Felix, and thereby won the series.

The greatest War Loan drive in the nation's financial history will be launched today. The goal is $13,000,000,000, of which $8,000,000,000 is to come from investors other than commercial banks. The quota for the New York Federal Reserve District, which includes New York State, Northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn., is $3,000,000,000 from non-banking investors and nearly $2,000,000,000 from the commercial banks.

In your recent editorial on renewal of the Trade Agreements Act -- ("Coming: An Acid Test") -- you state that this will be an "acid test" of our intentions "because it will tell our present partners among the United Nations what they may expect of us in the field of economic cooperation * * *."

Every year it is news when Mrs. Yetta Weisbrod has a birthday. Yesterday was her 108th and an official party in her honor was held at the Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Jacob, the Bronx, where she has lived with 600 near-contemporaries for the last five years.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 11 -- The newly created Civil Affairs Division of the War Department, which advises the Secretary of War on civil affairs matters in occupied areas, will have on its staff a number of graduates of the School of Military Government established last May in this quiet Southern town whose university was founded by Thomas Jefferson.

CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- Merry Fahrney, patent medicine heiress, who quietly divorced her fifth husband here in 1941 and went to South America after obtaining a Swedish passport through the marriage, also cut herself off, at least temporarily, from her American fortune in the process, Federal Reserve Bank officials said today.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Here is the text of President Roosevelt's statement in the Public Debt Act of 1943:

NEW DELHI, India, April 11 (AP) -- Despite heavy casualties, Japanese patrols were reported today continuing efforts to cut off units of British forces on the west side of the Mayu Peninsula of Southwest Burma that were seeking to move to a concentration area on the Arakan front in the hills a few miles north of Indin.

NEW ORLEANS, April 11 -- Nervous selling in cotton futures because of different interpretations placed on the President's freeze order on prices and wages overnight on Thursday and on weakness in outside markets turned mid-week modest gains on the Cotton Exchange here into losses of around $1.50 a bale going into the final day of last week.

If the world is indeed to enter into a "century of the common man" we will be remiss in the spirit of our national ideal if we fail to have the common man of the world endowed with the right and power to control his own destiny.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Jack Cody, veteran swimming coach of the Portland, Ore., Multnomah Athletic Club, ended a thirty-year wait today as his "flashy foursome" won the team championship at the Women's National A.A.U. senior indoor swimming meet.

The final meeting of the New York Society of Teachers of Dancing, Inc., was held yesterday morning at the Hotel Astor. After a program in which Joshua T. Cockey of Baltimore, vice president of the Dancing Masters of America, presented ballroom numbers, Madelon Quinn exhibition ballroom combinations and Dorothy Duryea other varieties of ballroom steps, the members elected officers for the 1943-44 season.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- Warnings that automotive transportation throughout the country, but especially along the Eastern seaboard, would collapse unless relief was given to retailers of petroleum products were voiced today at a meeting of the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Conference.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 269 United States soldiers missing in action, including these with next of kin in New York:

WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- The most significant of recent proposals for winning the peace doubtless is the resolution introduced in the upper house of Congress by two Republican and two Democratic Senators, Dr. George A. Finch, director of the Division of International Law of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said today.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- The Presidential directive that is expected to result in the placing of ceiling prices on grains as well as other agricultural products was largely responsible last week for a wide open break in the markets on the Board of Trade.

Wartime activities sponsored by Smith College alumnae in the metropolitan district and those furthered at the college will be discussed at the annual Spring luncheon, "Smith in Wartime," to be held on Saturday in the main ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt under the auspices of the New York Smith College Club.

Prescott S. Bush, a partner in the private banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman Co. and the 1942 national campaign chairman of the United Service Organizations, Inc., has been named national campaign chairman of the National War Fund, it was announced yesterday by Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the fund.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Navy revised its tally of Thursday's great air battle near Guadalcanal for the third time today, announcing that later reports had disclosed that the Japanese lost thirty-nine planes and that an Allied fuel oil boat, previously reported as sunk, was merely damaged.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- A telephone strike, threatened by James A. Beirne, president of the National Federation of Telephone Workers, would be a strike against the government and should be called only after a membership vote, executives of five Illinois telephone workers' unions declared today.

The President's latest anti-inflation order makes it more necessary than ever that we follow clearly the future policy of the War Labor Board, that we understand just what our present situation is and that we know definitely what the past policy of the Board has been.

The Right Rev. George Algernon West, English Bishop of Rangoon, Burma, strongly urged the American people yesterday to become part of the great, world-wide Christian offensive that is ready to be hurled against the common enemy. He occupied the pulpit as guest preacher at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
LONDON, Monday, April 12 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique, as broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

OLD BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., April 11 -- In a field of twenty-six starters today in the amateur all-age stake, the leading event of the final day of the Southern New York Field Trial Club meeting, the outstanding winner was the lemon and white pointer bitch, Jake's Betsy Ross.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- Navy communique 340:

FARMINGDALE, L.I., April 11 -- The first step toward the employment of New York City Chinese and of college girls living in the metropolitan area for work on farms in Western Suffolk and Nassau Counties was taken this afternoon at a meeting of farm owners at the State Institute of Applied Agriculture here.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Roosevelt announced tonight that he had allowed to become law without his signature the Public Debt Extension Bill together with its rider repealing his executive order limiting salaries after taxes to $25,000 a year.

The George Rutledge Company, woodworkers filling war contracts with a main plant in Montclair, purchased the industrial property at 105 Lincoln Avenue, Orange, N.J., for addition to its present facilities. The buyer has occupied the property unler lease for some time.

A special "Service of Mourning" was held yesterday morning at the new Serbian Orthodox Church of St. Sava, formerly Trinity Episcopal Chapel, Twenty-fifth Street, just west of Broadway, to commemorate the second anniversary of "the murderous attack upon the open city of Belgrade made by the Nazis on Palm Sunday, 1941."
Apparently the news from Lakewood that Van Lingle Mungo was in shape and raring to go for the Giants was not merely wishful thinking.

The present crisis was characterized as "a summons to a larger evangelism" in a Lenten message made public yesterday by the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America. The message was released by the Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, president, who explained it was an official statement adopted by the representatives of twenty-five denominations.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Government planners are freely admitting that the toughest of post-war problems is implied by the statement in the Atlantic Charter guaranteeing to all nations ready access to raw materials.
The text of the report by the committee appointed by Governor Dewey to study business and employment opportunities in New York City follows:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices regained the loss of the previous week and rose from 111.7 to 112.2. The farm produce index rose 1.8 per cent, as increases in cattle, hogs and potatoes more than offset decreases in apples, wheat and lamb.

COMMACK, L.I., April 11 -- State police today arrested Charles Longworth of Virginia Avenue, Bay Shore, as the driver of an automobile that did not stop after killing two men Friday night as they were walking on Jericho Turnpike here.

It was the good fortune of Dmitri Kabalevsky yesterday afternoon to have the first performance in America of the overture to his opera. "Colas Breugnon," given by Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra in the NBC Studio, Radio City, for an international broadcast, the last of the season's series.

Prices of cotton declined last week on liquidation prompted by President Roosevelt's order for placing a ceiling on all commodities affecting the cost of living. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net losses of 27 to 35 points.

Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, heads of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation and labor officials joined forces at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to work out plans to curtail absenteeism in the Curtiss-Wright plants.
LONDON, April 11 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:
MOSCOW, April 11 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- The War Labor Board announced today unanimous approval of a wage agreement between two children's apparel associations and the International Ladies Garment Worker's Union, A.F. of L., calling for a flat 5 per cent increase for piece workers and $1.00 to $2.00 a week increases for all workers paid weekly, retroactive to Dec. 1, 1942.

In his initial competitive appearance after an absence of approximately two years, August von Munchhausen of the Saltus Club won six of eight matches at the Salle Santelli yesterday to top the qualifiers in the metropolitan and non-divisional trials of the national open individual electric epee championship.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11 -- The Portuguese liner San Miguel, bearing the bodies of ten of the twenty persons killed Feb. 22 in the crash of the Yankee Clipper in the Tagus River, near Lisbon, tied up today at a pier at the foot of Washington Avenue after a three-week voyage from Lisbon.

The United States Trust Company will observe today its ninetieth anniversary. Chartered on April 12, 1853, the concern was one of the first in this country organized exclusively to conduct a trust business. Its charter subsequently was used as the basis of the general law covering all trust companies in this State.

The Lavallee-Smith Choir of the Chateauguay Regiment, Canadian Army Reserve, conducted by Jean Charbonneau, gave its first New York concert last night in Town Hall. Composed of thirteen men from the regiment and sixteen women members of its auxiliary, the chorus is named for the late Alphonse Lavallee-Smith, a revered organist and choirmaster of Montreal.

Today the Treasury launches the largest war bond campaign in history. The goal is thirteen billion dollars, or about enough to pay our war expenses for two months at the January rate of expenditure. The announced goal is a minimum, not a limit. We raised nearly this much in the December war bond drive, which had a goal of nine billion dollars.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 11 (U.P.) -- American forces have smashed back through Faid Pass to avenge their February defeat there, and Allied armies driving twenty-seven miles north of Sfax and to the outskirts of Kairouan have compressed the Axis into one-eighth of Tunisia as its last African foothold, it was disclosed tonight.

A national campaign against all types of discrimination against Negroes in the armed forces and in industry was approved yesterday at the closing session of the two-day meeting of the Eastern Seaboard Conference of the National Negro Congress at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street.

LONDON, April 11 -- With General Bouscat, head of General Henri Honore Giraud's mission to the Fighting French, due here soon, the French National Committee met for three hours today, primarily to receive General Georges Catroux's report on his conversations with the French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa.

Ilya Ehrenburg, the Russian novelist and journalist, has written a new novel, "The Fall of Paris," to be published by Knopf on June 7. The book, growing out of the author's long years of residence in France, takes a group of characters forming a cross-section of Parisian life and relates their individual and common experiences against the backdrop of the last years of the Third Republic.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- Rains have blanketed part of the dry area in the Winter Wheat Belt, relieving dry surface soil conditions. A Weather Bureau weekly summary had indicated that there were dry sections in parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Kansas, Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, New Mexico, Iowa, Missouri and Illinois.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 11 (AP) -- America Lightnings, ranging out over the Sicilian Strait between Tunisia and Sicily twice today, ran into opposition, scoring heavily. Of the twenty-seven planes knocked down, twenty-one were transports.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 11 -- Reconnaissance over La Maddalena Harbor in Northern Sardinia revealed today that the Italian heavy cruiser Trieste, which was bombed by Flying Fortresses yesterday, had sunk.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 11 -- Springfield and West Springfield police continued dragging the Connecticut River today for the body of a man who they have reason to believe was Rollin C. Dean, 57 years old, of Westfield, N.J., purchasing agent for the Rockefeller Foundation in New York.

PITTSBURGH, April 11 -- Steel ingot production last week again remained at 100 per cent of rated capacity, and there is every indication that a like tonnage will be produced this week. This sustained high output is expected to be continued for some time unless unforeseen difficulties, such as sudden breakdowns, occur.

With little more than a fortnight left before the expiration of extended agreements under which the soft coal industry is operating, the deadlocked wage negotiations between the United Mine Workers and bituminous operators of the Appalachian region will enter their crucial phase this week.

DETROIT, April 11 -- The possibility that oil soon will have to be abandoned for common heating purposes was predicted in a report made public tonight by the American Chemical Society, which begins a week's convention here tomorrow.
The German Sunday communique, as recorded by The United Press:
MIAMI, Fla., April 11 (AP) -- The Navy's Silver Star award was pinned yesterday on the breast of Lieutenant John L. Laird, 22, of Minneapolis.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- About 3,000,000 childless married men now in deferred draft classifications apparently are slated to be shifted to a 1-A status, making them subject to induction soon, under a draft reclassification shuffle expected tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Moral Rearmament, in a ninety-three-page booklet, has set forth as its war record the stimulation of production through labor-management cooperation.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, April 11 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, chief of United States forces in the European theatre; Major Gen. Russell P. Hartle and American and British officers and correspondents watched today as a Lynn (Mass.) platoon of combat engineers demonstrated their readiness for a try at the German coastal defenses.

Your editorial "The Manpower Bill" is timely in directing the attention of your readers to the organizations and public administrators who hope to win the war without mobilizing the entire resources of the nation.

UTICA, N.Y., April 11 -- Elimination of cold cuts from meat rationing, and specialty items from processed food rationing, was urged on the Office of Price Administration today at a special emergency meeting here of the officers of the New York State Food Merchants' Association.

MEDFORD, N.J., April 11 -- Village Dictator, a pointer handled by Lester Varne for John Rush of Jacksonville, Fla., today won the members' all-age stake, final event of the English Setter Club's annual Spring field trial meeting.

A contribution of $100,000 from Eastern Air Lines, Inc., to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the campaign to raise $12,920,700 in this city. The gift was one of the largest received by the fund recently.

Constitutional reform in New Jersey seems overdue. The State Constitution was adopted in 1844, when New Jersey was still a sparsely settled rural area, and has been amended only four times, then only in minor respects, according to the New Jersey Constitution Foundation, a nonpartisan research and educational organization.

Celebration of the bicentennial anniversary of Thomas Jefferson's birth, which occurs tomorrow, began here yesterday. In pulpits and in public meetings, speakers recalled his contributions as the architect of American freedom. They emphasized the timeliness of celebrating these things while they were being so widely challenged.
LONDON, April 11 -- The news from Africa today shows quite clearly that the last phase of the Tunisian campaign is starting.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 11 -- Columbia announced today the purchase of screen rights to a story, "Washington, I Love You," by Ruth McKenny, author of "My Sister Eileen." The new story will be published serially in The New Yorker before filming.

OMAHA, Neb., April 11 -- Six hundred United States Army men under the command of Colonel Harry Amadson came to the aid of hundreds of Nebraska State Guard and civilian workers at noon today in an effort to save the Omaha municipal airport area from inundation.

LONDON, April 11 (Reuter) -- Just before leaving last week for Adolf Hitler's headquarters, Premier Mussolini conferred at length with Nicholas Kallay, Hungarian Prime Minister, without German assistance at the meetings. This fact and the tone of Mr. Kallay's speeches give color to the view that Signor Mussolini has faced Herr Hitler with a demand in Hungary's name as well as in Italy's.

Reproductions of fifty significant advertisements that have appeared recently in newspapers are contained in Supplement No. 4 to the book "Advertising Goes to War" which has just been issued by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

The management of the two night clubs known as Cafe Society believes that any music that has vitality in a bistro will have what it takes to hold forth at Carnegie Hall. Acting on this belief, Cafe Society moved up to Carnegie Hall last night, bringing with it all its lares and penates of entertainment.

A strange thing about those fine perfumes that all women long for and many women love is the trait they have of quickly becoming imperceptible to the wearer. The phenomenon is explanied in complicated chemical terms by a perfume designer who has finally succeeded in creating one that does not do such a disappearing act.

FONDOUK, Tunisia, April 10, 7 P.M. (Delayed) (U.P.) -- British advance armor drove up two roads today toward the holy city and road junction of Kairouan. At last reports armored cars were only ten miles from the town, encountering only light shellfire.

CHICAGO, April 11 -- All deliveries of corn other than September held last week at ceiling prices on the Board of Trade, and elevator interests reported that it was becoming increasingly hard to purchase the May delivery.

Bruno Walter and the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra gave a program yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, opening with Schubert's Seventh symphony in C major, continuing with Haydn's 'cello concerto in D major, with Joseph Schuster, the orchestra's first 'cellist, as soloist, and concluding with Richard Strauss's rondo, "Till Eulenspiegel's Merry Pranks."

The United States is facing "one of the greatest periods of its development" in which it will achieve freedom from want through the processes of "kindly revolution" that have marked the progress of this nation from its beginning, Adolf A. Berle Jr., Assistant Secretary of State, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- In response to the objections of producers and distributors, the Office of Price Administration postponed today by a month the effective date of Price Regulation No. 339, fixing prices and requiring marking of women's rayon hosiery.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 (AP) -- The accuracy with which British intelligence experts have anticipated changes in designs of German military equipment long before the innovations appear on the battlefield has been an important factor in the defeat now engulfing Axis armies in Africa, military men said today.

LONDON, April 11 -- Pietro Mormina, writing in the Italian newspaper Tribuna Illustrata, said that Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler and Premier Benito Mussolini would soon discuss the possibility of bombing attacks on New York, the Berlin radio reported today.

Though General Alexander warns us there is still heavy fighting ahead in Tunisia, the days of the Axis in Africa seem numbered. Perhaps it is in recognition of this, and in fear of an early invasion of Italy, that Mussolini and Hitler have had a four-day meeting. In the last week of defeat and head-long retreat the Germans have lost all of Southern Tunisia as well as the mountain passes which guarded their flank.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 12 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Police Commissioner Valentine, speaking to 5,500 members of the Police Department Holy Name Society yesterday morning at a communion breakfast in the Hotel Astor, old them to "beware of dual jobs, because you're taking an awful gamble."

WASHINGTON, April 11 (U.P.) -- French resistance to the Germans is now thoroughly organized and in many instances is supported by modern arms and materiel, according to advices reaching Fighting French headquarters today.

The United Nations will need the help of private organizations for "the work of human salvage" that must accompany the march of Allied Armies into Europe and the Far East, Joseph C. Grew, former United States Ambassador to Japan, declared today in a nationwide radio address.
The annual memorial service of the New York Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution was held yesterday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

The Jewish Forum, a publication devoted to "uniting Jew and non-Jew in safeguarding democracy," celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary with a dinner at the Hotel Commodore yesterday. Representatives of three faiths emphasized American opposition to discrimination.

Declaring that the recent hearings before the Board of Estimate on his proposed executive budget of $153,071,123 for 1943-44 "were the easiest in many a long year" because of difficulty in finding "any real, honest cause for complaint," Mayor La Guardia yesterday advised disgruntled real estate taxpayers to direct their protests to the department stores that took part in the successful drive to prevent the city from doubling its sales tax.

Wholesale markets were busy last week filling last-minute requests for goods needed to round out stocks for pre-Easter events, according to a summary of the week's activity prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- The Polish Telegraph Agency said tonight that the Germans had erased the ghetto at Krakow in a three-day massacre that started March 13, and also had eliminated the ghetto in Lodz.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 11 -- Jersey City, which always has had a rear view of the Statue of Liberty, received today a thirteen-foot copy that could be seen from all angles.

AT A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, March 21 (Delayed) -- The second installment of the life story of little Patsy Lee is more pleasant than the first. Under the gentle ministrations of the French Catholic Sisters of St. Mary and companionship of other children she has learned to smile again.

The report for 1942 of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, released for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $36,464,030 before depletion of metal mines, equal to $4.20 each on the 8,674,338 capital shares outstanding.

The war has meant many sad things to many people but to the male contingent of commuters on the Long Island Railroad yesterday it brought, to put it mildly, an agreeable surprise. For the first time in its history the Long Island has added to its nomenclature of railroading the term "trainwoman."

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 11 -- Jimmy Wilson looks suspiciously like the cat who has just swallowed the canary. He beams all over and his eyes twinkle. When he started to talk, the waves of optimism bowled over all careless bystanders.

One of the wartime crises that we do not propose to worry much about is the shortage of baseball umpires. A dispatch carried on The Associated Press wires from Chicago called attention to this handicap facing the American League and pointed out that only ten arbiters will be on duty instead of the even dozen last season.

LONDON, April 11 -- Although it has been impossible to digest all at once the plans of Great Britain and the United States for a postwar international currency union, the initial stock market reactions show that certain fairly definite opinions have been formed.

LONDON, April 11 (AP) -- Faced with the necessity of stretching their slim allotment of clothing coupons an extra month, Britons spent less on wardrobes in February than in any month since February, 1938.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The War and Navy Departments have joined in a request that Congress promptly pass the pending bill which would reserve exclusively to the Army, the Navy and the American Red Cross the use of the Red Cross name and emblem.
ST. LOUIS, April 11 (AP) -- Bunching six hits in two innings, the world champion Cardinals today defeated the Browns, 5 to 2, in the second of seven city series games.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street, announced to his congregation at yesterday's service that the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. had raised $946,000 of the $1,000,000 objective of its Wartime Service Fund.

The scope of the Pan-American Conference of Women scheduled for Wednesday afternoon at the New York Times Hall, was widened yesterday with the announcement of the participation of a representative from Canada. Mrs. F.B. Cutter, president of the Canadian Women's Club of New York City, will be among the speakers.

Declaring his intention to reorganize the Board of Education, in time, into a completely harmonious body in all of whose members he would have confidence, Mayor La Guardia made a blistering attack yesterday upon Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the board, for his part in the recent rejection of Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, for the post of adult education director in the city school system.

On Thursday New Jersey's trout fishermen will be out on the streams for the opening of another season, which in past years has been an important occasion for the fishing fraternity in the Garden State.
DETROIT, Mich., April 11 -- Reports on the work women are doing in chemistry will feature the 105th meeting of the American Chemical Society, which opens here tomorrow and continues until Friday.

People are learning that, regardless of severe restrictions, life must go on, the Rev. Ira W. Langston, one of the twenty West Side pastors participating in a united Lenten preaching project, said yesterday in a sermon in the Central Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) at 142 West Eighty-first Street.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick drew yesterday a parallel between the present era and 200 years ago, the time of Thomas Jefferson. In a sermon in the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street, the pastor pointed out that on both occasions great opportunities to be of service were presented to the people and their leaders in this country.

Declaring that labor must assume leadership in translating the effort on the home front into offensive action against the enemy, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, called last night for a balanced economy that did not hit a dead end after merely effecting wage controls on workers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 12 -- Allied fighter planes shot out of action twenty-three of forty-five Japanese fighters and dive bombers attacking Oro Bay, twenty miles south of Buna, New Guinea, Sunday, in an air battle at sub-stratosphere levels, and General Douglas MacArthur warned that the enemy apparently has begun an air offensive "which may attain a considerable scale of effort."
MOSCOW, April 11 -- The Soviet Union has harnessed to its peoples' will two traditional features of Russia -- her gypsies and her wolves.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The OPA'S move today to control restaurant prices coincided with an account by Senator Nye of a man who paid $1.20 for a quart of milk served in a Washington hotel.

Capt. William Alexander Cooper, in 333 E 68th St; Lawrence F. Sherman Jr., in 325 E 72d St through Douglas Gibbons Co; Capt. George T. Yerger, in 149 E 40th St through N.A. Berwin; De Witt V. Kelly, in 301 E 21st St -- Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 11 -- An ace squadron leader, Lance Wade, 28-year-old American-born commanding officer of a fighter squadron of the desert Allied Air Force, set a new Middle East record of enemy aircraft destroyed by shooting down his twentieth victim this week.

Further moves to help in combating the inflationary spiral, poised for enforcement ever since James F. Byrnes stepped down from the United States Supreme Court to assume the task of directing an economic stabilization program to further the war effort, came last week from the White House.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 7 (Delayed) -- Food and health conditions in the French island of Martinique are deteriorating steadily and the islanders live in intensifying terror under a regime whose only aim is apparently to maintain itself in power, an informant believed to be unimpeachable said tonight.

The Schwarze Korps, an official Nazi paper, expressed the opinion that "the middle class is dead and should not rise again after the war," according to a report of the Swedish paper Svenska Dagbladet quoted yesterday by the British radio.

New York City's economic future, because of declining trends in its manufacturing industries, which may be accelerated by the war, presents a major community problem that will require the attention of its ablest leaders in industry, commerce and labor as well as of the city and State governments, according to a report by the Hanes Committee on Employment in the city, which Governor Thomas E. Dewey made public yesterday in Albany.

The Dodgers really poured it on the Yankees yesterday at the Stadium. They spotted the American League champions two runs, hammered Atley Donald to shelter in a five-run inning, took liberties with the fork-hand flipping of young Tommy Byrne and galloped off with a 9-to-5 victory, which gave them a clean sweep of the three-game series in the Bronx.

Both from his study and his office in the White House the President has a clear view of the new Jefferson Memorial. He can look down from the park-like and now blossomy vista, past the Washington Obelisk, to the dazzling white dome of the temple he will dedicate on Tuesday to his favorite American, one of the four men in history he most admires.

WASHINGTON, April 11 -- The Republican party will welcome the Democrats' suggestion for late party conventions and a short campaign next year to promote wartime unity if satisfactory assurances are received that President Roosevelt does not want the job for the fourth time and would refuse the nomination if it were tendered to him.

LONDON, April 11 -- Wall Street's week-end break came too late to affect stock market sentiment here generally, although it will doubtless exert influence in some directions when markets reopen tomorrow. Markets as a whole responded moderately last week to the favorable trend of war news generally and particularly to stimulating developments in Tunisia.

Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, called yesterday upon Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, to reorganize the Democratic organization in Manhattan to take in all Democratic groups or face a series of Assembly district leadership fights in which the Young Democrats would participate.

AT THE TUNISIAN FRONT, April 8 (delayed) -- To give an idea of what this disappearing southern front looks like, this correspondent offers some jottings from his diary after a day's tour along the lines in a Chinese jeep that was destined for Chiang Kai-shek, but got mixed up in the rush:

Now is the time to check the equipment that will be used next Summer in preserving food. Now is the time, too, to get this equipment in shape, to determine where fruits and vegetables will be stored once they are processed, and to decide whether one's canning or dehydrating or whatever will be done at home or at a community center.

INDORE, Central India, April 7 (Delayed) -- Once upon a time a pretty American girl just out of school married a former Maharaja of a great Indian State. I do not know whether it can be added that "they lived happily ever afterward," but perhaps it would not be much exaggeration.

The Canadian free dollar was irregularly lower last week. After early values of 90.32 cents, a slight bulge in the offerings caused a recession to 90.06 cents, on Friday, with a rally to 90.12 cents, the close on Saturday, for a loss of 1-16 cent from the preceding week.

LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- The transfer of ninety Americans from the Royal Air Force and the Royal Canadian Air Force to the United States Eighth Air Force was announced today by the European Theater of Operations of the United States Army.

LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- Two months after his arrival in Europe to confer with Pope Pius XII and visit United States armed forces Archbishop Francis J. Spellman has packed his bags for a second visit to North Africa.

Under the joint auspices of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office and the Department of Markets, the first consumer service center to be located within a city public market was opened in a brief ceremony yesterday at the Essex Street market, between Delancey and Rivington Streets.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Farm real estate values throughout the country rose sharply in the twelve-month period ended March 1, the Department of Agriculture announced today. The increase in values, most of which came during the last four months, was the highest in any year since 1920.
Because of war conditions, the Presbytery of New York voted yesterday at its annual meeting to send only half the usual number of delegates to the General Assembly in Detroit on May 27.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 7, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: Increases of $156,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $320,000,000 in Reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, $1,107,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $300,000,000 in deposits its credited to domestic banks; and a decrease of $857,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Maximum prices on beef carcasses and wholesale cuts were adjusted today by the Office of Price Administration with a view to equalizing the position of all sellers and to prevent an abnormal diversion of "belly meat" to hamburger.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- Private advices today predict another reshuffle in German diplomatic circles following the recent death of Baron Hans-Adolf yon Moltke, Reich Ambassador to Spain, and the retirement of'Diego yon Bergen, the Germany envoy to the Vatican.

John A. Coleman, who first became associated with securities trading as a floor page of the New York Stock Exchange when 15 years old, at 41 has been nominated as the Exchange's candidate for chairman of the board of governors.

It is estimated that an army of about 3,000,000 volunteer workers has been organized throughout the country to make personal solicitations in the Second War Loan Drive which started yesterday. The goal of $13,000,000,000 will require the utmost in sales effort.

Dr. Janet R. Aiken, 50 years old, a member of the teaching staff of Columbia University for many years, has been notified by Professor John H.H. Lyon, head of the English department in extension, that she is not to be a member of the faculty after the close of the present school semester.

CHICAGO, April 12 (AP) -- Live hogs suffered the widest price break of the current crop year today, when prices dropped 40 to 50 cents a hundred pounds, with the top slumping to $15.30, compared with $15.80 last Friday. Cattle were steady to 25 cents off and lambs closed weak and 25 to 40 cents lower.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court upheld today a $4,000,000 income tax assessment imposed by the Federal Commissoner of Internal Revenue on the Chicago Stock Yards Company on the ground that the company had been "availed of" during 1930, 1932 and 1933 in order to prevent the imposition of a surtax upon its stockholders.

The Yankees, who failed to beat the Dodgers in three games over the week-end, yesterday found the combination of rain and cold just as formidable, and their exhibition game with the Braves at the Stadium was called off. Weather permitting, Joe McCarthy will send his men against Casey Stengel's Boston aggregation at 3 o'clock this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Before a capacity audience, including cabinet members, Supreme Court justices, foreign diplomats, members of Congress, Army and Navy officials, "We Will Never Die," the pageant commemorating 2,000,000 Jewish victims of Nazi barbarity, was presented in Constitutional Hall tonight.

A nation-wide drive to raise $25,000,000 for the overseas relief and refugee aid programs of the agencies of the United Jewish Appeal, will be launched tomorrow with a dinner at the Plaza Hotel, Alexander E. Arnstein, chairman in the metropolitan area, announced yesterday.

The Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives heard yesterday from Secretary Hull an eloquent and persuasive appeal for prolonging the life of a law to whose administration he has given nine years of devoted service -- the Reciprocal Trade Act. Mr. Hull did not attempt to argue that this law is of great practical importance at the present moment.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- "Switzerland's frontiers are sacred. They cannot and will not be subjects of discussion but they will be defended," Marcel Pilet-Golaz, chief of the Swiss Political Department [Foreign Office] said yesterday in addressing the Radical-Democrat party congress at Geneva.
SFAX, Tunisia, April 11 (Delayed) -- This small industrial town, road junction and naval base, which has been an objective of the British Eighth Army, is already in the back-waters of our advance.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Treasury officials reported tonight a "tremendous" response in the first few hours after the opening of the Second War Loan Campaign to raise $13,000,000,000 for war financing. It was disclosed also that the drive is just the starting gun of a $70,000,000,000 program to finance the war this year.

Five new designs by Helen Cookman for parts of the "Victory" uniform for women air raid wardens and volunteers in report centers were approved yesterday by Mayor La Guardia, David A. Thompson, acting commandant of the Air Warden Service, announced.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- Vera Hruba, Czechoslovakian figure skater, has been signed to a seven-year optional contract by Republic. Her first picture will be "Gay Blades," a skating musical to be produced here this Summer. The company intends to make at least one picture a year of this type with Miss Hruba starred.
Last night's program of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was made up exclusively of what might be termed antiques, but the performance was out of the top drawer.
LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

" Mother Roper," the biography of Mrs. Janet Roper of the Seamen's Church Institute, who died on April 5, will be an Autumn publication of Doubleday, Doran. Jonathan Finn, the author, had been working with Mrs. Roper on the book for several months before her death.

New Yorkers, faced with the assignment of raising nearly $5,000,000,000 of the $13,000,000,000 Uncle Sam is seeking in the Second War Loan, greatest borrowing drive in world history, rolled up their sleeves yesterday and went to work with a will.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 -- American fighting men in the active war theatres are willing to risk their lives day or night without complaint or hesitancy, but when they learn that workers quit the production lines for five hours to complain of inadequate telephone service, as occurred recently, they wonder if it is all worth While.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 12 -- The population of the Warsaw ghetto has been reduced from 500,000 to approximately 40,000, according to the annual report just published by the Swedish Israel Mission, a Swedish "Aryan" organization aiding Jewish victims of German persecution.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The President has finally declined to abandon his drastic plan to limit and control the news of the international food conference that will open in May at Hot Springs, Va. He intended from the beginning that there shall be no more open reporting of this meeting than of military activities.

The Army Air Forces "have gone a long way toward solving the oxygen-starvation problem," they announced yesterday in releasing details of a new altitude chamber that duplicates atmospheric conditions seven miles above the earth.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- The internal situation in Bulgaria is rapidly becoming more tense as the time approaches when the government can be expected to publish its "grave decisions," according to reports received here from Sofia tonight.

LONDON, April 12 -- Introducing a record-breaking budget with total estimated expenditures of 5,756,114,000, Sir Kingsley Wood, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, said in the House of Commons today that he expected to raise 56 per cent of it from current revenue without increasing the income tax.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Office of Price Administration officials hailed the I.C.C. decision as one which would assist them in controlling prices. In many cases, they indicated, the lower freight charges will avert the necessity of increasing prices of some manufactured products whose costs have gone up.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The scattered impulses of American women "to get down to good earth" and help solve the United Nations food problem were united today by the appointment of Miss Florence Louise Hall as head of the Women's Land Army of the United States Crop Corps now in the process of creation by Congress.

With some 13,595 hardy spectators huddled under the stands away from the cold, driving rain, Jamaica's race meeting yesterday entered its first full week with a seven-race card in which Johnny Longden completed a triple aboard Circle M Ranch's Sir War to take the $2,000 claiming sixth race, the feature.
The German Monday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Paying scant attention to the new Selective Service regulations issued only a few hours before, the House today passed the Kilday bill to write into law rigid rules for the calling of registrants for induction according to categories based upon relative dependency status, and for the exhausting of each category throughout a State, rather than a local draft board, before turning to the next.

Imperial Oil, Ltd., controlled by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, reported yesterday in its annual statement for 1942 net income of $14,663,097 after all charges, including taxes and reserves, equal to 54 cents a share on 26,965,078 shares of capital stock.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- After what he called "an important discussion on the Pacific" with President Roosevelt today, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Attorney General and Minister for External Affairs, said he felt confident that before his mission here was completed there would be "good news for the American and Australian forces in the Southwestern Pacific."

EVANSVILLE, Ind., April 12 -- It sounded like a good team at that, Hank Greenberg, Charlie Gehringer, Billy Hitchcock and Dutch Meyer in the infield, Barney McCosky, Pat Mullin and Walt Evers, a "sure-thing" find from Beaumont, in the outfield, Birdie Tebbetts catching and Al Benton pitching.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 12 (AP) -- The Dixiana Stable's Amber Light put in another qualifying bid for the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs today when he scored an impressive victory over the Milky Way Stable's No Wrinkles. The race was a feature of the newly opened Keeneland season.
PERHAPS the best way to offer a commentary on Alec de Montmorency's "The Enigma of Admiral Darlan"* is to summarize its contents.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 12 -- The six-day "Nassau County at War" exposition to stimulate the sale of war bonds opened today at Adelphi College here.

The Community Service Society held a fourth anniversary meeting yesterday at the New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, marking also the second year of the society's Institute of Welfare Research. The society grew out of a merger of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor and the Charity Organization Society.
CHICAGO, April 12 -- Thomas Jefferson, President, statesman, architect, inventor and man of many other interests, was credited tonight with being the first New World writer to mention the submarine.

CHUNGKING, China, April 12 (U.P.) -- More than 1,000 Japanese, who launched attacks Saturday on Chinese positions north of Lini, about 120 miles southeast of Shantung, Province's capital of Tsinan, were repulsed by "ferocious" Chinese resistance after a twenty-four-hour battle, it was announced today.

Today, the 200th anniversary of the birth of Thomas Jefferson, third President of the United States, will be celebrated with ceremonies in every State and in thousands of cities and other communities under the auspices of the Bill of Rights Sesqui-Centennial Committee of the Council Against Intolerance in America, the committee announced yesterday.
Mrs. Hinman Magraw, through Culver, Hollyday Co, Inc, in 930 5th Ave; Mrs. Lawrence Morris, through Duff Conger, Inc, in 1150 5th Ave -- Louis Carreau, Inc, brokers.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Every able-bodied man, single and married, between 18 and 38, will be inducted into the armed forces by the end of the year, with the exception of 3,200,000 deferred for essential industry and agriculture and for hardship reasons, under new selective service orders issued today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission.

LONDON, April 12 -- Mrs. James V. Forrestal, wife of the American Under-Secretary of the Navy, predicted today that the restriction on Waves' service outside the continental United States would be lifted.

Ethelbert Smith said yesterday that he saw by the paper that New York City is losing trade at an alarming rate. Well, no wonder. Considering the lack of enterprise and intelligence with which the city's merchants offer their wares to the public it is a wonder that they can sell enough goods to pay for the red ink in their balance sheets.

FORT DIX, N.J, April 12 -- More than 3,000 soldiers were disappointed today when the Giants and the Dodgers, scheduled to play a full nine-inning game, were thwarted by miserable weather and had to call it off after an inning and a half.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 12 -- Wendell Willkie has told California Republicans, in response to an invitation to enter the State's Presidential primary next year, that he has not decided on his course of action.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Representative Martin, Republican leader of the House, said tonight that he would circulate a petition to discharge the Ways and Means Committee from further consideration of pay-as-you-go taxation unless it reported out such a bill within the next few days.

Red-letter days are those big moments in a woman's life when she wants to be remembered as looking her prettiest. It was for these special occasions that Oppenheim Collins showed a comprehensive collection of some of its prettiest clothes at its weekly "quickie" fashion show during lunchtime yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, issued a statement today disclaiming responsibility for the methods used or competence shown in the teaching of history in the schools, and for the activities and statements of Hugh Russell Fraser in that connection.

Fourteen women were appointed yesterday by the Board of Transportation as change makers for the city's rapid transit system as the board began putting its new policy of replacing men with women where possible because of the manpower shortage.

The Broward County, Fla., Port Authority has awarded to John Nuveen Co. a new issue of $3,763,000 of refunding bonds. The issue consists of $359,000 of 3 1/2s due on Dec. 15, 1944 to 1950; $804,000 of 3 3/4s due on Dec. 15, 1951 to 1957, and $2,600,000 of 4s due on Dec. 15, 1958 to 1970.

The four-story apartment house at 1023 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by the Hoboken Bank for Savings to Charles D'Anduono through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker. This structure is fully rented. Pierson Brand were the attorneys.
ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- The American way of life certainly is worth a 4 to 6 per cent mortgage on our national income, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, declared today.
Nearly four million books have been collected in the first four months of the 1943 Victory Book Campaign, it was announced yesterday at Victory Book headquarters in the Empire State Building.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- The attitude of the Fighting French contingent in U.S.S.R. toward political events in North Africa was expressed last night by a young Breton, Sergeant H. Bourveau, a member of General Petit's military mission, in a broadcast from radio Moscow. Sergeant Bourveau left France for Britain at the time of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's capitulation.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Announcement late Saturday that the Office of Price Administration would advance the ceiling price on yellow cash corn by 5 cents a bushel had a far-reaching effect on the price of oats and rye today on the Board of Trade.

The members of the New York Drama Critics Circle will meet this afternoon at the Algonquin to pick what they regard as the best American play of the current season, and the best imported from elsewhere. The voting on the best domestic play is expected to be close, with Sidney Kingsley's "The Patriots," Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" and the Maxwell Anderson "The Eve of St. Mark" as the most promising contenders.

AN ALLIED AIR BASE IN NORTH AFRICA, April 10 (Delayed) -- Plane and jeep have superseded the camel as North Africa's chief mode of transportation, and much credit goes to the young men who act as taxi drivers across these vast expanses, shuttling non-chalantly between Atlas peaks and over horrible stretches of road mined at the shoulders in weather that even mad dogs would think twice about challenging.

LIMA, Peru, April 12 (U.P.) -- Two hundred thousand people today welcomed Vice President Henry A. Wallace in the most spectacular demonstration ever accorded a foreign statesman here when he arrived for a three-day visit as an official guest of President Manuel Prado.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- A draft registrant, convicted of failing to keep his Selective Service Board properly informed of his address, obtained a Supreme Court review of his case today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 12 (AP) -- The American and British air forces continued today to strike terrible blows, converting scores of enemy vehicles into scattered wreckage and virtually wiping the Axis from the skies.

City officials were critical yesterday in their comment on the report of the Hanes committee, which found the city facing a serious economic decline in the postwar period unless trends in its manufacturing industries, which have been falling for a number of years, are reversed.

WITH U.S. FORCES, in Central Tunisia, April 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- Short of manpower, Reichsfuehrer Hitler has been forced to augment his troops in North Africa by pressing into service soldiers of conquered nations, German convicts, political suspects and even native African Arabs who had originally been shipped to Germany as laborers, it was disclosed today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, April 13 -- Allied forces shot thirty-seven Japanese planes out of action during a 100-plane raid on the great Allied base at Port Moresby, New Guinea, before noon Monday and General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique today said that the "enemy's air offensive is believed to have been blunted and his immediate plans dislocated."

An eleven-point "check list" used by the Army Air Forces in determining the extent to which excessive profits on their war contracts are subject to renegotiation was announced last night by Lieut. Col. Charles H. Dyson, budget officer for the A.A.F., at a meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The text of Secretary of State Hull's statement to the House Ways and Means Committee today follows:

Reduced price-fixing operations for Southern mills and uncertainty over the policy to be invoked by the Office of Price Administration in the determination of ceilings on raw cotton were reflected in an erratic cotton futures market yesterday.
LONDON, April 12 -- Something unpleasant often happens to Americans abroad when they are exposed to Hollywood's more expansive efforts at box-office patriotism.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Three new attacks have been made by American airmen against two important Japanese air bases in the Solomon Islands area, the Navy Department announced today. Furthermore, Kiska, the principal enemy position in the Aluetians, was raided twice, thus bringing to nineteen the total of raids against this island during April.

Proper use of advertising as a channel of communication with the public will bring about a greater unity of purpose than can be achieved by a variety of speeches and exhortations by government officials, resulting in varied interpretations, Chester A. LaRoche, president of the Advertising Council, declared yesterday at a luncheon to the trade and consumer press, in which he reported on the council's progress.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Drawing a pessimistic picture of the fuel oil situation as it shapes up for next Winter, Secretary Ickes warned Eastern householders today to convert their heaters at once "or develop a cold blood stream by the time cold weather returns."
CHUNGKING, China, April 12 (U.P.) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek warned today that China was facing her most critical moment of the war.

The Hanes committee report that declining trends in New York City's manufacturing industries demand prompt, coordinated action by the community's ablest leaders and the local and State governments to protect the city's economic future was generally commended yesterday by business and civic representatives.

Bethlehem Steel Company became yesterday the first ship-building organization in this area to receive the Maritime Commission's M pennant and flag for two of its repair yards, when the awards were made to the Hoboken and Brooklyn-Fifty-sixth Street yards by Rear Admiral H. L. Vickery, vice chairman of the commission.

LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- Sir Kingsley Wood, in his budget statement today disclosed that the budget for the past fiscal year had been overspent by 351,000,000 and that Britain had borrowed 340,000,000 more than was anticipated originally.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 17 per cent for the week ended April 10 in comparison with the same week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Three grand prizes, as well as awards to six runners-up in the Jefferson bicentennial essay contest sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Board of Education and the Catholic school system of the city, will be announced tonight in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Non-rationed foods and labor-saving kitchen devices "for the maidless household" were featured in the Navy League Kitchen Cupboard Shop that opened yesterday at 746 Madison Avenue. Dehydrated tomato paste and tomato cocktails, bouillon paste, a brand of "real" pulverized coffee, a piquant sauce to replace chili sauce and mustard honey to be used in lieu of mustard were among the Cupboard's non-rationed highlights.

BOSTON, April 12 -- A quartet of iron-fisted amateur battlers, two of them service men, thrilled the National A.A.U. boxing tournament's opening night crowd with their punching prowess as they gained the 147-pound semi-finals tonight at the Boston Garden.

Reversing a Supreme Court ruling, in a decision made public yesterday, the Appellate Division held that directors and former directors of the Bush Terminal Company cannot recover from the company the expenses incurred in successfully defending a suit brought against them by the trustee of the company for alleged illegal dividend payments.

Because of the seriously unbalanced inventories existing in many sections of the wholesale grocery trade, current rationing regulations affecting replacement purchases will probably force some suppliers to discontinue sales of certain items for an indefinite period, it was reported in the trade yesterday.

LONDON, April 12 -- The reaction of the stock market here to the new budget will not be seen until tomorrow, as trading had ended for the day before the Chancellor's new taxes were made known. Tobacco and brewery shares were only a trifle easier pending the budget statement.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 12 -- Racing forty-eight miles in a day, the British Eighth Army today captured Sousse, the last Axis port below Tunis, and, with Anglo-American forces that took the holy city of Kairouan, drove the enemy tonight onto the old Carthaginian promontory for the final battle of Africa.

KAIROUAN, Tunisia, April 11 (Delayed) -- A British scout car, an armored car and two jeeps entered this holy city of Tunisia at 11 A.M. today. Less than an hour later they were covered with hundreds of wild flowers strewn by cheering civilians. As they arrived, a happy citizen hoisted the French tricolor once again on the roof of the town hall and remained there dancing with joy.

The Hanes committee, appointed by Governor Dewey to survey business and employment opportunities in New York City, has made a report that deserves the prompt and serious consideration of all who are interested in the welfare of the city. The committee has performed a community service by bringing to a focus not only the short-term but the long-term aspects of the city's problem.

Thomas H. Chilton, director of the technical division of the engineering department of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., has won the 1943 Egleston Medal of the Columbia University Engineering Schools Alumni Association for "distinguished engineering achievement," it was announced yesterday by R.A.W. Carleton, president of the association.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 12 -- A second history quiz among the 7,000 college freshmen recently tested on their knowledge of American history should be taken by THE NEW YORK TIMES, and the new examination should be based on interpretive, rather than factual, questions, 125 history teachers and students from the Bergen-Passaic Counties area urged today.
The shipbuilding industry was the principal customer of the steel industry in 1942 for the first time in the annals of steel production, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The Adams Express Company reports a net asset value of $32,787,362 on March 31, 1943, equivalent to 345 per cent of the principal amount of outstanding funded debt. The net resources, after providing for the debt, amount to $15.91 per share for 1,463,400 common shares, comparing with $11.69 a share on Dec. 31 and to $9.69 a share on March 31, 1942.

Retailers and other community business and professional interests should play a vital role in stimulating manufacturers to develop post-war plaguing to maintain employment for a national labor force of 55,000,000 and to secure maximum productivity, O. Scott Fletcher, field director of the Committee for Economic Development, yesterday told the convention of the Affiliated Drug Stores at the Hotel Biltmore.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 12 (U.P.) -- Captain Edward V. Rickenbacker appealed to his home State Legislature tonight to enact legislation "to eliminate the racketeers and all those who are prostituting the principles upon which fair labor practices and labor organizations should be based," and said that too much optimism if it did not actually lose the war would prolong it for an indefinite length of time.

BENDIX, N.J., April 12 -- Three hundred of the 6,000 workers of the Bendix Aviation Corporation's plant here quit work today and were joined soon afterward by a small group from the concern's plant in East Orange, N.J. They charged that grievances had been disregarded by the company and government agencies.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Sparkman bill to commission women physicians and surgeons in the Medical Corps of the Army and Navy, which was passed by unanimous consent vote in the House last week, was passed today by voice vote in the Senate and sent to the White House.

The President has allowed the Congressional repeal of his net salary limitation of $25,000 to become law without his signature. He explains that he was forced to do this because the repeal was attached as a rider to an act permitting the now unavoidable expansion of the public debt.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 -- With the assertion that the Axis nations do not have a single warplane left "without a master in the Allied group," aircraft manufacturers of the East and West assembling here today promised to send to battle areas this year a whole line of planes with every model "markedly improved."

The OPA is planning to issue specific dollars-and-cents ceilings for used mechanical washers, Thomas P. Kelly, chief of the agency's appliance unit, declared yesterday at a meeting of dealers in the Hotel McAlpin. Similar ceilings will be issued also for the 600,000 ice boxes which the War Production Board has authorized for production this year, he said.

LONDON, April 12 -- The Italian newspaper Tribuna Illustrata was quoted in a Berlin broadcast today as declaring that Reichsfuehrer Hitler and Premier Mussolini would decide "whether and when" New York was to be bombed.

" Desert Victory," feature-length British documentary film recording the Eighth Army's rout of the German Afrika Korps in the Libyan campaign, will go on view this morning at the Globe Theatre. The document, which depicts the victorious British troops in action from El Alamein to Tripoli, was filmed by camera men of the British Army and R.A.F. motion-picture units under the supervision of Lieut. Col. David MacDonald.

A resolution pledging the full support of the nation's 15,000 banks in the Second War Loan Drive was adopted yesterday by the administrative committee of the American Bankers Association, meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The resolution not only pledged the aid of the banks in selling government securities to the public, but assured the Treasury of the willingness of the banks to purchase the amounts of securities necessary to supplement sales to the public.

The Musicians Union, Local 802, headed by Jacob Rosenberg, made public yesterday a financial report for 1942, to be supplied to all of its 16,500 dues-paying members. The report shows net assets of $415,500, liabilities of $29,122 and surplus of $386,378.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The following questions and answers were prepared by Selective Service headquarters to explain revision of draft classifications:
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- The text of the War Manpower Commission's statement on new draft classifications follows:

Motorists convicted in the city's traffic courts on speeding charges will face the possible loss of their gasoline ration books as well as fines, it was disclosed yesterday in Queens Traffic Court, Kew Gardens, where more than 100 speeders were numbered among the 470 cases called before Magistrate Francis X. Giaccone.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Paul Hagen, author of "Will Germany Crack?" declared today that, while the collapse of Germany was not yet imminent, there was evidence that the "home front" was beginning to display signs of crisis resembling those that led to the debacle of the First World War.

WITH AMERICAN FORCES IN SOUTHERN TUNISIA, April 12 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr., in an order of the day, congratulated his troops of the Second Corps today on the successful conclusion of the hard twenty-two-day battle for El Guettar, asserting that "the splendid record of the American Army has attained added luster."

In accordance with a resolution adopted unanimously yesterday by the board of directors of the New York County Lawyers Association, Dean Embree, president of the association, appointed a committee to investigate reports that the American Bar Association does not admit Negro lawyers to membership.

The annual report of the Board of Higher Education, featuring the work in special courses set up to meet specific war needs, was presented to Mayor La Guardia yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the board.
FORT BENJAMIN HARRISON, Ind., April 12 (AP) -- The Indians' payroll was caught in the training season's neatest squeeze play because a flip of a coin sent Outfielder Oris Hockett heading for home.
LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
The text of the address by Secretary Morgenthau launching the Second War Loan drive, and delivered at a rally in Carnegie Hall last night, follows:

Confidence that the Senate would adopt the resolution advising participation of the United States in a United Nations organization to maintain peace after the war was expressed yesterday by Senator Carl A. Hatch of New Mexico, in an interview at the Waldorf-Astoria. Adoption of the resolution, he said, would enable President Roosevelt to move for such an organization.

Hospitals of New York already are threatened with exhaustion of their April allotment of ration points for meats, fats and cooking oils, it was learned yesterday. Smaller hotels, including the residential group, admit that they are in a similar plight.

Cooperation of the OPA, the WPB and the OCS in the allocation and equitable distribution of lining supplies to the coat trade is being sought by the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, it was learned here yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- The Chicago Sun announced tonight the resignation of Turner Catledge, its editor for the last year. Mr. Catledge joined the Sun staff as a roving correspondent when it was founded Dec. 4, 1941, by Marshall Field.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 13 (AP) -- German troops launched five heavy attacks yesterday at Soviet lines before Volkhovo, eighty miles southeast of Leningrad, and were beaten back after losing more than 2,000 men in a bitter flare-up of hand-to-hand fighting on this long-quiescent northern sector, Moscow reported early today.

After the war malaria in the Veterans Bureau Hospitals will be as much a national problem as it is in Latin America, Captain William S. Bainbridge, medical director of the United States Naval Reserve, declared yesterday at a one-day institute on "Middle America and the United States" held at the Waldorf Astoria to signalize Pan-American Week.
Dorothy Thompson, columnist, revealed yesterday that she would marry Maxim Kopf, Czech painter and refugee from Prague, now living at 310 East Forty-fourth Street.

VALLETTA, Malta, April 12 (Reuter) -- Malta's Governor and Commander in Chief, Field Marshal Viscount Gort, who has just paid a five-day visit to North Africa, visited General Sir Harold Alexander's headquarters on the Tunisian front and saw British and American forces making their victorious advance against Axis troops.

LONDON, April 12 -- The labor of hundreds of thousands of men, on the job for many months, has transformed the entire Atlantic Coast from North Cape to the Bay of Biscay into a defensive stronghold less vulnerable than the old West Wall inside Germany, Nazi sources declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The OPA today offered garment manufacturers, here to discuss Fall price lines, a proposal to permit them to add new lines in this classification for women's, children's and girls' Fall outerwear at any price point provided the levels do not exceed the manufacturers' highest base period price lines.

Aristocrat, letter-writer and no public speaker, a man of books and sciences, averse to public appearance, how did Jefferson come to be a great popular leader and hero? His success seems a little paradoxical, but the popular instinct was sound. We are apt to forget that the Declaration of Independence didn't sweep away social and political inequalities and injustices.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Roosevelt's visitors included Representatives Welch, Patman, Brehm and Baldwin, Clark Griffith, Dr. Herbert Evatt, Senator McKellar, Under Secretary Welles, Joseph E. Davies, Admiral King and Secretary Hull.

When General Rommel's "invincibles" were moving eastward through Libya eleven months ago their right wing struck a snag at a place called Bir Hacheim, in the desert southwest of Tobruk. A few days ago a monument was unveiled at this spot. It commemorated the steadfastness of some of General de Gaulle's Fighting French troops, who for more than two weeks resisted the Axis attacks.

ATLANTA, April 12 -- President M.L. Brittain of the Georgia School of Technology says that there was a surmise among some Navy men that Amelia Earhart Putnam, who disappeared on an equatorial flight around the world in 1937, fell into the hands of Japanese and was put to death.

How to make over a man's discarded shirt into a crisp bungalow apron is a new fashion tip to conservation-conscious housekeepers. Suggested as a feminine form of camouflage on the home front, patterns for three types of aprons are available.
TRENTON, N.J., April 12 -- Governor Charles Edison declared in an address here tonight that the liberal and progressive attitude of Thomas Jefferson was needed now.

NEW CITY, N.Y., April 12 -- Edward C. Dormann, former Sheriff of Rockland County, was sentenced to a term of 3 to 6 years in State Prison here today in Supreme Court on charges of conspiracy to operate a numbers racket in the county.
GAFSA, Tunisia, April 10 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A yellow-haired California farm boy entered Sfax all alone today ahead of the main body of the British Eighth Army.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 12 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Secretary Hull asked the House Ways and Means Committee today to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for another three years without change. It was the third time the Secretary of State had returned to Congress to ask renewal of the act approved in 1934.

A group of modern Greek songs, mostly folk songs, was the unusual feature of the official New York debut of Nota Camberos, comely young Greek soprano, at the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night. The program opened with two Italian groups, the first consisting of songs by Durante, Caccini and Pergolesi, the second made up of operatic arie.

With the financial machinery of the nation mobilized in support of the Second War Loan drive, interest slackened yesterday in the securities markets. Although the stock market had a burst of strength in the morning, most gains were eliminated as selling predominated in the late trading.
