The newest product to come to the attention of this department is a meal that arrives from a hamlet in Southern Vermont. It is a blend of three whole grains -- corn, wheat and rye -- that are ground together at a stone mill that is said to date from 1791.
Members of the Long Island Surf Fishing Club believe that the surf anglers are at a distinct disadvantage when competing with the boat fishermen in any national fishing contest.

Today's events: Marian Murray, soprano, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Serenade, Museum of Modern Art, 9; Ellen Osborn, soprano, Town Hall, 8:30; Brooklyn Symphony Orchestra, Sir Thomas Beecham conducting, Brooklyn Academy, 8:30.

The Board of Missions of the Methodist Church, New York City, has granted permission to the North American Newspaper Alliance to distribute the following documents: "I Bear My Witness," by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, and "I Confess My Faith," by Madame Chiang Kai-shek -- the testimony of two of the world's outstanding Christians and Methodists.

One of the most patriotic services which women can render in the present crisis is that of giving aid in the care of children of mothers who work in the war plants. It does not offer opportunity necessarily to wear a uniform, but for the woman who does not put such things first and who genuinely wants to serve her country this offers a most practical and constructive field.

Premier Hideki Tojo told the opening session of a Japanese Governors' Conference at Tokyo yesterday that "the current situation is steadily increasing in gravity" and that every effort must be made to increase production, to reduce civilian consumption further and to eliminate "unsettled feeling" among the people.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- Robert De Forest Boomer of 52 Wall Street, New York, a partner in the firm of Auchincloss, Parker Redpath, was suspended by the Securities and Exchange Commission today from four national securities exchanges for six months for deceiving "the legation of a certain friendly foreign government."

NEWARK, N.J., April 12 -- The Office of Price Administration here charged today that sixteen restaurant owners in North Jersey had failed to report all their inventories in registering for processed food rationing.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12 -- In a brief filed with the United States Supreme Court in Washington today the Securities and Exchange Commission defended its right to compel the $2,300,000,000 North American Company to strip itself of all its holdings except a comparative handful of properties in and about St. Louis.

A "protest meeting" called by the public affairs council of the American Labor party at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night urged the Board of Education to reconsider its rejection of Mark Starr, education director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, for the post of director of adult education in the public school system.

The annual rush to pay State income taxes began in earnest yesterday, as increasing numbers visited the State Building, 80 Centre Street, and branch offices to file returns in advance of the deadline at midnight next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- General Order 50, under which the government will stabilize prices for food and beverages served by restaurants, cafeterias, hotels and other eating places away from home, was made public today by Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator.

MOSCOW, April 12 (AP) -- Valentina Grizodubova, chairman of the International Women's Anti-Fascist Committee, told a big Moscow meeting today that women of the United States and Great Britain had aided the Red Army.

The bureaucracy in Washington was assailed last night by Alf M. Landon, former Governor of Kansas and 1936 Republican nominee for President, as having failed to foresee the need for production of food and oil.

Announcing that the United Nations are now "piling up the thunderclouds of the greatest attack in history," Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. appealed last night to the American people to provide the funds to pay for this offensive and for others to follow.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 12 -- A wave of contract cancellations at the conclusion of the war that "will shake the foundations of the free enterprise system" was predicted today by Dundas Peacock controller of the Elliott Company, in an address at a war conference of the Controllers Institute of America in which he urged immediate steps be taken to ease the impact of such a consequence.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 12 -- Complete details were given in Vichy today of the "happy results of Chief of Government Pierre Laval's policy" whereby 250,000 prisoners of war in Germany will become "free laborers" because an equal number of conscript workers had been deported from France in the first three months of the year.

In his statement on April 4 Mayor La Guardia brought the crucial problem of the need for adequate medical care into the spotlight once more. He is, of course, completely right that under present conditions any serious sickness or a major operation sets the average family budget back not only for months, but sometimes for years, and that it is not unusual for a moderate-income family to sink into debt in times of illness.

The fund left to the Seeing Eye, Inc., in the will of Mrs. Isabel D. McHie, who once subscribed to the motto, "The more I see of men, the more I like dogs," was valued yesterday at $126,626 in the tax appraisal of her estate.

Though he was born in Canada and is a citizen of this country, Carlo Corelli follows the style of the traditional operatic tenor of Italy. At his first New York recital at the Town Hall last night, he practiced many of the tricks of the trade -- most of them obvious.

A FAR WESTERN BASE, in the Andreanof Island, April 3 (Delayed) -- Despite repeated bombing, the Japanese are pushing to completion a long fighter field on Kiska and a long bomber field on Attu, the Eleventh Bomber Command headquarters disclosed today.

New York City's 155,465 childless married men will be the largest group of draft registrants here to be in immediate danger of losing their deferred status as a result of the revised regulations that became effective yesterday, it was announced by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, local Director of Selective Service.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (U.P.) -- The Air Medal for meritorious action while participating in aerial flights in the India, Burma, Middle Eastern and Far Eastern theatres of war has been awarded to ninety-four officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Air Forces, the War Department announced today.
Luigi Lucioni's first New York one-man show in four years opened with a preview yesterday afternoon at the Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue. It will continue through the month.
The Italian Monday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

Mrs. Nancy Souder, 29 years old, daughter of the late Melvin A. Traylor, who was president of the First National Bank of Chicago was killed last night by a plunge from a tenth-floor window of the Hotel Plaza, where she had been staying with her husband, J. Robert Souder, Kansas City oil man.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Large and small concerns, numbering about 7,000, whose production for the war effort is the manufacture of such non-dramatic items as hand tools, agricultural implements, trucks and miscellaneous articles and metals supplied to foreign nations under the lend-lease program, will become eligible for the Army-Navy Production Award under a plan announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission, by a vote of six to five, has revoked until Jan. 1, the general freight rate increases which it granted a year ago.

Albert Stern, a 77-year-old ironworker who walked nine miles to court "for the exercise," obtained a $2,500 settlement of a damage action before Supreme Court Justice Frank E. Johnson in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES IN CENTRAL TUNISIA, April 10 (Delayed) (AP) -- American dead who gave their lives in a vain attempt to stop the German tide that swept through Faid Pass on Feb. 14 were avenged today by their buddies who crashed their way back through that same mountain pass, heedless of exploding mine fields.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, April 13 (AP) -- The noon communique:
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, added his voice today to the swelling chorus of appeals for the purchase of war bonds.

Twenty-four contract bridge teams began play last night at the Hotel Pierre for the national open team-of-four championship and the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup. All the entrants were to play through qualifying rounds last night and tonight, after which the field will be cut to sixteen teams.

FRENCH LICK, Ind., April 13 -- Every morning Jimmy Dykes would stretch out comfortably in the softest chair in the lobby, casually open his morning paper and light his cigar. That operation completed without misadventure, James would bark cheerfully at his hired hands: "Hit the trail, boys." And off the White Sox would go on a five-mile hike while Manager Dykes took his personal Spring training by remote control.

The novelty of last night's program by the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House was the first presentation this season of Antony Tudor's "Dark Elegies," set to the "Kindertotenlieder" of Gustav Mahler.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Roosevelt, dedicating the majestic Thomas Jefferson Memorial as a "shrine to freedom," told the nation today that the agonies of war serve to heighten man's appreciation of freedom, and expressed his confidence that the "seeming eclipse" of freedom in wartime "can well become the dawn of more liberty."

CONSTANTINE, "the Grik," had a motto he had figured out for himself: "Tin the guy." In those three words he summed up perfectly the only lesson he had learned from life, the predatory jungle code by which he lived. His friend Milo, a Blue Nose sailor pursued by the furies far from his native Nova Scotia, believed in and practiced the same brutal egoisn.
Spokesmen for Macy's, Gimbel Brothers, Saks-Thirty-fourth Street and Saks Fifth venue yesterday issued the following statement:

Governor Dewey and Mayor La Guardia will serve as honorary chairmen of the sixth annual Greater New York Fund campaign, beginning on May 3, for the benefit of 406 voluntary welfare and health agencies and hospitals, it was announced yesterday by W. Randolph Burgess, general chairman.

Worcester, Mass., awarded yesterday to the Worcester County Trust Company a new issue of $800,000 of revenue notes. The bank bid an 0.37 per cent basis for the notes, which are dated April 15 and are payable on Oct. 15 and Nov. 11.

In his widely acclaimed book "One World," Wendell Willkie declares that this war in which Americans are fighting and dying is a "war of liberation." It is, to him, a war of liberation which "includes giving to all peoples reedom to govern themselves as soon as they are able, and the economic freedom on which all lasting self-government inevitably rests."

Justice Jane M. Bolin of the Domestic Relations Court was elected last night to membership in the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. She is the first Negro woman to become a member, although a number of Negro men are members.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The rest of the world is watching Congressional action on the expiring reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for proof whether the United States really intends to cooperate internationally, the House Ways and Means Committee was told today by the Secretaries of Commerce and Agriculture, and the Coordinator for Inter-American Affairs.
The Russian Tuesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -Chairman Donald M. Nelson disclosed tonight that the War Production Board had abandoned, for the present at least, all studies looking toward the concentration of industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -"God Is My Co-Pilot," a story by Colonel Robert Lee Scott, a member of Major Gen. Claire Chennault's China Air Task Force, has been bought by Warners and will be produced under that title by Hal Wallis.

More than 800 persons attended a luncheon and fashion revue entitled "The Easter Parade," given yesterday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop and its sixteen affiliated welfare units that receive the proceeds of all sales at the shop.

The vast and momentous campaign of the British Eighth Army in Africa, which began when the men of that outfit turned in fury on the German Africa Corps near El Alamein last October and chased it 1,300 miles into Tripoli, is recounted in a brilliant factual film entitled "Desert Victory," which opened for public showings at the Globe Theatre yesterday.

In a ceremony unparalleled in circus annals, Carl L. Norden, Inc., gots its third Army-Navy E production award in Madison Square Garden at last night's performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey show. The audience of 15,000 persons was made up of Norden workers and their families.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -Fixing maximum prices for fresh tuna, the OPA today took the first step in carrying out President Roosevelt's order of last week to bring all cost-of-living foods under price control.
Your issue of April 5 contained a letter from Charles Davila, dealing with the Pan-European Conference recently called in New York at the invitation of New York University.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Stocks of petroleum held by British commercial oil companies in many parts of the world have been made available for fueling United States naval vessels, the Navy Department announced today. The arrangement was carried out by the British Admiralty under an extension of reciprocal lend-lease aid.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 13 (AP) -- Rated nicely through the mile and seventy yards by Jockey Whitins, Mrs. Wallace Renard's Merry Glow won the Worcester Purse at Narragansett Park today to become the first double winner at the three-day-old meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)--President Roosevelt signed into law today legislation suspending until six months after the war the requirement of banks to pay deposit insurance assessments on balances resulting from subscriptions for war bonds.

Although Manolo Espejo, undersized 30-year-old Filipino, was acquitted by a General Sessions jury late yesterday afternoon at his trial for bigamy, perjury and unlawfully procuring a marriage license to wed a 14-year-old girl, now a mother, Judge John J. Freschi warned him, because his first wife is alive, not to resume his marital relations with the girl wife unless he obtains a divorce in his first marital venture.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The American Farm Bureau Federation, strongest of the "Big Four," was credited with two more victories at the Capitol today.
The three essays that won the grand prize awards in the Thomas Jefferson Bi-Centennial Essay Contest sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES appear below. Each was entitled "What We Owe to Thomas Jefferson."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 13 -- A political crisis that for two months has threatened to disrupt President Ramon S. Castillo's National Democratic party came to climax today when Governor Rodolfo Moreno of the Province of Buenos Aires resigned.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Dr. Florence Seibert, associate professor of the Phipps Institute and noted bio-chemist, received today the first $2,500 achievement award of the American Association of University Women.

Not every college girl can find employment in war industries during the short Summer vacation, but all can help to release others for essential work, Mrs. Dean S. Schloss, head of the undergraduate placement service at Hunter College, declared yesterday, explaining that Hunter girls are caring for children of working mothers.

The time may not be long before an army frees Italy, Attorney General Francis Biddle told a cheering audience of 3,000 Americans of Italian origin at a Jefferson celebration in Carnegie Hall last night.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 12 (Delayed) (AP) -- Well-informed business circles predicted today that Turkey and Germany would sign a new barter agreement this week involving the equivalent of approximately $25,000,000, but said that Turkish chrome -- which the Nazis are most anxious to obtain -- would not be among the commodities to be exchanged.

Formulation of a concept of minimum production "to hold the line" of an essential civilian economy is crucial, Robert R. Nathan, chairman of the War Production Board planning committee, said here yesterday. While the civilian economy so far is just beginning to feel the impact of the gigantic war production program, he declared, the time is coming when "a tractor may be more necessary than a tank."

Shoe manufacturers exhibiting at the Fall Volume Shoe Show at the Hotel New Yorker reported yesterday that the second day's sales had wiped out the bulk of the footwear being offered. Many producers withdrew their lines and stated that they were sold up.

Winners in the city-wide finals of the Thomas Jefferson Bicentennial Essay Contest for New York City senior and junior high schools and elementary schools, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were announced and prizes were awarded last night at a meeting in The New York Times Hall at 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The holders of Class A stock of R. Hoe Co., Inc., at their annual meeting here yesterday approved creation of a new issue of $1,250,000 of first mortgage 5 per cent bonds to mature in April, 1955. The bonds will be bought by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

NEWARK, N.J., April 13 -Bench warrant were ordered issued here today by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney for fourteen defendants who failed to appear for arraignment on an indictment charging them with having participated in a black-market meat conspiracy of national scope.
LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Oliver Clandorf continued his testimony yesterday in Special Sessions Court where he is on trial with his son, Frank, on charges of using their Hotel Hermitage, Seventh Avenue near Forty-second Street, for purposes of prostitution. The son, however, declined to testify and the trial was adjourned to April 20.

SFAX, Tunisia, April 11 (Delayed) -- (General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, British Eighth Army commander, was received with cold stares and silence when he rode into this city, ruined by Allied planes on his orders, but an hour later the once resentful French and Arabs were cheering him wildly.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP) -F.J. Fell Jr., vice president and controller of the Pennsylvania Railroad, told stockholders at their annual meeting today that the action of the Interstate Commerce Commission in suspending an increase in freight rates will cost the railroad approximately $30,000,000 a year in operating revenues.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 14 (AP) -- The noon communique:
The Tuesday German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Contributions to the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City have now reached a total of $12,247,000, which is only $673,700 short of the campaign goal of $12,920,700, it was announced yesterday by John P, Stevens Jr. vice chairman of the fund.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 13 -- The devastating reception that the new Japanese air offensive has received from American fighters in New Guinea and the Solomons is of far-reaching significance and may affect the course of the Pacific war for months to come.

"Tomorrow the World," a play by James Gow and Arnaud d'Usseau, will open this evening at the Ethel Barrymore under the aegis of Theron Bamberger. Ralph Bellamy and Shirley Booth are featured. Others in the cast include Dorothy Sands, Edit Angold, Richard Taber, 12-year-old Skippy Homeier, Paul Porter Jr., Richard Tyler, Waiter Kelly and Joyce Van Patten, who will alternate with Nancy Nugent.

The government proposed yesterday to the United Mine Workers and soft coal operators of the Appalachian region that a six-day week for fifty-two weeks in the year be guaranteed in lieu of the $2 increase demanded by the miners in their basic wage.

Alf M. Landon, Republican candidate for President in 1936 and former Governor of Kansas, denounced yesterday President Roosevelt's failure to provide for bi-partisan Congressional representation on the American delegations that will discuss food and refugee problems with representatives of Allied nations at separate conferences in Hot Springs, Va., and Bermuda.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In both military and political circles here it is expected that the approaching completion of the Tunisian campaign will close one chapter in the war and clarify the positions of Spain and the French forces outside France.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Roosevelt declares in a PanAmerican Day message to be read before the Governing Board of the Pan American Union tomorrow that each of the American republics, in carrying out measures of continental defense and mobilization against aggression, "will assure its place in the world-wide concert of free nations which will constitute the international society of the future."

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -- "It is not a sin (in the eyes of the Catholic Church) for young Frenchmen to strive to avoid compulsory labor service in Germany, neither is it within my province to advise them to go," said Achille Cardinal Lienart, Bishop of Lille, on March 21 in addressing several thousand boys and girls of his diocese.

The Yankees, Dodgers and Giants will go all out for civilian defense today at the Stadium. For this is the afternoon that will find all three local clubs in action in an elimination double-header, from which the proceeds will go to the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. The first game will start at 1 P.M.
The Tuesday Italian communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said at a press conference today that recent Japanese raids on Port Moresby, New Guinea, were indications that the enemy was "stepping up his air activity."

The British Eighth Army has come out of the wilderness into the land of Canaan. It has come with tanks, some of them made in America, protected by planes, many of them made in America, but it has come with men produced in Britain, in Australia, in New Zealand, in Ireland and in India.

Edgar Auchincloss, 32 years old, an importer and a great grandson of Daniel Sloan, for many years president of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions to the indictment accusing him of criminal negligence on the night of Aug. 20, 1941, when the car he was driving crashed into another and then into a taxicab at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, Wednesday, April 14 (AP) -- The United States Army Officers' Candidate School will graduate its largest class today, with seventy-one enlisted men from twenty-three States becoming second lieutenants. The first class graduated forty-six and the second commissioned fifty-seven.

The new British budget will inevitably be compared in many ways with our own. But the most striking comparison of all should not be overlooked. This is the simple fact that Britain does have a budget, and that we do not. We have only something that we have conspired to call a budget.

The pennant races may wander into a lot of confusion this season, but an overwhelming percentage of baseball writers believes the world champion Cardinals will come to roost on top of the National League again.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- In their unceasing drive against Japanese bases in the Pacific, American airmen bombed five enemy positions in the Solomons and !again made four attacks on Kiska in the Aleutians during the Sunday-Monday period, the Navy Department reported today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 14 -- General Douglas MacArthur, whose planes have blunted two big recent Japanese aerial thrusts in New Guinea, warned today that powerful Japanese naval forces were within "striking distance of Australia," which, he said, can be held off only if the Allies keep command of the skies.

Registration of out-of-town buyers in the market last week numbered 986 as against 954 in the preceding week and 1,045 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to THE NEW YORK TIMES listings. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 401, which compared with 420 recorded last Tuesday.

It is encouraging to see from your Washington report published in your issue of April 12 that the "government planners are freely admitting that the toughest of post-war problems is implied by the statement in the Atlantic Charter guaranteeing to all nations ready access to raw materials."

Along with news of successful Allied air action in New Guinea General MacArthur warns us that Japan controls the outer sea approaches to Australia and "if we lose the air, naval forces cannot save us." For whatever purposes of strategy, Japan is making a spectacular effort to gain control of the air in the Southwest Pacific.

BOSTON, April 13 (U.P.) -- Tony Peppi of Boston, lone New England entry to reach the finals of the fifty-fifth annual national A.A.U. boxing championships, was the first champion crowned tonight as the two-day tourney drew to a close at the Boston Garden before some 7,500 fans.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The four interior panels of the Jefferson Memorial are inscribed with inspirational quotations from the Declaration of Independence and other writings of Thomas Jefferson. The four inscriptions are:

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 (U.P.) -- American fliers yesterday destroyed a Japanese settlement in Northwestern Burma and British airmen continued their assaults on enemy positions around Akyab, it was announced today. All Allied planes returned safely.
LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- The noon Russian communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The Women's City Club of New York disclosed yesterday that it was seeking a conference with Acting Presiding Justice W. Bruce Cobb of the Domestic Relations Court to urge immediate establishment of a special children's shelter for those facing trial in the court.

The Aluminum Company of Canada, Ltd., subsidiary of Aluminium, Ltd., reported yesterday in the 1942 annual statement, net profit of $13,924,433, equal to $9.28 a share on the capital stock, against $13,992,362, or $9.32 a share on the same basis, the year before.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 13 -- Dr. Charles L. Weitz of 74 Foster Avenue, a medical practitioner here since 1919 and a lieutenant in the Army Medical Corps in the first World War, died today at the Mount Vernon Hospital of the effects of drinking nitric acid at his home last night, according to Dr. Amos O. Squire, county medical examiner.
LONDON, April 13 -- The United Nations are "more than holding their own" in the Atlantic battle against U-boats, Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today.

TRENTON, N.J., April 13 (AP) -Rationing of automobiles during the first war year forced 415 auto dealers in New Jersey to have their operating licenses canceled in 1942, Motor Vehicle Commissioner Arthur W. Magee reported today.

Astronomical sales continue on Wendell L. Willkie's book "One World," published last week by Simon Schuster. Yesterday orders totaled 48,000 and the number of total copies now ordered or printed is quoted as 370,000.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The War Labor Board today unanimously adhered to the literal meaning of President Roosevelt's wage stabilization order of April 8 by trimming down a referee's award to the confines of the "Little Steel" formula.

LONDON, April 13 -- Lord Woolton, Minister of Food, indicated today that the ordinary consumer need not expect too much meat or milk in the months ahead but emphasized his determination to see that British children would not suffer through any shortage that might arise.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- A revised report on the food situation will be issued by the Office of War Information within a few days, Gardner Cowles, domestic director of OWI, said today. It will replace the earlier report, which was one cause of the differences leading to the resignation of Henry Pringle, head of the writers' division in the Public Relations Bureau of the organization, and most of his staff of writers and research workers.

Fifteen of New York City's biggest department stores and the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York were fined a total of $80,000 in Federal court yesterday on charges that they conspired to boycott THE NEW YORK TIMES because the newspaper gave notice of increased advertising rates effective in May.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 13 -- Princeton's baseball team had too much power for Rutgers today, defeating the Scarlet, 14 to 5. Coach Chuck Ward used three pitchers in a vain attempt to stem the Tigers' batters, but none of them was equal to the task.

ALBANY, April 13 -- Governor Dewey today signed the Desmond bill which permits persons intending to be married within the State to obtain the license from any town or city clerk, instead of from the clerk in the community where the woman resides.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- An independent claimant agency to assess the needs of civilians and see that goods are properly distributed to them is essential to the winning of the war, Joseph L. Weiner, Director of the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Supply, told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today at a hearing on the Maloney bill to establish a Civilian Supply Administration.

State income tax offices in New York City continued busy yesterday, but not busy enough to satisfy tax officials, who warned that a huge "last-minute" rush was piling up for today and tomorrow. The deadline for filing returns is midnight tomorrow.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 13 -- News of night bombing operations by New Zealanders in the Solomons, contained in a South Pacific communique, was called an indication of the growing strength of the New Zealand Air Force in that region in an Air Department statement today.

No further applications may be filed for individual licenses to export commodities to British Empire countries, excepting Newfoundland, Labrador and the Middle East, the Board of Economic Warfare announced yesterday in issuing the first details on its new program licensing system.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -Navy communique 342:

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 13 (AP) -- A petition for removal of J.S. Rex Cole of Los Angeles as guardian ad litem of 14-year-old Peter Bennett Plant, was filed with Superior Court Judge William J. Shea today at a hearing to determine whether the youth is the son of the late Philip M. Plant of Waterford.

A three-month-old boy was snatched from his carriage yesterday in front of his home at 331 East Thirty-first Street and was found two hours later, apparently none the worse for his experience, in a hallway at 720 Tenth Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Selective Service Director, authorized today establishment of a conscientious objectors' camp at Chungking, capital of Nationalist China. It will be the first conscientious objectors' camp outside the jurisdiction of the United States.

Count Fleet did the expected at Jamaica yesterday before 16,193 persons, when he made light of his opposition and easily captured the St. James Purse in what may be regarded as his public trial for the $25,000 added Wood Memorial on Saturday.

Prompted by the government's desire to popularize plentiful non-rationed foods and remove some of the pressure from foods in short supply, Quaker Oats will begin next month a special "family of products" advertising campaign embracing ten of the leading products in its line of non-rationed items.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 13 -- The Allied aerial bombardments of the Reich are threatening to cause serious disorganization of the German home front because of the administrative problems they create, according to a person who was in Berlin during the three heavy Royal Air Force raids on the Reich capital the nights of March 1, 27 and 29.

All-American cottons were highlighted yesterday in Zachary Bogert's Cotton Shop fashion show during luncheon in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. Printed piques, checked ginghams, sentimental colored chambrays and sleek pure silk shantungs in twinkling shades made the Summer ahead look cool, calm and collected.

Today's events: Della Calapai, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P.M.; Jan Peerce, tenor, Town Hall, 8:30; Anna Daube, soprano, New York Times Hall, 8:30; Robert Goldsand, pianist, sixth recital in his Beethoven sonata series, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 14 (AP) -- The Allies wrested the aerial initiative from the Japanese yesterday, hitting two large enemy ships in the North New Guinea coastal harbor of Hansa Bay.

Mayor La Guardia, continuing his attack on department stores, accused several yesterday of trying to bring back starvation wages and sweatshops. He spoke before a crowd of 10,000 at Seventh Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street at noon at the start of a $10,000,000 war bond drirve by the war employment board of the fur industry.

Magistrate J. Roland Sala, in Brooklyn Felony Court, assailed yesterday the use of the term "mugging," which he said was a misnomer for old-fashioned robbery and assault, and he said he would "enjoin any newspaper or news agency from identifying a defendant according to race, creed or color, unless the identification is an essential part of the story or of the crime charged."

On Monday the Victory Corps of Stuyvesant High School, First Avenue and Fifteenth Street, started another of its many campaigns, this time to sell $125,000 in war bonds among students and teachers for a dive bomber to be known as The Spirit of Stuyvesant.

CHUNGKING, China, April 13 (U.P.) -- Japanese forces have infiltrated during the past two days into Chinese positions around the enemy-held stronghold of Hwajung in the northern Hunan Province, breaking a two-week lull in the battle for the control of the fertile territory between Lake Tungting and the Yangtze River, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.
The regular ticket for offices of president, vice presidents and councilors were announced yesterday by Actors Equity Association. The election will take place on May 28 at the Hotel Astor.

A group of apparel suppliers in the New York market who were creditors of the late S. Klein, Union Square department store operator, at the time of his death on Nov. 15 last agreed yesterday to await the decision of executors of the estate before attempting to organize a protective committee that would seek to cooperate in facilitating payment of old obligations.

Garment trade unions have shown a willingness to make adjustments in their wage scales to obtain war contracts for New York City manufacturers, George A. Sloan, city Commissioner of Commerce, said yesterday in commenting on the statement in the Hanes committee report that high wage levels in the city was one of the factors most frequently cited by business men as adversely affecting business and employment.
Ralph William Close, Minister from the Union of South Africa, and Mrs. Close are expected to arrive today at the Plaza.

Detective Cesare Bonnano told Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein and a blue-ribbon jury in Brooklyn yesterday that Charles J. Farley, 26-year-old nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, admitted to him that he had shot and killed Patrolman Nicholas C. Moreno after holding up a Greenpoint gasoline station.

Sixteen teams won their way to the knockout matches last night in the contract bridge tournament for the national team-of-four championship and the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup, under way at the Hotel Pierre. The surviving teams included all the pre-tournament favorites, among them the four teams seeded by the Vanderbilt Cup committee.

Railway securities dropped sharply yesterday on the decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission suspending the increase in freight rates, granted in March, last year, from May 15 to the close of this year. With most of the carriers now in the excess-profits tax brackets, 90 cents out of every dollar, minus a 10 per cent postwar credit, must be paid to the government in taxes.

One hundred fifteen New York City hospitals and other charitable institutions learned yesterday that the Office of Price Administration arrangements here to relieve their distressing shortage of food under point rationing allocations had been complicated by a new order requiring strict adherence to the rules governing supplemental allowances.

Headed by the largest single bond purchase ever made anywhere -- an order from the Prudential Insurance Company of America for $400,000,000 of war bonds -- the Second War Loan drive gained momentum in this area yesterday. At 11 A.M. the Treasury's War Finance Committee announced that a total of $1,365,000,000 had been subscribed in the Second Federal Reserve District from sources other than commercial banks.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -Four desperadoes chose the thirteenth of the month for a spectacular break from Alcatraz Island Prison and none of them made it.
WASHINGTON April 13 (U.P.) -The War Department made public today the name's of 234 United States soldiers held prisoner of war by the Japanese.

LONDON, April 13 -- In another age what happened today in the House of Commons might have led to a clash of swords. In any other country it almost certainly would have meant an exchange of blows. Here it led to a verbal bout in which the challenger, on the figurative ropes, was saved by the Speaker just as many another challenger has been saved by the bell.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (U.P.) -The War Department announced today the award of 122 decorations -- including the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal and the Oak Leaf Cluster to the Air Medal -- to officers and noncommissioned officers of the Air Forces for anti-submarine patrol flights over the Atlantic.

Ellen Osborn, soprano, gave her debut recital last night at Town Hall, singing German, French, English and American selections. The first two groups on the program were German numbers by Bach, Mozart, Hugo Wolf and Schumann.

WITH THE U.S. AIR FORCE, in China, April 13 -- Major Gen. Claire L. Chennault, Commander of the Fourteenth United States Air Force, opened the air base softball season today by pitching his Headquarters team to a 17-13 victory over the Boaber Squadron nine.

Bolstered by developments in Washington on farm price issues, the cotton futures market advanced belatedly yesterday to gains of as much as 22 points, or $1.10 a bale, from trade, local and New Orleans buying. At the close on the New York Cotton Exchange the list of active contracts showed net gains of 16 to 19 points, equal to 80 to 95 cents a bale, ending a four-day losing spell.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The President dedicated the Jefferson Memorial and canceled his regular press conference.
LONDON, April 13 -- The French National Committee met today and began discussions on the report that General Georges Catroux had laid before it Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -Joseph B. Eastman, transportation director, today predicted a steadily increasing volume of petroleum for for the Eastern States, but he cautioned that military demands made it unlikely that easing of restrictions on civilian consumers could be expected.

MONTREAL, April 13 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian shipments of newsprint in March amounted to 248,469 tons and were 59,697 tons, or 19.4 per cent, lower than in the corresponding month in 1942, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today in a monthly statement.

The New York Drama Critics Circle celebrated Jefferson Day yesterday by voting its award for the best play of the season to Sidney Kingsley's "The Patriots," a drama in which Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton are the two leading characters.

The conversion of packaging from critical to non-critical materials and the elimination of frills have saved millions of pounds of vital materials needed for the war effort, Walton D. Lynch, vice president of the National Folding Box Company, declared yesterday at the opening session of the wartime packaging conference and exposition sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel Astor.

The Interstate Commerce Commission's suspension of increases in the railroad's freight rates brought yesterday fresh and sharp retreats in prices on the Stock Exchange, with the rail stocks and bonds the heaviest losers. Buying support reappeared, however, in the final hour and declines of 1 to 3 points in the carrier shares and as much as 5 points in the bonds were shaded considerably at the close of trading.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 13 -- It is now possible to say that the British First Army elements operating in the extreme north have regained all the ground lost when the enemy launched his offensive on March 27 except a strip of the Beja-Mateur Road between Hunt's Gap and Sidi Nsir.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Seven Wave doctors, about to complete an eight weeks' intensive indoctrination course at the National Naval Medical Center here, were watching the White House today, hoping for the President's signature of the bill to commission women doctors in the Army and Navy in any theatre of war.

The American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, has resigned from the Canadian Trades and Labor Congress because delegates to a recent congress convention in Winnipeg, including two members of the musicians' union, voted to let a children's orchestra entertain them, it became known yesterday.

Two New York City doctors, reported missing since the fall of Corregidor, are prisoners of the Japanese, relatives disclosed yesterday. They are Captain Harold W. Keschner of 451 West End Avenue and Captain Samuel Bloom of 505 Elmwood Avenue, Brooklyn.

LONDON, April 13 -- The government's budget proposals were received favorably by today's stock markets, where rises in the prices of beer and tobacco shares showed that no qualms were felt about any possible falling off in the present record of consumption.

UTICA, N.Y., April 13 -- Almost half of the 1,915 daily newspapers in the United Sates, or 899, are charging five cents a copy, it was made known today at the opening of a two-day meeting here of the New York State Circulation Managers Association. The statement was made in a report submitted by Elmer Laycock of the Schenectady Gazette.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Arabs of North Africa are making "lend-lease soup" taste like their favorite "Kuskus," or "couscous," simply by adding a small amount of available native foods to the dehydrated basic soup stock shipped by the United States.

Having meat and fats and cheese all relegated to the same set of red stamps makes rationing a difficult problem for customer and dealer alike. At least, that is the impression gained by this department from a recent survey of private households, local chain stores and independent butcher shops.

Ten awards of $1,000 each have been made by the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters to creative workers in the fields of music, painting, sculpture and literature to enable them to continue their work.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 13 -- A suit to foreclose the $54,900 mortgage bonds on the property of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, which was incorporated in 1886 and has been one of the most fashionable yachting centers on Long Island Sound, was filed this afternoon in Supreme Court here.

NEW DELHI, India, April 13 -Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles's letter to Professor Ralph Barton Perry of Harvard University, in which he took up the Indian problem, was seized upon by the press here today as an outstanding pronouncement of American policy.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (U.P.) -The War Department made public today the names of 193 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

Don Short won his second start with a two-hit performance as St. John's Prep, defending champion, blanked St. Francis Prep, 11 to 0, in a Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. game at Red Hook Stadium yesterday. Short has permitted only six safeties in his two triumphs.
UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK, ss:

Another diphtheria death occurred in New York City last week, making a total of ten so far this year. Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. Since there were only seven diphtheria deaths in all of 1942, the current increase indicates the need for immunization without delay of every child over 9 months old, Dr. Stebbins declared.
A reader in Malverne, N.Y., writes under date of April 8:

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Representative Martin of Massachusetts, House Republican leader, called today for Congressional representation by members of both parties at the coming United Nations food conference at Hot Springs, Va., "the conference in Bermuda and every conference held for the purpose of reaching important agreements upon our economic life."

LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- Princess Elizabeth, heir presumptive to the British throne, spent today with a tank battalion of her own regiment, the Grenadier Guards, in her first public engagement entirely on her own.
Excerpts from the address of Dr. George D. Stoddard, State Commissioner of Education, at the Thomas Jefferson Bi-Centennial celebration in the New York Times Hall last night, follow:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 13 (AP) -A communique:

ALBANY, April 13 -- An effort to revive, by statute, a group of New York City tax certiorari proceedings outlawed in 1942 through a decision of the Court of Appeals was blocked today when Governor Dewey vetoed the Bewley bill.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 13 -- The British First Army, thrusting twenty miles above Kairouan, swung into a siege line with the Eighth Army driving up the coast today, thus pinning the Axis in its Tunisian corner, while Allied fliers plastered the last enemy airfields as well as communications and bases.

LONDON, April 13 -- First Lieutenant Robert B. Wallace, second son of the Vice President, has just completed a series of six surveys of the tastes of American soldiers in this war theatre, it was learned today. His findings constitute a veritable Gallup survey of 2,353 G. E's throughout Great Britain by which military and possibly civilian agencies will be guided in future education, recreation and other special service programs.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address at the dedication of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial:

CAMP UPTON, L.I., April 13 -The Giants and Dodgers carried their ancient rivalry deep into the other end of Long Island today, but so far as the Polo Grounders were concerned, it was carrying the thing a little too far.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The belief that a final clean-up of Axis forces in Africa was almost in sight was indicated today and the capital began to talk anew of greater battles to come -- on the Continent of Europe.

DETROIT, April 13 -- Experiments showing that vitamin A saves the lives of animals infected with whooping cough, one of the most serious diseases of children, and the further discovery that a protein constituent enables the body to store a supply of this essential vitamin for emergency uses, were reported today before the meeting of the American Chemical Society.

Although many metropolitan anglers will take part in New Jersey's inaugural of the trout season tomorrow, some of the commuters from Connecticut will not be in New York on Saturday for a corresponding good reason.

An uncommonly rewarding program of new and unfamiliar music distinguished the fourth of five Serenades at the Museum of Modern Art last night. Nearly all the works played or sung had some points of distinction, and several were markedly outstanding.

Thomas F. Manville Jr., asbestos heir, filed suit in Supreme Court yesterday charging that his sister, Mrs. Lorraine Manville Dresselhuys, "by misrepresentations, deceit and suppression of facts, fraudulently induced" him to sign a document on Nov. 20 last year renouncing his right to dispose by his will of the principal of the $2,000,000 trust fund left to him by his father, founder of the Johns-Manville Corporation.

Major league opposition, such as the Dodgers provided last week-end and the Braves yesterday, has not brought the Yankees a victory yet. Casey Stengel's outfit scored a 7-5 victory over the McCarthymen at the Stadium and in so doing emphasized the fact that the American League champions, among other shortcomings, still are in need of conditioning.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- A "scramble" for world air routes will accompany the expansion of commercial aviation when nations geared for warplane production return to the manufacture of civilian air equipment, W.A. Patterson, president of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation, said today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 14 -- To expedite further the output of American war planes and to coordinate the facilities of the aircraft industry at the battlefronts as well as on the production lines, sixteen air-frame and engine manufacturers of the East and West formed today the National Aircraft Production Council, Inc.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, appearing by invitation before the City Council yesterday, spoke in favor of a bill to amend the city's administrative code to place 745 employes of the Park Department on an annual instead of a daily salary basis.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -The news was broadcast from Paris today that General Jean-Jules-Henri Mordacq had committed suicide last evening by throwing himself into the Seine River from the bridge facing the French Academy building.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Reports that the House Appropriations Committee had voted to eliminate payments of funds to bring the prices of agricultural products up to parity and sought to ban the sale of commodities owned by the Commodity Credit Corporation at less than parity had considerable influence today on grain trade sentiment.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 14 -- The Germans, extending their new offensive operations on the northern front to the Leningrad area, attacked yesterday with tanks and infantry, but were thrown back with heavy losses, a Soviet communique said today.

Three books by Latin Americans have won awards in Farrar Rinehart's second Latin-American literary prize competition, it was announced yesterday. The contest was sponsored by the division of intellectual cooperation of the Pan American Union and the publishing concern.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- From Michigan, which fills no inconsiderable portion of the nation's food-basket, came two assaults today on the President's arrangements to keep secret the effective discussions and negotiations at the international food conference, which is to be held in May at Hot Springs, Va.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today acquisition by the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation of 18,000 shares of its $6 preferred stock, but expressed doubt that similar transactions should he approved in the future.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. The new attraction at the Rialto will be "Tonight We Raid Calais," a Twentieth Century-Fox production starring Annabella and John Sutton. Among the supporting players in the topical drama are Beulah Bondi, Lee J. Cobb, Robert Lewis, Howard da Silva and Marcel Dalio. . . .
CHUNGKING, China, April 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Baseball executives yesterday still were pondering the effect of the government's newest draft regulations and their first reactions were mixed because some clubs apparently may be helped and others may be hurt by the changes.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 13 -- Discounting in advance further "grave developments" in the Tunisian campaign, where, both Berlin and Rome admit tonight, the situation is "serious" because of "the lack of aerial support," German and Italian military commentators adopted concertedly a line of propaganda interpreted in diplomatic quarters here as "ominously significant."

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, who has inspired, directed and headed many a picket line during his tempestuous career, was himself picketed yesterday. The picketing was done by members and leaders of the C I.O., which Mr. Lewis founded and of which he was president during its first five formative years.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 14 (UP) -- Britain-based bombers of the Royal Air Force attacked Northern Italy last night for the first time since Feb. 14, officials announced early today, striking twenty-four hours after Soviet planes had carried the air war into Germany from the East again with an attack on Koenigsberg, capital of East Prussia.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 13 -The thirteenth annual Eastman School Festival of American Music opened tonight in the Eastman Theatre with a performance by the Eastman School's Senior Symphony Orchestra, Dr. Howard Hanson conductor.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -Introduction of "war model" overalls on a basis similar except as to compulsory features to that under which so-called "utility" models of clothing have been marketed in England was sponsored by the OPA today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (U.P.) -- A Senate-House conference committee agreed tonight on a bill providing $26,100,000 to set up a land army, principally of imported aliens, to produce and harvest crops this year.
A group of portraits by Salvador Dali will go on view privately this afternoon at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, and tomorrow the show, scheduled to last until May 5, opens to the public.

LIMA, Peru, April 13 -- Peruvians of all classes again today turned out in large numbers in honor of Vice President Henry A. Wallace as he visited agricultural experimental stations, schools of agriculture, botanical gardens and a workingmen's hospital, restaurant and homes.

It is good news to learn, through John MacCormac's story in THE TIMES, that some Congressional advocates of planning consider the prospects to be favorable for restoring the $1,400,000 fund of the National Resources Planning Board.

Having just returned from out of town, my attention has been called to a letter addressed to you by Charles A. Davila and published in your paper of April 5. I have no intention of engaging in any controversy with Mr. Davila, but to submit only the following facts:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Lucille Ball will play the leading role in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's "Meet the People," based on the revue of that title which originated here and later Was seen in New York. The picture will start early next month with E.Y. Harburg as producer. Virginia O'Brien of the original show has also been signed for the film.

The annual entertainment, known as the "Easter Bonnet Luncheon," will be held on Easter Sunday in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador for the benefit of the Chaplains Emergency Fund, New York Port of Embarkation. The beneficiary cares for and sends to their destinations, service men who arrive in New York and are temporarily without funds.

LONDON, April 14 -- Captain Anna W. Wilson today assumed command of the Waacs in this theatre. At the moment, her "force" includes three women, all of them officers, but that situation is due for a sharp change.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 14 -- French authorities have started a round-up of several hundred young men still "in the bush" in the Haute Savoie to avoid compulsory labor in Germany. Their action follows an incident in which one State policeman was killed and another perhaps fatally wounded.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 14 -- In an address broadcast to the nations of the Americas on Pan-American Day, Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu made a strenuous defense of Argentina's neutrality policy. He said it arose from Argentina's desire to avoid "sterile moments" in their constant effort to improve moral and material conditions of all men who made their home in Argentina.

A small but thriving black market in living-room furniture, in which several manufacturers have continued to use steel springs in violation of Order L-135 and are selling these goods at higher than ceiling prices, is being investigated by the compliance division of the War Production Board, it was learned yesterday.

Disappointment shrouded suite 1107 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. Mrs. Carl A. Hatch, its occupant, beckoned three other Senators' wives into a huddle for a "post mortem" on a mass interview from which they had just returned, and reported the consensus.

You quote Petroleum Administrator Ickes as saying once more that the East should convert to coal or expect a "cold blood stream" another Winter. Mr. Ickes also expressed himself as "satisfied" with the way coal was distributed last season.

The Fencers Club No. 1 trio of Mrs. Marion Lloyd Vince, Miss Helena Mroczkowska and Miss Dorothy Lancaster won the women's metropolitan team championship for the second straight year on their home strips last night.

Henry James was born in this city on April 15, 1843. Probably most of us have forgotten his birthplace because his family, coming here from Albany, afterward settled in Cambridge, and he lived so much abroad. He is one of our chief literary glories. In "Washington Square" he has embalmed the memory of his native town.
The Wednesday German communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Twelve women were sworn in for special duty as toll-booth attendants by the New York City Tunnel Authority and the Police Department yesterday to replace policemen who have either joined the armed forces or accepted jobs in specialized war industries.

The news from Maine today is that the ice is out of Sebago Lake, a signal that starts another fishing year in the pine tree area. And, appropriately enough, those who were awaiting the word "go" in New Jersey last night, were hoping that ice would not be along the edge of the State's streams for the inaugural this morning.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by The Associated Press:

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 14 -- After letting three other horses try to match the early speed of the B.F. Lister's heavily favored Centredale, Mrs. Weston W. Adams's False Face came from behind today to win the Warren Purse at Narragansett Park by a neck.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 14 -- The British-American talks on the refugee problem scheduled to open Monday will take up the problems not only of actual refugees who have left their countries for neutral or Allied territory but also of potential refugees unable to leave their countries but eager to do so because of persecution.

Thomas J. Curtis, a labor representative on the Industrial Council of the State Labor Department, held that position while also practicing in the department as a licensed representative of workmen's compensation claimants and grossed $43,000 in one year on compensation cases, he testified yesterday before Moreland Act Commissioner William F. Bleakley.

The Southern Coal Producers Association, one of the two groups of operators involved in the deadlocked soft coal wage negotiations, followed the lead yesterday of the Northern mine owners and rejected the government's proposal for a guarantee to the United Mine Workers of six days' work a week for fifty-two weeks, or for the period for which the proposed new collective agreement for the industry is sought.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 14 -- An agreement has been reached between Brazil and the United States to set up stores to provide foodstuffs and other items essential to the life of the rubber worker in the Amazon rubber fields, officials declared today.

The controversy between Mayor La Guardia and the department stores, arising from their part in the movement against his tax program and executive budget, erupted yesterday into an exchange of scathing statements between the Mayor and Walter Hoving, chairman of the Committee to Reduce the Budget Through Sensible Economies.

LONDON, April 15 -- The extent of the differences still existing between the followers of General Henri Honore Giraud and those of General Charles de Gaulle became apparent today when the contents of the memoranda that the two French leaders had exchanged were analyzed.

Four Senators made a joint appearance here last night at a citizens' rally in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to speak in favor of committing the United States Senate immediately to some organization of the United Nations equipped with sufficient force to keep the peace in the postwar world.
The annual Easter sale of the New York division of the Woman's National Farm and Garden Association was held yesterday at the home of Mrs. Carll Tucker, 733 Park Avenue.

On the first anniversary of his election as leader of Tammany Hall, former Representative Michael J. Kennedy disclosed yesterday that he wants "the Hall" to play a more dynamic role in public affairs than it has in the past and predicted for it a "very bright future" based on the experience gained during his first year as leader.

St. John's baseball team had little trouble, except for the hardships of lingering Winter, scoring its second Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference victory at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, yesterday. Using three pitchers and leading from the first inning, the Redmen turned back Brooklyn College, 9 to 4, to make their conference record two victories and one defeat.

NEWARK, N.J., April 14 -- The National War Labor Board has sent telegrams to John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and three other officials of the union calling on them to halt a strike that was called here Monday by District 50 of the U.M.W. at the plastics division of the Celanese Corporation of America, a war-production plant, it was disclosed here today by Robert L. Simmons, plant manager.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- To substantiate a recent statement of Donald Nelson to a Senate committee that there was no need to set up a separate civilian agency to see that the home front was kept adequately supplied, the War Production Board today issued a review of its orders of the last five weeks for protection of the civilian economy.

Modern air power has created an "indivisible world" and in so doing has made the destiny of the world "indivisible," Gill Robb Wilson, president of the National Aeronautic Association, told 125 members of the Wings Club, Inc., yesterday at the first anniversary luncheon of the group at its quarters at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission announced today that the Cabot Gas Corporation and its parent company, Godfrey L. Cabot, Inc., had reapplied for permission to discontinue furnishing natural gas to certain customers in New York State.

LEWISBORO, N.Y., April 14 -- Frederick Smith Warren, president of the Davis and Lawrence Company, chemical manufacturers with a plant in Dobbs Ferry, was found dead in his automobile here tonight with a bullet wound in his head. He was 71 years old.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 14 -- Allied planes continued their offensive against enemy supply lines yesterday, destroying seventy-three enemy aircraft on two Sicilian fields and six in the air at a cost of only three.

Three midtown theatres will present new film attractions this morning. At the Radio City Music Hall, the offering will be "Flight for Freedom," an RKO production starring Rosalind Russell and Fred MacMurray. Among the supporting players in the romantic drama are Herbert Marshall, Edward Ciannelli, Walter Kingsford and Damian O'Flynn.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The text of an OWI announcement praising American war correspondents follows:

CHICAGO, April 14 -- A twelve-point program aimed at providing sanctuaries for Jews and other victims of Nazi tyranny by having neutral sources obtain the Reich's agreement to their emigration to havens of refuge to be established by the United Nations was adopted tonight by a mass meeting of Jewish and non-Jewish organizations of Chicago.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek proposed yesterday that the four great nations -- the United States, Great Britain, Russia and China -- take the lead in forming a post-war world council to exercise disinterested control of countries which eventually would have absolute freedom.

LONDON, April 14 -- Captain Alec S. Cunningham-Reid, who was upbraided by Minister of Information Brendan Bracken in the House of Commons yesterday, undertook today to explain why he was in Honolulu when the Luftwaffe was trying to bring Great Britain to her knees in 1940.

The Association Hospital Service of New York, through its three-cent-a-day insurance plan, paid 118,000 claims for hospital treatment in 1942 as compared with 112,000 in 1941, Louis H. Pink, president of the service, reported on Tuesday at the annual meeting of voting members at 370 Lexington Avenue, the organization announced yesterday.

George S. Van Schaick, regional director of the Office of Civilian Defense, urged civilian defense councils yesterday to use the schools to the greatest possible degree in conveying to families and homes the opportunity for patriotic service through participation in war activities.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The majority of a War Labor Board panel has recommended a 6 per cent wage increase for 65,000 employes of the dress manufacturing industry in New York, it was learned tonight.

To a Spring season that has not found the Forties overwhelmed by new ideas, Theron Bamberger last evening brought "Tomorrow the World," by James Gow and Arnaud d'Usseau. It takes up the question, which is a timely one, of how German children can be brought back into the human race, endoctrined as they are with the Nazi philosophies.

LONDON, April 14 -- Premier Mussolini is just as popular as ever with the Italian masses and the Italians are not on the verge of evolution against the Fascist regime, despite the hard knocks Italy has received, in the opinion of Commander L. Brown, British Navy officer who has just returned to this country from a prisoner-of-war camp in Italy following his capture on July 20, 1940.

Jan Peerce was heard in his postponed recital, presented as the final event of the season's Endowment Series, last night in Town Hall. The Metropolitan tenor had prepared a program embracing a wide variety of offerings, all of which were delivered in a manner that attested to his sound musicianship.

A vital difference between the bombing of Berlin and London, aside from the incomparably greater destructive power of today's "blockbusters," is that the raids on the Reich occur at the climax of the war instead of at the beginning. The bombing of London took place before Britain was prepared either to retaliate or to protect herself with anti-aircraft defenses.

The swiftly mounting tide of State income tax returns reached a high point for the year so far. The deadline for filing returns without penalty is midnight tonight. Since Rollin Browne, State Tax Commissioner, announced that as only 10 per cent of the expected 1,500,000 returns were in hand at the close of last week, it is believed the majority of payments due will come in a flood today.

EVERY biographer creates his own Thomas Jefferson. Last year Saul K. Padover, assistant to Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, wrote of Jefferson, the New Dealer, and Albert Jay Nock, whose biography remains the most sprightly of them all, painted Jefferson as the eternal enemy of those who try to convert social power into state power.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Arrangements for newspaper coverage of the United Nations Food Conference at Hot Springs, Va., next month, constitute "an abridgment of the freedom of the press," it was asserted today by the Standing Committee of Correspondents, representing the 560 American and foreign correspondents accredited by Congress to covering that body.

The war brought another change to the city last night when the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, turned over its main exhibition room to a display designed to help war workers. Heretofore this large hall on the library's first floor has been devoted to outstanding exhibitions of bibliographical interest.

Twelve millinery colors for the Fall and Winter seasons have been adopted by the millinery color committee of the Textile Color Card Association, it was announced yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director. Designed to conserve dyestuffs but to retain fashion significance, the colors are adaptable for medium and dark fur felt and for wool felt.

NEW DELHI, India, April 14 (AP) -- In a resurgence of fighting on the Arakan front in Western Burma, British troops yesterday frustrated Japanese attempts to infiltrate their recently re-formed lines in the Gyindaw sector, a British communique announced today.

LONDON, Thursday, April 15 (UP) -- Red Army troops, resuming active offensive operations against the German bridgehead in the Kuban, have captured a series of German pillboxes and trenches and held them against repeated determined counter-attacks, a Soviet communique said today.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 14 -- The Japanese still have large numbers of aircraft, including many bombers, concentrated in the Southwest Pacific and can, if fey consider it worth the price, continue their week-old air offensive in the New Guinea-Solomons area.

Seven of the 104 one-act plays submitted in the Soldiers' Playwriting Contest sponsored by the Special Service Office of the Second Service Command, United State Army, and John Golden, will be judged for final awards next Sunday.

Interest was divided yesterday at Jamaica between the victory of Scotland Light in the Rostand Handicap and the announcement that Jockey Don Meade had been "denied" a license and that Jockey Eddie Arcaro's application for a license had been "deferred." The effect is to keep on the ground and under discipline perhaps the two best-known jockeys in America.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A 26 per cent increase in deposits, an 11 per cent decrease in loans and a 94 per cent jump in the banks' holdings of Federal Government obligations was reported today for the 13,347 insured commercial banks by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

Prices recovered quickly yesterday on the stock market from the previous day's shock of the Interstate Commerce Commission's suspension of the increased freight rates previously granted to the railroads. Selling dwindled to the smallest volume in recent sessions.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, in Southern Tunisia, April 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- America's famous First Infantry Division was congratulated today by Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. for "a truly great performance" in the battle of El Guettar.

Assurance that the OPA does not intend to restrict unreasonably in any of its future regulations the profits that woolen jobbers might make under MPR 163 was given by Russell L. Burrus of the OPA's wool division at last night's joint meeting of the Woolen Jobbers Association and the Woolen Wholesalers National Association in the Hotel New Yorker.

Hospitals will get as much rationed food for their patients as they used last December -- and "considerably more" when they need it -- upon certification by the physician in charge that such amounts are necessary, Sylvan L. Joseph, regional administrator of the Office of Price Administration, declared yesterday.

Delia Calapai, New York pianist, gave her first recital in this city yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She played a Sonata in G major by Haydn; Sonata, Opus 90, in E minor, by Beethoven; two nocturnes and the Scherzo in B minor, Opus 20, by Chopin; Sonata.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Representative Kennedy, Democrat of New York, said today he would submit to a special House committee "the whole question" involved in a Justice Department action against fifteen New York stores accused of boycotting THE NEW YORK TIMES advertising pages.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The Office of Price Administration will soon establish a committee of representative wholesalers and retailers from the drug trade to work out new specific dollars and cents price ceilings on drugs and cosmetics, John J. Toohy, head of the drugs, cosmetics and soap section of the OPA, announced here today.

Although gross operating revenues of the Western Union Telegraph Company in the first two months of this year aggregated $22,287,378, a 15.9 per cent rise above the 1942 volume, net income declined to $375,124 from $650,875, A.N. Williams, president, told stockholders of the company yesterday at their annual meeting.

With New York setting the pace for the rest of the country with war bond sales of $2,015,000,000 up to 11 A.M. yesterday, the nation as a whole passed the $4,000,000,000 mark on the third day of the Second War Loan drive, with great financial institutions, moderate investors and persons of modest means combining in the effort to raise $13,000,000,000 this month.

Mayor La Guardia made public without comment yesterday a report by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, charging that the Hanes committee, by a "questionable use of statistical material," had painted an "unduly dark picture" of the city's and State's manufacturing trends.
The two top seeded players in the Red Cross handicap squash racquets tournament at the Yale Club made their exits from the competition last night.

With only a small amount of help from government agencies, the woolen and worsted industry could continue to produce enough to clothe our own population adequately so that no rationing of clothing should be required unless the government purchases large quantities of wool fabrics for foreign relief, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, told members at their annual meeting yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 14 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Fighting French delegation announced today the death in an airplane accident in Great Britain of Count Gabriel de Gramont, lately a captain in the Fighting French Air Force who had been a member of the staff of the French Embassy here from 1937 to 1940.

The Energy Control Company, sales representative for manufacturers of power plant equipment, has leased the five-story building, 25 by 100 feet, at 49 East Thirty-fourth Street from Charles F. Noyes. The concern is headed by Justus T. Vollbrecht, who organized it in 1942 as a continuation of the business he operated previously as an individual.

DETROIT, April 14 -- To find the workers to keep the arsenal of democracy going at top speed, the War Manpower Commission has worked out a program to stop labor pirating and labor hoarding, job shopping and absenteeism, prejudice and discrimination against Negroes, women and older persons, Fowler V. Harper, deputy chairman of the War Manpower Commission, told the American Chemical Society tonight.

John J. Clark, a business agent for Local 1456 of the Dock Builders and Shorers Union of the Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, A.F. of L., was released in $5,000 bail yesterday in Special Sessions to await trial for failing to file State income tax returns on an alleged income of $82,375 in 1940 and $17,500 in 1941.

CONCORD, N.H., April 14 (U.P.) -- Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, charged today that the New Deal was engaged in "un-American deviltry" that is "being aimed right at the heart of Congress."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The way of fredom, mutual understanding, justice and peace which obtains in the Americas was pointed to by Cordell Hull in a Pan American Day address tonight as an example to the rest of the world in the years to come.

After the first shock a person on the New Haven trains will admit, of course, that no offense was intended by The United Press. But it did make a person sit back to read that the Axis in Africa now controls an area only about the size of Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Major Gen. E. B. Gregory, quartermaster general of the Army, made public today the first comprehensive explanation of Army food purchases and struck out at critics who "falsely attribute to military requirements food shortages that are due to other economic factors."

Application of the "death sentence" of the Public Utility Holding Company Act to the Electric Bond and Share Company's system under present wartime conditions would be nothing short of "confiscation," C.E. Groesbeck, chairman, and S.W. Murphy, president, declared yesterday in their 1942 report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Brig. Gen. Shelley U. Marietta, commanding general of the Army Medical Center in Washington, known as Walter Reed Hospital, has a simple formlula for the tremendous job that is being done. They work for two things -- to save lives and salvage human bodies.

The annual Paddy Reilly Dog Hero Medal, sponsored by the Greenwich Village Humane League, 55 Eighth Avenue, was awarded yesterday to Sven of Bagaduce, a Shetland collie, for the rescue of a man in a blizzard.

Declaring that the United States is an "unknown quantity of a postwar equation," Anne O'Hare McCormick, editorial writer of THE NEW YORK TIMES, told an audience of the Institute of Arts and Sciences of Columbia University last night that the United States should join with Great Britain, Russia and China in shaping "the world of tomorrow."

Civilian defense workers in this city, from Mayor La Guardia down, should be much obliged to the editor of an Italian newspaper, La Tribuna Illustrata, and to a General Sato of Japan. Their defense work is tedious and often thankless, just because they cannot persuade their neighbors that there is real danger of an air raid.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 15 -- The Japanese attacked Milne Bay, Allied base at the southeastern tip of New Guinea, with seventy-five to 100 planes in daylight yesterday and Allied defenders shot thirty planes out of action, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique revealed today.

Charles Whitehead of the Plainfield Country Club, who won the New Jersey open and amateur championships last year and several times before then, was accorded first place on the 1943 honor roll of the Metropolitan Golf Association, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- New ceiling prices on cash corn and the May and July futures became effective at the opening of business today on the Board of Trade. No. 2 yellow sold up 5 cents a bushel to $1.07, the maximum permitted under the new regulations.

ALBANY, April 14 -- The Butler bill, increasing Workmen's Compensation Law benefits for widows and dependent children, was signed by Governor Dewey today. It permits a total recovery of $25 a week instead of the present $22.50.

LONDON, April 14 -- Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman's conversations in London with Allied governments on post-war relief problems have revived or rather brought forward speculation upon the part Russia expects to play in this vital task.
