CHUNGKING, China, April 14 (U.P.) -- A Chinese communique tonight reported heavy fighting in the Hupeh-Hunan border area of Central China, where Chinese troops drove the Japanese from a strategic center south of the Yangtze River, but were forced to surrender a newly recaptured village to the reinforced enemy.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 14 -- Lieutenant Thomas Dudley Harmon, football star at the University of Michigan in 1938, 1939 and 1940, and the greatest scorer in gridiron history, is "missing in the South American area," but his shocked parents were clinging stanchly tonight to the hope that he is still alive.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 14 (AP) -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower calls Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel "a great general" but "not a superman," and adds he is confident that the Axis leader and his troops, despite his generalship, will be thrown out of Africa.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Propaganda in territory held by the enemy has been entrusted to the Office of War Information, as in 1917-18 it was the responsibility of George Creel's Committee on Public Information. Mr. Creel's employment of this weapon was sure, coordinated and devastating.

Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America, said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that sales for the first two months of the year were 22 per cent greater than in the 1942 period, continuing the upward trend noted last year.

The United States may have to fight another war after the cessation of present hostilities, against "the enemy of our own international indifference," William L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board, declared last night at a dinner in the Hotel Plaza opening the United Jewish Appeal's Greater New York fund campaign.

BENDIX, N.J., April 14 -- As the informal strike of members of the United Automobile Workers of America went into its third day at the local plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation and twenty-five more of them were discharged for "absenteeism," extension of the walk-out to other New Jersey plants of the company was threatened today by Dominick Di Galbo, organizer for the C.I.O. union.

President Roosevelt is the "outstanding personage in the world today" as well as the greatest living American, in the estimation of City College seniors polled in a survey this week by the senior class council. The seniors also indicated they favor a fourth term for Mr. Roosevelt if the war is not over by 1944.

Making the first monthly increase in 1943, new life insurance busiiess in March totaled $752,561,000, or 13.7 per cent above the same 1942 month, according to a statement forwarded by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Chamber of Commerce.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 14 (AP) -- Two down and three holes to play, Corporal Ronnie Williams of Camp Butner, medalist, squared the match and won on the nineteenth from Tommy Bumbarger of Davidson College in the first round of the forty-third annual North and South amateur golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Denying accusations that the Office of War Information seeks to paint only the brightest government pictures, Elmer Davis, director of the information agency, said today its only function was to give the public the facts, and to accomplish that, he declared, the OWI was doing "its damndest."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, intimated today that the issue of grade labeling on canned goods might be compromised by a regulation of the Office of Price Administration requiring retailers to tell consumers on request the grade ratings of fruits and vegetables but not compelling such labels on cans.

Discussion of wartime publishing problems and plans for closer cooperation between British and American book publishers will mark the six-week visit to this country of three British publishers -- Walter Harrap of George G. Harrap Co., Ltd.; Geoffrey Faber of Faber Faber, Ltd., and G. Wren Howard of Jonathan Cape, Ltd.
The action of the American Bar Association in refusing to admit to membership Assistant District Attorney Francis E. Rivers solely because he is a Negro merits the severest criticism.

The first Waac group to be assigned for duty with a combat force in this country joined a New York unit of the Anti-aircraft Artillery Command yesterday. Moving into the "nerve center" of a regiment on Long Island, the women prepared to help take over defense of the coastal area.

We are glad to publish in another part of this page today a letter from Wilbur F. Murra, executive secretary of the National Council for the Social Studies. We are the more pleased to do this because we do not find ourselves in disagreement with Mr. Murra. We were appalled, as he must have been, at the revelations of student ignorance made in our American History Survey.

In an era of considerable scarcity the Dodgers simply had too much of everything yesterday as they crowned themselves the so-called "mythical" baseball champions of Greater New York by polishing off both the Yankees and Giants in the CDVO double-header at the Stadium before a gathering of 35,301 frostbitten but highly enthusiastic onlookers.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- A plan for the sale by the Illinois Iowa Power Company of its interests in the Des Moines Electric Light Company and the Iowa Power and Light Company to the Continental Gas and Electric Corporation was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

A flurry of buying of March cotton supplemented by less substantial purchases of October and December contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, believed to be covering of short positions by interests that had liquidated last week, reversed yesterday a downward trend in futures prices near the close.

LONDON, Thursday, April 15 (U.P.) -- Southeast coast watchers reported that the largest number of British night bombers ever seen over the Strait of Dover flew toward Europe last night. Night aerial warfare flared on both sides of the English Channel as the Germans attacked two Thames estuary towns with explosives and incendiaries.

The increasing demands to save transportation space has forced the armed forces to undertake food compression as a partial solution and the Quartermaster Corps has started a broad-scale project, William W. Black of the research and development branch of the Office of the Quartermaster General declared yesterday at the morning session of the wartime packaging conference and exposition, sponsored by the American Management Association, at the Hotel Astor.

Brigadier Frederick H. Kisch, 65-year-old Chief Engineer of the British Eighth Army, has died in action in Tunisia, the Palcor News Agency reported last night, quoting London advices. [He was killed last Sunday in the Sousse advance, The United Press reported from London.]

Sales of the National Biscuit Company in the first quarter of 1943 were 40 per cent ahead of a year ago, while profit for the period was about 35 cents a share, Frederick Beers, vice president, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at Flemington, N. J., yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- Rear Admiral Ralph A. Davison, assistant chief of the Bureau of Aeronautics, arrived here today three hours late for a meeting of the National Aircraft War Production Council, Inc. When his plane, carrying him from Washington, reached Albuquerque, N.M., at 6 A.M., the hostess told him:
Mayor La Guardia tried out as a big league sports commentator and announcer yesterday, but professionals like Red Barber, Bill Stern, Sam Taub and a host of others are not worrying about their jobs.

THE weather was perfect at the Yankee Stadium yesterday -- for an Army-Notre Dame football game. There was just the proper nip to the air for a slashing off-tackle run or a booming downfield punt. But it hardly was ideal for a two-base hit or a two-base error.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The medical director of the Selective Service system reminded Senators today that soon all additions to the armed forces must come from present high school age youths, whom he criticized in general as "soft and flabby."

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- If local interests, whether public or private, fail to formulate definite plans for the establishment of foreign trade zones in our principal-ports immediately after the war ends, the Federal Government will probably take action to create them, it is to be gathered from the 1942 report of the Foreign-Trade Zones Board, published today.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, urged that the Senate adopt the Ball-Burton-Hatch-Hill resolution "without delay" after he had conferred with those four Senators and Senator Joseph F. Guffey of Pennsylvania at the university yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Board of Economic Warfare today announced that the Brazilian Government had requested the United States not to authorize the exportation of certain commodities to Brazil on the ground that the limited shipping space must be conserved for war and essential civilian supplies.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Dewey today vetoed the Crews bill mandating minimum salaries of $1,200 a year for junior school clerks in New York City and requiring payment of annual increments of $100 until a maximum $2,000 was reached.
CHUNGKING, China, April 14 (U.P.) -- A communique:

NEWARK, N.J., April 14 -- An indictment charging John Alijian of Jersey City, operator of a chain of dry cleaning establishments, with having tried to give a $60 bribe to an investigator for the compliance section of the War Production Board was handed up here yesterday by the Federal Grand Jury.

James L. Rodgers Jr., president of the Plaskon Company, Inc., and L.G. Bryan, in charge of production for the Libbey-Owens-Fond Glass Company, were elected yesterday vice presidents of the latter concern following its annual meeting in Toledo.
LONDON, April 14 -- The stock markets here were quieter today, with a steady tone. Improvements in shares influenced by tax proposals announced in the government budget were held mostly.

The man who coined the phrase, "when in doubt string along with the winner," never heard of the Yankees but that's probably why the sports writers have selected the New Yorkers to top the American League pennant race for the third straight year.

Mrs. Catherine O'Connell sold the southeast corner of Ritter Place and Union Avenue, in the Bronx, after it had been in the family for ninety - three years, through Charles W. Brown, broker. The property includes a four-room cottage and a seven-room dwelling, occupying the corner lot of 46 by 100 feet.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- To permit the new specific "dollars-and-cents" ceilings on retail beef, veal, lamb and mutton prices to be re-examined to determine whether they were in accord with the President's "hold-the-line" anti-inflationary executive order, the Office of Price Administration postponed their effective date today for one month.

The April 11 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES quotes Hugh Russell Fraser as saying: "The vicious system of teaching whereby the social study extremists have a contempt for the facts of American history must be corrected. If money is needed [to improve history instruction], it is to combat the practices of the National Council for the Social Studies and its twin brother, Teachers College, Columbia."

Stocks of oil products on the Atlantic seaboard last week declined to another new low level, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the close of the period, the institute's index, covering gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil, stood at 28.8, compared with 30.5 at the close of the previous week and 58.3 on Nov. 7, 1942, when the present downward trend started.

Newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities, measured by Media Records, registered a gain of 5.9 per cent last month over March, 1942. For the first quarter of the year the increase was 6.7 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator McNary, minority leader of the Senate, joined with the Republican members of the Senate Finance Committee today in a statement requesting their "House colleagues" to report out a tax bill as speedily as possible so that the Senate "might conclude this essential legislation ahead of any Congressional recess."

With perhaps 200,000 Axis troops herded into the "coffin corner" of Tunisia the last phase of the long battle for Africa begins. If Marshal Rommel still commands this army he cannot hope for victory. He can only win delay while Hitler completes the defenses of Europe.
STOCKHOLM, April 14 (AP) -- Hungary has refused Axis requests for troops to help defend the Balkans and at the same time is withdrawing soldiers from Russia, usually reliable sources said today.

LONDON, April 14 -- Immediate preparation by the Great Powers of plans for a world peace policy was urged in the House of Lords today in a debate on foreign policy in which many speakers put searching questions to the government.

With the first anniversary of Major Gen. James H. Doolittle's air raid on Tokyo last April 18 drawing near, a high Japanese military official told the Japanese people yesterday that continuous air raids over the United States would be necessary to "crush the fighting spirit of the American people" because "the American people are people who are stubborn and like to fight."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 14 -- Three or more German bombers prying around the main Swedish naval anchorage at Karlskrona today were engaged by anti-aircraft fire and Swedish fighters. One of the intruders got a close-up view within 100 meters of the marine base and another made a prolonged flight over the area.
WEST POINT, N.Y., April 14 -- Army defeated Manhattan at baseball on Doubleday Field today by a score of 5 to 1.

LONDON, Thursday, April 15 (AP) -- Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel commandeered the mansion of a rich olive-grove owner for a recent twenty-one-day stay in Sfax, but an Italian general lived in a tent in the back yard, Tunisian dispatches reported today.

A report on post-war planning which calls for joint participation by industry, banking, agriculture and labor, under the leadership of one qualified organization to formulate a national post-war plan of reconstruction was made public yesterday by the post-war planning and reconstruction committee of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

The 1942 annual report of the Electric Bond and Share Company, which has just been forwarded to stockholders, devotes considerable attention to informing the stockholder just where he stands as a utility holding company investor in view of the many problems facing the holding company industry.

A "foolproof" permanent wave is what a Fifth Avenue salon is promising every woman who comes in through its shiny glass doors. Every wave, they say, is certain to be an unqualified success because the whole thing -- including conditioning oil and even the lotion -- is made to order for the individual customer.

The Board of Education voted yesterday at its regular meeting to reconsider the appointment of Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, for the $7,500 position of adult education director of the New York City school system.

Operations of the Row Chemical Company and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended with February resulted in a consolidated net profit of $7,351,633 after provision for Federal income and excess profits taxes, equivalent to $5.70 a share on the common stock outstanding, according to a statement issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- A Senate and House conference committee settled differences on a wartime pay bill for government employes today by a compromise that included more liberal provisions for lower-salaried workers. Major provisions, effective until June 30, 1945, call for:

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Army has asked for 300 specialists in psychological warfare to help win the victory in North Africa and thirty-five of these experts in information and propaganda are already on the African front, Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said at a press conference today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during March totaled 995,513 bales of lint and 108,851 bales of linters, compared with 967,406 bales of lint and 131,820 of linters during March last year.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Army and Navy fliers, operating from American bases in Alaskan waters, teamed up for six more punishing attacks on Kiska Island in the Aleutians, where the Japanese are doggedly completing a fighter plane strip despite continued blows from the air, a Navy communique disclosed today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 15 (AP) -- The noon communique:
Discrimination cannot be attacked "in terms of public agitation or legislation, but rather in terms of specific cases," Ordway Tead, president of the Board of Higher Education, asserted yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 14 -- Railroads have "reached the bottom of the barrel" so far as increasing the available supply of cars through the continued repair of those out of service, R.W. Brown, president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, declared today at a meeting here of the Atlantic States Shippers Advisory Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 14 -- Marshal Ion Antonescu, Premier of Rumania, contributed a two-day visit to the round of meetings between Adolf Hitler and his Axis allies following the departure of Premier Mussolini, it was announced in Berlin tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Two meat-packing companies charged today in complaints filed in the United States Emergency Court of Appeals that OPA orders to supply the government with certain meats are resulting in financial loss to slaughterers and threaten to impede the production of carcass beef.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 14 (AP) -- French and American troops were deploying southwest of the British yesterday for coordinated blows that are expected to push the German forces into the Mediterranean.
The Wednesday Japanese communique, as broadcast from Tokyo and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Tribute to the bravery of American newspaper men, radio reporters and photographers assigned to war coverage, but who "can't fight back" when their lives are jeopardized, was paid today by Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information.

LONDON, April 14 -- An official of the Ministry of Economic Warfare whose business it is to find out and face the facts said today that there was no chance that Germany would weaken on the food front this year or next year, for the simple reason that there were no immediate prospects of a serious food shortage either in Germany or the occupied countries.

Bold planning and bold action on the part of thousands of individual business men to meet the demands of post-war economic development were advocated yesterday by leaders of government and industry at the first public conference of the Committee for Economic Development, recently organized for this purpose.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, ruled today that President Roosevelt's "hold-the-line" order against inflation would be violated by any modification of current rent control regulations to conform to the lines of a four-point program put forward by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
Loft buildings, apartment houses and a taxpayer were among the properties in Manhattan that changed hands in deals reported yesterday.

Mrs. James Truman Bidwell gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois. Her guests included Mrs. Robert Grant, Mrs. Samuel A. Thompson, Mrs. John Walthour and Mrs. John Baker Jr. Another luncheon party at La Salle du Bois was given by Miss Peggy Tenney, whose guests were Mrs. Herbert C. Chase, Miss Ellenor Vandermade and Miss Marian Hodges.

Women have a great role to play in the post-war development of hemispheric unity in the Americas, according to the consensus expressed yesterday afternoon at a Pan-American Day "Inter-Hemispheric Conference" in the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Difficulty is being encountered in preparing a slate for election as directors of the General Aniline and Film Corporation at the postponed annual meeting, to be held on May 11, it was disclosed yesterday in Washington by Leo T. Crowley, Alien Property Custodian, Mr. Crowley has control of 97 per cent of the shares, formerly held by interests connected with the German Dye Trust.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Senate received today from the White House nominations for the first four active commodores to be appointed in the Navy since 1899.

LONDON, April 14 -- The House of Commons today adopted Sir Kingsley Wood's record-breaking budget of 5,756,114,000 in an atmosphere of resignation after a routine debate. There was little criticism of the Chancellor of the Exchequer's resort to indirect taxation to make up the anticipated deficit.

Blackout tests were called last night in Nassau and Westchester Counties and in the southern part of Putnam County, with the drill lasting thirty-one minutes in Nassau and twenty-nine in Westchester. It was Nassau and Westchester's first experience with the triple audible signals instituted by the Army for the Eastern Seaboard last February.

Edward Malloy, of 28-49 Thirty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens, pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions at his trial for the theft of $14,000 worth of scotch and rye whisky from a freight terminal in Twenty-sixth Street last year.

Duty and fun inspired the styles for the Summer fashions shown yesterday by Lanz Fifth Avenue at luncheon in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Where duty ended and fun began was hard to determine, for all the clothes were so pretty.

Nowadays cooking for two -- an occupation that used to be associated with blissful brides -- demands all the concentration you would give a crossword puzzle. In fact, many of the women this department has encountered have given up trying to do it, saying they prefer to "eat out" rather than struggle with War Ration Book 2.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Legislation allowing the Coast Guard to send Spars outside the United States, particularly for service in Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico, was approved today by the House Merchant Marine Committee.

Lieut. Gen. Patton. American commander on the Central Tunisian front, has issued an order of the day congratulating his troops on their victory at El Guettar. "After twenty-two days of incessant fighting in the mountains of the south," he said, "you have won the battle of El Guettar.
ALGIERS, April 14 (AP) -- The plan submitted by General Giraud to General de Gaulle was said to propose the following measures:

Unless the kosher meat supply, in this city is increased at once, 4,000 butchers will have to close their shops after the Passover holidays, Jack Kranis, general counsel for the Federation of Kosher Butchers of Greater New York, said yesterday.

Colby M. Chester, general chairman of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City, announced yesterday that several large contributions had been received by the fund, thereby narrowing the gap that remains to be closed before the city will have filled its quota of $12,920,000.

The sale of Pullman reservations for a "service charge" by certain travel agencies that advertise that they can obtain such reservations when tickets are "sold out" at the railroad terminals was being investigated yesterday by the Trunk Line Association, representing the railroad lines serving, the New York area.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A House fight over the question of whether the Department of Agriculture's Farm Security Administration should be abolished is scheduled tomorrow as the result of action today by the Rules Committee.

Eight teams won their way to the quarter-final round of the national contract bridge team-of-four tournament for the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Pierre here in matches that lasted into the early hours of the morning.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Department store sales for the week ended April 10 were 28 per cent above sales for the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This gain followed a loss of 7 per cent for the week ended April 3 from a year ago.

Addressing members of the New York Urban League, which is working to improve the status of the Negro, Newbold Morris, president of the city Council, announced last night that William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, soon would release a report showing that juvenile delinquency in the city is not dominant among any particular race but cuts through the whole population.

Is the Administration preparing for another of those "victories" over John L. Lewis under which Mr. Lewis gets substantially what he asked for in the first place? It begins to look that way. Let us first recall a bit of history. In November, 1941, the National Defense Mediation Board refused to award Mr. Lewis a closed shop in the "captive" coal mines.

Carrying the burden of a seven-game winning streak into Ebbets Field yesterday, the Dodgers barely avoided having it snapped by their farm hands, the Montreal Royals. Brooklyn eked out a ninth-inning decision, 4 -- 3.
It is really astonishing that the Washington correspondents and practically the whole American press should fail to grasp the urgent need for secrecy at the United Nations Food Conference next month.

The mounted division of the city's Police Department, which has a normal quota of 359 horses, is short twenty-three horses due to the demands of the Army in the horse market, Police Commissioner Valentine revealed yesterday during the presentation of certificates of honor to sixteen members of the department for rescuing animals during 1942.

The Southern Coal Producers Association, one of the two groups of operators involved in the soft-coal wage negotiations, sent a telegram yesterday to Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, formally rejecting the government's proposal for a guaranteed six-day work week over a period of fifty-two weeks as a compromise settlement of the dispute with the United Mine Workers.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senate leaders made progress today in an effort to avert a display of Congressional disunity on extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act and on the emerging Senate resolution to commit Congress in advance of an armistice to post-war international cooperation.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- One of the reasons publicly given by fifteen writers and publishers for their resignation from the staff of the Office of War Information makes clear why the resignations were inevitable. They came to the "conviction," they said, "that it is impossible for us * * * to tell the full truth."

Formation of a National Aircraft Production Council, to coordinate the constructive work of the existing East Coast and West Coast regional councils, should lead to a still further intensification of the team-work which has been so marked in the successful attainment by the aircraft industry of an almost incredibly high production goal.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The government should "set the example" with respect to draft deferments, the committee asserted, the report disclosing some "disturbing" figures on deferments of Federal employes, figures "indicative of the fact that no clearly defined policy in government has existed since the passage of the Selective Service Act of 1940 whereby women and men over the draft age or men having physical disabilities would be considered first in government hiring."

The property tax now being levied by the county of Los Angeles on merchandise which is in warehouse in that area awaiting transhipment to foreign countries is "unfair and unreasonable" and in violation of the laws covering interstate commerce, exporters charged yesterday at a meeting of the Latin-American section of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Frederick Brown has resold to a client of Harry Sherman the six-story building containing sixty-four apartments at 575 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. The size of the plot is 84.7 by 210 feet and the building has a reported annual rental of more than $43,000.

The gap in the forward movement of the stock market produced by the new anti-inflationary measures and the suspension of increases in railway freight rates was closed further yesterday as buying on the New York Stock Exchange increased in volume.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 15 (AP) -- The board of directors of Delaware Park decided today to forego racing this year at the mile track in near-by Stanton.

The directors of the Pere Marquette Railway Company last October initiated the policy of reducing the company's debt by buying the first mortgage bonds, R.J. Bowman, president, told stockholders in the annual report for 1942. He said that by the end of the year some $2,250,000 of these bonds had been retired and that additional purchases had been made in 1943.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Henry L. Stimson, Secretary of War, promised an "increasing flow" of planes to Australia today but pointed out at his weekly press conference that there were many demands for military supplies from all quarters. This was a polite but unmistakable rebuke to General Douglas MacArthur's determined efforts to get more planes.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed increase of $155,657,000 in holdings of United States Government securities during the week.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway awarded today, subject to the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval, a $5,200,000 issue of 1943 serial equipment trust certificates to Halsey, Stuart Co. of Chicago and six associates including Otis Co. of Cleveland.

Victory gardeners should try to plant more seeds this week-end if the weather continues dry, Thomas H. Everett, horticulturist at the New York Botanical Garden at Bronx Park, declared yesterday in announcing that the recent cold weather had not harmed any of the crops planted at the Bronx Park demonstration garden on March 25.

Intimations that a ceiling may be placed imminently on cotton at the highest levels of the last five days brought nervous selling into the futures market yesterday, keeping prices mixed throughout the moderately active session. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed 10 points higher to 11 points lower than the previous close, with near positions exhibiting pronounced weakness as values of the six months tended to converge.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -Striking members of Local 12,666 of District 50, United Mine Workers, ignoring the National War Labor Board's appeal that they return to work at the plastics division, here, of the Celanese Corporation of American, a war-production plant, voted unanimous this afternoon to continue their walk-out until their grievances had been adjusted.

"La Mia Canzone Al Vento" (A Song to the Wind), an Italian-language feature, will have its premiere at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse on Saturday, April 24. The theatre's current tenant, the Italian film "You Love Me, I Love You," will start its eighth and final week today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Senate was in recess. Its Judiciary Committee recommended approval of the bill providing for Senate confirmation of higher-bracket government officials. The Foreign Relations subcommittee considered resolutions on post-war policy; the Banking and Currency Committee continued hearings on the bill to establish an independent Office of Civilian Supply.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Secretary Ickes, as Petroleum Administrator, said today that there could be no increase in gasoline allocations for the East Coast with storage stocks at their present low levels and still dropping despite a record tank car mavement east-war 924,079 barrels daily for the week ending April 10.
ALBANY, April 15 -- The conviction of first degree murder found against William Flynn in New York City was unanimously reversed today by the Court of Appeals which directed a new trial.
CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -Speculators have been "having a wonderful time" in the bullish, wartime stock market. Brig. Gen. Leonard P. Ayres observed today.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 14 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The bodies of twenty-three American soldiers, in flag-draped coffins, were buried in an American cemetery outside this bustling North Australian town today with all the honor the United States can pay her soldier dead.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Organized labor may decide to shelve all its current wage demands in favor of annual wage, according to high officials of the American Federation of Labor, the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the railway brotherhoods.

Considerable publicity has been given to a double-header baseball game held on April 14 for the benefit of the CDVO. I'd like to express a hope that equal publicity will be given to the allocation of whatever money is raised. I do not suggest that some one is going to make off with it; I only want to know whether the Air Warden Service is going to get some it.

BALTIMORE, April 15 (AP) -Maryland's rationed racing season, reduced to twenty days this Spring because wartime restrictions made it impossible for more than one track to operate, will start tomorrow at the Maryland Jockey Club's Pimlico track.

Only fourteen of thirty-six departments had advertising linage increases last month over the March, 1942, figures, according to a breakdown of department store linage here by Media Records. Total linage for stores last month was 2,963,399 as against 3,180,964 a loss of 6.9 per cent.

Berne, Switzerland, sitting on its tall island of neutrality in the Nazi ocean, reports a strange bit of news, just fished up from where Florence, Italy, used to be. This is that "a German explorer, Emil Moeller," has just discovered documentary evidence "that confirms April 15, 1452, as the date of Leonardo da Vinci's birth."
LONDON, April 15 -- The stock markets were cheerful today but little activity was shown. Gilt-edge stocks remained dull, the War Loan 3 1/2 per cents losing 1/16 to u105 7/16.

In its first change of ownership in fifty-nine yeas, the property at 915 Third Avenue and 201, 203 and 205 East Fifty-fifth Street has been sold by May M. Lalor and George B. Fargis, as administrators of the estate of Mary C. Breslin, to Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators.

Two thousand students from the city's schools packed the Hunter College auditorium to heal the New York Philharmonic's second Spring concert yesterday. Walter Beckett, conductor, described the audience as "the most music-loving in the world and the best.

To judge from the comment one hears in the street, few elements have been so destructive of national morale as the vacillation and constant mind-changing of War Manpower Commissioner McNutt and Selective Service Director Hershey.

TOMMY HARMON'S plane has been reported missing in the South American area and sports fans everywhere are shocked at the news. For three whirlwind football seasons the Michigan halfback flashed across the consciousness of America as one of those supermen whom sports alone can create. Missing and dead? Perhaps.
The majority of "last minute" taxpayers were filing their State returns on 1942 income by mail yesterday, it became evident last night. The deadline for filing without penalty expired last midnight.
LONDON, April 15 -- Prime Minister Churchill defended the electoral truce in the House of Commons today as essential to national unity.

Possible challenge in the courts of the legality of OPA's rayon hosiery regulation No. 339 "which may mean the end of the OPA just as happened in the case of the NRA," was hinted yesterday at a special meeting to discuss the order held by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Convicted of the mugging robbery of a Bronx building superintendent, two men were sentenced yesterday in Bronx County Court by Judge Harry Stackell to prison terms. Although indicted for first-degree robbery the jury convicted the prisoners of second-degree robbery.

LONDON, April 15 (U.P.) -- The German High Command claimed today that seven British vessels, including two destroyers, were sunk or left sinking after attacks by German motor torpedo boats in the English Channel Tuesday night.

The primary function of motion pictures in helping to shape the post-war world will be in "promoting mutual understanding and sympathy" among peoples of all creeds and nationalities, Will H. Hays declared yesterday in his annual report to the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, Inc.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Fifteen men and women who have just resigned from Office of War Information Writers Division stated publicly today that they quit because it was impossible for them to tell the "full truth" and that domestic activities of the OWI were controlled by "high-pressure promoters who prefer slick salesmanship to honest information."

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The McKellar Federal job confirmation bill, which President Roosevelt once asserted would "turn the clock back" on the merit system, was recommended for passage today by the Senate Judiciary Committee with a declaration that "it lays no withering touch upon the merit system."

The Radio Corporation of America and the Rockefeller Foundation have disposed of their entire holding in the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation to a group headed by Dillon, Read Co., which began to reoffer the shares in the form of a secondary distribution soon after 4 P.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- "Education of student nurses should be financed by the Federal Government as a war emergency measure, like the education of other essential professional and technical students," Representative Frances P. Bolton of Ohio, author of a bill to subsidize the nursing profession during the war, declared today.

The Ballet Theatre last night devoted its program at the Metropolitan Opera House to repetitions of three of its most successful works of other seasons and the second presentation of Leonide Massine's "Capriccio Espagnol," which he has recently restaged for this company.

The gasoline supply situation in the city was so tight yesterday that many passenger car drivers and independent taximen had to shop around from service station to service station to redeem their ration stamps.

Consolidated Chemical Industries, Inc., reported yesterday in its annual statement for 1942, a net income of $1,044,253 after all charges, including Federal, State and Argentine income taxes, of $285,460 and $1,728,000 excess profits taxes.

FORT HANCOCK, N.J., April 15 -- Fort Hancock's baseball team was still without a victory after losing a six-inning clash on the post diamond today, 1 -- 0, to New York University, which gained its third straight triumph.

In response to appeals by retail lumber dealers for immediate price relief, Peter A. Stone, price executive of the lumber branch of the Office of Price Administration, yesterday appointed a committee of retailers who will meet with him today for the purpose of working out a basis for temporary schedules.

Detectives of the West Fifty-fourth Street station were confronted last night with a mysterious assault case that had them baffled. The only thing certain about it was that Mrs. Nancy Belcher, 50 years old, of 135 West Fifty-sixth Street, was in Roosevelt Hospital with her throat slashed.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, April 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commanding the Allied Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific, speaking for publication today for the first time since he returned from his mission to Washington, said:

LONDON, April 15 (U.P.) -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval has placed at the disposal of Fritz Sauckel, German labor chief for the occupied territories, the entire 1,250,000 French soldiers held as war prisoners, a French announcement reaching Madrid said today.

The first of the three performances of J.S. Bach's "Passion according to St. Matthew," which will culminate the present PhilharmonicSymphony season, took place last night under Bruno Walter's direction in Carnegie Hall. An impressive array of singers, choristers and soloists assisted in this performance, which was given without cuts, and sung in English, to an admirable translation of Picander's text by Henry S. Drinker of Philadelphia.

The statement by William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, in criticizing the Hanes Committee report, that the State equalization tables indicate New York City real estate is underassessed was characterized yesterday as "little short of a shocking attempt at distortion" by Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 15 -- It is now possible to disclose that Field Marshal General Albert Kesselring, paratroop expert, has been in command of the Axis land, sea and air forces in this area, holding a position similar to that of General Dwight D. Eisenhower in the Allied forces.

The Yankees and Giants, still licking their wounds from the trouncing both received from the Dodgers in the double-header on Wednesday for the benefit of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, were even deprived yesterday of such pleasure as they might have derived from taking out their feelings or each other.

CHUNGKING, China, April 15 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have advanced nineteen miles in the past twenty-four hours in a drive westward from their Northern Hunan Province stronghold of Hwajung and have recaptured a strategic center in Southern Hupeh, seized by the Chinese last week, it was announced today.

The Ringlings -- Robert, the president, Mrs. Charles and Mrs. Aubrey, vice presidents of the Big Show -- allowed memory to keep them company yesterday. Yesteryear's circus pattern stood out in bold relief.

LONDON, Friday, April 16 -The Moscow radio said today that in Russia "a small undisciplined minority is disorganizing the railway transport so vital in war time," and that as a result the Supreme Soviet has ordered all railways to operate under military law.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, April 16 (AP) -- A strong attempt by the Japanese to supply and man their base at Wewak, on the north coast of New Guinea, is under attack by General Douglas MacArthur's bombers.

The Nazi agency D.N.B., which transmits in Morse code to German domestic newspapers and radio stations, sent out a correction yesterday ordering editors to eliminate a reference to Adolf Hitler as "supreme commander of the armed forces" from a dispatch previously sent.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Seven American-born Japanese, four men and the wives of three, will arrive tomorrow from a Relocation Camp in Arizona to relieve the labor shortage created by the war on the home farm at Olney, Md., of Secretary Ickes, and that of Sam Rice, former outfielder of the Washington Baseball Club, who has 20,000 chickens on his place five miles away.

A medical service for injured workers in compensation cases, headed by Dr. Leo Eiserson, has continued in operation under the management of an "orderly," although the physician has been in the Army for eight months, according to evidence presented yesterday before Moreland Act Commissioner William F. Bleakley at the Bar Association.

War bond sales in the Second Federal Reserve District, excluding purchases by commercial banks, reached $2,250,000,000 yesterday noon, according to Allan Sproul, chairman of the War Finance Committee, which is directing the campaign in this area.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A conference with industry representatives to map out a hog ceiling program which can be invoked quickly if hog prices do not decline from present levels has been called for Tuesday by the War Food Administration and the Office of Price Administration.
ALBANY, April 15 -- The Court of Appeals, in a 4-to-3 decision, today declared unconstitutional the local law which prohibits itinerant peddling on New York City streets.

Net profit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the first quarter of 1943 was $42,344,538, or $2.27 a share, comparing with $43,707,993, or $2.34 a share, in the same period of last year. Dividends paid in these periods were $42,045,347 and $42,045,287, or $2.25 a share.

NEWARK, N.J., April 15 -Pretzel-bending, under a ruling handed down here yesterday by Major Howard Lepper, area director of the War Manpower Commission, is not a pursuit essential to the winning of a total war. As a result, Miss Vernet Witham, 19 years old, of Elizabeth, N.J., will leave her job in a pretzel factory to return to her former employment of stitching shirts for soldiers.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, April 16 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Office of Price Administration today placed under dollars-and-cents ceilings all hardwood lumber produced in the New England and Middle Atlantic States, and all species of soft wood lumber in addition to white pine produced in the New England States, Pennsylvania and New York.

Split into two sections, the Polydor six-furlong sprint for 4-year-olds and upward featured yesterday's racing at Jamaica with a $2,000 purse in each division. In spite of snow that fell heavily just prior to the first race, 13,378 spectators sent the mutuel handle almost up to another million-dollar total, moving $996,769 through the windows.

The increasing shortage of lumber will necessitate a lumber salvage program and the reusing of certain types of containers, G.A. Garratt, chief of the division of technical service training of the Forest Products Laboratory, Department of Agriculture, declared yesterday at the concluding session of the wartime packaging conference and exposition, sponsored by the American Management Association at the Hotel Astor.

With the announcement today of a campaign to recruit 800 canditates for training as practical nurses, the New York City Nursing Council for War Service, 654 Madison Avenue, emphasizes the importance of practical nurses in the war.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The showdown between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the $2,300,000,000 North American Company over the constitutionality of the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act failed today to materialize when the Supreme Court refused to hear arguments on the issue because of a lack of a quorum, although eight justices were on the bench.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., April 15 -- New Jersey anglers in traditional fashion greeted the opening of another trout season today. In many respects it was an unusual one, for, despite the inroads of war, enthusiastic fishermen were out early and returning home with their limit catch in many instances long before 9:30 A.M.
The financial position of the National Dairy Products Corporation is the best in its history, L.A. Van Bomel, president, declared yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- The Bank of England announced today in its statement of condition for the week ended yesterday that its note circulation had risen u3,983,000 in the week to a new high record of u943,494,000.

NORTH TUNISIAN FRONT, April 15 (U.P.) -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Minister of Propaganda, is the publisher of an eight-page, full-size outcroping of purported journalism called "Adler in Sueden" or "Eagle in the South." Nominally the responsibile party is a certain Lieut. Col. Kohl, with headquarters in Munich, but no one who knows the Goebbels touch can fail to detect it here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Robert Cummings has relinquished the lead in "Fired Wife," which went into production today at Universal, to return to duty in the submarine command of the Civilian Air Patrol. Robert Paige, who has been under contract at that studio for two years, will play the role.

The Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities have agreed to merge into a single organization, officials of the two organizations announced last night.

ALBANY, April 15 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Di Costanzo bill continuing the New York City emergency rent laws until July 1, 1944, and the Moritt bill, making aliens eligible, for the first time, for old age assistance and assistance to the blind.
A new meat shortage was developing in New York City as the potato famine became more acute. The shortage in poultry continued. [1:1.]

Yesterday was the day of days -- for this year -- at the High School of Music and Art. It was the fifth annual concert of original compositions by the school's budding geniuses. But there were two significant departures from the rule which established -- as 13-year-old Kathy Franklin said -- "that progress is here to stay."

Purchasers of seats on the New York Stock Exchange are likely to be quite as ticklish as buyers of stocks. Time after time, as prices of seats have dipped, prospective buyers have run away, putting in new bids at lower levels. On the records of the Exchange are the figures of one bidder who started out in 1936, when the range was $174,000 to $84,000, with a bid well below the market.

Half silvers of the American National Fur Breeders Association brought a top of $35 at the sale conducted by Lampson, Fraser Huth, it was reported yesterday. One-quarter silvers sold up to $25, and one-eights and darks to $17. Prices realized were above the March levels.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15 (AP) -- Increasing German pressure was reliably reported tonight to have forced the government of Finland near to a crisis last week-end amid indications that a political shake-up, especially among proGerman officials, was pending in Helsinki.

New York City school children, for the first time in many years, will not get their customary Easter vacation this year. As a fuel saving measure, the Board of Education closed the schools for the week of Feb. 1 and announced at that time that the Easter holiday would be discontinued.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- Though considerable liveliness was reported today from several sectors of the front, the news in general confirmed an editorial in the army newspaper Red Star, declaring that the army's principal occupation now is preparation for future battles.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 15 -- British infantry, scaling a 2,204-foot height under heavy enemy mortar and light arms fire and employing pack-mules to bear their equipment, have retaken Djebel el Ang and Heidous, key points near the Medjez-el-Bab to Tebourba road that leads to Tunis.
Four teams won their way last night to the semi-final round of the tournament at the Hotel Pierre for the national contract bridge team-of-four championship and the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup.

Miss Anne C. Delafield Finch, daughter of Judge Edward R. Finch, has purchased for occupancy the three-story dwelling at 148 East End Avenue, facing Carl Schurz Park, from the estate of Franklin E. James. Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc., was the broker.

Bank clearings of the major cities of the nation in the week ended on Wednesday again topped the $9,000,000,000-mark for the second time this year. With the exception of the Feb. 4 week, the current total was the largest for any week since 1931, according to yesterday's report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

LONDON Friday, April 16 (U.P.) -- German infantry and tanks have been thrown back with heavy losses in counter-attacks designed to relieve the relentless pressure of the Red Army against the Kuban bridgehead, a Soviet communique reported today.

Ever since that institution at the Empire opened on Nov. 8, 1939, it has become traditional for the two mainstays of "Life With Father," Howard Lindsay and Dorothy Stickney (Mr. and Mrs. off stage as well as on), to take a holiday every Summer.

MONTREAL, April 15 -- Social insurance can play a dual role in the economic readjustment and reconstruction that will be necessary when the war ends, Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, declared here tonight at the conference of the Canadian-American Women's Committee on International Relations.

Major commercial fruit and vegetable growers from areas east of the Mississippi, gathering in New York for a meeting of the Fruit and Vegetable Cooperative Association, reported yesterday that they and their fellow-producers were confused and uncertain of how to reconcile destructive frosts, skyrocketed wage scales, OPA price ceilings and a continuing flow of discouraging official statements from Washington with the country's need for an abundant food supply.

A new silver fox pelt, the color of a natural blue with a silky overlay of silver, made its debut yesterday at the "Prelude to Easter" fashion luncheon in the Persian Room of the Hotel Plaza. It was developed by Fromm, 275 Seventh Avenue, who showed a short jacket made from skins of this new breed of fox.

Wage increases within the Little Steel formula and President Roosevelt's hold-the-line order were announced yesterday for 22,500 Consolidated Edison employes by Aaron Horvitz, chairman of the board of review which has been considering pay rises requested by the Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 15 (AP) -A communique:

LONDON, April 15 -- Germany's homeland war resources received shattering aerial blows from east and west last night. Russian planes set great fires in the Baltic supply ports of Danzig and Koenigsberg, while British bombers heavily blasted industrial Stuttgart.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Between now and the end of the year, industry must do some post-war planning and it must have its plans ready to get back into civilian business on a new and enlarged basis, B.B. Geyer, president and chairman of the board of the New York advertising agency, Geyer-Cornel Newell, asserted here today at the closing session of the National Wholesale Druggists Association Convention.

The six-story apartment house at 1422 Nelson Avenue, the Bronx, containing seventy-two apartments, has been purchased by Isadore B. Geller, operator, for cash over a first mortgage of $228,000. The property was held for $265,000 and is reported to have a gross annual rental of $38,500.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Organized labor's revolt against the wage "freezing" aspect of President Roosevelt's executive order of April 8 broke out in two quarters today.

For the first time since 1929 New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System have exhausted completely their excess reserves, it was revealed yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its weekly report, as of the close of business on Wednesday.

DETROIT, April 15 -- Discovery of an entire new class of chemical compounds for the treatment of syphilis, a new compound that effectively checks the growth of tubercule bacilli and is tolerated in large doses in human beings and a new approach to the treatment of malaria and other bacterial diseases were described today before the American Chemical Society.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 -- The Italian public -- which has long suspected, if it has not known, the worst -- was informed in no uncertain terms today that the situation in Tunisia was rapidly passing from the "gravely serious" to the "hopeless" in an official review of the fighting in that area since the crushing of the Mareth Line.

BENDIX, N.J., April 15 -- Striking members of the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers, C.I.O., today threw a picket line around the plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation here and continued the picketing started yesterday at the company's East Orange plant, where a sympathy strike is on.

The Board of Estimate authorized yesterday the appropriation of $50,000 for preparation of plans for the approaches of the proposed $60,000,000 Narrows Tunnel connecting Brooklyn and Staten Island. The board approved a fee of $30,000 to the firm of MadiganHyland, engineers, for planning the Brooklyn approaches and one of $20,000 to the same firm for studies, plans and specifications for the Staten Island approaches.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -The Great Northern Railway asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to issue a promissory note for $1,265,689 evidence of indebtedness under a conditional sale contract for the purchase of 500 seventy-five-ton ore cars at a total cost of $1,582,100.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A House Military Affairs subcommittee, headed by Representative Costello of California, charged in a report today that the Federal Government "and private industry to some extent" had been lax in setting up standards for filling their manpower needs from persons not eligible for the draft.
LONDON, Friday, April 16 (AP) -- The midnight Russian communique broadcast by Moscow an recorded by the Soviet monitor:
Spokesmen for dress manufacturers in this city declared yesterday that the industry could not afford wage increases at present without an easing of OPA regulations governing manufacturing costs.
CHICAGO, April 15 -- The largest cash corn business in many months and liquidation in wheat, oats and rye vied for market leadership today on the Board of Trade.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15 -Many textbooks on hygiene contain misleading statements on alcohol and many American school children are losing confidence in pleas for temperance because they are misinformed about alcohol's effects, a nation-wide survey, made by Anne Roe in the Quarterly Journal of Studies on Alcohol, published at Yale, said today.

Pocket Books, Inc., announce that their recent edition of "See Here, Private Hargrove" has broken all previous records for quick sales in Pocket Books. The long time record is still held by Dale Carnegie's "How to Win Friends and Influence People," with more than a million and a quarter copies sold in the small edition.

Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles declared yesterday that this hemisphere already has a "regional understanding," based upon the Good Neighbor policy, referring to the "regional councils" for Europe and Asia that Prime Minister Winston Churchill recently proposed as a basis for future international peace.

LONDON, April 15 -- The Fighting French National Committee met for the third and last time today to consider General Henri Honore Giraud's memorandum containing his formula for fusion. The result was a decision to send General Georges Catroux back to Algiers immediately to argue the urgency of an immediate meeting between General Charles de Gaulle and General Giraud.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- More than five years ago, the Dies committee reported today, Adolf Hitler and his Nazi party put into operation in the United States a "diabolical scheme" for spreading Nazism throughout the world.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Before deducting bank loans and funded debt assets of the Tri-Continental Corporation on March 31 were $31,843,927, against $25,619,063 on Dec. 31, 1942, and $22,453,667 at the end of March, 1942, according to the quarterly report just issued.
LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- The midday Russian communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor here:

The twenty-seventh annual exhibition and sale by the Society of Independent Artists will be held from May 5 through May 19 at the Hall of Art, 24 West Fortieth Street. Any one may become a member by paying the $5 membership fee, which must be received by April 24.
NEW YORK The Duchess of Richmond has arrived from Washington and is at the Ritz Tower.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 15 -- Munich "near beer" is among the latest items of which Berliners have been deprived under a general scheme to reduce civilian freight traffic by 50 per cent. Henceforth beer can be hauled not more than thirty miles from the brewery.

Snap beans dropped about 5 cents in price during the week owing to increased shipments from Florida and quality has improved considerably, according to the Consumers Service Bureau of the New York Department of Markets. Spinach and turnips also showed a slight decline; otherwise most vegetables are more expensive than they were last Friday.

Skiing of midwinter variety instead of the Spring type expected at this time of the year was reported yesterday in the popular resorts of the north. Manchester's Snow Valley, Rutland's Pico Peak and Stowe's Mount Mansfield, best-known Vermont points; Franconia Notch's Cannon and Lafayette Mountains and the White Mountain National Forest facilities of Mount Washington, New Hampshire's most popular areas, reported superb running.

The Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn has sold the twelve-story Medical Arts Building at 62 Hanson Place, corner of South Elliott Place, to the Norwegian Ministry of Commerce through the Social Welfare Committee for Norwegian Seamen in America, to be occupied as a home for Norwegian seamen.

LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- The Air Ministry News Service announced today that the reorganization of Allied air forces in the Mediterranean had been completed with division into three forces -- the Middle East Command, the Northwest African Air Forces and the Royal Air Force in Malta.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The question of Poland's frontiers with Russia arose on two fronts here today when Secretary of State Cordell Hull denied that President Roosevelt and Anthony Eden, the British Foreign Secretary, had agreed in their recent conversations on the desirability of restoring her pre-war boundaries, and the Polish Ambassador, Jan Ciechanowski, revealed anxiety over the prospects in a letter made public at his embassy.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- A plea that all the forces needed in the war against Japan be provided quickly was made by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Minister for External Affairs and Attorney General of Australia, in a radio address here tonight over the Columbia network.

In an address before the New York Rotary Club in honor of Pan-American Day, Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles added a footnote to Mr. Churchill's recent broadcast on the post-war order. Somewhat to the surprise of Washington, the Prime Minister sponsored the concept of a Council of Europe and a Council of Asia, in neither of which, it was quickly noted in this country, could the United States be properly included.
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The United States has invited the United Nations Governments and eight associated nations to send delegates to Hot Springs, Va., next month to discuss post-war food problems. This will be the first conference of its kind. It will set the pattern for other conferences during and after the war.
A luncheon and fashion show were given in the grand ballroom of the Pierre yesterday for the benefit of the women's auxiliary of the Greek War Relief Association at 730 Fifth Avenue.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 -Sotir Janeff, rabidly pro-German President of the Bulgarian Sobranje [Parliament] Foreign Affairs Commission, personal adviser to King Boris and editor of the semi-official Slovo, was shot dead in front of his home this morning.
ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) -- Even though Chet Laabs hit two more runs, the Browns barely emerged with a 6-to-5 victory over the Cardinals in an exhibition today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Canada has been shipping so much war material to the United States, and so severely curtailing her purchases of all but essential civilian products here, that she may soon have to "water down" the Hyde Park agreement or take other means to prevent the accumulation of too much American exchange.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Immediate studies of all essential civilian industries to discover and fill their material and supply requirements are planned by the War Production Board in cooperation with representatives designated by each industry affected, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the WPB, said today.

MONTREAL, April 15 (AP) -- Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, said tonight that in some occupations women workers "have far outstripped the production records of men formerly doing that work."

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Ten more aerial attacks on the growing Japanese air base at Kiska, which inflicted damage on the runway and on beached float planes, have been carried out by Army bombers and fighters, a Navy communique reported today.

The American Red Cross War Fund drive reached $12,247,000 yesterday, still short by $673,700 of the $12,920,700 goal set for New York City. To date, 1,850,000 persons have made contributions and of these 350,000 individual offerings were made in the last ten days.
CHUNGKING, China, April 15 (UP) -- A Chinese communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 15 -- German naval experts concede the Allies a total of 21,000,000 tons of available shipping and make that estimate the basis for predictions that the race between Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz's U-boat packs and American and British shipyard performance will leave the German, Italian and Japanese coalition victor on the seven seas.

A large subscription has been enlisted for the Spring tea dance in behalf of the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals, which will be given tomorrow at the Stork Club b a group of this season's debutantes. Miss Tricia Hurst, a Nurse's Aide at the hospitals, heads the executive committee for the dance.

A resolution calling for the awarding of the gold medal of the New York Southern Society to Mme. Chiang Kai-shek was unanimously adopted last night at a meeting of the society in the University Club, 1 West Fifty-fourth Street.

Gradual rather than revolutionary changes in post-war products and services are expected by industrial managements to lead to the highest living standards America has known, according to a cross-sectional report on post-war plans of industrial companies announced yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers.

MUNCIE, Ind., April 15 (AP) -The Pirates leaped on Lefty Hal Newhouser for 5 runs in the sixth inning today and easily beat the Tigers, 5 to 1, behind the steady pitching of Johnny Lanning, Lloyd Dietz and Rip Sewell.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended April 10. At 103.5 per cent of the 1926 average the all-commodity index was 5 1/2 per cent higher than at this time last year.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 15 -- Following up General Douglas MacArthur's statement of yesterday expounding the principle that land-based aviation and not naval power is the governing factor in the forward movement of a military force in the island warfare now being fought in the Western Pacific, the general's spokesman today carried his commander's probing into the Southwestern Pacific war situation a step further.

The spiritual problems rising from the migration of 20,000,000 workers throughout the country provide one of the greatest challenges faced by churches today, the Rev. Dr. Frederick Zimmerman, secretary of the Board of Domestic Missions of the Reformed Church in America, declared yesterday at the meeting of the Women's Board of Missions of that denomination.

Two last-inning Columbia errors enabled Fordham to shade the Lions, 3 to 2, yesterday as the rivals launched their Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference campaigns in a wintry setting on wind-swept Fordham Field.

NEWARK, N.J., April l5 -Jersey's quota of $455,617,000 in the second War Bond drive already has been exceeded by two of its twenty-one counties, it was announced here today by John E. Manning, State Administrator of Bond Sales.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- A plan of the United Gas Improvement Company to exchange its holdings of common stock of the Erie County Electric Company for common stock of the Eastern Shore Public Service Company, a subsidiary of the General Gas and Electric Corporation, was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Garment Box Manufacturers Association, whose members all are in New York City, to cease operating a plan whereby they had allegedly fixed and maintained prices for garment boxes.

Mayor La Guardia put this city's private mansions into the museum class yesterday. While tapping pollard oak doors and carved paneled walls on an inspection tour of the old Whitelaw Reid mansion at 451 Madison Avenue, he predicted a "new era" in housing.

LONDON, April 15 -- Some friends of Britain in the United States still show a complete lack of understanding of what the empire means to Britons, it was declared in the House of Commons today by Sir Leonard Lyle, Conservative.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An Army heavy bomber caught a Nazi U-boat on the surface of the Caribbean Sea and destroyed it with depth charges, and, ten days later, a United States destroyer picked up a member of the Nazi crew who survived the attack, the Navy disclosed today.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Increased demand for chemists was reflected last night by recent graduates participating in a symposium on "intervewing and employment of chemists," who emphasized at a meeting of the New York chapter of the American Institute of Chemists that they, rather than the companies, were assuming the initiative in pre-job interviews.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 16 -- Of all rationed products, the one which American families find it hardest to cut down on is meat.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Placing restrictions on the use of gold and palladium by large manufacturers of jewelry the War Production Board admitted today that the curbs were not intended to conserve metal but rather to force release of needed facilities and workers for war production.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- Country grain dealers turned loose a flood of cash corn today and sales of around 1,250,000 bushels for deferred shipment were reported on the Board of Trade. This amount, said to be the largest single day's business in a long time, is understood to cover only part of the purchases.

Action of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee yesterday in refusing to recommend continuance of the President's nine-year-old power to devalue the dollar, although favoring continuation of the $2,000,000,000 Stabilization Fund, was applauded generally in financial circles here yesterday.

Millions of women will take war jobs when their communities provide child care centers, transportation and other community services, but the job of convincing many women in the United States that they are needed in "every kind of job that keeps the wheels turning in wartime" has yet to be done, according to a pamphlet issued yesterday by the Public Affairs Committee, a nonprofit educational organization.

A special Easter sale, opening on Monday and continuing through the week, will be held at the permanent gift shop of the Metropolitan Division of Bundles for America, 684 Madison Avenue. The mart specializes in gifts for men in the armed forces, and its stock for the sale will be augmented by other articles suitable as gifts for all occasions, including perfumes, china, garden utensils and train baskets.

MADRID, April 16 -- General Count Francisco Gomez de Jordana, the Foreign Minister, made it known today that Spain was ready to offer her good services in the interest of a speedy and just peace and to collaborate in the negotiation of treaties that would lessen the danger of future wars.

LONDON, April 16 -- Rabbi Irving Miller, Secretary General of the World Jewish Congress who has arrived in London from New York, said today that the time had come for an earnest and effective effort to save the Jews in Europe from total destruction.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 -- Jacques Mornard, alias Frank Jackson, confessed killer of Leon Trotsky, today was sentenced to a total of twenty years. The sentence was on two counts, nineteen years and six months for premeditated murder and six months for illegal bearing of weapons.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 16 -- Two British destroyers met two Italian destroyers off the Sicilian coast last night and sank them, Admiral Sir Andrew Browne Cunningham, Allied Naval Commander in Chief in the North African and Mediterranean theatres, announced laconically today.
DADDY," asked my daughter Elizabeth when she looked at the cartoon on the cover of Harold L. Ickes's "The Autobiography of a Curmudgeon,"* "does that man eat people? Is he a cannibal?"

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Prompted by the resignation of fifteen writers from the Office of War Information, Senator O'Mahoney today introduced a resolution demanding a complete inquiry into the policies of government agencies disseminating war news. Presentation of the resolution was regarded by many as making it almost certain that OWI will be investigated.

Michel Fokine's "Russian Soldier," to the music of Prokofieff's "Lieutenant Kije" suite and with setting by Mstislav Dobujinsky, received its first performance of the Ballet Theatre's Spring season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

A committee of New York retailers will assist the Boy Scouts of America, recently designated as the official couriers of the United States Government, in the administration of an important phase of home-front war activities, it was announced yesterday.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

DETROIT, April 16 -- The promise of a vast new reservoir of manpower, now going to waste through absenteeism, was held out today at the closing sessions of the American Chemical Society, with the announcement of four new types of sulfa drugs that have already reduced by more than 50 per cent the loss in man-days due to the common cold at the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The Mitchell bill, fixing a maximum limit of $1,000,000 upon which Sheriff's poundage may be computed, was signed today by Governor Dewey, who said there was no justification for huge poundage fees "for performing no greater service than delivering a paper."

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- New slate-gray Summer working uniforms for officers, designed to replace the present khaki uniforms and to "provide greater protection to forces afloat," were announced today by the Navy Department.

CHAOUACH VILLAGE, Northern Tunisia, April 16 (AP) -- Artillery-supported British infantrymen battled the Germans today in a range of hills from which the promised land of the Eastern Tunisian coast is visible on a clear day.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull denied vehemently today that the reciprocal trade-agreements program had been used to encircle Germany and had forced that country into war.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, April 17 -- The Japanese convoy of nine ships that attempted to land at Wewak, New Guinea, has fled beyond Allied bomber range after two of the merchantmen were sunk, the High Command announced today.

ATLANTA, April 16 -- Governor Ellis Arnall presided at the opening today of a two-day session of a hundred delegates of the Southern regional conference of the Council of State Governments. Criticism was voiced against the Federal Government and Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York.

A nation-wide campaign to obtain pledges from the estimated 250,000 British subjects in this country for donations to the Red Cross Blood Bank for the armed forces of the United States, was launched yesterday at a meeting in the Bank of Manhattan Company' building at Madison Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

The attention of the Bureau of Naval Personnel has been directed to the Book Review section of THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 4, and particularly to the right hand columns of page 4 of that section, "Lessons In Command," consisting of book reviews of "Officer Candidate School" and "The Naval Officer's Guide."

LONDON, April 16 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden met the Foreign Ministers of Allied governments today and told them more intimately than he could tell Parliament the results of his talks in Washington and Canada and heard their views.

The Second War Loan drive slowed down in New York City yesterday with a reported advance of $110,000,000, while Allan Sproul, chairman of the War Finance Committee in this district, and Treasury Department spokesmen in Washington emphasized that the drive was entering its tougher phase of reaching the small investor and ordinary citizen.

John Barbirolli, former conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, has been appointed permanent conductor of the Halle Orchestra of Manchester, England. His duties will begin July 1 as the sixth permanent conductor that the second oldest English orchestra has had since its foundation in 1857.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

ANDREANOF ISLANDS, Alaska, March 31 (delayed) -- The Japanese are "stronger than ever on Kiska and Attu," returning Army pilots reported after bombing the enemy bases in the Aleutians for the thirtieth time in March at a twenty-five-foot elevation.

IRVINGTON, N.J., April 16 -- Judge Frederick D. Masucci of the Second District Court awarded $300 today to Mrs. Geraldine McNair of 191 Avon Avenue, Newark, in her suit accusing her landlord, Benjamin Packin of 35 Madison Avenue, also Newark, of overcharging her for her five-room apartment in violation of the rent-freezing order effective in Northern New Jersey war production areas last year.
CHUNGKING, China, April 16 (U.P.) -- A Chinese communique:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- In carrying out hundreds of successful missions of destruction in the European and Southwest Pacific war theatres six bombardment groups of the Army Air Forces have shot down 558 enemy planes since going on combat duty, the War Department revealed today.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- While members of a C.I.O. affiliate were called upon to abandon a strike against the War Labor Board's first decision under President Roosevelt's "hold-the-line" order, the C.I.O. members of the board today issued an opinion declaring that the case "is an example of the injustice caused by applying" the executive order "as now written."

The news coming out of Europe is oddly contradictory. As the siege lengthens and the hour for deciding the fate of the Continent draws near, it is natural that these contradictions should increase and multiply. Whatever else they signify, they sound a warning that the armies outside the gates have been a long time coming and meantime things have been happening in the dark that can only be sensed or guessed at.

Twelve, including Count Fleet, are named for the $25,000 added Wood Memorial Stakes today at Jamaica, where the crowd and betting are expected to set the peaks for the meeting. There had been a disposition in some quarters to hold that the prowess of Count Fleet would scare away competitors and make for a small field, but quite the opposite occurred.

Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel granted yesterday a motion directing John E. Varley as trustee to make a distribution of $500,000 to participation certificate holders of the Federation Bank and Trust Company and providing for the appointment of a referee to supervise the distribution.
