WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Spurred by a call from Speaker Rayburn for early action on pay-as-you-go taxation, Republican and Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee met tonight in the first show of cordiality since the floor tax fight two weeks ago and made progress toward reporting a compromise tax measure to the floor next week.

Serge Rubinstein, international financier, was arrested Tuesday by immigration authorities and is at liberty under bond of $1,000, awaiting a hearing on allegations that he entered this country by means of a fraudulent passport, it became known yesterday. The charges, if substantiated, could lead to the entry of an order of deportation, to be carried out when foreign travel becomes possible.

ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP) -- The world champion Cardinals climbed all over four Browns' hurlers for five doubles and a triple to win the fourth contest of the city series, 9 to 2, today as Mort Cooper went the route, holding the American Leaguers to seven hits.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 16 (U.P.) -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower, during his latest trip to the front, was under fire several times, once missing a bomb by only a few minutes, it was revealed today. He returned to his headquarters last night

LONDON, April 16 (U.P.) -- A British destroyer and sloop sank two German motor torpedo boats and damaged four others early yesterday morning off the east coast of England, the Admiralty announced today.

COS COB, Conn., April 16 -- More than 2,500 residents of this community stood in the cold today to watch Harold C. Powers, proprietor of the little Diamond Hill Machine Shop, receive the Army-Navy "E" award in a ceremony marked by the presence of Army and Navy officials industrial leaders and political dignitaries. James V. Forrestal, Under Secretary of the Navy, and Representative Clare Boothe Luce were the principal speakers.

Making his annual report to the directors of The Associated Press in session here yesterday, Kent Cooper, general manager of that news-gathering organization, said that "the great stories of the war have been told graphically, truthfully and comprehensively by the greatest array of reportorial eyewitnesses The Associated Press has ever had in wartime."

It will be no easy matter for holders of gasoline ration A books to obtain B books as a means oil making up part or all of the 50 per cent cut in the basic ration that went into effect last month, the Office of Price Administration let it be known yesterday.

LONDON, April 16 -- Following German reports of the discovery of the corpses of 10,000 Polish officers who were Soviet war prisoners massacred by the Russians near Smolensk in 1940 -- the Polish War Minister, Lieut. Gen. Marjan Kukiel stated tonight that the Polish Government had suggested an impartial investigation by a Red Cross commission on the spot.

WILLEMSTAD, Netherlands West Indies, April 17 -- The company's activities are directed more and more toward the United Nations' war effort, the management of N.V. Philips Gloeilampen Fabrieken, Dutch incandescent lamp and radio manufacturer, announced in a report for the fiscal year ending on April 30, which was approved yesterday by a general shareholders' meeting held here.

THE Indians were playing an exhibition game with the Pirates and Cleveland had runners on first and second. Obviously, the situation at the time called for anything except a double steal. On the next pitch, however, the two Indians broke for the next base. One was thrown out at third and a promising rally choked off.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administrator, has recommended a general crude-oil price increase averaging 35 cents a barrel, he told the House Small Business Committe today.

Dr. Alan Valentine, president of the University of Rochester, told the American Society of Chartered Life Underwriters yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that realization of the four freedoms "would cost every American so much money that most of our present economic elbowroom and nearly all of our private enterprise system would have to vanish."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 16 (U.P.) -- Germany has concentrated strong forces on the Arctic front, apparently as a safeguard against an Anglo-American invasion as well as against a Russian offensive from the Murmansk area, Swedish correspondents reported today in dispatches sent during a conducted tour of the line along the far northern Finnish-Russian frontier.

The plea on behalf of the average-sized basketball player voiced by Willoughby W. Albin in THE TIMES last Saturday deserves commendation. Several of the points he made in counseling against raising the height of the baskets from ten to twelve feet were well founded.
REIDSVILLE, Ga., April 16 -- Leland Harvey and Forrest Turner, will-o'-the-wisp Georgia convicts, led twenty-two other prisoners in a daring break from the White Marble State penitentiary today.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 16 -- Corporal Ronnie Williams of Detroit, now stationed at Camp Butner, N.C., advanced to the thirty-six-hole final round of the forty-third annual North and South amateur golf championship today with a 3-and-2 victory over John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y.

Only $1,255,000 of new municipal bonds will come up for award next week, in line with the general plan to keep municipal and corporate financing at a minimum during the present Second War Loan Drive. This total compared with this week's figure of $3,654,707, according to the Daily Bond Buyer, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $18,566,636.

BALTIMORE, April 16 (AP) -- A crowd of 10,415 turned out at Pimlico today to observe the bicentennial of organized racing in Maryland and to watch an experimental card of eight races which started at the unusually early hour of noon.

LONDON, April 16 -- From many parts of Europe today came reports indicating that the Axis was rushing preparations for an Allied assault The most notable was a proclamation by Premier Mussolini declaring that Sicily, Sardinia, Pantelleria and Lampedusa, island bastions guarding the Italian mainland, would be operational areas.
Cold weather canceled the game at the Polo Grounds yesterday between the Giants and Dodgers for the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, but the Brooklyn club came up with a news item of some interest.

An investor represented by Herbert Charles Co. has purchased the nine-story and penthouse apartment building for seventy-five families at 25 West Sixty-eighth Street from the Ed and Al Frieidman Realty Company, the original builder.

There will be one closing on Broadway tonight and two on the road. The local casualty is "Counterattack," which terminates its run at the Adelphi Theatre after having played eighty-four performances, divided between that house and the Windsor.

The teams of the Mayfair Bridge Club and of the veteran Waldemar Yon Zedtwitz won their matches last night in the semi-final round of the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup contest for the national contract bridge team-of-four championship at the Hotel Pierre.
As a part of its Easter program, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will place on exhibition today at The Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park a rare medieval sculptured lintel given by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

Two naturalized citizens of German origin were sentenced yesterday to terms of fifteen years in prison by Federal Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Brooklyn for transmitting war information from the United States to Germany. They were Paul Hermann Karl Grohs, 47 years old, of 91-11 90th Street, Woodhaven, Queens, who had pleaded guilty, and Frank Heinrich Wilhelm Grote, 41, of 946 East 181st Street, the Bronx, who stood trial and was convicted.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The State Board of Bar Examiners, composed of John Kirkland Clark, New York; Philip J. Wickser, Buffalo, and John T. DeGraff, Albany, announced today that out of 478 applicants for admission to the bar on Feb. 24 and 25, 265 had passed.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The United States Navy, greatly enlarge since Pearl Harbor, now is composed of seven fleets, Secretary Frank Knox revealed today in announcing sea commands for the four officers nominated for the rank of commodore under a new Navy regulation re-establishing that rank.

Investment banking activities were virtually at a standstill here this week as dealers and underwriters centered their efforts on making the Second War Loan Drive a success. No new issues of corporate, State or municipal bonds were offered to the public in the week, making it the first period of lapse since the week ended Feb. 19.

The American correspondents listed by OWI the other day as dead in line of duty would have been the last to claim any special merit for what they were doing. They died in accidents, by disease and by enemy action. The dangers they faced were no more and no less than those encountered by the survivors.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16 --Yale's nearest approach to the historic social week of peacetime days was begun tonight with the presentation of Shakespeare's historical play "Henry IV" by the united Dramatic Association and the School of Drama of the university and by the Spring concert of the glee club.

Two great fund-raising organizations for Jewish charities, one serving Brooklyn and Queens, the other Manhattan and the Bronx, have just merged to form "the largest single philanthropic structure of voluntary medical and social welfare agencies for meeting local needs in the world."

A pressure campaign to force the Book-of-the-Month Club, which has 600,000 members throughout the country, to withdraw its May selection, "The Fifth Seal," an English translation of the Russian novel by Mark Aldanov, was disclosed here yesterday.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange last month rose 111,000 shares, going from 663,750 on Feb. 26 to 774,871 on the March 31 settlement date, according to a report issued yesterday. Neither figure includes short interest in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

LONDON, Saturday, April 17 -- American heavy bombers hammered enemy U-boat bases and harbor installations at Lorient and Brest on the Breton coast in a daylight assault yesterday that was a high point in renewed around-the-clock Allied bombardment of strategic targets in Nazi-held Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Warnings that China cannot last another year without more air power and that the Japanese in the Aleutians are a growing menace to the American west coast were heard in the Senate today, but Senator Barkley, majority leader, replied that the war could not be won by strategy developed in the halls of Congress.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 16 -- Admiral Georges Robert, French Commissioner for Martinque and Guadeloupe, told The Associated Press in a letter received here today that fulfillment of the three following conditions would induce him to join the struggle against Germany:

Every Saturday this column suggests menus for the coming week that are built around the fresh fruits and vegetables that are fairly plentiful, that adhere strictly to rationing allowances and are simple to prepare. Although it has been the department's custom in the past to assemble them for four persons, we have received so many requests for meals for smaller families that we now plan for three.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House is expected to act next week on a controversy raised by the Bureau of the Budget over whether the War Shipping Administration rather than the Navy Department should control construction of an additional 1,000,000 tons of naval auxiliary vessels authorized recently by the House Naval Affairs Committee.

Some 20,000 refugees from France have managed to escape into Spain in less than five months, counted from Nov. 11, when the Germans overran the so-called "free zone" that they had allocated to Vichy in June, 1940. The exodus has worked up at an average of about 1,000 persons a week.

Many substitute packaging materials, which appear highly satisfactory under present conditions, will not survive a return to peacetime because of the changed conditions surrounding "shelf life," according to comment at the packaging exposition sponsored by the American Management Association, which closed yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

SANTA ANA, Calif., April 16 (AP) -- Private Joe DiMaggio's Spring training has been somewhat different this year and not much time is devoted to baseball at the Santa Ana Army air base, where he is stationed, but the Yankee Clipper hasn't lost his batting eye.

Having admitted the gradual embezzlement of $30,000, Virginia Johnstone Colgan, 28 years old, collapsed in Federal court yesterday when Judge John W. Clancy told her that her punishment would be eighteen months in prison.

A 17-year-old schoolboy confessed yesterday that he had assaulted a young married woman at Pleasant Plains, Staten Island, last February, a crime for which Alphonse Caruso, 34 years old, the father of four children, was convicted last March 15 and was about to be sentenced.

NORFOLK, Va., April 16 (AP) -- Two major steps incident to the reorganization of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company, which has been in receivership more than a decade, were taken today when Judge Luther B. Way of the Federal District Court issued two orders pertaining to the affairs of the company.

PERTH, Australia, April 16 (U.P.) -- Army Minister F.M. Forde said in a speech today that the Australian Government wanted not only to accumulate sufficient fighting strength to defend the country but to accumulate forces that would enable it to launch a great counter-offensive.

The Ruml plan of skipping one year's Federal taxes to put all taxpayers on a pay-as-you-go basis will "sooner or later" be adopted, Representative Frank Carlson of Kansas forecast last night in a speech before 100 business men at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Former Governor Alf M. Landon of Kansas said tonight that the manner in which Governor Dewey is meeting the New York State farm problem has attracted widespread interest and approval throughout the nation, particularly in the Middle West.
NEW DELHI, India, April 16 (AP) -- A U.S. Army Air Force communique:
CHUNGKING, China, April 16 (AP) -- Chinese troops killed, wounded or captured 600 Japanese in scattered, inconclusive fighting in various parts of China, the High Command said today.

TRENTON, April 16 -- Ration books worth 5,544,000 gallons of gasoline and ration sheets with an aggregate value of 10,000,000 gallons of fuel oil were stolen from the Trenton War Price and Rationing Board apparently some time Wednesday evening, Ralph W. Hackett, district OPA manager, reported to police today.

Town Hall was packed last night for the last of the four concerts of chamber music given in that auditorium by Adolph Busch and his colleagues. The size of the audience was the result of the preceding concerts of this series, devoted principally to chamber music of J.S. Bach, and in significant respects models of what Bach style in performance should be.

The announcement in Quebec of the end of a strike tying up two of the largest North American newsprint mills removed a new threat to United States newspaper supplies yesterday, according to The Associated Press, while high officials of war control agencies of the United States and Canadian Governments conferred in New York on the general paper situation.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 16 (AP) -- A communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 -- Floyd Hamilton, once a member of the Bonnie Parker gang off desperadoes in the Southwest, was found hiding in a storeroom at Alcatraz today, seventy-two hours after he was thought by officials to have been shot to death in a prison break.

The report of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and its subsidiaries, announced yesterday for the six months ended with February, shows a net profit of $4,855,475, or 6.32 a common share, in Canadian currency after deducting $7,053,941 for income and excess profit taxes.

Vegetable growers supplying the New York market, meeting here yesterday with Geoffrey Baker, price executive of the grocery products branch of the Office of Price Administration, subjected him to ninety minutes of questioning as to policies the agency intends to follow for the next several months and gradually elicited this picture:

ALBANY, April 16 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today the Wilson bingo bill which would have authorized local governing bodies, upon petition of 5 per cent of the community's voters, to issue permits for the operation of bingo games by religious, social or fraternal organizations.

One sentence, "There were no significant changes at the front," now runs like a refrain through the Moscow communiques. But as activity wanes on the ground it waxes in the air. Both German and Russian planes are driving deep into hostile territory. The Russian raids on Koenigsburg are reported to be the most destructive East Prussia ever had.

There seems to be no indication that any one perceives danger in the constant reiteration, particularly by government agencies, of the Four Freedoms. These are all worthwhile objectives for any society that is moderately civilized.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has bought the film rights to Victoria Wolf's novel, "Truth in Demand -- The Diary of an Army Nurse." The film will be produced by Robert Kane under the title "Salute to a Lady."

Theodore H. Silbert, executive vice president and treasurer of the Standard Factors Corporation, and Edwin B. Meredith, president of the Industrial Securities Corporation of Middletown, Conn., announced yesterday that stockholders of Industrial Securities had ratified a plan for the purchase of all their assets by Standard Factors at a special meeting held in Middletown.

An employe of the State Department of Labor attempted suicide yesterday morning shortly before he was expected to testify before the Moreland Act inquiry into the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law. It was learned later that the investigating commission was seeking explanation of the death in January of another prospective witness.

MOSCOW, April 16 -- A successful attack on a strong point marked yesterday's fighting in Lieut. Gen. Ivan Maslennikoff's revived offensive in the Kuban delta of the Western Caucasus. The Germans counter-attacked, but paid a heavy toll without regaining their lost ground.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Because steel-plate production had dropped appreciably since the recent disclosure by the Truman committee that the Carnegie-Illinois Company had supplied uninspected steel for war purposes, Chairman Donald Nelson of the War Production Board telegraphed plate mills throughout the country today not to "lean over backward" in inspection to a degree which would interfere with output.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today the award of 484 air medals and oak leaf clusters to air medals to officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Eigth Air Force in England.

Heartened somewhat by the continued silence in official quarters in respect to ceiling prices on cotton, other than the announcement early that no price clamp will be applied until the cotton trade has had the opportunity to express opinion in the matter, local cotton traders yesterday swerved to the buying side in late dealings in the futures market, erasing losses of 3 to 5 points and establishing gains up to 6 points.

Although anglers have been discussing the possibility of allowing the use of boats on some of the Putnam and Westchester County watershed lakes and reservoirs, it was learned last night that such an order already has been signed and boating will be permitted on some of the upper lakes.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- The Cubs made only two hits off three White Sox hurlers today but scored in the eighth inning without resorting to their bats to win, 1 to 0, before 2,424 fans at Wrigley Field.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A Navy communique announced today that Army bombers and fighters had struck eight more blows at the Japanese air base and camp on Kiska, but indicated by inference that, despite the heavy bombardments, the enemy might have made some progress in carving the airfield out of Kiska's rocky terrain.
BOSTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Red Sox blanked Harvard University, 21 to 0, today in a game postponed a day because of the weather and finally played despite it.

MOSCOW, April 16 (AP) -- The Russian Air Force, joining in the assault on Germany's war industries with a succession of heavy attacks on Koenigsberg and Danzig, is relying principally on four-motored, heavily armored bomb freighters -- probably having features similar to the Flying Fortresses, Liberators, Stirlings and Lancasters with which their Allies have heaped destruction on Adolf Hitler's workshops.

To raise funds for five organizations which are rendering special wartime services to members of the armed forces and their families, committees of the St. Bartholomew's Community House Club will present an original opera, "Florence Nightingale," in the auditorium of the clubhouse at Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street, May 3-7 at 8:30 P.M.

Rowing's abbreviated season will get under way early this evening with a triangular regatta among Rutgers, Princeton and Columbia over the Henley distance of a mile and five-sixteenths on the Raritan River at New Brunswick. This marks the first home regatta against major opponents for Rutgers since the New Jersey college took up the sport.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., April 16 -- The Post-Gazette asserted today that the Truman Senate committee's exposure regarding production of steel plates at the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's Irvin Works was a distorted presentation of facts because the inquiry was one-sided and incomplete.
Easter sunrise services this year will have a definite military air and, despite wartime restrictions, are expected to attract record turn-outs.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Asked at his press conference to comment on the statement at Barcelona of General Count Francisco Gomez de Jordana, the Spanish Foreign Minister, Secretary of State Cordell Hull recalled President Roosevelt's declaration at Casablanca for unconditional surrender.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- A national plan to consolidate the activities of all groups in America "who advocate this country's participation in a post-war system of collective security backed by force" was presented today to more than 600 luncheon guests of sponsors of the plan.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Statements made last week by Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and other labor officials that the country would soon be confronted with mass unemployment because more war goods of some types had been made than could be shipped or used, were denied today by spokesmen for the War Production Board.

A compromise agreement has been effected with about one-half of the 100 sub-dealers, who revolted yesterday and refused to meet a quarter of a cent a quart increase for the products of three dairy companies, and they will resume milk deliveries this morning, it was announced last night by Frank Sollento, president of Chesterfield Farms, one of the affected companies.

Sculptors, painters, illustrators and actors have always had to meet the technical problem of absolute evil exhibited in the human face. How does one paint, or make up for, the role of Satan, Iago, Richard III, Ivan the Terrible over the body of the son he has murdered?

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 16 -- As patrols of the powerful Eighth Army felt out enemy positions along the thirty-three-mile southern line anchored on Enfidaville today, British First Army forces in the north near Medjez-el-Bab and French forces on the western flank of the southern line beat off desperate Axis counter-attacks.
NEW DELHI, India, April 16 (AP) -- British troops ambushed two parties of Japanese in the Mayu Hills of Burma yesterday and inflicted casualties, a British communique said today.

The Victoria Home for the Aged in Ossining, N.Y., will benefit by a tea dance to be given on May 11 at Sherry's under the auspices of the Royal Standard Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire in the State. Misses Betty and Patricia Doyle are co-chairmen of the event.

If we can detach our minds for a moment from the immediate predicament, let us consider the ninth century B.C. It was disastrously cold and wet in Europe, with snow and ice the year round in the northern sections. On the other hand, the seventh century A.D. was warm and dry, presumably with light to middling westerly and southwesterly winds.

The proposal that Eddie Grant be selected for baseball's Hall of Fame, as advocated in THE TIMES last Saturday by the American Legion Post named in his honor, may have some merit, but I don't think much of the idea.

" Into the Valley," John Hersey's account of a Guadalcanal skirmish, published by Knopf and recently named the Council on Books in Wartime's second "imperative" book, will be one of the May releases of Pocket Books, it was announced yesterday.

Continuing his attack on the Hanes committee report, which said that declining trends in the city's manufacturing industries in recent years presented a serious problem requiring prompt community action to save further decline in the post-war period, Mayor La Guardia released a letter last night at City Hall from Robert Moses, Commissioner of City Planning.

Guy Cary of Shearman Sterling has been elected a director of the City Investing Company. He also is a director of the National City Bank of New York, the Home Insurance Company and the Southern Railway Company.

CAIRO, April 16 (AP) -- Liberators of the Ninth United States Army Air Force successfully attacked the Sicilian harbors of Catania and Palermo by daylight yesterday, a United States communique announced today.
LONDON, Saturday, April 17 (AP) -- The Soviet midnight communique, broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

CHICAGO, April 16 (U.P.) -- Lee Savold, Paterson, N.J., heavyweight, survived two early trips to the canvas and then came on to knock out them Franklin, Cleveland Negro, in 2 minutes 55 seconds of the eighth round tonight at the Chicago Stadium.

Yielding only two hits, Don Short registered his third straight shut-out as the St. John's Prep nine beat Loughlin, 17 to 0, at the Prospect Park Parade Grounds yesterday. It was the third victory in a row for the Redmen in the Brooklyn C.H.S.A.A. series.

Penny pinching "of the worst kind," reducing welfare services to children, has helped to produce the present tremendous increase in juvenile delinquency, Justice Justine Wise Polier of the Domestic Relations Court charged in an interview yesterday.

Trading turned more conservative yesterday in the stock market and prices on the Stock Exchange backed down moderately under the pressure of late profit-taking and the usual week-end adjustments. The snapback from the decline produced by the Interstate Commerce Commission's decision in suspending the rail freight rates increases had been so strong that broke welcomed the leveling off of the recovery, moderate as it turned out.

Bingo, not old enough yet to have its name registered in the dictionaries, has had a great vogue and roused a curious conflict of opinion. Its partisans and its enemies have seemed equally determined. It has been used largely for charitable and religious and other good purposes.

LONDON, April 16 -- In the stock markets here today home rails provided the chief interest. Buyers again were attracted by the high yields obtainable during the period of government control of the carriers, and a shortage of stock accelerated the rise in prices.

Retail sales here continued to show an increase this week over the comparative 1942 period, but the percentage increase was smaller than for the preceding week. Department-store volume was around 10 per cent or so higher. Fickle weather conditions and the inauguration of the Second War Loan were major factors during the week.
ALGIERS, April 16 -- General Henri Honore Giraud hopes to lead an army of 300,000 Frenchmen in the coming invasion of Europe and to plant the tricolor in the city of Metz, old capital of Lorraine.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 16 -- Deputy County Clerk John R. Longo, 29-year-old foe of Mayor Frank Hague, was dismissed today from his $6,500-a-year position by County Clerk William H. Gilfert, following his refusal to resign.
MONTREAL, April 16 -- Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor, toured aviation plants in the Montreal district today and investigated operation of the selective service office here.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Senate voted unanimously today to take from the President the power to devalue the dollar, which he has possessed but not exercised in the nine years since the devaluation of 1934.

ANNANDALE, N.Y., April 16 -- Senorita Rosa Oliver, vice president of the Union of Argentine Women, declared today in an address opening a conference of inter-American students at Bard College that Pan-Americanism would not work through propaganda but needed frankness in political and cultural intercourse between the Americas.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The House deadlock blocking pay-as-you-go tax legislation began to break up today as Republicans supporting the modified Ruml skip-a-tax-year plan and opposing Democrats agreed to seek a compromise.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- The Russsian noon communique as broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Soviet radio monitor here:

Lieut. Col. Walter W. Plechner, 40 years old, former member of the Chemistry Department at City College and nationally known as an industrial chemist, was killed in action in North Africa on March 4, it was learned yesterday at the college.
CHICAGO, April 16 -- Kenesaw Mountain Landis, 76-year-old commissioner of baseball, eased his feet down from his littered desk and fixed piercing eyes on his questioner.

DALLAS, Texas, April 16 -- Wee Ben Hogan returned to the links today to lead the Texas Victory open golf tournament field through the first eighteen holes. He rammed in a twenty-foot putt on the last green to finish with a 67, five under par.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 16 -- The formation of a political party sponsored by the government was duly authorized in a telegram that President Isaias Medina Angarita sent a State Governor and other officials last night.

The medical license of Dr. Edward Spencer Cowles, prominent psychiatrist, was suspended yesterday for one year by the State Board of Regents, which found him guilty of "fraud and deceit" in his conduct of his Body and Mind Foundation, a psychiatric clinic.

The Perkins-Steelman proposal to guarantee John L. Lewis's soft-coal miners a six-day week for fifty-two weeks was an attempt to give the union a substantial pay rise and still keep technically within the President's latest "hold-the-line" order. The inevitable effect of this proposal has come so quickly that it must have appalled even its authors.

The Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medal was awarded yesterday to Captain Alexander S. Henry of New York City in recognition of his quick action and heroic work under extreme difficulties which resulted in the saving of his ship after a severe bombing attack at Murmansk.

A total, of fifty-two contributions to the American Red Cross War Fund were announced yesterday by J.P. Stevens, vice chairman of the city-wide campaign, now in its last stages. The largest was $2,000 from the law firm of Willkie, Owen, Otis, Farr Gallagher, of which Wendell Willkie is the senior member.

Dr. John R. Steelman, director of the United States Conciliation Service and President Roosevelt's representative in the wage negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the coal operators, said yesterday that the deadlock was growing more serious with the approach of the May 1 deadline, when a strike is threatening only two weeks from now if a new contract is not signed by that time.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Navy communique 345:

Bishop William T. Manning will preach the Palm Sunday sermon at the 11 A.M. service tomorrow in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and his topic will be "The Eternal Glory of the Cross." The "Procession of Palms" will move through the length of the cathedral.

LONDON, Saturday, April 17 (U.P.) -- The Germans threw thousands of men and fifty tanks into battle in the Kuban yesterday in an attempt to regain a height of great strategic importance, but the Red Army emerged the victor after a day of bitter fighting in which the enemy lost heavily, a Soviet communique reported today.

The post-season performances at the Metropolitan Opera House were resumed yesterday afternoon when Gounod's "Faust" was presented as the season's third opera sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild for high school students of the metropolitan area.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 16 -- Dartmouth and Princeton split two closely contested games today, Ralph Bowman hurling the Indians to a 3-0 victory in the opener and John Eide gaining an even break for the Tigers with a 4-3 triumph. The double-header opened the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League season.

Alf M. Landon, former Governor of Kansas and 1936 Republican candidate for President, appealed last night in a radio speech for the establishment of a national war council to unify and direct America's contribution to winning the war and for the basing of post-war relations between nations on the fundamental, everyday virtues of honesty, integrity and responsibility that govern relations between individuals.

A great deal of attention has recently been devoted by various private and government agencies to the question of re-education of the Fascist nations after the war. Next to creating an economic system that will insure lack of incentive for aggression this should be the most important post-war problem.

Warner Brothers have announced plans to make "Destination, Tokyo," a pictorial account of the United States submarine, which sank a record member of Nipponese ships off the coast of Japan. The studio intends to use for the picture the entire cast of its current topical drama, "Air Force," with the exception of Arthur Kennedy and Gig Young, both of whom are now in the armed services.

Three former bellhops in the Forty-second Street Hotel, near Seventh Avenue, testifying yesterday at the Special Sessions trial of its two owners on charges of operating the place for purposes of prostitution, told of an alleged "check-off" there for prostitutes, reminiscent of the notorious "brass check" used forty years ago on the lower East Side.

To cover added costs of distributing advertised lines of women's rayon stockings, the OPA has been requested to include a suitable differential for branded lines in forthcoming amendments to MPR 339, Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, announced yesterday at the group's annual meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

E. Burd Grubb of Coggeshall Hicks entered the field yesterday as an independent candidate for the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Grubb, a former president of the New York Curb Exchange, has served two terms as a governor on the big board, the first running from 1937 to 1938 and the second from 1940 to date.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- An increase of 13 per cent in sales of independent retailers in March, compared with March, 1942, was reported today by J.C. Capt, Director of the Census. Dollar sales in March were 10 per cent over those for February.

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented an all-American concert last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York. A feature of the event was the first New York performance of the new Trio, No. 2, in A minor, by Heniot Levy, Chicago pianist-composer, which was played by the Henry Hadley Trio with Mr. Levy at the keyboard.
If any one can split hairs more deftly than a lawyer it is a barber. And when they joined forces yesterday they emerged with as neatly trimmed a contract as ever befuddled the innocent public.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (Science Service) -- Among the 603 inventions which won patents here this week was a blackout paint which can be easily applied to windows with brush or spray. It can be removed readily with a rag dipped in turpentine.

The Polish Institute of Arts and Sciences held a conference of food experts yesterday to discuss "The Nutritional Reconstruction of Poland," but the leading expert, Dr. Frank G. Boudreau, chairman of the food and nutrition board of the National Research Council, changed the subject to some extent by citing the needs of Americans for "protective foods to insure good health."

BALTIMORE, April 16 -- Eight Baltimore shipyard welders were accused today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of sabotaging vessels being built for America's war effort by doing faulty welding to earn money faster.

New York City hotel and restaurant owners were advised at a conference here yesterday with Office of Price Administration officials from Washington that they must "revise menus and push non-rationed dishes" in order to serve "a decent portion of ration foods" to customers.

Two lieutenants in the U.S. Naval Reserve, Joseph J. Lordi of the New York A.C. and Richard Berger of St. Louis, gained the semi-final brackets of the Red Cross handicap squash racquets tournament at the Yale Club last night.

Fears that essential home-front supplies of cotton textiles, already pinched by sizable military demands, may be reduced to a dangerous level were expressed yesterday by Worth Street suppliers as a result of new and attractive inquiries just received from the British Purchasing Commission for substantial quantities of utility fabrics for commercial uses.

The great reception given to the new metropolitan racing season by the large crowds visiting the Jamaica track during the past few days is highly significant beyond the fact that the fine turnouts further demonstrate the popularity of the sport.

SCARE buying and high income tax payments have combined to keep Easter trade within easy hailing distance of last year's figures. The latest comparisons with 1942 show substantial gains, but the late holiday this year means that peak business is ranged against the post-Easter slack period of twelve months ago.

THE discussion concerning knowledge of American history by college freshmen in THE NEW YORK TIMES suggests similar conditions in the field of musical history. Students know comparatively much more about recent music than its historic background.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- "A year ago, when American bombers thundered in Tokyo, the Japanese people were undoubtedly badly shaken," General Doolittle said in an anniversary statement to The Associated Press, issued here today.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP) -- Minus the flare and some of the enthusiasm of normal years, professional baseball makes its 1943 debut tomorrow with the opening of the Pacific Coast League.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- In allowing the bill that raised the debt limit from $125 billions to $210 billions to become law without his signature, the President assailed a "rider" on the legislation and the whole device of "riders." The particular one he attacked was a provision, affixed in the Senate, which specifically denied to the President authority he had claimed -- and used -- to limit all salaries after taxes to $25,000 a year.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 17 (AP) -- Delegations claiming to represent millions of workers in nine European countries, including Germany, announced today a framework for post-war reconstruction calling for a socialistic democracy based on a planned economy to replace nazism and fascism.

THE tropical islands of the South and Southwest Pacific have been swept with terrific suddenness from an isolated, backwater existence into the main current of human affairs by our war with Japan. Gay, easy-going Polynesians; stalwart, frizzly-haired Melanesians; New Guinea Negritos and Papuans in the last year have come into mass contact with whites and felt the full impact of the machine age of the outside world.

Shocked by the catastrophe that has befallen their co-religionists in Nazi-occupied Europe but with faith unshaken in the approaching downfall of Hitler, Jews in all parts of the world where freedom of worship still prevails tomorrow will begin at sundown observance of the festival of Passover, commemorating the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt.

PLAGUE SHIP -- Thanks to the vigilance of its municipal Health Department New York City has escaped a possible attack of the plague. Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins told a conference held in New York by the United Hospital Fund the story of a ship which arrived from Casablanca about two months ago.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Senate Foreign Relations Committee members tonight interpreted as "encouraging" from a United Nations standpoint the statement of Admiral Georges Robert, French Commissioner of Martinique, that the fulfillment of certain conditions would induce him to join the fight against the Axis.

NOT since the days of the Little Club, which flourished two decades ago where the Stage Door Canteen now functions, has Ralph Maurice been represented on the local night club scene. But on or about next Wednesday evening Mr. Maurice, who operates the Ross-Fenton Farms in Asbury Park, promises to return to the Broadway sector with a new club called Casablanca.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- After discussing simplification of testing procedures for steel plate designed to maintain maximum output of this war product without unduly lowering its quality a meeting of steel industry representatives and government officials today nominated a smaller group to formulate specific proposals.

ORRIN PIERSON'S 300 acres straddle the highway a little distance from the village. They lie in a sort of shallow earthen bowl and the bowl's rim, sharp against the Spring sky, is formed by Shawangunk Mountain and by lesser ridges of the Catskill foothills.

Captain Edge Rickenbacker, aviation executive, issued another warning yesterday concerning the need of eliminating avoidable absenteeism and of having "twice as many workers" enter war production throughout, the country. He made this statement after receiving a testimonial scroll from 500 employes of the Gilfillan Brothers' plant for the manufacture of aircraft parts in Los Angeles.
PRINCETON, N.J, April 17 -- Of all domestic problems of the war, the most difficult to solve has been manpower.

Checks for a total of $19,500 were distributed by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to representatives of social service divisions of city departments and a camp for underprivileged children. The checks represented the share allocated to the Mayor's Committee on Special Welfare Relief from the proceeds of last year's baseball game between the Police and Fire Department nines.

I am never surprised when somebody -- in fact everybody -- comes up and asks me: "How did you get along with Saroyan?" For the record, although we had exchanged a few telegrams and letters, I did not meet Saroyan until after I had written the screen play for "The Human Comedy" and the picture was more than halfway through filming.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- American publishers received a warning today from Donald Gordon, chairman of the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board, that they must further reduce their consumption of newsprint if Canadian exports plus domestic American production are to be expected to cover their needs.

AN ALLIED HOSPITAL BASE IN NORTHERN TUNISIA, April 15 (Delayed) (AP) -- A young British lieutenant lost his life today trying to remove one of a number of "butterfly" anti-personnel bombs dropped by an Axis night raider in a triangle formed by the Thibar Monastery and two Allied hospital units.

NO thinking person can take lightly the exposure by THE NEW YORK TIMES of the ignorance of college freshmen about important aspects of American history. The astonishment and distress expressed by prominent educators, leaders in Congress and other public figures prove that.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 17 (AP) -- Lieutenant Tommy Harmon, former football star at the University of Michigan, is safe after a plane crash in South America, the Antilles Air Task Force Headquarters announced today.

IN his lifetime, the vigorous, warm, masculine and gregarious personality of John Keats invited his contemporaries to know him better. Once they met him, they rarely were disappointed, despite the legend (fostered by the Quarterlies) that his character was "erratic, unlearned, exaggerated, despising proportion; morally weak, gluttonous, of bizarre taste."

The Greater New York Fund has set $4,500,000 as the minimum goal of its sixth annual campaign in behalf of 406 voluntary welfare and health agencies and hospitals, it was announced yesterday by W. Randolph Burgess, general chairman. The campaign will open May 3.

W. SOMERSET MAUGHAM compiled a book of "The Greatest Stories of All Time" (Doubleday Doran Co., $2.49) and wrote an introduction to it that has taken its place among the real contributions to literary selectiveness.

ERNEST NEWMAN has written thirty stories of operas (previously published) which cover the better part of the standard repertoire in French, German and Italian. "More Stories of Famous Operas" covers twenty-nine additional operas and has been most keenly awaited by music lovers.

Forecasts that the supply of steel for military, naval and shipbuilding needs soon will appear to have been more than amply covered and that metal will be available for non-essential civilian needs within the next six months, or less, are being heard here and in Washington, particularly in circles which are continuously in touch with the situation.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (U.P.) -- American women must take an ever-increasing part in production of arms to smash the Axis because "in a profound sense, it is a women's war," President Roosevelt said in a message tonight to the congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

NOTED artists of the opera, concert stage and the dance are donating their services to the "Parade of Stars," a gala performance to be given in aid of the Federation of Crippled and Disabled, Inc., on the night of April 30 at the Federation Concert Hall, 163 West Fifty-seventh Street.
The customary "official statement" by a league president on the eve of the opening of a new baseball season is a pretty silly thing at best. In these war-torn days it is doubly silly.
A BRAND new kind of literature has sprung up guide American women in participation in the war program. Here is a partial survey of the new books of this kind.

THE blurb on the jacket is right when it says that this is a "rather more pretentious novel" than the romances usually dished up by Mr. McCord. It is the first half of the book which digs deeper than usual.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- The White Sox saw the Cubs take a five-run lead in the first three innings today and then came back to win, 6 to 5, scoring the deciding marker with two out in the ninth inning and evening their formal city series at one game apiece.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 17 -- Complete responsibility for Radcliffe's program of instruction will be assumed by the Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences on July 1. In a joint statement issued tonight by President James B. Conant of Harvard University and President Ada Comstock of Radcliffe the Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences as an official body will supervise course offerings, assignment of instructors and recommendations for degrees of students enrolled in Radcliffe College.

IN the Sunday TIMES radio section of April 4 there appeared in the column "One Thing and Another" the statement that, due to the expected induction of some of the younger stars and the illness of several of their elder colleagues, the problem of uncovering new talent had been raised again.

A Japanese-made slide rule, absolutely precise but dropped on the American market to undersell domestic products, was an instrument in the successful bombing of Japan a year ago today. The story of that Nipponese product and its part in the raid came today from the field engineering section of Wright Aeronautical Corporation, of Paterson, N.J., builders of the Cyclone engines which power the North American B-25 bombers.

FLOWERS, like fashions, have their periods of popularity. This may explain why one of the most spectacular and charming perennials, which graced virtually every garden of note during our grandmother's time, had fallen into disuse and only recently began again to come into its lovely own.

OTTAWA, April 17 -- The three problems of food production and distribution, of wartime refugee immigration and of currency stabilization, which will be the subjects of international conferences during the coming weeks are all of primary interest to Canada.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The House today postponed until next week final action on its Appropriations Committee's recommendation that Federal aid to small farmers, sharecroppers and tenants be eliminated. Four days of dragging debate on next year's Agriculture Department Appropriation Bill had indicated the impossibility of passing the measure today.
Stockings that come in jars and bottles are literally pouring into the market, and all of the prophets predict a bare-legged Spring.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- Navy communique 346:

MEMBERS of the general committee headed by Mrs. H. Lawrence Bogert Jr., who are working to further the success of the performance of "Oklahoma" on the night of May 3 at the St. James Theatre for the benefit of the Children's Village will meet tomorrow at a tea to be held at the clubhouse of the New York Junior League.
CINCINNATI, April 17 -- In an address at the D.A.R. Congress today Governor Bricker pointed to the importance of the organization's role as one of the custodians of America's traditions and heritage.

AS of the moment and the forthcoming "Lady of Burlesque," Edward Francis Michael O'Shea (Eddie, that is) is firmly in the grip of the gods, and up in Hartford, Conn., where he came from, his children are proud as all get-out.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The text of the order by Manpower Commissioner McNutt regulating tire transfer of workers was as follows:

The power of the President to devalue the dollar further will lapse on June 30. That was made clear last week by the action of the Senate in refusing to vote the extension of this power, although approving continuance of the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund for another two years.
CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Today's review of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The final conquest of Tunisia will impose upon the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations the first major test of its ability to prevent suffering in an area freed from Axis domination.

IN "Turn of the Dial" Chard Powers Smith has given us a decidedly unusual novel -- if, indeed, one can call it that. It is clearly a number of other things. It is an outline of the changing views of the American public with respect to foreign policy from 1936 to the present.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- John L. Lewis's present role is an anomalous one. He is aloof from the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations and at the same time he is the spearhead of their efforts to keep President Roosevelt's "hold the line" policy from remaining a virtual wage "freeze."

LONDON, April 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commanding United States forces in the European theatre of operations, told interviewers today that he could not see a quick finish of the war or a sudden collapse of Germany, but he said strategy had been prepared by the military staffs of the Allied nations to hit the Axis European powers.

THE Chinese Government's Central Broadcasting Administration announces that its Spring schedule of transmissions calls for broadcasts beamed to North America between 10 and 11:30 A.M. on 9.635 and 7.171 megacycles.
DALLAS, Texas, April 17 -- Ben Hogan, who is starting at the bottom in the Army, ranked at the top today in Texas' Victory open golf tournament.

NOTHING in modern times is more dramatic and exciting than the development of wireless and radio, beginning when young Guglielmo Marconi, in his father's garden in Bologna, pressed a Morse telegraph key and discovered that metal filings behaved strangely under the effect of a certain electrical impulse.

Milk subdealers who went on strike last Friday against the Whitestone Farms Dairy, 1831 Coone Avenue, the Bronx, reached in agreement with company representatives yesterday and announced through Joseph Cappelli, a member of the dealers' negotiating committee, that milk deliveries to approximately 200,000 families in the Bronx would be resumed tomorrow morning.
Boat fishing will be permitted on some of the best waters in Putnam and Westchester counties, according to the order signed by Mayor La Guardia.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Senator Wagner, chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, said today he and a majority of his committee favored the Maloney bill to set up an independent Civilian Supply Administration.

Much of industry's uncertainty about the renegotiation of war contracts can be eliminated in 1943 by a "tightening up" in administrative policies and wider adoption by procurement officers of "forward pricing" contracts along with three other types of simplified transactions, it was indicated yesterday by price adjustment officials.

THE United States has one of the best theatres and some of the most talented playwrights in the world, but this theatre and these authors are still unknown to the vast South American public, who can see their work only in the movies, where it is usually disfigured and altered.

HAROLD L. ICKES has proposed a peace plan and true to character wants to fight for it. He uses seventeen chapters of "The Autobiography of a Curmudgeon" to tell how he became "the snarlingest creature that ever went to bed with his boots on," and at times is a bit dismal in doing it.

BALTIMORE, April 17 -- Miss Judy Johnson of Washington, D.C., received a steeplechase jockey's license today, marking the first time in Maryland racing history that a member of her sex has been made a bona fide professional rider.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, April 18 (AP) -- The noon communique:

CHICAGO, April 17 -- Grain markets developed a distinctly firm undertone today on the Board of Trade, due as much to lack of pressure as to aggressive buying. Mills were on the buying side of wheat futures and the close was 5/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel higher than yesterday.
Setting: A New York apartment house and an inn somewhere in Connecticut.

DAFFODILS are spreading a golden carpet on the banks of English streams. Hawthorns are in bloom and forsythia is reflecting the furtive rays of the English sun. It is Spring again in England and such a Spring as has not been seen here since that paradoxically grim one three years ago when the Nazis rode roughshod over the Low Countries and France while nature smiled benediction upon this lovely land.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 17 -- The possibility of bringing out what the British delegation previously had called "potential refugees" from occupied countries will be surveyed when the Anglo-American talks on the international refugee problem opens on Monday, Harold Willis Dodds, chairman of the American delegation told a press conference today.

THERE being nothing exactly cosmic on the calendar this morning, consider the astonishing popularity, on the current airways, of the old joke. Not the old joke that is treated to what technicians call the "switch," in the fond hope that it will have the tinsel look of newness, but the honestly old joke, unashamed of its antiquity.

Belgians in Britain will be aided by a program of American Indian folklore to be given on the night of April 29 at the home of Mr. and Mrs. W. Hamilton Russell, 63 East Ninety-third Street, by Te Ata, American Indian diseuse.

SANFORD TOUSEY, whose Cowboy Tommy stories and other books have so often proved a boon to youngsters whose interests have outstripped their reading ability, can be depended on to tell in direct, swiftly moving fashion a story full of actuality and well supplied with authentic details.

DESPITE the cold April, New York City's 700 parks have started their Spring and Summer programs. Like fellow-countrymen in less congested cities and towns across the land, New Yorkers enjoy the sight of green things growing, and the city is well prepared to gratify their wishes.

Great Britain has been studying its Stock Exchange and has concluded that their efficient maintenance is necessary to the national effort. It also has studied banks and insurance companies to see where manpower may be saved, and a special committee has recommended that insurance companies be limited in their attempts to get new business or to switch policies.
LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

EACH evening when dusk falls over this white city by the Mediterranean a tall, spare figure paces the terrace of a white-walled palace high in the hills above Algiers. Before he returns to his work General Henri Honore Giraud, French civil and military commander in North Africa, turns and gazes northward across the Mediterranean toward France.

NOW, when more and more tasks are waiting for women, and when new professions are opening their gates to them, Americans will perhaps be interested to hear what Englishwomen are doing in horticulture, a field in which American women have not been particularly active so far.

Turning in a well-rounded performance, Bob Swenning of the Skating Club of New York, captured the men's senior crown in the feature event of the twenty-second annual Middle-Atlantic figure skating championships at the Iceland Rink yesterday.

Newspaper editors and publishers from all over the country will gather here this week for the annual meeting and luncheon of The Associated Press, which will be held tomorrow, and the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association from Tuesday to Thursday inclusive.

THE hardly novel contention that the Second World War started, not in Poland in 1939 but in Spain in 1936, is the thesis of this book by an English newspaper correspondent who was in Barcelona when the first shots were fired and was still there when General Franco's troops marched in three years later.
COWBOYS working on J.A. Broderick's big spread leased from the Choctaw Nation in old Indian Territory:

CHICAGO, April 17 -- The machine tool industry, busy since 1940 in war production, now is threatened with operating at a loss, says an expert in the field who has completed a survey for the War Department. The survey was by A.G. Bryant, Chicago manufacturer, member of the WPB advisory committee, and a director of the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

DETROIT, April 17 -- War industry in the Detroit arsenal now employs 605,000 persons, a "conservative" estimate, according to the Detroit district office of the War Manpower Commission. This figure, based on employers' reports, represents an increase of 14,000 over February and 27,000 over January.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Possibility of developing "war model" shoes or utility types of shoes was the chief topic discussed at meetings of the shoe manufacturers industry advisory committee and the shoe retailers industry advisory committee and WPB officials in Washington this week.

Those scholars and classicists of the New York Athletic Club's Yachting Department who during the Winter months brush up on their mythology are going to do something about it this afternoon at Travers Island at 4 o'clock.

In praising Prime Minister Churchill's suggestion of a Council of Europe and a Council of Asia under a world institution, Mr. Hoover and Mr. Gibson in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of April 4, and various of our commentators in other places, assume that such regional organization is what Mr. Churchill would prefer.

" POUDING the Beat" is no longer confined to New York's finest. Khaki-uniformed, visor-capped women volunteers attached to the City Patrol Corps are now on day and night duty at Grand Central Station, working closely with the policemen stationed there.
MOSCOW, April 17 -- Heavy fighting continues in the Kuban delta, accompanied by air battles over the Western Caucasus between the Kerch Strait and Krasnodar.

NEWARK, N.J., April 17 -- Soon after the National C.I.O. Committee for American and Allied War Relief had announced here today that the C.I.O. had collected more than $7,000,000 for the Red Cross, its authorization was sought to allow one C.I.O. unit, irate because the Red Cross had featured Captain Eddie Rickenbacker in a motion-picture trailer, to rescind a $25,000 pledge to that organization.

Earnings of the Allegheny-Ludlum Steel Corporation for the three months ended with March are estimated by W.F. Detwiler, chairman of the board, at $1,419,240 after taxes based on the present rate giving no effect to the 10 per cent post-war refund, according to a preliminary statement announced yesterday.

Yehudi Menuhin, violinist, who has just returned from a three-week visit to England, where he played for United States and British troops and for many war-relief organizations, declared yesterday there was great need to send the highest type of artist to entertain our troops abroad.

MR. ROBERTSON leaps into this story pretty much as an enthusiastic larrikin leaps into a shindig at a rousing wake, with all his body and with his brogues ready for action. The reader barely gets by the title page before things begin to happen.

HERE, after a couple of published lapses that went by the names of "Mildred Pierce" and "Love's Lovely Counterfeit,'" is James M. Cain again, this time with a trio of novelties assembled under the title of "Three of a Kind"; the Mr. Cain who startled, and perhaps shocked, you with "The Postman Always Rings Twice" and "Serenade," who deals in prose that hums and pilots that hypnotize.

In the Navy scheme of physical conditioning, competitive sports rather than mass calisthenics and gymnastics are favored as inculcating qualities of leadership, quick thinking and an aggressive will to win.

BALTIMORE, April 17 -- Preston M. Burch's Cassis staved off a strong bid by the favored Star Copy today to take one of the two features on the second day of Pimlico's five-day war-relief meeting, while Mrs. Sidney Zell's Unchallenged romped away with the other main event.

OF the thirty-five feature pictures in production at the major studios this week only nine deal with the war. This is the lowest mark for this type of film in several months, with indications that in succeeding months the war story percentage will be cut down even more.

" AMERICAN IDEALISM," by Floyd Stovall, is a provocative book but one that at the same time gives the answer to many questions, for our reactions during the war, and our attitude to the dire problems that must follow, are sure to be conditioned by the national idealism whose development Professor Stovall has so ably recorded.

LONDON, Sunday, April 18 (AP) -- Russian troops, in a renewed fight to oust the Germans from their remaining Caucasus foothold around Novorossiisk, have killed 4,000 of the enemy and destroyed or damaged seventeen tanks in the last two days, Moscow announced early today.

LONDON, April (U.P.) -- The League of Nations has been notified by Generals Henri Honore Giraud and Charles de Gaulle that they still consider France a member, despite the withdrawal two years ago of the Vichy government.

YOUNG Storm MacKenzie, who had inherited from his father the Diamond M Ranch, out near the cow town of Mesalta, Ariz., knew that the watershed must be preserved or the ranch would be doomed. So, when Lester Warde's Great Western Timber Company began buying up the forests, Storm paid old Ben Hendricks $20,000 for the Palos Verdes pine-covered slopes.

NEW DELHI, India, April 15 (Delayed) -- Etiquette in the Burmesse jungle is explained with detail and humor in a booklet just issued by the British air forces, entitled "Under the Greenwood Tree, or How to Acquire Burm-ease."

LIKE her first novel, Miss Gilmore's second shows that she has the knack of turning out facile fiction of the type that many women like to read year in and year out. The heroine, Mary Lee Putnam, is young, slim, beautiful and blond.

Protesting the plan to restrict the press in reporting sessions of the International Food Conference an abridgment of Freedom of the an abridgement of freedom of the press as well as a breach of faith with the American people, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, urged yesterday that Congress act to establish a priority order for distribution of the nation's food supplies.

A COMPOSITE book on present and future world affairs is being planned by the Book-of-the-Month Club for July issue. The program calls for assembling parts of new or recent books by Henry Wallace, Wendell Willkie, Herbert Hoover and Hugh Gibson and Sumner Welles and publishing them in one volume, thus presenting a cross-section of important opinion.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 17 -- Continuing the run which has seen the Blakeen Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman R. Hoyt of Stamford take many best-in-show honors here, including last year, Ch. Blakeen Luzon, a white standard poodle, triumphed at the seventeenth annual fixture of the Springfield Kennel Club at the Municipal Auditorium tonight. Fred A. Bearse judged. The winner was shown in beautiful condition by Norman McBrien.

THIS is the third book of Claudia, not counting the highly successful play about that very amusing and appealing child-wife. The continuing story, bringing back Claudia and David, is like meeting old friends again and very nice, self-sufficient people, too.

A committee of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association and a group representing dentifrice makers will try to find out this week why propylene glycol, one of three solvents they are permitted to use under government drug and food regulations, has been allocated by the War Production Board.

The day's work done, the supper eaten, the countryman smokes a slow pipe over his newspaper, pausing often to stare unseeing at a page. At last he gets pen and paper and goes into the dining room, settles down at the big table where he has room for thoughts as well as elbows.

AN unusual collection of books in French and Russian, together with autograph letters and documents will be sold at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Monday afternoon. They are the property of Mr. and Mrs. Harris Hammond of Bordertown, N.J., David Frankel of New York, A. Hourvitch and others.

COMPANION-CROPPING is a profitable and practical way of producing maximum crops in minimum space and is especially important now to those with small gardens. Broadly speaking, companion-cropping is the planting of small or quick maturing crops in the same row with large and slow-growing ones.

MID-SPRING being a season of the year which in less serious times was conducive to pleasure cruising to Southern waters, the Seamen's Church Institute of New York has devised a novel plan for its annual Spring benefit.

New York is destined to be the greatest artistic center in the world, in the opinion of Alfredo de Canas Valenzuela, Chilean painter, who has been commissioned by his country to study the development of art in the United States. He arrived in this country last January, spent several months in New York, and is now going to Washington, after which he will return to Chile by way of Mexico and Central America.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 17 -- Japanese military aviation is good and is getting better. This is the consensus of experts here who, during the last ten days of intensified Japanese air activity over New Guinea and the Solomons, have had a new chance to size up the enemy air forces.

Despite the fact that the first full year of the war produced the largest total registration of pure-bred dogs in the history of the American Kennel Club, a decrease in the number of registrations has marked the opening months of 1943.

THE phenomenal results of the three-week tour from which the Metropolitan Association has returned to this city indicate considerably more than a fortuitous box-office killing. There probably has been no such public response to the association's offerings outside of New York in the history of the organization.

The Mayfair Bridge Club team of Harry J. Fishbein, Alvin Roth, Tobias Stone, Fred D. Kaplan and Harold A. Fagin won the national contract bridge team-of-four championship and the Harold S. Vanderbilt Cup at the Hotel Pierre last night, in the final round of the tournament, which had been in progress since Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that proposed changes in the New York milk-marketing order would be submitted to the industry for approval within a few days. The changes would adjust the cheese-making allowance to encourage the manufacturers of this needed high-protein food, especially during the Spring and Summer months of peak milk production.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 17 -- The pictorial weekly Veckojournalen reports that a woman was among the three Munich University students who were executed last February for spreading anti-Nazi tracts. The others, it says, were soldiers, one a Stalingrad Sixth Army survivor who had been decorated with two Iron Crosses, -- first class and second class.
WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Chairman Nelson of the WPB, in a memorandum to the staff today, suggested immediate methods for curtailment of paper use within the board. The memorandum said:

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Republican National Committee today circulated in a pamphlet, "A Typical New Deal Smear and Distortion," the report by Ralph H. Lutz, Professor of History at Stanford University, absolving former President Hoover of the charges made against him in February by Vice President Wallace and Senator Theodore F. Green, Rhode Island, Democrat, that he had misjudged the war situation in a private memorandum twenty-five years ago.

PIERRE MATISSE offers at his gallery an interesting glimpse of movements that characterized the first decade of modernism. This show, which will remain current through May 1, deals with fauvism, cubism and surrealism chief emphasis, however, being placed on cubism and its variants.

Friday's slipping tendencies of the prices of stocks disappeared yesterday. The stock market opened firm and went on to gain fractions. Closing prices were at about the best levels of the day and the gains wiped out the minor losses of Friday.

THIS is an exciting and up-to-the-minute story, with a lot of danger for the young heroine, one murder and plenty of spy work. Ruth, half English, half American, was living in Tokyo with her mother and her German stepfather when the bombs fell on Pearl Harbor.

FELIX FERRY, who already has raised half the money he needs, would like to revive "The Gypsy Baron," the Johann Strauss Jr. operetta that was first done abroad in 1885 and last revived here at the Lewisohn Stadium on Aug. 6, 1942.

MOSCOW, April 17 -- Red Star, the Russian Army organ, announced today that 4,000 miles of railroad that had been put out of action by enemy occupation and recovered by the Red Army's offensives was now usable. The first through train for Stalingrad left Moscow this week carrying, among other passengers, a number of technicians for Stalingrad's reconstruction.

IN his first novel Charles Mills, a Georgia-born writer, who has studied singing in Italy and now is working at the University of North Carolina, is much preoccupied with the question of aristocracy. It is a preoccupation that at first blush seems a bit remote for these times; but for Mr. Mills, and doubtless for other people, it is real enough.

This is an auspicious time to start to plan for the post-war period. With the spirit of Thomas Jefferson pervading the Halls of Congress and our school houses, we naturally compare the principles that governed his conduct with those which govern the conduct of our contemporaries.

THE formula is hardly to be recommended for general application, but here is one way of becoming one of the world's leading orientalists: be born in a little Midwestern town to an amiable and able hardware merchant, live the traditional kite-flying, butterfly-collecting, little-red-schoolhouse boyhood, decide to be a botanist, chemist or druggist, then change your mind and decide to be a clergyman, change it again and decide to be a philologist.

OUR subject today is juvenile delinquency, and the views, for a change, are those of the children themselves. Parents who are not thoroughly rested had better go on to the crossword puzzle, because the boys and girls have made up their minds: the trouble is, they say, parents don't make them toe the line.

John L. Lewis charged yesterday that large industrial and financial interests are engaged in a conspiracy with "national politicians" to bring about a lockout of the coal miners on May 1 and to deny them their demands for higher wages to meet the increased cost of living.
WHAT shall we do with Japan after she is defeated? Whatever peace planners may have to offer, they must bear one central fact in mind. That fact is Japan's long-term preparation for world domination.
Setting: New York, uptown, downtown and around the edges.

MORE than a hundred stories have been collected by Mrs. Gruenberg in this substantial volume attractively illus trated in black and white by Kurt Wiese. Here are realistic stories, folk and fairy tales, myths and fables, Bible stories and a few nonsense rhymes thrown in for good measure.

THE teaching of mathematics is incomparably poor on all levels. An assortment of verbose definitions is learned by rote. The mechanical manipulation of symbols and equations is boring. After graduation what has been learned is forgotten.

The annual award of the American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born went last night to Earl G. Harrison, United States Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, for his "outstanding contribution to the mobilization of the foreign born for the victory program."

BOSTON, April 17 (AP) -- One hundred and thirteen plodders -- eight of whom are among the top-ranking favorites -- will compete tomorrow in the grueling forty-seventh annual twenty-six-mile, 385-yard, Hopkinton-to-Boston marathon for the honor of being crowned with a laurel wreath.

LONDON, April 17 -- It is the view in London that the world stands on the threshold of great events -- that the decisive phase of the war, although not its concluding phase, is at last in sight. Both the Axis and the Allies are under compulsion to make fateful moves, because no longer is it possible for any of the belligerents to stay their hands and argue that time is on their side.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The $13,000,000,000 sought by the Treasury in its Second War Loan Drive this month seems like a lot of money, but it is less than is currently being spent for war purposes in two months' time. War expenditures are now running at somewhat more than $7,000,000,000 monthly.
Setting: New York City and Long Island.

UP at Hunter College, where Waves and Spars have taken over the halls of earning, the Retailers Uniform Agency has opened shop for accessories and doodads. There are two shops -- or in naval lingo, two ship's stores -- located in the "ship's hold."

Post-war plans for education, calling for the expenditure of vast sums of money, are now being considered by leading educators in various sections of the country. This question has received added impetus with the recent publication of the National Resources Planning Board report, outlining an extensive school program.

THE debacle of Pearl Harbor, Hong Kong and Singapore, of Malaya and Burma, showed us that neither Americans nor Englishmen know enough about the peoples of Asia, either foes or Allies, for war or peace. Such agelong ignorance cannot be quickly mended Language alone is barrier enough between people -- and of our Allies.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (U.P.) -- Attorneys for Max Stephan, Detroit restaurateur, were reported tonight to have advised Supreme Court Justice Frank Murphy that Stephan acted on the advice of a prominent Detroit citizen when he harbored Peter Krug, German flier who escaped from a Canadian prison camp.

FRANK CLARK veteran stunt pilot, has been flying before the movie cameras longer than any other West Coast aviator. He has a collection of newsreel shots of his stunts going back to 1918, when he first began doing tricks with an airplane.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 17 (AP) -- American delegates to the Anglo-American refugee conference will begin their search Monday for places of refuge for Nazi-persecuted Europeans on a strictly practical basis, regardless of pressure from various interested groups, they indicated today. The conference may last two weeks.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17 -- Warren Wright's Ocean Wave and Mrs. Ethel V. Mars's No Wrinkles definitely looked like Kentucky Derby starters today as they finished one, two in the Elmendorf Purse at Churchill Downs. However, the finish of the $1,200 race left the Derby status of six other Western eligibles for the May 1 turf classic in doubt.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and other union representatives met yesterday with transcription company representatives in an effort to iron out a ban on recordings for radio use which has been in effect since last August.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 17 -- As the race for victory enters what might be the home stretch, anxiously watched by a small gallery of neutral onlookers, spectators in Sweden are wondering where an Allied victory will lead their country.

Declaring that the city cannot afford to establish the precedent that members of legally independent bodies should take orders from the Mayor, the executive committee of the Citizens Union yesterday urged Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the Board of Education, not to resign because of his controversy with Mayor La Guardia over the rejection of Mark Starr for the post of director of adult education.

LONDON, April 17 -- Britain has absorbed the budget blow delivered by Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood last Monday without flinching and even with a sigh of relief -- as if to say: "Is that the worst he can do?"

WASHINGTON, April 17 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 170 United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Office of War Information stated today that most civilian car owners could not hope to obtain synthetic rubber tires before the last half of next year. For essential civilian driving some synthetic tires may be available earlier but how many, said OWI, "is still an open question."

ON the Eastern Front any German soldier who captures or destroys a heavy Russian tank is granted a two weeks' furlough and permission to go home. Destruction of a light tank, twenty-six or thirty-two tons, is worth only one week's leave, no trip home.
