MISSOURI -- On Journalism Plans are under way at the School of Journalism of the University of Missouri to substitute for the customary Journalism Week, held annually since 1910, the Journalism Week speeches in book form, "Journalism in War," to be made available to the public, Frank Luther Mort, dean, has announced.

CHINA has never been adequately articulate on her political aims and social structure. Too much has been written, perhaps, of her customs and book learning, not enough of her present. This may be because China and the Chinese people have been deeply imbued with the Confucian edict, "It is more important to know about others than that others should know you."

The principles which, he said, will guide his country after the war were stated by Dr. Ladislav Feierabend, Czechoslovak Minister of Finance, in an address at the Opera Victory Rally in tribute to Czechoslovakia which was broadcast over the Blue Network during an intermission of the perfomance of Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

TREE peonies are aristocrats of the first order, expensive yet worth every cent they cost. Like old furniture in the house they are a permanent delight, good not for seasons alone or years but actually for generations.

PERIODICALLY it strikes the critic as appropriate that his reasoned approach to art be reaffirmed. Some time having elapsed since the last previous communique on the subject, it may not be amiss to state once more the line of critical procedure long ago determined upon.

MERE novelty may be held suspect until its inherent worth has been proved. The fact that Lincoln Rothschild hit upon a new approach in the matter of presenting a subject vast in scope would be of no special significance were the result, as revealed between covers, unsatisfactory.
TOM GILL'S light, entertaining story is built around the ruins of a Mayan city in the Central American jungle. He brings the odor of the steaming coastal tropics to the reader as his tale unfolds.

Former Governor Charles Poletti has been commissioned a lieutenant colonel in the Army and assigned to the Civil Affairs Division of the Chief of Staff, Section on Military Government of Occupied Countries, it was learned last night.
BLUEJACKETS with big hearts for blondes, redheads and brunettes do not hesitate to enlist the aid of Navy League shoppers, to judge by a letter to Mrs. J. Truman Bidwell of Servicemen's Service.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Regulations intended to "freeze" essential workers to their jobs and to prevent the transfer of workers for higher pay except in the interest of the war effort were issued today by Chairman Paul V. McNutt of the War Manpower Commission.

LOCAL 802 of the Musicians Union reports that 2,497 members entered the Armed Forces in the last year. This figure is revealed in the annual treasurer's report which shows a decrease of $18,365 in dues in 1942 from the total in 1941. Members who enter the military services are excused from paying dues.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Three bills vesting greater leeway in the courts for dealing with youthful offenders between the ages of 16 and 19 were signed today by Governor Dewey, who said they mark a new advance in the handling of criminal offenses committed by persons in that age group.

Fall buying of ready-to-wear will begin actively next month, when many buyers representing retail stores will arrive here on their initial trips for the new season. Current indications are that because of the uncertainties in the situation the garment trades are likely to have "July in May and early June" so far as buyers' arrivals are concerned.

WALTER S. SCOTT, a leading philatelic figure for many years, will be the speaker at "Colonel Green Night" on Wednesday evening at the Collectors Club, 22 East Thirty-fifth Street. He will review the spectacular activities of Colonel E.H.R. Green while assembling postal pieces.

While plans are still in an indefinite stage, the war agencies intend to start the reconversion of industry to the production of essential civilian goods by the end of the Summer, reports indicated last week. This step will be made possible by the concentration of war production in the most efficient plants, with a smaller wastage of vital materials, and the cutback in output of many types of war materiel which consume vital materials.

CHUNGKING, China, April 17 (AP) -- A plane-supported Japanese force of 3,000 men captured two small towns in a thrust east of the Yangtze River port of Ichang before they were forced into retreat by an attack that cost the foe 600 killed, the Chinese High Command said in a communique today.

Chess devotees in this vicinity have expressed satisfaction over the action of the New York Chess Association in selecting Syracuse as the place for its annual meeting, in conjunction with the open championship of the United States Chess Federation. Play has been set for Aug. 14 to 28.

ALBANY, April 17 -- Governor Dewey will appoint either Charles Evans Hughes Jr. or Thomas D. Thacher, New York City Republicans and former United States Solicitors General, to the Court of Appeals early next month, it was stated today.

FROM Brazil comes a 40-centavos violet stamp which commemorates the "Centenario" (Centenary) of the founding of Petropolis on "16 de Marco" (March 16), 1843, this date and 1943 being inscribed. This city, twenty-seven miles north of Rio de Janeiro, was established under the auspices of Emperor Dom Pedro II, and the design of the stamp reproduces Brazil's 1866 200-reis stamp bearing Pedro's portrait.

Predicting a teacher shortage of 75,000 by next Fall, Dr. Donald DuShane, secretary of the National Education Association's democracy commission, warned yesterday that the nation's public school system "faced collapse" unless Federal aid were granted.

Department store sales, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table of percentage comparisons with a year ago for the Reserve districts, for the last two weeks and the latest four-week period:

BUENOS AIRES, April 17 -- Argentina is among the world's greatest producers of agricultural goods in general and foodstuffs in particular. In normal times she produces about one-half of the world's total crop of linseed, ranks second after the United States as a producer of corn, is among the first four or five producers of meat and stands eighth as producer of wheat.

OPENING a week apart, three shows of paintings by deceased American artists are to be presented in New York galleries. The Babcock Gallery has put on an exhibition of the work of Ernest Lawson, from 1889 to 1938.

IT is announced by the Grand Central Galleries that thirty-eight paintings were sold from the memorial exhibition, "Paintings of the Sea," by Frederick Judd Waugh. The recent exhibition attracted more than 15,000 visitors. Purchases, we are informed, were made for both museum and private collections.

HOME-MADE ONION SOUP takes the place of canned, and saves points. To prepare it: Saute a cup of onion slices in a bit of fat until brown, then add a mixture of three cups of water and three chicken bouillon cubes.

Trading in cotton futures continued yesterday to be ruled by caution as no definite statement from the Office of Price Administration on the contemplated ceiling on the commodity was forthcoming. On the New York Cotton Exchange only routine trade business was negotiated in a small and featureless market.

MISS FLORENCE LOUISE HALL is as urban as her stylish earrings, as rural as her small home town, Port Austin, Mich. She is the very symbol of that unity of farm and city, which she believes must and underwrite her Women's Land Army of the United States Crop Corps.

WENDELL L. WILLKIE'S "One World" is exciting not only because of the richness of the material in it -- he was, of course, one of the most fortunate of all reporters, with entre everywhere, and his book is first-rate journalism -- but because of the feeling that is behind it of a world opening up, of frontiers that are not far any longer.

LONDON, April 17 -- Declaring that he had information showing that anti-Semitism had increased in the recent past, the Archbishop of Canterbury called on all Christians today to unite in resisting such prejudices to the utmost in their power.

PEARL HARBOR, April 17 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, presented medals to twenty-three officers and men of his command, mostly submariners and airmen, in ceremonies at the submarine base here today.

ONE cannot read of the efforts of man to fly in the many years before he accomplished that apparent miracle without a feeling that there was a strain of mysticism in those pioneers who sought to defy gravity, even before Newton told them what made them earthbound.

The self-service combination market handling a weekly business volume of about $2,500 is the "ideal" type of grocery operation under present conditions and has the best chance of survival through the wartime period, according to A.F. Guckenberger, secretary of the New York State Food Merchants Association.

A GROWTH of moss on the lawn serves as a warning to the home owner that the soil is not sufficiently fertilized or nourished. Proper fertilizing can turn a double trick -- it rids the lawn of unsightly moss and helps the development and growth of the grass.

TWO Norwegian officials in exile tell a plain tale of heroism among their people at home. The story is documented and authoritative -- grim shadow spreads over the background. Yet the atmosphere is electric with the irrepressible humor of a glorious audacity, and it is with chins up, laughter in their eyes, irony on their lips.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 17 -- Slashing attacks by British and French troops in the shell-swept mountain heights of Northern Tunisia cut new wedges today in the enemy siege line that rings Tunis and Bizerte at a distance of twenty-five to fifty miles.

WOMEN active in the work of the Home for Incurables have taken over the first mezzanine of Radio City. Music Hall for the 9 o'clock performance of the motion picture, "The More the Merrier," on the night of May 6 to raise funds for the institution.

Columbia's "Somewhere in Sahara" company finished a two-month location trip on the California desert this week. Zoltan Korda, who is directing the picture, reports simulation of war during this venture can best be described by the term used by General Sherman in describing factual warfare.

The untimely passing of that great and internationally renowned character actor, Conrad Veidt, must have come as a profound shock to the many who recall his forceful portrayal of the general in "Escape," opposite Norma Shearer, as well as to the few who can still remember his work in "The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari," upon which his initial fame was so largely based.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 17 -- Aldo Vidussoni, Secretary General of the Italian Fascist party, resigned from his post during a meeting of the Fascist party directorate in Rome at which Premier Mussolini presided tonight.

WOMEN have always run the world! Papa may have ranted and roared in Victorian days, and Mama may have appeared to be a mouse. But literature and the family diary bear witness that many, if not most, of Papa's ideas were timidly whispered to him by Mama after she had lain awake all night or spent two weeks planning.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, April 17 -- To date Americans have collected everything for their soldiers, from cigarettes to bedroom slippers. It has been books for the Army, smokes for the Army, sweaters for the Army, fruitcake for the Army, socks for the Army.

LONDON, April 17 -- In wartime censorship is ever present, but its workings are often smoother and fairer than outsiders believe. The censorship of Great Britain is probably the most efficient, the most liberal and the least troublesome of any belligerent country -- including the United States.

THERE are several hundred kinds of Sage and they are found growing in all parts of the world except in the very coldest climates. In our own West are several members of the family usually associated with barren country or rocky mountain slopes.

THE Ballet Theater has extended its engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House through May 9, thus compassing what is said to be the longest ballet season ever to be played in that theatre. A total of thirty-eight performances will have been given, and if attendance continues at the current rate it will be the Ballet Theatre's most successful run.

NEW DELHI, India, April 17 -- The United States Tenth Air Force bombing raids on Rangoon have been so effective, Major Gen. Bissell, commander of the Air Forces in India, said today, that use of that vital port had been "practically denied to the enemy for the past month."

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- The Empire Power Corporation and its subsidiary, the United Gas and Electric Corporation, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for exemption from the Investment Company Act of 1940 for the delivery of a $2,765,900 promissory note by Empire to United Gas and Electric in return for 24,975 shares of Empire $6 preferred shares as part of a plan to redeem all the 62,828 shares outstanding.

ZANE GREY died in 1939, and a new Western yarn by him comes like a voice from the tomb. But this novel is authentic Zane Grey. It has all the earmarks of his familiar style and abounds in his characteristic emotionalism, sentimentality and verbosity.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- If present liberal feeding of corn and oats to livestock continues, Purdue University's department of agricultural statistics said today, suppies of these grains remaining on farms on July 1 will be down to about the 1938-41 average for that date while units of livestock and poultry on farms are likely to be 20 to 25 per cent above the average in those years.

Cold weather and the war loan drive were major factors affecting retail trade here last week. Gains over the corresponding period of 1942 were scored, but they were smaller percentagewise than in the preceding week. Department-store volume was up about 10 per cent, estimates indicated.

On the high plains of the range country cattle and sheep last week were cropping the bright green shoots of Winter wheat and rye. In Iowa farmers divided their time between plowing and the care of hordes of new-born pigs that required watching in the unseasonable cold.

HUMAN history is like paleontology. Owing to a certain judicial blindness even the best intelligences absolutely fail to see the things which lie in front of their noses. Later, when the moment has arrived, we are surprised to find traces everywhere of what we failed to see.

Smashing home first within two-fifths of a second of the Jamaica track record, Count Fleet yesterday won the $28,650 Wood Memorial Stakes before 24,074 persons who had come to see a champion and weren't disappointed.

Industrial financing of university engineering research must supplement private endowment in the post-war period, Professor James Kip Finch, associate dean of the School of Engineering at Columbia University, declared yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 17 (AP) -- The American Navy will commission more ships this year "than comprised the entire fleet at the end of 1942," Secretary Knox declared today, and, at the war's end, will be an important factor in helping maintain the peace.

The Parkchester development in the Bronx, which normally consumed 8,000,000 gallons of fuel oil a year to supply heat and hot water for its 171 buildings, will convert to coal, it was announced yesterday.

ALONG cherished heresy on the part of progressive museum folk and writers on art has been that the way to get the public interested in art is to make art easily available for the public and to get them to look at it. Last year the Metropolitan made available in reproduction sixty of the Italian drawings from the museum's collections.

THE critics held their annual meeting last Tuesday and it was peaceful. Those who had come early hoping that one or two who had been attacking each other in print might do so in person were disappointed, to put it as mildly as possible.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- One of the most powerful and widely known agencies created since this country entered the global conflict, the Office of War Information has been newly spotlighted by internal dissensions whose repercussions no one can yet forecast.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Belated response to public demand for action on pay-as-you-go taxation was in evidence in the House today. It looked as though the House would get a tax bill and the Easter recess which was jeopardized by the tax stalemate existing until yesterday.

ANY one who has pursued the news around the radio dials, over, say, a four-hour stretch on a day when the announcers are talking about German Admiral Doenitz and the Russian river Donets can understand why CBS had Mr. Greet do something about it.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The sinking of five more Japanese ships and the damaging of two others in Pacific and Far Eastern waters by American submarines was announced by the Navy today. The Navy also stated that a record number of thirteen raids in one day had been made on Kiska in the Aleutian Islands by United States planes on Thursday.
" Red, White and Washington," by Marion Hammett and Malvine Stuart Cole, a play about a government office and the people who work in it. Audrey Wood is the agent.

Nazi authorities in Norway have turned down Swedish offers to care for Norwegian Jewish families and a group of undernourished and sick Norwegian children, the Stockholm radio said yesterday in an English broadcast to the United States.

Earnest voices from all sides urge us to plan for the post-war world. Nowadays, gentlemen, it is our favorite occupation and one of the few pleasures left. It costs not a dollar that ought to go for war bonds. It requires no red coupon, or green, as the case may be.

LONDON, April 17 -- A series of recent events, not the least interesting of which was the most recent -- a speech by the Spanish Foreign Minister, Count Francisco Gomez de Jordana, declaring that Spain was ready to defend her independence and willing to help in the restoration of peace -- has focused attention upon that non-belligerent nation at the western end of the Mediterranean.

STEFAN ZWEIG lived in two worlds so different that one of them might almost as well have been on the moon. Most of us who are not too much younger to be able to say the same thing of ourselves nevertheless forget that there is a whole new generation of grown men whose consciousness first awoke after the first World War and who, therefore, never knew a world which was not disturbed, unsure and apprehensive.

THE lowly "spud" has risen considerably in reputation since it became scarce in the market, and many a back-yard gardener is wondering whether it might not pay him to grow a bushel or two of potatoes, along with his beans, peas, carrots and tomatoes.

At least one golf championship of national caliber for women will be played this Summer when the Western Open match play event is staged over the Glenoaks Golf Club course at Chicago during the week of June 28-July 2.
ST. LOUIS, April 17 (AP) -- Getting unexpected scoring punch from rookie outfielder Milt Byrnes, the Browns defeated the world champion Cardinals in an exhibition game today, 9 to 4.

SCIENCE and technology rush forward at so breathless a pace that even the specialists have difficulty in keeping up with them. Botanists know no more about Diesel engines than other well-educated persons, and geologists have no conception of what the aeronautic engineers are doing to make airplanes bigger, faster and safer.

CLEVELAND, April 17 (AP) -- The Republic Steel Corporation announced that it had telegraphed the War Labor Board's chairman, W.H. Davis, and the War Production Board's steel division director, H.G. Batcheller, today that Republic's Troy (N.Y.) blast furnace was closed this morning by a strike, shutting off "more than 700 tons of pig iron per day."

For the boys from Guthrie, Okla., and Owensboro, Ky., and Agate, Col., and Minter City, Miss., the Atlantic crossing is by far the greatest wonderment they've ever seen The first general, the first howitzer, the first Flying Fortress, the first divisional review were impressive.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The possibility of an increase in the coffee ration soon was held out today by Price Administrator Prentiss Brown. Meanwhile, he said the improvement that has taken place in the coffee supply assures that the present ration of one pound a person every five weeks can be maintained.

Early in this war many independent schools, in a laudable desire to cooperate with the government, planned to discard important features of their traditional curriculums and prepare their boys directly for military service. Later, authoritative advice induced them to retain English and the social sciences as basic subjects, but to place an increased emphasis on mathematics, chemistry and physics.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 17 -- Charging that the National Administration is not yet waging a "hard war," Representative Clare Boothe Luce, speaking to her Fairfield County constituents tonight, lashed out at handling of the manpower situation, assailed politics in Washington and declared, "There is no more important war bill than a total tax bill."

Major league baseball, having managed to survive the rigors of a streamlined all-Northern Spring training campaign, sets out this week upon an even more spectacular venture -- the launching of a championship season whose outcome seems almost completely shrouded in uncertainty but which none the less looms as interesting as any the game has ever known.

Rain spoiled a preview of New York's three major league ball clubs yesterday for many fans. The downpour caused cancellation of the scheduled contest between the Dodgers and Yankees at Ebbets Field and the clash between the Giants and Senators at the Polo grounds.

How much absenteeism is caused by sickness and how much by a combination of high wages and indifference to the country's needs? The statistics shed no light on the question. It is known that 90 per cent of all industrial disability is caused by illness that originates outside of the shop.

EARLY risers who have shivered through the Easter-dawn services of other years will take comfort in the thought that this year Easter, coming almost at its latest, April 25, should be warm. Again Central Park Mall will be the scene of a sunrise service that annually attracts many New Yorkers as well as visitors.

OF the seven short stories in this volume, five deal directly with the trials of England at war and the other two are war stories although with a slightly different background. All, in a sense, are thrillers.

HISTORIANS of the generation of our grandchildren will be coldly objective about the spiritual bankruptcy of Europe on the eve of World War II. They will consider it the logical end of the drift from faith that began with the Renaissance, the period to a rather involved sentence in the story of man's search for the meaning of himself.

An advertisement in this newspaper by the Buick division of General Motors pays tribute to the adaptability shown by automobile dealers in the face of a situation which has brought special hardships. When automobile building halted, Buick dealers numbered about 3,000.

AMERICAN dealers generally have shown a high regard for the catalogues they produce and have tried to make them readable and informative as well as persuasive. While many of them are of a strictly utilitarian nature, designed for ready reckoning by the harassed librarian and the busy collector, a substantial number go beyond the bare bones of mail-order bookselling.

OTTAWA, April 17 (Canadian Press) -- Ordinary Canadian export and other receipts of United States dollars are sufficient to cover non-war exchange requirements, Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley said last night in the House of Commons.

New York City's percentage of manufacturing wage earners in the United States tell from 8.4 per cent in 1899 to 6.4 per cent in 1939, "a decline of 23.8 per cent," the State Division of Commerce said in its study. "Trends in Important Manufacturing Industries in New York, 1929-1939," issued in 1942.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A sobering reminder of the blood and sacrifice that the United States is prepared to contribute in this war against tyranny was pounded home this week in a vulnerable spot -- the family group.

LAKELAND, Fla., April 17 -- The South is watching with considerable interest and some doubt the experiment which got under way in Florida's rich Everglades this week as the first of several thousand Negroes from the Bahama Islands began harvesting thousands of acres of vegetables.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- If the crescendo of warnings from Allied Headquarters in Australia proves to be prophetic of coming events, a new offensive action, in which either the Allies or the Japanese may strike first, may be shaping up.

HOLLYWOOD. IRELAND, which gave Shaw to the theatre, Joyce to literature Yeats to poetry and to New York most of its police force, did not overlook Hollywood when it was dispensing favors. It gave the cinema city Geraldine Fitzgerald, who is as Celtic as the moors and mists of her homeland.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Treasury announced today the subscription figures and the basis of allotment of subscriptions from commercial banks for their own account for the current offering of seven-eighths of 1 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness, Series B-1944.

LONDON, April 17 -- A record wartime football crowd of 105,000 today watched England defeat Scotland, 4 -- 0, in an international soccer match at Glasgow's Hampden Park. It was England's fifth victory in nine wartime internationals.

More than 1,000 merchant marine officers and licensed members of shipping shore staffs have joined the United States Maritime Service as commissioned officers in the War Shipping Administration's program to "dress up" and improve the industry, it was announced yesterday.

War Secretary Stimson announced last week that a constantly increasing flow of aircraft and other military supplies will be shipped to General MacArthur. "We will keep our American and Australian fliers supplied with sufficient planes not only to replace our losses but to build up our aircraft to counter the increasing enemy air strength."
CHICAGO, April 17 -- Baseball will open its second war year with fan interest higher for this time of the year than it has been in many seasons.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 17 (AP) -- A communique:

North Africa is the largest and richest source of Axis-controlled phosphate deposits. Insignificant amounts of phosphate are sprinkled through Belgium, France, Poland and Spain, but these have not been mined commercially. Prior to the war, North African phosphates plus some from Florida supplied most of Europe, but with the fall of France, production in North Africa dropped almost half.

ANTONY TUDOR'S latest ballet, "Romeo and Juliet," may well develop into a box-office success. It has one of the most popular of all stories, a production which for lavishness and visual beauty has not been matched in many a day, Alicia Markova and probably the best ballet company in the world to present it, and certainly one of the most original and important of choreographers to guarantee its standards.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 16 -- Walther Lenny, 36 years old, a Berlin teamster, and four accomplices in a meat racket with stolen ration cards, were summarily sentenced to death in a Berlin special court on Tuesday. The five were executed immediately.

Having recently returned from an extended trip, I had brought to my attention the interesting letter, published in your issue of March 21, by Ulysses Grant-Smith on the need of all nations for unhampered ingress and egress to world markets.

Professor Laski's letter in THE TIMES last Sunday, taking Mr. Churchill to task for not initiating "our new society" in the midst of the present crisis, cites as a historical example of similar lost opportunities in the past "the period after 1865" -- presumably in the United States.

SOMEWHERE beyond the walls and overhead the scream of the bomb grew steadily louder. By instinct the small group sitting around the table in the hotel lounge leaned away from the side of the room where the tall glass doors opened into the driveway court.
WITH herbs taking a place in every Victory garden, and condiments becoming more popular and necessary to supplement foods, the horseradish may well come back to more prominence in home cultivation.

THE London theatre boom continues and the managers have no more respect for the wartime public than to keep on feeding it with revivals. Only twice during the last month have we been allowed to see new plays -- one homegrown, one American.

If at any time in the last twenty-five years a Liberal writer and political leader aged 84 met a Liberal writer and political leader aged 45 or less they would almost certainly need an interpreter. They would not be speaking the same language.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (U.P.) -- With a fully equipped airfield at Kiska the Japanese would be in position to bomb American bases on the Alaskan mainland and raid American shipping in Alaskan waters. They also would be in an ideal position to nip any westward offensive movement in that region.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 17 -- The Second United States Corps suffered 5,372 casualties in its holding action that accompanied the British Eighth Army's drive through the Gabes Gap to the Enfidaville line, General Dwight D. Eisenhower revealed today.

VANCOUVER, Wash., April 17 (AP) -- Speed in the air enables the Army to bring wounded men from the Alaskan war zone -- where most of the casualties are from aerial action -- to Barnes Hospital within twelve hours after the men return to base from a battle mission.

THE fourth annual exhibition by members of the American Veterans Society of Artists, Inc., is being held in the old Academy Room of the American Fine Arts Galleries. Most of the exhibitors are veterans of the First World War, although some are now in service and others engaged in related activities.

RAISING dahlias from seed is somewhat like taking a chance on a lottery -- there is no telling what may develop. However, seedling dahlias provide a fascinating hobby and one may spend many hours watching the plants unfold in their diversified forms.

" THIS Thomas Jefferson, I find, is a very difficult person to write about. Even in his old age he will remain as elusive as a young colt. You can never ask him to stand still and to stay still for more than a few moments at a time."

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- The War Labor Board has voted 5 to 4 to raise the pay of 26,000 lumber workers in the Pacific Northwest, it was disclosed today by Wayne L. Morse, public member of the board, who dissented on the ground that the increase should have been larger.

A Victory Concert will be given on the night of May 7 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the sponsorship of the National Federation of Music Clubs to augment its war service fund. The federation since midsummer of 1941 has been supplying phonographs, records, radios, band and orchestra instruments to army camps and naval bases in this country and, in recent months, has undertaken a similar service for outgoing transports and detachments overseas.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- THE NEW YORK TIMES recent survey of the knowledge of history held by college freshmen was "ridiculous, amateurish and unreliable," Dr. Erling M. Hunt, head of the Department of the Teaching of Social Studies, Columbia University Teachers College, told the Middle States Council for the Social Studies today.

A desire to see Joe Louis defend his world heavyweight championship against Billy Conn for the benefit of Army Emergency Relief was expressed recently by United States Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey.

NEW DELHI, India, April 17 (AP) -- The United States Tenth Air Force reported in a communique today the destruction of a railway bridge ten miles northeast of Penbaw, Burma, and the immobilization of another five miles south of Mogaung with three hits.

To keep the reduction in 1943 civilian food supplies within the 6 per cent limit predicted by the Office of War Information in its detailed report last week, the growing, processing and distributing branches of the food industry must exert superhuman efforts in the face of mounting difficulties.

DETROIT, April 17 (AP) -- Hal White and Hal Newhouser pitched the Tigers to a 2-to-0 victory over the Pirates today before 1,365 spectators at Briggs Stadium. The Pirates still hold a 3-to-2 lead in their exhibition series.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 17 -- H.P. Haag's Devalue staged a stirring late drive today to win the $2,500 Roger Williams Handicap by four lengths from Mrs. Wallace Renard's Mixer before 16,000 at Narragansett Park.

The United States Treasury had to obtain $50,000,000,000 through borrowing in 1942, and more than $31,000,000,000 was obtained from investors other than commercial banks, it has been disclosed by C.J. Devine Co., one of the nation's largest dealers in government securities.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 17 -- Placing first in six of the fourteen events and rolling up frequent second, third and fourth places, the Naval Academy track team today defeated Columbia and Pennsylvania in a triangular meet.

The war in the West centered last week in Tunisia. There the long African campaigns that had started with Italy's entrance into the war in 1940 seemed near their end. An army of nearly 200,000 Germans and Italians was penned in a strip of ground less than 100 miles long and varying in width from 100 to less than thirty miles.

A CENTURY of postal paper -- regarded as one of the most important single factors in the development of inter-American relations -- is to be commemorated by The Pan American Centenary of the Postage Stamp under the joint auspices of the Pan American Union and the American Philatelic Congress on Nov. 26 and 27.
Rabbis in sermons here urged yesterday that the conference on refugees to be held in Bermuda this week take immediate action to rescue Jews in Nazi-occupied Europe.

With main-floor accessory trade excellent, retail trade continued active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

With the birthday of Adolt Hitler and the start of the new salvage drive for household copper, bronze and brass coming on Tuesday, it has been designated as "Hex the Axis Day," Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the city's Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, announced yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 17 (AP) -Heavy British bombers raided Naples again Thursday night and Liberators of the United States, Ninth Air Force struck Catania Harbor, on the east coast of Sicily, in daylight yesterday, communiques announced today.

More than 4,000 scientists participated in last week's meeting of the American Chemical Society at Detroit. The war loomed large. Synthetic rubber, petroleum, malaria, food, chemical warfare, gas, fuel -- about every phase of war chemistry was discussed. Here we can summarize only those papers which are of general interest.

IT is still not too late to plant thoroughly dormant fruit trees, though early planting is preferable. Roots should be cut back slightly to bright wood, and the top headed back from half to two-thirds. Any lateral branches which are spaced three to eight inches apart along the trunk and which are so situated that they can serve as the permanent framework of the tree should be left in place.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- With Warren Halliburton, hurdler, and Freshman Ed Conwell, sprinter, setting the pace, New York University opened its outdoor track season by overwhelming Temple's squad on the Owls' rain-soaked field today, 96 to 29.

LAUREL HARRIMAN and her uncle John, well-known physician, lived in the big white brick house and were very comfortable and happy until the doctor acquired a couple of assistants and a wife. There was a housing shortage, so the young doctors moved into the brick house.

LIEUTENANT CARL BRIDENBAUGH in his fine review of my "Mutiny in January" has inadvertently libeled the memory of an honest man and a good soldier by confusing Dr. Jonathan I. Dayton of Elizabethtown, N.J., with Captain Jonathan Dayton of the same town.

A GRANT from the Carnegie Endowment will insure the regular publication of the present yearly record of events in the Americas. The usual initial difficulties in enterprises of this kind, together with the fact that a complete recapitulation of the first fifty years of Pan-American activities swells this volume, seem a sufficient excuse for its somewhat belated appearance.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 17 -- Placing workers on a war footing, mobilized especially for work in the Amazon rubber region is urged by Coordinator Joao Alberto Lins de Barros.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 17 -- Vichy hinted today that the tobacco ration in France -- four cigarettes a day for men and none for women -- would be reduced by one-third next month and that it would be difficult to maintain the bread ration at its present standard, already notoriously insufficient.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 17 (UP) -- General Eisenhower said today that the battle of Tunisia had reached a climax, with Allied forces now ready to "administer the final phase" in the campaign to drive the Axis from Africa.

A FEW weeks ago this corner let loose a moderate blast against the very poor quality of coverage which our news films have given the war. The general deficiency, as we saw it, has been that Army and Navy authorities have been sitting too tightly on the newsreels and haven't sent along sufficient stuff themselves.

As the emphasis of the Second War Loan drive shifted to the little investor, evidence that he is coming through on a scale not before shown in this war was made public yesterday. Nearly one out of three persons solicited by sixteen bank teams in Manhattan and the Bronx during the first three days of the drive made purchases ranging from $25 to $500.

THE Easter display at the New York Botanical Garden will open today in the main conservatories and will continue through May 9. Plants from the Holy Land, including pomegranate, carob, cedar of Lebanon, cypress and olive will be included in the display.

CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) -- Jimmy Conzelman, rough-hewn, 45-year-old coach of the Chicago Cardinals, professional football team, will receive an honorary master's degree in science and physical education tomorrow at the University of Dayton (Ohio) commencement exercises for making the only serious speech in his life.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 17 -- Taking nine of fourteen firsts and tying for another, Princeton's track team opened its season in Palmer Stadium today by defeating Rutgers and Haverford in a triangular meet. The Tigers amassed 100 1/2 points to 75 1/2 for the Scarlet and 33 for the Pennsylvanians.

In Russia last week two mighty armies awaited the passing of Spring mud. Only at the far southern end of the 2,000-mile battleline was military activity notable. There, in the Kuban region of the Caucasus the season was sufficiently advanced to favor attack and the Red Army seized another of the remaining Nazi strongpoints guarding the Wehrmacht's bridgehead beyond the Sea of Azov.
More than 2,500 athletes from over 400 colleges, schools and service outfits will converge at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, for the forty-ninth annual Penn relay carnival Friday and Saturday.

A FLYING FORTRESS BASE, in England, April 17 (U.P.) -- One of the greatest armadas of Flying Fortresses ever assembled against any target in the European theatre battled through fierce Nazi fighter opposition and strong anti-aircraft fire today to deliver a record blow, fittingly against the Bremen plants assembling Focke-Wulf planes, the most bitter aerial enemy of the Fortress bombers.
A WARM-HEARTED, very human story of a pet crow and two children who loved him dearly, an understanding father and mother and an aunt who was by no means as difficult and crotchety as she appeared.

LONDON, April 17 -- United States Army medical authorities working in a laboratory somewhere in the United Kingdom have developed a simple laboratory test by which they can detect the difference between a mild form of pneumonia that has become increasingly common here and the better-known serious type.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- The Polish National Council stated today that it did "not believe the motives given" by the Russians for shooting the Polish-Jewish labor leaders, Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 17 -- Preparations for "large-scale Spring manoeuvres" in the region of Salonika have just been completed by the Bulgarian and German general staffs, according to a report received here today.

THE intellectual's a strange bird. Socrates, who drank hemlock, out of a stiff-necked pride; Galileo, who betrayed himself to keep his skin and yet had to say under his breath "The earth does move." Byron, dying for liberty in Greece.*** Trotsky, an intellectual destined to lose because, like the rest of us, he was unable to adjust himself to his times.

LONDON, April 17 -- The crucial problem of food distribution in post-war Europe, where starvation is likely to be a menace long after the guns have ceased firing, brought an appeal for u500,000 today. The International Cooperative Alliance hopes that this may help cooperative movements in occupied countries to get back on their feet.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 513 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.
Greenwich Village, which some years ago established a reputation for the bizarre, produced something new yesterday -- a contest for dogs and cats in which everybody won a prize.

In response to the critical wartime need for home economists in private industry, the armed forces and on the civilian front, American colleges and universities have now geared their programs directly to the work of preparing women for the thousands of vital war jobs in this field.

NOT many living composers in their middle thirties have had their music recorded as frequently as Dimitri Shostakovich. The Soviet composer has fared exceptionally well on disks, and were it not for the ban on recordings since last Aug. 1 he would be doing even better.

CAIRO, April 17 -- Although the culmination of Field Marshal Erwin Rommel's "Goetterdaemmerung" on the Tunisian heights absorbs the attention of the entire world, a series of relatively minor events, each in itself entirely undramatic, serves to indicate a gradual shift of interest.

A WRITER must work alone; he must forego occupational gregariousness with others of his trade. His first job is to reflect something of the life by which he is surrounded and of which he is a part. This eliminates other writers as neighbors; a writer ought to be surrounded by normal people living a normal life, and writers are not normal people and they live a ridiculous life.

Japanese propagandists marked the eve of the first anniversary of the raid on Tokyo by reviving for the outside world, with significant alterations, a four-day-old speech in which a high military official warned that Japan must stage continuous air raids on the United States to defeat the Americans, "who are stubborn and like to fight."

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- From today's Navy communique about the thirteen raids made on Kiska Thursday it appeared that newly constructed hangars put up at tremendous effort might never house the enemy planes they were intended to receive, so incessant were the attacks.

HUMBLE beginnings are not only the single way of getting into radio writing, but the imperative way. It is best to make your mistakes before a comparatively small listening audience and when there isn't too much money or prestige involved.

At the final concert of the season of the Young People's series of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning twenty-nine youthful subscribers received awards from the hands of Lucrezia Bori for the excellence of their notebooks giving their impressions of the year's programs.

" Are you all set for some good news?" a smiling priest, the Rev. Francis J. Seeger, asked William H. Burghardt yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. He then told Mr. Burghardt that his son, First Lieutenant William Burghardt, reported missing by the War Department, was safe.

A series of four Louis XVI Royal Aubusson medallion tapestries, the property of the estate of the late James Speyer of this city, were among the art objects sold at auction yesterday in the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

THIS year our publishers' Spring announcements differ notably from the normal pre-war style. They are fewer in number; they appear later; many of them are repetitions of announcements made several months ago that still await fulfillment: many others concern reprints now available of books that have for some time been lacking in the book stores; and they are largely expressions of hopes that may be deferred rather than definite and positive assurances.

WHEN Marian Farley, a New York stenographer, received word that her brother Bill had been killed in an automobile accident at Gold Center. Nevada, she bought a secondhand car and drove out there. For Bill had written that, at last, he had acquired a valuable property.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Opinions were divided here today on the question whether Admiral Georges Robert, French High Commissioner for Martinique and Guadeloupe, in setting forth conditions under which he would join the United Nations, had made a bona fide offer or was playing for time to ease the pressure to which he is being subjected by the United States.
In the interests of post-war collaboration may I offer some comments on the article by the Irish Minister to the United States in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of April 4?

State Senator Stephen J. Wojtkowiak, Democrat, of Buffalo, has retained Henry Epstein, former Solicitor General, as counsel in an action to test the constitutionality of the legislative reapportionment act, passed at the last session of the Legislature, it was announced yesterday.

WAHINGTON, April 17 (U.P.) -- The Navy today announced the names of 293 members of the United States Merchant Marine, reported as dead or missing, to their next of kin between March 1 and 31, 1943. The list includes forty-three read and 250 missing, whose next of kin live in thirty-six States, Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

AS historical novels go these days, "Valley in Arms" is brief. Obviously Earl Schenck Miers has done his research, but like the good storyteller he shows himself to be here, he has left most of it out when it came to the actual writing.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 17 -- Paradoxical as the publication last Thursday by the Italian War Office of a eulogy about the British Eighth Army and its "definite superiority" may seem, it cleared the atmosphere on the home front. Enough so, in fact, that for the first time since the fitful days of the battle of Egypt when an Axis victory in Africa appeared within grasp, the Italian man in the street breathes freely.

THERE are two Washington D.C.'s in the United States, the capital of the Republic and Washington, Daviess County, Ind., a typical Midwestern community of 9,000, half-way between Cincinnati and St. Louis on the B. O. The functions, problems and viewpoints of these two communities are necessarily different.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- The fighting men of New York State, in the thick of the Pacific fighting since Dec. 7, 1941, have won in large numbers every decoration for gallantry, bravery and outstanding achievement that it is in General Douglas MacArthur's power to award.

WITH 10-year-old Nancy Nugent prancing onto the stage in short skirts in "Tomorrow the World" that opened Wednesday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre the third generation of a theatrical family makes her pretty curtsy as a professional.

WHAT may result in radio's biggest musical event in recent years is the revelation that Fritz Kreisler is considering an appearance before the microphone. At this juncture there are no specific details on his possible radio debut -- indeed, the whole venture is still on the uncertain side -- but it was learned that the violinist's personal manager, Charles E. Foley, had been "in negotiation" regarding some sort of a program.

UNITING for the first time to present a luncheon-fashion show for the benefit of their respective philanthropic organizations, committees representing the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery and the Spence Adoption Nursery are completing plans for the fete to be given under their auspices on April 27 in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis.

Although retail business hit its Easter peak, wholesale volume slowed down last week, according to the weekly trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Retailers were said to be exerting every effort to keep their stocks within required inventory limitations for the first report period.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 17 -- For the eleventh successive year the hardy dinghy sailors who defy cold weather held their national championship today, and so close was the going that two skippers tied for first place at 70 points each.

The date of Easter may be as early as March 22 and as late as April 25. Schools, transportation companies, hotels, business houses -- all are affected. Reformers of the calendar would stabilize Easter so that it would always fall on the Sunday that lies between April 9 and April 15.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The immediate impact of the President's "hold-the-line" order against inflation has been great at the National War Labor Board, for in one blow it has settled about 10,000 out of 17,000 requests for voluntary wage or salary increases now before the board -- settled them by forcing the board to deny them.

Retailers were said to be exerting every effort to keep their stocks within required inventory limitations for the first report period.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18 (AP) -- Earl Naylor's home run with one on base and the score tied at 1 -- 1 in the sixth inning, gave the Phillies a 4-1 triumph over the Athletics in the fourth and final game of the city series today before 3,500.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Scattered liquidation of wheat futures developed at times last week on the Board of Trade here. May showed a tendency to lose ground compared with the deferred months, hedges being changed over into them. The aggregate trade, however, was light and prices as a whole held within narrow limits.
MOSCOW, April 18 (Reuter) -- The Russian radio, in a broadcast to Germany today, made this statement on German allegations about the "discovery" of the bodies of 10,000 Polish officers near Smolensk:

LONDON, April 18 -- More and more Londoners who have neither the inclination nor money to go to a movie on Sunday afternoon have found a cheaper attraction, in which they also seem to find more entertainment.

There was some easing of deliveries in ready-to-wear last week owing to cancellations necessitated by inventory control, yet in some markets, notably the low-end dress division, retailers found it difficult to get promises of shipments on goods needed for Easter selling, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Representative Martin of Massachusetts, the minority leader, said today he had revived the Republican Study Committee on Extraordinary Monetary Powers of the President with the purpose of giving particular attention to the Treasury's post-war monetary stabilization proposals.

At sundown tonight Jews will begin the observance of the Passover festival in commemoration of their ancestors' deliverance from bondage in Egypt. In this city they will attend services in synagogues and temples and hold ceremonial Seder feasts in their homes.

A statement condemning President Roosevelt's policy of restricting news coverage of the approaching Food Conference of the United Nations, on the ground that it is setting a dangerous precedent and that it is denying to American citizens information essential to the formation of sound public opinion, was issued yesterday by Roy A. Roberts of the Kansas City Star, president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

With the increase in long-distance flying above mountains and oceans there has been a good deal of speculation, especially among civilian passengers, as to how great a distance one can see from high altitudes. The Clipper captains of Pan American Airways have been asked this question a good many times.

The difficulty in "seeing the everlasting truth when it stands new and quiet amid the world's denial" was emphasized yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, in his Palm Sunday sermon.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (U.P.) -- "Victory" gardeners may chase potato bugs and rake and hoe in their I backyard plots with no fear of "shortages" of paris green and garden tools, the War Production Board made known tonight.

Ever since the death of Mrs. Janet Roper on April 5, merchant seamen, their wives and mothers and friends have been writing to the institute paying tribute to "Mother" Roper and asking if some fund could be set up in her memory.

Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman and his band will give the regular series of Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts this Summer. The sixty concerts scheduled are the gift of the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, as they have been for the last twelve years.

A warning that the "sudden awakening of public interest in the post-war problems is not in itself a guarantee of the continuing support for sound policies in a changing world" was sounded yesterday by Dr. James T. Shotwell in a report to the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

In 1917 Georg Brandes, sustaining the arguments of Henri Lambert, declared that if the victors of the first World War applied to the vanquished unequal treatment by means of tariffs the defeated nations would have "but one aspiration -- revenge and liberation. They would profit by every division between the conquerors, and within fifty years would break their chains." This prophecy erred only on the side of understatement.

ST. LOUIS, April 18 (AP) -- The Cardinals won the sixth and final game of the city series, 11 to 0, today, because the Browns' pitchers were wild and generous, their defense was leaky and their batters couldn't hit Lefty Ernie White, the Cards' starter. Each team won three games in the Spring test.

Alarm lest Congress fail to renew the Trade Agreements Act in June led 1,200 members of the American Economic Association to make public here yesterday a warning addressed to Representative Robert L. Doughton, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

BOSTON, April 18 (AP) -- Bobby Doerr's fifth-inning homer into the left-field screen with Eddie Lake on base enabled the Red Sex to open their three-game intracity series with the Braves with a 5-3 victory today before a 10,010 crowd at Fenway Park. The Red Sox donated all the $8,835.15 receipts to the Red Cross.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, April 18 (AP) -- Major Kenneth McCullar of Batesville, Miss., one of the men responsible for the high development of skip-bombing, which has cost the Japanese many vessels, is dead.

With the opening this morning of the second week of the nation's $13,000,000,000 Second War Loan drive, New York City, with 82.5 per cent of its $3,000,000,000 non-banking quota already collected, faced an intensive drive by thousands of volunteer War Bond salesmen who are expected to top this week the assigned quota by a wide margin.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 18 -- Another victim of the "ill health" at present sweeping the Italian Cabinet and party leaders, Carlo Tiengo, Minister of Corporations, resigned today after less than three months in office. Premier Mussolini named as his successor Tullio Cianetti, the present undersecretary in the same Ministry.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Monday, April 19 (Reuter) -- Adolf Hitler at his meeting with Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Hungarian regent, asked that more Hungarian troops be sent to the eastern front, according to reports from Berlin.
The Italian Sunday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The United Press:

If there is any doubt as to the existence of dramatic ability in the Army ranks, that notion was repudiated yesterday in the Special Service Branch Theatre of the Army's Second Service Command at 52 Broadway.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- Violent German and Rumanian counter-attacks have failed to dislodge Lieut. Gen. Ivan Maslennikoff's forward elements from ground gained on the first day of the resumed offensive against the enemy's last Kuban foothold.

The anniversary of General Doolittle's spectacular raid on Tokyo finds the high expectations excited by that sudden swoop from "Shangri-La" a little deflated. We have never been able to repeat the raid. General Doolittle himself warns that we must repeat it many times before this war is won.

CHUNGKING, China, April 18 (U.P.) -- Japanese attempts to broaden their foothold around Hwajung in Hunan have been smashed with more than 300 casualties to the enemy, a Chinese communique announced today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 18 -- The noted Welsh terrier, Champion Flornell Rare-Bit of Twin Ponds, owned by Mrs. Edward F. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., tonight gained his sixteenth best-in-show title. Handled by John Goudie, Rare-Bit was placed at the head of 696 rivals in the fourth annual show of the Saw Mill River Kennel Club, held at the County Center.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 18 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer confirmed today the purchase of film rights to the Anna Seghers novel, "The Seventh Cross," for which Twentieth Century-Fox and Warners also were reported to have bid. The story, which has an English translation by James Agalston, deals with the experiences of seven fugitives from a Nazi concentration camp.

The cut every Winter-book bettor felt -- the gash on Count Fleet's foot -- apparently was responding to treatment yesterday, even though a piece of hoof had to be cut away, and Trainer Don Cameron said he would ship the "Derby dandy" to Louisville today, "barring accident," The Associated Press reported.

PITTSBURGH, April 18 -- Raw steel output last week dropped 1 1/2 points to 98.5 per cent of rated capacity. Indications are that this activity may be slightly bettered this week. It is believed that repairs to furnaces have been responsible for the slight drop in steel ingot production.

MOSCOW, April 18 -- The Presidium of Supreme Soviets has awarded the title of Hero of the Soviet Union posthumiously to Lieutenant Otokar Yarosh of the Czechoslovak Army, it was announced today. This is the first time that the State's highest military decoration has been awarded a foreigner.
PHILADELPHIA, April 18 -- The Cramp Ship Building Company launched two submarines and two floating workshops into the Delaware River within forty-three minutes today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 18 (U.P.) -- In yesterday's raid on Palermo, Flying Fortresses scored direct hits not only on ships but on a waterfront workshop and a floating dry-dock.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., reported yesterday for 1942 a consolidated net income of $30,808,397 after charges, taxes and provision for $9,350,000 tax liability in the event of the recovery of foreign investments which have been charged off.

The promise of warmer weather yesterday cheered householders who had used the last of their fuel oil rations in the unseasonably cold spell, but left them with the problem of what to do about hot water from now until Oct. 1, when the new ration year begins.
Six new films, including a Mexican and an Italian importation, comprise the week's openings. The schedule follows:
LONDON, April 18 (U.P.) -- The Russian noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

ALBANY, April 18 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today, without comment, the Anderson bill providing for the licensing of motor vehicle dealers and salesmen by the State Motor Vehicle Bureau. The measure would have fixed annual fees for licenses and required the posting of surety bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Three Philadelphia men were accused by the Federal Trade Commission today of misrepresentation which induced manufacturers of war supplies to purchase an aluminum product called "colalloy" at prices from 20 to 60 per cent higher than comparable materials.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 18 (AP) -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced the support of his organization today to the fight of the United Mine Workers of America for pay on a portal-to-portal basis.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) -- Navy Communique 348:

AN AMERICAN HEAVY BOMBER BASE, in North Africa, April 17 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Axis is relying less on fighter planes and more on anti-aircraft guns to defend its southern front against the terrific blows being dealt from Africa by the Allied air forces.

Argentina is the "eyes and ears of the Japanese Government in the Western Hemisphere," said Raymon Lavalle, former Argentine consular attache in Tokyo, in a coast-to-coast broadcast in this country last night.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 18 (AP) -- Senator Green of Rhode Island said in a statement issued here last night that criticism of him in a pamphlet by Ralph H. Lutz, professor of history at Stanford University, "is unjustified."

Emphasis of the spiritual values i at stake in the war is the best possible basis for long-range planning of our relationships with the other American republics, the Rev. Joseph F: Thorntng declared yesterday at a communion bres-kfast of the New Amsterdam Council of the Knights of Columbus at the Hotel Astor.

LONDON, Monday, April 19 -- Royal Air Force planes pounding at German shipping lashed at an enemy convoy of fifteen ships off the Netherland coast and raided the docks at Dieppe yesterday after light but widespread action over Northwest Germany, the Low Countries and France through Saturday night in the Allied air offensive.

I served as an officer of the United States Army in 1917, 1918 and 1919. I was proud of that service then and I am proud of it today. Because of my pride in the United States Army, I hate to see it used as a threat to force men into civilian war jobs. Yet that is just what the "work or fight" order of the War Manpower Commission amounts to.

EDGEWATER, N.J., April 18 -- The possibility of a general walkout at the Edgewater plant of the Aluminum Company of America grew stronger today as 1,000 members of Local 16, Aluminum Workers of America, voted unanimously to rescind the local's no-strike policy and thus set the stage for a strike vote Tuesday among the 3,000 employes.

Bias against the Negro is due in some measure to the failure of certain magistrates and judges to understand conditions in Harlem, it was charged yesterday by members of the Harlem Lawyers Association at an open forum they sponsored at the Mother African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, 160 West 137th Street.

HAMILTON, April 18 (AP) -- Shipping and immigration handicaps in the rescue of many thousands of additional refugees from Nazi oppression in Europe were foremost problems facing the British-American refugee conference here tonight.

A directory of employment opportunities open now to college women has been issued by the Smith College Vocational Office. Based on the openings that have been reported to Mrs. Marjory P. Nield, director of the office, the fourteen-page booklet analyzes "the changing picture of the employment situation" in thirty fields ranging from applied mathematics to social works.

The Anglo-American conference on the refugee problem which begins in Bermuda today is important both as a symbol of future cooperation among the United Nations and as the first attempt at international collaboration to mitigate the appalling horror of Hitler's war of extermination since the outbreak of that war.

In the belief that out of the war social and economic changes are bound to develop, the New York Academy of Medicine has named a committee of distinguished doctors and laymen to study the relationship of medicine and the changing order.

Changing the look of a suit is not only a personal economy and satisfaction. It helps, too, in the government's program of conservation of clothes. This is one springtime when the trick will be practiced extensively, to the benefit of the family exchequer.

The formation of a new film distributing company known as Film Classics, Inc., was announced yesterday by Bertram A. Mayers, attorney, of 608 Fifth Avenue. The object of the company, according to Mr. Mayers, "is to continue in circulation the better type pictures produced independently, both in this country and abroad, which were distributed originally by the major film companies."

More than 3,000 persons, the largest audience of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's season, attended the final concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon. The program was a repetition of the Thursday and Friday performances of St. Matthew's Passion, by Bach.

Wider use of residential restrictions on the upper East Side of Manhattan is recommended in proposals for amending the zoning law as it applies to the section between Second Avenue and the East River from Sixtieth to Ninety-sixth Street.

Informed observers in Washington expect the next two months to be the most revealing of the war. Three weeks ago they were saying the African campaign was so far behind schedule that the plans for the Summer offensive might be jeopardized. Now the time estimates are being revised.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC (Delayed) -- Well-deserved recognition was given "Scat" this week when Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., Commander of the South Pacific Area and the South Pacific Force, commended this air transport organization.

LONDON, April 18 -- Opinion on the latest budget is admirably summed up by The Economist, a financial newspaper, which says: "By far the largest budget this country has ever seen is also one of the least controversial. It is remarkable enough that the Chancellor of the Exchequer could propose to spend 5,756,000,000 in a single year, which is more than the whole national income as recently as 1940.

Americans the country over are grimly determined to let nothing stand in the way of winning the war, but they are concerned over a number of problems, including the handling of the manpower situation, the outlook for food production, the possibility of putting taxes on a pay-as-you-go basis, and the failure to concentrate a larger part of our strength in the Pacific theatre of the war.

President Getulio Vargas of Brazil can be sure of good wishes from the United States on this, his sixtieth birthday. Another man in his place could have done much to obstruct hemispheric solidarity. President Vargas led the way toward it. The efforts of Axis propagandists to win him over to their side failed.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Thirty-two Senators oppose committing the United States at this time to post-war participation in an international police force to preserve the peace.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Committee on American History sent telegrams to Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York and Governor Walter S. Goodland of Wisconsin today requesting that they investigate the teaching of American history in the State-sponsored Milne School at Albany and State-sponsored and controlled Wisconsin High School.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 112.2 to 111.9. The general trend in the prices of farm products was downward as a result of the recent stabilization activities in Washington. For example, the sharp decline in the price of hogs came about after Administrator Brown threatened to place a ceiling on the price of live hogs unless the price dropped of its own accord within a reasonable time.

LISBON, April 18 (AP) -- An exchange of wounded British and Italian war prisoners was completed here tonight, with two trains taking 409 Italians home and the hospital ship Newfoundland sailing with 314 incapacitated British soldiers.

LONDON, April 18 -- "Familiarity breeds contempt," and thus it is that a further increase of 50,000,000 to the record 1,000,000,000 in the Bank of England's fiduciary note issues was passed almost without comment.

LONDON, April 18 -- Sergeant Dennis Smith of the Royal Air Force stood in the door of a doomed bomber over enemy country and took a million-to-one chance. He tried to save two lives with one parachute.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 18 -- Nearly 500 New Bedford women, including grandmothers and high school girls, are working part-time in war plants here to help beat the Axis, according to a survey. Their employers are the Cornell Dubilier and Aerovox companies, condenser manufacturers, and the Goodyear Corporation, which is making barrage balloons.

BOSTON, April 18 -- Little Gerard Cote, a Canadian infantry sergeant stationed at Valleyfield, Que., became the sixth repeater in the forty-seven-year history of the famed Boston A.A. marathon today when he finished 1 minute 38 1-5 seconds ahead of Private Johnny Kelley of Boston and the United States Army, who was second.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Little change was shown in the lard and fat situation here last week, although stocks in the hands of retailers are reported to have increased, the temporary stay in lend-lease business permitting packers to cover a larger percentage of their output into retail outlets where stocks have been built up considerably.
VALPARAISO, Ind., April 18 (AP) -- "Disarmament is the only way future wars can be avoided," former Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska said today in a commencement address at Valparaiso University.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Increased talk of large imports of oats and barley from Canada to supplement supplies of feeding grains in this country led last week to some liquidation by holders of futures on the Board of Trade here, but the market received good support on the breaks. High premiums continue to be paid for domestic oats in the cash market and farmers are shownig little disposition to sell.
WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Meat rations will continue on a weekly basis in May, officials said today.

"Queens Die Proudly" is the title of W.L. White's new book to be published June 3 by Harcourt, Brace. It is the story of the "Swoose," the only one of the original thirty-five planes stationed in the Philippines that has been brought back to this country.

Connecticut's trout season opened under cloudy skies. New York and New Jersey did not fare any too well at the hands of the weather man and he played no favorites with the Nutmeg State enthusiasts on Saturday.
CHUNGKING, China, April 18 (U.P.) -- A communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, April 18 -- The Italian occupying authority in France is credited with the intention of transferring into the Alps all Jews hitherto subjected to "enforced residence" on the Riviera. Their destination has been reported to be Megeve, a fashionable mountain resort closed to the French by Vichy because "patrons flaunted their wealth" and encouraged a black market.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (U.P.) -- One hundred and nine officers and enlisted men of a Flying Fortress squadron have returned to the United States on a group furlough after a 200,000-mile battle odyssey of bombing missions in China and Burma, in Libya and, more recently, in the thick of the Tunisian fighting, the War Department disclosed tonight.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- With their new second-base combination figuring in five double plays, the Cubs defeated the White Sox, 4 to 1, before 8,281 at Wrigley Field today and went ahead, two games to one, in the home-town portion of Chicago's annual Spring series.

DETROIT, April 18 (AP) -- The Tigers squared their exhibition series with the Pirates at three games each by pushing home a run in the tenth inning on Catcher Paul Richards's-single for a 1-to-0 victory before 6,846 spectators at Briggs Stadium today.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- Chicago furniture market sponsors, whose Winter exposition drew disapproval from the Office of Defense Transportation, announced today they would conduct a ten-day show in June "because 96 per cent of America's merchants and 80 per cent of its manufacturers believe it necessary."
The New York Chapter of the American Red Cross issued yesterday a call for 150 additional registrants for its partly completed Gray Lady class, which is to start training April 26.

Courage, already demonstrated by our soldiers in the present conflict, must be supplemented by faith if we are to translate a military victory into a moral and spiritual victory, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

Believing that the time has come for industry to encourage public thinking and discussion about postwar planning, the International Nickel Company will embark on a new advertising campaign soon in over 100 newspapers, magazines, farm papers and trade publications to invite citizens everywhere to join in a "nation-wide town meeting" of post-war discussion.

In Ireland the other day a child of 6, poking under a stone, is said to have found a thousand silver pennies. Their date is not given. The last English silver pence were issued in 1661 or 1662. The first ones were coined in the reign of the Saxon King Offa, in 700 and something.

Mayor La Guardia gave the local Office of Price Administration a virtual ultimatum yesterday when he declared in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall that it was the responsibility of OPA to protect the public from exorbitant prices and that he would let the people of the nation as well as of New York City know of any failure to discharge that responsibility.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 18 -- Governor John W. Bricker warned 156 graduates at the University of Dayton commencement exercises today that in preparing men and women for post-war leadership higher education must guard against "any trend toward State collectivism."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 18 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Robert P. Patterson and James V. Forrestal, Under Secretaries, respectively, of War and of the Navy, announced today the selection of thirty-nine industrial plants to receive the Army-Navy production award for outstanding performance on war work.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 19 (AP) -- A lone Liberator bomber on a reconnaissance flight bombed a 10,000-ton Japanese merchant vessel in Kavieng Harbor Sunday morning and on its way home shot down an enemy fighter plane over Vitiaz Strait.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- To meet a prospective shortage of high-protein feeds, the Agriculture Department is negotiating for the importation of feed wheat from Canada and will start next week a nation-wide voluntary domestic program for conservation of the dwindling supply of this raw material for the production of milk, livestock and poultry products, it was learned today.
The publication in your issue of April 16 of a letter titled "An Air Warden Is Hopeful" and signed "Blue Alert" embodies certain implications which are definitely misleading to the public.

The Giants made just as many hits, but not nearly enough runs as the Senators yesterday at the Polo Grounds and Ossie Bluege's outfit handed the New Yorkers a 9-3 setback before 5,000 chilled fans, many of whom left long before the last out.

Enrique Quinones, star center forward of the champion Hispano soccer team, made a fine showing in his farewell game before joining the Army next Thursday. He tallied twice and passed to Salcedo for another goal at Brooklyn Oval yesterday as the Hispano's defeated the Wanderers by 4 -- 2 in a second-round Lewis Cup contest.
Tonight's events: Bach Circle of New York, Town Hall, 8:45 o'clock; Bach's St. Matthew Passion, presented by the John Harms Chorus, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 8:30.

CHICAGO, April 18 (AP) -- The National Association of Retail Grocers stated today that a survey of grocers showed they wanted some processed foods removed from the point-ration program and favored use of the red statmps only for meat.

It is pretty well established by now that the British have a good many admirable and likable qualities and a few traits (we have some ourselves) that are a little irritating to others. Nothing would be so irritating, however, as to have the British or any other people perfect.

SUVA, Fiji Islands, March 24 (Delayed) -- A strong native Fijian force is training under command of Brigadier J.G.C. Wales to fight the Japanese. Some of them have been training for two and a half years.

NYACK, N.Y., April 18 -- Ferry service between here and Tarrytown, which was stopped in November, 1941, after almost 100 years of operation, has been resumed. The first trip was made last Monday morning, with daily service since.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 18 -- International church circles in Geneva report an impending move by the Quisling authorities in Norway to eliminate further opposition to the government church through the conscription of opposition pastors in the civilian labor draft.

If Joe McCarthy tossed restlessly in his sleep last night, that can be easily understood by the 9,949 fans who were at Ebbets Field yesterday as well as others who have followed the misfortunes of the Yankees this Spring.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 18 -- Eight more races were held today at the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Corny Shields came out of the scramble of craft with his boat Sissy as the national Class B dinghy champion.

Public confidence in securities did not appear unduly ruffled last week by events on the domestic economic front. In the wake of further anti-inflationary efforts by Washington, the stock market received another jolt when the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled that increases in freight rates granted the railroads last year would be suspended from May 1 until Jan. 1, when they would be reviewed.

Announcement last week that the Office of Price Administration was about to impose a ceiling on cotton brought some nervous liquidation into the futures market, but the gains acquired in the early part of the period were sustained for all active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange, as indications of strong opposition to the move led to a subsequent belief that the original drastic action might be modified or not invoked at this time.
There's something about the freshly washed feeling of an April atmosphere that makes women want their complexion to match the dewy freshness of the season.
