Lubka Kolessa, pianist, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Born in the Ukraine, Miss Kolessa received her musical training in Vienna, where she studied with Emil Sauer. When but 15 she toured the principal cities of Europe, and has appeared with leading orchestras abroad, She now lives in Ottawa.
Mrs. Theodore Weicker of 1115 Fifth Avenue will give a dinner tonight at her home for Dr. Victor Fernandez Manero, Minister of Public Health of Mexico, and Mrs. Manero.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The Agriculture Department reduced today its estimates of 1943 civilian supplies of a large number of foods, including meats, fish, poultry, milk and milk products, fats and fruits. Estimates of supplies of a few commodities, principally canned fruits and vegetables and sugar, were revised slightly upward from those set at the start of the year.

Ways by which fuller use can be made of the available skill and talent still untapped in this country will be discussed at a "National Wartime Conference of the professions, arts, sciences and white-collar fields" on May 8 and 9 at the Hotel Commodore, it was announced yesterday.
The German Sunday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

A syndicate of investors represented by Wasserman, Behr Shagan, attorneys, has purchased from the Straight Improvement Company the ten-story store and left building on a plot 70 by 88.6 feet at 282 Seventh Avenue, at the northwest corner of Twenty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, April 18 -- Highly beneficial rains which ranged up to 1.72 inches in some areas have broken the drought that threatened heavy damage to Winter wheat in some sections. The precipitation was heaviest in the States where most needed.

PEARL HARBOR, April 18 -- It is believed here that the Japanese, having experimented recently with concentrated large-scale air attacks for the first time in the Southwest Pacific theatres, may now be analyzing the probabilities in some new offensivedefensive blow, which, however, would not necessarily take the direction apparently feared in Australia.

Holy Week and the week before Christmas (traditionally lean at the box office) are the only two periods of the year when managements may take advantage of the Actors Equity dispensation permitting suspension of engagements with no obligation to pay their casts for the missing performances.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 19 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Girls and women in ever-increasing numbers are being recruited as workers in automobile repair shops with considerable success, according to a report made public today by the National Automobile Dealers Association.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 18 -- The Allied and German air forces traded blows in long-range bombing raids yesterday. Flying Fortresses hit four ships and set one afire at Palermo, Sicily, with their escorting Lightnings destroying seventeen enemy fighters.

LONDON, April 18 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for March, based on 1930 as 100, was 162.2, compared with 162.1 for February and January, and 158.8 for March, 1942. March levels were the highest since the outbreak of the war, representing an increase of 65 per cent on pre-war prices.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- American Lightning fighters shot down two Japanese bombers and three of the bombers' escort of six Zero fighters over the enemy base at Kahili in the Shortland Island area in the Solomons Islands today (Solomons time), then encountered another bomber and shot it down, according to a Navy communique.

An investor has purchased from Sarah Levin and Dora Brodsky the thirty-family apartment house on a plot 40 by 118 feet at 2945 West Thirty-second Street, in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn. The buyer, who was represented by Samuel K. Beier, attorney, paid cash over a first mortgage held by the Greater New York Savings Bank.

The Tokyo radio recalled last night the air raid on Japanese cities April 18, 1942, by United States fliers led by Major Gen. James H. Doolittle and declared that the United States "has recently feverishly been trying to attempt a second air raid."

Leadership in Congress has at last asserted itself. The House has been brought to recognize the great responsibility that it seemed for a while in danger of shirking. A withholding tax must go into effect not later than July 1. The credit for insisting on a quick compromise seems to belong mainly to Mr. McCormack, the majority leader; Mr. Martin, the minority leader, and to Speaker Rayburn.

SOUTH PORTLAND, Me., April 18 (AP) -- Some New England Shipbuilding Corporation employes who received a day off when the Liberty ship contractor went on a six-day work week today reported for duty as usual but were not admitted to the yard.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- Speaker Rayburn, who broke the pay-as-you-go deadlock on Friday by calling House leaders of both parties together to work out a compromise tax bill, will play a vital role tomorrow in removing the remaining obstacles to a pay- as-you-go bill.

As the Department of Agriculture lowered its estimates of 1943's supplies of a large number of food items, spokesmen for fruit and vegetable growers who supply much of the Eastern seaboard all year round sat down yesterday and, summing up developments of three days of meetings here, put their finger on the reasons for the revisions.

The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, blessed the palms yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral and presided at the mass that followed the traditional procession of palms, in which he took part.

The Third Avenue Committee, representing business and real estate interests that have been active in seeking demolition of the Third Avenue elevated line, suggested yesterday that the Board of Transportation could save $648,000 annually by shutting down the line from City Hall to 129th Street between 9 P.M. and 5 A.M. daily.

WITH THE NORTH AFRICAN STRATEGIC AIR FORCE, April 17 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Eleven of the men who flew Mitchell bombers from aircraft carriers to bomb Tokyo with Major Gen. James H. Doolittle sought tonight -- without much hope -- to arrange a celebration Sunday of the first anniversary of the first bombing of Japan.

Mayor La Guardia made public yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, the general outlines of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's plan to construct and operate after the war a landscaped community of thirty-five medium-rental apartment buildings on the seventy-two-acre tract bounded by First Avenue, Avenue C, East Fourteenth Street and East Twentieth Street.

George Worth, Phil Lubart, Herbert Spector and Walter Vignini qualified yesterday for the national saber tournament, which will be held here on June 12. Leading the qualifiers was Worth, who came through with four triumphs in the final round-robin of the competition at the Salle Santelli.

ADVANCE ARMY BASE IN THE ALEUTIANS, March 30 (Delayed) -- The weather was dirty, and this mission -- a wild commando raid from the sky -- was even more so. But all thirty-two of us had volunteered, so the sooner it was over the better.

Keeping within your fat allotment is no easy task, but it may be achieved successfully if you eliminate elaborate cakes, pies and such from your menus, and reduce the shortening in other foods whenever possible.

Police Commissioner Valentine announced yesterday the names of twenty members of the department who will be honored for acts of bravery during 1942. One of the men, Detective Joseph A. Miccio, was killed in line of duty. The medals will be presented late in May or early in June.

WITH THE BRITISH EIGHTH ARMY, North of Sousse, April 15 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- About three weeks ago General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery was discussing the strategy for the final battle of Tunisia at his field headquarters with Major Gen. Walter Smith, Chief of Staff for General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the Allied Commander in Chief.

The success of the tremendous wartime home-canning program organized and promoted by the Federal Government is endangered by the threat of an intensified sugar shortage, leading members of the sugar industry asserted yesterday.

LONDON, April 18 -- Anthony Asquith, son of Lady Oxford and an executive of the British film industry, told an industry gathering today that "Desert Victory" was not only a magnificent film but also a powerful "piece of propaganda."

LONDON, Monday, April 19 (U.P.) -- Germany threw increasingly heavy forces of infantry, tanks and airplanes into counter-attacks in the Kuban area Sunday, only to be repulsed with great losses, as on preceding days, Russia's Sunday midnight communique reported today.

LONDON, April 18 -- Adolf Hitler has exacted a pledge from Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Regent of Hungary, that he will oppose any British-American invasion of the Balkans, Berlin broadcasts reported today.

Dropping of a "me-first" attitude, or that of "my country, right or wrong," was urged upon the world yesterday morning as a step to prevent another world war, by the Rev. Franklin P. Cole, preaching at the Congregational Church-in-the-Gardens, Forest Hills, Queens.
KEARNY, N.J., April 18 -- The Federal Shipbuilding and Drydock Company launched three warships today, a destroyer at its Kearny shipyard and two destroyer escorts at its Port Newark yard.

CINCINNATI, April 18 (AP) -- Manager Lou Boudreau of the Indians kicked away the ball game today, giving the Reds a 2-1, 10-inning victory for a sweep of the four games of the Spring exhibition series.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 18 (U.P.) -- British representatives to the Anglo-American Conference on War Refugee Problems, which opens here tomorrow, indicated tonight there was little possibility for any immediate relief for millions of hapless persons in Europe.

The "Shangri-La" from which American planes took off to bomb Tokyo apparently was revealed at last yesterday to have been aircraft carriers, a year after the United States Air Force gave Japan the first bombing in its history.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Carl Spaatz said today that his Northwest African Air Forces had "secured supremacy of the air" since the Mareth Line battle began on March 20 and had shot down 519 Axis planes since that date, against a loss of 175.

LONDON, April 18 -- A serious situation has arisen because of the severe shortage of hospital space and the growing shortage of medical and nursing personnel. More babies are being born all the time, yet hospital facilities are decreasing.

WASHINGTON, April 18 -- The offering, through the Federal Reserve banks, of one-year 7/8 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series C-1944 in exchange for 0.65 per cent Treasury certificates of indebtedness of Series C-1943 and 3/4 per cent Commodity Credit Corporation notes of Series F, both maturing May 1, was announced today by the Treasury.

DETROIT, April 18 -- Country-wide consumer rationing of liquor is inevitable in the next few months, officials of the National Alcoholic Beverage Control Association said today, on the eve of their semi-annual convention.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Senate considered calendar bills, approved the conference report on the government overtime bill, received the Taft resolution for investigations into OWI and CIAA propaganda, received the Truman report on investigation of steel plate tests and recessed at 1:07 P.M. until noon Thursday.

LONDON, April 19 -- Easter Week was ushered in today with new blows from the air against the "European fortress." The Germans retaliated in a far smaller measure with a number of their low-level hit-and-run attacks against coastal towns in Southern and Eastern England. With the arrival of better Spring weather the air war has been intensified by both sides.
Baseball games involving college nines that were scheduled to be played in this area yesterday were canceled or postponed because of bad weather.

As the Red Cross announced a list of gifts to its 1943 War Fund yesterday, headed by one of $10,000 from the William Wrigley Jr. Company, the New York chapter of the Red Cross received two station wagons as gifts for use for services to the armed forces and in the disaster relief work of the chapter.
If the Dodgers can break from the barrier at top speed and get off to an early lead, they have an excellent chance of winning the National League pennant race.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, in a formal statement tonight charged William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, with trying to "stop me from telling the American people facts about rubber which had been certified as correct by his own office."

Confirming what has become increasingly evident in recent days, Lieut. Gen. Spaatz, commanding the Northwest African Air Force, flatly declares that the Allies have now achieved air supremacy in the hotly contested Mediterranean battle zone. To clinch the argument, Allied Headquarters in North Africa announces that on Sunday and Monday Allied planes shot down no fewer than ninety-six enemy aircraft, including sixty-eight big Junkers transports, at a loss of only eleven Allied planes.

A recent poll by The Associated Press showing thirty-two Senators opposed to United States participation in policing the world after the war was characterized yesterday as "most disquieting" by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a statement issued in behalf of the Carnegie Endowment for Peace, which he also heads.

An inquiry made by The Associated Press throws an interesting but by no means entirely revealing light on the present frame of mind of the Senate regarding the role of the United States in the post-war world. Each member was asked the question: "Do you favor committing the Senate and the country now to a post-war course of preserving the peace through an international police force?"
WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Two moves aimed at keeping an eye on propaganda disseminated by government agencies were made in the Senate today.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, April 19 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace declared today that if, after the war, riches again fall in the hands of a few, the war will have been in vain and democracy will have failed.
NEW ORLEANS, April 19 (AP) --Phillip Murray, president of the C.I.O., commented favorably on the War Manpower Commission's job freeze order in an interview here today.

Calling for united action by all nations to organize the post-war world on a basis of international cooperation, the Sons of the Revolution at their triennial meeting in Fraunces Tavern, at Broad and Pearl Streets, adopted yesterday a resolution rejecting isolation for the United States in the interests of future peace.

BUENOS AIRES, April 19 -- The recent rise of the peso in the free market has induced the Central Bank of the Argentine Republic to change what is known as the official exchange rate for non-regular exports.

A simple new device with which, it is believed, volunteers can produce surgical dressings three to five times faster than the present rate has been offered to the American Red Cross by the Delaware chapter.
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Navy communiqu 349:

SOMEWHERE IN NORTH AFRICA, April 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- Major Gen. James H. Doolittle and thirteen fliers who accompanied him on the flight over Tokyo and now are serving under him in this theatre celebrated the first anniversary of the famous raid today with dinner at a farmhouse near advanced headquarters.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 20 (AP) -- Fierce new German attacks, launched regardless of costs in attempts to widen their bridgehead in the Kuban area of the Caucasus near Novorossiisk, have been repulsed. About 1,600 more Nazis were wiped out and seventeen planes destroyed, the Russians announced today in their midnight communique.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- A hearing was set down today by the Securities and Exchange Commission for May 18 on a voluntary plan filed some time ago for reorganization of the Laclede Gas Light Company, disposal of the electric utility assets it operated to Union Electric Company of Missouri, and partial compliance by the Ogden Corporation with Section 11 (b) of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

The Council of Actors Equity Association will hold a special meeting this afternoon to see what can be done to clarify the status of the actor in relation to the "work or fight" order issued by Manpower Commissioner McNutt in February.

WITH THE CHINESE ARMY, on the Salween Front, April 18 (Delayed) -- Although the Japanese profess to be occupying Western Yunnan, the occupation is not very extensive, for I recently crossed the Salween River and spent nine days unmolested in forbidden territory under the protection of ingenious Chinese guerrillas.

Procurement of essential food requirements for the British West Indies, Bermuda and the Bahamas has been made more difficult by shortages that are developing in this country, J. Huggins of the British Colony Supply Mission declared yesterday at the opening of a three-day conference of Caribbean import controllers in the Hotel Governor Clinton.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- The second major step in carrying out the Middle West Corporation's sweeping program for integrating its utility system was announced today by Purcell L. Smith, president.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 -- Twentieth Century-Fox today renewed its option on its contract with Ann Rutherford, now on loan to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and assigned her to the lead in "Goodbye, My Lover, Goodbye;" Helen Deutsch's story of a wartime love affair, for which the company reportedly paid $75,000.

Susie, who is "2-year-old-size," was being undressed again. As uncertain childish fingers unfastened Susie's oversized buttons, the child was encouraged in her task by the volunteer "habit-training" teacher who sat by her side. For Susie -- a rag doll -- and the teacher, a volunteer orthopedic nurse's assistant, both work for the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- A five-run rally in the tenth inning enabled the Braves to gain an even break in their city series with the Red Sox today as they took a 6-1 decision from the Yawkey men before a Patriot's Day crowd estimated at 2,000 fans.

The fifty-seventh annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association will be held from today until Thursday inclusive at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The opening session at 10 o'clock this morning will be devoted to the wartime problems of papers with less than 50,000 circulation.

An exhibition of paintings by members of Local 91, International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, will open with a special preview this afternoon at 4 o'clock at the American British Art Center when a jury composed of William Meyer-owitz, Theresa Bernstein, Otto Soglow, Isabel Bishop, Edward Hopper and Luigi Lucioni will award six prizes.

Basil L. Walters, executive editor of The Minneapolis Star-Journal, told the opening session of a three-day meeting of the National Newspaper Promotion Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday that the newspapers of America have gained new prestige by their leadership in campaigns to sell war bonds and collect scrap metal.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 19 -- Herbert Todd Ehlers, 11 years old, was found dead late this afternoon in the basement of his home, 18 Ardmore Avenue, hanging by a belt from a low beam.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, April 20 (AP) -- Allied bombers started fires in attacks on Kupang, Dutch Timon, and Finschafen, New Guinea, Monday, the high command reported today.

A club for members of the Waacs, Waves, Spars, Women's Marine Reserve Corps, Army and Navy Nurses's Corps, and similar corps of the United Nations, will be opened April 30 in the former Whitelaw Reid mansion at 451 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Responding to inquiries about observance by Jewish war workers of the feast of Passover, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, emphasized today the importance of maintaining unbroken production of essential war items.

Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, chairman of the European executive council of the Joint Distribution Committee, who spent nineteen months in Europe and North Africa, traced yesterday in an interview the relief work already done for refugees in Europe and Africa, and declared that Tunisia would be a "testing ground for the much greater task that will face us when the Allied forces invade Europe."

Sergei Rachmaninoff, Russian-born pianist and composer who died on March 28 at his home at Beverly Hills, Calif., left his entire estate, with the exception of two parcels of real estate in Germany, to his widow, Mrs. Natalie A. Rachmaninoff, according to the will filed yesterday for probate in Surrogate's Court here.

Because of a White House request for clemency, the six-month sentence imposed yesterday by Justices Cooper, Doyle and Oliver in Special Sessions on Stephen Smithney, a former assistant secretary in the General Electric Company, for sending annoying letters to President Roosevelt, Mrs. Roosevelt, Owen D. Young and many other prominent persons was suspended.

The speculation by ticket agencies, hotel porters and others in railroad passenger transportation referred to lately in the news columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES was largely curtailed by the Pullman Company last year. Formerly, one railroad ticket could be used to purchase unlimited seat or berth space, and reservations, requiring no ticket, could be made to cover long periods.

In his speech at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press yesterday, Kent Cooper, general manager, paid tribute to fourteen press and radio reporters who have been listed as dead or missing in the war.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following changes for week ending April 14, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: An increase of $477,000,000 in United States Government obligations, a decrease of $259,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks and increases of $136,000,000 in balances with domestic banks, $224,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $269,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

New Jersey's opening day carried with it many unusual features and by the time another one rolls around it is expected that many anglers will be able to enjoy one of the finest stretches of trout water in the State, heretofore closed to them.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Charges by Hugh Russell Fraser, chairman of the Committee on American History, that "ersatz" American history is taught at Milne High School, the practice unit of the New York State College for Teachers, were denied today by Dr. John M. Sayles, president of the college.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., April 19 -- The Federal court trial of five men indicted under the Civil Liberties Law in connection with the lynching of Howard Wash, a 48-year-old Negro who had been convicted of murder, will begin here tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Philadelphia and Washington, two of the lesser lights in the American League, will start big-time baseball off on its second season of the war tomorrow with ceremonies that traditionally mark the natioal pastime's opening in the nation's capital.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The War Production Board today took steps toward reducing the variety and sizes of cotton, rayon and wool blankets, while at the same time assuring production of utilitarian and well-wearing types. As a result of the order (M-298) it is anticipated that unit production of blankets will be increased.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- The plan for liquidating in part the United Gas Improvement Company, oldest utility holding company in the nation, was approved overwhelmingly today by the holders of common stock at a special meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Indications that the Administration is thinking about relaxing its restrictions on press coverage of the United Nations food conference next month at Hot Springs, Va., leaked out of an extraordinary closed session of the Senate Foreign Relations and Agriculture Committees today.
A new issue of $750,000 certificates of indebtedness was announced yesterday by Mount Vernon, N.Y., for award on April 27. The issue will be dated May 1, 1943, and will be payable on Feb. 15, 1944.

Defeating Hitler first is a strategic policy, but it does not mean that Germany, rather than Japan, offers the greatest threat to the Australian, American or European way of life, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Foreign Minister, declared in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Drake.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The War Manpower Commission is preparing an amendment to its job-control regulations whereby local offices of the United States Employment Service may be permitted to approve transfer of workers in essential industries at higher pay if they are utilized for the effective prosecution of the war.

Add to the list of films opening this week "White Savage," which will arrive at the Rivoli on Saturday. The cast of the Universal production, which is set on a South Sea island, is headed by Maria Montez, Sabu, Jon Hall and Don Terry. . . . "Reveille With Beverly," a Columbia comedy with music, will be the new attraction at the Abbey Theatre on Friday.

Northeast Airlines has filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board an application for a helicopter service to carry air mail and express from the roof-tops of more than 400 postoffices and railroad stations in the New England States and New York. This gives additional substance to the shadow of one type of flying which is to come.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 19 -- The first public meeting of the recently formed Italia Libera, the Australian-Italian anti-fascist society, was held last night. A manifesto was adopted as follows:

On Wednesday of last week Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, said that an Army report revealing the base of the Tokyo raiders and other details would be made public within a few days. On Friday he announced that further consultation with the War Department showed that "clearance has not been completed."

Mrs. Warner M. Van Norden was re-elected for the twenty-second year as president of the Bible and Fruit Mission to the Public Hospitals of New York City at the sixty-eighth annual meeting held yesterday afternoon in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Van Norden, 7 West Fifty-seventh Street.

If you would show your admiration for your favorite ballerina, do not send her a bouquet -- present a package of bobby pins to her. A pair of real silk tights, a yard or two of elastic, a dozen safety pins, a tube of liquid adhesive or a can of cleaning fluid would be equally welcome.

The eleven-story and penthouse apartment house on a plot 59 by 85 feet at the southwest corner of Fortieth Street and Lexington Avenue has been sold by the Bank for Savings in the City of New York to the 124 East Fortieth Street Corporation. The sale was for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $210,000 for ten years

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 19 -- Several French divisions in North Africa have already received United States equipment, including Sherman tanks, 90-mm. anti-aircraft guns, 3-inch anti-tank guns and tank destroyers. These are the latest equipment that America is producing.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today the award of medals to 302 officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Eighth Air Force, including the Distinguished Flying Cross to Brig. Gen. James P. lodges.

QUINCY, Mass., April 19 (AP) -- [The first United States naval yes-! L sel named in honor of a foreign l I city, the heavy cruiser Canberra, iwas launched today at the Fore River shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company. Lady Dixon of Washington, wife of Sir Owen Dixon, Australian Minister to the United States, was sponsor.

EDGEWATER, N.J., April 19 --E.H. Grotefend, superintendent of the Aluminum Company of America's plant here, declared today that the remelting department, heart of the plant, had been closed on Friday because seventy-five union members had quit in violation of the union contract while their representatives were presenting grievances to the management.

Pamphlets telling Italian citizens to be polite in the event of an Allied invasion are being distributed by the Italian Government, Radio France, in Algiers, said yesterday in a French-language broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission.

Observance of the Festival of Passover began last night in temples and synagogues throughout the world with time-honored ceremonies and prayers. But while Jews commemorated the deliverance of their ancestors from Egyptian bondage there was added to the ancient rites a new note caused by religious persecution in Nazi-dominated lands.

The stock market wavered yesterday after an attempt to rise, with interest on the New York Stock Exchange not intense enough to further a recovery. Gains ranged to 1 point in the morning, but the list turned irregular shortly after the noon hour and quotations were only irregularly higher at the close.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names and next of kin of 175 United States soldiers killed and seventy-four missing in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle East, North African, Pacific, Southwest Pacific, Alaskan and North American areas and in the Philippine Islands.

War is the theme uniquely dealt with by Julio de Diego in his just-opened one-man show at the Nierendorf Gallery, 53 East Fifty-seventh Street. However, although the titles are quoted headlines and fragments of dispatches, the oils, temperas and gouaches to which they appertain are by no means "realistically" treated.
Benjamin F. Fairless, president of United States Steel, issued a statement in New York last night saying:

What is the United States and what are the United Nations going to do about food for occupied Europe? This question is raised today by Howard E. Kershner in a letter published on this page. Mr. Kershner knows what he is talking about because he was for two years in charge of the distribution of food to French children.
The Finnish Monday communiqu, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Although presumably not more than five decision days remain for the Supreme Court at the present term, the tribunal again today postponed action on eight eases of major importance. The court has recessed until May 3.

CHIEF MILLER started off on a note of righteous indignation and finished up reminiscently mellow. The Chief is the lacrosse coach at City College now, but in the old days, when he was an athlete himself, he was one of the famed Carlisle Indians. As such, he naturally is a worshiper at the shrine of Jim Thorpe.

New York City grocers declared yesterday that they had begun to throw away filler meats spoiling on their hands because there were few buyers, even under reduced point rationing. At the same time both the local Office of Price Administration and the City Markets Department pressed punitive actions against violators of price ceilings and other regulations.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 19 (AP) -- A communique:

Dr. Sylvanus G. Morley, archaeologist of the Carnegie Institution at Washington, has won Columbia University's $1,000 Loubat Prize for his work on "The Inscriptions of Peten," it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president.

The Department of Agriculture's downward revision of estimates of 1943 civilian supplies of a large number of foods still leaves too rosy a picture of prospects, according to spokesmen for growers in this region who unanimously echo the fear expressed by H.W. Voorhees of Trenton that "Mr. Wickard will soon make another revision downward and we will be on very severe and short rations within a few months."
WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Athletic shoes worn by professional baseball players are "work shoes," but the same shoes when used by semi-professional and amateur athletes are not.

LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- Throwing its mighty home-based bomber arm into the battle to finish off the Axis in Africa, the Royal Air Force crossed the Alps in strong force last night and delivered for the second time in a week a violent and concentrated attack on units of the Italian Fleet huddled in the Spezia naval base, on the northwest coast of Italy.

By agreement virtually unanimous among those present the opening number of the concert given by the Bach Circle of New York last night in Town Hall was adjudged one of the finest offerings of the evening. It was one of the Handel oboe concertos, in G minor, with Mitchell Miller as the accomplished oboist.

After Secretary Morgenthau had urged the House Coinage Committee yesterday to approve a two-year extension of the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund, Representative Andresen, according to The Associated Press, asked the Secretary: "Can you make use of the Thomas amendment to issue three billions in greenbacks?"

The regional War Labor Board announced yesterday that it has approved increases of $1.40 a week for maintenance men and $2 a week for supervisors in several hundred buildings in the garment area. The action of the board was in six separate cases and was the first affecting New York City employers since the issuance of President Roosevelt's hold-the-line order on April 8.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 11 per cent for the week ended April 17, in comparison with the like week a year ago, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Taunt and Princequillo dashed off with the principal races at Jamaica yesterday, while from Belmont Park Count Fleet and Blue Swords dashed off to the Kentucky Derby.

Factory employment in the United States reached 16,000,000 in February, the highest on record, rising 160,000 in the month, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday. The board pointed out that in 1939 only 10,000,000 workers were engaged in manufacturing, or thirty-one out of every 100 civilian workers in non-agricultural activities, as against thirty-eight today.
NEW DELHI, India, April 19 (AP) -- A communiqu:

LONDON, April 19 (U.P.) -- The Spanish Government has notified United States Ambassador Carlton Hayes that Portuguese air mail service between Lisbon and Tangier, Spanish Morocco, a link in the only daily route between Britain and North Africa, will be stopped in eight days unless the Allies furnish more gasoline for Spain's own service to Spanish Morocco, The Daily Telegraph reported today.

Negotiations for a new wage agreement affecting 450,000 soft coal miners will be resumed this morning, after a long week-end recess, when another effort will be made to break the deadlock between the operators of the Northern and Southern Appalachian regions and representatives of the United Mine Workers of America, headed by John L. Lewis.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 19 -- President Getulio Vargas, celebrating his sixtieth birthday today, spent the anniversary with friends at a ranch near Petropolis.

Dr. Louis G. Small, 40 years old, who is under a Sing Sing sentence of three to six years on his General Sessions conviction last Juy for operating an abortion mill with two other physicians, is the subject of a country-wide search ordered yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- American air forces, punching at the growing Japanese aviation threat at both ends of the Pacific front, have carried out ten more attacks in the Aleutians, nine of them on Kiska, and three in the Solomons area in which the enemy apparently sustained greater than usual punishment, a Navy communique disclosed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 19 -- Two hundred film actors are expected to go to work at the Lockheed-Vega aircraft plant now that the company has arranged split-shifts on the production line in order to give employment to Hollywood players who seek further means of doing their share of war work.

FREEHOLD, N.J., April 19 -- Joseph L. Donahay was elected surrogate of Monmouth County by fourteen votes, Common Pleas Judge John C. Giordano ruled today after recount of eighty districts at the demand of E. Donald Sterner, who was defeated by Donahay in November.
Residents of Forest Hills are willing to spade up their back yards as victory gardens to aid in the war, but when it comes to chickens, they are "agin 'em" in a respectable community.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, April 19 -- Lieutenant Tommy Harmon, who had been missing after his plane crashed in the jungle April 8, was at a United States Army base at this port today, tired but in good condition.

BALTIMORE, April 19 -- One of ten Baltimore shipyard welders accused of sabotage by doing faulty work on vessels under construction was sentenced to a year and a half in prison today in what Federal prosecutors said was the first such case in the nation.

CHUNGKING, China, April 19 (U.P.) -- Chinese forces have repulsed Japanese drives in two widely-separated sectors, Shantung Province in the North and Kwantung in the South, and have recaptured a village near the enemy-held Yangtze center of Ichang, the Chinese High Command reported tonight.

CINCINNATI, April 19 -- Declaring the main objective of the American people to be victorious in the briefest possible time to prevent needless sacrifice of life, members of the national society, Daughters of the American Revolution, adopted a resolution today condemning "strikes, absenteeism, selfish domination of boss racketeers and incompetence and greed in political and industrial groups."

The Jewish Agency for Palestine, in a memorandum addressed to the Bermuda Refugee Conference yesterday, urged that measures of rescue be launched immediately on behalf of 4,000,000 Jews estimated to be still surviving in Nazi-occupied countries.
Buildings in the midtown and the downtown areas attracted the bulk of the business leases reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- War industries were warned today that they must adhere strictly to government specifications for materials, no matter how stringent, in a Senate (Truman) committee report which took the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation to task for permitting falsification of inspection records.

Public school pupils in New York City have pledged to buy 800 jeeps for the Army. Reporting on the progress of the women's division of the War Savings Staff in the Second War Loan Drive, Mrs. Courtlandt Barnes said yesterday that "almost without exception, the city's 800 public schools have undertaken to buy bonds earmarked for at least one jeep, and in some cases they are raising funds for two."
LONDON, April 19 (U.P.) -- German radio stations observed the eve of Adolf Hitler's fifty-fourth birthday tonight with programs reflecting the anxiety of German leaders ver the course of the war.

A net profit of $2,632,186 was reported yesterday for the first quarter of this year by the National Biscuit Company. The figure, which is after providing $3,830,707 for Federal income and excess profits taxes after deducting the post-war credit, is equal to 35 cents a share on the 6,289,448 shares of common stock.

Those were some handsome remarks which Mayor La Guardia made the other day about THE NEW YORK TIMES and they certainly go far toward effacing the memory of anything heated or hasty in the past, going or coming.

Even our armed forces are no more vital to victory than the courageous crews that man the merchant marine of the United Nations. To keep their morale at a high pitch and to make them feel at home on our shores should be the concern of us all. The Seamen's Church Institute is the largest shore home in the world for active merchant seamen of all races and creeds.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 19 (AP) -- A Ninth United States Air Force communiqu:

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 19 (AP) -- Siravo and Petrucci's Midluck registered his second consecutive victory today as he beat Mrs. D.A. Buckley's Grand Party by a length and one-quarter to win the Taunton Purse at Narragansett Park.

A firm resolve to maintain a free press in this country and a proposal to rally the forces of the American press to persuade the peace conference to guarantee the freedom of world news from governmental control were the keynotes of yesterday's annual meeting and luncheon of members of The Associated Press at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- A complete breakdown threatened tonight in the bi-partisan friendly effort to write a compromise pay-as-you-go tax bill. House Democratic and Republican leaders remained far apart on what part, if any, of one year's income taxes should be abated.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Owners of merchant ships must pay for "maintenance and cure" of sailors injured on shore leave, without misconduct on the seamen's part, the Supreme Court held today in an opinion regarded as an example of the broadened views of the tribunal as now constituted.

BALTIMORE, April 19 -- Pharien, owned by Mrs. Ray Feinberg of Chester, Pa., won the Midway Purse, featuring today's program at the Maryland Jockey Club's Pimlico oval. The 4-year-old filly, well handled by Jockey Danny Scocca, who was riding his fourth winner of the meeting, scored by two lengths.

MOSCOW, April 19 -- Under the headline, "Hitler's Polish Collaborators," Pravda, the Communist party organ, devoted a leading editorial today to the statement issued by the Polish Government at London on the subject of the German charges that Russia had killed a large number of Polish officers captured during the 1939 Soviet campaign in White Russia and the Western Ukraine.
The text of the annual report of the Board of Directors of The Associated Press, as ead at the annual meeting of members yesterday, follows:

Th split between Tammany Hall and the Democratic State Committee over tactics in connection with reapportionment was emphasized yesterday when it became known that the State Committee had disassociated itself from formal connection with the lawsuits seeking to invalidate the redistricting, because of the attitude of Tammany in favor of the new district lines.

ALBANY, April 19 -- The Mitchell bill, eliminating the requirement that stamps be affixed to all transferred stocks and securities, was signed today by Governor Dewey, who said the change will save the State between $15,000 and $20,000 and relieve brokers of the necessity of maintaining large stocks of stamps, paid for in advance.

Bankers' acceptances outstanding in the United States showed a further gain in March, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its regular monthly compilation, as of March 31. The total outstanding on that date was $129,818,000, a gain of $2,756,000 on the month, but a decrease of $52,857,000 since March 31, 1942.
LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- The Russian noon communiqu, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
CINCINNATI, April 19 (AP) -- Uncle Sam pointed tentatively to two mainstays of the Reds today: double no-hit Johnny Vander Meer and Outfielder Mike McCormick.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau urged the House Coinage Committee today to approve a two-year extension of the $2,000,000,000 stabilization fund, but did not ask for renewal of the President's powers to devalue the dollar.

A conference to plan intensifying of advertising's part in the war effort, and particularly to further the work of war advertising committees in local communities throughout the country will be held by the Advertising Federation of America on June 28 to 30 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- A report that President Roosevelt has told friends he will not under any circumstances consider a fourth term was circulated today by Frank Comfort, Democratic National Committee man from Iowa.

A reception will be held Sunday at the Hotel Astor for Anna and Maxa Nordau, authors of the biography of Dr. Max Nordau, Jewish scholar and author and collaborator with Dr. Theodor Herzl in the establishment of the Zionist movement.
The Monday Italian communiqu, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

Setting a be-ribboned box on the writer's desk, the woman announced that some of the cookies hidden inside had been baked two weeks before; others one week before, and the rest, within the past forty-eight hours. "Can you tell me which cookies are freshest?" she asked.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 19 -- British Spitfires and American Warhawks set a record yesterday by destroying seventy-four enemy planes in a single engagement and came back this morning to knock down eleven more.
CHUNGKING, China, April 19 (U.P.) -- A communiqu:
Police emergency squads were kept busy last night as high winds and rain smashed windows, tore away signs and was responsible for at least one death.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) -- While their shell-raked, crewless ship raced crazily like "a ball of fire" over the horizon, surviving American Navy and Coast Guard seamen were machine-gunned methodically by a Japanese cruiser as they struggled in the water off Tulagi last September, a survivor reported today.

Fifty-four years ago today Adolf Hitler was not doing any harm to any one, or even planning any. He had just been born. His father was a minor Austrian customs official, who had had his name legally changed from Schiklgruber or Schuklgruber. His mother was Klara Polzl, whose own mother had also been a Hitler.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The creation of a council composed of the heads of French overseas territories, to act as trustee for the French nation in relations with the United Nations and to take charge of liberated portions of France while the French High Command keeps order there, has been proposed as a basis of French unity in a memorandum by General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in North Africa.

CLEVELAND, April 19 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. James H. Doolittle flew the first bomber to take off from an aircraft carrier 250 miles from Japan on the Tokyo raid a year ago, The Cleveland Press said today in an interview with a crew member of one of the carriers.

A special meeting of the Industrial Council of the State Department of Labor has been called by Acting Industrial Commissioner Michael J. Murphy for 10 A.M. tomorrow, it was disclosed yesterday. The meeting is to consider the information thus far developed at public hearings of the Moreland investigation into the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law.

Corporal Harry Giffords, Army Air Forces, arrived in New York yesterday for a two-week furlough, to spend Passover with his family in Queens and to transact some business. He carried with him a patent for an air-conditioning improvement perfected while he has been in the Army.

A special committee of the Federal Bar Association decided yesterday at a closed session to "proceed cautiously" in dealing with the American Bar Association for its alleged discrimination against Negroes.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 19 (U.P.) -- General Sir Henry Maitland Wilson, British Commander in Chief in the Middle East, today completed a four-day visit here that was designed, he said at a press conference, to reach a coordinated agreement with the Turkish General Staff.

Mel Ott and his Giants were set to drop into West Point yesterday but the annual visit and ball game against the Cadets was cancelled on account of the weather. A telephone call to the Point disclosed that it was raining there and there was no sign of a let-up, so the manager reluctantly called the game off.

The New York Singing Teachers Association will hold a "Song Mart" at 7 o'clock tonight in the Hotel des Artistes, 1 West Sixty-seventh Street. Composer members of the group, New York publishers, singing teachers and singers will meet for a program presenting songs by twelve leading American composers.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today the Desmond bill which, he said, could be used to circumvent the requirement of the City Home Rule Law that a new charter be submitted only on petition of 15 per cent of the voters.

With the approval of all the government agencies concerned, the New York Furniture Exchange has decided to hold its Summer market from June 7 to 11, Walter M. Engel, president, announced yesterday. This followed an announcement in Chicago that the markets there would be held from June 21 to 30.

BOSTON, April 19 -- Arguments for and against an immediate curtailment of advertising as a contribution to the war effort were presented here today at the opening of a two-day meeting of the first district, Advertising Federation of America.
CHICAGO, April 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The Office of Defense Transportation is planning to order a further cut of 25 per cent in the total mileage of truck operators, it was learned yesterday. The order, which is directed "across the board" and affects all common, contract and private carriers, is written and only awaits the signature of Joseph B. Eastman, ODT director, to become effective, it was understood.

American service men are winning the hearts of Brazil's young women with jitterbug music and hamburgers, it was said here yesterday. While dancers in this country move hesitantly to swing-band interpretations of the samba, young Brazilian women are threatening to disjoint themselves in learning the frenetic steps of jitterbugging, it was declared.

The war savings staff of the Treasury Department announced yesterday that Carnegie Hall already is sold out for the Easter Sunday War Bond concert of Arturo Toscanini and the NBC Symphony Orchestra, with Vladimir Horowitz as piano solist.

Fredric March of "Skin of Our Teeth" voiced yesterday an appeal for 2,000 volunteers for the Volunteer Aircraft Warning Service of Manhattan as the organization opened its first information booth in the International Business Machines Building, Madison Avenue at Fifty-seventh Street.
LONDON, April 19 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communiqu:

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- Following is the text of the memorandum proposing a basis for French unity that General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, sent to General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French Leader, on April 1, as translated at General Giraud's headquarters and made public by the French Military Mission here:

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- War Ration Book No. 3, due for issuance to consumers in midsummer, will provide the Office of Price Administration at last with an "all-purpose" ration book sufficiently flexible to be used for virtually any item, officials said today.

Week-end sales of war bonds in the Second Federal Reserve District were $190,000,000 and brought the total sold to investors other than commercial banks to $2,665,000,000 as of 11 A.M. yesterday, it was announced by Allan Sproul, chairman of the War Finance Committee for the district, which consists of New York State, Northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The five-day House debate on the agriculture appropriation bill was drawn out by spokesmen for "small farmers," who were aroused by the Appropriations Committee's action in striking out, decreasing or reallocating the control of various appropriations designed to aid this farm group.

Yesterday marked a three-fold celebration at the French Seamen's Foyer, 63 West Forty-fourth Street. A "reunion in New York" took place among four Frenchmen from Havre who had not seen each other since before the war and met accidentally at the canteen.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 19 (AP) -- Allen T. Simmons's Harvard Square, making his first start since his winning effort at Tropical Park Dec. 30, again raced to victory in the Creekview Purse, featured race of the Keeneland program, today.

Playing with a zest generated by their world series triumph of last Fall, National League clubs defeated American rivals in twenty-eight of the forty-five inter-league contests this Spring, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Lend-Lease Administration has shipped 126,184 tons of food, clothing, medicines and other necessities valued at $26,250,000, to North Africa in the four months since United Nations' forces arrived there, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Administrator, announced today.

While rumors again circulated yesterday that the OPA was removing furs from price ceilings, information obtained in official quarters by the National Federation of the Fur Industry indicated this was not the case, it was stated yesterday by Avery T. Salter Sr., executive secretary of the federation.

Hearings on an income tax petition that may have an important bearing in the long controversy over whether the income from bonds issued by the Port of New York Authority is taxable by the Federal Government began here yesterday before United States Tax Court Judge Clarence V. Opper.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 19 -- The limits of achievement that may be possible as the result of the Anglo-American talks on the international refugee problem -- already hinted at by both delegations in press conferences -- became more clearly defined at the formal opening of the parley this morning.

There is so much misunderstanding of the proposal to feed the children of the occupied countries that I would like to ask your indulgence in order to restate the case, based upon my four years' experience of feeding children in Europe.

HARTFORD, April 19 -- Governor Raymond E. Baldwin presented to Mrs. Adele Wainwright in Bushnell Memorial Hall today a hand-illuminated copy of the Connecticut General Assembly's resolution expressing "heartfelt gratitude and deep admiration" to Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright and to his American and Filipino command "for their heroic defense of Bataan Peninsula and of Corregidor Island."

President Roosevelt has written to Arturo Toscanini thanking him and the NBC Symphony Orchestra for their March 24 concert for the benefit of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. His letter and the reply by Mr. Toscanini re-emphasized the truth "that art can flourish only where men are free."

Still affected by the indecision in regard to the imposition of ceiling prices on raw cotton, the cotton futures market experienced yesterday another featureless session of small volume. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed unchanged to 9 points lower than Saturday's final quotations, with the new-crop positions relatively weaker than the old crops.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 19 -- A sensational turn to the mystery of the Swedish submarine Ulven, missing since Friday morning, was furnished tonight when naval authorities announced that her sister-ship, the Draken, had been fired on in home waters last Friday by a German merchantman.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, April 20 (U.P.) -- The noon communiqu:

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision by a three-judge Federal Court in Newark holding that it lacked jurisdiction to test the validity of the emergency price control act.

WASHINGTON, April 19 -- The Farm Security Administration went out of the window today in so far as the House is concerned when a $715,099,662 appropriation bill for the Agriculture Department for 1944 was tentatively approved.

For some reason or other, the temporary ceiling on cotton prices, which was expected to be issued over the week-end by the Office of Price Administration, has been delayed. According to reports in the trade, it is considered likely that Washington authorities may adopt other measures to prevent cotton prices from getting out of bounds.
If all the indecision expressed by the major league managers on the eve of the second baseball campaign of the present war era were placed end to end it would be as evasive as an Axis communique.

SAYVILLE, L.I., April 19 -- An eight-day Easter vacation cruise of ten members of a Rockville Centre Sea Scout troop ended in disaster today in the storm-churned waters of the Great South Bay when their thirty-six-foot converted cabin cruiser capsized two miles off shore here.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (U.P.) -- War Manpower Commissioner Paul V. McNutt, who controls the destiny of wartime baseball, predicted tonight that the sport will be able to carry on through the war despite the approaching induction of all able-bodied men between 18 and 38.

The seven-story apartment house at 27-27 Central Avenue, Hartsdale, Westchester County, has been purchased by Dale Estates, Inc., from the Bowery Savings Bank. This property is assessed for $401,800. Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft represented the seller and Peck Peck the buyer.

CHICAGO, April 19 -- Domestic wheat markets today held within narrow price limits, with trading largely of a professional character despite a bulge of 3 1/4 to 3 3/8 cents in Winnipeg. There was general buying in the Canadian market on a report that the Commodity Credit Corporation had asked for offers of 2,000,000 bushels of Canadian No. 3 and No. 4 Northern for May through July shipment from Fort William to Eastern American ports.

LONDON, April 19 -- A savage four-day battle between bombers, of the British Coastal command and a tenacious U-boat pack in which the stake was the safety or destruction of two important east-bound convoys was described today in the first official account of the danger encountered in mid-March by ships bound for this island.

Although the downward trend in sales continued in the first three months this year, "a fairly satisfactory profit for the first quarter" was predicted by R.F. Bensinger, president, at the annual stockholders meeting held yesterday in Chicago.

LONDON, April 19 -- The stock markets here began the week on a cheerful note, with home railway issues providing the chief feature. Renewed investment demand found the market short of stock and some sharp gains were recorded.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Samuel Crowther, Sunapee, N.H., author and publisher, told the House Ways and Means Committee yesterday that the Roosevelt-Hull trade treaty policy "by-passed the people" and should be called "an act to establish a dictatorship."

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- War Ration Book No. 3, the "all-purpose" book, will be distributed through the mails to more than 120,000,000 individuals beginning late in June and ending July 21, the OPA announced today.

ALBANY, April 20 (U.P.) -- Edward C.O. Thomas, State civilian protection director, warned today that enemy air attacks were a possibility and said that blackouts and daytime alerts would be intensified in the near future. He said that simulated air raids might be held with Army plans.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senators defeated the Athletics, 7 to 5, in Griffith Stadium today to launch the major league baseball season before a war-conscious crowd of 25,093.
LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 690, which compared with 986 in the preceding week and 869 in the like period of last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations numbered 187 as against 401 last Tuesday.

Several marketing and product research companies are switching a considerable portion of their faciilties to post-war planning for industry, it was reported yesterday, but most research organizations are apparently still busy on work connected with the war.

Ecuador has now issued a list of "nonessential" items for which import permits will not be granted, prohibiting their import from the United States or from any other country via the United States, except in cases of "extreme emergency," the Department of Commerce announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- A consumer may ask his retailer to exchange a cut of meat that was bruised or otherwise unfit for use when it was bought, the OPA said today. The customer then may receive other meat of the same point value.
Uncle Sam has made certain that his fighting nephews, wherever they may be, will know all about the baseball season, The Associated Press reports.

Admiral Georges Robert's written statement, published last Saturday, has been generally interpreted as a distinct softening of his attitude, as a clear indication that in the near future he will bring over the resources of Martinique to the United Nations.

Trade buying in the near months on the New York Cotton Exchange, though not very substantial, recouped yesterday small initial losses and brought the market to final net gains of 9 to 18 points, placing the list of active futures at the highest closing levels in ten days.

London will be appraising two Noel Coward premieres on successive nights next week, according to word received here by John C. Wilson, Mr. Coward's partner. "Present Laughter" will open April 29, and "This Happy Breed" on the next night.

The case load of meningitis rose again last week in New York City, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. There were forty-eight new cases and twelve deaths, bringing the total for this year so far to 488 cases and ninety deaths, compared with 135 cases and twenty-seven deaths at this time in 1942, and thirty-one cases and eleven deaths in 1941.
CHUNGKING, China, April 20 (U.P.) -- A communique:

When Moe Penn saw the same man who had robbed him of $10 eight days ago return to his hat store at 148 Clinton Street last night he shouted "What, again?" brushed aside the brandished pistol and lunged at the intruder.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- A two point program designed to bring quick relief of actual distress among the country's smaller manufacturing plants was announced tonight by Colonel Robert W. Johnson, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation and vice chairman of the War Production Board. The plan revolves around the prime contractor.

BALTIMORE, April 20 -- Ask Aunt Ada, 4-year-old filly from the stables of Captain H.H. Hecht, today romped off with the $1,500 Pearl Harbor Purse, which featured the fourth day of Pimlico's five-day war relief meeting.

George L. Cooper, 48 years old, of 166 East Ninety-second Street, a salesman for the Phillips Ribbon and Carbon Company, Inc., of 349 Broadway, went berserk early yesterday morning and after beating and stabbing his wife, Valerie, 38, and their son, Allen, 5, leaped or fell to his death from a rear window of the apartment on the second floor to the courtyard below.

In some unaccountable manner it has got printed abroad that this department has constituted itself the champion of "good English." Letters are all the time coming in strongly urging us to don our trusty armor, put lance in rest and sally forth against this or that particular offender.

RICHMOND, Va., April 20 (AP) -Stockholders of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway elected two new directors today and received a statement from Carl E. Newton, president, that increased railroad traffic "may turn out to be a millstone around the neck of the roads" because of accelerated wear in equipment and roadway.
A Winter of no little discontent and considerable apprehension having finally run its course, the long-awaited inaugural of the 1943 major league championship gets under way today.

The two players who met in the final of the Red Cross tournament of the National Squash Tennis Association reached the concluding round of the handicap Red Cross squash racquets tournament at the Yale Club last night.

TAMPA, Fla., April 20 (AP) -- Eight men and a black kitten, survivors of a small Norwegian merchant vessel sunk by an enemy torpedo in the Gulf of Mexico, have landed in Tampa. The sinking was the first in the Gulf announced by the Navy since Aug. 26.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Fifteen days of aerial dueling in the Southwest Pacific, scene of the current bitter struggle between the Japanese and the Allies for supremacy of the skies, has cost the enemy 128 planes destroyed or damaged, nineteen warships and cargo vessels damaged or sunk and twelve other ships possibly damaged, the War Department announced today.

Pre-Easter influences were at work in force yesterday and prices in the stock market gave way fractionally in one of the dullest sessions so far this year on the Stock Exchange. Traders again showed little inclination to change commitments and quotations milled around in listless manner through most of the day.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 -- Plant committees, equally representative of management and employes, will pass on certificates of availability when Northern California workers hereafter seek to change from one plant to another.

Employment opportunities for college graduates have increased 500 per cent since the war began and offer new job possibilities for girls without technical training, Miss Josephine Hammond, head of the graduate placement service at Hunter College, declared yesterday.

AT UNITED STATES AIR BASE IN SOUTHERN CHINA, April 19 (Delayed) -- The reported movements of Japanese troops from Manchuria might be regarded as a "defensive alert" in the opinion of Major Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commander of the United States Fourteenth Air Force, in an interview this morning.

LONDON, April 20 -- The resignations and criticism affecting the Office of War Information in Washington have attracted attention to its branch office here, where in comparative obscurity a staff of seventy-five men and women labors quietly to spread confidence among our Allies and consternation among our enemies regarding the American war effort.

An association to coordinate the work of three committees engaged in relief, evacuation and rehabilitation of European refugees has been formed under the name of the Refugees Relief Trustees, Inc., it was announced yesterday by L. Hollingsworth Wood, chairman of the new organization.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 20 (AP) -- Count Fleet, the favorite, and Blue Swords, a strong contender, checked in at Churchill Downs today, while seven other Kentucky Derby candidates entered tomorrow's running of the $10,000 added Blue Grass Stakes.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Sharp reductions in point values of all frozen fruits and vegetables and of all types of rationed soups, canned, bottled, dried or dehydrated, will take effect at 12:01 A.M. Thursday, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

The board of directors of The Associated Press announced yesterday the designation of Frank B. Noyes, president of The Washington Star, as honorary president of The Associated Press and of Kent Cooper as executive director. Mr. Cooper remains as general manager a post he has held since 1925, fifteen years after entering the service of the press association.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- She was a new Liberty ship, the Virginia Dare, on her maiden voyage. She must have seemed a helpless target to the seven enemy bombers, including at least two German Junkers-88s, that tried to sink her. Yet the Virginia Dare and her "green" gun crew shot down the seven bombers, and her cargo of war goods got through.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., April 20 -- J. Press Reddock, Sheriff of Jones County, identified today two of the four men on trial here in the lynching of Howard Wash at Lau rel in October as members of a mob which forced its way into the jail where the Negro was confined. The trial is before Federal Judge Sidney E. Mize and a jury.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 20 (AP) -- A communique:

PRINCETON, N.J., April 20 -- Unless some unforeseen development arises, the American public will have its way on pay-as-you-go taxation. In accord with overwhelming public sentiment in favor of such a step, the House is rushing to take action this week on a pay-as-you-go measure.

SUPERIOR, Wis., April 20 (AP) -- Counsel for seven major oil companies answered a charge in Federal court today that they had conspired to fix oil prices by declaring that the alleged conspiracy was in reality a price stabilization meeting called under the National Recovery Act program.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The War Department's statement tonight on the American raid on Japan follows:

Miss Miriam Fitch, 19 years old, of 1 Parade Place, Brooklyn, book-keeper by day and a student at night in the School of Business and Administration at City College, was a patient in Kings County Hospital yesterday following an attack by an unidentified man on Monday night.

When President Roosevelt turns up in Monterrey, Mexico, exchanging words of the warmest friendship with President Avila Camacho, one has to realize that a good deal of water has flowed down the Rio Grande since the First World War, and a good deal more since Presidents Taft and Diaz met on the International Bridge at El Paso in 1909.

CAMP FORREST, Tenn., April 17 (Delayed) -- The full field equipment of a well-trained infantry division was displayed to President Roosevelt today in a thirty-minute drive in which he was guided by Lieut. Gen. Ben C. Lear, commander of the Second Army, who its to retire soon because of age.

The American Silk Mills plant in Orange, Va., received yesterday an Army and Navy E pennant for production of parachutes and flare drops, and Army and Navy pins were awarded to 700 employes, the company announced at its offices at 1400 Broadway.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey has offered to transfer permanently to the United States Government the patent rights on Buna-S synthetic rubber, Ralph W. Gallagher, president, announced yesterday. The offer is subject to the approval of the company's stockholders at their annual meeting in June and also is conditioned on an agreement by the government that it expand its expenditures for research in the synthetic rubber field up to at least $5,000,000.

ALBANY, Ore., April 20 (UP) -- Robert E. Lee Folkes should be given death or freedom, the State urged today after the defense in the "Lower 13" murder trial rested suddenly without calling the accused man to testify.

Davis S. Meister, operator, has purchased from the Bradbury Building Corporation a wholly-owned subsidiary of Webb Knapp, Inc., the property at 142 Fifth Avenue and 3-5 West Nineteenth Street. The plot, taking in the northwest corner of the intersection, is improved with two ten-story buildings occupied for store and manufacturing purposes.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20 -- The strike at the plastics division here of the Celanese Corporation of America extended beyond the production department today as fifty mechanics and eighteen electricians joined the walkout that was called April 12 by Local 12,666 of District 50, United Mine Workers.
CINCINNATI, April 20 -- Admiral Edward C. Kalbfus, member of the Navy General Board, addressed the Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Hounse unanimously passed the War Brokers Bill by voice vote this afternoon after only fifteen minutes of explanation by Chairman Vinson of the Naval Affairs Committee. There were only forty-five members on the floor, many having gone to the opening baseball game.

CINCINNATI, April 20 (AP) -- General Manager Warren C. Giles of the Reds was as unhappy today as the hen with a brood of ugly ducklings. Giles, be it remembered, was the National League's representative on a three-man committee that "formulated" the 1943 model baseball.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Congressional investigation of the operations of Office of War Information will start tomorrow when Elmer Davis, director, stages a press conference for the benefit of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Only members of Congress and reporters will be admitted.

LONDON, April 20 -- Fighting French circles awaited word today of the reception accorded to their note to General Henri Honore Giraud, rejecting his proposals for setting up a central French authority and urging a meeting between the French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa and General Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The resignation of Mrs. August Belmont of New York from the central committee of the American Red Cross and the election to succeed her of Mrs. William O. Rowland Jr. of Torresdale, Pa., was announced today by Norman H. Davis, national chairman.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 20 -- Four hundred families in this city have filed reservations for food lockers that the American Frozen Food Lockers Company intends to install here, according to the White Plains Civic and Business Federation, agent for the enterprise.

EDGEWATER, N.J., April 20 -- A call for a general strike of about 3,000 employes of the Edgewater plant of the Aluminum Company of America beginning at 11:30 o'clock Thursday night, was issued tonight by the executive board of Local 16, Aluminum Workers of America, C.I.O., following voting in which the union said a 2 to 1 majority of 2,069 workers voted to strike.

PEARL HARBOR, April 20 -- When Lieut. Comdr. Dudley W. (Mush) Morton brought the submarine Wahoo into port after a recent patrol she wore a broom at the mast to signify a "clean sweep" of a four-ship Japanese convoy near New Guinea.
LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

CAIRO, Egypt, April 20 (AP) -- The Americans, who with British and South African fighters blasted fifty-eight Junkers-52's and nineteen other planes to destruction Sunday off Cap Bone, were disclosed today to have been members of the Fifty-seventh Fighter Group.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Defense Plant Corporation, an RFC subsidiary, has agreed to finance construction of an extension of the 20-inch petroleum products pipeline from Seymour, Ind., to the harbor area of New York City, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, said today.

American Red Cross Gray Ladies will shed their famous veils. A simplified cap, designed to match a new Spring and Summer uniform, features their new outfit. Mrs. William Royce Roe, director of hospital and recreation for the New York chapter, announced yesterday the arrival of the first of the modernized uniforms.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Joint United States-Bolivian commission of labor experts that visited Bolivia recently as the aftermath of a strike of tin miners has made a report to the Bolivian Government, and copies were made available today at the State Department.
The five-story garden-type apartment house containing sixty suites at 2523-25 University Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Raylin Palty Corporation to Henry Gelet, operator.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and subsidiaries, primarily those operating in the Western Hemisphere, had in 1942 a consolidated net income of $2,142,545, in contrast to a net loss of $193,218 in 1941, Sosthenes Behn, president, disclosed yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Virtual agreement on a pay-as-you-go tax bill was reported reached tonight by leading members of the Ways and Means Committee, who have been conferring almost continuously since last Friday in an effort to end the tax stalemate.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., April 16 (Delayed) -- Pausing on his war inspection tour, President Roosevelt relaxed and rested for a night and a day at the famous treatment place for victims of infantile paralysis, where he first came twenty years ago.

An exhibition of paintings by art students of Local 91, International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, was opened yesterday at the American British Art Center, to assist British War Relief. David Dubinsky and Sir Robert Appleby head the list of sponsors for the exhibition, a list which includes the names of more than a score of people well known in society and in business and professional fields.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20 -- The operators of the Mosque Theatre Building at 1020 Broad Street, this city, were accused in an information filed today in the United States District Court here with having violated a conservation order of the War Production Board by having spent some $4,000 recently in remodeling the basement of the structure into a night club, known as the Terrace Room.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 20 (AP) -- Unless Germany makes a satisfactory reply to a request for an explanation of the attack by a German merchantman on the Swedish submarine Draken, an authoritative source declared tonight, the Swedish Government may act to halt the use of this nation's territorial waters by German ships.

Simplification or various textile products, particularly those utilizing rayon or other scarce yarns, in order to expand civilian supply will be spurred by the WPB's new policy of providing A-2 priorities on essential materials for manufacturers adhering to standardized products, it was declared yesterday by Worth Street suppliers.

NEWARK, N.J., April 20 -- Bench warrants were ordered issued here today by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney for three meat wholesalers who failed to appear in court to answer an indictment charging them and fifteen other corporate and individual defendants with having participated in a nation-wide black market meat conspiracy.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (U.P.) -The Apostolic Delegation announced today that Pope Pius XII had appointed the Right Rev. Mgr. Joseph A. Burke, pastor of St. Mark's Church at Buffalo, as Titular Bishop of Vita and auxiliary to the Most Rev. John A. Duffy, Bishop of Buffalo.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -- While a train filled with German war materiel was on a siding in the Lyon region of France today a bomb was exploded under one of the cars. No one was killed, according to the report received here, but much material damage was done.

DETROIT, April 20 (AP) -- K.T. Keller, president of Chrysler Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting here today that the corporation "has not been confronted so far with any critical situations in securing its wartime manpower requirements."

The Committee of Ambulances for our Army, headed by Mrs. William Astor Chanler, announced yesterday after a meeting at her home, 141 East Nineteenth Street, that it had pledged to turn over 250 ambulances to the Second Service Command by July 1.

MONTERREY, Mexico, April 20 -- President Franklin D. Roosevelt of the United States and President Manuel Avila Camacho of Mexico jointly pledged tonight to fight the war through to final and complete victory over the Axis so that the Good Neighbor policy of the Americas can be extended to a whole world in which there will not be exploitation of the resources and people of one country for the benefit of any group in another.

While delivery conditions in the wholesale apparel markets are easier and cancellations on longstanding orders have appeared, little or no off-price merchandise is available, reports in merchandising quarters here yesterday indicated. This situation, it was predicted, would be duplicated in post-Easter retailing, when markdowns will be at a minimum in most cities, possibly being more likely on dresses than on coats or other outer apparel.

LONDON, April 20 -- The "Shangri La," from which United States planes raided Tokyo last April, was an aircraft carrier, Major Gen. Nakao Yahagi, chief of the army press section of Japanese Imperial Headquarters, told newspaper men, according to a Tokyo broadcast heard here today by an editor of the Ministry of Information.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 20 (AP) -- Captain E.V. Rickenbacker sent a telegram to the Florida Legislature today endorsing a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would outlaw organized labor's closed shop in employment.
