BERNE, Switzerland, April 20 -- Bulgarian troops in Eastern Thrace early today began their "special manoeuvres," involving fifteen to eighteen divisions and a number of German "specialists," believed to total eleven divisions.
LONDON, April 20 -- The swift strides made in British aircraft production were disclosed by Sir Stafford Cripps today with the declaration that the aviation industry was now the country's largest.
Mr. and Mrs. James Lakeman Ward have returned to the Sherry-Netherland from Palm Beach.

BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Casey Stengel, the 52-year-old manager of the Braves, who mixes plenty of hilarious wisecracks with his baseball wisdom, will be forced to do all his master-minding from a hospital cot for at least the first week of the National League season.

The first food dehydrators for home use are expected to make their appearance in this market within the next month, when the Metropolitan Device Company, Brooklyn, introduces a new line of these appliances, it was learned yesterday.

An important deal involving an entire block on the west side of Manhattan at Columbus Circle was reported sold yesterday. The Mutual Life Insurance Company, through the Wood, Dolson Company, brokers, sold the two-story and basement business building known as 15 Columbus Circle to Henry Kaufman and Jack Cansino.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 20 (AP) -- Everybody expected the Philadelphia National Leaguers to beat Yale today, which they did, 7 to 0; but a surprise to every one was the Phillies' opening inning battery of Ogden Miller, Yale's athletic director, pitching to Bill Cox, the new owner of the Phillies.
The two-pronged drive by city and Federal authorities against alleged violators of food price ceilings and other rationing regulations was broadened considerably yesterday.
Among the larger apartment house units reported yesterday as taking new tenants was Tudor City, where the Fred F. French Management Company listed nineteen, as follows:

A portrait of one of Columbia University's earliest professors, Captain Claude Antoine Villet de Marcellin, who served in the American Revolution, has been presented to the university by a trustee and alumnus, Edmund Astley Prentis, a New York engineer, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president.

Latest reports from agricultural centers throughout the country indicate that the 8 per cent increase in farm production urged in the Federal Government's program will not be realized this year, according to L.A. Hawkins, agricultural adviser of the International Harvester Company.
The Treasury's Department's flag, which is awarded to companies whose employes put 10 per cent or more of their pay into War Bonds, was presented to American Airlines yesterday at La Guardia Field.

SAYVILLE, L.I., April 20 -- Coast Guardsmen, State troopers and local police continued today their search for the three Rockville Center Sea Scouts missing since noon yesterday when their 36-foot cabin cruiser, Legionnaire, was swamped and sunk in Great South Bay, two miles south from here, causing the deaths of seven of their fellow-Scouts.

ALBANY, April 20 -- The State War Council, moving to carry out the statutory provision for day care of children whose mothers are employed in war work, today made public the rules which must be followed in connection with State aid for wartime child-care projects.

SFAX, Tunisia, April 15 (Delayed) -- British Army assault parties landed on the Kerkennah Islands, in the Gulf of Gabes east of Sfax, early yesterday and occupied them without firing a shot, giving the Allies control of two of the six island stepping-stones between Tunisia and Sicily.

A loan exhibition of paintings, drawings and sculpture, to be held for the benefit of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, at the Wildenstein Gallery, will open with a preview on Tuesday evening at 9 o'clock. An admission charge of $5.50 will be made.

LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- Princess Elizabeth, fast-growing and fun-loving but already at grips with earnest matters of life, will be 17 tomorrow, the beginning of the final stage of adolescence from which she will emerge as a full-fledged public figure.

Lists furnished by State Legislators from which the management of the Jamaica Race Track filled pari-mutuel clerk jobs were offered in testimony yesterday at a State Labor Relations Board hearing on a jurisdictional fight between the Mutuel Ticket Agents Union of the American Federation of Labor and the Pari-Mutuel Employes Guild.

Dr. T. Tertius Noble, organist of St. Thomas Episcopal Church for thirty years, founder of its famous choir school and composer of church music, will retire on June l3, it was learned yesterday. He expects to devote his leisure time to composition, the editing of music and writing.

PITTSBURGH, April 20 -- Civilian inspectors for the Navy who passed steel plates at the Irvin Works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, testified today before the Federal grand jury investigating Truman Senate committee allegations that some material delivered to war agencies was defective.

THE baseball season steps off in full stride today, which is a step quite a few folks never thought would be taken. The pessimists were certain several months ago that the major league campaign would never get under way. Now they are equally convinced that it will experience the blind staggers by the Fourth of July and collapse in a bedraggled heap by August.

Private Edward Joseph Hoffman, 25 years old, who posed as "Sergeant Gallagher" to get money from wives, mothers and sweethearts of men in the Army on the pretext of helping the men to visit home before going overseas, was identified by half a dozen of his victims at Police Headquarters yesterday.

EASTON, Pa., April 20 -- Dr. Paul F. Cadman, economist of the American Bankers Association, told the graduating class of Lafayette College today that plans for the social security of mankind should be characterized by true liberalism, lest they jeopardize man's independence and lead to governmental tyranny.

The annual report of the Conservation Department of New York contains some observations and thoughts of wartime problems of conservation that should be set down for consideration, since they are an expression of the official family of our State leaders.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Only speedy action by the government in supplying materials needed to produce an adequate amount of farm implements will enable agriculture to meet 1944 food requirements, Fowler McCormick, president of International Harvester Company, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, and Judge Marvin Jones, chairman of the United States delegation to the International Food Conference at Hot Springs, Va., next month, indicated expectations today that differences between the press and government officials over news coverage of the sessions would be adjusted.

PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., April 14 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt got a realistic picture today of the training and weather conditions which make marines tough enough to fight through to victory on the sandy beaches of the Solomon Islands.

It was a happy notion of Connecticut's to choose the anniversary of the Battle of Lexington to express the gratitude and the affection that all Americans feel for Lieut. Gen. Jonathan M. Wainwright. New York can claim a special interest in him. His grandfather of the same name was born here and killed in action at Galveston in 1863 in command of the steamship Harriet Lane.

FORT BENNING, Ga., April 15 (Delayed) -- Live ammunition crackled within a few feet of President Roosevelt today as he sat in an open car to watch a group of officer candidates move up a long valley to take a hill which was under fire from machine guns and mortars.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- The War Department announced today promotion of 636 Women's Army Auxiliary Corps officers, including 175 second officers to first officers and 461 third officers to second officers.
LOS ANGELES, April 20 (AP) -- To Tommy Gorman, Canadian sportsman, banning of horse races and other sport during wartime is just plain tough on the service man.

Mileage ceilings have been fixed by the Office of Defense Transportation for taxicabs operating in New York City, it was announced yesterday. Single-shift cabs are limited to 2,700 miles a month and double-shift taxis to 4,100 miles. These figures represent reductions of 15 to 20 per cent from current mileage.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The secret of "Shangri-la," from which Major Gen. James H. Doolittle and his boys flew to rain bombs on Tokyo on April 18, 1942, was finally unveiled by the War Department tonight. The bombers' starting point was the U.S.S. Hornet, the gallant aircraft carrier since lost in the epic battle of Santa Cruz in the South Pacific.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Secretary Morgenthau's request for continuance of the $2,000,000,000 currency stabilization fund and the President's power to devalue the dollar, which the Senate trimmed on Friday by eliminating the authority over the dollar, appeared today to be headed for further modification tomorrow at the hands of the House Coinage Committee.

The latest official interpretation of the recent postoffice regulation affecting parcel post export shipments, under which the exporter's representative is considered the addressee, is "assinine and ridiculous" and threatens established business practice as well as the Good Neighbor Policy itself, foreign traders charged yesterday.

Dr. Richard M. Brickner, author of the forthcoming "Is Germany Incurable?" to be published by Lippincott on April 28, will be interviewed by Lee Barker of Doubleday. Doran on the "Books Are Bullets" program over WQXR today at 5 P.M.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that no reduction in prices will be required as a result of the War Production Board order altering the constructions on which all sheeting looms are required to operate.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 20 (AP) -- W.J. Susini's Get Off, 7-year-old son of American Flag, made his first start this season a winning one by taking the Block Island purse by a nose from A.S. Pierce's Allegro, the favorite, at Narragansett Park today.

CHICAGO, April 20 -- Aggressive buying of wheat and rye futures headed by a house with Northwestern connections turned the grain markets upward today on the Board of Trade and prices made additional gains later on the announcement that the House had passed the Agricultural Appropriation Bill eliminating parity benefit and incentive payments to the farmers.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- The Senate was in recess. Its Appropriations Committee approved the $3,269,700 Independent Offices Deficiency Bill. The Banking and Currency Committee approved a bill to establish an independent civilian supply administrator.

The difficulties of municipalities in floating bond issues were brought out yesterday in the United States Tax Court when Louis H. Schimmel, director of the municipal advisory council of Michigan, testified that municipal bonds in his State would not have been sold if Federal income tax charges had had to be included in the interest rates.

The General Electric Company had in the first quarter this year a net profit totaling $10,442,576 after all charges, equal to 36 cents a share on 28,845,927 shares, Gerard Swope, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders held in Schenectady.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 21 (AP) -- A small but heavy-hitting force of Flying Fortresses bombed the Japanese base at Wewak, New Guinea, yesterday, destroying a 6,000-ton cargo ship and damaging a smaller boat.

THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be congratulated on its outstanding leadership in presenting the merits of the pay-as-you-go tax question so forcefully. It is particularly timely because the enactment of such a tax has a direct bearing on staying inflation. The chief cause for inflation today is the pressure of $35,000,000,000 of excess income against a diminishing supply of goods.

A smear of lipstick, said to have been taken from the left hand of Norman Smith, 17 years old, became yesterday the basis for scientific testimony at his General Sessions trial on the charge of attempted criminal assault on Miss Gladys Kaurin, 23, a singer, at 2:30 A. M., St. Patrick's Day, as she was on her way from the subway to her home in Washington Heights.

LONDON, April 20 (AP) -- Dingle Mackintosh Foot, Laborite, told the House of Commons today that Sweden was exporting to Germany besides raw materials, certain classes of goods outside "the strict category of war materials" that "may be used either for civil or military purposes."

Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japanese Ambassador to Britain until Pearl Harbor and throughout his career a leading advocate of Japanese cooperation with the United States and Britain, was named Japanese Foreign Minister yesterday as part of a sweeping Cabinet reorganization by the Premier, General Hideki Tojo, Axis broadcasts announced.

Easter chicks are being bought this year with an eye to their potential laying abilities rather than for their soft yellow fluff or musical cheeps. Unrationed meat on the platter for future Sunday dinners is also the watchword of the thousands of amateurs who have decided to grow their own.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, April 20 -- New Zealand's reciprocal aid to the United States is not made without difficulties for this country, the press emphasized today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- Upholding the government's contention that the Pullman companies have a complete monopolization of furnishing sleeping ears to railroads, a special Federal Court found the companies and thirty-one officers and directors guilty today of violations of the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.

MAXWELL FIELD, Ala., April 15 -- (Delayed) President Roosevelt saw evidence today of America's mounting air power as 8,000 cadets from three flight training centers showed the stuff that will win them wings.

Manufacturers who insist they will have to return to 1942 models in consumers' durable goods in the post-war period were sharply criticized yesterday by Leo H. Rich, an associate of Walter Dorwin Teague, industrial designer, and a member of the business committee of the National Planning Association.

The net profits of the first 100 companies engaged in retail trade to issue their annual reports declined 8.6 per cent last year in comparison with 1941, according to the results of a survey issued yesterday by Childs, Jeffries Thorndike, Inc.

FORT OGLETHORPE, Ga., April 17 (Delayed) -- While an all-woman military band sprightly played "There's Something About a Soldier," twenty-four companies of the Women's Auxiliary Army Corps paraded today before their Commander in Chief at this training center, which is sending out six companies of women soldiers a week to relieve men for combat assignments.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20 -- The Christian Science Monitor of Boston is the winner of the F. Wayland Ayer Cup, highest award in the thirteenth annual exhibition of newspaper typography, conducted by N.W. Ayer Sons, Inc..

The New York State Food Merchants Association, representing 5,000 retailers, appealed yesterday to Mayor La Guardia on health and other grounds to help them move perishable cold cuts, which the stores say they are beginning to throw away because of spoilage.

BOSTON, April 20 -- New England advertising men were told today of a successful wartime advertising campaign, the theme of which in advance of the release of copy had been checked and approved by a large majority of the 250 newspaper editors and publishers to whom it was submitted as a preliminary test.

ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Moffat bill exempting the real property of the Metropolitan Opera Association from real estate taxation in New York City. The exemption had been opposed by Mayor La Guardia, but the Governor said that "a matter which is so vital to the culture of this State, the nation and the world, transcend home rule."

LONDON, Wednesday, April 21 (AP) -- A few German raiders dumped bombs on two London districts late last night during a brief alert that sent the capital's devastating anti-aircraft barrage into action.

The Commonwealth Southern Corporation capitulated yesterday to an order of the Securities and Exchange Commission and announced that it would undertake a comprehensive capital reorganization designed to reduce its outstanding securities to one class of stock, all of which would be common.

Experts in home economics are asking women to prepare now for the Summer preserving season by becoming familiar with appropriate methods and by getting equipment ready. The following article, the first of a series, deals with canning.

George A. Sloan, chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, cited last night statistics to prove that many large war production contracts were being subcontracted and declared that some of the most important of the latter were being let in New York.

The public doesn't know John Brice. In fact, the thousands who make their way into the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus daily and nightly in Madison Square Garden never heard of him. He's not the man on the flying trapeze nor the artist who puts the horses through intricate gaits nor the trainer who snaps the whip at the wild animals.

A faint-hearted horse that had quit in many a race, Happy Lark charged like a Guadalcanal Marine yesterday and returned 4 to 1 in the Jamaica feature for perhaps the biggest betting coup of the meeting. In a field of seven, six furlongs through the mud, the 6-year-old led from end to end to score by half a length, with Skin Deep second, and the favored Scotch Trap a distant third.

LONDON, April 20 (U.P.) -- General Draja Mikhailovitch, in a message that reached The United Press today from his secret mountain headquarters in Yugoslavia, said that he had rejected "with disgust" many attempts by the Germans and Italians to have him surrender.

REIDSVILLE, Ga., April 20 (AP) -- How three whisky stills were found in Georgia's State Penitentiary prior to the mass escape of twenty-five of the institution's toughest convicts was revealed today by Warden H.R. Duvall.

THE most widely read author of our time is neither Margaret Mitchell nor Adolf Hitler. Such well-known literary figures as Marion Hargrove and Wendell Willkie, best-selling writers though they may be, aren't even in the running. The undisputed champion is an assistant librarian of the House of Commons now serving on Lord Louis Mountbatten's staff as official historian of the commandos, Hilary St. George Saunders.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 21 -- A Soviet communique, in the first reference in weeks to the Kalinin front, said today that a Russian detachment there made a surprise attack on strong fortified enemy positions, captured a dominating height and held it against six enemy counter-attacks.

Officers of the Philco Corporation were reassigned at the organization meeting of the directors yesterday. James T. Buckley, president, became chairman of the executive committee and John Ballantyne, who has been serving as vice president in charge of operations, became president.

BOSTON, April 20 (AP) -- Norman Brown, lanky right-handed pitcher, today threatened to quit baseball when the Red Sox management notified him that he had been released to the Louisville American Association farm team.

LONDON, April 20 -- Activities today in the stock markets were confined mainly to the diamond-mining and home-rail sections. Diamond shares were active under the influence of the record profits shown by Consolidated De Beers, which rose 3/8. Home rails were subjected to profit-taking, which, however, was absorbed easily and with little change in prices at the market's close.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 20 -- The British Eighth Army has initiated the "big drive" toward Tunis by attacking in force northwest of Enfidaville and has "penetrated" the enemy position, it was announced officially tonight.

Captain Leland P. Lovett, Director of Public Relations of the Navy, revealed here last night that the 500-mile "gap" in mid-Atlantic where the German submarines have taken their biggest toll, was now being patrolled by ship-based helicopters. "We think they will be the secret of success against the submarine," he said.
ABOARD PRESIDENTIAL TRAIN, April 20 (U.P.) -- Members of the party accompanying President Roosevelt on his tour of the country and his trip:

LONDON, April 20 -- Britons can expect to hear their beloved church bells rung this coming Easter Sunday, as well as on all Sundays thereafter and also on special occasions. Prime Minister Churchill said so in the House of Commons today.

LONDON, April 20 (U.P.) -- General de Gaulle, broadcasting to France tonight, promised his countrymen that the Allied victory would result in a new deal for France in which the rights of the individual would be protected and the main sources of common wealth would be administered or controlled by the State.
WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Organized labor attacked President Roosevelt's "hold the line" order of April 5 from two sides today.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Brushing aside the War Production Board's opposition and its reorganizational steps designed to discourage Congressional action, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee approved unanimously and reported out today the Maloney bill which would take the Office of Civilian Supply away from the WPB and establish it as an independent administration with coordinate, rather than subordinate, powers.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 20 (Canadian Press) -- Preliminary calculations show that the physical volume of business in Canada in March reached a higher point than at any other time in Canadian industrial history, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 20 -- Vassar's second Institute for Family and Child Care Services in War Time, a training and demonstration center for parents, teachers, social workers and other professional workers, will be conducted from July 1 to 30, Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president of the college, announced today.

OTTAWA, Ont., April 20 (Canadian Press) -- Preliminary calculations show that the physical volume of business in Canada in March reached a higher point than at any other time in Canadian industrial history, according to the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 20 -- Vassar's second Institute for Family and Child Care Services in War Time, a training and demonstration center for parents, teachers, social workers and other professional workers, will be conducted from July 1 to 30, Dr. Henry N. MacCracken, president of the college, announced today.

A plan for setting up community canning centers in schools in the rural sections of this area was presented yesterday at the opening session of the North Atlantic Regional Conference for State's supervisors and teacher trainers in vocational agriculture.

Construction contracts awarded in the thirty-seven Eastern States during the first quarter of this year aggregated $1,083,876,000, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation. Although this was a decline of 20 per cent from the high record total of the first three months of 1942, it was slightly in excess of 1941's first-quarter total.

LONDON, April 20 -- Pointing out that a steel ring is gradually closing around Hitlerite Germany, Soviet Ambassador Ivan Maisky predicted today that the next six or seven months would have the greatest significance in the history of this war.

An advance of $120,000,000 in a single day toward the $3,000,000,000 war bond quota that has been set for investors other than the commercial banks in the Second Federal Reserve District was announced yesterday by Allan Sproul, chairman of the War Finance Committee.
NEW DELHI, India, April 20 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

ABOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN SOMEWHERE IN THE UNITED STATES, April 19 (Delayed) -- President Roosevelt, making a second secret inspection trip of the country at war, declared today that the highly trained troops he has seen in training camps of the Southern United States and their battle-seasoned colleagues in North Africa would do a good job in knocking the Axis out of Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (U.P.) -- A Maritime Commission official said today that an investigation by the Navy, the commission and the WPB showed that all steel plate delivered by the Carnegie-Illinois Corporation was "perfectly sound steel for ships."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 21 (AP) -- The noon communique:

It is mere coincidence that the memorandum sent by General Giraud to General de Gaulle proposing a basis for unity of action until France is liberated should be published almost simultaneously with the result of The Associated Press poll of the Senate on the question of American participation in an international police force to keep the peace.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -The Office of Price Administration appealed to the Interstate Commerce Commission today to reject the Hudson Manhattan Railroad's application to increase from 8 to 10 cents its passenger fare from Jersey City and Hoboken, N.J., to downtown New York City.

The Knickerbocker Hospital was saved from a threat of suspension of its operations by a ruling handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein permitting the hospital to use the principal of a trust fund of $1,000,000 left to it in 1895 by James Hood Wright, then its president.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 20 -- The tank and dive-bomber -- the two chief offensive weapons that the Germans developed before this war and on which they banked largely to win the "lightning war" begun almost four years ago -- have now been outclassed and virtually rendered useless, according to gratified British artillery and air experts.

At the end of this week the Guffey Coal Act, unless it is extended by Congress, will automatically expire. The House Ways and Means Committee, however, has already approved by a vote of 21 to 1 a resolution for a temporary extension of the law for 120 days.

Passover, the Jewish festival commemorating the deliverance of the ancient Hebrews from bondage in Egypt, symbolizes the ultimate triumph of the cause of freedom and liberty over the forces of oppression and persecution, rabbis declared in sermons yesterday, the first day of the celebration.

Rotterdam, N. 1r. Blair Co., Inc., and Bacol Stevenson Co., won yesterda the awar of $250,000 of Rottel dam, N. Y., sewer district bond The issue is dated April 15, 194: and matures, beginning on Oct. ; 1943, and thereafter from April: 194 to 1971.

WASHINGTON, April 20 -- Disclosure today that President Roosevelt is visiting Mexico while Vice President Wallace also is out of the United States on a South American tour prompted inquiries Whether this country has an acting President for the first time in its history.

Thus far in the war Argentina has enjoyed an extremely favorable trade balance with the United States and thus has acquired large dollar balances. Also, a substantial amount of refugee capital had been lodged temporarily in Buenos Aires.

LONDON, April 20 (U.P.) -- Adolf Hitler conferred with Vidkun Quisling, arch-traitor of Norway; Josef Terboven, German overlord of Norway, and Heinrich Himmler, head of the Nazi secret police and Elite Guard, at his headquarters yesterday, the eve of his fifty-fourth birthday, the German radio announced today.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 20 -- John R. Longo, 29-year-old foe of Mayor Frank Hague, who was dismissed as deputy Hudson County clerk last Friday, and J. Owen Grundy, 31, prominent in Republican politics here, were indicted today by the Hudson County grand jury for allegedly "altering, forging and counterfeiting" Longo's voting record in the Bureau of Elections, in which office both defendants had been employed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 20 -- Esther Williams, young swimming star under contract to Metro-Goldwin-Mayer, has been assigned to the lead opposite Red Skelton in the forthcoming picture "Mr. Co-Ed." John Murray Anderson will stage the water ballet scene for this film, which also will feature Phil Spitalny's All-Girl Orchestra.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- Navy communique 350:...
NEW DELHI, India, April 20 (AP) -- A communique:

ALBANY, April 20 -- Governor Dewey said today that a bill designed to cover the sale of horse meat to the public is "quite essential," but that he was compelled to veto the only bill on the subject passed by the 1943 Legislature because the measure "wholly fails to achieve that purpose."

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- Resolutions, including one that would have instructed the directors of the Curtis Publishing Company to accept beer, wine and liquor advertising in The Saturday Evening Post, were voted down by overwhelming margins today at the annual meeting of the stockholders.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Dr. Goodwin B. Watson, chief analyst, and Dr. William E. Dodd Jr., assistant news editor of the Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service of the Federal Communications Commission, were pronounced today "unfit" for government employment in a report by a special investigating subcommittee of the House, because of connections or associations with organizations and movements deemed to be "subversive."

Net profit of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended with March amounted to $9,555,472 after all charges and taxes, according to a report for publication today.

Accusing Mayor La Guardia of "lack of comprehension" of the problem, 300 delegates of welfare agencies, parent-teacher associations, trade unions and civic organizations demanded last night that the Mayor insert in his budget a $1,000,000 appropriation as the city's share of the cost of child care for New York's working mothers.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- High officials, members of the diplomatic corps and other representatives of the United Nations were among the guests at the first showing here today of the more recent work of Arthur Szyk, Polish artist and illuminator, in whose savagely satirical cartoons of Axis leaders the technique of an ancient art is revived with telling effect upon today's war effort.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 21 -- Movement of refugees on a very large scale is definitely out of the picture as it is seen by the British and American delegations to the conference on the international refugee problem, according to comment made tonight by the heads of both groups after the second full day of deliberations here.

CLEVELAND, April 21 (AP) -- Lanky Jim Bagby pitched a three-hitter today, struck two singles and then brought to a climax a perfect exhibition by lining a ninth-inning fly which gave the Indians a 1-to-0 triumph over the Tigers in the clubs' inaugural game.

Westchester and Putnam County fishermen who intend to take advantage of the opportunity to use boats on the lakes or reservoirs recently designated by the Mayor's order, have been making arrangements to have them moved on farmers' trucks.

LONDON, April 21 -- For the first time since he arrived here ten days ago to conduct exploratory talks with the Allied nations on post-war civilian relief needs, Herbert H. Lehman, United States Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, met the press today at the American Embassy.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Allied air smash over Nazi Europe, scheduled to reach full might late in the Summer and counted on as the keystone of United Nations strategy for speediest victory over Germany, will be seriously weakened by a shortage of 100-octane gasoline unless drastic action is taken immediately, Under Secretary of War Patterson warned today.

LONDON, April 21 -- The hitherto secret texts of the speeches that Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Premier Jan C. Smuts delivered to Great Britain's coal miners and operators last Oct. 31 were released today for publication.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The texts of President Roosevelt's statement on the execution of some of the American fliers who raided Japan and of the State Department's communication to Japan follow:
LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
The Berlin radio advised the American people to refuse to buy war bonds and decline to pay taxes, according to a broadcast heard in New York yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

DETROIT, April 21 -- Eight labor members of the Detroit War Manpower Commission management-labor advisory committee resigned today in protest against President Roosevelt's national labor stablization order issued last week through Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commissioner.

Declaring that Adolf Hitler had made his "one great miscalculation" in failing to count on the ability of American industry to swing into war production as quickly as it has, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, revealed yesterday that United States airplane production probably would reach the 7,000-a-month rate this month, or come close to it, and promised it would keep on growing until it was as large as needed.

BUENOS AIRES, April 21 -- Strict control of incoming capital began to be applied today by all commercial banks under the supervision of the Central Bank of the Argentine Republic in accordance with a decree isued late last night by the Finance Ministry.

Robert Goldsand, pianist, ended his Series of seven Beethoven recitals, in which he played all of the sonatas, in the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall last night before an audience that filled the hall and gave him an ovation after the closing work, the great Opus 3 in C minor.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 (AP) -- Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney heard arguments and reserved decision today on whether he should dismiss an indictment charging the Marine Maintenance Corporation of Bayonne and two individuals with conspiracy to defraud the United States on war contracts.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 22 (AP) -- Ten Japanese bases were attacked in light raids by Allied bombers and fighters yesterday, the High Command announced today.

A UNITED STATES ARMY BASE IN SURINAM [Dutch Guiana], April 21 (AP) -- I had been flying at 8,000 feet for nearly two hours through a heavy rain turbulence. I spotted an opening in the clouds and started to spiral down to fly contact beneath the overcast.

A new phase of the Moreland Act inquiry into the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law, described as "clipping the claimant," was begun yesterday with testimony that a lawyer charged an injured boy $240 above the $50 fee allowed by the State Department of Labor.

LONDON, April 21 -- Sweeping out in force in perfect flying weather, British bombers last night blasted manufacturing and other war installations in the Baltic ports of Stettin and Rostock, left Berlin alight with fires and ranged widely over other sections of occupied Europe today in one of the war's biggest air assaults on German communications.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, April 21 -- An impressive total of evidence, topped today by the new statement of General Douglas MacArthur's spokesman, has accumulated within the last few days that a major Japanese offensive move in the Australian theatre may be made in the near future.

A NORTH AFRICAN AIR BASE, April 21 (AP) -- Giving for publication the first eyewitness account of the Tokyo raid by any participating airmen, three Army Air Force officers disclosed tonight that, after the attack, the United States bombers had flown fifty miles out to sea to make the Japanese think that they were going back the way that they had come and thereby to hide their China destination.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 21 (AP) -- Vice President Henry A. Wallace, making his last major address on his Latin American tour, declared tonight that individual liberty tempered to permit mass unity must be a fundamental policy of the democracies in building a lasting world peace.

It is cheering news that helicopters are already in use against the submarine, even though doubtless still on a small scale. Captain Leland P. Lovette, Director of Public Relations of the Navy, is authority for the statement that the 500-mile "gap" in mid-Atlantic where the German submarines have taken their biggest, toll is now being patrolled by ship-based helicopters.

The "hold-the-line" executive order does not abolish the need for price readjustments to take care of the rising costs of civilian goods production, and the real test of price control lies ahead when low cost merchandise stocks are exhausted, Q. Forrest Walker, economist of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., said last night in an address before the division of advanced study of the elehanty Institute.

LONDON, Thursday, April 22 (AP) -- Soviet troops, aided by airmen who "inflicted devastating losses," beat off another series of mass German counter-attacks yesterday in the Northwestern Caucasus near the Axis bridgehead of Novorossiisk, Moscow announced early today.

CAIRO, April 21 (AP) -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York disclosed today that he had visited the Allied-occupied ports of Gabes and Sfax in Tunisia and the Tunisian battlefront before arriving here for an overnight visit en route to Jerusalem, where he will spend Easter.

As the gasoline supply situation became so bad yesterday that only prompt action by the office of the Petroleum Administrator for War averted suspension of service by three public bus lines, the PAW asserted that mounting military requirements had caused "an actual shortage of gasoline in this area" and that it was unlikely there would be any improvement for at least the rest of this month.

LAHORE, Punjab Province, India, April 20 (Delayed) -- The Punjab, British India's most important province, carries on as it did before the death of its famous Premier, Sir Sikander Hyat Khan, last December. It was important to ascertain this, for there are strong centrifugal forces at work inside the province, as throughout India, and what happens in the Punjab is going to have a great effect on the future of the country.

Holy Week services were conducted at noon yesterday by the Salvation Army on the steps of the Subtreasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets under the direction of Brigadier William G. Harris, principal of the Training College in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The War Labor Board threatened tonight, in effect, to ask President Roosevelt to order troops to break up the picket line which John L. Lewis's District 50, United Mine Workers, has thrown around the Celanese Corporation of America's plant at Newark, N.J.

LONDON, April 21 -- Here as a representative of organized Protestantism of the United States, Dr. Adna Wright Leonard, Resident Bishop of the Methodist Church for the Washington, D.C., Area and chairman of the general commission of United States Army and Navy chaplains, today continued his tour of Army hospitals and other military installations, where in many cases he spoke to wounded veterans of the Tunisian campaign.

William E. Holmwood, chairman of the Newark draft appeals board, announced yesterday that Selective Service registrants of New Jersey who are fathers of nursing babies or who have wives in advanced stages of pregnancy will be put in Class 3-D, unless the wives have adequate means of support.

HAVANA, April 21 -- The American Chamber of Comerce of Cuba approved today a resolution urging extension of the trade agreements act which gives President Roosevelt authority to enter reciprocal trade agreements.

Dropping from the direction of a bright moon, a bomb hit a British church. On top of the pile of resulting debris demolition workers found a seaman's prayer book open at a page that contained this line: "We had fainted unless we had believed."

Abolition of Farm Security Administration funds for farm purchase, for rehabilitation loans to tenant farmers and sharecroppers, for purchase of tools, equipment and livestock may have a devastating effect on the war program, C.B. Baldwin, national FSA Administrator, declared here yesterday.

The War Shipping Administration hopes to obtain permission from all big industrial companies to search through their personnel rosters for the names of experienced seamen, who will be urged to return to the sea as a patriotic duty, it was announced yesterday by Craig S. Vincent, Atlantic Coast regional representative of the WSA's recruitment and manning organization.

A perverse Spring which had practically wrecked baseball's northern training and exhibition schedule continued to raise havoc yesterday when it scored a complete washout of New York's effort to launch the major league championship season.

Manpower shortages are opening new vistas of employment for women in the newspaper field Widespread employment of women, not only as reporters but as workers in the mechanical departments of small plants throughout the country, was recognized as an inevitability by publishers attending meetings this week of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

I am enclosing a portion of a letter which I received from a young lieutenant in the American Army. He has visited the Open House for Officers in Hotel Delmonico on several occasions when he has been here in New York, and I think it might be of interest to the public to know of the opportunities offered here for building up friendly relations between the young people of the various Allied nations.

In Pearl Buck's article entitled "Can England Trust Us?" appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine April 18 she calls for the cooperation of England, Russia and this country in the post-war world, meaning that the three shall operate jointly to a common end.

Lauris Steere, a student at Hamline University, St. Paul, and Bernard Goldstein, student at the Boston University of Music, are cowinners in the first student composition contests ever held by the National Federation of Music Clubs, it was announced today.

Nancy Wilson Ross, novelist and author of "Farthest Reach," a nonfiction work on the Northwest, has spent six months gathering material for a book on the Waves. Holt plans to publish the book this Summer under the title "The Waves: the Story of the Girls in Blue."

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Kerr Committee attack repeats false charges made by Representative Dies eighteen months ago. Of twelve alleged "front" organizations, I belonged only to Consumers Union and the Descendants of the American Revolution, to both of which have been given wide liberal support.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The tentative agenda for the international food conference, scheduled to open May 18 at Hot Springs, Va., and the hopes of its United States organizers call for worldwide regulation of the food supply of the globe in the interests primarily of human health, secondly as an economic measure which would lay the foundation for healthy national economies and free international trade, and thirdly as a preservative of peace.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, April 21 (AP) -- The girls that the natives left behind presented a problem in domestic relations today for the American and Australian Army officers in this jungle battleground.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, April 21 -- President Roosevelt of the United States and President Avila Camacho of Mexico ended twenty-four hours of conferences today after a luncheon at the naval air training station here at which Mr. Roosevelt declared the training programs of the United States armed forces for officers of Latin-American countries were a wide and long step forward for continental defense and unity of purpose.

Tuesday The Associated Press made Frank B. Noyes its honorary president. It was a new honor, the only new one they could think of, for the surviving founder of the association, thirty-eight years its president, is still one of its directors. He was almost born in a newspaper office.

ALBANY, April 21 (U.P.) -- Morris U. Schappes, former instructor at City College, New York, convicted on perjury charges, was pictured in arguments before the Court of Appeals today as a victim of "judicial lynching."

Six hundred British and dual-nationality women have left this country for voluntary service in England since the British Government issued an appeal for workers last August, it was disclosed yesterday. Sixty per cent of the volunteers have entered the military and semimilitary branches open to them, the majority going to the Auxiliary Territorial Service.
Flying Officer George F.R. Jackson Jr. of the Royal Canadian Air Force was killed on active service in England on Monday, according to word received here yesterday.

Preceding by a few hours the news of the murder of the American fliers by the Japanese Government, there was published yesterday the Army's long-delayed report on the details of the raid. It told the dramatic story of an exploit that does everlasting credit to those who planned it and achieved it.

The City Planning Commission yesterday set May 5 as the date for a public hearing on a resolution to modify the city's master plan by enlarging already designated slum clearance areas in Manhattan to include the seventy-two-acre tract upon which the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company plans to construct a post-war $40,000,000 medium-rental housing project.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- General Henry H. Arnold pledged the Army Air Forces tonight to the utter destruction of Japan's "inhuman war lords" in vengeance for the execution of American fliers captured after last year's raid on Tokyo.

Good Friday, commemorating the crucifixion of Christ, will be observed tomorrow more widely than ever before, because it falls upon a world increasingly plunged into war. Everywhere prayers will be offered that as Christ's resurrection followed His death so there may follow upon this "darkest hour" in modern history the resurrection of a free world.

Fifty-five graduate nurses, including several that saw service in France during World War I, were ready for Service in World War II yesterday after completing refresher classes given by the Brooklyn Nurses Replacement Committee, a joint enterprise of the Nurses Association of the Counties of Long Island and the Brooklyn Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration announced tonight the full list of sharply reduced point values scheduled to take effect at midnight on frozen fruits and vegetables and all rationed soups.

Elimination of the 10 per cent reduction in mark-up and an advance in the effective date of amendment No. 5 to MPR 287 to May 15 from June 15 because of the heavy anticipatory buying now going on, were advocated yesterday by Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, at a special meeting of the organization at the Hotel Governor Clinton.

In line with its recent tendency to relax restrictions on consumer durable goods production, the War Production Board is now preparing the fina draft of an order which would more than double the production of cooking and heating stoves, it was learned here yesterday.

Prizes in journalism were awarded yesterday at the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Walter M. Dear, president of the association, made the presentations.
The Rome radio reported last night that the Japanese had captured the six-man crew of an American plane near the border of Hunan Province, China, The United Press reported.

Public Law 252 states that "during the present emergency temporary appointments as officers in the Army of the United States may be made * * * from among qualified persons." The Controller General, who pays the Government bills, has ruled that a woman is not a person, with the result that, though she may be a practicing physician, she may not receive a commission in the Medical Corps.

The Netherlands News Agency reported yesterday, quoting the Japanese-controlled Batavia, Java, radio, that Japanese authorities in the Netherlands East Indies had set up new rules to "punish" allegedly rebellious acts by Netherland, British and American prisoners, including the death penalty, The United Press said.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The War Production Board has assigned William F. Gibbs, its controller of shipbuilding, to direct a study of specifications for steel plate for shipbuilding with a view to revisions "harmonizing them with the true requirements."

Since margins will probably be narrower and cost reduction of vital importance in the post-war era, careful planning will be essential and further development in budgeting and standard costs can be expected, James L. Dohr, director of research of the American Institute of Accountants, declared last night at a dinner meeting of the Brooklyn chapter of the National Association of Cost Accountants at the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A.
The Italian Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:
Your recent editorial "A Camouflaged Wage Rise?" is a lone cry in the wilderness which is not being heeded by self-serving pressure groups.

Unless something goes radically wrong, you can look for the largest International League opening day crowd today at Jersey City when the double "A" circuit gets under way in the two New Jersey cities.

CHUNGKING, April 21 (U.P.) -- The Japanese drive along the Tsang River east of Canton has collapsed and the battered enemy remnants have retired to their original bases after having lost 800 men to Chinese counter-attacks, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Army airmen, continuing their daily blasting of the growing Japanese stronghold in the Aleutians, have carried out fifteen new attacks on Kiska, a Navy communique announced today.

ALBANY, April 21 -- Governor Dewey vetoed today eight bills affecting the regular or teachers' retirement systems in New York City, including the Wicks bill, permitting a member of the employes' retirement system to elect the age of 55 for retirement up to Jan. 1, 1944, instead of Oct. 1, 1942.

BALTIMORE, April 21 (AP) -- Henry L. Straus's Preakness candidate, New Moon, showed his heels to a field of four other sprinters today to romp off with the $2,000 Port Moresby purse, feature of the closing program of a five-day war relief meeting at the Pimlico race course.

CHUNGKING, April 21 -- In connection with the Tokyo Cabinet changes announced yesterday Chinese Government sources here today said the appointment of Mamoru Shigemitsu as Foreign Minister, following similar changes in the Finance and Greater East Asia ministries, indicated a considerable strengthening of the former "moderate" group relative to the fascist militarists.

NEWARK, N.J., April 21 -- A filling station operator, who allegedly admitted to inspectors of the district bureau of the Office of Price Administration that he had "netted" $1,000 in six weeks from the illicit sale of gasoline, failed to appear for an administrative hearing before OPA Commissioner Clifford R. Snider here today, but testimony was taken in his absence and decision reserved.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Truman committee, reporting to the Senate its findings after extensive investigations into the Navy and merchant marine ship construction programs, declared today that the Navy had done "a magnificent job" in building a first-class fighting fleet, but it held that in doing so it sacrificed protection of vessels carrying vital cargoes to overseas battlefronts.

In defiance of every law of civilized warfare the Japanese Government has murdered in cold blood some of the American fliers who bombed military objectives in Tokyo and other centers of war production. To this brutal act of a government whose thin veneer of modernism covers a primitive savagery the only possible answer has been made by our State Department.

Two horses, Omission and Bull Reigh, became double winners yesterday at Jamaica when 10,850 persons drove them both into heavy favoritism and rejoiced at their victories. It was another raw day, such as has become so common, and the track was sloppy.

CHICAGO, April 21 -- Employes of Marshall Field Co. were notified yesterday that the United States Circuit Court of Appeals had voided a National Labor Relations Board order requiring the company to bargain with Local 291, United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, C.I.O., as the representative of the employes in that bargaining group, which comprises about 450 of the store's 8,000 employes.

The United States Secret Service announced yesterday that thirty men had been arrested and more would be, and that counterfeit gasoline ration stamps with a face value of 2,500,000 gallons had been seized, with printing plates, during a ten-day offensive against a huge black market ring of dealers in this city.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, April 21 -- President Roosevelt's visit to Mexico has done more to improve relations with the United States than any single gesture on the part of Washington in this century, Senor Miguel Aleman, Secretary of the Interior, said today as President Avila Camacho returned the visit which President Roosevelt paid to him in Monterrey yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 21 -- In a two-pronged drive the British Eighth Army has captured Enfidaville, on the eastern end of the thirty-three-mile southern Axis line, and has driven nearly two miles into the towering hills beyond Djebel Garci, fourteen miles west of this key town, it was announced tonight.

CLEVELAND, April 21 -- Leonard Rose, first 'cellist of the Cleveland Orchestra for the last four years, has been engaged for two solo performances next year with the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra and also will become first 'cellist of the 100-year-old organization.

The shortage of office personnel can best be overcome, by increased efficiency based on additional pay incentive, Eugene J. Benge, president of Benge Associates, management engineers of Chicago, declared last night at a meeting of the National Office Management Association in the Hotel Belmont Plaza.

The cotton futures market adhered yesterday to the lethargic trading and narrow price movement characteristic of it for the last week. Action on cotton ceilings and disposal of the government's stocks was awaited. Local and New Orleans selling accounted for final net losses of 5 to 9 points for the six active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.

LONDON, April 21 -- The stock markets were much quieter today as a result of the approach of the Easter holiday. Gilt-edge stocks were easier, with the War Loan 3 1/2 per cents down 1/8 to 105 5/16. Home rails were affected by profit-taking, London, Midland Scottish losing 1/4 to 32 3/4, and Southern deferred, 3/8 at 24 3/4.
A Finnish communique as broadcast Wednesday by the Lahti radio and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:
It would not be like the Royal Air Force to forget Adolf Hitler's birthday. Bonfires lit by British bombs in Stettin, Rostock and Berlin itself will help Germany remember the occasion.

CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Walter C. Rawls, manager of the St. Louis branch of E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., of New York, investment bankers, testified today at a hearing of the Securities and Exchange Commission that he gave "personalized" service in handling securities for the Board of Missions of the former Methodist Episcopal Church South.

Some adjustment may be made shortly in the inventory control order L-219 to equalize those provisions which affect garment producers and their fabric suppliers either directly or indirectly, J.A. Wagenbauer of the WPB declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Uptown Credit Group in the National Republican Club.

The text of Donald M. Nelson's address yesterday before the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention, in response to the presentation of a souvenir brochure from Richard W. Slocum of The Philadelphia Bulletin, containing a report on the nation-wide campaign conducted by the newspapers last Fall to collect scrap metal so that the steel mills and war production could be kept going, follows:

LONDON, Thursday, April 22 -- An almost unprecedented communique issued shortly before midnight by 10 Downing Street declared that reports were coming in from "several sources" that Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler was preparing to use poison gas against the Russian Army.

Interrupting his trial for first-degree murder, Guillermo C. Castro, 27-year-old Puerto Rican, who killed Miss Carmen Colon, 18, on Jan. 13 in the street near her home at 118 West Sixty-third Street, pleaded guilty to second-degree murder yesterday in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The House will get another chance to vote on pay-as-you-go tax bills within the next two weeks as the paradoxical result of the inability of members of the Ways and Means Committee, who have tirelessly sought a compromise since last Friday, to reach an agreement.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 311 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Asiatic, European, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas. Of the men on today's list 192 were wounded in North Africa. Soldiers with next of kin in New York numbered twenty-nine; in New Jersey, twelve; and in Connecticut, six. All enlisted men, unless otherwise specified, they are:

Alexander Borovsky presented an all-Bach program at his second New York recital of the season, given last night in Town Hall. The Russian pianist had been heard eighty-seven times in Europe and Latin America in recitals devoted to works by the Leipzig master, but not previously in the United States.

LONDON, April 21 -- Britain's famous submarine Thunderbolt, in which ninety-nine men perished when, as the Thetis, she sank four years ago during trials, is missing in the Mediterranean and must be presumed lost, the Admiralty announced tonight.
Mrs. W. Morgan Churchman has arrived from Whitemarsh, Pa., and is at the Plaza.

CINCINNATI, April 21 (AP) -- The fifty-second Continental Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the smallest in recent years, came to an end today with at least three cities actively seeking the 1944 meeting.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 22 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Japanese Government has barbarously executed some of the eight American aviators captured from Major Gen. James H. Doolittle's raid on Japan, April 18, 1942, on the grounds that they intentionally bombed non-military installations and deliberately fired on civilians.

EDGEWATER, N.J., April 21 -- Confronted with the refusal of the international president of the union to sanction a strike, the executive committee of Local 16, Aluminum Workers of America, will hold a meeting tomorrow morning at 10 o'clock, presumably to review its action in calling for a general walk-out tomorrow night at the local plant of the Aluminum Company of America, which is engaged exclusively in producing sheet metal for the Army and Navy.

Further reductions in allotments of distilled spirits to wholesalers in this area and a general tightening up of the informal rationing systems now in effect are planned by distillers in view of the growing scarcity of liquor, it was reported in the trade yesterday.
The German Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

In an effort to get poultry moving again in regular trade channels, the Office of Price Administration has revised ceiling price regulations that some handlers found objectionable and is starting a vigorous drive on black-market poultry operations, it was disclosed yesterday.

Experts in home economics are asking women to prepare now for the Summer preserving season by becoming familiar with appropriate methods and by getting equipment ready. The following article, the second of a series, deals with preservation by salting. A third column will be concerned with home dehydration.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Navy communique 351:

CAIRO, Egypt, April 21 -- Grain, in the Middle East will be crops among the best in recent years, with an unprecedented bumper; wheat harvest in Iran, an excellent barley output in Iraq and considerably better than average crops anticipated in Syria, Egypt and Turkey.

Some people's feelings about the State Department can be very simply described. Even if it was good they wouldn't like it. When they are very, very angry with the State Department they draw cartoons asking the porter in the State Department building to sweep out a lot of rubbish labeled Berle, Standley, Bullitt and the like.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Tighter control over the "T" gasoline ration allowance for trucks, taxicabs and other commercial vehicles is being planned, at the Office of Price Administration as an adjunct to the Office of Defense Transportation's new regulation fixing mileage ceilings for taxicabs at 15 to 20 per cent below current levels, Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, said tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (U.P.) -- Selective Service headquarters decreed tonight that Federal workers could not be deferred for occupational reasons except under the executive policy which requires examination of individual cases by a special presidential committee.

LONDON, April 21 -- German atrocities in Poland are increasing because army losses have made the German determined to maintain the "equlibrium" between the populations of Germany and Poland on their own terms, the Polish underground declared today in a message addressed to Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee, in his capacity as leader of the Labor party.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 21 -- Plain Ben Jones rode back into the Kentucky Derby picture today on a wave -- Ocean Wave, the colt a lot of folks had about decided to count out of the big May day scramble.
WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Following is the text of the French National Committee's note concerning General Henri Honore Giraud's answer to the committee's memorandum dated Feb. 23:

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Something more fundamental than the falsification of records by employes at the Irvin Works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Company and the consequent delivery of steel plate 5 per cent below specified tensile strength must have been responsible for the recent cracking of some welded ships, officials of the company stated at a meeting with the War Production Board and representatives of the Army, Navy and Maritime Commission.

Certificates were awarded to eighteen group winners at the American Newspaper Publishers Association convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday in a safe-driving contest for newspaper delivery trucks held by the A.N. P.A. and the International Circulation Managers Association.

One week ago, member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City were entirely out of excess reserves and actually showed a deficiency of $30,000,000 in required reserves. Last Friday, as the result of shifts of funds from private deposits to government war-loan accounts, on which reserves are no longer required, the New York City banks found themselves with excess reserves of more than $300,000,000.

Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, told shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday that the management of the Bell System would do everything in its power to see that the system comes through the "trial of war" fundamentally unimpaired and able to continue to furnish the American people with the "best telephone service in the world."

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, is convinced that the "hold the line" edict of President Roosevelt regarding living costs can be met once "black market" operations are strangled.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 21 (AP) -- Despite a drop of 200 in the number of university and college contestants Drake Relay officials believe as many as five meet records may fall in the thirty-fourth annual carnival Friday and Saturday.

Fifteen Russian students, the first group of its kind to be sent by the Soviet Government for foreign study, will be assigned to service by the Russian consul general in New York when they finish an eight-month training program in American affairs and clerical work at Columbia University next month, it was announced yesterday.

The wage negotiations between operators of the Appalachian region and the United Mine Workers, affecting 450,000 soft coal miners, remained deadlocked after another long session yesterday. Representatives of the Southern Coal Producers Association met briefly with union spokesmen at the Hotel Commodore.

Additional names of politicians, headed by James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, figured yesterday in the continued hearing before the State Labor Relations Board in the jurisdictional fight between the Mutuel Ticket Agents Union, A.F. of L., which is conducting a strike at the Jamaica Race Track, and the Pari-Mutuel Employes Guild, characterized by the A.F. of L. as a company union.

LONDON, April 21 -- With the benefit of the nicknames of two of the greatest collegiate teams in the United States, if not of their stars, what is believed to be the first formal game of American football ever played here will take place on May 8, it was confirmed today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, declared today that henceforth no group of workers would be permitted to receive wage increases beyond the 15 per cent "Little Steel" formula for "alleged manpower considerations."

CINCINNATI, April 21 -- Johnny Vander Meer paid off on four years of trying by pitching the Reds to a 1-0 victory today over the Cardinals, who got only two singles in eleven innings off the tall southpaw.

Assets of the Hardware Mutual Casualty Company increased $1,618,689 last year to a new high of $17,567,046 on Dec. 31, 1942, it was reported yesterday at the twenty-ninth annual meeting of policy holders held in Stevens Point, Wis. Surplus to policy holders at the year end totaled $3,606,738, or $472,659 larger than a year earlier. The general voluntary reserve was $690,000 against $530,000 at end of 1941.

ST. LOUIS, April 21 (AP) -- The four-hit pitching of Southpaw Al Hollingsworth and batting punch gained for the Browns their seventh consecutive opening day victory as they blanked the White Sox today, 3 to 0, before 4,421 fans.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- In a memorandum made public today by his representatives here, General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader, makes several observations on the proposals for French unity framed by General Henri Honore Giraud, French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, and published on Monday.

AT AN ADVANCE BASE IN THE ALEUTIANS, April 2 (Delayed) (AP) -- Daring, good marksmanship, good seamanship and oodies of luck were responsible for a small American naval force's David-and-Goliath victory over a superior Japanese fleet in the Aleutians on March 26, ranking admirals of the North Pacific said today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Joseph B. Eastman, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, announced today that all requests by railroads for authority to operate additional Summer services involving the use of Pullman sleeping-car equipment would be denied.

A San Francisco judge has ruled that labor unions have a right to refuse to use labor-saving mechanical devices. Dismissing anti-trust indictments against seventy-eight persons, contractors and labor unions, Judge A.F. St. Sure has upheld a labor union's contention that painting with spray guns would cut down available work for its members.

The executive board of the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, has sustained the right of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society to dismiss fourteen musicians at the request of Dr. Artur Rodzinski, the Philharmonic's new conductor, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, April 21 -- A Royal Air Force commentator declared in the most emphatic terms today that the United States Army Air Force system of checking and rechecking claims by its airmen about the number of enemy planes destroyed, probably destroyed, damaged or probably damaged was at least as "severe" as the British system, if not more so.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 21 -- The secret Polish radio appealed for help tonight in a broadcast from Poland and then suddenly the station went dead.

A patrolman with an injured side and the broken plate glass window of the McBride Theatre Ticket Agency were the chief "casualties" of a blitzkrieg staged in Times Square yesterday morning by a noisy but good-natured crowd of 'teen age youngsters who stormed the Paramount Theatre to get a glimpse of Alan Ladd on the screen and Harry James blowing his trumpet on the stage.

To the end that all employes doing comparable work might get wage increases at the same time, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday appealed from a directive of the War Labor Board which granted rises for 384 and left unchanged the pay rates of 535 workers.
CHICAGO, April 21 (AP) -- Truett (Rip) Sewell held the Cubs to three scattered singles today as the Pirates won their opening game of the baseball season, 6 to 0.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the pottery and wool industries before the Ways and Means Committee today recommended abandonment of the reciprocal trade-treaty program on the ground that no one knows what conditions will be when peace comes, but proponents testified extension of the act is advisable in order to assure close political as well as economic relations with other nations.

The index of finished oil products stocked in the East Coast area again declined last week to a new low level, according to the American Petroleum institute. The index, which stood at 28.1, compared with 28.8 a week earlier and 58.3 on Nov. 7, 1942, when the downward trend started. The compilation covers gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil and is based on sup- plies in 1940 and 1941, adjusted to seasonal variations.

The stock market, made yesterday a substantial move toward pulling itself back to the high levels of early April as prices on the Stock Exchange advanced fractions to more than a point. Under the sponsorship of the public utilities, the list was strong from the start and considerably more active than it had been recently, with the final hour setting the pace for volume and enlargements of value.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- New automobiles are selling faster under recently relaxed rationing rules, and the government and automobile dealers agreed today to postpone at least until the end of the year plans for government purchase of the unsold stock of new cars.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Elmer Davis held a press conference today before a dozen members of the Senate Judiciary Committee who sat silent while the director of the Office of War Information was cross-examined for more than an hour by nearly 100 newspaper men and women.
In Dr. Sarah Wambaugh's letter, published in Sunday's TIMES, there are a number of inaccuracies, a few of which call for comment.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., April 21 -- Within the gates and walls of The Homestead here, precincts which the press of the United Nations is to be permitted to enter during the international food conference at stated times only, there is a very pleasant compound called Cottage Row.

COMMANDER HOWARD LAMMERS, a naval officer who was killed recently in an airplane accident while on a mission to Ceylon, had a favorite theory that the Battle of Jutland changed the history of the world. True, the failure of Jellicoe to push the battle to a victorious conclusion did not keep the Allies from eventually defeating Germany.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 21 (AP) -- David A. Crawford, president of the Pullman Company, told directors today that a decision by a special Federal expediting court in Philadelphia holding that the company had violated the anti-trust laws "comes at a time when the railroads of the country" have asked Pullman to lease and operate 1,200 special type troop sleeping cars.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 21 -- Numerous blackouts for Westchester County between April 26 and May 29 will be requested of the State Director of Civilian Protection by the defense officials of Westchester County and of the six cities in the county, Captain Rossiter Holbrook, deputy county director of civilian protection, said today.

The Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association has concentrated its efforts in the last year on the development of institutional advertising, according to the thirtieth annual report issued yesterday. Chief source for the presentations to advertisers was the "Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading," which, through scientific research, gave advertisers proof that their messages would be read.

Rather than have its theatres dark whenever there is a shortage of touring attractions, the United Booking Office intends to overcome such contingencies by installing vaudeville shows. According to Marcus Heiman, head of the U.B.O., a variety bill is now being organized by William Miller to play the week of May 9 at the Erlanger, Buffalo, and the following two weeks (May 16-29) at the National, Washington.
WASHINGTON, April 21 (U.P.) -- Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican, of New York, a pre-Pearl Harbor non-interventionist, today called for prompt reprisal against Japanese prisoners.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 21 (AP) -- A communique:

Walter M. Dear, president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and of The Jersey City (N.J.) Journal, in the annual presidential address at yesterday morning's session of the fifty-seventh annual convention of the A.N.P.A. at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel called on the publishers to observe "eternal vigilance" as the "price of liberty" against governmental restrictions.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 21 -- Berliners are expecting a reduction in the meat ration from the present 350 grams a week to 300 grams [ten and a half ounces], perhaps less. Otherwise the food situation for the Reich appears good enough, but fear is expressed that the prolonged drought may produce crop failures of far-reaching consequences in Germany's situation.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The Office of Price Administration advised housewives today to go ahead with canning plans on the same basis as last year since no changes are contemplated in providing sugar for home canning.

BOSTON, April 21 (U.P.) -- The story of a survivor of a sinking revealed tonight how 202 passengers and crew of his ship were rescued by a Coast Guard combat cutter. The action is believed to have been one of the greatest rescues of life by a single vessel in maritime history.

Everywhere in England the church bells are ringing again. In bombed Canterbury and all the ancient towns built about the medieval cathedrals; in Westminster and the leafy squares of ravaged London; in the cloistral quadrangles of Oxford and Cambridge; in the steeple-topped villages of the South Downs and the Great North Road, the familiar chime of bells, so long unheard, falls on the air once more.

Having booked most of their Fall business well in advance of the Summer markets, several manufacturers of semi-vitreous dinnerware have withdrawn their lines for an indefinite period, possibly for the remainder of the year, it was reported yesterday.

A collection of paintings by contemporary artists, assembled by Monroe Wheeler of the Museum of Art, will be placed on view on Wednesday at the headquarters of Friends of Greece, Inc., 52 East Fifty-seventh Street, to aid children in Greece.
WITH THE CHINESE ARMY, on the Salween Front, April 19 (Delayed) -- Don't judge a Chinese soldier by his appearance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 21 -- Constance Bennett today withdrew from the cast of Andrew Stone's United Artists production, "Hi Diddle Diddle." She was to have played the role of night club entertainer, a part from which Lupe Velez previously had withdrawn.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 21 -- In anticipation of an invasion, the Germans have moved their administration center in the Netherlands inland a good distance from the coast, according to an uncensored message received from a reliable source there.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- News that Japan has executed some of the American fliers captured after the bombing of Tokyo brought indignant comment in Congress today and predictions that it would arouse the American people to a greater fighting pitch.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21 -- Dr. Harold C. Urey, Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University, and Professor George W. Pierce of Cambridge, Mass., received Franklin Medals tonight for their achievements in scientific fields at annual medal day ceremonies of the Franklin Institute.

Even in such a relatively modern art as that which goes by the name of cosmetology the "good old days" have something to offer. And wartime shortages are bringing to light a number of homely, old-fashioned potions that seem to stand up pretty well beside the hifalutin' inventions of the pre-war period.

NEW DELHI, India, April 21 (U.P.) -- British fliers made damaging sweeps over Western Burma yesterday, with Blenheim bombers dropping their missiles squarely on a concentration of 500 Japanese soldiers in the Mayu Peninsula hills and fighter planes strafing enemy transport and buildings in the Akyab district, a British communique reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 21 -- Arriving here to take over his new post as the War Production Board's vice chairman in charge of civilian requirements, Arthur D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., said today that the civilian supply agency should remain within the WPB rather than operate as an independent agency, as proposed under the Maloney bill, which now is before the Senate.

The Colored Orphan Asylum at Riverdale, in the Bronx, had an average daily attendance of 183, representing 66,623 days of care, in the twelve months ended on Nov. 1, 1942, according to the 106th annual report, made public yesterday During the period the foster home department's average population was 376, representing 137,241 days of care.

LONDON, April 21 (U.P.) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden and Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee pledged anew today that Great Britain would fight the Axis, including Japan, to unconditional surrender.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, April 21 (AP) -- First Lieutenant J. E. Swett, Marine Corps pilot, shot down seven Japanese dive-bombers -- a record for this war for one pilot in a single air action -- during the heavy enemy attack on April 7 on the Guadalcanal-Tulagi-Savo Island area.

Formation of a professional advisory council for the Fordham University School of Social Service to direct its curriculum in the light of war and post-war needs in welfare work was announced yesterday by the Rev. Raymond J. Schouten, regent of the school. The nineteen members are headed by Archbishop Francis J. Spellman, director of New York Catholic Charities.

WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP) -- The House added a restriction of its own today in passing the Senate-approved measure to extend for two years the President's authority over the $2,000,000,000 currency stabilization fund. The Senate withdrew the President's power to devalue the dollar and the House adopted an amendment by Representative Reed of Illinois designed to prevent use of the $2,000,000,000 in the $5,000,000,000 international banking fund proposed by Secretary Morgenthau for post-war use.
