WASHINGTON, April 21 -- The War Production Board's beverages and tobacco division was transferred today to the War Food Administration in the Department of Agriculture.

A fresh wave of war bond purchases added $140,000,000 yesterday to the total that has been sold to non-banking investors in the Second Federal Reserve District since the opening of the Second War Loan Drive ten days ago. The total sales in this category now amount to $2,925,000,000, it was announced by Allan Sproul, chairman of the War Finance Committee of this district.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, from her place of retirement in the Hudson River Valley, issued a statement yesterday, distributed by the Chinese News Service, condemning the execution of American fliers by Japan and calling for the latter's speedy defeat.

The first of the two "Parsifal" performances to be given this week of the Easter season took place last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. An immense audience sat fascinated by the subject and by the particular color and character of Wagner's music.

A parody on the daily activities of the Red Cross workroom at the Women's City Club was the feature of a tea given yesterday in appreciation of the work of volunteer members in making surgical bandages at the club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street.
LONDON, April 21 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, April 21 -- Jefferson Caffery, the United States Ambassador, declared today that the Board of Economic Warfare and all other war agencies were working in full cohesion and without friction, doing their utmost to increase efficiency and produce more raw materials for the United States.
NEW DELHI, India, April 21 (AP) -- A communique:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 (AP) -- Joseph E. Grew, who as Ambassador to Japan had a front row seat during General Jimmy Doolittle's raid on Tokyo a year ago, said today that "since learning of the dastardly action of the Japanese Government in executing some of our armed forces who fell into Japanese hands as an incident of warfare, I have been able to think of little else."
The circus seldom fails to stir repercussions in the realm of exhibitions. The blithe contagion this year has spread as usual, if not on a very large scale.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Expressing "serious disagreement" with regulations issued Saturday by Paul V. McNutt in accord with the injunction of President Roosevelt on April 8 to regulate' hiring, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, today requested the manpower chief to replace the recent job-stabilization order with a policy whereby employment stabilization would be governed solely through the operation of joint labor-management stabilization agreements.
An act of heroism comparable to those contained in war communiques was performed yesterday by a Brooklyn policeman.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to provide city funds, estimated at about $120,000 a year, to aid in paying for day nursery care for the children of working mothers. The board acted under State legislation stipulating that the State will pay one-third of such costs, the city one-third and the mothers one-third.

With the statement that the demands of the United Mine Workers for wage increases and readjustments of working conditions, affecting 80,000 hard coal diggers in Pennsylvania, are "impossible of fulfillment," anthracite operators yesterday offered a four-point counter-proposal to the union's twenty-one demands.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- A double by Pete Fox in the fourth inning was converted into a 1-0 victory for the Red Sox today as Tex Hughson and Jess Flores opened the American League season here with a brilliant pitching duel before 4,553 at Shibe Park.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP) -- Take all 2,500 athletes who will compete in the Penn relays tomorrow and Saturday, line them up single file and pick the one who looks the least like a great runner and you will probably hit upon a bespectacled 19-year-old divinity student named Jeffrey Kirk.

WITH THE CHINESE ARMY ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, April 20 (Delayed) -- Excepting the parts of the Burma Road the Chinese destroyed to block a possible Japanese advance, the main artery of travel through Yunnan Province toward the Salween River is in good condition.

General Montgomery would show up badly in an information quiz. Early in the Tunisian campaign General Eisenhower's representative offered the commander of the Eighth Army a souvenir of his own choosing.

Once more the supposed leadership of the House of Representatives has proved sadly inadequate. After a febrile series of day, night and Sunday meetings, after repeated announcements from both sides of herculean efforts at compromise, the Democrats and Republicans of the Ways and Means Committee have emerged without a compromise.
LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- Note circulation, as reported by the Bank of England in its weekly condition statement, increased 4,358,000 to the record total of 947,852,000.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A War Department spokesman said today that America would not sink to the level of the enemy by taking reprisals against Japanese prisoners for the execution of the American fliers, and meanwhile Congress boiled with demands that more attention be given to the war in the Pacific.

LONDON, April 22 -- Armored cars and tanks have moved into Warsaw, where the ghetto populace is resisting deportation of the city's remaining 35,000 Jews. The battle was still raging when the Polish exile government in London received its latest news last night.

UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, April 23 (U.P.) -- Allied medium and attack bombers caused heavy damage yesterday in a raid on enemy-occupied islands and villages in the Nassau Bay area of New Guinea, ten miles south of the Japanese base at Salamaua, and dispatches said American aerial scouts found enemy air activity increasing over a 1,000-mile front from Rabaul and Kavieng to Wewak on the New Guinea coast.

The threat of a stoppage of soft coal mines employing 450,000 men became acute yesterday as the War Labor Board intervened in the deadlocked bituminous negotiations after Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, had certified the dispute to the board.

MEXICO CITY, April 22 -- President Roosevelt, according to Mexican circles with whom this writer talked yesterday while he was aboard President Manuel Avila Camacho's Presidential train, has already extended an invitation to the President of Mexico to visit him in Washington.

Speeding at sixty-five miles an hour in a seven-mile chase, two patrolmen in a radio car fired eleven shots early yesterday into a stolen car being used by two youths on parole, who were making their getaway after robbing tailor shop.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- A Work stoppage, involving about 100 women employes, tied up production in the sensitive drill department of the Bendix Aviation Corporation's plant today and a Federal Labor Conciliator was called in an attempt to settle the dispute.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The War Department made public today the names of 1,126 American civilians interned by Germany, Italy and Japan, in addition to those already listed. These internees were reported to the office of Major Gen. Alien W. Gullion, Provost Marshal General, through the International Red Cross.

NEW DELHI, India, April 22 (AP) -- A small formation of Liberator bombers of the Tenth Air Force attacked Bangkok, Thailand, early yesterday in the third American bombing of the Thai capital, a United States communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Three Canadian monetary experts here to discuss the Treasury post-war currency stabilization, and particularly the United States plan for it, made it clear at a press conference today that they had no intention of committing Canada to any policy in the matter.

Through the Felony Court arraignment yesterday of a girl in her 'teens and a matronly woman on separate charges of compulsory prostitution, it was revealed that the police, for the second time in a month, had uncovered an organized vice traffic with schoolgirls as the prostitutes, which Magistrate Francis X. Giaccone denounced as "shocking."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 22 -- Five persons, including two women, have been put to death in Munich as anti-Nazi plotters and twelve have received prison sentences of six months to twenty years, according to the Berlin correspondent of the Stockholm newspaper Nya Dagligt Allehanda.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22 -- The fact that fewer than 2,500 persons were in the stands did not stop the Newark Bears from launching their International League campaign, sixtieth in the history of the circuit, at Ruppert Stadium today. It rained right up to game time, but Newark officials were happy the contest got under way, because the champion Bears handed Pepper Martin's Rochester Red Wings a 3-2 setback.

Warning that the Anti-Trust Division of the Department of Justice will make every effort to prevent the re-establishment of the cartel system, Assistant Attorney General Tom C. Clark told a special meeting of the American Business Congress at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night that the preservation of free enterprise is the principal aim of the division during the war and the post-war rehabilitation period.

NEWARK, N.J., April 22 -Strikers at the plastics division here of the Celanese Corporation of America, for the second time during the eleven-day dispute, ignored today an order of the National War Labor Board to return to work.

EDGEWATER, N.J., April 22 -Under pressure from four governmental agencies and their own international executive board, members of Local 16, Aluminum Workers of America, voted today to call off a general walk-out that was scheduled to start at 11:30 tonight at the plant here of the Aluminum Cormporation of America.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Prices for farm products and foods advanced slightly in primary markets during the week ended April 17, but other markets were steady and the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of nearly 900 price series remained unchanged at the recent peak level of 103.5 per cent of the 1926 average.

The Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is president, has abandoned the administration of relief for the duration because of a reduced wartime budget, but will lay more stress than ever before upon securing employment for talented young musicians, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (U.P.) -The War Labor Board, charging that the United Mine Workers' District 50 attempts to "coerce" the government into ending its jurisdictional spute at the Celanese Corporation's Newark (N.J.) plant, warned tonight that the case would be referred to President Roosevelt unless the strike is ended immediately.

Sixteen colors for women's gloves have been adopted for the Fall season by the Textile Color Card Association's glove color committee, it was announced yesterday by Margaret Hayden Rorke, managing director. The hues are skyblush, Florida sky, golden grain, California olive, wild grape, Mandarin purple, canal blue, colonial green, flying blue, Algerian sand, eagle gray, Rio coffee, fertile green, festival red, golden tobacco and Concord wine.

James Silvers, the middle-aged former "public relations officer" on race tracks, who recently was convicted in Special Sessions of maintaining a room in a ten-room suite in an apartment at 525 Park Avenue last Jan. 9 for gambling, paid a $250 fine yesterday to avoid going to the workhouse for thirty days.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association adopted a resolution yesterday authorizing the appointment of a committee to protect the rights of newspapers to gather and publish news, to represent the press at Congressional hearings and to protect its newsprint, manpower and other supplies against any official interference that is not really necessary to the war.

A primitive telephone which an ancient Indian ruler in Peru used more than a thousand years ago in his palace has been placed on exhibition here as part of a collection of Peruvian antiquities in the art department of the Official Commercial Agency of the Peruvian Industries, 11 East Forty-eighth Street.

The peculiar behavior of jitterbugs, chiefly but not entirely adolescents, who have swarmed to the Paramount Theatre to sigh and all but swoon over the trumpeting of the band leader Harry James, continued yesterday to the disgust and amazement of police and puzzled adult passersby.

As a nation-wide wave of anger at the revelation that the Japanese had executed some of the American fliers who bombed Tokyo sent war bond sales bounding upward yesterday, the Second Federal Reserve District, consisting of New York State, Northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn., went over the top with total sales of $3,475,000,000 to investors other than the commercial banks.

The City of Chicago Municipal Employes Annuity and Benefit Fund yesterday sold, through competitive bidding, $6,215,000 of bonds from its investment portfolio. The bonds consisted of various issues of the city and of its political subdivisions.

ALBANY, April 22 -- A third challenge of the validity of the State's new legislative reapportionment law was filed today on the eve of arguments in Albany County Supreme Court on an order to show cause why the statute should not be declared unconstitutional.

Unless present plans are altered, Everett Marshall will return to Broadway in late June, probably opening at the Majestic, in a repertory program consisting of "The Student Prince" and "Blossom Time." These perennial revivals have provided the star with an extensive tour this season under the Shubert banner.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 22 -- Hammering three Columbia pitchers for ten hits, Princeton's Eastern Intercollegiate League champions turned back the Lions, 7 to 3, on University Field today. Southpaw John Eide limited the visitors to five hits and shut them out during his eight innings on the mound, the losers rallying to score all their runs off Dick Armstrong in the final frame.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Their voices a little shaky as they commented on the execution of their comrades by the Japanese, two of Major Gen. James H. Doolittle's fliers revealed here today that so faithfully did they carry out their orders to bomb only pre-selected objectives they even passed up such legitimate military targets as an unprotected aircraft carrier and a line of pursuit ships parked on an enemy airport.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- In a joint attack on the War Shipping Administration and the Truman committee, the maritime committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations charged today that the WSA was "unable and unwilling to face the facts of the war shipping crisis" and that the Senate investigating body accepted its "alibis on why the job is not being done,"
EVANSVILLE, Ind., April 22 (AP) -- The death list in the crash of an Army airplane at the Evansville airport late last night was put at ten this afternoon, in a statement by Major F.C. Dickson.

The Right Rev. Henry St. George Tucker, presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church and president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, issued yesterday the following Easter message for 1993:

The guilt of persons arrested by the United States Secret Service for issuing counterfeit ration stamps for gasoline cannot be presumed until it is proved. But the fact that illicit stamps with a face value of 2,500,000 gallons have been seized is abundant proof that this despicable traffic exists.

TRENTON, N.J., April 22 (AP) -The New Jersey Banking Advisory Board, acting under its statutory authority, has issued a regulation designed to prevent State banks and trust companies from overloading with real estate mortgages and real estate acquired through foreclosed mortgages.
Under a leaden sky that would have cast a pall over almost any other community, the Dodgers yesterday opened the National League baseball season at Ebbets Field, and they opened it with a bang.

LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- Ending a twelve-hour lull in the Allied aerial pounding of the Continent, the Royal Air Force attacked railways, shipping and other military targets today in a series of extended raids over France, Belgium and the Netherlands.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Allowing only five hits, Claude Passeau and Eddie Hanyzewski pitched the Cubs to a 4-3 victory over the Pirates today, evening the season's opening series at a game apiece.

George H. Howard, who has been president of the United Corporation since soon after the formation of that super utility holding company in 1929, yesterday suddenly resigned as head of the corporation, explaining that he wished to devote more time to his "personal affairs."

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The American Army of today is the "best we have ever had," said Roane Waring, National Commander of the American Legion, as he reported at Constitution Hall tonight upon a 25,000-mile trip he had just taken through military camps in this country and in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Navy announced today that Army bombers had carried out a large-scale daylight bombing attack on Nauru, an island west of the Gilbert group, inflicting considerable damage and shooting down five to seven Zeros that sought to stop them, with no losses to the American planes.

The number of distressed plants throughout the country does not exceed 2,500, Colonel Robert L. Johnson, chairman of the Smaller War Plants Corporation, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Biltmore, held in conjunction with the opening by the Quartermaster Corps of a new exhibit of military equipment at 521 Fifth Avenue.

The people of New York should read very carefully the recent report of the Dewey Committee on Business Conditions in New York City. The situation is serious, and unless corrected, the unemployment situation after the war will be the most serious this city has ever had to contend with.

With evidence that the State Department of Labor approved the practice of a roentgenologist over objections of the County Medical Society and the Attorney General, Moreland Act Commissioners William F. Bleakley and Herman T. Stichman revealed yesterday that they were investigating the "entire field" of X-ray work in compensation cases to see if the kickback system was general.

The board of directors of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation has approved "in principle" a settlement tentatively agreed on in the $5,000,000 suit by Brewster Aeronautical and a group of minority stockholders against Alfred J. and Ignacio J. Miranda, F. William Zelcer, the Brewster Export Corporation and others, it was disclosed yesterday at a hearing before Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein.

With a flourish that brought victory in the ninth inning, the Yankees inaugurated their 1943 championship campaign at the Stadium yesterday before the smallest opening-day gathering in the forty-year history of the club.

Coat manufacturers should limit acceptance of Fall orders to the volume that they feel certain they will be able to produce, according to the recommendations of a merchandising and marketing program presented yesterday at a meeting of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers at the Hotel Astor by Samuel Klein, executive director.

The forty-four apartment building at 2401 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, assessed for $180,000, has been sold by the Wadebern Apartments, Inc., to 2401 Newkirk Avenue Corporation, the sale being subject to a mortgage of $112,600.

The National Distillers Products Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries reported yesterday for the first three months of 1943, net profit of $2,235,007 after all charges including $5,795,001 Federal income, capital stock and excess profits taxes.
WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Senate acted today to give recognition, by insignia, to officers and members of crews of merchant ships which carry vital cargoes to overseas battle fronts.

More than 70,000 motor-boat enthusiasts in this area seemed destined yesterday to spend a land-locked Summer as the district Office of Price Administration said that local rationing boards had been instructed to grant no gasoline rations for nonoccupational motor boating, except for boats which are part of the Coast Guard Auxiliary.

Squadron Leader John L.H. Eliott of the Royal Canadian Air Force, 26 years old, younger son of Sir Gilbert Eliott, a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, was killed in action on May 8, 1942, on a bomber raid over enemy territory, according to word received here yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia appointed yesterday a committee of sixteen, headed by himself, to study and report on a comprehensive plan of medical and health insurance for persons of moderate income. The committee held an organization meeting in the Mayor's office at City Hall and will meet there again in about three weeks to map out a course of action.

More than 2,000,000 contributors have joined in bringing the current total of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City to $12,557,190, which is within 3 per cent of its objective of $12,920,700, it was announced yesterday by John P. Stevens Jr., vice chairman of the fund.

The present vagaries of the American censorship were strikingly illustrated on our first page yesterday. In column three Donald Nelson announced that airplane production in the country will probably reach 7,000 this month. In column four the Truman committee of the Senate complained of the Government's "hush-hush policy" regarding merchant shipping losses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 22 -- Van Johnson, who was recently injured in an automobile accident and is expected to return to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer within two weeks to complete his role in "A Guy Named Joe," will play the lead in "Meet Me in St. Louis," with Judy Garland.

WINDSOR, Ontario, April 22 (AP) -- A strike closed down Plant No. 2 of the Ford Motor Company of Canada today and conferences between union leaders and company officials continued tonight with no indication of an agreement.

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Jones said today automobile dealers can sell rationed stocks of new automobiles to the government after July 1, despite a decision to postpone regulations calling for mandatory government purchases after that date.
Joe Lordi of the New York A.C. won his second Red Cross squash tournament last night.

JERUSALEM, April 22 (AP) -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York will broadcast to the United States from Jerusalem on Easter Sunday at 9:30 P.M. Palestine time [2:30 P.M. New York time], and will be the principal celebrant at a solemn pontifical high mass at the Basilica of the Holy Sepulchre.

The General Sessions jury of six men and six women that for a week had been listening to testimony in the trial of Norman Smith, 17 years old, in the Washington Heights mugging of Miss Gladys Kaurin, 23, a singer, at 2:30 A.M. last St. Patrick's Day, convicted him yesterday of attempted rape and second-degree felonious assault.

If the tendency of children to leave school at 15 or 16 to take jobs opened up for them by the war is not reversed, it will result after the war "in an era of demagoguery that will destroy our institutions," Dr. Willis A. Sutton, Superintendent of Schools of Atlanta, Ga., warned last night.

The day to be observed as Easter was fixed with reference to the phases of the moon by the great Council of the Christian Churches that met at Nicea (now Isnik, in Asiatic Turkey) in the year 325 A. D. Under the Nicean rule, Easter is celebrated on the first Sunday following the fourteenth day of the new moon that begins on or after the vernal equinox (March 21).

The principal securities and commodity exchanges in the United States will be closed today in observance of Good Friday, as will be the case with the leading exchanges in Canada. Various livestock markets, however, will remain open.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The House took an Easter recess tonight, with pay-as-you-go legislation scheduled as the first order of business when it meets again May 3. The Senate did not recess. The issues when the battle is resumed will be the Doughton, Carlson, Knutson and Forand-Robertson bills.

Captain Eddie Rickenbacker was named chairman of the general committee sponsoring the National A.A.U. outdoor track and field championships at a luncheon tendered him yesterday at Toots Shor's. The games will be held at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, on June 19 and 20, and the proceeds will be donated to the Army Air Forces Aid Society.

With thousands of service men receiving Easter holiday furloughs and many more thousands of civilians either unable or unwilling to heed orders of the Office of Defense Transportation to stay at home during the week-end rush, hotel, amusement and transportation operators predicted yesterday a record volume of business starting this morning and ending Monday night.

The Appellate Division dismissed yesterday, in a three-to-two decision, disbarment proceedings brought by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York against Edmund J. Donegan and Max N. Koven, attorneys who were officials of the former State Title and Mortgage Company.

NEW DELHI, India, April 22 (AP) -- The Defense of India Rule No. 26, under which more than 8,000 All-India Congress leaders, including Mohandas K. Gandhi and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, were imprisoned without trial and have been held since last Sept 8, was declared invalid today in a judgment read in the New Delhi federal court.

CINCINNATI, April 22 -- The Reds claimed their fourth straight extra-inning, one-run victory today -- two in exhibitions and two in championship games -- as Ray Starr took full advantage of the new baseball to blank the world champion Cardinals again, 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, lashed out today against persons who believe the armed forces have reached the saturation point in equipment and that industry can begin to devote itself to increased production of civilian goods.
LONDON, April 22 (AP) -- The midday Russian communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
LONDON, Friday, April 23 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique broadcast by Radio Moscow:

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Department store sales for the week ended April 17 were 15 per cent higher than in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 28 per cent for the week ended April 10 of the corresponding week of 1942.

IT'S a cinch, folks. The Dodgers are in. Except for the minor item of having 153 games still to be played, the pennant was claimed by the Flatbush faithful at Ebbets Field yesterday. The skies may have been gray and threatening, but hope flared brightly in Brooklyn hearts as the Brooks took the measure of the hated Giants in the opener.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The House devoted nearly three war-time hours today to debate on the Maas bill to make the Waves permanent, allow them to go overseas, grant them pensions and raise and increase their commissioned ranks.

A report on the first two and a half years of functioning of the Corlears Hook Medical Association, an experiment in voluntary health insurance among low-income families which began in June, 1940, was released yesterday by the association's office at Gouverneur Hospital, Gouverneur Slip, New York City.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -- Agents of the Federal Food Distribution Administration seized today a carload-shipment of 45,000 pounds of Maine potatoes and turned them over to the Army for soldiers at Fort Dix.

Charles J. Farley, nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, denied emphatically to Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein and a blue-ribbon jury yesterday that he shot and killed Patrolman Nicholas C. Moreno on the night of May 23, 1939.

Reflecting the present Second War Loan Drive, the banking statistics for the week ended on Wednesday, as released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, show some of the widest net changes of any week in many years.

Full details of the famous Doolittle raid over Tokyo, now officially announced from Washington, permit release of a manuscript written by Captain Ted Lawson, pilot of one of the planes in the raid. Random House will publish the book early in July.
CHICAGO, April 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Mrs. Mary Moore Thomson of Glendale, Ohio, mother of four sons and president of Western College for Women, Oxford, Ohio, was chosen the American Mother for 1943 yesterday at a meeting of the American Mothers Committee of the Golden Rule Foundation, 60 East Forty-second Street.
More than 8,000 deer skins have been contributed by New York State hunters to the war effort, according to the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, following various appeals sent out last Fall.

The Mecca Theatre and the adjoining stores occupying the west side of Avenue A from Fourteenth to Fifteenth Street, have been acquired by the Acropolis Holding Corporation, a subsidiary of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, as part of the site for the big post-war housing project which the insurance company will erect on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

The Second Federal Reserve District, of which New York City is the principal component, has gone over the top magnificently in the Second War Loan Drive. Up to noon yesterday war bonds to the value of $3,475,000,000 had been sold in this district to investors other than the commercial banks.
NEW DELHI, India, April 22 (AP) -- A United States communique:

ROANOKE, Va., April 22 -- At this point on the path northward to the Shenandoah Valley, after inspecting the site of the international food conference at Hot Springs and supplementing the efforts of a companion engaged in recruiting an A.W.V.S. land army to help harvest food crops of Virginia, a Washington dispatch strikes the eye and brings too prompt a reminder of the war capital of this country.

Many women actively interested in the work of the Frontier Nursing Service and the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association are planning dinner parties to precede the Blue Hill Troupe's performances of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta "Iolanthe" on Friday and Saturday nights next week at the Heckscher Theatre.
NEW DELHI, April 22 -- The All-India Moslem League will open the most important annual session of its thirty-year history tomorrow.

For the purpose of promoting the wider use of motion pictures in educational programs a group of educators has formed the Educational Film Library Association, Inc., it was announced yesterday at the organization's headquarters at 45 Rockefeller Plaza.

Reflecting the current war-bond drive, record pre-Easter sales and sustained industrial activity, bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday rose to the best weekly volume since the opening week of 1931, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

ARMY HEADQUARTERS IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, April 22 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Millard F. Harmon declared today "we will stick to our plan of taking every opportunity to strike the most vulnerable targets Japan exposes to us."

LONDON, April 22 -- Not all the American soldiers over here came in uniform from the United States. About fifty a month have simply dropped in at the recruiting office in the heart of the British capital and have been sworn in by First Lieutenant Winston K. Pendleton of Atlanta, Ga.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed a decrease of $375,764,000 in holdings of United States Government securities during the week.

In a colorful ceremony a new Victory Chapel was formally opened yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Cross on Forty-second Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. More than 500 persons, including many relatives of men in the armed services, were present.

In a large announcement in THE TIMES today the Standard Oil Company (N.J.) states: "Last Thursday we offered, subject to the approval of our stockholders, to transfer permanently to the United States Government (through the Government's Rubber Reserve Company) patent rights on the Buna-S * * * the tire rubber which forms the basis of the government's synthetic rubber program.

Sir war heroes were guests of honor and did the talking last night at a "Victory Dinner" of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, concluding its convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. John Kieran, columnist of The New York Sun, acting as toastmaster, questioned them about the high spots of their adventures.
NEW DELHI, India, April 22 (AP) -- A British communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 22 -- Major Gen. James H. Doolittle called on the United States today to bomb Japan until the empire crumbles and it begs for mercy, to show that it failed in its aim when it executed some of the fliers who accompanied him on the first raid in history on Tokyo.

ALBANY, April 22 -- Motor fuel tax revenues distributed to localities are only about half the amount disbursed a year ago, Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, announced today. He said that about the same amount of beverage tax money was being distributed as in the first quarter of last year.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A new listing of critical materials and their possible substitutes was issued today by WPB. The list, No. 8 in the series, indicates present and anticipated trends in production by the changed positions of several materials in the new listing.

More than $500,000 of a larger sum, to be announced later, contributed by American labor, will be used to build ten new war relief projects for British workers this year, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement by Matthew Woll, president of the United Nations Relief, A.F. of L., and Irving Abramson, chairman of the National C.I.O. War Relief Committee.

Among the new rentals reported yesterday was an apartment in 19 East Eightieth Street to Alexander Spear, treasurer and director of the Spear Furniture Company. William A. White Sons arranged the lease. Through the same brokers, Sidney G. Smith, actor, took an apartment in 10 Mitchell Place.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 22 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Senator Wheeler contended today the armed forces already contain more men than can be sent abroad for the next two years. He so commented when the Senate postponed action until next week on his proposal to exempt fathers from military induction for the remainder of 1943.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22 -- Robert C. Lally, 18 years old, model student at the Greenwich, Conn., High School until his graduation a year ago, was sentenced here today by County Judge Frank H. Coyne to serve an indeterminate term in Elmira Reformatory for the stabbing of Mrs. Lanphear Buck of Blind Brook Lodge, Rye, on the night of Jan. 8 in a parking lot at the Rye Hotel near her home.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 22 -- Under the leadership of a white-bearded colonel, 250 Greek soldiers, banded together in the first Hellenic Commando, have just completed their first campaign as a unit and are returning eastward from Tunisia for further special training for the liberation of their homeland.

LONDON, April 22 (U.P.) -- American forces in Great Britain will join in blanketing war objectives in Germany with gas if the Germans resort to gas warfare on the Russian front, it was indicated tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A War Department spokesman took occasion today to explain further why information on "Shangri-la" was not disclosed previously. He said it had been desired to keep the Japanese guessing "because a further raid was -- and is -- a decided possibility" and because protection of the crew and the Hornet -- since lost in the Battle of Santa Cruz --was essential.

Price ceilings are to be clamped on sweet potatoes and other white potato substitutes within a matter of days, price executives at the regional office of the Office of Price Administration disclosed yesterday as the prices of these vegetables, which are now exempt from ceilings, continued to soar yesterday in wholesale markets due to the potato shortage.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (U.P.) -Secretary Knox declared tonight that the United Nations could not win complete victory over Germany until the Atlantic U-boat menace was utterly destroyed.

On the Salween Front Brooks Atkinson makes us see the Chinese soldiers as well as if we were looking at them with our own eyes. Their uniforms are faded, patched, thin for the cold weather. If they are not barefoot they wear straw sandals, made by themselves.

Mrs. John T. Pratt, first woman Representative from New York State and for fourteen years New York Republican National Committeewoman, was elected president of the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, yesterday at its annual meeting.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Abbey, the newcomer will be "Reveille With Beverly," a Columbia comedy with music featuring Ann Miller, William Wright, Franklin Pangborn, Dick Purcell and the Duke Ellington, Bob Crosby, Count Basie and Freddie Slack orchestras.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 22 -- A desperate German attempt to forestall the opening of a final Allied offensive in Northern Tunisia was frustrated Tuesday night when veteran infantry and artillery of the British First Army broke an attack launched on an eight-mile front south of Medjez-el-Bab.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Allied planes are destroying "at least 50 per cent" of Axis ships and transport planes attempting to operate between Italy and Tunisia, thus causing a "serious dislocation" of the attempt to supply the beleaguered Axis forces, Robert P. Patterson, Under Secretary of War, stated at a press conference today.

JERSEY CITY, April 22 -- Driving thirteen solid hits, the Buffalo Bisons, led with considerable enthusiasm by Mickey Rocco, spoiled Jersey City's International League baseball opener today. Gathered from the offerings of three Little Giants' hurlers, the hits brought the visitors a 5-to-3 victory.

IN that strange island called Ireland they still sing "The Minstrel Boy" and "The Low-backed Car"; they still dance furious folk dances that are exacting tests of athletic skill and coordination; they still twist English language into lush, poetic, flavorsome music; and they still walk hand-in-hand with sadness, futility and a resigned desperation indistinguishable from the spiritual climate of Chekhov and Turgenev.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22 -The political philosophy of Thomas Jefferson, except for what he called some of its superficialities, was described tonight by Dr. Carl Becker, professor emeritus of history at Cornell University, as being fully acceptable for twentieth century democracy.

An art exhibition and sale will open at the art gallery shop of Friends of Greece, Inc., 52 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Wednesday. A press preview will be held Tuesday. The proceeds will be used to aid children of Greece.
A High Command communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Friday, April 23 -- Soviet troops mowed down hundreds of Germans still attacking their Kuban valley lines above the enemy bridgehead at Novorossiisk in the Caucasus, and the Red Air Force made mass raids on Nazi military formations and other targets, Moscow announced early today.

Unless fresh supplies of cotton from government-owned stocks are made available soon to relieve spinners from their current ceiling "squeeze" civilian textile supplies will continue to grow tighter in the next few months, when a seasonal drop in total production is anticipated, it was declared yesterday by Worth Street suppliers.

Further restrictions on travel this Summer will curtail a certain amount of resort and transportation advertising, but from the overall standpoint these defections will not cut seriously into volume, according to advertising agents. The placing of the bulk of national advertising campaigns on a war effort basis is practically eliminating the seasonal factor in advertising so that losses in some classifications will be offset by gains in others which normally decline in hot-weather months.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Reports from Bermuda indicate that the British and American members of the refugee conference there have accepted the view expressed in the State Department's note last February that refugees should be kept as near as possible to the areas where they now are.

Although the lack of developments in both the price-ceiling issue and the proposed marketing of the Commodity Credit Corporation's stocks of cotton were instrumental in curtailing volume again, the cotton futures market yesterday rose moderately on the strength of continued trade price-fixing for Southern mills.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 22 (AP) -- Trustees of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company today petitioned the United States District Court for permission to pay three back coupons on first and refunding bonds of the system amounting to $14,200,000.

Snap beans here dropped again in price and are 5 cents cheaper than they were last Friday. The Department of Agriculture reports that shipments from Florida are plentiful and soon will be augmented by receipts from North and South Carolina.

The stock market fortified its position yesterday within the range of the highs of early this month and the lows of last week, and traders showed no disposition to abandon their positions despite the closing of major markets today for Good Friday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 22 -Buldging warehouses in California port cities, holding many millions of dollars' worth of goods destined for export, are adding to the worries of those exporters who have not become accustomed to this State's personal property tax.

An eighteen-point program on democracy through which New York City teachers and schools can help develop the American way of life and stress democratic procedures among the city's 1,000,000 school children was presented yesterday by the Committee for the Study of Practical Democracy in Education, headed by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens member of the Board of Education.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Gugino bill, increasing minimum weekly unemployment insurance benefits from $7 to $10 and changing eligibility requirement's, was signed today by Governor Dewey, who said the new law was "an important advance in the increase of security for our people."

LONDON, April 22 -- The Berlin radio, replying to the British statement warning of gas war reprisals, quoted German Foreign Office circles as saying that Germany would stand by a pledge given last year that she would use poison gas only if her enemies used it first.

An eighteen-point program on democracy through which New York City teachers and schools can help develop the American way of life and stress democratic procedures among the city's 1,000,000 school children was presented yesterday by the Committee for the Study of Practical Democracy in Education, headed by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens member of the Board of Education.

ALBANY, April 22 -- The Gugino bill, increasing minimum weekly unemployment insurance benefits from $7 to $10 and changing eligibility requirement's, was signed today by Governor Dewey, who said the new law was "an important advance in the increase of security for our people."

LONDON, April 22 -- The Berlin radio, replying to the British statement warning of gas war reprisals, quoted German Foreign Office circles as saying that Germany would stand by a pledge given last year that she would use poison gas only if her enemies used it first.

Formation of a health panel to assist Office of Price Administration officials in disposing of requests for supplemental food rations that are backed by a physician's certificate was announced yesterday by Russell H. Potter, acting district manager of the Office of Price Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The Office of Price Administration, through an amendment to its regulations, today fixed maximum prices for poultry, at the wholesale level, provided fixed charges which operators may charge for haulage, and reduced from thirteen to six the price classifications into which poultry can be sold.

TRENTON, N.J., April 22 (AP) -Attorney General David T. Wilentz was asked today by Governor Charles Edison for an opinion on whether any action taken by the State Racing Commission would be official so long as it had only two members.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22 -- The Westchester County Recreation Commission maintained its regular program during 1942 and added special events to promote wartime physical fitness, but kept expenditures 12 per cent below total appropriations, the commission said today in an annual report.

A meeting of the junior committee for the tea dance to be given May 11 at Sherry's under the direction of the Royal Standard Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, Inc., was called yesterday at Sherry's by Miss Tricia Hurst, chairman of the committee.
Stockholders of the Johns-Manville Corporation held an informal meeting yesterday in the Hotel Roosevelt and heard Lewis H. Brown, president, explain the operations of the company.
CLEVELAND, April 22 (AP) -- Virgil (Fire) Trucks, young right-hander, handcuffed the Indians today, allowing only four scattered hits while the Tigers punched out a 4-to-0 victory at League Park.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Six different war agencies, the views of which were summarized by the Office of War Information, agreed today that vacations for war workers were considered necessary by the government. But one of them, the Office of Defense Transportation, stressed the fact that the vacations should be spent as near home as possible.
WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP) -- Navy communique 352:

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- The United States Senate voted unanimously today to extend the life of the Guffey Bituminous Coal Act of 1937 only thirty days from April 24, when it was due to expire unless renewed. This action immediately prompted speculation as to whether the hand of John L. Lewis, miners' president, had been strengthened in his contest with the operators.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 22 -- Community canning centers and clubs will have a better chance than individual families of obtaining pessure cookers, for 150,000 of which the Department of Agriculture has allocated materials, Edward Lipman, administrative officer of the New Jersey War Board, reported here today.

CHICAGO, April 22 -- Grain markets showed a firm undertone today on the Board of Trade with trading featured by large exchanging operations in corn futures that put the May at a premium of 1 1/4 cents a bushel over September at one time, the widest difference of the season.
CHICAGO, April 22 (U.P.) -- Baseball Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis today pledged immediate steps toward return of the "rabbit ball" to the major leagues.

Six men, sentenced yesterday in Federal court, Brooklyn, to prison terms in the theft of gasoline ration stamps from the Queens rationing board, were denounced by Judge Grover M. Moscowitz as having committed a "traitorous" act.

MARYKNOLL, N.Y., April 22 -- Maryknoll sisters formerly stationed at Dairen, Manchukuo, now are interned in Shanghai and some others who staffed missions in the Fushun (Manchukuo) area are at their central house in the city of Fushun and are in good health, according to word received at the Motherhouse, here, through the Apostolic Delegation in Washington.

ALBANY, Ore., April 22 (AP) -- Robert E. Lee Folkes, dining car cook, today was convicted of murder in the sleeping-car slaying of Mrs. Martha Virginia James. The jury made no clemency recommendation, making the death penalty mandatory.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- A move has been started here to reconvene the Baruch committee, which mapped out the nation's wartime rubber program, for a study of the current synthetic rubber situation and settle once and for all whether the program should be cut back.

WASHINGTON, April 22 -- Aides of Under-Secretary Patterson said today that in contending that the air offensive of the United Nations was threatened by the priority given to synthetic rubber he had stated these views:

Women owners captured several Jamaica races yesterday, the victories including that of Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's home-bred filly Farmerette, who has started and won twice this year. It's entirely possible that Farmerette is going somewhere in the 3-year-old filly ranks, not only off her juvenile form but also in view of her victory in the Toujours Purse yesterday.
LONDON, April 22 -- Activity in the stock markets here was reduced today because of the approaching Easter holiday, but the general tone was firm.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 22 -- The decision of the International Red Cross as to the handling of the "Katyn affair" was communicated to the national sections of the Red Cross immediately concerned late this afternoon. Its tenor will not be revealed to the general public until a communique is issued late tomorrow.

In THE TIMES editorial of April 18 "Looking for Loopholes" it is suggested that wage increases are not inflationary if they are coupled with increased war production through incentive wage payments. May I differ with this assertion?

April showered her first gift of sunshine in many days on yesterday's planting of lilies at the Prometheus Fountain, Rockefeller Center. Swaying gracefully in the breeze, the thousand white blooms bowed to the praise of countless promenaders.

The Fairfax, a fifteen-story apartment hotel at 116 East Fifty-sixth Street, has been purchased by David H. Knott, the hotel operator, as a personal investment from the Bankers Trust Company, which acquired it under foreclosure of a mortgage of $520,000.

College crews move into action on three waterways today, the second regatta of a season which opened last week with Princeton's victory over Rutgers and Columbia. All three of these crews are back in action today, but Columbia serves as host for the city's first regatta when Navy's veteran eight comes to the Harlem for a dual regatta.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Treatment of shock through local blocking of nerve pathways was described as effective today by Wilbur W. Swingle, professor of biology, in an address before the American Philosophical Society.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The War Production Board issued today an order requiring radio set owners to turn in old parts in exchange for comparable new ones purchased or installed by repair men, except in cases in which return of the part is impracticable.

In your editorial of April 17 you suggest increasing wages and labor income by a soundly designed system of incentive payments or payments based on results, and thus restrain inflation and increase production. Recently it was proved in four aluminum factories that incentive pay increased production by 20 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 -- Track stars from Notre Dame and Michigan shared the spotlight with metropolitan New York athletes today as the forty-ninth annual Penn Relay Carnival opened before 5,000 fans at Franklin Field, with a field of 2,500 representing 400 colleges, schools and service posts.

William D. Frad, 63-year-old card player, was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy to two and a half years' imprisonment for evading payment of $102,660 income taxes during 1936 and 1937. His income for the period, according to the government attorneys, was mainly from gambling and amounted to $256,049, on which he paid only $1,006 in taxes.

I am a young man without any dependents who was physically rejected by the armed forces. Owing to circumstances it proves impossible for me to get any war work. I am in unessential work and feel, like many other fellows my age who have been rejected, that we are not doing enough.

MOSCOW, April 23 -- The Russians are holding their own in the Kuban and all the Germans' attempts to widen their bridgehead and free Novorossiisk from the attention of Russian guns have broken down against a stanch defense.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- A request for "constructive suggestions" from individuals and organizations on how burdensome reports required by the government from business firms can be eliminated or modified has been issued by a group of national trade organizations, the United States Chamber of Commerce said.

AT SEA WITH THE PACIFIC FLEET (Delayed) -- Another link in the chain of fortified island bases the United States is forging in the Pacific, from which some fine day will come the big push toward Tokyo, was set in place yesterday by an occupation force of the Pacific Fleet.

In answer to the demand for current books on American history serving as background for this country's participation in the present war, the Council on Books in Wartime has prepared a list of recommended readings in American history.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The War Shipping Administration is drafting a revised form for its standard ship charter contract in order to effect economies in wartime operation of the merchant marine, WSA officials said today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 23 -- Jerry Thompson, black-haired distance runner from the University of Texas, gambled and triumphed today in winning the two-mile run, which high-lighted the opening of the thirty-fourth annual Drake Relay carnival.

Several hundred merchant tailors of the 6,000 or so throughout the country will have to close their doors this year unless the government restrictions affecting them are eased, Aaron I. Binsky, secretary of the Manhattan Merchant Tailors Association, declared yesterday.

Germany has disclaimed responsibility for the action of the freighter Altkirch of Bremen in firing on the Swedish submarine Draken on April 16, the official German news agency, D.B.N., said in a broadcast recorded here yesterday by The United Press.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- Harry Bridges, West Coast long-shore leader, told a Senate subcommittee today that waterfront production by stevedores on this coast outmatched that anywhere else in the world. His statement was disputed by Paul Eliel, chairman of the Pacific Coast Maritime Industry Board.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 23 -- Post-war threats to the Southern cotton industry, in the form of foreign competition and a 3,000,000-bale surplus of American fiber, can be conquered successfully by using scientific research to solve problems of production and marketing, Dr. Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, declared today at the meeting here of the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 23 -- Warners have announced the purchase of screen rights to "The Conspirators," a novel by Frederic Prokosch, dealing with Allied and Nazi underground activities in Portugal. The picture will be produced by Hal B. Wallis on a large scale and, according to the studio, its cast will include Ann Sheridan, Humphrey Bogart, Paul Henreid, Sydney Greenstreet and Helmuth Dentine.
LONDON, April 23 -- President Roosevelt's announcement that the Japanese had executed several American fliers who participated in last year's raid on Tokyo has created deep indignation here.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 23 -- Under poor scenting conditions, a New Jersey dog gathered what few honors there were today in the opening stake of the thirty-second annual meeting of the Orange County Field Trial Club, held over the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.

ALBANY, April 23 -- The Ehrlich bill, permiting any locality to issue bonds for the payment of salary bonuses to public employes, was vetoed tonight by Governor Dewey, who said the measure might wreck the finances of 12,000 units of local government.

Attorneys' and accountants' fees of $176,661 were awarded yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente out of a judgment for $476,549 filed in favor of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company against the Koppers Company in an accounting suit brought by minority stockholders of the gas company.

LONDON, Saturday, April 24 -- Prime Minister Churchill pledged the British Air Force today to join the United States in bombing Japan until "this cruel and greedy nation" has been stripped of its power "to molest the civilized world."

A board composed of representatives of the Giraud French, the de Gaulle French and the United States Navy will consider the cases of any more French sailors who may want to jump Giraud-controlled ships to join the Fighting French Navy, it became known last night.
Mrs. Lucie de Vienne, in 71 E 77th St., Pease Elliman, agents -- Warren Marks Associates, brokers.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Governor Dewey signed today the Suitor bills increasing statutory fees allowed trustees of testamentary and expressed trusts for the first time in twenty years.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- In a stormy annual meeting today of stockholders of Montgomery Ward Co., in which one small stockholder repeatedly attacked the management's labor policy, Sewell L. Avery, president, predicted that the people eventually would free the nation from what he termed the coercive practices of labor unions.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., April 23 -- After arguments divided on the interpretation of State's rights the case of Barney Jones, Allen Prior and Luther Holden, deputy jailer, accused of violating the Civil Liberties Statute in the lynching of Howard Nash at Laurel last October, went to the jury tonight in Federal Court.

The Associated Press is to be congratulated for bringing before the eyes of the people the most important question of the day, and not only the day but of the limitless future -- namely, Is the United States Senate willing to commit itself on the issue of post-war participation in an international police force to preserve peace?

The Ferargil Gallery will open on Monday an exhibition of oils, water-colors and pastels by James N. Rosenberg. Proceeds from sales will go to the American Red Cross. Monday marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of a similar exhibition of work by the artist-lawyer, held for the benefit of the Red Cross during the First World War.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The crop outlook this year is encouraging and the yield should be good if the weather is favorable, Chester C. Davis, War Food Administrator, said today at his first press conference since assuming office last month.

LONDON, April 23 -- Two hundred Soviet planes battered the East Prussian industrial city of Insterburg last night, carrying Russia's air attacks against important German supply centers to a peak with the Red Air Force's sixth heavy raid of the month over Germany.

PITTSBURGH, April 23 -- Delay in contract negotiations covering the Appalachian bituminous fields was blamed today for a flurry of wildcat strikes at captive coal mines in this area that seriously crippled production.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Charles W. Holman, secretary of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation, today called the Administration's reciprocal trade authority a "powerful document for dictatorship" and described its use as part of "a prologue to the swelling act of a world corporate State."

Today's events: "La Traviata," 2 P.M., and "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci" and "Dance of the Hours," 8, Metropolitan Opera House; Mary Becker, violin, and Hardesty Johnson, tenor, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, assisted by The New York Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Greater New York Chorus, Washington Irving High School, 8:30; "Carmen," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

GENEVA, Switzerland, April 23 -- In an equivocal 100-word communique issued just before noon today the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva accepted "in principle" the demands of the German Red Cross and the Polish Government in London "to participate in the identification of the bodies" of the Polish officers in the forest of Katyn, near Smolensk.

LONDON, April 23 (U.P.) -- Strikes, sabotage and armed defiance of the German occupation forces were reported sweeping through Belgium today as patriots struck against German efforts to conscript workmen for labor in the Reich.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 23 (U.P.) -- Allied pilots who destroyed twenty giant German transports over the Gulf of Tunis described the affair as "more fantastic than an H.G. Wells story."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 23 -- Kitty-hawks and Spitfires of Air Vice Marshal Sir Arthur Coningham's Tactical Air Force scored a spectacular victory over the Gulf of Tunis yesterday when they utterly destroyed a formation of twenty huge six-motored Merseburg 323 transports as they approached Tunisia carrying supplies of gasoline and troop reinforcements to the hard-pressed German forces.

BARRANQUILLA, Colombia, April 23 (AP) -- On the eve of his departure from South America, Vice President Henry A. Wallace laid the first stone of a monument to George Washington here today and declared in a speech that the world will need "men of stable character" to guide it through the difficult post-war period.

American service men, standing guard at far-flung battle stations across the seven seas, are thinking of home at Eastertime, if the deluge of orders from soldiers in foreign service for "flowers by wire" is an indication.

In one of the largest realty transactions of the year in Westchester County, Supreme Court Justice Nolan at White Plains has authorized sale of the former Kings Ridge Golf Club property of 100 acres to Herbert Daniel Stone, New York lawyer of 505 Fifth Avenue, for about $40,000.
MONTPELIER, Vt., April 23 -- Demanding equalization of gasoline rationing throughout the country, the six New England Governors ended today a two-day conference.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 23 -- The Kansas City Star published on its first page today the sentiments of "An Army Wife," identifying herself only as "I. E.," regarding the United Nations food conference at Hot Springs.

Since the beginning of the century the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children has carried on its work of healing in this city. Now for the first time in twenty years it is asking the public to help in establishing an expanded program.

NEW DEHLI, India, April 23 -- Evidence that the sort of atrocities exemplified by the execution of some American airmen who bombed Tokyo is a common practice of the Japanese in all theatres of war was given here today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (U.P.) -- Quarterly ratings of the National Boxing Association, issued today, emphasized that the world lightweight championship is still vacant despite recognition of Beau Jack as titleholder by the New York State Athletic Commission.

With the threat of an imminent mine stoppage affecting 450,000 soft-coal diggers hanging over the country, the stage was set yesterday for the showdown between the national War Labor Board and John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, but the mine chieftain did not announce how he planned to give final battle.

Enthusiastic response to the efforts of the National Association of Insurance Agents to raise a fund for a public relations campaign designed to acquaint the public, Congress and State legislators with the functions of insurance and agents was reported yesterday by the association.

Ten tournaments, spaced between May and October, have been arranged, according to the schedule announced yesterday by the Long Island Golf Association. Of these, five will be benefits events, two of which will be for the Red Cross.
ALBANY, April 23 -- Appropriations totaling $725,000 for plans to extend State parkways were made available today when Governor Dewey signed the Wicks bill.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Four United States airline companies have applied to the Civil Aeronautics Board, the last one only two days ago, to fly international routes which will take them over Canadian territory. Three other major airlines are now flying such routes on contracts for the Army or Navy.

LONDON, Saturday, April 24 (AP) -- German troops, attacking repeatedly in the Northwestern Caucasus, again were hurled back to their original positions, suffering 500 casualties and losing thirty-six planes, Moscow announced early today.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Constitutionality of the first legislative reapportionment law enacted in New York State since 1917 was challenged in Albany County Supreme Court today on the grounds that provision for a fifty-six-member Senate invalidates the statute.
LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- The stock market was quiet in today's holiday trading.

Baseball and racing are here again. The tracks, if Jamaica thus far is any criterion, evidently will have a successful season, and major league baseball probably will fare well too. It is not only upsetting, but revolting to think they will thrive.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The War Labor Board recommended to President Roosevelt today that he intervene in the twelve-day dispute at the Celanese Corporation's Newark (N.J.) plant, after officials of District 50, United Mine Workers, had refused a third request to order strikers back to work.

Good Friday, a normal holiday in the New York Stock Exchange, was transformed yesterday into a good selling day when the men who know how to use the telephone to get buyers for worth-while issues sold $16,156,000 of war bonds to their customers in 1,158 individual sales.

LONDON, Saturday, April 24 (AP) -- Combined blows of the American heavyweight bombers and the R. A. F. "train-buster" air fleet against Adolf Hitler's rail transport are smashing his dwindling supply of locomotives at the rate of 150 a month, the Air Ministry reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Navy communique 353:

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The Senate Truman committee investigating the war program stepped suddenly today into the priorities battle between the War and Navy Departments and William M. Jeffers, rubber director.

The recent announcement concerning baseball made by War Manpower Commissioner Paul V. McNutt probably will not be relished by devoted followers of the national pastime, for although the sport is going to be permitted to live for a while longer, it is going to be choked to death slowly.

There is a lesson to be learned from the latest act of savagery of the Japanese High Command, but it is not what some members of Congress appear to think it is. These members of Congress believe that it is now their duty and their opportunity to change at once the whole strategy of the war.

The shortage of upholstery fabrics, which appears to be getting more serious, is expected by some furniture manufacturers to be even a greater bottleneck than the lack of lumber by next Fall, when production of living room goods would normally be stepped up.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 23 (U.P.) -- Three heroes of last year's historic raid on Tokyo said today that the Japanese, in executing several American fliers captured during the mission, had made the word "Jap" the "vilest expression on the face of the earth."

As General Montgomery's veterans hammer at Rommel's coastal positions north of Enfidaville, British amphibious commands move up to occupy the offshore islands which control the Straits of Sicily. Djerba, a sizable island in the Gulf of Gabes, was seized some weeks ago. Now the Kerkennah Islands off Sfax have been taken without the firing of a shot.

With many anglers expected to be out on the streams this weekend, the Connecticut Board of Fisheries and Game has announced a list of streams that were stocked both prior to and after April 17 to serve as a guide to the residents or non-residents who may be fishing those waters.

NEWARK, N.J., April 23 (AP) -- Long Tom Ananicz, making his International League debut, held Rochester to five hits today while his Newark team-mates made ten to gain their second straight victory. The score was 5 to 1.

The "Easter crisis" developing in Finland is one more sign that the stage is being set for decisive action in the European theatre. The fourth Easter is not like other Easters of the war; in 1940, '41 and '42 the peoples of Europe watched the Spring flower with a sinking of the heart.

The annual Good Friday matinee of Richard Wagner's "Parsifal" was presented yesterday at the Metropolitan Opera House. A capacity audience which had bought up all the tickets long in advance was on hand, augmented by as many standees as the law would allow.

HISTORICAL novels are usually great bores. But there is one person in America who writes them with all the urgency and pace and contemporary directness of a Hemingway. That person is Howard Fast, who wrote about George Washington last year in "The Unvanquished." This year Mr. Fast has applied his remarkable technique to "Citizen Tom Paine."*

Easy and comparatively quick to prepare are the meals suggested by this column for the coming week. Aside from main dishes, the only foods that require baking are one batch each of muffins, biscuits and corn bread; apples, dumplings and a sponge cake.

Indicating one of the greatest and busiest Easter week-ends in recent years, thousands of visitors poured into the city yesterday and last night to cram every available hotel room and theatre seat in Manhattan.

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Competition of war industries for untrained workers is forcing non-essential industry to exert its ingenuity to keep going, and the retail drug store is no exception in this case. A canvass of retail drug stores throughout the country, conducted by the National Association of Retail Druggists, shows that this line of business is having its ups and downs, but mostly downs, in keeping workers on the job.
Allow me for the sake of the clarification of a fundamental issue to comment briefly on the very interesting letter on Collective Security by Dr. Sarah Wambaugh in your issue of April 18.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 23 -- The immediate question before the American and British delegations of the international refugee conference dealt with refugees in what were called the "perimeter States," countries contiguous to Nazi-ruled territory, said Senator Scott Lucas of Illinois and Osbert Peake, British spokesman, at separate press interviews today.

Germany is calling up millions of men for a strategic reserve by mobilizing veterans of World War I, men of around 40 years who have had no training, and boys of the Hitler Youth, the German Trans-ocean Radio announced yesterday. The broadcast was recorded by The United Press.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Secretary Knox said today that the Truman committee was incorrect in its statements that German submarines were sinking 1,000,000 tons of Allied shipping a month, and that the losses exceeded the tonnage of new ships being built "by the United States and Britain."

Transit traffic in the United States, that by omnibus and street car, reached last year a new high record of about 18,000,000,000 passengers, an increase of 4,000,000,000, or 28 per cent over 1941, according to the American Transit Association.

Favorable weather coupled with a spurt in last-minute buying of Easter apparel and accessories swelled retail trade totals here this week. Department store sales were estimated as running around 15 per cent higher than a year ago. Apparel volume was large and in percentage gain probably was as good or better than that of the preceding week when weather conditions were less favorable.

Leo Sowerby's Sonata for Clarinet and Piano and Gail Kubik's Sonatina for Violin and Piano have been chosen for publication this year by the Society for the Publication of American Music, of which Oscar Wagner is president. Mr. Sowerby had won this annual award of the society previously in 1921, 1927 and 1931.

Worshipers by the thousand thronged churches of the city at Good Friday services yesterday. The need for sacrifice as an assurance of victory for the United Nations but with a spirit of good-will toward all mankind was emphasized.

Easter, or "the Feast of the Resurrection," as chronicled in the calendar of ritualistic churches, will be celebrated tomorrow in a world of continuing war. In all cathedrals and churches prayers will be offered that a "just and righteous peace following victory for the United Nations" will be attained before the dawn of Easter 1944.
Captain Alexander T. Baldwin, T.S.A.; Mrs. Baldwin and their daughter, Miss Joan Baldwin of Bedford Hills, are at Mayfair House.

AN almost forgotten athletic hero of another year recently took time out from his duties with the Army Air Force in North Africa to jot a few lines to Asa Bushnell, his one-time boss. Lieutenant Ray Barbuti, a crack football official of recent seasons, was the man at the African side of the correspondence.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- President Roosevelt extended today Secretary Ickes's supervision over the solid fuels industries to give him authority to ration civilian fuel supplies if and when this might become necessary.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- The new pay-as-you-go tax bill of Chairman Doughton of the Ways and Means Committee, behind which the House Democratic leadership appears to have thrown its support, carries a strong implication that an effort will be made in Congress to avert an increase in individual income tax rates in the general tax bill to be drawn later in the year.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Notions counters in the nation's stores will offer their usual varied assortment, but a shortage of some items and a substitution of materials in others will reflect wartime limitations, according to a survey released by the War Production Board today.

This year Easter millinery is fun. There are no dictates that say hats must be large or small; that they must sprout flowers or be starkly plain; that they must be foolish or sensible. If there is one rule that governs them it is that they must be becoming.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The government will come into possession of about 180,000,000 bushels of wheat a week from today unless several hundred thousand farmer-borrowers in the meantime pay off $225,000,000 in loans extended on the grain last year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, April 24 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur's heavy bombers made solo excursions over Japanese Southwest Pacific bases on Good Friday and one of them, encountering a small enemy convoy south of Kavieng, New Ireland, started an 8,000-ton ship on its way to the bottom.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (Science Service) -- Greater safety in aviation, both military and civil, is sought by two inventions on which United States patents have just been granted.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 23 -- George Emlen Roosevelt Jr. was held by the Navy shore patrol today on a technical charge of desertion. A seaman, second class, he was picked up last night at the Bohemian Club and charged with being absent without leave from the Treasure Island section base since 8 A.M. Feb. 16.

MOSCOW, Saturday, April 24 -- Marshal A.M. Vasilevsky, identified by the official Tass News Agency as Chief of the General Staff of the Russian Army, has received Lieut. Gen. Giffard Le Quesne Martel of the British military mission to discuss current war problems, it was announced today.
Easter's advent will be observed tomorrow in the suburbs with many dawn services, both indoor and outdoor, in communities in Westchester, Long Island and Northern New Jersey.

Not often does Congress pass a bill that pleases "everybody." The measure authorizing the War Shipping Board to furnish and issue to merchant seamen insignia denoting their deeds and experience is a bill that Americans will unanimously favor. Anybody who has served in the Merchant Marine since Pearl Harbor is to be entitled to an emblem denoting that fact.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- United States forces have occupied Funafuti, the largest island of the strategically located Ellice group, the Navy Department revealed today in announcing that the Japanese have bombed our new Southern Pacific base.

LONDON, April 23 -- More than 400 British and Dominions' men and women, the majority of the contingent being fighting men so badly wounded in the Middle East that they will never again see front line service, arrived at a West Coast port today on the Red Cross ship Newfoundland from Lisbon after a voyage from Italy, where they had been prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Administration forces in Congress prepared today to wage a determined fight to obtain at least a two-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act without yielding to amendments which might cause serious repercussions abroad during and after the war.

Japan threatened yesterday to punish severely American prisoners in her entire operations area, including Manchukuo. At the same time Tomokazu Hori, government spokesman, said Americans would not be denied treatment as prisoners of war "merely for participating in air raids."

JERUSALEM, April 23 -- Kneeling and praying at each Station of the Cross, Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York led hundreds of American Catholics of the armed forces and thousands of representatives of other nationalities along the Calvary route of Via Dolorosa this morning.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 23 -- Derbyville had its first look at Count Fleet in action today -- and climbed right on the bandwagon.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Relations between the United States and Finland, which have been gradually becoming more strained, have taken a turn for the worse through the reduction, on orders of the State Department, of the American Legation staff in Helsinki to a single diplomatic official and a small clerical force.

Violations of L-135, which forbids the use of steel springs in new furniture, were inevitable as a result of the "unreasonableness" of that order, Martin J. Bernholz, chairman of the Upholstered Furniture Industry Joint Conference, declared here yesterday.

The Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada, in its annual statement covering operations in 1942, disclosed yesterday an increase in total admitted assets at the year-end to $1,044,389,675 from $992,761,140 on Dec. 31, 1941.
BOSTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

The German people were told of the Japanese execution of the American fliers who were prisoners of war in Tokyo in stories appearing under the following "canned" headline, approved by the Nazi agency, D.N.B. for use in German papers, according to a report yesterday to the Office of War Information:

CHICAGO, April 23 -- Decentralization of the nine Army Service Commands in the United States will be ordered by the War Department when success of an experiment started in the Sixth Service Command here last Monday is apparent, Major Gen. Henry S. Aurand said today.

Commenting on the statement of Harry S. Knight, secretary of the board of governors of the American Bar Association, that his application for membership had been "delayed," Francis E. Rivers, Negro assistant district attorney of New York, declared yesterday that "the officers of the association, in stating that my application has not yet been rejected, are kidding no one but themselves."

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- Clifford J. Durr, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, refused today to answer questions about his personal financial affairs for a House committee, investigating the FCC.
