A demand for over 1,000 Chinese farm workers, mostly from the up-State dairy and poultry farms, particularly the regions around Batavia, has been made within the past week, according to the regional office of the United States Employment Service, at 11 West 42d Street.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, April 24 (AP) -- The noon communique:

NEWARK, N.J., April 23 -- The War Department's Office of Dependency Benefits here is distributing an average of $2,000,000,000 yearly in family allowances and allotments to soldiers' dependents, making it the government's biggest disbursing agency with the exception of the Lend-Lease Administration.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Captain Joe Foss of Sioux Falls, S.D., a farm boy who joined the Marines and is now ranking American fighter plane ace, remarked here today that he would like to get to Tokyo for a "short talk" with the executioners of the captured American fliers.

Back from Hollywood yesterday, Michael Todd disclosed the details of an unusual deal made with Jules Stein, president and owner of Music Corporation, who has been trying to purchase the screen rights to "Star and Garter." Mr. Todd reported that he had leased the screen rights of his Broadway revue to Mr. Stein for the sum of $175,000 and that after three years they will revert to him.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 23 (AP) -- Most of the United States Legation staff in Helsinki left the Finnish capital by plane for Stockholm suddenly today in what was seen by observers here as the beginning of a "war of nerves" to force the Finns to abandon the war on the side of the Axis.

LONDON, April 23 (U.P.) -- Germany is still taking the lion's share of European food supplies, while her Italian allies are getting little more to eat than the people of the occupied countries, and in some instancees, less, the British Ministry of Economic Warfare reported today.

No sooner did Secretary Perkins certify the soft-coal mine dispute to the War Labor Board than more than 2,000 miners walked out in the Pittsburgh district. Union officials, in accordance with the fiction fashionable since the no-strike pledge was given, regretted their inability to "restrain" the men.

JERUSALEM, April 23 (U.P.) -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman will celebrate Pontifical High Mass at the Church of the Holy Sepulcher Sunday. He will broadcast a three-minute talk to the United States Sunday night [2:30 P.M. New York time] and will say mass at Bethlehem on Easter Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23 (AP) -- With Russ Christopher and Luman Harris combining to hurl shut-out ball, the Athletics chalked up their first victory of the season by beating the Red Sox, 5 to 0, in the only game played in the major leagues today.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) -- The Navy Department said today it had authorized its personnel to wear clasps on their uniforms to indicate participation in the major campaigns of the war, and bronze stars to indicate action in the principal engagements.

The Diamond Alkali Company, in its annual statement for 1942, made public yesterday, reported a net profit of $3,787,518 after all charges including $2,174,156 income taxes and $1,807,227 excess profits tax. The profit is equivalent to $3.57 a share on the 1,062,434 shares of stock outstanding and compares with $4,599,177, or $4.33 a share earned in 1941 after deducting $2,085,013 income taxes and $1,508,316 excess profits taxes.
The Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau will hold a round table conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania on May 5.

ALBANY, April 23 -- Completing action on the last of 842 thirty-day bills, Governor Dewey signed tonight a bill permitting him to appoint a layman instead of a physician and qualified psychiatrist as State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene.
A High Command communique broadcast from Berlin and recorded here by The Associated Press:

Except for the offering of a small issue of municipal bonds to the public, the market here for new investments was dormant this week. The single flotation, one of $250,000, was in contrast to an absence of offerings in the preceding week.

ATLANTA, April 23 -- The regional Office of Price Administration placed today ceiling prices, effective Monday, on all meals and food items, including wines and other alcoholic beverages, sold in eating and drinking places in the southeastern States, North and South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Mississippi, Tennessee, Virginia and Alabama.

WASHINGTON, April 23 -- Representatives from the National Retail Dry Goods Association and other trade groups conferred here today with executives of the WPB's Office of Civilian Supply, to discuss having certain types of workers in department stores classified as "essential" workers within the meaning of regulations set up by the War Manpower Commission.

All the "baloney" about "balata," which has been agitating players and officials of the major leagues since the season opened, now may be tossed into the discard. The leagues are to get a new ball, one that will approximate or exceed the jackrabbit qualities of the 1942 pellet -- but not before two more weeks.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 23 (AP) -- A communique:

NEWARK, N.J., April 23 -- "No comment" was the reply of Howard Gill, president of the Celanese U.M.W. local, when informed this evening of a Washington dispatch saying that if troops were sent to the plant it would be to break up the picket line, not to take over its operation, as the government had no quarrel with the company.

TRENTON, April 23 -- Nineteen persons were injured in varying degrees, two motor trucks and thirteen automobiles were damaged and hundreds of war-plant workers were delayed this morning when dense fog on a low stretch of a State highway near Bordentown, N.J., about seven miles from here, caused a series of collisions in quick succession.

I read with interest in THE TIMES last Sunday that United States Senator W. Warren Barbour of New Jersey is trying to stir up a world heavyweight championship boxing bout between Joe Louis and Billy Conn.

WITH THE CHINESE ARMY ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, April 21 (Delayed) -- At the entrance to the compound a gay sign in Chinese lettering read "The people of Taiping welcome the American Red Cross and our own charitable enterprises" for Dr. Wesley May (Johns Hopkins Medical, 1933) and his mobile medical unit had crossed the Western Yunnan rice fields on horseback.
A High Command communique broadcast from Rome and recorded here by The Associated Press:

It cannot really be that a person's own friends are so much better citizens than the national average, but it certainly would seem so by comparison with the headlines. The headlines, for example, report an outbreak of unessential driving when the ban on pleasure driving was lifted and people were put on their honor.
LONDON, April 23 (AP) -- The Soviet midday communique as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet radio monitor here:

The regional office of Price Administration Enforcement Division announced yesterday that it had begun its fight on black markets in the poultry trade at the source with indictments against three poultry growers in Wilmington, Del.

ALGIERS, April 23 (U.P.) -- Plans for the early release of virtually all political prisoners interned in French Morocco and Algeria were disclosed today with the announcement that about 700 Spaniards had obtained visas for Mexico.

Thirteen, including Apache, Riverland, Marriage, Devil Diver and Mioland, are entered in the $10,000 added Excelsior Handicap today at Jamaica, where the largest attendance of the meeting is expected if the weather continues favorable.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The London Base Command's basketball team won the European theatre championship, defeating the Divisional Grays, 52 to 43, in the final game of a tournament in London's Royal Albert Hall, the War Department announced tonight.

Three runs in the sixth inning gave C.C.N.Y. a 6-3 victory over Brooklyn College in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game before a sparse crowd at Lewisohn Stadium yesterday. The runs broke a 3-3 tie that Brooklyn had brought about in the fifth.

THE present reviewer cannot recall any other study of the England of our day that will compare for intimate knowledge and sound thinking with Professor Brogan's brilliant survey. The usual apologia for the English people sets out to prove that the English are really much better than they look; as when we learn that English arrogance is really shyness, or the thing that looks like English stupidity is English reserve.

IT seems curious that barristers who write of murder, and other men of letters whose works deal with killings, so often -- as in this case -- apply to the most dunderheaded homicides such misleading titles as "The Art of Murder."

WITH THE CHINESE ARMY ON THE SALWEEN FRONT, April 22 (Delayed) -- While plodding slowly toward the apparently receding Salween River the two other correspondents and the writer who have been touring this area found ourselves delayed for five days in a small village in Western Yunnan.

LONDON, April 24 -- A new chapter in the war was opened this week as the last phase of the Tunisian campaign began. This final chapter in Tunis -- which may be ended quickly or may be prolonged for several months -- also ushers in a new year of war in which the Germans will undoubtedly mount another, perhaps their final, major offensive. Another March, 1918, is at hand.

Medicine has made extraordinary progress in the last fifty years, but that progress still shows gaps. The diagnosis and treatment of disease have been highly developed, but the physician tom often stops with medicines. Cripples, the tuberculous, the sufferers from heart trouble and arteriosclerosis can be aided only up to a certain point by drugs.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 24 -- Cornell and Pennsylvania split an Eastern Intercollegiate League double-header today. The Ithacans won the first game, 3 -- 1, behind the four-hit pitching of Don Clay, while the Quakers captured the nightcap, 5 -- 1, as Bernard Kucyznyski allowed only three safeties.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 24 -- Yale overcame the University of Connecticut, 13 -- 2, on a windswept field today. The twenty bases on balls generously contributed by Antonez, Andersen and Durette figured in most of the Yale scoring. Two wild pitches and two passed balls also aided the Elis.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 24 (AP) -- A communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 -- As President Roosevelt conferred with President Avila Camacho of Mexico this week, it appeared as if efforts would be made to bring as many as 50,000 Mexican nationals into Far Western States, chiefly California, to help meet farm production quotas this year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 24 -- The whole Allied line -- the Americans on the left, tanks and infantry of the British First Army in the center and the British Eighth Army on the right -- smashed forward yesterday to open a general Allied offensive against the Axis army penned into the narrowing strip of plains and knobby hills in Northern Tunisia.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Although he received no semblance of formidable opposition and won with the greatest of ease, Greg Rice ran speedily enough around the breeze-swept Franklin Field track today to register the lone record-breaking achievement of the forty-ninth annual Penn Relays.

PLANS have been completed for the authors' tea and auction to be held in aid of the United Yugoslav Relief Fund, sponsored by the American Friends of Yugoslavia, Inc., on Thursday afternoon at the national headquarters of the organization, 11 West Fifty-seventh Street.

BALTIMORE, April 24 (AP) -- Unchallenged, a speedy son of Challenger II, from the stables of Mrs. Sidney Zell, won his third victory in eight starts this year when he captured the $2,460 Baltimore Spring Handicap before a crowd of 15,561 at Pimlico today.

IN our first picture of Prince (then Count) Hermann Pueckler-Muskau in "Grand Seigneur," we find that "his cold features, more regular than a man always desires, spoke of pride, complacent self-consciousness, and contempt for the mass of humanity" and in one of the last glimpses we observe that "in his blue silk caftan and wide red Turkish trousers, his long white beard framing his still youthful cheeks, he resembled the picture of a Mohammedan prophet."

MIAMI, Fla., April 24 (AP) -- Sunburned and genial, Vice President Wallace returned from a tour of seven Latin-American countries today with word that he found some fear there that the "Good Neighbor" policy would not continue after the war.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration and the War Food Administration acted today to keep the price of 15/16-inch middling cotton from rising above 21.38 cents a pound.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 24 -- Squarely upon the highroad into Turkish Thrace, just east of the Bulgarian frontier, stands an arresting signboard flanked by tough Turkish soldiers bearing bayoneted rifles. In bold black letters a foot high, the sign warns all comers from the west: "Stop."

The Treasury Department has been approving with few changes the majority of salary increase requests which have come before it in the last six months and only a slight tightening of restrictions is expected to follow issuance of new regulations under the Presidential "hold-the-line order" of April 8, according to opinions expressed by business men last week.

Grabbing a length's lead with a quick racing start and hanging on to all but ten feet of it over the mile and three-quarters course on the Harlem River yesterday, Columbia's varsity eight-oared crew gave the new rowing season its first upset with a defeat of Navy's eight.

Uncle Sam's "answer man" -- who is a woman eleven times out of thirteen -- moved yesterday into the Chanin Building, prepared to answer mail, telephone and personal visit questions from the public about training for essential industry, location of neighborhood rationing boards, status of bill before Congress and other matter pertaining to the Federal Government.

Maintaining its unbroken record of continuity, begun in 1875, the Kentucky Derby will be run next Saturday at Churchill Downs with reduced attendance and betting, but with the value still $75,000 added and with the enthusiasm at the fever pitch which has marked so many renewals of the Blue Glass classic.

Racing reached new heights yesterday at Jamaica when 34,183 persons rolled up a betting total of $2,162,046, smashing the track's previous high by hundreds of thousands, and giving the course its first two-million-dollar public pool.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 24 (AP) -- William M. Jeffers, the rubber director, said today that other government officials could well copy his methods of getting a job done instead of "sitting around desks and issuing orders and grousing."

The wholesale markets experienced their typical pre-Easter lull last week, with mails light and the bulk of orders for Fall merchandise, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co.

If we are determined to mobilize the school teachers for the task of preventing another world war by re-educating men's minds we may do so. But we can use the school teachers and the school supervisors much more effectively than by setting out to educate the Germans away from the habit of being Germans.

HATTIEBURG, Miss., April 24 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury freed three Jones County citizens here today of civil liberties charges in connection with the lynching of a Mississippi Negro, thus ending the first Federal action taken against white men in a Southern lynching case in forty years.

OF the countless tributes to Jefferson celebrating the 200th anniversary of his birth, one of the most significant is the current display at the William L. Clements Library in Ann Arbor, Mich. Its contents are lucidly and entertainingly described in a handsome illustrated booklet, "Thomas Jefferson, 1743-1943.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Acting in accordance with President Roosevelt's hold-the-line order, the Office of Price Administration today reduced by one to two cents a pound the new retail ceiling prices for beef and lamb which had been scheduled to take effect on April 15 and postponed when the President's order was issued.

FROM private collections, museums, galleries of historical portraits and exclusive clubs, paintings categorized under a heading of "Portraits of Yesterday and Today" will comprise a loan exhibition valued roughly at half a million dollars, which will open with an invitation preview the night of May 4 at the Hotel Gotham branch of the Grand Central Art Galleries and continue to May 16, as a means to raise funds for the American Red Cross.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., April 24 -- Beginning this Summer, Mount Holyoke College will reserve a number of places in its enrollment for students who wish to combine college study with work in a Holyoke war industry. Under the plan, undergraduates who live at the college work three days a week in industry and devote three days to college classes and study.

Disregard by the OPA of established trade practices in current and prospective price regulations threatens the distribution structure and will eventually harm seriously many small and large retailers, without producing any benefit to the consumer, Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R.H. Macy Co., Inc., said in an interview at the week-end.

I NOW know what Mr. Churchill means by the "trustful Dutch." I spent more than three weeks with them on one of their ships which was by no means large even when it was built forty-five years ago. It had a dent in the bow from a recent collision and it creaked in every seam.

For a few fleeting minutes yesterday at Ebbets Field the Phillies and their new owner, Bill Cox, who watched them from a box behind the visitors' dugout, had delusions of grandeur. That was in the third inning, when four hits off Bobo Newsom and a Brooklyn error netted them three runs and a 3-1 lead.

IF a biography of the city of Washington is, as Mr. Stevens believes, a Cinderella story, then its early architects are the heroes of it. These men were not Americans and all had their ideas of grandeur, borrowed from their native lands, for the swamp on the Potomac. L'Enfant was the enfant terrible of the lot.
PRINCETON, N.J., April 24 -- Ten men left on the bases told much of the story of Princeton's defeat by the Ellis Island Coast Guard nine today. The visitors won by 6 to 3.

LONDON, April 24 -- The news that American women doctors will receive commissions in the United States Army was welcomed by women members of the Royal Army Medical Corps and others with the Royal Air Force and the Women's Royal Naval Service, who have served with British troops and the women's auxiliaries here and abroad since the war began.

SINCE May Day comes within the compass of this week, it is not unnatural to find the immediate temper of the times turning toward folk matters, even though they have in some respects a more practical cast than they used to have, on account of the war.

AMONG the delights of early Spring are the first robin and the first violet; nor does the violet lose any of its charm if its fragrant blossoms are found not in woodland or meadow but in one's own garden.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has finally won his long fight to raze the old Aquarium building as part of the reconstruction of Battery Park, it appeared yesterday with his announcement that the State Court of Appeals had denied an injunction against him.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The early development of radar, the radio detecting and ranging device which tells of the approach of enemy aircraft and ships and determines the ranges, was described by the War and Navy Departments jointly today for the information of the general public.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24 -- Members of the United Mine Workers, on strike at the local plant of the Celanese Corporation of America, capitulated this evening to an order from President Roosevelt directing them to cease picketing and return to their jobs at once.

THE manager of one of the Tennessee Valley's huge new aluminum plants paused as he was escorting a visitor through the rolling mill. The great building was shuddering with the impact of metal on metal as aluminum slabs weighing 3,200 pounds were grabbed by the rollers, on their way to become wings for fighting planes.

THERE are still very silly, very pretty girls in England, apparently, and Nan Grey might easily he put at the top of the list. The story of her marriage -- honeymoon omitted -- to a man nearly twice her age, her flirting and generally foolish gayety and her eventual honeymoon, beginning on the last page, is like Nan herself, silly but pretty.

LONDON, April 24 -- Berlin and Rome, through their controlled newspapers, were still hailing with loud approval the Japanese action in executing some of the United States fliers who raided Tokyo a year ago, according to reports reaching London.

The publication of a book, the full title of which was "Hui-lan Koo (Mrs. Wellington Koo), An Autobiography," was yesterday canceled by Dial Press after thousands of copies had been distributed to book stores and 400 reviewers throughout the United States.

ERSKINE CALDWELL has come back from the steppes at last. He returns with a heart-warming book about the South he understands so completely, a book in which the Caldwell trademarks of dry rot, degeneracy and despair are conspicuous by their absence. His admirers may rejoice now that his stint as a Russian correspondent has ended.

IN moments of crisis, a nation rediscovers its past. The dusty record of yesterday's failures and triumphs offers solace for today's defeats and hope for tomorrow's victories. Viewed in the light of the past, the grim present is seen, in its true proportions, as a stepping-stone to the future.
The Italian Saturday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

VILLANOVA, Pa., April 24 -- Rallying in the fourth and fifth innings, Villanova defeated Manhattan today, 7 -- 2. The Wildcats drove Pitcher Warren Schlickenrieder out of the box in the fifth, Jerry Girard going to his rescue.

The gigantic war program which last year sent production skyrocketing to unprecedented levels failed to increase the corporate net income of industrial companies engaged principally in manufacturing. Reflecting the heavier taxes land higher operating costs, 817 companies in this review reported for 1942 a total net income of $2,244,143,720, a decline of 15 per cent from the $2,624,948,364 figure of the previous year.
I read with interest and approval the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 14 of the excellent letter of E.D. Williams.

THE gist of this book is that America is a democracy with reservations, and that the American tradition with respect to colored minorities needs to be reconsidered in the light of our war for democracy and of the peace we hope to make.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- While the Nazi U-boat fleet remains one of the gravest threats to the Allies, there is a glimmer of encouragement in the significant fact that the 500-mile "gap" in mid-Atlantic, athwart the main shipping routes, now is the greatest danger zone.

A broad program of cooperation with business schools, designed to raise teaching standards to a level which will meet the specifications of employers, is being mapped by the New York chapter of the National Office Management Association, it was learned last week.

ALGIERS, April 24 -- The union of General Henri Honore Giraud's North African regime and General Charles de Gaulle's Fighting French is no nearer than it was a month ago, despite the negotiations through General Georges Catroux and the spate of plans presented by both groups.

SECOND of three shows seeking to establish new valuations of their subjects, an exhibition of paintings by Theodore Robinson has opened at the Macbeth Gallery. The range of the late Ernest Lawson's work has been revealed in the current show at the Babcock Gallery, and tomorrow the Milch Gallery will open an exhibition of work by the late Childe Hassam.

Last year the shipbuilders of this country produced seven and one- half times the merchant tonnage built in 1941, H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, told the annual meeting of the council last week. This was the first meeting of the group under their new name, which was changed from the National Council of American Shipbuilders by a vote of the members.
CLEVELAND, April 24 (AP) -- The Indians staged a three-run rally in the ninth inning today for a 3-to-2 triumph over the Tigers.

POPEYE the Sailor and jokes about little boys who won't eat their spinach have made America spinach conscious. And a lot of us have come to agree with the little boys that spinach just does not appeal to our appetite. For if you don't like spinach you just don't like spinach.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Motorists whose gasoline ration cards permit them to drive over 240 miles a month will become eligible for the best grade of tires May 1.

New orders booked by furniture manufacturers in March were 17 per cent lower than in February and 21 per cent below March, 1942, it was reported yesterday by Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants. However, the report pointed out that the bookings did not reflect the actual current demand for furniture, but only the extent to which manufacturers were willing to commit themselves on future shipping schedules.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Ways and Means Committee today reported a new pay-as-you-go tax bill which the majority leader, Representative McCormack, invited the Republicans to support as "a fair and practical solution of the problem."

FALSECARDING in bridge is, perhaps, as much of an art as several bridge writers have asserted. To a far greater degree, however, it is a science. The inspired falsecard, done on the spur of the moment in a totally new situation, is so rare as to be almost nonexistent.

The $2,000,000,000 United States Stabilization Fund, set up under the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 from part of the profit realized by the government when the dollar was devalued, apparently will be extended by Congress for another two years from June 30.

New and important French books continue to come out -- in Paris! A dramatic record of some 500 of these, published in 1940, 1941, 1942, has just appeared in New York in the April issue of the Romanic Review (Columbia University Press). The information has been gathered and presented by Professor Henri Peyre of Yale.
CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

ALLIED HEADQUATERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 24 (U.P.) -- A Royal Air Force plane patrolling near Naples, presumably yesterday, was disclosed today to have found an anchored Cant-501 flying boat and, roaring in to the attack, left the ship listing, with its crew struggling in the water.

AS a good hair-raising thriller "Experiment Perilous" is far above the average for its literary, psychological, well cushioned background. The theme is fear, covert and only fleetingly revealed, but ever present in throbbing undertones.

A NOVEL several degrees better than the average run of light fiction, Edith Austin Holton's new story presents an interesting and lifelike picture of Cape Cod as it was a little less than a hundred years ago. Those were the days of flounces and hoopskirts and carryalls, when girls' "soft cheeks" were frequently "mantled with blushes" and they were old maids -- in other words, family drudges -- if at 25 they were still unmarried.

When the United Nations troops landed in North Africa last November they found that "the Axis had stripped the land of its resources and left the people hungry and ragged." The quoted words are from the current report of Lend-Lease Administrator Edward R. Stettinius Jr.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, April 24 -- A resolution calling for the appointment of a committee of teachers of American history to study and analyze the current controversy concerning the teaching of that subject in the nation's schools was adopted unanimously here yesterday by delegates to the thirty-sixth annual convention of the Mississippi Valley Historical Association.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The American Philosophical Society awarded tonight its Franklin Medal to Carl Van Doren, author, who was named historian of the society at the close of the annual three-day meeting.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 24 -- The Naval Academy baseball team registered a 12-to-6 victory over the Columbia nine today behind the hurling of Jeff Davis. The Navy southpaw struck out ten and allowed only six hits. He was relieved by Paul Burdette in the eighth.
The Chinese Saturday communique, as broadcast from Chungking and recorded by the Federal Communications Commission:

DESPITE the inconveniences of war, the hikers are out following their pedestrian avocation. Many of the young men who used to walk around the city are now covering tropical or desert terrain, and shoe rationing offers a good excuse for those too lazy to get out of bed before noon.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- Battling against a strong head wind and rough water, Princeton's varsity crew won its second straight race of the season today by beating Pennsylvania and Rutgers in the opening of the Red and Blue's sixty-ninth rowing campaign on the Schuylkill.

Sophomore Sandy Silverstein was the most active man on Fordham Field yesterday as the undefeated N. Y. U. baseball team, aiming squarely at the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference title, made it four straight for the campaign and three in the league.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Army and the Navy, backed by the United States Public Health Service, have been fighting an unsung war against an enemy which could defeat our troops without firing a single shot and could use our own airplanes for a successful invasion of our shores.

THE importance of the Aleutian Islands, lying at the northerly apex of what has been called the strategic triangle of the Pacific -- Panama Canal to Hawaii to Attu Island -- is becoming more and more clearly recognized. After a long "holding" period, recent communiques indicate that we are at last making serious preparations to drive the Japanese out of those islands.

Commander Bennett M. Dodson, U.S.N.R., district cadet instructor of the United States Merchant Marine Cadet Corps in New York, left last week to take up his new duties as superintendent of the Merchant Marine Cadet Basic School at Pass Christian, Miss., it was announced yesterday by the War Shipping Administration.

Since his inauguration on March 3, 1933, President Franklin D. Roosevelt has traveled 252,336 miles. His trips have ranged from leisurely week-ends on the Potomac to a dramatic airplane flight to the North African theatre of war. They have taken him back and forth across the country and into eleven foreign lands.

The Joint Distribution Committee, one of the participating groups in the United Jewish Appeal for distressed refugees, announced yesterday through Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, chairman of the European executive council of the committee, an appropriation of $200,000 to guarantee the maintenance for one year of 1,000 homeless children who would be sent to Switzerland from France if such a rescue program materializes.

MANCHESTER, Vt. -- While the streets of Manchester, Manchester Depot and Manchester Center are heavy with mud, just five miles east of here skiers are disporting on Snow Valley's East Mountain for a record season of sport to the surprise of old-timers, who have never seen such an extended Winter.

CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The Chicago Tribune suggested tonight that England, Canada, Australia and some other countries could join the United States as new States if the nations concerned wanted a "closer association" and took certain steps toward an enlarged union.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCE, in China, April 17 (Delayed) (AP) -- Eight of the American fliers who bombed Tokyo and who are now assigned to the China theatre said today that Major Gen. James H. Doolittle had led the flight across the Japanese coastline barely thirty feet above land.
TURN ABOUT FURNITURE -- A line of furniture as sturdy and versatile as wartime conditions demand has been created by designer Norman Bel Geddes for the nomadic homes of contemporary Americans.

WOMEN who have long taken an active interest in the work of Stony Wold Sanatorium are completing plans for the annual Tip Top Ball to be held next Saturday night in the Garden and Embassy Rooms of the Ambassador in aid of Stony Wold.

WHEN the St. Regis Roof is opened with a dinner dance May 4 for its late Spring and Summer season the fete will represent traditional benefit for the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is president.

FOUR MILLION books have been collected in the 1943 Victory Book Campaign since the drive opened on Jan. 5, Paul B. Badger, chairman of the campaign, has announced. Mr. Badger says the quality of the books collected this year is so much better than last year's that the 1943 net total will probably surpass that of 1942.

THE moving qualities of Bruno Walter's direction of the uncut version of the St. Matthew Passion are now a matter of record. The mighty music that is this enormous score of a Leipzig "Director Musices" is an incontestably overpowering experience.

Kenney, air commander in the Southwest Pacific, pinned air medals on the crew that had fired an 8,000-ton Japanese cargo vessel and left it in sinking condition only a few hours before.

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 24 -- Army won a hard-fought game today from Lafayette's nine, 3 to 1. Hiller hurled well for Lafayette, fielding lapses by his team-mates aiding the cadets.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 -- Hal Price Headley's Anticlimax celebrated the opening of Churchill Downs Spring meeting today by leading from end to end to take the sixty-ninth running of the Clark Handicap, before a crowd estimated at 15,000.

At the present time industrial users have a three to six weeks' supply of it on hand.

TWO annual folk festivals join the more sophisticated offerings of the week to usher in a busy May. Tonight the Ballet Theatre returns to the Metropolitan Opera House to begin its extended Spring season with Stravinsky's "Apollo," Balanchine's first ballet in this company's repertoire, as the novelty of the occasion.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24 (AP) -- Blasting three pitchers for thirteen safeties, including two home runs by First Baseman Walt Allston, Rochester scored its first victory of the new season today, defeating Newark, 6 -- 1, in the finale of a three-game series.

MOSCOW, April 24 (AP) -- German troops have given up their desperate counter-attacks in the Kuban region of the Caucasus, front dispatches said today, ending, for the time being at least, what had been expected to develop into a large-scale offensive to force the Russians back and enlarge the North Caucasus bridgehead.

NEW DELHI, India, April 24 (U.P.) -- American Liberator bombers, attacking Japanese-held targets in the Rangoon area Thursday night, battered the Tilawa oil refinery south of the city and scored "good results" at the Mahlwagon railroad yards, the Tenth United States Air Force reported today.

The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of the Archdiocese, officiated yesterday at a funeral service for Mgr. Arthur J. Kenny, rector for the last thirty years of St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church, 405 East Seventy-ninth Street.

A survey made public last week by the Swedish Board of Trade set Sweden's merchant marine losses, up to the first of this month, at 167 ships, representing 482,576 gross tons. A total of 1,133 persons, of whom 788 were Swedish nationals, lost their lives in those sinkings.

LONDON, April 24 -- Queen Wilhelmina broadcast an Easter message of confident hope to the Netherlands tonight. She said that traitors and oppressors in her conquered land would ultimately be brought to justice.

BOSTON, April 24 -- It is quite possible that balata, the much discussed ingredient of the wartime baseball, suddenly came to life today. Then, again, it may have been the Giants.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 24 -- The Navy placed in commission today its new $8,000,000 air station carved from dense pine woods near this seashore resort for the express purpose of servicing fleet battle units.

THE Beethoven Alcove at the New York Public Library will be opened informally from 5 to 7 P.M., on Wednesday. Bronislaw Huberman and Harold Bauer will play one of the sonatas for violin and piano by the composer.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 24 -- The large-scale movement of refugees is impossible under wartime conditions and neither the United States nor Great Britain, alone or jointly, can begin to solve the refugee problem. These two concrete impressions have emerged after almost a week's discussion of the refugee problem by the American and British delegations here.

For sinking two Japanese ships in a single bombing run the Distinguished Flying Cross has been awarded to Brig. Gen. William E. Lynd, the War Department announced in Washington yesterday. General Lynd sank the ships near Wewak, New Guinea.

THE Free Netherlands authorities in London have made available an advance photograph of the design of the promised stamps of Curacao and Surinam to commemorate the birth of Princess Margriet, third daughter of Crown Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard, at Ottawa, Canada, on Jan. 19.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Announcement by the White House this week that the Japanese Government, in defiance of all the rules of war, had executed some of the eight American Army aviators captured after Major Gen. James H. Doolittle's raid on Japan last year, focused public and official attention on the question of war prisoners, their number and their treatment.

THE two days' British Association conference on "Science and the Citizen" dealt incidentally with a few points at which science impinges upon literature. Sir Lawrence Bragg defended scientists against the charge of being too technical in the presentation of their subject.

The child psychiatrist leading the group was in no way taken aback; the war is real to these families in terms of rationing, he said, so it's the topic uppermost in their minds.

ALONG in November, or thereabout, the Messrs. William Gaxton and Victor Moore and Miss Vera Zorina should be arriving on Broadway in a new musical show. CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) -- The Cubs and Pirates continued to use the new 1943 "dead" ball today, but found it lively enough for twenty hits. Pittsburgh made twelve but did not have the pitching or fielding to match, and lost, 6 to 3.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 24 (AP) -- The Swedish Government, announcing the discovery of German mines in Sweden's territorial waters, sent a blunt note to Berlin today warning Germany about the mine-laying and expressing dissatisfaction over the German reply to a protest against the firing upon the Swedish submarine Draken by the German merchant ship Altkirch.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- With its symbols of guns, tanks, airplanes and aircraft carriers, War Ration Book No. 3 was introduced to the American public this week. The book, intended to replace books one and two when the stamps they contain are exhausted, will be distributed to consumers this Summer.

THE United States is passing rapidly into a fiercer furnace of pain than American history has known hitherto. The approaching tryst with pain will unquestionably lead to one of two results.

CHICAGO, April 24 -- Scattered selling of wheat futures which disclosed a lack of aggressive support gave the market an easier undertone on the Board of Trade today. Closing sales were about the bottom with losses of 3/8 to 1/2 cent a bushel.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 (AP) -- Four Kentucky Derby candidates turned in good work-out times on a sloppy track today in preparation for next Saturday's running of the $75,000 added turf classic.

THE use of the purple varieties of cauliflower and broccoli has been rather limited in this country and there seems to be no good reason for it. LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 24 -- Mrs. Lois Hammel Masterson, wife of Frank C. Masterson, Wall Street stock broker, was found dead in bed this morning of an overdose of sleeping medicine in her home at 25 Larchmont Avenue. She was 36 years old. Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester medical examiner, listed the death as accidental.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 24 -- Ed Kearney's double in the last of the eighth inning scored Roy Triebel from third base to give Hofstra an upset 3-2 victory over St. John's in a return Manhattan Collegiate Conference game today. St. John's won the previous meeting, 7 -- 0.

"They can stay for a month, or two months, or six months, or a year if they want to," he says, and judging from he contented faces in Nura's pictures it seems very likely that they will stay a long, long time.
LONDON, April 24 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The tax situation in the House this week-end was something like a Times Square crowd -- there was a lot of milling around but no way of telling which way people were going.
Plans for the establishment of an International Education Office, to deal with educational problems on a world-wide basis, are being formulated by a commission of school leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- The Federal Housing Administration today announced a delayed-payment plan for persons who take out FHA-financed loans to convert their home-heating plants from oil to other fuels this Spring and Summer.
CAIRO, Egypt, April 21 (Delayed) -- Bringing the war in North Africa to a conclusion, with fierce fighting at many points and incessant air attacks upon the foe, coincides with Holy Week.

On April 18, 1942, sixteen American bombers were over Japan. They had taken off from the deck of the carrier Hornet, 800 miles off the coast, and flown in to strike at armament works, railroad yards, dockyards and oil refineries. Last week the story of what had happened to the eighty men in the crews was released.

AFTER three generations the riding Christianis are home from the road -- for a little while. For this season at least the "world's greatest -- and most daring family of bareback riders" has deserted the big top, the backlots of Peoria and Podunk and its silver-painted private Pullman car; when the circus came to town this Spring under a lot of noise and red paint there wasn't a Christiani in it.

IF this first novel by the author of the best-selling "Battle for the Solomons" were merely a local-color piece -- an authentic picture of the numbers racket during the period ranging roughly from 1929 to 1934 -- then it would be an easy matter to classify "Tucker's People" and lay it aside.

UNABLE to have lunch with Fala due to that worthy's presence in Monterrey on matters of state last week, this corner finally was content to lunch instead with Herb Morgan of MGM who served as a sort of proxy.
IF the Victory Garden is a success, the next step in home food production is to can a sufficient amount to see the family through the Winter months.

WHEN he was Superintendent at West Point after the World War Douglas MacArthur settled upon the practice of coming late to the office in the morning after his subordinates had already been on the job for some hours. He found that the practice contributed to efficiency.

WITH the first full wartime season of radio nearing an end, the broadcasting industry finds that its bigger operatives are enjoying an almost unprecedented boom while the small independent stations are forgotten perhaps more than usual.

Fencing for women is one sport that has thrived on war. The fencing clubs and colleges being within easy reach of transportation in the metropolitan area, the women have taken advantage of this to polish off their foils and opponents on all possible occasions.

Although operating a sharply reduced number of aircraft in comparison with the equipment used in the year preceding the war, the domestic airlines of the United States last year set new records for the volume of cargo, air mail and revenue passenger-miles, Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, announced yesterday.

The Connecticut Board of Fisheries and Game, the National Research Council and Bingham Oceanographic Laboratory at Yale, directed by Professor Merriman, have begun research to determine how much additional food can be obtained from unused marine resources.

The Metropolitan Opera's Saturday afternoon broadcasts over the Blue Network have won the first award of the Women's National Radio Committee as the musical program which, in the opinion of its members, has best served the war program in the last year.

Thirty million victims of this war in Europe, Asia and Africa have received help from the American Red Cross. From Iceland to the war-ravaged provinces of China the Red Cross has struggled to reduce civilian suffering. It swung into action with the attack on Poland.

The New York Mandolin Symphony Orchestra, Ignace Strasfogel conducting, gave its nineteenth annual concert last night at Town Hall before a large audience. The New York Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus took part. The orchestra consists of office and factory workers and high school students.

The Motor Products Corporation reported yesterday for the nine months to March 31 a net profit of $779,385, equal to $1.99 a share of common stock. This was after provision of $150,000 for possible inventory losses, reserve of $340,000 for post-war adjustments and $5,331,900 for estimated Federal come and excess profits taxes.

It is fitting that Easter should come late in this cold Spring. There has been a kind of late Spring in more respects than weather. Looking back only a few years we can see that the old faith in the recurrent surge of goodness and truth suffered some killing frosts. No green thing could grow, no flower open, no bird sing in the bleak Axis January.

AIDED by more seasonal weather, Easter trade jumped ahead in the week and probably set a new all-time high. Men's wear business suffered, of course, through the lack of its uniformed customers, but the difference was made up in the over-all trade total by the great expansion in holiday accessory sales.

Bruhs Mero, who has been dancing hereabouts for some time in other people's companies and has given solo recitals in his own little "Dance Gallery" downtown, last night came uptown to The New York Times Hall for his first independent Broadway performance.

THE barren swamplands of Southern New Jersey, dedicated to mud and mosquitos are contributing to the war. From five to twenty feet below the surface lies white cedar ready for building into mine sweepers for the Pacific, submarine chasers for the Atlantic, sleek motor patrol boats and stout tanks that carry water to soldiers in the African desert.

LONDON, Sunday, April 25 (U.P.) -- Russian pilots destroyed eighteen German planes yesterday in the Northwest Caucasus, where Soviet forces had broken up an Axis offensive that left the enemy "bled white," a Red Army communique said today.

Endorsement of the reciprocal trade agreements program last week by the American Federation of Labor and the National Association of Manufacturers, in view of the previous opposition of the two groups, is the most significant development in recent economic history, foreign traders asserted yesterday.

A resolution urging President Roosevelt and the New Deal Administration to "put a vigorous hand upon organized industry and commerce and smoke out such henchmen as Eddie Rickenbacker and similar open-shoppers" was adopted yesterday at the annual city convention of the Social Democratic Federation in People's House, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

PEARL HARBOR, April 24 -- The occupation of Funafuti island in the Ellice group in the South Central Pacific gives the United States a toehold in the area whence the Japanese themselves might well be contemplating a blow against the Hawaii-Australia life-line.

The merger last week of the New York Federation and the Brooklyn Federation of Jewish Charities into a single organization was described by Governor Dewey in a message made public yesterday as an important "step forward" in the serving of the human needs of a city that "is one great community with similar interests in all boroughs."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 24 -- Five of Alabama's largest coal mines were idle today as miners failed to report for the Saturday shift at shafts of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company and the Woodward Iron Company. The idle mines employ about 7,000 men.

STOKESIA merits attention as a lovely addition to the perennial garden. The many desirable features of this old-fashioned flower should appeal to those who are in search of useful and easily grown plants.

Four years ago Liverpool builders launched one of Britain's most famous submarines, the Thetis. On a trial run in Liverpool Bay, the new craft sank and her personnel of ninety-nine men perished. Raised, finished and renamed Thunderbolt, she won a reputation in the Mediterranean for her effective harassment of Axis supply lines to Africa.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, April 25 -- Far-ranging Allied bombers covering nearly 1,500 miles, gave the big Japanese airplane assembly base of Kendari, in the Celebes, its first pounding since Feb. 10 yesterday, dropping twenty-one tons of bombs which destroyed five planes on the ground and wrecked repair shops.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Office of War Information announced today a war casualty total of 78,249. This figure, representing an increase of 12,869 since the last OWI report on Feb. 20, apparently did not include some of the most recent Tunisian losses. The OWI explained that the figures were only for casualties whose next of kin had been notified as of yesterday.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 24 -- Hugh McAteer, Chief of Staff of the outlawed Irish Republican Army, who has a price of 3,000 on his head, made an audacious appearance before a meeting of armed I.R.A. men tonight and warned the United States that its troops stationed in Northern Ireland were likely to become involved in hostilities with the Irish Republic.

Favored by mild weather, Easter trade ended here yesterday with substantial increases for the week. Department store volume was estimated as about 15 per cent ahead of last year, while the increase for specialty shops was larger. Comparison, of course, was with the post-Easter period of 1942. Apparel buying was active, and main floor and accessory departments in many instances were crowded.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Although there is no disposition to minimize the discussion of questions of immediate importance to the war which took place on a realistic basis this week between President Roosevelt and President Avila Camacho, in diplomatic opinion here, the outstanding value of Mr. Roosevelt's trip to Mexico will be found to lie in the broader significance that is already generally being attached to it.

THE gardener who starts his seeds indoors in seed boxes usually faces a problem when the time for transplanting arrives. The young plants are so tender, and winds and rains cause so much trouble that many never survive to reach a sturdy age.

The comitia minora of the New York County Medical Society, 2 East 103d Street, replied officially yesterday to "certain" criticisms made on the admission of a large number of foreign physicians to membership in the society.

OMAHA, Neb., April 24 -- That happy agricultural brotherhood which was achieved in the days of farm adversity and through which the administration's farm policy was evolved and activated has become pretty well shot in these days of farm prosperity.

LONDON, April 22 -- Private Houston Quinn of Atlanta, Ga., has just received his first eight-day leave since he came to Britain, but instead of spending it sightseeing and having a good time in London, he is buckling down to farming in response to this country's need for volunteer farm workers.
" BRAINS have no sex," Mme. Chiang Kai-shek told a press conference in Washington when asked her views on the Equal Rights Amendment. Everybody agreed with her, it seems. Everybody present, that is.

Two of radio's more important annual meetings are scheduled this week -- the National Association of Broadcasters convention at the Palmer House, Chicago, Tuesday through Thursday, and the Fourteenth Institute for Education by Radio in Columbus, Ohio, Friday through May 3.

JANE ENGLAND has done another of her African stories, again with the brooding feeling of impending danger. The setting is a homestead in Southern Rhodesia, with a big, shady house, walls a foot thick and whitewashed, thick thatched roof, leopard skins on the walls of the big living room.

WHEN rheumatism hit Hashknife Hartley so hard that he could not ride his bronc, he and his old side-kick Sleepy Stevens went down to the little town of Pinnacle near the Mexican border where there was a hot spring, owned, like all the rest of Hawk Hole, by a picturesque giant of a squaw-man called Big Medicine Hawk-worth.

POST-WAR NYLON -- When the war ends there will be a rush for nylon stockings. We are told that du Pont nylon plants will be able to shift from parachute to stocking yarn, not in months or weeks, but in days, once the word is given. It will be a matter of reducing the number of the holes through which the molten nylon is extruded, so as to produce fewer filaments and therefore finer yarn.

THIS is better than I had anticipated. After days -- no, weeks -- of uncertainty and false alarms I am finally off. And this ship is no Dutch coaster loaded with TNT (to which I had originally been assigned), but a comfortable little English banana boat, carrying nothing more than a cargo of lamb.

During the past few years much emphasis has been placed by New York City school officials on the introduction and expansion of democratic procedures in the classroom. Supervisors and teachers are being encouraged in every way possible to introduce such practices and to make their schools living examples of the American way of life.

THE most tried and the one thoroughly trained body of men which the Allied Nations, excepting Russia, have to offer is the British Eighth Army. Most correspondents who have been with it in the field find it hard to set limits on its capabilities. In fact, it would seem that nothing could resist it.

Wendell L. Willkie, Governor Thomas E. Dewey, Senator Robert F. Wagner and Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota joined last night in urging immediate action for the rescue of European Jews from extermination and stressed the importance Palestine as an instrument in this effort.

ABOARD PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S SPECIAL TRAIN, April 24 -- From a window of President Roosevelt's special train and the vantage spot of an automobile near the Commander in Chief's on a secret inspection tour, one gets a picture of America's resources, physical, industrial, agricultural and spiritual, which are being summoned to an all-out effort to win a global war.
The weather man came out from behind his charts, graphs and gadgets last night and said: "Tell the Easter paraders they can wear the best hats they've got."

FOR some really chic ideas on Easter bonnets for this season thumb through a Sears, Roebuck catalogue of Spring offerings of the year 1900. Take the tip from Miles White, who found in a forty-three-year-old edition of that famed household classic much of his inspiration for the riotously gay costumes of the musical production "Oklahoma!"

Development of the military force of the United States to the extreme limit to win the war and the maintenance of a sufficient amount of that force to safeguard the nation against the possibility of future war were urged yesterday by Henry Morgenthau Sr. in an interview at his home, 1133 Fifth Ave. Mr. Morgenthau's eighty-seventh birthday will be tomorrow.

THE past week's major new radio event was "Salute to Youth," which took its weekly place on the WEAF-NBC schedule last Tuesday evening at 7:30, bringing with it an impressive company of veterans and youngsters -- and an idea.

ACOUSTICS is the science of sound, its production, transmission and effects, so says the dictionary. "Quality" of sound is what results when applied acoustics makes something "sound natural." It follows, then, that what constitutes musical quality must be an approximate solution, for no two persons -- or engineers -- hear musical sounds alike.

THE sun never looks down on the Green Mountains of Vermont with more astonishment than on the first of May, when trout brooks, foaming like champagne, race down from the last snow banks melting on the summits.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, April 24 (AP) -- Although 25,000,000 Americans are buying their War Bonds by the payroll deduction method, the Treasury "still isn't satisfied," Secretary Morgenthau declared here today.

OWING to the war, not all the stamps which have been issued in Europe during the past few years have reached New York. A notable example is Norway's 1-krone, which was released on Sept. 2, 1941, to commemorate the centenary of the completion of the central building of the "Universitetet i Oslo" (University of Oslo).

MEXICO CITY, April 24 -- As President Manuel Avila Camacho's special train was heading toward the Mexican border Wednesday afternoon and the Presidents of the United States and of Mexico were holding their hands aloft in a final gesture of farewell, a Mexican official turned to the writer and said: "This is the Good Neighbor policy come home."

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 24 (AP) -- Buffalo made a clean sweep of its two-game series with Jersey City by defeating the Little Giants today, 5 to 4, behind the brilliant four-hit pitching of Floyd Giebell.
WASHINGTON, April 24 -- Secretary Hull, in a statement today, called for the extension by Congress of the reciprocal trade agreements authority for another three years, without amendment.

For the past two or three years we have had a plant which came to us as Pineapple Sage. Dealers classify it as Salvia rutilans, but apparently it is some hybrid form and not a true species. The flowers resemble the common Scarlet Sage, which is usually grown as an annual.

A QUARTER of a century ago next May 16 a headline in THE NEW YORK TIMES read: "First Air Mail to Washington in 200 Minutes." Lieutenant Torrey H. Webb, an Army air pilot, had on the previous day flown mail from New York (starting at Belmont Park) to Washington for the first time on regularly scheduled service.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP) -- Navy communique 354:
Mrs. Chauncey McCormick of Chicago has come to the Waldorf-Astoria, where she has been joined by her son, Lieutenant Roger McCormick of the Army Air Forces.

GEORGE JEAN NATHAN, notable critic and bachelor, has written a small book enticingly entitled "Beware of Parents" and neatly subtitled "A Bachelor's Book for Children." It begins pleasantly with a fetching photograph of a darling little boy at an early skirted age, labeled "The Author Before He Became a Bachelor."

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 -- In open defiance of the demand by the War Labor Board that there be no interruption in the production of soft coal because of a snarl in contract negotiations, about 3,000 miners voted overwhelmingly today to continue a two-day walkout from four pits in Western Pennsylvania.
LONDON, April 25 (UP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
BOSTON, April 25 -- The Giants staged an Easter parade today that proved highly entertaining to a gathering of 10,443 and even more beneficial to the Braves.

LONDON, Monday, April 26 (AP) -- Russian troops have seized the mountains rimming the Black Sea port of Novorossiisk, last major German base in the Caucasus, the Berlin radio acknowledged last night. The Soviet midnight communique said that an attacking Red Army had improved its positions in that area.

The United Mine Workers, through John L. Lewis, president of the union, continued yesterday its defiance of the War Labor Board, which has assumed jurisdiction in the wage dispute between the miners and soft coal operators of the Appalachian region.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 25 -- The Swedish Government tonight published the text of a second note to Germany protesting the attack by a German merchantman on the Swedish submarine Draken in Swedish waters.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- It is now apparent that both the British and United States Governments have plans for an international capital loan agency to supplement the machinery for international currency stabilization already under discussion.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Asserting that price control is impossible without labeling of canned goods by grade, fifteen women's organizations have protested to President Roosevelt, James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, and Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, against Mr. Brown's recent statement questioning his power to require such labeling.
Five new films will have Broadway openings this week. The schedule follows:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 26 (AP) -- The noon communique:

In Central Park, Carl Schurz Park, Radio City Music Hall, and other places in the city thousands of New Yorkers and visitors from out-of-town observed at dawn the celebration of the Resurrection. For those outdoors, the weather was good, except for a slight chilliness that disappeared as the sun rose.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 25 (AP) -- Mounting indications from usually reliable sources pointed tonight to a break in diplomatic relations between the United States and Finland, perhaps tomorrow. Reports from Helsinki that German sources seemed confident that the Finns would remain loyal to the Axis added impetus to the belief in many quarters that a rupture was imminent.
The German Sunday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
LARCHMONT, N.Y., April 25 -On an Easter Day that could not have been more propitious, the post-season regatta of sailing dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club was held today.

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- Robert M. Roloson, 39 years old, a director of United Air Lines, his wife and two of their three children perished in a fire that raged early today through their twenty-three-room mansion in the exclusive Woodley subdivision west of suburban Winnetka.

OTTAWA, April 25 (U.P.) -- Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell announced tonight that the compulsory transfer of labor from industries of low essentiality to more essential employment has been adopted to avert threatened manpower shortages in some war industries and on the farms.

HANS WAGNER, greatest of all the short-stops and now coach of the Pirates, tells such fantastic stories that it often is difficult to determine where the truth ends and the Wagner imagination begins. Not so long ago he was describing the first night baseball game he ever played in, perhaps the first ever held.

Sales of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and affiliated stores for the year ended on Jan. 30 amounted to $161,326,055, largest in the company's history, according to Jack I. Straus, president, in the semi-annual unaudited report for the six months ended on Jan. 30, released for publication today.

LONDON, April 25 -- Business and the stock markets slowed down appreciably last week on the approach of the Easter holiday, but the turnover was much larger than was generally anticipated. This is due to a revival in activity in home railway issues and a continuance of the boomlet in diamond and African gold shares.
A demand for houses in Brooklyn was indicated by transactions reported over the week-end.

Mayor La Guardia expressed satisfaction yesterday with the speed and efficiency of the Fire Department in handling the blaze aboard the munitions-laden freighter that was scuttled Saturday night in New York Bay.

XAVIER HERBERT is a tough Australian with a broken nose like a prizefighter's. He has wandered over much of his native land, working in sawmills, cattle-droving, tapping dingos, studying the black aborigines of the Northern Territory, diving for pearls with the Japanese in the Arafura Sea. He has lived on breadlines in England, bicycled the length of Europe from Calais to Athens and written a novel that went begging for a publisher for four years.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The volume of freight transported by motor carriers last month increased 13.6 per cent over the February volume and 21.1 per cent over the March, 1942, volume, the American Trucking Association reported today.

At least one industry in the city has welcomed this year the traditional rains of April. Echoing the frequent blasts of wind is the collective sigh of relief of the cleaners and dyers as they view gray skies and puddled streets. They know people won't get their clothes cleaned in rainy weather.

A dividend of $2.25 a share for 1942 was announced yesterday by the Union Labor Life Insurance Company, owned entirely by unions of the American Federation of Labor and other labor organizations, through Matthew Woll, president of the company and vice president of the A.F. of L.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -American soldiers are assembling their own combat vehicles and cargo trucks in North Africa, the War Department reported today. Shipped in "knock-down" style, the parts of motor vehicles are taken from docks of motor assembly centers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 25 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will film the "Ziegfeld Follies," in technicolor as its first musical without a story. The picture, it has been announced, will be a straight musical revue, utilizing studio stars and specialty acts from Broadway.

CHUNGKING, China, April 25 (AP) -- A powerful push by a Japanese force of more than 40,000 against Chinese concentrations in the eastern tip of the Chungtiao Mountains was acknowledged by the Chinese High Command today to have scored initial successes against bitter opposition.
Miss Helen Catherine Du Bois has arrived at the Pierre from Washington.

The statement of Colonel Alec Cunningham-Reid in the House of Commons, that among other advantages the United States expects to derive out of the war is international domination of the air, together with apprehensions variously expressed in Parliament and elsewhere in England concerning post-war commercial air power, has aroused deep interest among Americans actively concerned in overseas transport of cargoes and passengers in air carriers.
PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (AP) -- Washington snapped the Athletics' two-game winning streak today sweeping a double-header before 17,000 at Shibe Park.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Rationing of civilian goods and decreasing inventories may bring about a new large-scale merchandising service, if experiments in swapping goods now being undertaken by the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations pans out.

While Aturo Toscanini was conducting the second movement of Tchaikovsky's "Symphonie Pathetique" yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall before 3,000 persons at the $10,190,045 War Bond Concert, Oswaldo Mazzucchi, his second 'cellist, suddenly stopped playing and slumped beside his instrument.
With the emergence of the new Ways and Means Committee majority tax bill, the opposition to the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan begins to take on an intelligible pattern.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, delivering the Easter sermon yesterday morning at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, made his theme the quest for certainty in a world of shifting values.

Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles has written a book setting forth the aims of this country for the post-war world, called "The World of the Four Freedoms," to be published by Columbia University Press May 17. Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, has written a foreword.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, APRIL 25 (UP) -A communique:

The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America in a research bulletin made public yesterday asserted that "the suffering of the Jewish people in Europe is beyond anything the civilized imagination can picture."

In the presence of a congregation of 7,000 persons with as many more standing quietly outside the church during the entire two hours of the ceremony, Bishop Stephen J. Donahue pontificated at the 11 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

LONDON, April 25 -- Church-bells and a large measure of sunshine set the tone for London's fourth war-time Easter Sunday today. The bells, particularly in the city, where they have always been famous, sounded a note of hope and cheer because, except for the special peals permitted last Christmas and to celebrate the German's rout from Egypt, the bells have been silent for almost three years.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 25 (U.P.) -- Booth Tarkington's dog Figaro is an honorary general in the Wags today, and the next 100 dogs sold at the municipal dog pound will become honorary privates or seamen, depending on the branch of service most to his owner's taste.

The concert given by Arturo Toscanini, Vladimir Horowitz and the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall to promote the purchase of United States War Bonds was as unpretentious in outward seeming as it was impressive in the character of the performance and the returns of the undertaking.

One of the phenomena to be expected of food rationing, if the German-controlled French press is believed, is a larger crop of young writers. This is a deduction reached from study of the findings of medical authorities in France, who assert that intellectual faculties develop more rapidly if the stomach is not overloaded.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 25 -- British tanks and infantry have hacked their way through bitter German opposition for small gains in two zones of the vast battle now raging throughout Northern Tunisia, it was officially announced today.

Federal and municipal authorities are expected to move today to ease the acute shortage of kosher meats, which has proved distressing to Orthodox Jews celebrating the Passover holidays. If efforts in their behalf should succeed, they may have some of the desired red meats tomorrow -- the last day of Passover.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 25 -- About 100 acres of docks and installations at Ferryville, on Lake Bizerte, have been devastated in repeated raids by United States Flying Fortresses and British Wellingtons, a Royal Air Force statement said today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 -Rufus Gentry, 25-year-old Buffalo right-hander with a 1-A draft classification, tossed an eleven-inning no-hit, no-run game today in the opener of a twin bill with the champion Bears before 3,862. The Bisons won by 1 -- 0 but Newark took the nightcap, 5 -- 2.

NEW DELHI, India, April 24 (Delayed) -- The eagerly awaited speech of Mohammed Ali Jinnah, president of the Moslem League, to the annual session or the league this morning was a repetition of his old accusation against the AllIndia Congress and Mohandas K. Gandhi.
There follows a brief review of some of the most interesting things -- products, shops, etc. -- that have come to the attention of the writer since the first of the year.

Except for a few last-minute calls for fill-ins needed for Easter selling, both retailers and manufacturers turned their attention to Summer and Fall lines, and a considerable number of advance orders were placed, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Mayor La Guardia converted his City Hall desk into a pulpit yesterday and delivered a twenty-minute Easter sermon, with world peace, faith and justice as its main themes. His broadcast made no mention of city affairs or civic problems.

The pamphlet report for 1942 of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, released for publication today, shows a net income of $62,083,984 after charges and taxes, equal, after preferred dividend payments, to $26.14 each on the 2,222,910 common shares outstanding, compared with $28,857,419, or $11.19 a common share in 1941.

BAYOINE, N.J., April 25 -- Fire destroyed the administration building of the marine detail at the Naval Supply Depot at Thirty-fourth Street here early this afternoon. The two-story frame structure had executive offices, a kitchen and dining room and barracks on the upper floor.

Japanese propagandists have concocted a "new international law" to cover the execution of some of the American fliers who bombed Tokyo on April 18, 1942, it was disclosed yesterday by the Nazi Transocean Agency in a Morse-code transmission to the Far East.

Movements of the Argentina peso and Canadian free dollar continued to interest traders in the foreign exchange market last week. The Latin currency shot up to 25.25 cents, unmatched since October, 1938, while the Dominion unit at 90.44 cents, retouched the year's highest made last March.

The resignation of William Goetz, production chief and vice president in charge of studio operations at Twentieth Century-Fox, to take effect upon completion of his current program of ten pictures, was announced yesterday by Spyros Skouras, president of the company. It was said that Mr. Goetz will form his own film producing company.
The dozens of new "cosmetic stockings" that have appeared on the market in the last few weeks are only the first, faint ripple of a gigantic flood that bids fair to inundate the nation.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Appointment of a Republican committee of House members to study post-war domestic problems was announced tonight by Representative Joseph W. Martin, the minority leader. Representative Charles A. Wolverton of New Jersey was designated chairman.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday his belief in "an honesty in this universe which will keep faith with those who keep faith with it."

The present war is not simply a war between armies but between ideas, although the truth is deeper than that, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared in his Easter sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -A demand made today by the Republican leader of the Senate, Mr. McNary, that Congress assume veto powers over reciprocal trade agreements, tightened the lines for the fight presaged over the question of renewing the Administration's authority to negotiate such agreements.

Only a week ago every one was asking what was wrong with the Yankees. They had gone nowhere in a hurry throughout the training season and were put to rout by the Dodgers. But with the pennant race under way, Joe McCarthy's men suddenly discovered the combination and apparently are proving that the only thing wrong with them was lack of work.

A Jefferson Bi-Centennial concert was given last night by the School for Democracy at the Penthouse Auditorium, 13 Astor Place. The program consisted of instrumental, solo and choral music, closing with a first performance of "That Freedom Plow," a musical play by Louis Lerman, with music by Earl Robinson.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 25 -- Atlantic City observed today its first Easter Boardwalk parade since its major beach-front hotels were taken over last Summer by the Air Forces, with khaki-clad soldiers and blue-uniformed Coast Guards lining the sea rails and Boardwalk shop fronts to watch the colorful spectacle.

ABOARD A BRITISH SUBMARINE TENDER, at a North African Port, April 25 -- Working perhaps the most dangerous small stretch of water in the world, Allied submarines -- French, Dutch, Polish, Greek and Yugoslav as well as British -- have been taking such a heavy toll of Axis merchant ships between Tunisia and Italy that the enemy has been forced to divert his supply line to the air.

The entire upper tier of boxes for the Red Cross benefit performance by the members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall next Thursday evening has been purchased for the use of enlisted men in the armed forces, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Henry M. Alexander, chairman of the box committee.

The first work by George Balanchine to finds its way into the Ballet Theatre's repertoire is his choreographic version of Stravinsky's "Apollon Musagete" which, under the title of "Apollo" and with the composer conducting, was presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

GROTON, Conn., April 25 -- The first submarine aboard which women worked in actual construction, the U.S.S. Dace, was launched today in a patriotic Easter Sunday setting at the shipyard of the Electric Boat Company.

NEW DELHI, India, April 25 -- William Phillips, special Presidential envoy to India, disclosed today that he had asked permission to see Mohandas K. Gandhi and Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, but it had been refused by the Indian Government.

When fresh water fishing hits its stride in Westchester and Putnam Counties this year, some of the bigger fish should be finding their way into the creels. Boat fishing on certain of the lakes and reservoirs will aid in the quest for big ones that move out into deep water and last season were able to get away from the fishermen anchored on shore.

A movement to oust former Representative Michael J. Kennedy as leader of Tammany will be carried into the primary election in August, it was learned yesterday. At least twenty Assembly district leadership fights are expected.

VERBANK, N.Y., April 25 -- A brilliant exhibition of bird work by a black and white English setter dog settled many arguments today during the running of the final event of the Orange County Field Trial Club's three-day meeting over the preserves of the Verbank Hunting and Fishing Club.
The Berlin radio said last night that the 10-year-old 14,500-ton United States aircraft carrier Ranger had been sunk by a German submarine in the North Atlantic.

In a book entitled "America, Russia, and the Communist Party in the Postwar World," written by John L. Childs and George S. Counts for the Commission of Education and the Postwar World of the American Federation of Teachers, the authors write: "It should be clear that the American Communist party is a movement whose leaders do not consider themselves bound by either the principles of American democracy or the standards of ordinary group morality.

One thousand five hundred persons thronged the church and the chapel of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, for the Easter Sunday service yesterday morning. The Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, pastor, was the preacher.
LONDON, April 25 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 25 -- Frank Pfeiffer, 46 years old, a former armored car guard, was charged today with killing a man and critically wounding a woman, both of whom had testified for his wife when she won a divorce from him in February.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Cold weather recently prevented the Winter wheat crop from making rapid growth, but the plant is reported as jointing from Southern Kansas southward. Harvesting is expected to start in about thirty days in the extreme south of Texas and should be under way in the northern area within forty-five days.

Hundreds of Americans have lived in Japan and come back with the report that the Japanese at home are law-respecting people, not guilty of the excesses their soldiers commit abroad.
