But the latest revelation of the Japanese mind -- the legal and formal murder of prisoners of war -- was not the crime of excited soldiers in an enemy country.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Cards which may do much to shape the future of every student will be distributed soon to all high schools of the country.

Because of the Dodgers' participation in the Brooklyn war bond drive, President Branch Rickey yesterday attended a Sunday baseball game for the first time in his forty-year connection with the sport, but this brought no luck at all to his club.

Twenty-eight years ago Australians and New Zealanders fighting against hopeless odds on the bloody shores of Gallipoli taught the world a proud new name. Ever since "Anzac" has remained a symbol of courage and devotion. Yesterday was not only Easter but Anzac Day.

L.E. Carpenter, manufacturer of leather cloth and coated products for the Army and Navy, has bought the twenty-acre property of the Gotham Silk Hosiery Company at Wharton, N.J., and will operate it in conjunction with its Newark factory.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Relief in the form of payments for work on public projects cost American taxpayers almost $25,000,000,000 during the 1933-42 decade.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (U.P.) -- An average American housewife with four mouths to feed had to spend $36 to set her table last month, $4 more than in March, 1942, Department of Agriculture statistics disclosed today.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- All outright trading in May, July and September corn last week on the Board of Trade was at the ceiling price of $1.05 a bushel, but there was no business in December, the ceiling on which is $1.01.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Ceiling prices continue to be paid for all pork products, and official reports indicate that as the result of the discrepancy between ceiling prices on cured products and the market prices for hogs packers continue to cut up the latter at losses ranging from $1 to $1.50 a hundredweight.

PITTSBURGH, April 25 -- A small rise in steel ingot output, a drop in the volume of new steel orders, a slowing down in plate shipments and a quiet scrap market featured news of the steel industry last week.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Although the wheat market showed a relatively firm undertone last week, prices held within comparatively narrow limits and bullish sentiment was tempered by the near approach of the maturity date on that percentage of the 1942 crop stored in elevators and a moderate amount of 1941 grain stored on farms.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 25 (AP) -- Jersey City captured both ends of a double-header from the Rochester Red Wings today, winning the opener, 11 -- 4, and the nightcap, 2 -- 0, as Bill Voiselle hurled a two-hitter. Through special permission from the International League president, Frank Shaughnessy, the teams used last year's baseballs.

ST. LOUIS, Apri1 25 (AP) -- Extra-base blows and four-hit pitching for seven innings by Johnny Niggeling, the knuckleball expert, gave the Browns the decision, 5 to 1, over the White Sox today in an abbreviated opener to a double-header, half of which was postponed by weather.

Produce jobbers who service New York City and an area within a radius of sixty miles with vegetables and fruits will "go on strike" tonight unless produce dis tributors agree to discontinue "tie-in" selling, William Zwillinger, president of the Produce Buyers Association, Inc., announced this morning.

John Golden announced yesterday that "The Home Front," the Phoebe and Henry Ephron comedy that opens tonight in Washington, will come to the Longacre on Wednesday, May 5. The leading roles will be played by Robert Burton, Ruth Weston, Ethel Owen, Katharine Bard, Francis de Sales Edwin Philips and John Philliber.

NEW ORLEANS, April 25 -- Increased trade support which found contracts scarce at times, a continued feeling of hopefulness that the Administration had determined that a ceiling price was not the answer to the cotton-price problem and scattered evening-up for the week-end combined last week to steady cotton futures on the Cotton Exchange here.

LONDON, April 25 -- Advising the people of Czechoslovakia that the time for "new and decisive military events" was very near, President Eduard Benes urged them to be prepared to coordinate their own uprising against their German masters with it.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -The War Department listed today Army Air Force personnel who participated in a "successful" raid April 18 on harbor and dock installations of Porto Torres in Sardinia.

The battle of transportation is being won, but the victory is not necessarily a permanent one, the Office of War Information reported yesterday in a comprehensive review of the conditions in all branches of the transportation industry in the United States.

Although Germany denies the report, the Headquarters of the British Eighth Army indicates its conviction that Marshal Rommel has left Africa for good, and that the supreme command over all Axis forces in Tunisia has been lodged in the hands of General Jurgen von Arnim, commander of the Tunis-Bizerte sector from the start.

Purple tulips, jonquils, forsythia and dogwood blossoms formed a garden setting in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador yesterday for "The Easter Bonnet Luncheon," given for the benefit of the Chaplains Emergency Fund, New York Port of Embarkation.

Attendance at Easter dawn services in the suburbs was generally smaller yesterday than in former years, the result of gasoline rationing and other conditions incidental to the war. The gaps in the ranks of worshipers at the outdoor ceremonies were the more noticeable in view of the perfect weather.

Sales of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31, last, reached a new high record of $137,643,637, an increase of $20,210,282 over the $117,433,355 reported for the preceding twelve months, according to Bernard F. Gimbel, president, in his report to stockholders.

Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared here yesterday "the chances are better than fifty-fifty that private enterprise will take such a part in winning the war and the peace that capitalism will be preserved in America."

Free from any surprise announcements that might depress values, the stock market in the shortened week of trading resulting from the Good Friday holiday recovered on Wednesday from its earlier sagging tendencies and ended the week with gains that lifted the price level to the highest point in about two weeks.

A special meeting of the stockholders of the International Mercantile Marine Company has been called for May 20 at Hoboken, N.J., for the purpose of voting on a merger of the company with the United States Lines Company. On the following day the stockholders of the United States Lines Company will hold their meeting in New York City to act on the proposals.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP) -The host of girls who keep the typewriters humming in the nation's capital went into the Easter parade today in costumes having as the outstanding feature bonnets which delighted thousands of soldiers in town from near-by camps.

WITH THE SECOND UNITED STATES CORPS, in Tunisia, April 23 (Delayed) -- American troops, in their toughest offensive test of the Tunisian campaign, fought their way into the German lines for fourteen hours today. At 5 P.M. they were holding positions halfway up Hill 575, Djebel el Gorraa, ready for a new advance.

LONDON, April 25 (U.P.) -- Fast and deadly fighters of the Royal Air Force resumed "train busting" operations in Flanders and France today and attacked water transport lines vital to Axis communications, the Air Ministry announced.

CAIRO, Egypt, April 25 -- Reports filtering out of Axis-occupied Europe indicate increasing fears of an imminent Allied invasion of the Continent from Asia Minor bases with the obvious eventual objective of establishing bridgeheads in the Balkan Peninsula through which the Danubian back door to Germany could be approached.

Further tabulation of week-end orders for war bonds in the Second Federal Reserve District brought to $3,845,000,000 the total of sales to investors other than commercial banks since the Second War Loan was launched on April 12, it was announced yesterday by Allan Sproul, chairman of the War Finance Committee for the district, which includes New York State, Northern New Jersey and Fairfield, Conn.

Caution dominated the cotton futures market last week as the trade awaited developments in Washington in regard to imposition of a ceiling on the commodity and the proposed sale of the government's stocks as a price-stabilization measure.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 -- The latest contribution to industrial fashions is a wardrobe for women workers in the aircraft industry. Collectively, the items are called "Flying Fortress Fashions" and the color in which they are made is known as "flight blue."

Bishop William T. Manning, preaching on "The Glory and Power of the Resurrection," in his sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, warned against the tendency to follow a "semi-rationalistic, merely humanitarian religion" and called strongly for a return to "eternal realities."

CHICAGO, April 25 (AP) -- Truett (Rip) Sewell, veteran Pittsburgh right-hander, who blanked the Cubs on three singles opening day, came back to beat them again, 6 to 2, today before a crowd of 7,349 and give the Pirates an even break in the four-game series.

CHICAGO, April 25 -- Prices of oats averaged somewhat higher last weeek on the Board of Trade here, with cash houses on the buying side of the May. Announcement that the export equalization fee on Canadian oats shipped to this country would be 6 cents a bushel is expected to hamper fresh business with that country.

The six-story apartment house for forty-eight families at 205 East Eighty-second Street has been sold by Emanuel A. Stern to an investing client of Benjamin Mintz. It was bought subject to a first mortgage of $130,000 held by the Bank for Savings and title was insured by the Lawyers Title Company.

St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, opened its doors yesterday to receive a throng of 2,200 Easter morning worshipers who, in a holy communion service, heard the Rev. Dr. Roelif H. Brooks the rector, pay homage to the members of the armed forces, and link the story of the Resurrection with the faith "needed so badly in a stricken, puzzled world."

The Standard Oil Company's proposed donation to the Government of its Buna-S patents raises some interesting questions. During the course of a hearing held by a Senate committee it was said that the company had been hoodwinked by the Germans and that it acquired nothing of high importance for $35,000,000.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 111.9. The raw materials index advanced 0.1 per cent as increases in the prices of cotton, eggs, apples and grains more than offset decreases in tobacco, vegetables, cattle and potatoes.
WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, commanding general of the Army Ground Forces, was wounded in action Friday on the Tunisian front, the War Department announced today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 25 -- This year Anzac Day coincided with Easter Sunday and all over Australia ceremonies were held today to observe the twenty-eighth anniversary of the landing of the Australian and New Zealand troops at Gallipoli in the last war and to honor all those who gave their lives for their country in the last war and those who have died in this one.

The tension in Finnish-American relations coincides with increasing strain between Germany and Sweden. The two crises are not separate phenomena, nor are they due simply to the fact that the tugs on her neighbor pull at Sweden, too, and make her precarious balance more difficult to maintain.

CLEVELAND, April 25 (AP) -- The balata ball wasn't entirely to blame today as the Indians and Tigers drew a total of twenty bases on balls and divided a holiday double-header, both games ending 4 to 1 before 10,283 fans at Cleveland Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- Employers were asked today by the Office of Defense Transportation to schedule vacations throughout the year as well as to begin and end all employe vacations on Tuesdays, Wednesdays or Thursdays.

LONDON, April 25 (Reuter) -Commenting on Colonel Robert R. McCormick's campaign for units of the British Empire to become new members of the United States after the war, a special correspondent said in today's Sunday Observer:

If the highways of Britain's tight little island are more dangerous than the fighting fronts of the world for men in the British armed services, as Mr. Hore-Belisha reported the other day, the same situation exists in the United States. In 1942 there were 147,544 casualties on the highways of Great Britain, whereas casualties in the armed forces in the first two years of the war amounted to only 145,012.
We believe that the time has come to draw the attention of the nation to a question that up to now has been submerged under the weight of the more immediate perils of war.

American industry lost 39,400,000 man days in January as a result of absenteeism resulting from illness, non-industrial accidents and personal reasons alone, according to a report of a survey made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

JERUSALEM, April 25 (U.P.) -Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York, after celebrating solemn high mass before hundreds of American soldiers and nurses in the Basilica of the Holy Sepulcher today, delivered a radio message to the United States proclaiming the war as a "Gethsemane of civilization" that would end in victory for the United Nations.

Both national and local campaigns for men's Summer clothing will get under way about the third week in May, depending on the weather, according to retail executives here. Budgets are fairly substantial because the 1942 season was a disappointing one and both manufacturers and stores carried over a fair amount of goods.
CINCINNATI, April 25 -- That "reluctant" ball gave the pitchers another happy day today as the Cardinals evened their opening series with the Reds on a 1-0 victory for Howard Pollet.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, April 26 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses, ranging along the north coast of New Guinea from Wewak to Saidor, delivered heavy punches for General MacArthur's air force in limited Easter Sunday operations.

In the first three months of 1943 relief shipments from Russian War Relief, Inc., to the Soviet Union left United States ports at the rate of $1,000,000 a month, it was announced yesterday by Edward C. Carter, president of the relief agency, at a meeting of its board of directors in the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway.
AN ADVANCE BASE IN THE ANDREANOF ISLANDS, Alaska, April 14 (Delayed) -- The Aleutians are no sideshow. Kiska and Attu are tough nuts to crack.

The Treasury Department announced yesterday that the Dodgers had sold $11,750 in bonds to fans at Sunday's game. Red Barber's urging over the air, brought more than $90,000 in additional pledges. The total attributable to the Dodgers directly now is $75,000,000.

A new wartime vacation school will be opened at Hunter College this Summer to help care for the children of working parents, Dr. Florence Brumbaugh, principal of the Hunter College Elementary School, announced yesterday. The program, which is now before the Board of Higher Education for approval, calls for a six-week session for children 5 to 11 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Indications that inventories of wholesale hardware dealers have fallen 48 per cent in the last twelve months, were seen by War Production Board officials here in reports received from members of the Hardware Jobbers' Industry Committee.

WITH UNITED STATES FORCES, West of Mateur, Tunisia, April 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- Easter religious services of nearly 200 United States soldiers were held today within view of a German hill outpost as the thunder of enemy cannon reverberated in the distance.
The stock market failed yesterday to break out of the midway position in which it had operated for a week and a half. Prices shuttled in a range of approximately a point.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting members in 101 leading cities, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 21: Increase of $1,012,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $4,355,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and a decrease of $32,682,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Forty-seven additional industrial establishments have been granted the Army-Navy Production Award for outstanding performance on war work, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, said today.

On the Russian front two powerful armies have apparently completed their preliminary movements and now face each other in the positions from which one or the other, or both, will strike. Because of the unusually early Russian Spring these blows may fall soon.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 26 -- Infantrymen of the Second United States Corps, fighting with reckless bravery, have smashed through the rough hills of Northern Tunisia to a point twelve miles west of the enemy's communications center of Mateur and twenty-five miles west of Bizerte.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee, much satisfied with the recent "press conference" held before it by Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, decided today to extend its study of official war news to the War, Navy and Post-office departments.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 26 -- Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, who was wounded last Friday at the Tunisian front, had to take a three-hour jeep ride to a hospital with a shell splinter lodged only a quarter inch from his brain, it was disclosed today.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, April 26 -- Engineering contributions to the medical profession in drying human blood plasma for the use of the armed forces were described today before the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Close students of John L. Lewis as a strategist and tactician, who for some weeks have been certain that in the current dispute over his miners' wages he would not deviate from his master chart, are now convinced of this. This chart requires a final phase in which Mr. Lewis confronts the President, having previously toyed with the Secretary of Labor and put her conciliator, Dr. Steelman, in his waistcoat pocket.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Four Corsairs, the Navy's single-seated, all-metal fighter planes, broke up a flight of thirty Japanese planes -- ten bombers and twenty protecting Zeros -- northwest of Guadalcanal, and shot down five Zeros, with loss of two of the American planes, the Navy stated today.

The Dodgers got the jump on the other National League clubs in returning to use of the 1942 baseball when the 1943 model was found defective, but the other clubs aren't complaining. Just a little envious, that's all, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
The Ballet Theatre devoted its program at the Metropolitan Opera House last night to repetitions of three ballet classics, with as many guest stars to reinforce its regular personnel.

The season of moth flakes, cedar chests and sealed packages is near. This year wool must be "stored like a treasure," experts declare. Printed or mimeographed, a deluge of pamphlets, leaflets and booklets is descending upon the American housewife, urging her to handle wool clothing and household goods with care.

The manpower shortage caused by the war has been eased in the last year by increasing participation by women volunteers in the daily routine tasks of the Hospital for Joint Diseases of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York City, it was reported yesterday by Mrs. Edwin H. Koehler, chairman of the hospital's women's division.

All is set for the sixty-first home opening of the Giants today at the Polo Grounds. With the Braves supplying the opposition, Mel Ott probably will call on right-handed Bill Lohrman to pitch. Lohrman failed against the Dodgers at Ebbets Field last Thursday.

The subway circuit begins it season tonight when "Claudia" starts a week's engagement at the Windsor, in the Bronx. This will be the fourth season of plays at a dollar top. The circuit this year includes theatres in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Passaic and Newark.

Charles J. Farley, nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, yesterday declared that he would not be on trial for murder if Mayor La Guardia had "not butted into the case." He complained that he was being used as a "political football."
MOSCOW, April 26 -- Following is the text of the note from Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, to Tadeusz Romer, Polish Ambassador:

Lyle Wilson testified yesterday in the Special Sessions trial of his brother-in-law, Frank Clandorf, and himself on charges of using the Forty-second Street Hotel, near Seventh Avenue, as a house of prostitution. He denied to Justices Weiboldt, Northrup and Hofmann that he was aware of vice and gambling conditions in the place until after police raids.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- War Artist Units, composed of military and civilian artists who will make paintings, drawings, etchings and sketches at the fighting fronts, have been established, and some such groups already have been dispatched to war theatres to begin their work, the War Department announced today.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., April 26 -- There was unanimity among the leaders attending the 148th annual commencement exercises of Union College here today that the only way by which America would win the war against the fascist nations was "to stand breast to breast against the enemy and fight it out."

Almost completely ignored in the betting by the biggest week-day crowd the track has had since opening day, C.A. O'Neil Jr.'s chestnut gelding Bally Boy raced through the five-horse field in the featured Class C St. Albans handicap at Jamaica yesterday to win by a couple of lengths and provide the venturesome in the crowd of 20,269 with $65.10 for each $2 win ticket.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Inter-American Coffee Agreement, a commercial treaty signed by fifteen American republics, has operated so successfully that it has been unanimously decided by the participating countries to extend the agreement until October, 1944, it was announced here today at the offices of the Inter-American Coffee Board.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission said today in its first public report on the subject that electric operating revenues of the larger privately owned utilities in 1942 were $2,762,857,000, a record high.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, April 26 (AP) -- A trigger-tempered dog named "Hey," which bit twenty unwary men on a troop ship en route to war, has been officially cited for helping dispose of a bothersome Japanese sniper and mortar-fire spotter on Guadalcanal.

LONDON, April 26 -- The Russian announcement of the severance of diplomatic relations with Poland received immediate earnest Cabinet attention tonight and no time will be lost by the British Government in taking steps to bring the two countries together again.
TORONTO, April 26 (Canadian Press) -- Vernon Bartlett, British M.P., who was in Toronto today to address the Canadian Club, said in an interview:

Experts in home economies are asking women to prepare now for the Summer preserving season by becoming familiar with appropriate methods and by getting equipment ready. The following article, the third and last of a series, deals with dehydration.
"I'VE been reading Erskine Caldwell's 'Georgia Boy,'"* said the Mark Twain enthusiast, "and it bothers me."

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- C. Bedell Monro, president of Pennsylvania-Central Airlines, called upon the air transport industry tonight to stop "day dreaming" about post-war aviation and get to work on a specific program, an outline for which he suggested.
The fifteen-story apartment house at 170-83 East Seventy-ninth Street, near Lexington Avenue, was bought by Frederick Brown, operator, from the Union Dime Savings Bank.

The Third Naval District announced yesterday that mental and physical examinations would be held here this week and next for 17-year-old boys who desired to become naval aviation cadets, with eight months of college training at government expense.
JERSEY CITY, April 26 (AP) -- Jersey City made it three in a row over Rochester in a loosely played game today, winning by a score of 10 to 8.

Preferring to gamble on getting government underwear orders rather than adjust their operations to the OPA's tentative standards for civilian "war model" garments because of dissatisfaction with ceiling prices, some underwear knitters have adopted a new policy of submitting bids to the quartermaster without having sufficient raw materials to complete the orders and then depending upon the WPB to divert required quantities from civilian yarn users, Worth Street suppliers reported yesterday.

The Office of Price Administration has tentatively completed a revised pricing regulation for the liquor industry which will permit wholesalers a mark-up of about 15 per cent, and retailers an advance over cost of approximately 35 per cent, it was learned yesterday.

The Second War Loan Drive is now in its final week, and the indications are that the nation-wide goal of $13,000,000,000 will be exceeded by at least $2,000,000,000. Further, it would appear that the New York district will exceed its quota of subscriptions from non-banking investors by close to $1,000,000,000.
The appointment of Charles Klem and Edward C. Gray as assistant vice presidents of the New York Stock Exchange was announced yesterday by Emil Schram, president.

The task of delivering to the families of American prisoners of war the 1,500 messages that arrive each month at the office of the Chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 477 Madison Avenue, is being retarded by a preponderance of faulty or incomplete addresses, it was disclosed yesterday.

UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION in England, April 26 -- This is a piece about a typical New York kid who, like thousands of others, a few years ago was carrying books to De Witt Clinton High School and then to New York University.

NEW DELHI, India, April 26 (U.P.) -- British and Indian troops guarding the approaches to Buthedaung, one of Field Marshal Sir Archibald P. Wavell's only remaining footholds in Western Burma, have been fighting during the past twenty-four hours against Japanese forces in the northern part of the Mayu Peninsula, west of the Mayu River, it was announced today.

The illegal use of ration stamps to promote a "black market" in shoes is under investigation by the office of United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa, it was made known yesterday. The inquiry is an outgrowth of earlier inquiries by Saks Fifth Avenue and officials of the Office of Price Administration.

Breakfast cereal manufacturers, with the assistance of the government, were reported yesterday to be preparing a nation-wide campaign to stimulate the consumption of their product. Cereals are in ample supply and unrationed, and the move is intended to swing greater consumer interest to them.
Three men in the armed forces are among the leaders in the current George Ruppert fishing contest, according to a tabulation just received.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- Secretary Stimson, declaring that "great opportunities are now developing for us to end the war as quickly as possible," opposed today the enactment of legislation which would bar the induction this year of fathers married before Pearl Harbor.

MOSCOW, April 26 -- Russia announced tonight she had broken off diplomatic relations with the exiled Polish Government in London because the Poles allegedly were conniving with Germany in an appeal to the International Red Cross to investigate German charges of the mass murder of Polish officers by Russians near Smolensk.
I read with greatest interest your splendid editorial in THE TIMES of April 22, "Women Army Doctors."

WASHINGTON, April 26 (U.P.) -- The War Department made public today the names of 156 United States soldiers held prisoners of war by Germany. The prisoners include thirteen whose next of kin live in New York and one from New Jersey. All enlisted men, unless otherwise classified, they are:

Asserting that the government's struggle to restrain the advance in prices and the cost of living has now reached a critical stage, the Guaranty Survey, monthly review of the Guaranty Trust Company, released yesterday, says that the present controls seem capable of dealing with the situation, provided these controls can be protected from pressure groups.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 26 -- Detectives arrested a man early today whom they accused of attempting to rob a local theatre last night by sending a note to the woman cashier threatening to dynamite the ticket booth unless she gave the bearer of the letter several hundred dollars in cash.

Victory Book Campaign headquarters announced yesterday that nearly 1,375,000 books gathered in, the 1943 book drive had already been distributed to all branchs of the armed forces, merchant marine, United Service Organizations and Red Cross.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 26 (AP) -- American and British representatives seeking a solution of the problem of refugees from Nazi-occupied Europe were understood today to have reached a tentative compromise on a plan to relocate European refugees temporarily in French North Africa, the Cyrenaica portion of Libya and the Diredawa region of Ethiopia.
CHICAGO, April 26 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, was accused today of hampering the war effort through his ban on recordings and transcriptions.

MR. EDWARD T. BRANNICK has been connected with the New York Giants since the mind of man runneth not to the contrary. He denied heatedly yesterday that he was secretary of the club when it was founded in 1876, or that he had assisted Abner Doubleday in planning the first diamond in 1839.

Further sales of war bonds totaling $40,000,000 were announced yesterday by Allan Sproul, chairman of the War Finance Committee of the Second Federal Reserve District. This brought the total sales to noncommercial bank sources in this district in the Second War Loan drive to $3,885,000,000 -- far beyond the original quota of $3,000,000,000 and within striking distance of the new goal of $4,000,000,000.

Documentary evidence was offered yesterday accusing General Henri Honore Giraud of planning to reduce the Jews in France to a condition of inferior citizenship, in violation of the laws of the French Republic.

Fifty years of feminine fashions were presented yesterday to 500 women by the New York Dress Institute at the Hotel Pierre for the benefit of the Immaculate Conception Day Nursery, which was celebrating its fiftieth anniversary.
LONDON, April 26 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Two shop foremen shared honors yesterday with Igor Sikorsky, designer of the helicopter, William Gibbs, designer of the Liberty ships, and Edmund Goldfield, who designed the mobile X-ray unit now used in the field by the Army, as winners in the sixth annual presentation of the American Design Awards.

Three new referees were appointed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora to replace former Governor Charles Poletti, who resigned after more than two years of service as referee in the proceedings brought by the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico to determine questions involved in the distribution to bondholders of funds in their possession.

INWOOD, L.I., April 26 -- Ensign Thomas Jacob Walsh, flying a single-seater Navy plane on a routine operational training flight, was instantly killed today when he crash-landed on the soft earth of a freshly plowed truck farm and the machine turned over and exploded.
WITH AN AMERICAN ARMY MULE PACK TRAIN, in Northern Tunisia, April 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- American soldier mule skinners described this country today as "worse than Guadalcanal."

A General Sessions jury, after deliberating for fifteen minutes, yesterday convicted Louis Schlefler, 49 years old, a lawyer, of extorting $1,500 from Moses Solomon, 74, paralitic head of the Windsor Court Realty Company at 145 Nagel Avenue, Inwood, L.I., under the pretext of "fixing" a pretended income tax investigator.

Tonight's events: Serenade, Museum of Modern Art, 9 o'clock; concert in memory of Ludwig Landshoff, International Center, 341 East Seventeenth Street, 8:30; Marguerite Le Blanc, soprano, assisted by Nina Dunkel, harp, Barbizon Recital Hall, 8:30; Apollo Club of Brooklyn, Brooklyn Academy.

A new issue of $5,000,000 of notes was announced yesterday by Boston, Mass., for award at noon tomorrow. The issue will be dated April 30 and will be payable on Nov. 4. Bidders are to name the rate of interest.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The Daniel Giraud Elliot Gold Medal was awarded to two naturalists of the American Museum of Natural History tonight by the National Academy of Sciences at its annual dinner-meeting.

Mrs. David Challinor, chairman of the women's general committee of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, announced yesterday that her group had gone over the top in the 1943 Red Cross War Fund campaign. With a quota of $750,000, the committee has raised $1,025,542 toward the city's goal of $12,920,700, she said.

Accelerated war production in the territories served by the North American Company System has resulted in record levels being set by operating subsidiaries, Edward L. Shea, president, told the company's stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

"At last, at last, it has come, the crack-up in enemy ranks," said Herr Goebbels over the radio and the teletype. "The war-weary deluded American people has turned on its warmongering leaders. These last three days, in front of one well-known warmongering newspaper called THE NEW YORK TIMES, popuar demonstrations of an ominous character have been under way.

Meeting yesterday in Mayor La Guardia's office at City Hall, the New York City War Council approved formally the city's program for caring for children whose mothers are employed in war industries. The program, involving an expenditure of about $360,000, of which the city contributes one-third, the State one-third and the parents the remaining third, previously had been approved generally by the Board of Estimate.

Operations of Franklin Simon Co., Inc., during the twelve months ended on Jan. 31 resulted in a profit for the second successive year since 1930, with sales reaching the largest volume in more than ten years, J. Howard Denny, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

Evening-up in the May contract on the New York Cotton Exchange in advance of first-notice day, today, weakened the cotton futures market moderately yesterday in a quiet session. May closed with a net loss of 14 points, while active months from July forward, in demand by trade buyers, ended unchanged to 3 points under Saturday's final quotations.

WINDSOR, Ont., April 26 (Canadian Press) -- Intelligent planContinued on Page tnirty-one Continued From Page Twenty-nine ning and enterprise by Canadian industry and with creative statesmanship will be needed to bring about post-war recovery and expansion of employment, Wallace R. Campbell, president of the Ford Motor Car Company of Canada, Ltd., told shareholders at the annual meeting today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Department store sales in the first three months of 1943 increased 12 per cent over those of the corresponding period of last year, but sales last month were only 7 per cent greater than those of March, 1942, while February sales were 33 per cent above those of February, 1942, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System reported today.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY, in Northern Tunisia, April 26 -- Four badly wounded Americans lay at a roadside collection station today, the victims of shots fired from ambush by German troops who had hidden while their companions waved the white flag of surrender.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today legislation ceding to Panama extensive United States holdings in that country -- an action that President Roosevelt described as desirable to remove conditions "which do not make for confidence and friendship."

CHUNGKING, China, April 26 (AP) -- Major Gen. Claire L. Chennault's Fourteenth United States Air Force announced in a communique today that five to nine Japanese planes were destroyed when a large enemy fighter formation attempted to attack an advanced base in Hunan Province.
STOCKHOLM, April 26 (Reuter) -- -- Swedish indignation at official German approval of Japan's execution of American pilots was voiced in an article in Allehanda today.

The wave of stoppages, now involving 15,000 soft coal miners in three States, spread yesterday as the United Mine Workers, through its international policy committee, prepared for what was expected to be drastic action today in the wage conflict affecting 450,000 miners in the Appalachian region and outlying areas.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names and next of kin of 496 United States soldiers wounded in action in North Africa. In issuing this list the War Department points out that during its preparation it is possible that later information may have been sent to the soldiers' relatives.

MEXICO CITY, April 26 (U.P.) -- President Roosevelt's meeting with President Manuel Avila Camacho created repercussions around the world and secured the framework for even more effective cooperation between Mexico and the United States in war and the peace to follow, Foreign Minister Ezequiel Padilla said tonight.

The authority of Mayor La Guardia to enforce the Federal egg price ceilings by invoking the city's short-weight and short-measures law was challenged by organized food merchants in the Bronx Supreme Court yesterday. At the same time Federal and city authorities arranged to confer this morning on the growing meat shortage, including the difficulties of the kosher shops.
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Grade labeling of canned foods apparently has been abandoned as part of the price and rationing program.

That Maynard Barython Johnson, 38 years old, has the appearance of a typical American may be stated on the authority of Alexander Brook, an artist. Mr. Brook chose Johnson as his model for the inspirational poster captioned "Remember me? I was at Bataan."

Paola Novikova, Russian soprano, made her first appearance in New York last night at Town Hall before a large and appreciative audience, singing a program entirely Italian and Russian, with the exception of two Spanish numbers.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR TRANSPORT COMMAND BASE, Somewhere in Britain, April 26 (U.P.) -- Australia is nice, and a fellow can have a dandy time in Chungking, but there is no place like home to the veterans of the Ferry Division of the United States Air Transport Command.

TORONTO, April 26 -- Lack of cooperation on the part of the Soviet Government was blamed today by Victor Podoski, Polish Consul General and envoy to Canada, in a statement on Moscow's breaking of relations with his government.
LONDON, April 26 (Canadian Press) -- King Haakon of Norway today was left figuratively holding a football trophy because no one qualified to receive it.

Predictions that rationing of milk and milk products was inevitable by the Fall and that a plan of "home-conditioning" to cut use of fuel by one-third would be ready within thirty days were made yesterday at the morning session of the one-day war conference of the American Trade Association Executives at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Russia's severance of diplomatic relations with the Polish Government, coming when Washington was bringing pressure upon Finland to deter her from aiding Germany against Russia, was learned here today "with regret," as an official spokesman for the State Department put it.

DETROIT, Mich., April 26 -- W. S. Bullock, widely known transportation executive, today was named acting general manager of the Detroit Department of Street Railways. He succeeds Fred A. Nolan, who has accepted the post of general manager of the Chicago Surface Lines.

Mrs. Wellington Koo, wife of the Chinese Ambassador to Great Britain, explained yesterday that the sudden withdrawal from sale of her autobiography on the eve of its publication was due to the fact that her husband had been unaware she was writing the book and always had opposed such a project.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 26 (AP) -- The Intrepid, third large aircraft carrier built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company plant since Pearl Harbor, was named today, several hours after she was floated off her graving dock building ways. Mrs. John Howard Hoover, wife of Vice Admiral Hoover, was sponsor.

LONDON, April 26 -- Having won one battle in Parliament recently for equal compensation for war injuries, many women in this country are now preparing themselves for another fight with the government over the terms under which they are to be enlisted in the Home Guard -- an army of nearly two million civilian soldiers trained to defend these islands should the Germans attempt an invasion.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- Vice President Wallace. back from his month's tour of seven Latin-American republics, reported at a press conference today that he found all eager to cooperate "to the utmost" in winning the war, but not fully realizing the difficulties encountered by the United States in providing shipping to supply their vital needs.

N.Y.U.'s unbeaten team maintained its unbroken string of victories in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday, making it four straight by defeating City College, 6 to 5, on Ohio Field. It was the second time the nines had met this season.

NEW DELHI, April 26 (AP) -- The Moslem League approved unanimously tonight a resolution warning the British of "strife sand bloodshed" if it is forced into a federation with the Hindus, religious and political opponents of the Moslems outnumbering the Moslems three to one.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 -- To halt "sharply rising costs to consumers" the regional Office of Price Administration said today that it would "freeze" restaurant prices in the three West Coast States Saturday to the highest charges of the week of April 4 to 10.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 26 (AP) -- Christopher Del Sesto, Rhode Island OPA director, today asked the Narragansett Racing Association to close its parking lots and asked police of Pawtucket and East Providence to ban parking on streets adjacent to the park.
The German Monday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 26 -- The Senate and the Chamber of Deputies met today to elect their officers in anticipation of the reopening of Congress. Its sittings should, according to the Constitution, be resumed May 1, though in practice the President usually delays the new session until the end of the month.

Mayor La Guardia restated yesterday his intention of participating in a labor unity and victory rally next Sunday at the Yankee Stadium as the committee in charge denied that the meeting was "a Communist affair."

The eight-week season of the Stadium Concerts this Summer will open on Thursday evening, June 17, at the Lewisohn Stadium of City College, it was announced last night by Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman. At that time Fritz Reiner and the orchestra will appear on a new demountable stage.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 18 per cent last week, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gain, marking the wind-up of Easter trade, was in comparison with the slower post-Easter period of last year.

BOSTON, April 26 -- Post-war planning within the framework erected in the Atlantic Charter and its four freedoms was advocated tonight by George S. Olive. president of the American Institute of Accountants, at the closing session here of the one-day wartime accounting conference, which will be repeated in other important war-production centers.
CHUNGKING, China, April 26 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

News that the Russian Government has broken off diplomatic relations with the Polish Government-in-Exile will come as a shock to all the United Nations. This is a victory for German propaganda. There can be little doubt that both the Russian and the Polish Governments have fallen into a Nazi trap.

The Chamber of Commerce of the United States, which usually meets in Washington, has brought its thirty-first annual meeting to New York, to find room for 3,000 leaders of enterprise who will assemble today at the Waldorf-Astoria for a three-day session.

CHICAGO, April 26 -- Spreading and local operations furnished a considerable part of the business in wheat futures today on the Board of Trade, prices declining around 1/2 cent a bushel early, but a rally came late in the session and closing trades were 1/8 to 1/4 cent lower

Almost hourly the map of Axis-controlled North Africa grows tinier. A few days ago it was described as about the size of Connecticut. Now it is about the size of Delaware. At the present rate of progress it will be the size of Rhode Island before the week is out. The Allied armies are hitting with the precision of a single machine.
There were some strange touches when a Red Cross nurse decorated for bravery was married yesterday to United States Army Sergeant John J. Curran in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Synchronizing with the publication of his book, "New Frontiers in American Painting" (Hastings House, $5), Samuel M. Kootz, one of the art world's tireless stormy petrels, opened yesterday at the Downtown Gallery, 43 East Fifty-first Street, an exhibition of sixteen paintings, all of which are reproduced between covers in the volume just mentioned.

Mourning and pleas for the victims of Nazi persecution marked the services yesterday in synagogues and temples as Passover, the festival commemorating the deliverance of the Jews from bondage in Egypt, drew to an end.

The gasoline drought that descended on local motorists three weeks ago and has since grown progressively worse found half of the 2,600 service stations in the city closed down over the week-end either because of empty tanks or scant supplies, and dealers yesterday said that they look for no relief for at least another ten or fifteen days.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 26 -- Finland's Foreign Minister, Baron Henrik Ramsay, was the special courier for his government who went to Berlin to sound out the Germans on the latest American suggestion that Finland submit her peace terms to Russia, according to information today.
The Maritime Commission's M. pennant was presented yesterday to two yards in Brooklyn for efficiency in repairing ships.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- To eliminate excessive prices for used washing machines, such as have been charged in many sections of the country since the production of new models, the Office of Price Administration today established dollar-and-cents maximum prices on all sales of used washers by dealers, auctioneers and individuals.

Dr. S. William Singer, David M. Hirsh, Paul Schiff, in 115 Central Park West; Mrs. Jack Butter, James E. Hoffey, in 265 Riverside Dr; Morton Neustadter, in 320 Riverside Dr; Mrs. Alice Weissburger, in 19 W 96th St -- Brown Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, brokers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 26 -- Columbia will make a picture dealing with the Coast Guard. The film, to carry the title "Sub Busters,'' will be produced by Irving Briskin. Malcolm Stuart Boylan will write the screen play.

BALTIMORE, April 26 (AP) -- Harvey Lee Thomas, 21-year-old former naval aircraft inspector at the Glenn L. Martin plant, was sentenced today to serve two years for sabotaging planes at the Martin plant.

News from Tunisia that Lieut. Gen. McNair was wounded in action last Friday is distressing. He is an invaluable soldier. May his recovery be quick and thorough! In the First World War he was the youngest American brigadier general. A West Pointer, he has studied and thought deeply on the art and science of war.

The report of the International Business Machines Corporation and its subsidiaries for the first quarter of this year disclosed yesterday a net profit of $8,206,604 before providing for United States Federal and Canadian income and excess profits taxes.
The Italian Monday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, April 26 -- The War Department said today that General McNair had been "severely but not critically injured."

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- A step to ease the rigid application of regulation restricting wage increases and job changes in a large section of the United States was taken today, when the Labor-Management-Agricultural Committee of the War Manpower Commission unanimously approved a tentative plan to meet some objections made by labor organizations.

The New York State Bankers Association announces that its members will hold the annual election of officers, by mail, beginning May 1. The polls will be closed on May 7. The official slate is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., April 26 -- Four prominent Philadelphians took steps today before the Securities and Exchange Commission to intervene in the proposed corporate simplification of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation and to solicit from preferred stockholders authorizations to represent them in the matter.

RIO DE. JANEIRO, Brazil, April 26 -- Brazilian Foreign Office officials denied today that Brazil would exchange the Brazilian diplomatic staff from Vichy, now interned in Germany, for German spies, interned in Brazil.

NEW CITY, N.Y., April 26 -- A jury was chosen quickly today at the opening session of the trial of Mrs. Helen E. Essex, vice chairman of the Rockland County Republican Committee, accused of perjury in two indictments. The case resulted from her testimony last Summer before the county grand jury that investigated gambling at the order of Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

WITH THE SECOND UNITED STATES ARMY CORPS, in Northern Tunisia, April 26 (U.P.) -- American infantrymen jabbed cautiously at retreating German troops in the rugged hill country southwest of Mateur today after a four-mile advance on Easter Sunday had carried them to a point within twelve miles of that key junction town on the road to Bizerte.

A picture of America today as it can be suggested in music was the motif of Leon Barzin's plan for the National Orchestral Association's closing program of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. America is vast, and it would take many programs to paint the canvas on the proper scale.

At the request of the War Labor Board, bituminous coal operators are now presenting their case before it. They contend that under the Little Steel formula and the President's hold-the-line order there is no excuse for a further increase in soft-coal wages at this time.

ALBANY, April 26 -- Only a few thousand men and women, most of them unemployables, will be thrown out of work on Friday, when all WPA projects in the State will be terminated. Lester W. Herzog, State WPA Administrator, said that the workers have been laid off gradually during recent months and that only 3,000 are still engaged on the approximately 230 up-State projects which will be closed on May 1.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 27 -- German troops attacking suddenly and in force stormed into a Russian-held town on the Lake Ilmen front Monday but were thrown back by Russian counter-attacks with losses of from 800 to 1,000 killed, Russia's midnight communique reported, today.

"Flight for Freedom" has played to 253,578 persons from its opening at the Radio City Music Hall on April 15 through Sunday night for the largest Easter holiday attendance in the theater's history, the management reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced today that ten seniors in high and preparatory schools had won George Westinghouse scholarships, valued at $1,850 each, for study at the Carnegie Institute of Technology's College of Engineering.

That old American custom, "crashing the gate," was the most vivid moment in the overseas career of Coast Guardsman Dominick Vilardi, he related yesterday, although his other adventures included a perilous landing operation on the Algerian coast during the first hours of the American invasion last November.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 26 -- The enemy lost 66,000 men killed, wounded and captured; 250 tanks and more than 1,700 planes in the North African fighting between Jan. 1 and April 15, according to figures released today by General Dwight D. Eisenhower's headquarters.

The opposition to Michael J. Kennedy Jr. as leader of Tammany Hall received a set-back yesterday when Assemblyman Patrick H. Sullivan, leader of the Eleventh Assembly District, announced that he was not a member of the group opposing Mr. Kennedy, and that instead, as a Tammany district leader, he intended to support Mr. Kennedy and his policies.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 26 (AP) -- A communique:

New York City's competitive production position in the dress industry with regard to garment centers in other areas should not be injured by the 7 per cent increase granted to wage earners in the metropolitan area by the War Labor Board, at least during the war, in the opinion of employers and labor spokesmen expressed yesterday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 (AP) -- They're running a preview of Saturday's Kentucky Derby tomorrow in two sections.

The United Telephone Organizations, an independent union of employes of the New York Telephone Company, issued a statement yesterday attacking the decision of the War Labor Board last Friday reducing a referee's award of a general increase of $3.60 a week under the Little Steel formula to $2 a week as "unfair and arbitrary" and as a class-conscious action in the interest of stockholders.

To win the war we must have high-octane gasoline for our fighting planes. And to win the war we must have rubber; our Army rolls on it. It is clear, therefore, that the conflict now in progress in Washington over certain critical materials, equipment and instruments which are essential to the production of both high-octane gasoline and synthetic rubber must be settled by a compromise.

In their very interesting and illuminating article in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of April 4 Mr. Hoover and Mr. Gibson make certain remarks about the League of Nations and its activities which need a supplement.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today the award of 134 decorations to officers and enlisted men of the Ninth United States Army Air Force for outstanding aerial achievements in the Middle East theatre of operations.

PITTSBURGH, April 26 -- The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company announced today that ten seniors in high and preparatory schools had won George Westinghouse scholarships, valued at $1,850 each, for study at the Carnegie Institute of Technology's College of Engineering.

Day after tomorrow will see the liquidation of the Work Projects Administration in New York. At its peak in 1936 WPA had 360,000 persons on its rolls in the State, of whom more than 240,000 were in New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -Negro tenants will occupy about 88,000 public housing units, representing 12 per cent of a total of 744,000 dwellings, and developed at a cost of more than $360,000,000 when the current public housing program is completed, Herbert Emmerich, Commissioner of the Federal Public Housing Authority, announced.

The remarks of Lieut. Gen. Somervell at the Chamber of Commerce meeting in this city yesterday make it clear that the time has not yet come when this country can safely divert a larger pat of its production from war work to civilian goods. There has been much pressure recently in favor of such a shift, on the theory that the Army and the Navy have overreached themselves.

CHICAGO, April 27 (AP) -- The so-called "dead" ball came back to lead a "double" life today as the Indians pounded five two-baggers, including two apiece by Manager Lou Boudreau and Otto Denning, to spoil the White Sox's home opener, 4 to 2.

SWEETWATER, Texas, April 27 -- Women fliers by the hundreds are threading the sky of West Texas in the Army's new program to prepare them for war service. There will be thousands of women in the program which the Army is supervising for the first time.

Because such current productions as "Flying Tigers," "Icecapades Revue" and "Hit Parade of 1943" have "contributed to the largest gross ever enjoyed by Republic during its seven years in the industry," the company has set its 1943-44 production appropriation at $16,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

Almost alone in its abstinence, New York City continues to observe its meatless Tuesday, although Mayor La Guardia, lifting his decree of last October just as meat rationing became effective this month, said meatless Tuesday would be optional for thirty days or longer.

Tonight's events: Donald Dame, tenor, assisted by New York String Quartet and Edith Weiss-Mann, harpsichord, Town Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Eda Rapoport, recital of her compositions, by Stefan Sopkin and Theodore Katz, violin; Selig Posner, viola; Leo Rostal, 'cello; Mary Frances Lehnerts, soprano; Milton Kaye and Miss Rapoport, piano; Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- The problems of manpower and materials occupied the attention of members of the National Association of Broadcasters at their war conference here today. Lawrence A. Appley, executive director of the War Manpower Commission, told the broadcasters that all reserves are gone and that vast supplies of labor must be developed to enable the military services and industry to reach their personnel objectives as set for the end of the year.

The Council on Books in Wartime will announce next week the selection of Wendell L. Willkie's book "One World," published by Simon Shuster, as the third "imperative" book chosen by its War Book Panel. Other books were W.L. White's "They Were Expendable," published by Harcourt, Brace last September, and John Hersey's recent "Into the Valley," a knopf book. "One World" has sold nearly 750,000 copies in only two weeks.

The report of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and wholly owned subsidiaries, issued yesterday by Carle C. Conway, chairman of the hoard, disclosed net earnings of $5,041,180 for the twelve months ended March 31, after deducting $9,783,888 for depreciation and estimated income and excess profits taxes.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A "shelf" of reserve Federal public works projects calling for the expenditure of $7,695,000,000 which could be used as a post-war buffer against economic recession was reported today by the National Resources Planning Board to be available.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 27 -- Dusty columns of British infantry drove a salient down the Medjerda Valley yesterday to a point twenty-three miles from Tunis as French and British infantry, with strong forces of Churchill tanks, closed in on Pont du Fahs, the vital enemy communications center in the southern sector.

In order go end diversion of the limited civilian supply of candy-bars and chewing gum to black market operators, who were said to be using the limited wartime supply of nationally known products to force the sale of inferior brands at excessive prices, the OPA may be asked to establish price ceilings for all confectionery products at the wholesale distributors' level, it was learned here yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- There was little in the trading today in wheat futures that attracted attention. Hedging sales and operations by mills were limited and professional traders continued to await the April 30 deadline when government loans on cash grain in elevators will mature.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, April 27 -- The Swedish military authorities are paying close attention to the presence of three high German officials near the Swedish border just west of Storlien. The Germans are Josef Terboven, Governor of Norway; General Nikolaus von Falkenhorst, in command of the German forces of occupation, and the Gestapo chief, Wilhelm Rediess.
LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

I am in receipt of a folder from the Department of Agriculture entitled "April Jobs." On the second page is the sentence, "The canning budget is fifty quarts of vegetables and thirty-five quarts of fruit to each member of the family."

ALGIERS, April 27 -- Negotiations for the union of all Frenchmen outside France were renewed today when General Henri Honore Giraud met General Georges Catroux and handed him a reply to the proposals made by the French National Committee.
The New Jersey Council has received a few entries for the Governor Edison fishing tourney, and one of them looms as a record.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, denied before the Truman Investigating Committee today, that allocations of critical materials to the synthetic rubber program in December entailed such shortages of aviation gasoline as to threaten the impending air offensive against the Axis, as charged recently by Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War.

The present scale of food production in the United States is inadequate to meet demands and one bad season resulting in a low-yield year will produce an unprecedented food crisis, according to speakers at a special session on "Agriculture in the Year Ahead" held in connection with the annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -- Rookie Jesse Flores today hurled the Athletics to a 2-1 victory over the Senators in a sixteen-inning marathon.

LONDON, April 27 -- Italy was brought under unprecedented aerial bombardment yesterday as Flying Fortresses made their longest flight from North Africa to bomb the unscarred Grosseto airfield eighty miles northwest of Rome and American Liberators from the Middle East devastated the Bari airdrome, on the Southern Adriatic, with 125 tons of explosives.

Relief for retail furriers and retail manufacturing furriers from MPR 178 has been requested from the OPA by the Retail Furriers Emergency Committee, sponsored by the Retail Manufacturing Furriers of America, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Charles Gold, counsel for the committee.

The first War Production Board directive to standardize models in the leather industry for civilian use will be issued shortly on luggage, it was disclosed last night at a meeting of the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America at the Hotel New Yorker.

A comprehensive view of Summer fashions was presented yesterday at the luncheon hour on the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis Hotel. The occasion was a benefit for the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery and the Spence Adoption Nursery. Six of New York's uptown stores participated, each exhibiting eight models.

Lulu Costantino, East Side, scored easily over Mario (Chico) Morales of Havana in the eight-round main bout at the Broadway Arena last night. Costantino had a seven and three-quarter-pound advantage over the Cuban, who weighed 123.

LONDON, April 27 -- Britain's mighty four-engined bombers showered thirty tons of bombs a minute on Duisburg, Europe's greatest inland port, for forty-five minutes last night in a raid that compared with the 1,000-plane attack on Cologne last May, the Air Ministry news service said tonight.
LONDON, April 27 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
The principal portions of the addresses made yesterday before the United States Chamber of Commerce follow:
LONDON, April 27 -- The stock markets here were generally a little subdued today by the news of the Russo-Polish rift.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A directive will be issued late this week changing the name of the Office of Civilian Supply to "Office of Civilian Requirements" and investing Arthur D. Whiteside, new War Production Board vice chairman in charge of the office, with complete authority to obtain information from all industrial divisions within the WPB.

BOSTON, April 27 -- Governor Leverett Saltonstall must have put what is inelegantly known as the "whammy" on the Yankees when he tossed out the first ball to open the American League baseball season at Fenway Park today.

OF recent years Earle (Greasy) Neale has built such a reputation as a football coach that most sports followers have quite forgotten that the Gray Fox of Philadelphia was a pretty good baseball player in his day. Good enough to last eight years in the National League, to be specific.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, April 28 (U.P.) -- An Allied heavy bomber scored a direct hit on a 4,000-ton Japanese cargo vessel in the Arafura Sea yesterday, it was announced today.

Bellevue had its one morning of unbridled joy for the year yesterday. For the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus made its forty-second annual visit to the "Circus Square" on Twenty-sixth Street, just opposite the East River.

CARACAS, Venezuela, April 27 -- President Isaias Medina Angarita in his annual message told Congress today that Venezuela had ended the fiscal year with a budget surplus of more than 5,000,000 bolivares. He gave revenues as 325,287,387 bolivares and expenditures as 320,121,932 bolivares.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The fact, well known in Washington, that the armed services are disposed to lay the blame for their supply difficulties on every doorstep but their own was soundly documented before the Truman committee today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 27 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler is asking France for more men, it was revealed here today. There were no details, which is to say that it has not yet been decided how the pill will be gilded this time.

LONDON, April 27 -- The Fighting French ranks in London have been swelled by five well-known Frenchmen who escaped from France and arrived here together, according to an announcement tonight by the Fighting French headquarters.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Reaffirming the right of securities having no current equity in a concern to share in a redistribution of voting power, the Securities and Exchange Commission gave approval today to an amended plan to revamp the capital structure of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company.

John Principe made his first start of the season a winning one for N.Y.U. yesterday against Hofstra at Ohio Field and thereby stretched the unbeaten Violets' streak to five in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference. The score was 4 -- 3.

Following is the letter addressed yesterday to Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, by International Policy Committee of the United Mine Workers, dealing with the wage crisis in the bituminous coal industry:

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- A range of subjects, covering both food and other agricultural products such as raw materials which go into clothing, tobacco and other materials, will be considered from many angles by the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture, according to the official agenda made public today at the State Department.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- The Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America was charged here today with refusing to renounce a tradition of pacificism and actively further the war effort, by officials of a newly formed organization seeking national leadership in the field of Protestant theology.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- While Axis air raids on the East or West Coasts were possible, the possibility was remote, Navy Secretary Frank Knox said at a press conference today when asked if the Japanese could use the bases they are constructing in the Aleutians for an attack on the Pacific seaboard.

Mrs. Boris G. Orlove Jr., retiring chairman of the Manhattan War Savings Staff of the American Women's Voluntary Services, was honored at a tea given yesterday by Mrs. Edgar W. Leonard, Greater New York Chairman of the A.W.V.S., in her home at 142 East Sixty-second Street. Mrs. Irving B. Le Vine will succeed Mrs. Orlove as head of the War Savings Staff.

The first open move by supporters of Thomas E. Dewey to block the renomination of Wendell L. Willkie for President in 1944 by the Republican party came last night in the form of a speech by Thomas J. Curran, New York County Republican Chairman, in accepting re-election as president of the National Republican Club.

LONDON, April 27 -- Determination, if not downright optimism, characterized the efforts today to effect a reconciliation between the Soviet Government and the Polish Government here. There were several hopeful signs. The first was that the United States seemed to be taking a direct part in the negotiations for a resumption of normal relations between the two members of the United Nations.

The Postoffice Department, on recommendation of Attorney General Biddle, has withdrawn second class mailing privileges from The Militant, an organ of the tiny Communist splinter known as the Socialist Workers' Party. It is difficult to sympathize with The Militant editors, who admittedly do not approve of the present war.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 -- While authorities stood by helplessly, watching with growing concern the appalling loss of coal tonnage needed by war industries, the wave of wildcat strikes continued to spread today through the Western Pennsylvania bituminous fields miners threw their support behind John L. Lewis in his battle with the War Labor Board.

CHUNGKING, April 27 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have captured Linhsien, Chinese mountaintop stronghold on the eastern side of the Taihang range in Northern Honan Province, and have made new gains in Shansi, west of the mountains, the Chinese High Command reported tonight.

Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding the Army Service Forces of the United States, revealed here yesterday that the armies of our Allies will not be equipped with their capital needs until the end of this year, and that our own Army "will not be so equipped until late in 1944."

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Nazi regime is looting occupied Europe by taking to Germany its machinery, war materials, art objects and even garden tools and door hinges, while taking over whole industries, at the rate of "tens of billions of dollars a year," the Board of Economic Warfare asserted today in a summary of the plunder of the Hitler conquest to date.

Pierpont V. Davis, chairman of the Manhattan finance section of the New York Fund, announced yesterday the following list of chairmen of the twelve finance and insurance divisions of the Fund, organized to enlist support in Manhattan for the fund's sixth annual campaign:

Fourteen members of the House Ways and Means Committee voted yesterday to recommend the continuance of the reciprocal trade agreements program in its present form. The bill now goes to the House, where opposition threatens it. In the Senate forty members polled last week by The Associated Press were found to be in favor of continuance for another three years, with only nineteen definitely opposed and thirty-seven noncommittal or not reached for comment.

Reporting on operating results of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana in 1942, Edward G. Seubert, president, informed its 96,000 stockholders yesterday that the company and its subsidiaries are completing or have under construction manufacturing facilities estimated to cost upward of $55,000,000, which will contribute directly to the war effort.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday for the first three months of this year a consolidated net income of $15,406,597 after all charges, taxes and a reserve of $6,000,000 for contingencies. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.04 each on the 8,703,252 common shares outstanding.
The Giants cut a luscious birthday cake for Horace Stoneham yesterday, and even if there was a little too much frosting the performance proved an artistic success.

A "victory" line of women's undergarments and sleeping garments is likely to result from the present scarcity of fabrics which will become acute during the last half of this year, it was predicted yesterday at a special meeting of the National Women's Undergarment Manufacturers Association, Inc., in the Hotel McAlpin.

As fresh war bond purchases of $27,000,000 brought the Second War Loan total for investors other than the commercial banks to $3,912,000,000 in the Second Federal Reserve District yesterday, Treasury officials in Washington expressed confidence that the national goal of $13,000,000,000 would be passed today.
The German Tuesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

JERSEY CITY, April 27 (AP) -- Rochester snapped Jersey City's winning streak at three in a row today, defeating the Little Giants, 8 to 2. The Red Wings picked on a trio of Jersey hurlers for nine hits, tagging Rube Fischer, who started and was charged with the defeat, for four hits and three runs over the first six innings.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, April 27 -- Miracles of production by American industry to meet the needs of global warfare were described tonight by Harold V. Coes, president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, speaking at the annual dinner of the society.

The fifth of the "Serenades" of rare music, ancient and modern, which have been given at the Museum of Modern Art, took place last night, with works on the program by Marcello and Vivaldi of the eighteenth century and Poulenc and Stravinsky of the twentieth.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The War Production Board today, acting at the request of the War Food Administration, assured can supplies sufficient to insure the packing of thirteen additional food products in cans this year. Through an amendment on Conservation Order M-81, WPB expects to facilitate consumption of stocks of cans and tinplate and to obtain a maximum food pack during this year.

W. Gibson Carey Jr., president of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce and member of the directorate of a number of corporations, was elected yesterday a vestryman in the parish of Trinity Church.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday numbered 690, which equaled the figure reported in the preceding week and compared with 753 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered the International Utilities Corporation today to terminate its existence because it unnecessarily complicated the structure of its holding company system.

Post-war advertisers will have to appeal to a market of women who through war work have acquired a knowledge of manufacturing processes and of product quality and through rationing and shortages have learned to do comparative shopping, Arthur Hirose, director of promotion and market research for McCall's and Redbook magazines, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Associated Printing Salesmen at the Hotel Piccadilly.
SOMEWHERE IN IRAN -- American war material is reaching Russia by way of the Persian corridor faster than the Russians can take it. Their warehouses and freight yards are glutted.
The Italian Tuesday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The smallest field at Jamaica yesterday produced the biggest upset when Royal Nap, paying $14.80 for $2, won by a neck from Bill Sickle, the 2-to-5 favorite. A crowd of 16,005 saw the neck-and-neck battle through the stretch decided in the last twenty yards when Warren Mehrtens threw enough into the drive to decide the six-furlong dash.

The first public hearing in the State Labor Department's effort to combat discrimination by employment agencies because of a job applicant's color or religion or national-origin was held yesterday before Acting State Industrial Commissioner Michael Murphy in the State Office Building, 80 Center Street.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Korean National Font Federation announced today that it had received reports from its agents stating that Premier Hideki Tojo of Japan had already selected the leaders of the invasion forces that he planned to send against the United States.

ST. LOUIS, April 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals found their batting eyes in the more friendly confines of Sportsman's Park today and, despite the dead ball, hammered out a 7-to-0 victory for Morton Cooper over the Cubs.

A new issue of $3,000,000 of pavement and funding bonds was scheduled yesterday by Rochester, N.Y., for award on Tuesday. The issue will be dated May 15, 1943, and will mature on May 15, 1944 to 1949. The interest rate is to be stipulate, by the bidders.

The report of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income after all expenses, taxes and other charges, of $29,867,468. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.65 a share on the company's outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $32,693,453, or $1.90 a common share, in the twelve months to March 31, 1942.

ALBANY, April 27 -- Federal and State agencies, in a joint move against "black markets" in meat in New York, have agreed to exchange information on violators, according to an announcement today by Senator Thomas C. Desmond, who is chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Nutrition.

The establishment of contract adjustment boards to facilitate the return of the nation's manufacturing industry to peacetime production as quickly as possible after the war was urged yesterday by Brig. Gen. John Ross Delafield, U.S.A., retired, speaker at a session on war contracts at the war council meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

MOSCOW, April 27 (UP) -- Russia has suspended and not broken relations with Poland and has left it up to the Poles whether there shall be a resumption of normal diplomatic intercourse or a full break, it was made known today.

The projected visit of Prime Minister Smuts to the United States is bound to stimulate interest in South Africa's contribution to the Allied cause. In proportion to its resources none of the free nations of the British Commonwealth has made a more gallant effort to speed the day of victory.

An investing client of O'Connell Butler, lawyers, has bought from the Bankers Trust Company the thirteen-story apartment building with stores at 174-76 West Eighty-seventh Street, at the southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue.
CHUNGKING, China, April 27 (U.P.) -- A communique:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, April 27 (AP) -- The Uruguayan Cabinet gave final approval today to a $20,000,000 loan negotiated in January by Vice President Alberto Guani with the Export-Import Bank of Washington for a public works program in Uruguay.
