Stockholders of the International Business Machines Corporation were informed at their annual meeting yesterday that the company would have an estimated $6,000,000 in cash reserves and tax credits at the end of the war to effect readjustments and resume normal operations.

By its action yesterday in issuing a call for bids on 242,664 common shares of the Houston Lighting and Power Company, the National Power and Light Company moves a step closer to complete liquidation in conformance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

George Warren Wong, 20-year-old Chinese-American engineering student, who lives at 63 Bayard Street, has been named by Representative Samuel Diekstein as first alternate appointee to the Military Academy at West Point, the first Chinese to receive the honor, Mr. Dickstein said yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 27 (AP) -- A communique:

ABOARD THE AIRCRAFT CARRIER INDOMITABLE, at Sea (Delayed) -- A proud and powerful symbol of searoving air might this great gray vessel made L her public bow today as the youngest queen -- but already a veteran -among Great Britain's flattops.

Representatives of official associations of the city's Police and Fire Departments announced last night that their members were seeking to obtain 600,000 signatures of registered voters on a petition demanding a $450 yearly cost-of-living bonus for members of both departments for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Dr. George W. Taylor, vice chairman of the War Labor Board apprised tonight of the stand taken by John L. Lewis as to continuance of work in the soft coal mines after Friday midnight, said that the new development would be the first business on the board's agenda tomorrow morning. The news came after the board had adjourned for the day.

Impulsiveness is not a characteristic of Soviet policy. Otherwise the abrupt break with the Polish Government-in-Exile might be attributed to a fit of temper. This is what the undiplomatic note suspending relations with the Poles sounded like; it fairly sizzled with anger and bitterness.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Flying through what Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, described as "bad and rotten" weather, American airmen attacked Kiska thirteen times on Sunday and swept down also on Attu, another Aleutian island where the Japanese are developing bases for land plane operations.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The United Nations had a net loss of nearly 1,000,000 gross tons of shipping at the hands of the Axis in 1942, the Navy said today in a statement to clear up differences between Secretary Knox and the Senate Truman committee. Mr. Knox said Friday that the Truman committee was incorrect in statements that German submarines were sinking 1,000,000 tons monthly.

Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123, against which there has been a widespread taxpayers' protest, was approved unanimously by the Board of Estimate yesterday. Adoption of a few minor changes did not alter the total.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Lippy Leo Durocher's Dodgers today backed into a victory over the Phillies because the young men for whom Bill Cox roots so enthusiastically were more inept than their opponents.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Civilian defense helmets may be manufactured and sold only to fill purchase orders from the United States Government or the government of any of the United Nations, under terms of General Limitation Order L-105, as amended today by the War Production Board.

A five-point program, including ceilings on livestock with subsidies to the farmers, was drafted for submission to Washington by Federal, city and food trade representatives at a conference on the meat shortage here yesterday. The proposals will be laid before the Office of Price Administration today.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 27 -- It was learned from a diplomatic quarter here late tonight that Finland, at the instigation of the United States, made "unofficial feelers" through the Swedish Government on April 4 for the communication of Soviet peace terms.

Judicial approval of a plan to ease payment of the principal of a $50,000,000 bond issue falling due May 1 was sought in Federal court here yesterday by the Delaware Hudson Company and the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation.

While American campus customs are not very different from university life in the Soviet Union, academic curriculums and methods in the two nations are quite another matter, according to three Russian students who have been studying at Columbia University for the last eight months.

The reciprocal trade agreements program is but a "step in the right direction" to meet the probable post-war situation and the United States may have to make considerable "sacrifices" in its tariff schedules as a matter of "peace insurance," G. Hilmer Lundbeck Jr., vice managing director of the Swedish American Line, declared yesterday.

Terms of the settlement agreed upon by the principal parties in the $5,000,000 suit by the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation and a group of its minority stockholders against Alfred J. and Ignacio J. Miranda, F. William Zelcer, the Brewster Export Corporation and others, were presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein for approval.

THE celebrated dualism of the German character has fascinated and baffled Germans as well as the rest of the world for centuries. That so able and so superficially civilized a people, so clean, so neat, so industrious, so gifted in music, science, medicine and industry, should glory in non-civilized behavior is one of the world's most sinister paradoxes.

A sequel to "Desert Victory," official film record of the British Eighth Army's victory over the vaunted Africa Corps of Marshal Rommel in the Libyan desert, is being shot now on the battlefield in Tunisia, it was disclosed yesterday by Lieut. Col. David MacDonald, chief of the British Army Film and Photographic Unit which made the current document.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 27 (U.P.) -- Governor Stassen of Minnesota resigned today to go on active duty as a lieutenant commander in the Navy.
NEW DELHI, India, April 27 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

Headed by one woman who has given 2,481 hours of service as a volunteer nurses' aide in the last eighteen months, 1,146 nurses' aides received service stripes for the work they have done in the hospitals and health institutions of the city, at a rally under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross held in Manhattan Center last night.

Benjamin Gollay, attorney for the Midtown Business and Professional Women's Club in its suit against the New York State Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs over the inclusion of Negroes, announced yesterday that the federation had reconsidered and accepted the Midtown club into membership.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Extension of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act for another three years was approved today by the Ways and Means Committee, 14 to 11. The close party vote and one Democratic defection were sufficient to indicate a hard fight on the House floor and only slim chances for the measure's passage without crippling amendment.

Beaten, cornered and thrown on the defensive on the military front, Hitler has displayed an often underestimated versatility by opening up a Spring offensive on another front -- the propaganda front. It is the only front on which he can still move freely, and it is on this front that he is now concentrating in the frantic effort to stave off defeat.

In Chicago today the 175th anniversary of the founding of the Encyclopaedia Britannica will be commemorated by an exhibition illustrating the history of that work and the succession of encyclopedias from Pliny the Elder's "Natural History" to the present. In some respects Pliny is our favorite encyclopedist.

Several of the exhibitions opening this week have been arranged as benefits for various war relief activities. This afternoon one of the exhibitions, consisting of work by some fifty contemporary artists, will open at the headquarters of the Friends of Greece, Inc., 52 East Fifty-seventh Street.

" The First Million," a comedy by Corporal Irving Elman, will open tonight at the Ritz. Jimmy Elliott, a 19-year-old actor in the cast of "Junior Miss," is the producer, making his Broadway debut as such. The comedy has an Ozark setting.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) -More than fifty mines were shut down today in the spread of a strike that held the possibility of halting production of soft coal by Saturday.

NEW DELHI, India, April 27 (AP) -- Consolidated heavy bombers of the Tenth United States Army Air Force struck the Thilawa oil refinery south of Rangoon yesterday and scored many direct hits on installations around the distillation plant and among storage tanks, today's United States communique said. One large tank exploded violently and caused a fire from which smoke was visible for forty miles.

Manipulations in the rayon gray goods market, said to have cost the consuming public between $500,000 and $1,000,000, were attributed to twenty-nine concerns and forty-two individuals yesterday by the office of United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa.

City firemen will be relieved of one tour of "V-duty," a voluntary system under which they have been contributing one extra tour of duty a week, under the terms of a change in the system authorized yesterday by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh.

" Crash Dive," a drama of the Navy's "pigboats" produced in technicolor by Twentieth Century-Fox, will be presented this morning at the Roxy. This is the last film made by Tyrone Power before he entered the Marine Corps. The cast of featured players includes Anne Baxter, Dana Andrews, James Gleason, Dame May Whitty and Charles Grapewin.

NEWARK, April 27 (AP) -- Ken Holcombe, 25-year-old right-hander of the Bears, bested the veteran Mike Roscoe in a tense mound duel today for a 2-1 decision over Buffalo and his second victory of the season.

CHICAGO, April 27 -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, at a news conference prior to giving an off-the-record talk before the National Association of Broadcasters war conference, replied to a Chicago Tribune editorial which charged that OWI is a haven for draft dodgers and Communists.

The Czechoslovak Information Bureau, 1790 Broadway, announced yesterday that it had every reason to believe that Mme. Franciska Plaminkova, formerly a Senator in the Parliament of her country and who has been imprisoned for some time because of her refusal to collaborate with the Nazis, had been executed recently by her captors.
PITTSBURGH, April 27 (AP) -- Runs produced by three pinch-hitters gave Pittsburgh a 4-1 victory over Cincinnati today in the Forbes Field opener before 11,937 fans.

LONDON, April 27 -- The so-called Anglo-American Legion, formation of which was announced last month, will not begin to function for at least another week, and then probably not under that name, it was learned today.

The stock market slipped off balance slightly yesterday as interest continued to diminish and prices on the Stock Exchange held in the narrow range of the last week. Spotty labor unrest throughout the nation, particularly the clash between Washington and the United Mine Workers' president, John L. Lewis, was seen by brokers as a more important factor than previously in the drying up of investment demand, particularly in the heavy industrial issues.

IRVINGTON, N.J., April 27 -- A work stoppage of the 618 production employes of Gould Elberhardt Co. at 433 Fabyan Place here halted war production at the plant today. The employes are members of Local 571, International Association of Machinists, A.F. of L. The plant makes vital machinery.

Spokesmen for the Ways and Means majority say that if the Senate passes the new tax measure by May 15 the Treasury will be able to put the withholding tax into effect on July 1. This seems like an attempt to place on the Senate the blame for any failure to meet this May 15 deadline.
Ernie Lombardi, ponderous catcher and National League batting champion last year as well as in 1938, will do his receiving this year for the Giants.

Combined net earnings of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation for the three months ended with March amounted to $3,095,188, equal to 85 cents a common share after dividends on the preference stock, Arthur O. Dietz, president, advised shareholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

Thomas J. Hargrave, president of the Eastman Kodak Company, reported to stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting held in Jersey City, an increase of 34 per cent in the March quarter volume of business transacted by the company and its subsidiaries situated in the Western Hemisphere, over the corresponding three months of last year.

The Viceroy's refusal to grant William Phillips, President Roosevelt's special envoy to India, permission to see Gandhi and Nehru before returning to submit his report to his chief will inevitably destroy the lingering hope for a political settlement that has persisted in spite of many repeated setbacks.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 27 (AP) -- A forecast that improved airplane and equipment models would be made this year, requiring difficult changes in plant, was given today to stockholders of the United Aircraft Corporation by Eugene E. Wilson, president.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 27 -- J. Owen Grundy of this city, who with John R. Longo, recently dismissed deputy clerk of Hudson County, was indicted a week ago on charges of "fraudulent alteration of election records," pleaded guilty today before Common Pleas Judge Thomas H. Brown.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 27 (AP) -- Declaring that steel production could not be increased but might be retarded by setting up an arbitrary 48-hour work week, Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, today opposed proposals to extend the 48-hour week throughout the steel industry, requiring time and a half pay for the hours in excess of forty.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Four-fifths of the men to be summoned to active duty in the Navy V-12 college program on July 1 will be inactive reservists already in colleges or universities and these will be allowed to finish additional terms of instruction in existing academic programs, the Navy Department said today.

The increasingly difficult problem of mobilizing 5,000,000 workers for war industries by the end of 1943 must be me by voluntary action by all classes, and the workers must be drawn from the ranks of housewives, students, older workers, handicapped workers, minority groups and workers transferred from less essential industries, Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, told members of the National Chamber War Council meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The War Labor Board by a vote of 7 to 4, industry members dissenting, decided today to ask James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, to authorize an interpretation of the President's "hold the line" order of April 8 to permit wage increases in some types of cases.

Cottage cheese, which does not require the expenditure of any valuable ration points, is useful in assembling main dishes that may occasionally take the place of meat and fish. Here you will see how favorably its protein content compares with that of other foods.
EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 27 -- Violence broke out tonight for the first time at the Bendix Aviation Corporation plant here as the strike of part of the production employes entered its third week.

BOSTON, April 27 (AP) -- Eighteen representatives of organized labor issued tonight a statement defending Russia's execution of two Polish labor leaders, Henryk Erlich and Victor Alter, and declaring "a traitor in any nation is a traitor to the whole United Nations."
LONDON, April 27 -- The outlook is good for a bounteous yield from British farms, although disastrous May frosts are always possible.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Office of Price Administration intends to fix gross profit margins for wholesale and retail whisky dealers and set flat prices for "new" brands of liquors, it made known today, as part of a campaign against what officials called "a black market" in diminishing supplies of beverage spirits.

LONDON, Wednesday, April 28 (U.P.) -- Russian planes, field guns and trench mortars attacked German fortifications, communications and airdromes throughout yesterday in selected sectors from the Kuban to the Volkhov River front south of Leningrad, a Soviet communique reported today.

TRENTON, N.J., April 27 (AP) -- Detective Captain Thomas A. Cooney said today three men, one of whom he identified as a former executive assistant in the State OPA organization, were under arrest on burglary charges in connection with an attempt made last night to open the safe in the Trenton War Price and Rationing Board office at 630 East State street.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 -- Ocean Wave rolled around Churchill Downs's muddy racing strip like the Johnstown flood today -- and for the first time even the mighty Count Fleet was threatened by the undertow.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, April 28 (AP) -- The noon communique:
I have discussed the Soviet-Polish problem with competent authorities here and their views can be summarized as follows:

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, April 27 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, Allied air commander in the Southwest Pacific, pinned medals today on the crew of a Liberator bomber piloted by Captain Charles P. Whitlock of New Brunswick, N.J., a former university lecturer.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- The Bermuda conference on refugees was defended against charges by Philip Murray, president of the C.I.O., by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, in a letter to the union chief made public today.

WASHINGTON, April 27 -- Clifford J. Durr, Federal Communications Commissioner, has been asked by the Cox committee appointed to investigate the commission to "reconsider" his refusal to reply to its questionnaire and to furnish without delay the desired information as to his financial affairs, "failing which appropriate procedure to bring about that end will be instituted."

With the local gasoline shortage growing steadily worse, 250 more service station operators were reported to have posted "no gas" signs on their tanks yesterday, making the total of day stations 750. In the meantime, farmers in New Jersey's western agricultural counties were expressing alarm over a delay in Spring planting attributable to the gasoline shortage, which has left them without fuel for operating power equipment.

NEW DELHI, India, April 27 -- The annual session of the All-India Moslem League closed at 3 o'clock this morning after adopting the strongest and gravest resolution in its thirty-year history. The British have been challenged in terms that one speaker termed "revolutionary."

ALGIERS, April 27 -- Vice Admiral Emile Henri Muselier, under whose direction the formidable land and sea defenses of the French naval base at Bizerte were constructed, is expected to arrive in Algiers soon to place his services at the disposal of the General Henri Honore Giraud Government, it was learned today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 27 -- Reviving its "Broadway Melody" type of picture, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is planning to go into production next month with a musical, under the title "Up and Down Broadway," in which Eleanor Powell and George Murphy again will be teamed.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 27 (AP) -Berlin spokesmen smiled at press conferences today and on behalf of Nazi Germany willingly accepted credit for the rift in Russian-Polish relations, it was reported here tonight.

MOSCOW, April 27 -- Tadeusz Romer, Polish Ambassador to the U.S.S.R., is expected to go to Kuybyshev at the earliest opportunity to arrange for the departure from the Soviet Union of the Polish Embassy's large staff.

A phenomenon calculated to make an OPA inspector blink occurred yesterday when the market price of shad dropped by more than half, following record catches of the fish in the Hudson River in the last two days.
WASHINGTON, April 27 -- House Republicans have called a party caucas for 10 A.M. on Monday, the day members return from their Easter recess to start the pay-as-you-go tax debate.

After allowing $7,655,259 for a post-war rehabilitation fund and $28,404,000 for adjustments in connection with renegotiation of contracts, the General Motors Corporation on the basis of the 1942 Revenue Act had a net profit of $33,074,031 for the first quarter of 1943, against $23,229,991 for the same 1942 quarter, according to the report of Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president, released yesterday.

LONDON, April 27 (U.P.) -- The London radio told of reports from European neutral capitals that German reinforcements and train loads of materiel were still pouring into Bulgaria. Execution of many Bulgarian patriots by the Nazis was reported.

With uncertainty still clouding the details of the contemplated sale of the government's stocks of cotton to help curb price rises, traders in cotton futures yesterday continued to pursue a course of caution, reducing their business until the effects of the projected stabilization program can be determined. Under light volume and offerings active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange broke a three-day decline in closing 4 to 12 points above Monday's final quotations.

Saints and angels carved and painted generations ago by untaught but devout folk artists of the Southwest comprise an Easter Week exhibition opened yesterday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. This primitive art flourished in the American Southwest from the early days of the Spanish settlement until late in the nineteenth century when cheap religious prints and mass production plaster figures of saints became available.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, announced yesterday that in the absence of new contracts with operators of the Northern and Southern Appalachian regions the entire soft coal industry of the United States, employing 450,000 miners, would come to a standstill at midnight Friday.

Establishment in war industries of "selective service relations departments" to avoid further loss of engineers and other employes considered indispensable to production was proposed yesterday by Dr. Albert B. Newman, regional adviser of the United States Office of Education.

America has become the world's center of learning, but her preeminent position as an educative force is being jeopardized by the insecurity of her teachers and the hindrances thrown in the way of objective scholarship, Dr. Theophile J. Meek, president of the American Oriental Society, told the opening session of the 155th meeting of the society at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Congress has a very bad record in tariff legislation because of the selfish nature of the subject. Once posed, the issue of the tariff always and instantly produce pressure groups seeking various advantages. Divided, none of the blocs can be sure of getting its share of the spoils.

Despite the action of the War Labor Board in Washington yesterday referring the coal wage dispute to President Roosevelt, John L. Lewis stood pat on the statement that the bituminous coal industry would be paralyzed in the absence of new agreements by midnight tomorrow, upon expiration of existing contracts.

A review of United States production was presented by Federal administrators yesterday at the thirty-first annual meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. They reported to the representatives of 1,000,000 enterprises that we had overtaken our war necessities in planes and ships but that we still had adjustments to make on the home front, in food and transportation.

A check for $26,244 was received yesterday at the headquarters of the 1943 Red Cross War Fund of New York City, 130 West Forty-second Street, representing the proceeds of the national championship basketball game on April 1 between the University of Wyoming and St. John's College in Madison Square Garden.

Apartment rentals were reported yesterday by brokers and managing agents in scattered sections of the city. Park Avenue, Tudor City, the West Side and the Bronx attracted new tenants in a continuance of the demand for suites.
DETROIT, April 28 (AP) -- Slender Tommy Bridges pitched and batted the Tigers to a 4-to-2 victory over the Browns in their delayed Briggs Stadium opener today before 17,943 spectators.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Representative Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, declared tonight that the 20 per cent withholding provision of pending pay-as-you-go tax bills "will not result in a single extra tax dollar being taken from the taxpayer's pocketbook."

Reichsfuehrer Hitler has concluded conferences with leaders of his southeast European allies and satellites designed, apparently, to line those countries up behind Nazi Germany to resist a United Nations invasion, German reports indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The Right Rev. Patrick J. McCormick, acting rector of the Catholic University of America, has been appointed by Pope Pius XIX to succeed as rector the late Bishop Joseph Corrigan, who died June 30.

More than 400 executives in retailing and other fields paid tribute last night to Ernest Katz, retiring controller of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., at a dinner in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Edward N. Allen of the Sage-Allen Company, Hartford, and president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, made a presentation of a testimonial scroll to Mr. Katz in recognition of his services to retailing.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The text of Secretary Perkins's letter to the policy committee of the United Mine Workers of America follows:

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- A survey designed not to "poll' the people of the United States but to give them an opportunity to express their opinions and hopes about the war and the future, has been in progress for the last two months.

The Germans have always prided themselves on their efficiency. It was supposed to be one of the distinguishing characteristics of the master race entitling it to rule the world in order to build a higher Kultur for its own benefit and for the ultimate benefit of the "inferior" races less talented.
Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Toronto yesterday that there had been no acute shortage of nickel.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Outhit, the Senators trimmed the Athletics, 3 -- 0, today with the help of Rookie Ewald Pyle's pitching and Philadelphia misplays.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Canadian pilots participated in thirteen raids on Kiska, the Japanese base in the Aleutians, on Monday, the Navy revealed today. The Canadians, flying Warhawks, made two of the assaults against the fog-shrouded island.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY in Northern Tunisia, April 26 (Delayed) (AP) -- Signs of German disintegration multiplied today as American and French troops continued their slow advance along the line from the Beja area north to the sea.

The National Conference of Investors, an association of railroad investors, announced yesterday that Congress soon would be asked to enact legislation requiring judicial reviews of the findings of the Interstate Commerce Commission in railroad reorganizations.

LONDON, April 28 (U.P.) -- Underground advices from Europe reported today that the Nazi governor of Warsaw narrowly escaped death and that several hundred German and Italian troops had been killed in a new wave of sabotage and armed revolt sweeping through Greece and Poland.

To the surprise of a great many, but not to her owner-breeder, Mrs. Dodge Sloane, Dare Me dashed off with the $7,775 Rosedale Stakes, a five-furlong dash that attracted nine juvenile fillies at Jamaica yesterday. In a previous effort, Dare Me had performed smartly, but few seemed convinced that was a first flight effort by the brown daughter of Challenger II.

LONDON, April 28 -- British destroyers clashed with an Axis supply convoy in the Atlantic near Brest early today and probably sank five enemy vessels in an hour-long battle furious that the confused convoy ships fired on each other.

Although fewer families than usual appear to be moving to their country homes, and fewer business houses are transferring to new quarters within the city, van owners and warehousemen are busier than usual for the Spring moving season centering around May 1, and in many cases have been forced to put off until next week some requests for service this week-end.
LONDON, April 28 -- The following is the text of a statement issued tonight by the Polish Government-in-Exile on the Russian-Polish crisis:

NEWARK, N.J., April 28 -- Consent injunctions prohibiting black market transactions in potatoes were issued here today by Federal Judge William F. Smith against five defendants on the basis of complaints filed by Nathan L. Jacobs, chief attorney of the district Office of Price Administration. The restraints forbade the defendants from buying, selling or transferring potatoes at more than ceiling prices.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. said here this evening that "as of the present" he did not "see forced savings on the horizon."
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Secretary Wickard has no intention at present of resigning his Cabinet post, as some of his advisers have encouraged him to do, it was learned today.

ALBANY, April 28 -- Supreme Court Justice Francis Bergan ruled today that the State Public Service Commission, rather than the Federal Power Commission, had authority to fix rates for additional emergency waterpower diverted from the Niagara River by the Niagara Falls Power Company to serve war industries in the Niagara frontier area.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- If today's Philadelphia story ever is screened nobody is going to believe it. Both Managers Bucky Harris and Leo Durocher still are incredulous. But the Brooklyn pilot has some balm for his feelings because the Dodgers won by 4-3 in the tenth inning on an unearned run -- their third of the bizarre contest and their fifth in two straight winning games.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 29 (U.P.) -- Allied bombers struck their second blow in two days at enemy shipping in the Arafura Sea, between Northwest Australia and New Guinea, scoring a direct hit and a near miss on a 2,000-ton cargo vessel and two near misses on a 1,200-tonner, both of which were left stationary in the water.

The Most Rev. Paul Yu Pin, Chinese Roman Catholic Bishop, who came recently to the United States from Chungking as a special envoy of the Chinese Government in behalf of the social welfare and rehabilitation of the Chinese people after the war, said yesterday that "China is fighting a poor man's war."

SANTIAGO DE CHILE, April 28 -- The United States dollar has dropped 10 per cent in value in the free market and the Argentine peso has increased by the same proportion as a result of regulations dictated by the Argentine Government controlling the movement of foreign exchange, the details of which have not yet been given out here.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Price reductions on war production contracts, refunds by contractors and miscellaneous recoveries effected through renegotiation of contracts by the War and Navy Departments and the Maritime Commission between April, 1942, and March 31, this year, amounted to $2,539,000,000, the Office of War Information announced today on behalf of the three agencies. Of the total saved, $955,100,000 represents actual refunds by contractors and $1,583,000,000 represents reductions in contract prices.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 28 (AP) -- State Supreme Court Justice Alonzo G. Hinkley awarded today overtime pay and "liquidated damages" totaling $33,848 to six editorial employes, including a city editor, of The White Plains Daily Reporter, which ceased publication Feb. 28, 1941.

Few Long Islanders outside the ranks of the Brooklyn Dodgers have ever faced a barrage of boos, catcalls, whistles and jeers such as that which greeted Helen Hanzelin, 18 years old, when the went to work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning. General Ben Lear should have been present.
SOMEWHERE IN IRAN -- Railroad men of the Casey Jones type, transplanted from the United States, have taken over operation of the Trans-Iranian Railroad to do a highball job of hauling for Russia.

Three new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Mission to Moscow," Warner Brothers screen adaptation of the book by former Ambassador Joseph E. Davies, will have its world premiere at the Hollywood Theatre. Directed by Michael Curtiz, the production stars Walter Huston and Ann Harding as Ambassador and Mrs. Davies, with Oscar Homolka, George Tobias, Gene Lockhart, Helmut Dantine, Victor Francen and Henry Daniell among the featured players.

LONDON, April 28 (Reuter) -- While Marshal Henri Philippe Petain was asking Reichsfuehrer Hitler for an armistice, the late Admiral Jean Francois Darlan was arranging for the transfer of the government to North Africa, it was said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 28 (U.P.) -- News of the threatened soft coal strike back home aroused anger today among American troops in North Africa, from officers down to buck privates.

An Office of Price Administration medical panel has allowed a 65-year-old diabetic only seventy-one of the 1,871 extra ration points her physician said she needed, Russell H. Potter acting OPA district manager, announced yesterday. The panel based its action on conclusions that simple cases of diabetes do not warrant extra points and that chicken broth, aside from any meat it may contain, is not nutritious.

Having noticed your article in today's paper about the fifty Nassau teachers who intend to work in the Grummnan aircraft plant in Bethpage, I thought you would be interested in knowing that there are ten teachers in Port Washington who have been doing that work since December.

Demand for securities and movements of prices were chilled again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange by the seriousness of the situation in the soft-coal mine fields, although the market hardened in the final hour to produce a mixed closing.
Fourteen Columbia University professors will retire on June 30, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, announced yesterday.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 -- The Kentucky Derby created its own "quiz show" today and immediately produced a question to which no one could offer an answer.

LONDON, Thursday, April 29 (U.P.) -- Russian and German air fleets battled fiercly over the Kuban yesterday and generally intensified air, artillery and reconnaissance activity indicated that the long Eastern Front was stirring into life in preparation for the Spring campaign.

The desirability of maintaining a "continuous" foreign policy along current lines as a means of fostering amicable trade relations in the post-war period and increasing the prospects for a lasting peace, was stressed yesterday by speakers at a meeting of the Export Advertising Association at the Hotel Belmont Plaza.
Tuesday, Connie Ryan was a Giant, all wrapped up in the cause of the New Yorkers. Came the big deal for Ernie Lombardi and Ryan, along with Hugh Poland, switched to the uniform of the Braves.

A $30,000,000 post-war improvement program recommended by the J.G. White Engineering Corporation for the Long Island Railroad and including provisions for faster schedules, smoother riding, more seats, cleaner travel, extended electrification and better ventilation was made public yesterday by the railroad.

A detailed forecast of what food the American housewife may expect to bring to her table during the next year, with assurance that there will be enough to supply an adequate diet for all the family, was given yesterday by Roy F. Hendrickson, director of the Food Distribution Administration, at a luncheon meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce at the Waldorf-Astoria.

NEW DELHI, India, April 28 (U.P.) -- American four-engined Liberator bombers pounded Japanese installations around the central railroad station at Rangoon, Burma, on Monday, heavily damaging warehouses and starting fires, it was announced today in a communique of the Tenth United States Air Force.

The Blue Hill Troupe, a company of amateur Savoyards, will open its nineteenth annual stage production for charity tonight with a performance of "Iolanthe" at the Heckscher Theatre. Other performances of the operetta will be given tomorrow and Saturday evenings, with all proceeds over actual production costs being directed to the Frontier Nursing Service and the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The story of how a Navy Catalina patrol bomber trapped an enemy submarine on the surface and sank it with depth bombs some months ago was disclosed by the Navy Department today. The surprise attack took place at an unrevealed spot in the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Responsibility for delays and shortages in aviation gasoline and destroyer escort ship production was thrown back at the War Production Board today by Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administrator, and James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, as the Truman committee heard more of the story of William M. Jeffers's success in obtaining critical materials for his synthetic rubber program.

MEXICO CITY, April 28 -- Alejandro Carrillo, Federal Deputy and editor of the Socialist newspaper Popular, today strongly attacked Americans and Mexicans who oppose President Roosevelt's Good Neighbor Policy. He spoke at a special session of the Chamber of Deputies held to commemorate the Roosevelt-Avila Camacho meeting in Monterrey on April 20.

In a statement supporting the Maloney bill, which would set up an independent Office of Civilian Supply, Frank E. Seidman of Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants, declared yesterday that only such an agency could deal adequately and efficiently with civilian problems.

Part of the home front in the United States is the campaign against unfair discrimination among our citizens. We do make progress. In Washington Commissioner Herbert Emmrerich of the Federal Public Housing Agency announces that Negro tenants will occupy about 12 per cent of the public housing units currently in use or planned.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Declaring that John L. Lewis had defied the order of the War Labor Board to call off strikes of members of the United Mine Workers in several districts, the board referred the bituminous coal dispute to President Roosevelt today.
WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Following is the text of the statement by the War Labor Board today referring the coal wage dispute to the White House:
LONDON, April 28 -- Business on the stock markets here today was on a small scale, and prices tended to ease.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 28 -- The claim of Maximilian J. Zicovich of Yonkers for a brokerage commission because of his efforts to sell the Luckenbach Steamship Company's freighters in 1939 was settled today for "slightly less than $200,000," Charles T. Murphy, counsel for Mr. Zicovich, said tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, April 28 (AP) -- A Flying Fortress crew, which on its own initiative switched from its mission of reconnaissance to one of attack, received Silver Stars for gallentry in action today.

The Spring, or silly, season in the theatre opened last evening, delayed a bit this year like the warm weather, but none the less impressive on arrival. The occasion was the unfolding at the Ritz of "The First Million," a comedy by Irving Elman, an event which served also to introduce to Broadway the newest boy producer, Jimmy Elliott, 19, who works as an actor in "Junior Miss."

Eda Rapaport, New York composer-pianist, presented a program of her own compositions last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. Mrs. Rapaport presided at the piano for a group of her songs. The rest of the elaborate series of offerings were delivered by a group of assisting artists, including Mary Frances Lehnerts, mezzo-soprano; Milton Kaye, piano, and a string quartet made up of Stefan Sopkin and Theodore Katz, violins; Selig Posner, viola, and Leo Rostal, 'cello.

JAMES BURNHAM is an interesting problem. Once upon a time he was a believer in medieval scholasticism. Later on he was a Marxist and a Trotskyist. A year or more ago he broke abruptly with his "proletarianism" to elaborate the rather bleak theory of the coming bureaucratic society which may be found in his provocative "The Managerial Revolution."
LONDON, Thursday, April 29 (U.P.) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight communique as broadcast from Moscow:

The Government of the United States now finds itself confronted by an ultimatum from John L. Lewis. Either Mr. Lewis gets a wage increase which violates the formula which the Government has set or the entire soft coal industry comes to a standstill tomorrow night.

Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44, as approved by the Board of Estimate on Tuesday, was received yesterday by the City Council and referred to its finance committee, which will hold its first public hearing at 11 A.M. next Thursday at City Hall.

Charles J. Farley, nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, was not guilty of killing Patrolman Nicholas C. Moreno on the night of May 23, 1939, after allegedly holding up a Greenpoint gasoline station, J. Kosling Crossman, Farley's lawyer, told Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein and a blue-ribbon jury yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Mills were persistent buyers of wheat futures today on the Board of Trade, and while profit-taking was evident, the close was at the top, with gains of 5/8 to 1 cent a bushel. May, showing an easy undertone due to scattered liquidation, went to even with July, compared with a premium of around 1 cent recently.
WITH U.S. AIR FORCE in the South Pacific, April 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- Sixty-six days of hell ended today for nine gallant American airmen who had been given up for dead.

THE first thing Branch Rickey asked his visitor was, "What's that book you have?" Informed that it was an advance copy of Frank Graham's "The New York Yankees," which will be published tomorrow, the Deacon of the Dodgers eagerly thumbed through the pages.

Retail credit collections showed an increase of 10.04 per cent during March, according to the twenty-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage for the month was 55.61, against 45.57 for March, 1942. All of the twenty stores had increases for the month.

Donald Dame, tenor, assisted by the New York String Quartet and Edith Weiss-Mann, harpsichord, gave a recital last night at Town Hall that delighted a large audience. The program was of unusual interest, ranging from Handel and Bach to Vaughan Williams and Charles Griffes.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- Navy communique 358:

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The country's problem after the war may be to control a boom rather than prevent a depression, Commerce Department economists reported today after reviewing post-war markets at the suggestion of the Committee for Economic Development.

The beautiful and charmingly arranged theme exhibition entitled "Fashion in Headdress" will open to the public today at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street. There were previews at $5 Tuesday evening and yesterday afternoon. Beginning today admission is 50 cents, plus tax.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Fuel oil rations for next Winter will be at least equal to those granted last year, in some cases being more generous, the Office of Price Administration assured consumers today in making public details of a simplified and liberalized program for allotting heating oil.

Leno Ferrarini's double that drove in three runs in the eighth inning gave Columbia a 5-4 victory over Princeton at Baker Field yesterday and brought about a tie among all five teams for the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League lead. It was the Lions' first victory in five starts.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 28 -- An announcement was made today that settlements totaling $60,000 had been made by an insurance company in damage suits totaling $250,000 filed in behalf of nine soldiers who were injured on March 26, 1942, when they were struck in front of the Teaneck Armory by an automobile driven by Charles E. Mordaunt, 36 years old, of 204 Ivy Lane, Englewood.

Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins told a meeting of the Women's Field Army of the New York City Cancer Committee at the Town Hall Club yesterday that women are playing a role comparable to that of men in the armed forces by their "valiant" fight to curb cancer.

The Petroleum Administration for War and the oil industry held out hope yesterday to the passenger-car driver that he would be able, in about two weeks or sooner, to redeem his gasoline ration coupons at his neighborhood filling station without any trouble.

AKRON, Ohio, April 28 (AP) -- Northern Ohio had three persons dead and destruction mounting upward of $4,000,000 tonight as it dug out of debris strewn by a series of tornadoes which left nearly 500 persons homeless and more than 150 injured.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 28 -- The Russian-Polish conflict remains in the forefront of the German political comment, and today's Berlin dispatches indicate that the Wilhelmstrasse intends to propagandize it for all it can.

Proposed legislation to carry out Mayor La Guardia's plan for early closing hours for retail stores during the war was filed yesterday by the City Council. The Council directed that a copy of a report by its Committee on General Welfare, which held public hearings on the proposed local law, be sent to the Mayor.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Although the visits to Mexico by President Roosevelt and to South America by Vice President Wallace seemed to some to indicate concern regarding Latin-American relations, especially in view of the speech of Ambassador George S. Messersmith deprecating suspicions in Mexico of a revived American imperialism, some of those in closest touch with the situation agree that the principal Latin-American grievances today are economic.

City College's Reserve Officers Training Corps, the largest voluntary unit in the country, will continue to function throughout the Summer, despite the anticipated call to active duty of its 400 cadet officers within the next few weeks, it was announced yesterday by Colonel Raymond P. Cook, commandant of cadets.

It has been a good many years since a Wall Street bank has entered the market for new capital, and stockholders of the New York Trust Company made a bit of current financial history yesterday by authorizing an increase of 100,000 shares at $75 a share, of which $25 a share will go to capital and $50 to surplus.

This evening the American-Irish Theatre will present "War Wife," written by the Rev. Will W. Whalen, former actor and playwright, at the Malin Studio Theatre, 135 West Forty-fourth Street The play will continue through next Tuesday night, with a cast including John A. Regan, who directed; Lawrence Tierney, Henriette Browne, Beatrice De Bruyn, Mary Lou Findley, Margaret Peters, Dianne Little and Michele Norman.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 28 -- The center of the German line, reeling under a series of Allied hammer-strokes, is slowly giving way. British infantrymen were battling the enemy this morning on Djebel bou Aoukaz, the last hill stronghold between the First Army and Tunis, twenty-one miles to the northeast across the plain.

Herbert H. Lehman, United States Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, and his son, Flight Officer Peter G. Lehman of the Eighth United States Air Force Flight Command, were heard in a broadcast from England over Station WJZ yesterday afternoon.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 28 (AP) -- The walkout of Alabama coal miners spread to thirteen more shafts today, bringing the number shut down to thirty-seven. The closed mines employ about 16,000 men and include all but one of the shafts supplying coke ovens.

One of the great If's of history is the Gallipoli expedition in the First World War. If the British had succeeded in forcing the Dardanelles, if Turkey had been forced out of the war on the side of Germany, above all, if war supplies had reached an exhausted Russia, it would have been a very different world from what it became after 1918.

It is about time for the different Federal agencies having to do with shipping and the defense of shipping to get together on what they are willing to disclose to the American public. No part of our war is more important than the campaign at sea. If we can get enough merchant cargoes across the Atlantic we can defeat Germany.

ALGIERS, April 28 -- Negotiations for French unity took an unexpected turn for the better today with the disclosure that General Henri Honore Giraud agreed with General Charles de Gaulle on most major issues.

CHICAGO, April 28 -- Radio stations are meeting their wartime obligations successfully, James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and Byron Price, Director of Censorship, told the National Association of Broadcasters holding a war conference here today.

All Americans should unite in calling the "bluff" of John L. Lewis in the mine leader's threat of a strike in the midst of war, James D. Francis, president of the Island Creek Coal Company of Huntington, W. Va., declared yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 28 -- Allied Air Forces in North Africa, striking some of the most concentrated blows in the history of aerial warfare, dropped nearly 1,000 tons of bombs and flew more than 5,000 sorties in the week ended April 23.

Free enterprise "cannot afford" the cost of policing and feeding the post-war world, the United States Chamber of Commerce was told here yesterday by Fred R. Fairchild, Professor of Political Economy in Yale University.

With twenty-five years as a judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York completed with the full day's work he did yesterday, Judge John C. Knox took occasion to commend the "universal kindness" of his associates in the court and the integrity of the lawyers with whom he has dealt.

A series of book discussions, sponsored and arranged jointly by the Hunter College Faculty Round Table and the New York Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, will take place in the Hunter College Library on the first four Mondays in May.

Directors of the Armstrong Cork Company declared yesterday an interim dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. The dividend is payable on June 1 to holders of record of May 10. Robert L. Johnson, president of Temple University, Philadelphia, was elected a director of the company.

If grandmother still treasures those lace curtains or her old-fashioned batiste petticoats, she had better put a padlock on the attic trunk. For, without question, there was started a movement yesterday to transform all such impedimenta into the latest in 1943 fashions.
The campaign to encourage sportsmen to continue to purchase fishing and hunting licenses whether or not they intend participating in the sports, seems to have grown to proportions in New Jersey.

Various government regulations are forcing industry to dig up facts and figures, which reveal that there is considerable room for the development of new advertisers among manufacturers who produce the so-called unbranded lines. This is particularly true in the textile field, which up to a few years ago had a comparatively small number of trade-marked advertisers.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 28 -- Conscript labor for French youth has brought Marshal Henri Philippe Petain and Chief of Government Pierre Laval such unpopularity that the government in Vichy still hesitates actually to enforce it against recalcitrants, it was indicated here today.

VALLETTA, Malta, April 28 -- A 25-year-old American who joined the Royal Air Force in July, 1941, Squadron Leader John Lynch of Alhambra, Calif., was responsible for shooting down the thousandth enemy aircraft by planes based on Malta, it was revealed today.

After a long and spirited session, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday turned down for the second time the nomination of Mark Starr, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, for the $7,500 position of adult education director of the New York City school system.

JERSEY CITY, April 28 (AP) -- Montreal defeated Jersey City in the opener of a three-game series today, 9 to 4. The Royals nicked Hugh East, Little Giant starter, for twelve of their thirteen hits and eight of their nine runs over the first seven innings.

The distribution of "penny milk" and in many cases free milk to school children, not only here but throughout the country, is in danger of being discontinued at the end of the present school term unless the Senate restores appropriations cut from the Agriculture Department supply bill by the House, it was learned yesterday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, April 29 (AP) -- The noon communique:
MOSCOW, April 28 -- Following is the text of an editorial on the Russian-Polish crisis in Pravda, Communist party organ, as translated into English and distributed today by Tass, Russian news agency:

More than eight times as many Boeing Flying Fortresses were delivered in 1942 as during the previous year, Philip G. Johnson, president of the Boeing Airplane Company and subsidiaries, declared yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and wholly owned subsidiaries showed a net income for the three months ended on March 31 of $14,739,314, according to the consolidated statement made available for publication today.

BOSTON, April 28 -- The Army took the lid off the biggest shoe box in the world today and revealed the purchase of 40,000,000 pairs of shoes since Pearl Harbor in 249 sizes ranging from 3 1/2 AAA to 15 1/2 EEE and thirty-two types especially designed for fighting in every quarter of the globe.

Numerous leases of store and office space in the midtown section of Manhattan were reported yesterday. Leases to four tenants in 576 Fifth Avenue completed the renting of the building at that address.

LONDON, Thursday, April 29 (U.P.) -- A large formation of planes, presumably en route to bomb Northern Germany, touched off anti-aircraft defenses in Sweden and Denmark early today after Berlin's leading radio transmitters had terminated their broadcasts suddenly.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 28 -- Paramount will feature Paulette Goddard and Sonny Tufts in its forthcoming musical "All Around the Town," previously scheduled for Bing Crosby. Tufts, former football player at Yale and night club singer, recently completed "So Proudly We Hail," his first picture, in which he also appeared with Miss Goddard.

Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Anstralian Minister for External Affairs, whose mission to this country a little over a year ago resulted in more closely uniting the Allied forces in the Southwestern Pacific, renewed his plea yesterday for "greater effort this year to prevent Japanese consolidation as well as possible Japanese offensives."

ADVANCED ALLIED AIR HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, April 26 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American planes showered the Axis lines today with leaflets calling on the Italians and Germans to surrender or die and announcing that Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel and his entire staff had fled, leaving their troops "holding the bag."

The three hotel owners who for four weeks had been on trial in Special Sessions for operating two hotels of a chain in the midtown district for purposes of prostitution were found guilty yesterday by Justices Weiboldt, Hofmann and Northrop.
PITTSBURGH, April 28 -- Wildcat strikes continued to spread swiftly today in the Western Pennsylvania bituminous fields. A complete shutdown was looked for by tomorrow.

BOSTON, April 28 -- The Yankees took careful aim at Tony Lupien today, fired a couple of vital shots through his first-base sector midway of their Fenway Park struggle with the Red Sox and gave Tiny Bonham a shut-out victory, his first triumph of the 1943 campaign. The count was 5 to 0.

Stocks of finished oil products on the Atlantic Coast held unchanged last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The index of the institute remained at 28.1, the low point reached in the previous week, compared with 58.3 on Nov. 7, when the downward trend started. The index is based on the stocks of gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil in 1940 and 1941, adjusted to seasonal variations.

CHUNGKING, Thursday, April 29 (U.P.) -- The Central News Agency reported today that American fliers shot down at least ten Japanese planes in bitter air battles yesterday morning when forty raiders attacked Kunming, capital of Yunnan Province and terminus of the Burma Road.

The name of Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, Brooklyn Democrat and minority leader of the State Assembly, was brought up again yesterday at a State Labor Board hearing on a dispute involving pari-mutuel employes at the Jamaica race track. The hearing, which will continue today, was held before Trial Examiner Sidney L. Cahn at the board's local headquarters, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

ALBANY, April 28 -- The State War Council, at a stormy session, today adopted a resolution promulgating all present price "ceilings" and regulations of the Office of Price Administration as the law of New York State.

Because city hospital internes have voiced dissatisfaction with the food served to them, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced yesterday that he would meet today with groups of internes to discuss their complaint.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 28 (AP) -- Death in Sing Sing's electric chair became almost a certainty tonight for Eli Shonbrun. Unless Governor Dewey commutes Shonbrun's sentence to life imprisonment, he will go to his death tomorrow at 11 P.M. for the robbery and murder of Mrs. Susan Flora Reich.

ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP) -- The Cardinals displayed anything but world championship form today, as the Cubs, taking advantage of four errors, blanked St. Louis, 4 to 0, on the seven-hit twirling of Hiram Bithorn.

Increased earnings for the first three months of 1943 over those of last year were reported by only one of the four steel companies which announced operating results yesterday. This was the Inland Steel Company.

The demand for loft properties in downtown Manhattan continued yesterday with the sale of the ten-story store and loft building at 535-37 Pearl Street, southwest corner of Elk Street, by Guy Cary and the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, trustees of Virginia R. Harrison and Barbara Westcott. The 535 Pearl Street Corporation is the new owner.

PATERSON, N.J., April 28 -- In what was described as a protest against a long delay by the War Labor Board in giving a decision on grievances of the union, 200 employes of the World Bestos Brake Lining Company of 52 Courtland Street went on strike last night and today and caused suspension of production at the plant, which is largely engaged in making war products.

Crowded hours seem to be the rule, not the exception these days. Extra-curricular war activities leave business girl and housewife alike little time for peaking into mirrors. If a nose is shiny, chances are it will stay that way.

Carl A. Gray, a Connecticut manufacturer, in an article, "Draft in Reverse," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 25 recommended the use of the Selective Service system to fit men returning from the war for civil employment. I question whether Mr. Gray is familiar with the services now available through the Federal Government and the various State vocational boards.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 28 -- Clashes between pickets and non-striking employes and between pickets and police occurred again tonight at the plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation here as the night shift reported for work.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture issued today final figures on the 1942 cotton crop showing production to have been 12,824,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each, compared with 10,744,000 bales produced in 1941.

To hear John L. Lewis talk about the plight of the coal miners, one would imagine that they were suffering while the rest of the community was flourishing. He quotes fallacious figures about the incomes of corporations before taxes. But he ignores the decline in their income after taxes as a result of the increase in taxes on excess profits.

A petition addressed to the management of the Hotel New Yorker, which has the restaurant concession at La Guardia Field, and signed by nearly 400 persons, mostly field employes, complaining about "the food situation" there, was brought to the attention of Mayor La Guardia and Marine and Aviation Commissioner John McKenzie yesterday.

Growers are refusing to sell poultry at the new ceiling prices fixed last week by the Office of Price Administration, with the result that receipts so far this week in the New York market are lagging far behind those of a week ago, when they were only 10 per cent of normal, leading poultry wholesalers reported yesterday.

William Allen White was married April 27, 1893. Mr. and Mrs. White have lived happily ever since. Their mutual sympathy is so strong that they are able to time an attack of influenza, endure and enjoy it together. For some days they have been in Roosevelt Hospital, and the formal commemoration of their fifty years together is wisely delayed until they are discharged, cured.

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- The executive board of the War Manpower Commission approved today a plan to extend the benefits of management-labor stabilization agreements to those areas of the country not covered by the sixty-seven voluntary stabilization agreements now in effect.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- The Rusaian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

For six innings in yesterday's Metropolitan Baseball Conference game between City College and St. John's at Dexter Park, bespectacled Phil Gelfand, Beaver twirler, had the Redmen completely baffled. He had yielded only four hits up to that point and the Beavers enjoyed a 2-to-0 lead.

The changing war situation in Europe has compelled the Selfhelp of Emigres from Central Europe, Inc., to alter its method of aiding refugees from the Nazis, but has by no means stopped such relief, the organization announced yesterday.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he had sent word to leaders of civic and religious groups in Harlem that he was powerless to interfere with the action of the Police Department in revoking the license of the Savoy Ballroom, public dance hall at Lenox Avenue and 140th Street.

LONDON, April 28 -- The accuracy of the bombing by the Flying Fortresses stationed in Britain was emphasized today by Dingle M. Foot, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Economic Warfare, when he told Scottish workers that in their last raid on the Renault works in a Paris suburb the planes had robbed Germany of at least 1,000 trucks in addition to other war material.

LONDON, April 28 -- The Polish Government, after receiving assurances from British and American authorities that no frontier settlement will be recognized while the war is on, has agreed to drop the issue that caused the Soviet to break relations with the Poles and give the United States and Britain a free hand in negotiating with Moscow for restoration of normal relations.

War "pools" of textile producers, already functioning in four basic branches of the cotton and rayon trades to facilitate military procurement, are slated to expand their activities during the balance of this year because of necessity to conserve critical materials and Manpower as well as to earn greater consideration for individual companies in the renegotiation of war contracts.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

ELWOOD, N.J., April 28 -- A forest fire that destroyed four homes and many outbuildings along the White Horse Pike was checked late this evening as more than forty State forest fire-fighters and firemen from eight municipalities battled the flames.
Reminiscent of the "pubs" that figured in much of England's great literature is a sparkling ginger beer that arrived in a Manhattan store a few days ago. Made in Hollywood -- a city that can, as you.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 28 -- An enlarged Intergovernmental Committee on Refugees will be one of the results of the Anglo-American refugee conference, it was understood today.
Mr. and Mrs. Percy Waldron Crane will return tomorrow to their Summer home in Convent, N.J., after spending the season at 35 Fifth Avenue.
NEW DELHI, India, April 28 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Army Air Force communique:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 28 (AP) -- A communique:

A combination of daylight precision bombing by American fliers and night bombing by the Royal Air Force "may well shorten the war in Europe," and "enable us both to turn our full weight upon Japan," Air Vice Marshal F. Macneece Foster of the Royal Air Force told 400 members and guests of the Canadian Club at a luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 -- The Public Service Company of Indiana, Inc., was authorized today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to solicit competitive bids on the issuance and sale of $38,000,000 face amount of first mortgage bonds, series E, 3 1/4 per cent, due on May 1, 1973.

Local councils of the Office of Civilian Defense were urged yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, director for the second region, to arrange a volunteer program of providing school lunches for children in areas where funds are not available through regular channels.

MOSCOW, April 28 -- The most interesting development in the Russian-Polish controversy today is a statement by the chairman of a group of Poles in the Soviet Union who have adpoted the name Union of Polish Patriots, that they have reason to believe the Soviet Government will give the Poles at present in the Soviet Union the possibility of taking up arms and fighting beside the Red Army for the freedom of their land.

Stockholders of the New York Trust Company, at a special meeting yesterday, authorized the plan of the directors to increase the bank's capital funds by $7,500,000. Under the plan, the capital stock will be increased by 100,000 shares, of $25 par value a share, to 600,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today the award of the silver star to twenty-three officers and enlisted men for gallantry in the North African theatre of operations. The citations included:

The suggestion that the two major political parties in the United States adopt identical planks on foreign affairs in their platforms for the 1944 Presidential campaign was made last night by H. Alexander Smith, Republican National Committeeman from New Jersey, in a speech to members of the New York Young Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

With business confined to routine trade price fixing and hedge selling, the cotton futures market yesterday held within a trading range of 3 to 5 points. The close was unchanged to 3 points lower than Tuesday's final prices, with the exception of the spot delivery, which ended with an advance of 3 points.

The report for 1942 of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, for publication today, shows a consolidated net income of $83,361,920 after charges, taxes, minority interests and provision of $7,000,000 for wartime contingencies. The net was equal to $3.06 each on the 27,283,587 capital shares outstanding.

The Guild Reporter, official organ of the American Newspaper Guild, disclosed yesterday that a controversy had developed between the national leadership and that of its New York local over the execution by the Soviet Government of Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter, Polish labor leaders, on the charge of being Nazi spies and subversive agents.

DOMEI, official Japanese news agency, in stories intended for use in the United States, reported several new appointments in the Japanese Government yesterday, according to a broadcast by the Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service.

The saga of the supply lines may turn out to be the greatest story of the war. The heroes of that saga are the new pioneers, impelled by sheer military necessity to plant airfields in the desert and the jungle and open up the oldest lands of the earth to modern speeds, techniques and mechanisms.

The three main requisites of an officer are "loyalty, courage and fortitude," and the tremendous task of seaborne transportation in wartime can be completed only through cooperation, Rear Admiral Frank J. Gorman, acting assistant commandant of the Coast Guard, said yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, April 28 (AP) -- The Reds spoiled 34-year-old Wally Hebert's first pitching assignment with the Pirates today, jumping on the big southpaw for three runs in the fourth to win, 3 to 1.

Extension of the consumer goods inventory limitation order L-219 to include merchants either with annual sales of $200,000 and over or with inventories totaling $50,000 or more was proposed yesterday at the first meeting of the Retail Trade Advisory Committee with officials of the wholesale and retail trade division of the WPB.
CHUNGKING, China, April 28 (U.P.) -- A communique:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 -- Entire populations of Chinese coastal areas that gave sanctuary to American fliers who bombed Tokyo last year were wiped out afterward by Japanese troops, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced here tonight to an audience of war bond workers in the War Memorial Opera House.
The German Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 28 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of United States Army Forces in the China-Burma-India theatre, and Major Gen. Claire L. Chennault, commanding general of the Fourteenth Air Force in China, arrived here today for conferences with General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, April 28 -- Production has been increased and costs lowered by a new method of broach rifling of machine-gun barrels at the Rock Island Arsenal, it was reported today to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers by William Baumbeck, chief superintendent of production.
DETROIT, April 29 (AP) -- Virgil (Fire) Trucks pitched his second successive four-hitter today to give the Tigers a 3-to-2 victory over the Browns and a sweep of the curtailed two-game series.
Net earnings reported yesterday for the first quarter of 1943 by the General Foods Corporation were 33,579,992, compared with $2,737, 481 for the first three months of 1942.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Creation of a joint economic committee consisting of two representatives each from the United States and Mexico to study the Mexican wartime economic situation was announced tonight by the State Department, which said the decision resulted from an agreement reached by President Roosevelt and President Avila Camacho at their recent meetings.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 29 (U.P.) The Florida House late today concurred with two Senate changes in a proposed constitutional amendment which would outlaw labor's closed-shop contracts in the State.
LOS ANGELES, April 29 (AP) -- The California Athletic Commission tonight sanctioned a proposed Summer boxing tournament in Los Angeles to decide the world lightweight championship.
Captain T. Suffern Taller, U.S.A., has leased a terrace apartment in 1100 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, Payson McL. Merrill Company, agents.

A public hearing will be held in the Panel Room of the Hotel New Yorker at 10 o'clock this morning by the poultry and dairy products subcommittee of the Republican Congressional Food Study Committee to investigate complaints by the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council that OPA orders are forcing virtually all poultry sales into the black market and sending legitimate concerns to the wall.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed an increase of $17,989,000 in holdings of United States Government securities during the week.

Drastic revision of the Board of Transportation's methods of fixing the wages of the 32,000 employes of the city's unified transit system and adjusting their routine grievances is recommended in the report of Mayor La Guardia's special committee to study labor relations on the city's lines.
The 17,000 members of the Police Department and 9,000 members of the Fire Department are about to solicit 600,000 signatures to a petition to a $450 annual "war bonus" for each man.

George W. Thompson, Tammany leader of the Twelfth Assembly District, Middle, and one of the leaders of the group seeking to oust Michael J. Kennedy from the leadership of Tammany, will have opposition in his own district, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- For the purpose of improving the war service pre-induction training of high school students in mathematics, science and pre-flight aeronautics, the Senate Committee on Education and Labor agreed informally today to report out legislation to create a Victory Corps to handle the program.

Tonight's events: University Women's Chorus, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30 o'clock; Louise Haydon, piano; Louise Hillyer, contralto and Louise Stanley, piano, in benefit for Turtle Bay Music School, George Washington Hall, 3 West Fifty-first Street, 8:45; Celia Saloman, piano, Greenwich House Music School, 8:30; "Parade of Stars" concert to aid the Federation of Crippled and Disabled, Federation Concert Hall, 163 West Fifty-seventh Street, 8:30; Mendelssohn's "Elijah," Woodhaven Music Festival, Methodist Church, Woodhaven, L.I.

The poultry situation is extremely critical these days declares a spokesman for the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets. There are few ducks or chickens of any kind to be had, owing presumably to heavy government buying and to increasing black market operations.

MOSCOW, April 29 -- The Soviet press today continues its campaign on the Polish question. Pravda publishes an article by publicist L. Volsky which blames great Polish landlords of Western Ukraine, Western White Russian and Lithuanian lands of being behind the emigre campaigning for restitution of Poland's pre-war frontiers.

MOSCOW, April 29 (AP) -- Tadeusz Romer, Ambassador of the Polish Government in London, left Moscow today on a slow withdrawal from the Soviet Union, headed first for the alternate Russian capital at Kuibyshev for a stay of about two weeks and thence to Teheran, Iran, to await further assignment.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent during the week ended on April 24, largely because of weakening prices for cattle and hogs. At 103.4 per cent of the 1926 average the comprehensive index is only slightly higher than at this time last month and about 5 per cent higher than it was a year ago.

Lynn Fontanne's continued illness, it was announced, has abruptly shortened the run of "The Pirate," originally scheduled to close tomorrow night at the Martin Beck. Miss Fontanne was barely able to finish Tuesday night's show and as a result the performances of Wednesday night and yesterday afternoon were canceled.

CHICAGO, April 29 (AP) -- Threats of ceilings on prices of live hogs resulted today in heavier shipments than had been expected despite recent downturns, and prices today dropped 15 to 25 cents a hundredweight under yesterday's averages. The top was $14.75. Fed steers were up 10 to 15 cents and lambs closed steady.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 29 -- A decided step toward a "democratic union" embracing all political parties and groups that wish to oppose government candidates in the Presidential election next September was taken in the early hours this morning when the national convention of the Radical party, after an all-night debate, approved such a union in principle.

The annual report of Paramount Pictures, Inc., issued yesterday by Barney Balaban, president, shows consolidated earnings of $13,125, 436 for the fiscal year ended Jan. 2 last, after all charges, taxes and $3,000,000 additional reserve provided for contingencies.

ABOARD ROOSEVELT TRAIN IN COLORADO, April 24 (Delayed) (AP) -- President Roosevelt took a lesson at Camp Carson today in the way hardened troops tackle combat problems they will meet soon on fighting fronts.

LONDON, April 29 -- Still another new transatlantic flying record was claimed today by Captain William S. May, a native of Winnipeg, who said he made a landfall-to-landfall crossing from Newfoundland to Britain in a Liberator, carrying a maximum lead of 56,000 pounds, in six hours and twenty minutes, in which he traversed 2,200 statute miles.
LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- President Roosevelt will be renominated and re-elected in 1944 if the war is still going on, and "everybody knows it," Senator Joseph F. Guffey declared tonight in an address prepared for a $25-a-plate Jefferson Day dinner.

The sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 81-83 Irving Place, at the corner of Nineteenth Street, has been purchased by the Samuel Knepper Company as one of three property acquisitions announced by that concern yesterday.

While rationing of women's clothes is not anticipated, retailers should not be "naive" in refusing to regard it as a possibility, George Engel, secretary of Jane Engel, Inc., operators of retail fashion shops, said yesterday in a talk before the Fashion Group at the Murray Hill Hotel.

The Japanese two-man suicide submarine captured after the attack on Pearl Harbor will arrive in this city at 8:30 A.M. today by way of the Holland Tunnel, on its coast-to-coast tour to stimulate the sales of war bonds. It will be on exhibition on the following schedule, during its five-day stay here:
LONDON, April 24 -- The ring closes in for the final crushing of Rommel's and von Arnim's forces in the north, the southwest and the south.

PERHAPS this is not a book review after all. It is more the appreciative reaction of a baseball fan who has just read Frank Graham's "The New York Yankees," which is published today. It is a fascinating and always engrossing story.

Contributions of $10 made to Sam Herman, described Wednesday as the "right-hand man of Assemblyman Irwin Steingut," Brooklyn Democrat and minority leader of the Assembly, were for the "Brooklyn office of Civilian Defense," James J. Buckley, mutuel cashier at the Jamaica (Queens) race track, testified yesterday at a State Labor Relations Board hearing of a dispute between rival unions at the track.

If we think now of the objectives that will help to lighten the load of the peace that must be won through "blood and sweat, toil and tears," we can hold on to the victory that is going to cost us so much, Miss Frances Perkins, Secretay of Labor, declared here yesterday.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, city Hospitals Commissioner, answered numerous complaints by internes of the twenty-seven municipal hospitals at a public meeting yesterday by promising "definite efforts to increase the quantity of food" provided to house staffs of the institutions and "to serve it better."
