Bishop William T. Manning, head of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, expressed the hope yesterday that the Cathedral of St. John the Divine might be completed after the war as "a thanks offering for a righteous victory and the coming of a lasting peace."

Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander in chief of the armed forces of the United States in China, Burma and India, has flown to Washington; and we hope he gets what he wants. He is an accomplished soldier and a master of meaty phrase, but his talent for autobiography is of the thinnest.

The 1943 Red Cross War Fund has surpassed both its national and its New York City goals, it was announced yesterday. In the Nation as a whole $138,000,000 has been contributed in response to the appeal for $125,000,000, while New York City has raised to date $13,552,000, which is $632,000 more than its quota of $12,920,700.

LONDON, April 29 (U.P.) -- The German fleet is reported massing in Norway for a battle with Allied forces if Norway is invaded. Continental dispatches indicated Axis defensive preparations on all the fringes of Europe.

Three exhibitions of prize-winning and other posters selected from the recent National War Poster Competition -- work shown at the Museum of Modern Art last Fall -- are being circulated by the Artists For Victory to outstanding museums and universities.

Harvesting farm crops in up-State New York and New Jersey will be an important part of the Summer activities of the Girl Scouts this year, Miss Grace Maxwell, director of farm aid, said yesterday at the annual conference of Girl Scout Region 2 in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

Seventy members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Wheeler Beckett, were heard in the last of a series of three concerts for high school students yesterday afternoon in Hunter College Assembly Hall. The series, sponsored by the William T. Morris Foundation, has met with such success that it is planned to continue it next season.

The two-family dwelling at 1417 Seventy-ninth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Luigi Mezzo. The property is assessed at $8,000. Slomka Brothers and Ignazio J. Mattia were co-brokers. The corporation also disposed of the two-family house at 923 Forty-eighth Street.

First-hand information of the field work being done by the Ducks Unlimited organization in the so-called duck factories, or breeding grounds, in Canada will be given by Tom Main, Dominion manager, at the annual D.U. dinner next week.

The concert given by the New York Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, with Dmitri Mitropoulos as guest conductor and Mishel Piastro as soloist, was the second occasion when that orchestra has given its service this season for the benefit of the Red Cross, the first having been last November when Toscanini led it with similar purpose.

LONDON, April 29 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden saw Ivan M. Maisky, Soviet Ambassador, today and told him exactly how the British Government viewed the severance of diplomatic relations with the Polish Government in London after consultations with the United States officials of the highest rank and talks with Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski and Count Edward Raczynski, Foreign Minister of the Polish Government.

" Isle of Passion" ("La Isla de Pasion"), a Mexican importation, will have its local premiere today at the World Theatre. The historical romance, which has Spanish dialogue and English titles, features David Silva. Isabela Corona, Chaflan and Miguel Angel Ferriz.

CHICAGO, April 29 -- The Commonwealth Edison Company had consolidated net profit of $5,766,980, equal to 45 cents a common share after Federal tax provisions on the basis of the 1942 Revenue Act, compared with $5,973,441, or 47 cents a share in the first three months of 1942, after a $700,000 adjustment for accruals of Federal taxes in excess of requirements.

LONDON, April 29 -- R.W. Hathaway, native of New York and a graduate of Yale, who served in the Royal Flying Corps in World War I and later became a British subject and assumed through marriage the position of Seigneur of the Channel Island of Sark, has been deported to Germany, according to information received today by his stepdaughter, Miss Beaumont, living in England.

The Second War Loan drive has passed its $13,000,000,000 goal in the nation and has also surpassed the new quota of $4,000,000,000 for investors other than the commercial banks in the Second Federal Reserve District, it was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 29 -- Joan Harrison, former secretary and later scenarist for Alfred Hitchcock, today signed a contract as associate producer with Universal and will handle "Phantom Lady," based on the mystery novel by William Irish.

ALBANY, April 29 -- New York State soon will have a first allotment of $30,000 of Federal funds to provide maternal care for wives of men in the armed forces, as well as nursing care for their babies, without cost to the family.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 29 (AP) -- The Studebaker Corporation and its subsidiaries reported today net profits of $939,514 in the quarter ended on March 31 after all charges and provision of $400,000 for contingencies. The charges included depreciation, interest on debentures, amortization of debt discount and provision for Federal income and excess profits tax.

Graduate nurses returning to work on a part-time basis are receiving a warm welcome in most hospitals in the city, where they are a partial solution to the shortage of professionals on the regular staffs. The idea, tentatively advanced during the past year, has now definitely taken hold, according to Miss Mary Burr, director of the New York City Nursing Council for War Service.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 29 -- With Europe firmly in the hands of the Axis, an invasion of the Continent is a "thing impossible," Dr. Joseph Goebbels, the German Propaganda Minister, asserted in his weekly round-up article in the magazine Reich, it was learned today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- After several months of preparation supervised by Brock Pemberton, New York producer and co-chairman of the American Theatre Wing's Stage Door Canteens, San Francisco's canteen was formally opened to service men tonight in the brilliantly decorated auditorium of the Native Sons of the Golden State.

The annual report of the Middle West Corporation for 1942, released yesterday by P.L. Smith, president, shows a net income of $1,836,776 after all expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to 55 cents a share on the corporation's 3,307,302 shares of capital stock outstanding, and compares with a net of $1,585,249, or 48 cents a capital share, in 1941.

ON THE NORTHERN TUNISIAN FRONT, April 29 (U.P.) -- Allied artillerymen are bombarding the Germans with propaganda shells which burst high in the air and shower leaflets warning the ordinary German soldier that he faces the imminent choice of dying in a hopeless fight or surrendering and living to see the green hills of his homeland, it was revealed today.

An exhibition of paintings by Miss Alison Stilwell, daughter of Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of the United States Army Forces in the China-Burma-India theatre, and Mrs. Stilwell, will be held at the gallery of T. Loo, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, from Tuesday through May 20.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Airplane superiority of the United Nations has attained such proportions that air casualties have been four to one against the Axis in the Tunisian operations, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson said today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 29 (U.P.) -- Officials of Narragansett Park refused today to close the parking lot at the race track and the Office of Price Administration announced it would police the track and prosecute patrons found violating gasoline rationing laws.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 29 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- The Bank of England weekly condition statement reported an increase of 5,560,000 in note circulation, to the record high of 953,412,000, the thirteenth consecutive weekly advance. An almost similar loss was reflected in the Bank's reserve.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 29 -- United States troops driving toward the vital Mateur road junction center south of Bizerte have made further Important advances in bitter hill fighting. But the Germans, fighting with the ferocity of cornered beasts, drove back the British from the summit area of Djebel bou Aoukaz, the last height standing between them and the coastal plain.
CHUNGKING, China, April 29 (U.P.) -- A communique:

MONTREAL, April 29 (AP) -- Because of financial difficulties, the Montreal Jockey Club has decided to suspend its racing activities at Blue Bonnets this year, but there were indications today the track might be leased to other interests.
CHICAGO, April 29 -- The majority of radio broadcasters are opposed to government advertising or subsidies in any form as an aid to small stations in financial distress.

Grade labeling is "unsound, impractical and un-American," Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufactureres of America, said yesterday in an open letter to Economic Stabilization Director James F. Byrnes and Price Administrator Prentiss Brown.

Eugene G. Grace. president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in reporting earnings for the first quarter of this year only slightly above those for the similar period in 1942, yesterday announced that he has taken a voluntary pay cut of 58.8 per cent which will make his total compensation this year $221,645, compared with $537,724 received in each of the years 1991 and 1942.
JERSEY CITY, April 29 (AP) -- Montreal made it two in a row and stretched Jersey City's losing streak to three straight today by defeating the Little Giants, 7 to 2.

Duke, 4 1/2-year-old airedale, who proudly has led a cadet corps up Fifth Avenue on St. Patrick's Day for three successive years, wearing an emerald-green ribbon on his collar, will march to martial strains for the duration. He took his "physical" yesterday on the roof of the Hotel Commodore, was classed 1-A and is in the Army now.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The Senate voted today, as President Roosevelt issued his ultimatum to John L. Lewis and his coal miners, to take new action on anti-strike legislation to strengthen the Executive's hand in preventing stoppage of production for war.
Following is the text of an address delivered here last night by Senator Walter F. George at the annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States:

Labor and industry must solve the tremendous economic problems of the future together or stand aside and see democracy, free enterprise and competitive capitalism go down, speakers declared yesterday at a session on "Democracy and War" attended by more than three hundred delegates to the annual convention of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Fred L. Soufert, 50 years old, who was alleged to have stolen $57,000 worth of coffee, tea and rice from his employers, S.A. Schonbrunn Co., Inc., importers at 77 Water Street, using 110,000 pounds of the coffee, valued at 522,000, in a black market he established recently in an empty store in Queens, was lodged in a Tombs cell yesterday to be arraigned for pleading today in General Sessions.

NEW CITY, N.Y., April 29 -- Mrs. Helen Essex of South Nyack, a Rockland County Republican leader for many years, was acquitted of first and second degree perjury tonight by a jury of nine men and three women before Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 29 (AP) -- Link, a consistent sprinter from the stable of M.A. Cushman, registered his second victory of the Pimlico meeting today when he came from off the pace to score over five rivals in the featured Heathen Purse.

The election of the Rev. Dr. Philip Sidney Watters, pastor of Memorial Methodist Church, White Plains, to the presidency of Drew Seminary for Young Women, in Carmel, N.Y., was announced at Methodist headquarters here yesterday by Wilson P. Tanner, president of the seminary's board of trustees.

Milk rationing in some form will be started soon in many American cities, but it is unlikely to be attempted in New York this year, Dr. Thomas G. Stitts, chief of the dairy and poultry branch of the Department of Agriculture, informed milk market administrators from all sections of the country at a conference yesterday in the Hotel Barbizon Plaza.

Emphasis on government objectives and other phases of the war effort has cut straight product advertising in publications down to 40 to 60 per cent of the total volume, according to various checks being made now. The percentage varies according to the different type of media, with newspapers first to reflect the increasing trend toward war advertising.

With traders awaiting the outcome of the coal wage dispute and further information on the sale of government cotton and the mid-April parity price for cotton, the cotton futures market experienced yesterday another session of listless activity.

From now on production for the military and output of the so-called rock-bottom needs for civilians must be on a par, since both are equally essential to the war program, Henry A. Dinegar, chief of the durable goods branch of the Office of Civilian Supply, WPB, declared yesterday at a regional conference of the National Retail Furniture Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The twentieth annual National Music Week, from May 2 to 9, will have as its keynote the "fostering of American and world unity through music." That the celebration of Music Week has particular significance this year is stressed in a letter from President Roosevelt to C.M. Tremaine, secretary of the National and Inter-American Music Week Committee.

Although the use of malt by large brewers was reduced 7 per cent below 1942 consumption levels in an order issued by the War Production Board on March 1, sales during the month were 21.2 per cent greater than those in March of last year, it was noted in the trade yesterday.

Two months ago the American Red Cross appealed to the American people for what its War Fund Chairman, Walter S. Gifford, calls "the largest amount ever asked for in one campaign by any organization in this country" -- $125,000,000. Today Mr. Gifford announces that $138,000,000 has been contributed, with some returns still to come in.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Senator Mead defended labor today against charges of unwarranted absenteeism in war production. He declared that recent emphasis upon the subject, long a problem in industrial operations, prompted "some reasonable doubt" as to whether patriotism or prejudice was the motive.

A war council of retailers will be held by the American Retail Federation on June 8 and 9 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced yesterday by David R. Craig, president of the federation. The objective of the meeting, he said, is to develop for the duration the most orderly flow of supplies possible to maintain the nation's civilians in best war trim.

FORT KNOX, Ky., April 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- Inspections of war centers which President Roosevelt began April 14 ended here today amid a blaze of tank and artillery fire in an Army display of armored offensive power.

Fordham's baseball team defeated Georgetown yesterday at Fordham Field, 14 to 1, but more important was the fact that when George Cheverko gathered in a pop foul behind home plate for the final out he sealed a no-hit pitching performance for Rudy Imarata in his first start for the Rams this season.

Phyllis Imbernone and Bobby Zaratarro, each 5 years old, face the world today perfect specimens of health. They were crowned "King and Queen" of health yesterday morning at the Lower West Side Center of the Children's Aid Society, 219 Sullivan Street.

LONDON, April 29 -- Some indication was given today that the British Government has a post-war plan to finance the education of those whose studies have been interrupted by the war. The plan will be extended to nearly 60,000 men and women demobilized from the armed forces and will cover those who wish to become teachers, lawyers, accountants, business executives, agriculturists and technicians of all kinds.

CHUNGKING, April 29 (U.P.) -- Japanese fliers, stepping up their Spring air offensive in China, today made their third attack this month on Lingling, Allied air base town in Southern Hunan Province, it was reported tonight.

The three-week gap in the stock market's advance was bridged effectively yesterday as buyers returned in sufficient numbers to raise values on an average of a point. The strong stand taken by President Roosevelt in the softcoal mining crisis encouraged buying in a long line of heavy industrial issues on the Stock Exchange, especially in those groups that would be injured in their war efforts by any lack of fuel
The German Thursday communique, as broadcast from Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Secretary Morgenthau gave his unqualified approval today to the Ways and Means Committee's new tax bill, which he estimated would add $2,734,000,000 to $5,623,800,000 to Treasury tax receipts in the fiscal year starting July 1.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 29 -- The threat of a pitched battle tonight between rival unions at the plant of the Bendix Aviation Corporation here failed to materialize into anything more vigorous than an exchange of taunts between pickets of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., and non-strikers, who are members of the Aircraft Workers of New Jersey.

Hugo Maiorana, Hofstra's big left-handed pitcher, stuck valiantly by his guns yesterday when defeat by Manhattan loomed ominously and his mates finally came to his aid in defeating the Jaspers, to 3, in an eleven-inning Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference encounter at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 -- New Jersey's ranking Republican leaders, in a move unprecedented for them, agreed here today to support Walter E. Edge, Governor of this State during the last World War and former United States Senator and Ambassador to France, for the party's Gubernatorial nomination in the primary election on Sept. 21.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt returned to the White House today after a sixteen-day, 7,600-mile inspection trip to training camps of the armed forces and war-production plants which impressed him anew with the value to individual and to country if each able-bodied young man gives a year's service in the camps and war plants in which the government has invested millions.
LONDON, Friday, April 30 (U.P.) -- The Russian Thursday midnight communique as broadcast from Moscow:

Congress must keep control both of the sources and methods of collecting revenue and the allotment or appropriation of public funds, Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, declared last night at a dinner of the New York City Control of the Controller's Institute of America, at the Hotel New Yorker.

The National Academy of Design, 1038 Fifth Avenue, one of the oldest organizations of artists in the country, announced yesterday that at its annual meeting eight painters, two sculptors, one architect and one graphic artist had been elected academicians.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Sole leather tanners and converters were directed today by the War Production Board to set aside only 20 per cent of their manufacturers' type sole leather band production for repair of civilian shoes during May and succeeding months until further notice.

Charley (Red) Barrett, who not only won more games than any other hurler in the International League last season but was named the most valuable player in the circuit, made his first start with the Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday and, at the expense of the Giants, won his spurs.

LONDON, April 29 -- The United States Army Motor Maintenance Service admitted somewhat sheepishly today that the exigencies of war had forced it to weatherproof many of the American Jeeps in use here with pink paint.

The Council on Books in Wartime has set May 10 for the official observance of the tenth anniversary of the Nazi burning of books. The New York Public Library will be the scene of the city's commemoration of the event. The library flag will be lowered to half staff from noon to 1 P.M.

Under-Secretary of the Treasury Daniel W. Bell said yesterday that the $13,000,000,000 Second War Loan Drive would be oversubscribed by at least $2,500,000,000. That would seem to be a conservative statement. It is known that many institutions and corporations which placed orders early in the drive are planning to enter additional subscriptions.

With the Second War Loan Drive drawing to a close, the Federal Reserve banking figures issued yesterday, covering the week ended on Wednesday, showed much smaller net changes than those in the week before. The New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased their earning assets to a new high mark, gaining in loans as well as in investments.

Miss Ruth Draper will present a program of original monologues on the afternoon of May 11 at the residence of Mrs. John Henry Hammond, 9 East Ninety-first Street, as a benefit for the work of the Home Thrift Association, which maintains a community center at 350 East Eighty-eighth Street, and a Save Store near by where donated articles are sold at low prices.

As an aftermath of the Board of Education's rejection of Mark Starr for the $7,500 post of adult education director of the New York City school system, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that he had warned Ellsworth B. Buck, president of the board, that the first time he got a chance "he would fire him."

CHICAGO, April 29 -- Moderate buying of wheat futures attributed to mills and reports that the Army would purchased an undisclosed amount of flour on Monday gave the wheat market a firm undertone in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 -- Six New Jersey churches that comprised the East German Conference of the Methodist Church were accepted into the Newark Methodist Conference at the latter's eighty-sixth annual meeting that opened today in St. Luke's Church here.

Do not New York City schools belong to the people of New York City? Sometimes we wonder. On April 28 the regular meeting of the Board of Education was scheduled for 4 o'clock. At that hour more than 100 citizens were assembled in the meeting room at 110 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, April 29 -- The Yankees had trouble overcoming Al Simmons today at Fenway Park, but they got around to disposing of the baseball ancient and the Red Sox in the twelfth inning, and won their first overtime game of the 1943 campaign by a count of 7 to 3.

ST. LOUIS, April 29 -- The 1942 "lively" baseball was used at Sportsman's Park today, but it wasn't until the ninth inning that the world champion Cardinals really became accustomed to it. They tied their game with the Cubs at 3 -- all then and went on to win in the twelfth, 4 to 3.

WITH A U.S. ARMY AERIAL TASK FORCE, in the Central Pacific, April 23 (Delayed) -- American Army four-motored Liberator bombing planes, striking twice in force within thirty-six hours in record-making raids, left important phosphate works and airdromes at Japan's outlying bases of Nauru and Tarawa gutted and bomb-scarred today.

NEW DELHI, India, April 29 (U.P.) -- American fliers have achieved "excellent results" in attacks during the past three days on Japanese installations in Central Burma, the Tenth United States Air Force reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The text of the telegram President Roosevelt sent today to John L. Lewis and Thomas Kennedy of the United Mine Workers, ordering the idle soft coal miners to work, follows:...
LONDON, April 29 (UP) -- British light coastal forces sank an armed German trawler during an offensive sweep off the Netherlands coast before dawn today, the Admiralty announced.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 -- Striking miners in the Western Pennsylvania bituminous fields maintained a defiant attitude tonight toward President Roosevelt's order to return to work on Saturday. They expressed determination to stand by their leader, John L. Lewis, against the Federal Government. Coal production in this area was virtually suspended by wildcat strikes which continued to close mines, even after the President's order was made public.
LONDON, April 29 -- The stock markets brightened again today, showing some recovery from the check caused by the Russo-Polish dispute.

PITTSBURGH, April 29 (AP) -- Johnny Vander Meer pitched six-hit ball for his second victory of the year today as the Reds beat the Pirates, 6 -- 1. The Cincinnati southpaw had a shut-out until the ninth, when Bob Elliott lined a double and scored on singles by Vince DiMaggio and Pete Coscarart.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt rode 7,652 miles in trains and automobiles on his second wartime inspection tour. He touched twenty States on the sixteen-day trip and he also was in the District of Columbia and Mexico, where he met President Avila Camacho.

The tone of the reply of the Polish Government, very moderate in comparison with the peremptory language of the Soviet note, evinces a sincere desire to re-establish normal relations with Russia. The Poles reaffirm their loyalty to the United Nations and omit all reference to the ill-chosen, Nazi-inspired issue which caused the break between the two countries.

FORT RILEY, Kan., April 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- Here, in the geographical center of America, where the original Territorial Capitol of Kansas still stands, the President spent a relatively quiet Easter Sunday at a post which predates the Civil War.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Penalties which are best calculated to deter and discourage the repetition of their offenses should be imposed upon States and individuals that have committed international crimes, the ethics committee of the Catholic Association for International Peace declared today in a statement entitled "Retributive Justice After the War."

The contribution of Scouting to winning the war was further manifested yesterday with the signing of the first "Wartime Scouting Contract" between the 65,000 Boy Scouts of Greater New York and "Uncle Sam."

" Characters with pistols" drove Louis Stark, manager of the Latin Quarter night club, from his home in Forest Hills to the club at 200 West Forty-eighth Street at dawn yesterday, casually marched him past a group of cleaners and forced him to open the safe.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Wage increases approved by the War Labor Board since it adopted its general wage freeze policies will have no significant effect upon inflation, the American Federation of Labor asserted today in its monthly survey It argued that the President's "hold the line" inflation policy "freezes labor but not prices."

Our vast war production program is reaching its peak but the private enterprise system "will be definitely on the spot again" when the war ends, Senator Walter F. George declared in an address here last night at the annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Transocean flights to combat areas, long a commonplace for bombers and other large planes, are being made by Lightning fighters, the Army revealed today.

A report submitted yesterday by Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens member of the Board of Education and chairman of its instructional affairs committee, proposed an experiment in which several classes of New York City school children would be sent to camp with their teachers during the Summer.

Check transactions in the week ended on Wednesday were considerably below the peak of the previous week but well above the level of a year ago, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly statement.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- On the eve of the one hundred and forty-fifth anniversary of the Navy Department tomorrow, Secretary Knox tonight praised the fighting men of the Navy, the Coast Guard and the Marine Corps as equals with great admirals of the past.

The death of Roberto Bracco, the dramatist, is a shock to us who hoped to see him again in a free Italy. He was among the very few who always maintained that the poor Duce was a gigantic fraud, created by propaganda -- fascist and foreign propaganda.

Minee-Mo, second at almost 60-1 in the rich Excelsior Handicap last Saturday, was made the 7-to-20 favorite in yesterday's Woodside Purse at Jamaica, and made the grade by four lengths. For a couple of days winning favorites had been scarce and the J.B. Partridge color-bearer was backed even more heavily than Best Risk, who had broken the losing streak in the preceding race.
NEW DELHI, India, April 29 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Army Air Force communique:

While the country is awaiting the consequences of the President's firm message to the officials of the United Mine Workers is as good a time as any to look into the mechanism of a Congressional group which wasn't able to get very far with John L. Lewis. This group is known as the Truman committee, so called because its chairman is Senator Harry S. Truman of Missouri.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 29 (AP) -- H.H. Haagg's Kantar Run scored his second successive victory of the meeting when he took the Quonset Point Purse by a length and a half over the Rum-stick Lodge's Tierce at Narragansett Park today.
LONDON, April 29 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:
Mayor La Guardia again reminded the public yesterday that the next surprise air raid drill would be entirely different from previous tests.

MONTREAL, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- Veteran pilots engaged in the vital task of delivering bombers to Britain have quietly shattered peacetime records for North Atlantic flying, the Royal Air Force Transport Command revealed today in its first disclosure of best performances for flights between various points on the northern ferry route.

The action of the State War Council in giving Office of Price Administration orders in effect as of Wednesday the force of State laws was welcomed yesterday by spokesmen for the OPA, by Mayor La Guardia and representatives of retailer organizations as buttressing efforts to control rising living costs despite potentialities for increased confusion that were seen inherent in the council's resolution.

The Office of Civilian Supply has adopted a positive program of selecting essential items for production, insisting on the proper preference ratings for materials and providing equitable distribution so "that elaborate machinery requiring consumer purchase certificates and the like is unnecessary," Richard N. Johnson, director of the consumer goods division of the OCS, declared yesterday at a luncheon session at the annual Spring meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29 -- Eleven hard-to-convince owners prepared tonight to pay $500 for the privilege of trying to upset the highly regarded Count Fleet in the sixty-ninth Kentucky Derby Saturday.

Assistant District Attorney Burton B. Turkus demanded yesterday that Charles J. Farley, 22-year-old nephew of the late Sheriff Thomas M. Farley, and his co-defendant, Louis Caridad, 22, be convicted of first-degree murder. He summed up before Kings County Judge Louis Goldstein and a blue-ribbon jury, which has been hearing evidence for four weeks.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29 -- Pressure groups have developed a situation in this country which is "fast becoming a dangerous menace to our democratic system," the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce was told today by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, April 29 -- "A number of concrete recommendations'' that "it is felt will lead to the relief of a substantial number of refugees of all races and nationalities" have been made by the Anglo-American delegations to the refugee conference that closed this morning.

The exploits of the nation's heroes were recounted and a plea for "faith in our leadership and in ourselves" to bring about "the unconditional surrender of our enemies" was made at formal ceremonies yesterday commemorating the 153d anniversary of the inauguration of George Washington as President on the site of the Sub-Treasury Building.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29 -- The Dodgers again outscored the Phillies today, 4 -- 3, for a sweep of the three-game series, but it could not be called a clean sweep. Only two of the Brooklyn runs were earned. Of the twelve they counted in the three contests, seven were given to them by errors.

OSSINING, N.Y., April 29 -- Eli Shonbrun and John Cullen paid with their lives tonight in the electric chair at Sing Sing prison for a murder committed in New York City in connection with a theft that netted jewelry valued at $2,000.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Department store sales in the week ended April 24 were 29 per cent above sales in the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 15 per cent for the week ended April 15 over the corresponding week of last year.

THE South is not only that part of our country south of the Mason-Dixon line, not only an economic problem, a regional culture and the place where children learn that "next to Robert E. Lee was the Lord God Almighty" in that order -- it is a state of mind. New England also has a past; California and Texas also burst their seams with local pride.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph M. Stilwell and Major Gen. Claire L. Chennault, who head the American ground and air forces in the China-Burma area, held a long conference today with Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson and General George C. Marshall, Army chief of staff.

More than $600,000,000 has been saved by the government in construction costs alone as a result of improved processes developed in recent years by engineers and chemists of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Thomas H. Chilton, director of the technical division of the company's engineering department, declared last night in accepting Columbia University Engineering Schools Alumni Association Egleston Medal for "distinguished engineering achievement."

Once upon a time there was a piece of official information in the newspapers of which the public could make neither head nor tail; so, after a while, it was announced that a clarifying statement would be issued.

The principal scheduled novelty of the Ballet Theatre's program at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was the first appearance of Maria Karnilova in the title role of "Helen of Troy." Perhaps it is Alicia Markova's heroic struggle against fatigue which resulted in her momentary collapse, however, that deserves first mention.

Five hundred representatives of Zionist societies and Jewish communal organizations in Greater New York attended a luncheon yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore given in honor of Judge Morris Rothenberg, chairman of the National War Effort Committee of the Zionist Organization of America, which sold $20,000,000 worth of war bonds.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Lieut. Col. Pierpont M. Hamilton of New York, great-great-grandson of Alexander Hamilton, was "terrified" during the exploit in French Morocco last November for which he was awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor.

I found your editorial this morning, "The Militant Case," very interesting, but I feel that you have missed one of the major problems involved: that is, the use of the Postoffice Department as a censoring agency without proper judicial review.

CLEVELAND, April 29 -- Striking members of the Street Car and Motorcoach Operators Union, A.F. of L., voted today to end a seventeen-hour walkout on the municipal transportation system and return immediately to their jobs.

BELFAST, April 29 (Canadian Press) -- At the end of four-months' party strife, Conservative Premier John Miller Andrews was reported today to have tendered to the Duke of Abercorn, Governor of Northern Ireland, the resignation of his entire Cabinet.

The President has accepted Mr. Lewis's challenge and appealed over his head to the coal miners of the country. He has told them bluntly that the strikes which have cut down production "are not mere strikes against employers of this industry." They are "strikes against the Government of the United States itself."

The establishment of a Junior League Library Bureau under the chairmanship of Mrs. Eric Neville Baynes -- which will staff and maintain libraries in service clubs and settlement houses -- was announced as a new project of the league yesterday afternoon at the organization's annual meeting and election of officers, held in the clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

Judge John J. Freschi in the Adolescents' Part of General Sessions yesterday committed Josephine Tencz, 17 years old, to the House of Good Shepherd as a wayward minor, abrogating the indictment accusing her of abduction and impairing the morals of several schoolgirl prostitutes.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 29 -- John R. Longo, former deputy Hudson County clerk, pleaded innocent before Judge Thomas H. Brown in Hudson County Quarter Sessions Court here today to an indictment. charging him with "fraudulent alteration" of his 1941 primary voting record and was released in $2,500 bail.

LONDON, Friday, April 30 -- Russian airmen were reported early today to have shot down 116 German planes in two days of fighting in the Caucasus, where German dispatches said the Red Army had launched an "expected large-scale attack" in an effort to throw the Nazis into the Black Sea.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 29 -- A "first batch" of 18,500 officers, non-commissioned officers and men of the Royal Netherlands Army, released on parole by the occupation authorities in the Netherlands toward the end of 1940, were rounded up and placed in fourteen concentration camps near the German border, according to an official report from The Hague received here tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown, acting in accord with President Roosevelt's statement to John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers, assigned investigators today to delve into price levels on cost-of-living commodities in major coal-producing areas.

With interest in industrial research at its highest point in history it is evident that industry is planning very comprehensively for the future, Harold K. Ferguson, president of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders of Cleveland and New York, said yesterday in a message commemorating the twenty-fifth anniversary of the company.

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 -- New Jersey residents went through another surprise blackout test tonight, the second since Tuesday in the learn-by-doing-frequently educational campaign of the State Office of Civilian Defense Director.
LONDON, April 30 (Reuter) -- There has never been a film quite like "Mission to Moscow," The News Chronicle's Washington correspondent, Robert Waithman, reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- American sea and air forces, striking separate blows against Japan's far-flung defense line, were revealed today to have laid down a naval bombardment against the westernmost of the Aleutians and stabbed from the air at the heart of the Gilberts in the South Pacific.

LONDON, April 29 -- Pursuing its task of spreading destruction among the sources of German war strength, the Royal Air Force carried out last night the most extensive operations of this war. Seagoing "eggs" were dropped throughout the Baltic Sea, a great training ground for Nazi submarine crews preparing for their part in the Battle of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- President Roosevelt served an ultimatum on John L. Lewis today, directing the head of the United Mine Workers to return striking bituminous miners to their jobs by 10 A.M. Saturday under penalty of having the Chief Executive use all his powers "as President and as Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy to protect the national interest and to prevent further interference with the successful prosecution of the war."

NEWARK, N.J., April 29 (AP) -- Dick Conger, Toronto right-hander who pitched the first eighteen innings of the epic twenty-one-frame battle against Baltimore recently, came back today and tossed a brilliant four-hitter to turn back Newark, 8 to 1, for the fourth straight triumph by the Leafs.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) -- One good inning was all the Senators needed today to defeat the Athletics, 5 to 1, thanks in part to the wildness of Pitchers Donald Black and Roger Wolff, who gave only five hits but walked eight men.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, April 30 (AP) -- Liberators executed a strong morning raid yesterday on the Japanese seaplane base on the island of Amboina in the Netherlands Indies.

WASHINGTON, April 29 -- The intensity with which American troops are now being trained far exceeds that of the First World War, Secretary Stimson said today on returning from a 6,000-mile tour of important camps.
With investment bankers engaged in the Second War Loan Drive, flotations of new securities here in April were curtailed. New bond emissions were the smallest for an April since 1933.

Sergeant Isadore Siegelman and Patrolmen Anthony De Nardo and Stanley Olszewski of the East 126th Street police station, who were suspended on charges of accepting gratuities in line of duty, were placed on one year's probation yesterday by Police Commissioner Valentine.

Asserting that the Roosevelt Administration was making "a concerted attempt to control the press," Miss Vivien Kellems, Connecticut industrialist, addressing the Westchester County Federation of Women in the Hotel Biltmore yesterday, compared the barring of reporters at the forthcoming food conference in Hot Springs, Va. as an example of "how they do it in Germany."

LONDON, April 30 -- Business on the stock markets here was at a minimum today, but the tone remained steady. Old Consols and local loans were down 1/8 each in the gilt-edge section, while home rails showed further improvement, Great Western rising 1/2 to 64 1/4 and London, Midland Scottish, 1/8 to 33 7/8. Foreign rails were firm.

Today's events: Louis Teicher, piano, Juilliard School of Music, 2 P.M.; Ernest Hutcheson, piano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Golden Hill Chorus, Town Hall, 8:30; Jane and Joan Rosenfeld, duo-pianists, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30; "Carmen," Mascagni Opera Guild, Community Center, 270 West Eighty-ninth Street, 8.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- With the war forcing the West to change rapidly from an agricultural economy into a great industrial empire, Governors or their representatives from nine States viewed with concern here today increasing centralization of power at Washington and called for alertness in the post-war era to protect individual enterprise and put new emphasis on local and State government.

Captain Joseph J. Foss, outstanding Marine Corps flier, who shot down twenty-six Japanese planes in ten weeks of action over Guadalcanal, attributed his success yesterday to the teamwork of the seven other pilots of his "Flying Circus," which he said consisted of "four farmers and four city slickers."

LONDON, April 30 -- Moscow has no intention of attempting to establish a rival left wing Polish Government in Russia. This became known here from direct authority today. In a sense it can be regarded as good news, inasmuch as it indicates that, however definite the Kremlin's break with Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski's government in London may be, the Soviet is still willing to keep open its discussions with Britain.

ROBERT M. HUTCHINS adds persistence to his persuasiveness. For lo! these many years he has been insisting that man is a rational animal, or at least an animal capable of rationality. The aim of human reason is to seek the good life. The good life is that which abounds in wisdom, virtue and enough material wealth to keep one from feeling the irrational compulsion to steal.

Twenty-three newspaper book reviewers and one magazine book critic participated in the Pulitzer Prize poll conducted by the Saturday Review of Literature, whose results were announced yesterday. Six of the critics chose Le Grand Cannon's "Look to the Mountain," as the best novel, with James Gould Cozzen's "The Just and the unjust," as the runner-up with four votes.

If the Soviet-Polish break could be considered solely as a battle in the war between Russia and Germany, it throws an interesting light on a question lurking in the background of the struggle. Would the Germans have blown up the Polish issue if they had any thought or hope of coming to terms with Russia?
FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 30 -- A tiny "war plant," operated by two teen aged brothers, is producing delicately tooled airplane parts for the Army Air Forces -- and with apparent success.

WITH AN ARMY AIR TASK FORCE, in the Central Pacific, April 24 (Delayed) -- Major Gen. Willis H. Hale, commander of the Seventh Air Force, studied a map of the Central Pacific combat zone today and promised that this week's heavy American bomber assaults on Japan's outlying bases at Nauru and Tarawa were merely a "warm-up" for the blows to come against the strongholds guarding the main approaches to the Japanese Empire.

A 28-year-old Queens housewife threw her two young children from a roof of a six-story apartment building in the Queensbridge Housing Development shortly before noon yesterday and then jumped after them. All were killed.

The possibility of merging two rival unions now disputing membership control over about 400 ticket sellers and cashiers employed at the Jamaica race track was discussed by leaders of the A.F. of L. group yesterday following completion of hearings before an examiner of the New York State Labor Relations Board, at 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, to determine which group should be designated as bargaining agent for the workers.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Sixteen prime cuts, steaks and roasts, of beef, veal and pork will cost a point more and twenty-five variety of meats, canned fish and other special products of relatively low point value a point less after midnight tomorrow, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Mexican economic crisis, one of the factors said to have brought Presidents Roosevelt and Camacho together for their recent conference and agreement to name a joint committee to recommend a solution, arises in main from problems created by Mexico's favorable balance of trade with the United States.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 30 -- Reversing pledges made by William Green, president of the A.F.L., and Lloyd Thrush, president of the Progressive Miners of America, an A.F.L. affiliate, that the union would not strike in conjunction with the United Mine Workers, two Illinois locals voted for a walkout tonight.

LONDON, April 30 (U.P.) -- Maxwell Anderson disclosed today that his dramatization of the Battle of Bataan, "The Eve of St. Mark," soon would be produced in Britain with a cast made up entirely of United States soldiers, Waacs and Red Cross girls, and sponsored by the United States Army, with performances free to Allied servicemen.

In answer to Frank Kellerman's letter appearing in THE TIMES last Saturday, I would like to say that it is pitiful that there are still a few persons in this country who believe professional sports are detrimental to the war effort and that they should be abolished during this time of stress.

A SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, April 30 -- This is the story of Delmar D. Wiley's 218 days as a castaway, a saga of lonely survival on the open sea and on the beaches of islets fringing the enemy-held Northern Solomons.

One of the first advertising campaigns aimed at creating European interest in American postwar products will be started in twenty-two foreign newspapers this month by Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company of Philadelphia.

NEW DELHI, India, April 30 (AP) -- Sharp local fighting has flared up again in some parts of the Arakan district of Burma, with British and Japanese forces alternately attacking and counterattacking, but there has been no change in the general situation, a British communique said today.
BALTIMORE, April 30 -- Nine distance stars were named today to contest the $20,000-added Dixie Handicap at Pimlico tomorrow, with chief support centering on Riverland and Attention.

Beginning tomorrow, meetings will be held throughout the country emphasizing "Christian Family Week." They will end on Mother's Day. Sermons tomorrow will in many cases deal with this emphasis. In connection with the programs there will be a special luncheon at 2:30 P.M. Thursday at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, for ministers.
NUTLEY, N.J., April 30 -- A ticking noise in a package mailed early this afternoon by a "mysteriously acting" woman to the Rev. Charles E. Coughlin at Royal Oak, Mich., caused a bomb scare here.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Roosevelt will start steps for government seizure of the country's coal mines at 10 A.M. tomorrow when his ultimatum to John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers expires, it was reported authoritatively tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- A battle of words preliminary to the final debate on pay-as-you-go taxation opening in the House on Monday will come tomorrow with the publication of the majority and minority reports of the Ways and Means Committee, presenting arguments for and against the committee's new bill.

The annual meeting of the Vocational Service for Juniors at the Uptown Club, 60 East Forty-second Street, yesterday re-elected Mrs. Edward C. Henderson as president. The organization's entire slate of present officers, with the exception of Mrs. Miles Kinsey, who is no longer in New York, also was re-elected as recommended by the nominating committee.

An upward trend in the demand for industrial real estate throughout the country as a whole was reported yesterday by Bethel T. Hunt of Memphis, Tenn., president of the Society of Industrial Realtors, who is on a tour of twelve of the principal cities of the East and the Midwest.

LONDON, Saturday, May 1 (AP) -- Russian troops, once more on the move in the Northwestern Caucasus, were reported by Moscow early today to have captured "several key enemy positions" in a plane-supported drive that the Germans said was another big Red Army offensive in which 150,000 men were attacking.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- West Virginia and Pennsylvania lead the nation's twenty-seven bituminous coal-producing States in tonnage, with Illinois and Kentucky ranking next.

TRENTON, April 30 -- The effort of Republican leaders to force voting machines upon Hudson County in an attempt to cut down the Democratic majorities customarily rolled up by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City received another setback today when the Supreme Court set aside a contract made by the State House Commission for purchase of machines.

An informal discussion on various topics relating to conservation, sportsmanship and the war may develop in New York when Dr. Ira Gabrielson, chief of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, comes here next week for a brief visit.

LONDON, April 30 (U.P.) -- A Yugoslav Government spokesman admitted today that General Draja Mikhailovitch's guerrilla Chetniks were fighting Russian-supported Partisans as well as Axis forces in the mountains of Yugoslavia because he considered the rival patriots in rebellion against his authority.

William W. Inglis, chairman of the Anthracite Operators Negotiation Committee, which for the past month has been in session with representatives of the United Mine Workers Union over a new contract, telegraphed Secretary Perkins yesterday pledging cooperation with the War Labor Board, to which she certified the dispute.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 1 -- The Japanese have opened a submarine attack in force to the east of Australia, the High Command reported today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Qualifying his statement with a warning "not to attach too much significance to it," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox announced at his press conference today that losses from enemy submarine sinkings had been "much lower" in April than during the previous month.

Life should be comfortable for the stay-at-homes this Summer. The family that is conserving gas and patriotically foreswearing non-essential traveling can console itself with a redecorated terrace, garden or back yard. Throughout the city, shops offer home-bound civilians all the "fixin's" in the line of Summer furniture.

The Second War Loan drive will end formally tonight at midnight. The nation-wide goal to raise $13,000,000,000 already has been achieved and the indications are that when the tabulations are completed next week the sales figure will be in excess of $16,000,000,000.

Churchill Downs will see today the strangest running of the Kentucky Derby in its history. Restrictions on rail accommodations and on gasoline have been so stringently applied that the sixty-ninth running of this famous contest will go down in history as the "Street-Car" Derby. Only automobiles with "A" coupons will be admitted to the grounds.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- Navy communique 360:
Sherwood B. Davidge, who has been associated with Moore Schley, one of the oldest firms in Wall Street, since 1927, has been admitted as a partner.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., April 30 -- Mayor Frank Hague reopened today the legal battle begun during the last war to reduce to a minimum the hazards attending the loading of munitions and other explosives in this city.

Shipments of the United Aircraft Corporation for the quarter ended with March rose to $159,169,553 from $110,137,717 in the first three months of 1943, according to the statement issued for publication today.

NEWARK, N.J., April 30 -- The district embracing Essex, Hudson and Union Counties may be designated a critical area by June 1 unless all conditions of the war manpower program are met within the next few weeks, it was asserted here today by Major Howard J. Lepper, area director of the War Manpower Commission, after he had conferred with representatives of major industries in this district.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.
A submarine lieutenant who traveled 9,000 miles by plane for his wedding here tomorrow declared yesterday that he was "more nervous than I've been any time in the last eighteen months."

NEWARK, N.J., April 30 -- Walter E. Edge, in a formal announcement today of his candidacy for the Republican Gubernatorial nomination in this State, pledged he would oppose Republican deals with the Democratic organization and that he would work for revision of the State Constitution.

Lewis Merrill, president of the C.I.O. United Office and Professional Workers of America, received yesterday another month's deferment from military service by Local Draft Board 17, 412 Sixth Avenue, after previously having been notified to report for induction on May 7.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in April was slightly smaller than in the previous month, with sales exceeding the two-million-share mark in four sessions, compared with the five sessions of March. Sales of 33,553,559 shares for the month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, were the second largest of any month since December, 1941, and the largest of a corresponding month since April, 1937.

CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- The Kansas City, St. Louis Chicago Railroad Company filed today a voluntary bankruptcy petition in Federal Court here asking that its affairs be reorganized under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act.

The Tokyo radio quoted Major Gen. Nakao Yahagi, chief of the army press section of Imperial Headquarters, as announcing in a Nagoya speech yesterday that Japan had completed establishment of strategic bases in the Southwest Pacific, "thus paving the way for contemplated new operations."

LIPHOOK, Hampshire, England, April 30 (U.P.) -- The Webbs, along with Ramsay Macdonald and their close friend, George Bernard Shaw, were leading figures in the intellectual Fabian Society out of which gradually developed the British Labor party.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The War Food Administration set up a new organization today to handle the farm labor program and announced that it intended to mobilize a United States Crop Corps of 3,500,000 workers to supplement the efforts of the skilled workers whom it will keep on or restore to the farms by virtue of authority recently granted under Presidential directives.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Russian sources here said today that Moscow had offered a compromise concerning the former residents of parts of Poland who are now in Russia, but that the Polish Government had declined.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The United States has severed political relations with Admiral Georges Robert, the Vichy-dominated High Commissioner of Martinique and Guadeloupe in the West Indies, and has terminated all agreements this government had previously entered into with him.

Most major coal companies and spokesmen for coal-consuming utilities and other industries in this city reported yesterday that a stoppage of mining would cause no immediate curtailment of activities here.

BERNE, Switzerland, April 30 -- "Thanks to the generosity of the German Chancellor," to use a stock phrase of the Vichy news agency, Chief of Government Pierre Laval has had his sop. Adolf Hitler received him yesterday, and private reports from Vichy tonight indicate that the Information Ministry is working overtime to present this news tomorrow in the most favorable light for M. Laval.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 30 -- The will of Edgar F. Luckenbach, president of the Luckenbach Steamship Company, who died last Monday, was filed for probate here today. The document, dated Jan. 7, 1939, had two codicils, one as of Dec. 5, 1940, the second of July 13, 1942.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30 -- David O. Selznick, who has not produced a picture since "Rebecca" more than two years ago, will resume activity for United Artists this Summer. Under the company designation of Vanguard Productions, Selznick first will produce a film version of Margaret Buell Wilder's first novel, "Since You Went Away," which he bought recently for $30,000 from galley proofs before its publication.

TRENTON, N.J., April 30 -- Because Governor Charles Edison failed specifically to notify Acting Governor I. Grant Scott, Cape May Republican, that he had returned to the State on June 25, 1942, from Asheville, N.C. to assume his executive duties, the New Jersey Supreme Court today refused to declare null and void a law signed by the Acting Governor, requiring liquor importers and rectifiers to sell their products to wholesalers when financial responsibility is shown.

Washington's patience with Admiral Georges Robert, High Commissioner of Martinique, has at last given out. Yesterday it was announced that our consul-general at Fort de France has been withdrawn. The note with which the State Department accompanied this action tells Admiral Robert definitely where he stands.

Auxiliary Bishop J. Francis A. McIntyre of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will ordain twenty-five deacons to the priesthood at 8 A.M. today in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street. The group will come from St. Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, Yonkers.
OTTAWA, April 30 (AP) -- A streamlined, mile-by-mile protection of the North Atlantic convoy route to Great Britain was announced today, with Canada and Great Britain sharing the responsibility.

Thirty days gets April. Many of us feel that she'd get what she deserved if it was life imprisonment at hard labor. April is a favorite with poets. Apparently they never go out of doors, depend upon their inspiration for heat and never have to bother about coal or fuel oil.

" Ung Dam Med Tur" ("A Young Lady With Luck"), a Swedish importation, will have its local premiere today at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. The comedy with music stars Sonja Wigert and features Ake Ohberg and Dagmar Ebbesen.

A Tokyo dispatch broadcast yesterday by the Berlin radio said that Japan was taking over today the cable lines of the Danish-owned Great Northern Telegraph Company between Vladivostok and Shanghai with a relay station at Nagasaki, in Southwestern Japan.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 30 -- While the Germans threw powerful but futile counter-attacks at the Allies at most key points along the Tunisian front yesterday, patrols of the French Africa Corps reached the shore of Lake Achkel at a point on the northern coastal road seventeen miles west of the Bizerte naval base and then dropped back three miles to establish a position on the height of Kef Touro.
Establishment of American bases in the Fiji Islands is a matter of national interest, says a bulletin of the National Geographic Society.

ATLANTA, April 30 -- Announcement that cotton textile manufacturing interests have begun banding together for a cooperative research program with the objective of checking the age-old trend of the industry to migrate to low labor cost countries, and of meeting post-war competition from paper, synthetic fiber, metal and other industries, was made here this afternoon in an address by Fuller E. Callaway Jr. before the convention of the American Cotton Manufacturers Association.

An exhibition pertinent to May Day will open today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. It comprises the "May-Day Sketchbook of Diego Rivera," in which are forty-four water-colors made in Moscow by the Mexican artist at the tenth anniversary celebration of the October revolution.

Pierre Laval, French Chief of Government, was injured by a time bomb while returning to Paris from a conference with Adolf Hitler, the Brazzaville radio of the Fighting French in Equatorial Africa said last night in a broadcast reported to the Office of War Information by the United States Government's foreign broadcast intelligence service.
MOSCOW, April 30 (AP) -- The noon communique:

DETROIT, April 30 -- Following a flurry of wildcat strikes which yesterday and today tied up three divisions of the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant and involved 2,850 workers, the company issued a sharp statement laying the blame on draft-age workers, the majority of them employed in the last few months.
NEW DELHI, India, April 30 (AP) -- A communique:

The literature of the ancient and honorable pastime of golf, the game which has withstood war, fires, floods and the duffer's dirge through several centuries, suffered a dimout of semi-blinding proportions in 1942.

Following is the text of the reply addressed yesterday to President Roosevelt by John L. Lewis and other officials of the United Mine Workers rejecting his ultimatum that they order idle soft coal miners back to work by 10 A.M. today:

It is not possible for any farm program to be written into law and completely satisfy our diverse agriculture or the varying types of farming which make up American agriculture. So it seems to me to be confusing for publications such as THE TIMES to state off-hand that any particular effort of the government to aid farmers has been of little benefit.

George P. Alderson, State Tax Commissioner for West Virginia, who is ex officio chief inspector of public offices, has issued a report of his office, giving details of State, county, municipal and special district bonds outstanding.

Things are at sixes, and sevens in the campaign of American women physicians and surgeons to get into the armed forces as commissioned officers, according to impatient spokesmen of the profession, and likewise according to Army and Navy procurement officers, who declared yesterday in the icy and impersonal tone of the service procurement man that the response had been scarcely worth mentioning.

The Ford Motor Company Building at the northeast corner of Broadway and Fifty-fourth Street, one of the outstanding units of the old "automobile row" developed by manufacturers and dealers in that neighborhood, has been purchased for cash by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and will be used as the new national headquarters of that organization, David Dubinsky, president of the labor group, announced yesterday.

A declaration that the price inflationary crisis is really over and that "deflationary forces are already in action" was made yesterday by Willard C. Wheeler of Sales Traffic Digest in an address at the Spring convention of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Biltmore.

A field of fifteen, including the top-weighted Doublrab, is named for the $5,000 added Jamaica Handicap, Metropolitan Jockey Club feature today. The name stake for the Jamaica track seldom, if ever, before attracted so good a field, and the hope of officials is that the weather will moderate so that there will be few scratches.
One of New York City's landmarks was inducted into the services yesterday when the old Whitelaw Reid mansion was opened as the Women's Military Services Club.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, said tonight that German planes and submarines had not stopped supplies reaching our forces in Tunisia, "but John L. Lewis may stop them."

Mayor La Guardia intervened in the city's acute potato shortage yesterday when he announced that he had arranged through the Markets Department to begin the sale of twenty carloads, or 600,000 pounds, of new California potatoes in the city's enclosed markets this morning.

Retail sales here this week tended to be spotty in comparison with a year ago, merchants reported yesterday. Increases were noted for some stores, while others which were up against 1942 anniversary sales figures figured on a loss for the week.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Senate's decision to return at once to consideration of anti-strike legislation to strengthen the President's hand in meeting stoppages of production of coal and other war essentials, provided a probable battle ground today for an attempt within that body to modify the recent order of Paul V. McNutt, Manpower Commissioner, for general induction of married and unmarried men into the armed services this year.
LONDON, April 30 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

BALBOA, Canal Zone, April 30 -- Three American women have started their own campaign to prove that they are qualified to serve in the United States merchant marine. They have started on a United Nations ship as mess attendants and are regular members of the crew, living in special quarters with the legend "Three Mess Boys" over the door.

OTTAWA, April 30 -- Canada and Great Britain will in the future take charge of all trade convoys from Northern Atlantic ports to the United Kingdom, while the United States retains strategic responsibility for the Western Atlantic, including escort operations not related to British trade convoys and local Canadian traffic, it was announced today.

TRENTON, April 30 -- Apparently irked by the action of Selective Service Board 2 of the Union-Springfield district in posting a list of registrants who have been deferred at the request of their employers, Colonel Edgar N. Bloomer, State Selective Service Director, announced today that a "thorough investigation" of the incident would be made, beginning Monday.

Government food policies formulated and enforced by the Office of Price Administration and the Food Distribution Administration need a thorough overhauling and reorientation if the Army is to get enough foods for its needs and food riots are to be avoided in large industrial centers, members of the Republican Congressional Food Study Committee were informed yesterday at a public hearing in the Hotel New Yorker.

John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers refused yesterday to comply with President Roosevelt's ultimatum that idle soft coal miners in the Appalachian wage dispute be ordered back to work by 10 A.M. today and that the union submit the controversy to the adjudication of the War Labor Board.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, April 30 (AP) -- A communique:

DETROIT, April 30 -- Representatives of 300,000 members of the United Automobile Workers of America, C.I.O., employes of General Motors Corporation, meeting here today, heard Walter P. Reuther, U.A.W.-C.I.O. vice president, demand that General Motors establish a post-war security fund for the benefit of its regular employes, including men in the armed forces.

The stock market completed yesterday a month of nervous disorders in the course of which it was first pried loose from its strong upturn by domestic economic developments, then snapped back to bridge the gap between the highs and the lows, and finally it closed out April in an area of indecision due to the soft-coal labor crisis.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 1 (AP) -- The noon communique.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- President Roosevelt assured the American Society of International Law tonight that nations of the globe must unite in a definite body of law to preserve civilization and prevent "a recurrence of the present reign of lawlessness."
LONDON, Saturday, May 1 (U.P.) -- The text of a May Day order of the day by Marshal Joseph Stalin, Premier of Russia, recorded from the Moscow radio:

The Salmagundi Club's Gold Medal of Honor was presented last night by Georg Lorber at the annal get-away dinner to Frederick Ballard Williams, N.A., for his outstanding services to the club and his achievements in art. The Gold Medal of Honor has been awarded only five times in the seventy-two years of the club's existence.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30 -- This strangest of all Kentucky Derbies came up with a new wrinkle today as Count Fleet and eleven other 3-year-olds were entered to run the mile and a quarter tomorrow for a necklace of roses worth $60,725.

Mrs. Henry P. Davison of New York City and Locust Valley, L. I., has declined to accept the designa!tion of "New York State Mother of 1943" after haviffg been notified I last week by the American iVfothers i Committee of the Golden Rule !Foundation that she had been i selected and would receive a medal Sunday, l{ay 9.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 30 -- Governor Harold Stassen of Minnesota left the Governor's chair this week to join the Navy, carrying with him the political goodwill of the great majority of Minnesota voters.

The American Cable and Radio Corporation and subsidiaries had a consolidated net income, after all operating expenses and other charges, of $830,249 in 1942, John L. Merrill, chairman of the board, disclosed yesterday in his annual report to stockholders.
LONDON, Saturday, May 1 (U.P.) -- The Russian Friday midnight communique as broadcast from Moscow:

Leading gymnasts from several sections of the country will participate in the annual national A. A. U. championships today at the West Side Y. M. C. A. Ten men's and seven women's individual crowns will be decided during the afternoon and evening.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Based on reports from 19,633 stores representing most kinds of businesses except department stores, sales of independent retailers in thirty-four States gained 13 per cent in March as compared with March, 1942, J.C. Capt, Director of the Census, announced today.
The German Friday communique as broadcast by Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Bob Johnson, veteran fly-chaser, selected today to strike the first blow he has made against Yankee pitching this season, and sent the American League champions down to defeat in their second overtime game in two days as the Senators won the series opener, 2 to 1.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 30 -- Five New York City radio stations won today a total of six citations among twenty-five for excellence in educational broadcasting awarded by the Institute for Education by Radio, which opened this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 30 -- A "great expansion" in the number of shares and amount of bonds listed in our markets was envisioned for the post-war era by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in an address to the Commonwealth Club here today.

In his warning to Mr. Buck that he intended to fire him "the first time I got the chance," Mayor La Guardia has done a disservice to public education. As president of the Board of Education, Mr. Buck is bound to vote according to the dictates of his best judgment. Were he to do otherwise he would be guilty of malfeasance of office.
Among the apartment leases reported yesterday was one for a suite in 430 East Fifty-seventh Street, taken by Eric Hatch, author and playwright, through Douglas L. Elliman Co.

RENO, Nev., April 30 -- Sally Bates Lorentz was granted a divorce today from Pare Lorentz, writer and moving picture producer, on charges of cruelty. It was announced that an agreement had been reached regarding the custody of their two children.

Cotton prices moved within a narrow range in dull trading yesterday as traders watched developments in the coal wage controversy. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures ended the session unchanged to 5 points lower than Thursday's close, with the spot month again the strongest of the six active contracts.

As in the preceding two weeks, the new investment market here this week was only mildly active, with only two issues of tax-exempt securities offered to the public. They amounted to $9,000,000 and compared with a single flotation for $250,000 a week ago and with $10,286,000 for four municipal loans in this week of last year.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (U.P.) -- The War Department announced today the award of the Air Medal to 111 officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Air Forces for anti-submarine patrol flights over the Atlantic.

Two intercollegiate rowing regattas are down for decision this afternoon. On the Harlem River Columbia's varsity, fresh from its upset of Navy last week, is favored over Rutgers in a dual race and at Philadelphia the Adams Cup has attracted four crews.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The nation's wheat surplus was admitted officially today to have disappeared practically when President Roosevelt suspended wheat import quotas to permit the importation of Canadian and Australian wheat for feed purposes.

JERUSALEM, Palestine, April 29 (Delayed) -- Schemes of permanent value for introduction in Palestine during the post-war era were outlined in Jerusalem today by the new reconstruction commissioner, Sir Douglas Harris, in an important statement covering most aspects of the Holy Land's eventual development.

Unlimited financial aid to carry on labor's underground warfare in France and other Axis-controlled countries and the additional promise that American workers will continue "out-producing the enemy" in tanks, planes, ships and guns highlight the recorded May Day address being internationally shortwaved around the clock since last night from Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, through the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Production of cotton fabrics will be increased by about 220,000,000 yards yearly without use of additional facilities, the WPB announced, as the result of an order it issued today further simplifying constructions of a long list of cotton material.

FREMONT, Neb., April 30 -- Germany cannot be bombed or starved into defeat and the church remains the only unconquered and surviving agency other than nazism in all occupied Europe, the Rev. Stewart Herman, attache of the American Embassy in Berlin, said today at the annual religious emphasis week at Midland College.

OTTAWA, April 30 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands today marked her thirty-fourth birthday by broadcasting a message to her German-oppressed countrymen, declaring that "our one purpose is to go back to Holland."

Outdoor flowers nodding their bright heads on the flower stalls this week bring a true touch of Spring to New York. The New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets announced yesterday that, with the appearance of first Long Island-grown daffodils on the market, the flower season is coming close to home.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (Science Service) -- Those new tires you are going to get, after the liquidation of Hitler, Tojo and Co., are likely to have a radically new type of reinforcement built into them. Instead of the new standard cords of rayon or cotton they will contain solid strands, or monofils, of nylon-type plastic -- the kind of thing already familiar as toothbrush bristles, fishing line leaders and tennis-racket strings.

Scheduled yesterday for their second meeting of the season, the first-place Dodgers and seventh-place Giants were kept apart by rain. This afternoon they will catch up promptly by playing two games at the Polo Grounds. They tangle in another double-header tomorrow.
CHICAGO, April 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Dejartment of Agriculture follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- Former President Herbert Hoover, in a message to be read at the National Conference for Palestine of the United Palestine Appeal, which opens here tomorrow, declares that "in these days of tyranny and persecution Palestine looms as a shining symbol of strength and hope to Jews, not only in Europe but throughout the world."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- To prevent war labor demands from "sabotaging the academic education of youth," Dr. Frederick Allen, director of the Philadelphia Child Guidance Clinic, today proposed to the Children's Bureau of the Labor Department that schools and employers unite to make wartime child employment part of education programs.

The University Women's Chorus of New York gave its Spring concert last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall before an appreciative audience of good size. Because Captain Morris Watkins, regular conductor of the ensemble, is on leave of absence serving with the United States Marine Corps, Lowell P. Beveridge, acting conductor, was on the podium.

Despite my admiration for Hugh Gibson, important statements made in his letter in THE TIMES of April 22 must not be suffered to go unchallenged. When a physician predicts that a certain thing will happen and it does happen, his diagnosis of the disease is said to have been correct.

PITTSBURGH, April 30 -- Sixty thousand residents of McKeesport, Greensburg and Leechburg, including 2,500 school children, were deprived of transportation today by a strike of nearly 100 American Federation of Labor bus drivers and mechanics of the Penn Transit Company to enforce demands for higher pay.

While there is no unanimity of opinion in the paper industry about supplies for this year, the conviction is growing that production will be sufficiently high to take care of all needs, according to opinions expressed yesterday. The chief difficulty lies in the increasing shortage of pulpwood which is now reflected in reports from a few pulp mills that they may have to close within a month or two unless wood supplies increase.

Alicia Markova received a most affectionate welcome last night from the Ballet Theatre's audience at the Metropolitan Opera House, where everybody was apparently anxious to show her how glad they were that she had recovered from her indisposition of the night before.
