CHICAGO, April 30 -- Irving W. Clark, manager of the Westinghouse electric appliance division's home building department, predicted today that most of the new homes which will be built in the early post-war period would not differ much from those built just before the war.

An exhibition of ancient Chinese and modern European paintings and drawings opened with a private view yesterday afternoon at the Bignou Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street. It opens to the public today and will run through June 12.

A twenty-year study of 450 centenarians, men and women, reveals that "life for some may begin at 100 instead of 40," it was reported yesterday before the annual meeting of the Eastern Psychological Association at Hunter College. The study was presented by Dr. Grace E. Bird, professor emeritus of the Rhode Island State College of Education.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 30 (U.P.) -- Regional authorities of the Office of Price Administration touched off an intensive "policing" campaign throughout New England today by assigning forty inspectors to Narragansett Park's million-dollar race track to check patrons' automobiles for violation of gasoline rationing regulations.

Distrist Attorney Frank S. Hogan made an unusual move yesterday to place a padlock on the fourteen-story Hotel Hermitage, in Seventh Avenue, near Forty-second Street, as an outcome of the recent Special Sessions conviction of two of its owners for operating the Hermitage as a house of prostitution.

The drive by the Secret Service and the Office of Price Administration against the gasoline black market resulted yesterday in the arraignment of Sidney Seewald, an unemployed salesman, on a charge of possession and sale of counterfeit gasoline ration coupons.
I read with interest Edward Alden Jewell's article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 25, "Morale -- A Lesson From Art in Time of War."
Two apartment sales on the Upper West Side were included in the residential deals reported in Manhattan yesterday.

The New York State Labor Relations Board yesterday ordered the dissolution of the Zone Oil Employes Independent Union as a company-controlled organization, and also ordered the Zone Oil Trucking Corporation, an affiliate of the Paragon Oil Company, 75 Bridgewater Street, Brooklyn, to rehire nine men allegedly dismissed for their activities on behalf of an A.F. of L. local.

LONDON, Saturday, May 1 (U.P.) -- Britain's heavy bombers, turning the Allied air offensive back to land targets after two days in which it had been directed chiefly against enemy sea lanes, attacked Germany last night, officials said today.

The sixteen-story loft building on a plot 100 by 98.9 feet at 44 to 50 West Twenty-eighth Street has been resold after a year's ownership by David W. Frankel, operator, to an investor represented by Bernard Strauss, attorney. It was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $493,000 in a deal negotiated by Williams Co.

Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne will go to England during the Summer to appear in two plays, Robert E. Sherwood's "There Shall Be No Night" and the Ferenc Molnar "The Guardsman," in both of which they have played on Broadway.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 30 -- The young intellectual leaders of Brazil are prepared to fight any imperialism, economic or cultural, and feel that there must be independence of thought and expression to preserve the integrity of the country, Professor Alfranio Coutinho told a group of philosophers from all parts of the Western Hemisphere today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Appealing to all Americans to support their government and its price stabilization program "in this crisis in the coal fields," Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, disclosed tonight a program to hold down the cost of living for wage-earners, including extension of price control to "every important commodity" and "a rollback of prices out of hand."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The first Japanese to be discovered on Guadalcanal since American marines and soldiers consolidated their occupation of that island last February were "intercepted and wiped out" by United States troops three days ago, the Navy Department revealed in a communique today.

WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) -- The government charged two corporations and eight of their officials today with packaging rejected dried egg powder for United States armed forces and for England and Russia, and with stealing tons of the food products.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Following is the text of the note sent by the State Department to Admiral Georges Robert, High Commissioner of Martinique and Guadeloupe:...

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- If the experience of a boy from Avenue B, New York City, proves anything, all you have to do to keep from being drowned when the waves wash you off the deck of your destroyer is to wait for another wave to wash you on to the deck of another destroyer.

Figures so far issued indicate that the railroads of the country in March enjoyed their largest gross revenues for a single month since the start of the war, with several carriers reporting the largest gross for any month in history.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Appealing to all Americans to support their government and its price stabilization program "in this crisis in the coal fields," Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, disclosed tonight a program to hold down the cost of living for wage-earners, including extension of price control to "every important commodity" and "a rollback of prices out of hand."

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The first Japanese to be discovered on Guadalcanal since American marines and soldiers consolidated their occupation of that island last February were "intercepted and wiped out" by United States troops three days ago, the Navy Department revealed in a communique today.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- Wheat traders today placed a bearish construction on an announcement that the import quota system on that grain had been eliminated in order to permit government agencies to bring in Canadian and Australian grain for feed purposes, but as this wheat will not be available for use by mills, the effect was short-lived and a good rally from the low point followed.

Ladenburg, Thalman Co., special agents, have notified holders of State of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, 7 per cent forty-year external bonds of 1926 that funds have been received sufficient to pay 17 1/2 per cent of the face amount of the coupons due on May 1, 1941. If accepted, payment will constitute payment in full.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 30 -- Governor Charles Edison expressed fear in a speech here tonight that the States, unless they accept their responsibilities, would "wither away" and lose their identity in an all-powerful Federal Government.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- With a record-breaking total expected by the time the Second War Loan drive ends tomorrow, Under-Secretary of the Treasury Daniel Bell and Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard tonight urged investors to get in their money at the eleventh hour.

WITH THE AMERICAN INFANTRY SOUTHWEST OF MATEUR, Tunisia, April 29 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Viciously fighting Germans, holding fortified hills, held up the advance of the American Second Corps in two sectors today.

LONDON, April 30 (U.P.) -- The Netherlands Government appealed to its former soldiers in the homeland today to defy all orders by German occupation authorities that would return them to concentration camps.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 (AP) -- Armour Co. of Delaware, meat packers at Chicago, filed today a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the proposed issuance of $35,000,000 in thirty-five-year, 7 per cent cumulative income debentures due on April 1, 1978.

CHARLES EDWARD WILSON is almost unique among the tribesmen from the market place who have come to Washington to help run the war. He keeps the market place point of view. which is that the important thing is to get things made and get them to the place where they are needed.

THIS is a behemoth of a book. Like a behemoth, it moves ponderously, and sometimes in circles. For all its length, it covers only a few months in the history of Massachusetts -- just after the colony had emerged from the battles, but not the backwash, of the Revolution.

I'M going to risk the ire of many of my colleagues by saying that, although I'm a newcomer, New York radio and its people have been very good to me! Every one seems to be taking pot-shots at radio, particularly in regard to its treatment of the aspiring actor, while no one has a word to say in its defense.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Whales, those greatest of mammals whose pastures comprise seven seas, will be hunted for their flesh, which will be used to help fill the gap in the nation's meat supply, the Department of Interior has announced.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 1 (AP) -- A communique:

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 1 -- H.H. Haag's Devalue scored his second consecutive handicap victory today when he won the $2,500 Rhode Island by a length and a half from C.P. Sower's Navy at Narragansett Park.

THIS is a book of twenty-one short stories. In such a number the quality as well as the kind is sure to vary. Some of these are nostalgic stories of childhood, some trim vehicles for remarks on the war, education, the states of society and other current topics, some full-bodied stories of more inherent weight.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- The whole subject of a Jewish homeland in Palestine "has suddenly become taboo in Washington," Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, declared tonight in the keynote address opening the National Conference for Palestine.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- In an ill-advised moment Manager Joe McCarthy selected Bill Zuber to make his Yankee debut against his old mates of the Senators at Griffith Stadium today -- and forthwith ran the American League champions into more trouble than they had encountered before this year.

Your correspondent R.Q.Z., in THE TIMES last Sunday, is somewhat in error in dating the popularity of Charles Carleton Coffin's books as in the Nineties -- and if his memory is open to question, certainly his judgment as to the merit of these books is much more so.

IF ground ivy, chickweed or some other form of creeping weed has infested your lawn, it can be brought under control and destroyed readily and economically. Either of two well-known weed-killing methods -- the liquid spray method or dusting with a chemical -- will produce excellent results.
LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

ANTIQUES as a significant link between a historic past and a wartime present will be the keynote of the Eastern States Antiques Fair, opening tomorrow at the County Center in White Plains. The exhibitors -- there will be around 100 -- are also stressing the fact that now, when modern-made furnishings are hard to get, an antique example may be found to be just as useful, and to cost little if any more.

FEW children fail to respond with enthusiasm to the animal story, which is, indeed, the common meeting ground of the highly imaginative and the more matter-of-fact reader, for the ways of animals, even those of a friendly dog or a family cat, supply that touch of wonder which child readers crave, and when the animal hero is an untamed denizen of the jungle or forest, the sense of mystery, of exploring the unknown, is deepened.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- In the last five strokes of a race that had been close every inch of the way Harvard's varsity crew got up to nose out Navy on the windblown Schuylkill today and take the Adams Cup for the sixth year in a row.

Four ways in which war contractors can facilitate renegotiation of their war contracts were enumerated last week by Lieut. Col. E. Waldo Emerson, chairman of the New York Ordnance District price adjustment board at 80 Broadway, who also disclosed that the current goal of the board is to close out all current renegotiations on 1942 volume by July 1.

LONDON, May 1 (U.P.) -- Occupied Europe marked the blackest May Day in history today as German authorities in the Netherlands were reported to have loosed fierce reprisals against recalcitrant workers and former war prisoners who have defied the German order to register.

The National Association of Suggestion Systems, organized last year by representatives of twenty-eight large companies in an effort to improve products, services and industrial relations through the efficient management of employe suggestion systems, will hold a two-day conference here on May 19 and 20 in the Hotel Shelton.

Representative Walter Ploeser of the House Small Business Committee advised the members of the New York Council of Wholesale Meat Dealers yesterday that they would have to "slug it out" with the Office of Price Administration Meat Section if they expected to continue in existence.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 1 -- Seasoned New Yorkers, veterans of many Tunisian battles, drove up the steep sides of Hill 523, one of the key heights essential to the control of the valley leading to Mateur, thirteen miles northeast on the road to Bizerte, and captured it in bitter bayonet fighting, it was officially reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Details of the stirring experiences of the three Americans fliers who were forced down at sea off Japanese-controlled New Britain and lived among inhospitable native tribes in the jungles of that country for ten months and twelve days until their rescue by the Royal Australian Air Force, were disclosed yesterday by the War Department.

In an effort to prevent the disruption of normal family life in wartime, a group of clergymen and religious leaders of various denominations issued an appeal to religious groups yesterday, on the occasion of the opening of "National Family Week," to encourage the adoption of planned family life and to reaffirm "the sacred responsibilities of parenthood."

The Civil War generation which used to sing of the time "when Johnny comes marching home" didn't regard the soldier's return as a problem to himself or any one else. Even the mobilization and demobilization of 1917-19 didn't long upset the domestic economy.

Retail tradde continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, particularly main floor and basement departments, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.

President Roosevelt has been asked to intervene in a dispute between employes of the Phelps Dodge Copper Products Corporation and District No. 4, of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, C.I.O., with a view to preventing a possible strike of 2,700 workers in the company's Elizabeth, N.J., plant when the present contract expires next Wednesday, James Lustig, union organizer, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A government agency which has spent more than ten billion dollars and at one time passed out monthly checks to 3,300,000 persons came to the virtual end of the trail this week.

Should the National Youth Administration be abolished? The question was formally posed to the American people -- or, more immediately, to their elected representatives in Congress -- by Senator McKellar upward of a year ago when he presented a bill calling for the elimination of the administration.

Magistrate Anna M. Kross disclosed yesterday in Bronx Magistrates' Court that she has asked Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands to inquire into reports that gangs of youths were roaming streets in the Bronx and beating citizens.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 1 -- When the last German soldier flops wearily into the ship in which he is being evacuated from Tunisia and starts to run the terrifying gantlet of Allied air and sea power, the triumphant Allies will be richer not only in the possession of all North Africa but in tactical and strategical experience which should be of utmost value in the future.

AS the title -- with a generous interpretation of its adjective -- suggests, this book is not a complete biography. We leave Jennie Jerome at the age of 50, with her marriage to George Cornwallis -- West. Her first husband, Lord Randolph Churchill, has been dead five years.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Colonel Emmett O'Donnell of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, said today that heavy and medium bombers of the Tenth United States Air Force have blown up communication lines, important bridges and supply dumps as well as other Japanese installations in Burma and that as fast as the Japanese repair their bridges or railways the Tenth pays them another visit.
Mayor La Guardia was just one of 15,000 approving citizens yesterday afternoon. The locale was Madison Square Garden and the attraction was the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus.

SET in a patriotic tricolor decor devised for the occasion by Ben Ali Haggin, the Red, White and Blue Dinner Dance in aid of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York will take place Friday night at the Ritz-Carlton. The fete has been in preparation for several weeks and is an annual springtime party in the interests of the club's many activities among men in the armed services.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -- The toughest part of piloting Count Fleet to victory in the sixty-ninth running of the Kentucky Derby today was waiting for the race to start, Jockey Johnny Longden announced after the big race.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- With gasoline stations running dry by the hundreds in the Eastern shortage area, the Office of Price Administration has stood ready for two weeks to take drastic action, such as renewal of the pleasure-driving ban or suspension of all retail sales.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Navy communique 361:

Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, in a statement on today's observance by the Council of a "Day of Compassion" for persecuted European Jews, said there had been found a "rising tide of concern among Christians" over their fate.

BALTIMORE, May 1 -- Turning on his familiar blazing finish, Riverland carried the colors of Harold A. Clark's Louisiana Farm to victory in the thirty-ninth running of the tradition-steeped Dixie Handicap before more than 17,000 persons at Pimlico today.

" FRANCIS BEEDING," signed to some thirty thrillers, and "David Pilgrim," responsible for several historical romances, are two noms de plume of a remarkable writing team which has successfully tantalized the reading public since 1923.

Three out of five companies are opposed to repeal of the Wages and Hours Law which would automatically eliminate the legal basis for time and half overtime after forty hours, with the bulk of the opposition to the law coming from smaller employers, according to the results of a survey completed last week by Austin M. Fisher, labor relations consultant.

LONDON, May 1 -- A copy of the first Stars and Stripes ever seen in British waters -- John Paul Jones's colors which flew from the mast of the raider Bonhomme Richard in 1779 -- was presented to the United States today by the nation that sent the original beneath the sea 164 years ago.

DETROIT, May 1 -- A demand that the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers support "the economic demands of the United Mine Workers" drew enthusiastic cheers today from 1,500 U.A.W. delegates in a regional conference.

John L. Lewis and other leaders of the United Mine Workers of America spent most of the day and evening yesterday pondering their next move in the union's general stoppage of the bituminous and anthracite coal industries, which appeared to be fairly com plete, as President Roosevelt seized control of mines throughout the United States.

Retail sales last year rose 12.3 per cent to a new high record but profits were 8.5 per cent under those of 1941, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES based on the annual reports of fifty-three leading mail order, chain store, department store and specialty shop organizations.
CHICAGO. lay 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United I States Department of Agriculture follows.

De Mille picture, "The Story of Dr. Wassell."

Commander Patrick Brennan, U.S.N.R., well-known chief engineer in the transatlantic run for many years, has been named New York District Supervisor of the United States Merchant Marine Cadet Corps at 39 Broadway, the War Shipping Administration announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- A statement that "on private enterprise rests the responsibility to supply jobs for all seeking them" was approved today by the Western Regional Conference of the Council of State Governments as it ended two days of discussion on post-war planning.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1 (AP) -- Although outpointed, 14 -- 7, in hits, the Bears turned back the Royals in the opener of a four-game series today, 6 to 5. The defeat was the first in the last five starts for Montreal.

THE business of the theatre has been described as two parts labor union and one part luck. Certainly, it something strange, if not wonderful, that 100-odd jobs a season manage to get before the rascals of the Drama Critics Circle, there to flower or perish by the omnipotent pen.

IT IS generally understood that in the creation of his life work of four gigantic novels Thomas Wolfe borrowed heavily from people and events in his own life. Every writer does this, of course, but Wolfe's portraits were so vivid and so recognizable that they caused quite a commotion, making enemies and stirring up petty gossip.

For the first time in its 189-year history Columbia University will offer a three-term academic year, instead of the traditional two-semester program, beginning July 5, for the duration of the war, Dean Herbert E. Hawkes announced yesterday.

C.J. Hambro, former Speaker of the Norwegian Parliament in Oslo, as chairman of the Supervisory Committee of the League of Nations, made public here yesterday cablegrams from General Henri Honore Giraud and General Charles de Gaulle pledging France's adherence to the League of Nations.

Because Thomas Jefferson did so much for science the 200th anniversary of his birth seems an appropriate occasion to review the contributions to science made by the government as the result of his influence.

THERE is no dearth of recordings of Beethoven's Concerto No. 5, in E flat, for piano and orchestra, Op. 73 (the Emperor). Nevertheless the latest version deserves a hearty welcome. It is by Artur Schnabel as the piano soloist and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra conducted by the late Frederick Stock (Victor DM-939, five twelve-inch records).

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 1 (AP) -- Toronto ran it's winning streak to five-in-a-row today and stretched Jersey City's losing skein to four straight by taking the opener of a four-game series from the Little Giants, 15 to 6.

Sales of 686,000 shares in the final hour lifted yesterday's volume on the New York Stock Exchange to 843,855 shares and made the day the third largest Saturday of the year. Stocks improved and closed with gains of fractions to more than a point, for investors were encouraged by President Roosevelt's order to seize the coal mines.

The establishment of thirty-five "rumor clinics" throughout this country and Canada to investigate malicious and meaningless rumors was revealed yesterday in panel discussions of the Eastern Psychological Association at Hunter College.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A Coast Guard cutter sank a German U-boat off the Carolina coast several months ago, the Navy reported today, and captured thirty-three members of the crew, including the commanding officer. This was the first time the Navy has announced the capture of prisoners from a German submarine.
Warning that the miners' walkout had brought demands upon Congress to repeal progressive labor legislation, Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin condemned it yesterday as threatening the war effort.

LONDON, Sunday, May 2 (U.P.) -- Russian air and artillery units, supporting infantry attacks against the Axis bridgehead in the Northwest Caucasus, yesterday blasted out forty German batteries and shot down twenty-four enemy planes, the Soviet High Command reported today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 1 (U.P.) -- Sir Basil Brooke today was named Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, succeeding John M. Andrews who resigned after criticism from his own Unionist party with regard to the government's unemployment policy.

THE best shrubs for the novice to plant, it has been said, are those that he likes best. This is true enough, if the "best liked" are picked from a large enough list and not from a mere dozen or so of those most commonly planted. The wider the choice the better the "best."

The President of the United States acted yesterday to end a threat to wartime America perhaps as great as any that has occurred on the battlefields. He ordered Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, coordinator of hard fuels, to take possession of all coal mines in which strikes or stoppages have taken place.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- Premier Stalin's appreciation of the strategic unity of the Allies' operations against Germany as expressed in his May Day order of the day and his declaration that Russian war aims envisage no peace with the enemy until he is utterly defeated are reflected in various articles in today's newspapers.
WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- There's fresh evidence that new and more powerful types of American combat planes will be in action soon.

Two New York University teams, the baseball and track outfits, continued undefeated yesterday at Ohio Field, where the Violet nine squeezed out a 7-6 victory over Manhattan College and the track team conquered Fordham, 90 -- 45, as Warren Halliburton paced N.Y.U. with a "triple."

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- American planes bombed and strafed Japanese positions in the Solomon Islands and set fires in operations during the past two days, the Navy announced today. All the planes returned.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 1 -- Slashing through a protective umbrella of enemy aircraft, Allied planes sank at least a half dozen enemy ships bearing men and supplies to Tunisia yesterday. One of the ships sunk was a de stroyer. An Italian light cruiser was left in flames as bomb-hits were scored on eight vessels.

IT is fitting that a descendant of a Mayflower Pilgrim should be the one to point out that New England history did not begin at Plymouth Rock. Historians know that, of course, but Dr. Howe was not writing for specialists.

THE approach and arrival of war in Java and its continuation in Australia are described here by a Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent. Some of the story is of necessity told at second hand, but it contains considerable spot reporting.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR BASE IN SOUTHERN CHINA, May 1 -- After funeral services on a hill today for four members of the Fourteenth Air Force who were killed during a Japanese bombing raid on this field Wednesday, the daily mimeographed News Bulletin appeared containing, among other skeletonized items, the report that John L. Lewis has ordered a strike of 450,000 soft coal miners.

Utterly unmindful of an unseasonable May Day that had teeth chattering and of an even more unseasoned Giant team that had its constituents in the stands groaning, the doughty Dodgers visited the Polo Grounds yesterday for the first time this year and came close to wrecking the place.

MEMBER units of the National Federation of Music Clubs representing many Eastern States have subscribed to boxes for the Victory Concert to be given Friday night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria to augment the federation's War Service Fund.

NEW DELHI, India, May 1 (U.P.) -- United States four-motored Liberator bombers hammered the docks at Rangoon on Thursday with more than twenty tons of bombs, the Tenth United States Air Force announced today.

SOMEWHERE IN THE SOUTH PACIFIC, May 1 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, Allied Air Commander in the Southwest Pacific, awarded four Oak Leaves and four Silver Stars today to an American Flying Fortress crew that led a formation of pursuit ships in an attack on a ten-ship convoy off Lae, New Guinea, in January.

Confronted with a break in diplomatic relations between Russia and Poland, which has given the Nazis their greatest propagandistic victory in a long time, the British and American Governments are now struggling to heal the breach and close the ranks of the United Nations for the common struggle against the common foe.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Roosevelt today ordered Secretary Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator for War, to take over all the bituminous and anthracite properties because "the national interest is in grave peril as a result of almost complete cessation of operations of 450,000 soft-coal and 80,000 hard-coal miners."

BY my count. "Airing in a Closed Carriage" is Gabrielle Margaret Long's 140th published book. Of these, ninety-eight have appeared as by Marjorie Bowen, twenty-six as by George R. Preedy, twelve as by Joseph Shearing, two as by Robert Paye, one as by John Winch, and one -- the autobiography. "The Debate Continues" -- under a form of Mrs. Long's maiden name, Margaret Campbell.
Former Governor Gifford Pinchot of Pennsylvania and Mrs. Pinchot have come to Mayfair House from Vashingon.

LEUTENANT BENNY LEONARD of the Maritime Service dropped anchor the other day and paused long enough to describe with manifest enthusiasm the type of work he is doing with several thousand boys on Hoffman Island, where he is in charge of the physical training and recreation programs of the station.

VICTORY GARDEN HARVEST SHOWS, which were held throughout the country in 1942 for the benefit of Army and Navy relief, will be featured again this year under the auspices of and in cooperation with the National War Fund, Empire State Building.

THE vast affluence of five dollars a day in the Colorado gold mines lured the young David Lavender away from the "thirty-a-month-and- found" wages of a cowboy. There can be no doubt that he earned every nickel of it, for he tells what he did with much vigor and no little charm.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Suspension by Moscow this week of diplomatic relations with the Polish Government in London, on the officially stated ground that the Polish authorities had placed credence in a German story of the slaying of Polish prisoners by Russians in 1941, was regarded here and in London as a distinct triumph of German propaganda, one of whose major aims is to drive a wedge between the United Nations wherever possible.

National Chief Commander William L. Sayers of the United States Power Squadrons will convene a luncheon meeting of the governing board on May 10 at the Hotel Astor when squadrons throughout the country will be represented.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Bolivia was welcomed into the family of the United Nations in consequence of her formal adherence to the Declaration of the United Nations through a note made public today from Secretary of State Cordell Hull to Tomas Manuel Elio, the Bolivian Foreign Minister.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 1 (U.P.) -- Admiral Georges Robert, High Commissioner of Martinique, rejected a plea from 500 leading citizens to join with the North African French a few days after the Allied landings in Africa, and asserted that Americans coming to Martinique would send French youths to work in United States factories, a well-informed source said today.

While the Treasury's comments upon the tax bill introduced in the House by Mr. Doughton, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, affirm the great advantages to be derived by the government from a pay-as-you-go tax plan, these comments overlook the fact that the proposal will not place taxpayers on a current basis until 1946, if then.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Publication today by the Office of Price Administration of the official consumers' point value table for processed foods for May revealed that all dried or dehydrated soups had been removed from rationing and that the point values for most fruit and vegetable juices had again been substantially reduced.

By the introduction of new legislation which would compel uniformity in the class rates on railroad freight throughout the nation, the "Southern politicians" are endeavoring to influence the Interstate Commerce Commission's pending decision in the matter, George E. Mace, manager of the transportation bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association, declared yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 4 -- Despite the difficulties inherent in the war situation, schooling was provided last Winter for all of Moscow's children. There has been a striking freedom from epidemics and, as far as it is possible to ascertain, the standards attained by the pupils are at a normal level.

Jane and Joan Rosenfeld, 19-year-old twins from Bloomfield, N.J., made their New York debut in a two-piano recital last night in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall. The program, which was warmly received by a large gathering contained as its chief offering the Handel-Klein Fifth organ concerto, Mozart's sonata in D major, Brahms's "Variations on a Theme by Haydn" and Saint-Saens's "Danse Macabre."

Fordham crushed Villanova on the Ram's diamond yesterday, 13 to 2. The game was shortened to seven innings because of the strong wind. Time out had to be taken repeatedly because of its blasts. It was a better afternoon for kite flying than for baseball.

ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP) -- The Reds, breaking up a pitchers' duel with a concentrated batting attack, defeated the Cardinals today, 7 to 3. The chief slugging honors went to Gerald Walker, Eric Tipton and Eddie Miller.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 1 -- The Fleet sailed into port with the sixty-ninth Kentucky Derby today without even getting lip a full head of steam.

The recent travels of the President and Vice President in Mexico and six other Latin-American countries, respectively, left no doubt that there is good-will on both sides of our southern boundary. A Washington dispatch sent to this newspaper by Harold Callender suggests that good-will is not so much a solution of our Latin-American problems as it is an atmosphere in which solutions can be reached.

WHEELER BECKETT, conductor of young people's symphony concerts, has just completed a series for high school and junior high school students in this city, using seventy members of the Philharmonic-Symphony.

THE Garden of the Ambassador will be formally opened for the late Spring and Summer season with a benefit dinner and dance on the night of May 12. Proceeds from the fete will advance the work of Dogs for Defense, Inc., a volunteer non-profit organization aiding the War Department as a procurement agency for supplying war dogs to our armed forces.

MIAMI, Fla., May 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Comdr. Maurice D. Jester, now assistant Coast Guard operations officer in the Seventh Naval District, with headquarters at Miami, told his story today on authority from Washington.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 1 -- The entire anthracite field in Eastern Pennsylvania was made idle today by a walkout of about 80,000 miners who remained unmoved by the announcement that the Federal Government had taken control of the mines which they quit last midnight at the expiration of their contract.
CHUNGKING, China, May 1 (U.P.) -- A communique:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 1 -- The withholding by the government of important war news over long periods of time was sharply criticized here today by radio men, and defended by government representatives, in a symposium on news broadcasting sponsored by Ohio State University.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Pennsylvania kept in the running for the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship by defeating Dartmouth in a double-header today, 8 to 5, and 9 to 6, on wind-swept River Field.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 1 -- With an unusually large number of important public offices becoming vacant at the end of this year, the dominant Republican organization of Westchester County faces several tantalizing problems in choosing candidates.

THE rectangular lawn of the University of Virginia -- founded in this, his home town, by Thomas Jefferson -- is dotted with the brown army uniforms and caps of university graduates of fifteen to thirty years ago. They have resumed the discipline of the classroom to train themselves for the administrative tasks that a conquering army will face.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 1 -- Warning his countrymen that the war was drawing nearer Sweden's borders as the decision in the great struggle approached, Premier Per Ahin Hansson, during an address to an International Labor Day rally in Stockholm today, indicated Sweden might have to repel acts !of violence.
AT the Brooklyn Botanic Garden a course, "Lilacs in Flower," will begin on Tuesday at 11 A.M. and will continue on May 11, 18 and June 8. The sessions are to be held outdoors in the lilac plantings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 1 -- Scoring four runs, Harvard tied the count at 8 -- all in the ninth and then won from Yale on a twelfth-inning surge today, 11 -- 8. The game, the 195th in the series, gave Harvard ninety-three victories to 101 for the Elis, with one tie.

SOME of the most spectacular bidding in the annals of American philately took place at the Collectors Club last week when the United States collection of William West, Philadelphia investment broker, who died in 1942, was sold by Philip H. Ward Jr. of Philadelphia for the estate.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The Navy program for placing women reserves in its hospital corps will put 300 more candidates into orientation classes tomorrow, while at the same time 115 graduates of similar courses will be assigned to duty in various park of the country, the Navy Department announced today.
LONDON, May 1 -- May Day celebrations were forbidden in Germany and occupied Europe but here and throughout the Allied world the occasion was marked today as a milestone along the road to victory.
CHICAGO, May 1 (AP) -- Rapping out thirteen hits, the White Sox rallied twice today to tie the score and then defeated the Browns, 5 to 4. It was only the Chicagoans' second victory of the season.

THE first one-man show in New York of oils by Francis Chapin of Chicago, current at the Brandt Gallery, reveals the artist as a very distinctive colorist. His landscapes are subtle in suggestive detail. His figure pieces are at once free and persuasive -- delightfully unposed and tonally acute.
Columbia, which has not had much to cheer over so far in its baseball season, got a big thrill yesterday when it handed Army its first defeat of the year at Baker Field. The score was 8 -- 7.

ON Tuesday comes the preview and on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday the first New York performances in the Brander Matthews Theatre of the chamber opera, "A Tree on the Plains," commissioned last year by the League of Composers of Ernest Bacon, composer, and Paul Horgan, librettist, for production under their auspices, as one of the most recent activities of The League in promoting American composition.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 176 United States soldiers killed, 312 wounded and sixty-four missing in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest areas.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 1 -- A striking contrast between the views of the Senate and the views of the American people on one important post-war proposal is revealed today in a public opinion survey throughout the nation.

OTTAWA, May 1 -- It was just two years ago since the Hyde Park agreement was signed between President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King, This week, Joseph M. Tucker, director of the Canadian Division of the United States War Production Board, revealed in a speech here the extent to which cooperation had been carried between these two good neighbor countries.

Victorious in three of the four events figuring in the women's all-around championship, Mrs. Pearl Perkins Nightingale of the Philadelphia Turners retained, the latter crown to supply one of the main highlights of the National A.A.U. gymnastic title meet at the West Side Y.M.C.A. yesterday.

IF anybody says "manpower" to a broadcaster arriving home this week-end from the war conference of the National Association of Broadcasters, he is likely to blow his top. The broadcasting industry has lost more than 26 per cent of its male personnel since Pearl Harbor to the armed forces; on some stations it is more than 50 per cent.

SUCCESSFUL in the recent presentation of a triple-personality program (namely, Frank Sinatra, Walter O'Keefe and Sheila Barrett), Linton Weil, overseer of the Riobamba, will be applying the same formula next Wednesday evening when he unfolds his new show at his East Fifty-seventh Street oasis.

By luck, Colonel Bayler went through the thick of the battle on all three islands, survived hundreds of shellings, bombings and snipings and, judging by his book, came out in fine spirits as a marine should.

A master of deep-water sail, who can look over the stern and see in the long wake the fifteen years well spent under sail, I regret that I cannot quite agree with your editorial, "Emblems for Seamen," where it says that "Compared with our men today, those of Clark Russell and Conrad had soft berths." And I am speaking from experience.

NOT many Japanese have surrendered. So a legend has grown up that the Japanese are tougher than other soldiers; that they don't fear death as much as white men do; that they form suicide squads every morning; that they never surrender. The legend is a caricature.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A proposal that the government work day be lengthened by forty minutes so that Federal employes could have Saturday afternoons off was summarily rejected by the Bureau of the Budget this week as contrary to President Roosevelt's policy.

The food dehydrating industry, concerned that the increasing use of home food drying equipment in inexperienced hands may result in serious loss of public esteem for the commercially prepared product, is planning an "educational" campaign to instruct housewives in the difficult techniques necessary to maintain nutritive values in the operation, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, May 1 -- Since the beginning of the year the Royal Air Force has made frequent and highly successful attacks on locomotives hauling war materials through Belgium, France and Holland. These attacks by R.A.F. "trainbusters" pay good dividends -- they dislocate the enemy's rail transport, prevent or postpone the delivery of urgent war materials and throw additional work on the already overladen German railway workshops.

STINGER: If Arab stevedores in a North Africa port set a record for moving cargoes in and out of Liberty ships, it can be credited to the Arabic vocabulary of Sergeant Pasquale Tango of New York. Sergeant Tango's Arabic is one word, used unsparingly. The word is "zid." It means "more."

LONDON, May 1 -- British journalism is still devoted to the bizarre in American life so long as it falls into an accepted pattern which is designed of Hollywood glamour, gangsterism and freakism, with statements along isolationist lines.
LONDON, May 1 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

NOW that we are at war, we have to change our approach somewhat to the problem of landscaping a new home. Good design is still an essential, but we pay more attention to requirements like simplicity, ease of maintenance and a low first cost.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- A large poster, done in colors, bearing the Stars and Stripes at the top of the text of the proclamation by which the Federal Government has taken over the mines was distributed to mine managers today by Fuels Administrator Ickes, together with a request that it be displayed prominently on all mine properties.

THE circus is a theatrical corporation formed to entertain large elephants and small boys, and since both of them obviously need it the whole thing should be set down as charity and the tickets should be tax free. For the circus comes to New York in the Spring, when the powers of resistance of elephants and boys are at their lowest ebb.

A campaign to enroll as Red Cross blood donors nearly 55,000 Western Union Telegraph employes throughout the nation, which would include 1,500 employes of the company in the metropolitan area, was opened yesterday at the Blood Donor Center of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross, 2 East Thirty-seventh Street, where the first group of employes appeared to give their blood for the armed forces.

CHUNGKING, China, May 1 (U.P.) -- A Chinese communique today reported a heavy attack by Chinese forces on the railway city of Anyang, near the Honan border, and severe fighting on both slopes of the Taihang mountain range on the Honan-Shansi border, in which the Japanese suffered "immense casualties."

Along the Western Front in France twenty-five years ago Allied airmen bombed the German lines with leaflets calling upon the Kaiser's soldiers to surrender. Many of them did. In the hills of Northern Tunisia last week the Allies mixed the same appeal with a grim reminder of Allied power.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Congressional comment on President Roosevelt's coal order left little doubt tonight that the Chief Executive has Capitol Hill support for taking over the strike-afflicted mines. At the same time several members of Congress expressed sympathy for the miners' wage demands, and Senator Langer, Republican, North Dakota, said blame for the strike should be placed on the United States Steel Corporation.
Some of the 6,000,000 or more prisoners of war are hard to reach. Italians held in more than twenty camps in East Africa constitute one such group.

TRENTON, N.J., May 1 (AP) -- Attorney General David T. Wilentz says New Jersey no longer has a legally constituted State Racing Commission since John P. Callaghan of Newark died and Louis A. Reilly resigned.

JOURNALISM rather than literature is in our time the means of expression of the French-Canadian mind, and this holds true on both sides of the border. To the south of it, in the great textile cities of New England, every French-Canadian settlement of consequence has its own French-language newspaper devoted to the interests of the French-speaking small town embedded in the larger American community.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Secretary Ickes took over the country's bituminous and anthracite mines today upon authorization of President Roosevelt. He immediately mobilized all government agencies in an effort to have the mines reopened as soon as possible and to assure a steady supply of coal to the war industries which may be imperiled by the cessation of work by 450,000 bituminous and 80,000 anthracite miners.

ALL over London one morning last November clerks, housewives, shopkeepers were queued up on the sidewalks waiting to buy copies of a book called "Front Line." Before the day was ended they had bought 343,000 copies.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 1 -- Day after day government officials and other observers from the East remark about the war feeling of the Pacific Coast. Along that 1,500-mile stretch from Seattle to San Diego, more than anywhere else in the country, they frequently say, they find people "grim and earnest," "unusually alert" and even "fighting mad."
LONDON, May 1 (U.P.) -- The coal strike situation in the United States shocked and puzzled the average Briton tonight because a similar work stoppage is almost inconceivable in this country.

THE north side of the New York Times Annex, just west of Times Square in Forty- third Street, shields a cheerful and warm expanse of sidewalk under the smile of the morning sun. And that is indeed most fortunate, for, as nearly as this witness could see, several thousand New York school children spent a lot of their Easter holiday there.

Taking and holding a slender lead, Overdrawn from the Dearborn Stable yesterday won the $6,775 Jamaica Handicap by half a length for the third straight year. Racing alongside for much of the six furlongs, but never able to get level with the speeding Overdrawn, was the gray Doublrab under top weight of 130 pounds.

THE New York Kindergarten Association will gain from a cocktail dance to be given the afternoon of May 24 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Stars of the stage, screen and radio will entertain on the program which includes the distribution of gifts.

General Kenji Doihara has been named Japan's eastern defense commander and "concurrently supreme war councillor," the Tokyo radio announced yesterday. His appointment was part of what the Tokyo radio described as a move to strengthen the Japanese high command, especially in regard to the Army Air Force.

BUSINESS being little short of phenomenal for the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, the season is to have a second extension. Now instead of closing next Sunday evening, when it is already under contract to depart for a week in Detroit, it will merely go away on a visit and return to dance until May 23.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- How long can John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America successfully defy the order of President Roosevelt as Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy, to submit the issues that led to a national coal strike at midnight to a duly constituted government tribunal, set up with the active cooperation of the miners' chief shortly after Pearl Harbor?

WITH civilian travelers more or less put on their honor not to crowd rail and bus carriers this year for long journeys, the short trip looms large on the vacation horizon. Directors of mountain and beach resorts near big cities are preparing for a busy season, and travel bureaus say they are getting increasing calls for places within 200 miles of the home base.
PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP) -- Rip Sewell, the Pirates' ace right-hander, held his spell over the Cubs today as he beat them for the third time this season, 6 to 3.

Let me add a bit of corroboration to Hugh Byas's belief that the Japanese murder of our airmen was due to an outburst of the savagery that has never been civilized out of the Samurai -- in spite of their boasted Bushido (Knightly Warriors' Code).

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 1 -- Wandering in the jungles of New Guinea there is an American officer of a United States fighter unit, Captain Chester E. Grigsby of Baltimore, Md. He has been assigned to find jungles plants that can be used as foods in emergencies.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The War Production Board issued an order today restricting luggage to seven basic types and drastically limiting it in size and design. The order, L-284, will take effect on July 1.

MISS HOFFMANN has the gift of entering so whole-heartedly into the tales she tells that the reader, too, completely identifies himself with the characters of the story. even when, as in one of this author's earlier books, the hero is a snail, while the absurd and lovable Siamese kitten in Miss Hoffmann's "A Cat of Paris" has, like the human beings in the story, a well-marked, convincing personality.

BUFFALO, May, 1 (AP) -- A system of price controls and rationing "is a frail reed" with which to combat inflation at the approach of victory or the actual end of the war, Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, said tonight.

ABOUT five miles from where he stood last week before members of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Lieut. Gen. Brehon B. Somervell, commanding general of the Army Service Forces, could have found plenty of cargo for waiting ships.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- Mark Starr of New York, educational director of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, told an institute on minorities today that he believed the country's coal miners would not work without a contract.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1 -- The position that foreseeable earnings, rather than the letter of contracts, should govern the distribution of securities in a reorganization of a corporation or a dissolution proceeding must now be regarded as the well-established policy of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CASCO was a young seal born on the Favorite island, where there was a seal colony and where Casco's mother returned every Spring to the peaceful seal nurseries. Protected and fed by his mother, Casco's early days were safe and happy.

AFTER one of the more arduous cross-country tours on record Ethel Barrymore sallied into town hardly a fortnight ago full of chuckles and retorts and more curiosity than a three- year-old. Without pause, she promptly scudded her assorted belongings into a spacious new apartment overlooking the East River where she supervised the dusting and received calls and callers at a rapid rate.

DETROIT, May 1 -- The Ford Motor Company management, following a conference with union officials, this afternoon, discharged 141 foundry employes whom it termed "ringleaders" in the strike which had disrupted production at the concern's Rouge Plant foundries since Thursday.

ON the new stage to be used this Summer for the Stadium concerts, operettas will be possible. There has been some talk of a revival there of "Show Boat," and there also has been some discussion with the Shubert interests concerning the possibility of putting on some of their operetta properties, such as "Student Prince" and "Blossom Time."

The historic Whitelaw Reid mansion has dismissed its pompous past and enlisted in World War II. From now on the Madison Avenue Renaissance mansion -- which vies in architectural interest with Gothic St. Patrick's across the street and the modern RCA Building two blocks away-- will proudly bear upon its front entrance WOMEN'S MILITARY SERVICES CLUB.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 1 -- Despite the necessity for change from the easy ways of peace to the "rigid temporary controls of war," democracy still has advantages in the fighting of total war, Dr. Vannevar Bush told 116 graduates of the Stevens Institute of Technology at the seventy-first commencement here today.

LONDON, May 1 (U.P.) -- The Admiralty announced today that British submarines had sunk ten more Axis vessels in the Mediterranean, running their total bag revealed in the past month to fifty ships sunk or damaged along the enemy's supply route to Tunisia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 1 (AP) -- Harvard University graduates its first class of labor leaders this month, a new milestone in its long history, with both the labor men and their professors expressing the hope that the experiment will find favor with unions and universities throughout the country.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 1 -- Army vanquished Columbia and the University of Pittsburgh in a triangular track meet today on a windswept field. The score was: Army 108 1/2, Columbia 34, Pitt 20 1/2. The cadets took ten first places, Columbia winning the other five events.

ALGIERS, May 1 (AP) -- General Henri Honore Giraud called on French workers in a May Day address tonight to put everything into the war effort. He promised the restoration of labor's liberties and an early and total victory over the Axis.
FACED with a shortage of alcohol, cosmetic chemists have devised many ways in which to stretch their quotas -- now reduced to 50 per cent of 1941 consumption.

MELBOURNE, May 1 (Reuter) -- Japanese forces situated in occupied territories to the north of Australia have constructed sufficient airfields to accommodate 1,500 aircraft at bases from Timor to Rabaul, Francis M. Forde, Australian Army Minister, stated today.

MORE than seventeen years have passed since Dr. Edwin Mires of Vanderbilt University published his trail-blazing best-seller, "The Advancing South," and still the volumes on Southern civilization and mores pour from the presses.

MANY Americans, those who were young at the time of the First World War, and those who are young now, must have felt the need for an affirmative and spiritual doctrine to fit the negations and materialisms of the present war.

THIS is a novel by an angry man. Mr. Chambers, who was an officer in the U.S. Navy, is angry at Republicans in general, but mostly at Hamilton Fish, Thomas Dewey and Joe Martin; at Father Coughlin, Senator Wheeler, at Colonels Lindbergh and McCormick, at striking war plant workers, at President-haters and President-hissers, at business-as-usual advocates, hoarders, chiselers and at it-can't-happen-here dreamers.

MOSCOW, May 1 -- "I don't know whether it's us or Fritz who's going to attack, but I do know there's going to be an offensive soon," an officer told me yesterday. He had arrived during the night from the front, tanned, spare and fit-looking, with the serenity that the front-line soldiers bring with them when they come into the capital.

TO cope with rationing on the one hand and an expanding clientele on the other -- a lot of people would rather "eat out" than struggle with shortages at home -- the restaurateurs in New York City have recently developed a variety of techniques that should prove useful to the rest of us who do our own cooking.

THE sufferings of adolescence as seen by the principal victim have been the subject of many a merry tale, Booth Tarkington being the name that comes most readily to mind as the leader of this school of literature.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- The majority and minority of the Ways and Means Committee filed bristling reports today on the Doughton bill and awaited the reaction of House colleagues returning for the pay-as-you-go, tax debate which starts Monday. Votes should be had by Wednesday.

BEFORE the Japs unleashed their fury on Corregidor it was a beautiful dark green volcanic isle about the size of Manhattan. It was shaped like a tadpole, being high and wide at the seaward end and tapering off to a low point on the bay side -- the side where the Nips eventually landed several thousand veteran troops through the shallow water.
HOT SPRINGS, Ark., May 1 -- Two organizations meeting in this city sent telegrams today to President Roosevelt requesting the immediate internment for the duration of John L. Lewis.

BY Presidential proclamation, National Family Week begins today. It is sponsored by national religious bodies and its aim is to rouse public interest in the family's wartime problems. The Office of Civilian Defense is distributing information through State and local defense councils.

MANY Army camps and hospitals throughout the country are planning to grow some of their own food supplies this year as a contribution to the general war effort. According to the National Victory Garden Institute, the War Department has decided that vegetables may be grown at camps where there is suitable soil adjacent to living quarters.

IN the first three volumes, "Lark Rise," "Over to Candleford" and "Candleford Green," of her fascinating and informative study of English village life, Flora Thompson has begun something that, when completed, should form a source book from which future historians may draw with utter confidence.

WHAT happens to the individual caught between the massive pincers of impersonal mammoth industry and equally massive and impersonal government is not so interesting as the outward forms of institutions with which we mostly concern ourselves.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, May 1 -- Vice Admiral John H. Hoover, commandant of the Tenth Naval District here, expressed doubt today that an actual state of war would develop against Martinique, but said the Navy was maintaining a day-to-day policy of watchful waiting.

A four-college conference on World Cooperation, meeting in six sessions at the various colleges from April 24 to May 2, was sponsored by the International Relations Clubs of Mount Holyoke, Amherst, Massachusetts State and Smith College.

" THIS Is The Army," the Irving Berlin musical, which enjoyed an outstanding success upon its single radio showing, is coming back to the airwaves in expanded form. Beginning May 18, it will be presented in a series of four one-hour showings at 9:30 P.M. Tuesdays over the Columbia Broadcasting System (WABC).

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 1 -- Behind the hurling of Jeff Davis, southpaw, the Naval Academy baseball team today defeated William and Mary, 17 to 1. Davis allowed the Indians three hits, struck out five and walked six.

After deliberating more than fourteen hours, a blue ribbon jury in Kings County Court was unable to agree on a verdict yesterday in the trial of Charles Farley and Louis Caridad, charged with the murder of a policeman. The jury was discharged by Judge Louis Goldstein and both defendants were taken to Brooklyn City prison.

The Army and Navy College Training Programs have made satisfactory developments to date. It is altogether likely that few Americans have visualized the fact that the Army-Navy plan for the utilization of the colleges constitutes what is probably the most comprehensive educational plan ever initiated involving the coordination of the efforts of several hundred institutions of higher learning from coast to coast.

DUBLIN, Eire, May 1 -- Dublin, the capital of this potato-growing, potato-eating country is now experiencing an acute potato shortage. The scarcity of butter, bacon and sugar was something that the people accepted, but the sudden shortage of potatoes has them mystified. Potato queues now are a feature of the city's life.

" See first, hit first, hit hard and keep on hitting," is the motto of both the American and British Navies. The implication is clear that a man who sees well by day sees equally well by night. As a matter of fact many a night lookout is as good as blind.
BOSTON, May 1 (AP) -- The Athletics got their first earned run in 51 innings but were shut out over the rest of the route today as the Red Sox took the game, 3 to 1.

THE importance of shipping in this war of supply and transportation is a truism. It cannot be overstressed, for our conception of an "adequate'' merchant marine will determine whether, in the peace to come, we shall retain war-won supremacy or again sink back to the old inferior position and let other nations carry our commerce for us.

THERE is something likable about Oscar Homolka. Maybe it is the joy with which he eats and drinks. Maybe it is the good talk which he practices with the ease and fluency of a man who is accustomed to good talk. Maybe it is the eyes twinkling in the porcine face -- sly, intelligent, scrutinizing eyes.

LONDON, May 1 -- The full extent of the diplomatic victory won by Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, when Vyacheslaff Molotoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, tendered Tadeusz Romer, Polish Ambassador, his passport cannot be gauged as yet.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP) -- Manpower Commissioner McNutt decreed tonight that steel mills working less than forty-eight hours a week may hire no new workers after June 1 without War Manpower Commission approval -- thus assuring, McNutt declared, that more than 525,000 steel workers will be on a forty-eight-hour basis by July 1.

THE Old World, in all its history, has never had hardier, braver, more skillful horsemen than those of this continent. In their various ways they have been colorful and courageous, and have played so great a part in our pioneering that portraits of these fast disappearing centaurs of the Americas that would include their psychology, exploits and the tricks of their trade, should be preserved.

Mount St. Michael High and Bishop Loughlin Memorial High each captured an open championship at the third annual Public Schools Athletic League Relay Carnival yesterday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

A five-point safety program designed to reach every industrial plant in the New York area in an attempt to reduce the accidents that are one cause of absenteeism was announced yesterday following a meeting of the directors of the Greater New York Safety Council in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 1 -- The firmness of the official note handed to Berlin by which Sweden condemned recent German violations of her neutrality has given rise to speculation as to whether or not Sweden is making ready to join the United Nations in declaring war on the Reich.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 2 (AP) -- A 5,000-ton Japanese ship was bombed yesterday off Dutch New Guinea and left sinking, the High Command announced.

The cotton futures market displayed yesterday the lethargy that has been typical of it for two weeks, with volume light and price fluctuations slight. At the close, however, the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange began to exhibit some buoyancy on speculative buying, which was attributed partly to strength in the securities market and partly to the Presidential directive for operation of coal mines.

There are a few items in the mail bag that carry a ring of confidence, if not a tone of outright enthusiasm. There are no laments about the lateness of the fresh water season or the handicaps of travel to favorite fishing grounds.

Parke, Davis Co., manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, and their subsidiaries, had a net profit of $2,204,307 in the quarter ended on March 31, after charges and a deduction of $2,510,000 for income and excess profits taxes, it was announced yesterday.

Dr. A.C. Thaysen and his associates of the Chemical Research Laboratory, Teddington, England, have developed a new food yeast, rich in protein. Five per cent added to a two-pound loaf of bread increases the nutritive value as much as would two eggs or a quarter of a pound of steak.

LONDON, May 1 -- Winding up what is believed to have been the greatest month of aerial bombing in history -- with nearly 10,000 tons of high explosives and incendiaries loosed on targets inside Germany and additional tons on objectives in Nazi-occupied territories and Italy during April -- the Royal Air Force pounded Essen, site of the big Krupp armament works, again last night. The R.A.F. had last attacked Essen on April 3.

OMAHA, Nebraska, May 1 -- During the last fortnight there have been heavy frosts or light freezes in the Corn Belt territory, which damaged sprouting small grains and flax. There have been cold, wet days that kept farmers out of their fields.

BAD MEMORIES -- Can you remember what your telephone dial looks like? Dr. Martin Scheerer of the College of the City of New York told the Eastern Psychological Association last week that nearly half the college students whom he tested included in their reproductions of the dial the nonexistent letter Q. More than half were wrong in giving the color of the numbers.

ON the second anniversary, March 27, of the German invasion of Yugoslavia, the Free Yugoslav authorities in London released four stamps -- 2-dinara blue, 3d slate, 5d carmine and 10d black -- with a portrait of King Peter II and crossed rifles and sabers at either side. Inscribed is "27 Mart 27" (March 27) and the dates 1941 and 1943.

LONDON, May 1 (Canadian Press) -- The mighty Arsenal Gunners today won the English League Southern Division Cup and set a scoring record for the Wembley Stadium by trouncing Charlton Athletic, 7 -- 1, before a crowd of 75,000, including members of the war cabinet.

SO many times, while reading this book, I found myself touched to the quick and thinking, "Was it so with you too?" Mrs. Leighton's daughter, like mine, resents the war that took her father away, but her boys are proud of him, the way my son is proud -- there is only that look of "strained maturity" to concern us.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, May 1 (U.P.) -- The weekly edition of the United States Army newspaper Stars and Stripes and French-language newspapers today avoided any mention of the coal strike in the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Following are the texts of President Roosevelt's statement and the executive order on the operation of the coal mines, together with Secretary Ickes's telegram to the operators:

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Jail sentences should be given to John L. Lewis and other leaders of the United Mine Workers, Representative Fred A. Hartley of New Jersey, said today, for disruption of coal production in the midst of war.

BOOK stalls still flow with simplified texts and popular-science discussions of navigation, meteorology, mechanics and elementary aerodynamics. Most of the material, cut small size for small mouths, implies a warning -- the smaller, the sweeter the pill the more doses necessary.
IN the search this year for new annuals we find several newcomers which are outstanding for their ease of growth and their unusual effectiveness, both outdoors and when cut.
DETROIT, May 1 -- Rookie Dick Wakefield lined a single to left field in the fifteenth inning today to score Roger Cramer from third base and give the Tigers a 3-to-2 victory over the Indians.

The Golden Hill Chorus gave its Spring concert at Town Hall last night before a large audience, enthusiastic in its appreciation of the interesting program and its admirable presentation. Two movements from Pergolesi's "Stabat Mater" opened the concert, followed by the chorus, "Hey Derry, Down Derry," from Bach's "Peasant Cantata," and "La Danza," by Rossini.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Congress has turned the spotlight on one of Washington's unique and colorful institutions -- the press conference.

Private and independent schools throughout the country are planning to operate Summer sessions to provide an opportunity for students to complete their high school courses before being called into the Army or the Navy.

As a result of the growing cooperation both politically and economically between the nations in the Caribbean area and this country, Latin America is expanding its activities, particularly in the agricultural field, to extend as much help as possible to the Allied war program.

DETROIT, May 1 -- Rookie Dick Wakefield lined a single to left field in the fifteenth inning today to score Roger Cramer from third base and give the Tigers a 3-to-2 victory over the Indians.

ALTHOUGH "Prelude to War" will be released theatrically on May 27, it is not certain at the moment whether the six other subjects in the series of Army-sponsored films generally titled "Why We Fight" also will be made available for public exhibition.

WITH THE UNITED STATES SECOND CORPS, In Tunisia, April 30 (Delayed) -- All day long big guns thundered through the narrow valleys as massed American artillery played a tattoo of death and destruction on Hill 609 -- Djebel Tahent -- which bars further progress by the infantry north and east of Sidi Nsir toward the Tunis plain.
WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Following are the texts of President Roosevelt's statement and the executive order on the operation of the coal mines, together with Secretary Ickes's telegram to the operators:

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- Jail sentences should be given to John L. Lewis and other leaders of the United Mine Workers, Representative Fred A. Hartley of New Jersey, said today, for disruption of coal production in the midst of war.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- To make more beef available to the armed services and to provide a more even distribution over the nation of available civilian supplies, the War Food Administration today suspended for May all temporary beef quotas and temporary increases in beef quotas to butchers and local slaughterers.

THAT vacation trip on which Howard Lindsay and R. McK. Crouse are now idling no doubt is from hour to hour being broken up with shop talk, to wit: The recent enthusiasm of Twentieth Century-Fox (why can't the movies keep off this page?) over the Margaret Curtis fantasy which goes by the title of "A Highland Fling," for which said outfit seems willing to put up what in polite circles is known as the wherewithal.

The Treasury's thirteen-billion-dollar issue of War Bonds required a lot of paper: 120 tons; almost enough, spread out, to cover a plot of land a mile long and a half-mile wide, or, in Western words, a half-section. The printing took fifteen days.

What undoubtedly will be the only field trial for retrievers in the Eastern section this Spring is slated today on the property of Charles L. Lawrance in East Islip, L.I. It will be an A.K.C. licensed event given by the Women's Field Trial Club, of which Mrs. J. Gould Remick is president.

UNDER YOUR LAMP SHADE -- The most careful of housekeepers is likely to forget the dusty linings of lamp shades and the grime that collects on bulbs and reflector bowls -- yet lighting experts estimate that 20 to 50 per cent of the light is lost by this neglect.
PITTSBURGH, May 1 -- Western Pennsylvania's 125,000 coal miners waited in uncertainty and bewilderment tonight for the next move of their chief, John L. Lewis.
The Columbia varsity eight-oared crew that led Navy home a week ago turned the tables on Rutgers yesterday.

Col. Gen. Vitez Gusztay Jany, commander in chief of the Second Hungarian Army, returned to Budapest from the Russian front yesterday and gave a glowing account of the retreat carried out by his forces during the Winter, when they served as "the rear guard of the rear guards" for the Germans, the Budapest radio declared in a domestic broadcast, reported by the Federal Communications Commission to the Office of War Information.

MANY of America's famed resorts have gone to war. Down high-ceilinged hotel corridors and ornate lobbies where in peacetime thick carpets achieved a cathedral quiet for guests who could pay $10 a day and up, now echo the clump of heavy, boots, the rousing calls of the bugle and the songs and shouts of exuberant young Americans.

THE job of training volunteers for the Women's Land Army is in full swing here at the 350-acre State Institute of Applied Agriculture. Women between the ages of 18 and 45 with no previous training are learning the fundamentals of applied agriculture from soil chemistry to animal husbandry.

Many American school children are losing confidence in pleas for temperance because they are being misinformed about the effects of alcohol, states Anne Roe in The Quarterly Journal of Studies in Alcohol. Her nation-wide survey indicates that every State except Arizona requires its public schools to teach the effects of alcohol.

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- President Roosevelt designated Sunday, May 9, today as Mother's Day in a proclamation which paid tribute to the loyalty and cooperation being displayed by the mothers of the nation in the war. The proclamation read:...

WASHINGTON, May 1 -- An administrative order setting up the Office of Civilian Requirements within the War Production Board, and clothing it with power necessary to provide civilians with all essential goods and services except food, housing and transportation, was issued today by Chairman Donald Nelson. The Office of Civilian Requirements will succeed the Office of Civilian Supply under Joseph Weiner and will be headed by Arthur D. Whiteside, president of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

DOCTORS a hundred years ago held a rather doubtful social position. Less respectable than lawyers, they were considered -- by their wealthier and more influential patients, at any rate -- rather in the light of upper tradesmen.

It was a novel entitled "The Edge of the Sword." and the author's name was not a familiar one to American readers -- that of Vladimir Pozner, a Frenchman of Russian parentage, a graduate of the Sorbonne, and

ELIE METCHNIKOFF, the illustrious co-worker of Louis Pasteur, died in 1916. One year before his death he composed a small book entitled "The Founders of Modern Medicine." This work was "the fruit of his idleness," for the war, which had broken out in 1914, completely disorganized the Pasteur Institute and put an abrupt end to all its research activities. Metchnikoff wrote in the introduction:

WASHINGTON. May 1 (AP) -- President Roosevelt conferred today with a group of labor leaders described at the White House as "an informal labor group" and not the Labor Victory Committee which will see the President next week about living costs.

HONOLULU, May 1 -- The Office of Civilian Defense has erected a wooden building on the grounds of the Shriners Hospital for Crippled Children as emergency quarters for victims of an outbreak of poliomyelitis. Since the first infection was reported in February thirty-four cases have been put under treatment.

The music unit of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office has announced programs to be given in Music Week, which begins today. On Wednesday at 8:15 P.M. in the concert hall of the Juilliard Graduate School, 130 Claremont Avenue, a music rally will be held in honor of the students of the Institute of Musical Art of the Juilliard School of Music who are in the armed forces.

Acting to "correlate the different functions which enter into exporting," the Board of Economic Warfare will establish a consolidated and considerably enlarged office at 61 Broadway on May 10, it was announced yesterday.

IN these days of ever-increasing wartime restrictions, keeping up the "morale" of the home -- giving the house a physical face-lifting that will maintain a cheerful atmosphere for the occupants -- becomes a difficult problem.

ADOLF HITLER bows himself out of the world picture in this dramatic preview of history to come. He is impelled to do so by the boot toes of some of his erstwhile henchmen, including Field Marshal von Keitel, Schacht, the Reich financier; Voegler and Krupp, the "representatives of Ruhr-and-Rhineland big business," and Oskar von Hindenburg, son of the former general.

NEITHER defeat nor victory ends a war. Only cowards and the soul-blind believe that, when conquered in the field, they must stop fighting and surrender and collaborate. Peoples once great have lost their greatness in this war by deciding to lower themselves to the level of their conquerors.

The Second War Loan Drive, just ended, raised about $16,000,000,000, but it failed to halt the steady weekly increases in money in circulation. On the contrary, during the three weeks covered by the drive, money in circulation rose $240,000,000 to a new high record of $16,593,000,000.

The net consequences of the wage issue between the Administration and the United Mine Workers cannot yet be assayed. But it would seem to be a well-founded expectation that among these, whether the leadership of John L. Lewis will be injured or enhanced, the President will not find that he has lost the predominant support of organized labor.
CLOVE PINKS, with their sweet, spicy fragrance, have long been a favorite of gardeners. Today, some of the offspring of these fine old-fashioned plants are proving even more delightful.

THE new Noel Coward film, "This Happy Breed," has gone before the cameras at Denham. In the strictest sense, this is a Coward project rather than a Coward film. The master wrote the original play, has supervised shooting script, cast the parts, and keeps a tight hand on every detail of production, but he will neither direct the film nor appear in it.

Last week's after-Easter business continued at a fairly good pace with the added impetus of Mother's Day gift purchasing, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. Difficulties of obtaining merchandise for immediate or near-by delivery continue to mount.

An illustrated brochure of fifteen pages, detailing the activities and needs of the Greater New York Fund, was published yesterday by the fund for its sixth annual campaign. The formal opening of the campaign will take place tomorrow night at the Astor Hotel, Walter S. Gifford, chairman of the executive committee, announced.
