IT would be difficult to find a group of plants more suited to our American scheme of gardening than the annuals. Only a small investment in time and money is needed to get quick results; the charm of growing annuals is that it is so simple.
The Saturday German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 2 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Rabbis yesterday expressed gratitude to churches affiliated with the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America for setting aside today as a Christian "Day of Compassion" for persecuted Jews in Europe.

To insure a durable peace after the war the nations of the world must establish the unassailability of the moral law, even above the rights of national sovereignty, speakers declared yesterday at an an-day regional meeting of the Catholic Association for International Peace, held at the De Porres Interracial Center, 20 Vesey Street.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 1 -- Cornell won two overtime games with Princeton by identical scores, 4 -- 3, today. The Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League contest, set for seven innings, lasted eight and ten, respectively.
CHUNGKING, China, May 2 (U.P.) -- A communique:

MOSCOW, May 2 (AP) -- Pravda, Communist party newspaper, today put the war effort of Russia's Allies in the same scale with the Red Army victory at Stalingrad and declared "the Hitlerite command fears active operations of our Allies on the European continent as it would fear fire.

Commercial air transportation has been called a young man's activity. Certainly it has shown every symptom of youthful energy and ready adaptability to wartime conditions. The report of Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, on the performance of domestic airlines in 1942 makes good reading.

Direct Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $25,510,552,800. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes, certificates of indebtedness and non - interest - bearing discount bills as follows:

Despite the predicted easing in the rubber supply through synthetics and the release of war tires to civilians, tire conservation campaigns by the large rubber companies will continue, according to indications. U.S. Rubber Co., for example, will release a new campaign today on the theme of preserving tires.
Under the heading "Darlan Plot to Foil Germans Reported" THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 29 reported an interview given in London by my colleague in the French Parliament, Pierre Vienot.

A ten-room dwelling and one and one-half acre of land at Sea Girt, N.J., were purchased by Miss Margaret Daum, the concert and opera soprano, from the estate of the late Rev. Adolph Holthusen. Henry Schwier was the broker.

Several leading churches here, with others planning to follow suit, are seeing to it that soldiers and sailors on week-end leaves get sleeping accommodations, "royal welcomes," and Sunday dinner invitations from parishioners.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Declaring that the Republicans had enough votes to pass the Carlson bill, Representative Martin, the House minority leader, today called off a party conference, set for tomorrow, on action to be taken when the House meets Monday to resume consideration of pay-as-you-go tax bills.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Warmer weather with rain would be highly beneficial in a number of sections west of the Mississippi River, especially in the light soil areas west of the 100th Meridian. The States east of the Mississippi have ample moisture, but growth of Winter grains and Spring-sown oats, barley and other crops is being delayed by continued low temperatures.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 3 -- Japanese planes, renewing large-scale attacks on Allied bases in the Southwest Pacific after a two-week lull, attacked Port Darwin, in Northern Australia, yesterday morning and inflicted heavy losses on Allied air defenders.

Underwriters headed by B. J. van Ingen Co., Inc., offered today $3,500,000 of City of Mobile, Ala., 4 per cent and 3 1/2 per cent tunnel revenue anticipation bonds dated April 1, 1943, and due on May 1, 1945 tO 1969. The proceeds will be used to refund $2,477,000 of tunnel bonds and to finance construction of improvements to the tunnel approaches.

Eighty-four fellowships and graduate scholarships with a value of $72,673 have been granted by Columbia University for 1943-44, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, announced yesterday. Because of the war, several endowed and university fellowships were not bestowed.

On the premise that future agricultural prices will be determined by the outcome of the coal miners' wage dispute, traders in cotton futures last week curtailed much of their activity to await settlement of the wage controversy. In exceptionally dull trading, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange continued an almost horizontal price movement, ending the week mixed, 1 point higher to 4 points lower than the preceding week.

Plans have been completed for the luncheon and card party in behalf of the Barat Settlement, 221 Chrystie Street, which will take place tomorrow at Sherry's under the auspices of the Barat Auxiliary. The proceeds will further the recreational and educational programs provided at the settlement for more than 400 children in a crowded district. Mrs. Frederick L. Kane heads the benefit committee and her assistant is Mrs. John S. Burke.

CHUNGKING, China, May 2 (AP) -- A Chinese High Command communique said today more than 1,000 Japanese troops had been killed or wounded in four days of fighting last month during a renewed effort of the invaders to clear out Chinese positions in Shantung Province north of the railroad between Tsinan and the Yellow Sea port of Tsingtao.

The House of St. Giles the Cripple will be assisted by a theatre party arranged by members of the Tiny Tim Society, the ladies auxiliary of the institution, for Wednesday night at the performance of "The Patriots," at the National Theatre. For more than twenty-five years the beneficiary has been aiding crippled children. The institution maintains a hospital at 1346 President Street, Brooklyn, and a home and school in Garden City, L.I.

Patrolman Alfred Muoio of the Snyder Avenue Station in Brooklyn called his desk lieutenant at 10:10 o'clock yesterday morning to report that a burglar alarm was ringing on his post at Flatbush Avenue and Linden Boulevard.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 2 -- Employes of the Condenser Corporation of America and the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation, at a mass meeting today, threatened to seek other jobs where they could produce more war materials unless the government either corrects existing conditions at the plant within forty-eight hours or takes over the production entirely.

An audience of 1,500 persons at Carnegie Hall who observed, under Protestant auspices, the Day of Compassion for the Jewish victims of Nazi atrocities, heard Pierre van Paassen, the author, assert that Palestine presented the only solution to the refugee problem.

Facing 50,000 workers at a "Labor for Victory" rally at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, Mayor La Guardia declared that the huge turnout tended to serve as a public pronouncement to the whole country that the working men and women in New York City are "seeking unity in their own country first."

Handicapped by the threat of a strike in the soft coal mines, the stock market moved cautiously in the early part of last week but quickly recovered when President Roosevelt issued an ultimatum ordering the miners back to work on Saturday morning.

LONDON, Monday, May 3 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers and fighters struck at industrial targets at Ijmuiden in the Netherlands yesterday, following up a heavy raid Saturday by big American bombers against the German submarine base at St. Nazaire that cost seven planes.

The two weeks' truce in the coal strike which was announced last night by Mr. Lewis, just as President Roosevelt was about to appeal to the miners to return to work, at least means that there will be no immediate disruption of the domestic economy of the United States and no imminent danger that our troops in the field will lack weapons and munitions.
Yugoslav patriots are carrying on activity of "mounting intensity on the Hungarian-Yugoslav frontier," the London radio said last night, quoting a broadcast of the Budapest radio.

LONDON, May 2 (Reuter) -- The Hon. Sir A. Ramaswami D.B. Mudaliar, one of India's representatives in the War Cabinet, and Hon. Sir Mohamed Aziz-ul Huque, High Commissioner in London, are to join the Viceroy's executive council, the former as member for supply and the latter as commerce member.

AN ADVANCED AIR BASE IN NORTH AFRICA, May 1 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Three boys who went to high school together in Charlotte, N.C. -- two of them the only brothers flying in the same plane in all of North Africa -- were in one of the Mitchell bombers that helped sink an Italian destroyer off Cap Bon Friday morning.

The cleavage in the New York State Republican organization between supporters of Governor Thomas E. Dewey and Wendell L. Willkie, 1940 nominee for President, came into the open yesterday when Rolland B. Marvin took notice of a recent speech of Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran.

BOSTON, May 2 (AP) -- The Red Sox split a twin bill today with the Athletics, coming from behind to win the opener, 7 -- 6, and then collapsing in the nightcap as the Mackmen racked up an 8-1 verdict.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY NORTHEAST OF BEJA, Tunisia, April 28 (Delayed) (AP) -- A big command car was speeding along a dirt road ahead of American infantry moving up through the fields when it suddenly came to a halt.
Following is the text of last night's address by President Roosevelt, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

RAPID CITY, S.D., May 2 -- Wendell Willkie, speaking at the National Memorial at Mount Rushmore today, urged Americans to take a lesson from the drill of a soldier, learning that "you can't parry a butt blow; you've got to beat it." He said the soldier learns to "get in a lunge first and beat the blow."

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 2 -- Radio as an instrument of greater understanding between the United States and Great Britain, now and in the post-war years, "deserves to be classified as an essential industry," Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister and special assistant to the British Ambassador, said here tonight in an address to the fourteenth annual Institute for Education by Radio, under the auspices of Ohio State University.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 2 -- No Congress of Industrial Organization union will go on strike in wartime as long as he remains the president of that organization, Philip Murray said today.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- Steel production last week rose a half point to 100 per cent of rated capacity. Barring unforeseen events the same rate is indicated for this week. However, continuance of the stoppage of coal production would cause steel output in this center to drop to some extent the latter part of this week.

The War Production Board has granted a priority for construction of a bulkhead that will make possible the development of a new 600-acre marine park on the Lower Bay shore of Staten Island, the city Parks Department announced yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, May 2 (AP) -- A pilot and his co-pilot, who succeeded after a valiant fight in rescuing trapped crewmen from a sinking plane in waters off New Guinea, were awarded the Soliders Medal today.

ALBANY, May 2 -- The Sheriffs of New York State have organized the Sheriffs Emergency Forces, "a veritable army of nearly 18,000 highly trained, well-equipped, civilian 'soldiers' that stands ready to respond to the beck and call of the New York State War Council's Office of Civilian Protection during any wartime emergency."

Germain G. Glidden of the Englewood Field Club, former national champion, succeeds Donald Frame at the top of the ranking of the Metropolitan Squash Racquet Association for the season of 1942-43. The ratings were announced yesterday by Chairman A.G. Town-send.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., May 2 -- Miss Mary Howard Constable of New York and Dr. William Yasuki Takahashi, a Japanese physician now an interne at the University of Michigan Hospital, were married here this morning in Lane Hall building of the campus Student Religious Association.

The wail of Scottish bagpipes mingled with the deep tones of the organ at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday afternoon at the annual St. George's Day service. The 5,000 persons in attendance heard a message from Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, that the tide of war definitely is turning in favor of the Allies.
We have read with interest your editorial in which you comment on our book, "America, Russia and the Communist Party in the Post-War World." We are in complete accord with your two main theses:

The heading "Mr. Hull's Trade Treaties" on an otherwise excellent editorial falls into a familiar error. The Reciprocal Trade Agreements are not "treaties." They are "agreements" with foreign countries and made under the authority of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

The planting of "spiritual victory gardens" in the hearts and souls of individuals and then in family life as an aid to attaining a lasting peace was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William F. King at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Japanese propagandists continued today their attempts to exploit the coal strike in America for Japanese purposes, with one shortwave broadcast to the United States by the Tokyo radio characterizing May 1, 1943, as the date "marking the period when the inevitable collapse, of the American machine became apparent."

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- War production drive headquarters announced today the award of national suggestion honors to 116 war workers, including thirty-five certificates of individual production merit and eighty-one letters of honorable mention, bestowed for ideas improving production submitted to Washington by labor-management committees in over 2,000 plants and shipyards during the past month.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Delay in delivery of the new balata balls restored the 1942 pellet to the use of the Yankees today at Griffith Stadium, and they proceeded to celebrate, swamping the Senators, 11 to 3, in the opening game of a double-header that attracted 32,218 fans. But the champions faded in the nightcap when the Kansas City rookie, Charley Wensloff, went down to defeat by 4 to 1.
PITTSBURGH, May 2 (AP) -- Playing heads-up ball behind the stingy pitching of Wally Hebert and Bob Klinger, the Pirates captured a double-header from the Cubs today, 3 to 0 and 1 to 0.

Dismembered, conquered and subjugated, but still fighting for freedom and independence as throughout her history, Poland today observes a national holiday full of tragedy, but also full of pride and hope for the future. For today is Poland's Constitution Day, commemorating the Constitution of May 3, 1791, which was adopted by a bloodless revolution led by a King and which became the first written democratic Constitution on the Continent.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 2 -- American, British and French forces have inched forward along most of the Tunisian front, improving their positions for the next phase of the Allied drive. Although hundreds of sorties were flown by the Allied Air Force, bad weather continued to hamper air support.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The National Negro Council, in an emergency meeting today, called on the 100,000 Negroes employed in the struck coal fields to return to work tomorrow as ordered by President Roosevelt.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 (AP) -- The Phillies and the Braves divided a double-header today before 12,942 fans. Boston won the first game, 3 to 1, while the Phillies took the second, 6 to 5, in twelve innings.

As part of a program sponsored by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, which designated yesterday as a Day of Compassion for the persecuted Jews of Europe, the morning service in St. George's Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square, included a sermon on "The Art of Living Together," preached by Rabbi Samuel H. Goldenson, of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, and special prayers for the victims of Nazi atrocities.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Creation of a foreign propertyholders protective committee to represent some 2,000,000 American investors who have had an estimated $5,000,000,000 of property systematically destroyed or looted by the Axis in the global war zones was announced today by Eugene P. Thomas, president of the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc.
Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 111.9 to 111.8.

We are glad to publish in another column on this page today a letter in which Robert H. Patchin, correcting a headline which inadvertently attached itself to a recent editorial, makes a strong case for continuation of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act. Of course, these agreements are not treaties.

Retail interest in the wholesale markets shifted from pre-Easter to Summer and Fall merchandise last week, with immediate demand mostly concentrated on special items for Mother's Day and graduation promotions, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 2 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped a four-game losing streak today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 -- 6, in ten innings, and 2-0. The double defeat halted a five-game winning streak compiled by Burleigh Grimes's team.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 2 (AP) -- A German newspaper admission that total mobilization has failed to provide Reichsmuehrer Adolf Hitler with all the trained manpowver he needs coincided with unconfirmed reports here today that the Nazis were trying to induct captured Russian soldiers into the German Army and to raise recruits in the occupied Baltic States.
LONDON, May 2 -- The situation in Poland was described in Polish circles here today as total underground war of the entire population against the German invader who is decimating the Polish people.
ALGIERS, May 2 -- General Henri Honore Giraud predicted today that the Tunisian campaign would be concluded this month and that the war would end in 1944.

CHICAGO, May 2 (AP) -- An eleventh-inning homer by Outfielder Chet Laabs in the opener and Steve Sundra's steady, seven-hit pitching in the nightcap gave the Browns a double victory over the White Sox, 3 to 2 and 5 to 1, before 4,525 fans today and enabled the St. Louis club to return home tonight at the .500 mark.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 2 -- In audacious daylight attacks off Cap Bon Peninsula, British motor torpedo boats have sunk a large motor vessel and two mine sweepers and set a German Raumboot -- a large motor patrol boat -- afire, it was disclosed today.

As many preachers devoted their sermons yesterday to the family in recognition of National Family Week, the religious committee sponsoring the observance that began yesterday hailed it as "a clear and unequivocal recognition" of the spiritual nature of the family.

Special religious and patriotic ceremonies in memory of the Polish men, women and children slaughtered when the Nazi hordes invaded Poland were held throughout the State yesterday. In this city the "Poland Day" services were sponsored by the New York State Conference of Polish Clubs, the United St. Stanislaus Societies and Chapter 25 of the Polish-American Relief Council.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 3 (AP) -- The noon communique:
LONDON, May 2 -- The Poles celebrated their National Day today on the outs with Russia but with many assurances of friendship and good-will from Britain.

New York City had its first Sunday air raid drill yesterday morning. It was ordered by the Army through the Second Service Command without previous warning to Mayor La Guardia or other city officials, but at its close the Mayor expressed his "complete satisfaction" with the manner in which the city had met the test.

A high-stooped white house at 8 East Sixty-first Street will open its iron-grilled and glass doors May 15 to the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States. Announcement of the Navy League's new headquarters was made yesterday by Mrs. Charles Howland Russell Jr.

The National City Bank of New York in its monthly letter, released for publication today, expresses the opinion that industrial production in the aggregate is approaching its ceiling. The bank states that not only are limitations of materials and manpower slowing down the three-year rise, which has doubled output since the Spring of 1940, but that shifts in the requirements of the war program make it difficult to get the utmost out of available facilities.

On Thursday evening at 8:30 several hundred boys and girls will take part in an open forum discussion of world events in Times Hall. Particular emphasis will be placed on the effect of the war upon youth and the part youth will have to play in molding the future world.

Mayor La Guardia appealed yesterday to Governor Dewey and the Republican members of the Legislature to make good their campaign pledges of last Fall by calling a special session at which the city would be empowered to impose new taxes to raise the revenue required to avert the threatened rise of sixteen points in the city's basic real estate tax rate.

NEW DELHI, India, May 2 (AP) -- American and British airmen attacked Japanese positions at many points in Burma yesterday, bombing and strafing troops, airfields and supply lines in widespread operations that lasted on into the night. Allied communiques disclosed today.

PITTSBURGH, May 2 -- A large part of the 125,000 bituminous coal miners in this area tonight heard the news that will send them back into the mines, discontinuing a stoppage that had already resulted in the United States Government taking over the operations of the mines.

Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, director of the Division of Instruction at Teachers College, has been appointed Director of Schools and School Experimentation in charge of the combined Horace Mann and Lincoln Schools, Dean William F. Russell announced yesterday.

AN old woman, her hair white in the moonlight, stood on the roof of an apartment building in Athens and watched the British bombers overhead. "Drop bombs on us -- we don't care," she said. "But, dear God, protect the British aviators. Don't let any harm come to them." In her own frail person she was a magnificent symbol of the fighting spirit of her people, the unflagging

Baseball, which some folks feared had gone into hiding for the duration, finally came back with a loud detonation yesterday as the young season's first banner turnout, a gathering of 50,257 which included 3,171 service men, packed the Polo Grounds to see the Dodgers and Giants play their second successive week-end double-header.

American troops in Tunisia captured Hill 609 at 1 o'clock last Saturday morning. Hill 609 is just one in the tangle of rocky peaks that bar the way to the plains of Tunis. But because it rises 2,000 feet in a precipitous slope, every yard of which was swept by Nazi machine guns, our doughboys called it "Djebel Devil." Nevertheless, they took it, and at the point of the bayonet.

PESHAWAR, India, April 29 (Delayed) -- Seven hundred and fifty Afridi chieftains gathered outside Peshawar this morning to discuss their problems and complaints and talk things over with Governor Sir George Cunningham. It was a sight that could not be duplicated anywhere in the world and it was interesting as an example of how the wheels go round in India.

An opportunity which amateur or professional fly tyers may have been seeking appears to be at hand. The Arts and Skills Unit of the American Red Cross is organizing a group to teach the art of fly tying to wounded men in the Army and Navy hospitals.
LONDON, May 2 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:...

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- President Roosevelt tonight put "responsibility for the crisis that we now face" as a result of the nationwide coal stoppage on the "national officers of the United Mine Workers and not on the Government of the United States."
WITH THE SECOND UNITED STATES CORPS, May 2 -- Two arms of the American offensive closed in on Mateur today.

LONDON, May 2 -- Firmly bent on personal discussions with General Giraud, General de Gaulle cabled to him today suggesting an immediate meeting in Algiers looking toward the ironing out of the differences blocking complete unity between their movements.

Lieutenant Governor Thomas W. Wallace warned 2,000 members of the Fire Department Holy Name Society yesterday that "certain groups" were seeking to bring about the regimentation of children through nursery care while their mothers were at work in war industry.

LONDON, May 2 -- The City, it is not too much to say, is perturbed seriously by the Polish-Soviet breach. To many who have not followed very closely the course of events between Russia and Poland, this break comes with somewhat startling suddenness, but it is no surprise to those who are politically better informed.

DETROIT, May 2 (AP) -- The Indians regained sole possession of second place in the American League today by hammering three pitchers for eleven hits to defeat the Tigers, 5 to 2, in the opener of a double-header before 22,040 spectators.
Brookhattan defeated the New York Americans by 6 -- 3 in a Lewis Cup soccer game at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

Unless the problem of employment is solved after the war, the entire system of free enterprise will give way to a form of State socialism, the post-war economic planning committee of the American Business Congress declared yesterday.
LONDON, May 2 (U.P.) -- An Admiralty communique:

I would invite your attention to the fact that an editorial of yours captioned "Lieutenant General McNair," which appeared on April 27, contains the statement: "In the First World War he was the youngest brigadier general."
Toilet lanolin is one of those rare substances that lead a double life. It is a medicine in the doctor's cabinet and a cosmetic on milady's dressing table.

Five wartime food demonstrations -- essentially alike and to be given simultaneously in each of the boroughs -- will take place tomorrow at 10 o'clock under the aegis of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office. Tickets, which are free, may be obtained through the local CDVO offices or the Block Service Organization.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The National Conference for Palestine unanimously adopted a resolution today condemning the White Paper of 1939 issued by the British Government to restrict Jewish settlement in Palestine and calling on the United States Government to make representations to annul the document and seek assurance that Jewish immigration and purchase of land in the selected homeland shall not be restricted.
An unidentified airplane fired four or more .50-caliber machine-gun bullets into the Park Slope section of Brooklyn at 12:10 P.M., yesterday. No one was injured.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 1 (Delayed) -- Soldiers at this advanced American base in one of the loneliest and most isolated parts of Australia relieve the monotony by talking to the lizards.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The general index of basic commodity prices based on the August, 1939, level declined from 176.4 on April 22 to 176.2 on April 30, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The index of controlled commodities rose from 162.7 to 162.8 in the period.

WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- The Navy today announced the decoration of ten submarine, commanders. Japanese warships, transports, cargo ships, merchantmen, even a submarine were included in the shipping they destroyed. In addition, damage was inflicted on many other enemy craft.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 2 -- While Pierre Laval's propaganda in Vichy today was representing him as having returned from his audience with Adolf Hitler staggering under a load of wonderful things for France in the "new Europe" -- when Germany has won the war -- Marshal Henri Philippe Petain was broadcasting to French labor in an atmosphere of gloom.
CLEVELAND, May 2 (AP) -- Buyers not already covered by Controlled Materials Plan numbers will receive little steel before July, the magazine Steel reported today.
Dave Finkle, associated for many years with Salomon Brothers Hutzler, has become a member of Bear, Stearns Co.

Preceded by a parade, the Association of Ex-members of Squadron A and its successor organization, the Manhattan units of the Fifty-first Regiment, New York Guard, held their fifty-third annual memorial service yesterday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

NEW ORLEANS, May 2 -- Belated liquidation in May options on first notice day at the beginning of last week, accounting for a temporary decline of about 75 cents a bale in that position, brought the week's only semblance of a variation in prices of futures on the Cotton Exchange here.

EAST ISLIP, L.I., May 2 -- Hi-Wood Mike, a field trial champion owned by Mrs. John S. Williams of Old Chatham, N.Y., and handled by James A. Cowie, this evening was awarded the top honors in the open all-age stake at the Spring meeting of the Women's Field Trial Club.
LONDON, May 2 -- The stock markets in London experienced a somewhat disturbed but on the whole satisfactory week.

LONDON, Monday, May 3 (U.P.) -- Russia said today that her troops had broken a six-day German offensive in force in the Novorossiisk area of the Kuban at a cost to the enemy of more than 7,000 men killed and twenty-five tanks and armored cars knocked out.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 2 (U.P.) -- A communique:

HONOLULU, May 1 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Rear Admiral C.A. Lockwood, commander of submarine forces of the Pacific Fleet, today presented decorations to three officers and nine enlisted men for submarine activities.

The Alleghany Corporation has consummated an agreement with a banking group for a loan of about $19,600,000 for six years at 4 per cent for the purpose of paying off not later than July 6, next, its outstanding $22,647,000 collateral trust 5 per cent bonds, due Feb. 1, 1944, the company announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Trading in hog products last week was largely routine. Brokers said that with half of the output going to the government, the remainder of the lard and meats must be spread very thin to take care of the domestic and export trade.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 2 -- The University of Rochester conferred degrees today on 220 men and women graduates at its ninety-third annual commencement exercises and gave diplomas in nursing to thirty-seven graduates of the School of Nursing, Strong Memorial Hospital, and performers' certificates to twenty-two Eastman School students.
JACKSON, Wyo., May 2 (AP) -- Cowboys with rifles in saddle scabbards and pistols in hip holsters drove 600 critters onto the Jackson Hole national monument area today.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 2 -- Viktor Lutze, Chief of Staff of the Nazi Storm Troops, was seriously injured in an automobile accident near Potsdam last Saturday. He was returning from an official trip when his car collided with another.

MOSCOW, May 2 -- The newspaper Pravda said today that the enemy's defeat was nearer now than ever before and stresses those passages in Premier Joseph Stalin's May Day order regarding the merging of the Allied offensives into a single blow.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Sales of all retail stores in March were estimated by the Department of Commerce at $5,052,000,000, which was 13 per cent above the same month of 1942. This gain, the department said, is partly due to the extra shopping day this year, but occurred despite the later Easter this year.
Mr. and Mrs. W. McMaster Mills, who had been at the Pierre, have gone to Newport, R.I., for the Spring and Summer.

One of the outstanding young representatives of the Women's Swimming Association, Miss Florence Schmitt, captured the women's 440-yard senior metropolitan A.A.U. free style championship to feature the aquatic meet yesterday in the seventy-five-foot London Terrace pool, the organization's headquarters.
LOUISVILLE, May 2 (U.P.) -- Don Cameron, who trained Count Fleet, was satisfied today with the colt's Derby performance, but was convinced he could travel much faster if necessary to win.
NEW DELHI, India, May 2 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Army Air Force Headquarters communique:...

Most of us have assumed that the purpose of the Office of Civilian Defense and of the various organizations affiliated with it is to prepare for civilian protection against enemy bombing and other forms of enemy action against the home front. But some odd things seem to be happening.
The need for maintaining adequate civilian food supplies was emphasized in addresses broadcast yesterday by Mayor La Guardia and Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America.

A half hour before President Roosevelt went on the air last night and denounced the general coal strike as a blow at the war effort, John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers called off the stoppage on the basis of a fifteen-day truce.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., May 2 -- The first contingent of women radio technicians of tomorrow -- unassuming in the traditional campus clothing and low-heeled shoes -- are prepared to start classes tomorrow at Purdue University. Eighty-seven girls from all parts of the country will formally open the first such training program in the radio and electronics field under sponsorship of the R.C.A.-Victor Division of the Radio Corporation of America.

THE classic remark delivered by Mark Twain that rumors of his death were slightly exaggerated applies perfectly. Those who view with alarm were about ready to inter baseball with or without full military honors. But one look at the tremendous crowd of 50,257 at the Polo Grounds yesterday revealed that the patient is still alive and kicking.

Tribute to Mrs. Mary McLeod Bethune, president of the Bethune-Cookman College, Daytona Beach, Fla., was paid yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who described her as symbolizing the "spirit of which all of us today want to be conscious." That spirit, she said, is one of courage, of love, of endurance and of hope.
LONDON, Monday, May 3 (Reuter) -- Commenting on President Roosevelt's order to the miners, The London Times said today:
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A lot of intuition and a dash of curiosity make women ideal censors, so good, in fact, that the government has hired 5,000 of them in the last year, officials said today.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Operations in oats on the Board of Trade last week were on a fair scale, but prices averaged somewhat lower because of profit-taking and scattered liquidation by holders of May contracts. Large quantities of Canadian oats have been purchased by American interests, but the movement of the grain is slow.

The Census Bureau keeps pelting us with statistics, even in wartime. There was the report a few days ago, for example, revealing that of 35,100,000 families in the United States in 1949 nearly half had no children under 18 years of age.
Five new films will open at Broadway theatres during the week. The schedule follows:

The Yiddish Culture Chorus, Vladimir Heifetz conductor, assisted by Emanuel List, Metropolitan Opera basso, and Semion Spielman, 'cello, gave its thirteenth annual concert yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Mania Platt, Feigel Sunshine and Bella Falik, sopranos, and Sol Tisman and William Meyerowitz, baritones, were featured. Sonia Eidus was at the piano for the chorus and Mr. Spielman, and Paul Berl for Mr. List. Part of the proceeds of the concert were for war relief.

The cost to the Federal War Damage Corporation of settling claims for losses of money and securities insured against possible enemy attack may be very slight, under an interpretation of the settlement clauses of the Federal policies to be issued today by the Money and Securities War Damage Group of 111 John Street.
ALBANY, May 2 -- The State Board of Examiners of Professional Engineers and Land Surveyors has issued licenses to the following persons who successfully passed the January examination:

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Growing tightness in the cash corn situation is reported, and elevator men report little or no possibility of any change in the immediate future. Farmers are refusing to sell cash grain freely owing to the press of field work, and no increase in the movement is expected until the latter part of the month, if then.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 2 -- Count Fleet packed his bags today and hopped a train for Baltimore and what looked like a sure-shot $50,000 in the Preakness while Derbyville still argued long and loud, "Is the Count fleet?"

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The reaction of government officials tonight to John L. Lewis's order calling off the nation-wide coal strike was one of deep relief and of hope that the fifteen-day "breathing spell" would be ended with an arrangement for guar anteeing the mine workers six days of operation every week that they work.
LONDON, Monday, May 3 (U.P.) -- The Russian Sunday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
WASHINGTON, May 2 (AP) -- Lend-lease administration figures showed today it shipped our allies about one-tenth of the available meat supply in the first three months of 1943.

Declaring that the burden carried by every Christian had taken on wider latitude and greater proportion with the world in its present state, the Rev. Dr. Kenneth D. Miller, president of the New York City Mission Society, said yesterday morning at the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, that those who professed to be carefree with conditions the way they are really had the greatest burdens in their hearts.

Former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, who had been abroad several weeks in connection with his duties as Director of the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, returned to the United States by Pan American Clipper yesterday.
The Pulitzer prizes in letters, journalism and music for 1943 will be announced this afternoon at Columbia University, following action by the trustees of the university.

Loomis J. Grossman, the operator, has purchased the four-story loft building at the northeast corner of West and Beach Streets from the Seamen's Bank for Savings for cash over a new mortgage of $111,000. The building is on a plot 90 by 100 feet and is occupied under a long lease by Adolph Goldmark Sons, wholesale grocery dealers.
ST. LOUIS, May 2 (AP) -- Solid, extra-base blows powered the Cardinals to two victories over the Reds today, 7 to 6 and 6 to 3.

KEARNY, N.J., May 2 -- For a few hours, today was the greatest in the life of Daniel Goodwin Jr. of 181 Pearsall Avenue, Jersey City, 3-year-old son of an employe of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here.

HONOLULU, T.H., May 2 -- Thousands of American service men at this Pacific center, where the war with Japan began, were amazed and infuriated today by the news that coal miners at home had gone on strike.

There is a striking contrast between Joseph Stalin's May Day broadcast and his Order of the Day to the Red Army last February. In the earlier pronouncement he did not mention his allies. He bluntly asserted that the Soviet Union was fighting alone. Although he spoke after Casablanca, he made no reference to the war council of Churchill and Roosevelt or to their efforts to induce him to be present.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 -- Frank Hiller, Lafayette College right-hander from Irvington, N.J., made his professional start today after signing with Newark early last week, and pitched the Bears to a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Royals in the nightcap of a double-header. Newark also won the opener, 3 to 1, and now leads the league.
LONDON, May 2 (Reuter) -- Colin Bednall, The Daily Mail's air correspondent, told a graphic story today of the substratosphere raid carried out by Flying Fortresses on St. Nazaire yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The grim story of the rescue of seven airmen from the Greenland ice cap after five months of persistent attempts in which five men died was told today by the War Department.

LOS ANGELES, May 3 -- A reassuring, but realistic, analysis of the dangers of inflation was made here today by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange and former chairman of the board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 3 -- Bold Captain, the son of Bold Venture, winner of the 1936 Kentucky Derby, annexed the Oak Ridge Farm Purse today at Churchill Downs in a field made up mostly of eligibles which did not run in the Derby.

City College still is without a victory over Fordham on the diamond. Handcuffed by the slants of left-handed Harry Magee, who yielded only three hits, the Beavers went down to a 7-to-1 defeat in their twenty-sixth meeting with the Maroon on the winner's field yesterday.

THEY were boisterous, rambunctious and colorful on the field and they were identically the same off it, too. This operative had heard some fantastic stories of the Gas House Gang of St. Louis on his recent Western trip and sought confirmation the other day from Branch Rickey.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- Some 1,800 men returned to work after a five-day strike at two Warwickshire mines, which, authorities said, cost the nation's dangerously small fuel stocks 17,000 tons of coal.

With the blessings of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which financed the production, Irwin Shaw's play, "Sons and Soldiers," will open this evening at the Morosco. Max Reinhardt, Norman Bel Geddes and Richard Myers are the producers. The featured players are Geraldine Fitzgerald, Gregory Peck, Stella Adler, Herbert Rudley, Millard Mitchell and Leonard Sues. Mr. Reinhardt directed the production and Mr. Geddes designed the settings.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Restrictions on press coverage of the United Nations food conference opening May 18 at Hot Springs, Va., have been modified.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- If "government officials" had not "requested" the conference here yesterday between John L. Lewis and the Coordinator of Solid Fuels, Mr. Ickes, the miners' leader might not have been in a position last night to anticipate the President's call-back of the miners with a statement in which he could grant a "truce" to the government.
MOSCOW, May 3 -- The Soviet press is still concerning itself principally with Premier Stalin's May Day order of the day, which had a perceptibly steadying and encouraging effect on public opinion.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Calling for the establishment of "a council of nations based on the United Nation to assume full responsibility in maintaining world order," Republican Post-War Policy Association, an anti-isolationist party group organized by delegates from twelve Midwestern States, was formed today on a national basis.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Whitney Bowles of Newfoundland, N.J., who refused, as a conscientious objector, to submit to military induction, must serve his three-year sentence, the Supreme Court held today in passing upon the first case of this kind to be presented during World War II.

CINCINNATI, May 3 (AP) -- The Reds, returning to their home lot and use of the not-so-dead 1942 ball, unleashed a seventeen-hit attack against four hurlers to win the opener of a three-game series with the Pirates today, 7 to 5.

Terms of a proposed settlement by which Universal Pictures Co., Inc., would be merged into its parent company, Universal Corporation, were presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins. The merger is proposed in settlement of a suit brought by Samuel I. Posen, director and stockholder of Universal Pictures, and other stockholders of the company.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -Elmer Davis, head of the Office of War Information, told a House military subcommittee today "insinuations that OWI is a haven for draft dodgers" are "untrue and unjust to the many loyal men who work tirelessly and faithfully for OWI."

LEWISBURG, Pa., May 3 -- William Fox, former wealthy motion picture producer, was released on parole from the Northeastern Penitentiary here today after serving five months and seventeen days of a year and a day sentence on charges of conspiring to obstruct justice and defraud the United States in connection with his bankruptcy matters.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn granted an order yesterday prohibiting Police Commissioner Valentine from conducting a departmental trial on charges of dereliction of duty against former Police Inspector Camille C. Pierne, former Lieutenant Terence J. Harvey and former Patrolman Thomas F. Keevan.

In their most forceful exhibition of hitting since April 24, the Dodgers defeated the cellar-dwelling Phillies at Ebbets Field yesterday, 5 to 3, and increased their lead over the second-place Cardinals, who did not see championship action yesterday, to two and a half games.

The sixth annual campaign of the Greater New York Fund, with its goal set at a minimum of $4,500,000, $300,000 more than was collected last year, was launched formally last night at a dinner in the Hotel Astor attended by 1,200 persons.

The country estate of North McLean, comprising sixty acres of land, a main dwelling, a superintendent's cottage and several out-buildings along Stoney Street, Peekskill, Westchester County, has been purchased from Mr. McLean by David Bunim, an executive of the Schenley Distillers Corporation.

Increases in the prices of steel products are the only alternative to the absorption of much of the income available to stockholders, as well as reserves for future needs, if there are to be material increases in employment costs or in taxes in the future, Irving S. Olds, chairman of United States Steel Corporation, warned stockholders yesterday at their annual meeting in Hoboken, N.J.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- There will continue to be plenty of drugs to meet all civilian needs even though the supply of raw materials may be reduced somewhat, Fred Stock, of the War Production Board, informed members of the American Drug Manufacturers Association meeting here today.

Fashion is never boring. It never reaches an impasse that permits the reporter to say: "There's nothing new to talk about." Even the war with its restrictions can't keep it down. Cut it off in one direction and it pops up serenely in another with a merry gesture.

Wet grounds, according to the powers-that-be, prevented the Yankees and the Red Sox from opening a four-game series at the Stadium yesterday and so, with a certain degree of reluctance, a double-header, the season's first there, was scheduled for Thursday.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- This was the "most happiest day of my life" for Lieutenant Steve Pissanos, former Plainfield, N.J., bakery worker now attached to the United States Army Air Forces.

NEW CITY, N.Y., May 3 -- Characterizing the methods of selecting grand jurors in Rockland County as "most irregular and more probably illegal," District Attorney George V. Dorsey opened an investigation today into the manner in which the lists have been prepared by the county's Board of Supervisors.

LONDON, May 3 -- Investigation of the cost of building thirty-two British warships has revealed profits up to more than 80 per cent, it was made known today, and because of the profits disclosed all builders concerned except one have accepted an Admiralty proposal to waive all claims for extras on certain ships.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- American merchant shipyards established another new record for ship production in .april by delivering 157 ships of 1,606,600 deadweight tons. This, announced today by the lVfaritime Commission, lifted the /943 production to 536 ships aggregating 5,370,200 deadweight tons, the four-month total exceeding the total tonnage constructed during the first nine months of 1942.-

BALTIMORE, May 3 (AP) -- Count Fleet, apparently on edge after his winning Kentucky Derby effort, arrived at Pimlico today to keep a date in the fifty-third running of the Preakness Stakes Saturday, and track experts began trying to name a colt that might push him to the wire in the $50,000 added event.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The House debated pay-as-you-go taxation for four hours today, but limitation of debate to two hours tomorrow emerged as one of the very few points of agreement, with the prospect that a final vote will be taken then.
The six-story apartment house containing sixty-six suites at 96-09 Sixty-sixth Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, has been purchased by an investing syndicate represented by Joseph Howard Katz, attorney.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names and next of kin of 170 United States soldiers held prisoners of war by Italy and 211 held by Japan. Of these prisoners, sixty-five hail from New York, nine from New Jersey and three from Connecticut.

NEW DELHI, May 3 (AP) -- Liberator bombers of the Tenth United States Air Force scored probable hits on military establishments on Diamond Island, 140 miles southwest of Rangoon and about 725 miles southeast of Calcutta, in a raid last Tuesday, it was officially announced today.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 3 -- Octave Blake, president of the Cornell-Dubilier Electric Corporation and its subsidiary, the Condenser Corporation of America, with 1,200 employes here, replied today to charges of representatives of the American Federation of Labor regarding conditions at the plant.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Brig. Gen. Norman Thomas Kirk to become Surgeon General of the Army, with the rank of major general.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 3 -Parisians are very anxious, according to private reports received here today, because several hundred bakeries have closed their doors for lack of flour. They fear the worst, because it is no secret that the period between the last bushel of the old crop and the first bushel of the new will be very critical.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., May 3 (AP) -- With Johnny Schmitz and Vern Olsen, former Cub pitchers, each yielding only one hit, the Great Lakes Naval Training Station won its third straight game today by beating the world champion Cardinals, 5 to 2, before 10,000 recruits.
The German Monday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Representatives of the government will make clear within twenty-four hours that the government has made no pledge to sign an agreement and will not negotiate a contract with the United Mine Workers of America, it was reported authoritatively tonight.

The award for the best drama of the year to Thornton Wilder, now a major in the Army Air Forces, marks the third Pulitzer prize to be won by the author of "The Skin of Our Teeth." Previous awards were for his novel "The Bridge of San Luis Rey," published in 1928, and for his play "Our Town," which was produced just a decade later.

Your dispatches quote spokesmen for organized labor as demanding that the President and his bureau heads "immediately put into effect * * * a vigorous price policy * * * that the cost of living be rolled back to May, 1942." And "the stubborn refusal to put ceilings on livestock continues to stand in the way of effective price control of meat."

The trustees of Columbia University announced yesterday that the Pulitzer Prize for the best original American play of 1942 had been awarded to "The Skin of Our Teeth," by Thornton Wilder, and that the prize for a distinguished novel had gone to "Dragon's Teeth," by Upton Sinclair. The awards were made by the trustees on the recommendation of the advisory board of the Graduate School of Journalism.

The mystery of the origin of machine-gun bullets that struck three houses in Brooklyn at 12:10 P.M. on Sunday was solved yesterday when the Eastern Defense Command and the First Army issued the following announcement:

NORTHERN TUNISIA FRONT, May 1 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Split-second timing and the ability to lie motionless in feigned death for twenty minutes saved the life of a British major the night German tanks broke through at Djebel Jaffa just before the Allied offensive started.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., May 3 -- Despite the fact that only a sprinkling of miners returned to work this morning, John J. Forbes, temporary czar of the anthracite industry, declared today that full-scale production of hard coal would be resumed tomorrow at every colliery.

The Robert L. Hague Post of the American Legion yesterday presented the American Legion Medal for outstanding heroism to Captain Edward V. Peters, master of an Esso tanker, in a ceremony at the Maritime Exchange, 80 Broad Street. Rear Admiral Stanley V. Parker, U.S.C.G., captain of the Port of New York, made the presentation.
NEW DELHI, India, May 3 (AP) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 3 -- American troops captured Mateur, the vital junction in Northern Tunisia, today. Tonight they were threatening the Bizerte area, only nineteen miles away, as well as the northern flank of the whole German position around Tunis.
The midtown section of Manhattan received the bulk of the contracts for commercial quarters reported yesterday by brokers.

BUFFALO, May 3 -- To meet what was described as "the most important problem facing American medicine today" -- the adjustment of medical practice to the demands of a rapidly changing world -- the house of delegates of the Medical Society of the State of New York voted unanimously today to appoint a committee to work out a long-range plan for "providing medical care for all, under the leadership of the medical profession."

James D. Walsh, who until midnight Sunday was a New York City detective and vice president of the Detective Endowment Association, became yesterday an assistant to United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa. Mr. Walsh is 33 years old and had been in the Police Department since April 1, 1937.

About a year ago this writer issued a statement to the press, the kernel of which was that for the duration of the war there should be as real "equality of sacrifice" as possible. The law requires that men be drafted for service in our armed forces, and certain regulations determine the order in which men shall be conscripted after they have registered.
LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

HALF the fun of the Pulitzer Prize awards is the opportunity they provide for argument. This year there will be fights all over the lot because of the fiction award, which has gone to Upton Sinclair for his third installment of the Lanny Budd series, "Dragon's Teeth." There will be fewer people to quarrel with the choice for biography, Samuel Eliot Morison's "Admiral of the Ocean Sea: A Life of Christopher Columbus."

ALBANY, May 3 (AP) -- Approximately $20,000 in State funds has been alotted to finance the child-care activities of twenty-eight New York City settlement houses, an official of the War Council reported today, but no other community has yet asked for State aid.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- President Roosevelt signed three bills, one authorizing certain agreements with Panama, one authorizing a toll bridge at Astoria, Ore., and one suspending the annual assessment work on mining claims.

The Second War Loan Drive has brought in an estimated $17,000,000,000 throughout the nation, of which the Second Federal Reserve District, with Manhattan as the spearhead, accounted for nearly $7,000,000,000. Of the national total $12,000,000,000 came from investors other than commercial banks.

LONDON, May 3 (AP) -- The Royal Air Force made two extensive sweeps over Northern France and the Netherlands today at a cost of eleven bombers and two fighters missing, the heaviest loss in recent daylight raids.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Dividing six to three, the Supreme Court today ruled that the Jersey Central Power and Light Company must come within jurisdiction of the Federal Power Commission as a public utility, with the commission entitled to control acquisition of Jersey Central securities by the New Jersey Power and Light Company.

Summer Millinery Week was opened at the luncheon hour yesterday in the Sert Room at the Waldorf by Saks Fifth Avenue. In the course of the week some of New York's leading authorities will present their trends for the coming months. It is certain that there will be among them, as was the case yesterday, forerunners of Fall.
Yesterday was a day of "firsts" for the new Women's Military Services Club in the former White-law Reid mansion at 451 Madison Avenue. The formal opening was last Friday.

The proxy statement for the annual meeting of stockholders of General Motors Corporation, to be held on May 25 at Wilmington, Del., mailed to stockholders over the week-end, presents amendments to the bonus plan which are to be voted on at the meeting.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The novel praise of the Western Allies in the Soviet press yesterday, supplementing the fuller recognition of their cooperation given in Premier Joseph Stalin's May Day order of the day, was regarded here today as indicating a new military solidarity with the West in a common struggle against Adolf Hitler.

Museums of natural science will have an important role in post-war education, A. Perry Osborn, acting president of the American Museum of Natural History predicted in the institution's seventy-fourth annual report, published yesterday.

"Lilac Garden," Antony Tudor's ballet of Edwardian frustration, was welcomed back last night into the repertory of the Ballet Theatre at the Metropolitan Opera House, both for its own sake and for the sake of its four-star cast, which had Alicia Markova, Nora Kaye, Hugh Laing and Mr. Tudor in its central roles.

The Trade Book Clinic of the American Institute of Graphic Arts has named five books for its May choices of new titles "coordinating purposeful design with sound execution." The selections are "The Art of Murder," by William Roughead (Sherilian House); "Flower Encyclopedia," by Albert E. Wilkinson (Garden City Publishing Company); "Gideon Planish," by Sinclair Lewis (Random House); "Let's Make More Things," by Harry Zarchy (Knopf), and "Tunis Expedition," by Darryl F. Zanuck (Random House).
WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The House on R Street, the scene of entertainments being investigated by a House committee inquiring into war contract fees, came back into the news today.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 4 (U.P.) The Russian Monday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

A week late, because of cold weather, the annual two-day Narcissus show of the Horticultural Society of New York opened yesterday at the society's headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue, with more than 5,000 blossoms on view.

While to most city folk the planting of a victory garden is a novel form of back-breaking labor, to the 200 young "farmers" and "farmerettes" who gathered yesterday in the gardens of the New York Plant and Flower Guild, at York Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, it was merely routine and most of them did not have to bend far enough to hurt their backs.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, May 4 (AP) -- Three Allied pilots are missing as a result of the Japanese attack on Darwin Sunday, the Allied High Command reported today.

WITH THE ADVANCED UNITED STATES ARMY, in Northern Tunisia, May 3--Major Frank Hill of Hillside, N.J., protecting Allied bombers attacking Axis shipping off Cap Bon in the Gulf of Tunis, told of a sight he said he never would forget, a delayed dispatch from the front said Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- In a ruling clarifying the highest price line rule that will be made applicable to retailers of women's, girls' and children's outerwear for the coming Fall season, the Office of Price Administration held today that retailers who have received adjustments will be allowed to sell at their adjusted top price lines.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis will offer publicly today a new issue of 165,000 shares of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., common stock, priced at $26 a share.
NEW DELHI, India, May 3 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

A German-selected commission, reputed to have been drawn from twelve countries -- all but one conquered or dominated by the Axis -- was reported by the Berlin radio yesterday to have charged that Polish officers were killed by the Russians near Smolensk in March and April of 1940, more than a year before Germany invaded Russia.

CHUNGKING, China, May 3 (U.P.) -- The Japanese are using parachute troops in the battle for the Taihang Mountains on the Honan-Shansi border in an attempt to smash stiffening Chinese resistance there.

Dedication ceremonies for the new $2,300,000 James Fenimore Cooper Junior High School at East 119th Street and Fifth Avenue were held yesterday even though most of the scheduled speakers failed to appear.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended April 28, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Increases of $1,177,000,000 in holdings of Treasury certificates of indebtedness; $176,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, and $2,050,000,000 in United States government deposits, and decreases of $215,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $155,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 3 -- The main plant of the Air Reduction Sales Company at 125 Monitor Street, manufacturer of oxy-acetylene equipment, engaged in fulltime war production, suspended operations today as the result of a wildcat strike of 1,200 employes.

LONDON, May 3 (Reuter) -- The Swedish radio reported tonight that the German naval attache in Stockholm visited the Commander in Chief of the Swedish Navy today to convey the deep regret of the German Navy at the less of the Swedish submarine Ulven.

PARAMARIBO, Surinam, May 3 (AP) -- United States Army Headquarters here announced today that searchers who had spent two weeks in the jungle hunting for survivors of the bomber crash from which Lieutenant Tommy Harmon escaped had returned without success.

LONDON, May 3 -- The epic story of the work being done by some 25,000 officers and men aboard British mine-sweepers -- those little ships of 200 or 300 tons that clear sea lanes in coastal waters both here and abroad for warships and merchantmen, enabling them to reach port safely -- is told in an illustrated booklet issued today by the Ministry of Information.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- A portable hand-generator radio transmitter with an antenna that can be held aloft from a life raft by a box kite has been developed by the Army Air Forces as a means of speeding rescue for fliers cast adrift in the open sea after crash landings.

LONDON, May 3 (U.P.) -- Premier Pieter S. Gerbrandy of the Netherlands urged all Netherlanders today to resist the attempt of the German occupation authorities to intern some 400,000 former members of the army.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 3 -Colonel Athenas Panteff, former chief of the Bulgarian State Police, was shot and killed while he was entering his house in the center of Sofia late last night, it was disclosed here today. Death was instantaneous.

While the country's coal miners were returning to the pits yesterday and Harold L. Ickes, Fuel Administrator, was setting up the machinery for government operation of the mines John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers were awaiting Mr. Ickes's initiative for negotiations for a new contract between the union and the government.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. thanked today the newspapers and others for their support of the $13,000,000,000 Second War Loan drive which he said was oversubscribed by more than $4,000,000,000.

Under very light trading, prices of cotton futures remained yesterday within a range of 3 to 5 points and closed unchanged to 4 points higher than Saturday's final quotations, at the session's peak levels. Principal buying support was supplied by the trade, covering short positions.

After two weeks of grueling fighting, American troops of the Second Army Corps have won their greatest victory in North Africa so far. They have captured Mateur, key junction point of railroad and highway communications, which is only eighteen miles from Bizerte and only thirty-four miles from Tunis.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 3 -- The Berlin correspondent of The Stockholm Tidningen cabled today that Russia would receive a steady stream of war materiel from the United States via Alaska and the Arctic Ocean during the Summer along a route free of German submarines and planes.

Seventy-five dehydrated foods were displayed yesterday, at the tasting of the Wine and Food Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The exhibit included such interesting items as a dried sauce for chili con carne, powdered mashed potatoes, compressed meat and compressed cranberries, and a concentated mix for bean and bacon soup.

In the season's conventional round of concert hall and opera house one is apt to forget how big a city New York is and how varied are its musical resources. In the churches of the city performances of rare quality often take place, mostly of religious music.

Events of the last week have convinced political leaders and observers that friends of Governor Thomas E. Dewey are working, with his knowledge, to prevent an early foreclosure of the Republican Presidential nomination for 1944 so that Mr. Dewey himself can be "drafted" if the prospects of victory look good.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 3 -- Viktor Lutze, Chief of Staff of the Nazi Storm Troopers, died in Potsdam last night as the result of injuries suffered in an automobile accident Saturday. He was 52 years old and ranked as one of the militant leaders in the National Socialist Storm Troopers, with whom he became identified in 1922.

STOCKHOLM, May 3 (U.P.) -Gunder Haegg, the flying fireman who cracked nine world running records last Summer, started training today for his expected visit to the United States and a series of meetings with America's stars.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 3 (AP) -- A special communique:

A group headed by Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $4,000,000 School District of Philadelphia, Pa., 1 1/2 per cent refunding bonds due $250,000 annually from May 1, 1944 to 1959. The bonds are priced to yield from 0.50 per cent to 1.55 per cent, according to maturity.

Admiral Georges Robert, High Commissioner of Martinique, disclosed last night that he had sent a note to the State Department protesting the United States' action in breaking off relations with Martinique. He urged that the department publish the text of his note.

The Fall wholesale season in women's apparel reached the active stage here yesterday with the arrival of many buyers representing stores in all parts of the country. A progressive increase in buyers' arrivals is expected, with the influx due to reach an early peak within the next two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 3 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision dismissing an "informers'" suit seeking $40,000,000 damages and penalties from the Bausch Lomb Optical Company of New York and Carl Zeiss, Inc., a New York subsidiary of a German concern, on the ground that the United States had been defrauded in the purchase of military optical instruments.

JERSEY CITY, May 3 (AP) -- Toronto evened its four-game series with Jersey City at two apiece today by defeating the Little Giants, 5 to 3, in fifteen innings, and regained first place over the idle Newark Bears.

A German communique broadcast yesterday by the Berlin radio asserted that during April the German Navy, in operations against British and American sea communications, had sunk sixty-three merchant ships totaling 423,000 gross tons.

Once more the Pulitzer prizes have been bestowed. Professor Morison's "Admiral of the Ocean Sea" is judged the best biography of last year. That distinction is amply deserved. Professor Morison has followed closely the track of Columbus and has shown himself as good a sailor as he is accomplished a historian.

Renewed heavy Japanese raids on Port Darwin have increased Australia's fear of invasion. But they are only one manifestation of Japan's widening activity in the Southwest Pacific. It now seems apparent that during recent months Japan has been changing the basis of her oceanic and island strategy.

BOSTON, May 3 -- Limited quantities of shoes for immediate delivery have been purchased here by procurement officers of the Treasury Department, acting for the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation in Washington, which is headed by former Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were unchanged from those of the corresponding week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a sales gain of 18 per cent over 1942.

PUEBLA, Mexico, May 3 -- Dr. Harlow Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, this evening announced the discovery of 75,000 new galaxies -- that is, cosmic units consisting of an average of more than 1,000,000,000 suns each.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 3 (U.P.) -Emphatic approval of the Federal Government's intervention in the coal crisis was heard in all quarters today, with such typical expressions as "It's about time" and "Now we really are cooking with gas."

If President Roosevelt can roll back prices of food and other goods to May, 1942 levels before contracts covering 250,000 shipyard workers on the Atlantic seaboard expire on June 23, the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, will forego demands for a general wage increase in a proposed new contract, John Green, president of the union, indicated yesterday.
PITTSBURGH, May 3 -- Slowly, and in some instances with haggling reluctance, the bituminous coal miners in this area began to follow the instructions of President Roosevelt and return to their jobs.

The action of the Office of Price Administration removing all dried or dehydrated soups from the rationing list will result in an almost immediate return to the booming sales volume which the industry enjoyed before the rationing restrictions were imposed, industry spokesmen asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- General wage increases ranging from 3 1/2 cents to 5 1/2 cents an hour have been unanimously granted by the War Labor Board to 3,700 employes of six sugar refining plants in New York and Massachusetts.

The seven-story store and apartment house on a plot 26.2 by 144.7 at 58 East First Street has been sold by the Manhattan Savings Bank to the 58 East First Street Realty Corporation. This structure contains 120 rooms and is assessed for $77,000.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Apparently taking advantage of improved weather, Army fliers have resumed their pounding of Japanese bases in the Aleutians, and marked the first of the month with thirteen attacks against Kiska and additional raids on two target areas of Attu Island, a Navy communique announced today.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 3 -The Greenwich Tuberculosis Association has published a 60-page booklet entitled "What's More, We Like It," a compendium of culinary information, recipes contributed by prominent citizens, and tips on wartime menus.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 4 (U.P.) -- Russian heavy guns opened up against the German Kuban River bridgehead yesterday.

The New York Junior League, 221 East Seventy-first Street, opened yesterday, with a luncheon preview, an exhibition entitled Contemporary American Masters. It opens to the public today, to continue through May 15 -- admission 50 cents in War Savings Stamps.
ST. LOUIS, May 3 (AP) -- That loud noise, brother, wasn't the noon whistle -- just Manager Billy Southworth's sigh on hearing Mort Cooper was not flirting with immediate surgery.

Varied divertissements have been planned for the cocktail party in behalf of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League of the United States to be held on Thursday at the Monte Carlo. In addition to a program by professional entertainers there will be an auction of hats and accessories donated for the occasion by well-known designers and shops.

LONDON, May 3 -- The stock markets here started the week on a cheerful note, and although business generally remained quiet, some activity was seen in home railway securities owing to fresh buying attracted by the current yields of junior stocks.

LONDON, May 3 (Reuter) -The Polish Minister of Social Welfare, Jan Stanczyk, said today that to avoid "any present or future misunderstanding" in the Russian-Polish relations, the U.S.S.R. should free 800,000 to 900,000 Poles who are at present in Russia "against their own and their government's will."

A new plan of recapitalization of the General Gas and Electric Corporation, calling for the divestment of assets, simplification of corporate structure and a more equitable distribution of voting power, was announced yesterday by the trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, which controls General Gas.

Federal and city authorities pressed their campaign yesterday against alleged violators of Office of Price Administration regulations. Severe penalties were imposed in different actions, each the first of its kind. Meanwhile the City Markets Department continued the sale of the 600,000 pounds of California potatoes rounded up by the department last week as California shipped 119 carloads of its new crop.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- In a complete change of front, the Supreme Court reversed itself today and held, by a vote of 5 to 4, that cities could not pass ordinances compelling members of Jehovah's Witnesses to pay a license fee for the distribution of religious literature.
LONDON, May 3 -- Fighting French circles here were awaiting a reply to the note cabled to General Giraud yesterday by General de Gaulle.

A special procurement program involving seasonal types of textiles and clothing for distribution to rehabilitated foreign populations was concluded here yesterday by lend-lease buyers of the Treasury Department, according to local wholesalers.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- The long-pending Connally bill, designed to give the President expanded powers in the seizure of strike-bound plants and mines, underwent Senate scrutiny today and almost immediately, as crowds watched from the galleries, was subjected to a tentative complete rewriting on the floor.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- In a peace move to break the bottlenecks in critical materials and equipment which have thrown the synthetic rubber, aviation gasoline and destroyer escort-ship production programs into conflicts, delays and shortages, principals in the long-waging controversy will go together to the sources of supply and seek to work out their differences cooperatively, plant by plant.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries, excluding Roxy Theatre, Inc., had a consolidated net profit of $10,609,784 for the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 26, 1942, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

Several dinner parties will be given tomorrow night before the entertainment in the ballroom of the Colony Club to aid the Girls Service League. The program will comprise monologues by Cornelia Otis Skinner, and Miss Emily Kimbrough; and violin selections by Miss Frances Magnes, who will be accompanied by Artur Balsam.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Virtually all tankcar shipments of heating oil from the Midwest to east coast points were placed under a temporary ban today by Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator for War. The step was taken to facilitate oil transportation and storage of petroleum products for the armed forces.

With all classifications showing substantial gains, advertising linage of eight New York newspapers rose 21.4 per cent last month over the like 1942 period, the year's best gain, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures.

Representative Martin Dies's taste in miscellaneous reading probably does not run toward books like Horace M. Kallen's monumental study of esthetics and life, "Art and Freedom." But if the thing has happened, or should happen, it is not difficult to guess Mr. Dies's response to Dr. Kallen's remarks on the late Work Projects Administration; especially the four celebrated arts projects -- art, writing, theatre and music.

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Instructions to all Federal managers of coal mines to operate their stores and commissaries in strict compliance with Federal price regulations were issued today by Solid Fuels Administrator Ickes. At the same time Mr. Ickes called on the Office of Price Administration to submit to him any evidence of violations of price regulations which the OPA may uncover during the period the mines are under Federal control.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 3 -- The Naval Academy baseball team capitalized on three hits and two errors today to defeat the Dartmouth nine, 6 to 2.

MATEUR, Tunisia, May 3 -American reconnaissance troops passed through Mateur today and fanned out to the east and north, one group taking a road along the west side of Lake Achkel. They could hear the smash of American bombs on Bizerte.

The Town Hall Endowment Series Award for 1943 has been given to Emanuel Vardi, viola, and Roland Gundry, violin, according to an announcement yesterday by Kenneth Klein, director of the Town Hall concert department.

The vote of the Supreme Court's newest member, Justice Rutledge, was decisive in two opinions rendered yesterday, one of which reversed a position taken last June, and both of which, taken together, reaffirm the right of Jehovah's Witnesses to agitate for their unusual creed.

On the basis of national figures, still incomplete, about $17,000,000,000 was raised in the Second War Loan drive just ended, of which an estimated $12,000,000,000 came from investors other than commercial banks. Yesterday the New York War Finance Committee provided some preliminary figures showing that $5,465,000,000 was raised in the Second Federal Reserve District, or about 45 per cent of the national total for this category.

In his radio address on Sunday night the President spoke to the country, and particularly to the striking coal miners, with that clearness and sympathy which distinguish his best utterances. His understanding was accompanied by a firmness of language that was highly reassuring.
"There are more fishermen out on our streams this year than we expected," asserted Commissioner Harry M. Armstrong in discussing some of the features of the early season in New Jersey.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 3 (AP) -- A.G. Tarn, whose son-in-law, Johnny Longden, rode Count Fleet to victory in the Kentucky Derby Saturday, did a little celebrating today by saddling Count d'Or, winner of the featured Valley Falls Purse at Narragansett Park.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Buying by houses with Eastern and Northwestern connections caused a sharp advance in rye futures today on the board of trade. Shorts covered freely on the way up, and closing sales were about the top with gains of 1 1/8 to 1 1/4 cents a bushel.
