To help salvage the art and scientific heritage of Europe from the destructiveness of war, American art scholars and museum officials have organized a committee through which they hope to place at the disposal of the Federal government the art scholarship of the country.

Braving early afternoon showers which sent them scurrying for shelter under the stands, 15,479 fans yesterday ushered in the last week of Jamaica's Spring meeting, which opened the racing season in New York on April 8.

The forces opposing the leadership of Tammany Leader Michael J. Kennedy Jr. will set up headquarters at the Murray Hill Hotel today under the name of the Committee to Reorganize the Democratic Party of New York County. Announcement to this effect was made yesterday by State Senator James G. Donovan of the Sixteenth district, who will be campaign manager for the committee.
WASHINGTON, May 3 (U.P.) -The War Production Board is expected to issue a new clothing order this week calling for slimmer feminine silhouettes, "cleaner lines" and elimination of more frills.

With the unobtainability of a maid turning many a city household into a scene of confusion and despair in spite of a rising pay scale, spokesmen for domestic workers described yesterday the essentials of a job that the average domestic might find attractive.

While Allied armies drive ahead in Tunisia another battle is in progress off the shores. It is being fought night and day in three dimensions: sky, sea and under water. It has turned the Strait of Sicily into a "death run".

LONDON, May 3 (U.P.) -- British light Mosquito bombers attacked last evening important railway workshops at Thionville, the center of the French Lorraine iron ore area incorporated by the Nazis into the Reich, and Russian bombers were believed to have made another attack on East Prussia.
CHUNGKING, China, May 3 (U.P.) -- A communique:

ALGIERS, May 3--General Henri Honore Giraud has asked General Charles de Gaulle to meet him in North Africa as soon after May 5 as he can conveniently arrive, it was announced tonight on behalf of the French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 3 -- In view of the coal crisis, Roane Waring, national commander of the American Legion, authorized today Maurice F. Devine, chairman of the national legislative committee, to put all the pressure which the legion could mobilize behind the passage of the Wadsworth-Austin national war service bill pending in Congress to draft civilians for wartime employment.

LONDON, May 4 -- The unmistakable eyebrows of John L. Lewis have been a familiar adornment in the British press the last few days and all papers have devoted much more space and emphasis to the threat of a great coal strike than they usually give to purely domestic American affairs.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 3 -- The "democratic union" to weld into a single unit all the parties and groups that will oppose the government-sponsored candidates in next September's Presidential election came virtually into being today.

In bygone days, fans leaving the Stadium often summed up a Yankee victory with a common expression: "What power!" But times have changed and even the proud followers of the McCarthymen are grateful for small favors, such as the one presented the Yanks by the Red Sox yesterday as the New Yorkers eked out a 4-3 decision behind Spud Chandler.
The threat of another stoppage in the coal industry loomed yesterday as a result of developments in Washington, upon which John L. Lewis, head of the United Mine Workers, maintained a grim silence.

Disagreeing with spokesmen for domestic workers who declare that maids prefer to take other work if their conditions are not met in homes, Miss Jessie M. Brinkley, legislative chairman of the New York Household Placement Association, an association of domestic employment agencies, said yesterday that they are taking war jobs primarily out of a spirit of patriotism.

PATERSON, N.J., May 4 -- A strike of 300 magnesium foundry workers and coremakers in the Fairlawn plant of the Wright Aeronautical Company was disclosed tonight in a joint statement by the company and Local 669 of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.

The Knickerbocker Greys held their last drill of the season at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-seventh and Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The program included presentation of a station wagon to the Red Cross in the name of the boys.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Maximum dollars-and-cents price ceilings, established on a "community basis," will be announced on twenty to thirty grocery products in 150 communities Sunday, the Office of Price Administration said today. The ceilings, fixing the highest prices at which any of the products listed may be sold in the particular community, will go into effect Monday.
LONDON, May 5 -- Plans for the revival of economic relations between Madagascar and the Allied Nations, insuring that strategic island's maximum participation in the war effort, were announced today.

With Tim Fiori scoring his fourth victory in as many starts and his first shutout for the season, St. John's defeated Fordham, 3 -- 0, at Dexter Park yesterday to displace the Ram nine in second place behind N.Y.U. in the Metropolitan Conference.

Encouraged by the public response to its two-day Narcissus Show, the Horticultural Society closed the exhibition at 10 P.M. last night with the announcement that it would hold a special one-day tulip show at its headquarters, 598 Madison Avenue, on May 19. The show will be free to the public.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 5 (U.P.) -- United States Flying Fortresses attacked German industrial targets at Antwerp late yesterday and, two minutes after the first bombs hit, funnels of flame and smoke leaped 2,000 feet above the Belgian city.
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 4 -- Waves, Marines and Spars joined today in graduating exercises at the Naval Reserve midshipmen schools in this city and Mount Holyoke.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 4 -- The growing military might of the United States is being played up all over the Middle East. It is the first time many in the Arab world have heard of American strength. This publicity, coupled with knowledge of Great Britain's forces, about which Moslems have reason to be well-informed, has turned against Adolf Hitler one of his chief propaganda weapons, power.

As Mayor La Guardia passed the half-way mark in his sale of twenty carloads of new California potatoes yesterday, the Office of Price Administration for this district disclosed that it had "invited" the Mayor's suppliers to appear to give the OPA data on wholesale prices.

PITTSBURGH, May 4 (AP) -- Bishop Adna Wright Leonard of the Methodist Church died in the airplane crash in which Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews was killed in a flight to Iceland, the Bishop's son, A.W. Leonard Jr., said he was notified tonight by the War Department.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 4 (U.P.) -- Spreading disaffection among German troops in Tunisia has resulted in a headquarters threat of reprisals against relatives of soldiers who surrender "without due cause" and against the men themselves after the war, it was disclosed today in a captured Nazi order.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director, rang down the curtain today on the Truman committee's investigation of one of Washington's priorities squabbles. He won applause from a packed hearing room.

JOHN C. KNOX, senior United States district judge of the Southern District of New York, has rendered distinguished public service to his country and the law for twenty-five years upon the bench. Before that he was an able United States prosecuting attorney. Out of this experience comes a book, "Order in the Court,"* which conforms neatly and exactly to all the preconceived patterns a reader might expect of such a book.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Senate began to edge away from drastic anti-strike legislation today as Senator Barkley, the majority leader, and others urged that the Connally bill and its many proposed amendments be sent back to the Judiciary Committee for indefinite "study."

Harry M. Kohn, 51 years old, of Harry 256 Villa Avenue, Cedarhurst, L.I., who formerly conducted a private detective agency at 286 Fifth Avenue, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of violating a law that has been on the statute books for sixty-two years, but, the court believes, never had been used before.

The housewife who can't buy all she wants for her family's three meals a day can find a partial explanation in the current report of Lend-Lease Administrator Stettinius. Our lend-lease food exports for the first quarter of this year included 437,000,000 pounds of meat, 600,500,000 pounds of milk products, 261,300,000 pounds of dried eggs and 64,600,000 pounds of dried fruits.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. "Next of Kin," a British topical drama, which is released here through Universal, will be the new attraction at the Rialto. Featured in the production are Nova Pilbeam, Basil Sidney and Phyllis Stanley.

TRENTON, May 4 (AP) -- A Mercer County taxpayer applied to the State Supreme Court today for a writ to review the constitutionality of the State's 1941 school bus law that requires Boards of Education to provide transportation for children attending parochial and other privately operated non-profit schools if free transportation is provided for public school children.
LONDON, May 4 -- Business on the stock markets here was small today, but the tone in all sections remained firm. Diamond shares staged a good recovery from recent profit-tatting.

The Branscombe Choral presented a program of much musical interest at its ninth annual Spring concert last night at Town Hall before a large audience. Opening with numbers by Gallus, Sweelinck, Josquin Des Pres and Morley, the chorus continued with works by Granville Bantock, Cyril Jenkins, Elinor Warren, Roy Spaulding Stoughton, David Stanley Smith, Nin, Debussy, Ravel, Young-Breck and Gaul.
LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Proposals submitted by Israel Feinberg, spokesman for the Joint Board of Cloak, Suit, Skirt and Reefer Makers Union, seeking wage readjustments and better working conditions in the renewal of a contract with the Infants and Childrens Coat Association, Inc., were rejected yesterday by Charles Baker, executive director of the association.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 4 -- About Monday or Tuesday the United States troops at the front will learn from the weekly of Stars and Stripes that a coal strike has occurred at home. For the moment, therefore, it is impossible to gauge the reaction of men fighting, dying and capturing ground to the fact that trade union members at home left their jobs.

Five specific changes in the proposed amendment No. 5 to MPR 287, to govern Fall pricing of women's and children's outer apparel, have been suggested in a brief submitted to the OPA by the National Coat and Suit Recovery Board through its legal and legislative committee, it was made known yesterday by Joseph L. Dubow, chairman of the committee and executive director of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association.

ELKTON, Md., May 4 (AP) -- A shattering explosion, followed by fire among buildings of the Triumph Explosives, Inc., caused the death of at least nine men and six women workers today with scores injured and indications that the toll of lives would mount with investigation.

WASHINGTON, May 4 (U.P.) -- John P. Monroe, cheerful master of the capital's mystery house on R Street, subject of an inquiry by a House war contracts subcommittee, asserted today he was "Washington's most investigated man."
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 4 (U.P.) -- President Isaias Medina Angarita has formed a new Cabinet, the newspaper Tiempo disclosed tonight. The Ministers are listed as follows:

For its willingness to recognize the need of reform in medical practice the Medical Society of the State of New York deserves praise. Out of its promised deliberations some good will undoubtedly flow, even though some of the addresses delivered before its House of Delegates raise doubts.

LONDON, May 4 -- A plebiscite conducted in the provinces of Eastern Poland soon after the occupation of them by the Red Army during the German invasion of the western half in 1939 is offered as moral justification for inclusion of this territory in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, May 4--Secretary Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator, today ordered all coal mines in his custody since Saturday to go on a six-day work-week, denied that he had made any agreement whatever with John L. Lewis to write a contract with the United Mine Workers and declared that there was no way out of the coal controversy, if such meant that the War Labor Board necessarily would be "by-passed."

CAMP PICKETT, Va., May 4 -- They were not very impressive as they charged down the bayonet course under the hot Virginia sun. They were just a handful of soldiers sticking bayonets into straw dummies. Yet the fact that these particular men had guns in their hands was significant, for the men were symbolic of salvaged divisions for the United States Army.

Dean Hawkes of Columbia was one of those rare men who impress themselves indelibly upon the minds and hearts of undergraduates and have a warm place in the memory of every graduate. Professor of Mathematics for ten years, he had been dean since 1918.
Mayor La Guardia presented an ambulance yesterday to the Army on behalf of students of the New York School of Printing in a ceremony in front of the General Post-office Building on Eighth Avenue.
The vanishing trolley is about to come back into its own with a woman motorman as its latest modern improvement -- if Board of Transportation plans, now in the experimental stage, work out.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- A Senate appropriations subcommittee today approved $28,000,000 for construction of a barge canal across Florida. Proponents had asked for a grant of $44,000,000.

The need for maintaining a normal home front and the role of social welfare and health agencies toward that end were stressed at the opening dinner of the Brooklyn Committee for the Greater New York Fund's sixth annual campaign at the Hotel Bossert last night.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Mutual action by peace loving nations against an aggressor seeking to impose by violence his will upon any one of them was urged today by Sir Norman Angell as the price not only of peace but of survival in a world certain otherwise to be "burned up every decade or two in ever more destructive wars."
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Sixty-three officers of the Army have been nominated by President Roosevelt for temporary promotions, all in the general officer class, the War Department announced today.

A review of all outstanding B and C gasoline ration books is being ordered by the Office of Price Administration to determine if holders are still eligible and whether the need all the gasoline allowed them, it was learned yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 4 -- Joan Crawford, who has been under contract to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer since 1925, has received a six-months' leave of absence to do a picture for another company. The leave results from a disagreement over the role assigned her in the forthcoming "Cry 'Havoc,'" which would have been her third successive war picture.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Senate received today a bill sponsored by Senator Bankhead of Alabama which would provide that at least half of a $25,000,000 to $30,000,000 fund be expended for advertising in weekly, semi-weekly, tri-weekly and monthly newspapers in small town and rural areas.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- When Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government in exile, arrives in Washington next week on the invitation of President Roosevelt, he will discuss with Mr. Roosevelt and other officials here the future organization of Central and Eastern Europe and the as yet undetermined relations between Russia and her European neighbors, it was learned authoritatively here.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Representative Hamilton Fish, Republican, of New York, answering criticism voiced by a New York supporter of Wendell L. Willkie, asserted today that a poll of Indiana Republican precinct committeemen, made by The Fort Wayne News-Sentinel, "proves conclusively that it would be political suicide for the party to nominate him (Willkie) again for President."

SECOND UNITED STATES CORPS HEADQUARTERS, Tunisia, May 3 (Delayed) -- Many important enemy airfields have been taken in the new American breakthrough. Another great airdrome at Sidi Ahmed, outside Bizerte, is now commanded by American artillery that was hauled forward over treacherous, dangerous roads today.

The net profit of Standard Brands, Inc., for the first quarter of 1943 rose nearly $1,000,000, or 8 cents a share, above that a year before, James S. Adams, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday. It was an open question, however, he said, whether this advantage would be maintained in future months, owing to the uncertainties in wartime operations.

OTTAWA, May 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canadians experienced their first "meatless Tuesday" today and dined in restaurants on fish, fowl, eggs, macaroni and other products of their own country. The mainstay of most menus was vegetables.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Forand-Robrtson bill would provide for income tax collections as follows:

ST. LOUIS, May 4 (AP) -- The Tigers chased veteran southpaw Al Hollingsworth to the showers in less than two innings today, scoring four runs in the meantime, then hung on for dear life to eke out a 4-to-3 triumph over the Browns.

Dr. Adna Wright Leonard, Methodist Bishop of Washington, D.C., left the United States last month for England, on the first lap of an inspection trip that was to have included Iceland, North Africa, India and China.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY AIR FORCES, in the South Pacific, April 21 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant Lou Zamperini, who abandoned a great track career to become an Army Air Force bombardier, today shared the credit for saving the lives of two seriously wounded fliers in what he described as the toughest race of his life.

LONDON, May 4 -- Reiterating his complaints over the indefinite postponement of his proposed trip to North Africa for consultations with General Henri Honore Giraud, General Charles de Gaulle declared tonight that he was prepared to proceed immediately to Algiers with a Fighting French delegation for meetings looking toward the solution of the problems standing in the way of complete harmony among Frenchmen.

LONDON, May 4 -- Premier-General Wladyslaw Sikorski, in a broadcast to Poland tonight commemorating Poland's national day, said that one of the main guiding principles of Polish policy had always been, and would continue to be, to secure friendly relations with Russia, but he added that "there are limits to concessions beyond which no Pole would go."

Reconstruction of a free international economic system after the war is both desirable and possible, Redvers Opie, economic adviser to the British Embassy, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Associated Printing Salesmen in the Hotel Piccadilly.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The expanding United States forces in the South Pacific have occupied the Russell Islands northwest of Gaudalcanal, thus providing strategic bases less than 100 miles from the nearest Japanese positions, the Navy Department disclosed today.

If an end can be put to factional disputes, the united efforts of all groups will solve the many problems causing danger to the food supply, Mrs. Ralph C. Lasbury Jr., former member of the Connecticut State Defense Council and director of women's activities for that State, declared yesterday.
The percentage of city realty taxes collected for the current fiscal year thus far has set a new record, City Treasurer Almerindo Portfolio reported yesterday.

OTTAWA, May 4 -- Although there have been fractional increases in the cost of such foods as meat, potatoes, cheese and oranges the operation of the price control ceiling in Canada has been so effective that the cost of living index during March advanced only .4 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 -- Sale of the United Gas Improvement Company's controlling interest in the Connecticut Railway and Lighting Company to Charles Ulrick Bay of Bridgeport, Conn., for $1,815,000 was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CHICAGO, May 4 -- The 1942 baseball and the Cardinals made their first 1943 appearances in Chicago simultaneously and with telling effect today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Joseph E. Davies is to leave tomorrow on a second "mission to Moscow" as a special representative of President Roosevelt in conversations with Premier Joseph Stalin. This was learned definitely today on authority that is not open to question, although no official announcement or comment was made at the White House.

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, Queens representative on the Board of Education, was succeeded yesterday by Dr. George H. Chatfield, the board's director of attendance, who was forced to retire from his $12,500 post to accept the Mayor's appointment.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- New records were set in naval aircraft and ship construction in April, and "peak production" was reached in both categories, Secretary Knox stated today at a press conference. Meanwhile, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, announced that in March several new "highs" were reached by the nation's war production machine.
CLEVELAND, May 4 (AP) -- Lanky Jim Bagby grabbed his third straight triumph for Cleveland with a steady five-hit, 2-to-1 decision today over the White Sox.
Brace yourself for the end of the base-hit drought. The "corrected" 1943 baseball, with a little "jackrabbit" added, is ready for distribution to the major league clubs, says The Associated Press.

A suggestion like the one dropped by the President the other day that the youth of America should be required, after the war, to give a year's service to their country must cause a very real fear to any thinking person. It was a suggestion too casually mentioned for such a large undertaking.

The physical records of youths who participated in physical training programs before entering the armed services were praised yesterday by officers of the Boys Clubs of America at "a wartime conference" of the organization in the Hotel Commodore.

The motion-picture industry was warned yesterday by Edward Kuykendall, president of the Motion Picture Theatre Owners of America, not to be blinded by the "dollar mark." Mr. Kuykendall spoke at the opening session of the fifty-third semi-annual meeting of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers at the Hotel Pennsylvania.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 4 -- The strike controversy in the coal industry focused attention on how such work stoppages can best be dealt with in war industries.

Men's clothing contractors here, who received approximately 75 per cent of the orders for 400,000 Army great coats released Monday and who expect to obtain a good share of the contracts for 1,800,000 regulation overcoats to be announced this week, asserted yesterday that this additional business would not interfere with their ability to meet civilian goods requirements.

NEW DELHI, India, May 4 (AP) -- Fighting planes carrying 1,000-pound bombs smashed two spans of the railroad bridge at Namkin, and Mitchell bombers dropped twenty-eight tons of explosives on railroad yards at Ywataung and Maymyo in the latest series of American forays over Burma, a United States communique announced today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 4 -- American forces are closing in on Bizerte from two directions today. The naval base is under heavy pounding from Allied bombers and within range of our artillery.

Faced with a problem of growing seriousness in obtaining licensed personnel for merchant vessels, the War Manpower Commission and the War Shipping Administration appealed yesterday to former marine engineers and deck officers now employed ashore to quit jobs non-essential to the war and to return to sea service.

Joseph (Joe Strawberry) Amoruso, 49 year's old, an ex-convict turned "gentleman farmer," was sentenced to a penitentiary term up to three years yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions on his previous guilty plea to a misdemeanor in the $1,000,000 yearly garment industry extortion racket of the Lepke-Gurrah gang ten years ago.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, May 5 (AP) -- The Allies have delivered their heaviest raid, made daringly by daylight, on Babo, Netherland New Guinea, the High Command announced today.

BALTIMORE, May 4 (AP) -- Convinced that the fifty-third Preakness Stakes on Saturday would produce only a contest for second money behind Count Fleet, Pimlico racing fans looked to the twenty-first running of the $10,000-added Pimlico Oaks tomorrow to provide the best contest of Maryland's biggest racing week.

When the American people understand the wisdom and the desirability of any change in the Constitution it does not take them long to effect such a change. This was proved by the repeal of prohibition. The Twenty-first Amendment, providing for such repeal, was submitted to the States by Congress on Feb. 21, 1933.

BUFFALO, May 4 -- A warning that we must streamline our civilian defense to meet a new type of air raid, in which "a moderate-sized squadron of planes can drop from 100,000 to 200,000 incendiary bombs over a city in an incredibly short time," was sounded today at the meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York by Colonel George Baehr, chief medical officer of the OCD, Washington.

The Masonic War Chest, with a goal of $250,000 in this State to be devoted to the interests of members in service and their sons, already has received $183,525, it was reported yesterday by William F. Strang, Grand Master of Masons of the State of New York, at the 162d annual meeting of the Grand Lodge in the Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

In one of the most daring moves seen at the meeting, Jockey Herb Lindberg sliced Beau of Mine through a narrow hole along the rail to capture the Old Koenig Handicap at Jamaica in a head-and-head finish with Jack S.L.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 4 -- King Boris of Bulgaria left Sofia, his capital, in haste on May Day on the advice of his government after anti-German demonstrations in a main boulevard, advices from Bulgaria said today.

The British admirals have given up negotiating with Admiral Rene-Emile Godefroy, the commander of the dozen French warships moored off Alexandria, Egypt. They have given up on the entreaties of Admiral Michelier, who virtually fulfills the function of Minister of Marine in North Africa.

Miss Anne Morgan, who has been president of the American Woman's Association since 1928, was named honorary president yesterday "in recognition of her valiant services as president" at a meeting and election at the association's headquarters at the Hotel Barclay.

Directors of the National Restaurant Association, Chicago, yesterday approved a national plan of cooperative institutional advertising for restaurants to inform the public of the "misconceptions that have arisen regarding the drastic cuts in food rationing to restaurants and other institutional users."

Increased use of soya bean flour as a means of conserving shortening in bakery products was predicted yesterday by speakers at the 1943 conference of the New York State Association of Manufacturing Retail Bakers in the Hotel New Yorker.

The radio industry of America is leading the way to victory over the Axis nations in the war and in the post-war period it will pave the way for a brighter and safer nation from the economic, communications and transportation point of view, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The future of Martinique and Guadeloupe, in the French Antilles, was left to the Navy today by the State Department.

The Monsanto Chemical Company and its American subsidiaries had a profit of $1,148,711 in the first three months of this year, after deductions for all charges including $3,380,300 for Federal income and excess profits taxes and $200,000 for possible increase in tax rates, the company reported yesterday.

OTTAWA, May 4 -- The Canadian Navy now has eight U-boats to its credit with many more "probables," Navy Minister Angus L. MacDonald revealed today in announcing a new list of decorations awarded to Canadian sailors.

Drafting of a new uniform contract for submission to operators of sixty-five shipyards on the Atlantic Coast was completed yesterday by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., in the Hotel New Yorker.

Eugene Loring's stunning little ballet "Billy the Kid," set to Aaron Copland's fine score, received its third performance of the current Ballet Theatre season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night and a bang-up performance it turned out to be.

WASHINGTON, May 4--The House passed by 313 to 95 today the Forand bill embodying the plan of Representative Robertson of Virginia to cancel $7,600,000,000 of the 1942 individual income tax liability and place 90 per cent of taxpayers on a current payment basis.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 4 -- The task of tracing down American complicity in General Henri Honore Giraud's escape last June from the Koenigstein Fortress was put upon Chief of Government Pierre Laval of Vichy at his audience with Adolf Hitler last week, it was learned today.

BOSTON, May 4 -- There may be any number of good and sufficient reasons why the convalescing Casey Stengel's Braves should not be trouncing the Giants in four out of six games this topsy-turvy, frostbitten Spring. But Jim Tobin's hitting and pitching, plus a home run thrust by Charlie Workman, proved a series of circumstances today against which the Giants had no reply whatsoever.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 5 -- Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, distinguished flying general and commander of all United States forces in the European theatre of operations, was killed Monday in an airplane accident in Iceland, his headquarters announced early today.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Conservation of transportation used in the distribution of beer is the objective of a plan being considered jointly by the War Production Board and the Office of Defense Transportation under which a brewer would be restricted in his use of railway transportation quarterly to a specified percentage of railroad cars and of car miles he used for beer shipments in the three-month period November, 1942, through January, 1943.

CINCINNATI, May 4 (AP) -- A three-run first inning, including Vince DiMaggio's two-run homer, started the Pirates on their way to an 8-3 victory over Cincinnati today to even the current series one-all.

Changing the name of Tammany and getting a "final divorce" between the Tammany Society and the New York County Democratic organization were listed yesterday as preliminary objectives of the group seeking the ouster of Michael J. Kennedy Jr. as leader of Tammany Hall.
Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews was the eighth American general to lose his life or to be reported missing in action since the war began, The -associated Press recalled. The others were:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 4 (AP) -- The American and French troops driving along the northern shores of Garaet Achkel toward the big naval base have met "some resistance," front dispatches reported tonight.

An open forum discussion on "The Future of Social Security in the United States and Great Britain," at which four distinguished experts will discuss leading problems of domestic social security, will be held at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on Friday at 8:30 P.M. before an invited audience.
BALTIMORE, May 4 -- Theodore R. McKeldin was elected Mayor of Baltimore today, becoming the first Republican Chief Executive of the nation's seventh largest city since 1931.

The pattern of dull trading and narrow price variation prevalent in the cotton futures market since the announcement two weeks ago that the government would dispose of some of its stocks of cotton as a price-stabilization measure was maintained yesterday. Fluctuations were restricted to a 2-to-3-point range, with active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closing mixed, 1 point above and below Monday's final quotations.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- Navy communique 364:

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Fearing that the Department of Agriculture might not continue its school luncheon program unless Congress specifically recommends it, eight groups have appealed to the department's War Food Administration for its continuance. Jesse Tapp, the WFA spokesman representing Chester Davis, administrator, with whom the delegation failed to obtain an audience, indicated that the department still favored using some of its appropriations for school luncheons.

Four hundred automobile dealers, meeting at the Hotel McAlpin yesterday to discuss with officials of the machinery branch of the Office of Price Administration a proposed price ceiling on used passenger cars, applauded vigorously when Ray Chamberlain, vice president of the National Automobile Dealers Association, flatly declared that "my organization is definitely opposed to used car price ceilings of any kind."

It is obvious that "Sons and Soldiers" should be a major event of the theatre season, for it was written by Irwin Shaw and was staged by Max Reinhardt before settings by Norman Bel Geddes. But last evening when the latter two in association with Richard Myers brought it to the Morosco it seemed not a little disappointing.

In what is believed to be one of the first meetings to give assurance to a company's dealers on post-war plans, officials of the Norge Division of Borg-Warner Corporation and of its metropolitan distributor, the Warren-Norge Corporation, told several hundred dealers yesterday that the company would not add to its outlets after the war, as the shrinkage in its distributing organization was very small.

CHUNGKING, China, May 4 (U.P.) -- The number of Japanese engaged in the large-scale enemy offensive along the Honan-Shansi border has increased to 60,000 men and some of the bloodiest battles of the war in China are raging there as Chinese forces continue to cling desperately to their strongholds in the Taihang Mountain range, it was announced tonight.

PUEBLA, Mexico, May 4 -- Another step forward in the knowledge of astronomics was made today when Dr. S. Chandrasekhar, 30-year-old mathematician of India, who has been working for the past five years in the Yerkes Observatory of the University of Chicago, demonstrated that the average life of the composition of a cluster of stars is between 3,000,000 and 5,000,000 years.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The government's projected subsidy of nursing education to provide more civilian and military nurses appeared today to be set for smooth sailing before House and Senate committees which will each hear twin bills on the program Thursday morning at 10 o'clock.

The coal strike has enraged Americans because of its effrontery, the complete disregard of its effect on the national war effort and the utter futility of the running-around-in-a-circle efforts made to stop it. Lewis's "truce" puts him in a better position to negotiate and win than before.

Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews was appointed commander of the United States Forces in the European theatre last Feb. 5, succeeding General Dwight D. Eisenhower. It was his third wartime as signment; he had previously served as chief of the Caribbean Defense Command and the Panama Canal Department and as commander of the United States Forces in the Middle East with headquarters at Cairo.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Herbert H. Lehman, Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, said today that his visit to London had convinced him of the necessity for the preparation by the Allies of assistance to civilians in liberated areas.

NEWARK, N.J., May (AP) -- Eight brokers in Toronto, Ont., were ordered today by Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein to cease buying or selling securities in New Jersey by telephone or personal solicitation.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 4 -- The American Legion drew up plans at its national headquarters today for gathering into membership eight or nine million veterans who will emerge from the present World War.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 5 (AP) -- Heavy fighting in the Western Caucasus has cost the Germans "serious losses in manpower and equipment" it was announced early today by the Soviet command several hours after the Germans acknowledged a forced withdrawal in that area some twenty miles above the port of Novorossiisk and the loss to the Russians of the town of Krimsk.

Topics of The Times of May 2, concerning Kalinin and the purge trials, sent me to my copy of the book "Mission to Moscow." There on Page 22 is an explicit statement concerning the meeting with Kalinin: "The President, Mr. Kalinin, sat back of his desk and assigned a chair to me facing Mr. Krestinsky, with Mr. Neymann, the interpreter, between."

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 4 -- Nicaragua's Minister of the Treasury, Ramon Sevilla, has requested Colonel Irving Lindberg, collector general of customs and high commissioner and fiscal agent for the country's frozen commercial debt, to arrange to pay off before June 30 the entire debit covered by the contract with the Foreign Trade Council, Inc., of New York, now amounting to more than half a million dollars and held by American, Canadian and British nationals.
NEW DELHI, India, May 4 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Army Air Force communique:

Brooklyn's first twilight game of the season, played in a wintry chill and under gray skies at Ebbets Field yesterday, was a grand and glorious success for Texas Jack Kraus, but it brought no joy to the 3,517 fans.

Four hundred and six New York City welfare agencies are represented by the Greater New York Fund in the campaign which has just begun to raise $4,500,000 for the coming year's needs. War does not diminish the needs of these agencies and the people whom they serve.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The Board of Economic Warfare disclosed today a revision of export license regulations for gift parcels sent to prisoners of war and civilians of the United Nations interned by the Axis.
WASHINGTON, May 4 -- President Roosevelt today proclaimed June 14 as Flag Day and asked the people to fly the Stars and Stripes this year along with the flags of the United Nations where feasible.

THE Customers Always Write: That flowery phrase-maker, Herbert Bayard Swope, the chairman of the Racing Commission, took pen in hand the morning before the Derby was run and, in commenting on recent remarks here, at least partially established himself as a prophet. He said:

"Three's a Family," a farce comedy by Phoebe and Henry Ephron, opens tonight at the Longacre. John Golden is the producer. Mr. Ephron staged the production and Stewart Chaney designed the setting. The cast includes Robert Burton, Ruth Weston, Ethel Owen, Katharine Bard, Francis de Sales, Edwin Philips, Doro Merande, William Wadsworth and Edmund Dorsay.

OTTAWA, May 4 (Canadian Press) -- Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell tonight issued the first order under National Selective Service Civilian Regulations looking to the compulsory transfer of men in the age groups designated under mobilization regulations from nonessential to essential work.
WASHINGTON, May 4 (AP) -- The death of Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews leaves at least temporary command of the United States Forces in the European theatre to his deputy, Major Gen. Harry C. Ingles.

Somewhat more than $11,000,000,000 worth of the $15,000,000,000 in government-financed war plant contracts let between June, 1940, to the end of February this year, are now completed, according to estimates yesterday by the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- The President received the Ministers of Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Dominican Republic and Haiti, who presented their credentials as Ambassadors; saw Governor Dempsey of New Mexico, Dr. Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador to London, and Wei Tao-Ming, Chinese Ambassador to Washington, and Lord Halifax, British Ambassador, and held a press conference.

A general picture of what well-dressed women will put on their heads was set forth yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. The taste of eight leading houses was combined in the showing, which was held by the Millinery Creators Guild.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 4 (AP) -- Four officials of Samuel Dunkel Co., Inc., New York City, pleaded innocent today when arraigned in the Federal Court here on charges of conspiracy to defraud the government of about $850,000 in connection with sales of dried egg powder for the armed services and lend-lease.

The Associated Church Press, an organization of 250 editors, managers, publishers and correspondents of Protestant church papers in the United States and Canada, opened last night a three-day meeting at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East Twenty-eighth Street.

Earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation in the first three months of this year, with March estimated, were equivalent to $1.04 a capital share on the basis of a 50 per cent normal tax and surtax on income and a 90 per cent excess profits tax, E.T. Stannard, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday.

Two Greek businessmen, brothers, who were reported to have substantial financial interests until the Nazis invaded their country, were indicted yesterday in Brooklyn with two other persons on charges of having smuggled into this country in 1930 17,500 ounces of morphine hydro-chloride worth $1,000,000.

There have been several performances of Bach's "Passion According to St. Matthew" this season, and last night his setting of the "Passion According to St. John" was presented at Carnegie Hall. The Dessoff Choirs and the Chapel Choir of Princeton University joined in the performance under the direction of Paul Boepple.

CHICAGO, May 4 -- Two thousand dollars a year has been proposed by Office of Price Administration economists as the minimum wartime income standard, a report on Civilian spending and saving disclosed today.

WITH A UNITED STATES NAVAL TASK FORCE, March 26 (Delayed) -- This small United States Naval task force fought a Japanese fleet of twice its size today, disrupted the enemy plans in a four-hour surface duel and retired without the loss of a ship.

J.M. Kurn and John G. Lonsdale, trustees for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, yesterday reported that operating revenues last year amounted to $90,079,600, an increase of $28,244,396 over 1941. Net income was $14,767,239 after charges and taxes, in contrast to a deficit of $223,663 in 1941.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. White have come to the Vanderbilt from Middlebury, Va.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4 (AP) -- Rookie Jess Flores pitched a three-hitter today as the Athletics defeated Dutch Leonard and the Senators, 3 to 1. It was the second victory in three starts for the little Mexican.

According to a German communique, Axis submarines and aircraft claim to have sunk a total of 423,000 gross registered tons of Allied merchant shipping during April. Coming from German sources, that figure may be accepted as the maximum figure of Allied losses for that month.

The Department of Justice's inquiry into alleged monopolistic practices of fire insurance companies, which resulted last November in the indictment of the South-Eastern Underwriters Association by a Federal grand jury in Atlanta, has been extended to this area.

CHUNKING, China, May 4 (U.P.)--A. communique: Taihang Mountains: Enemy troops at Wulikwan, north of Siuwu, in Northern Honan Province, again moved northward toward Hutungyen on the morning of April 27. The Chinese, apart from meeting them, sent a strong force to strike at the enemy's flanks.

The "Golden Nineties" loan exhibition at the Grand Central Galleries (Hotel Gotham branch) opened with a preview at 9 o'clock last evening and, beginning today, will be open to the public until May 16 -- the hours, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. on weekdays, noon to 6 o'clock on Sundays.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Details of the clash in Aleutian waters between Japanese and United States warships on March 26 finally were revealed today by the Navy. Six American ships drove away a heavier and numerically superior force of Japanese cruisers and destroyers, defeating an apparent attempt to push through supplies or reinforcements to one of the enemy bases.

The largest single expenditure of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York system in 1942 was for wages, salaries and pensions, which aggregated $75,225,000, according to the company's annual report to employes, released yesterday.

Fourteen local housing authorities in various parts of the country will offer on Wednesday next, through competitive bidding, new issues of temporary loan notes aggregating $12,364,000, it was announced yesterday. All the issues, which are to be sold separately, will be dated June 2, 1943.

TRENTON, N.J., May 4 -- Colonel N. Bloomer, State Selective Service director, indicated tonight that New Jersey industries must be prepared to send 50 per cent of draft-eligible male employes into the armed forces within six months after May 15.

Some hundred and fifty duck hunters are expected to attend the annual dinner of Ducks Unlimited at the Columbia University Club tomorrow evening and to listen to a report of the organization's activities in Canada.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 1 (AP) -- communique:
Colonel Maurice Simmons, the Police Department property clerk, has a $13,901.21 headache and he is trying to use some of the legal minds of the Corporation Counsel's Office as headache powders.

One of the best booklets the writer has seen so far on the subject of canning is "Canning at Home," by Marion C. Pfund, a sixty-three-page bulletin that has just been issued by the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University.

MATEUR, Tunisia, May 3 (delayed) -- A single American half-track captured Mateur today and an American reconnaissance battalion consolidated the capture in a two-shot battle. Each of the shots killed a straggling German sniper.
The Administration's policy in the coal wage dispute is still ambiguous. Until it is clarified we shall not know whether the Administration or Mr. Lewis has come off the victor.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,428, which compared with 690 in the preceding week and 711 in the like period of last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations numbered 740, as against 402 last Tuesday.

Whatever may be the ultimate outcome of one of the most serious strikes ever to occur in this country, the fact will remain that one man took it upon himself to defy the Government of the United States and to jeopardize the whole war effort, not only of ourselves but of our allies.

LONDON, May 4 (AP) -- The Nazis acknowledged today that the grim prospect of an Allied invasion of Europe was so imminent that it might by-pass the Tunisian bridgehead and come in the form of an amphibious assault on the Sardinian and Sicilian stepping-stones, even before the collapse of Tunis and Bizerte.

James Madison High's baseball team gained its fourth straight success in as many Brooklyn P.S.A.L. games by routing New Utrecht, 7 -- 3, on the Green and White diamond yesterday. In other Brooklyn clashes, Manual topped Lafayette, 2 -- 1; Erasmus shut out Midwood, 2 -- 0, as Johnny Weiss yielded only one hit and fanned thirteen, and Brooklyn Tech routed Abraham Lincoln, 7 -- 3.

Any number of us today find ourselves thinking of the author of a recently published autobiography and wishing that the author lives up to its title and more. In his discussions with the president of the United Mine Workers we devoutly hope that the writer of this autobiography is not content with showing himself a curmudgeon.

Esther Forbes, Pulitzer Prize winner for "Paul Revere and the World He Lived In," published by Houghton, Mifflin, will have a new book out this Autumn. A novel, laid in Revolutionary Boston, it will cover the same period as her prize-winning history.

War put such obstacles in the way of the Society of Independent Artists this year that the easier course for them would have been to cancel their twenty-seventh annual exhibition. All the organization's active officers, with the exception of John Sloan, veteran president who has not been well, are engaged in war work, as are a number of the board of directors.

Despite restricted production over the last year, wholesalers and retailers of automotive parts, by cutting into their inventories, have been able to enjoy excellent sales volume, and at present are running as much as 10 per cent ahead of 1942, a peak year, it was reported yesterday at the closing session of a regional conference of the Motor and Equipment Wholesalers Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 4 -- Six more Japanese ships, including two destroyers, have been sent to the bottom and a seventh has been probably sunk, all of them attacked by United States submarines ranging the waters of the Pacific and Far East, the Navy announced in a communique late today.

Testimony of fifteen character witnesses, including a Yonkers judge, a rabbi, six school teachers and a number of business and professional men, including three lawyers, in General Sessions yesterday helped to save 20-year-old Joseph Barth, a night class student in George Washington University, from a prison term for shooting his brother-in-law, Dr. Jerome Meadow, in his dental offices at 203 East Fifty-eighth Street last Nov. 28.

OMAHA, May 5 -- For the seventh consecutive year, the National Safety Council announced today, Union Pacific employes have had the lowest accident-frequency rate for Class I railroads, 3.32 per million man hours in 1942.

The emotional impact that advertising can exercise on the public is being graphically illustrated in the response being accorded to numerous ads in the form of thousands of letters and endorsements and demands for reprints, according to agency executives.

Interracial cooperation was practiced in this country on an unprecedented scale during the first war year, according to the annual report, made public yesterday, of the National Urban League, an organization for social service among Negroes.

A guided tour of the shops and salons reveals a medley, of charming and practical cosmetic gifts for Mother's Day. Since no one mother is like any other, our list of shopping suggestions includes ideas for mothers of every sort, size and description.
CHUNGKING, China, May 5 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

Most lamp buyers who have sought to replenish their stocks following the extension granted to manufacturers have been disappointed, it was reported yesterday. It was pointed out that, while manufacturers had based their appeals on the fact that they still had inventories of sockets and cut wire, they were now finding it impossible to obtain adequate supplies of china and other parts.

In these days when Presidents get around more than they used to it is natural that President Enrique Penaranda de Castillo of Bolivia should be paying this country a visit. Bolivia has not been the most fortunate of the Southern republics. It suffered horribly in the pitiable Chaco wars with Paraguay.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Lend-lease exports in March were the highest so far, reaching a total of $708,000,000 and bringing total shipments since the program began in March, 1941, up to April 1 to $7,104,731,000, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., lend-lease administrator, said today.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 5 -- Behind the two-hit pitching of Southpaw John Eide Princeton's baseball team defeated Yale today, 10 to 1. The Tiger hurler walked seven and fanned six, being particularly effective with men on bases.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The replies of Premier Joseph Stalin to the questions propounded to him by Ralph Parker, Moscow correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, were generally interpreted here today as indicative of Russian concern over an adverse reaction in the world, and particularly among small European States, to the Russian-Polish controversy.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Secretary Ickes signed an order today enabling him to seize coal stocks anywhere when such action becomes necessary to protect civilian war plants and essential civilian users from shortages.

LONDON, May 5 -- Major Gen. William S. Key, Provost Marshal General in the European theatre of operations, today assumed command in this theatre following announcement of the death of Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, which shocked and saddened Allied circles here.

The report of the American Water works and Electric Company, Inc., and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on March 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income, after all expenses, charges and certain tax adjustments, of $3,823,885, compared with a net of $3,928,376 in the twelve months to March 31, 1942.

A UNITED STATES AIR BASE in Southern China, May 4 (Delayed)--Having recently acquired a new group of B-24 heavy bombers [Liberators] the Fourteenth United States Army Air Force staged the largest air raid today against the Japanese since the Americans began operating in China.

A resolution supporting the demands of coal miners and declaring that "the fight against John L. Lewis is not the issue" was adopted unanimously yesterday at a regional meeting of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., in Manhattan Center.

BALTIMORE, May 5 (AP) -- Hal Price Headley's Askmenow showed today that she had lost none of her class as she carried the familiar navy blue and white colors of the Kentuckian to victory in the twenty-first running of the $10,000-added Pimlico Oaks.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP) -- The Jacksonville (Fla.) Gas Company, an operating unit of the American Gas and Power Company, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to permit it to pay $51,297 expenses in connection with its reorganization into the Jacksonville Gas Corporation.

Borough President James A. Burke of Queens, revealing that Dr. George H. Chatfield, Mayor La Guardia's newest appointee to the Board of Education, had not been a resident of Queens until he took a hotel room there recently, issued a formal statement yesterday attacking the Mayor as "Public Enemy No. 1 so far as Queens is concerned."

Appointment of a committee of the American Newspaper Publishers Association to protect the right of newspapers to gather and disseminate information was announced yesterday by President Linwood I. Noyes of the Ironwood (Mich.) Daily Globe.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The prospect of drastic revision of the House pay-as-you-go tax bill by the Senate appeared increasingly likely as the Senate Finance Committee prepared to open brief hearings tomorrow morning.

The Navy is winning the battle against Axis submarines in the North Atlantic and will not cease its vigilance "until the cold waters of the North Atlantic are too hot for Axis submarines," Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews, commander of the Eastern Sea Frontier, declared yesterday.

Acting for the first time under a recent resolution of the State War Council that gave Office of Price Administration regulations the force of State law, the OPA district office here obtained yesterday thirty-five summonses in Magistrates courts against poultry and potato retailers accused of violating price ceilings.

Unless something as yet unannounced comes along before June 1, the play-opening season ended last evening with the arrival of "Three's a Family," at the Long-acre. It did not end on too happy a note, for the comedy turned out by Phoebe and Henry Ephron is some distance from being hilarious; it would be weak even though the Winter rules for Broadway were not still in force.

A group of security holders in the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad Company, at a meeting held here yesterday, decided to contest the move of the United States District Court of Minnesota, Fourth Division, to continue jurisdiction over the road for six years after the lifting of the receivership.

Unprecedented use of newspaper advertising space, of radio and of telegraph message service seemed yesterday to have halted effectively the sale and use of all Fletcher's Castoria shipped from the Castoria plant at Rahway, N.J.

The duplex apartment in the Beckman Campanile, 450 East Fifty-second Street, which formerly was occupied by Alice Duer Miller, has been leased by Miss Ethel Barrymore through Douglas L. Elliman Co., who also leased apartments in 25 East Eighty-sixth Street to Ervin Oplatek; in 157 East Seventy-second Street to Mrs. Frederick Vietor through Duff Conger, and in 81 Irving Place to Seth T. Brewer.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 5 -- The wreck of the Swedish submarine Ulven, sunk April 16 while on manoeuvres with thirty-three members of its crew, was located this afternoon at a spot off Stora Poelsan Island, approximately eleven miles due west of Goeteborg.

" The Russian Story," a feature-length film about life in Russia and the struggle of the Russian people against invaders during the last 800 years, has been completed and will be released here the first week in June, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Fourteen persons were killed in the plane crash in Iceland in which Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, commanding general of United States troops in the European theatre, lost his life, the War Department reported late today.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Wheat futures started firm and finished easy today on the Board of Trade. Mill buying was in evidence early, but the market quickly slowed down and trading was restricted until near the close, when weakness in rye led to some professional selling.

RIO DE JANIERO, Brazil, May 5 -- In a spectacular "good neighbor" gesture Brazil today canceled the seventy-one-year-old debt of Paraguay, contracted as a war indemnity after the termination of hostilities between the two countries in 1872.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 5 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Announcement by the War Department today that the Army Air Forces would eliminate civilian schools from its broad program of technical training for mechanics was followed by a vigorous protest from a civilian school spokesman that the private operators were being "let down" after investing large sums in the Army program.

Park Lane Courts, a thirty-five-family apartment building at Park Lane South and Metropolitan Avenue, opposite Forest Park, in Kew Gardens, L.I., has been sold by the Kew Gardens Corporation, Alrich Man, president, to an investing client of the Ralph M. Lauer Realty Company.

Moving with increased precision because of previous drills, residents of New York, Long Island and communities in the southern part of the State went through a fifty-one minute air-raid test last night in the widest practice alarm yet ordered by the Second Service Command for this area.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The President saw Senators Hayden and McFarland; Constantin Fotitch, Yugoslavian Minister; Herbert Evatt, Australian Foreign Minister, and Herbert H. Lehman, director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, and presided at a State dinner for General Enrique Penaranda President of Bolivia.

A suit described as the "opening gun in a drive against fake charities" was started yesterday by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein with the signing by Supreme Court Justice Isidor Wasservogel of an order permitting the Attorney General to sue to annul the charter and end the corporate existence of the East Side Free Kitchen Center, 624 East Fifth Street.

The strike of employes of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, which for the past: two weeks had put pickets at the gates of its Eclipse Pioneer Division plant in East Orange, N.J., was settled last night after a conference in the offices of the National Labor Relations Board here in which representatives of the Army Air Forces, the War Production Board and the United States Conciliation Service participated.

MOSCOW, May 5--Premier Joseph Stalin in a personal letter to your correspondent, received early this morning, has emphatically stated his government's desire to see established after the war a strong and independent Poland.

" HASN'T it been a lovely Spring?" asked Joe Cronin as he pulled his overcoat tighter. "We had a training period where the pitchers never had a chance to pitch or the hitters to hit. Then we froze during the exhibition games and, as a crowning touch, we were greeted with that new ball when the season started. A pumpkin, that's what it is.

In his proposal that our government should start post-war medical planning, Dr. Morris Fishbein remarks that "the action by the British Parliament on the medical aspects of the Beveridge plan is likely to affect seriously the nature of medical practice in our own country."

LONDON, May 5 -- The largest concentration of four-engined bombers ever sent out on a war mission smashed at, Dortmund, Germany, last night with nearly 1,500 tons of blockbusters in a saturation raid approximating the weight of destruction heaped on Cologne by more than 1,000 planes nearly a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Axis forces are intensifying their use of "phony propaganda stories" to whip up sentiment at home and disrupt the foreign-born population here, Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, said today.

ALGIERS, May 5 -- General Henri Honore Giraud today informed General Georges Catroux, General Charles de Gaulle's representative, that he still insisted that his projected meeting with the Fighting French leader should be held in a quiet spot where calm discussion would be possible, instead of in Algeria, as General de Gaulle insisted.
A good many who spend a week or two in Maine each Spring trout fishing, following the break-up of the ice, have been waiting patiently for more news of open waters.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Forty-four applications for licenses to operate new air lines after the war are pending before the Civil Aeronautics Board. This was made known today when the CAB announced it wa. conducting a survey of American aviation to aid in determining the government's post-war international air transportation policy.
LONDON, Thursday, May 6 (U.P.) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
In the fields and pastures of New York State, in the woods and swamps, along the country roadsides and even in the rural backyards, there are weeds to be had for the cutting -- something for nothing.

A project to restore to celluloid 5,000 motion-picture subjects made from 1897 to 1917, most of them heretofore unavailable, has been undertaken by the Library of Congress, it was announced yesterday by Howard L. Walls, curator of the Library's new film collection, before the Society of Motion Picture Engineers, meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Major Gen. Harold L. George, commander of the Air Transport Command, who arrived yesterday from Washington, announced the establishment of the Domestic Transport Division under the direction of Colonel Harold R. Harris. The announcement was made at a conference in the division's new headquarters at 33 Pine Street.

BOSTON, May 5 -- Deciding the time had arrived for drastic action, Melvin Ott gave his faltering Giants a violent shaking today and the results were electrifying as well as most depressing to 4,879 disappointed onlookers.

The leading torpedo manufacturer in the United States, Amertorp, subsidiary of the American Can Company, is now turning out six times as many torpedoes as the figure set by its Navy contract for June next according to Carl G. Preis, vice president.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Two recent government orders to industry are, in effect, the very reverse of "holding the line" against inflation as outlined by the President. One was the direction of Manpower Administrator McNutt that the steel mills go on a forty-eight-hour basis.

Three Pulitzer traveling scholarships for 1943, part of the annual prizes and awards established under the will of Joseph Pulitzer, were won by Seymour Ethan of Passaic, N.J., Henry Giniger of Brooklyn and Evelyn Simpson of Omaha, Neb., all students in the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, the trustees announced yesterday.

The $40,000,000 medium-cost housing project of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, tentatively designated as Stuyvesant Town, and to be located in the area bounded by Avenue C, First Avenue, East Twentieth Street and Fourteenth Street, will go before the City Planning Commission on May 19 for a public hearing.

A report of the Children's Division of the Domestic Relations Court for the first four months of 1943, made public yesterday, showed that in the five boroughs 1,603 "allegedly delinquent children" came before the court. This represented approximately a one-third increase over the 1,208 in the same period of 1942, and a 60 per cent increase over the 1,092 in 1941.

The annual report of the City Stores Company, for publication today, shows net sales of $60,623,556 for the fiscal year ended with January, an increase of $6,751,492, or 12.5 per cent over the $53,872,064 volume of the previous year.

One year ago today General Jonathan M. Wainwright walked out to the battle line on Corregidor, where a hopelessly outnumbered American and Filipino force was trying to fight off a Japanese landing force, and with a trembling voice and tears in his eyes ordered the surrender of the last American stronghold in the Far East.

With the remark that he expected the reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation to be completed this year, Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell yesterday authorized submission to the Securities and Exchange Commission of a plan of recapitalization for a subsidiary of the Associated system.

In answering promptly and frankly the questions put to him by Ralph Parker, the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES in Moscow, Premier Joseph Stalin has addressed his first letter to an American newspaper and made the first statement since the rupture of diplomatic relations of Russia's policy toward post-war Poland.

Dr. William S. Carpenter, chairman of the Department of Politics at Princeton University and consultant to the Consumer Banking Institute of Washington, D.C., said yesterday that the public debt of the United States at the end of the war, although it will be the largest in the history of the world, can be safely manipulated by the government to promote national prosperity so long as it remains widely distributed among the American people.

Even the doghouse moves into father's bedroom in the new ten-room exhibit opening today at Lord Taylor. The small son is in the same room, while down the hall one room has been made into a combination nursery-bedroom for his war-bride sister.
Colonel George P. Brett, U. S. A., Airs. Brett and the latter's mother. A{rs. George Dallas Yeoroans, and G. Platt Brett 3d have come to the Vanderbllt from Easton, Conn.
Operators were the leading figures in the purchase and sale of realty in Manhattan yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- His left arm in a sling and a patch covering the back of his head, Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair, commanding general of United States Army Ground Forces, returned here early this afternoon by airplane, ending the last lap of his air journey from the Tunisian battlefront, where he was severely wounded on April 23.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- With feed supplies dwindling under the record wartime livestock production program, the War Food Administration today took steps that it said were designed to prevent hoarding of corn by feeders, feed mixers and manufacturers.

WITH THE SECOND UNITED STATES CORPS, In Tunisia, May 4 (Delayed) -- On the slopes of Hill 609 poppies blow as red as any in Flanders and among them lie Americans who died as bravely and as grandly as any who fell in the Argonne, at Gettys burg or at Bunker Hill.
PUEBLA, Mexico, May 5 -- Dr. L. Don Leet, director of the Harvard seismographic station, predicted today that Popocatepetl, Mexico's largest volcano, was due to erupt soon.

LONDON, May 5 -- Although the stock markets here were generally cheerful today activity was restricted to the more speculative sections. Diamond shares continued yesterday's rally, De Beers gaining 3/8 and Consolidated 1-10.

Government regulations that encourage black markets are threatening the entire inflation control program by squeezing out of business established retail distributors, according to John A. Logan, president of the National Association of Food Chains.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. William S. Key, who will serve as acting commander of American forces in the European theatre, has been Provost Marshal General of the European theatre since October, 1942.

Stocks of finished oil products along the Atlantic Coast last week declined to another new low level, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The index of the institute at the week-end stood at 26.3, compared with the revised figure of 27.7 in the previous week and 58.3 on Nov. 7, 1942, when the current downward trend started.

Although aircraft contracts continued to be placed at about the same volume as in 1942, placements of government contracts for war supplies and facilities during the three months ended in February declined to a little over $14,000,000,000, against a quarterly rate of $22,500,000,000 last year, it was announced yesterday by the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board.

ILLMO, Mo., May 5 -- Under the protection of ninety officers and men of the Missouri State Guard armed with sawed-off shotguns, about 125 men resumed work this afternoon on construction of a section of the government-financed pipeline being built to carry gasoline from Texas to the East.

Ralph, Budd, president of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, told stockholders at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that the road carried more freight and more passengers in the first 1943 quarter than in any comparable period in its history.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 5 -- The Legislature gave final approval today to a bill increasing to $50 the monthly pension maximum for more than 153,000 California residents.
CLEVELAND, May 5 (AP) -- A committee of holders of preferred

LONDON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Tension increased in Norway and Belgium tonight after the assassination of four Nazi leaders. The Gestapo chief, Kurt Daluege, was reported to have assumed the direction of reprisals.

The most significant and encouraging thing that the House did on Tuesday was to bury the bill of its own Ways and Means Committee by the crushing roll-call vote of 230 to 120. In that vote the House once more rebuked its own committee majority, as well as the Treasury, which had endorsed the bill.

A new shipment of British cartoons has arrived in this country and has been added to the British and American cartoons in the current "Speak Their Language" exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum. The original shipment was lost in transit and the lost drawings have been replaced by the artists.

A plant in which the largest airplane engines for the newest long-range bombers will be made is being completed in Chicago, K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, yesterday told 400 industrialists, bankers and publishers at a luncheon in the Hotel Biltmore.
PHILADELPHIA, May 5 (AP) -- Alex Carrasquel hobbled the Athletics today for the third time this year, allowing four hits as the Senators won, 8 to 1.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, arrived here today from Richmond, Va., by automobile for an official visit and was an overnight guest of President Roosevelt at the White House tonight.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo will open a Spring season on May 19 at the Broadway Theatre, according to an announcement yesterday by S.J. Denham, president of Universal Art, Inc., the sponsoring organization of the company. The engagement will continue through May 29, with performances every night including Sundays and with Saturday matinees.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 5 -- Widespread rioting, during which both the police and military were forced to fire on crowds with machine guns, has raged in Sofia since late yesterday afternoon following the national funeral services held for Colonel Athanas Panteff, slain last Sunday by "anti-Axis assassins," according to uncensored information reaching diplomatic quarters here tonight.

BUFFALO, May 5 -- Three years of operating experience of a prepayment medical plan in Western. New York have revealed that for such plans to succeed a complete medical program must be offered, which would include medical and surgical care by general practitioners and also specialists' services in the home, the doctor's office and the hospital, it was reported before the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the State of New York here today.

A game that seemed drawing to a peaceful close at the Stadium yesterday suddenly fell apart in the ninth inning and, for the second day in a row, the Yankees needed a good-sized handful of luck to nose out the Red Sox, 4 to 3. The score and the deciding innings were the same on both days and, in each instance, a throw figured in the final result.

Mikhail Shayne, Russian pianist, will give a Russian recital for the students of Hunter College at 4 P.M. today. The program will consist of works by Scriabine, Moussorgsky, Rachmaninoff and Balakireff.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 5 -- The national leaders of the American Legion took under consideration today a proposal from business sources to collect and spent $20,000,000 a year "to keep America sold on Americanism."

Reporting on operations for its fiscal year ended with February, Martin L. Straus, president of Eversharp, Inc., announced for publication today that sales nearly doubled those of the previous year despite the fact that in excess of $3,500,000 in orders remained unfilled due to a directive of the War Production Board.
New York University's league-leading nine met its master for the first time of the season yesterday in Southpaw Rudy Imarata and a faultlessly fielding Fordham team.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Bank deposits in the United States passed the $100,000,000,000 mark for the first time in the country's history in 1942. This was shown in the annual year-end condition statement for all banks issued today by Preston Delano, Controller of the Currency.

The National Federation of Music Clubs will open at 10 A.M. today in the Biltmore Hotel, the first biennial convention it has ever held in this city. The meeting will last for three days and will be featured by the selection of four winners for the federation's $1,000 prizes in its fifteenth biennial Young Artists auditions.

Frieda S. Miller, former Industrial Commissioner, testifying yesterday at the Moreland Act investigation of the Workmen's Compensation Law, characterized as "shocking" the testimony of previous witnesses and admitted that gifts to referees, doctors and others handling compensation claims had the "aspects" of bribery.

LONDON, May 5 -- Declaring that the German Air Force was waning in power, a competent Royal Air Force commentator asserted today that the R.A.F., the Dominions air forces and the British-based squadrons making up the fighting air strength of the Allied European countries "considerably" outnumber the Luftwaffe.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- More than $7,000,000,000 of assets of enemy and enemy-occupied nations are now under "freezing" control or are under the control of the Alien Property Custodian, the Office of War Information reported today.

A family collection of nearly 1,000 autograph letters and documents, by and relating to outstanding Americans of the Colonial, Revolutionary and Federal periods, is to be sold at auction here. Most of the collection has never been published and much of it is believed to be new to historians.

The government's new No. 1 man in the petroleum supply set-up for the entire East Coast, H. W. Dodge, described himself yesterday as "neither dictator nor savior" and said he would work closely with the petroleum industry to bring as much gasoline and fuel oil as possible into this area to meet all military requirements first and then to make supplies available for equitable distribution for civilians.
Lewiston, Me., announced yesterday that it will open bids on May 11 at 5 P.M. on $650,000 of revenue-anticipation notes dated May 1 and payable on Dec. 31.

Wendell L. Willkie will receive a leather-bound copy of his own book, autographed by the members of the War Book Panel of the Council on Books in Wartime, who have chosen "One World" as the third "imperative" war book, at a ceremony at council headquarters, 400 Madison Avenue, at 5 P.M. today.

LONDON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Premier Mussolini, speaking from his Venice palace balcony in Rome today, told a cheering crowd of 100,000 Fascists that "Italy must and will return to Africa," and asserted that traitors of "no matter what rank and race" would be shot without mercy.

Sing Sing prison lost a prospective occupant and an unnamed shipyard kept a welder yesterday when Judge George L. Donnellan, sitting in General Sessions, "reversed" himself in the case of a prisoner he had already sentenced.

In a bristling nose finish that left the crowd of 16,384 gasping, George D. Widener's homebred Lucky Draw yesterday captured the Youthful Stakes, won last year by another of his breeding, Red Sonnet. Walter Mann, up on the son of Jack High, was as fatigued and breathless as a jockey can be after such a finish, but at least he kept his wits about him and weighed in.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 5 -- Axis propaganda directed to the predominantly Moslem Middle Eastern peoples has been hammering consistently along certain lines during the past few months, particularly to the effect that Great Britain no longer is the chief menace to Arab independence. That role, the propaganda continues, has now been usurped by the United States.

Achievements of the American cooperative movement "will be well nigh unbelievable" within five or ten years, Shih-Chi Hu, secretary of the Cooperative League of China, declared yesterday at the conclusion of a 3,000-mile tour of United States consumer co-ops, during which he spoke before more than 100 local meetings in the Midwest.

MONTREAL, May 5 (Canadian Press) -- At the annual meeting of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company here today D.C. Coleman was elected chairman of the board of directors and re-elected president. Mr. Coleman, who was appointed president last year, succeeded the late Sir Edward Beatty in that office and also follows him as chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Four checks, each of $608,296.30, proceeds of the scrap rubber drive conducted by the petroleum industry last Summer by request of President Roosevelt, were presented today to the American Red Cross, Army Emergency Relief, Navy Relief Society and United Service Organizations.
