A resolution asking Congress to take immediate steps to limit the term of office of the President to two terms of four years each is expected to provoke discussion today during the second day's session of the fifty-second annual meeting of the National Society of the Daughters of the Revolution at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- Taking note of the fact that tomorrow is the first anniversary of the surrender of Corregidor, Secretary of State Cordell Hull declared today that America would avenge Japanese savagery, while President Manuel L. Quezon of the Philippines predicted that "soon -- it cannot be too soon -- the second and final Battle of the Philippines will begin."

Warning of possible failure of retail inventory control order L-219, because of lack of adequate enforcement machinery, Jay D. Runkle, general manager of Crowley, Milner Co., Detroit, said yesterday that assurance of strict enforcement was vital to retailing if the law-abiding merchant were not to be greatly penalized in stocking merchandise in the present "football rush" for goods in the wholesale markets and "as-ready" shipments by manufacturers.

When I read in THE TIMES today that the air trainees at Atlantic City were forbidden to sing "Roll Out the Barrel," "I've Been Working on the Railroad" and six other songs which post headquarters said might be interpreted as "slurs on women, the courage of soldiers, or as drinking songs," innumerable slurs on that particular post headquarters immediately came to my mind and without benefit of any songs.

CINCINNATI, May 5 (AP) -- Bucky Walters pitched and batted the Reds to a 3-2 victory tonight in the first night game of the season, knocking in two runs with a single and holding the Pirates to five hits.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, May 6 -- General Douglas MacArthur, commemorating the first anniversary of the fall of Corregidor in Manila Bay, said today that "until we lift our flag from its dust we stand unredeemed before mankind."
A special German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A predominant group within the Administration would welcome, and may even go so far as to provoke, a new show-down with John L. Lewis. The double purpose would be to retrieve some of the public "face" which officials are beginning to believe was lost in the first climax of the coal crisis Sunday night and to remove, as far as possible, from the scene the menacing figure of the man Lewis.
CHUNGKING, China, May 5 (U.P.) -- A communique:
WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- Navy communique 367:

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The House Military Affairs Committee listened for hours today to John P. Monroe, "mysterious" and generous host to high government figures in the "big red house on R Street," but came out with little more information other than a picture of how a "manufacturers' agent" operates in wartime Washington and how profitable his occupation is, even though he gets few contracts for his clients.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 5 (AP) -- The Florida Senate passed today, 50 to 5, a bill to give married women the right to manage their own property but first amended it to give husbands the right to sue for alimony.
NEW DELHI, India, May 5 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, Thursday, May 6 -- Red Army troops have broken through the German lines in the Kuban of a fifteen and a half mile front for a gain of eight miles and have captured nine inhabited places in addition to the heavily fortified defense base of Krymsk, whose loss the Germans had admitted Tuesday, Russia's Wednesday midnight communique said today.

The Bronx and Queens drives for the Greater New York Fund, which has set its goal at $4,500,000 this year, were opened yesterday. Borough chairmen and other speakers stressed the greater need for welfare work owing to war conditions.
LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The Down Town Glee Club, under George Mead, gave its Spring concert last night in Carnegie Hall before an enthusiastic capacity audience. The chorus, now in its seventeenth year, was assisted by John Baker, baritone, one of its active members for four years, who was a winner in this year's Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air.

A coordinated advertising campaign, similar to that now being conducted by a dozen railroad companies, was suggested to the insurance field yesterday by John W. Barndollar, field secretary of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, at the Spring meeting of the Insurance Advertising Conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Dean Frank H. Sommer of the New York University School of Law, who is retiring after fifty years as student and teacher, and Professors George Luther Clark and William F. Walsh of the Law School faculty, who also are retiring at the end of the present term, were honored at a farewell dinner given at the Hotel Lafayette last night by the Law School Pre-Bar Association.

Summer broke upon the scene, sartorially speaking, in the Charleston Gardens at Altman's yesterday afternoon. Skins glowed with golden tan (they were deftly made up by Charles of the Ritz). Bathing girls (they haven't put a toe in the sea this season) stepped from the platform and down the runway.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- A draft agreement on the important subject of world relief and rehabilitation after the war is being dispatched by the United States Government to the governments of the United Nations for their consideration and comments.

CHICAGO, May 5 -- Claude Passeau, veteran Cubs' right-hander, and Max Lanier, Cardinals' southpaw, dueled through fourteen action-packed innings today before an "inning-ending double-play ball" bounded freakishly over Second Baseman Jimmy Brown's shoulder to drive in the run that gave the Chicagoans a 2-to-1 victory.

CLEVELAND, May 5 (AP) -- The Indians pulled into a first-place tie with the Yankees when southpaw Chubby Dean whipped Chicago in the opener of a twin bill today, 2 to 1, but fell back again as the White Sox captured the 11-inning aftermath, 5 to 2.

The ninth annual awards of the Women's National Radio Committee were announced here yesterday at a luncheon held at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. "America's Town Meeting of the Air," a WJZ-Blue sustaining program carried on Thursdays from Town Hall, won top vote of the committee in the forum classification for the eighth time.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 473 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Asiatic, European, North African, Pacific and Southwest pacific areas. Action in North Africa accounted for the wounding of 422 of the men.

WASHINGTON, May 5--President Roosevelt's mandate to "hold the line" against inflation precludes the possibility of an upward adjustment of yarn and textile prices, the Office of Price Administration announced today. Some producers had asked the OPA to readjust prices of their products, and the impression had gained currency that upward revisions in prices were impending, OPA officials said.

The letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of April 24, entitled "Rejected but Would Serve," signed by J.W., is really a request for information. Inasmuch as thousands of young men have been rejected by the armed forces because of a physical impairment, probably an answer to J.W. will be welcomed by many others.

If Bucky Harris were of a mind to start proceedings, he could press charges of assault and battery against the Dodgers for what they did to three of his pitchers yesterday at Ebbets Field. The Philadelphia manager, with 4,465 persons as eyewitnesses, unquestionably would have a good case in any court of law in the land.

WASHINGTON, May 5 (AP) -- The War Department made public today the names of 473 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Asiatic, European, North African, Pacific and Southwest pacific areas. Action in North Africa accounted for the wounding of 422 of the men.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- The system of using zone numbers in addition to street addresses on mailed matter, now adopted in Canada and many large European cities, soon will be applied to the 178 largest cities of the United States, Postmaster General Walker announced today.

Nine days after "Uncle Harry" achieves its first year on Broadway, the Thomas Job melodrama, co-starring Eva Le Gallienne and Joseph Schildkraut, will end an honorable career May 29 at the Hudson. This was acknowledged yesterday by the office of Clifford Hayman, producer of the play in association with Lennie Hatten.

" Action is of utmost urgency and there is a narrow channel between the world of today and the world of tomorrow," Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES told members of the Women's Action Committee at a luncheon yesterday in Town Hall.
LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey asserted today that induction of fathers would be started in August "if not sooner" and subsequently Selective Service headquarters issued instructions under which fathers in the thirty-five listed essential industries might receive preferential deferment.

" Action is of utmost urgency and there is a narrow channel between the world of today and the world of tomorrow," Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick of the editorial staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES told members of the Women's Action Committee at a luncheon yesterday in Town Hall.
LONDON, May 5 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, May 5 (U.P.) -- Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey asserted today that induction of fathers would be started in August "if not sooner" and subsequently Selective Service headquarters issued instructions under which fathers in the thirty-five listed essential industries might receive preferential deferment.

ST. LOUIS, May 5 (AP) -- Manager Luke Sewell of the Browns tried a revamped line-up and before the game was over threw in four pitchers and three pinch-hitters in an effort to stop the ambitious Tigers today, but Detroit swept to its fourth consecutive triumph over St. Louis, 5 to 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 5 -- Margaret Sullavan, who has been out of pictures since "Back Street," produced in 1941, has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the role of Smitty in "Cry Havoc," the part which Merle Oberon relinquished because of illness.

Purchasing agents for the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation, headed by former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, have been operating in the men's clothing market, it was learned yesterday. It was asserted that a broadening of such buying would undoubtedly affect civilian supplies, which are tight but appear adequate from both the standpoint of fabrics and manufacturing facilities.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 5 -- American patrols drove through the town of Eddekhila, about twelve miles south of Mateur, today as the Germans apparently moved part of their forces from the naval base of Bizerte southward to Tebourba.

The job of collecting industrial scrap will not be finished until the war is over, Paul C. Cabot, director of the Salvage Division of the War Production Board, declared yesterday as chairman of the Industrial Salvage Committee for Greater New York met to launch their 1943 campaign which will stress collection of scrap copper, brass and bronze.

Another bureau chief in the Office of War Information has resigned. Like some of the earlier secessionists, he has gone to work for the Board of Economic Warfare. Normally, when a man throws up his job we take it as a matter of course that he goes to work for some other employer.

Herman Neuberger, 'who usually spends his time patrolling the outfield for City College, yesterday proved his versatility by going to the mound for the Beavers and administering a 6-to-1 defeat to Brooklyn College in the Kingsmen stadium.

Now that the Second War Loan Drive has reached a successful conclusion, investment bankers are looking forward to a revival of interest in corporate flotations. One of the first big issues to be brought out is the $20,500,000 loan for the Public Service Company of New Hampshire.

General Andrews died as he wished to die, in action. He may have been at the controls himself on that last flight with Bishop Leonard through the Iceland fog. If so, the plane had a skillful pilot. No American flier in the European command had a finer record in the air.

Price-fixing in the near months, induced by a growing belief that sales of cotton by the government will not exert an adverse effect on prices, brought moderate gains and more active trading in the cotton futures market yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts closed with net advances of 6 to 9 points.

Revision of the New York milk-marketing agreement to provide a minimum increase of 50 cents a hundredweight, or slightly more than 1 cent a quart, in the producer price of all Class 1 fluid milk has been asked of the Department of Agriculture by the Metropolitan Cooperative Milk Producers Bargaining Agency.

In the recent liquidation of the Work Projects Administration, with its enormous staff of workers, extending all over the country, there was a decided feeling of satisfaction by taxpayers, who have felt that it should long ago have been abolished.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, May 6 (AP) -- A small formation of Liberators wrecked a 5,000-ton cargo ship and possibly damaged two 500-ton vessels in a raid late Tuesday afternoon on Japan's North New Guinea feeder base of Wewak.

NEWARK, N.J., May 5 -- The mother of a prospective draftee, who allegedly walked into the offices of Local Draft Board 4 in West New York, N.J., yesterday and torn up papers concerning her son, was arraigned here today before United States Commissioner William J. Bartholomew and released in her own recognizance on a charge of having interfered with the operation of the Selective Service Act by use of force and violence.

The board of directors of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society has approved a contract with the United States Rubber Company for commercial sponsorship of the Philharmonic's Sunday afternoon concerts on the radio, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, May 5 -- American fliers have carried out nine more attacks against the Japanese on Kiska, in the Aleutians, and in the South Pacific four enemy bases have been blasted from the air, a Navy communique announced today.

BOSTON, May 6 -Pleased by the manner in which his Giants effected a quick about-face here after threatening to crash through the bottom of the National League, Manager Mel Ott set out for Philadelphia today confident that the forthcoming five-game series with the Phillies would lead to a berth in the first division for his club.

"Conservation is a subject of wide popular interest, many-sided and sometimes very dramatic," says Mrs. Rosalie Edge, chairman of the Emergency Conservation Committee in her organization's annual report.

Two young hoodlums who tried to rob a tenement flat at 83 Maujer Street in the Bushwick district of Brooklyn were thwarted yesterday by a housewife and her husband. One burglar was killed, accidental victim of his own pistol fire, and his partner was arrested.

AT ADVANCED AMERICAN HEADQUARTERS, Outside Mateur, May 5 (Delayed) -- Djebel Achkel lies like a clenched fist on a pleasant plain that leads to the wide still lake called Garaet Achkel. Capricious fates brought 600 Americans -- men from Texas, Arizona, New York, North Carolina and Pennsylvania to fight for Djebel Achkel.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 6 -- To Pete Ladislaw and Sylvester Gardiner of the Plandome Golf Club went the distinction today of being the first winners of the 1943 golf season on Long Island.

LONDON, Friday, May 7 -- Red Army troops have made new advances northeast of Novorossiisk in their offensive against the Axis Kuban bridgehead after breaking five German counter-attacks in a day of wild fighting, often at hand to hand, Russia's midnight communique reported.

Because motor trucks are wearing out much faster than they are being replaced, the nation is facing "a very critical situation" in highway transportation, Robert Cass, chief engineer of the White Motor Company, told the national transportation and maintenance meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

PESHAWAR, India, May 1 (delayed) -- Mohammed Ali Jinnah and his Moslem League have a hard fight before them to win this province, where the Moslems number 93 per cent of the population. In the long run, however, there can be little doubt that it will be theirs.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Bolivia is mobolizing her young men for work in the fields and the mines as her first step in practical cooperation in the war effort of the United Nations, General Enrique Penaranda, president of the republic, said at a press conference today.

WITH SOUTH PACIFIC FLEET, Feb. 27 (Delayed) -- With Guadalcanal cleared of all but a few bands of Japanese, another short step up the Solomons was taken by American forces who occupied the Russell Islands, a group that lies some twenty-five miles northwestward of Guadalcanal.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday exceeded the record volume set a fortnight ago and rose to the highest level for any week since the first week of 1931, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The total for the twenty-three leading cities was $10,097,762,000, or 40.6 per cent above the $7,183,035,000 for the corresponding week last year.

Lowell Leonard Naeve, who spent a year and a day in prison in his fight against war, carried his campaign to the psychopathic ward in Bellevue yesterday. He was sent there for mental observation by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe on the suggestion of United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa, although both judge and prosecutor agreed that the 24-year-old artist's condition probably was not caused by insanity.

Seven specific conditions under which an employer in an essential industry may grant a statement of availability to an employe and thereby permit him to transfer to another essential industry at a higher wage were listed yesterday by Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, in a statement clarifying the limited labor stabilization plan currently in force here.

Mrs. Elizabeth Campbell Lewis, who lives at the Hotel Plaza, yesterday obtained a summons against the Sherry-Netherland Hotel, charging failure to black out the hotel's lights during Wednesday night's test. It was issued by Magistrate William Klapp in Yorkville Court and is returnable on May 17.

One of next season's major events will be Gilbert Miller's presentation of Rose Franken's newest play, "Beyond the Farthest Star," a title Miss Franken happened to borrow from her own short story, published in the July, 1939, issue of Redbook.
MOSCOW, May 6 (AP) -- The noon communique:

We shall soon be addressing letters to Jones P. Jones, 22 West 413 Street, New York 37, or to Smith K. Smith, 11 Sixteenth Avenue, New York 3. The mysterious numerals after New York are the new delivery zones into which the United States Postoffice is dividing all big American cities.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics index of prices in primary markets moved up 0.1 per cent during the week ended on May 1, offsetting the decline of the preceding week. Prices were higher for fruits, vegetables and certain other foodstuffs, while most grains and cotton were lower.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Truman committee, reporting on its investigation of the priorities conflicts in the synthetic rubber, aviation gasoline and destroyer escort ship programs, told the Senate today that the basic faults lay in the weaknesses in the control of the war effort.

Charges that the Young Communist League is trying to "capture" the first national conference of the United States Student Assembly, to be held here today, tomorrow and Sunday, were made yesterday by Irene Murray, general secretary of the organization.

Joe Cronin may not have the best pitchers in the league, but he has the most generous ones. Yesterday, Mace Brown of the Red Sex made the day perfect for 9,985 fans at the Stadium's double-header, handing the Yankees their second victory of the afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- The mother of Mother's Day, a frail little spinster who resembles Whistler's Mother, urged today that her countrymen wear war stamp flowers this year instead of the traditional carnation.

MOUNT CLEMENS, Mich., May 6 -- Colonel William T. Colman, air base commander at Selfridge Field, was under arrest and observation in the Army Hospital at Battle Creek today after the shooting early yesterday morning of Private William McRae.

In the midst of the prolonged and heated controversy that has arisen over the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan, the nature of the withholding tax that is now scheduled to go into effect on July 1 has been largely overlooked. The fact that Republicans, Democrats and sponsors of the numberless compromise pay-as-you-go plans all took over the committee withholding tax without question has led to the mistaken belief that the proposed withholding tax is a good one.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Leon Henderson, the country's first price and rationing administrator who relinquished his post last December after members of Congress had demanded his removal because of the Administration's setbacks in the last election, has taken a post with private industry, he said here today.

Former Representative Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, yesterday pictured Philip J. Dunn, a lawyer credited with great political influence during the leadership of John F. Curry, with being the major force back of the committee to reorganize the Democratic party of New York County, which seeks to oust him from the leadership and divorce the local Democratic organization from the Tammany society.

A taxpayer's action has been started to oust George H. Chatfield, newly appointed Queens member of the Board of Education, who resigned from his $12,500 post as director of the attendance bureau to take this non-paying position, it became known yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Commission house buying of wheat futures gave the market for that grain a firm undertone today on the Board of Trade, and while professional traders sold at times they were forced to cover short sales late in the session and the close was about the top, with gains of 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel. May sold at the highest price since late in March.

John Hersey, author of "Into the Valley," published by Knopf, and Carlos P. Romulo, author of "I Saw the Fall of the Philippines," will be guests on the "Fighting Words" program commemorating the fall of Corregidor on May 6, 1942, over WMCA tomorrow at 6:45 P.M.
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- A famous father-and-son pair of soldiers. Brig. Gen. Theodore Roosevelt and Captain Quentin Roosevelt, was cited today by the Army for gallantry in action in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Committee on American History issued a statement today suggesting a plan for reformation of the teaching of American history in high schools. It was urged that high school students as freshmen should have a full year of the history of the United States.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 6 -- A partial relaxation of police and military restrictions in Sofia today brought about no lessening of the tension in the Bulgarian capital, according to late reports received here tonight.

Motion picture camera crews of the Army Air Forces are taught to shoot with machine guns as well as cameras before going aloft on combat missions and at least three camera men have been credited with shooting down enemy planes, it was disclosed yesterday at the closing sessions of the Society of Motion Picture Engineers fifty-third semi-annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The adjourned special meeting of the stockholders of the Creole Petroleum Corporation was adjourned again yesterday with the understanding that it would be reconvened toward the end of this month. It had been called to act upon the proposed consolidation of Creole and the Lago Petroleum Corporation.

For the second time in four weeks, the New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, on a weekly reporting day, showed not only no excess reserves but an actual deficiency in reserves required to be kept with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Premier Joseph Stalin's desire for a "strong and independent" Poland, expressed in his letter yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent in Moscow, should smooth the way toward more friendly relations with Yugoslavia and generally reassure those States in Russia's broad orbit where Moscow's breach with the Polish Government had caused alarm, in the opinion of diplomatic circles here that are in close touch with Europe.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, May 7 (AP) -- The noon communique:
BOBO NEWSOM rubbed his jaw tenderly. "I've had a tooth pulled and it interferes with my talking," said the large and amiable Dodger pitcher. "And when I can't talk I'm very seriously handicapped."

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -- Just three years ago General Jacob L. Devers, then a colonel, was jumped over 474 other colonels to become a brigadier general. Today, an energetic, athletic man known for having one of the broadest grins in the Army, he is the country's youngest lieutenant general.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Disapproval of the Interstate Commerce Commission's ruling relating to the Rock Island Lines because it did not take into consideration the improved earnings of debtor roads under wartime conditions was expressed by E.N. Brown, chairman of the board, in the annual report distributed today to stockholders at the company's annual meeting.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Abbey Theatre the attraction will be "At Dawn We Die," a British film about the French underground, which is released here through Republic Pictures. Featured in the production are John Clements, Godfrey Tearle, Hugh Sinclair, Greta Gynt and Judy Kelly. . . .

Two M-4 General Sherman tanks, brought to New York City in connection with the Army Ordinance display at the Chrysler Building, lumbered along prearranged routes yesterday and took up positions in Times Square and at the Sherman statue in the Grand Army Plaza, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

Alluring flattery was the keynote of the Millinery Fashion Inspiration showing of Summer hats presented by three outstanding designers, Lilly Dache, Sally Victor and John-Frederics, yesterday at luncheon on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 6 (U.P.) -- A special communique:

The Loudon Packing Company, Terre Haute, Ind., has called a special meeting of stockholders on May 21 to vote on a proposal to authorize sale of all the company's assets, except cash on hand and in banks and claims for tax refunds to Standard Brands, Inc., and to take action on a resolution voted by directors last month to dissolve the company on the consummation of the sale.

Doubling of the original advertising budget to $500,000 for the film "Mission to Moscow" has been decided upon by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Charles Einfeld, director of advertising. At least 80 per cent of the funds will be spent in newspapers, including religious publications and foreign-language papers.

The extent to which post-war economic reconstruction progresses in the United States will determine the solution of economic problems "in the world as a whole," Dr. H.C. Coombs, director general of Post-War Reconstruction in Australia, declared yesterday in addressing the 175th annual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York held in its building at 65 Liberty Street.
NEW DELHI, India, May 6 (AP) A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

WENDELL WILLKIE went to Egypt and Iran, Russia and China, and wrote a short and simple book about what he learned. Prodigious numbers of his fellow-Americans are clamoring to read it. Eve Curie went to the same places, and to India and Burma, too, and has written an immense and comprehensive book about the world at war.

WITH THE BRITISH FORCES, Near Tebourba, May 6 (AP) -- Tank-supported British infantrymen broke through Axis defenses for four miles on the main road from Medjez-el-Bab to Tunis today after capturing Djebel bou Aoukaz, a key height overlooking the Medjerda River Valley. An Axis counter-attack was repelled.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 6 -- New light on the roles of Robert D. Murphy, Civil Affairs Officer on the staff of General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of Allied Forces in North Africa; General Maxime Weygand, former French pro-consul, and General Henri Honore Giraud, in the North African landing, came today from the French officer, Major Gen. Charles Mast.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A revised version of a report submitted by the WPB's program committee last January to guide the war agency in assessing the needs of the civilian population has been turned over to the newly created Civilian Requirements Division of WPB.

CHICAGO, May 6 (AP) -Hi Bithorn, the Cubs' Puerto Rican right-hander, smothered the Cardinals for the second time in eight days today, 5 to 1, as Chicago captured the series two games to one. It was the season's third victory for the big right-hander.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- "Petting" and "pampering" of Japanese internees in Western camps managed by the War Relocation Administration, Senator Robertson of Wyoming told the Senate today, had led to conditions which might become dangerous.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Following is the text of the Connally Anti-Strike Bill as passed by the Senate yesterday:

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- During the week ended May 5 member bank reserve balances decreased $240,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $90,000,000 in money in circulation, $279,00,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $11,000,000 in Treasury cash and $61,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by increases of $195,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $5,000,000 in Treasury currency.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, May 7 (U.P.) -- In a surprise attack, Allied troops have occupied the village of Bobdubi, only five miles south-southwest of the Japanese base of Salamaua, thus threatening the enemy supply line to Mubo, General Douglas MacArthur's headquarters reported in the noon communique today.

A man and a woman and two Florida land promotion corporations were found guilty in Federal Court yesterday of mail fraud, violation of the Securities Exchange Act and conspiracy. The jury acquitted one defendant and failed to reach agreement as to another and was discharged by Judge Henry W. Goddard at 12:50 P.M., twenty-four hours after beginning deliberations.

The German radio yesterday for the first time reported the existence of huge concrete anti-aircraft gun towers as a major part of Berlin's defenses against air raids and said they could house gun crews of 200 and provide shelter for large numbers of civilians.

JERUSALEM, May 5 (Delayed)--The Allies are making steadfast efforts not to upset Middle Eastern economy any further than military operations necessitate. Huge convoys constantly bring in food as well as military supplies to ease the burden of local producers.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The House received today the Connally anti-strike bill, which passed the Senate yesterday by a 63 to 16 vote, and referred it to the Committee on Military Affairs.

Evidence that the State Department of Labor ignored repeated complaints against a compensation clinic, even "protected" it, and charges that a deputy commissioner "whitewashed" the case of an accused doctor were brought out yesterday at the Moreland investigation into the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law.
NEW DELHI, India, May 6 (U.P.) -- American airmen on Tuesday dropped more than thirty tons of bombs on the Japanese-held Sittang River center of Toungoo in Burma, it was announced today.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to accept as a gift from Sailors Snug Harbor, for use as a city park the 9.2 acres of land in Staten Island that it accepted in 1941 and then rejected after Mayor La Guardia had accused the would-be donor of seeking to dodge taxes and maintenance charges by turning the property over to the city.

BALTIMORE, May 6 (AP) -- Allen T. Simmons's Blue Swords, who finished second to Count Fleet in the Kentucky Derby last week and is expected to do the same in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, had his first workout today for the $50,000 added Pimlico race.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 6 (AP) -- Our fighting men are winning their battles on the military front, but the home front is not yet winning its battles, Roane Waring, national commander of the American Legion, told a public meeting here tonight in reporting on his recent North African tour.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Proposing a seven-point program for government and industry to allow for full post-war use of all the nation's natural resources, Frederick C. Crawford, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, today urged President Roosevelt to make a "Churchill-like" statement to reassure industry of the continuance of the private enterprise system.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 -- Harvard, which has lost Head Coach Dick Harlow, most of his ranking gridiron aides and Athletic Director William J. Bingham to the armed services, today announced suspension of intercollegiate football for the duration.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Office of Price Administration disclosed today measures to wipe out the black market in potatoes, but simultaneously admitted that it had approved a rise in bread prices in one State and two cities in the West.

Walter Rothschild, president and general manager of Abraham Straus, Inc., Brooklyn, was elected president of the Retail Research Association and the Associated Merchandising Corporation at the meeting yesterday of the board of directors at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Targe became the first four-time winner of the Jamaica meeting yesterday when he took the track at the start of the Flushing Purse and had three lengths to spare at the end of a mile and a sixteenth. It meant a perfect record for the son of Swashbuckler at the Metropolitan Jockey Club course, where racing will end tomorrow with the $15,000 added Grey Lag Handicap.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, chief of the armored force, recognized as one of the hard-driving, aggressive general officers of the United States Army, will succeed the late Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews as commander in the European theatre of operations, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson announced today.
LONDON, Friday, May 7 (U.P.) -- The Russian Thursday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
ROCHESTER, May 6 (AP) -- With Sylvester (Blix) Donnelly hurling six-hit bail, the Rochester Red Wings turned back the champion Newark Bears, 5 to 2, before a! home opening crowd of 10,941 today.

EDMONTON, Alberta, May 6 (Canadian Press) -- The Edmonton Bulletin in a copyright newspage story today said Solon Low, Provincial Treasurer, and W.A. Fallow, Minister of Public Works, are leaving immediately for New York and Ottawa to discuss refunding of Alberta's $140,899,000 public debt and "other financial matters."

IN THE MEDJERDA VALLEY, Tunisia, May 6--The pounding of hundreds of guns and bombings by seemingly endless formations of heavy bombers ushered in today's heavy British attack; the second phase of the Allies' offensive against the Tunisian bridgehead of the Axis had started.

Details about the operation and plans of the armed services' college training programs were given last night by General Joseph N. Dalton, director of Army training, and Captain Herbert W. Underwood, U.S.N., administrator of the training program for Waves, at the annual dinner of the American College Publicity Association, which began a three-day convention yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker.

LONDON, May 6 (U.P.) -- Fighting French headquarters, pressing for French unity parleys in Algiers despite objections of General Henri Honore Giraud, today sought to reassure him against possible embarrassing demonstrations there in behalf of General Charles de Gaulle.
NEW DELHI, India, May 6 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 6 (U.P.) -- Ten Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee assailed tonight the Reciprocal Trades Act as wholly inadequate to deal with post-war foreign-trade problems and demanded a Congressional investigation of the entire question.

The National Urban League, an organization for social service among Negroes, reports wider interracial cooperation during the past year, and room for more. The Negro, like any other American, wants to take part in the war to the limit of his abilities. He has certainly found need for his services.

LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- The Moscow radio broadcast a statement today by Andrey Y. Vishinsky, Deputy Commissar of Foreign Affairs, reiterating Russian assertions that the Polish Government in London was "under the influence of pro-Hitlerite elements" and declaring that Polish officials, press and radio were continuing to circulate false statements concerning relations with Russia.

ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -- Harold B. Fell, executive vice president of the Independent Petroleum Association of America, today denounced Price Administrator Prentiss Brown's action in denying an increase in prices for crude petroleum as "contrary to the advice of every agency and group in the United States that has knowledge of the petroleum industry."

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- Senator Lucas of Illinois, who was a member of the United States delegation to the recent international refugee conference in Bermuda, criticized on the Senate floor today an advertisement concerning the conference which he said was inserted in THE NEW YORK TIMES Tuesday by the Committee for a Jewish Army of Stateless and Palestinian Jews.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Department store sales declined 5 per cent in the week ended May 1 as compared with sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This decline followed a gain of 29 per cent in the week ended April 24 over the corresponding period of last year.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 6--From scores of North African airdromes hundreds upon hundreds of Allied bombers and trim fighters, some of them also bearing bombs, sped through the air today on 2,000 sorties over Tunisia and the Sicilian Strait pounding mercilessly at the harassed, retreating Axis forces and supply lines in the second day of a great new aerial blitz that has achieved "complete air domination."

Down in the heart of the fur district, in one of the most crowded sections of Seventh Avenue, is a small, almost shabby, shop with a sales record of War Bonds and Stamps higher than almost any other in the city. Just one of the hundreds of small shops along Seventh Avenue, it is distinguished only by the War Savings posters and pictures in the window and the red and blue sign over the door.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 -- Behind the seven-hit pitching of freshman Ed Gniewek, Pennsylvania defeated Columbia on River Field today, 10 -- 3, and took undisputed leadership in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. The Red and Blue had been tied with Cornell for first place.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 6 (AP) -- Premier Sir Basil Brooke today named two former Cabinet colleagues as members of his new Northern Ireland Government, which also includes two Presbyterian ministers and the first Labor representative the government has had in twenty-two years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 6 -- Dudley Nichols, who is under a producer-writer contract at RKO, will make his debut as a director on the lot in "Government Girl," Adela Rogers St. John's story of wartime Washington in which Olivia de Haviland will be starred. The picture starts on May 24.
CHUNGKING, China, May 6 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Civilian textile needs will suffer further as a result of the OPA's announcement that the President's "hold-the-line" order means no price increase in yarns and textiles can be sanctioned, Worth Street suppliers declared yesterday.

The three-day business meeting of the National Federation of Music Clubs opened yesterday morning at the Biltmore Hotel with some 300 delegates from thirty-four States attending. The meeting, substituted for the organization's biennial convention because of war conditions was the first to be held in this city during the thirty years of the federation's existence.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Restrictions on the sale of used and rebuilt sewing machines and clothing manufacturing machinery were partially relaxed today by the War Production Board. As a result, used and rebuilt industrial sewing machines may be sold, leased or rented without restriction if their sale price when new did not exceed $175 as of Oct. 1, 1941.

WASHINGTON, May 6--In the absence of John L. Lewis and other officials of the United Mine Workers Union, spokesmen for the bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian region today resumed presentation of their case to a National War Labor Board panel.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- A grave shortage of nurses threatens military and civilian health, Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, told a public health subcommittee of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee today.

Governor Thomas E. Dewey, in urging yesterday the five States bordering New York to follow New York's action in giving Office of Price Administration regulations the force of State laws, met with cool responses from Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey and Governor William N. Wills of Vermont.

Shopping becomes simplified when everything one needs, from lingerie to topcoats, is offered on one floor. This is precisely what Wanamaker's have done with their new budget floor in the fashion store which opens to the public this morning.

A decision to hold its three championships this year at the Lake Placid Club during the same week in July was announced yesterday by the New York State Golf Association. The Metropolitan Golf Association also released its schedule, but its plans are more ambitious, ten tournaments from late this month to mid-September, making up the list.

The importance of contract renegotiation in the stock market was emphasized yesterday in a letter sent by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, to the presidents of listed corporations. He asked that "a notice be sent to stockholders as soon as the revised results of operations have been determined," even when the change in earnings is relatively small.

MOSCOW, May 6 -- Premier Joseph Stalin's letter to me was typed on a single sheet of plain white paper of foolscap shape without heading or watermark. Also it bore no address to denote where it was written.

Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon gave a luncheon yesterday in the Persian Room of the Plaza. Her guests were Mrs. James Lees Laidlaw, Princess Irbain-Khan Kaplanoff, Mrs. Robert Ogden Bacon, Mrs. Haliburton Fales, Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, Princess Alexis Obolensky, Mrs. Graeme Donald, Mrs. George H. Hull and Mrs. Eliot Tuckerman.

Dean Hawkes's influence at Columbia University, as immeasurably beneficent as it will always be unforgettable to all who worked with him, was the gift of a fine mind implemented by a truly great character. His liberal and broadly humane ideas stimulated one's thought, but what won one's admiring affection was his quiet, utterly unpretentious, dryly humorous and warmly friendly personality.

Because of lack of trained examiners many men have been inducted into the armed forces who cannot stand up under war strain, Dr. Ernest Sachs of St. Louis declared yesterday morning in the presidential address at the opening session of the annual meeting of the American Neurological Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Wendell Willkie was honored yesterday by the Council on Books in Wartime with the naming of his book, "One World," as the council's new "imperative" for wartime reading.

While the title Lord Chief Justice is only seventy years old, his is one of the most venerable of British posts and can be traced back under another name to the Norman kings. While the Lord Chancellor is technically superior, his is only a political and temporary office. Hewart took the usual route to one office or the other.

Renewed threats of the Office of Price Administration to impose a ceiling on cotton as soon as the average price at the ten designated spot centers in the South reaches 21.38 cents a pound, the price at which the government is releasing some of its holdings, dampened sentiment in the cotton futures market yesterday.

Former Dodgers or Dodger farm hands still are giving Lippy Leo Durocher headaches. Yesterday Babe Dahlgren singled across the tying run in the eighth inning at Ebbets Field and in the tenth Glenn Stewart, recently affiliated with Montreal, walloped a three-bagger that gave the Phillies a 3-2 triumph and an even break in the four-game series.

The fruit situation is not so good as it was in previous Springs, reports Mrs. Frances Foley Gannon, director of the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets. Shipments of Louisiana strawberries total less than a third of what they did last year at this time, because had weather has held back the crop.

Believed to be the first woman ever to be indicted in this city on such a charge, Mrs. Belle DeMarco, 44 years old, owner of a midtown beauty shop, will be arraigned in General Sessions today on eight counts of compulsory prostitution.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 6 -- Paced by hundreds of bombers and fighter planes and supported by thousands of guns, massed United States and British divisions struck today for Bizerte and Tunis. By midafternoon the British had captured Massicault, only fifteen and a half miles from Tunis and the pivot of the whole Tunis position.

The six-day week which Secretary Ickes has ordered in the coal mines means a 30 per cent increase in the weekly pay of the miners as compared with that for a five-day week. This means a 30 per cent increase in wages for only a 20 per cent increase in hours, and perhaps for a much smaller increase in the output of coal.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Chester C. Davis, War Food Administrator, reported today that "a current appraisal of the farm labor situation indicates that there is an available labor supply sufficient to produce and harvest a 1943 crop up to the levels of the announced goals."

LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England, issued today, reported a new high record for notes in circulation totaling 953,938,000, but the gain over the previous week, 526,000, was the smallest shown in more titan three months.

Five thousand motion-picture films made between 1897 and 1917, and subsequently lost, will be restored for those who care to see them if the Library of Congress carries through a project just announced by Howard L. Walls, curator of the Library's new film collection. For many years film producers printed copies of their silent dramas on paper and copyrighted them as a series of separate photographs.

LONDON, May 6 -- William J. Thorne, Laborite, implied in a question he submitted in the House of Commons today that Frau Rudolf Hess had joined her husband in England. Herr Hess, Adolf Hitler's deputy, has been a prisoner in England since his mysterious flight to Scotland from Germany in 1941.

OTTAWA, May 6 -- Canada's mutual aid plan for the provision of $1,000,000,000 worth of food, arms and ammunition to other members of the United Nations was introduced into the House of Commons today by Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley.

John A. Brown, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in a report to employes, stated yesterday that the company's payroll last year approximated $97,800,000 and that it paid or made provision for paying $71,500,000 to the government in taxes, not including the $69,000,000 in gasoline taxes collected for the States.

Surrogate James A. Foley named Irving Bowdoin Kingsford of Bernardsville, N.J., yesterday as temporary administrator of the $1,500,000 estate left by Miss Edith G. Bowdoin, daughter of the late George Sullivan Bowdoin, a member of J.P. Morgan Co.

The United States of the early days of its independence and of today when it is fighting for the Four Freedoms met in the gift shop gallery on the second floor of Bonwit Teller yesterday afternoon. It was an interesting conceit that brought together early American paintings with sophisticated American clothes.

The Board of Transportation voted unanimously yesterday, at the request of Mayor La Guardia, to permit John H. Delaney, chairman of the Board of Transportation, to continue in service until June 20, 1945, despite the fact that he reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 on June 20, 1941.

The joint plan of Park Commissioner Robert Moses and the New York Zoological Society to construct a $1,502,000 oceanarium at Coney Island to replace the Aquarium at Battery Park, received a temporary setback yesterday when the Board of Estimate first votes down a resolution to appropriate money for plans and designs and then laid the matter over until its June 11 meeting.

Success in integrating Negroes in war work in New York State was reported yesterday by the State Committee on Discrimination, which found in a recent survey that while total employment in war industry had risen 7 per cent during the last year, Negro employment had increased 366 per cent.

The same shock troops of budget economy who stormed the Board of Estimate hearings last month in a vain effort to obtain reductions in Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $573,071,123 for 1943-44 renewed their assault yesterday at a public hearing before the finance committee of the City Council.

Favorable response to men's Spring neckwear offerings by retailers was reported in the market yesterday. In some instances reorders were starting to be received by manufacturers. Washable types have not reached the sales tempo which was anticipated, but it is believed that they will show an increase as the season progresses.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Director Elmer Davis of the Office of War Information said today there is "no question but that there will be allied operations on Continental Europe this Summer."

Earnings of Paramount Pictures, Inc., for the first quarter of 1943 are estimated at $3,560,000, after all charges, including an estimated provision for Federal taxes, according to a statement by the company yesterday. The amount includes $701,000 from Paramount's direct and indirect interest in the earnings of partially owned nonconsolidated subsidiaries.

Ignoring the plea of a lawyer for the release of Norman Jackson, 17 years old, on a suspended sentence, Judge John J. Freschi yesterday in General Sessions committed the youth to Elmira Reformatory on his conviction last month under the name of Norman Smith, in the attempted rape and felonious assault on Miss Gladys Kaurin, 23, a night club singer.

Volunteer men and women serving as "price aides" will form an integral part of the neighborhood price panels which will be set up Monday under the ration board of each borough to familiarize retailers and consumers with the community price ceilings which go into effect Monday morning, OPA officials reported yesterday.

LONDON, May 6 -- Very few changes in prices were recorded today on the stock markets, for although the tone was steady, business was restricted. Gilt-edge stocks gave way, both War Loans losing 1-16 each and old Consols 3-16.

"We cannot divorce the domestic food problem from that of the rest of the world," Francis Flood, in charge of Food Lend-Lease at the British Embassy, Washington, said yesterday at the closing luncheon of the Garden Club of America's thirtieth annual meeting in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, May 6 (U.P.) -- The four-motored Liberator bomber in which Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews and thirteen others were killed on an Icelandic hillside Monday night had become lost from its guiding radio beam and was flying in weather that limited visibility to forty feet, the sole survivor of the crash said tonight.

While a War Labor Board panel in Washington began hearings in the soft coal dispute between the United Mine Workers and operators of the Appalachian region, with the union continuing to ignore repeated invitations to appear, the conflict between the miners and the Administration resolved itself yesterday into a war of nerves.

The island of Funafuti, one of the Ellice group, was revealed yesterday as the place to which Navy planes took Captain Eddie Rickenbacker and his companions after they had spent twenty-one days on life rafts in the South Pacific. The disclosure was made by Colonel Hans Christian Adamson, who was Captain Rickenbacker's aide on the flight and one of his companions on the raft.

The annual report of the Brill Corporation and underlying companies, announced yesterday, showed for 1942 a net profit of $1,894,436 after deductions of $5,434,300 for State, Federal income and excess profits taxes.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The Treasury announced today a change in procedure in bidding for the weekly issue of Treasury bills in order to distribute these securities more widely.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The North African campaign apparently "is entering its final phase" and "the noose is tightening around the Axis army," Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson declared at his press conference here today.

Domei, the Japanese news agency, transmitted an English version of a speech delivered by Premier Hideki Tojo in Manila yesterday in which he said Japan was now ready to deliver "a thorough and crushing blow at the enemy's armed power."

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Unless President Roosevelt's "hold the line" order of April 8 is made "workable," the labor members of the War Labor Board are prepared to resign, according to a report today following a conference between the board members and James F. Byrnes, director of the Office of Economic Stabilization.

Continuing its drive to wipe out black markets in meat, the Office of Price Administration barred yesterday the Strauss Packing Company of 595 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, from dealing in rationed meat for one year, beginning June 1.
The German Thursday communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- The text of the report of Chester C. Davis, Food Administrator, to James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, on the farm outlook, follows:

Furniture store sales in the Second Federal Reserve District during March were off 12 per cent from the 1942 month, and in New York City showed a decline of 7 per cent for the period, it was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
CLEVELAND, May 6 (AP) -- Five White Sox hurlers paraded before the Indians today and were hammered for twelve hits as the Tribe took a 6-to-3 victory to end the series.

The Metropolitan Opera will extend its 1943-44 season four weeks to last for twenty weeks instead of sixteen as in the last few years, it was announced yesterday. The new season will begin on Monday evening, Nov. 22, and will run through April 8, 1944.

The Metropolitan Collegiate Conference game between City College and St. John's at Lewisohn Stadium started yesterday with Jerry Reisel throwing ten straight balls, and just before it ended, he left the mound after walking three, giving a double, making a wild pitch and a bad throw to first.

Former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer of the Appellate Division, who was recently elected president of the American Jewish Committee, urged Americans last night to unite in taking a forthright stand against those Nazi-like persons who spread the virus of racial hatred in this country.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 6 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants pounded out a 15-to-4 victory over Buffalo today before an opening-day crowd of 12,500. It was the Bisons' eighth straight defeat.

The varied types of assistance which the regional appeals office of the War Production Board gives to manufacturers were cited yesterday by the regional office in a review of its first year of existence. The office was set up on May 5, 1942, and had only one WPB order to occupy its attention, M-126, which curtailed and prohibited use of iron and steel in specified items.

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- One day of speedy action by the Senate Finance Committee was enough to indicate a strong tendency to substitute a simpler pay-as-you-go provision, along the lines of the Ruml plan, for the relatively complicated partial tax abatement parts of the Forand bill, which the House adopted by 313 to 95 on Tuesday.

On May 3 you published an editorial, "What Is Civilian Defense?" which was prompted by an issue of the Consumer's Wartime Digest, published by the Manhattan Consumers Service Division of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

Prices on the stock markets broke yesterday through previous peaks to close at the highest levels since Nov. '18, 1940, despite a moderate amount of liquidation which unsettled the list toward mid-day. On the average, additions were around a point, with some issues exceeding this mark, while the volume on the Stock Exchange, again because of a full sized burst of trading in the final hour, continued above the 2,000,000-share pace.

LONDON, May 6 -- Premier Joseph Stalin's letter expressing a desire for friendship with a "strong and independent Poland" after the war and Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski's prompt declaration that Poland also wished friendship with Russia were regarded in authoritative circles in London today as indications that there was still good cause to believe that the breach that Nazi propaganda drove between the two countries could be healed.
With interest centering largely in multi-family buildings, realty activity in Manhattan yesterday covered a wide area. Savings banks and an insurance company were among the sellers.

ALBANY, May 6 -- New York State and its location face a revenue loss of more that $10,000,000 in the current fiscal year unless the existing procedure of renegotiating Federal war contracts is changed, Rollin Browne, president of the State Tax Commission, warned today.

America will face a wave of post-war isolationism based upon a general feeling of insecurity unless soldiers coming home find jobs, Dr. George Dinsmore Stoddard, New York State Commissioner of Education, said yesterday at exercises commemorating City College's ninety-sixth anniversary.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) -The Athletics mauled two Washington pitchers for 11 hits today and walloped the Senators, 7 to 0. Roger Wolff became the first Athletics' pitcher of the season to hurl a shut-out.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 6 (AP) -- The names of sixteen American airmen released from interment in Turkey were announced today, the day after their arrival here.

As the Allied armies chase the Axis forces to the ever-narrowing beaches of Tunisia the Russians are pushing them out of their last strongholds in the Caucasus. The two most active battlefields of the moment are more than 2,000 miles apart as the eagle flies, but the terrain, the tactics and the character of the fighting are curiously alike.

The regional Office of Price Administration here denied yesterday that tavern operators in this area had been invited to the two-day conference opening in Washington today on the proposed new wholesale and retail liquor pricing regulation.
ST. LOUIS, May 6 (AP) -The Browns broke the Detroit jinx today, pushing over a run in the ninth to beat the Tigers, 1 to 0, for the first time in five games this season.
WASHINGTON, May 6 -- President Roosevelt's visitors included the President of Bolivia, the new Colombian Ambassador, the new Costa Rican Ambassador, George McCullough and Robert E. Sherwood:

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Length of continuous service in Congress determines who shall be the chairmen of its committees. A new member, or even one who has served two or three terms, may be ideally constituted for an important chairmanship. But by the workings of the seniority system he will find himself near the bottom of the list, subject to the committee power of a man of far lesser competence.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has sold six two-family houses in Brooklyn to the Frandix Corporation through Hayes Goldfarb, brokers. They are located at 4111 Bedford Avenue, 1524 East Twenty-fourth Street and 1564, 1568, 1570, and 1572 West Eighth Street.

CHICAGO, May 6 -- Henry A. Dinegar, chief of the durable goods branch in the WPB's Office of Civilian Requirements, declared today that production for the military and output of so-called "rock-bottom" needs for civilians must be kept on a par, since both are equally essential to the war program.

Secretary of State Cordell Hull will open on June 5 a special series of radio programs believed to be "the most outstanding general statement of the problems which will confront the country in connection with the peace," it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) -- With the Republican minority in temporary control, the House refused today to agree to two Senate changes in the Treasury-Post Office Appropriations Bill and registered again its opposition to the government's silver purchase program.

LONDON, May 6 -- After hearing of the appalling flight of children in two occupied European countries, a London conference of maternity and child-welfare experts framed a resolution asking that the British Government grant immediate facilities not inimical to the war effort for the transport of food to these children.

The $13,000,000,000 Second War Loan, although already oversubscribed by more than $5,000,000,000, did not produce enough of "the kind of money that is burning a hole in Mr. America's pants pockets,'' William M. Robbins, chairman of the United States Treasury Department's War Finance Committee, declared yesterday in warning against "undue satisfaction" at results.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 6 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, May 7 (U.P.) -- Fighting French headquarters said tonight that it was considered "more necessary and urgent than ever" that General Charles de Gaulle and several members of his French National Committee go to Algiers without delay to confer on French unity.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee received a detailed report today from the Chandler subcommittee which investigated conditions in Japanese relocation camps in seven Western States.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 7 (AP) -- General Henri Giraud announced tonight the appointment of General Charles Mast as Resident General of France in Tunisia. General Alphonse Juin, commander of French troops in the field, will serve as Resident General until the arrival of General Mast.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- While thirteen witnesses testified at a Senate committee's hearing on legislation to make nursing as attractive as women's new military organizations, the Office of War Information entered the campaign today for more nurse power by reminding girls who answer the country's call for student nurses that they are releasing other women for the front.

Affected by the generally favorable tenor of the war news, the cotton futures market declined moderately in late trading yesterday as price-fixing failed to absorb the increased hedging. At the close active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 13 points below Thursday's last quotations, with the near months relatively stronger than the distant.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Workers in the Philadelphia area will be put under the forty-eight-hour week by July 1 as a means of achieving the most effective use of manpower in the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Delaware region, it was declared today by Wesley T. Englehorn, acting regional director of the War Manpower Commission.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 7 -- President Vargas publicly acknowledged today that, except for United States financing and "the friendly intervention of President Roosevelt," Brazil would not today be on the way to the manufacture of steel.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- United States citizens who are prisoners of war and are interned in Germany and Italy may be sent cigarettes and tobacco every two months starting next Monday under a plan announced today by the War Production Board.

SELFRIDGE FIELD, Mich., May 7 (AP) -- A second shooting, the wounding of a civilian by a sentry, occurred at Selfridge Field today, less than twenty-four hours after the disclosure that the former commanding officer of this Army air base, Colonel William T. Colman, had been arrested following the wounding of a Negro private.

The business building at 1052-1058 Thirty-eight Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the J.S. Gould Son's Company to the Denross Company, through the Chauncey Realty Company. The sale was made subject to a mortgage of $12,187. The property is assessed at $23,000. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

The Yankees met the Athletics yesterday for the first time this year and the result was what might reasonably have been expected. Inspired by the clubbing of Bill Johnson, Newark graduate, and the pitching of Charley Wensloff, refugee righthander from Kansas City, the champions smothered Connie Mack's crew, 6 to 2, at the Stadium.

The majority of the retail liquor package store operators in this area favor early closing as a means of conserving their limited stocks, and more than 85 per cent of all the dealers here will have acted to shorten their store hours beginning on Monday, the Metropolitan Package Store Association reported yesterday.
In recent months we have read and heard frequently of baseball's value as a source of entertainment and as a morale builder for our men in the armed forces.

So the ODT has cracked down on bus-traveling racing fans by ordering a halt in the use of extra vehicles accommodating Jamaica track customers. What a laugh! Evidently only railroad patrons are entitled to "relief" from congestion.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 7 -- Tunis and Bizerte, last main Axis strongholds in Africa, were captured today by British and American forces just 181 days after the Allied landing in North Africa.

The Childs Company was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien to pay to two holders of debentures the full face value of their holdings of the company's unpaid 1943 debentures, which the company has asked holders to exchange for a new issue due in 1957.

Tomorrow will be Mother's Day, with a special significance this year because so many mothers of the nation have sent sons to fight for freedom in distant parts of the world. To millions of American mothers will come from their sons in uniform, in factory overalls and business suit, messages, flowers and other gifts in token of love and gratitude felt because of years of protective care.

Stockholders of the Edward G. Budd Manufacturing Company will be asked at an adjourned annual meeting, to be held in Philadelphia on July 13, to approve a proposal for the refinancing of the 7 per cent preferred stock on which dividend accumulations now total $87.50 a share.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 7 (AP) -- A communique:

All yesterday afternoon and all last night the news of an Allied victory came over the air and along the cables. Thousands of words, written to the thunder of guns and the roar of falling bombs, built up the picture, detail by detail, of the advance of the Allied troops and the occupation of Bizerte and Tunis.

GUADALCANAL, May 3 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese seaplane base at Rekata Bay on Santa Isabel Island was pulverized today in a coordinated raid by Army, Navy and Marine Corps planes that leveled a portion of the target with 2,000-pound daisy cutter bombs.

In all this talk of wages and hours -- rate per hour, $2 more per day, and weeks worked per annum -- practically nothing is read or heard about two basic essentials from the point of view of the workingman and his family, from the point of view of the employer, and, most important of all, from the point of view of the general public.

The Book Publishers Bureau announces that a dinner will be held by the book trade on May 18 at the Hotel Astor for Walter Harrap, Geoffrey Faber and G. Wren Howard, British publishers now visiting in this country, under the joint sponsorship of the British Ministry of Information and the Office of War Information.

At the victory concert given by the National Federation of Music Clubs for its War Service Fund last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Nan Merriman, 23-year-old mezzo-soprano, of Cincinnati, Ohio, was announced as the only winner of a $1,000 award in the organization's biennial Young Artists Auditions held earlier this week at the Biltmore Hotel.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 7 -- Asserting that the New Deal bureaucracy was seeking to perpetuate itself by the re-election of President Roosevelt for a fourth term, Harrison E. Spangler, Republican National Chairman, called on the President tonight to contribute to national unity in prosecution of the war by announcing his refusal to be a candidate.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 8 (AP) -- The noon communique:
The German Friday communique as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

PITTSBURGH, May 7 -- Fourteen hundred miners walked out tonight at the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation mine No. 4 near California, Pa., after the management had served notice that it proposed to levy a $1 a day fine against each man participating in last week's five-day wildcat strike.

Conservation and repair services in department stores have shown a large growth and have become aggressively promotional-minded in recent months, according to a survey of the scope of these services in the three test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles issued yesterday by Meyer-Both Reports.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 186 United States soldiers killed in action in the Alaskan, Asiatic, European, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas and in the Philippine Islands. Those listed from the Philippines had been reported previously as missing in action.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 8 (AP) -- Allied bombers heavily raided Babo, Dutch New Guinea, and Madang, New Guinea, yesterday, General Douglas MacArthur's command announced today.

The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has sold the seven-story loft building at 25 Spruce Street, northeast corner of William Street, in the wholesale leather district, where there has been a good demand for property in the last few weeks. The corner parcel is 23.6 by 96.8 feet and is assessed at $135,000. It was sold through Henry B. Root, Inc.

At a White House press conference yesterday the President revealed that the Second War Loan Drive has raised $18,300,000,000, compared with the original goal of $13,000,000,000. The oversubscription was far greater than any of most optimistic predictions.

AT THE TUNISIAN BATTLEFRONT, May 6 (Delayed) -- This outfit felt very good. They had been fighting for two weeks as infantrymen -- they were motorized reconnaissance troops originally -- and driving the Germans all the way.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning will observe the twenty-second anniversary of his consecration as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York on Tuesday by presiding over the 160th convention of the diocese. The next day the Bishop will be 77 years old. He is completing forty years as a clergyman in Manhattan and fifty-four years in the priesthood.

Despite the fact that his sympathies are with the miners, William S. Jack, president of Jack Heintz, Inc., Cleveland, declared yesterday that John L. Lewis, in ordering a coal strike, could not have done a better job for Hitler and Mussolini if they had paid him.

A total of 230 athletes from seven colleges will compete in the eleventh annual metropolitan intercollegiate track and field championships at Brooklyn College Field today. Those who represent New York University are presumably the cream of the crop so far as team strength is concerned.

From all reports, considerable money has been spent in Greater New York for sirens in the air raid warning system. But from personal observation, some of these sirens have been placed without thought. Last night's air raid test proved the point, if proof was needed.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- A contention that death sentences were imposed on Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel Weiss and Louis Capone, alleged members of the Brooklyn murder ring as a result of testimony from "self-confessed gangsters, thugs and murderers" was presented to the Supreme Court today by attorneys for the condemned New York men seeking a reversal of the conviction.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle said today that the National Bronze and Aluminum Foundry Company and seven officials had been indicted at Cleveland, Ohio, on charges of violating the sabotage law and conspiring to defraud the government.

United States armored forces that proved more than a match for the German Africa Corps in the North African fighting suffered a definite defeat yesterday when two M-4 General Sherman tanks that had taken up positions Thursday on Park Department property at Times Square and at Fifty-ninth and Fifth Avenue, without permission of Commissioner Robert Moses, were forced to retreat to new locations.

The Connally bill passed by the Senate on Wednesday does two main things: it gives explicit statutory sanction to the War Labor Board, which would be extremely helpful to the board's prestige and authority, and it provides for a method of combating strikes in wartime. This method ought to be carefully considered before it is adopted by the House.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) -- The noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Professor Vincent du Vigneaud, who discovered the chemical structure of the vitamin biotin, was elected chairman of the New York Section of the American Chemical Society at the annual meeting last night in the Pennsylvania Hotel. About 250 members and guests of the society attended.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Constitutionality of the Office of Price Administration's Order No. 339, providing for the sale of women's rayon hosiery under a grade-labeling system, was challenged today by a group of eleven hosiery manufacturers in a brief filed with the OPA and with that agency's "court of review" set up under the Emergency Price Control Act.

Petty annoyances can cause more neurosis among civilian populations than bombings from planes, Dr. Foster Kennedy of Cornell University and physician in charge of the Bellevue Hospital neurology department declared yesterday at the sixty-ninth annual meeting of the American Neurological Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, May 7 -- The stock markets here ended the week on the dull side despite good war news from Tunisia.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 7 -- "Patched-up leagues of nations" and "refitted balances of power" were condemned by Professor G.A. Borgese of the University of Chicago tonight as mere "palliatives" which would fall short of supplying world needs after the war.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.
BALTIMORE, May 7 -- The Fleet was anchored in Baltimore tonight -- battened down as the shortest-priced favorite in the pari-mutuel history of the Preakness Stakes.
LONDON, May 7 -- Stanislawa Tokalewska, a 20-year-old Polish girl who was in Tokyo during the United States bombing raid in April, 1942, described in London today the Japanese reaction to the attack.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- An average reduction of 10 per cent in the cost to the consumer of beef, veal, pork, lamb, mutton, coffee and butter, effective June 1, was announced today by Price Administrator Prentiss Brown, together with the information that the rollback was to be accomplished with the aid of subsidies.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 7 -- In what was described by an Office of Price Administration lawyer as the first case of its kind in the country, Vice Chancellor Maja Leon Berry permitted OPA to become a defendant today in eviction proceedings brought by a bank against a tenant.

Activity in the new investment market here this week improved over the preceding three weeks, when bankers were engaged with the Second War Loan drive. A sizable block of public utility securities, originally floated in March, and two new bond issues, one tax-exempt and the other for a railroad, were marketed.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 7 -- General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander, field commander of the Allied armies in Tunisia, declared today in a special order of the day that "We have grouped our victorious armies and are going to drive the enemy into the sea."

How Mayor La Guardia could say that the air raid alarm of Wednesday night was 99.9 per cent perfect is hard to understand. I am in the Air Warden Service in the midtown Manhattan area and know how bad the cooperation of the public was there. Not in the year or more that I have been giving service have I seen it so bad as during the last alert.

LONDON, Saturday, May 8 (AP) -- A tremendous Soviet artillery and air barrage was reported early today to have knocked out another German defense line before Novorossiisk in the Caucasus as the Russians killed nearly 1,000 more Axis troops and shot down twenty-seven enemy planes in the drive to the Black Sea.

Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, Deputy Coordinator of Fisheries for the United States Department of the Interior, arrived in New York yesterday from Washington to confer with leaders of the commercial fishing industry on methods to increase the supply of sea food this year.

Cheerful tidings from the flower stalls this week-end indicate that moderate prices will prevail for the next few days. A capsule report from the Department of Markets tips off the public to the fact that on the eve of Mother's Day flowers cost far less than they did at Easter.

The costs involved in placing suggested new social security programs into effect in Britain and the United States aroused a lively interest from the audience at a forum discussion sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES last night on "Social Security and Post-War Planning in the United States and Great Britain" at The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

HARTFORD, Conn., May 7 -- After considering Governor Dewey's letter suggesting Connecticut cooperation on State and local enforcement of Federal regulations of Office of Price Administration on ceiling prices and food distribution, Governor Baldwin late today referred the matter to the legal committee of the Connecticut State War Council.

A compensation ring, which included doctors, representatives of claimants and others, in a widespread fraud, caused the city to pay 166 per cent more in 1941 for medical expenses of injured municipal employes than in 1934, although claims decreased 12 per cent in that period, Commissioner of Investigation William B.
