Herlands disclosed yesterday.

Stalin might have used a red pencil to sign his now famous letter to Ralph Parker of THE TIMES. He is supposed to like red. Some anxious souls fear to offend the Russians by calling them "Reds," but actually the word, like the color, means to them something fine and splendid.
NEW DELHI, India, May 7 (AP) -- A Tenth Air Force communique:

Five recommendations designed, within the limitations imposed by the State Constitution, to reduce city expenses in connection with municipal pension systems, are contained in a report by the pension subcommittee of the Mayor's Committee to Study City Finance, made public yesterday at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- Navy Communique 369:

Through some mix-up in Albany, an applicant for a job as a boxing referee, "with good political connections," was sent to the State Department of Labor and, though lacking qualifications, became a referee in compensation claims, Commissioner of Investigation William B. Herlands disclosed yesterday before the Moreland act inquiry at the Bar Association.

AN ALEUTIAN ARMY BASE, Jan. 28 (Delayed) -- American troops on Jan. 12 occupied Amchitka, an island of the Rat group in the Aleutians about seventy miles from Kiska, thereby threatening that Japanese-held base.

Directors of the Creole Petroleum Corporation decided yesterday to omit the company's semi-annual dividend of 25 cents a share, normally paid in June. The company stated that the wartime shipping restrictions continued to affect adversely its earnings and financial position.

The letter signed "A Dodger Fan" that appeared in THE TIMES last Saturday surely must have angered every loyal Giant rooter. Although it is not necessary to refute the arguments in that letter comparing the Giants and Dodgers (for the final standing this year will bear me out), I can't stand by and tolerate such an unfair comparison of the two clubs.

The test of war, Herbert Hoover told the closing session of the Boys Clubs of America at the Hotel Commodore last night, has proved the mettle of the American boy. Unregimented product of a democracy, the former President said, the American youth has remained an individualist.

Though next week's new municipal financing will amount to $13,218,500, most of it will consist of short-term note issues. Included in the total is $12,364,000 of notes, consisting of individual issues of fourteen local housing authorities throughout the country, all of which are scheduled to be awarded on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- A movement to make the Senate-adopted Connally anti-strike bill stronger and more far-reaching, and to apply punitive restrictions to all war production stoppages by labor disputes, whether the plants involved are in government hands or not, took form in the House side today.

The stock market was hit yesterday by the widest inroads in almost a month as heavy liquidation engulfed the list in the final hour and set prices back 1 to 2 points. Offerings on the New York Stock Exchange were so urgent on the good news from Tunisia that the ticker tape proved unable to keep abreast of floor transactions.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- Andrey Y. Vishinsky, Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs, late last night called the British and American press representatives to the Foreign Commissariat's conference room and read them a declaration repeating recent charges against the Polish Government in London and adding new accusations.

Harry A. Gourfain, who produces the stage shows at the Capitol Theatre, and Charlie Barnet, the band leader, have announced that they will present on Broadway their untitled musical comedy production late in the Summer. The former has completed the book with Sidney Fields, radio comedian, and Mr. Barnet has attended to the score, for which Mr. Gourfain is contributing the lyrics.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The Ruml plan's principle of 100 per cent abatement of the 1942 individual income tax liability was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee. The vote was 13 to 6.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- President Roosevelt repudiated what he considers acts of financial exploitation in Latin America during the Coolidge era when he announced at his press conference today that he had apologized to General Enrique Penaranda, the Bolivian President, for an American loan made to Bolivia more than fifteen years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 (AP) -- A medium Norwegian merchant ship eluded a "wolf-pack" of at least three enemy submarines by skillful manoeuvring in the Atlantic early in March, then apparently headed back into the same pack and was sunk the next day, the fourth naval district disclosed today.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 7 -- Sweden's Foreign Minister, Christian E. Guenther, took issue tonight with the critics of his neutrality policy.

It is not only in their news columns, filled with reports of battle and heroism on land and sea and in the air, that American newspapers show the impact of war. Steadily since Pearl Harbor the character of the advertising columns has been undergoing a change. With civilian goods of many kinds scarce or severely rationed, there has been an impressive growth in the daily press of the public relations or institutional type of advertising.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Amid reports that at least ninety-nine other persons in the Philadelphia area had been ordered to leave the vicinity for sections of the country where they could not jeopardize the war effort, Mrs. Olga Schueller, 53, defied the Eastern Coast Command today to compel her to obey its order that she quit the region.

Retail trade here improved this week as warm weather increased the demand for seasonal merchandise, chiefly accessories and apparel. Estimates indicated department store sales will probably show an increase over the corresponding week last year.

Manufacturers declared yesterday that civilian supplies may be further reduced by the army request for bids on 19,062,860 shirts to be submitted on May 25 and 28. It was pointed out that reduced manpower and the reluctance of smaller manufacturers to bid on government business would necessitate the reduction in the output of civilian lines.

A two-day Negro press conference was opened yesterday at 9:15 A. M. in the Hotel Pennsylvania under the auspices of the Council for Democracy. The meeting, which brought together Negro and white editors, was organized after an industrial survey by the council last Winter had covered all of the major industrial areas where integration of Negroes into war work was studied.

A field of eleven, including Riverland and Attention, is named for today's $15,000 added Grey Lag Handicap, feature at Jamaica on the final program of the most successful meeting the Metropolitan Jockey Club has run in its long history, dating back to the early years of this century.

"The Ox-Bow Incident," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama starring Henry Fonda, will be the new attraction opening today at the Rivoli. Produced and written for the screen by Lamar Trotti from the novel by Walter Van Tilburg Clark, the production, which was directed by William A. Wellman, features Dana Andrews, Mary Beth Hughes, Anthony Quinn. Jane Darwell, Henry Morgan, William Eythe and Frank Conroy.

Pressing its drive against retailers in the ration cut-point war that started several weeks ago, the district Office of Price Administration issued yesterday a one-week's suspension order against Harris Dairies on a charge of reducing the rationed value of butter to one point.

Allan Sproul, chairman of the New York War Finance Committee, reported yesterday that of the national total of about $18,000,000,000 of new securities sold in the second War Loan drive, the Second Federal Reserve District accounted for $7,020,548,000, or about 39 per cent.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- Following is the text of a statement made by Andrey Y. Vishinsky, Vice Foreign Commissar, to representatives of the British and American press yesterday and distributed by the Tass Agency:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 6 (Delayed) -- When the Italians occupied Tripoli during their war with the Turks in 1911, many patriotic Tripolitanian Arabs emigrated to Damascus in Syria, starting an influential colony. Thus the occupation of Tripoli by the Eighth Army had an enormous effect on that Islamic center and was a great blow to Axis prestige in the Middle East, even beyond that ordinarily reckoned.

Although Cat Cay and Bimini might be expected to be out of the news for the duration as far as sports fishing is concerned, an announcement from the Florida Coast Guard indicates that the Bahama waters may serve as a source of tuna supply.

The menus for next week presented here today follow the pattern set by their predecessors. They are planned (1) with the budget of red and blue stamps in mind, (2) with a heed for good nutrition, (3) with an eye for the current good buys in the market.

Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard College complained yesterday that factory representatives "come snooping about colleges trying to lure away young mathematics and science students before they are fully trained." That is one of the three main problems facing women's colleges today, Dean Gildersleeve told 500 delegates to the 121st convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, held in the Hotel Astor.

BOSTON, May 7 (AP) -- Before a glove could be laid on him. Henry Armstrong of Los Angeles, only triple champion in ring history but now without a title, knocked out Tommy Jessup of Springfield tonight with a terrific two-fisted attack to the head and body at the end of the first minute of their scheduled ten-round bout at the Boston Garden.

CHICAGO, May 7 -- More favorable weather conditions for the growing Winter crop caused declines of 1 3/4 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel today on the Board of Trade. The break was the most severe in more than a month. Final sales were at the day's bottom prices.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The islands of Amchitka and Adak in the Western Aleutians have been occupied by Army-Navy expeditionary forces that have built up military positions, including airfields, thus making possible the punishing raids on the Japanese-held bases of Kiska and Attu during the past two months, the Navy announced today.

High-ranking officers of the armed forces and their wives were among the guests of honor at the gala Red, White and Blue Dinner Dance given last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton as a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The occupation of Bizerte and Tunis by the Allies a week sooner than the earliest date mentioned in previous estimates by military authorities here reduces the future operations there to hardly more than a mopping-up task, military men said here tonight.

Patrons swinging cuesticks, routed an armed gang using infiltration tactics to holdup a poolroom at 182 Fifth Avenue at 12:50 P.M. yesterday. One gang suspect, an ex-convict on parole, was captured in a BMT subway exit by a pair of traffic patrolmen who have been on duty in the shadow of the Flatiron Building for more than thirty years.

International cooperation for peace, as in war, can be attained only if a majority of citizens understand and accept its need, Mrs. Linville K. Martin of Winston-Salem, N.C., president of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, declared yesterday at the opening of the association's twenty-third annual conference.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Chemicals allocated for distribution this month by the chemicals division of the War Production Board had a dollar value of approximately $88,000,000, WPB announced today. The total compares with applications for about $100,000,000 worth received by the war agency.

PHILADELPHIA, May 7 -- Only the Phillies caught fire from the heat wave at Shibe Park today. The Giants merely swooned on the spot while being walloped in the opener of a five-game series. Mel Ott's team went down to a 13-3 defeat.

MOSCOW, May 7 -- Exploiting the capture of Krymsk by advancing both north and west, the Red Army has now, according to this morning's reports, effectively divided the enemy's forces in the Kuban, leaving the broad, marshy zone between the right wing defending Novorossiisk and the left wing north of the Kuban River.
LONDON, May 7 (Reuter) -- Count Edward Raczynzki, Polish Foreign Minister, tonight issued the following statement:

A prison sentence of 20 years to life was imposed yesterday in General sessions on Guillermo C. Castro, 27 years old, who had pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in the shooting of Miss Carmen Colon, 20, on the night of Jan. 12 as she was emerging from a party at 120 West Sixty-third Street.

ST. LOUIS, May 7 (AP) -- Representative Walter C. Ploeser of Missouri today told the Independent Petroleum Association of America that the Office of Price Administration must assume full responsibility for a threatened oil shortage by its rejection of a recommended increase in prices of crude oil.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP) -- The Red Sox staged a two-run rally in the ninth inning to defeat Washington, 3 to 2, before 17,177 fans tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Expressing pleasure that the Second War Loan drive had been over-subscribed by more than $5,000,000,000, President Roosevelt said today that the large volume of savings reflected in bond purchases totaling $18,300,000,000 very definitely reduced the need for enforced savings but had not changed the Administration's goal of $16,000,000,000 in additional revenue through taxes, savings or both.
WASHINGTON, May 7 -- Joseph E. Davies is going to Moscow to carry a letter conveying a special message from President Roosevelt to Premier Joseph Stalin.

BENTON, Tenn., May 7 -- The effort of the Tennessee General Assembly to remove the State's 53-year-old poll tax barrier from its ballot boxes lost the first round in the courts today when Chancellor T.L. Stewart of Winchester ruled that the repeal statute violated the State Constitution.
CLEVELAND, May 7 -- John L. Schmeller, president of the National Bronze and Aluminum Company, denied today the grand jury's charge that the company had offered defective castings to the government.

The annual observance of Mother's Day will take place tomorrow in Protestant churches of all denominations. Pastors will preach sermons on "Mother." The day will mark the close of "Christian Family Week." Synagogues will mark Mother's Day at their services this morning.

KOHAT, NORTHWEST FRONTIER PROVINCE, May 2 (Delayed) -- order to make a check on the political information received in Peshawar, THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent has come to this famous litle garrison town at the foot of the Kurram Pass leading into Southern Afghanistan. It served merely to confirm the impressions received in the provincial capital.

LONDON, May 7 -- The statement by Audrey Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Vice Commissar of Foreign Affairs, came as a slap in the face to those in the Polish Government in exile here who thought they saw in Premier Joseph Stalin's recent declaration in favor of a strong independent post-war Poland and Polish Premier Wladyslaw Sikorski's retort courteous a basis for the resumption of Russo-Polish relations.

CHICAGO, May 7 (AP) -- A long double to left center by Luke Appling with one out in the tenth broke up a hurlers' duel between Johnny Humphries and Hal White today and gave the Chicago White Sox a 1-to-0 decision over the Tigers in the opening game of their series.

Labor and material shortages will make it impossible for most baby carriage manufacturers to come anywhere near the increased production quotas announced by the War Production Board last week, it was predicted in the trade yesterday.

The pamphlet report of the Illinois Central System for 1942 shows that last year the carrier's funded indebtedness was reduced by $26,208,340 to $342,392,325 at the year-end. An important part of the debt reduction included a payment of $10,000,000 to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on a note dated May 31, 1939, which reduced the amount of that loan to $25,140,000.

Hunter juniors upset college conventions yesterday by triumphing over the favored senior class at the college's twenty-seventh annual interclass "sing" or musical competition. The victorious juniors, who won the traditional silver baton prize, scored heavily for costumes, effects and originality of lyrics.
Citations to four Marine Corps officers from the New York area for bravery at Guadalcanal were revealed here yesterday.

ALBANY, May 7 -- State Controller Moore today made public a letter from Councilman Joseph P. Sharkey, Democratic majority leader of the New York City Council, asking the amount of the city's share of State-collected taxes since July 1, 1942, and an estimate as to the amount that will be paid the city by June 30.

EVERYTHING that Thomas Wolfe wrote was filled with an enormous appetite for living. Picking up his "Letters to His Mother"* I had half expected to find a good deal of the topical and perfunctory sort of thing that usually gets into letters that college students and young people on their own write home. But these letters of. Tom Wolfe read like passages from his novels.

Because accountants made and then discovered an error in the method of computing a provision for Federal taxes, the New York Curb Exchange yesterday suspended dealings in the common stock of United Aircraft Products, Inc. The error, reported by Haskins Sells, showed net profits in 1942 as $1,505,889.

Relying extensively on inferences drawn from a manuscript called "Hungryman's Library," by Randolph Godfrey Phillips, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here decided yesterday that that former newspaper man and industrialist was a conscientious objector and should therefore be released from the Army.

The second half of a personnel shift between the petroleum industry and the Petroleum Administration for War was effected yesterday with the appointment of Charles L. Harding as general counsel to the Petroleum Industry Committee.

William Fellowes Morgan Sr., civic leader and philanthropist, who died on May 2, left his estate in trust for the benefit of his wife, Mrs. Emma L. Morgan of 510 Park Avenue. This was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate. His estate was formally valued at "more than $10,000."

CHICAGO, May 7 -- The wage dispute between the railroads and the fifteen non-operating unions moved closer to President Roosevelt's hands today. The three-man emergency fact finding panel hearing the case announced, after an effort to settle it had failed, that it has completed its big job of assembling information.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 7 -- The funeral of Viktor Lutze, chief of staff of the Nazi Storm Troops, was held in Berlin today in the presence of Adolf Hitler and a large gathering of party, Army and government leaders.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 7 -- John Cassidy's single to right field with one out in the ninth inning scored Ed Kearney and Frank Garafola to give Hofstra College a 5-4 victory over Brooklyn College in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game today.

To eliminate wastage of highly essential shipyard labor, the War Manpower Commission announced yesterday that beginning May 17 all new workers in the forty-five shipyards in the greater part of New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut must be hired through the United States Employment Service, terminating the "outside hiring lines" at yards that employ more than 185,000 workers.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., May 7 -- The Dionne quintuplets came to the United States for the first time today on their way to Superior, Wis., where they will sponsor five cargo ships Sunday. They made a brief appearance on the rear platform of their special car, just long enough to wave greetings to about 1,000 who crowded about the station to catch a glimpse of the 8-year-olds.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

The United States Trust Company as trustee has sold the five-story apartment building at 2558 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, for cash above a mortgage of $120,162. The property is assessed at $150,000. Grenell Realty Agency was the broker and Jacob Emil Leitner acted as co-brokers.

Wide brims to cast shadows, and wide brims to set behind pompadours to frame the face, rivalled tiny toques provocatively tilted over the eyes in the collections presented yesterday by Peg Fischer, Madame Pauline and Florence Reichman. This was the last of the series of Summer millinery fashion luncheons at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Nicolai Lopatnikoff, who lives in New York and teaches composition at the Hartt Musical Foundation in Hartford, Conn., has won the Cleveland Orchestra's $1,000 prize for a new composition for symphony orchestra, it was announced yesterday.

THIS is Redemption Day for those horses that were supposed to win the Kentucky Derby and neglected to do so. This is the day of the Preakness at Pimlico, when stunned Churchill Downs favorites that failed to triumph get their chance to take a canter along the comeback trail.

There is one angle of the controversy between John L. Lewis and the government which has received little notice. I refer to the effect it will have -- in fact, already has had -- upon union labor itself.

ATLANTA, May 7 (AP) -- Although no vote is anticipated until after the war is "happily ended," a plan for reunion of the Presbyterian Church in the United States and the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America will be submitted for study at the eighty-third session of the general assembly of the United States church, May 27 to June 2, at Montreat, N.C., it was announced today.

State Senator James G. Donovan, chairman of the Committee for the Reorganization of the Democratic party in New York County, yesterday challenged Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, to prove his assertion, by naming names, that judges in New York City had been "made" by Philip J. Dunn.
CINCINNATI, May 7 (AP) -- Fireman Joe Beggs came to the rescue of Johnny Vander Meer in the ninth inning today and helped the Reds eke out a 5-to-4 triumph over the Cubs.

Today's events: Orrea Pernel, violin, and Maxine Stellman, soprano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30 P.M.; People's Philharmonic Chorus, Carnegie Hall, evening; "La Traviata," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

Beau Jack and Bob Montgomery, who meet for the lightweight championship of the world at Madison Square Garden on May 21, visited the New York State Atheltic Commission yesterday to sign formal articles for the clash. The boxers also posted appearance forfeits of $1,500 apiece.

The Citizens Union yesterday accused the City Planning Commission of "disregard of the public and undue haste" in amending the city's master plan last Wednesday to expedite consideration of the $40,000,000 post-war Stuyvesant Town housing project of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Spinnakers will be few and far between in the yacht racing on Long Island Sound this Summer. The International class decided to carry on, as it did last year, kite carrying at intervals. The S class owners voted to do away with them, and last night, at a dinner meeting of the Atlantic class in the Hotel Shelton, it was decided to do away with them, at least for the early part of the season.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 -- Paramount today announced two co-starring roles for Brian Donlevy in pictures to be made after "America" for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The first will be in "Double Indemnity," the James M. Cain story for which the studio is seeking Barbara Stanwyck and Edward G. Robinson.

CHUNGKING, China, May 7 (AP) -- Japanese landings on the southern shores of Tungting Lake, only fifty miles from Changsha, capital of Hunan Province, were viewed today as indicating that a new Japanese drive on the capital was under way and with it the possibility of a determined attempt to crush free China.
Mrs. Townsend Phillips has come to the Pierre from Newport, R.I.
AMCHITKA ISLAND AIR BASE, Feb. 16 (AP) (Delayed) -- Despite a series of eight Japanese bombing raids, this American air base only a few minutes' flight from Kiska Island went into operation today.

WASHINGTON, May 7 -- The commander of the United States submarine lay dying on the bridge. The Japanese gunboat, though sinking, was raking her deck with heavy machine-gun fire, and the American vessel had to crash-dive or be sunk.

Cooperation of American Protestant churches with the governmental post-war program of relief for the world's war-stricken areas was pledged yesterday by the recently formed Church Committee on Overseas Relief and Reconstruction in a "statement of purpose."

Home construction will become "one of the dominant forces in the nation's economy" in post-war years, Federal Housing Commissioner Abner H. Ferguson declared yesterday in urging institutional investors to help finance the program and thus "contribute largely to the preservation of private enterprise financed by private capital."

The Koppers Company and its wholly owned subsidies reported yesterday in a statement covering the twelve months ended on March 31 net profit of $3,895,225 after provision for renegotiation of contracts and $12,985,061 for State and Federal income and excess profits taxes.

Joseph Stalin in a personal message to Winston Churchill last Monday congratulated the Royal Air Force on its bombardment of Germany. "I welcome the bombing of Essen, Berlin and other industrial centers of Germany," said Premier Stalin.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (Science Service) -- Helicopters, the submarine's newest nemesis, figure prominently among the 606 new inventions on which United States patents have been issued here during the past week. Outstanding are two designs by the well-known aviation engineer, Igor I. Sikorsky of Trumbull, Conn.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 7 (AP) -- Yale announced plans today to play twelve football games next Fall, the longest schedule in its modern gridiron history. The news came on top of the decision by the Elis' arch-rival, Harvard, to quit varsity football for the duration.

BOSTON, May 7 -- Augie Galan hit his first home run as a Dodger with two aboard in the second inning, scored the tying run in the seventh and singled home the winning run in the eighth to give Lippy Leo Durocher's league-leaders the opener of the four-game series with the Braves today.

Leighton MacCarthy, Canadian Minister in Washington, and Hugh Scully, newly appointed Canadian Consul General in the United States, took part yesterday in the presentation of two ambulances to the Canadian Navy at the headquarters of the Maple Leaf Fund, 601 Fifth Avenue.

An apartment of eleven rooms and five baths has been leased in 1115 Fifth Avenue by Pedro Zuloaga, commissioner of the Technical Institute of Immigration and Colonization of Venezuela. Douglas L. Elliman Co. arranged the lease.

Reversing a ruling made nearly a year ago by Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter, the Appellate Division ordered yesterday the resumption of the trial of a suit brought by Leopold Mannaberg, Austrian refugee, against Ely Culbertson, bridge expert, and others.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 7 -- A new military offensive by Japan is forecast in a special dispatch from Tokyo to the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung. The war in the Far East is about to enter on a new phase, the paper's correspondent says, citing recent statements by Major Gen. Nakao Yahagi, Chief of the Army press section of Imperial Headquarters, as the basis for his assumption.

NEW DELHI, India, May 7 (AP) -- Heavy bombers of the American Air Force operating from India struck a damaging blow yesterday at Japanese efforts to reclaim valuable mining properties in Burma which were made unserviceable by their owners during the "scorched earth" retreat from that country last year.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, said yesterday that he had no comment on President Roosevelt's statement in his Washington press conference that the miners were now Federal employes and that accordingly he did not expect them to strike against their government.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 7 -- Thirty thousand Jews in Tunis and another 1,300 in Bizerte passed from the cruel treatment of the Nazis, in which they have been black-mailed and half starved, when the Allies entered the two key ports.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 7 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval is getting his answer in the form of bombs thrown at German soldiers. When he returned from his interview with Adolf Hitler he pleaded for "comprehension" by the French, which would assure for France a wonderful future when Germany won the war.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 7 -- As the great Allied blitz continued on an undiminished scale today it was officially disclosed that the Allied air forces in North Africa flew more than 2,500 sorties yesterday and dropped 1,250, 000 pounds of bombs to set a new record.

Rowing, so far as big regattas are concerned, comes to the end of its season on the Severn River, off the buildings of the United States Naval Academy, this afternoon. The Childs Cup, oldest of the rowing trophies save one in the country, will be contested by the varsity eights of Columbia, Pennsylvania and Princeton, with Navy and Massachusetts Institute of Technology as guest starters.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- According to plans recently revealed by Herman V. Yeager, manager of Pocono Manor, this resort will revert to civilian use not later than July 1. During the period of the hotel's occupancy by the Navy many improvements have been made.

The need for increased health, educational and recreational facilities for school children was emphasized yesterday by authorities on children's problems at a conference and luncheon sponsored by the Play Schools Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Reports from Moscow say that the Russians received enthusiastically the news of the United Nations success in Tunisia and that they thought it would lead soon to the second front in Europe, for which Stalin has been asking for so long. In view of the fact that for two years the Russians have borne the brunt of the toughest attack of Hitler's armies, it is not difficult to understand this reaction.

LONDON, May 8 (U.P.) -- German planes were active over Britain during the night and early this morning. Four enemy raiders were shot down over Britain and a fifth was bagged over a base in Northern France.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The smashing Allied victory in North Africa was everywhere regarded here as a prophecy of things to come. Now that the Americans have got their stride and teamwork has been perfected with the British, more smashing blows are expected against the Axis.

In the area around Pittsburgh, Pa., there are 125,000 men who dig the soft coal on which much of the nation's war production depends. They number more than one-fourth of all the bituminous-coal miners in the country. They believe in, are committed to, and probably will follow John L. Lewis, the United Mine Workers leader.

LONDON, May 8 (AP) -- Today was heralded as one of the greatest and most heartening of the war. The nation's joy, thankfulness and hope for the future was proclaimed up and down the country. The British press acclaimed the victory as a prelude to a smashing Allied invasion of Europe.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 8 -- Renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, now before Congress, as a necessary step toward insuring world peace in the post-war era was urged tonight by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State.

Eighteen members of the crew of a United States Lines vessel, officially presumed lost for several months, have survived the sinking of their ship and are "alive and well" in a Japanese prison camp in Java, Dutch East Indies, according to short-wave broadcasts from Tokyo received in this country and relayed to the families of the seamen, the United States Lines reported yesterday.

BIZERTE, May 7 (delayed) -- American tankmen who led the triumphant march into this great Mediterranean seaport today had to remove the flowers strewn on their vehicles by the happy French inhabitants before they could fire at a few German guns that challenged them from the oppsite side of the city.

DEAR ALBERT: This is our first warm day this Spring. There are some snow patches on the hills, but the ground is soft around the barn, and the pond in front of the house is brimfull. When your mother came in from the milking she talked about the time when you and Walter made a plank raft together and poled around the pond this time of year.

HIGHLAND PARK, N.J., May 8 -- Aided by a courageous motorist, a straight-shooting Highland Park policeman ended with a bullet tonight the flight of a man who had killed a guard of the Middlesex County Jail in New Brunswick after kidnapping the guard to break out of the jail.

AS the mobile canteen slid to a standstill before a small house in one of London's suburbs, the driver picked up a small book from the driving seat. To refresh her memory, she turned up the address and read the following entry "Latchkey wrapped in newspaper underneath sandbag -- 3d -- no pastry."

VALLETTA, Malta, May 5 (Delayed) -- A large-scale map of the Mediterranean which has been housed far underground in this island fortress is now being taken out to give place to a brand new one and in such way is a leaf definitely turned in Malta's history.

In a letter to Senator Harry S. Truman, chairman of the Special Committee Investigating the National Defense Program, Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, last week expressed agreement with the committee's report that this port is not being utilized to its full capacity.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- General George C. Marshall, Army Chief of Staff, and General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in North Africa, paid tribute in Mother's Day messages tonight to the inspiring part that brave and self-secrificing American mothers are taking in the war.

" ONE WORLD'S" success story has made publishing history. An estimated 50,000 copies a day were sold in the first ten days after the book was released. In the same period arrangements were made to have the book appear in Swedish, Spanish, Portuguese and German.
PEOPLE stood jammed together, staring at the closed gates with such fiery intensity that they seemed to be waiting for St. Peter. But it turned out to be only the 6 o'clock train to New York.

" FRONT LINE" is the story of how Hitler's aerial legions banged Britain, of how bombs falling from the face of a full moon fired, blasted and destroyed buildings, killed and maimed the people in and around them, and of how the very sense of national unity and common peril welded all the people, noble lords and Cockney commoners, into a unit of such determined resistance that they won a stalemate.

A twelve-month program to prepare girl high school graduates for positions demanding technical knowledge in the airplane and other war industries has been announced by the School of Science of Simmons College. This program is designed to meet an urgent demand by war production plants, and especially those manufacturing aircraft, for women with a fundamental knowledge of the physical sciences, mathematics, drafting, and the problems of industrial organization and management.

REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. -- Neither war nor alarums of war will prevent the Rehoboth Art League from carrying out an extensive program at this resort, which is known because of its popularity with Washington legislators and diplomats as "The Summer Capital."

THE uses of Vinca minor, or periwinkle and myrtle, as it is commonly called, are well known and widespread. It is a perennial that adapts itself beautifully wherever a ground cover is needed, either for sun or shade, and its bright little blue flowers are universal favorites.

GEORGE HUMMEL'S newest novel is described on the dust jacket as "a great panoramic novel of the growth of America." The story itself is big enough to fill the hollow spaces in this great meaningless phrase without too much rattling around.

NEW DELHI, India, May 8 (U.P.) -- Reinforced Japanese columns, driving a wedge between imperial forces in Western Burma, have created a "direct threat" to the two most important remaining British bases east of India despite heavy casualties and intensified American and British aerial assaults on enemy supply centers and communications, it was announced today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 9 (AP) -- The noon communique:

ALMOST without exception, as far as a visiting correspondent could see, they were all very serious. As the somewhat solemnly entitled "Fourteenth Institute for Education by Radio" went on from day to day for four days in Columbus, Ohio, where it concluded early last week, most of the 700-odd registrants at that annual parley seemed to be listening attentively and taking notes busily, and in general the atmosphere was not one of levity.

MONTREAL, May 8 (AP) -- Private Johnny Greco made a tangible bid for a shot at Beau Jack's lightweight title tonight by punching out a clean-cut decision over New York's Terry Young. One of the largest fight, crowds since the days of Montreal's famed Leo (Kid) Roy -- 9,367 -- turned out for the show, sponsored by the Canadian Army.

LONDON, Sunday, May 9 -- Russian troops, pouring through an elaborate defense belt girding Novorossiisk, today threatened to inflict a staggering defeat on Axis Caucasus forces and produce another debacle in quick succession to the Allied triumph in Tunisia.

INTO a single volume of 500 pages, Miss Curie has managed to pack every major battlefront of this war. The result, as the continents file by, is an achievement of brilliant writing and shrewd observation which has not been surpassed by any other reporter.

CURRENT projects of the Help the Russian Prisoners of War Committee, an affiliate of the Tolstoy Foundation, Inc., will be materially aided by a musicale to be given Wednesday night at the home of Dr. A. Hamilton Rice, 901 Fifth Avenue.

THE college of the future has not yet reached the blueprint stage, although countless faculty committees are discussing possible blueprints. But the main features of the terrain on which it must rest are beginning to appear. One of those features is now glaringly clear.

PALO ALTO, Calif., May 8 -- If the American soldier driving a General Grant tank in Tunisia or piloting a Grumman fighter in the Solomons knows his Plato and his Aristotle he is better prepared for death or life than if he lacked this extra armor of the "humanities," Lewis Mumford told delegates from fifty Western colleges and Universities on the Stanford campus tonight.

More than 300 French seamen, crew members of the various French merchant vessels now in this country, voted last week to form an American section of the French Seamen's Union with headquarters in the offices of the International Transport Workers Federation at 5 Beekman Street.

A COUPLE of lusty yippees are clearly in order for Agnes de Mille and the dancing she has staged for the Theatre Guild's utterly charming "Oklahoma!" It is frequently the case that when artists from the ballet and the concert stage turn to Broadway they unconsciously look down their noses even at their own work.
CHUNGKING, China, May 8 (U.P.) -- A communique:

The People's Philharmonic Choral Society, under Max Helfman, presented a program entitled "Music for Heroic Times," last night in Carnegie Hall, before a large and enthusiastic audience. The chorus was assisted by Gertrude Ribla, soprano; Michael Zetkin, tenor, and Joseph Posner, baritone.

LUISE RAINER tiptoed into Hollywood a few weeks ago to go to work for Paramount, where it was figured her inner talents would show off fine slongside Lamour and Goddard and Lake, who are well-gifted on the outside.

NOW that the Warners have cut loose and turned out a feature-length film in "Mission to Moscow" which boldly puts political persuasion on the screen, it is time to start thinking about such pictures in something more than academic terms.

BALTIMORE, May 8 (AP) -- A gay throng packed the grandstands and clubhouse of historic old Pimlico today for the Preakness Stakes. The unreserved sections were packed by 11 A.M. and the crowd started overflowing into the infield, where special mutuel machines had been set up.
THESE are two more of the now numerous training books spawned by the need for swift training of workmen to make the engines of war.

THE thesis of Dr. Sturmthal's volume on the downfall of European labor is that, in the struggle culminating with 1938, labor was not farsighted enough to accept political responsibility for the social and democratic program to which it was committed.

The annual luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy, held yesterday at the Hotel McAlpin, was devoted to a discussion of means to prevent want, unemployment and insecurity in the world after the Allies have won the war.

Concern for human welfare, supported by relief and rehabilitation measures after the war, was advocated yesterday by speakers at the twenty-third annual conference of the Association of Junior Leagues of America, in session over the week-end at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Congress has before it the Lea-Bailey bill to modernize our legislation affecting civil aeronautics. It has many new and desirable features looking to a solid foundation for the development of civil aviation in all its phases -- common-carrier operation, miscellaneous commercial operation and private flying.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 8 -- After having destroyed seventeen ships yesterday and left more, including a destroyer, burning, as well as having strafed and bombed enemy trucks and infantry columns, Allied planes were at work in full force again today.

Organization of a united religious council at City College, composed of representatives of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish undergraduate clubs, was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, the president. The council will provide for the recreational and social needs of student soldiers stationed at the college.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- A powerful and well-balanced team of cadets, representing the United States Military Academy at West Point swept to a record-breaking victory in the annual Heptagonal track meet on Franklin Field today.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Pay-as-you-go taxation this week reached the inevitable stage of Senate revision of House action. It seemed equally inevitable that the Senate would largely rewrite the House bill with strong likelihood that some form of the Ruml plan would emerge from the Senate and be accepted by the House.

The Board of Transportation has taken the first step to make possible the appointment of Magistrate Edward C. Maguire as a deputy commissioner at an annual salary of $12,000, it was learned yesterday. Magistrate Maguire, who will resign from the bench to accept the new post, will be assigned to handle various matters concerned with labor relations between the Board of Transportation and the 32,000 civil service employes of the city's' unified transit system.

LARGE benefit exhibitions continue to be brought forward. Several opened last week, swelling the season's list, already long. These include the brilliant "Golden Nineties" show at the Hotel Gotham branch of the Grand Central Galleries, a group of contemporary American paintings and sculpture at the Junior League Clubhouse, and a group of African figures exhibited for the benefit of the Fighting French Relief. Inc., at 2 West Fifty-seventh.

CRESS is one of the cooler sounding vegetables on a hot Summer day, used for garnishing, in salads and sandwiches. There is no difficulty in producing a crop of either water or garden cress, if one will provide suitable growing conditions and gather leaves before flower buds or seeds appear.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The War Labor Board said today that it was "powerless" to grant women "equal pay for equal work" unless President Roosevelt's hold-the-line stabilization order was clarified.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- At Atlantic City today mothers from all sections of the country will be reunited with their sons serving at Atlantic City's Basic Training Center No. 7, Army Air Forces Technical Training Command. Recognition of Mother's Day is to be given at a special symphonic concert in the Army-occupied Municipal Auditorium, the world's largest convention hall, by the AAF post military band.

Salaries of white-collar workers in this city's five boroughs are moving upward, according to the annual survey announced yesterday of weekly clerical salaries completed by the industrial bureau of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

A NEW recording of Beethoven's String Quartet No. 12 in E flat, Op. 127, is something to look forward to, and if the Budapest String Quartet has made the recording, then there is occasion for rejoicing. The new album by the Budapest ensemble of this score (Columbia M-537, five twelve-inch records) seems to this corner the most attractive release of the month.

Three children and their father were taken down an aerial ladder yesterday as fire destroyed the apartment in which they were sleeping at 452 West Fiftieth Street. Two of the children and the father were burned.

When the United Nations troops march across Europe on the final stages of their journey they may carry with them maps showing where buildings with a historic or artistic interest are located and where paintings and other cultural treasures are likely to be found.

IN the somewhat world of wacky the comedians, a really successful performer is one who tells jokes at night. There are good ones who tell jokes in daylight -- some of those early morning wags, for instance -- but not until they reach the big, sponsored, after-dark hours do they consider that they have arrived. Well, then, Garry Moore has arrived.

In a gloomy report submitted to the American Chemical Society, Dr. William A. Albrecht of the University of Missouri declares that the human species is degenerating because of a declining soil fertility.

LINCOLN, Neb., May 8 (AP) -- Captain Joe Shy, who won the 100 and 220 yard dashes: Maurice Alexander, who took both hurdle races, and Elmer Aussieker, with a record-breaking toss of 52 feet 1/4 inch in the shot-put, paced Missouri today to an easy triumph in the annual Big Six Conference track meet.

A survey of textbooks in use in high school American History classes, to attempt to determine their adequacy as teaching devices, indicates that many such texts are not meeting the best needs of the secondary school students. Some 300 questionnaires were sent to cities of over 50,000 population and to various State departments of education to get the information.

The door to pleasure boating for 1943 has been opened a tiny crack by the OPA in Washington. Yachtsmen holding gasoline ration coupons issued prior to the ruling of April 24 will be able to obtain fuel. It has also been explained that boats with gasoline already in their tanks will not be prevented from operating.

Evidence continues to prove that the faith which dependable experts have placed in the qualitative excellence of our aircraft was fully justified. Even armchair critics have admitted the capability of our big bombers, the Flying Fortresses and Liberators, for the work for which they were designed -- high-altitude precision bombing.

Steps designed to foster compliance with inventory control order L-219, particularly a plan under which all merchants who do not report stocks may be required to file a signed statement as to whether their inventories are under the allowable limits, are under consideration in official quarters, it was learned here at the weekend.
Sam Mele, clean-up man for New York University, stepped to the plate in the eleventh inning yesterday with the Violet and Manhattan in a 2-2 deadlock at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

CAPTAIN PATRICK J. MCDONALD of the New York Police Department is an arresting figure of a man. When he stands alone he immediately forms a crowd because his shoulders have the majestic sweep of Killarney's hills while his voice has the delicious lilt of his native County Clare. Pat stands 6 feet 5 inches tall and weighs more than 300 pounds.

RECENTLY Stephen Spender was rung up by a representative of one of the Ministries and was told that if he would like to write a propaganda piece he could be released from all other duties. He declined the offer, for he believes himself to have no talent for such writing and he considers it of no value.

HER small daughter's appearance is at once the delight and despair of almost every mother. A young girl's "beauty problems" are fewer but also more acute, according to most authorities, than those of the older woman.

MOSCOW, May 8 -- As Russian bombers and fighters continue to slash into the reserves the Luftwaffe is reported bringing forward to advance operational air fields behind the central and southern fronts, units of the Red Army in North Caucasus are converging on Novorossiisk.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 8 -- A new wave of anti-Semitic propaganda is being launched by the German press, led off by an article by Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Propaganada Minister, on "The Jews and the War" in this week's issue of his magazine, the Reich.

THIS journal, kept by a former captain in the Second North African Division, now a major in the Free French Forces, begins on the 23d of August, 1939, the day on which he was recalled from civilian life in Paris to report for duty to his regiment.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 8 -- Navy oarsmen ruled the choppy, wind-swept Severn today. Duplicating the victory attained by the smooth-stroking varsity in the afternoon's opening race, the junior varsity and plebe eights triumphed nicely to give the middies a clean sweep in the final major regatta of the wartime-abbreviated intercollegiate rowing season.

New betting records, several of which officials believe to be American or world highs, were set yesterday at Jamaica, where 30,056 persons saw Boysy, at $37.40, doggedly hammer his way home first in the $19,150 Grey Lag Handicap while the extraordinary figure of $2,174,497 clicked through the monster totalizator for a new world record on a seven-race program.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 8 (AP) -- Massachusetts Institute of Technology led Harvard by three points tonight at the end of the first day of racing in the seventh annual national dinghy championships of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association held on the Charles River, under the auspices of the M.I.T. Nautical Association.
WHAT will amount to a New York edition of a French opera comique is being planned to open here next October. It will be known as the Free French Opera Bouffe Company, according to Francis P. Loubet.

GEORGE HALE, a gentleman of good intentions, is the latest to fall under the Saroyan spell. He has acquired the stage rights to a part of "Razzle-Dazzle, or the Human Ballet, Opera and Circus, or There's Something I Got to Tell You; Being Many Kinds of Short Plays as Well as the Story of the Writing of Them, Period."

CELERY is another of those crops which the experts advise the amateurs to forget about until they have accumulated a little more experience. It's a rather exacting crop to grow in the home garden, requiring a rich soil and plenty of moisture to keep the plants growing strongly.

MRS. CORLISS does a neat job in light fiction, and her new novel is one of her best. It is a triangle story, with the husband and wife in their early thirties and the interloper one of these beautiful, open-eyed and outspoken gals of 20.

TUNIS, May 7 (Delayed) -- German cannon fire faded to the southeast and rain swept in in sheets from the Mediterranean as the long line of big British tanks we were accompanying rumbled past the suburb of Le Bardo into the streets of Tunis.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., May 8 -- Three thousand employes of the Westinghouse Lamp Division plant here stayed away from work today in protest against what they describe as "stalling" on the part of the company and the local manager Clerical workers and maintenance crews reported as usual.

NEXT Saturday, May 15, marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the United States air mail, which from modest beginnings reaches today into every continent with the speed and precision predicted by this newspaper and a few aeronautic notables a quarter-century ago.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 8 -- A single by Roy Triebel in the ninth scored Nat Militzok to give Hofstra a 4-3 victory over City College in a return Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference clash today.

New York far surpasses any other port in the country in the volume and value of its foreign export and import trade and in its domestic commerce, but the Port of New York Authority, in a recent analysis, held there should be no complacency about the port's post-war competitive position.

The war for North Africa was near its end yesterday. Crack German troops of the Grenadier and Elite Guards, of Marshal Erwin Rommel's Africa Korps, were being crowded into the hills of tiny Cap Bon. These were the men who had helped drive the British into the sea at Dunkerque in 1940, who had spearheaded the drives into Russia in 1941, who had hammered at Egypt's gates in 1942.

Mount St. Michael High of the Bronx, led by Leslie Kleist, scored 25 points to win the open team laurels at the fifth annual Boys High School interscholastic track and field games at Boys High Field, Brooklyn, yesterday.

As full United States participation in the United Nations' tea agreement awaited arrival of the first shipments scheduled under the new allocation plan, Benjamin Wood, managing director of the Tea Bureau, announced yesterday that there was a two-and-a-half month "backlog" of tea known to be held by distributors when the plan formally went into effect on April 3 and an undisclosed but substantial amount in addition which was held by the government.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Apparently -- the qualification is advisable in any statement concerning the tumultuous organization of the war program -- Donald M. Nelson has weathered another effort to supplant him as chairman of the War Production Board. If so, however, this was his narrowest escape.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 8 -- The remnants of the Axis force in Northern Tunisia -- cut off, split up or fleeing toward Cap Bon -- were being harried today by swarms of Allied planes and shot down and rounded up by swiftly moving columns of tanks and infantry.

Coal is one of the depressed industries that is expected to assume a far greater role in the nation's economy after the war. In fact, if the war should be of long duration, the coal industry may not have to wait until the cessation of hostilities before that position has been achieved.

LONDON -- Though the whole of Belgium proper is at present in the hands of the Germans, the Belgian Government in London still controls all the riches of a region comprising a twelfth of the African Continent -- the Belgian Congo -- and those riches are strengthening the United Nations war machine.

The vast army of white-collar workers are contributing a vital part toward the war program and a growing tendency to lose sight of this group in the rush of wartime planning, production and strategy was seen yesterday by Wayne L. Morse, dean of the University of Oregon Law School and public member of the National War Labor Board.

WHEN High Tor, the highest and probably the most famous crag along the Hudson River Palisades, had passed formally into the hands of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission, nature-lovers on both sides of the Hudson breathed easier.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 8 -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower, his face tanned from the sun, received newspaper correspondents today and told them that he had been informed by telephone last night of the capture of Tunis and Bizerte after his return from the front.

Coal miners are born, not made. Sons follow their fathers into the pits. The ancestors of America's miners mined coal in Wales, Poland, the Saar. The typical miner of today lives as his ancestors lived, in a shabby house of a remote village pitched near the entrance to a mine. In the other houses of the village are his relatives and boyhood friends, miners all.

The Reciprocal Trade Treaty powers seem to be up for renewal by Congress and for debate by the country. Advocates of renewal assume that these treaties have helped promote peace, democracy, freedom and trade, and they argue that administrative controls of tariffs have proved better than Congressional log-rolling.

Premier Hideki Tojo returned to Japan yesterday from a visit to the Philippines, and indicated that all was not peaceful in the islands when he declared that the Japanese Army there was carrying on "military operations" and working for the establishment of "peace and order," according to a Tokyo broadcast to Japanese areas, recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.
TUNIS, May 7 (Delayed) (AP) -- Hysterically happy inhabitants by the tens of thousands welcomed the Allied armies into Tunis late today.

THE White House is not merely the President's home; it is an institution. That, at least, is what the Office of Price Administration has decided when it comes to food rationing; and it was emphasized by Mrs. Henrietta Nesbitt, housekeeper for the President and Mrs. Roosevelt, when she was interviewed for this article on wartime menus in her domain.

OF the many art exhibitions offered this Spring to raise funds for various philanthropic and war-relief projects, one of the most unusual in prospect is that of paintings by Stark Young, author, lecturer, translator and former drama critic, who in recent years has turned to painting in oils as a new medium for his artistic expression.
BOSTON, May 8 -- Acrimony and the new balata ball were strongly in evidence today as the Braves beat the Dodgers, 3 -- 2.

FORT MONMOUTH N. J., May 8 -- After supper, when the day's drilling, firing practice and other duties are completed, hundreds of soldiers leave their mess halls and hasten to improvised classrooms, eager to improve themselves in academic fields.

With the fall of Tunis and Bizerte into the hands of the victorious Allied armies, the final defeat and annihilation of the last Axis forces in North Africa appear to be so close at hand that popular interest is already running ahead of the event to the next logical step, which is the invasion of the European Continent.

In the nine months ended on March 31, the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, producer of linseed oil, processor of soy beans and distributor of tung and various other imported oils, had a net profit of $2,762,797 after Federal income and excess profits taxes, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A clear-cut answer to the question of what the United States intends to do about Finland might have been provided before now if the Polish-Russian crisis had not intervened.

An end of the collection of general household scrap rubber was ordered yesterday by Frank D. March, city salvage director of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, upon instructions of the War Production Board.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 8 -- Despite intensive jamming by Axis stations, the French had news last night of the fall of Tunis and Bizerte through British and American broadcasts.

THERE are at this moment in the United States alone about 230 organizations concerned with the planning of the post-war world. They represent only a part of recent activity in this field. In the two decades which separated the two wars there appeared many thousands of books dealing with the international organization of peace, and not a week passes without additions.

The psychoanalyst, so frequently treated with disdain, has suddenly won the respect of the press, and all because hundreds of boys and girls are willing to stand in line to hear a swing band. Thousands of Americans have spent days in line for a world's series game and have paid exorbitant prices for boxing bouts and musical comedies without being subjected to ridicule.

Summer weather continued with a vengeance in New York yesterday, the temperature rising to 85 degrees at 4 P.M. to make the day the warmest of the year and only two degrees under the record high for the date of 87 degrees in 1936.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- A single by Pete Fox, scoring Roy Partee, gave the Red Sox a 2-to-1 victory over the Senators today in a ten-inning tussle before 5,000 fans.
CASABLANCA, French Morocco, May 8 (AP) -- The United States is providing tanks, guns and equipment and planning to help build a great French army in North Africa.

WHEN the publishers announce on the jacket of this book that the "reader is treated as a modern visitor," they indulge in a mild libel of the authors and a gross exaggeration of the treatment accorded visitors by even so hospitable a city as New York.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 8 -- Major Gen. Omar N. Bradley has commanded the Second United States Corps during the entire operation leading to the capture of Bizerte, General Dwight D. Eisenhower announced today.

Henry F. Markwalter, marine operations manager and operations manager and operations adviser of the War Shipping Administration, resigned last week to become assistant general manager of the Luckenbach Steamship Company and associated interests, it was announced here yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, May 8 -- A fierce Chinese counter-attack against Japanese landing forces on the south shore of Tungting Lake at Yulangchow cost the enemy half his forces and forced the remaining half to flee from shore in their boats, a High Command communique said today.

Fordham scored a 12-to-10 victory over the Mitchel Field service team yesterday on Fordham Field. The Maroon, after trailing by seven runs in the third inning, got to four Army pitchers to chalk up its seventh victory of the year.

WAR and the vicissitudes of war have enormously increased the demand for railroad transportation service. Part of the additional demand has resulted from the growth of war production. The huge increases in railroad freight and passenger traffic are in part, however, a direct consequence of such developments as the operations of German submarines in the Western Atlantic, of Japan's conquest of the sources of our crude rubber supply and of shipping shortages.

LISTEN, my children, and you shall hear the story of famous bands and a trumpetier. Dig, my Jacks and Jills, you all know the story of the Pied Piper of Hamelin. Well, here is a story of the Pied Piper of New York. His name is Harry James.

The National Federation of Music Clubs at the concluding session of its biennial business meeting at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday adopted a resolution protesting the order of the War Manpower Commission of Feb. 2, putting music teaching and music schools in the same category "as gambling halls, billiard parlors, clothing rental and massage parlors as non-deferrable occupations."

THE telephone rings at an office of the United States Employment Service. The personnel director of an aircraft plant wants to know whether he can get thirty airplane woodworkers in a hurry. The manager of the regional office, without even consulting his files, knows the answer.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 8 -- During the past year a significant change has come over the anomalous and predominantly Moslem area known as the Middle East. From a situation where Axis armies were hovering on the borders of the Nile Valley and menacing the front door to this area in Turkey and the back door to the Caucasus the Allies have entirely gained the initiative.

IN no country have the people of the Soviet Union been so consistently interested as in the United States of America. Despite long periods of diplomatic estrangement, the Russians have never lost their sympathy with their fellow men in the New World. These two lands, an objective observer might say without fear of Russian contradiction, are peculiarly fitted for collaboration.
PITTSBURGH, May 8 -- Government control of the mines seemed to make no difference tonight to miners striking against fines for recent wildcat walkouts in the bituminous fields.

There are one or two conclusions that may be reached after attending an annual meeting of Ducks Unlimited. Outstanding, of course, is the reaction that as long as Tom Main, Canadian manager for the organization, is on the job restoring the "duck factories" in the Dominion there will be no lagging to improve the waterfowl breeding conditions.

The New York State Bankers Association announced yesterday the results of its fiftieth annual election of officers, and the first it has ever conducted by mail ballot, resulted in the election of the regular slate. E. Chester Gersten, president of the Public National Bank and Trust Company of this city, was elected president of the association, to succeed John P. Myers, president of the Plattsburg National Bank and Trust Company, Plattsburg, N.Y.

SOWING seed thinly is a most economical procedure. It prevents wasting of seed, saves a great deal of work in thinning out the crowded seedlings and conserves additional moisture and available plant food for the very young plants.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- The Administration's plan to use subsidy payments to cut retail food prices drew angry protests today from surprised members of Congress, along with intimations of legislative action to halt the move.

BUFFALO, May 8 (AP) -- The Greater Buffalo, one of the largest passenger steamers on the Great Lakes, was commissioned the U.S.S. Sable today in colorful ceremonies and put in service as the Navy's second inland training aircraft carrier.

The film "Mission to Moscow" is the first instance in our country of totalitarian propaganda for mass consumption -- a propaganda which falsifies history through distortion, omission or pure invention of facts, and whose effect can only be to confuse the public in its thought and its loyalties.
WITH emphasis on rest and relaxation for war workers, Pennsylvania is well prepared for its role of host to many thousands of visitors during the warm months.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The War Production Board today restricted the sale and delivery of 39-inch 80/80 4.00 yard print cotton cloth orders carrying a preference rating of AA-5 or better, with the intention of restricting the use of such cloths to essential end-products only, particularly in production of military and industrial-type fabrics.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 8 (AP) -- A communique:

HERE is a searing antidote for those all-out readers who disliked John Steinbeck's "The Moon Is Down" -- a fictional account of the rape of Lidice that should haunt the isolationists for years to come. Here is a propaganda novel, pure and simple, preaching a crusade with hate for its banner -- and succeeding magnificently.

STOCKHOLM, May 7 -- On the eve of his departure for the United States, Sweden's great runner, Gunder Haegg, declared today he was eager to compete in American meets for war relief purposes and flatly denied published reports to the contrary.

THE Bach Choir of Bethlehem, Pa., will hold its thirty-sixth Bach festival Friday and Saturday at Packer Memorial Chapel, Lehigh University, in that city. In addition to the chorus of 200 voices, the participants will include forty members of the Philadelphia Orchestra, and, as soloists, Louise Miller, soprano; Lilian Knowles, contralto; Ernest McChesney, tenor; Bruce Boyce, baritone, and Rand Smith, bass.
There are not many new singles in the May releases, but several that are available are of more than average interest.

HERE is Mr. Kelland again with another snappy, up-to-the-minute story, full of eccentric characters, set in Hollywood and on location in Arizona, with lots of amusing dialogue. It is headed by an authentic cowgirl, owner of thousands of acres rented by the STG studios, and the lanky young man who gets her, secretary to Archibald, who is the great authority on Napoleon.
CHICAGO. MAY S (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Ceiling prices that may be charged for more than 300 food items beginning tomorrow by small independent food retailers in New York City, exclusive of Richmond, and Nassau County were announced here by the District Office of Price Administration yesterday at the same time that community dollars-and-cents ceilings were set up in more than 130 cities throughout the nation.

A curving chain of broad streets encircles the medieval heart of Dortmund, in Westphalian Germany. These streets -- Koenigswall Sudwald, Ostwall -- bear the names and follow the line of the stout walls that ringed the old part of the city as late as 1863. Within this perimeter are churches dating from the eleventh century, a Town Hall going back to the thirteenth.
The Yankees lost a ball game at the Stadium yesterday. What is more, they lost to the lowly Athletics before a gathering of 9,593, of whom 8,347 were paying spectators.

SOPHIE came every Friday to give a thorough cleaning to the author's house in a small town twenty miles from Bridgeport. At lunch time and in casual conversation her employer-friend, who tells the story, learned a great deal about Sophie, her children, her late husband, the people she worked for on other days of the week, her relatives and about Sophie's fervent patriotism as a fairly new American.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- A series of additional air raids on the Japanese positions in the Aleutians was reported by the Navy today. Kiska was hit five and Attu Island seven times on Thursday. Several fires were started. The raids on Attu represented a stepped-up tempo in the attacks on that objective.

Not merely "softness," but actual "sloppiness" is characteristic of many phases of both national and individual life in the United States, Wilson L. Fairbanks, telegraph news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES and founder of its education section, said yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel New Yorker at which he received honorary life membership in the American College Publicity Association.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Assembly Inn at Montreat, general assembly grounds of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, is being remodeled and renovated in preparation for the annual Summer assembly there, following departure this week of 264 Japanese and Germans, interned there the past six months.

The United States Conciliation Service of the Department of Labor was urged yesterday by the Independent Communications Guild, an independent union, to intervene in the labor dispute with Press Wireless, Inc., of 1475 Broadway, that resulted in a strike of 135 employes of the company last Friday night.

MAY was ushered in with the largest number of gallery exhibitions -- approximately twoscore -- of any week in the current season. Many of the events deserve more detailed comment than can be given them at this time and comment on several which continue beyond the present week must be deferred until later.
The American mother was praised as a true heroine of the war by rabbis in Mother's Day sermons here yesterday. The observance of National Family Week also was a sermon topic.

On Wednesday the last of the Spring courses at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden will begin. The series, on "Native Ferns," is presented from 6:30 to 7:30 P.M. on four successive Wednesdays, and will include a study of these plants and means of identifying them.

Drs. J.J. Pfiffner, S.B. Binkley and A.D. Emmett announce in Science that they have isolated and crystallized the anti-anemic Bc vitamin -- half a million times more potent than fresh liver -- which may speed convalescence from many illnesses because of its blood-regenerating effects.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Foxcroft Horse Show, which will open tomorrow morning, will be a community event for the benefit of charity. Ten open classes are listed and nine for Foxcroft pupils only. Prizes will be given in war stamps, $5 for first, $3 for second and $2 for third.
Students, especially girls, will have an excellent opportunity to influence public opinion in the post-war world, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday in addressing 750 high school students.

Early American silverware, historical prints and oil paintings were among the art objects sold yesterday at the final session of the auction of property of Mrs. J. Austin du Pont and others at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street. The day's receipts were $23,687 and the three-day total was $45,990.
The farther south of New York a motorist lives the easier he finds it to obtain supplemental gasoline rations for his passenger car, a survey made in five key cities disclosed last night.
LADY WITH A FLOOR -- A perennial problem with every homemaker is the upkeep of the floor. It is the part of the house that receives the most wear and it requires more care than any other surface.

" Black caviar," now in quantity production at East Alton, Ill., is the soldier's name for ball powder, which, as its name suggests, comes in globules. The powder is made by a new process under water five times more rapidly than is ordinary smokless powder.

Based on current prospects in raw materials and weaving facilities, output of women's apparel fabrics of rayon and of wool for Fall will be slightly under last year's peak figures but not much changed from the more normal demand that prevailed at the start of the 1941 Fall season, textile suppliers reported here yesterday.

A majority of the members of the United States Student Assembly, holding its first conference yesterday at the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue, twice fought off what the participants regarded as Communist bids for control and then heard Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt denounce the methods of the Young Communist League as "intolerable in this country."

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in an interview last night, deplored conditions in the coal mining areas and expressed the hope that a settlement of the strike issue would take into consideration not only the conditions the miners are living in today, but the incomparably worse conditions they have endured during the last ten years.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 9 -- A small transport, its decks and superstructure congested with Japanese troops, was fired and sunk yesterday in the second straight day of heavy Allied air attacks on Madang, New Guinea.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Former Governor Lehman, in his first press conference since his return from London, confirmed today the report that negotiations were going on for the formation of a United Nations relief organization in which the United States is expected to take the leading part.

LONDON, May 8 -- The news that Allied forces had entered Tunis and Bizerte was received here today with quiet satisfaction. Speakers throughout the country spoke with pride of the greatest Allied victory since the Wehrmacht was hurled back at Stalingrad.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Permission to charge higher prices and add larger mark-ups was asked of the Office of Price Administration today by representatives of the liquor package store owners of twenty States. They argued that without some such easement they would be unable to stay in business.

IN this war the "technical manoeuvre" known as "getting the hell out of there" covers a multitude of situations. It is what a submarine commander or a P-T boat skipper does after firing his torpedoes; what a B-17 crew does after the bombardier's shout of "Bombs away!"; what a fighter pilot does after his ammunition is exhausted.

WASTHINGTON, May 8 -- The brief national coal strike which was halted by a "neck-to-neck" finish when President Roosevelt and John L. Lewis called upon the bituminous and anthracite miners to return to the pits revealed but one chapter in a more comprehensive situation.
It's print time. At this season of the year prints begin to blossom in the stores, bringing with them the same cheeriness that the flowering trees bestow on the outdoor scene.

VINES are useful as well as beautiful inhabitants of our gardens. Together with trees and shrubs they may be a part of the background or, singly, vines make striking focal points. Nine times out of ten vines are planted for a utilitarian purpose: to screen the drying yard, conceal the compost heap, shut off the adjoining empty lot.
THE odoriferous onion -- so necessary as a smother on steak or liver or as flavoring for soup or salad, not to mention its value raw or cooked -- should be included in every home garden.

ALLIED FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 8 -- It was suddenly discovered this week that American troops had become veterans. At a heavy cost of life but with a determination and willingness to sacrifice themselves reminiscent of Belleau Wood and the Argonne, they smashed through unimaginably difficult mountain country to capture Bizerte and unhinge the right flank of the whole Axis Tunisian position.

It is evident that Hugh Gibson does not agree as to the primary importance of our position in world affairs between the wars, or he would not say "it is difficult to see how the addition of one or more members" to the League could have remedied "the interplay of great forces and of the operation of power politics in endeavoring to control them."

THE things children like often differ greatly from the things grown-ups think children will like. People who work with the young soon find this out, and it was proved again when close to 1,000 boys and girls voted on their choices in a recent exhibit of prints arranged for them at the Junior Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

AFTER the flood of revivals to which the London theatre managers have subjected us it is a pleasant change to record the arrival of two new plays by Noel Coward, "Present Laughter" and "This Happy Breed," which are being run in alternation at the Haymarket.

MOST books coming directly out of our Army have been written by privates, and one observer of this fact indignantly asked: What are the officers doing? Colonel Thomason is an answer to the query; he is telling it for the marines, and should be able to hold his line indefinitely in the battle of books.

LONDON, May 8 (Canadian Press) -- Blackpool today won the English league, northern division, cup by defeating Sheffield Wednesday, 4 -- 3, in a two-game, total-goal series that closed the major football season.

READERS of this collection of fantasy tales from Story Magazine will be their own critics, for as Whit Burnett says in the foreword it is "a book of imagination." and imagination is the place where people depart from each other and go separate ways.

A German who deserted from the American Army before the first World War and who confessed yesterday to having plotted in 1914 to blow up the strategic Welland Canal on instructions from Franz von Papen, then German military attache here, was among the thirty-one enemy aliens arrested in greater New York this week-end.

LORD HALIFAX, the British Ambassador, and Lady Halifax head the list of patrons and patronesses for the tea dance and cocktail party to be given Tuesday at Sherry's by the Royal Standard Chapter, Daughters of the British Empire, as a benefit for the Victoria Home for the Aged in Ossining, N.Y.

THE eighteenth annual Spring Song Festival and Dance of the People's Chorus of New York will be given under the direction of Lorenzo Camilieri, its conductor, on the evening of May 20 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
