FOR the past five years, or ever since the Diamond Horseshoe opened its doors, Billy Rose has successfully dedicated his shows to that bygone era of mustache cups, whalebone corsets, bustles and Billy Watson's Beef Trust. But sometime toward the end of this month, possibly around May 26, the Tom Thumb impresario will radically deviate from that policy by presenting a Summer show that will peek into the future.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- Buster Maynard, the Giants' slugging outfielder, gave a vigorous demonstration today that seemed to prove two points of considerable interest concerning the current affairs of baseball.

FATHER ISAAC HECKER, founder of that Congregation of St. Paul which has its church in the heart of New York, had swallowed his own dram of the elixir of New England. As a boy he knew the Manhattan of the Forties.

A plan providing for the release of draft-eligible war workers for induction into the armed services without disruption of production schedules on vital war equipment has been worked out by two subsidiaries of the Sperry Corporation in collaboration with the Selective Service System, it was announced yesterday by Thomas A. Morgan, president of the corporation.

THE exact size of America's bridge-playing population is a much-argued point. It has been estimated as high as 35,000,000 and as low as 15,000,000. Whatever the correct figure. a group that has bought as many as 50,000,000 decks of playing cards and 1,000,000 instruction books in a single year must be a vast one.

The American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators calls attention to a decision of the Vermont Supreme Court which may have a wide bearing on billboard control when that question comes to the fore again. The court upholds the constitutionality of a State law which had been challenged by the billboard industry.

NEWARK, N. J., May 8 -- Seven metropolitan newspaper women received here today certificates of merit from the New Jersey Women's Press Club for outstanding contributions to their field of writing. The awards were presented at the annual luncheon meeting of the club in Schrafft's Restaurant here.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace was named yesterday as the winner of the poll taken annually among its membership by the Association of Teachers of Social Studies, as the American who has contributed most to the thought or to the teaching of the social studies.

FENNEL is a delicious Italian vegetable that has come very much into favor in recent years. It has been grown for centuries in Italy and Southern Europe, but owing to climate and soil conditions it has generally been considered difficult to grow in this country.

IT can hardly be said of Cornelia Otis Skinner that she has yearned to be a movie star. A literate and versatile woman, Miss Skinner has for quite a few seasons been conducting her career very successfully far from the peripheries of the movie colony.

In a letter sent to Mayor La Guardia yesterday, the Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association declared that it was "astounded" at his failure to reappoint Mrs. Johanna. Mr. Lindlof as a member of the Board of Education. The association prepared an extensive itemized list of activities that Mrs. Lindlof had sponsored or supported during her seven-year term of office.

To achieve a stable economy in the post-war world, more employment-providing industries must be established to balance the laborsaving enterprises, so that production does not continue to outstrip both employment and purchasing power, Dr. Robert J. McFall of the Magazine Marketing Service declared here yesterday.

ON Easter Sunday the U.S.S. Dace slid down its ways -- the first submarine that women helped to build. As one foreman said, "We were all a lot of skeptics, but the whole top of the boat was burned and welded entirely by women, and when the Navy passed it as a perfect job we were sold."

SLIP COVERS this Spring are not merely versatile short-cuts to home attractiveness. In these days of priorities and furniture shortage they are also the answer to many a conservation problem. Ungainly side chairs (such as the three illustrated above), chipped tables and worn-out sofas are back in service, brought up to date by smartly made slip covers. The make-it-yourself movement is spreading and many department stores now have classes in slip-cover making.

THE music news of the week -- the commercial sponsorship of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony for a "series" of fifty-two Sunday afternoon concerts -- represents quite a coup for the amiable Paul M. Hollister and the CBS sales department.

A reader calls attention to Mrs. Roosevelt's comment on THE NEW YORK TIMES recent survey of what American college freshmen know about American history. Mrs. Roosevelt said: "I don't think it is half as important to remember some of the things people did not know in THE TIMES test as to know where to go to look them up and how to look them up."

NEW accessions and a rearrangement of the silver collection at the Museum of the City of New York draw attention to the most extensive group of old-time New York craftsmanship in this metal to be seen in any museum.

In a capacious storeroom in the basement at 10 Rockefeller Plaza crates, boxes and bundles, neatly labeled and carefully camphored, give mute testimony to the faith of the Dutch community here in the ultimate liberation of its homeland.

NEW YORK'S observance of the silver anniversary on Saturday of the establishment of regularly scheduled air-mail service by the government -- between New York and Washington on May 15, 1918 -- will include an exhibition of rare and interesting air-mail covers and stamps under the sponsorship of the local members of the American Air Mail Society.
Biochemists and nutritionists now speak of six B vitamins with considerable familiarity. These six are thiamine, riboflavin, nicotinic acid, pantothenic acid, pyridoxine and choline.

THE discussion of newcomers crashing New York radio seems to be going on apace. I read Elsajean Geyer's letter in the radio section of THE TIMES on April 18. Then along comes Bill Zuckert two weeks later with an entirely different picture, or so it would seem, and as another newcomer I've simply got to have my say.

Dr. Theodore R. Freedman, under indictment for larceny in connection with padding bills for treating workmen's compensation claimants, has lost his license to practice medicine in such cases, Michael J. Murphy, Acting State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday.

The Committee for a Jewish Army of Stateless and Palestinian Jews issued yesterday a statement in answer to the criticism made on the Senate floor on Thursday by Senator Lucas of Illinois concerning an advertisement inserted in THE NEW YORK TIMES by the committee last Tuesday "condemning" the work of the recent international refugee conference in Bermuda.

FORTUNE GALLO'S San Carlo Opera Company will give a series of twelve performances from Wednesday, May 26, through Sunday, June 6, at the Center Theatre. The company will number about 200, with a large orchestra, chorus and ballet.

THE deep voice of First Deputy City Clerk Murray W. Stand rolled out from the midst of daisy plants, Easter lilies and a bowerful of potted ferns. "Do you, Gene Chapoton, take this woman to be your lawful wedded wife?"

THE prize award season ended last week on a note of high comedy. The drama critics met with considerable formality on Sunday evening, officially to give their good-will plaque to Sergeant Sidney Kingsley for his "The Patriots," and barely had the echoes died when from Morningside Heights came word Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" had won the Pulitzer Prize.

IF possible, Mr. Matson's sequel to "The Passionate Witch," which he completed for Thorne Smith of mad memory, is even crazier than that wildly supernatural tale. When Jennifer was killed twice and buried at last you may have thought that must be the end of her beauty and naughtiness.

MR. GRAHAM'S book is the result of exhaustive research, personal associations that go back through many years, and it has painstaking attention to detail. The wonder is that the book has not been written earlier, for the material has been there a long time.

Prices of stocks recovered yesterday almost all the ground lost on Friday and the trading was the largest for a Saturday in more than a year. Volume of 1,063,210 shares on the New York Stock Exchange was the best since Dec. 27, 1941, and the week's turnover was the largest since the week which ended on May 18, 1940.

NAVAL TRAINING STATION, Norfolk, Va., May 8 -- A new and startlingly realistic scientific training device, invented to advance the Navy's program to make its anti-aircraft gunners the most deadly in the world, has been put into use at this mammoth center, where "specialists" in air defense and anti-submarine warfare are being turned out by the thousands.

It never happened before and the chances are that it never will happen again -- a team scoring 108 points in a fifteen-event championship track and field meet, as did Emil Von Elling's Violets from New York University yesterday at Brooklyn College Field.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8 -- Excellent relief pitching by Ralph Cox, plus a six-run eighth inning, won an important Eastern League baseball game for Pennsylvania today as the Quakers came from behind to down Princeton, 10 to 6. The Orange and Black shelled Bert Kuczynski from the mound early in the contest, but Cox came along to check the Tigers.

VALLETTA, Malta, May 8 -- The shrill cry of the siren, which a few months ago sent townsfolk hurrying to the cellars, brought them to the rooftops on this day of victory to survey towns and checkered parcels of land that now appeared to be safe and secure forever against the threat of enemy occupation.

FOG shrouds the waterfront. It drifts above the rough gray surface of the river like ragged streamers of steam rising from a gigantic weld. Docks and boats stand blurred and lost in the gray. The long, canopy-like skeletons of steel rising above the ways of the shipyard melt into mist.

A CITY-WIDE "attic hunt" to collect worn clothing which can be remade into garments for three million homeless children in England is now being conducted by members of the newly formed Salvage Sewing Division of the British War Relief Society, Inc.

Millions of trained workers for the post-war world, in industry, the professions, teaching and the arts -- this is the aim of the War Prisoners Aid of the Y. M. C. A., at work in prison camps through out the world.

LONDON, May 8 -- A major struggle took place today at the White City Stadium, and it wasn't the football game between two United States Army teams for the benefit of the British Red Cross Prisoners of War Fund.

DESPITE the much-publicized reports that the film rights to Captain Eddie Rickenbacker's life story were sold for "the highest figure yet paid for a single piece of potential picture material," it is now disclosed that there has been no direct purchase.

Revived activity was noted in wholesale markets last week as a result of ordering by the many buyers in town, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company. More buyers are expected this week and next.
The matter of the repeal of the Chinese Exclusion Act will come up before the House Committee on Immigration and Naturalization on May 12.
ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The annual display of tulips in the collection of some 2,000,000 plants set out in this city's park areas and along the Boardwalk will be in full bloom next week.

Claims for a share in the nation's steel supply in the third quarter of 1943 have mounted to such considerable proportions that it has become necessary for the steel division of the War Production Board to pare the requirements from all sources, including the Army and the Navy.

MOSCOW, April 22 -- The Russians are fighting a great battle and winning it. It is not a battle that is making headline news. It is a battle against destruction, against smashed bridges, ruined roads and tangled railway tracks.

THOSE rugged individuals who have annually hit the trail for a furlough of hiking in the wild country will probably have a number of new companions this year -- companions whose idea of using shanks' mare is a mile walk.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) -- In what his associates said was a protest against asserted domination of the War Manpower Commission by "management" interests, Fowler V. Harper resigned today as deputy chairman of the agency.

THE manpower problem is simple in conception. War is a consumer of men as it is of materiel. It needs fighting men and it needs men in factories and on the farms to produce supplies. The manpower problem is to get the men (and women) for these purposes and to distribute them proportionately according to war needs.

Prices of cotton held steady again yesterday in dull trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. Fluctuations were within a 5-point range, and the close was irregular, 2 points higher to 4 points lower than Friday's final quotations.

Reichsfuehrer Hitler's last grip on the Mediterranean was broken yesterday as Allied flags flew above Bizerte and Tunis and the harried remnants of a once-proud Axis army retreated to their last stand in the Cap Bon peninsula.

BIG ICEBOX -- In a man-made Arctic at Northwestern University's Technological Institute engineers are making tests of military equipment at 78 degrees below zero -- probably the lowest temperature ever attained for full-scale research. The cold is so intense that water poured from a glass turns to ice before it strikes the floor and immediately builds up stalagmites.

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- Official and unofficial Washington's penchant for eating any place but at home caused acute embarrassment to several citizens this week and added "the big red house on R Street" to the capital's alliteratively alluring dwelling houses.

" SEVEN GOTHIC TALES" was published nearly ten years ago, but people who read it have no trouble remembering it. Like all wonderful things, it was not entirely new, yet there was never any book quite like it.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 8 -- Army defeated the University of Pittsburgh, baseball team on Doubleday Field today, 9 -- 2.

Walsh of Fordham University predicted yesterday at the New York regional meeting of the Catholic Historical Association at the Hotel Commodore.

Economists did battle Wednesday night at the New School for Social Research. At the end of the conflict there was no decision but a sneaking suspicion in more than one mind that the government is quite likely to try out the theories that were under fire.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 8 -- The Calumet Farm's Nellie L., a daughter of Blenheim II, toyed with her opposition today to win decisively the sixty-ninth Kentucky Oaks, second richest stake of the Churchill Downs Spring meeting.

A DEMONSTRATION victory garden will be the setting for a "farm in the sky" party to be given for the benefit of Russian War Relief on Friday afternoon, and repeated Saturday, on the terrace of Mme. Helena Rubinstein's penthouse at 625 Park Avenue.

SOPHISTICATED listeners at opera and symphony who gathered last week in Brander Matthews Hall to hear "A Tree on the Plains," a chamber opera by Paul Horgan, librettist, and Ernest Bacon, composer, may well have exclaimed or cringed in their seats as naive ineptitudes of this musical folk drama succeeded each other and they waited, till the final fall of the curtain, to see what would happen next.

BALTIMORE, May 8 -- With the serenity of an old gentleman in his rocking chair on a front veranda Johnny Longden sat down on the famous back of Count Fleet this afternoon and rode a mile and three-sixteenths to fame and glory in the fifty-third running of the historic Preakness Stakes.

Because "knowledge is of value only when it can be used," fifty students of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia are putting academic theory into practice by publishing daily newspapers in eight New York towns after only one day's preparation in the strange communities, Dean Carl W. Ackerman said yesterday in reviewing the school work this semester.

WEATHER conditions have become more of a factor in the current condition of retail trade and the change last week to warmer temperatures brought out livelier buying. In spite of the impact of higher income taxes and the huge amount subscribed to the war loan, the reaction from the Easter splurge was less than last year.

The week-end meeting in Washington between members of the Office of Price Administration and representatives of wholesale and retail liquor dealers on the proposed new pricing order for the industry in the so-called open States produced certain "complications" which may delay the scheduled issuance of the new regulation on June 1, it was reported here yesterday.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., May 8 -- J. Harry Miles's Itabo, a 19-to-5 shot, today won the $2,500 Blackstone Valley Handicap before a closing-day crowd of 25,000 at Narragansett Park.

THAT this novel about love and the war should end tragically will be a surprise to many readers. For, even though the book deals with the slow death of a French Army transport on its way from Syria to Marseille in the late Spring of 1940, it also tells of the love between two Americans an Army surgeon and a newspaper woman, and tells their story glowingly, with that shiny touch of magazine covers.

P. time-table, when a boy came with a telegram from the employer upon whose behalf he was advancing the "Hot Mikado" road tour.

They mention the minutes used in budgeting points, the hours spent in marketing, the afternoons filled with war duties.

AMHERST, Mass., May 8 -- A triple by Pitcher Bill Donovan in the eleventh inning enabled the Williams baseball team to beat Amherst today, 3 to 1. The home team tallied once in the seventh inning and enjoyed this lead until the ninth, when Williams tied the count.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, May 8 (AP) -- Taking advantage of a deception that pulled the bulk of the German tanks in North Africa well out of their path, British armored forces slashed swiftly through Tunis and today were chasing the retreating enemy to his last refuge on the African continent -- Cap Bon Peninsula.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 8 -- Navy's midshipmen today proved themselves as good on land as they are on the water by gaining top honors in the elimination test of the Eastern intercollegiate golf team championship, at the Springdale Golf Club, home links of Princeton's team.

OTTAWA, May 8 -- Nearly a million people, or one in every eleven in Canada, have subscribed to the Fourth Victory Loan. With still another week to go, about a third of the amount of $1,100,000,000 still has to come in.

Stock markets generally interpreted last week's news developments favorably and, save in the final hours of Friday, strode forward on all fronts. Prices scaled the barrier from which they had receded after April 6 and went on to the best levels since Nov. 19, 1940.

LONDON, Monday, May 10 -The Russian Air Force, bolstered by American-made planes, has destroyed or damaged 930 German planes in the past week as the prelude to decisive Summer land campaigns, Moscow disclosed early today.

PITTSBURGH, May 9 (AP) -- The world champion Cardinals, pepped up by the return of two ailing stars, jumped on the Pirates for an 8 -- 1 victory in the first game of a double-header before 25,887 fans today, but had to be content with a 3 -- 3 tie in the nightcap, which wound up in a wild scene.
PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -There was still no end of bounce in the new balata ball today, but there was practically no bounce whatever in the Giants.

WASHINGTON, May 9--M. Lee Marshall, chairman of the board of directors of the Continental Baking Company, has been appointed Deputy Administrator of the War Food Administration in charge of programs for the provision of supplies, machinery, equipment, materials and facilities used in producing and processing food.
A recent letter in your columns by Representative Emanuel Celler raises certain points and asks certain questions with regard to the Equal Rights Amendment, now before Congress.

LONDON, May 9 (AP) -- General Wilhelm Krueger, chief of the Gestapo in Poland and principal organizer of the German terror campaign against the Poles, was shot fatally in Cracow on May 2, official Polish circles reported today.

Along with knitting, the war has brought a renaissance of the art of sewing a fine seam and of whipping up samples of various kinds of fine needlework. Manufacturers of embroidery yarns, stamped goods and similar equipment report that enthusiasm is mounting, especially in the field of applique.

BUFFALO, May 9 (AP) -- More than 800 women, some of them employed as seamstresses, salesgirls, beauticians and waitresses before the war, are doing man-size jobs now in the steel mills of Buffalo and Lackawanna.

DETROIT, May 9 -- Representative Paul W. Shafer of Michigan and two aides arrived here today to investigate alleged irregularities at the Selfridge Field Army base, John C. Lehr, United States District Attorney, declared he intended to ask the Federal grand jury for the indictment of at least fifty civilians who, he asserted, had been involved in efforts to gain specific considerations for service men at the field.

In announcing formation of the Help the Children Committee, Inc., with headquarters at 444 Madison Avenue, James Wood Johnson, its head, declared yesterday that "Hitler may win the youth of the world, even after he has himself been destroyed in a military sense, unless we give the coming young generation now the attention it must have."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 9 -- The United States First Infantry Division, the Fighting First, including a high percentage of New Yorkers and Easterners, has borne the brunt of the heaviest mountain fighting through perhaps the most difficult territory in the American sector in following up the enemy.

Fortunately, it is a commonplace human trait to insist upon making the best of things as they are. Forced by scarcity to do without, we immediately begin to rationalize the situation and discover that we are better off really, for the deprivation.

Today's confusion has arisen from religious indifference, or laziness, from a disintegration of moral standards and from "philosophical illiteracy," declared the Rev. Marion J. Creeger, associate program director of the Army and Navy Department of the Y.M.C.A., 347 Madison Avenue, in a sermon yesterday morning.
CINCINNATI, May 9 -- Cincinnati took a double pasting from the Cubs, 13 to 2 in the first game and 4 to 3 in the nightcap, before a crowd of 10,714 today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Senators swept a double-header with the Red Sox before 19,000 fans today, taking the nightcap, 8 to 2, after edging out the Sox, 3 to 2, in the ten-inning first game.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 10 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, May 9 (U.P.) -James A. Farley, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, speaking today at the annual war Mother's Day services at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier and in Arlington Amphitheatre, declared that the nation depended on its mothers to protect its democratic institutions, just as it depended on its sons to guard its sovereignty on the world battlefields.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., May 9 (U.P.) -Roane Waring, National Commander of the American Legion, today branded the South Fork Post 673 of Johnstown, Pa., as "un-American."
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) -Heavy bombing raids throughout the Solomon Islands area battered three Japanese destroyers and four enemy bases, the Navy reported today. One destroyer suffered a direct hit.

LONDON, May 9 (U.P.) -- The Air Ministry news service said tonight that nearly 700 United States and British war prisoners were freed at La Goulette, Tunisia, from an Italian ship which ran aground under heavy Allied air attacks while heading for Italy.

LA FOLLETTE, Tenn., May 9 (U.P.) -- Checks for $100 have been given the families of ten coal miners who were killed Wednesday in an explosion at the Etna Coal and Coke Company's mine here, by John J. Lewis and officials of the United Mine Workers.

Conversion to war production has been accomplished by the Rudolph Wurlitzer Company without ill effects, according to an annual report by R.C. Rolfing, president. Net profit for the year which ended on March 31, after all charges and an appropriation of $150,000 for contingency reserve, was $755,545, against $704,311 for the preceding year.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 9 -- Elizabeth Bradley, a junior at Vassar College, has learned that having a famous father is not all fun. Her father is Major Gen. Omar N. Bradley, who commanded the Second United States Corps during the entire operation that led to the capture of Bizerte.

FORT OGLETHORPE, Ga., May 9 (AP) -- Declaring that "more and more Waacs are going to go overseas," and that many thousands more than have responded to the recruitment call were needed at once for duty in the Continental United States, H.C. Petersen, executive assistant to the Under-Secretary of War, called today for "a greater response" from available women of the nation.

Business conditions in New York are improving, despite efforts of detractors to make them worse, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday in his weekly radio talk from City Hall. The Mayor said that weekly reports from George Sloan, his Commissioner of Commerce, have been quite encouraging and that even the department stores cannot "discredit New York City" because their own business has been increasing.

The third annual communion and breakfast of the St. George Association of the United States Treasury Department in New York was held yesterday morning, with 650 members attending. They met in St. Thomas Episcopal Church at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street at 8 o'clock for services conducted by the Rev. Roelif H. Brooks and then went to a breakfast in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, May 9 -- Germany's fear of an Allied invasion through the Balkans increased tonight and Turkish reports said Nazi occupation authorities had warned that if they were obliged to abandon I Greece they would leave the country in ruins.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Outlook for the new Winter and Spring wheat crops is gradually coming to the fore as a price-making influence, and a considerable part of the erratic price changes on the Board of Trade last week reflected reports as to the condition of the crop.

HONOLULU, Hawaii, May 9 -Everyone not directly employed in war work should immediately seek such employment, Admiral Chester Nimitz' declared today before 17,000 persons at a rally here opening Governor Ingram Stainback's "Work to Win" campaign to relieve Hawaii's labor shortage by enlisting all possible workers.

Trading and price fluctuations in the cotton futures market last week were slight as caution, stemming from uncertainty over the ultimate effect of the government's sales of its stocks of the commodity to check any rise in prices, enveloped the market. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended the week with net advances of 5 points to losses up to 6 points.
As an ardent admirer of Rachmaninoff and all great music, I want to comment upon the editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 2.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 10 (AP) -- Seven Japanese medium bombers struck at the remote Allied airfield at Millimgimbi in Australia's Northern Territory east of Darwin Sunday but caused little damage and only light casualties.

Tonight is the anniversary of a characteristic Nazi ceremony in Berlin and many other university cities in 1933. The next week the rest of the university cities observed the rites. Incited by the hierarchs of the Nazi faith, students had for days been going about in automobiles collecting books deemed heretical.

Without recognizing the "fact of God," we cannot understand man, and until we understand man, we cannot solve our problems, the Rev. Dr. N.J. Gould Wiekey of Washington declared yesterday in a sermon at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 9 (AP) -The Bisons pounded the Newark Bears for six runs in the first inning today, then had to punch over another in the tenth with one out to win, 7 -- 6, before 4,355.

John van Druten has completed a new play, temporarily entitled "The Voice of the Turtle," which Alfred de Liagre Jr. will produce early next Fall. An out-of-town tryout will precede the Broadway premiere. Mr. van Druten's last play was "The Damask Cheek," which he wrote with Lloyd Morris and which ran for ninety-two performances earlier this season with Flora Robson in the leading role.
Brookhattan defeated the Wanderers by 3 -- 2 and the New York Americans turned back the Hispanos, 5 -- 2, in the Duffy Cup soccer series at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Paced by Rudy York's first 1943 homer, the Tigers exploded an extra-base attack in the eleventh inning to take the second game of a double-header, 4 to 1, from the White Sox before 10,201 fans today after Rookie Dick Wakefield's muff of an inning-ending fly gave the Chicagoans the opener, 3 to 1.

Fifteen assistantships and fourteen scholarships for the scholastic year 1943-44 have been awarded by the Fordham University Graduate School, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Gustave Dumas, dean of the school.

With eighteen named for the Toboggan Handicap and fourteen for the Fashion Stakes, racing at Belmont Park is scheduled to start today with post time set for 1:30 P.M. Shut Out, last year's Kentucky Derby winner, is scheduled to make his first appearance this season in the Toboggan as one of a three-ply Greentree Stable entry that also includes Devil Diver and The Rhymer.

The significance of our occupation of Amchitka Island, only 73 miles from Kiska, lies not in what it has already accomplished but in what it portends. The belated announcement that we have held this new Aleutian base for four months and built an airfield on it explains the pattern of almost continual bombing to which Kiska and Attu have recently been exposed.

At the same time as it has published dollar-and-cents ceilings on retail food prices to go into effect today the Office of Price Administration has announced another policy of the first importance. It will "roll back" by an average of 10 per cent, effective June 1, the price to the consumer of beef, veal, pork, lamb, mutton, coffee and butter; and it will do this with the aid of subsidies.

LOS ANGELES, May 9 -- How Dave Levitt, former aircraft worker who is accused of denouncing Captain E.V. Rickenbacker as "No. 2 rat of the second World War," became an employe of the fire department, is explained by Fire Chief Alderson in a report sent to the City Council.

SAVANNAH, Ga., May 9 (AP) -Merrel P. Callaway, trustee of the Central of Georgia Railroad, has notified creditors and other parties interested in the railroad's reorganization that hearing on a petition to sell nearly $2,000,000 in bond issues of three other railways owned by the Central has been set for May 22 in the United States District Court here.

The Voge Opera Group presented last night at the New York Times Hall excerpts from eleven operas, sung in Italian, German, Russian and English by a cast of eleven young men and women. The men were modernly dressed in black trousers and white collarless shirts, the women mostly in simple black frocks.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The French military mission here published today the text of the letter sent by General Henri Honor6 Giraud on April 27 to General Charles de Gaulle asking the Fighting French leader to confer with him as soon as possible at either Marrakesh in French Morocco or Biskra in Algeria.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (U.P.) -Senator George, chairman of the Finance Committee, said tonight the skip-a-year tax measure based on the Ruml plan would be reported to the floor tomorrow. He said he hoped debate could be held to a single day and that a vote could be taken either on Tuesday or Wednesday.

An "international commemoration" of the tenth anniversary of the burning of the books by the Nazis will take place this evening at the Studio Theatre, 66 West Twelfth Street, at 8:15 o'clock, under the sponsorship of Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, Dr. Albert Einstein, William L. Shirer, Franz Werfel and others.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 -Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will make a picture based on the Japanese invasion of Indo-China, under the title "Saigon." Harry Hervey, novelist and playwright, who sold the original story to the studio, has arrived to work on the development of a screen play.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 9--Dr. Joseph Goebbels has been fighting a losing battle here, where American propaganda has slowly overwhelmed the Nazis' energetic and carefully planned effort to convince the Swedes that Germany has right on her side and is bound to win the war.

CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- Awarding of thirty-nine Rosenwald fellowships totaling $65,500 and twenty-one scholarships totaling $16,000 was announced by Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund.
MOSCOW, May 9 -- Telegrams of congratulations on the North African victory were sent today by the All-Slav Committee at its meeting in the Moscow Trade Union Hail this afternoon.

At a time when war conditions have multiplied the number of foot ailments, scientists have perfected the medical use of a substance known to all housewives that is having "amazingly wonderful" results in healing foot injuries, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Podiatry Society of the State of New York at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

New York City's plans to undertake the retailing of meat as well as potatoes and fish were indicated at City Hall yesterday following the regular Sunday broadcast of Mayor La Guardia, who at first only hinted that Markets Commissioner Daniel P. Woolley was now "negotiating on something else."

CHUNGKING, China, May 9 (U.P.) -- Chinese guns have smashed new Japanese attempts to land on the south shore of Tungting Lake by sinking four loaded enemy transports, but the invaders have captured another town north of the lake, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE in Northern India, April 27 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant George M. Colarich, 29, of Coleraine, Minn., walked wearily into headquarters today and told how he bailed out of a P-40 and tramped through the jungles over the Naga hills before reaching civilization nine days later.
Seven new films will open here this week. The schedule follows:

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor slipped into the city yesterday, raising less stir than the gentle morning breeze. The Sunday quiet of Pennsylvania Station went unbroken. Travelers hurried on their way-unaware that royalty rode in on the Silver Meteor.

The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, at Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, delivered there yesterday a sermon on "The Might of a Minority." He declared that in the building of a more united world order the church must rise above divisive and sectarian spirit within its own ranks.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Organized labor as represented by the Labor Policy Committee of the Office of Price Administration promised today to throw its weight behind the new OPA control program "in so far as this represents a genuine rollback in the cost of living."

Joan of Arc was a humble French girl who led an army to victory, seated the king upon the throne of France and perished a martyr to her love of country. France in her time was dismembered and ravaged. The king lived in obscurity, shorn of authority. With the support of the Duke of Burgundy, the enemy occupied the north of France.

Eager to get started on production of Fall goods, manufacturers in most apparel fields have closed their Spring and Summer lines, leaving little merchandise in the market to cover fill-in ordering, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
CHICAGO, May 9 (AP) -- The Bureau of Agricultural Economics, commenting on the livestock feed situation, reports as follows:

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 111.8. The relative stability of the index in the past four weeks indicates that the efforts of the government to hold down prices are temporarily effective.

The strike of 150 technical and clerical employes of Press Wireless, Inc., whose transmission lines serve the great news-gathering agencies as well as many individual papers, continued yesterday as charges and counter-charges on the responsibility for the walkout, begun Friday evening in the midst of a stream of important war news, came from the company and the Independent Communications Guild, the union directing the strike.
The German Sunday communique, as broadcast fro Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

The Allied armies entered Tunis and Bizerte six months to the day after the Americans landed in Africa. "You have been a long time arriving," said the first Frenchman who greeted Drew Middleton, THE TIMES correspondent, whose account of the march into Tunis was so vivid that the reader heard the sobs and shouts of the people and saw the home-made British and American flags flying beside the Tricolor in the thick Mediterranean rain.

SUPERIOR, Wis., May 9 -- A world ship-launching record was set here today at the Walter Butler Shipyard when the Dionne quintuplets named five oceangoing ships. The ceremonies, too, marked the first occasion on which the quintuplets had appeared in the United States.
A world organized for peace is no perfectionist ideal but a realistic social necessity, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday morning in his sermon in The Riverside Church.

LONDON, May 9 -- Two of the most intellectual young men in Uncle Sam's army have collaborated on a highly unintellectual character called "Artie Greengroin, private first class," and as a result the fan mail of the magazine Yank is increasing and Artie has become the most controversial private in the European theatre of operations.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Receipts of 975,000 bushels of Canadian oats last week and reports that 300,000 bushels more were en route here gave the market for that grain a weaker undertone and the close yesterday on the Board of Trade was at losses of 1/2 to 7/8 cent a bushel, with May at 62 5/8 cents, July at 60 7/8 to 60 3/4, September at 60 1/4 and December at 61 5/8 cents.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 9 -- More than 1,000,000 tons of shipping space were saved last year by carrying out the recommendations of the Middle East Supply Center, it was announced today at the conclusion of a three-day meeting here of British-American experts from all countries in the Middle East.

With the need for women workers expected to reach the critical stage by Fall, a large-scale campaign to recruit women workers for both essential civilian and war industry will break in September, according to the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- President Roosevelt's first public comment on the Tunisian victory came tonight in messages of congratulation that he dispatched to General Dwight D. Eisenhower and General Henri Honore Giraud.

With more colleges represented in the 100-yard dash than in any other test on the sixteen-event program, the crowning of a new I.C. 4-A sprint champion or champions will produce exciting competition in the sixty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. meet at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, Saturday.
The port of New York is operating at top efficiency in handling the volume of war and lend-lease shipments passing through it, spokesmen for maritime interests declared yesterday.

The annual Festival of Jewish Music (Ritual-Chassidic-Secular), sponsored by the Synagogue Light in conjunction with the American Chapter of the Religious Emergency Council of the Chief Rabbi of Great Britain, was given at Town Hall last night before a large audience.

MEXICO CITY, May 9 -- Archbishop Luis Maria Martinez, primate of Mexico, today consecrated Mgr. Alonso Escalante as titular Bishop of Sora at a ceremony held at the Church of Guadalupe, Mexico's national shrine. The consecrators were Mgr. George J. Donnelley, Auxiliary Bishop of St. Louis, and Mgr. Mariano Garrida of Laredo, Texas, Auxiliary Bishop of Corpus Christi.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 9 -- A small group of International Class sloop skippers set out in their craft on Long Island Sound today off the Larchmont Yacht Club in their annual tune-up event. That really means a test of rigging, but the skippers just cannot help racing.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 9 (AP) -- Six concentrations of vehicles moving up the peninsula toward the little port of Menzel-Temine were destroyed in a typical Allied strafing operation yesterday.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 9 -Navy today won its first major golf victory when the middies rallied to beat Princeton for the 1943 Eastern intercollegiate team championship.

BOSTON, May 9 -- Future processes and by-products of the food industry "may become as diverse as those of coal and carbon," Harry A. Bullis, president of General Mills, Inc., Minneapolis, predicted today in a special message broadcast to American armed forces overseas.
NEW DELHI, India, May 9--British and Indian forces in Western Burma have withdrawn from Buthedaung, one of their last footholds in the Japanese-occupied colony; it was announced today.

A substantial portion of control over Supreme Court patronage has been taken away from Presiding Justice Francis Martin of the Appellate Division of the First Department, and has been vested in all seven Appellate Division justices instead, it was disclosed yesterday.

MOSCOW, April 24 -- A few days ago the writer made a short trip along the broad military highway that runs to the Western Front arid saw the havoc the retreating German Army had inflicted on towns in Smolensk ,Province.
LONDON, Monday, May 10 (U.P.) -- The Russia Sunday midnight communique as broadcast from Moscow:

Every once in a while some one in the beauty business is struck with the overwhelming realization that a woman comes into a beauty shop seeking efficiency and results, not poetry and incompetence. The war, in this respect, is apparently having a stimulating and gratifying effect -- for more and more of the salons about town have settled down to an atmosphere of businesslike, efficient accomplishment.

MOSCOW, May 9 -- Yesterday a cartoon appeared in Pravda showing a single dagger grasped by British, American and Russian hands pinning Adolf Hitler to the ground. At the top of all newspapers today appears the text of Premier Joseph Stalin's congratulatory messages to Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Roosevelt.

Conditioned by the rigors of rationing, housekeepers are obliged to get full value from every bit of meat they purchase nowadays. To aid them in their task, this column mentions various "pointers" on cooking-to-prevent-waste that are included in a report published by the National Livestock and Meat Board in Chicago.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR BASE IN INDIA, May 8 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- America's newest and largest twin-engined cargo planes today completed a trip more than half way around the world, during which pilots of United States civilian airlines took part in what was described as the longest and biggest mass flight in transport history.

In view of the point rationing, it seems highly important that every effort be made to provide local centers for the canning and preserving of fresh fruits and vegetables by the housewives of the metropolitan area.

PITTSBURGH, May 9 -- Members of the United Mine Workers held local meetings throughout the Pennsylvania-West Virginia-Ohio tri-State area tonight for discussion of the issue which has grown out of imposition of fines on participants in last week's strikes.
A plea to the Association of Junior Leagues of America to take a stand on social welfare legislation was issued last night by the association's vice president, Mrs. Victor H. Shaw of Fairmont, W.Va.

Extra-base hits became the fashion again yesterday in the American League, once the kingdom of sluggers, and it probably was no coincidence that the hitting upsurge coincided with the debut of the lively model balata ball in the circuit, The Associated Press reported.

CHICAGO, May 9 -- Increased receipts of hogs at Western packing points has failed to change the general situation in pork products owing to the large demands from the government and for lend-lease purposes, packers report.

Sharp criticism of the War Production Board for its alleged failure to plan for maximum textile production was expressed yesterday in a report of the executive council of the Textile Workers Union of America, which will open a convention in Carnegie Hall this morning.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The text of the Office of Price Administration's survey of food prices in coal mining communities made at the request of President Roosevelt follows:
The warm weather has brought thoughts of Peconic Bay to many fishermen who usually go down to the east end of Long Island each May.

Hugh C. Thuerk, president of the Bradford Electric Company, has been appointed chairman of a new post-war planning committee of the Edison Electric Institute, it was announced yesterday by C.W. Kellogg, president of the institute.
ABOARD A FLYING FORTRESS, Over Palermo, Sicily, May 9 -- The biggest all-American bombing raid in history is devastating the Sicilian port and industrial city of Palermo this Sunday noon.

Joseph M. Schenck, former board chairman of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, has been signed to a seven-year contract as "executive production head" of the studio, it was announced yesterday by Spyros Skouras, president.

BALTIMORE, May 9 (U.P.) -Count Fleet, who romped home to victory in the Derby and Preakness, rested quietly in Pimlico's rambling barns tonight as his masters charted an ambitious program designed to make the longlegged brown colt the outstanding 3-year-old in turf history.

IN Denmark lives a baroness, a strange and grandly gifted woman who by some odd chance has strayed into the twentieth century from distant regions beyond time and space. An aristocrat in her mind and in her lineage, she is both fascinated and repelled by the idea and the tradition of aristocracy, its formal, ritual patterns of pride and conduct and its dependence on falsities and cruelties.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP) -- Collecting twenty-five hits, the Indians beat the Browns, 6 to 5, today in the thirteen-inning opener to a weird double bill, but dropped the seven-inning nightcap, which the Brownies won, 7 to 5, on three blows.

Communist undergraduate organizations in the colleges of this country -- and Fascist organizations, if any should present themselves -- were barred from membership in the newly organized United States Student Assembly by the constitution it adopted here yesterday at the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue, at the close of a heated three day's session.

WITH THE AMERICAN ARMY AIR FORCE, Somewhere in China, May 9 (U.P.) -- American heavy and medium bombers blasted Japan's largest aviation center in Southern China today when they raided Canton, dropping bombs on the airdromes there.

The Goldman Band has issued program schedules for the 1943 season of the free Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in Central Park and Prospect Park, Brooklyn, beginning, respectively, on June 16 and 17. As in recent years, sixty concerts are to be given in the twenty-sixth season.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 9 -- General Henri Honore Giraud, in a broadcast today on Joan of Arc's anniversary, called on the people of France to attack the Germans when the Allies land in Europe.
CHUNGKING, China, May 9 -- A communique:

William B. Osgood, who owns an estate on Lexington Avenue, Yorktown, in Westchester County, has extended his holdings by purchasing the adjoining fourteen acres formerly known as The Homestead. The latter is in the Lake Mohegan area and includes an eleven-room dwelling, two-story cottage, a barn and several smaller buildings.

The Department of Parks announced yesterday that it had set aside additional fishing areas for solt water anglers and surf casters of New York City who, because of the restrictions on off-shore fishing boats, must necessarily find their recreation in near-by waters.

TUNIS, May 8 (Delayed) -- The Allied bugles blew in Tunis today and a city truly delivered from evil rose up to greet its deliverers -- long files of dusty, grinning British infantry and solid columns of tanks. All around there were signs of war. Thousands of German and Italian prisoners marched up the gleaming white road that leads from the city to the hinterland.
The Italian Sunday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The United Press:

CHUNGKING, China, May 9 -All the Chungking newspapers bless a muggy Sunday morning with hossanahs of praise for the United Nations victory at Tunis and Bizerte and simultaneously calling attention to the necessity of victory in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- Substantial" violations of maximum price regulations in coal mining communities were reported today by the Office of Price Administration in making public results of a survey. The survey indicated, however, that food costs were "not out of line with prices in comparable near-by cities."

William B. Osgood, who owns an estate on Lexington Avenue, Yorktown, in Westchester County, has extended his holdings by purchasing the adjoining fourteen acres formerly known as The Homestead. The latter is in the Lake Mohegan area and includes an eleven-room dwelling, two-story cottage, a barn and several smaller buildings.

Agreeing that the white-collar worker is the "forgotten man" of the war, delegates at the closing session of the National Wartime Conference at the Hotel Commodore decided yesterday to set up a permanent committee to represent the interests of this group in the national economy.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (U.P.) -- The Senate today heard charges that Stephen S. Chandler Jr. of Oklahoma City had assaulted a stenographer in his office about eight years ago, and then confirmed his appointment to a newly created Federal judgeship in the Western Oklahoma District.
LONDON, May 10 -- The stock markets here displayed firmness on the news from Tunisia, but business did not expand as much as had been expected, and in some sections recent prices failed to hold.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 7 per cent for the week ended May 8, in comparison with the same week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank.

LONDON, May 10 -- Arriving rare within a week of the death of Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews in the plane crash in Iceland, Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, his successor, taking over command of the European Theatre of Operations today, declared that there would the no let-up in the air offensive against Germany, but if possible an intensification of effort in that phase of the war and others.

A luncheon will be given today by the New York Junior League at its clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street, to mark the presentation of the Central Bureau for Hospital Libraries, long a major project of the league, to the United Hospital Fund.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange ran for ten minutes after the opening bell at 10 A.M. yesterday without benefit of messengers, pages or pneumatic tube operators as a result of an unauthorized strike of 300 regular employes.

W.P. Brown, president of Briggs Manufacturing Company, said at the annual meeting in Detroit yesterday that earnings for the first quarter were higher than in the 1942 period and that April shipments of war products were the highest for any month since Pearl Harbor.

Production of electric furnace steel in April set a new high record of 382,532 net tons as a result of additional furnaces put into service in the last two months. This compared with a production of 381,219 tons in March and 321,324 in April, 1942, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. Electric furnace steel is used for aircraft and tank armor and other war materials.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, May 11 (AP) -- Allied and Japanese warplanes traded light blows over a widespread area to the northward of Australia yesterday as Australian ground forces repulsed an enemy attack on Allied positions in the Mubo area of Northeast New Guinea.

Germany is still strong and the world faces another Summer of major crises, which will determine the duration of the war...

Among those reported yesterday as having taken residential space was Mrs. Ruth Bryan Rohde, former United States Minister to Denmark, who, with her husband, Major Borge Rohde, leased an apartment in 121 East Fifty-seventh Street through Huberth Huberth, broker.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 5: An increase of $422,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, decreases of $324,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks and $570,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and an increase of $452,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Passersby collected yesterday as workmen completed the erection of six black platforms over the fountains down the middle of the esplanade in Rockefeller Center. Captions in white letters appear on each side of the platforms, and the one nearest Fifth Avenue attracted considerable attention.

Adolf Hitler told the German people yesterday that their Eastern Front armies were suffering "superhuman hardships" and stressed that the war was being carried into the "towns, market places and villages" of the German Reich itself.

An estimated 5,000 Negro registrants here holding 1-A cards will all be called for induction during June. As those rejected for physical unfitness will be reclassified in 4-F, Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service Director here, said yesterday that local boards expect to have no 1-A Negroes remaining on their lists by the end of next month.

Common sense rather than the complex statistical approach should be used in the preparation of appeals for relief under the excess-profits tax, according to a statement prepared by Randolph E. Paul, general consul of the United States Treasury, which was read for him by Joseph G. Blandi, a member of his staff, last night at a meeting of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The local Office of Price Administration and the Police Department, acting on orders from Mayor La Guardia, cracked down on two fronts yesterday in the drive against holders of B and C ration books believed to be using their gasoline coupons for non-essential driving.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- An administrative order issued by Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, today set the functions and organization of Donald D. Davis, vice chairman for operations. The office of the operations vice chairman is responsible, together with the three controlled materials divisions, for the execution of established WPB policies, plans and general methods, Mr. Wilson stated.

Perhaps the many opportunities for employment in New York State mental institutions would interest those older women recently released from WPA, about whose present plight "Clubwoman" writes in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Similar opportunities are also open to men.
Early settlement of the strike of 150 employes of Press Wireless, Inc., serving news agencies and individual papers as well as the Office of War Information, appeared probable yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, May 10 (AP) -- Japanese soldiers have demonstrated again that they are masters of jungle warfare in this section by compelling British and Indian troops to evacuate Buthedaung, leaving the entire east side of the Mayu Peninsula on the Bay of Bengal in enemy hands.

LONDON, May 10 -- Professor Reinhold Niebuhr of New York, speaking at the assembly of the Congregational Union of England and Wales in London today, said he hoped that Americans' answer as to whether they had a moral obligation to the rest of the world after the war would be yes.
The Bell Chorus of New York will give its tenth annual Spring concert in Town Hall at 8:30 o'clock tonight.

The Broadway engagement of "Blithe Spirit" will be suspended at the Booth on Saturday, June 5, John C. Wilson announced yesterday. It will resume its run on Labor Day and, after an engagement lasting at least four weeks, will go on tour in the East, eventually reaching the West Coast after an invasion of Canada.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The Army-Navy Production Award has been granted to thirteen more industrial plants and one construction project for outstanding performance on war work, Under-Secretaries Patterson and Forrestal announced today.

Plans for a Times Square Victory Arch showing the Four Freedoms were announced yesterday by Robert K. Christenberry, president of the Broadway Association, at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor, to mark the thirty-second anniversary of the organization.

It was laughter and cheers and lusty song to the glory of the sawdust ring all through the morning yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, for the fiftieth consecutive year, presented a special performance for 14,000 underprivileged children.

As 252,000 pounds of new California potatoes started to move through normal distribution channels to metropolitan housewives yesterday. Mayor La Guardia's foray into the potato field was officially described as that of contact-maker rather than as active dealer or seller and the volume of supplies that his efforts have made available became a subject of sharp dispute.
ALLIED HEADQUAIATERS IN NORTH AFRRICA, May 10 (AP) -- A communigue:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 10 (U.P.) -- Allied planes swept Cap Bon in never-ending patrols today, turning its waters and beaches into Axis death traps.

With an "effective buying income" of $8,729,607,000, the people of New York City had $1,000,000,000 more to spend last year than in the previous year, Sales Management magazine reports in its fourteenth annual "Survey of Buying Power," out today.

The North American Company took steps yesterday to divest itself ultimately of its one-third Common stock interest in the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, one of the nation's largest operating utilities. Directors of North American declared a common stock dividend in the form of one share of common stock of Pacific Gas for each 100 shares of North American common stock held.

Many persons seem to share the curious idea that cereals do little except encourage an unpleasant plumpness. Women who don't hesitate to eat cake for dessert -- "just a sliver, please" -- act as if they considered you mildly deranged if you suggest some oatmeal for breakfast. "

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., May 10 -- The baseball diamond that the Brooklyn Dodgers used in Spring training here was the setting for a half-hour chat between Mme. Chiang Kai-shek and Wendell L. Willkie during the early evening of Sunday, April 25, it was disclosed today.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 10 (U.P.) -- Explosion of a hydrogen-filled free balloon in an open field late today near Ellisburg, seven miles east of here, killed three Navy officers and shattered windows in a half-mile radius.
WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Talk was revived here today of permitting distillers to use part of their production to offset the rapidly dwindling stocks of liquor.

Fashion was left at the post yesterday at the opening of the Belmont Spring Race Meet. Mayor La Guardia, OPA and the weather certainly worked boots and saddle to keep the well-dressed society woman away from the races.

The first New York City exhibition by members of the Associated Artists of New Jersey opens today at the Riverside Museum, 310 Riverside Drive, to continue until Memorial Day. Some twenty-five artists are represented by oils, water-colors, sculpture, drawings and prints.

John A. Coleman, who started out in Wall Street as a page boy on the New York Stock Exchange twenty-six years ago, was elected chairman of the board of governors of the institution yesterday at the annual election. All other members of the Exchange's regular slate also were elected, despite contests for two posts on the board.

Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, praised the "reporters of war" yesterday for personifying contemporary ideals of American journalism. He spoke at the school's thirtieth anniversary service in St. Paul's Chapel, on the campus, at which fifty journalism students and faculty members were present.

Two public utility issues, aggregating approximately $50,000,000, were awarded yesterday to investment bankers at competitive bidding sales. A refunding issue of $38,000,000 of Public Service Company of Indiana bonds went to an underwriting syndicate headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., and Harriman, Ripley Co., Inc., while Smith, Barney Co. and associates entered the only bid for 242,664 shares of common stock of the Houston Lighting and Power Company.

FORT OGLETHORPE, Ga., May 10 -- You can concoct all the funny stories you want to about the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps -- they tell some of the best ones on themselves -- but they challenge you to laugh off the fact that they have turned themselves to their part in this war with a seriousness, a verve and a method which would do credit to the toughest of the services.

One thousand persons stood in front of the New York Public Library at noon yesterday and watched in silence as the library flag, fluttering against a gray and threatening sky, was slowly lowered to half-staff as part of the nation's observance of the tenth anniversary of the burning of the books in Nazi Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Despite the modern design and equipment of the new National Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md., of which she is scheduled to become chief nurse, Lieutenant (Junior Grade) Grace B. Lally would rather return to her hard, exciting work as chief nurse on the hospital ship which in five months in the South Pacific war zones cared for 4,039 patients, of whom only seven died.

GENEVA, N.Y., May 10 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek received the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters (LHD) at the Hobart-William Smith College commencement this morning. The degree was awarded in absentia, but was received for her by Dr. Hollington K. Tong, Vice Minister of Information of the Republic of China.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Awards of the Air Medal to 122 officers and enlisted men of the Army Air Forces for anti-submarine patrol flights over the Atlantic were announced today by the War Department. The citations read:

The Tokyo radio, in a broadcast recorded by The Associated Press, reported yesterday that an Allied submarine had shelled the vicinity of Horobetsu village on the southeastern coast of Hokkaido Island --the second largest of the string of islands which constitute the Japanese homeland.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, May 11 (AP) The noon communigue:

It was May 10, 1868. A covered wagon progressed slowly along the trail from Chillicothe, Ohio, to Nebraska City, Neb. En route, in the outskirts of Springfield, Ill., a child was born. "That was me," said Edward Grant Barrow yesterday as he celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday at his desk.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 10 -- For the second successive day the Desert Allied Air Forces sent a force of 100 bombers against the Italian island airfield of Pantelleria, forty-five miles off Cap Bon, yesterday, while Middle East bombers raided Messina in Sicily.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the government may prosecute violators of Office of Price Administration price ceilings without fear of injunction by Federal District courts.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York had an operating deficit of $130,504 last season and "some such help" as the recently negotiated contract for radio sponsorship of the orchestra's Sunday afternoon concerts was necessary if "the organization was to go forward," it was reported yesterday by Marshall Field, president of the society, at the annual meeting in Steinway Hall.

Dr. Henry F. Johnstone, Professor of Chemical Engineering at the University of Illinois, received the 1943 award of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers last night at the thirty-fifth semi-annual meeting of that organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CANTON, N.Y., May 10 -- "In the modem world the theory of isolationism is neither realistic nor workable," Dr. Edmund Ezra Day, president of Cornell University, told the eighty-eight seniors who were graduated this morning at the commencement of St. Lawrence University.

CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) -- Six executives of the National Bronze and Aluminum Foundry Company pleaded innocent today to Federal charges of sabotage and fraud in supplying castings for warplane engines.
CHUNGKING, China, May 10 -- Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek cabled congratulations today to President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill on the Allied victory in Tunisia.

CHUNGKING, China, May 10 (U.P.) -- The Chinese High Command announced tonight that fighting was continuing on the north shore of Tungting Lake, in Northern Hunan, and south of the Yangtze River, in Southern Hupeh, where the Japanese scored no decisive successes during the past twenty-four hours. Enemy attempts to land on the south shore of Tungting Lake again were repulsed.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Southern coal operators contended at a War Labor Board panel hearing today that a recent Circuit Court decision supporting the demand of iron ore miners for portal-to-portal pay "has no direct bearing" on the soft coal wage dispute.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, May 10 (U.P.) -- Captain Gerald J. Crosson of Huguenot Park, Staten Island, received an Air Medal today for rescuing a wounded comrade from a burning airplane that exploded and blew both of them to safety in a bomb crater.

WASHINGTON, May 10--President Roosevelt signed two bills, one calling for expansion of hospital facilities for dependents of naval and Marine Corps personnel and the other authorizing an insignia device for merchant marine sailors. His visitors included the Panamanian Ambassador; T.V. Soong, Secretary Hull, James W. Gerard and Arthur Hays Sulzberger.

The six-story house containing sixty-three apartments known as Paldean Court, 17 Fifth Avenue, Pelham, Westchester County, has been sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to a client of Wallace Grove through Owen A. Mandeville, broker.
The German Monday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, May 8 -- The following questions and answers on home canning were issued today by the Office of Price Administration to help housewives know how to get and use sugar allowed for this purpose. Coupons for buying sugar for home canning will be vailable at local ration boards on and after May 15.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10 -- A legal opinion by Attorney General David T. Wilentz that the horserace meeting at Garden State Park could go on as scheduled July 7 to Sept. 12 despite the two vacancies in the four-member State Racing Commission was made public today by Governor Charles Edison.
Crown Princess lVartha of Norway, accompanied by her lady-inwaiting, Eme. Ragni Ostgaard, has arrived at the Waldorf-Astoria from her home in Bethesda, Md.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A Livestock and Meat Board, composed of representatives of the armed services, packers, meat distributors and the Office of Price Administration and War Food Administration, is being considered to direct the production and distribution of meats and help police black market operations.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -Destruction of a German submarine by a Navy Catalina flying boat that found it surfaced in West Indian waters during March was reported today by the Navy.

The Celanese Corporation of America and certain of its directors won yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Kenneth O'Brien the dismissal of two of the three causes of action in a minority stockholders' suit by Seymour Bayer. Justice O'Brien said that the two causes of action were "legally insufficient."

Despite continued resistance of trapped Axis remnants, the fighting in Tunisia is nearing the end. The Battle of Africa has been won. The Battle of Europe is about to begin. It will be a battle that will dwarf all previous ones. For the enemy, though shaken, is still powerful. And he is as cunning as he is powerful.

The American Library Association is conducting a program to send $100,000 worth of United States publications to a limited number of libraries in each of the twenty other American republics, in answer to reports that Latin Americans would read more books published in the United States if they were made available.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- For some time it has been apparent that the policy-makers of the administration have turned to Federal subsidies of producers and processors of basic cost-of-living items as the easiest temporary solution of their war-wages and war-prices troubles.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 768 United States soldiers missing in action in the Alaskan, Asiatic, European, North African, South Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

Restoration of the War Labor Board's independence to enable it to pass upon wage increases without the restrictions imposed by various executive orders will be demanded by the executive council of the American Federation of Labor when it meets in Washington beginning May 17, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that she had not, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES account of the United States Student Assembly Conference, which she addressed last Saturday, "recalled that she had worked with the American Students Union," nor had "eighteen students marched out in a body" in consequence of her stated loss of confidence in their protestations that they were not Communists.

Five one-act plays, written by soldiers and entered in the soldiers' playwriting contest of the Second Service Command, will be given a single performance Monday night, June 7, in a Broadway theatre. The plays will be acted, directed and designed by soldiers from camps in this area and will be presented under the general title, "The Army Play By Play."

The absence of men now serving in the armed forces, the ban on gasoline for pleasure-driving and the fact that the Turf and Field Club was not opened for luncheon and cocktails before or after the races failed to put a full damper on the opening-day program of the Westchester Racing Association's Spring meeting at Belmont Park yesterday afternoon.

LOUIS ZAMPERINI, the intercollegiate mile champion of a few years back, has been in the news again. This time he was credited with saving the lives of some fellow-crew members on a bomber which was riddled by the Japanese over the Pacific. Before that he had been cited for some bombing activities of his own.

MADRID, May 10 -- In a clear appeal for world peace, Generalissimo Francisco Franco declared last night at Almeria that the present world-wide conflict had reached a "dead point" and that neither side now had the power to destroy the other.

Edouard Muller, president of Unitac, Inc., of Panama City, which conducts the Nestle products business outside Continental Europe, says in the annual report for 1942 that net profit after general expenses amounted to $3,319,717 compared with $3,424,200 in the preceding year.

The National Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System reaffirmed yesterday their belief that the FCC rules sustained by the Supreme Court would have to be revised if the present system of broadcasting were to survive.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 10 -- A new rest center in a little city on the sunny, sub-tropical northeast coast of Australia has, during recent weeks, become a mecca for American air and ground crews on leave from New Guinea bases. Seven hundred to a thousand servicemen from the New Guinea air base are now being regularly accommodated at the new center.

When Miss Ruth F. Woodsmall, general secretary of the world's Young Women's Christian Association, went to Algiers fifteen years ago to study Moslem women she had no better crystal ball for the future than any one else. Yesterday she sat in a "Y" office here and told of a more recent study of British and American women stationed with armed forces in the North African city.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 10--With operations in North Africa now in the mopping-up stage some observers considered today that the battle of Europe had already begun with the mass Allied air attacks on Palermo and Messina in Sicily and on Pantelleria Island.

Commissions as second lieutenants in the Army Air Forces and diplomas certifying completion of an eight-month course in meteorology at New York University were awarded to ninety-nine aviation cadets in ceremonies at the University Heights campus.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- The speech reported today by Generalissimo Franco, urging peace because of what he described as the danger of communism, was regarded here as a German-inspired propaganda manoeuvre timed to coincide with the journey to Russia of Joseph E. Davies, President Roosevelt's special envoy, and to take advantage of the Polish-Russian split precipitated by an earlier stroke of Nazi propaganda against Russia.

A plan to use the all-Army cast of "This Is the Army," the Irving Berlin musical, on a series of sponsored radio programs was abandoned yesterday after the American Federation of Radio Artists, an American Federation of Labor affiliate, interposed objections on the ground that soldiers should not be used to exploit a commercial product.

DETROIT, May 10 -- A new treatment for epileptic seizures of the type known as "petit real," manifested by temporary disorders of personality and mental black-outs, and for psychomotor attacks in which the victim temporarily loses control of his bodily movements, was reported here today before the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.
NEW DELHI, India, May 10 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

An attack on John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, and a plea for continuation of the New Deal in 1944 marked an address by Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union of America, at the opening of its biennial convention yesterday in Carnegie Hall.

Those who are now advocating the extensive use of subsidies in this country point to the use made of them in Great Britain and Canada. But any comparisons of this sort must take into account the differences between the situation in these countries and here, as well as the limited role that subsidies can play, if they are not themselves to become a far greater evil than the evils they are intended to avert.

The trend in commercial airliners may be toward bigger and bigger planes, but the war has made the exact opposite true for the motor vehicles that ply between La Guardia Field hangars and planes on the loading platform.

AT A UNITED STATES AIR BASE IN SOUTHERN CHINA, May 10 -- Since the Fourteenth Air Force's new heavy bombardment group took the most conspicuous part in Tuesday's surprising raid on Haiphong and Hainan Island and Saturday's on Canton, it is now possible to state in print that it exists.

The Viennese Roof of the St. Regis was treated to a cotton showing yesterday at the luncheon hour. Farmerettes pranced down the runway and washable frocks were recommended. The exhibitor was Mary Lewis.

TRENTON, N.J., May 10 -- The Legislature tonight completed passage of a bill that will give the voters the opportunity at the November election to say whether the 1944 Legislature shall prepare a revised State Constitution and submit it to the citizens at the 1944 general election.
A number of private dwellings were involved in Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday by brokers.

Following another request by the Office of Defense Transportation that furniture shows be called off, the New York Furniture Exchange has canceled the Summer market which had been scheduled to run from June 7 to 11, it was learned last night following a meeting of the board of directors.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 10 -- At least 25,000 Germans surrendered to the Second United States Corps before and after hostilities had ceased in the Bizerte area at 11:40 A.M. yesterday, it was officially disclosed today. They include six ranking generals.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Overriding opposition by the War Production Board and the Truman committee investigating the war program, the Senate, by a 44-29 vote, adopted today the Maloney bill to take the Office of Civilian Supply away from the WPB and establish it as a separate, independent administration with coordinate rather than subordinate powers.

LONDON, May 10 -- Tulips bloomed as gloriously in beds in St. James's Park today as they ever did in the Netherlands when for the third time since the Nazi occupation of their homeland a little band of refugees gathered m the bombed Netherland church of Austin Friars in the City today to pray again for the deliverance of their people.

Only a deficient knowledge of European history can induce people to favor the cutting up of Germany. The unification of the Germans was a logical event in the chain of national units which in the nineteenth century prepared a united Europe that, whatever happens, will be completed by the twentieth.
The Italian Monday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Householders seeking fuel oil rations for the coming season will not be asked whether they can convert oil-burning furnaces to some other fuel, Prentiss M. Brown, Office of Price Administration head, said today.

Cotton futures prices were a bit easier yesterday under light long liquidation and hedge selling from the South. Favorable war developments abroad and uncertainties concerning the operation of the cotton-stabilization program were factors in both the quietness and easier trend in the market.
